



-A- 
a (noun neuter) the first letter of the Ateso alphabet; a vowel letter as in ‘arm’. 
a-1 prefix forming infinitive of ko-verbs: abaar ko-a (to knock off); aditakin ko-o (to dash away, run off very fast).
a-2 prefix of adjectival and derivative nouns expressing past tense qualities. acobe Dr. Ecookit noi: Dr. Ecookit was very astute. ecobe (adjective) clever; astute; wise. acobeu (derivative noun of ‘ecobe’) (noun F) cleverness; astuteness; wisdom.
a-3 prefix of feminine nouns singular and plural, and nouns of average size (neither too small nor too big in size): amoru: a stone, a pebble; aberu: a woman; akine: a she-goat
a-4 prefix of feminine prepositional nouns: amot: in the pot; akokoroi: at, among the chicken; angor: among, towards women; adere: in or into the calabash; akongu: in (to) the eye.
a-5 pronominal prefix of 1st person singular of ko-verbs in present tenses, and 3rd person singular and plural of past perfect tenses. akoto (eong) alosit Soroti: I want to go to Soroti, the word ‘eong’ – I, me - can be omitted without loss because the word “akoto” already implies ‘I want’. ko-verb - aime: to lick (with the tongue); 3rd person past perfect tense – ame: she/he/it has licked (with the tongue).
aa! (interjection) No! Do not! Stop it. aa! kolot ngina: No! go there.
aabaat (plural aabaan) (noun F) (Usuk) a crack in the mud. 
aabaran (plural aabarak) (noun F) (Usuk) a rich man; a wealthy man. cp. ekabaran
aabarenon (plural aabarenok) (noun F) (Usuk) a barber; a man who cuts or shaves people’s hair.
aabea nukitim (plural noun F) dandruff. aabea nuka ilac: nits; eggs of lice. aabea nuka alos: badly ground grain. 
aabelan (plural aabelak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who wounds someone’s head with a stick. 
aabenyan (plural aabenyak) (noun F) (Usuk) a guerrilla fighter; a rebel; a rogue; a lawless person, etc 
aabokan (plural aabokak) (noun F) (Usuk) a spy, a tempter; a digger; one who digs. aabokan atesia: a professional grave-digger. cp. engu.
aabolian (plural aaboliak) (noun F) (Usuk) a player; a jester; joker; sportsman or an athlete. 
aabuoron (plural aabuorok) (noun F) (Usuk) a robber; a confiscator. cp. ekabuoron. 
aabwaan (plural aabwaak) (noun F) (Usuk) a superintendent; a guard (of thing); a headman; one who builds fences or enclosures. 
aabwoan (plural aabwoak) (noun F) (Usuk) a sponsor; one who stands (bail, for election, etc). cp. ekabwoan
aabwoikinan (plural aabwoikinak) (noun F) (Usuk) a sponsor, backer, supporter, guarantor, etc 
aabwoikiniton (plural aabwoikinitok) (noun F) (Usuk) a delegate; one who stands and challenges another. cp. ekabwoikiniton.
aacerit (plural aacer) (noun F) (Usuk) a star. aacer: a constellation; stars. 
aacoan (plural aacoak) (noun F) (Usuk) a wise man; a wise person, a clever person. cp. ekacoan
aacudan (plural aacudak) (noun F) (Usuk) a witch; a wizard; a cannibal; a night dancer (figurative) (approvingly) a person who does things cleverly, in a clever way, like a juggler. cp. ekacudan.
aacukut (plural aacukun) (noun F) (Usuk) a blacksmith's bellows used for forging bells for dancing, or spears and axes; a blowpipe; the engine of a ferry boat. cp. acukut
aaculon (plural aaculok) (noun F) (Usuk) an arbiter; intermediary; arbitrator; a go-between. 
aadedengan (plural aadedengak) (noun F) (Usuk) a severe, savage or cruel person or animal. cp. lokadedengan.
aadekan (plural aadekak) (noun F) (Usuk) a patient; a sick or ill man. cp. ekadekan.
aademaran (plural aademarak) (noun F) (Usuk) a robber; a plunderer. cp. ekabuoron. 
aadiekan (plural aadiekak) (noun F) (Usuk) a judge; a mediator; an arbitrator or arbiter.
aadilon (plural aadilok) (noun F) (Usuk) an early riser or traveller. amina eong aadilok: I like early risers. 
aadingiriran (plural aadingirirak) (noun F) (Usuk) a fast runner; a fast cyclist. 
aadonyon (plural aadonyok) (noun F) (Usuk) a tailor; a dress-maker. cp. lokadonyon.
aadotean (plural aadoteak) (noun F) (Usuk) an adulterer; a fornicator; a prostitute; a sex worker. 
aadukon (plural aadukok) (noun F) (Usuk) a builder; an architect; a mason. 
aadyekan (plural aadyekak) (noun F) (Usuk) intercessor; adjudicator; separator; judge; arbiter; rescuer. 
aageretan (plural aageretak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who massages, embrocates (sets a bone); masseur.
aagogongon (plural aagogongok) (noun F) (Usuk) the strong, severe, hardy, difficult, strict one. 
aagolon (plural aagolok) (noun F) (Usuk) a doorkeeper; a prison guard; a loser; a failure (in school). cp. lokagolon
aaguman (plural aagumak) (noun F) (Usuk) an archer; one who bleeds cattle to extract blood (for food).
aagwelan (plural aagwelak) (noun F) (Usuk) a buyer; a purchaser. 
aajakunan (plural aajakunak) (noun F) (Usuk) a rescuer; a saviour; a redeemer; a liberator. 
aajalan iboro (plural aajalak iboro) (noun F) (Usuk) a generous, liberal, open-handed, big-hearted, charitable, or munificent person. 
aajaran (plural aajarak) (noun F) (Usuk) a living person; the living. aajarak ka lukatwak: the living and the dead. 
aajean (plural aajeak) (noun F) (Usuk) a potter; a person who moulds with clay, etc. 
aajenan (plural aajenak) (noun F) (Usuk) an eyewitness; a martyr; one who knows; a deponent. 
aajengan (plural aajengak) (noun F) (Usuk) a skinner; a person who removes the skin from a slaughtered animal.
aajepan (plural aajepak) (noun F) (Usuk) a wood cutter; a lumberman; a cheat; a trickster. 
aajion (plural aajiok) (noun F) (Usuk) a fighter, combatant, boxer, wrestler, pugilist, rebel; a warrior, soldier. 
aakadakinan (plural aakadakinak) (noun F) (Usuk) a depressed, sad, downhearted, or disgusted person. 
aakapiton (plural aakapitok) (noun F) (Usuk) a soldier in arms; a person in arms. 
aakinangan (plural aakinangak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who hears but does not answer. 
aakoran (plural aakorak) (noun F) (Usuk) a distributor; a benefactor. 
aakorion (plural aakoriok) (noun F) (Usuk) a cultivator (a farmer who cultivates land); a planter; a grower of crops; a sedentary farmer; a peasant farmer. cp. ekakorion.
aakwenan (plural aakwenak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who laughs; a scoffer. 
aakwenaran (plural aakwenarak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who ridicules; one who derides. 
aalakany (plural aalakanya) (noun F) (Usuk)a cooking pot having a wide aperture
aalakunan (plural aalakunak) (noun F) (Usuk) a saviour; a redeemer. 
aalemunan (plural aalemunak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who removes something. aalemunan esolo: a taxpayer. aaleman epaaba: a cotton sorter or picker. aalemunan eluk: one who pays a fine for committing adultery or pays on behalf of an adulterer. cp. ekalemunan.
aaliaton (plural aaliatok) (noun F) (Usuk) a creeper; a creeping thing (like a snake, worm). 
aaliliton (plural aalilitok) (noun F) (Usuk) a jealous or envious person. 
aalimonokinan (plural aalimonokinak) (noun F) (Usuk) a preacher, cleric, or reverend; an informer; announcer. 
aalimoron (plural aalimorok) (noun F) (Usuk) a reporter; a betrayer, traitor, rebel, turncoat, defector, or a deserter; an announcer, presenter, telecaster, or a broadcaster. 
aaliokon (plural aaliokok) (noun F) (Usuk) a liar; a hypocrite; a quack. 
aalokan (plural aalokak) (noun F) (Usuk) a man who ensnares; a man who traps; a man who sets traps. 
aalokunan (plural aalokunak) (noun F) (Usuk) an adolescent male; one who traps or ensnares. 
aaloman (plural aalomak) (noun F) (Usuk) an entrant; one who enters somewhere; an adulterer. aaloman aberu (plural aalomak angor) (noun F) (Usuk) adulterer. cp. lokeluk. aaloman kinga: a guard; a watchman; a witch. 
aalomaran (plural aalomarak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who enters; an entrant; a recruit; a newcomer. 
aaloton (plural aalotok) (noun F) (Usuk) a pedestrian; a traveller; an explorer, voyager, trekker, a tourist; a passenger, or a commuter.
aalumon (plural aalumok) (noun F) (Usuk) a swimmer; a (scuba) diver. 
aalungan (plural aalungak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who refuses something (in anger). 
aalyaton (plural aalyatok) (noun F) (Usuk) a creeping thing. 
aamamian (plural aamamiak) (noun F) (Usuk) the missing; absentee; the non-existent thing; imagination; phantom. kideikis loamamian: leave something for the absent one. edar ngolida amamiak: I waited for him in vain. cp. atitai. 
aamejan (plural aamejak) (noun F) (Usuk) a hunter; a seeker. 
aamejat (plural aamejak) (noun F) (Usuk) a clever hunter or a person fond of hunting. 
aameran (plural aamerak) (noun F) (Usuk) a sot; a drunkard; an alcoholic. 
aamimit (plural aamimin) (noun F) (Usuk) a small bee.
aamodan (plural aamodak) (noun F) (Usuk) a cheat; a conman; fraudster; swindler; one who cheats. 
aamonyan (plural aamonyak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who weeps; one who cries; lachrymose. 
aamuriait (plural aamuria) (noun F) (Usuk) a grape fruit from ekamuriei shrub, eaten ripe or as a vegetable seasoning when crushed raw. 
aangatan (plural aangatak) (noun F) (Usuk) a robber, burglar, mugger, or a raider; a brigand, a bandit, or thug.
aangibiriran (plural aangibirirak) (noun F) (Usuk) a fast runner. cp. ekadingiriran
aanyaman (plural aanyamak) (noun F) (Usuk) a snob; a sycophant; a pest (literally, the one who eats). aanyaman apese (plural aanyamak apese) (noun F) (Usuk) one who takes part of a girl’s dowry. aanyaman itunga (plural aanyamak itunga) (noun F) (Usuk) a cannibal; a man-eater. engatuny lokanyaman itunga: a man-eating lion. cp. angu.
aanyanar ko-a (transitive verb) to examine, superintend, supervise, or inspect. 
aanyanaran (plural aanyanarak) (noun F) (Usuk) a Protestant or Church of Uganda bishop; inspector; overseer. 
aanyet (plural aanyeta) (noun F) (Usuk) a mirror; something for seeing or for examining; the act or state of seeing or examining. cp. aroet; alabira. 
aanyinyir (plural noun F) (Usuk) sweat; perspiration. 
aanyit ko-o (continuous verb) to keep in view. 
aanyun ko-a (transitive verb) to see for oneself; to feel by touch; to meet or see each other. akoto aanyun ijo: I want to see you. aanyuni ber: I'll first see for myself. abu eong kaany ican: I had trouble or difficulty. 
aanyunet (plural aanyuneta) (noun F) an example; a specimen; a model; a mirror; a sign; a miracle. 
aapegan (plural aapegak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who denies; a protester; one who objects. cp. ekapegan
aapetan akiro (plural aapetak akiro) (noun F) (Usuk) a lawyer; a pleader. 
aapeton (plural aapetok) (noun F) (Usuk) a kicker; one who kicks. aapeton emopiira: a football player. emopiira lopetot: a ball for kicking; a football. 
aapikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be near to, close to. aapikis kesi oiduka: they are nearing the shops.
aapikinit ko-a (intransitive verb) (Usuk) to be approximate to, close to. aapikinit eong ikar akwatat luapolou: I am nearing a hundred years of age.
aapiu (singular noun F) (Usuk) vicinity; nearness; propinquity. 
aapolon (plural aapolok) (noun F) (Usuk) (a title of respect) a great person; a principal; an important person. 
aapu ko-a (intransitive verb) to be near; to be close to; to be imminent. (Conjugation: 1st person - aapie eong: I am near. iapie ijo: you are near (to me). kiapie iso: we are near. Imperative: koapu: come near (singular). koapuutu: come near (plural). koapie: be near (singular). koapiete: be near (plural). cp. ayapu, eiduny. idunyasi kesi: they are near one another; they are neighbours. 
aapucon (plural aapucok) (noun F) (Usuk) one who prepares a feast to reconcile with another; a peace-maker; a reconciler; an arbiter. cp. lokapucon
aapupon (plural aapupok) (noun F) (Usuk) one who is listening; a listener; a hearer. aapupok: the audience. 
aapurokinan (plural aapurokinak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who replies or answers back; a pleader; a lawyer; an intercessor. 
aapuron (plural aapurok) (noun F) the intercessor; an arbiter; an advocate. cp. aatubon
aapuun ko-a (intransitive verb) to come near; to be imminent. koapuutu: come near, be near (plural).
aaracor (plural aaracorin) (noun F) (Usuk) a plant, Labiate. 
aarakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to force or to compel; to kill elsewhere. aarakin bon: to commit suicide. aar bonik: to kill one another.
aarakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to kill for someone else; to cause to do by force; to convince of guilt. 
aaran (plural aarak) (noun F) (Usuk) a murderer; a serial killer. 
aarar ko-a (transitive verb) to despatch off, kill, or destroy; to kill off. lokaaran; ekaaran: a murderer. aarar: to abrade; to destroy (a court case) or to extinguish; to abrogate a legislation.
aararet (plural aarareta) (noun F) (Usuk) abrogation; scrapping; annulment; nullification; cancellation. 
aare (noun F) (cardinal number) two; a couple. 
aaremon (plural aaremok) (noun F) (Usuk) one who spears; one who punctures. 
aaret (singular noun F) (outside Usuk) cow-dung; manure. (jocular) a huge mound of human faeces. cp. aoret.
aario (singular noun F) a slaughter; a killing; a murdering; a massacring; a slaying; a putting to death; the death sentence. 
aarotan (plural aarotak) (noun F) (Usuk) a spy; a sleuth; a scout; a detective. aarotan iyemuto: a journalist. aarotan akiro: a spy or sleuth.
aarucon (plural aarucok) (noun F) (Usuk) a fitter; a plumber; a linkman. 
aarun1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to requisition. 
aarun2 ko-a (transitive verb) to get by killing; to get after long pleading or begging; to raid; to extort or get by force, coercion, or threats. 
aaruwon (plural aaruwok) (noun F) (Usuk) a commander-in-chief of an army or any group.
aasaan (plural aasaak) (noun F) (Usuk) a woman servant. aasaan ateker: a family or clan caretaker; an attendant; a servant. 
aasaban (plural aasabak) (noun F) (Usuk) a liar; fraudster; conman; a charlatan doctor; a witchdoctor; an impostor. 
aasabat (plural aasabak)(noun F) (Usuk) a perennial or perpetual liar; a fraud; a charlatan; a dubious medicine man. 
aasean (plural aaseak) (noun F) (Usuk) a voter; the electorate; a constituent; an elector. 
aasian (plural aasiak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who escapes, i.e. an escapee; one who runs away; a fugitive; a deserter. 
aasioman (plural aasiomak) (noun F) (Usuk) a school-goer; a student (of reading). cp. asioman
aasuban (plural aasubak) (noun F) (Usuk) the maker; the creator; the moulder; the manufacturer; God the Creator. 
aasupon (plural aasupok) (noun F) (Usuk) a tracker dog; a ferret dog; one who smells out (something hidden). 
aatacan (plural aatacak) (noun F) (Usuk) one who pays up; a payer; a financier or sponsor. aatacan esolo: a taxpayer. aatacan iropito: a paymaster; a payroll officer.
aatereunan (plural aatereunak) (noun F) (Usuk) a confessor (of bad doing); a rat (one who betrays a cause); a black leg; a sell-out. 
aatubon (plural aatubok) (noun F) (Usuk) a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. aatubon akituk: a butcher of cows. aatubon imusaagon: a court judge.
aatumunan (plural aatumunak) (noun F) (Usuk) a youth; a young girl of 14–16 years; an adolescent girl. 
aatupiton (plural aatupitok) (noun F) (Usuk) a follower; an attendant; a cohort; an aide; a servant; a henchman; a companion. aatupiton Yesu: Christ’s disciple.
aatwan (plural aatwak) (noun F) (Usuk) the mortal being; the dead one.
aawean (plural aaweak) (noun F) (Usuk) a man who sows; a broadcaster (of news or seeds).
aawokon akipi (plural aawokok akipi) (noun F) (Usuk) a water-drawer; a person who fetches water. 
aawurian (plural aawuriak) (noun F) (Usuk) a parent. 
aawuton (plural aawutok) (noun M) (Usuk) a castrator; an emasculator. cp. aiwut. 
aayeton (plural aayetok) (noun F) (Usuk) a carver; one who chips away. 
aayuunan (plural aayuunak) (noun F) (Usuk) a rescuer; a saviour; a liberator; a redeemer. 
abaaba ko-a (transitive verb) to strike, hit or beat (with a hard object on a hard surface) repeatedly. kinyek abaaba eong akakou k’ebela: stop conking my head with a stick.
abaangat (plural abaangan) (noun F) a crack in the dry mud. erit loeonit ileleba abaangan: dry mud in the kraal has a lot of cracks.
abaango (plural abaangon) (noun F) a species of wading bird resembling a duck; a green ibis.
abaar ko-a (transitive verb) to kill, to slay, to lynch an animal or person. ekotosi itunga abaar ekokolan: the mob wants to lynch a thief.
abaasi (plural abaasin) (noun F) a motor bus.
abaati (plural abaatin) (noun F) a corrugated iron or zinc sheet; a roof made of iron sheets; an iron or zinc-roofed house. cp. amabaati
ababai (plural ababa) (noun F) the buttocks or anus; the rectum; the sacrum or coccyx (part of the skeleton). 
ababairet (plural ababairen) (noun F) a xylophone. ababairen nuimusugun: the glockenspiel (literally, the European xylophone).
ababar ko-a (intransitive verb) (of beer, fruit) to begin to ferment or to ripen. 
abaikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be overcome by shame; to be overwhelmed with shame, guilt, or vice; to be abashed. abaikis ejakait akiro: the chief is guilty of wrong doing. abaikis nges iponesio lueroko: she/he is steeped in vice. abaiki ngol emusaago: he was found guilty. 
abakaasa (plural abakaasan) (noun F) an envelope (i.e. a covering for a letter). 
abakas ko-a (transitive verb) (plural of abala) to call; to say. ebakai ai?: what is being said? what do they say? what do they call it? ebakas itunga: people say.... ebekoi: it is said. abala eong…: I say…; I am of the opinion that….; I think…; I was on the point of saying…. ibalas bo yesi ai?: what do you think?; what do you say? ebala esukaali pii: (the half-dissolved) sugar is (or feels) like jelly or syrup. ebalai: it is said; people say... nuebalai; nuabekoi; erwom: what is said; rumours. cp. ebalai, nuebalai.
abala1 (noun F) a plant; a root parasite of sorghum, Striga. 
abala2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to promise; to say; to repeat. nepe abala kalim akiro, kebapete akit: just as I was about to utter a word, I received a slap on the ear. (intransitive verb) to do; to sound like; to be imitating the stated sound, act, etc. ebala mwe mwe: it sparkles; it glitters.
abalabala ko-a (intransitive verb) to talk at random; to talk nonsense. 
abalabalat (plural abalabalan) (noun F) a pennant wing; (outside Usuk) a nightjar (a nocturnal bird of the swift family with a harsh discordant cry). 
abalanana ko-a (intransitive verb) to keep promising; to keep saying; to keep repeating. 
abalang1 (noun F) a plant, its ash used for salt, Vernonia cirnerea.
abalang2 (plural abalanga) (noun F) salt extracted from plant ash. aitokony abalang: (in a ceremony) to give food cooked with abalang to a woman who has recently given birth. aitale abalang: (of a person) to abstain from or go without eating salted food.
abalar ko-a (intransitive verb) to promise. akiteng naebalare mamai ngesi na: this is the cow which was promised to uncle. 
abaliiga (plural lukabaliiga) (noun F) (a legendary character in Teso tales) a cheat; a conman; a fraud; a swindler.
abangaan ko-a (intransitive verb) to become stupid, mute, foolish, deaf, or daft; to make a fool of oneself; to play the fool. 
abangaanar ko-a (intransitive verb) to become hysterical, stupid, deaf, foolish, silly, mad, etc.
abangaanut (singular noun F) folly; stupidity; madness; dullness, etc. aikany abanganut: to endure (someone else’s) stupidity. 
abangacin (plural abangacinio) (noun F) a fat greenish-yellow grasshopper. 
abanganai (plural abanganain) (noun F) a Flappet lark. 
abangit (plural abangin) (noun F) a female twin-child. cp. amuut.
abao (plural abaoi) (noun F) a board; a chalk board; a wooden block; a timber.
abar (collective noun F) riches; wealth; treasure. cp. amio.
abaraapu (plural abaraapun) (noun F) a refrigerator; a fridge; an ice block; ice cream.
abarak (plural abaraka) (noun F) a pot for drinking or serving beer (an almost circular-shaped pot into which undiluted beer is decanted from the eli pot and hot water added). 
abarakakait (plural abarakaka) (noun F) a large pot with a small mouth. 
abaran (plural abarak) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a rich man; a wealthy man. cp. ekabaran
abaren ko-o (transitive verb) to shave (hair or wool). ebareni papa epenek kede emweeso: daddy is shaving his beard with a razorblade. cp. aibany, ainger. 
abarit ko-a (intransitive verb) to be rich in livestock, money, or non-crop items. 
abarun ko-a (intransitive verb) (of things) to become numerous, plentiful, abundant, or copious. 
abasang (plural abasanga) (noun F) a pointed stick for digging or fighting; a cudgel; a dibble; a bludgeon. cp. akuta.
abasiisi (plural abasiisin) (noun F) a bonus; a baksheesh; an additional benefit. 
abatot (plural abatoi) (noun F) a yam, Dioscorea. cp. aokot: an edible yam. 
abaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to dissolve; to soak; to melt; to become wet. ebaunit do ekonipur elos bon: your back is now soaked with dirt. 
abean (plural abeak) (noun F) truth; certitude; certainty. akiro nuabeak: a maxim. 
abeanakin (transitive verb) to do in turns or in shifts. 
abeanut (singular noun F) righteousness; virtue. 
abeanut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be truthful, just, or virtuous. 
abear ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a traveller) to turn towards; to lead to; to head towards. 
abebe (plural abebei) (noun F) antelope (a wild animal in the goat family with red lips). 
abebelei (plural noun F) goats’ dung; rats’ dung. cp. acin k’imirio, aleleng.
abebelei (plural of abelebelet) (noun F) remains, remnants. cp. abelebelet. 
abebenok (plural abebenoka) (noun F) a wing (of a bird, a fly, etc.); an aileron (of a fixed-wing plane). 
abeberiar ko-a (intransitive verb) to be ahead; to be there before others. luabeberikinos: the first people, animals, vehicles, etc to go.
abeberikin alosit ko-a (intransitive verb) to set off on a journey first (reflexive verb) to be the first. 
abeei (plural of abeet) (noun F) eggs; nits; spawn. 
abeet (plural abeei) (noun F) an egg (in general). abeet naka akokor: chicken egg. abeet naka emun: snake’s egg.
abeeya (plural noun F) badly ground grain; dandruff (in hair); scurf. 
abei (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a thorny tree in the ecomai family with edible fruit, Balanites orbicularis. 
abeikin ko-a (transitive verb) to result in; to say the right thing by guessing; to tell the truth; to guess correctly. 
abeit1 (adverb) truly; indeed. abeite cut mam ijo iswamat ngun?: indeed you did not do that (wrong)? 
abeit2 (singular noun F) the truth. enera eong abeit: I speak the truth.
abeit3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be authentic, true, just, actual; to be good, adequate (transitive verb) to belong to. kibeitos yes akiro: it is your fault; you are at fault (plural). 
abeitok (plural noun F) three-days-old millet or sorghum beer (brew) ready for drinking. 
abekar ko-a (transitive verb) to take off a shell; to shell a nut; to remove a scab from a wound. 
abeket ko-a (intransitive verb) (disapprovingly, of a person) to have long nails; to have jiggers. 
abeketait (plural abeketa) (noun F) an eggshell (after the bird has hatched). 
abeketet ko-a (intransitive verb) (disapprovingly, of a person) to be long-nailed. 
abekot (plural abekono, abekoi) (noun F) a virgin (girl or woman). 
abekun (transitive verb) (of something in an egg) to hatch out; to remove from the shell. 
abelanar ko-a (transitive verb) to break up hard things one after another. abu epakasit kobelana amor kere: the porter cracked all the stones one after the other. 
abelar ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person or an animal) to break through a fence, door, or an enclosure; (of thieves) to break into a house and steal; (of a traveller) to go through the bush (where there is no road). 
abelat (plural abelan) (noun F) a wound on the head (after one was struck with a stick or club on the head). 
abelat (plural abelana) (noun F) an arm ornament for dancers (made of carved wood). 
abelebel ko-a (transitive verb) to hit or wound repeatedly on the head; to crush (nuts or grain) roughly. 
abelebelet (plural abelebele) (noun F) a breadcrumb; a bit of amukeke (dry sliced potatoes); a tiny piece or remnant of bar soap; a piece of eggshell. cp. abolokok; aolokonyoit; abulukuk. 
abelekek (plural abelekeka) (noun F) a skull; a toe or finger nail; a piece of calabash or pot; a potshard; a tortoise shell. abelekek nakakou (plural abelekeka nukakwes) (noun F) a skull. abelekek nak’ebokorit (plural abelekeka nuk’ibokor) (noun F) a finger-nail; a claw. 
abelerer ko-a (intransitive verb) to have big eyes. 
abelun ko-a (transitive verb) (of cows, prisoners) to break out; to emerge from; to force oneself in or out towards the speaker. 
abeneniar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become simple, light or easy. abeneniar aswam: work has become easy (perhaps because more people have been drafted to do it). abeneniar abwokon: the burden has become light (less heavy).
abenenu (singular noun F) lightness; ease; simplicity. ipimae emisaani abenenu arai alangiru naka ibore: the weights measure how light or heavy something is.
abenenun ko-a (intransitive verb) (of something previously heavy) to become light (not heavy) or thin. 
abenot (plural abenoi) (noun F) a cork or float.
abenyan (plural abenyak) (noun F) a rebel; an insurgent; a dissenter; a guerrilla fighter. 
abenyanu (singular noun F) rebellion; insurgency; mutiny; defiance. 
abenyanut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be mischievous, lawless, indifferent, harsh, or quarrelsome; to be truculent or confrontational. 
abenyu (singular noun F) guerrilla war; harshness; lawlessness; malevolence; cruelty; malice. 
aberakin1 (adverb) coming first. 
aberakin2 (intransitive verb) to start something before someone else; to be before someone else; to take initiative. aberakina eong togo: I went into the house first (that is, before anyone else). 
aberakinet (plural aberakineta) (noun F) a self-start; an initiative; an early start. erai aberakinet nake: she/he took the initiative (literally, the initiative is hers/his). 
aberar ko-a (intransitive verb) to start or to be first; to be earlier. ikoku yen eberar osomero nges ekui ebela: the child who goes first (earlier) to school misses the cane. cp. aberun.
aberiang ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to get excited or animated once. 
aberiangang ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to be and remain excited. 
aberu (plural angor) (noun F) woman (generally). naberu: yeniberu: female; feminine. 
aberun ko-a (reflexive verb) to start or to come first (towards the speaker). koberun ber ne: come this way before anyone else. 
aberut (collective noun F) a multitude or a crowd of women. cp. angorit. 
aberyang (singular noun F) intellect; intelligence; excitement; stimulation. cp. acobeu. 
abeseeni (plural abeseenin) (noun F) a plastic basin (for bathing); a bath tub. cp. akalaya: a metallic trough.
abeun ko-a (transitive verb) to speak out the truth; to say the right thing. 
-abian (adverb) (of or relating to) yesterday or the previous day. ibian: yesterday; last night. bian kace: ngoon: the day before yesterday. akware nabian: yester night; last night.
abiasit (plural abiasin) (noun F) a live bullet; a cartridge. cp. arasaasit.
abicilaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become narrow (transitive verb) to make narrow. 
abicilil ko-a (transitive verb) to be or have protruding narrow lips; to have a narrow mouth. ibicilil ngesi akituk: she/he is narrow-mouthed. ibicililas ngesi ipon: she/he has protruding lips.
abiikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to pass wind for; to fart or to blow off for (a vulgar and indecent behaviour). cp. aiwu acin.
abiira (plural abiirai) (noun F) a plant whose fibre is used for thatching and the flowers are eaten as atigo or alilot in eboo vegetables, Hibiscus lunarfolices 
abiiwu (plural abiiwun) (noun F) a sling (for throwing a dart or a stone). cp. aporocet
abikirat (plural abikiran) (noun F) (in the Catholic church) a sister; a nun. cp. epuleera.
abila (plural abilai) (noun F) a small traditional shrine; an altar; a (certain) tribe or race. 
abilakin ko-a (transitive verb) to break for; to count for; to betray. abilakin abotet: to betray. 
abilakinio (singular noun F) judgement; reckoning; determination of someone’s fate. abilakinio abotet (noun F) betrayal (of one by someone else); treachery (by the other party). cp. atubokinio.
abilar ko-a (transitive verb) to deny; to refuse (used only of ekisil or opinion or accusation). abilar eong (adverb) excepting me or counting me out. alemar eong: except me or count me out. 
abilet1 (plural abileta) (noun F) a hem; a fold; a break. cp. atokosit. 
abilet2 (plural abileta) (noun F) a list; a schedule; a rota. 
abiletait (plural abileta) (noun F) (of something breakable) a piece; a portion; a part; a morsel. 
abilianar ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk proudly; to swagger. cp. aijer iwos bala emabwor: to twist one’s buttocks with pride like a baboon. 
abilibil ko-a (transitive verb) to break into small pieces often; to infringe, violate, breach or contravene many times. abilibilio naka apedorosio: a violation of rights.
abilibilibele (plural abilibilibelen) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a swift (bird). 
abiloi (plural of abilot) (noun F) sticks for making a reed fence. cp. atekat.
abilot (plural abiloi) (noun F) a flute; a bush with hollow stem, used as pop-gun, Stegano taenia araliacea; a reed-grass, Phragmetes mauritianus.
abilun ko-a (intransitive verb) to bargain; to fix a price; to master something; to pull down a tree branch. 
abinin (plural noun F) maize, sorghum or millet bran. 
abiokotar ko-a (intransitive verb) (disapprovingly, of toe- or finger-nails) to grow long. 
abiolos (plural abiolosin) (noun F) an ambulance. cp. abiules
abir1 (noun F) a kind of grass used for making brooms; a drought-resistant variety of sorghum grown in the dry season (October – December). cp. enyang. 
abir2 (noun F) a plant used as medicine against beginning of leprosy (when rubbed on the body), Indigofera.
abiro (plural abiroi) (noun F) a club; a big stick used as a weapon (with or without head or knob); a life-preserver. akou nak’abiro: a knob of a club. 
abitakin ko-a (reflexive verb) (of people or animals) to huddle together with cold or fever. cp. acunakin: to cross arms on chest due to cold. 
abitun ko-a (intransitive verb) (of white ants) to come out of a narrow passage. 
abitunun ko-a (intransitive verb) (of living things) to come one by one out of a narrow passage or outlet, door, or gate; to pull through a narrow opening one after another.
abiules (plural abiulesin) (noun F) an ambulance. cp. abiolos
abo? (interrogation) what about? How about? cp. do bo...?; abo jo?; do bo jo?: what about you? why not you? abo nu?: how about these?
aboboriot (plural aboborio) (noun F) wood from ebobore used for cattle-troughs; an edible ebobore fruit. 
abocit (plural abocin) (noun F) a barren woman. cp. ebwacit, abwacit.
aboga (singular noun F) amaranthus vegetable with green leaves, the stem of which is used to extract salt ash, Amaranthus spinosa. cp. edoodoo
aboi (plural aboyoros) (noun F) the big stomach of ruminant animals i.e. the rumen; the tripe. 
abok (plural abokia) (noun F) (a reference among friends) a tough woman; an iron lady. cp. akoc
abokaar ko-a (transitive verb) to dig away; to dissuade; to tempt or trick away. 
abokanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to cover up; to bury. 
abokar ko-a (transitive verb) to dig up slightly; to dig away a little. 
abokeboke (singular noun F) a plant from which salt is extracted, Asystasia gangetica 
abokenen ko-a (transitive verb) to dig, tempt, etc repeatedly. 
aboketait (plural aboketa) (noun F) temptation; lure; enticement; inducement. 
abokikin ko-a (transitive verb) to dig down; to dig for someone. 
abokio (singular noun F) temptation, or being tempted. 
aboko (plural abokoi) (noun F) a crown; a shell headdress; a mitre. aboko nak’ikukwa: crown of thorns. aponi kitanapai Yesu aboko nak’ikukwa: Jesus was worn a crown of thorns.
abokony (plural abokonya) (noun F) the lower jaw; the chin. cp. anyakaet.
abokonyony (intransitive verb) (an insult) to have big jaws. 
abokoror (singular noun F) prickly heat. ikaunit imukeru abokoror: a baby has a rash due to prickly heat.
abokoyat (plural abokoya) (noun F) an egg-shell cp. abubuket: shell (of anything); apacetait: ground nut shell. akiseta: scrapings of potatoes (amukeke stuck at the bottom of the cooking pot). 
abokun ko-a (transitive verb) to dig for oneself; to dig up; to dig out; to undermine; to tempt. 
abolet (plural aboleta) (noun F) a race; a competition; a contest; a sports ground or stadium. cp. elaagano, eisaawe
abolia1 (plural aboliasio, aboliasinei) (noun F) a game; a drama (a play); a jest; a joke; a trick. cp. emocet, ewaet: joke. 
abolia2 ko-a (transitive verb) to play (games or football, etc); to jest; to joke (with akiro). aboliar akiro: to make a joke of something serious. aboliai eong: abolia eong: I am playing. eboliaete kesi emopiira: eboliasi kesi emopiira: they are playing football. aitumor abolia kimurwokini aswam: to spend time playing and forgetting one’s tasks.
aboliaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to revel; to play away; to bamboozle. koboliaasi ngina: play over there. kilosi aboliaar Soroti: we are going to play at Soroti. 
abolibol (plural abolibolia) (noun F) a swelling as of pregnancy; a dew-lap (of animals such as cattle, horses, donkeys) 
abolobol ko-a (intransitive verb) to race; to compete. 
aboloc ko-a (intransitive verb) to peel off the bark or skin easily; to be flexible. 
abolokic (plural abolokico) (noun F) a spoon. 
abolokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to race with (one another); to compete. cp. aibol. 
abolokok (plural abolokokio) (noun F) the skull; an eggshell. cp. abulukuk, abelekek.
abolor ko-o (reflexive verb) to run together; to agree; to be ready (to die, to promise). abolor toma atwanare: to be ready to die in a contest or duel. 
abolun ko-a (transitive verb) to win; to race; to come racing. 
abomoror ko-a (intransitive verb) (of stomach) to be large or fat. 
abonan (plural abonak) (noun F) (in the Roman Catholic faith) a holy virgin. cp. abekot 
abonanut (singular noun F) virginity. 
abong (plural abongian) (noun F) the evening. 
abongeresio (plural noun F) the first stomach of a cow; the rumen (as a site for regurgitation). cp. apunuka; anyakinyak; asuorony; aboi. 
abongo (plural noun F) a herb whose seeds are used as simsim. 
abongobong ko-o (intransitive verb) to keep returning, turning round (like a dog barking in different directions). 
abongokin ko-o (transitive verb) to repeat, return; to answer; to reply. kobongok alimun nu nan ibala jo: repeat what you said earlier. kobongok ngesi ebe: answer him/her thus. abongokin kanuka: to be responsible for. ijo ibongokini kanuka iboroka luaoliosi: you will be responsible for my lost things. 
abongokinet (plural abongokineta) (noun F) an answer; a reply; a response; a reposte; a rejoinder.
abongor ko-o (intransitive verb) to go back; to return to a place (away from the speaker); to retire. abongori eong nat ore: I am going back home later. 
abongun ko-o (intransitive verb) to come back; to return (towards the speaker). ibonguni wori?: when will you come back? inyo mam epedori abongun moi karaida moi kace? Bian: (a riddle) what cannot return tomorrow or the day after? Yesterday.
abongut (plural abongun) (noun F) a bark cloth; the fibre of a bark tree; (Ateso Atororo) a blanket. 
abonot1 (singular noun F) meekness; mildness; humility. 
abonot2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be meek, humble. 
aboogi (plural aboogin) (noun F) a train wagon; a truck trailer. 
aboola (plural aboolai) (noun F) (formerly) a 10-cents coin. aboolai: money 
aboole (plural aboolei) (noun F) a cob (without maize) used as cork for bottles, etc. 
abooti (plural abootin) (noun F) a vote; a ballot paper. 
abor (plural aboria) (noun F) a place for goats outside the house; deep water. 
aboranakin ko-a (transitive verb) to allot. 
abosanut (singular noun F) stinking; rotting easily; perishable; unpreserved.
abosetait (plural aboseta) (noun F) remains of a rotten thing. 
abosikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to become rotten for; to rot somewhere, to somebody. 
abosino (plural nukabosino) (noun F) a female child surviving after the death of other children born before her. 
abosus (singular noun F) foulness; rottenness; putrefaction. 
abosuun ko-o (reflexive verb) to become rotten for; to rot somewhere, to somebody. 
abotet (plural abotei) (noun F) treachery; a plot; a device. abilakin abotet: to betray. 
abotirir (noun F) obesity; elephantiasis (of the scrotum). cp. ebatiira; akuwe
aboyaar ko-a (transitive verb) to stretch oneself; to straighten oneself or something. 
abu (intransitive verb) I have come, etc (abunere) (forms past tense of verbs). abu kiswama: she/he/it worked. 
abua (plural abuwai) (noun F) a hole, a cave (for wild animals); a hiding place. cp. abwa
abubuket (plural abubuk) (noun F) a rind; a shell or husk (of nuts, potatoes ,etc); a bark (of tree) 
abuburiar ko-a (transitive verb) to overturn; to turn upside down; to lie face down, capsize, upset. aibiror ebuburia: to fall forwards. 
abubusia (plural abubusian) (noun F) a water rat; a mink; a spotted-neck otter, Lutra maculicollis; a mink skin used as bracelet. enapit abubusia: she/he is wearing a mink-skin bracelet. 
abubut (plural abubui) (noun F) a banana fibre. cp. amugogot.
abucelel ko-a (intransitive verb) to be red-lipped. 
abuikin ko-o (transitive verb) to coerce, compel, force, or oblige; to slander (intransitive verb) to forget or slip the memory. abuikin itunganan akiro: to judge a man wrongly. kabuik: I forget. abuikin ekisil: to domineer. 
abukokin ko-o (transitive verb) to pour into, down, on. abukokin akima: to take a basket of winnowed millet or sorghum, pour water into it and leave it for a certain number of days till the millet begins to germinate. 
abukor ko-o (transitive verb) to pour away, empty out (away from speaker). 
abuku (plural abukui) (noun F) a book cover; a plough share (part of an ox-plough). 
abukuleru (plural abukulerun) (noun F) a species of edible termite. ikok luenyamio: edible termites.
abukun ko-o (transitive verb) to pour out (towards speaker). 
abukyoit (plural abukyo) (noun F) eyelash or eyebrow. 
abulaayat (plural abulaayan) (noun F) a European woman; a word in a European language. 
abuleesut (plural abuleesun) (noun F) a girl slave; a maid servant. 
abulet (plural abuleta) (noun F) opening of abscess or mouth of abscess. 
abulo ko-o (intransitive verb) to burst; to explode. abulo abeet: the egg has burst. abulo eboomu: the bomb has exploded. abulosi itunga: the crowd dispersed. cp. aduos itunga: the crowd scattered in all directions (after a fight or police intervention). abulo abus: the boil has burst. 
abulon (uncountable noun F) pus.
abulor ko-o (reflexive verb) to burst open. abulor abus: to burst open a boil or an abcess. 
abulucaaret (plural abulucaareta) (noun F) a bruise, scraping, a rubbing off. 
abulucar ko-a (transitive verb) to bruise, scrape, or rub off (skin).
abuluki (plural abulukin) (noun F) a bugle. cp. aluut, arupepe. 
abulukuk nak’akou (noun F) a skull. abulukuk nak’adere: a slightly broken calabash (almost intact). cp. abelekek. 
abulun ko-o (reflexive verb) to burst open. abulun amoitena: to disembowel. 
abulurur (noun F) a swelling in the ear. 
abunakin akanin ko-a (transitive verb) to fold hands. 
abunar eiyengane ko-a (transitive verb) to hold in the breath. 
abunere1 (singular noun F) advent; the arrival. 
abunere2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to come. abunere kaneka: to emanate from me. abuni: I will come. kiponi: we will come. epote: they will come. abu: I have come. kipou: we have come. apotu: they have come. kiponi kinomai: we were beaten. adau eong abunere: I have already come. kidau iso aponere: we have already come. (note how abunere becomes aponere when the subject is plural)
abunguret (plural abungureta) (noun F) a lump; a loaf. cp. alunguret.
Abunore (singular noun F) the Coming (of Jesus Christ); the advent.
abunus (plural abunusyo) (noun F) the paunch; the fatty tissues of the stomach. 
abuonokin ko-o (intransitive verb) to hesitate; to be in doubt; to forget a point; to vacillate; to waver. 
abuonor ko-o (intransitive verb) to swell all over the body. 
abuor ko-o (transitive verb) to rob, plunder, or confiscate. ebuonorete kesi iboro kitunga: they rob people’s things. apotu kobuosi: they robbed. 
abur (uncountable noun F) sleeping sickness disease of cattle, Nagana; Trypanosomiasis. 
aburaasi (plural aburaasin) (noun F) a (shoe or hair) brush. aburaasi naka amuk: shoe brush. aburaasi naka itim: a hair brush.
aburacu (plural aburacun) (noun F) a hook and eye; a fastener; a stud; a clasp. 
aburan ko-a (transitive verb) to claim a debt; (of a baby) to begin to grow or become fat after delivery. abunit eong aburan emong: I have come to claim my bull (you owe me). cp. aibura.
aburanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to cover for; to allot.
abures (singular noun F) fatness, thickness; obesity. cp. atumes.
aburet (plural abureta) (noun F) a tool for tightening the skin of a drum. 
aburetait (plural abureta) (noun F) a wrapper, a cover; an envelope; a re-sowing. 
aburucaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to slip and fall; to slip and escape. 
aburucikin ko-a (transitive verb) to slip off; to slip into. 
aburucun akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to say what you did not intend to say; to let out a secret; to be inopportune or impolitic. elemuni koburuc ace: lest she/he reveal what was not intended.
aburun ko-a (transitive verb) to panic; to be in a bad way, state, trouble, bad plight. kaburunitos eong ican: I am horrified by poverty. ejai ibore yen kaburunit eong: there is something troubling me. 
aburututu (plural aburututun) (noun F) a river frog. 
aburuun ko-o (intransitive verb) to become thicker. 
abus (plural abusion) (noun F) a boil; a carbuncle; an abscess or swelling. ebus: a very big abscess; a boil. aibul abus: to cut open an abscess.
abuset (plural abuseta) (noun F) abrasion. 
abuswa (plural abuswai) (noun F) a big bowl. cp. etuo loelal. 
abutar ko-a (intransitive verb) to close mouth, to sulk; to be unobliging; to say nothing; to keep quiet; to be or look sullen, morose. kobuta!: shut up! (plural kobutasi!: keep quiet!) 
abuton (plural abutok) (noun F) an eternal person. Lokasuban loabuton: God eternal.
abutor ko-o (transitive verb) to shed (rub) skin off; to bruise, abrade; (of a person’s skin) to become smooth and healthy-looking.
abutosit (plural abuseta) (noun F) snake’s skin (when it has been shed off); a slough; a peel. 
abutunge (plural abutungei) (noun F) a bud; a sprout. 
abutur ko-a (intransitive verb) to swell, blister. 
abuturaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go away with pursed lips; to go away angrily i.e. with sulky face. 
abuturur ko-a (intransitive verb) to look gloomy; to sulk; to show an angry face; to purse lips; to mooch or mope; to be swollen; to be bruised 
abutuun ko-o (intransitive verb) to begin to swell; (of abscess) to begin.
abutuunet (plural abutuuneta) (noun F) a swelling; an abscess; a pustule; a boil.
abutuusit (plural abutuusin) (noun F) a rubber boot; a jungle boot; a boot. 
abuuba (plural abuuban) (noun F) a bicycle pump. cp. aiwudet. 
abuun ko-o (intransitive verb) (of dough) to swell, rise, ferment; to inflate; to puff. 
abuyior ko-o (transitive verb) to overcome by force, great exertion; to bully; to rape; to rob. ikoto ijo abuyior eong: you want to rape or coerce me. erono abuyior apese: it is bad to rape a girl. cp. aitingakin.
abuyoor ko-o (transitive verb) to force; to rape, bully; to dragoon. 
abwa (plural abuwai) (noun F) a hole, cave (for wild animals); a hiding place. cp. abua
abwaade (plural abwaadei) (noun F) a prostitute. cp. amalayat; ayekeret
abwaar ko-a (transitive verb) to make a new homestead. abwaikin: to settle down in a place; to make new home for someone else. abwaun: to come, settle near by. 
abwacit (plural abwacin) (noun F) a barren woman; a lesbian. araus abwacit: (of a woman) to be barren or a lesbian. araun abwacit: (of a woman) to become sterile, barren or homosexual. 
abwakar akonye ko-a (transitive verb)  to charm the eyes by sprinkling poison on them. 
abwakat (plural abwakan) (noun F) earrings. 
abwal (plural abwalin) (noun F) a water-hole; a fountain; a pond; deep waters. cp. abwel
abwalaanut (noun F) enticement; negligence; slowness (intransitive verb) to be negligent or slow. 
abwalar ko-a (intransitive verb) to be taken or to take unawares and unprepared; to mislead somebody; to fall upon suddenly; to delay; to dally; to waste time; to be lazy; to be negligent. kidum ijo eong abwalara: you have found me unprepared. abu atwanare kobwalaa ngesi: death took her/him by surprise. cp. alecor
abwalun ko-a (intransitive verb) to come out into the open; to appear outside. cp. alomun. 
abwang ko-a (reflexive verb) to break; to come or fall to bits; to crack. cp. angeda, abila, aria, acila. 
abwangar ko-a (intransitive verb) to run mad; to go wild, mad; to run amok; to run helter-skelter, become hysteric. abwanga adeka: the illness made him mad. (transitive verb) to drive or make mad; to madden. cp. aikerepikin. 
abwangun ko-a (intransitive verb) to break out; to germinate (as of mushrooms, grey hair, small-pox). abwangun adeka kinga: (of sickness, etc) to appear. abwangun epuuru kakuwan Oluka kere: chicken-pox has broken out all over Oluka’s body. abwangut imaruk: big mushrooms have sprouted. 
abwaresikin ko-o (transitive verb) to lasso or to get hold of quickly; to catch for somebody; to tie quickly on something. 
abwaresor ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch away from speaker; to sweep away; to blow away chaff or dust. abwaresun: to lasso. 
abwaresunet (plural abwaresuneta) (noun F) the lasso or lassoing. 
abwaret ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch away (as of hawk snatching a chick); to take suddenly and without asking; to snatch a meal; to fling a rope. 
abwas (plural abwasia) (noun F) a fence round a kraal, homestead, etc; an enclosure. 
abwatakin ko-a (transitive verb) to sprinkle on. 
abwatar ko-a (transitive verb) to catch or snatch (hens, cows, etc). abwatar aberu kanuka etal: to lead or to introduce a girl (after conception of first child) to her parents’ home, being sprinkled with water as she enters the home. abwatar akipi: to shake off water. 
abwataror ko-o (transitive verb) to be introduced with an offering of goat or anything. akoto akonikine abwataror amurake: I want your goat to make a present to my in-laws. 
abwatunio ore (noun F) a traditional cleansing ceremony (involving sprinkling or smearing with water, cow-dung or raw millet porridge) performed at the entrance to the homestead before allowing in a long lost relative (presumed dead) or a daughter who gave birth to twins.
abwaun1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to hide inside, surround, encircle (as fence). 
abwaun2 ko-a (transitive verb) to hold; to contain water. ibwaunit erot akipi: the road is holding puddles of water. 
abwel (plural abwelin) (noun F) a well; a spring of water. cp. abwal
abwengun ki-a (transitive verb) to open eyes wide; to start out of bed, when being throttled or when resisting sleep. 
abwo (plural abwos) (noun F) (formerly) a tail ornament of animal skin worn by old women; a flap. 
abwoar ko-a (intransitive verb) to stand aside. kobwoa laije: stand over there. 
Abwoatidwe (noun F) May (literally, the month of uneasy hungry children). cp. Opedelei.
abwobwoot ko-a (transitive verb) to loiter or stand idle. 
abwoenen ko-a (intransitive verb) to keep standing up. abwoenen kawai k’erot: to keep standing by the side of the road. 
abwoetait (plural abwoeta) (noun F) an easel; the standpoint; one’s opinion or position in a debate, an issue, etc 
abwoikin ko-a (transitive verb) to stand up for; to guarantee; to sponsor, stand bail for; to be a godparent (to a child being baptised); to brave and face an attacker; to dare; to withstand. 
abwoikiniton (plural abwoikinitok) (noun F) a sponsor or guarantor; a godparent; a representative or delegate; one who stands and challenges another. cp. ekabwoikiniton.
abwonokin ko-a (reflexive verb) to doubt; to hesitate or vacillate. cp. abuonokin. 
abworon (plural abworok) (noun F) a girl who refuses to marry or who refuses her husband. cp. aagiron.
abwotar ko-a (transitive verb) to emigrate; to go to another country. 
abwotun ko-a (transitive verb) to immigrate from another country this way. 
abwoun ko-a (transitive verb) to stand surety or bail; to refuse. abwou je: he has refused. cp. aigir.
abwounet (plural abwouneta) (noun F) a stop (sign); a fullstop; a stopping place; a station; a stage (for a bus or taxi). 
abwoyaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to calm down, relent, settle down, become clear (of water). ebwoyaaritos akip: the water has settled down (i.e. which was turbulent and dirty). abwoyaa akwap: the country has calmed (settled down). 
acaadula (plural nuacaadula) (adjective) (of a woman) perennially having no food in the granary. aberu ngin acaadula: that woman has food insecurity (that is, her granary is always empty). 
acaago (plural acaagoi) (noun F) the Luffah plant, its fruit is used for making bathing sponges. 
acaanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to give constant light; to keep on enlightening; to throw light on. ecaanakini akolong iboro kere: the sun constantly enlightens every object. cp. aitacaanakin. 
acaapa (plural acaapan) (noun F) a bandage; a patch; a tourniquet; a rag.
acabakin ko-a (transitive verb) to run quickly to something or someone (with long, light strides). abu ikapa kocabakin emir: a cat ran quickly (with long, light strides) after the rat. 
acabalalaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to run swiftly this way. 
acabar ko-a (intransitive verb) to run away quickly; to dash away. 
acabun ko-a (reflexive verb) to hurry towards speaker. kocabun lailo: come quickly this way. cp. aiceb 
acaikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to shine upon, on, for; (of a person previously depending on another) to come face to face with hardships. 
acak (plural nuacak) (noun F) a light-green harmless arboreal snake, Chlorophis. cp. oliborit
acakakin ko-a (transitive verb) to throw on to (reflexive verb) to fall on. cp. aibirokin; atiakin; adoore. kacakakin ngesi eong: she/he/it fell on me. 
acakanar ko-a (transitive verb) to throw away (one after another); to squander; to abjure; to discard. 
acakar ko-a (transitive verb) to fling away; to exile; to banish; to adjure. acakaret naka amoru: a stone’s throw. 
acakat (plural acakai) (noun F) a rain stone; white round pebbles found in akao. cp. alica
acakenen ko-a (transitive verb) to throw repeatedly. 
acakia (plural of acak) (noun F) a green harmless arboreal snake. cp. oliborit
acalaanar ko-a (reflexive verb) to scream repeatedly; to be rowdy. 
acalaani (plural acalaanin) (noun F) a sewing machine; an instrument (like a curved knife) for weeding millet. 
acalaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to shout out, yell, scream; to cry out; to shriek. cp. acelaar. 
acalar ko-a (reflexive verb) to melt away (as of fat or butter); to dissolve or dilute (because it is thick). 
acamakin ko-a (transitive verb) to permit; to acknowledge, allow, or sanction; to agree. kocamakinai eong abunere orekon: permit me to come to your home (reflexive verb) to be reconciled. 
acamakinet (plural acamakineta) (noun F) a permit; a consent; a sanction; an approval. abalua n’acamakinet: a written permit. 
acamanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to show off. cp. acamit: akoto: I want. 
acamun ko-a (transitive verb) to consent, assent, comply; to undertake; to agree, accept, abide, accede; to hit an object aimed at. acamu ngesi ebe asabi: she/he admitted that she/he lied. acamunos ngol ka okokuke: he is reconciled with his son.
acamunet (plural acamuneta) (noun F) compliance; agreement; assent; admittance. 
acamunit ko-a (intransitive verb) to be willing; to want. anyarau eong Ocaatum ido ecamunit ngesi aupar ka eong: I have invited Ocaatum and he is willing to come with me. 
acany (plural acanya) (noun F) a foot deformity acquired in childhood; a painful incurable sore under the sole of foot; sole granuloma. ejai eong acany naepol noi: I have got a large incurable sore underneath my foot. 
acaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become clear, light, bright, shining, etc. (intransitive verb) to shine; to be warm, be hot. ecaunit lolo akolong: the sun is bright today.
acaunet (plural acauneta) (noun F) a drought; a dry spell; sunshine. 
ace- (feminine adverbial prefix) some. acepaarit (plural acepaarasia) (adverb) some day; occasionally. aceberu: another woman.
acece (singular noun F) gravy; sauce; soup; consommé; broth. 
acedakin ko-a (transitive verb) to spy upon; to inspect secretly; to take by surprise; to come upon suddenly or unnoticed; to confide a secret. icedanakin ijo eong apaarasia kere: you always take me by surprise, come upon me suddenly, unexpectedly. ejaas nuakoto eong acedakin ijo: I have something to tell you confidentially. 
acedanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to whisper; to tell little secrets. ejaas kesi nuecedanakinete ipaupakec: they have secrets which they tell their companions. 
acedar ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk quietly away; to go away unobserved (transitive verb) to take away stealthily (a mild form of stealing). ejai lokecedaa ekasigala kane: there is someone who furtively took my cigarette away. 
acedekanar ko-a (intransitive verb) to keep jumping along; to prance; to skip across. elosete apesur acedekanar kauno: the girls are going to have a skipping game. 
aceduna (plural nuceduna) (noun F) a secret. etogo loinerare nuceduna: a private room or office. einer nuceduna: to speak secrets. 
acedunun ko-a (transitive verb) to eat daintily (little by little). acedunun inyamat: to eat food piecemeal. 
aceederuwa (plural aceederuwan) (noun F) a mosquito net. cp. aitiiba
aceerin (plural of aceerit) (noun F) lines on the hand or cloth; stripes on anything. aceerin nuka etuko ibusiak: the stripes of the zebra are beautiful. 
aceger ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a thin or slender person) to walk about naked. sirikiceger kakonye k’itunga: do not walk naked in public (that is, in front of people). cp. angecer.
acegerer ko-a (intransitive verb) to be thin. icegereras yesi: you are thin, emaciated. 
acegerikin ko-a (reflexive verb) to walk naked or in rags; to walk (as of a thin person). 
acekanut ko-a (transitive verb) to be fertile; (of hair or weeds) to grow quickly. 
acel1 (noun F) conflict; noise; cacophony; uproar. ingai eyaunit acela ne?: who is brings dispute here? 
acel2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to conflict; to shout; to quarrel. acel bian je akiring kia: the guy quarrelled the whole night for the meat.
acelakin ko-a (reflexive verb) to dissent; to quarrel with. acelakinos ekiliokit k’aberuke: a man has quarrelled with his wife. cp. ecelas: are quarrelling. 
acelanar ko-a (reflexive verb) to quarrel (intransitive verb) to be inimical. ecelanara itunga ngul: those people are not friends (that is, they are always quarrelling). 
acelanut (noun F) the habit of shouting; making noise; boisterousness. kinyek acelanut: stop being cantankerous.
acelar ko-o (reflexive verb) to shout; to scream. cp. acalaar: to scream. 
acelatun (plural acelatunio) (noun F) a ditch. 
acelenen ko-a (intransitive verb) to quarrel repeatedly; to nag. 
acelikite (plural acelikiten) (noun F) a species of bird, White-bellied florican. 
acelit (plural acel) (noun F) a shell of a snail or any mollusc. toto k’acelit: toto k’acel: a snail; a snail shell. 
acen (plural acenion) (noun F) a niece on sister’s side. (note: on brother’s side these are called akoku: daughter). cp. ajejait: a niece (from the point of view of both the maternal or paternal aunts).
acereded ko-a (transitive verb) (of men or animals) to be firm, refuse, struggle against abduction. acerededet: all out; doing the best you can. abu akiteng kocereded neakotor eong arikor nges: the cow struggled as I was dragging it away. 
acerit (plural acer) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a star. acer: a constellation. 
aceritoit (plural acerito) (noun F) linear marks of a spilt liquid. ajaas Icodat acerito nuka akiyo: Icodat had furrows of tears on account of weeping often. ejaas ikoku acerito nuka akile: the child has marks of spilt milk on its body. 
acerokin ko-o (intransitive verb) to put stripes on; to make stripes on cheeks with tears, hence to weep. 
acerosit (plural acerin) (noun F) a stripe on stockings or on a zebra’s body. 
acetakin ko-a (transitive verb) to brush lightly and hit something else; to rub or touch lightly in passing; (of a shot or of a missile) to graze (and always hitting another object). acetakin emal ikoku: the arrow grazed and hit the child. 
acetanar ko-a (intransitive verb) to keep slipping off (a tree). cp. ajurutanar: slip on slippery ground. 
acetek ko-a (intransitive verb) to dance; to scuffle; to shuffle. Elisabet, kacetekata: Elizabeth, come let us dance. 
acibakin ko-a (transitive verb) to drink a little for somebody else (usually for small babies, as a mother does, or birds teaching nestlings to take food). 
acibun ko-a (transitive verb) to take a sip, drink or smoke little by little. akoto acibun apuru: I want to smoke cigarettes a little. 
acicing ko-a (intransitive verb) (used in infinitive and in 3rd person followed by an infinitive) to do or happen seldom or rarely. ecicing papaka abunenen ne: my father rarely comes here. acicing naka edou ngesi ayauni etengei: the scarcity of rain brought the famine. aiticicing: to cause to happen seldom or to do seldom. isiru kesi keticicingito eong alosit Bugondo: it is mosquitoes that make me go to Bugondo rarely. 
acidikik ko-a (intransitive verb) to have small breasts. icidikik aberu na: this woman has small breasts (that is, she is small-breasted). 
acigait (plural acigai) (noun F) a swelling on the ankle. cp. acikait 
acigwa (plural acigwai) (noun F) (Usuk) a sunbird (a small bird believed to bring bad or good omen when it flies overhead to the left or to the right).
acikait (plural acika) (noun F) a swelling on the wrist. cp. acigait
acikilikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to drop right into (water or anything). acikilikin akolodong toma akipi cikil: a tortoise dropped heavily into the water. 
acilakin ko-a (transitive verb) to break into a house (after splitting the door or walls). acilanakin alelesia: to irrigate. 
acilar ko-a (transitive verb) (of cloth) to tear off; to drain. acilar akipi: to drain away water. acilar akou ko-o (reflexive verb) (of person or animal) to break down, become mad, unmanageable, run off, go away quietly. 
acilet (plural acileta) (noun F) a tear (in cloth); a split (in the wall or wood); a passage (in a crowd). 
acilicil ko-a (transitive verb) (of cloth) to tear to pieces; (of a stick) to split into splinters. cp. ainged: to break (a rope, string, thread, etc). aibil: to break (a promise, wood or command). aibwang: to break (glass or pottery). atiakin etogo: to break down a house. 
acilicilun ko-a (reflexive verb) to become torn to pieces; to rags. acilicilunos inapen kere: all the clothes are torn to rags. 
acilitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to be unmanageable, not listen to anybody; to be cheeky, a rascal. 
acilun ko-o (reflexive verb) to break one’s way through (this way); to erupt; to irrigate. kocilun lailo: make your way towards me. acilun akipi: to irrigate (with water). 
acin (plural noun F) faeces; excrement (of animals or birds); ordure. aiwu acin: to gas; to fart. acin kimirio: rat droppings or excreta; (figurative) rice grain. cp. emuceeri
acinga (plural acingan) (noun F) a prong, a fork of a tree. 
acingakin ko-a (transitive verb) to place between prongs; to put between fork or between any narrow opening; to squeeze in between (reflexive verb) to place or press oneself into a narrow space. (intransitive verb) to be amongst, between. kocingakinos yesi da nepenen: you also squeeze yourselves in-between there. adum eong ikoku ecingakina kiding otunga: I found the child amongst the crowd. 
acingakina ko-a (transitive verb) to be in between; to be in the middle of other things or people. 
acingar ko-a (reflexive verb) to pass, squeeze through a narrow opening, pass through difficulties. abu eong kacingaror akiro ngun: I got that case through with great difficulty. 
acingat (plural acingata) (noun F) a narrow place; a narrow passage. cp. acilet
acinget (plural acingeta) (noun F) a prong, a fork of a tree. cp. acinga
acinioit (plural acin) (noun F) human faeces; excrement of an animal or bird. aiwu acin: to pass wind, blow off, or to fart. 
acipa (noun F) name of grass used for making granaries or barns, Digitaria spp. 
acoa (plural acoasinei) (noun F) sense; wisdom; wit; knowledge; cleverness; skill; shrewdness; ability; dexterity; adroitness. aitub acoa: to decide; to make a decision. acoa na Iteso: Teso brew (called ajon). acoa nasubunet (singular noun F) instinct; intuition; gut feeling. 
acoanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to be always careful. 
acobet (plural acobei) (noun F) a bird, a wax-bill. 
acobeu1 (uncountable noun F) acumen; intelligence; wit; sense; wisdom; cleverness; brains; astuteness; shrewdness. emamei ngesi acobeu: she/he has no brains. cp. aberyang
acobeu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be wise, keen, intelligent, clever, shrewd. kocobeu, sirikoni nen: get wise, do not behave like that. 
acobok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a girl) to have or to go about with developed breasts. ecoboki apese ngin: that girl flaunts her developed breasts. icobokokas ikisin: the breasts are developed. 
acocora (plural noun F) the porridge-like waste product in the distillation of crude alcohol. cp. akima, acwatai.
acocorot (plural acocoron) (noun F) a francolin-like bird. 
acodirir ko-a (intransitive verb) to be tall, long, high. 
acodocod ko-a (transitive verb) to keep tempting, enticing. 
acodokokor1 (plural acodokokoroi) (noun F) a chestnut sparrow. 
acodokokor2 (plural acodokokoroi) (noun F) a vegetable. 
acodongong ko-a (intransitive verb) to be long legged, tall (noun F) height, tallness. koyanga akonicodongong ngina: go away, please (literally, take away your imposing height). 
acodun ko-a (transitive verb) to test, tempt; to try to challenge. aingisetaiti kon erai naka acodun: your question is a challenge. aswam ngin ecoduni akonicoa: that work tests your intelligence. apak nak’acodunio: the hour of trial or temptation. 
acodunet (plural acoduneta) (noun F) a trial, test, temptation. 
acodunio (singular noun F) temptation; enticement; inducement to do something morally wrong. 
acogorar ko-a (intransitive verb) to become awkward; to be cruciform. 
acoikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to avert; to see through; to beware of; to draw oneself away. acoiki ekokolan ngol akiro ngun: the thief has seen through the trap. kocoikis acoa naka ajokit: beware of the devil’s tricks. acoiki ngesi: she/he has withdrawn because she/he feels at fault. cp. ajenikin: to take to heart. 
acoikinet (plural acoikineta) (noun F) foresight; wisdom; intention; certitude. acaadula emamei acoikinet: a woman with an oft empty granary has no foresight. 
acoikinit ko-a (intransitive verb) to note; to beware of; to draw oneself away. 
acoit ko-o (intransitive verb) to take care, look carefully, be aware. kocoite: be careful; beware. kocoitos!: (plural) beware!; know what is happening! aitocoit: to make, cause to be careful, to care. eswamat eong ngun komam acoit: I did that carelessly. 
acok1 (plural of acokit) (noun F) sweet potatoes (native); Irish potatoes; potato or cassava tubers. acok k’Imusugun: Irish potatoes.
acok2 ki-o (transitive verb) to herd or to feed cattle or any other livestock; to follow (somebody or something) everywhere. 
acokicok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of eyes) to water. acokicokoto ikoku akonye: the eyes of the child are wet with tears (transitive verb) to sprinkle water in order to lay the dust. 
acokit (plural acok) (noun F) a sweet potato (native); Irish potato; potato or cassava tuber. acokit na Imusugun: an Irish potato.
acokom ko-a (intransitive verb) to eat something nice, tasty (especially meat). 
acokonye (plural nukacokonye) (noun F) a minx; a rude and daring girl (who looks you in the face); a curious woman. 
acoler ki-o (intransitive verb) to have a crown of hair standing up. 
acoliar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become thin; to become watery. acoliaros ajon nu: this beer has become thin, watery. 
acolib ko-a (transitive verb) to point; to sharpen. kicolibikinai eong ekakalaamu: sharpen my pencil. 
acoman (plural acomanin) (noun F) a traditional pad worn by women during menstruation. cp. adoobe
acomeit (plural acomei) (noun F) a species of bird. 
acomil ko-a (intransitive verb) to sit down sorrowfully, uncomfortably with watery eyes. cp. acolicol. edoteana. 
acomilil ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inquisitive; to have a piercing look; to brood or worry. inyo bo icomililar ijo kane?: why are you (singular) here brooding? 
acookonye (plural nuacookonye) (noun F) a woman with lustful eyes. 
Acoolit (plural Acoolin) (noun F) a word in the Acholi language; an Acholi woman or native of Gulu, Kitgum or Pader districts of northern Uganda. Acoolin: the Acholi women; the Acholi language (one of the Luo dialects, the others being Langi of Lira and Apac, Alur of Nebbi, and Ethur of Kotido). cp. anyakoit: a northern woman.
acooro (plural acooron) (noun F) a cap, hat, helmet. 
acoricorot (plural acoricoron) (noun F) a drop of liquid. 
acoroi (collective noun F) (general name for) termites; a worker ant. 
acoto (uncountable noun F) cow’s urine. cp. ekulam k’akituk. 
acoun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become careful, wise, prudent, cultured. 
acous ko-a (transitive verb) to be wise, to be clever; cleverness; wisdom; to be cute, astute. 
acowe (plural acowei) (noun F) a wading bird, lily-trotter, Actophylornis. 
acualat (plural acualan) (noun F) meat removed from the hide or skin when pegging the hide/skin to dry (cooked and eaten). 
acuar ko-a (transitive verb) to press out; to wring out, squeeze out. 
acuc (plural noun F) juice pressed out from used beer or from the remains of beer (given to children to drink in the morning). 
acuducud ko-a (transitive verb) to cause or make marks or spots (on head by a ringworm or bad shaving); to make spots on anything else; to spoil by witchcraft. icuducud ijo epaabaka: you have killed my cotton by witchcraft. 
acuduun ko-a (intransitive verb) to come here to practice witchcraft. kinyek acuduun lailo, kocudaa obukus ngina: do not come here to practice witchcraft, rather practice it there in your own home area. 
acugurikin ko-a (reflexive verb) to bend; to walk with stooped shoulders, with a stoop; to walk with round shoulders. ecugurikina ngesi kanuka aterot: she/he/it stoops due to the cold. 
acugurur ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk with a stoop. 
acuikin ko-a (transitive verb) to squeeze for somebody else. kocuikinai eong emucuuga ngol: squeeze that orange for me. 
acukia (plural acukiai) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a sunbird (a small bird believed to bring bad or good omen when it flies overhead to the left or to the right). cp. acigwa.
acukudikin ko-a (transitive verb) to arch. 
acukulet (plural acukulen) (noun F) a bump or a dip or a hole in the road. ileleba acukulen orot lo: this road is very bumpy. 
acukulul ko-o (intransitive verb) to be bumpy, rutty, full of holes, ruts. icukulul erot: the road is bumpy. icukululos irotin: the roads are bumpy. 
acukumac (plural acukumacia) (noun F) a burning log or faggot. 
acukut (plural acukun) (noun F) a blacksmith's bellows (used for forging bells for dancing, or spears and axes); a blowpipe; the engine of a ferry boat. cp. aacukut.
aculoit (plural aculoi) (noun F) a bead (ornament). 
aculokin1 ko-a (reflexive verb) (of people) to mix in a crowd; to be in the middle of, mixed up with. adum eong ikoku eculokina kiding otunga: I found the child in the midst of the people. cp. acingakin. 
aculokin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to make lukewarm (by adding cold water); to pacify by words or by mere presence. kolot ijo koculok itunga ngul: go and pacify those quarrelsome people (by showing yourself up or talking to them.) 
aculokin3 ko-o (reflexive verb) to interfere; to go and sit in the wrong place; to enter into a dispute uninvited. 
aculokinet (plural aculokineta) (noun F) a stain; a spot of dust. 
aculonokin ko-a (transitive verb) to stain often; to stain repeatedly; to variegate (colours, hues). 
aculot1 (plural aculoi) (noun F) a young hen; a pullet. cp. akokor, imiot
aculot2 (plural aculon) (noun F) a stain; a mark; a blemish. 
aculucul ko-o (transitive verb) to stripe; to stain repeatedly; to keep blemishing, be spotted. 
aculurikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to rest on top; to be on top (transitive verb) to put on top. adum eong apupu iculurikina kuju atitipu: I found a hedge-hog on top of an anthill. cp. aiculurikin
aculuru (plural aculurun) (noun F) the top of a roof. cp. eswi, atunyuru. 
acumulul ko-a (intransitive verb) to squat on haunches; to mooch, look sour; to sulk. lokapesenin edili acumululit okitui: the one with debts goes out very early to the bush and sits there on his haunches mooching about. 
acunakin ko-a (transitive verb) to make an archway for somebody else (reflexive verb) to shrug shoulders. cp. aiyug ikeperin: to shrug one’s shoulders.
acunanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to make an opening for water to run off; to make archway; (of water- passage or canal) to narrow out. 
acunar ko-a (intransitive verb) to pass through a narrow opening. cp. aridar: to squeeze through; acingar. 
acunasit (plural acunasia) (noun F) a curvature; an arch. 
acunetait (plural acuneta) (noun F) an archway; a lintel of door or window; a bend or curve. 
acunun ko-o (reflexive verb) to squeeze into (transitive verb) to squeeze into a narrow opening. cp. acingun, aridun. 
acupun ko-o (transitive verb) to single out. kicupunit ijo eong bon aitaswam: you have picked me out to work often. acupun adekanakin: to be constantly ill. kacupunit eong adeka ngin: that disease always catches me (of all people). 
acupuno ko-o (reflexive verb) to be singular, peculiar, strange, eccentric. ecupuno ngesi noi: she/he is very strange; she/he is very peculiar. 
acur (plural acuria) (noun F) a head dress made of feathers. 
acuria (plural acuriai) (noun F) (Ongino, Kumi) a ceremonial pot with two mouths. cp. adogoria. 
acurupar ko-o (reflexive verb) to taper down 
acurupiar ko-a (transitive verb) to fold together; to fold to a point. 
acut (plural acutio) (noun F) a vulture, Neophron percnopterus. cp. atarukot.
acuubu (plural acuubun) (noun F) (in Pallisa, Tororo) common salt (sodium chloride). cp. amuunyu. 
acuuma (plural acuuman) (noun F) a ginnery; a flourmill; any machine or instrument. acuuma nairies alos: a flour mill. acuuma nailoset igoen: a cloth-washing or laundry machine. cp. atukituk.
acuun ko-a (transitive verb) to wring out; to press out, squeeze out. acuun akiyo: to weep (literally, to squeeze out tears). acuun akinyet kocok: to press oil from seeds. ajon nuecuitai: ajon nuecuu: beer which has been strained, pressed or squeezed. 
acuurut (plural acuurun) (noun F) a woolly-necked stork; a black crake, Limnocorax. 
acwalat (noun F) juice of potato or fruit. 
acwatai (plural noun F) the porridge-like waste product in the distillation of crude alcohol. cp. akima, acocora.
acwetar ko-a (reflexive verb) to glance off. cp. acetar. 
acworet (noun F) a plant that keeps bedbugs away, Pseudarthria hookeri. 
adaanakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to clap hands for someone (in a token of gladness or joy); to welcome; to clap hands at play. kodaanakis ejakait akanin: welcome the chief by clapping your hands. 
adaanakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to finish all for. kodaanak akonigogong nen: exhaust your strength there. 
adaanakin3 ko-a (transitive verb) to give a report of; to give an account; to give an explanation. kodaanakinai nuiswamat ijo kangina: give me an account of what you did there. 
adaanakin4 ko-o (reciprocal verb) to beat one another often. itelepai lu edaanakinos apaarasia kere: these boys are always fighting or beating one another. 
adacakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall or throw oneself into danger; to endanger oneself (transitive verb) to endanger another. sirikidacak eong toma akiro: don’t endanger me, that is, do not get me into that case. 
adacanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to spoil; to waste or squander. sirikidacanaa edia kwap: do not spill the vegetables on the floor.
adacar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go to waste, do in vain; (of water) to pour over. adacaros isiriginika tai: my money has gone to waste. adacar kwap: to fall. elosi ngesi adacar: she/he/it is going to fall. (transitive verb) to throw away thick matter (transitive verb) to do in vain. idacanari ijo aikatakon: you fish in vain. 
adacun ko-a (of akiro, things) to drop in front of a person. 
adaduli (plural adadulin) (noun F) a straw hat. arai kidolit adaduli, konap: if the hat fits, wear it.
adae (plural noun F) spoor, dust or mud on sole of foot. ailakilakar adae: to run away (literally, to shake off the dust on one's feet).
adaet (plural adaeta) (noun F) a mallet; a stick for threshing millet or beating house floor. 
adaikin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to finish for; to tell the story or case. kadaikis akokoroi nu akakimai: these chickens have finished my millet. mam ijo idaikit atukot akiro kere: you have not told the gathering the whole story or all the facts. 
adaikin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to thrash for someone; to lash for someone; to give a hiding. 
adaikin3 ko-o (reflexive verb) to be lost to. kadaikin eong ikakoku: my child is dead (literally, my child is lost to me). abu ngesi kodaikin toma akaninika: she/he died in my arms. kidaikinos oni iinonosiowok lukolo: our old customs are lost to us (i.e. they have died out). 
adairekita (plural adairekitan) (noun F) a female director; a manageress. cp. akengarenikinon
adak ko-a (intransitive verb) to graze (by oneself); to feed (by oneself); (of cattle) to eat; to browse; (of a person) to eat too much. edakas imongin: the bulls are grazing, feeding. edakas akituk: the cows are grazing. edaka akiteng: the cow is grazing. adakit akiteng: the cow has grazed. edakito akituk: the cows have grazed. cp. acok.
adakai (plural adaka) (noun F) dregs; remnants of beer. 
adakakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to carry onto; to rear for, on or into; to entrust to, confer upon, give in custody. kanukinyo kidakakitor ijo eong ebela?: why do you want to beat me, that is, why do you carry the stick against me? kadakakit eong ijo ikakoku: I entrust my child to you, or give it to you for custody. 
adakakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to choose a leader; to elect, appoint; to lift up onto something. kidakakinio bo ijo ajakaanut wori?: when were you appointed to leadership? 
adakar ko-a (transitive verb) to carry away (reflexive verb) to be confused; to be abashed; to have swollen head (with shame); to be proud, over bearing, carry head high; to be very hairy. adakar ijo akou: you are ashamed, or overcome with shame. edakara Apolo akou: Apolo is proud. adakar aberu ngin akou: that woman has a bushy head, full of hair. 
adakara ko-a (intransitive verb) to be arrogant; to brag. 
adaket (plural adaketa) (noun F) a bier, a litter; a stretcher; a crane. 
adakiika (plural adakiikan) (noun F) a minute, sixty seconds. cp. esaawa: an hour; time; a clock; a watch. 
adakit ko-a (transitive verb) to carry. edakit aberu ikoku: the woman is carrying a child. 
adakun ko-a (transitive verb) to dismount; to bring hither. adakunos akile: the milk is boiling up (by cooking). adakun emugaati: the dough is risen. adakun eong akeju: my leg is swollen. 
adal (plural adalia) (noun F) a cape (of coat); lapel (of shirt or coat); a collar (of a dress). 
adalacar ko-a (reflexive verb) to fester; to ulcerate. adalacar ajimike: her/his wound has festered. 
adalaka (noun F) (formerly) a variety of finger millet. 
adalarac (plural adalaraca) (noun F) an edible shrub, Oxygonum atriplicifolium. 
adalidal ko-a (intransitive verb) to be hanging down; to come down; to come near; to hang down low; to hang and swing; to dangle. emong lo edalidali abolibol: this bull has a dangling dewlap. edalidalete ikisin luka aberu: the woman's breasts are floppy. edalidalete aki: lop-eared. edalidali edou: the cloud is low (that is, it is threatening to rain). 
adam (plural noun F) the brain; the cerebrum; the grey matter; wisdom; intellect. 
adamo ko-o (transitive verb) (not used with liquids) to close or to fold or press together; (of a toothless person) to eat. edamoi ikoku emaido: the child (having no teeth) eats soft nuts. 
adamoikin ko-o (transitive verb) (of book, cloth, skin, etc) to close, fold or press together; (of lips in pain) to compress. kodamoik emukule ngol: fold that skin. cp. airajaraj.
adamokok ko-a (intransitive verb) to be folded, flat; (of bag, breasts, football) to be empty. idamokokos imopiiran: the balls are empty. idamokokos ikisin: the breasts are flat, that is, there is no milk in the breasts. 
adangar ko-o (reflexive verb) to take once for all. koyanga acok ngupengun kodangaror: take those potatoes only and no more. cp. atwaniara. 
adanyot (plural adanyoi) (noun F) a fruit of ekungur tree. cp. akungurot
adapadap ko-a (transitive verb) to come or go alongside of; to stalk; to put many patches on; to patch up; to keep in repair (of anything). edapadapat engatuny kauj: the lion is stalking our kraal. edapadapatai esaatikon: your shirt is patched all over. 
adapadapaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to move away stealthily; to edge away, off. 
adapadapat ko-o (intransitive verb) to keep on visiting someone bashfully (seeking favours). kanukinyo idapadapator ijo?: what are you after with your repeated visits? (transitive verb) to look on longingly. edapadapat ikoku emugaati: the child looks longingly at the bread. (transitive verb) to go stealthily; to be artful. edapadapatos kesi: they are artful or tricky in their movements. 
adapadapaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to try to regain favour in a roundabout way; to make overtures; to insinuate. edapadapauna aberu ngin abongokin k’okilenike: that woman is making overtures to return to her husband. (reflexive verb) to come stealthily. adapadapaunos: they are returning stealthily. 
adapakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be hidden. adapakinos bo akinei ai?: where have the goats hidden themselves (i.e. where are they)? (transitive verb) to put near something. ai bo idapakit ijo ikaboro?: where have you hidden my things? 
adapakina ko-a (intransitive verb) to be depending on (someone or something). 
adapalal (noun F) flatness; evenness; smoothness. 
adapalanut (noun F) flatness or evenness (intransitive verb) to be flat. 
adapao (plural adapaon) (noun F) a porch; the eaves; a hiding place.
adapenen ko-a (transitive verb) to keep stalking someone or something; to continually repair by adding patches. kapas eong adapenen etogo lo: I am tired of repairing this house (or patching this house).
adapet (plural adapeta) (noun F) a patch (on cloth or anything).
adapidap ko-a (transitive verb) to catch (chickens) by stealth, side-stepping. 
adatat (plural adatan) (noun F) a newly cleared plot of ground; a new garden, field. 
adaun ko-o (reflexive verb) to be finished; to die. adaunos akipi: the water is finished. (intransitive verb) to finish; to accomplish, consummate; to complete, exterminate. kodau ber akoniswam: first finish your work. (intransitive verb) to be sufficient; to be enough. mam apeesan ngun edolete: that money is not sufficient. (adaun is also used to translate ‘after’, and ‘to be dead’). kidau aswamukon, kobu: after your work, come here; or, come here when you have finished your work. adaun papaka: my father is dead. adaunos eong akituk: my cows are finished or are dead. 
adauna (noun F) absoluteness; absolutism. 
adaunet (plural adauneta) (noun F) the end. idol ijo adaunet naka epelu: you have reached the end of the task. cp. esange; awasia.
adea ko-a (intransitive verb) to crack; to make a crackling sound (as of a beam going to break). adeas akito kokuju togo: the rafters in the house are cracking. 
adeasit (plural adeasia) (noun F) a (small) crack; a flaw, chink; a fault. adere na ileleba adeasia: this calabash is full of little cracks.
adebe (plural adebei) (noun F) a tin; a metal can.
