adedea ko-a (intransitive verb) to keep cracking, sizzle (like sound heard when grass is burning). cp. adea. 
adedengan (plural adedengak) (noun F) a severe, savage or cruel woman or animal. 
adedengiar ko-o (reflexive verb) to flare up; to go for; to molest. adedengiar ao kane: the bees are turning wild here. adedengiar ejakait: the boss has flared up. 
adedengikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to reprimand; to threaten; to be hard to; to be cruel or severe to; to treat harshly. kidedengikini moi ijo ejakait: the superior will reprimand you tomorrow. abu ekingok kadedengik eong: the dog made for me savagely. 
adedengu (singular noun F) severity; cruelty; barbarity. 
adedengun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become severe, cruel, harsh, etc. age ekingoko kon adedengun: your dog is getting fierce. 
adeet (plural adeeta) (noun F) a plucking instrument; the place where the fruit was picked off. ejaas adeeta manaka, esubit bala ekokotai epaabaka: there are signs that my cotton has been plucked. 
adeikin ko-a (transitive verb) to pluck vegetables or fruits for someone. kodeikinai eong da edia edis: pluck some vegetables for me too. 
adeka1 (plural adekasinei, adekasia) (noun F) illness; disease; indisposition; epidemic; sickness; ailment. adeka naikopitoi: a contagious disease. adeka nakwana: the disease of these days (such as AIDS). adeka ya: that disease (known to you already).
adeka2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be ill, sick, ailing, unwell; to ail. adeka eong: I am ill. ideka ijo: you are ill. idekana ijo: you are always sick.
adekakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be ill, unwell, sick, etc of something; to go down with; to catch an illness. adekakin eong aola: I have a cough. aitedek: to tend a patient; to look after a patient, to nurse. 
adekanakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be constantly ill, etc edekanakinos idwe: the children are always ill. 
adeke (noun F) a variety of banana plant whose ripe fruit is boiled before being eaten. cp. ebogoya. 
adekerer ko-a (intransitive verb) to be wasted, thin, emaciated. idekereras itunga etengei: the people are emaciated with famine. 
adekis (plural adekisya) (noun F) a hospital; a dispensary; a health centre. 
adelonor ko-o (intransitive verb) to scream, to weep bitterly at intervals, like a woman whose husband or child has died. 
adelor ko-o (intransitive verb) to cry out, exclaim, shriek, howl, wail, etc; (usually of human beings, but also of animals) to ejaculate, yell. kanukinyo adeloriata itelepai?: why have the boys wailed? 
ademar ko-a (transitive verb) to take by force; to rob or to plunder, extort, confiscate; to dispossess; to grab. apotu lukabuorok kademasi ekatogo: robbers plundered my house. 
ademececar ko-a (intransitive verb) to become too wet. 
adengelel ko-o (intransitive verb) to be anxious; to rejoice, be glad; to run for joy; to flirt, keep company with. adengelelooto idwe adumun akiring: the children are very glad to get meat. apotu idwe kodengelelooto alosit aiyeng: the children ran with joy when going on holiday. sirikidengelelok etelepat ngol: do not keep company with that boy (because he is bad). 
adengelelet ko-o (intransitive verb) to go or do with pleasure. edengelelet ngesi iswamai: she/he works with pleasure. 
adengelelokin ko-o (intransitive verb) to be glad, rejoice for something or on account of somebody. adengelelokit eong adumun egaali: I am glad (happy) that I got a bicycle. 
adengis (plural adengisio) (noun F) a thing to pluck with; the place where a fruit has been plucked; the place where the esidengideng-worm has cut. 
adengokin ko-o (transitive verb) to pluck for someone. kodengokinai eong emucuuga: pluck me an orange. 
adengor ko-o (transitive verb) to pluck off, away. adengor etometomet: to tie off a wart. 
adengoret (plural adengoreta) (noun F) the place from which a fruit or cotton was plucked. aanyunit eong adengoreta: I have seen the marks left after the fruit was plucked. 
adengosit (plural adengosio) (noun F) a scar left after beating or a swelling.
adengun ko-o (transitive verb) to pick off fruit; to knock off. 
adeor ko-a (transitive verb) to gather (fruit, vegetables) and take away; to pluck, pick (for oneself) and take away; to run away very fast. 
adepar (adverb) (used with the sense of aitelekaar) exceedingly; more than; better than; more, etc. (preposition) beyond; further than. ibu ijo kokoko irwan akany ka adepar: you stole five times and more. 
adepar ko-a (transitive verb) to overtake; to go past; to pass, surpass; to overlook, trespass; to miss; to omit; to be more than. adepar ekisil: to trespass; to go beyond the rules or the law. ideparit ijo erot: you have gone beyond the path. ejaas nges akituk nuedeparito akwatat: he has more than a hundred cows. sirikidepa ekisil lo: do not breach this law. 
adere (plural aderekai) (noun F) a calabash; a half gourd, used for drawing water or beer; a bowl.
aderecaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to slip away without waiting. aderecaar ekokolan: the thief ran off or away without being caught. 
aderecitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to dash; to go with long jumps. 
aderit (plural aderin) (noun F) a sickness caused by eating the meat of ederit (bushbuck) owing to clan taboos forbidding it. cp. akolicic
adero (plural aderon) (noun F) a small scorpion. cp. ekiliton
aderonokin ki-a (transitive verb) to write in straight lines, go straight for; to speak the truth; to tell of a secret evil; to reveal a bad thing in the presence of the evil-doer himself/herself. kideronok akonikiro: speak the truth (straighten your words). 
aderut (plural aderun) (noun F) a twig used for making wicker baskets, doors or winnows (erite), Phyllanthus discoiceus. 
adeseikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to tell the truth; to repeat or say the same. ideseik ijo akiro nuakoto eong da alimun: you have said exactly what I wanted to say. adese ngesi Ateso: she/he is fluent in Ateso language.
adeset (plural adeseta) (noun F) a spark of fire; a splash of rain water, etc. cp. atwenyet. 
adesiar1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to retort; to answer quickly and correctly (with akiro); to become familiar with. 
adesiar2 ko-a (transitive verb) to beat or flog mercilessly; to hit point blank; to shoot on target. abu ngesi kodesia akokuke: she/he beat her/his daughter mercilessly.
adesitoi1 (noun F) alacrity; agility. 
adesitoi2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of nervous person when called) to jump up quickly, be agile; (of a flea) to keep on jumping from one place to another; to be a quick and zealous worker. edesitoi etelepat je aswam: that boy is a quick and zealous worker. edesitoi etelepat lo neejai apese ngin: this boy is constantly going after that girl. 
adetakin ko-a (transitive verb) to splash for somebody; to sprinkle, throw water on something, at some- body; to give a little. kanukinyo kidetakina ijo eong akipi?: why did you splash water on me? (reflexive verb) (of water or liquids) to fall on, to splash on, to drop on. adetakinos akipi oitaadaka: the water has splashed on my bed. 
adetanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to spill or boil over; to spark. edetanar akim: the fire is sparking. edetanaros akipi: the water is splashing off, i.e. boiling over. (transitive verb) (of men or animals) to disperse. adetanaros itunga atipe: the people dispersed at once. 
adetar ko-a (transitive verb) (of animal, birds) to throw off; to shake off from body like water or anything else after washing; to toss up. cp. aibwat. 
adetat (plural adetan) (noun F) a spot or a drop of water or liquids. 
adetekewait (plural adetekewa) (noun F) an edible berry from edetekewai tree. 
adetelel ko-o (transitive verb) to flirt or make love to; to court. edetelelet etelepat neejai apese: the boy flirts with the girl. 
adetokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to grab at; to snatch away. kedetokinos ikokolak luko Owino ikeboro: the thieves from (Kampala’s) Owino market snatched away his belongings. 
adetor ko-o (reflexive verb) to jump up, spring up, stand to attention (used at a race when starting or at a parade to stand to attention). kodetor, kodetoros akerit: run, get off quickly. 
adetudetun ko-o (reflexive verb) to get up, rise at once, suddenly and run away. adetudetunos itelepai kimurokis iitaabonokec: the boys rose and ran off leaving their books behind. 
adetun1 ko-o (reflexive verb) to rise or get up at once; to rise very quickly or to wake up with a start; to choose one only; to select one by one. abu ngesi kodetun ekwenyuni: she/he woke up with a start. 
adetun2 ko-o (transitive verb) to throw or to throw a little water at oneself. 
adeudeu (plural adeudeun) (noun F) a six-stringed arched harp. cp. adigidigi.
adeun ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall off from tree (as of fruit); to be plucked or picked. adeun epaaba epol noi lolo: much cotton has been picked today. adeunos imucuugai bon: the oranges have fallen off by themselves. 
adeyaar ko-a (transitive verb) to throw at and hit; to answer to the point. cp. aidyak: to throw and miss. mam ijo ijeni adeyaar, idyakenenei ijo duc: you do not aim well, you always miss the target. ideyaa ijo akiro: you have answered well (to the point); you have hit the point (in your answer). 
adi? F (interrogation) how many? angor adi?: how many women are they?
adiakaret (plural adiakareta) (noun F) a mistake, fault, crime. 
adianakin akonye ko-a (transitive verb) to keep aiming sharply, carefully, accurately with one eye closed; to keep looking through a narrow hole; to wink at. 
adiar ko-a (transitive verb) to look through a narrow hole; to aim or peer away. adiar akongu kotoma apedot: to look at something through a pinhole. 
adidima (plural adidimai) (noun F) a quarrelsome, noisy woman. cp. alelema.
adiding ko-a (intransitive verb) to be narrow. ediding ngesi aomisio: she/he is narrow-minded. ediding kesi aomisio: they are narrow-minded. aitididing: to make narrow, slender; to cause to shrink. 
adidinga (noun F) a swelling in the neck; east coast fever in cattle. cp. ibokorwa. 
adidingaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become narrow, slender; to shrink. adidingaar egoe lo: this dress does not fit. 
adidingikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be too narrow for. kadidingikit eong epale lo: these trousers are so narrow for me. 
adidio (plural adidion) (noun F) a dragon fly. 
adieket (plural adieketa) (noun F) a law court; a magistrate’s court. cp. ekooti. 
adigidigi (plural adigidigin) (noun F) a one-stringed tube fiddle played to accompany a human voice; an African violin. cp. adeudeu.
adiiga (plural adiigai) (noun F) a sheep; an ewe. cp. amerekek
adiije (plural adiijen) (noun F) a female disc jockey.
adiikin ko-a (transitive verb) to look at carefully; to aim carefully; to look with one eye closed through a small hole. kodiik adebe ngin akongu, motoko ejai apedot: look carefully at that tin, perhaps there is a small hole. adiikinit akonye: to be shortsighted. adiikinit akongu: to be short-sighted (one eye); to slit one eye. 
adikam ko-a (transitive verb) to eat thick porridge; to eat thick food. 
adilituun ko-a (transitive verb) (of mushroom) to uproot; to eradicate. 
adilokin ko-a (intransitive verb) to start (doing something) early. alosi eong adilokin ainyam: I shall have an early breakfast. edilokinete akituk adak: the cattle will go to graze early. 
adilun ko-o (intransitive verb) to arrive or come early. adiluni moi tupuruc sek: I shall come (rise) very early tomorrow morning. 
adimasita (plural adimasitan) (noun F) a headmistress; a head teacher. cp. akesisianakinan
adinga1 (intransitive verb) to be enemies; to be at loggerheads; to hate. edingas ebu ka ekingok: the hyena and the dog are enemies. 
adinga2 (plural adingai) (noun F) a disease of nose causing a very offensive smell; infection of septum in the nose; sinuses or sinusitis. 
adinganut1 (intransitive verb) to be aggressive; hostile. 
adinganut2 (noun F) hostility; enmity; aggressiveness. 
adingiriar ko-o (reflexive verb) to run fast (away). kodingiriaros karai ikotos ayuun: run away fast if you want to save yourselves. 
adingirir ko-a (intransitive verb) to run fast, race along. edingiririt egaali lo noi: this bicycle cruises very fast. kodingirir oiduka: run quickly to the shop. 
adingiririkin ko-a (transitive verb) to run fast to fetch something. kodingiririk ekileng kore: run quickly home and fetch a knife. 
adingirirun ko-a (reflexive verb) to run very fast this way. kodingirirunos lailo: run quickly this way. 
adingit (plural adingin) (noun F) a fiddle. 
adinyo (plural adinyoi) (noun F) a sheep given as present to father or mother-in-law; a hoe with long handle (used while standing). 
adiobore (plural adioboro) (indefinite pronoun F) anything; a scrap (of something). 
adiope diope F (numeral adverb, used with plural feminine nouns) one by one; one after another. angor adiope diope: one woman at a time. kolomanasi adiope diope: go in one by one. (adverb) singly; one by one. kopotu adiope diope: come one by one, singly. 
adiopet F (numeral adjective) one. akiteng adiopet: one cow. akine adiopet: one she-goat. 
adiotai (adverb) a little; some; a piece. koinakinai ajoola adiotai: give me a piece of cloth material. 
adiotitai (adverb) a little; a bit. koinakinai acece adiotitai: give me just a little more soup. 
adipakin1 ko-o (reflexive verb) to crumble; to fall down on; to fall in (of house); (of a grave) to become depressed. adipakin etogoka: my house has sunk (or my house is ruined because my wife is dead). (transitive verb) to crush; to raze. abu ekitoi kodipak ekatogo: a tree fell and crushed my house. 
adipakin2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to walk one behind another in procession or in Indian file. 
adipakinet (plural adipakineta) (noun F) a procession. 
adipalat (plural adipalan) (noun F) a depression; a dip; a plain in a valley; a flood plain.
adipanyany ko-a (intransitive verb) to be short, low (of house). 
adipar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go together (in Indian file); to accompany. kadiparos oni kere: let us go together (Indian file). cp. aupar. 
adipidip ko-o (transitive verb) to pummel; to beat repeatedly (with a fist or club); to knock heavily. 
adipiikin ko-a (transitive verb) to get a glimpse of; to flash of; a momentary flash of. adipiikit eong engatuny, konye aolio: I got only a glimpse of a lion, but it has vanished. 
adipirir ko-o (transitive verb) to keep behind someone. cp. adipit
adipit ko-a (transitive verb) to keep behind, close; to follow. edipit ekingok papake: the dog usually follows its master. 
adipokin ko-a (transitive verb) to beat with a fist at a certain place, at home or somewhere else in presence of someone; to beat for someone else. abu eong kadipok nges oreke toma: I dealt him a few blows at his very home. 
adipun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come together in company. kodipunos oreka: come together (Indian file) to my home. cp. aupun. 
adiritit ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a tree or anything) to stand straight. 
adisaar ko-a (transitive verb) to beat once on the back with a fist or club. 
adisamam ko-a (intransitive verb) to have large prominent buttocks. 
adisianar ko-o (reflexive verb) to dwindle away; to abate. 
adisiar ko-a (reflexive verb) to become smaller; to become childish. 
adisirikin ki-a (transitive verb) to make a person look spruce (like a girl before her marriage); to fit nicely (reflexive verb) to be spruce. idisirikinos yesi: you are spruce. egoe lo mam kedisirikinit eong: this dress does not fit me. 
adisirir ko-o (reflexive verb) to look smart; to have a handsome appearance; to become stout and to be well built; to be spruce. idisirir etelepat ngol: that boy is smart in his appearance. 
adita (plural aditai) (noun F) a small basket. cp. ebukit: big basket. cp. api. 
aditakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to dash out; to escape. aditakin ekokolan: the thief dashed off and escaped. 
aditeu1 (noun F) smallness; infancy, childhood. 
aditeu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be small, humble, little, young; to be in childhood. edit ngesi: she/he/it is small or young. edisiak kesi: they are small or young. akoto kodit ijo: I want you to be small or humble. kodisiak: be small or humble. aitiditeun: to make smaller; to minimize. cp. aitidisiar. 
aditeun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become small; to decrease; to become humble. aditeut akituk kotoma aujokon: there are only a few cows left in your kraal. aditeu akuwanake kanuka adeka: he has become thin on account of disease. 
aditianut (intransitive verb) to be childish. 
aditidit ko-o (intransitive verb) to take big lumps of any solid food. editiditei ngesi atap: she/he takes food in big lumps. 
aditor ko-o (reflexive verb) to stretch oneself chest forward and arms out. 
aditot (plural aditono) (noun F) a valley.
adiun ko-a (transitive verb) to look at speaker through a narrow hole; to look in through a small hole (like keyhole). ingai ediunit akongu toma togoka?: who is peeping into my house?
adoakin ko-a (transitive verb) to snap a finger at (to call attention). kanukinyo kidoakinitor ijo eong ebokorit?: why did you snap your fingers at me (call my attention)?
adoanakin (transitive verb) to snap at repeatedly. kodoanak ekingok ngol ibokor kobu: snap your fingers to call that dog.
adoanar ko-a (transitive verb) to keep snapping; to smack repeatedly. kodoana ibokor kere: snap all the fingers.
adoar ko-a (transitive verb) to snap (fingers or to fire a gun). kodoa emuudu: fire the gun.
adodanar ko-a (transitive verb) to point constantly, repeatedly. 
adodar ko-a (transitive verb) to point with lips or with index finger; to point away. edodarit emuudu laije: the gun is pointing the other way. 
adodikin ko-a (transitive verb) to point out for; to show somebody. kododikinai erot: point out the road to me i.e. show me the way. cp. aitodikin 
adoditono (noun F) a direction. 
adodoot ko-o (transitive verb) to interfere. kinyek adodoot toma akiro numam eraas nukon: do not interfere in what is not your business. 
adodor ko-o (imperative verb) to be quick, easy; to hasten (doing something or becoming something) easy, easily, soon. edodor ngesi abunere: she/he/it is likely to come soon. 
adodoromunyel (plural nukadodoromunyel) (noun F) a quick cook; a woman who is quick to conceive again after birth or marriage. edodor aberu ngin: that woman conceives quickly. 
adodorot (plural adodoron) (noun F) a species of water-bird, Grebe. 
adoelel ko-a (intransitive verb) to lie at ease; to be slender; to be emaciated. 
adoere ko-o (intransitive verb) to drop; to fall. 
adogoria (plural adogorian) (noun F) a pot with two or three mouths (traditionally associated with rituals pertaining to the birth of twins – for example, it was used for burying the placenta of twins in the swamp; beer provided during the twin-dance was drank from it). cp. acuria.
adoikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to befall, fall upon; to happen to; to fall into. kadoikis eong akiro: I am in trouble. 
adokar1 (singular noun F) Ascension (Christ’s ascent to heaven on the fortieth day after the Resurrection). Apaaran na Adokar: Ascension Day.
adokar2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to climb up or away from; to ascend; to embark (not to disembark). kodoka kuju togo: climb on the roof (of the house). 
adokarot (plural adokaron) (noun F) acclivity. 
adoke (plural adokeen) (noun F) a species of bird, White-crested lourie. 
adoket (plural adoketa) (noun F) a ladder; steps; staircase; berth; landing site. 
adoketait (plural adoketa) (noun F) a stepping-stone; a level; a rung of a ladder; a distinction; a rank; a scale; a class; a grade. eitaabo lo esiomio kadoketait nakokuju: this book is read at higher levels of study.
adokikin ko-a (transitive verb) to climb on, in, for, to. kodokik ao ngin: climb up for that honey. 
adokit ko-a (transitive verb) to be aboard. adokit abaasi, agaali, edege, kice da: to be aboard a bus, train, aeroplane, etc. 
adokita (plural adokitan) (noun F) a female doctor (who administers western medicine). cp. amuron naka adekis 
adokoco (plural adokocon) (noun F) fork or cleft in tree. 
adokokin ko-a (transitive verb) to pick vegetables for somebody. ikakoku, kodokokinai eboo: my dear child, pluck some eboo vegetables for me. 
adokon (plural adokosio) (noun F) a gift; something extra given by seller; a baksheesh. 
adokoriait (plural adokoria) (noun F) a kind of berry. 
adokoror1 (noun F) thinness; leanness. 
adokoror2 ko-a (reflexive verb) to be lean, thin, emaciated, wasted from disease. cp. adekerer. idokororas idwe lu: these children are emaciated (from starvation) 
adokun ko-a (intransitive verb) to climb down or come down, descend; to alight, dismount. kodokutu kere kokitoi: come down all of you from the tree. (note: to come down of birds or planes is adoun or adoore, but to disembark from a vehicle is adokun). 
adol (plural adolia) (noun F) a species of fresh water fish; elephant snout fish, Mormyrus. 
adolio ko-o (intransitive verb) to arrive (somewhere away from speaker) with something to deliver; to reach with. 
adolit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be ample; to be perfect, just enough, sufficient, holy; to be just; to be adequate, apt, or convenient. mam akiro kon edolitos: that is no answer; what you say is wrong. 
adolokin ko-o (transitive verb) to call upon; to visit; to approach; to affect. alosi eong adolokin mamaika kocanike: I am going to call on my uncle in his difficulty (i.e. to condole with him). 
adolore ko-o (intransitive verb) to arrive; to reach; to be sufficient, enough, right, or correct; to occur, happen. abu kodolu: she/he/it arrived. apotu akiroke kodoloto: what she/he said was right or came to pass. adoli ore kon moi: I shall reach your home tomorrow. kodol kojokan: safe journey; bon voyage. 
adolun1 (noun F) advent. 
adolun2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to arrive here; to arrive there where you are. 
adomelait (plural adomela) (noun F) dried up exudates from eyes due to conjunctivitis or inflammation of the conjunctiva of the eye. 
adomoc ko-a (intransitive verb) to approach somebody with dirty dripping hands or feet. sirikidomocun neka kakanin kon: do not come near me with dirty dripping hands. 
adomocaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to be full of perspiration; to drip with perspiration, perspiring, sweating very much. adomocaaros idwe akaulo abolia: the children drip with perspiration after playing. 
adomola (plural adomolai) (noun F) a small container for liquids, such as a five-litre jerry can. cp. ajerikan
adongakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to betray. abu je kodongak opaperoke: he betrayed his friend. 
adongakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to reserve food, keep for. sirikimurwok adongakin idwe inyamat: do not forget to reserve some food for the children. 
adonganakin ko-a (transitive verb) to dole out for. 
adongar ko-a (transitive verb) to take away food to somebody else; to reserve food for. 
adonge (plural adongei) (noun F) a barren female (person or animal). cp. arakan; abwacit.
adongit ko-a (transitive verb) to hold on to; to stick to opinion; to pinch; to be indelible; to hold with pincers; to be deep-rooted. idongit ijo akiro nuadaunos: you hold on to what is settled (against you). 
adongit ko-o (transitive verb) to follow persistently. inyo bo idongitor ijo aupa ka eong?: why do you persist in following me (against my will)? 
adongodong ko-a (intransitive verb) to pinch all over the body; to have pinching or griping pain in the stomach (as after eating hard food like roasted maize or roasted cassava); to have the gripes. kadongodongoi eong akoik: I have griping pain in my stomach. 
adongun ko-o (transitive verb) to pinch for oneself; to hold with pincers. adongun lukabong: to have supper or dinner. adongun lukapaaran: to have lunch (to be actually eating). 
adongunet (plural adonguneta) (noun F) pincers. 
adonyit (plural adonyito) (noun F) a seam; a hem line; a line of stitching. 
adonyokin ko-o (transitive verb) to mend clothes; to patch up; to mend for; to wrap something in. kodonyokinai ekapale: please, mend my trousers (for me). kodonyok apeesan ogoe: wrap the money in the cloth; or, sew the buttons on the dress.
adoobe (plural adoobei) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a small piece of cloth covering the female genitalia during menstruation; a tampon. cp. adoome, amuleyi.
adoobo (plural adooboi) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a bucket; a pail.
adoome (plural adoomei) (noun F) (Usuk) a small piece of clothing covering the female genitalia during menstruation; a tampon. cp. amuleyi, adobe.
adoonokin ko-o (transitive verb) to keep dropping on to; to keep putting into. (intransitive verb) to keep falling on or into. kadoonokis eong atiokisyo nuipu: many troubles keep on befalling me. 
adoor ko-o (intransitive verb) to go down; (of sun) to set; to dive, plunge into the water. adoo akolong: the sun has set. cp. alomar, aijesar.
adoorakin ko-a (transitive verb) to defame or slander somebody. abu ewadikan iyemuto kodoorak eminisita akiro: the news reporter defamed the minister. 
adoore ko-o (intransitive verb) to fall; to alight; (of plane) to land; (of bird, etc) to descend. ekoto edege adoore Soroti: the plane is about to land in Soroti. adoore boo: edou aitep lopeti: to rain incessantly. 
adoorian ko-a (transitive verb) to complain; to lament; to bewail, grouse, grumble at; to squeal. adooriani eong ikakoku yen atwana: I lament over my dead child. inyo bo idoorianete yesi?: why are you mournful? 
adooro (plural adooron) (noun F) an artesian well; a protected water spring or well. cp. ekicoi; egiilo.
adoosan (singular noun F) the smouldering of the fire; the glow. cp. asaran. 
adopony ko-a (intransitive verb) to be nearly blind; to be one-eyed, eyelid permanently closed. edoponyi ngesi alosit: she/he walks like a half-blind person. 
adoponyoun ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a blind man) to come toward the speaker. adoponyoun etelepat neajai eong: the half-blind boy has come to me. 
adopudop (adjective) whitish-grey. 
adorakin ko-a (transitive verb) to give a second name, usually after 3-6 years. ekiror lodoret: a second name. 
adorodorot (plural adorodoron) (noun F) a lark. 
adoronyikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to vomit (of animals only). koyangaa ekonikingok ngina, kinyek adoronyikin idoronyike nen: take your dog away, so that it may not vomit here. 
adosa ko-a (transitive verb) to break or crush (as of shell of groundnuts). sirikidosa abeei: do not drop these eggs (or do not burst the eggs by letting them fall).
adosaar ko-a (transitive verb) to break a thing by letting it fall; to burst as egg or cup or glass or husk of nuts. (reflexive verb) to break by falling; to burst. adosaaros abeei: the eggs are broken (by falling or otherwise). 
adosaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to crush for somebody. 
adote (plural adotea) (noun F) a woman who has illicit intercourse constantly; a harlot; prostitute. cp. amalayat.
adote ko-a (intransitive verb) to have illicit sexual intercourse once. cp. adoteu: illicit intercourse very often. edoteete kesi: they are having illicit intercourse. (note: matrimonial intercourse is aimorikikin - emorikikinos ngesi ka aberuke: he is having sexual union with his wife). 
adoteanar ko-a (reflexive verb) (of a man) to develop a strong passion for women. adoteanar ekesa ngol: that guy is becoming a womaniser. 
adoteanut1 (intransitive verb) to be in the habit of having illicit sex. cp. adoteu.
adoteanut2 (singular noun F) inclination to illicit sexual intercourse. 
adotear ko-a (intransitive verb) to go somewhere to have illicit sexual intercourse. 
adoteu (singular noun F) adultery; fornication; lust; libido.
adotor ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall off of hair, feathers, thorn, jiggers. adotoros ajul nuka ekokor: the feathers of the cock have fallen off. (reflexive verb) (of hair, feathers, thorns, etc) to fall off. 
adotun ko-o (transitive verb) to extract; to take or pull or pick out this way. cp. alemun. 
adoun ko-o (intransitive verb) (of rain or anything) to fall down, drop down this way. adoutu iitaabon kere kwap: all the books have fallen down. edounene edou apaarasia kere: it rains always. 
adoyaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to shout, fall out in anger against somebody (for sometime); to become thin; (of a swelling) go down; to hit. kanu bo kinyo idoyaaror ijo?: why have you grown thin? adoyaar edoi: to make a noise by snapping a rope to chase locusts or birds from ripening grain. elosi akabus adoyaar: my swelling is going down. 
adoyanar ko-a (transitive verb) to crack a whip. edoyanarete idwe idoyan airengianara ikweny: children are cracking whips to drive away birds. 
adua (noun F) sperms; semen humanum. cp. adwa, alepon.
adudu ko-o (transitive verb) to stretch or disperse; to press outwardly; to make a passage through crowd; of birds or animals by gunshot or other way) to disperse. adudu akuwan: to stretch the body; to stretch oneself. 
adudung ko-a (transitive verb) to overtake; to come upon, pursue closely. edudungit ekingok ipoo: the dog is in hot pursuit of the hare. cp. aturiaikin: to catch or take by surprise, like a thief; to beset. 
aduduo (plural aduduos) (noun F) thunder; explode or burst (of anything). apupi eong aduduo nakokuju: I hear thunder. 
adui (plural adwiyon) (noun F) a lair, a burrow, a pit, pitfall, a cave. 
aduikin ko-o (transitive verb) to blow up (a house); to explode towards; to shoot (a bird); to blast (a rock). akoto aduikin amoru: I want to blast a rock. koduik ekweny ngol: shoot that bird. 
aduke (noun F) abode, nest of rat; humble abode; homestead.
aduketait (plural aduketa) (noun F) a building; a structure; an edifice. 
adukit ko-o (intransitive verb) to inhabit, live in. edukit etoori okitoi ngol: an eagle lives in that tree. isubit ijo bala idukit oreka: it is as if you live with me (by always visiting me). edukit kwana eong aola atorob: I have an incurable cough (literally, a cough inhabits my chest). 
adukokin ko-a (transitive verb) to build for someone, hence to marry a girl, a woman. ekoto ngesi adukokin akoku k’ejakait: he wants to marry the chief's daughter (intransitive verb) to marry in general; to get married. idukokin bo ijo wori?: when are you going to marry? (reflexive verb) to be married. adukokinos kesi: they are married. 
adukokino (singular noun F) a marriage; a wedding. adukokino kus ejokuna: yours is a good marriage. 
adukon (plural adukok) (noun F) a builder; an architect; a mason. erai ngesi loadukon: he is a builder or a mason. 
adukonor ko-o (reflexive verb) to leap, prance; to bounce (said of animals in general, but especially of little lambs). cp. asukonor
adukor ko-o (transitive verb) to build away from old homestead. koloto kodukoosi ngina awai: go and build away from the old homestead. 
adukun ko-o (transitive verb) to build for oneself. akoto eong adukun itogo idiokasilon: I want to build a little house for myself. 
aduli (plural adulin) (noun F) a hunting horn. 
adulusus ko-o (intransitive verb) to have fat falling buttocks. idulusus ijo: you have fat falling buttocks. cp. aduleses. 
adumakin ko-a (transitive verb) to receive for someone; to procure for another; to find in or somewhere. ekoto kodumakin ijo toma aswamukon: you should be found at your work. adumak eong ngesi ore: I have found him/her at home. 
adumanakin1 (reflexive verb) to meet constantly in a certain place. nepene edumanakinos itunga: it is here that people meet each other. 
adumanakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to keep supplying; to give always. eong duc kadumanakini ijo inyamat: it is I who always supplies you with food.
adumar ko-a (transitive verb) to go and meet or join someone. alosi adumar papaka: I am going to join my father. adumari nges acepaarit: I shall join him/her some day. alot ngesi adumar aberu: he has gone to meet a woman (he has gone for a rendezvous with a woman). 
adumun ko-a (transitive verb) to meet; to find; to receive; to accept; to earn, acquire, or obtain. inyo idumuni ijo karai kitwania aijar nakokuju?: what will you gain if you lose eternal life (heaven)? kadumakini ijo ai?: where shall I find you? 
adumunet (plural adumuneta) (noun F) a gain; a use; value; a profit; a receipt; a meeting place. atikit nadumunet aiboisit: admission ticket. 
adumunia ko-a (transitive verb) to profit by; to gain by; to get by, etc. inyamat ejaas kanuka adumunia agogong: food is there for getting strength (to gain strength).
adumunun ko-o (reflexive verb) to meet one another often; to meet often; to come together often (transitive verb) to get often, receive or accept often. loiswamaenenei edumununei kotoma aswamuke: a worker will always receive benefit from his/her work. 
adunge1 (noun F) edible termites and white ants for cooking. cp. abukuleru. 
adunge2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of fire only) to go out. adunge akim: the fire is out (extinguished). 
adungeor ko-o (intransitive verb) to be extinguished; (of fire) to go out. akim namam edungeori: the undying fire. cp. asilior. 
adungokin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut for someone. kadungoki eong ebiyat mana: the spear grass cut me while I was in the garden. 
adungor ko-o (transitive verb) to curtail; to send evil away by sacrificing a lamb and leaving it in the wild for carion to eat. alosi eong adungor apesenikon: I am going to curtail your expenses. cp. angotiloor. 
adungot (plural adungon) (noun F) a cut; a wound. epol adungot: the cut is big. 
adungudung ko-o (transitive verb) to cut lightly in many places with a razorblade or knife; to cut (skin) often. adungudung okoku kon akan k’emweeso: your son has cut his hand with a razorblade. 
adungulul ko-o (intransitive verb) (of leg, arm, etc) to be short or maimed. 
adunguret (plural adunguren) (noun F) a grass stump left after grass fire. cp. aran. 
adunyakin ko-a (transitive verb) to work hard at; to persevere in; to do daily, go on with. kodunyakis aisisia apaarasia kere: continue learning everyday. kadunyakis aceswam: let us go on with other work. 
adunyanar (reflexive verb) to be or become zealous, industrious, etc. 
adunyanut1 (noun F) persistence; perseverance. cp. akukuranut. 
adunyanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be persistent, obsessed, etc. edunyana, edunyaka: she/he is (they are) zealous. 
adunyar ko-a (intransitive verb) to come behind; to follow; to imitate, come after. edunyarit ikoku eipone kapapake: the child takes after its father’s habits. alosi eong ore, kodunya ijo: I am going home, you come after me. 
aduo ko-o (intransitive verb) to explode, as of gun or rocket or rocks. apupunit eong emuudu eduo: I have heard a gun go off. eduduo lolo akuj noi: it is thundering very much today. 
aduor ko-o (transitive verb) to explode or detonate; to scatter away; to disperse or take flight. 
adupakin ko-a (transitive verb) to fix; to plant (a pole, stick, spear in the ground); to put a nail, peg in the wall or ground; to plant (cassava, etc). kodupak esumaalit arwatat, akoto eong aikajakin ekagoe: fix a nail in the wall, I want to hang my clothes on. kodupak emeleku kageutu aicil epelu: put the plough into the ground and let us start the work. 
adur (noun F) sexual intercourse in humans; copulation. cp. akwar
adurakin ko-o (reflexive verb) (of human beings) to have sexual intercourse; to copulate (not of animals). cp. akwarakin (of animals only). 
adurar ko-o (reflexive verb) (of men) to go and have sexual intercourse elsewhere (not at home or near the speaker). 
adusa ko-a (transitive verb) to throb; to beat (of anything heaving, falling). kodusa etuo ngol: churn the milk well (i.e. make the churn throb). edusai ekatau erono: ebala ekatau dus-dus: my heart beats irregularly (badly). 
adusaar ko-a (reflexive verb) (of anything) to fall forward or backwards. adusaar ikoku: the child fell over (from a high bed while asleep, or while learning to sit) (transitive verb) to knock down. 
adusaun ko-a (reflexive verb) (of heart) to beat; to fall forward or backwards down; to pulsate. edusaunun ekatau: my heart beats quickly. adusaun epir akouka: the pole fell forward onto my head. 
adusukuk ko-o (intransitive verb) to be dumpy; (of something edible) to be very soft. 
adutakin ko-a (transitive verb) to share with; to contribute to; to give to, endow somebody. kodutakinai eong da adipeesan: give me also a little money. Ikristayon icorakinitai adutanakin ekanisa apeesan kec: Christians are asked to contribute a tithe to the church. 
adutakinet (plural adutakineta) (noun F) a contribution; a portion; a gift; a tithe. mam ijo ilemunit adutakinetekon: you have not given in your contribution.
adutanut1 (noun F) liberality, generosity. mam ijo ijeni adutanut: generosity is unknown to you; or, you are not generous.
adutanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be liberal, generous.
adutar ko-a (transitive verb) to irrigate; to fill (tanks) with water; to distribute over there; to over fill. itunga luko Misiri edutanarete akipi toma omanikoriakec: the Egyptians irrigate their gardens. epakasit edutanari akipi ataagi: the porter fills the tank with water. (reflexive verb) to be overfull. inyo bo idutaritor ijo asaanit na?: why have you overfilled this plate? adutaros ataagin: the tanks are overfull, overflowing. 
aduuda (singular noun F) potato flour; atap from potato flour (tastes sweet if cooked without tamarind fruit). 
aduwet (plural aduweta) (noun F) a catapult. cp. aporocet 
adwa (plural noun F) semen; sperms. cp. alepon. 
adwal (plural adwalia) (noun F) a woman’s apron made of skin; a woman’s plaited straps. 
adwalakaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become flat; to droop (owing to lack of strength or energy); to become soft, flat (as of breast). adwalakaar atap: the millet bread is soft (poorly mingled, i.e. watery). cp. adialakar. 
adwalikidetok (noun F) a plant, Cape- gooseberry. 
adwarakin ko-a (transitive verb) to prophesy for someone; to predict or foretell what is to befall another. kodwarakinai eong atwanareka: foretell my death. 
adwarar ko-a (intransitive verb) to foretell; to predict, prophesy, divine. 
adwaret (plural adwareta) (noun F) a prophecy, divination, a foretelling, a conjecture. adwareta nuka lokadwaran Isaia: the prophecies of the prophet Isaiah. 
adwaris (singular noun F) bitterness; pungency; acridity of things, words and heart; asperity. mam akoto adwaris naka etauke: I do not like his quick temper (the bitterness of his heart). 
adwarun1 (singular noun F) puberty; adolescence; (formerly) age-grade feast for youths reaching puberty – literally, the child has become sour. cp. asapan. erai lolo na apaarit nakadwarun: today is the age-grade feast day. cp. aiburun, alokunet.
adwarun2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to grow stubborn; to be obstinate; to be refractory; to grow wild; to become bitter, serious. adwaru apese ngin: that girl has grown wild, stubborn i.e. she listens to nobody. adwaru ecooro kwana aiar akokoroi: the chicken disease (coccidiosis) constantly kills hens. adwaru apese: the girl has grown big (developed breasts or reached puberty). adwaruut akiro: there is trouble brewing.
adwarus (singular noun F) bitterness; pungency; acridity of things and words and heart; asperity. mam akoto adwarus naka etauke: I do not like his quick temper (the bitterness of his heart). 
adwekelel ko-a (intransitive verb) (of food) to be flat to the taste.
adwomakin ko-a (transitive verb) to eat for or somewhere else. adwomaki ikoku edia orot: the child ate the vegetables it was carrying on the way. 
adwomar ko-a (transitive verb) to finish eating all the vegetables. adwoma ikoku edia kere: the child has eaten all the vegetables. 
adyaka ko-a (intransitive verb) to trespass; to commit a fault; to sin. idyaka ijo: you have trespassed; you have erred. 
adyakalal ko-a (intransitive verb) to be soft (to touch). idyakalal alupot: the clay is soft (ot touch). 
adyakaret (plural adyakareta) (noun F) a fault, a mistake, a sin, an offence, a transgression, defect. 
adyekakin1 (noun F) intercession; arbitration. 
adyekakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to reconcile; to propitiate; to intercede for; to pacify. koar akokor nadyekakinet itunga: slaughter a chicken for reconciling those quarrelling. (reflexive verb) to be reconciled, pacified; to give in, submit, calm down; to make peace; to intercede. adyekakinos ikulepek bonik: they are reconciled by themselves. 
adyekakinet (plural adyekakineta) (noun F) reconciliation; propitiation; intercession; pacification. 
adyekar ko-a (transitive verb) to separate combatants i.e. to take one away. kodyeka itunga kwi: go and separate those people. (reflexive verb) to be separated; to separate oneself. 
adyekun ko-a (transitive verb) to pull (fighters) apart, save from; to guard; to come and rescue. kodyekunai eong kaneka lokasurupika: come and rescue me from my enemy. kodyekutu angor kinyekis aarakin: pull the fighting women apart, lest they kill each other. kodyek akitukukon, kinyek aisab: guard your tongue from telling lies. (reflexive verb) to be pulled apart, saved, extricated from danger. adyekun akituk: to guard one’s tongue. 
aedakin ko-a (transitive verb) to peer through half-closed eyes; to warn by winks; to be intent on work. aedakin elacit: to play one a trick. alosi eong aedakin ngol elacit: I am going to conspire against him (play him a trick). iedakit lolo papaka aswam: my father is intent on working today. 
aedo (plural aedoi) (noun F) a species of bird with a long neck, eats reptiles, and is a non-wading bird, Kori bustard. 
aejo (plural aejon) (noun F) a gem; a jewel. 
aekar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go far away; to depart; to be advanced; (of inanimate things) to have disappeared; to do well, become an important person. aekasi itunga ore: people have gone home. aekasi ikasirigin tai: my money has gone for nothing. aeka ekagoe: my dress is worn out. eekarit aberu: the woman is advanced in years i.e. she is aged. 
aeketet (plural ieketetas) (adjective) (of a man) having big, swollen testicles. 
aekun ko-a (intransitive verb) to come near; to approach; to accede. koekutu ne: come nearby. aisiekun: to make or force to come near, etc. 
aelekek (plural ielekekas) (adjective) (of a woman or girl) having half-grown breasts. 
aelo1 (noun F) adultery; fornication; love affair; sexual intercourse. 
aelo2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (formerly) to be friends; to help in a friendly way; to be blood-brothers; (these days) to commit adultery or fornication. eeloete kesi noi: they are great friends: they are blood brothers. eelos kesi: they are lovers. 
aelokin1 ko-o (reflexive verb) (formerly) to become blood-brothers; (these days) to become lovers; to have an affair; to have sexual intercourse. neageata kesi aelokin, apotu komatata aokotokec: when they became blood-brothers they drank each other’s blood. kinyek aisud aelo, imina aikatun esilim: do not get involved in casual sexual intercourse, you may acquire HIV/AIDS.
aelokin2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to have friendship with; to have sexual intercourse with (a man, woman, boy or girl). aelokinos apese ngin kede etelepat ngol: that girl and that boy are intimate friends. 
aelor ko-o (transitive verb) to prompt; to move instinctively; to stir. aimony naka ikoku aelo totoke: the cry of the child has moved its mother instinctively. itaok eelorit totoke k’aruoke: the calf stirs the mother by its cry. 
aelut (plural aelun) (noun F) an edible round black fruit from ewelu or ekarukwei tree; a stick or leaf from ewelu tree, Vitex madiensis, Vitex doniana. 
aenanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to tie up, bind (several things together) for somebody. koenanak akinei ngun nen: tether those goats there. 
aenanar ko-a (transitive verb) to tie into separate parcels. koenana iitaaboi kamurengen: pack the books in separate parcels. 
aenar ko-a (transitive verb) tie up and take away. aena lolo epakasit emuogo: the servant/porter has tied up and taken away cassava today i.e. has stolen cassava. 
aenet, aenetait (plural aeneta) (noun F) (Usuk) a knot; a lace; a sash; a package; a parcel; something for tying. auno naenet: a rope for tying. 
aenikin ko-a (transitive verb) to tie on, bind in or up; to fasten on or to. koenik auno omorosingike: tie the rope round her/his/its neck. koenik baa-ba: fasten it very tightly. 
aenun ko-a (transitive verb) to bring something tied; to bring a parcel. inyo bo ienunit ijo?: what kind of parcel have you brought? 
aep (plural aepei) (noun F) an axe. ailikor aep: to become brave or do a brave act. Isiriamun lueduonorete iboomun atwakianakin ilikonorete aep: Muslims who commit suicide with bombs do brave acts.
aerier ko-a (intransitive verb) to be transparent; to be thin (as of paper or glass or skin); (of belly of a kink lizard) to be so full that entrails are seen. 
aesikin ko-a (transitive verb) to let go, set free; to make room or passage. koesikinai: let me go; set me free. cp. aosikin, aisikin. 
aet (noun F) noise made by cutting into slices or as of cutting stalks of grain. 
aetanunan (plural aetanunak) (noun F) (Usuk) a foster-mother; a step-mother; an adopted mother.
aetokin ko-o (transitive verb) to give a name or nickname. 
agaali (plural agaalin) (noun F) a railway train; an ox-cart or an ox-wagon. agaali na apuru (plural agaalin nu apuru) (noun F) a railway train. cp. amagaalit. 
agadigadi (plural agadigadin) (noun F) a wheelbarrow; a pushcart. cp. amagaalit
agagaat (plural agagaan) (noun F) a cotton stalk or stick left in the garden after harvest. cp. aasirim. 
agagar ko-a (transitive verb) to put, squeeze, push, cram big things into small or narrow places or openings. sirikigagar asadukun togo loediding: do not try to cram big boxes into a small room. 
agagaraun ko-a (transitive verb) to bring some bulky object into a narrow place.
agagarikin ko-a (transitive verb) to push or put a big thing into a small place or room; to squeeze through a small opening; to cram in. inyo bo igagarikinia ijo amotoka orot loediding?: why have you parked this big car on this path? mam eong apedori agagarikin eitaabo lo kere toma akouka: I cannot cram this whole book in my head. (reflexive verb) to push, place, cram, squeeze oneself into a narrow opening or place (not to fit). inyo bo igagarikinor ijo ne?: why have you squeezed yourself in here? 
agak (plural agakia) (noun F) a raven (completely dark without a white ‘collar’). cp. ekuruk: a pied crow, i.e. the one with a white ring of feathers round its neck.
agalapua (singular noun F) a camphor leaf or stick. 
agalibidin (plural noun F) spectacles; goggles; specs; eyeglasses. 
agalon (plural agalonin) (noun F) a gallon (a liquid measure in America). 
agangat (plural agangan) (noun F) aid; assistance. agangat nasodit: first aid; the help you give a sick or hurt person before a doctor comes. aigangakin itunganan: to help or assist someone; to come to someone's aid.
agangarakou (plural nukagangarakou) (noun F) one with a big head; a fat-head. (a term of abuse)
agar (plural agaria) (noun F) a fish with fins (in general). cp. aporogot, lukecor
agarakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be well-packed; to be full; (of cattle and others with udder) to be with young inside i.e pregnant or gestating. agaraki akiteng: the cow is near calving (i.e. the udder is big). (note: for pregnancy of a woman, use agorun). 
agaramikin ko-a (transitive verb) to obstruct with. egaramikit eipyei ekitoi orot: lightning has felled a big tree onto the road. agaramikin emaase mana: a swarm of locusts has settled on the field. agaramikin emong kwap, agir anyoun: the bull has fallen down and will not get up. 
agariait (plural agaria) (noun F) a fish with fins (in general). cp. agar
agarit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be too tight, not well fitting, too small for; to be stuck (in a narrow opening). kagarit eong epale lo: these shorts are too tight for me. egarit epeta ibokor: the ring is too small for the fingers. 
agasia (plural noun F) rubbish; dirt; grime; filth; muck. 
agat ko-a (intransitive verb) to roar; to speak or shout simultaneously. egata akim biribir: the wild fire is roaring uncontrollably. cp. agatun.
agatun ko-a (intransitive verb) to speak or shout simultaneously, together. egatunete Isureta: ‘kotwana! Ibweny’: the thief-cursers shout together: ‘let him die!’ 
agear ko-a (transitive verb) to start off (a journe, a meeting, or anything); to begin to make a start with. agear alosit: to start off on a journey. wori igeara ijo aswam?: when are you going to start work? 
ageero (plural ageeron) (noun F) an artesian well. cp. adooro.
ageget (plural agegei) (noun F) a tilapia fish; ngege. cp. aporogot, lukecor
agegetu (noun F) astringency; acerbity. araito ngun ejai egegetu: those fruits are astringent (cause constipation if eaten). cp. aitebukin. 
agegit (plural agegin) (noun F) a bunch of grain kept in the smoky kitchen roof for seed. cp. anganit. 
ageikin ko-a (transitive verb) to make a start for someone else; to precede; to begin with. Tanganyika ageikini too naka Africa aipugaikin bon: Tanganyika preceded other East African countries in gaining self-rule. kogeikinai eong emukeeka keswama: start for me the mat and I shall go on weaving. 
agelakin ko-a (transitive verb) to choose for; to sort out for, pick out for. kogelakinai eong ekamong: pick out my bull for me from your kraal. (reflexive verb) to be different; to differ; (of colour) to change. agelakinos akonikiro ka nuk’opaupakon: your statement differs from that of your companion. cp. aseikin.
agelakina ko-a (transitive verb) to be in contrast. 
agelanar ko-a (transitive verb) to make a selection; to pick out what you want. kogelana ikoniboro kinyek lukos: pick what is yours and leave ours. 
agelar ko-a (transitive verb) to pick out; to sort out; to choose and take away; to detach; to excommunicate; to isolate. kogela akituku kon kane: pick out and take away your cows from here. (reflexive verb) to be different; to differ; to be unlike. (intransitive verb) to separate; to settle difficulty outside court; to go one’s own way. egelas akituk ngun bonik: those cows separate and go to their own kraals. kogelas yesi ikulepek bon kore: settle your affairs amongst yourselves at home. 
agelegel ko-a (transitive verb) to sort out; to group; to parcel out according to quality or price. kogelegel ikoniboro igwelanari: sort out your goods when selling. 
agelegela1 (noun F) disparity; inequality; discrepancy; inconsistency. 
agelegela2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be different, varied, etc. egelegela itunga: people differ. 
agelegeleun ko-o (reflexive verb) to be divided; (of a family or tribe) to live in different places. agelegeleunos kwana ikatunga: my people are now living in different places or countries. 
agelem ko-a (transitive verb) to castrate, or to emasculate. agelem imongin: to castrate bulls. cp. aidong. 
agelemaar ko-a (transitive verb) to castrate or emasculate. agelemaar eitaabo: to expurgate a book. 
agelemio (noun F) castration; emasculation. cp. aidongio 
agelun ko-o (reflexive verb) to be different; to be innocent i.e. to be different from those guilty. 
agerasit (plural ageran) (noun F) a scar left after intentional cuts on the body; a small incision on the body; a tattoo; an engraving. 
Agereesat (plural Agereesan) (noun F) the English language or word; an English woman; an Anglican Christian woman. Igereesan ineras Agereesan: the English speak English. 
ageret ko-a (transitive verb) to massage; to embrocate; to smoothen; to plane. egeresi ngesi akeju naingunyakina: she/he is massaging a dislocated foot. 
agerun ko-a (transitive verb) to make bleed by incising; to tattoo; to cut tribal marks. agerun iburuo: to cut tribal marks. 
agerunet (plural ageruneta) (noun F) a cut, incision; an instrument used for tattooing or incising.
agete (plural agetei) (noun F) a gazelle, Gazella granti. 
agetemem ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a distended belly. 
ageun1 (noun F) the beginning; starting point; origin. 
ageun2 ko-a (transitive verb) to start; to begin, originate. (adverb) since; henceforth; from this point onwards. ageun lolo, mam bobo eong abuni orekon: from now on, I will not come to your home. (intransitive verb) to begin, start, originate. itungasinei apotu kogeutu ka Adam: all peoples originated from Adam. 
ageunet (plural ageuneta) (noun F) the beginning, the origin, cradle, cause. ijeni ijo ageunet naka itungasinei?: do you know the origin of man? 
agideudeu (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) music. cp. ekosio, edisiko.
agietakin ko-a (transitive verb) to catch (an animal) in a trap; to set a trap; to ensnare, to take away a prop. abu atukot kogietak ejakait kosi, kosodete airengiar: the council found our chief on the wrong and dismissed him. (reflexive verb) to go off by itself, as of a gun or a trap. abu emuudu kogietakin bon: the gun went off by itself. 
agietun ko-a (transitive verb) to remove a prop, support; to pull away; to strike a match. karai kigietu ijo epir, ibiror etogo: if you take that support away, the house will fall. 
agigit (plural agigin) (noun F) a peg; a dowel; a tenterhook; a hanger. 
agiilo (plural agiilon) (noun F) a borehole pump (named after a pioneer driller in Teso in the 1940s, S. Gill). 
agilaasi (plural agilaasin) (noun F) a glass thing in general; a glass pane or louvre.
agilo (plural agiloi) (noun F) the gap left after two incisor teeth have been intentionally removed from the lower jaw (as a fashion gimmick). 
agion (plural agiok) (noun F) (in the Catholic faith) a saint; a holy person; a perfect person. cp. nakagion
agior ko-o (intransitive verb) (in the Catholic faith) to become holy, saintly, or perfect. aitagior: to make holy, perfect, or saintly. 
agipakin akongu ko-a (transitive verb) to keep looking at; to follow with the eyes so as not to lose sight of; to inspect closely, keep an eye on. loeswaman isaawan egipakit nginisuat akongu: a watch-maker inspects every part of the watch closely. kogipakite ikokuka akongu: keep an eye on my child.
agipar ko-a (transitive verb) to see someone or something from afar quickly, but not clearly; to catch sight of; to catch a glimpse of; to espy. kagiparit nan eong ijo ibuni: I espied you coming from afar. 
agipun ko-a (transitive verb) to recognise from nearby; to spot or find a thing lost. agipunit eong ekapiiso: I found my needle. 
agiraar ko-a (transitive verb) to wash, rub, rake away, clean up. kogiraasi erit koleleasi akipi: take away the mud so that the water may run off. 
agirait (plural agirai) (noun F) the natural lines or folds round a young person’s neck (often admired as signs of beauty in women); an armlet, bangle, wristlet, bracelet. 
agiria1 ko-a (transitive verb) (of skin or wound) to peel off. 
agiria2 ko-a (transitive verb) to take (vegetables served, rubbish with a rake) in great quantities; to take plenty; to stampede (of dancers or animals); to make thundering noise. agiriata idwe edia: children have taken vegetables in handfuls, big helpings. egiriaete kesi isirigin luipu: they get big pay cheques. agiria akeje: to make a thundering sound with feet, putting them down simultaneously in dancing; to stampede. 
agiriaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to rush away; to start off quickly; to make off. abu eong kaany engatuny kasodi agiriaar: I saw a lion and I ran away. agiriaar amuny kakuwan: (of skin by sun, chemicals, hot water, or fire) to be bleached or peeled off. cp. akakaar.
agiriakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to gather (as of rubbish for burning); to rake together, scrape together (as of money, etc). kogirianakisi atunyeny kere akim: gather all that rubbish and burn it. (reflexive verb) to run to safety. agiriakin ikoku totoke: the child has run to its mother (for safety). 
agiriakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to run for one’s life; to rush after; to run after (as after a thief or animal after prey). cp. akakakin; amotakin.
agirianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to rake up (as of rubbish for burning); to gather up; to mark out (as a day’s work or task). (reflexive verb) to collapse. kolot kogirianak agasia akim: go and gather up rubbish into fire. kigirianakinai eong ipelun: mark out my daily tasks; give me my job description. 
agiriaun1 (noun F) influx; invasion; incursion; flowing down. 
agiriaun2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to be plentiful, abundant; to come in a crowd; to crowd together. agiriaunos itunga togo: people have rushed into the house. (transitive verb) to bring many a crowd together; to catch many (as of fish); to gather a big crop of cotton; to harvest together. abu Acipa kogiriau agaria: Acipa caught a lot of fish. kagiriautu akimai: let us harvest all the millet together. 
agiriaun3 ko-o (reflexive verb) to start with a rush; to run, rush this way; to startle (as from sleep); to abound. cp. akakaun. 
agiriis (singular noun F) grease (thick lubricating oil for machinery). abu emakanika kisutak agiriis opiororo loegaalika: the mechanic put grease in the flywheel of my bicycle. 
agirikaca (singular noun F) horticulture; agriculture. 
agiris ko-o (transitive verb) to chafe, abrade; to rub off; to bruise; to graze. egirisi amoru na akanika: this stone bruises my hand. 
agirisionor ko-o (reflexive verb) to graze, bruise, chafe. egirisionoro akouka: my head is bruised. 
agirisior ko-o (transitive verb) to rub off; to erode; to bruise. akipi nuk’edou egirisionorete alup: the rain water erodes the soil. cp. agiriaar. 
agirisioret (plural agirisioreta) (noun F) a bruise, erosion, corrosion, attrition. 
agiro ko-o (intransitive verb) to roar; to thunder; rumble. egiro lolo edou noi: it is thundering violently today. cp. airurum.
agirokin1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of rain, etc) to thunder; to threaten; (of a lion) to roar. agiroki edou: the rain is threatening, it is thundering. agiroki engatuny: the lion roars. 
agirokin2 ko-a (transitive verb) (of a person) to refuse; to be difficult, abnegate, resist; to shout at; to be hard; (of disease, injury) to be painful to; to deny. abu eong kalot neejai ejakait, konye kagirok eong noi: I went to the chief but he was hard on me i.e. he shouted at me. (reflexive verb) to fall out with each other; to become enemies. agirokinos aberu k’okilenike: the wife has fallen out with her husband. 
agiron1 (plural agirok) (noun F) a girl who refuses to marry or who refuses her husband. cp. abworok.
agirun2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to thunder once; (of rain) to threaten. abu edou kogiru bian kokide: the rain thundered yesterday in the east (the rains are near). 
agisa ko-a (transitive verb) to eat very much; to gormandise; to kill big animals or men (especially big or great men). abu esilim kogisa Iteso: AIDS killed important Iteso. 
agisaar ko-a (transitive verb) to kill a big animal or man. agisaa bian Ojiirot etom: Ojiirot killed an elephant yesterday. 
agisakin ko-a (transitive verb) to kill something big for somebody. kagisakit eong atwanare onaceka: death has taken away my big brother. kagisakit eong eloket ibaren: the Karimojong cattle rustler has plundered my livestock. agisakin akiru kwap: it rained very heavily. 
agisaun ko-a (transitive verb) to bring big game home; to gather many or much (as of cotton, money or anything) (reflexive verb) to come in great quantities; to amount. agisaun edou: the rain came down in great torrents. 
agita (plural agitai) (noun F) a guitar (a musical instrument with six strings). 
agitakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to choke while somewhere. ai bo kigitakini ijo acokit?: from where did the potato choke you? 
agitakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to separate for, keep apart or back for. alosi eong agitakin ijo akonikituk: I shall keep your cows apart. 
agitakina ko-a (intransitive verb) to be in contrast, different, dissimilar. 
agitanar ko-a (transitive verb) to sort out; to put separate; to divide in groups; to assort. kogitana igoen ilosi: sort out clothes as you wash. cp. aisek. 
agitar ko-a (transitive verb) to allocate; to put aside; to separate, detach, isolate. kogitasi itunga luedekas awai: isolate patients. (reflexive verb) to separate oneself; to go aside; to be different, not to be the same. egitara ibaren ngul, mam eraas luka: these cows are not mine, they are different. 
agitarit ko-o (transitive verb) to have (something) separate, assorted; to have something one’s own. egitarit ngesi eketogo kwana: she/he has her/his own house nowadays. 
agitigit ko-a (transitive verb) to classify, categorize, order, organise, catalogue, sort, or grade. 
agitun ko-a (transitive verb) to put apart; to sever; to separate; to keep back for oneself. agitunit eong acok auni: I kept away three potatoes for myself. 
agius (noun F) (in the Roman Catholic church) holiness; sanctity; sainthood; perfection.
agogomit (singular noun F) a place which is practically treeless and has plenty of short grass; the savannah. 
agogong1 (noun F) strength, power, force, might, potency, muscle, vigour; energy, life, oomph, vivacity, enthusiasm, liveliness; hardiness, power of endurance, resoluteness, toughness, stamina, durability, robustness; firmness, determination, steadfastness, resolve, decisiveness, control; backbone, moral fibre; severity, brutality, sternness, ruthlessness, strictness. emamei ngesi agogong: she/he has no strength or moral fibre. egogong baa-ba: it is very hard, difficult, etc 
agogong2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be strong, energetic, etc. kogogong yesi da kotoma aswamukus: be hardworking in your jobs. 
agogongikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be hard or difficult for. kagogongikit eong aswam ngin: that work is difficult for me. 
agogongor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become strong; to become hardened; to become energetic, difficult, strict, etc. agogongor lokadekan: the sick man has become strong. 
agogor ko-a (transitive verb) to tire out; to wear out; to tax strength. kegogor eong aswam na: this work has tired me out. cp. agagar: to squeeze big things into small space. 
agogoriar ko-a (transitive verb) to tire out; to wear out; tax strength. kegogoriasi eong aswamusinei ngun: those jobs have tired me out. cp. agagariar: to push big thing into a small place. 
agogorikin ko-a (transitive verb) to tire out; to be tired for, on account of; to be awkward for. kigogorikitai ijo aidak epir ngol: they have given you to carry that heavy pole. 
agogwa (singular noun F) sexual intercourse (of people, not of animals) 
agol1 (plural agoloi, agoloik) (noun F) a urinary bladder; the pubic region; the lower abdomen. 
agol2 (singular noun F) uterus; womb. cp. auries
agola (plural agolaik) (noun F) a room, niche; a pocket; vestibule, hall. kirupak akan agola naka esaati: put your hand in the shirt pocket (and give me something). 
agoliam ko-a (intransitive verb) (of tall people) to walk. ai bo lolo igoliamete yesi?: where are you tall people going today? 
agolit (plural agolito) (noun F) a log for closing the gate of kraal. 
agolitomei (singular noun F) the north, i.e. the direction on one’s left when one faces the rising sun. cp. nyakoi: north, ngalakimak: south, kide: east, too: west.
agologolot (plural agologolon) (noun F) a metallic bottle top; a species of fish, Synodontis victoriae. 
agolokin ko-o (transitive verb) to stop; to shut up in; to lock in; to imprison; to block; to prevent from; to keep indoors (as of rain or other obstacle). abu ejakait kogolok nges: the chief put him in prison. kagoloki eong edou ne: the rain has stopped me from leaving here. (reflexive verb) to slam (the door). agolokin ekek: the door has slammed itself. agolokinos akiro: the case is finished (closed). agolokin ekaporoto: my throat is blocked. 
agolol ko-o (reflexive verb) to shut oneself up; to be in trouble, difficulties; to be prevented by. agoloro eong togo kanuka akurian: I have shut myself up in the house for fear. agoloritos eong aswamusinei ore: I am kept at home by all sorts of work. 
agolor ko-o (transitive verb) to corner, prevent escape; to ambush, catch, shut out. kagolori eong ijo acepaarit: I will catch or ambush you one day. agolor aibobon: to be constipated. cp. agogongor akoik. 
agolot (plural agolon) (noun F) a hollow in tree; a beehive; a confessional box (in a court of law or Roman Catholic church). 
agolun ko-o (transitive verb) to shut, cut off; to put inside brackets, shut out or in; to prevent progress. agolu nges ekalitiini lailo: the quarantine has prevented him from leaving here. (reflexive verb) to be included, cut off this way (as of men or animals by water, etc). 
agongaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to lean against; (of sun or moon) to go down. agongaa akolong too: the sun has gone down (is leaning against the Western wall). (reflexive verb) to side together. 
agongakin1 ko-a (reflexive verb) to lean on, upon; to depend on. agongakinos akwapin too: countries are leaning on western capitalism. 
agongakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to lean something against, upon. kogongak egaali arwatat: lean your bicycle against the wall. 
agonganar ko-o (reflexive verb) to lean on one another; to understand one another; to rely on one another, help one another. kogonganaros bonik kotoma aswamukus: help one another in your work. 
agongot (plural agongoi) (noun F) a species of fish; a bracelet; roots of weeds, or a kind of tree whose sticks make good building material. 
agongun ko-a (transitive verb) to mark or stain oneself or one’s clothes leaning against something. ai bo kigongunia ijo etulia ngol?: where did you lean on to get that soot (on your back)? (reflexive verb) to fall back on to lean towards or against. agongunos akiro ngun newok: that case is turning (or leaning) against us. 
agoolu (plural agoolui) (noun F) a millipede. 
agor (plural agorin, agoreik) (noun F) angle; corner; bay. 
agoreik (plural of agor) (noun F) an angle; corner; a bay. 
agoromoit (plural agoromo) (noun F) plaited grass for a belt (for tying firewood).
agoror ko-o (transitive verb) to take away with finger (from narrow container); to gouge out; to scoop out. kogoro ijo da akinyet koyanga: you also take a little butter with finger.
agorun1 ko-o (transitive verb) to scoop out, dig out. 
agorun2 ko-o (transitive verb) to tire out; to make tired; (of women and animals) to be near bringing forth. kagorunit eong aswam na: this work has tired me out. agoru aberuka, ekoto aidoun: my wife is in advanced pregnancy and wants to give birth. 
agorunun ko-o (transitive verb) to keep scooping out, digging out (as of mucus from nose). 
agougou (plural agougoun) (noun F) a chameleon. egelanakin agougou: a chameleon changes its colour. 
agoyaar ko-o (reflexive verb) (of man, house, etc) to lean over somebody or something.
agoyaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to lean over; to incline. egoyaara ipopongo lu: these cactus trees are leaning over. egoyaara ikoku yen iponesio neerono: this child’s manners are inclined to bad ways. 
agoyi ko-a (transitive verb) to lean; to push aside with arms or shoulder by leaning aside against. 
agoyiikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to lean forward, on, over. sirikigoyiikin ikoku: do not lean forward on the baby. 
agugu1 (plural noun F) bran; grain chaff.
agugu2 (plural nukagugu) (noun F) a homestead sparrow (a bird). 
agugut1 (plural agug) (noun F) the contents of a calabash fruit; the sponge-like substance found inside the anthill. 
agugut2 (plural agugu) (noun F) chaff of grain. 
agule1 (adverb) at the back of the house. 
agule2 (plural agulei) (noun F) an enclosure; a backyard; a corner; a peninsula; a bay, gulf. 
agulit (plural agulito) (noun F) a large navel; an umbilical tumour; hernia. cp. aguti
agumakin ko-a (transitive verb) to shoot at, into, for; to aim at. agumakini eong emal togo lo kotwana lokecwean: I shoot an arrow into my burnt house so that the arsonist may die. (reflexive verb) to shoot one another with arrows. agumakinos idwe: the children shot each other with bow and arrow (at play). 
agumar ko-o (reflexive verb) to dash away; to shoot past; to flash by. agumar egaali: the bicycle darted past. (transitive verb) to send an arrow flying; to shoot off, eject. koguma emal kuju: shoot the arrow up into the sky. 
agumitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to keep dashing about. inyo bo ibunitor ijo igumitoi kwangin?: wby do you come dashing along like that? 
agungurut (plural agungurun) (noun F) (formerly) a 5-cent coin.
aguosos (adjective) (of a person) fat around the waist. 
agurai (plural nukagurai) (noun F) a very poisonous yellowish snake. 
agureeda (plural agureedan) (noun F) a road grader tractor; a farm tractor. cp. atingatinga
agurumaar ki-a (transitive verb) to set out, inflate (as of tyre, football, pot or granary); to make round from oblong. 
agurumikin ki-a (transitive verb) to make round, barrel-like (as of pot or granary). kigurumik edula akoik: make the granary nicely round. 
agurumum ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fat-bellied. 
aguti (plural agutin) (noun F) umbilical hernia; a swollen navel. cp. aipule: navel. 
agutiaanar ko-a (intransitive verb) to have umbilical hernia. 
agutianut ko-a (intransitive verb) to have umbilical hernia; to have a big navel or a long umbilicus. 
aguuru (plural nukaguuru) (noun F) a large, ugly kind of praying mantis. cp. eicolong-ebu. 
aguurut (plural aguurun) (noun F) a brook; stream. cp. ecilet. 
aguurut (plural aguurun) (noun F) a deep river; channel; waterfall; valley; ravine; turbulent current; cascade. 
aguurut (plural aguuruto) (noun F) a torrent or a waterfall; a dangerous stream. 
aguwom ko-a (transitive verb) (of a fat man) to walk heavily; to waddle. 
agwaam ki-a (transitive verb) to make rough; to roughen. apotu ikukwa kigwaamata akakuwan: the thorns made my skin rough. 
agwaamam ko-a (intransitive verb) to be rough-skinned; to be covered with dirt, rough. igwaamam ijo: you are rough-skinned. 
agwaamikin ko-a (transitive verb) to beat with something very rough; to cut skin (like the scourging of Jesus Christ; to slander; to calumniate. kinyekinai agwaamikin eong numam enerit: do not slander me for what I did not say. 
agwaamu (noun F) (of surface) roughness. cp. angengeu. 
agwaanya (plural agwaanyai) (noun F) a bathing shelter; a urinal.
agwaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to get another into trouble. agwaiki ikoku papake akiro: the child has got its father in trouble. 
agwanga (plural agwangai) (noun F) a woman prophet; a prophetess. 
agwaragwar ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch often; to tear with claws. kagwaragwar eong ikapa: the cat has scratched. 
agwaramam ko-a (intransitive verb) (of skin) to be scaly, rough. cp. agwaamam.
agwarar ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch slightly. agwara etoori ikoku ademar akekiring: the eagle scratched that child slightly in the process of snatching away meat. (reflexive verb) to give a sign by a scratch or pull; to take a person aside. agwararos kwi awai: they gave each other a sign to go aside. 
agware (plural agwarei) (noun F) a species of bird; a laughing dove. cp. egirigirio, elele. 
agwaun akirot ko-a (transitive verb) to commit a fault; to rouse to anger; to incite, excite, carp, calumniate; to attack. agwau lolo ejakait da akiro: the chief has also committed a crime this time, i.e. has also got in trouble. agwautu idwe ao: the children have roused the bees (into anger i.e. they have disturbed them).
agwaunet (plural agwauneta) (noun F) calumny; aggression; attack; belligerence.
agwaunun ko-a (transitive verb) to keep slandering, provoking, calumniating, challenging. 
agweeret1 (plural agweer) (noun F) a broom made of twigs; a twig used as firewood; a cane for beating. 
agweeret2 (plural agweer) (noun F) a bush used for making brooms; small twigs of firewood. 
agwei (plural agwean) (noun F) a new crop of millet. aikony agwei: to taste first millet meal. koom emuron kobu aitokony itunga agwei: call the heathen priest to bless the first millet meal. cp. angorot. (The heathen ceremony is as follows: the priest - emuron - takes the first morsel, after which the others do the same (take a morsel); the ladle with which the meal was stirred is placed above the doorway, for the children take the new meal next morning. Before the priest and the people partake of the food, he makes the sign of the cross on himself, smearing first himself and the people with the food and then throwing it in lumps to the four winds – north, east, south, and west). 
agweikin ko-a (transitive verb) to coil for; to mould for, do pottery for, etc. kogweikinai amot: mould me a pot. 
agwel ko-a (transitive verb) to buy; to purchase. kogwel egoe kaloto: buy the dress and let us go. 
agwelakin ko-a (transitive verb) to buy for, at, in. ai bo kigwelakini ijo egoe lo?: from where did you buy this dress? 
agwelanar ko-a (transitive verb) to trade; to barter. 
agwelanaran (plural agwelanarak) (noun F) a merchant; a seller; a vendor; a trader; a dealer; a broker; a perpetual traitor; a serial betrayer. 
agwelanaret (plural agwelanareta) (noun F) a marketplace; a bazaar; an auction. cp. esokooni.
agwelar ko-a (transitive verb) to sell; to betray. kogwelasi egaali ngol: sell that bicycle. 
agwelegwel ko-a (transitive verb) to keep bribing or corrupting; to buy often. 
agwelun ko-a (transitive verb) to buy for oneself; to redeem. igwelunit ijo nyo?: what did you buy? what favours are you trying to buy?
agwetakin ko-a (transitive verb) to fall or drop or go by removing support suddenly; (of match) to strike, to light; to dismiss, or to depose; to pull the trigger (of gun), to fire. sirikigwetak ekaicolong: do not remove my chair and let me fall. (reflexive verb) to fall; to be dismissed, deposed (of chiefs and the like); to go off (of a trap, trigger of gun, etc). 
agwetun ko-a (transitive verb) to fall or drop or come down when the support is suddenly removed; (of match) to strike, to light.
agwolom ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a hungry giant) to move about awkwardly (with an empty belly swaying). 
agwolomaar ko-a (transitive verb) (of a hungry giant) to go away awkwardly (with an empty belly swaying). 
agwolomom ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a giant) to be haggard and hungry. 
agwolomun ko-a (transitive verb) (of a hungry giant) to come awkwardly (with an empty belly swaying). 
agwotakin ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to trouble people by immigration. inyo bo kigwotakiniata yesi iso?: why do you trouble us by your immigration? cp. abwotakin
agwotar ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to emigrate. agwotasi itunga luipu okekwa je: many people have emigrated to the other side of the swamp. cp. abwotar.
agwotun ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to immigrate; to come near. kogwotutu lailo: migrate this way. cp. abwotun.
agyel ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to bribe; to buy; to favour. igyelit ijo ejakait ngesi ketelekaritor eong emusaago: you bribed the chief and that is why I lost the case. kingara ijo eong ido kogyelite je: you dislike me alone and favour him. cp. agwel
ai bo? (interrogation) where?; where to?; where from?; wherein? ai bo ilosi ijo?: where are you going? 
ai- prefix forming infinitive of ko and ki verbs. ailip: to pray (ki); aiduk: to build (ko). 
ai? (interrogation) where? 
aiar ko-a (transitive verb) to kill, murder, or abolish. kaar eong akure: I am thirsty. aarakin bon: to kill oneself; to commit suicide. aiar aswam: to dismiss from work. aiar etengei: to alleviate hunger. aiar akure: to quench thirst. aiar ekisil: to abrogate, abolish a law. aiar ajakaanut: to oust from power; to depose from chieftainship. cp. aiyar.
aiba1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to get moist, wet. 
aiba2 ko-a (transitive verb) (of night or new day) to become light. ebai akwap: it is dawn; it is very early. kolot ebai kide: go at dawn; go very early in the morning. abu ngesi kolot osapaali nepe ebai kide: she/he set off for a trip very early in the morning.
aiba3 ko-a (transitive verb) to hit; to tap with stick; to crack. aba ngesi akouka: she/he has conked my head. 
aibaaj ki-a (transitive verb) to owe; to borrow money. kebaajiki eong aingadis isirigin imilionin ikany bon: the bank has lent me five million shillings only.
aibaajikin ki-a (transitive verb) to lend or let somebody borrow money. 
aibaajun ki-a (transitive verb) to borrow or have a money loan. 
aibabakin1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to go begging for something. adol bodo ikerai luko Katakwi aibabakin: the internally displaced people of Katakwi are nearly begging for alms.
aibabakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to give a little to a beggar. Isusan, kolot aibabakin emuduk isirigin akwatat: Susan, go and give the blind man a hundred shillings. 
aibabatoi ki-a (intransitive verb) to be destitute; to go about begging; to be in need; to be poor. ibabatoi ngesi ailipitoi inyamat: she/he goes about begging for food. cp. ailipilipitoi. 
aibaiba ki-a (transitive verb) to pound something which is hard. cp. aicang. 
aibak ko-a (transitive verb) to slit, cut open an abscess with a scalpel or anything sharp. aibak abus: to open an abscess. 
aibakar ki-a (intransitive verb) (of many people together) to walk abreast. cp. aikaar. 
aibakibak ki-a (intransitive verb) to argue ineffectively; to talk nonsense in dispute; to crack (of potato heaps – a sign that big tubers are underneath). ibakibaki ijo tai: you talk nonsense; you are panicking for nothing, yet! ibakibakit acokit alup: the potato has cracked the soil. 
aibaliig ki-a (intransitive verb) to cheat a person out of his belongings; to defraud, swindle, con, dupe, or trick.
aibam1 ki-a (intransitive verb) aibam aokot: (of a woman) to menstruate. aibam naman enangi: menorrhoea; continuous menstruation. cp. ajaus olap; adeka elap; ekuje.
aibam2 ki-a (transitive verb) to plaster; to level off; to ram down (as of floor); to press into a lump (as of bread or atap). erai Okwi lokebaman itogoi: Okwi’s profession is plastering house floors. ebamakin ekume: the nostrils are blocked (unable to smell). cp. isikakina ekume; ilupudud ekume.
aibames (plural aibamesia) (noun F) menstruation. 
aibamibam ki-a (transitive verb) to beat earth repeatedly; to ram a grave or house repeatedly; to stamp down persistently. ejaas idwe aibamibam akwap eboliasi: children are stamping the ground as they play. cp. aitutu; ailir 
aibana ki-a (transitive verb) to fold cloth. kibana ber ijo igoen luinomitai: you first fold clothes that have been ironed.
aibang ki-a (transitive verb) to eat food with no vegetables or relishes. ibangi ngesi atap: she/he eats atap (millet or sorghum bread) without vegetables. 
aibany ki-a (transitive verb) to press down (as of earth into a hole, etc); to trample down. mam akoto yes aibany amanaka: I do not want you to trample down my garden. (intransitive verb) (of tree, man or animal) to be short and stout. ibanyit etelepat ngol: that boy is short and stout. aibany kakeju ki-a (intransitive verb) to go far on foot. ilosi ijo k’egaali arai ibanyi k’akeju?: are you going by bicycle or on foot?
aibanyakin kwap ki-a (reflective verb) to flop down; to be too weak to stand (only used for children learning to walk, or drunken/weak person). ebanyakin ikoku kwap: the child has flopped down (while trying to walk) (transitive verb) to throw or press down. abu eong kebanyak nges kwap kiuta: I threw him down on his buttocks while wrestling. 
aibap ki-a (transitive verb) to slap on the cheeks or ears; to smack; to strike at an angle. aibapakin akanin: to acclaim, welcome, applaud (by clapping hands). aibapar alup: to throw the gauntlet; to take up a challenge to a fight. 
aibapabap ki-a (transitive verb) to slap cheeks or ears repeatedly; to clap hands. cp. aidip: to punch on the back with a resounding blow. 
aibapasit (plural aibapasia) (noun F) a slap on the ear; a clap. 
aibar ko-a (intransitive verb) to become rich, wealthy, well to do (only used in infinitive). abarar, abaranar: (of cows, goats, chicken, etc) to become many; to become wealthy, well to do. cp. aimi: to have a bumper harvest in food regularly. 
aibat ki-a (transitive verb) (of a person) to walk barefooted; to pad; to go on foot. aibat k’akeje: to move barefooted (without shoes); to foot (not to use a transport vehicle).
aibatis ki-a (transitive verb) to baptise. aibatis esirikaalet kede akim (ayangaar nges ojie): to baptise a soldier with fire (take him to the frontline).
