aibe1 (singular noun F) a gambling game with cashew nuts, a hole in the ground, more than one player contributing cashew nuts and apiku (a stone for hitting a nut outside the hole as chosen by the opponent – hitting that nut alone means you win all the nuts; hitting more than one means you fail and the chance goes to the opponent; nuts entering the hole belong to the person who threw them in; apiku entering the hole having nuts means that player will lose those nuts i.e. the nuts continue in play). 
aibe2 ki-a (transitive verb) to crack a hard nut; to crack stones. 
aibe3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be true. cp. abeit. 
aibe4 ko-a (transitive verb) to go to; to lead to. abeata kesi ai?: where have they gone? what has become of them? ebeit aswam: abaout to; just going to do something.
aibebe ki-a (intransitive verb) to crack nuts or stones. 
aibebeloor ki-o (transitive verb) to push, return earth into hole or grave; to fill up again; to turn (anything) upside down by pushing. 
aibebeun akiro ki-a (intransitive verb) to elicit information; to investigate.
aibecokin abeit ki-o (transitive verb) to say exactly what is meant; to do exactly what is wanted; to fit; to mimic or imitate exactly. 
aibeeleanut (noun F) viciousness; quarrelsomeness; mischief. 
aibega ki-a (transitive verb) to spy; to pry; to inquire secretly; to detect. 
aibeibe ki-a (intransitive verb) to crack a hard thing gently. aibeibe imaidoko: to crack cashew nuts. (transitive verb) to beat rocks into small pieces. aibeibe amor komoru Abela: to crack rocks at Abela Rock quarry (in Katakwi town).
aibek ko-a (intransitive verb) to hatch eggs; to remove a scab from a wound. 
aibekibek ki-a (transitive verb) to gnaw at (figurative); to try to find out; to try to do or know what is above you or beyond you, what you do not know. cp. aikocikoc. 
aibel1 ki-a (transitive verb) to crave for, hanker after; to desire ardently for food in general, especially for meat. 
aibel2 ki-a (transitive verb) to cut up or split firewood. 
aibel3 ki-a (transitive verb) to glean or dig up potatoes, cassava or anything from the ground. 
aibel4 ko-a (transitive verb) to bash or crack the head with a stick; to break into small pieces. 
aibele ki-o (transitive verb) to turn or change from side to side. kolot aibele acok kakim: go and turn potatoes in the fire. 
aibelear ki-a (transitive verb) to tell a secret about someone; to expose somebody wrongdoing; to give someone away. 
aibeleikin akonye ki-o (transitive verb) to look sternly at someone; to look daggers. inyo bo kibeleikinitor ijo eong akonye?: why do you look daggers at me? 
aibeleonor ki-o (intransitive verb) to turn about (as in sleeplessness); to keep turning round. 
aibeleor ki-o (transitive verb) to turn; to translate languages (like Apuda has done here). 
aibeleun ki-o (transitive verb) to turn something round or inside out (as of shirt); to turn back; to turn this way; to look or turn round; look behind; look this way. kibeleutu akituk lailo: turn cows this way. kibeleunos lailo (plural): turn this way.
aibelianar ki-a (intransitive verb) to become greedy; to be greedy. 
aibelibel ki-o (intransitive verb) to roll about. ibelibelos idwe kotoma asinge: the children roll about in the sand. 
aibelibelo ki-o (reflexive verb) to roll oneself about; to keep rolling in bed from side to side. ibelibelos idegei luejie kokwamin: the jetfighter planes roll in the skies. 
aibeliikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to hanker after; to hunger after (meat). 
aibelokin1 ki-o (reflexive verb) to turn away; (of knee, ankle) to be twisted, sprained. ebelokin eong akung: my knee is sprained. 
aibelokin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to turn something about; to turn upside down; to interpret; to translate. kibelok emukule ngol: turn that hide upside down. 
aibemakin ki-a (transitive verb) to throw down on or somewhere (reflexive verb) to fall down on something.
aibeniben ki-a (transitive verb) to make thin; to slice thin. ebenen einer, konye aswam…: talking is easy, but working…. 
aibeny ko-a (intransitive verb) to start a quarrel or a dispute. 
aiber ko-a (intransitive verb) to be first; to come first. ikoto ijo aiber kotoma aingito: you like to be the first in the class examination. 
aiberuikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be like a woman in actions; to be woman-like; (of a man) to be effeminate. iberuikit ekesa ngol: that guy is very effeminate.(an insult) 
aibesenen ki-a (transitive verb) to be splitting often (as of wood, etc). 
aibeset (plural aibeseta) (noun F) an implement for splitting (such as a hatchet, an axe, a panga, etc). cp. ayep. 
aibet ki-a (transitive verb) to cut up; to split, saw, chop, chip. ibesi ngesi akito: she/he is splitting fire-wood. aibet akituk: to be ready to cry; to sulk. aisibet: to make to split, chop, saw, chip. cp. aireb: to cut (hair, clothing, etc) with scissors; to cut vegetables with a knife ready for cooking. 
aibetenen ki-a (transitive verb) to be splitting often (as of wood, etc). 
aibetun akituk ki-a (transitive verb) to screw up one’s face; to be at the point of crying; to sulk. 
aibi ko-o (transitive verb) to pass out wind; to gas; to fart.
aibic1 (singular noun F) a traditional Teso game for boys involving nuts being thrown into a small hole drilled on the ground at a distance of about four metres and a flat round stone called apiku used to aim at nuts that do not enter the hole. 
aibic2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to hit cashewnuts in a game of aibic. aibic imaidoko: to play the game of hitting cashewnuts. cp. aibe.
aibida ki-a (transitive verb) to angle; to catch fish with a hook, i.e. with eibidas or eibidaet. 
aibielibiel ki-o (intransitive verb) to boil up; to effervesce; to bubble up. 
aibielonokin (reflexive verb) to turn back quickly and re-appear. ibielonokin aberu kotogo: the woman is busy in the house, i.e. going in and out. 
aibielor ki-o (intransitive verb) (of a woman from collecting water or a trip) to turn back quickly 
aibiikin ki-a (transitive verb) to place (something somewhere). cp. aibwaikin. 
aibiiny ki-a (intransitive verb) to feel or to be unwell (not used often).
aibiinyanakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be often unwell. 
aibiinyikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be or feel weak or unwell. 
aibil1 ko-a (transitive verb) to break; to fold; (of anything) to transgress; to crease. aibil asuat: (of a husband and wife) to solemnise a marriage by breaking a piece of iron and each keeping their piece as a sign of faithfulness. abilakin abotet: to betray. abilakin akeje: (when sitting) to double up legs. abilakin ekia akeje: to put poison in foot prints. aibil ekisil: to break the law. aibil akeju: to fracture or break the leg. aibil akoit: a traditional Iteso/Karimojong ceremony of breaking the bone, to signify the end of animosities between the two peoples and the start of sharing (the thigh bone of an animal should be broken in half). cp. aidol, anunuk.
aibil2 ko-a (transitive verb) to make a list of; (of the bride’s relatives during marriage) to state the number of cows and goats to be paid as dowry; to count by heads or tickets. aibil akwes: to count heads. 
aibiler ki-o (intransitive verb) to be mad, delirious, mentally deficient. 
aibilerikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become mad, delirious, mentally deficient. 
aibilerikinet (singular noun F) hysteria; hysterics; frenzy; madness; rage; fury. 
aibilinyaar ki-a (transitive verb) to push back (the foreskin or prepuce); to plaster the wall with mud. 
aibina ki-a (intransitive verb) to gyrate the waist (like one dancing a kiganda dance). aibina kadodi: to dance to a kigisu circumcision dance.
aibir ki-o (transitive verb) to throw at; to hit; to pelt. 
aibiribir k’amor ki-o (transitive verb) to throw stones at; to pelt. ekoto Angopu aibir Idengot k’ebela: Angopu wants to throw a stick at Idengot. 
aibirokin1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to throw at one another; to fall; to fall upon. abu Igella kibirokin kwap: Igella fell down. 
aibirokin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to throw down. abu Ogweere kibirok Icumar kwap: Ogweere threw Icumar down. 
aimwany ko-a (transitive verb) to break something (soft and powdery) into two. aimwany emuogo: to break a cassava tuber into two pieces.
amwany ko-a (reflexive verb) to break suddenly. amwanyi etelepat akeju komopiira: the boy's leg has been broken in a football game. 
mwany (adverb) broken completely
aibironor ki-o (reflexive verb) to keep falling; to fall repeatedly. 
aibiror1 (singular noun F) a fall; a slip, fault, sin, transgression; failure.
aibiror2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall; to fail; to commit a fault; to sin; to blunder. ebiror Odeke kotoma aingito: Odeke failed in his school exams. ebiror ikoku erono noi: the child has fallen badly. 
aibiror3 ki-o (transitive verb) to throw away (anything). 
aibirun ki-o (intransitive verb) to lose a case; to fall forward, down this way. 
aibisaalikit (adjective) (of body colour) jaundiced; yellowish. 
aibit1 ki-a (transitive verb) to pluck leaves (of vegetables); to fish. 
aibit2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to come in or go out; (of ants or birds) to fly out; to swarm. ebisete ikong: the ants are swarming. 
aibit3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to leak or drip. ebisi ekume: the nose drips. cp. aiit
aibitiikin (intransitive verb) to crave for; to long for; to become greedy. 
aibitionor ki-o (reflexive verb) to become greedy, stingy, miserly. 
aibitionut (singular noun F) stinginess; longing; craving; greed, avarice; egoism. 
aibiun ki-a (transitive verb) to notice, observe, spy out. 
aibobon ki-a (intransitive verb) to pass stool; to defecate; to empty one’s bowels; discharge the bowels. cp. alosit kinga; aikingan; alosit obar. 
aibobonet (plural aiboboneta) (noun F) the anus; the descending colon. cp. aidoole 
aiboc ko-o (transitive verb) to take off the bark; to shell. 
aibogoikin ki-o (intransitive verb) (of milk) to curdle. ebogoikis akile: the milk has curdled. 
aiboi ki-o (intransitive verb) to sit, dwell, camp; to delay, wait, rest, dally; to be seated; to live in: aiboyenen: to dwell. itunganan iboyie k’inyamat: man lives on food. mam ijeni ebe inyamat iboyio itunganan?: don’t you know that man lives on food? edumunit ngesi agogong nakibois: (of a patient) she/he has got the strength to sit up. 
aiboibo ki-o (transitive verb) to munch, gnaw, eat raw especially potatoes, cassava or raw mango fruit, sounding like bobo. aiboibo ikel: to gnash or grind one’s teeth. 
aiboikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to sit down on. kiboikin oicolong: sit on the chair. kiboikin kwap: sit down (on the ground). ai bo lolo iboitor ijo?: where did you stay (delay) this time? alosi aiboyior Serere: I am going to settle down in Serere. cp. alosior; aiboyiun – settle, stay here. 
aibois (plural aiboisio) (noun F) an abode, a place, or a thing to sit on or settle in. abois naibecokino: the right place. aiboisio kere: everywhere; in every place.
aiboisit (plural aiboisio) (noun F) dwelling place; address; home; resting place; abode; a chair. aiboisika: in my place; instead of me. ai bo iboyoo ijo?: what is your address? aijul neiboyoo: to change address.
aibok1 ko-a (transitive verb) to dig a hole for planting or for a grave; to cultivate. aibok acok: to heap potato mounds; (slang during the 1987 Teso insurgency) to dig one’s own grave before being killed. aibok ibilenga: to dig for mudfish. 
aibok2 ko-a (transitive verb) to tempt; to ask in order to trap; to find out, or to spy. 
aibokiboka ki-a (intransitive verb) (of body or anything) to tremble. 
aiboko ki-o (transitive verb) to catch flying ants and eat them; to light up with a torch. ebokoi eong ikong: I am catching and eating white ants. ibokoete kesi ikong: they light up torches to catch white ants. 
aibol ko-a (intransitive verb) to compete with; to race; to contest. 
aiboleikin ki-o (transitive verb) to promise; to make a contract; to come to terms; to agree to. cp. acamun; aipeg. 
aibolony ki-a (transitive verb) to circumcise. cp. aikep. 
aibong ko-o (intransitive verb) to return, go back, or to retire; to reflect. 
aibongibong ki-a (transitive verb) to make (cord or pot) too thick; to make thick (what should be thin); to wear a thick cord. inyo bo ibongibongia jo auno ngin?: why do you make that string so thick (too thick)? 
aiboonokin ki-o (intransitive verb) (of many) to sit. kiboonokinos ne: sit here (plural). 
aibos ko-a (intransitive verb) to rot, stink, putrefy, fester; to disintegrate. aibos tulutul: to become thoroughly rotten. 
aiboyior ki-o (intransitive verb) to stay away; to settle down somewhere. 
aibu1 ki-o (transitive verb) to hammer; to knock (feet) against. 
aibu2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to swell, ferment. 
aibu3 ko-o (transitive verb) to force; to coerce, compel; to slander. 
aibubu ki-o (transitive verb) to hit; to knock, hammer. kibubu isumaalin okek: nail the door. 
aibubuakin ki-a (transitive verb) to urge one on. cp. aiburuburar: to dragoon. aiburuburakin: to urge away. 
aibubukin ki-o (transitive verb) to peg out., crucify; to hammer on or down; to nail. 
aibubulatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to bustle or make noise with utensils. 
aibubulaun ki-o (intransitive verb) to appear noisily and suddenly (transitive verb) to search out noisily. 
aibubuor ki-o (transitive verb) to hammer away (as nail into wood.) 
aibubwanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to dragoon. 
aibubwes (plural aibubweta) (noun F) (an implement for hammering, such as a mallet, a tack hammer; a sledge hammer, etc). cp. anyul 
aibuc ki-a (transitive verb) to miss; to err; to be or do accidentally.
aibucar ki-a (intransitive verb) to slip off; to go against; to say or do things that are not what someone wants. abucar asaanit ter kwap: the plate slipped and dropped down (broken). 
aibucaret (plural aibucareta) (noun F) a mistake; an error. 
aibuce (noun F) a touch; a feel; a stroke or pat.
aibuk1 ki-a (transitive verb) to churn swing, rock, push to and fro; to shake, convulse. akile nuibukuk: churned milk. (intransitive verb) to waggle.
aibuk2 ko-o (transitive verb) to pour; to empty; to make water. 
aibukakin ki-a (transitive verb) to churn for; (of heart) to palpitate. ibuka etauka: my heart palpitates. 
aibukaret (plural aibukareta) (noun F) a riddle or brainteaser; a puzzle, a poser; a cross-word puzzle; a conundrum.
aibukubuk ki-a (transitive verb) to heave, buffet, rock, swell (of waves), to shake much. 
aibul1 ki-a (transitive verb) to take a little (especially of a liquid) from each container of anything to avoid overflow. 
aibul2 ko-o (transitive verb) to incise and let out entrails or contents; to crack raw eggs. kobul ikwenyit: disembowel the bird. aibul abus: to incise an abscess. kobulok abeei oikopo: crack the eggs into a cup.
aibular ki-a (transitive verb) to catch up the overflow. kibulak ekamule adere: catch up the overflow of the beer in the calabash.
aibuleikin ki-a (transitive verb) to add beer to beer; to pour in more beer (to same container). 
aibulon ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a boil or abscess) to become ripe; to suppurate; to form pus.
aibulu (plural aibului) (noun F) a species of destructive termite; an anthill or fat termites from which queen ants come. (From aibulu come fat flying ants called ikwaresia, which pair with slender ones called ingerepo - that fly in the morning from a different anthill called angerep - the result of this is that new anthills are formed of one kind or another). 
aibulubulun ki-a (reflexive verb) to overflow or bubble up (as of a well); (of a liquid) to gush out; to ooze out. 
aibulubulunun ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a liquid) to keep gushing out, to flow out, continually. 
aibululuikin ki-a (transitive verb) to look blue or azure. 
aibun ko-a (transitive verb) to have in the hand; to close in; to stop; to block; to gag a person; to fold (hands). kobun ikonikumes: block your nostrils. kobun akituk: close your lips. 
aibunga ki-a (transitive verb) to beat or thrash; to give blows. kebungaata kesi eong: they have beaten me. 
aibungatait (plural aibungata) (noun F) a thrashing; a beating; a blow. adumu aberu ngin aibungata nuipu: that woman has got many beatings. 
aibunget (plural aibungeta) (noun F) a cluster, a mass (of anything); a swarm (of bees); (Ateso Atororo) a thousand. 
einene (singular noun M) a swarm of migrant bees temporarily resting in a tree like a ball. 
aibupokin ki-o (transitive verb) to throw down with a thud. 
aibur ko-o (transitive verb) to re-sow (after failure of first sowing); to cover a drum with a skin; to seal; to wrap; to encase; to envelop. cp. airap, aiswap, ainuk. aibur abalua: to close the envelope. 
aibura ki-a (transitive verb) to claim as a debt; to demand, press for; to dun. 
aiburakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be uneasy, impatient, fidgety, on tenterhooks, on pins and needles to do something; to be anxious to begin action; to be eager, or keen. keburakit eong alosit: I must be off. 
aiburakinet (plural aiburakineta) (noun F) anxiety; a worry; nervousness; fretfulness. 
aiburakinit (transitive verb) to be anxious; to be impatient. 
aiburubur ki-a (intransitive verb) to be quick (in going or doing). kiburubur alosit: go quickly. 
aiburuburakin ki-a (transitive verb) to urge away; to urge on. 
aiburuburar ki-a (transitive verb) to urge away. 
aiburukuny ki-a (intransitive verb) (of mushrooms, flowers, leaves before opening out) to bud. 
aiburukunyun ki-a (intransitive verb) (of mushrooms or girls’ breasts starting out) to swell. 
aiburun ikisin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a girl) to develop breasts at puberty. eburu ipese ikisin: the little girl has developed breasts.
aiburututun ki-o (transitive verb) to draw out water or ajon with a narrow-mouthed vessel, causing a low imitative sound. 
aibus1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of weather) to be hot; to be warm. ibus lolo akwap: it is hot or warm today. ebusuu etogo lo: this room is neat and trim; this room is hot. (plural ibusak itogoi lu or ebusuutu itogoi lu).
aibus2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fitting, apt; to suit, behove, befit; to be proper to, be fair to, convenient. aibusakin: to be fitting, befit, suitable to, expedient, proper, sufficient, becoming, or behove. 
aibus3 ki-o (transitive verb) to throw down (object).
aibusakinit (intransitive verb) to deserve; to be necessary, apt, pertinent, appropriate, suitable, or proper. 
aibuse (singular noun F) warmth; sweat; heat; perspiration. cp. amwanus. 
aibuses (singular noun F) glory; honour; esteem; fame. ainakin aibuses: to honour; to give honour (intransitive verb) to be honourable; to be glorious. ikoto jo aibuses: you want fame. 
aibusian ki-a (intransitive verb) to grub along, look for food. 
aibusibusitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to gurgle. 
aibusokin ki-o (transitive verb) to throw down (with a thud). ikoto kebusok kwap?: do you want me to throw you down? (reflexive verb) (in wrestling) to fall down. 
aibusor ki-o (transitive verb) to throw down heavily; to slam. (reflexive verb) to fall down with a thud. 
aibusubusakin (intransitive verb) to become hot for someone. 
aibusun: to throw down with a thud (reflexive verb) to fall down heavily. 
aibusuun ki-a (intransitive verb) to look tidy, neat, trim, fitting. ebusuu eigoo lolo: the town looks neat and trim today. cp. ibus eigoo lolo: the trading centre is warm today. 
aibut1 ki-o (transitive verb) to pull apart a limb or twig; to congest plants in sowing; to represent, take the place of.  
aibut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a snake, chameleon, etc) to shed skin; to moult; to peel, to be blistered; to live long or forever; to be eternal. ebusi Lokasuban: God lives eternally. kobut kakwap: live long on earth. 
aibutokin ki-a (reflexive verb) to plunge oneself into (anything); to be stuck in mud. ebutokin itaok toma orit: the calf is immovably stuck in the mud. ebutokin ejakait toma omusaago: the chief is involved in a very serious case. 
aibutor ki-o (transitive verb) disrupt, pull apart. 
aibutung ki-a (intransitive verb) to sprout; to form buds. 
aibutunget (plural aibutungeta) (noun F) the shoot; the sprout; the bud (unopened). 
aibuubuar ki-a (transitive verb) to urge on. 
aibuwanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to collect and move things about; to shuffle; to pack. ingai ibuwanakin kotogo kalo?: who is shuffling in this house? inyo bo ibuwanakina ijo ikaboro kwangin?: why do you move my things about like that?
aibuyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give many things not counted. 
aibwa1 ki-a (transitive verb) to hide; to keep away, put aside; to abscond. aibwa ikinyom: to hide choice seeds (grain) completely. 
aibwa2 ko-a (transitive verb) to fence in; to surround with a fence or hedge. 
aibwaadeikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become a prostitute. 
aibwaanar ki-a (transitive verb) to shout, scoff at, ridicule, or to jeer at. ibwaanario ngesi: she/he is an object of jeers and scoffs. 
aibwaar ki-a (transitive verb) to send away with a curse. 
aibwabwaat ki-a (intransitive verb) to keep hiding things from public view; to keep concealing. 
aibwaciikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become sterile; to be impotent. 
aibwaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to lay down, place, put down. aibwaikin etau: to heed; to put one’s mind to; to take to heart. aibwaikin akanin kau: to put hands behind the back. aibwaikin akan: to sign a letter or any document. 
aibwait ki-a (transitive verb) to be keeping concealed or in hiding; to hide. ibwait ijo ibore: you are hiding something. 
aibwakanar ki-a (transitive verb) to swing, to vary (as of incense); to miss a thing one wants; to fan, wave a fan; to hit, catch, slap (as of hawk trying to catch a chick); to fail to catch, etc. abwaka etoori imiyot: the eagle missed the chick. akoto eong aibap ngesi konye kabwaka aibwakar: I wanted to hit her/him but I missed. ebwakanari esaseredooti elutaari: the priest incenses the altar. 
aibwakibwak ki-a (transitive verb) to wave (with hand or anything); to flutter (with wings). aibwakibwak abebenoka: (of birds) to move wings up and down (sitting or standing); to flap wings. 
aibwakibwaket (plural aibwakibwaketa) (noun F) a fan (for blowing air about). 
aibwal1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to threaten rain. ebwal edou: ibwalete idowon: rain clouds are threatening to rain. ibwalete idowon karai ekotos aitep: the clouds put on ornaments if they want to bring rain. 
aibwal2 ki-a (transitive verb) to wear feathers in hair or put on ornaments for feast; to adorn the head. ibwalete itunga elosete okosio: people ornament themselves as they go for dancing.
aibwalukukun ki-a (intransitive verb) to hang over (as of hair over eyes); (of grass over path, branches of tree over road) hanging over. 
aibwalukun ki-a (reflexive verb) (of feathers) falling over eyes; (of branches of a tree) hanging over a path. 
aibwamaar ki-a (transitive verb) to spear to death; to cause to drop senseless. 
aibwan ki-a (transitive verb) to look after a bride in her new home. 
aibwanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fill a store; to put something in constantly, continuously. 
aibwanen ki-o (transitive verb) to ride on horseback (or on any animal); to mount; to ride on cow. 
aibwang ko-a (transitive verb) (of pottery) to break; (of anthill) to produce mushrooms. cp. ainged (of rope, string, or thread); aibil (of sticks or trees); airi (of wall, glass); aicil (of cloth) 
aibwangibwang ki-a (transitive verb) to singe; to burn the surface; to scorch. aibwangibwang imolokonyo luakiteng: to singe the hairs on the cow’s hooves (when preparing them for cooking).
aibwany ki-a (transitive verb) to gate-crash, intrude; to be a parasite. aibwany ajon: to gatecrash a beer party (of an uninvited person). 
aibwanyun ki-a (intransitive verb) to get by gate-crashing. 
aibwap ki-a (transitive verb) to follow up; to trace; to track; to follow trail. aibwapakin: (of a boy after girl, a hunter after an animal, etc) to go after or follow somebody. 
aibwapar ki-a (transitive verb) to track down (especially of girl going after boy.) 
aibwapit ki-a (transitive verb) to keep going after; to seek, look for. 
aibwaret (plural abwareta) (noun F) a shout; a holler; a bawl. apupi eong aibwaret: I hear a shout. 
aibwaribwar ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk fast. 
aibwat ko-a (transitive verb) to sprinkle; to retreat and stand aloof; to see, look at from afar; to espy. abwasit: to keep at bay; to eschew. 
aibwel ki-o (intransitive verb) to bubble up. 
aibwelibwel ki-o (intransitive verb) to boil over or bubble over (of water or beer).cp. aibielibiel. 
aibwikin ki-o (transitive verb) to hammer in or push in by force. cp. atingakin. 
aibwo ko-a (intransitive verb) to stand, stop, halt, stand up. 
aibwok ki-a (transitive verb) to carry on the head; to transport. 
aibwoket (plural aibwoketa) (noun F) a bier; the head (as a place for carrying). 
aibwokokin1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to throw oneself on; to attack in a rush. cp. aitukurian: to frighten. 
aibwokokin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to carry for somebody. 
aibwokor ki-a (transitive verb) to carry away. aisibwok, 
aibwolol ki-o (intransitive verb) to cry out; to wail; to moan; to squeal. 
aibwon ki-a (transitive verb) (of new wife) to share everything with a co-wife. 
aibwong ki-a (intransitive verb) to exult, acclaim; to show outwardly the joy of having won the war or gained victory. cp. aigwong. 
aibwony ki-a (transitive verb) to rip off a twig; to pull by jerks; to tug at a tree branch; to pull a rope as in tug-of-war; to strain, tweak. aibwony ajon: to suck beer ravenously. 
aibwonyar ki-a (transitive verb) to pull or tear open (of a box that has been nailed); to disrupt; to pull away from speaker. 
aibwonyun ki-a (transitive verb) to pull (towards speaker); to uproot. 
aibwor1 ki-o (intransitive verb) (of girl) to refuse to marry. ibworit apese ngin: ibworokit apese ngin ikiliok: that girl refused suitors. cp. agirokin
aibwor2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to become fierce; to rage. 
aibworar ki-a (intransitive verb) to be or to feel relieved (after illness); to give oneself a respite; to be free. alot ejakait ore aibworar: my husband went home to rest a little.
aibworit ki-o (intransitive verb) to be fierce, raging, or cruel. ibworit ejakait: mister or the chief is in a rage. ibworitor ekingok akiring: the dog is fierce on account of the meat it stole. 
aibworo ki-o (transitive verb) to bewail, weep, or cry over a stolen thing or a dead person. ibworoete kesi ikeceboro: they bewail, cry over their stolen belongings. aibworo or (often) aibworoenen: to bewail often; to weep for repeatedly. ibworos kesi ekecetunganan: they bewail their deceased male relative. aibworo aimony: to weep loudly; to cry out.
aibworokin ki-o (transitive verb) (of a man or an animal) to attack. 
aibworun ki-o (transitive verb) (of smell) to become too strong; (of smell) to waft towards the speaker; (of dog) to come towards to attack. ebworunio lokapolon asaduku: the chief would not give the box; or, the stench of the big man in the coffin is too much (for the mourners). 
aibwos ki-a (transitive verb) to pull, drag, heave; to jerk. aibwosit: to be pulling, hauling. 
aibwosar ki-a (transitive verb) to drag out; to drag away; (of a crowd) to go somewhere; to pour off (a great quantity of liquid). ebwosaros akipi: the water has flowed (out of the pot or container). ebwosaros itunga toma okosio: many people have gone for the dance. ebwosaros ikong: the white ants have swarmed. 
aibwosun ki-a (transitive verb) to pull or drag in; to drag towards oneself; to pour towards the speaker. aibwos ajon: to drink heavily (beer). 
aibwot ki-a (transitive verb) to shake out (something thick out of a narrow vessel, like butter out of gourd, or sediment out of bottle); to throw out. kibwota atitot ngin: throw that salt ash sediment. 
aibwot ko-a (intransitive verb) to migrate; to move to another place; to change place of abode. 
aibwotun ki-a (transitive verb) to take out (as yolk out of egg, butter out of gourd, as kernel out of fruit and cohesive matter in general). aibwotibwotun: to take out completely from. 
aica1 (plural acaeta, acaisia) (noun F) light; brightness; brilliance; transparency; lustre; clarity. Aica: a privately owned Ateso newspaper launched on June 7, 2003 (the proprietor was Hon. Grace Akello – the then state minister for Northern Uganda Reconstruction). aica naka akonye: the brightness of the eyes. 
aica2 ki-a (transitive verb) to disapprove; to keep despising; to regard as wrong or useless; to criticise. icait ngesi aswamuka: she/he criticised my work. 
aica3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to give light to; to shine, be light; to be transparent; to be brilliant; to dazzle, be aglow. Nyakoi neecaa amoding: the north where the desert blisters. ecai akolong: the sun shines. 
aicaar ki-a (transitive verb) to despise; to have a low opinion about; to animadvert; to blame. kecaasi eong itunga: people have developed a low opinion of me. acamun aicaario: to take the blame; to say that you are the person who did wrong. cp. aica: to criticise. 
aicab ko-a (intransitive verb) to run quickly (with long, light strides). 
aicak1 ki-a (transitive verb) to tread on; to trample down, press down; to to set foot, enter; to dare, attempt, try. aicak egaali: to ride a bicycle. aicak akimai: to trample down millet (in the granary, to compact it). mam bobo eong ecaki togokon: I will not set foot in your house again. mam eong ecaki alimun acekiro: I shall not try to say anything else. mam eong ecaki atwanare: I will not die. aicak emun ekori: to make a blunder; to get into trouble by being indiscrete (literally, to step on the snake’s tail).
aicak2 ko-a (transitive verb) to throw one after another. kocakata akito ngun kwap: throw those sticks down (one after another). 
aicakar ki-a (transitive verb) to trample away; to tread on (like grass, etc when looking for something lost.) 
aicaket (plural aicaketa) (noun F) a foot-step; a sole of foot; a sole of boot; a shoe footprint. cp. aicaketait
aicaketait (plural aicaketa) (noun F) a foot-step; a sole of foot; a sole of boot; a shoe footprint. 
aicakicak ki-a (transitive verb) to pound, mash things that are not dry. cp. airuk: pound (as of groundnuts, dry potatoes, etc). cp. airie: to grind between two stones. aicangicang: to pound anything dry or hard; to crush. 
aicakun akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to get into trouble. 
aical ko-a (transitive verb) to melt; to thin by adding yeast to beer; to liquefy (said of anything else, like adding water to something.) 
aicam ko-a (transitive verb) to take possession of; to agree; to accept; to inherit, succeed, comply, abide. kinyekinai ber eong katwana, kocam konye ereka: wait till I die before you inherit my home. 
aican ki-a (transitive verb) to pester; to annoy; to trouble; to ail. kecanete eong icuc: flies trouble me (pester me). 
aicana ki-a (intransitive verb) to be poor, troubled, afflicted. icanas isomero lu kere: all these students are poor. ecana eong: I am poor. icanasi kesi: they are poor. 
aicanakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to become poor. icanakinos bo yesi wori?: when did you become poor? wori bo kicanakinor ijo?: when did you become poor? 
aicang ki-a (transitive verb) to pound dried potatoes or cassava. cp. aicak. 
aicangicang ki-a (transitive verb) to pound dried potatoes or cassava. cp. aicakicak: to mash fresh potatoes or cassava. 
aicania ki-a (transitive verb) to pester with, annoy with; to vex with, etc. inyo bo kicania ijo eong?: why do you vex me (literally, with what do you vex or annoy me)?
aicanican ki-a (transitive verb) to lay waste; to spoil, to sin, to transgress; to waste. 
aicanicanet (plural aicanicaneta) (noun F) a sin, transgression; wastage. cp. aronus. 
aicanicanun ki-a (reflexive verb) to become spoiled; to become wasted. ecanicanun akekuwan: his body is wasting. ecanicanunos iponesioke: her/his manners have become spoiled. 
aicanicanut (singular noun F) misfortune; bad luck. 
aicanio ki-a (intransitive verb) to be passive; to suffer tribulation. 
aicanuun ki-a (intransitive verb) to be rare, deficient, uncommon, infrequent. ecanuutu akipi nuelaete kotoma akwap: clean water is getting scarce in the world. 
aicap ko-a (transitive verb) to hoe; to weed; to pluck a chicken or any bird. 
aicar ko-a (transitive verb) to beat; to strike a person on any part of his body; to slog either with stick or hand; to lash. 
aicarakam ki-a (intransitive verb) (of milk) to curdle. icarakamitos akile: the milk is curdled. cp. aikamun: (of milk) to curdle. 
aicasetait (plural aicaseta) (noun F) a base of strength; a foundation to build on; a prop to lean on.
aicasit ki-a (intransitive verb) to be supported; to be strong or well to do, energetic. kicasite kere aswam: be ready to work hard, i.e. be strong enough to work hard. icasit ekesa ngol: that man is well to do; that man is hardy. icasit ikoku karwatat: the child is supported by the wall (while learning to walk). 
aicat ki-a (intransitive verb) to stand firm or to grow strong; to convalesce or recover from sickness; (of maize) to ripen; to insist on an argument. ecat ekirididi lo: this maize has formed seed. 
aicatakin ki-a (transitive verb) to lean on as a support (in getting up); to be constant and persevering. itwani etengei karai mam icatakinit aswam: you will die of hunger unless you keep working, i.e. work constantly. 
aicaticat ki-a (intransitive verb) to improve after illness. ecaticat ngesi: she/he/it is improving (healthwise). 
aicatun ki-a (intransitive verb) to be based on; to arise from; to build on; to steady oneself. icatunit etogo lo k’ingaroi: this house is built on stones. ai bo icatunitor aitubu kon ngin?: on what is your judgement based? 
aicawa ki-a (transitive verb) to detract; to backbite or slander. 
aiceb ko-a (intransitive verb) to run quickly and lightly. 
aicebokin ki-a (transitive verb) to frequent; to come often; to do or go often for something; to do constantly; to distress often; to beset often. ecebokis Ilok aingat Katakwi: cattle rustlers have frequented raiding Katakwi. inyo bo kicebokitor ijo eong?: why do you come to worry me all the time? kacebokit eong ajokit: the devil bedevils me with temptation. 
aicec ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a wound or sore) to fester or become bigger; to become septic. aicec nak’ajimi: blood poisoning; septicaemia; toxaemia. 
aiced ko-a (intransitive verb) to stalk, walk stealthily; to walk on tiptoe; to go unobserved (intransitive verb) to spy upon secretly. ecedete itelepai togo loka apesur: the boys walk stealthily to the girls’ house. ecedi ikapa neejai emir: the cat walks stealthily towards the rat. 
aicediced1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to hop gently; to skip. 
aicediced2 ki-a (transitive verb) to prick lightly (as in tattooing or vaccinating). icedicedi edokita akan k’episo: the doctor pricks the arm with a needle. cp. aicumucum.
aicedicedun ki-a (transitive verb) to follow somebody secretly; to stalk behind. kicedicedun ne: come stalking this way. 
aicegeg ki-o (intransitive verb) to stand with feet astride, legs apart; to stand for a long time. 
aiceger ki-a (transitive verb) to plant or to put down a forked tree (or to hang things on the fork). 
aicegere (plural aicegerei) (noun F) a shelf; a fowl roost. 
aicegerikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall lightly (as of a cat falling down). abu ikapa kicegerikin omeesa: a cat fell lightly on the table. 
aicek ko-a (intransitive verb) (of weeds, of hair on body) to grow long; to grow quickly; to be overgrown; to be desolate; to fledge. ecekit Ocole atorob: the hair on Ocole’s chest is long; Ocole has a hairy chest. ecekit amisirika: my garden is overgrown with weeds. ecekit ere ngol: that home looks desolate (overgrown with grass). 
aicekicek ki-a (intransitive verb) to keep on raining a long time (used with edou: rain). ecekicek lolo edou: it has been raining incessantly today. 
aicel1 ki-a (transitive verb) (of infection) to cause a swelling in the groin or pain in groin. 
aicel2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to scold at; to rave, sound hollow; to flare up; to use harsh language. 
aicelel ki-a (intransitive verb) to be conspicuous; to dominate; to be very big; (of big men, animals and things) to be visible from afar. etogo loicelelei: a high-rise building. iceleleete itogoi lu: these houses are prominent (high-rise). 
aicem ki-a (transitive verb) to squeeze the stomach with the knees (this is done by women with the idea to procure an abortion or to relieve pain. A small girl kneels on her stomach and presses the woman's abdomen with her knees)
aicemakin ki-a (transitive verb) to touch or press lightly. 
aicer ko-o (transitive verb) to have or leave stripes or lines or traces of a liquid. abu Icodat kocer akiyo: Icodat had furrows on her cheeks (formed by his tears). ecerit ikoku akile: the child has traces of milk on it (after drinking or sucking milk). 
aicerer ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a rider down the slope and on free gear) to move very fast, quickly. icererei epikipik: the motorcycle freewheels. (note: not used of human beings or animals) 
aicererear ki-a (intransitive verb) to move or ride fast away from speaker. 
aicerereun ki-o (reflexive verb) to move or ride fast towards speaker. ecerereun egaali neka: a bicycle came fast towards me. kicerereu lailo: move fast this way. 
aicet akwap ko-a (intransitive verb) to shuffle feet on the ground.
aicib1 ki-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to plait (as a basket or mat); to weave rope into a net for fishing or hunting; to interlace; to braid, take a nip. cp. aicip.
aicib2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to sip, drink or smoke a little. kocib akipi kilikoria ekia: drink a little water to swallow the medicine. 
aicicik ki-a (transitive verb) to bleach; (of a cloth in water) to lose colour. 
aicicikwa ki-a (intransitive verb) to change colour (in washing). 
aicicit akonye ki-o (transitive verb) to lift head and look around; to be too curious. cp. aiyilit akonye.
aicid ki-a (transitive verb) to scrape (as of a pot); to wipe dry with finger (usually of plate of vegetables). 
aicidar ki-a (transitive verb) to empty roughly; to wipe off thoroughly. kicidaa asaanit ngin: wipe that plate thoroughly clean (with your forefinger). 
aicigiciga ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk or run unsteadily (like one having sore joints). 
aicik1 (adverb) exceedingly. ainyam aicik: to eat exceedingly. aimat ajon aicik: to drink beer excessively. cp. aitelekaar. 
aicik2 ki-a (transitive verb) to press or squeeze. aicik akoik: (of women) to press the stomach to procure an abortion. aicik akan: to make fingerprints; to sign with thumb (as of one who cannot write); to swear not to do. 
aicik3 ki-a (transitive verb) to warn the host (before a beer party takes place) of one’s coming, so that she/he can prepare; to invite somebody to pay a visit; to take preventive measures; to warn against (as hiding beer against undesirable visitors, or warn a girl against a bad boy). 
aicikakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to promise to pay a visit. 
aicikakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to surpass; to press on; to clamp; to keep down, hold down.  erait epaaba kon noi aicikakin: your cotton surpasses all others in pods. kicikak apapulai ngun k’amoru: press those papers down with a stone. aicikakin akan: to sign with a thumb. icikakit ikapa emir kwap: the cat is holding down a rat. cp. aitelekaar
aicikakinet (plural aicikakineta) (noun F) a promise of a visit; a cue or a hint (communicated through pressing the other one’s hand or other part of the body); a stamping, a pressing or embossing (by impressing with something). 
aiciket (plural aiciketa) (noun F) a stamp; an impression (object). 
aicikicik ki-a (transitive verb) to press down; to exceed.
aicikun ki-a (transitive verb) to press down. aicikun akoik: to procure an abortion. cp. aijecun. 
aicil ko-a (transitive verb) to split, break open; to tear. kobu nepe ecila kide: come at daybreak or come at dawn. aicil egoe: to tear a dress. aicil erot: to cut a road (through the bush); to make room through the crowd. aicil epelu: to take on a task (also used when starting to plough a furrow, shouting to oxen ‘aicil’: start and get on). 
aicing ko-a (intransitive verb) to make way through a narrow passage. kocing imor ngul: go (and squeeze yourself) between those mountains. 
aicip ki-a (transitive verb) (Usuk) to weave; to plait (of nets and mats); to knit, intertwine. cp. aicib.
aicipakin ki-a (transitive verb) to place child on mother’s back; to weave or plait for someone else. 
aicipar ki-a (intransitive verb) to sit with legs outstretched i.e. to be idle; to stretch legs; to rest. kapas eong aswam, alosi aicipar: I am tired of working, I am going to sit down (with legs outstretched). 
aicir ki-a (transitive verb) to milk. cp. ailep, aidal. 
aicirio ki-a (passive verb) to be milked; to be able to give milk. akiteng na mam ekoto aicirio: this cow does not want to be milked. 
aicirun ki-a (transitive verb) to milk for oneself. akile nu nan pac ecirunio: fresh milk. 
aico ko-a (intransitive verb) to beware; to be mindful; to be cute, shrewd, careful; to be wise, clever; to be bashful, timid, shy. etelepat lo eco noi: this boy is very clever. eco ngesi noi: she/he/it is very timid, shy. sirikico: sirikiyong: do not be shy. cp. ecobe.
aicoca ki-a (transitive verb) to bring to bay, cause a fight for life.
aicoce ki-a (transitive verb) to hate everybody. 
aicoco ki-a (transitive verb) to water flowers, crops, etc; to sprinkle water on flowers or anything as on floor before sweeping; to spill; to urinate voluntarily or otherwise as of men or children. ingai kicocoi akile togo: who has been spilling milk on the floor? 
aicocom ki-o (intransitive verb) to cause others to fight; to urge on into a fight; to exaggerate evil; to egg on; to instigate. icocomono etunganan lo: this man is fond of exaggerating mistakes of others. 
aicod1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to limp or walk on one leg. 
aicod2 ko-a (transitive verb) to pierce slightly. abu ekukwai kocod akamopiira: a thorn pierced my tyre. 
aicodicod1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to run on one leg; to keep limping; to prick or pick repeatedly like a bird, or like a person pricking with a needle or anything pointed. kicodicodi ijo kwapekwangin: go on limping like that, go on trying (said of anybody trying hard to do a thing). 
aicodicod2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to walk or run on one leg. aicodokin: to limp on account of. ecodokin ngesi ejose: she/he has pretended to limp (in order to shirk work); she/he feigns limping. aicodor: to limp away. 
aicodo ki-o (intransitive verb) to limp, hobble; to go on one leg; to be paralysed; to wobble or to be a cripple. icodoi ngesi: she/he limps. 
aicoge ki-o (intransitive verb) to walk with a walking stick; to poke with a stick. aicoge alosit: to walk like a tall man. 
aicogeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to prop; to strut, prop oneself up with the elbow or bent leg or stick. 
aicoger ki-a (transitive verb) to make in an awkward shape; to make (a chain) roughly; to place poles as in the beginning of a building. 
aicogeun ki-a (intransitive verb) to be painful; to sting (of pain) in the stomach; to have a stinging pain in the stomach. kecogeunit eong ibore kotoma akoik: I have a stinging pain in the stomach. 
aicogiar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to impugn; to pain very much; to prop up; to poke.
aicogiar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to tell off straight away; to attack at once; to assault as soon as a person appears. inyo bo kicogiara jo eong?: why did you tell me off like that? 
aicogoor kwap ki-o (transitive verb) to raise and support; to stay. kicogoo asoto ngin: lift and support the top of that grain store (to take out the food). cp. adakar. 
aicok ki-a (transitive verb) to make (water) foul by stirring up dirt; to make foul, dirty. kinyek aicok akipi ngun: don’t dirty that water (i.e. do not stir up dirt in the water). 
aicoka ki-a (intransitive verb) (of fruit or grain) to ripen. icokaete akimai: the millet is seeding. 
aicokaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to form seed or grain. ecokaikis imomwa: the sorghum is seeding. 
aicoki ki-o (transitive verb) to herd, to feed cattle; to follow (somebody or something) everywhere. icokie ngol aberuke acok: he follows his wife everywhere (to prevent other men committing adultery with her). 
aicokicok ki-a (transitive verb) to make wet; to drizzle continually; (of eyes) to be teary. cp. otojoto: rain again after a pause, so called because it lulls one to sleep. icokicoki edou akwap: it drizzles. 
aicokun ki-a (reflexive verb) to be stirred as of water (transitive verb) to dirty by stirring. ecokunos akipi: the water is foul. 
aicola ki-a (transitive verb) (of potatoes, eyes) to be watery. icolaete akonye akiyo: the eyes flow with tears. 
aicolakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be watery. ecolakis acok komanaka: the potatoes are becoming watery in my garden. 
aicole ko-a (intransitive verb) (of blood) to be watery, not quite red and healthy. 
aicoleikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of blood, milk) to become watery (for). ecoleikis aokot kakuwan: the blood in the body has become watery. 
aicolia akeje ki-a (intransitive verb) not to walk in line or in step. icoliai ngesi akeje: she/he walks out of step. aicolia awoore: to sing out of tune. aicolia abolia: to play a bad game. cp. ailolior.
aicolicol ki-a (intransitive verb) (of eyes, wound) to be teary, watery. 
aicolong ki-o (transitive verb) to rest one’s head on a pillow; to be seated on a chair, etc; to subdue, subjugate. abu kadum ngesi icolongit amoru: I found him seated on a stone. 
aicolonget (plural aicolongeta) (noun F) neck rest; head support or pillow. cp. amuteete
aicom ki-a (transitive verb) to beat grain; to thresh, jostle, or press; (in fighting) to press down with hands or feet. kicom akimai ngun: thresh that millet. aicom alup: to knead earth into mortar. 
aicoman ki-a (transitive verb) (of a woman) to menstruate; to put on adoobe (rags worn by women during menstruation). 
aicome ki-a (transitive verb) to spread lies and disaffection to cause a fight; to slander, or to cause a fight. icomei ngesi: icomeete kesi: she/he (they) slander her/him (them). cp. aisiom. asabakin.
aicomeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to tell, to spread lies about; to be dissatisfied with. 
aicomel ki-o (intransitive verb) to have an oval, pointed narrow head. 
aicop ko-a (transitive verb) to put hot water in fresh ajon (traditional beer); to begin to do something intentionally; to start an action. aicop ajon: to place a pot of beer before guests. cp. aige. 
aicoper ki-o (transitive verb) (of finger, ears, etc) to point upwards (intransitive verb) (of a new plant) to grow upwards; (of hair, etc) to point upwards; to point straight up. 
aicor ki-a (intransitive verb) to conspire; to arrange or settle privately, incite. icoras yesi aibunga eong: you are conspiring to beat me, i.e. you are inciting each other to beat me. 
aicor ki-a (transitive verb) to exhort, urge, persuade, or induce; to warn or instigate. kecorit eong ijo sirikilot ore: I warn you not to go home. cp. eicor: to incite each other or one another. loicoritai: one who has been warned to keep a secret. aicor ekingok: to teach a dog to hunt. aicor imongin: to urge fighting bulls on. cp. aitusup. 
aicorakin ki-a (transitive verb) to command, bid, or demand action; to give an order; to dictate; to advise. kecorakit eong ijo alosit: I order you to go. abu kecorak nges apaikin: I advised her/him to stop.
aicorakinet (plural aicorakineta) (noun F) a command; an injunction; a charge; a commission; an order; a mandate; a regulation; an edict; a counsel. ejai ijo aitodol aicorakinet naka ejakait: you have to obey the chief’s order. 
aicorakitoi ki-a (transitive verb) to force to. mam eong akoto aicorakitoi: I do not want to be forced. 
aicorar1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to persuade oneself; to induce one another. ecoraros idwe toma aboliakec: children have induced one another to go and play. 
aicorar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to win the heart or sympathy of somebody; to persuade to one’s side. abu Malinga kicora imukopin owaike: Malinga persuaded the commoners to side with him. 
aicoret (plural aicoreta) (noun F) counsel; instruction (from a teacher); advice. aingitun aicoret kaneejai itunganan: to ask for someone’s advice.
aicori ki-a (transitive verb) to fetch water (from the well). kicoriata akipi: fetch water (from the well).
aicoricor ki-a (transitive verb) to sprinkle; to scatter water over. kicoricor akipi toma akopit ngun: sprinkle water on that fibre.
aicororikin1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of animals) to be pregnant. cp. aigaun. 
aicororikin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to pour on; to pour in drops i.e. slowly. kicororikit bian edou: it rained (a little) yesterday. 
aicorun ki-o (reflexive verb) to plot together while approaching here. ecorunos kesi aiar nges: they plotted to kill him. 
aicu ko-a (transitive verb) to squeeze or press out liquid; to wring (as of clothes.) 
aicua ki-a (intransitive verb) (of meat) to exude liquid; to be juicy. 
aicucaun ki-a (transitive verb) to drain off liquid in salt making. 
aicucuk ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a new cloth after first washing) to bleach, fade, change colour; to lose colour. egoe lo etapit aicucuk: this cloth often loses its colour in washing. cp. aicicikwa.
aicucukwa ki-a (intransitive verb) (of cloth) to lose colour in washing; to be colour dirty. cp. aicicikwa. 
aicud ko-a (intransitive verb) to practice witchcraft for bad purpose. cp. aipyed: to bewitch, etc. aipolia: to use anti-witchcraft means on the crops. 
aicuicuita ki-a (intransitive verb) to chirp or chirrup. 
aicuk ki-a (transitive verb) to clean millet or sorghum by pounding it slightly in a mortar to remove chaff. cp. aicur or aicang: to pound dry potatoes or cassava into powder using a mortar. cp. airuk: to pound groundnuts to paste.
aicuk ki-o (transitive verb) to pump (as pumping water, air into bicycle or bellows for a forge); to walk like a lame man (as if one leg is short). 
aicuke ki-a (intransitive verb) to incite to fight. icukei ngesi itunga: she/he incites people. cp. aicome.
aicukeanut (singular noun F) incitement or being fond of intrigue. 
aicukokin ki-o (transitive verb) to dance with bells tied to legs; to syncopate the musical instruments. cp. ailejakin. 
aicukor ki-o (transitive verb) to peddle (a bicycle) quickly away. kicukoo egaali oiduka: peddle the bicycle quickly to the shops. kicukoo akeje: run fast. 
aicukul ki-o (transitive verb) to make holes or bumps, make bumpy. kinyek aicukul erot kwangin: do not make the road bumpy so. icukulete imotokan irotin: motor vehicles make the roads bumpy. 
aicukulikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall into a hole; to go over a bump. ecukulikinos itunga toma acukulen: people have fallen into the ditches. 
aicukun ki-o (transitive verb) to peddle quickly this way (on a bicycle) or run very quickly (on foot). kicuku egaali lailo: peddle quickly this way. kicuku akeju lailo: run quickly this way. 
aicul1 ki-a (transitive verb) to heap up; to dump, lump, congest, or agglomerate. 
aicul2 ko-o (transitive verb) to mix hot and cold; to cool, or to mix sweet and sour; to mitigate or to palliate. kocul esupu lo, emwana noi: cool down this soup, it is too hot. 
aicul3 ko-o (transitive verb) to stain, blemish, disgrace. enapit ngesi egoe loeculitoi neereng: she/he wears a red-striped garment. sirikicul erekon: do not disgrace your family. 
aiculakin ki-a (transitive verb) to heap up for somebody; to cumber; to dump for (reflexive verb) to accumulate; to mount up. eculakinos agasia togokon: the rubbish has accumulated in your house. 
aicular ki-a (reflexive verb) (of anything) to heap up; to accumulate, mount up. ecularos apeseninikon: your debts have mounted. 
aiculat (plural aiculan) (noun F) a heap; a pile; accumulation. 
aiculurikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to rest on top; to be on top (transitive verb) to put on top. adum eong apupu iculurikina kuju atitipu: I found a hedge-hog on top of an anthill. 
aicum ki-a (transitive verb) to stab; to pierce; to spear; to prick; to puncture. aicumio k’ikukwa: to be pierced with thorns. icumitai amopiiraka k’ikukwa: they have punctured my tyre with thorns. aicum epiiso: to inject or inoculate (with a needle). aicumun ebeele: (especially by double-dealing women at a dance) to start a fight (by courting two men).
aicumakin1 acukumac ki-a (intransitive verb) to brand with fire. koyautu akituk kicumanakinai acukumac: bring the cattle to be branded. 
aicumakin2 akou ki-a (intransitive verb) to recline head on fingers or on the whole palm as a sign of sorrow. cp. aiturur. inyo bo lolo icumakinitor ijo akan amatenget, iomit anyoika?: why do you recline your head, what are you thinking about? 
aicumakin3 ki-a (transitive verb) to pour in or on. kicumak akipi amot, kimwa bo oni ai?: pour a little water in the pot, after all how many are we? aicumakin ki-a (transitive verb) to spear for someone or somewhere. kolot kicumakinai ebileng: go and spear a mudfish for me. 
aicumakin4 ki-o (reflexive verb) to spear oneself; to commit suicide by spearing or stabbing; to spear or stab for someone. 
aicumar ki-a (transitive verb) to have an acute pain (anywhere). kecumarit eong ibore esyep: I have pain in my side. 
aicumet (plural aicumeta) (noun F) a fork; something for piercing or for spearing. 
aicumetait (plural aicumeta) (noun F) a wound from a stab. 
aicumul ki-a (transitive verb) (of anything) to put into small heaps. 
aicumulikin ki-a (transitive verb) (anything) to put into small heaps. 
aicun ko-a (transitive verb) to bend as of bow or archway; to make horns of a bull meet each other like an arch. ecuni ngesi erute lok’ere: she/he is making an archway in front of her/his house. ecuni ngesi emong: she/he is making the bull’s horns narrower. aicun ekek: to make the entrance narrower. 
aicuny ki-a (intransitive verb) to dab; to mark or tick off with a writing instrument; to dip. mam ijo ijeni aicuny edia: you do not know how to dab vegetables (by dipping the food slightly in the sauce). 
aicunyanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep dipping, as of a duck dipping its head into or under water; to keep dabbing on like one washing a wound or cleaning it; to dip lightly into the liquid. aicuny ebokorit toma akile: to dip the finger in the milk. 
aicup ko-o (transitive verb) to pick out (from here and there); to gather; to single out. sirikicupucup, kolema kere: do not single out, take them all. 
aicur1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to leap with joy; to play or dance, jump about for joy; to jubilate, be gay; to rejoice, enjoy oneself; to effervesce. icuros apesur: the girls are playing, enjoying themselves. 
aicur2 ki-o (transitive verb) to thresh in a mortar; to pound; to extract. kicur alos ejok: thresh the millet well. 
aicurun ki-o (reflexive verb) to come prancing about; to come running like a kid. itelepai, kicurunos lailo: boys, come playing this way. 
aicut ki-a (transitive verb) to destroy or finish off one by one. adau egwang aicut imiyoi: the wild cat has finished off the chicks (snatching them one at a time). cp. airikakin. 
aicutakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to finish for somebody; to refuse to do again, make up one’s mind, not to do again; to resolve never to do again. akoto eong aicutakin aswamuke: I want to finish off his work. ecutakin eong abunenen orekon: I shall make up my mind never to visit you again. cp. aisilakin.
aicutar ki-a (transitive verb) to finish off, to kill off well, deplete, despatch. aswam kere naiswamai ijo, ejok aicutar ngesi: whatever you do, finish it well. icuta ijo akonikiro?: is that all you have to say? 
aicuwa ki-a (intransitive verb) to be porous; (of a wound) to ooze. 
aicwal ko-a (intransitive verb) to cause to melt. cp. aical
aicwala ki-a (intransitive verb) (of potatoes and cassava which are old and watery) to be watery and tasteless. ecwalata acok: the potatoes are watery (when cooked). 
aicwe ki-a (transitive verb) to burn, set on fire, put fire to; to fire, ignite, light. cp. ainok: to be on fire, burning, alight. 
aicween ki-a (transitive verb) to mock; to ridicule. inyo bo kicweenia ijo eong?: why do you mock (ridicule) me?
aicweikin ki-a (transitive verb) to set fire to; to burn, fire, ignite. cp. aicwe. 
aicweis (plural aicweisia) (noun F) an incinerator. 
aicwenikin ki-a (transitive verb) to ridicule; to mock. 
aicweyet (plural aicweyeta) (noun F) ordeal by fire; an incinerator; a burner. 
aida1 ki-a (transitive verb) to bury; to dig under. aida lukatwak: burial (of the dead).
aida2 ko-a (transitive verb) to lash, to whip, castigate; to beat the floor of a house (to level it); to scourge; to thrash millet, sorghum, etc. koda etogo: beat the floor of the house. aida k’ebela: to thrash; to drub. adaenenoo: to be beaten, to be allowed to be beaten. mam aberu adaeneno: a woman should not be beaten. 
aidaanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep burying in, digging under (as of weeds). kidaanak ekoropot lo kwap: keep digging this weed (ekoropot) under. 
aidaanar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep taking away; to keep pilfering. ejai ibore idaanari imiyoika kane: something keeps snatching my chicks. 
aidaar ki-a (transitive verb) to pilfer, take away. edaa nan egwang akakokor: the wild cat took away my hen this morning.
aidac1 akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to throw out words; to speak at random; to talk nonsense; to talk foolishly. kinyek aidac einer: do not talk irresponsibly. 
aidac2 ko-a (transitive verb) to throw thick matter (like mud or any semi-liquid matter) (not used of solids nor liquids); to throw bad things (dung, etc) at/on something hard. edaci ngesi alupot toma arwatat: she/he throws mud on the wall. 
aidadaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away secretly (reflexive verb) to abscond. 
aidadakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give secretly (of poison or anything). 
aidadat ki-a (transitive verb) to steal secretly. cp. aijolilit. 
aidadaun ki-o (reflexive verb) to come secretly, stealthily (at night or during the day); to bring secretly. edadaunos ikokolak bian oreka: thieves came to my home secretly yesterday. 
aidaet (plural aidaeta) (noun F) a burial; a thing for burying; a shroud. 
aidaidaar ki-a (transitive verb) a corruption of aidadaar: to take or steal secretly; to pilfer; to smuggle. 
aidaidaun ki-o (reflexive verb) a corruption of aidadaun: to come unnoticed, unaware; to come upon unnoticed. idaidaun atwanare aidaidaun: death comes without timing. idaidaunos ikokolak: thieves come secretly. 
aidaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to bury in. idaikinio ngesi togoke: she/he will be buried in her/his house. 
aidak1 ko-a (transitive verb) to carry; to rear a child. kodak ikoku kon kojokan: carry your child well. 
aidak2 ko-a (transitive verb) to lift up; to carry in the hands or on the laps. edakit ngesi akou tai: she/he has no brains; she/he carries her/his head about for nothing. cp. ainap: to carry on the back, or on the carrier of a bicycle.
aidal ki-a (transitive verb) (of a person) to milk straight into the mouth; to squirt from teat. idali etelepat akiteng: the boy milks from the udder direct to his mouth. 
aidam ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk with toes spread out; (of child) to toddle; (of old men or children) to totter; to hobble along. 
aidamidam ki-a (transitive verb) to soak; to make thoroughly wet; to drench. abu edou kedamidam eong: I was thoroughly drenched by the rain. cp. aidemidem. 
aidanga ki-a (transitive verb) to cut or divide into big pieces. mam akoto ijo aidanga akakiring: I do not like you to cut my meat into very big chunks. 
aidangakin ki-a (transitive verb) to cut a large piece (of meat, etc) for somebody else. 
aidangidang ki-a (transitive verb) to undertake what one cannot do; to try the impossible; to make too thick; to make too big. kinyek aidangidang etogo naarai mam ipedori aiduk nges: do not attempt to build such a big house, because you cannot finish it. 
aidangun ki-a (transitive verb) to cut a big piece for oneself. 
aidany1 ki-a (transitive verb) to make hard by trampling; to trample down or on; to flatten out. kinyekis aidany akacok: do not trample down my potatoes (intransitive verb) to be flat. idanyito atenueik nuk’etekwa: the branches of the etekwa tree are flat (branch out like umbrella). cp. aijany.
aidany2 ko-a (transitive verb) to kill or take many; to massacre; to kill a great number of; to slaughter; to ravage. edanyit ekodoi itunga kane: small-pox killed many people here. abu eloket kodany idwe luko Ngariam okaru 2001: the Karimojong cattle rustlers massacred the children of Ngariam in 2001. (transitive verb) to live long; to finish food - eating all or nearly all; eat much. sirikidany atap: do not finish all the millet bread. aidany ikar swi: to live for many years.
aidanyakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to squat down; (of a child) getting up and falling down, unable yet to walk. kidanyakinos nen: squat down there. 
aidanyany ki-a (intransitive verb) to be sitting down doing nothing. kanukinyo idanyanyaata yesi kane?: why are you sitting here idle? 
aidao (singular noun F) a funeral; a burial; interment. cp. aidaet. 
aidap ko-a (transitive verb) to bypass; to go alongside; to put at the side of (as grass or anything at the side of house or road). kodap akituk ngun koreu kes lailo: go alongside those cows and lead them this way. 
aidapal ki-a (transitive verb) to make flat; (of hilly or bumpy place) to flatten. 
aidar aijar (singular noun F) hygiene; safety; care for one’s life. 
aidar ki-a (transitive verb) to wait for; to watch; to guard, keep or protect; to expect. idarete ikweny abeeikec: birds protect their eggs. 
aidarakin ki-a (transitive verb) to watch for (in place of) someone; to mind for. kidarakinai eong ere: mind my home for me. 
aidarar ki-a (transitive verb) to await somebody in order to let him/her do something, or in order to tell or send him somewhere immediately. edarit eong Omongin aingit acekiro: I am ready waiting for Omongin to ask him something. keker ngesi ngina aponi kidararai ainom: when she/he ran away she/he found them waiting ready to beat her/him.
aidare ki-a (transitive verb) to await; to wait for. cp. aidareun. kidareunoi: wait for me. (1st person: edarei eong. 2nd person plural: idareete. Imperative: kidare (plural: kidareoto).
aidareikin ki-o (transitive verb) to wait a little for, have patience. kidareik, alosi aitac ijo: have a little patience, I am going to pay you. 
aidares (plural aidaresa) (noun F) a prison, waiting room or place; a dungeon; an ambush; a lying in wait; watching; guarding; waiting. cp. aidaresa
aidaret (plural aidareta) (noun F) a prison, a waiting room or place; a dungeon; an ambush; a lying in wait; watching; guarding; waiting. cp. aidaris
aidareun ki-a (transitive verb) to watch out for; to wait for; to wait; to bide. kidareu akiro nukiponikito ijo: wait for what will befall you. 
aidario (singular noun F) conservation; protection; custody. 
aidaris (plural aidarisia) (noun F) a prison; a waiting room or place; a dungeon; an ambush; a lying in wait; watching; guarding; waiting. cp. aidares
aidarit ki-a (transitive verb) to be awaiting for; to be watching; to be guarding or protecting; to be expecting. 
aidat1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to lie in ambush; to keep motionless. idasit ekokolan: the thief is lying in ambush. 
aidat2 ko-a (transitive verb) to clear bush to make a garden; to make a new field. cp. akor. 
aidatakin ki-a (transitive verb) to lie in ambush for someone; to remain silent; to refuse to answer. cp. aililingikin. 
aidaudaun ki-a (transitive verb) to raise (as of dust, etc). idaudau ijo apua: you raise the dust (by dancing). (intransitive verb) to rise, come up (as of dust, vapour, clouds, mist); to wave in the wind (as of feathers, banners, leaves, etc). edaudaun apua kokau k'emotoka: the dust has risen behind the motorcar. edaudaunos ajul nuk’ekweny kokwam: the bird has lovely soft feathers waving in the wind. 
aidaudawonokin (transitive verb) to raise (dust, etc) continually to annoy somebody. kinyek aidau- dawonokin eong apua: stop raising the dust to annoy me. 
aidayo (singular noun F) a burial; interment. cp. anukio.
aide1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (said of anthill when it has holes everywhere for white ants to swarm). ideit atitipu na: this anthill has many little exits (akonye - eyes) for the white ants to swarm. (note: these little eyes or holes are made by termites just before white ants swarm). 
aide2 ko-a (transitive verb) to pluck vegetables; to gather fruit; to pick cotton; to knock down fruits from the tree; to speak a language fluently. edei ngesi Ateso aide: she/he speaks Ateso fluently. edeete itunga epaaba: people are picking cotton. (intransitive verb) (of a hard object) to crack; to break slightly. adea eikopo: the cup has cracked. sirikide eikopo: do not crack the cup. cp. aicil
aidec ki-a (transitive verb) to crush, pound fine, beat (as of mud, or soft things); to batter. aidec akou nak’emun: to crush the head of a snake (intransitive verb) to go on raining without stopping. abu bian edou kidec akware kiya: it rained the whole night yesterday. 
aidecakin ki-a (transitive verb) to crush, to pound for; to step or stand on. kidecakinai eong emaido lo: crush, pound fine this groundnuts for me. edicaki amoru ekabokorit: a stone has crushed my toe. sirikidicak akejuka: do not step (or stand) on my foot. abu eong kedicak luk'asurupika: I crushed my enemies. cp. airiecakin. 
aidecidec ki-a (transitive verb) to keep on beating (as of fresh or wet sisal, etc). 
aidecidecaar ki-a (transitive verb) to make, cut into pulp (as of groundnuts). 
aidede1 (singular noun F) eruption (as of wound or rinderpest). 
aidede2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to come out, into; (of a sore) to develop; to come to a head; (of a boil) to have pustules. 
aidedeun ki-a (intransitive verb) to appear (transitive verb) to straighten out (folds of cloth or anything). kidedeu atorob: chest out! expose your chest. 
aidediar ki-o (reflexive verb) (of anything) to lie on the back, right side up, or face up. cp. abuburiar: to lie on face, face down, prone or upside down. kidediar!: lie on your back!. kobuburiar: lie on your stomach! koper eidedia!: lie on your back (transitive verb) to put on the back or right side up or face up; to turn face up. kidedia asaanit ngin: turn that plate up. 
aideerakin ki-a (transitive verb) (of cattle or things or soldiers or boys) to put in a line. kideerak akituk elosete aimat: let the cows go to drink in a file. edeerikinos isirikaalei: the soldiers are lined up (intransitive verb) to go straight without deviating. edeeriki ngesi erot: she/he has gone straight ahead. aideerakin itim: to shave the head, leaving lines. 
aideerikin ki-a (transitive verb) to carry a load on the head freely, not touching it. 
aideide ki-a (transitive verb) to report; to tell on; to whisper, inform; to betray; to accuse. alosi eong aideide nukon kaneejai papaka: I am going to tell (on you to) my father. cp. alimor.
aideidea ki-a (transitive verb) to whisper; to talk softly.
aideideikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to whisper to someone’s ears. inyo bo nan ideideikini ijo ngesi?: what did you whisper into her/his ears? kideideikinai: whisper it to me. cp. aiweiweikin.
aideikin ki-a (transitive verb) to leave something over or to someone else. kideikinai eong da ajon adis: leave a little beer for me too (reflexive verb) to be left over for someone. 
aidek1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to click the tongue in disapproval. 
aidek2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a penis) to be erect. 
aidekar ki-a (intransitive verb) to refuse, disapprove, despise, show contempt by making a clicking sound with the tongue. cp. aikedar. 
aidekek ki-o (intransitive verb) to be sticking up; to protrude, stick out. idekekei akitoi kanen, kocoite: there is a protruding stick there, be careful. 
aidekereun ki-a (transitive verb) to put one side up; to lift up eyelids. kidekereu abukio: look out (lift your eyelids). 
aidekeriar ki-a (reflexive verb) (of grass, etc) to bend upwards; (of tail of squirrel when running) to stick up; (of a piece of wood on the ground) sticking up. 
aidekerikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to dare to attack; (of a small person, etc) to hang onto. abu eong kedekerikin nges lokatuman: I beat him (though he is much bigger). edekerikinos luk’ocaalo kwi luk’otaun kotoma aboliasinei: those teams from up-country beat those from town in sports. abu Daudi kidekerikin Goliasi: David dared Goliath. 
aidekidek ki-a (transitive verb) to stop a cow, etc with a click of the tongue; to call chickens by clicking the tongue. 
aidekidekun ki-a (transitive verb) to click with tongue to halt; to make to go slowly or stand (used only of cattle when out of hand - to stop them, make them listen - usually when milking). 
aidel1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to impose on someone's kindness. idela ikoku kaneejai tataake: the child imposes on the kindness of a grand mother (confident, trusting in). 
aidel2 ki-a (transitive verb) to show off; to swank with; to be ostentatious. ideli ekesa ngol itunga k'egaalike: he shows off with his bicycle. 
aidelanut (intransitive verb) to be fond of showing off proudly. 
aidelel ki-o (intransitive verb) to protrude; to be conspicuous; to be visible; to stand out; to be prominent, evident, exposed, pellucid, or tremendous. ideleleete akiro ngun: those things are very clear. idelelei ngesi noi kotoma ojako: she/he is very conspicuous amongst chiefs. idelelei Soroti kane: Soroti is very prominent from here. 
aidelun ki-a (transitive verb) to persuade, advise, prevail on, or to influence. kidelu ekesa ngol ketegwel ngesi eong akiteng ngin: persuade that man to sell me that cow. cp. aijodo. 
aidem ko-a (transitive verb) to confiscate; to rob; to plunder, snatch from. sirikidem iboro k’itunga: do not rob people of their things. sirikidem itunga iborokec: do not rob people of their possessions. 
aidemidem ki-a (transitive verb) to make soft; to soak; to make damp; to drench. edemidem edou ekapale: the rain has soaked my pants. idemececas ikaperito: my beddings are very wet. 
aideng1 ki-o (transitive verb) to cut round slightly (not to cut through). 
aideng2 ko-o (transitive verb) to beat once but very hard. ikoku yenerono edengi nges papake: a bad child is severely beaten by his father. edengedengeete kwi imongin noi: those guys beat bulls very much. 
aideng3 ko-o (transitive verb) to drink out in one go. 
aideng4 ko-o (transitive verb) to pluck fruit or vegetables. edengi ngesi araito: she/he plucks fruits. cp. aide, aidim. 
aidenge ki-o (intransitive verb) to do alone, by oneself. edengei eong aiduk ekatogo: I have to build my house alone. idengeete yesi ikusinyamat?: are you eating by yourselves? 
aidengeria ki-a (intransitive verb) to produce fruit in great quantities. ikito ngul idengeriato noi: those trees are laden with fruit. 
aidengideng ki-o (transitive verb) (of a ring) to cut a finger; to cut round something (such as a tree) and leave the middle uncut 
aidengokin ki-o (transitive verb) to surround, go in front to stop running; to stay. kidengok ikokolak ngul: go round and intercept those thieves. 
aideny1 (noun F) intention; a set purpose. 
aideny2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to prepare oneself, be prepared, be ready. idenyit ijo alosit: you are ready to go. 
aideny3 ki-a (transitive verb) to have intentions of doing something good or bad; to intend, determine, premeditate. ejaas nuidenyit ijo kaneka: you are loath me. 
aidenyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to have evil intentions against someone; to annoy somebody. kidenyakinit ijo eong apaarasia kere: it is always your intention to harm me. cp. aicebokin. 
aidenyakinet (plural aidenyakineta) (noun F) determination. 
aidenyit ki-a (intransitive verb) to have a mind to; to be determined; aim at, intend. edenyit eong abunere orekon: I am determined to come to your home. 
aidep1 ki-a (transitive verb) to pick, gather; (of animals or birds) to pick white ants or food. kolot aidep akito: go and gather firewood (intransitive verb) to talk a lot; to babble. idepi ikoku: the child talks a lot or has cried for a long time. 
aidep2 ko-a (transitive verb) to exceed or go beyond; to tuck in or under. kidep aitiiba: tuck in the mosquito net. aidep ekek: fill the openings in or at the side of the door against mosquitoes. 
aidepidep ki-a (transitive verb) to gossip, tell tales about, or spread rumours. 
aidepidepanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be a tale-teller. 
aider1 ki-a (transitive verb) to set a broken or fractured bone right; to solder a piece of iron; to poise, set, put up a pole for support. akoto aider ekatogo: I want to put a pole under the roof of my house (to support it). aider akoit: to set broken bones using splints or Plaster of Paris.
aider2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to cross (a river) going along a fallen tree or rope. kider ekitoi kocoite ilatar: go gently along that tree (crossing a river) but do not fall (slip). 
aider3 ki-o (transitive verb) to go straight along a path without deviating; to speak the truth; to go straight ahead. kidero cut ilosi: go straight ahead. etubi ejakait akiro ideritos: the chief settles cases justly. aiteder akiro: to justify; to settle justly; to make straight; to rectify matters. 
aideranakin ki-a (transitive verb) to plant far apart; to spread out; to put in order, plant at regular distance. kideranak ikito irai: plant the trees far apart. (reflexive verb) to be far apart, scarce, to be few. ideranakina itunga oitela ngol: there are a few people in that parish. 
aideranakina ki-o (reflexive verb) (of plants) to be scanty, sparse, few, scarce, or patchy 
aiderer ki-o (intransitive verb) to be straight, direct; (of speech) to be clear; to be straight forward. idererei erot ngol: that road is straight. idererei einer kon: what you say is clear (you are not beating about the bush). 
aideriar ki-a (transitive verb) to freewheel. 
aiderikin ki-a (transitive verb) a corruption of aidarekin: to wait for somebody awhile. kiderik papa kon abunit: wait awhile for your father. 
aidet1 ki-a (transitive verb) to fish with a hook; to wash clean or thoroughly; to look sharply at; to stare at. alosi eong aidet agaria: I am going to fish. kidet akaisuuka: wash my sheet well. aidesit icop: to stare or gaze without blinking (with eyes wide-open). idesit ngesi akonye: she/he looks very severely and sternly, i.e. she/he has a very stern and severe look. aidetakit akonye: to stare or gaze at.
aidet2 ki-a (transitive verb) to kill quickly; to despatch after having been nearly killed. apotu kesi kidetata emorotot eapie atwanare: they killed off the python when it was nearly dead. 
aidet3 ko-a (transitive verb) to send particles (of anything) flying; to scatter sparks or tiny drops, splash, or to sprinkle; to tell off repeatedly. kinyek aidet akipi nuarokok ogoen: stop splashing dirty water on clothes. edesete idwe akipi: the children are splashing water. adetokin itunganan akiro: to tell off or scold someone.
aidetar ki-a (transitive verb) to bale out water (as in canoe or pool, etc); to purge. kideta akipi k’ataker: bale out the water from the canoe or boat; to wash very clean. 
aideukukin ki-a (transitive verb) (of belly) to distend. 
aideun ki-a (transitive verb) to leave some (not finish all). sirikidau ajon, kideu ace: do not finish all the beer, leave some (reflexive verb) to remain or to be left over. amat eong ajon, konye edeunos adis: I have drank beer, but there is a little left over. adaunos ajon: the beer is finished. edeunos ajon: there is beer left over. 
aideunet (plural aideuneta) (noun F) a remainder; remnant; remains; dregs. 
aidi1 (plural aidieik, aidin) (noun F) the highest point (of anything); greatest height of tree or house or rock, etc; the apex. cp. aidio
aidi2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to aim (a gun or a sling) accurately (with one eye shut). abu Daudi kodii Goliasi k’amoru: David aimed accurately at Goliath. 
aidia1 (transitive verb) (of men, animals, ants, etc) to go many together. idiaete isuunyo: the black biting ants go out together. cp. aidii
aidia2 ki-a (transitive verb) to drain away (water from well or hole); to take away (men etc). kidiaata akipi nuk’okicoi: drain away the water from the water hole. 
aidiaar ki-a (reflexive verb) to go many together. ai bo idiaaros yesi kere?: where are you all going (so many of you). apotu itunga kidiaaros neejai Yesu ipu: a big crowd accompanied Jesus. (transitive verb) to take many (of living beings). ediaa ejakait itunga oreke: the chief has taken many people to his home. 
aidiakidiak ki-a (transitive verb) to make soft (by wetting); to eat something soft and watery; (of a drenched person) to run. cp. aidiakalal. 
aidiakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to go in procession, in a line like ants (isuunyo). ediakis isuunyo amej: the black fighting ants are going in line to hunt. 
aidiakit ki-a (intransitive verb) to do wrong; to err.
aidianakin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of living beings) to keep coming in crowds; to gather in crowds. idianakinete lolo akweny osamai ainyam ekutelek: the birds have gathered in the swamp to eat army worms. (reflexive verb) to keep coming or going in crowds. cp. edianaros.
aidiar ki-a (transitive verb) to drain, draw away people from their homes or to drain water from a hole or well; (of men, etc) to take away many. aswamusinei nuko Jinja idiaritos itunga ipu: the Jinja works have drawn many people. idiaritos itunga luka akwapisinei: they have drawn people from other countries. 
aidiare ki-o (transitive verb) to go and look for vegetables (only used in infinitive). kolot adiare: go and look for vegetables. 
aidic1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to be always together; to suit each other, agree with each other. idicas Odong ka Opio: Odong and Opio are always together. akim mam idicas ka akipi: fire and water do not go together (do not agree). 
aidic2 ki-a (transitive verb) to grind fine; to grind well, pulverise, triturate. koyautu alos naidicic: bring well ground millet. 
aidic3 ki-a (transitive verb) to kill fleas with fingers; to crush (anything). cp. aiyed. 
aidicakin1 akeje ki-a (transitive verb) to put heels or feet together like soldiers; to clamp; to measure by the feet (putting one before the other); to tread or step on somebody’s feet inadvertently; to grind fine; to press for. kidicakis akeje: put your heels together. aidicakin etau: to be brave. kidic alos na: grind this millet fine. idicak ijo ekabokorit: you have stepped on (crushed) my toe. 
aidicakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to be of the same mind; to be friends with. edicakinos do ikesa kwi: those guys are now close friends. 
aidicanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to keep going with a friend; to keep going together. ai bo idicanaros yesi duc?: where are you always going together? 
aidicanara ki-a (intransitive verb) to be in friendly relation; to be agreeable to each other. idicanara yesi noi: you are very friendly to each other. 
aidicar ki-o (reflexive verb) to go in company. edicaros Apuda ka Ikasangat apejo: Apuda and Ikasangat have gone together (in company) for a visit. 
aididia ki-a (reflexive verb) to whisper; to talk to oneself. cp. aiyeyea. 
aididianakin ki-a (transitive verb) to whisper into another’s ear; to speak in a high, sharp tone as of women and children. 
aididior ki-o (transitive verb) to conceal, delay (reflexive verb) to hide oneself; to be delayed; to stay away long. 
aidiece ki-a (transitive verb) to do on purpose; to do intentionally. cp. apele, akanga
aidieny ko-a (transitive verb) to reap sorghum. cp. aisak. 
aidier ki-a (transitive verb) to make a present of; to present with; to give away, distribute. idierit ngesi ikeboro kere, ecanuu do: she/he has given all her/his things away, and now she/he is poor. 
aidierakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give as a present; to give away; to distribute; to lavish. kidierakinai eong da idis: give me also a few. 
aidii (transitive verb) (of men, animals, ants, etc) to go many together in Indian file. idiiyaete imukunyo elosete: the black biting ants go out together Indian file. cp. aidia
