aidik ki-a (transitive verb) to drink much of anything; (of child) to suckle much (making a noise). idikai ngesi ajon: she/he drinks much beer. kidikaata ajon: drink plenty of beer. (intransitive verb) (of anything) to be thick. 
aidikakin ki-a (transitive verb) to suck; to drink in one draught; to bite. 
aidikes1 (singular noun F) density of a liquid; concentration; thickness. 
aidikes2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be thick; to curdle. idikok akile nu: this milk is thick. 
aidikidik ki-a (transitive verb) to frequent a place; to do frequently; to throb (of heart, etc). sirikidikidik itogoi lueroko: do not frequent bad houses (intransitive verb) to be frequent, constant. ebala eporotoka dikidik: my throat throbs. idikidiki etau loka ekakeran: the heart of a runner beats quickly. 
aidikior ki-o (reflexive verb) (of liquids) to become thick, stiff, coagulate. edikioros akile: the milk has become thick. 
aidikiun ki-o (transitive verb) to curdle, congest; (of liquids) to become thick, dense; (of an activity) to intensify. 
aidil1 ki-a (transitive verb) to put in more than necessary; to increase. kinyek aidil akito toma akim: do not put too many sticks into the fire (do not choke the fire). 
aidil2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to go early; to travel early in the morning. kodiloto moi yesi osomero: go to school early tomorrow. 
aidila ki-a (intransitive verb) to be many, plenty, abounding; to cook edila (wild pea leaves) vegetable. idilas akituk ko Teso: there are plenty of cattle in Teso. 
aidilakin ki-a (transitive verb) to overdo, put many or much at once; to order to do too much. sirikidilak abalang odia: do not put too much salt ash into the vegetables. sirikidilak eong aswam: do not let me do too much: do not overwork me. (used with any verb, meaning: too or very much, i.e. to overdo; to do to excess; to overdose) 
aidilar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to increase. kidila ekaropit: increase my pay (reflexive verb) to increase; to be added; (also) to fling. edilaros ikatunga: my people have increased. ibareneka mam idilara: my cattle have not increased. kidilakata kolo: what a crowd there was. cp. aidil.
aidilar2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to abound; to become many, plentiful, much. idilaros do inyamat ekaru lo: there is going to be plenty of food this year. (transitive verb) (of anything) to drag away, pull away. 
aidiles (noun F) abundance; plenty; cornucopia; plethora. 
aidilidilar ki-a (transitive verb) to drag along, far away. edilidilasi ijaka ekokolan: the chiefs have dragged away a thief. 
aidiluun ki-a (intransitive verb) to become many, abundant, plentiful, increase. ediluutu akituk nuedekasi: the number of sick cows has increased. 
aidim1 ki-a (transitive verb) to cut down bush or grass; to gather (of groundnuts); (of cashewnut fruit) to break off. kolot aidim amoni: go and cut the thicket. kolot aidim emaido: go and pluck groundnuts. cp. aideng. 
aidim2 ki-a (transitive verb) to pick, pluck, prune, gather, pluck. alosi eong aidim emaido: I am going to pluck groundnuts. aidim ekitoi: to prune a tree. (note: to pick of birds is atodunun). 
aidimakin ki-a (transitive verb) to cut for or in some place. kolot aidimakin amoni ngina: go and cut the bush over there. 
aidimic ki-a (transitive verb) to crush with foot or with a heavy object. idimicik ijo ekabokorit: you have crushed my toe (with your foot). 
aidimicikin ki-a (transitive verb) to crush with foot or heavy body or stone. kidimicik imir ngin k’amoru: crush that little rat with a stone. 
aidimidim ki-a (transitive verb) to cut short (especially vegetable plants); (of goat, sheep) to nibble at leaves or grass. kirengia ikalol ngin, idimidimi akimai: drive away that kid, it nibbles at the growing millet. 
aidimidimunun ki-a (transitive verb) to pluck a few vegetables (for a short time). 
aidimokin ki-o (transitive verb) (of movement) to stop suddenly. 
aidimun ki-a (transitive verb) to cut a thicket or bush for oneself. akoto aidimun ikukwa ainakin akinei: I want to cut thorns for the goats.
aidinga ki-a (transitive verb) to drink much of water, beer, etc; to booze. idingaete kesi ajon: they drink much beer. cp. aidika.
aidingidinga ki-a (intransitive verb) to be too many. idingidingas itunga kokanisa, mam ipedori aiboikin kwap: there are too many people in church, you cannot sit down. 
aidiny1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to moan or blubber. apup eong eidiny loka idwe: I heard the sighing of the children. 
aidiny2 ki-a (transitive verb) (in child birth, defecation) to bear down or push; to groan; to sigh. 
aidinyakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to refuse; to object (usually by a grunt); to help to strain; to help somebody to strain himself (accompanying him with groans). 
aidinyun ki-a (transitive verb) (in child birth, defecation) to force out by constant pressure. 
aidio (plural aidioi) (noun F) a peak; the highest point; greatest height of tree or house or rock, etc; the apex. cp. aidi. 
aidior ki-o (reflexive verb) to disappear, vanish; to plunge (used with adverb dii di or duu du: entirely). edioros iboro ka dii di: my things have disappeared, vanished completely. cp. aingop. 
aidip1 ko-a (transitive verb) to follow closely. adip ikoku papake: the child is following closely behind its father. 
aidip2 ko-o (transitive verb) to strike; to beat, box (with a fist or club); to punch; to contuse, belabour. kodip etau: beat your breast (for shame). inyo bo kidipio ijo eong?: why did you strike me with your fist? 
aidipidipar ki-o (reflexive verb) to go away together; to run off together. adipidiparos kwi Kampala: the guys ran off together to Kampala. 
aidipokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to stoop down; to hide. kodipokinos kwap, abu elope: stoop down and hide, the owner has come. 
aidir ki-a (intransitive verb) to go far away; (of a bird) to go upwards; (of roots) to bore deep; to dig a hole, straight down. idirit ijo iboki aipany: you dug the hole very deep. aidiririar akejen: to direct one’s foot-steps.
aidiriakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to put straight on (like putting cigarettes behind the ear or in the mouth or pole on the roof, etc); to drive a spear straight into an animal or person. Kidiriak esigala akitikon: put that cigar behind your ear. aidiriakin alosit: to go straight away. cp. aitenakin alosit. 
aidiriakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall headlong. abu eong kediriakin toma aipany: I fell headlong into a hole. 
aidiricar ki-a (reflexive verb) to splash. kitor amotoka orot idiricanaros akipi: the water splashes when a car passes through puddles on the road. 
aidiridir ki-a (intransitive verb) (of bird) to hover; to pirouette; (of water) to spout. aidiridir nak’akipi: a maelstrom. 
aidirir1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of liquids) to spout; (of blood, etc) to gush. idiririete akipi kotoma akongu: the water gushes from a spring. 
aidirir2 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of person) to stand upside down; (of any thing) to stand on head. idiririete ikomion: the tree stumps (after cutting trees) remain standing. idiririete iitaabon: the books are standing upside down. 
aidiririar ki-a (transitive verb) to dig deep down. idiririaritos imirio aipany: the rats have dug their hole deep down. 
aidiririet (plural aidiririeta) (noun F) a spout; a tap; a jet; a watering can; a syringe.
aidiririun ki-o (reflexive verb) to gush out; to spout out. ediririunos akile k’okisin: the milk has squirted out from the breast. 
aidit ko-o (transitive verb) to beat very much. sirikidit ikoku kwangin: do not beat the child thus. 
aidiya ko-a (intransitive verb) to go in a long file in procession; to progress. idiyaete lolo itunga osokooni l’Ocorimongin: there is a long procession of people going to Ocorimongin market today. cp. aidya.
aido1 ko-a (transitive verb) to smack lips, snap fingers; to lick (sugar, salt, etc); to taste from open palm; to dip tongue into sugar, etc (in palm of hand).
aido2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to drop; to fall. aido okela k’ebu: to be in wrong hands (literally, to fall on a hyena’s teeth). edoit ekanusu ne: my shilling has dropped here.
aidoc ki-a (transitive verb) to keep pricking or picking the same place; to sting in the same place. idocete akokoroi acok: the hens keep pecking at the potatoes in one spot. 
aidod ko-a (transitive verb) to point at; to point out; to show. kanukinyo kidoditor ijo eong?: why do you point at me? 
aidodok (plural aidodokai) (noun F) (a general name for) a frog. 
aidodoka (plural nukaidodoka) (noun F) a plant, Solanum. 
aidoel (plural nukaidoel) (noun F) a striped hyena, Hyena hyena. 
aidoido1 ki-a (transitive verb) to get (gather) little by little; to get into a habit (of stealing or doing anything); to ask habitually for or be in the habit of doing something. loidoidoi mam inyekini aibar: he who gathers little by little is sure to get rich. cp. ainaikin, aipyelun. 
aidoido2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to give a nice taste for; to give a taste of; to like; to like to; to be sweet to. kedoido eong esukaali: (the sugar gives me a nice taste) I like sugar. kedoidooto eong ajon: I like beer or I like the taste of beer. ibunit ijo kidoido aimat ajon: you have come here with the hope of drinking beer. 
aidoidoikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to taste well to; to be tasty to; to find tasty, nice. edoidoikis ikoku akile: the child has liked milk. cp. ajijimikin. 
aidoikin ki-o (transitive verb) to place or put inside; to drop inside, put in the mouth to taste. kidoik akimai odula: put the millet into the granary. 
aidois (plural aidoisio) (noun F) maternity; labour ward; delivery room. cp. aisidounet
aidok1 ki-o (transitive verb) to pile up; to place on top; (of hands) to lay on (during confirmation). 
aidok2 ko-a (transitive verb) to climb up; (of animals) to mate. 
aidok3 ko-o (transitive verb) to pick (teeth or bone); to gnaw at bone. adum eong ekingok edoki akoit: I found a dog picking a bone. adokis ikel: a tooth pick. cp. adokisio. 
aidokidok ki-o (transitive verb) to take everything (that is there) away; to do in detail. sirikidokidokoo akwi k’acok kere: do not take away all the potato cuttings. aidokidokun akiro kere: to go into details. 
aidokio (plural aidokosio) (noun F) a pile, heap (of anything). 
aidokio akanin (noun F) confirmation in to the Protestant church. 
aidokokin ki-o (transitive verb) to place or put one on top of the other. kidokok amot okyala: put the pot on the hearth (reflexive verb) to be one on top of the other; to be stapled up one on top of the other; to overlap. edokokinos ikelake: her/his teeth are overlapping each other. aidokokin akan: to swear an oath; to put on hands conferring a sacrament (such as when corfirming young Christians). aidokokin aboko: to crown. akopiira naidokokinitai: double tier hat. 
aidokonokin akwi ki-a (transitive verb) to put potato leaves on the heaps ready for planting. kidokonok ijo akwi kuju apanya, abuni eong aira: put the potato leaves ready, I shall come and plant them. 
aidokor ki-a (transitive verb) to replant potato heaps after first potato leaves have dried up. cp. aidokonokin akwi. 
aidokorian ki-a (intransitive verb) to be persistent, persevering; to keep in mind. kidokorian akiro ngun: keep that in mind. idokorianete kesi akiro: they keep it in mind. 
aidokorianut (noun F) persistence; determination. 
aidokoriaun ki-a (transitive verb) to investigate; to go in to find out. abu ejakait kidokoriau akiro kere: the chief investigated every case. 
aidokorikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be persistent in; to be persevering; to insist in doing something, whatever obstacles in the way; to be keen on. kinyek aidokorikina akot egwelet egaali kikidioko isirigin: do not be so keen on buying a bicycle, when you have so little money. (transitive verb) to persevere, go on, etc. idokorikina idwe abolia: the children are keen on playing. 
aidokosit (plural aidokosio) (noun F) a layer; stratum; a pleat; a hem. 
aidokudokun ki-o (transitive verb) to bring away or out all that is there; to leave nothing behind; to remember everything; to call up past events good or bad; to detail, to rake up - hence to be spiteful. kinyek aidokudokunun nunan adaunos sek: do not rake up all these nasty things of the past. 
aidol1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to lie in misery or sickness; to lie in folds, doubled up with pain. idola lokadekan kotogo: sick person lies doubled up with pain in the house. 
aidol2 ki-a (transitive verb) to coil (a rope); to fold (cloth). kidol auno ngin: coil that rope. 
aidol3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to arrive; to be enough; to be right, sufficient. mam etelepat lo edolit: this boy is not right. aitodol: to cause (make) to reach, etc; to complete, to fulfil. (adverb) until; up to; hitherto. aitodol kwana: until (up to) now. 
aidolakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fold up (cloth or body with pain). adeka nges idolakit ngesi: it is sickness that has kept him/her in bed. aidolakin akeju: to sit cross-legged. (reflexive verb) (of anything) to be folded up, shrivelled up. 
aidolar ki-a (transitive verb) to coil away from speaker. 
aidolidol ki-a (transitive verb) to fold many times round, like a bandage or a snake round a twig. 
aidolidola ki-a (reflexive verb) to droop; to be hanging down like a sick person or anything too weak to stand up. 
aidolo ki-o (transitive verb) to lace or tie bundles of twigs on walls or roof of a traditional Teso hut. idoloi ngesi eketogo: she/he is tying struts on her/his hut, or is lacing up walls of her/his hut. cp. ailodo.
aidomakin ki-a (transitive verb) to plunge; to dip into; to dye. akoto aidomakin ekagoe toma akipi: I want to dip my dress in water. 
aidome ki-o (transitive verb) to eat; to throw into the mouth and eat. idomei ikoku emaido: the child is throwing groundnuts one after another into the mouth and eating. 
aidon ki-a (intransitive verb) (of rain) to drizzle for a long time; (of rain, liquid) to drop, to leak; to drizzle. abu bian edou kidon kiya: it drizzled the whole night yesterday. 
aidonakin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of water or medicine) to drop on or into; (of a leak in something, water oozing) dropping from leak or rain. kidonakinai ekia akonyeka: drop some ointment into my eyes. idonanakinos akipi oitaadaka: the water keeps dripping on my bed. 
aidong1 ki-o (intransitive verb) (Usuk) to remain. edong ngesi ore: she/he has stayed at home. cp. aisal, apaikin. 
aidong2 ki-o (transitive verb) to tap latex juice from a tree; to castrate animals. aidong ebule: to tap latex from ebule tree. aidong ekiliokit: to emasculate or castrate a male. aidong ikorwa: to castrate he-goats.
aidong3 ko-a (transitive verb) to pinch, nip, hold tight; to take food with fingers; to abide by. inyo bo kidongia ijo eong?: why did you pinch me? aidong ikoku iwos: to pinch a child on the buttocks.
aidonga ki-a (intransitive verb) to leap into the air; to dance up and down. idongaete itelepai: the boys are dancing or leaping. aidonga ekirakira: to leap up and down in a cultural dance called ekirakira.
aidonget (plural aidongeta) (noun F) the place where animals are castrated. 
aidongio (noun F) castration. 
aidongis (plural aidongisio) (noun F) the scar left after castration. 
aidongit ki-o (intransitive verb) (Usuk) to remain behind; to pass time. 
aidongor ki-o (transitive verb) to subjugate, subdue, humble by constant beating and telling off. edongori lolo eong epalikon: I am going to subdue your cheeky ways today. 
aidony1 ki-o (transitive verb) to finish eating all the food; to finish all the drink (of beer and milk only). sirikidony akile kere: do not (finish) drink all the milk. edonyoto kwi inyamat bian: those men finished all the food yesterday. 
aidony2 ki-o (transitive verb) to pound dried food (like potatoes or cassava). kidonyoto emuogo: pulverise that cassava. cp. airuk emaido, aicur akimai. 
aidony3 ko-o (transitive verb) to sew, knit; to mend clothes; to patch embroidery; to repair (anything). adonyoto apesur igoen: the girls sewed the clothes. 
aidoole (plural aidoolei) (noun F) anus; a bottom (of anything); arsehole. 
aidoonokin ki-o (transitive verb) (as of food into throat, as of mother bird feeding young ones, or of letting a vessel down into a hole) to let down repeatedly. cp. aidoikin. 
aidoor1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to rattle (like bicycle chains when free-wheeling); to gurgle; (of a person) to snore. ekonigaali idooroi noi: your bicycle rattles very much. idooroete akipi kodaraca: the water gushes under the bridge. cp. aidoror.
aidoor2 ki-o (transitive verb) to put something into the mouth unnoticed by another. cp. aimelekedoor: to eat something before anybody has a chance to taste of it. (transitive verb) to lessen or drop prices. (reflexive verb) to become less in price. edoor etiai loka acok: the price of sweet potatoes has plummeted. 
aidop1 ki-a (transitive verb) to emaciate; to waste, dry up (by sickness, age, and of fruit by the sun). adau adeka aidop papaaka: illness has wasted my grand father's body or strength. abu akolong kidop imucuuga: the sun dried up the little orange plant. 
aidop2 ki-a (transitive verb) to kill off (after wounding); to finish off food.
aidop3 ki-o (intransitive verb) to become very hot; to be red hot; (of cigarettes, tobacco) to become ashes. idopit emukaro: the underground kiln is very hot. edop amiidika: my tobacco pipe is nearly out. edop ekasigala: my cigarette is nearly burned out. edop ekatau kanuka ican: akono ekatau: my heart is burned out with anger or sorrow. cp. asaran.
aidop4 ko-a (transitive verb) (of a piece of grass, etc) to poke the eye. kadopit eong anyait akongu: a bit of grass has poked my eye. 
aidopakin ki-a (transitive verb) to finish off for.
aidopar ki-a (transitive verb) to finish off, kill off. aso jo kidopaa ajon ngun: well, you finish that beer. 
aidopokin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become red-hot with or for (roasting). idopokit eupa acok: the fireplace is hot and ready for roasting potatoes. 
aidopor ki-o (intransitive verb) to be or to become emaciated, wasted, dried up (by sun); to fall in the grave, etc; to become ashes. edopo akakuwan kanuka adeka: my body is wasting through illness. 
aidopun ki-a (transitive verb) to finish off (a thing by oneself). okwe, kinyekinai eong kedopu ajon ngun: please, let me finish that beer. 
aidor1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to put on the fire to boil; to cook (water or food). cp. aipoore.
aidor2 ki-o (transitive verb) to slander, detract, defame. inyo bo idoritor Abunyang?: why do you defame or slander Abunyang? sirikiyau akiro nuka edorit: do not malign others before me. 
aidoridor ki-a (intransitive verb) to gurgle. 
aidorokin (akipi) ki-o (transitive verb) to put a water (pot) on fire; to boil (water for cooking, or for tea or food, etc); to heat. (reflexive verb) to be busy a long time. aidorokin iitaabon: to sit very long in one place reading for exams. edorokinos itunga oicolongo aipup imusaagon: people have been busy hearing long cases and are tired (said of any action lasting too long and tiring people). 
aidoror1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to gush; to gurgle; to rattle; to snore; to rush (of water fall). idororoete idwe: the children snore (in their sleep). idororoete igaalin luka Iteso: the Iteso bicycles rattle. idororoete akipi kotoma aguurut: the water roars into the waterfall. akoto ekia loka aidoror iporotoi: I want medicine for gurgling. 
aidoror2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to rattle, snore. ekonigaali idororoi noi: your bicycle rattles very much. idororoete akipi kodaraca: the water gushes under the bridge. 
aidosidos ki-a (transitive verb) to treat carefully (as of eggs, glass cups and all fragile things). kidosidosata iboro ngul: treat those (very fragile) things carefully. 
aidosilaar ki-o (reflexive verb) to die a hidden death; to die alone in misery. adum eong obonipe kidosilaar: I found the hermit had died. adosilikin akakiteng okitwi: my cow died alone in the high grass. 
aidot ko-o (transitive verb) to pluck a bird’s feathers; to pluck beards; to pick jiggers or thorns out of foot or anything. edosi etelepat epuusa: the boy is picking out a jigger. 
aidotidot ki-o (transitive verb) to pluck out hair, feathers, beard one by one. edeke ngesi edosidosi iketim: sickness made his hair fall off. 
aidotor ki-o (transitive verb) to take away; to remove (anything). kidoto jo epir: you pull out the pole (from the ground). kidotosi ber ejakait ngol, ekoto ecamusana: remove that manager, he takes bribes. edotoros imelekes: the hoes have come loose from the handles. 
aidoun ki-o (transitive verb) to give birth to; to bear, bring forth a child. edou aberu ngin idwe luipu: that woman has brought forth (borne) many children. (note: to bear - of fruit: aira; of animals: auri) 
aidounio (noun F) birth. ameun aidouniokon: since your birth; or, from the time of your birth. apaarit naka auriokon: your birthday. cp. aurio, aurunio.
aidu1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to swim; to dive. edui etelepat ngol noi: that boy knows how to swim. 
aidu2 ko-o (transitive verb) to fire a gun or rifle; to shoot; to blast or blow up. eduit ngesi emuudu: she/he fired a gun several times. 
aiduc ki-o (transitive verb) to do for a long time, keep at it; to go on doing some work. akoto aiduc aswam na: I want to keep at this work. 
aiducokin ki-a (intransitive verb) to do everyday, continually, or many times; to persevere, do regularly. kiducok ailip: persist in asking (praying). 
aidudu ki-o (transitive verb) to roast quickly in fire, keeping the thing to be roasted in hand or moving it to and fro in the fire - as of a cob maize, a potato, cassava, dried meat, a stick, etc 
aiduduar ki-a (transitive verb) to raise clouds of dust. eduduasi amotokan apua: the cars have raised clouds of dust. (reflexive verb) to rise up as clouds of dust or as clouds, swarms of birds, flies. (note: of birds, men or living animals, use ediaros: to go or rise many together; to rise, of things like dust, mist or vapour: eduaros) 
aiduduor ki-o (transitive verb) to hide completely; to take away secretly. eduduo mutan ikabore: somebody has hidden my thing completely. eduduor akakinei: my goats are lost altogether. 
aiduiduikin ki-a (transitive verb) to roast for.cp. aidudu. 
aiduk ko-o (intransitive verb) to build; to erect, construct; to step-thatch. 
aidukul ki-a (transitive verb) to hollow out anything. akoto eong aidukul ekitoi koraun ataker: I want to hollow out a tree to make a canoe. sirikidukul atap: do not hollow out the millet bread (bad manners). sirikidukulata akitukes: do not pout your lips. 
aidukulikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hollow out for someone or something. kidukulikinai atuba: make a trough for me. aidukulikin akan: to hook fingers to make a hollow to hold water, etc. 
aidukulun ki-a (transitive verb) to dig a hole, trench or ditch for protection; to make concave. alosi eong aidukulun ikai yen aperi: I am going to build a little hut for sleeping. 
aidukur ki-o (intransitive verb) to camp; to bivouac like scouts; to encamp or settle in. 
aidul ki-o (transitive verb) to deepen (a hole). kidul aipany na: deepen this hole. 
aidulel ki-o (intransitive verb) to be convex, as of a rock or any other massive object; to lie in a big heap; to be very big; to stand out. idulelei emoru: the rock is convex. 
aiduleor ki-o (reflexive verb) to make a somersault, overturn. (transitive verb) to overturn; to turn over as of a motor car; to capsize. 
aidules (plural aidulesia) (noun F) depth. aidules kwap na angolol: depth below sea level. cp. aojau.
aiduleun ki-o (transitive verb) to raise one side up and overturn this way. kiduleutu emotoka kokau: raise the back of motor car. 
aidulokin ki-o (transitive verb) to make deeper; to deepen for someone; to exaggerate. kidulok aipany: make the hole deeper. aidulokin akiro: to exaggerate a tale. 
aidulor ki-o (transitive verb) to make deeper. 
aidum ko-a (transitive verb) to find; to receive; to accept; to get; to gain; to procure. abu kadum ejakait ejai ore: I found my master at home. 
aidung ko-o (transitive verb) to cut; to incise, lacerate, nick; to offend. adung eong ekileng: the knife has cut me. ikoto ijo aidung eong etauka kakirokon: you want to say something offensive (cutting my heart). idungi ijo akiro erono: you are using offensive language. 
aiduny1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be near or close to; to be neighbours. 
aiduny2 ki-a (transitive verb) to place near, close to; to put near. kiduny epaaba irai: plant cotton plants close to each other. 
aiduny3 ko-a (transitive verb) to toil, labour, work hard, keep at, persevere, continue; to wear oneself out. kadunyata aswam: let us work hard. idunyit ijo ngun atitai, agir je akonikiro: you toil for nothing (wear yourself out for nothing), he will not listen. cp. ailuny. 
aidunyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to be near each other, be contiguous; (of anything) to put near, close together; to abut. erono aidunyakin ekine nepepe k’ebu: it is bad to put a goat near a hyena (reflexive verb) to be close together; to go together; to suit each other. ikapa k’emir mam idunyakinos: a cat and a rat cannot be together. 
aidunyet (plural aidunyeta) (noun F) a neighbour; the one near. erai ngesi nakidunya ka eong: she is my neighbour. 
aidunyetait (plural aidunyeta) (noun F) abutment.
aiduokar ki-o (reflexive verb) to go back, return. kiduokaros ber, ibongunete moi: go home now and come back tomorrow (used in anger).
aiduokun ki-o (reflexive verb) to return tomorrow; to come back to (used in anger). kiduokunos moi, emamei ber lolo apak: come back tomorrow, I have no time today. 
aiduopokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be finished, as of air in tyre; to go flat, as stomach with hunger. eduopokin amopiira: the tyre has become flat (empty). 
aiduor ki-o (reflexive verb) to swim across; to sink, as of anything in the water. lomam ejeni aidu, elosi aiduor: he who cannot swim will sink. aiduor etau: to decide, intend, or propose. eduorit eong ekatau abongor ore: I made up my mind to go home for good. cp. alemun etau. 
aidup ko-a (transitive verb) to fix a handle (of a hoe or any tool). kodup akulep omeleku lo: fix a handle to this hoe. aidup akiro: to interfere in a dispute or case. sirikidup akirokos: do not meddle in our dispute. aidup emuudu: to load a gun. 
aidupaun ki-a (transitive verb) to beat once with a resounding blow; to explode on. 
aidupaunun ki-a (transitive verb) to shell heavily; to bombard heavily with cannon or grenades. edupaunun bian edege loka ajore Ilok: the army plane yesterday bombarded cattle rustlers. 
aidupokin1 akim ki-o (transitive verb) to throw into the fire or dust or powder. iponesio kon lueroko kidupokinete ijo toma akim: your bad habits are going to put you in trouble. (reflexive verb) to fall into (the fire). edupokinos acok oupa: potatoes have fallen into the hot ashes. (note: to fall into liquid is ailumokin)
aidupokin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to cast, throw on to a heap of ash, etc. kidupok acokit okuruba: cast that potato into the heap of hot ashes. 
aidupokin3 ki-o (reflexive verb) to interfere in, meddle with. sirikidupokin akirokos: do not meddle in our dispute. 
aidupor ki-o (transitive verb) to betray; to make a dupe of; to make somebody be fined for what is not his fault, as of a father being fined for his child's mistake; to pay fine for; to renege. kedupoo ikakoku: my child made me pay a fine; or, I am fined (imprisoned) for my child. edupo aola ekokolan: a cough betrayed the thief. cp. agwelar.
aidupudup ki-o (transitive verb) to pound into powder; to powder (by walking, grinding); to cause dust; to poke ashes looking for fire; to stir up the dust (as of birds or hens) to clean themselves of fleas; to clean grain by heating. 
aidupudupoor ki-o (transitive verb) to destroy completely by fire, burn to ashes or decay by age to dust. abu akim kidupudupoo ekatogo: the fire burnt my house to ashes. edupudupoor ekatogo: my house burned down completely or has decayed altogether. 
aidupuk ki-o (transitive verb) to cause to be well-ground or well-cultivated; to soften. kidupuk emanikor: cause the farmland to be properly ploughed. 
aidur ko-a (transitive verb) (of a man) to have sexual intercourse with a woman; to screw (a woman). (note: this word only applies to the action of a man on the woman, joint action is adurakin). cp. aikwar (used for the action of male animals only, and does not apply to sexual intercourse between humans - unless used as a term of insult). 
aidusor ki-o (intransitive verb) to fall on the back of head. cp. aikilarikin. 
aidut1 ko-a (transitive verb) to give out to each; to serve food to many; to endow, bestow to each; to give things away; to divide (as of cake) to many; to dispense. ejeni ekepugan aidut ajakaanut: the ruler knows how to distribute his power or posts. 
aidut2 ko-o (transitive verb) to pull out completely; to weed by pulling up; to uproot. edusi aberu eduan: the woman is pulling out the weed.
aiduuda ki-a (transitive verb) to beat; to pound or stamp like cassava or dried potatoes; to beat, pound a person. iduudaete angor acokokec: the women are pounding their dried potatoes. eduudata bian kwi ekokolan: those guys clobbered a thief yesterday. cp. airuk, airie.
aiduun ki-o (reflexive verb) to swim this way. kiduun lailo: swim this way. 
aiduwa ki-a (intransitive verb) to raise dust, smoke, or mist. iduwai apua: the dust is rising. iduwai emotoka lo apuru: this motorcar is belching smoke (carbon). 
aiduwaunun ki-a (intransitive verb) to raise dust, smoke, or mist this way. iduwaununei ijo apua lailo: you are raising dust this way. 
aidwal ki-a (transitive verb) to talk nonsense; to pester by nonsense; (of a child) to suck breasts that no longer has milk. aidwal atap: to stir millet porridge well. 
aidwalidwal ki-a (transitive verb) to make a soft, weak meal (by adding much water); (of woman) to run with flat breasts. kidwalidwal atap kanyama kwangin: just make some soft meal and let us eat it as it is. idwalidwaluna akuwanake kanuka ican: she/he is weak on account of poverty or worries. 
aidwalidwalakin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of someone with no strength) to run (reflexive verb) (of porridge) to become soft, thin. kidwalidwalak ijo da: try to run even if you have no strength. 
aidwar ko-a (transitive verb) to prophesy; to foretell; to predict; to divine; to guess. abu Yesu Kristo kodwar nuka amudiario naka Jerusalem: Jesus Christ prophesied the destruction of Jerusalem. 
aidweny ko-a (transitive verb) to reap or to harvest sorghum; to finish off completely (by killing or eating). kadwenyata imomwa: let us reap sorghum. yen ewei aronusyo edwenyi ican kakuj: she/he who sows sins will reap sorrow in heaven. cp. aidyeny, aisak, aitob.
aidwetidwet akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to wink repeatedly. 
aidwom ko-a (transitive verb) to eat vegetables with atap; to drink millet/sorghum brew before water is added; to eat greedily; to speak inopportunely; to dip into something unclean or something clean but with unclean instrument. cp. aidwomakin, adwomanakin: to eat a lot (every now and then).
aidya ki-a (transitive verb) to drain away (water from well or hole); (of many birds, clouds, people, animals) to rise or move together. cp. aiduaar, aiduduar. 
aidyak ko-a (transitive verb) to miss aim. (intransitive verb) to miss (the target); to fail to reach; to fail; to go astray; to make a mistake; to commit a fault. adyak eong airem etyang: I missed spearing (killing) an animal. inyo bo adyakit eong?: what have I done wrong? 
aidyakar ki-a (intransitive verb) to trespass; to sin; to make a mistake or commit a crime.
aidyam ki-a (transitive verb) to beat with a long soft stick. 
aidyas ki-a (intransitive verb) (of anything) to go on increasing. idyatas idwe kwana osomero eidyas: the number of pupils in the school is increasing daily. 
aidyasetait (plural aidyaseta) (noun F) a storing place; a treasury, storeroom. 
aidyat ki-a (transitive verb) to heap up; to store, save up, conglomerate. aidyat akiro: data collection or gathering. kinyek aidyat apesenin: do not let your debts pile (heap) up. akoto eong aidyat akimai odula: I want to store up millet in the granary. idyasitos kesi akiro nuipu toma odikisyonari: they have gathered many words in the dictionary. 
aidyatakin ki-a (transitive verb) to compile for another; to gather for another; to collect for another. kidyatakinai eong akiro nuka Ateso: gather for me Ateso words. 
aidyatakinet (plural aidyatakineta) (noun F) a gathering; a collection; a compilation. edikisyonari erai aidyatakinet naka akiro: a dictionary is a collection of words (compilation). 
aidyatar ki-a (transitive verb) to gather and send away; to collect with the intention to take away. abunit eong aidyatar isirigin kane: I have come to collect money and take it away. 
aidyatenen ki-a (transitive verb) to keep storing up. 
aidyatun ki-o (reflexive verb) to mount up; to increase. edyatunos apeseninika: my debts have mounted. (transitive verb) to gain, to collect for oneself. 
aidyatus (singular noun F) a gathering, collection (of anything, also of people). 
aidyek ko-a (transitive verb) to intervene, adjudicate, separate combatants; to defend; to come to the rescue, alleviate, arbitrate. koinakinai akipi kadyekia akure: give me some water to alleviate my thirst. to mediate; to separate quarrelling persons; to reconcile, intercede. cp. aityak (of all other things to be separated). kodyek luejios kwi: separate those fighters. 
aidyel1 ki-a (transitive verb) to lick (something dry). adum eong akingok idyeli asaanit: I found a bitch licking a plate. cp. aime. 
aidyel2 ki-a (transitive verb) to lift between two or more persons; to carry as of a heavy load hanging down i.e. a dead body. inyo bo idyelitos yesi?: what load are you carrying between yourselves? 
aidyelar ki-a (transitive verb) to carry away (between two or more people); to lick all off. 
aidyelit ki-o (transitive verb) to be carrying together. idyelitos kesi epir: they are carrying a pole. 
aidyelun ki-a (transitive verb) to carry a heavy load together this way. kidyelutu ne: carry it here. 
aidyeny ko-a (transitive verb) to reap or to harvest sorghum.. kadyenyata imomwa: let us reap sorghum. yen ewei aronusyo edyenyi ican kakuj: she/he who sows sins will reap sorrow in heaven. cp. aidweny, aisak, aitob.
aidyo (plural aidyoi) (noun F) the peak; apex; acme; highest point. 
aiga ki-a (transitive verb) to protect or to shield; to guard (usually with the hand or arms) against harm or a beating or heat of the sun; to dodge; to catch (water or anything) with a vessel. toto igai idweke kinyekinai ainomonom: the mother protects her children from being beaten. aiga akiro: to refuse absolutely (by turning away one's face); to excuse oneself. 
aigaar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to ward off; to parry. akoto eong aibel nes, konye kigaari do ngesi ebela: I wanted to beat his head but he parried the blow (or stick). aigaar akiro: to deny (usually with gesticulations). (reflexive verb) to guard or protect oneself; to deny or refuse. egaaros ngul kotoma akiro kanu ejenete kesi: they have denied the truth. 
aigaar2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to take sides with combatants; to become allies. apotu Italianin kigaaros owai loka Igirimanin kojie lokiareit lokakwapin: the Italians took sides with the Germans during World War II. 
aigaara (noun F) protection; the lee side. aigaarakon: your protection or defence. 
aigaet (plural aigaeta) (noun F) self-defence; an alibi; an excuse; a justification. 
aigaga ki-a (transitive verb) to catch something falling or thrown at; to hold. kigaga ikoku ekoto aibiror: catch the child, it is going to fall. 
aigagaikin akanin ki-a (transitive verb) to hold out both hands (palm up) for begging; to guard the possession due to a son or anybody; to hold for somebody; to receive for somebody; to hold in trust for someone. igagakit aberu akanin ilipi: the woman stretches out her hands when she is begging or praying. abu okokuka lokegagakit eong kotwana: my son who supported me died. aigaganakin aimat: to drink one after another from the same vessel. (reflexive verb) to give to one another; to share (anything). cp. ainanakin; aijanakin.
aigagakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hold out both hands (palm up) for begging; to guard the possession due to a son or anybody; to hold for somebody; to receive for somebody; to hold in trust for someone.
aigagam ki-a (intransitive verb) (of cereal seeds) to begin to ripen. egagamata akimai: the millet is beginning to ripen. 
aigagaun ki-a (transitive verb) to hold or to catch a fallen or thrown object or falling person. kigagau emopiira kojokan: catch the ball and hold it. cp. aitun. 
aigaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to shield; to protect; to guard from harm; to shade; to place something (stick, hand, etc) in between to prevent a blow, etc; to put out a vessel for catching rainwater or overflowing water (reflexive verb) to avoid a blow by shifting aside or guarding oneself against blow (by hand or anything); to shade oneself from the heat of the sun.
aigal ki-a (transitive verb) (of more than one) to work or do together; (of many) to share work; to gang up on or against someone or something. kegalata aswam na: let us do this work together. apotu kesi kegalata eong: they united to beat me. 
aigalaanut (noun F) helpfulness; alliance (intransitive verb) to be helpful or supportive; to be allies. 
aigalakin ki-a (transitive verb) to combine to help or work for somebody. kigalakinai aswam: join me in this work. kegalakinos aiduk ekanisa: let us build the church together. 
aigalal ki-a (transitive verb) to skim off (like cream from milk); to strain; to filter. igalalai totoka imomwa: my mother is straining the sorghum for making beer. aigalal edia: to eat vegetables cooked in water only, with no flavouring or groundnut paste in. 
aigalalaar ki-a (transitive verb) to skim off; to do superficially. 
aigalalaun ki-a (transitive verb) to skim for oneself. 
aigalaleta (plural noun F) dross. 
aigalar ki-a (transitive verb) to combine for common action. kopotu kegalasi aswam tetere kidauni ngesi atipet: come let us work together to finish fast. 
aigali ki-o (transitive verb) to fence off; to fence round; to bar; to close off. igalit ijo erot ngol?: did you close off that road? 
aigaligal ki-a (transitive verb) to attempt a task too big for one person; to weed, clean (by oneself). egaligalit eong aswam ngin: this work is too big for me alone. mam eong bon apedori aigaligal akituk: I alone cannot manage to look after all those cows. kigaligala ijo amanaka aicap: you weed my garden by yourself. 
aigaligalakin ki-a (transitive verb) to drive (fish into a net, goats into the pen, cattle into the kraal, etc) in by approaching with outstretched arms from side to side. 
aigalikin ki-o (transitive verb) to defend; to prevent; to support; to block. kigalik amoru okek: put a stone in front of the door to prevent it from opening or closing. kigalikinai tetere mam ngesi kenomi eong: defend me lest she/he beats me. aisigalikin: to help; to assist; to shade. emamei etunganan lok’esigalikit eong aswam na: I have nobody to help me in my work. 
aigalionokin ki-o (transitive verb) to put bars, obstacles, thorns around for protection. kigalionok ikukwa orot ngol tetere mam itunga edaunete araito: put thorns on that road so that people may not finish the fruits. 
aigalior ki-o (transitive verb) to block a road, etc; to shade, to prevent someone from seeing; to push aside, out of the way; to block. kigaliorit ijo eong aanyun, kolot awai: you obstruct me from seeing, move aside. igaliorit ekitoi erot: the tree has blocked the road. kigalio ekitoi awai: push the tree aside. cp. airap.
aigalisit (plural aigalisio) (noun F) a curtain, drape, blind, screen, shade, or shutter; a spare or stand-by thing.
aigaliun ki-o (transitive verb) to include or fence in. cp. aigalior: to exclude from anything; to shield from. egalior je awai: they have excluded him, i.e. they have simply ignored him. 
aigalun ki-a (transitive verb) to mob (a person); to pool together (of anything). kegalutu inyamat kanuka epucit: let us pool the food together for the feast. aigalun einer: to talk about a person present. inyo bo kigalunitotor?: why did they mob you? cp. alukun einer.
aigam ki-a (intransitive verb) to lie, tell falsehood. igami ekesa ngol: that man is lying. cp. aisab; ailyok.
aigamakin ki-a (transitive verb) to calumniate, lie; to perjure, fib, tell stories, be economical with the truth; to slander. sirikigamak eong akiro: do not calumniate me. 
aigamar ki-a (transitive verb) to tell off straight away; to attack at once; to assault as soon as a person appears. inyo bo kigamaria ijo eong?: why did you tell me off like that? 
aiganan ki-a (intransitive verb) to sit on one’s buttocks with legs apart; to be the boss, i.e. sit and give orders for things to be done. 
aigang1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to support another or to ally; to plead, advocate for. igangas ngul etubete akakiro: they support one another in settling my case. 
aigang2 ki-a (transitive verb) to make stand (as of a kiln, roof, etc) by using props; to build a brick kiln. kegangata emukaru: let us pile a brick kiln. aigang akito: to pile firewood ready to set fire on. 
aigangakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give support to; to take sides with; to encourage; to be ally to. kigangakinai eong kotoma akiroka: side with me in my cause. (reflexive verb) to support one another, help one another, encourage one another; to be ally. kegangakinos kotoma aswamuwok: let us help one another in our work. 
aiganganar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep on supporting (as of a sick person who is too weak to help herself/himself). kopaikisi yesi ne aiganganar lokadekan kinga: stay here to take the sick person out regularly. (reflexive verb) to support one another; to help one another; to side one with another (in a case). 
aiganget (plural aigangeta) (noun F) a defence, backing, a foundation, a support. 
aigangigang ki-a (intransitive verb) to be unable to do a work by oneself only. egangigangit eong aswam ngin elope bon: I am doing the work I cannot do by myself. 
aigangun ki-a (transitive verb) to prop up, support; to stay. ebela iganguni akimat: the stick supports an old woman. igangunete ipirin etogo: the poles support the house. (reflexive verb) to lean against; to support oneself; to steady oneself. 
aigar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to drive fish into a trap. igarete angor agaria aitiiban: the women drive the fish into the fishing net. cp. aigaligalanakin.
aigar2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be too big to fit; to be jammed; to be stuck. agarit eong ekek: I am too big to get through the door (or I cannot pass through this narrow door). 
aigarar ki-a (intransitive verb) to sit astride; to stretch out legs (while sitting). kiboikin ejok, sirigararai: sit decently, not with legs parted out 
aigasigas ki-a (intransitive verb) to be just alive; to be just breathing. eringa lokadekan igasigasi: the sick man is still breathing with difficulty. 
aigasiikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become dirty, stained, or filthy. ikoku yen koleje alai egasiiki noi kwana: the child who used to be very clean is now very dirty. igasiikit ekonimoyo: your soul has become evil. 
aigat ko-a (transitive verb) to curse thieves or debtors, as by the Isureta clan (clan of cursers) (the aggrieved people together with a suspected thief gather around an anthill where they burn a white chicken alive while the curser shouts, ‘mutan kotwana’ (let so-and-so die) and the people answer, ‘kotwana, ibweny-ibweny’ (let him/her die completely), then Isureta will block holes of the anthill with leaves of itulel and everyone runs off from the anthill without looking back. If the person cursed is the actual thief, he/she may begin to die within a few days unless he/she pays back what was stolen plus a fine of a cow to Isureta who will then unblock the holes of the anthill); to wish good health to the sick; to wish someone prosperity. 
aigatar ki-a (intransitive verb) to slip; to walk unsteadily, make a mistake. erot loerurut einakini itunganan aigatar: a slippery road causes a person to walk unsteadily. cp. aibucar, aigetar.
aigaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to be pregnant (early months). aigaun akiro: listen attentively, often with hand pulling the pinna (ear). kigautu akiro: listen attentively. aigaun akipi: to trap or catch water with hands or a vessel. ipu akipi nuigauna: much water was collected. 
aigaunet (plural aigauneta) (noun F) a receptacle for catching water; a tank; something for warding off attack; a defence; argument. ebela erai eigaunet: a stick is a defence weapon. nuinera ijo mam eraas aigaunet: what you say is no defence. 
aige ko-a (intransitive verb) to start to do something; to begin; to originate; to leave befor someone; to move in front of someone. koge ber aiduk etogo: begin first to build a house. (adverb) first; to begin with. aige, kolot ber ainyam: to begin with (first of all), go and eat. 
aigel ko-a (transitive verb) to sort out; to segregate; to pay a fine, to pay indemnity, damages; compensate, award. akoto eong aigel akakiro: I want to pay my fine. aigel asurup: to pay a fine for having murdered a person; to pacify the relations of murdered man, so that they do not take any vengeance on the murderer. 
aigen ki-a (transitive verb) to eat alone or by oneself. erono aigen inyamat kiteete luce: it is bad to eat food alone while others look on.
aigeng ki-a (intransitive verb) to trot, run slowly. koge aigeng, abu edou: start running slowly, the rain has come or it begins to rain. 
aigengigeng ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a short man or animal) to run; to run with short steps and slowly; to trot.
aiger1 ki-o (transitive verb) to measure or mark a plot; to mark. 
aiger2 ko-a (transitive verb) to engrave, inscribe; to tattoo with tribal marks; to scarify; to write; to draw blood with small incisions so as to treat some disease when medicine is smeared on the cuts; to put stripes on pots, calabashes, or gourds. angor kesi egerete iburuo: only women do the tattooing. 
aigerosit (plural aigerosio) (noun F) an engraving; a mark (as of a house plan or that of a boundary). 
aigesiges ki-a (intransitive verb) to sweat, perspire profusely. kegesiges eong: I am sweating profusely. aitegesiges: to make to perspire profusely. itegesigesi aswam ngin: that work makes one sweat. 
aigesitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to stagger; to try make an effort. kigesitoi ijo kwapekwangin: keep on trying; do not give up. cp. aigetanar
aiget1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to stumble; to walk unsteadily. igeta ngesi bala lokameran: she/he walks unsteadily like a drunken man. 
aiget2 ki-a (transitive verb) to slice potatoes, cassava, bananas, etc. 
aigetanar ki-o (intransitive verb) to stagger; to try make an effort. igetanar ijo bala imera: you stagger as if you are drunk.
aigetar ki-o (reflexive verb) to wobble, dodder, stumble backwards or sideways; to toddle; to lose your balance; to falter, make a mistake. apotu kesi kigetaros: they went staggering away or they made a mistake. 
aigetigeta ki-a (intransitive verb) to go or walk drunkenly, wobble, stagger, walk unsteadily, etc. igetigetas eong idwe kore kangina: my children at home are very weak, wobbling about. 
aigigin ki-a (intransitive verb) to eat much; to gormandise. 
aigik ki-a (transitive verb) to keep punching or prodding in the stomach. inyo bo kigikia ijo eong?: why do you punch me in the stomach? 
aigikakin ki-a (transitive verb) to punch a person in the ribs or stomach; to prod in any part of the body. kegikaki ngesi eong amarana: she/he punched me on the ribs. 
aigikaun ki-a (transitive verb) to prod in the stomach; to punch. kegikau lolo ejakait eong kanuka esolo: the chief punched my stomach because of taxes. 
aigim ki-o (intransitive verb) to test, try, attempt, make an attempt. egim ikoku alosit: the child has tried to walk. cp. aitam, aigimonor, atamanar. 
aigimokin ki-o (intransitive verb) to find out; to experiment, try out, inspect. kolot kigimok ber erot: go and find out the way. 
aigimor ki-o (transitive verb) to try, experience; to find out; to test. egimo eong etunganan ngol, konye mam bobo akoto nges: I tested that man, but I do not like him now (reflexive verb) to try, attempt. egimoros kesi auta, konye akuruokis: they tried to wrestle but failed. egimos akonyeka emong ngol: my eyes are pleased with that bull. 
aigip ko-a (transitive verb) to peer up, distinguish at a distance; to notice; to recognise far off; to see far off. abu eong kagipa ijo ilwana: I recognised you at a distance.
aigir1 ki-a (transitive verb) to inscribe; to engrave; to write; to scratch into; to comb, mark out; to make lines. cp. aiger. 
aigir2 ko-o (transitive verb) to refuse, disclaim; to renounce; to deny, disown, or abnegate. (intransitive verb) to fail; to be unsuccessful. egirit akuwan: I am not feeling alright; my health is failing. cp. ainger.
aigirakin ki-a (transitive verb) to engrave on; to write to; to mark out for someone else. akoto aigirakin ijo ebalua: I want to write to you. kigirakinai eong etogo: measure a house for me. 
aigiretait (plural aigireta) (noun F) a line, a mark; a comb made of ox-rib; a writing, engraving. 
aigirigir1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to do script writing; to write like a child (illegibly), draw crooked lines. 
aigirigir2 ki-a (transitive verb) to engrave often; to carve often; to write often, etc (intransitive verb) to be a carver; to be a writer or clerk, engraver. 
aigirigiret (plural aigirigireta) (noun F) writing, writ, script, symbols, inscription, letters, text. aigirigireta: scriptures. 
aigisetait (plural aigiseta) (noun F) a splinter; a strip; a sliver; a shred; a fragment; a chip. 
aigit1 ki-a (transitive verb) to clear the throat; to cough; to take off outer fibre of sugarcane; to strip off; to chip off. 
aigit2 ko-a (transitive verb) to choke, obstruct, throttle, suffocate. agit ikoku acokit: the potato has choked the child. 
aigit3 ko-a (transitive verb) to sort out, distinguish; to separate; to classify; to sever, put apart. 
aigitakin ki-a (transitive verb) to splinter for; to strip off for, or peel for; to clear the throat (to attract somebody’s attention). egitakin akitoi obokoritika: a stick has splintered in my finger. kigitakinai eong ekaajo: peel the sugarcane for me. 
aigitar ki-a (transitive verb) to clear throat; to cough. kigita eporoto kowou ekosio: clear your throat and sing a song. cp. aijotar
aigo ki-o (transitive verb) to fasten (as of chain or lock); to lock, handcuff; to lock a door, etc; to straighten using force; to discipline, to hammer out, to panel beat, to mould, to clear up using strong arguments. aigo akiro: to straighten out a case; to clear up using strong arguments. egoi etunganan ngol akiro kotoma atukot: he clinches the case by strong arguments in court. cp. aigol.
aigogo (plural aigogoi) (noun F) a nest for hens; a cavity, grave. cp. ailit. 
aigogol ki-a (transitive verb) to entangle; to trip up. sirikigogoloto lucetelepai ipesete emopiira: do not trip your fellow boys in the football game. 
aigogoleor ki-o (transitive verb) to tackle, as in football; to cause to stagger, trip. inyo bo igogoleoro ijo nges?: why did you trip her/him? (reflexive verb) to stagger and fall. 
aigogwa ki-a (intransitive verb) (of people) to have sexual intercourse. cp. aigwaka. 
aigoikin ki-o (transitive verb) to grip tightly; to clamp; to clasp; to lock up; to lean on. kigoik ikusiboro togo: lock up your things in the house. 
aigol ko-o (transitive verb) to shut, close; to lock; to prevent. kogol ekek: shut the door. egolit ngesi erotoka lokadumun aswam: she/he/it is preventing me from getting work. (intransitive verb) to be last. Okolimo egolit: Okolimo is the last (in class, in a sport). 
aigoligol ki-o (transitive verb) to stir; to disturb (a liquid with stick. or spoon). kigoligol ber eles kagolot: first frighten out the squirrel from the tree hole with a stick. 
aigoligolokin ki-a (transitive verb) to stir up; to poke in or at (with stick). kigoligolok etogo kere, tetere emir elomuni: poke round the things in the house so as to frighten out the rat. 
aigoligolun ki-o (transitive verb) to cook quickly. kigoligol aditap kanyam: just cook a little food quickly and let me eat. 
aigong1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk infirmly, needing support; to loiter; to jog, saunter. 
aigong2 ko-a (transitive verb) to lean something against or on, upon; to put against; to abut. kinyekisi aigong iboro arwatat: do not lean things against the wall. 
aigongakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to start running unsteadily (as an old man does). 
aigongigong ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a person who has no strength) to run. igongigongi ngesi bala emojong: she/he runs like an old man. kigongigong akwap, angatu edou: start running away, it is going to rain. 
aigongor ki-o (transitive verb) to put things haphazardly (into room or box); to put things topsy-turvy. kinap iboro ejok, sirigongor kes aigongor: pack things neatly, do not just throw them anyhow. 
aigonon ki-o (intransitive verb) (of tree) to be heavily laden with fruit. 
aigooda ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk in an unnatural way (especially like a woman in advanced pregnancy); to be affected in manner of walking; to walk with affectation; to be proud, showy. igoodaete lolo itelepai kotoma agwelanaret: the boys are walking in an affected manner in the market. 
aigoodakin ki-a (transitive verb) to show off for or somewhere. igoodakinete itelepai apesur: boys show off in the presence of girls. 
aigoonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to repetitively hammer away or lock up. 
aigor1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of pregnant woman) to be tired by hard work (transitive verb) to tire out; to weary; to fatigue. 
aigor2 ko-o (transitive verb) to get out with one’s finger (as dirt from ear, mouth or nose).
aigore ki-a (transitive verb) to put in a corner, aside, out of the way. kigoreata igaalin agule: put your bicycles aside. 
aigorear ki-a (transitive verb) to tuck away; to hide inside. kigorea akituk, abu amuranikon: hide the cows, your father-in-law has come. (reflexive verb) to be hidden; to be put inside. kigorear, abu lokasurup: hide yourself, your enemy has come. cp. aingop. 
aigoreikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hide, put in a corner for; to drive into a corner (as cattle or men); to tuck away. kigoreik akituk awai kotubor amotoka: drive the cattle aside to let the car pass. 
aigorigor ki-a (transitive verb) to keep poking at (mouth, nose or ear); (of worms) to dig a hole in a tree, etc; to explore, examine. sirikigorigor ekumekon: do not prod your nose. David Livingstone ngesi abu kigorigor Africa: David Livingstone explored Africa. 
aigorigora ki-a (intransitive verb) to be infirm, hoarse; to speak in a low tone; to grumble. egorigora eong, mam apedori alosit Kampala: I am too infirm, I cannot go to Kampala. 
aigorigorar ki-o (reflexive verb) to move quickly but unsteadily (as on a bicycle). 
aigorigorit ki-o (intransitive verb) to be weak from long illness. igorigorit ngol, sirikebuu: he is weak, do not let him come. 
aigorigorokin ki-a (transitive verb) to poke at (in, etc) for someone else; to explore for. kigorigorokinoi eong akwap nako Karamoja: explore the Karimojong country for me. 
aigoror ki-o (intransitive verb) (of birds about to fly) to spread out wings (transitive verb) to flex one’s arms ready to pounce at someone; to be fully fledged. 
aigu ki-a (intransitive verb) to knock the toe or foot against; to stumble the foot against. cp. aibu. 
aiguanakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to keep stumbling.
aigugunaar1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to be overloaded, overdressed, overburdened. ai bo igugunaaros yesi?: where are you going with your heavy loads? cp. aiolila, agiraun
aigugunaar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to load heavily; to make heavy; to oppress; to overload. igugunai ejakait iketunga: the chief oppresses his people. kinyekisi aiguguna amotoka: do not overload the car. 
aigugunatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to be carrying about a great load; to be overloaded, oppressed. 
aigugunaun ki-a (reflexive verb) to come heavily loaded; to be burdened (transitive verb) to bring heavy load. kigugunaunos bo yesi kai?: where have you come from with such a heavy load? 
aiguikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of foot or toe) to knock against; to stumble; to trip; to be scandalised. keguiki eong: I stumbled. 
aiguk ki-a (transitive verb) to punch; to give a punch. cp. aigik
aigukakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hit (with a fist or elbow); to hit on the side for; to nudge. kanukinyo kigukakinia ijo eong?: why did you hit me? ai bo kigukakinia ngesi ijo?: from where did he punch you? ai bo kigukakit ngesi ijo?: what part of your body did he hit you? 
aigul ki-a (transitive verb) to speak a language as an expert at it; to know a language well. iguli ngol Aswairin noi: he is an expert at Kiswahili. 
aigulakin ki-a (transitive verb) to address a person in a foreign language. 
aigulanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to punch; to keep talking to people in a foreign language (reflexive verb) to punch or box one another. igulanakinos idwe: the children are boxing. 
aigular ki-a (transitive verb) to interpret for people away from speaker. 
aigule ki-a (transitive verb) to make an enclosure; to form a bay; to walk round an enclosure; to put things in the backyard. 
aigulear ki-a (transitive verb) to put or take aside; to cut off the way. 
aigulugulaar ki-a (intransitive verb) to rattle, rumble (as of fluid in stomach). igulugula akakoik: my stomach is rumbling. cp. aiguruguro: to rumble. aigulugul ikingok: to shake a pup after feeding on milk so that it may grow more quickly. 
aigulugulakin ki-a (transitive verb) to build a little hut for goats or sheep; to rattle out words of a language unknown to the listeners. egulugulaki Emusugut Amusugun: the white man rattled out his English (to those who do not understand English) (reflexive verb) to speak to one another in foreign languages not understood. itunga luko Babel apotu kigulugulanakinos: the people of Babel spoke and did not understand one another. 
aigulun ki-a (transitive verb) to interpret for an audience here. 
aigum ko-a (transitive verb) to aim, to pierce or to shoot with an arrow; to sting. aigum akituk: to bleed cattle. agumun aokot: to draw blood.
aigumugumitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to sneak along. 
aigun ki-a (transitive verb) to eat much. cp. aisik; aigen; aigigin.
aigunuguna ki-a (intransitive verb) to struggle in vain; to show refusal by struggling. igunuguna apese na: this girl is refusing (by wriggling). 
aigur ki-o (transitive verb) to stir, mix, or mash. aigur abeei: to beat eggs; to mix eggs well. 
aiguret (plural aigureta) (noun F) a ladle; something for stirring. 
aigurokin ki-a (transitive verb) to stir for; to stir once. aiguror ebalua: to write a sarcastic or sharp letter. 
aigurugur1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to run whilst carrying a load in front of one; to rattle (of stomach). kiguruguraros ka ikoku ore, abu edou: go home with the child, it is going to rain. cp. aigulugul.
aigurugur2 ki-o (transitive verb) to keep stirring; to disturb; to stir or cook a little food by oneself; (of a burrow) to dig deep and with cellars. akoto aigurugur ikatap bon, kapas eong aitanyam luipu: I want to prepare a little food for myself, I am tired of feeding many. 
aiguruguro ki-o (reflexive verb) to mumble; to grumble; to speak in a low or deep tone; to whisper in a low deep tone. ejaas luiguruguros kotogo kaje: there are people murmuring in that room. 
aigurugurooro ki-o (intransitive verb) (of anthill or rat holes) to be dug deep with cellars. 
aigurumun ki-a (transitive verb) to make a short and round-bellied granary or pot. 
aigurun1 ki-o (reflexive verb) (of things and speech or opinions) to get mixed up; to be in disorder. kanyoutu kane, egurunos akiro: let us go away, there is a mix-up here. 
aigurun2 ki-o (transitive verb) to stir or mash for oneself; to stir this way; to stir feelings of people. kigurutu atap kedenyiata erot: mingle a little food for our journey. eguru ekesa ngol akiro nuedwarak: he has stirred up the feelings of people by sarcastic language. 
aigwa ko-a (transitive verb) to provoke; to incite; to calumniate, slander, challenge. sirikigwa eong: do not provoke me. 
aigwaigwa ki-a (intransitive verb) (of skin) to have eczema; (of skin) to be rough, not smooth. igwaigwait akakuwan: I have eczema. cp. akwatamam. 
aigwaka ki-a (transitive verb) to have illicit sexual intercourse; to cohabit (of human beings only); to fornicate. cp. aigogwa.
aigwakakin ki-a (transitive verb) to have sexual intercourse with somebody's wife. 
aigwar ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch; to lacerate. kagwar eong ekukwai: the thorn has scratched me. 
aigwe ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to coil; to fold round; to mould. kogwe aikit kibwokia akito: coil a head pad for carrying fire-wood. 
aigweny ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to finish completely. cp. aijweny
aigwer ki-a (transitive verb) to prune, strip off (leaves of any plant). 
aigwerakin ki-a (transitive verb) to prune for or somewhere. kigwerakinai ekitoi ngol: prune that tree for me. 
aigwerar ki-a (transitive verb) to make bare (as of a tree or plant by stripping off its leaves); to prune bare too much. (reflexive verb) to be bare, leafless.
aigwet ko-a (transitive verb) to remove support, seat, prop, etc and make fall; to keep switching on (as of electric lights, radios, etc). 
aigwiligwila ki-a (reflexive verb) to twinkle, sparkle, glimmer, gleam, flicker, or glow. 
aigwong ki-a (intransitive verb) to rejoice; to acclaim, applaud, exult; to applaud; to acclaim; to extol. abu ngesi kigwong kerem engatuny: she/he was exultant after spearing the lion. cp. aibwong.
aigwongakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to rejoice on account of; to applaud; to exult. kigwongakisi emuu eberu: rejoice for the woman has given birth to twins. cp. aibwongakin
aigworo ki-o (transitive verb) (Serere) to mourn, bewail; to wail, to cry. cp. aibworo
aigwot ki-a (transitive verb) (Serere) (of butter from a gourd) to take out from a narrow opening; to migrate. cp. aibwot
aiir ki-a (transitive verb) to taste; to perceive with the tongue. iiri ngesi inyamat: he/she is tasting the food. 
aiiranar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep obeying or listening to (understand); to be intelligent. 
aiirar1 (singular noun F) understanding; cognition; obedience. 
aiirar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to hear; to understand; to hearken; to listen. iirasi yesi?: do you hear? have you heard? 
aiires (noun F) taste. ejai nges aiires naka ajon: she/he has a taste (for beer); a good judgement. aiires (plural noun F) (for) tasting. ajon nukiires: beer for tasting. 
aija ki-a (transitive verb) to accept, take from, collect, hand over, respond to call; to take and to give; to serve and to receive; to echo, give a present. kolot kija esolo: go and collect the tax. ejaan esolo: tax collector. ijaete imor: the mountains echo. 
aijaanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to serve, keep handing over. akoto ijo aijaanakin eong: I want you to serve me. 
aijaar ki-a (transitive verb) to accept; to receive from; to take away from. kijaa nges: take it. aijaar akiro: to reply; to echo. aijaar aikor: to take away for distribution. 
aijaaret (plural aijaareta) (noun F) an echo, reverberation, resonance, ricochet, or repetition. iremanakini ekingok aijaareteke: the dog is barking at its echo. 
aijadaanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to slouch, walk lazily. 
aijaet (plural aijaeta) (noun F) echo; reverberation; resonance. iremanakini ekingok aijaeteke: the dog barks at its echo. 
aijaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hand over to; to donate to; to serve to; to offer; to permit, give permission; to donate; to lend, concede; to impart, give or supply. kijaikinai ibore ngin: hand me that thing. akoto kijaik eong alosit ore: I want you to give me permission to go home. kijaik nges: give him. kijaikinai eong: give me. 
aijait ki-a (transitive verb) to hold out arm for begging; to beg, implore, supplicate. cp. ailipit; aigagat
aijak1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be exhausted, very tired; to pant, stagger. ijaka ngesi kanuka aipas: she/he is staggering with tiredness. ajakit akure: to be thirsty. 
aijak2 ko-a (transitive verb) to open with difficulty; to take off a thing stuck to something else (like taking off a stamp from a letter or open a lid of a box nailed down); to help deliver (a child or calf) at difficult birth. aijak akituk: to open the mouth when lips are parched with thirst or when jaws are swollen; to press down bottom jaw. ajakit akure: throat dried up, difficult to swallow, hence to be thirsty. ajakit eong itaok: I helped at the birth of calf by pulling it out. ajak ngesi akanin nuka lokatwan: she/he separated the clasped hands of a dead man. kajakit eong eibel loka akiring: I want to satisfy or to relieve the longing for meat. aijak anyakaeta: to be exhausted (with jaws hanging). 
aijakijak ki-a (transitive verb) (of cats or dogs drinking) to lap up. cp. aijur: (of cows or goats) to drink in one go.
aijakun ki-a (transitive verb) to wear out, down; to exhaust, finish. kejakunit eong adeka: illness has weakened, worn me down, or finished me. 
aijal ko-a (transitive verb) to give away freely, surrender, forsake, cede, leave to; to offer up, or sacrifice. ajalit eong akaijar kanuka akwapuka: I am risking my life for my country. 
aijalaanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to loiter, wait, hang around, linger, dally, skulk, dawdle, or loaf. 
aijalakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to be negligent about; to be sluggish in; to be careless with. ijalakin ijo kotoma akoniswam: you are negligent in your work regularly. ejalakinos itunga lu kaswamukec: these people are careless about their work. aitajalakin akoik: to relax the stomach (when tied too tight). 
aijalijala ki-a (intransitive verb) to be sluggish, negligent, careless; to do sluggishly, slovenly, lax; to have no zeal in work. ijalijalas kesi kotoma aswamusineikec: they are lazy or careless in their work. kejalijalit eong akuwan bala akoto adekakin: I feel weak as if about to fall sick. 
aijalionor ki-o (reflexive verb) to walk lazily, proudly, sluggishly. sirijalionor korot ilosi, kiwonyi atipet: do not walk so proudly on the road, be quick. 
aijam ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a fat man, slow walker, etc) to get off, start off; (of woollen blanket) to be soft. akoto eong aijam eringa akwap ecai: (I am a fat person) I want to start off before it is dark. 
aijamam ki-a (intransitive verb) to be at leisure, sit idle; to be idle, workless; to keep calm; to loaf; to vegetate. ijamamai ijo kaswamukon: you are at peace in your work. 
aijamijam1 ki-a (transitive verb) to talk nicely; to get round a person, to persuade; to induce; to tempt; sirikijamijam eong, mam alosi aiyuun: do not tempt me, I shall not agree. cp. aiyamiyam. 
aijamijam2 ki-o (reflexive verb) (of clouds) to lower. ejamijamun edou lo aicek lolo kia: this cloud is hovering low, it may rain the whole night. 
aijamijama ki-a (transitive verb) (of soil after rain, or of a woollen blanket) to be soft. sirikijamijam eong, mam alosi aiyuun: do not tempt me, I shall not agree. cp. aiyamiyam. 
aijamijamakin ki-a (transitive verb) to neglect. ijamijamakit aberu ngin ikedwe: that woman is soft on her bad-mannered children. cp. aiyamiyamakin. 
aijang ki-a (transitive verb) to shake; to rock. kinyek aijang ekitoi: stop shaking the tree. 
aijangar ki-a (transitive verb) to shake off; to awaken somebody by shaking them. aijangar akuwan: to take bodily exercise (by moving the body, shaking it, doing physical exercise). (intransitive verb) to be shaky; to be ill.(reflexive verb) to try something difficult. kolototo kijangaros aut kangina: go and try to wrestle over there. 
aijangaun ki-o (reflexive verb) to appear fastidious, finicky, faddy, or fussy; to come to a person with fastidious ways. 
aijangijang ki-a (transitive verb) to shake repeatedly, agitate. ijangijangi ijo emeesa: you are shaking the table. 
aijangijanga ki-a (intransitive verb) to be unsteady; to tremble; to shake; to rock; to stagger; to be fastidious, difficult to please, squeamish. ijangijangas apapulai: the papers are shaking (in the wind). 
aijany ki-a (intransitive verb) to flourish; (of a family – ateker) to have many members; to grow out into many branches. ijanyit ekitoi ngol: that tree has many branches. cp. aijom
aijar1 (noun F) life; bringing forth. aijar namam edaun: eternal life. aikul aijar: to enjoy or gratify oneself. cp. ainyam ejanta: to enjoy or indulge oneself greatly.
aijar2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be alive; to be healthy; to escape from danger; (of a female) to bring forth or deliver an offspring. ejarit ngesi: she/he is alive, healthy. ajar eong kotoma adeka: I have recovered from sickness. ajar akaberu ipese: my wife has delivered a baby girl. cp. angaleun.
aijarijar ki-a (transitive verb) to make loose; to slacken (a rope).
aijarijara ko-a (intransitive verb) to be too loose, too slack, too big, not to fit.
aijaun kia.(transitive verb) to receive in the hands; to accept; to welcome a guest. aijaun ekosio: to sing the refrain of a song. aijaun akiro: to accept, believe. sirikijau akiro numam ijeni: do not believe any story that you are not sure of. aijaun akoik: to be pregnant. ajaun aberuka akoik: my wife is pregnant. 
aije ko-a (transitive verb) to mould pots; to weave mats or baskets; to plait with grass; to weave; to make grass granary; to make round. kojeata amoti aare: mould two pots. kojeikinai edula: make me a granary of clay and grass. kojeasi ngesi ngina arai bo kojeutu ngesi ne: mould it over there or do it here. 
aijeburikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to be abandoned, derelict or relinquished. ireria lu kere ijeburikitos: all these homes are desolate. 
aijec1 (singular noun F) prolonged pain after childbirth; abortion through natural causes (not intentional); miscarriage. cp. aicikun akoik: to procure an abortion.
aijec2 ki-a (transitive verb) (of women and animals) to abort; to speak the whole truth; to say all one knows, speak out. aberu ngin etapit aijec idwe: that woman is fond of aborting. abu ngesi kijece akiroke inera: she/he told the whole truth. cp. aicik.
aijecakin ki-a (transitive verb) to abort for. akiteng ngin abu kijecak itaok idiope, kasodi eong agwelar nges: that cow aborted once, so I sold it. 
aijece ki-a (transitive verb) to do on purpose; to do deliberately. 
aijeceikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do on purpose; to do deliberately. 
aijecun ki-a (transitive verb) to abort or miscarry (a pregnancy). 
aijek ki-o (transitive verb) to rock; to hang up; to shake; to swing; to raise on high; to dangle; to depend. kijek ikonigoen arwatat: hang your clothes on the wall. ijeki emuron akae: the witchdoctor is shaking the rattle. kijekono ikoku motoko kinyek aimony: rock the child to and fro, perhaps it may stop crying. cp. ainen.
aijekeun1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to swing up and down. ejekeun akekoik kanuka etengei: his stomach swings up and down on account of hunger. ijekeunit enenwa akou kokitoi: the bat hangs head down from the tree. 
aijekeun2 ki-o (transitive verb) to let down (as of a basket from a tree, or a bucket on a rope). 
aijekijeko ki-o (intransitive verb) a repetition of aijek: to swing, etc; to shake. kidol jo Kampala airabes ijekijekos imeederan: if you reach parliament in Kampala the flags flutter in the wind. cp. aijel.
aijekokin1 ki-o (reflexive verb) to be too short, too little, not long enough, not enough, not sufficient, insufficient. ejekokin auno na, mam edolit aitem etogo: this string is too short, it is not long enough to measure the house. cp. akadakin.
aijekokin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to hang up. kijekok etaala kuju: hang up the lamp. cp. aikajakin 
aijekokin3 okitoi ki-o (reflexive verb) to hang oneself on a tree. cp. amyedakin. 
aijekoor ki-a (intransitive verb) to hang or to swing away. 
aijekor ki-o (intransitive verb) to be little or too little; to be short, insufficient. ejekoros inyamat kakoikika: my stomach is empty with too little food in it. 
aijel1 ki-a (transitive verb) to lick (anything, like a dog does). ijeli ikapa akekuwan: the cat is licking its body. cp. aime, aidyel.
aijel2 ki-o (transitive verb) to swing legs, when sitting on tree or table or high place; (of broken leg, cloth hung to dry) to swing in the wind. cp. aijeko. 
aijelel1 ki-o (intransitive verb) (Serere) to sleep on a bed. ejelelei eong kokuju oitaada: I am sleeping on the bed. cp. aicelel.
aijelel2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to rain heavily but locally. ejelel edou ko Kapir: it rained heavily in Kapir. 
aijelelaar1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to glide or slide away (as of a snake). 
aijelelaar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to hurl, launch, throw by force (as of a catapult, sling, etc). ijelelaanarete idwe ikojoi kotoma akabwaikec: the children hurl arrows with their bows. 
aijeleleikin ki-o (transitive verb) to put on top of a shelve; to shelve (as of kitchen things, cups etc); to put on a table after cleaning. 
aijeleleun ki-o (intransitive verb) to glide this way, towards us. 
aijeliar ki-a (intransitive verb) to slide away; to slip away; to freewheel; to roll away; (of life) to ebb away; to be slowly flying. 
aijelijel ki-a (transitive verb) (of food or drink) to be tasteless; to be fed up with. 
aijelijelikin ki-a (transitive verb) to be tired of or fed up with; to have a disgust for somebody or something (used with etau: the heart). ijelijelit ekatau ekesa ngol: I cannot bear the sight of that guy. ejelijelakinos itunga lu itawonokec: these people cannot stand each other. 
aijem ki-a (transitive verb) to taste with tongue once. kijem edia arai edolit amuunyu: taste the sauce if the salt is enough. cp. aiir.
aijemijem ki-a (transitive verb) to taste with tongue more than once. kijemijem ecaai arai ejijim: taste the tea if it is sweet. cp. aiiranar.
aijen1 (singular noun F) knowledge; understanding; perception, or sense; cognition. cp. acoa 
aijen2 ko-a (transitive verb) to know; to be able; to understand; to recognise; to be ware of; to distinguish. kijeni ijo eong?: do you know me? ejeni ngesi aijen: she/he knows very well. aijen aberu: to have carnal knowledge of a woman. ejena ngesi noi: she/he is well-known, or is esteemed. 
aijeng ko-a (transitive verb) to flay; to skin (as of an animal); to cut open by surgery; to slaughter; (of animals) to cut up or to skin; to operate upon. cp. atubutub. 
aijeny ko-a (transitive verb) to clean with fingers (as of food from plate or ladle). cp. aidweny
aijep ko-a (transitive verb) to cut down; to chop; to fell a tree; to lumber; to cleave. kojep ekitoi: cut down the tree, fell the tree. aijep etunganan: to cheat a person out of his belongings; to defraud, swindle, con, dupe, or trick. ejepi ejakait ngol iketunga k’acoa: that chief cleverly defrauds (cons) his people. cp. aibet: to chop firewood.
aijer1 ki-a (transitive verb) to belch. aijer egwei: to belch from indigestion or constipation; to have an evil breath.
aijer2 ki-a (transitive verb) to twist (rope); to screw; to unwind; to twist words or statements, twist the neck, or to wring cloth. sirikijerak akakiro: do not twist my words. aijerun edoi: to twist a rope (for chasing birds or locusts).cp. aije.
aijer3 ko-a (transitive verb) (of anything) to spread out on ground to dry or for any other reason. kojera amukeke kooko: spread the sliced potatoes to dry. kojeras egoe kaany eong: spread or hold out the cloth, let me see. 
aijerakin ki-a (transitive verb) to screw on or off; to twist together; to twist (words) for; to twist (neck) for; to wind (as of watch); to contort. kijerakinai eong auno: twist for me a rope. sirikijerak akakiro: do not twist my words. (reflexive verb) to squirm, writhe, twist, or struggle. 
aijerasit (plural aijereta) (noun F) a screw, spiral marks of a saw or plane; unevenness.
aijeruko ki-o (intransitive verb) to be unmanageable; to rebel against; to be rebellious; to walk proudly, slowly. sirijeruko kakonye kapapakon: do not be rebellious against your father. ijerukos itelepai lu: these boys are unmanageable.
aijerukokin ki-o (transitive verb) to rebel against. cp. angerokin. 
aijerun akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to look sideways angrily at somebody. 
aijerun ki-a (intransitive verb) to belch. aijerun inyamat: to belch (due to satisfaction).
aijes1 ki-a (transitive verb) to slip or put down; to let down (as of price or like putting shillings on the table, millet into the granary, etc). kijes ikonisirigin omeesa: put your money on the table (i.e. letting them slip from hands). kijesasi ekusitiai kwap: lower your price. aijes eporoto ki-a (transitive verb) to lower the voice, inflect the voice. aijes einer: to speak at a low tone; to modulate speech. aijes awoere: to sing in lower tones. 
aijes2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be coloured thus. ejesi akonikiteng ai?: what colour is your cow? ejesi bee: it is red. ejesi cuc: it is black. ejesi kia: it is very white. ejesi pus: it is grey. ejesi naese: it is mottly grey. ejesi naongor: it is dark brown. 
aijesakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to slip, glide, go down, or to slope down. erot lo ijesakin kwap obuka: this road goes down to my village. 
aijesar ki-a (transitive verb) to put down (as of price); to let down, abase a thing high up; to let slip down; to pour out. (intransitive verb) to glide, go, slip down (as one going down-hill, etc); to slip down, slide, decline. (reflexive verb) to go down; to diminish (as of water in river, as of people or anything); to slope down. 
aijesaret (plural aijesareta) (noun F) effusion; abasement; demeaning; degradation. 
aijesitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to totter (like a child or drunken person). cp. aigesitoi
aijesun ki-a (transitive verb) to lower, make smaller, diminish. kijesu eporotokon: lower your voice. (intransitive verb) to diminish; to slope down, become smaller, slide down. (reflexive verb) to come down this way; to diminish; to descend; (of rain or water) influx.. ejesunos ikiliok ajesa: the men have come down into the valley. 
aijet ko-a (intransitive verb) to look like. ejesi kia: looks very white. cp. ejesi. 
ajiun ko-a (intransitive verb) to fight for; to try very hard to do something. ajiun apugan: to fight for self-governance. 
aiji ko-o (intransitive verb) to fight; to contend; to resist; to race, conflict. akoto aiji kajo kegaali: I want to race with you on the bicycle. ejiete kesi: they are fighting. ejiosi itelepai: the boys are fighting. ajiun apolou: to fight or struggle for one’s status (and win).
aijiar ki-a (transitive verb) to polish with fat or anything. cp. aninaar, airudar , aiswagar. 
aijie ko-a (transitive verb) to coil (rope or carrying pad); to make round. ejieete angor aikita: the women coil the carrying pads. 
aijier ko-a (transitive verb) to spread out to dry; to dry in the sun. cp. aisiarar, aterar, aloiar, aiweliwel, aijer. kolot ber aijier acok: go and spread out to dry the potatoes (in the sun). 
aijiiko (plural aijiikon) (noun F) a spoon; a ladle. cp. akaale
aijik ki-a (transitive verb) to absorb (as of liquids); to press down (as of cotton in bag); to press in (as of cotton wool in ear); to punch (a person or things); to close off hermetically. cp. aicik. 
aijikakin ki-a (transitive verb) to block up, close up (as of road, door, ear with cotton); to have constipation. ijikakit ngesi erot k’ikukwa: she/he has blocked the road with thorns. ijikakina erot: the road is blocked. ijikakina akit: the ear is blocked, she/he is deaf. ijikakina akoik: she/he has constipation. 
aijikar ki-a (transitive verb) to absorb (as of liquids); to dry up through absorption.
aijilil ki-a (transitive verb) to strain; to distil; to filter (liquids); to sift. kijilil akipi kolema agasia: strain the water to remove the dirt. cp. ailep. 
aijililaar ki-a (transitive verb) to drain away. (reflexive verb) to disappear (as of water after rain); to infiltrate. cp. aleliar. 
aijililet (plural aijilileta) (noun F) a strainer; a sieve; a filter. cp. eijiliet.
