aijililiar ki-a (transitive verb) to drain away. (reflexive verb) to disappear (as of water after rain); to infiltrate. cp. aleliar. 
aijililikin ki-a (transitive verb) to filter into or for; to instil. kijililik akipi amot na: filter the water into this pot. 
aijililikinet (plural aijililikineta) (noun F) a sieve; a strainer. cp. aliet.
aijim ki-o (intransitive verb) to be cloudy, misty, no sunshine. ijimit lolo akwap: it is very cloudy, hazy, misty today. 
aijimiikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to develop into wounds or ulcers; to be covered with ulcers or sores; to be ulcerated. akakuwan kere ekoto aijimiikin: my whole body is going to become ulcerated (be covered with ulcers, sores). 
aijimijim ki-o (intransitive verb) (of weather) to be drizzling; to be cloudy; to be overcast; to spit a little (like a snake); to tremble with cold. ijimijimi emun aimul: the snake spits poison. ijimijimi edou akwap: it drizzles. ejimijimit eong akuwan aterot: I am not feeling well on account of the cold. cp. alibakin, ailimilim, aimwaanar, aijir.
aijimikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to hurt; to be sore. ijimikit akakuwan kanuka aterot: I feel very cold. cp. aibinyikin.
aijimokin ki-o (intransitive verb) (of the sky) to be very cloudy or dark with rain; to spit a little. ijimokit Soroti, bala etepi edou: it is very dark over Soroti as if it is raining there. 
aijip ko-a (transitive verb) to look at or inspect (a very small object like a jigger in one’s foot) carefully; to look sharp. cp. aigip; ajupujup: to look at small things. 
aijipijip ko-a (transitive verb) to keep looking sharply (at a small thing, like a jigger or small thing fallen on the ground); to go and look; to go and find out. 
aijir ki-a (intransitive verb) to drizzle; to cry or weep softly. aijirijir aimony: to weep softly. aijirijir awoore: to sing softly. kinyek akiru kijira, kolot: let the drizzle cease, and then go. 
aijiriar ki-o (reflexive verb) to relent; to go slowly; to freewheel. cp. aiyapar, aideriar, aikwaar. 
aijirijir ki-a (intransitive verb) to be drizzling; to sing softly; to mourn quietly. aijirijir eporoto: to croon. 
aijirijiriar ki-a (intransitive verb) to rain a little; to slacken (of rain or liquids); to boil away (as of liquids slowly boiling and evaporating away). ejirijiriasi akipi ngun, kodaka awai: that water is boiling away, take it from the fire and put it aside. 
aijirikin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to sprinkle in drops (as of salt, dust, etc); to pour out a little. kijirik akipi eboga: sprinkle water on the vegetables. loibatisai ijirikini ngesi akipi oreet: he who baptises pours a little water on another’s forehead. cp. aijiilikin.
aijirikin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to refuse to leave a place. ejirikin ngesi togoke: she/he has refused to leave her/his house. cp. agirokin.
aijo ki-o (transitive verb) to pour without missing target (as of liquid); to let fall; to take to heart (of words). kolot aijo akipi amot: go and pour water into the pot. 
aijobira ki-a (intransitive verb) to go about aimlessly, pointlessly, uselessly, without direction or without purpose; to roam or wander about. 
aijodijod ki-a (intransitive verb) to try to persuade repeatedly; to try to prevail on; to misadvise; to hop on one leg. kijodijod ekesa ngol alosit ore: persuade that guy to go home. cp. aicodicod. 
aijodo ki-o (transitive verb) to persuade; to prevail on; to advise, adulate, pull wires. cp. aiyodo: to influence; to fish for compliments, show servile flattery; to flatter. kejodoi eong jo alosit: I am persuading you to go. cp. aidelun. 
aijodoet (plural aijodoeta) (noun F) flattery; sweet talk; smooth talk; sycophancy; adulation. 
aijogan ki-a (transitive verb) to feel excited. aisijogan: to excite, enthuse, animate, motivate or agitate. 
aijoikin ki-o (transitive verb) (of liquids) to pour into; (of things) to pour into; (of animals or people) to gather into. kijoik akile ocupa: pour milk into the bottle. kijoik akimai odula: put the millet into the granary. kijoik akituk auj: drive the cows into the kraal. (reflexive verb) to gather; to contain, hold much. ejoikinos akipi nuipu toma ataagi ngin: a great deal of water has gone into that tank. cp. ailosikin. 
aijoja ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a few amongst many) to fight or beat; (of one against more than one) to fight roundabout, running in all directions. abu eong kejoja kokiding otunga luepu noi: I fought in the midst of many people. (transitive verb) to change or to be changed about often. lukapolok ijojaete esisianakinan: the authorities shift the teacher about. aijoja atapen: to keep shifting the grinding stone from one hand to the other. aijoja akiro: to go from one to another, telling them a story or news. aijojakinit lailo laije: to dart here and there in vain. aijoja ikiliok: (of a cheating woman) to play one man against another; to double deal. cp. alimonor. 
aijojaanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to gather crowd (of men, animals, fish, etc) together in one place; to drive together, rushing about. aijojaanakin ibaren luiramiramere: to drive livestock together in a sown millet field (to trample the seeds into the soil).
aijojatoi ki-a (intransitive verb) to be astir. 
aijok ki-o (transitive verb) to change from place to place. kapas eong aijokio ikar kere: I am tired of being transferred every year. cp. aijul.
aijokokin ki-o (transitive verb) to change to another place; to transfer. ejokokit eong akakituk orekon: I have transferred my cows to your home. (reflexive verb) to exchange. kejokokinos oni akituk aare: let us exchange two cows. 
aijokor ki-o (transitive verb) to change; to take to, remove to another place. kijoko eicolong lo ngina: shift this chair there. 
aijolakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to serve; to be a waiter to. akoto ijo kijolak eong kane ajai: I want you to serve me from where I am. cp. aijaanakin, aiyakitoi. 
aijolil ki-o (transitive verb) to steal constantly, secretly. kidoido je aijolil iboro k’itunga: the habit of stealing people’s property is now engrained in him. cp. aidadat. 
aijolilis (plural aijolilisio) (noun F) a crane or pulley for lifting loads. 
aijolior ki-o (transitive verb) to lower carefully; steal quietly. cp. acedar. 
aijoliun ki-o (transitive verb) to lower carefully. 
aijom ki-a (intransitive verb) (of tree branches) to spread out; (of family) to spread out, to branch out, or to expand afar. ijomit emuria noi: the weeds have spread out very much. aijom alosit: to waddle; to walk slowly, heavily (like a fat person or animal). ijomijomi epege alosit: the pig waddles when walking. cp. anyanyaar, aipit, aliar.
aijomoor ki-o (transitive verb) to ensnare from somewhere; to persuade and lead away; to lead a person away into a trap; to deceive or ambush. ekoto ngesi aijomoor eong oreke: she/he wants to trick me into going to his home (to take me there to beat). 
aijomoun ki-o (transitive verb) to ensnare from here; to persuade and lead this way; to lead a person this way into a trap; to decoy, deceive or ambush. akoto eong aijomoun ngesi oreka: I want to trick him to my home (to bring him here to harm). 
aijong ki-a (intransitive verb) to take some away or off; to cut off (as of cloth); to reduce number or quantity of anything; to diminish quantity or value or number; to cut pay. ijongit ijo akituk noi: you have diminished your cows very much. sirikijong ikasirigin lueropit, kiyatak: do not cut my pay, increase it. 
aijongakin ki-a (transitive verb) to take away what is too much or too full too many (as of water out of too full vessel, as of too much money, food or of cows). kijongak akonikituk, epuata kauj: take some of your cows away, they are too many in the kraal. 
aijongar ki-o (transitive verb) to diminish; to take out, away, abolish (laws); to stop (as of drinking or of a leak, etc). sirikiyatak ijo aijong ajon: do not take any more beer - stop drinking. ijongas ajon kotoma amot: the beer has diminished in the pot. ejongaros ikasirigin: my money has diminished. 
aijongijong akuwan ki-a (transitive verb) to shake the body; to exercise or to work out or train; to do callisthenics or aerobics. 
aijonijon ki-a (transitive verb) to beat up. 
aijono ko-o (intransitive verb) to be calm; to be at ease; (of temperature) to have cooled down; (of food) to have cooled down; (of an angry person) to have calmed; to be calm; (of adult people or children) to be at ease; (of hunger) to calm down; (of wounds) to get better or heal i.e. less painful. 
aijony ki-a (intransitive verb) to run (taking short steps) like a child; to run like short men do; to jog. 
aijonyijony ki-a (transitive verb) to canter, run, gallop, trot, jog or sprint. 
aijool ki-o (transitive verb) to throw down; (of things into a hole or water) to let down; to steal. kijool iboro ngul toma aipany naarai mam bobo ekotoi: throw those things into the hole because they are no longer wanted. ijoolie ekokolan iboro k’itunga: the thief steals people’s things. cp. akokwaar, aidoonokin. 
aijoolikin ki-o (transitive verb) to put or let down a heavy load on to a lorry or anything; to put quietly aside; to put quietly into the pocket. kijoolikis emoru ngol toma amotoka: lift that big stone onto the lorry. cp. acedakin. 
aijoolis (plural aijoolisio) (noun F) a crane for loading; a native pulley used to let heavy loads down or lift them from a deep hole. 
aijoolun ki-o (transitive verb) to lower carefully. 
aijoor ki-o (transitive verb) (of a receptacle) to contain; (of a container, vessel) to hold. etogo lo mam epedori aijoor itunga lu kere (naarai edite noi): this house will not hold all these people (because it is too small). amot ngin ijoorit acupai atomon: that pot holds ten bottles of liquid. 
aijop ki-o (transitive verb) to make unequal (in size, length, height or number); to put unevenly; to make uneven; to make different. kijopoto icupai ienete: tie the bottles in alternation. aberu ngin ijopijopi aur: that woman alternates her children (produces boys and girls in alternation).
aijopijopo (noun F) disparity. ijopijopo etiai akakituk kanukon: there is disparity between the number of my cows and yours. 
aijopokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be unequal (in size, quantity, height, number); to be different. ijopokino etaceka kalokon: my pay is different from yours. (transitive verb) to make unequal. 
aijopor ki-o (transitive verb) to make unequal; to shorten (of anything); to cut off (a piece); to diminish (of solid things and of numbers). kijoposi etiaikec: make their number unequal. (reflexive verb) to be unequal; to be less, have diminished, etc. 
aijor1 ki-a (transitive verb) to catch as of fish or ants, locusts; to hunt. aijor agaria: to catch small fish. cp. aiyor
aijor2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to squat; to crouch, sit down on haunches; to sit down to work; to persevere doing it, etc. aijor aswam: to work always (literally, to crouch all the time working). aloto luce kere, eong bon ajori kane: others have all gone, I alone am sitting here on my haunches or left at home. 
aijore ki-o (transitive verb) to hunt animals; to raid people; (of many) to steal or rustle. Ikaramoja ka Iturukana ijoreete itunga luce: the Karimojong and Turkana tribes raid other peoples. 
aijoreun ki-a (transitive verb) to make prisoner; to catch slaves; to hunt or catch animals, small fish, locusts or ants. apotu kolo Imo kijoreoto Iteso: in the past the Baganda or foreigners made the Iteso their slaves. 
aijorijor ki-a (transitive verb) to get fed up with; to catch repeatedly; to annoy; to dislike; to shun. ejorijori eong ekatau: I have angina pectoris (a heart disease which periodically causes pain in the chest); I feel like vomiting. aswam ngin ekoto aijorijor eong: I am getting fed up with that work. 
aijorijoronor ki-o (reflexive verb) to keep on visiting for the sake of food, begging food or anything else. sirijorijoronor oreke: do not annoy him with your frequent visits to his home. aijorojoronokin: to be in a hurry. aijorojorunun: to run this way. aijorijoror aswam: to work quickly ahead; to hurry to work. aijorijoror alosit: to run quickly. 
aijorijoroor ki-o (transitive verb) to push one ahead; to force to do; to do quickly. ejorijoroo ejakait etunganan kanuka esolo: the chief has made a man run for his graduated tax (catching him and pushing him forward) (intransitive verb) to run quickly; to be on the point of doing; to hurry quickly. 
aijorim ki-a (transitive verb) to take all; to catch all; to steal all men or animals or fish or anything. abu ekokolan kijorima ikaboro kere: a thief stole all my property. ijorimaete kesi akokoroi aiar: they kill chicken en masse. 
aijorimaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away all (people, animals and things); to kill all; to destroy, annihilate, obliterate or devastate all. adau akolong aijorimaar epaaba kere: the heat has destroyed all the cotton in the farm. (reflexive verb) to be all finished. ejorimaaros ikatunga kere atwakare: all my relatives are dead. cp. amudiar.
aijorimaun ki-a (transitive verb) to do a thing or an action altogether; to take all, catch all; to steal all, etc and bring. ejorimautu ijaka itunga kanuka esolo: the chiefs caught all the people for defaulting graduated tax. (reflexive verb) to be all in a certain state or condition. ejorimaun epaaba akonore: the cotton is all blossomed at once. ejorimaunos itunga ailip ebaga: all the people are attending Christmas prayers. 
aijoronor ki-o (transitive verb) to seize, catch; to take away continually; to raid constantly. ejai egwang loijoronori ikamiyoi: there is a wild cat that keeps on taking away my chicks. 
aijose ki-o (intransitive verb) to pretend, feign; to act as if; to dissemble, dissimulate. ijosei ngesi iswamai: she/he pretends to work. ejotoi ngesi ejose: she/he pretends to sleep. epod ngesi ejose: she/he pretends to complain. aimony ejose: to pretend to weep/mourn/cry. adeka ejose: pretended sickness. 
aijoseikin ki-o (transitive verb) to pretend; to feign; to sham. ijoseikinit ijo ajo: you are feigning sleep. aijoseonokin: to pretend/feign regularly. 
aijoseonut1 (noun F) pretension; sham; charade. 
aijoseonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to pretend; to sham. 
aijot1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of the sun or moon) to set; to go down. aijot eporoto: (of a nervous person about to make a speech) to clear the throat. elosi akolong aijot: the sun is about to set. aijot ore: to go home. kijota ber ekoniporoto: first clear your throat. aijot ebarenit: sharpen the razor. 
aijot2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to lean over aside (to let somebody else pass). 
aijot3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to shift from side to side. aijot iwos: to shift on one’s buttocks. ijosi ngesi iwos iboyei: she/he is shifting on her/his buttocks. 
aijotakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to sit on one buttock; to sit aside; (of anything) to lean over (transitive verb) to put something aside (to let somebody pass) (reflexive verb) to sit on one buttock; to sit aside; (of anything) to lean over cp. aisiepokin, agoyaar: (of anything) to lean over; to lean aside. 
aijotar eporoto ki-a (intransitive verb) to cough slightly; to clear throat. aijotar aola: to cough slightly. 
aijoun ki-o (transitive verb) to call hither; to gather here; to bring here. kijou itunga kwi lailo: call those people here. (reflexive verb) to lead this way; to come here. ejounos itunga kwi kere lailo: all the other people have gathered here. 
aiju ki-a (transitive verb) to suck dry; to absorb; to hiss in anger or disapproval. eju akwap akipi kere: the earth or the soil has absorbed all the water. ijui ikoku ikisin katotoke: the child sucks the breast of its mother. cp. anakar akipi kere.
aijuanar ki-o (transitive verb) to deride, ridicule, scoff, disparage, mock, scorn, or disdain.
aijuar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to despise; to insult, jeer at; to refuse with insulting looks. engisit eong ngesi kosodi ngesi aijuar eong: I asked him but he jeered me. sirijuanari itunga: do not jeer people. cp. amenit.
aijuar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to suck away; to absorb; to drain, evaporate; to finish completely. ejuasi alup akipi kere: the soil has absorbed all the water. (reflexive verb) to dry up; to be absorbed; to be despised. ejuaros akipi kere kanuka akolong: all water was evaporated by the sun. 
aijuarit ki-o (transitive verb) to laugh at; to scorn, ridicule. ijuanaros itunga lu: these people are hissing in anger. ejua eong etau: I have disliked it. ijuarit ekatau akonikiro: I despise what you say.
aijuet (plural aijueta) (noun F) suction; absorption; assimilation. 
aijuijo ki-a (intransitive verb) to drizzle, feel miserable. kejuijuit eong akuwan: I feel miserable. ejuijuit eong etau: I feel doubtful about it. 
aijuikin ki-a (transitive verb) to suck for a short time. kijuik ajon kolot: you suck a little beer and go. 
aijuju ki-a (transitive verb) to drain off or to mop up; (of blotting paper) to absorb or suck; to kiss; to carry pollen; to drink up; to keep sucking (as of child, or as of bees sucking pollen or butterflies sucking flowers). aijuju inyamat: to digest or absorb food. ijujue acukia atur: the sunbird is sucking flowers. cp. aijujuar
aijujuar ki-a (transitive verb) to drain off or to mop up; to drink up; to absorb or suck; to keep sucking (as of child, or as of bees sucking pollen or butterflies sucking flowers). aijujuar inyamat: to digest or to absorb food. ijujue akoik inyamat: the stomach absorbs the digested food. ejujuasi ikapejok ajon: my visitors have finished all the beer.
aijuk1 ki-a (transitive verb) to push; to despatch; to send. kijuk ekagaali, kapas eong: push my bicycle, I am tired. cp. aiyaki. 
aijuk2 ko-o (transitive verb) to refuse (of anything). ajuk ikakoku abunere osomero: my child has refused to come to school. cp. ainger.
aijuk3 ko-o (transitive verb) to paint, smear with ashes or clay, or contents of goat, sheep or cattle bowels as ordeal of the Iteso; (of a person or an animal) to become angry, furious, irate (like a bull goring an anthill with its horns in preparation for a fight). ejukete Iteso aberu naepotie ikijit: the Iteso smear a young Teso woman who is pregnant with contents of a cow’s stomach. aijuk akiria: to mark or tarnish with flour. ejukitai nges akiria: she/he is covered with flour dust (after grinding millet or cassava). 
aijukakin ki-a (transitive verb) to send a thing to; to send on errand; to send for somebody; to actuate. kejukakit eong jo etelepat lo: I am sending you this boy. kejukakit eong ijo eitaabo lo: I have sent you this book. 
aijukanar ki-a (transitive verb) to send often; to export and import. 
aijukar ki-a (transitive verb) to send somewhere on an errand; to consign; to send away; to push forward; to despatch; to make visible, protruding, push forward. aijukar ko posita: to send by post. kijukasi: push off. akoto aijukar ijo Katakwi: I want to send you to Katakwi. (reflexive verb) to go away in crowds (as of people to market, of a swarm of locusts, etc). ejuka aberu akoik: that woman is clearly pregnant and is about to deliver (literally, pushes her stomach forward). 
aijukujuk ki-a (transitive verb) to be too much for; to be unable to do or look after a work by oneself. kapas eong aijukujuk eduan: I am tired of weeding alone. ejukujukit eong idwe ngul kere: I am looking after all those children by myself. ejukujukit eong aswam ngin: I am doing all that work (and is too much for me). (intransitive verb) to be crowded together; to be near one another. ijukujukas itunga kokeresia: people are crowded in the cathedral. cp. aigangigang.
aijukujuka ki-a (intransitive verb) to be many. ijukujukas ikong: there are many white ants. 
aijukujukakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be packed together or crowded; to be full of. ejukujukakinos ipejok oreka: my house is full of visitors. 
aijukun ki-a (transitive verb) to send hither (of a big crowd); to import; to push this way. (reflexive verb) (of anything) to crowd together; to gather or be crowded together; to push one another; to exude. 
aijul ki-a (transitive verb) to turn round; to alter (food, etc); (of place or clothes, manners or religion) to change; to interpret, convert, or to translate. cp. ailoc: to transfer (persons or animals or things); to turn round. aijul edini: to be converted to another religion or faith. akoto aijul inyamat luanyami, kapas eong ainyam alos: I want to have a change of food, I am tired of millet. 
aijulakin ki-a (transitive verb) to translate for; to change about; to do alternatively (as fighting one and then another, doing this and then something else, change food about). ejulaki aberu ngin aur: that woman has altered her birth (that is, has borne a child of a different sex from the previous one). 
aijulanakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be changeable, fickle, variable, unsettled, unpredictable, unreliable, unstable, unfixed, irregular, or undependable. 
aijular ki-a (intransitive verb) to lose free will; to be mad; to ask God for a favour; to put somewhere else. cp. aipolia: to gather for prayer. 
aijulir ki-a (transitive verb) to witness or to testify in a law suit. cp. aijen. 
aijulujul ki-a (transitive verb) to change about; to turn about; to be reconverted; to interpret; to spread talk; (of crops) to rotate. 
aijulujuleta (plural noun F) a rotation (as of crops). kibusakinit yes akor kaijulujuleta: it is necessary that you plant in rotation. 
aijulul ki-o (intransitive verb) to slope downwards, as of roof; to be stooped; to hang down upside-down. ijululei emenia kokuju okitoi: the bat hangs head downwards on the tree. ijululeete irotin: the roads slope downwards. cp. abuburiar.
aijulun ki-o (reflexive verb) to be converted; to be changed about; to be head first (in birth), head down (in falling). cp. eijuluna.
aijulunio (singular noun F) conversion (to the speaker’s side or viewpoint); adaptation; alteration; translation; renovation.
aijunga ki-a (transitive verb) to dress wounds; to give hot compression; to wash clothes without soap. cp. aimad, aicu. 
aijungakin ki-a (transitive verb) to dress wounds for; to give hot compression to, squeeze (cloth when washing); to make a dress with pleats. 
aijup ko-a (transitive verb) to pick out (as of a jigger or thorns); to prick (as of little wounds); to scrutinize (a thing nearby or person far off); to pick potatoes or anything. ajupujup: to repeatedly pick or prick (as remnants of food in teeth); to find out. cp. aijip.
aijupujup ki-a (transitive verb) to go and look, go and find out. cp. aijipijip. 
aijupun ko-a (transitive verb) to pick (as of teeth or food, especially of a hen or birds). cp. ajipun. 
aijur ko-a (transitive verb) to lick; to sip, suck up, or to sniff up. ejurete akituk akipi: the cows drink water (from a nearly dry swamp). ejuri ngesi ecaai loemwana: she/he sips hot tea. aijur edoot: to lick salt clay. 
aijut ko-o (transitive verb) to wipe clean (with finger or anything); to shave clean with razor; to clean the anus after defecating. aijut aidoole: to wipe the anus (after going to the toilet).
aijuwanar ki-a (transitive verb) to jeer; to despise, mock, deride; to scoff. inyo bo kijuwanara ijo eong?: why do you jeer at me? 
aijwaka ki-a (transitive verb) (of a person with rotten teeth) to chew, suck dry tough meat or food. ijwakai emojong akekiring: the old man sucks the tough meat because he lacks teeth. 
aijwakar (transitive verb) to suck meat dry, as of children or old men (note: for animals such as dogs or cats, use aijwakijwak: to lap milk, water, etc). cp. aijwaka
aijwakijwak ki-a (transitive verb) (of dogs and cats, etc) to lap liquids. ijwakijwaki ekingok akile: the dog is lapping milk. cp. aijwekijwek. 
aijwala ki-a (transitive verb) to make beer tasteless by adding too much water; to make soup tasteless by always boiling the same bone or meat again and again. ijwala ijo adakai ngin k’akipi: you spoil the beer by adding too much water. 
aijwalaar ki-a (transitive verb) to make altogether insipid, as of soup. 
aijwalaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be insipid; to be tasteless, stale for. ijwalaikit emugaati lo: this bread is stale, tasteless.
aijwalaun ki-a (transitive verb) to despise, ridicule. 
aijwalaunit ki-a (transitive verb) to be despising, ridiculing. 
aijwat ko-a (transitive verb) to beat, give a thrashing, hitting. adum eong ejakait ejwasi etunganan: I found the chief beating a man (for not paying tax, perhaps). cp. aile, aida.
aijwatar ki-a (transitive verb) to beat slightly (with small stick); to sweep a little; to clear throat (before speaking). cp. aijotar.
aijwekijwek ki-a (transitive verb) (of dogs and cats, etc) to lap liquids. ijwekijweki ikapa akile: the cat laps milk. cp. aijwakijwak. 
aijweny ko-a (transitive verb) (of anything) to finish eating completely. cp. aidweny.
aika1 ki-a (transitive verb) (of many together) to beat or hunt abreast for big and small animals; (of a man who has a case) to persecute. ikaete itelepai imirio: the boys are hunting rats. abu America kikaa Isiriamun kanuka asurokinio napaarasia 11/9/2001: America persecuted Muslims after the September 11, 2001 plane attack on the World Trade Centre in New York. cp. eriga, aikat.
aika2 ki-a (transitive verb) to interfere; to cause trouble. ikaenenei ijo akiro apaarasia kere: you are always looking for trouble. 
aikaap (singular noun F) beginning of pregnancy in cows. 
aikaar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to hunt away from home. alosi aikaar: I am going to hunt over there 
aikaar2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to walk abreast (many together); (of a tree or plants) to branch out; (of a family) to branch out; to be a big family, spread out. (reflexive verb) to walk abreast; to spread or branch out or ramify. ekaaros isirikaalei korot: the soldiers are walking abreast on the road. ekaar edou etepi: the rain is going in front like a broad screen. ekaaros ikito atenueik: the trees have branched out. ateker naka Oumo ekaar: Oumo’s clan (the founder of Kumi town) has spread out. cp. alalaar, anyaar, apoloor. 
aikaboikin ki-o (transitive verb) to grasp; (as of football) to grip, to catch (when thrown at); to catch (as of a dog catching a piece of meat thrown in an open mouth). kikaboik emopiira: catch the ball. 
aikabub ki-o (intransitive verb) (of all seeds) to be fully swollen with water and ready to burst; to be fully grown. ekabubuutu imomwa: the sorghum seeds have swollen out (full of water, ready to burst). 
aikabubukin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be drowsy; to be heavy with sleep; to be fully grown. ekabubukinos akonyeka kanuka ajo: my eyes feel heavy with sleep. 
aikabubuun ki-o (intransitive verb) to be fully swollen, satiated with water, fully grown, quite ripe (as of maize seed or any fruit). 
aikac ko-a (transitive verb) to intercept; to cut off, as of thief trying to escape; (of animals in hunting trying) to surround it and catch it; to leave a passage. yesi kere kokacata amotoka tetere mam kinangari: all of you leave a passage for the car lest it knock you down. aikac aswamusinei: to do many jobs or tasks concurrently. 
aikacikac ki-a (intransitive verb) to run fast. kikacikacata ore, abu edou: run home fast, rain is going to fall. 
aikacikacakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to run after or to run for. 
aikad ko-a (intransitive verb) to be wanting; to be lacking; to be missing; to be short; to be insufficient. kikadito jo iponesio lukajokak: you lack good manners. ekadit esukaali lo, kiyatak: this sugar is not enough, add more. 
aikade ki-o (transitive verb) to hook down a high branch in order to pluck fruit. cp. aiwope, aikode. 
aikadeikin ki-o (transitive verb) to hang up; to hook up or to take down by hook (of things high up). kikadeik ekakooti ngina: hang my coat there.
aikadeun ki-o (transitive verb) to take down with a hook (of anything too high to reach with the hand); to trip up (in football). cp. aikodeun
aikadidikin akoik ki-o (transitive verb) to fill nearly, not eat a full meal. ekadidikit eong inyamat akoik: I have half-filled my stomach. kikadidik epuko akiria: partially fill the sack with flour. 
aikadidio ki-o (intransitive verb) to be partly full; to be nearly full. amoti ngun ikadidios: those pots are nearly full. 
aikadidior ki-o (transitive verb) (of anything) to fill partly. kikadidionosi amoti ngun k’akipi: fill those pots partly with water. ekadidionoros amoti nu akipi: there is less water in these pots than before. 
aikaika ki-a (transitive verb) to rake off, take off with fingers (as of grass after slashing, as of rubbish after winnowing, as of groundnut shells after shelling). ikaikai ijo akiro inera, mam ilimunit nukabeit: you only touch the outside of the matter, you did not tell the essence of the case. 
aikaikaun ki-a (transitive verb) to rake off, take from surface (leaving the bottom or the real thing, the essentials alone). aikaikaun akiro: to give the substance or the gist of a question or of a case. 
aikaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to get the common knowledge of; to acquire knowledge, do in common; to make common that was not so; to get accustomed to; to spread news or anything, make common, spread out. sirikikaik akiro ngun otunga: do not spread that to the public. ekaikin ediiniwok akwapin kere: our religion has spread all over the world. kikaikis itunga alosit kigaalin k’ainap lomusugun: people have made it a common thing to travel on bicycles and to dress in European fashion. cp. aisiarakin.
aikaj ki-a (transitive verb) to hang up; (of house) to put up the roof. alosi aikaj atunuru: I am going to put up the roof. 
aikajakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hang up on; to postpone or suspend (of a case). ekajakini eong ekakaaso arwatat: I am hanging my cassock on the wall. ekajakin ber emusaagokon: your case has been postponed for the moment. 
aikajakinet (plural aikajakineta) (noun F) a peg on the wall (for hanging clothes on); a tenterhook. cp. aikajet
aikajanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hang on (as a rule); to keep postponing; to procrastinate, put off, delay, postpone, adjourn, dally, defer, drag your feet. sirikikajanak aswamukon: do not procrastinate. 
aikaje ki-a (intransitive verb) to be mad, delirious, or insane; to become mad; to be mad; to run mad; to be insane. cp. aikerepikin, aibilerikin. 
aikajeikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to have become mad on account of; to tend to become mad. ekajeiki etelepat ngol kanuka aisisia: that boy has become mad with studies. cp. aikerepikin, aibangubangun. 
aikajet (plural aikajeta) (noun F) a peg for hanging things on. cp. ekoli. 
aikajikaj ki-a (intransitive verb) (of child) to babble; to stutter; to be not well ground. (transitive verb) to grind roughly. ikajikaji etunganan ngol einer: that man stutters. ikajikajete kesi akimai iriete: they are not grinding the millet well. cp. aingejingeja.
aikak ko-a (transitive verb) to block up (said of a cow with very big udder about to bring forth or a man with a swollen scrotum or a big swelling). ekakit akiteng ngin ekot aur: that cow’s udder is very big (is blocking up her legs) it wants to bring forth. ekakit etunganan ngol abus: that man has a big abscess between his legs (he cannot walk well). ekakit ikoku aberu: the child has blocked the woman’s cervix (during labour). 
aikakoikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become ice or icy; to freeze.
aikal ki-a (transitive verb) to speed up together; (of anything) to do quickly; to do together quickly. ikalete idwe inyamat enyamete: the children eat their food quickly (because they are many and food is little). kikalas aswam na kodaun atipet: hurry on together with the work so as to finish it soon. aikalar aswam: to do quickly together. ekalaros ajon: the beer has been finished (by many people). cp. aigal. 
aikalal ki-a (intransitive verb) to cry loudly; to weep loudly; to shout, bawl. ikalalaete idwe aikalal, ido awoere mam ewoete: the children in the choir simply shout, they do not sing. 
aikalalanut (singular noun F) uproar, shouting, hubbub, noise, racket, hullabaloo, din, clamour, or tumult. aikalalanut ngin nakinyo?: what is all that hubbub about? 
aikalalat ki-a (intransitive verb) to shout; to quarrel, cry in alarm. inyo bo ikalalatotor ngul?: why do those people shout? 
aikalalator ki-o (transitive verb) to extol; to praise loudly. 
aikalalikin ki-a (transitive verb) to shout; to do in shouting, quarrelling; to raise the voice above others; to shout, sing or speak louder than others. sirikikalalak iwoi: do not sing louder than others. 
aikalam ki-a (transitive verb) to make a jump; to jump over; to lift across; to pass over; to bounce. kikalam auno na: jump over this rope. mam eong apedori aikalam, naarai adeka eong akeju: I cannot skip, my leg is injured. kikalam iboro ngul juwai: lift these things across. cp. ailam.
aikalamar ki-a (transitive verb) to bounce or to jump across; to lift across or over; to pass over. cp. aisilamaar.
aikale ki-o (transitive verb) to volley; to take up (a song) in a high tone; to raise the voice. ekaleu ngesi emopiira eroko kedolo kwap: she/he volleyed the ball before it reached the ground. cp. einyure: a cricket game played by the Iteso. 
aikaleikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to get stuck up high (in a tree or on a roof). ekaleikin emopiira amoni: the ball has remained hanging in the thicket. 
aikalekin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become a compound, ekal. 
aikalel ki-o (intransitive verb) to float or drift. emopiira ikalelo k’akipi: the ball floats on the water.
aikaleleor ki-o (reflexive verb) to float down and away; to sail away. 
aikalelitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) (of anything) to float on or to; to be floating; to be afloat. 
aikalelo ki-o (intransitive verb) to float, drift, glide, hover, hang or soar. ataker ikalelo kokuju akipi: the canoe floats on the water. 
aikaler ki-o (intransitive verb) to be sleepless; to lie awake. abu eong kekaler akware kiya: I was awake all night. cp. aikoler.
aikales ki-o (transitive verb) to pretend not to hear; to snub (only used of not hearing). enera eong, kikalesi ijo aikales: I talk and you behave as if you do not hear. cp. aijose, aikamole.
aikaleseun ki-o (transitive verb) to come this way; to step this way. 
aikalesikin ki-o (transitive verb) to disappoint; to ignore; to let one down. kekalesikinit ekesa ngol eong: that fellow disappointed me. 
aikalesoor ki-o (transitive verb) to leave work undone, pass over undone. ikalesoonori ngesi aswam: she/he leaves the work undone. 
aikaleun ki-o (intransitive verb) (in Karamoja) to raise voice; to shout; to cry with loud voice; (of animals) to bay with loudly; to roar (used with eporoto).  engatuny ikaleuni eporoto: the lion roars. cp. aiworoun.
aikam ki-a (transitive verb) (of anything) to catch; to snare; to seize; to capture. aikam lukecor: to catch fish. aikam enyel: to corrode; to rust. aikam akiro: to take notes; to pay attention; to tape record. cp. amerikin, amasikin.
aikamakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to catch for; to take for somebody; to clip together. 
aikamakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to remain stuck; to agglutinate; to coagulate; to be entangled; to remain fixed. ikamakina epaaba toma ajimi: the cotton wool is stuck on the wound. ekamakin amotoka toma orit: the motorcar is stuck in the mud. 
aikamanar ki-a (transitive verb) to catch one by one, keep catching and taking away; to echo. ikamanarete imor iporotoi: the rocks echo the sounds. 
aikamar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away; to snatch away; to arrest. ekacudan ikamari akonye: the witch takes away the sight of people. aikamar akonye: to roll eyes; to look about aimlessly; to squint. abwakar akonye: to throw or sprinkle poisonous liquid or dust at someone’s eyes. 
aikamaraar ki-o (reflexive verb) to point down; to bend down and up (as of branches of tree, horns of cows - some pointing up and others bending down); (of speech) to be contradicting; (of eyes) to squint. ekamaraaros akusikiro: your statements are contradictory. 
aikamarikin ki-a (transitive verb) (of a speaker) to alter a statement; (of branches of a tree) to hang or bend over; (of cows horns) to point in different directions - one horn up, one down, or crossing over each other. 
aikamesikin ki-o (transitive verb) to look away from, avert eyes (as of a typist typing and at the same time looking at his/her copy); to keep an eye on. alosi eong atan, kikamesik ijo ekek: I am going to the well, keep an eye to the door. cp. aingepesikin.  
aikamisoor ki-o (transitive verb) to refuse; to reject, leave undone. inyo bo ikamisooro ijo aswamukon?: why do you shirk your work? aikamisoor akiro: to refuse to believe. cp. aikalesoor.
aikamun ki-a (transitive verb) to catch (a thief or birds or animals); to capture, apprehend; (of blood or milk) to coagulate; to clutch. aikamun akiro: to understand; to know. aikamun akim: to catch fire; to go on fire. aikamun adeka: to contract some disease or sickness. aikamun erot: to start off on a journey or trip. 
aikamunio (singular noun F) a capture; detention; the arrest; apprehending 
aikamunit ki-a (transitive verb) to be concerned or affected (adverb) concerning; re; in relation to; to be applicable to. ikamunitos akiro nu ijo: this matter applies to you. 
aikamur ki-o (intransitive verb) (of any fruit, millet, etc) to begin to ripen; (of eyes) to fall asleep. ekamuroto akimai komanaka: the millet is ripening in my garden. ekamuroto akonyeka ajo: I am falling asleep. 
aikan ki-a (transitive verb) to tempt; to entice; to allure, attract, invite, to induce (to good or evil). sirikikan nges toma aronusio: do not entice her/him to evil. 
aikanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to entice; to tempt. sirikikanak nges akiro nuabu ngesi konger: do not tempt him to do what she/he refused. 
aikanar ki-a (transitive verb) to entice; to go and do something good or bad. ijo ibu kikana nges alosit akoko: it is you who tempted her/him to go and steal. cp. aiyamiyamaar, abokar, aijodoor. 
aikang ki-a (intransitive verb) to do roughly; to talk incoherently; to walk jerkily (like walking on hot or rough ground).
aikangikang (reflexive verb) to grind very badly; to talk broken language. aikangikang alos: to grind millet for bread very badly. 
aikanikan ki-a (transitive verb) to entreat, plead, implore, beg, pray, beseech, ask, or request; to pacify; to make clicking noise with the tongue; to talk one round or persuade. aikanikan akiteng: to entice a cow to give milk by making a clicking sound with tongue. cp. aidekidek.
aikanikanit ki-a (intransitive verb) to keep entreating; to pacify; to beseech. kanukinyo ikanikanitor ijo ikoku yenidela?: why do you plead with a fractious child? cp. aingaingait. 
aikany ki-a (transitive verb) to endure; to bear; to suffer. aikany etengei: to starve; to fast. aikany akure: suffer thirst; to be thirsty. aikany abangaanut: to be very stupid. aikany akolong: to endure the sun’s heat. aikany ican: to endure misery, poverty. aikany akiro: to be patient. 
aikanyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to persevere; to endure for; to suffer for. kinger aikanyakin acok itwaniari ekal: if you do not persevere in herding you will not get married. aikanyakin ebela: to suffer the cane. 
aikanyanut1 (singular noun F) stubbornness; persistence; obstinacy.
aikanyanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be headstrong, obstinate, stubborn, or persistent. 
aikanyikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do for the fifth time; to add one to four. ikanyik ijo lolo akoko: it is now the fifth time that you steal. kikanyik akituk kaloto iso: add one more cow to four and make it five and we go. 
aikap ko-a (transitive verb) to equip; to hold a weapon ready to fight. (intransitive verb) to look very strong and healthy; to be in first pregnancy. aikap akiro: to have a speech ready; to be well prepared, equipped to speak. ekapit ngesi einer: she/he has her/his speech ready. ekapit akiteng ngin, edolit akwario: that cow looks very fit, ready for mounting (by the bulls) (transitive verb) to make ready; to equip; to arm. kokapata imuudun, apotu Ilok: get your guns ready, cattle rustlers have approached. 
aikapeikin1 ki-a (transitive verb) (of a beehive) to have honeycombs; (of skin) to become leathery. 
aikapeikin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to do for the sixth time; to make six.
aikapel ki-o (transitive verb) to make white or spotted; to cause white patches. ikapelit ijo emaido ipeit: you made the groundnuts spotted by not roasting it well. 
aikar ki-a (intransitive verb) to fail in health, power, etc; to be too tired to get up; to rest after fruitless toil; to be fatigued; to founder, despondent; to be finished, no strength left, dying, fading away, declining. ekar emojong lo cut: this old man is truly tired. ekar epolon: the old man is now failing in health. ekar imojong: the old men are tired.
aikarakin1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be stumpy, small, dwarfed; to be stunted in growth. ekaraki ikoku yen, agir apoloor: this child is small and short, it has failed to grow. ekarakis kes, mam bobo ebongunete: they are defeated, they will not return. ekarakinos itunga lu ojie: they were all killed in battle. 
aikarakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to fail in something or somewhere; (of competing teams) to draw; (of a sick person, animal) to become tired and fall down for dead. ekaraki ngesi ne: she/he broke down here. ekaraki ngesi aswam na: she/he failed in this work. cp. akurwokin, aitegakin. 
aikare ki-o (intransitive verb) (of women only) to scream; to shout for joy; to ululate. inyo bo ikareete yesi?: why are you ululating? 
aikareikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to shout with joy for somebody or in some place; to welcome loudly; to ululate. kikareikis imu: ululate to welcome the twins. (note: aikare is only done by women)
aikareor1 edeke ki-o (transitive verb) (in traditional ceremony) to lead sickness (edeke) away (food is boiled, mixed with blood and ashes in a little vessel, and taken to the swamp together with a hen or a goat that will be left there while people run back home without looking back. if one looks back, edeke will also return). cp. aremor edeke. 
aikareor2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to shout or scream away with joy while holding a spear, knife or stick. atingit eong akwara aikareo: I hold a spear while shouting for joy. ekareosi kesi ngina: they are screaming over there. 
aikareor3 ki-o (transitive verb) (of women) to welcome men after a big game hunt or feast, leading them home; to welcome a big person or twins home. 
aikareso ki-o (intransitive verb) to sneeze. ikaresos: they sneeze. 
aikaresoor ki-o (intransitive verb) to sneeze away. aikaresoor akiro: to finish a case. aikaresoor adeka: to become well after sickness. 
aikaribuun ki-a (transitive verb) to welcome in; to let in (a guest, visitor); to say ‘Karibu!’ 
aikarun ki-a (intransitive verb) to be overcome, come to a draw, deadlock; to be unable to do; to be too difficult for. kekaru eong aswam: the work has defeated me. (reflexive verb) to be a draw (in games); to be equally strong in fighting. ekarunos kesi kotoma autakec: they are equally strong in wrestling. cp. aipikor.
aikasas ki-a (intransitive verb) to be tall, big and fat, as of an elephant. ikasasai Ikasangat: Ikasangat is tall and fat or is very big. cp. aikeses. 
aikasasaun ki-o (reflexive verb) to break out; (of a sickness) to become visible; (of a boy or girl) to become big. ekasasaun eong ekodoi kakuwan: small-pox has broken out on my body. cp. abwangun.
aikaset (plural aikaseta) (noun F) a basket for catching ikole (catfish); a cutlass for slashing grass; a slasher. 
aikat ki-a (transitive verb) to slash (as of grass); to hunt with sticks; to catch ibilenga (mud fish) in baskets. aikat akiro: to get into trouble. aikat inya: to slash grass. cp. airi akiro. 
aikatakin ki-a (transitive verb) to catch for or in some place; (Usuk) to try to do. (reflexive verb) to get oneself into trouble. ekatakin eong toma akiro: I got myself into trouble. aikatun adeka: to catch an infection (through irresponsible behaviour).
aikatakinet (plural aikatakineta) (noun F) a catch; a try or a trial. aikatakinet nasodit: the first catch; the first instance. 
aikatany ki-a (transitive verb) to make an opening wide (of anything). kikatany ekek loka etogoka: make the door of my house wide. cp. aitalal
aikatanyikin ki-a (transitive verb) to make a wide opening in something; to make wide, broad. kikatanyik amot iswamai: make a wide mouth to the pot. cp. aikatanyar; aikatanyun. 
aikatar ki-a (transitive verb) to examine, inspect traps; to go and find out about a petition, etc. aikatar akopyo: to go very early (hence to beat the dew). 
aikaun1 emir ki-a (transitive verb) (of many people) to chase a rat or any small animal with sticks. 
aikaun2 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of skin disease) to break out, to become visible. cp. abwangun, aikasasaun. 
aikaun3 ki-a (transitive verb) to encounter; to meet with or to come across. ekau eong emorotot korot: I encountered a python on the way. ekaunit eong akiro: I encountered trouble. cp. airiamakin.
aikawu ki-o (transitive verb) to cook, boil maize or sorghum grain. 
aikawuikin ki-o (transitive verb) to boil grain or any food for somebody quickly (without cooking properly). ikawuikini toto ikekoku inyamat: mother quickly cooks food for her child. 
aikawuor ki-o (transitive verb) to cook food quickly (half done) for somebody away. 
aikawuun ki-o (transitive verb) to preserve vegetables by drying; to preserve by boiling and drying (as of cow blood, or bean-leaves or meat by boiling a little and drying on fire or in sun). kinyamit iso eboo lokikauuno: we ate preserved eboo vegetables. 
aike1 ki-a (transitive verb) to raise; to lift; to elevate. kikeata akanin: raise your hands. cp. arior. 
aike2 ki-o (transitive verb) to scrape; to do a carpenter’s work; to chisel. 
aike3 akiria ko-o (transitive verb) to fry or roast beer dough by turning it up to prevent from being singed or burnt at the bottom. 
aikear ki-a (transitive verb) to raise up, lift up, elevate, make higher (as of a wall); to do better. aikear akanin: to raise hands up; to surrender, give up yourself. (reflexive verb) to be lifted, raised up, etc. kikeasi iporotoi: raise your voices. kikeasi akiro: speak louder. kikeasi aisisia: learn better, study better, or improve the education standards. 
aikeb ko-a (transitive verb) to trim hair on forehead (by girls only). aikeb akiro: to speak nicely (literally, to trim one’s words). 
aikec ki-o (intransitive verb) to dance, boogie, or bop. 
aikecokin ki-o (intransitive verb) to dance for someone. cp. aicogekin, aidimokin. 
aiked ki-o (transitive verb) to brand (dry gourds and calabashes, or bulls and cows) with a red hot iron (considered to be beautiful marks); to decorate (utensils, cattle) with brand marks. cp. amacar. 
aikedar ki-a (transitive verb) to click the tongue with indignation. cp. aidekar
aikediked ki-a (transitive verb) to engrave marks on pottery or to brand beauty marks on cattle. 
aikeike ki-o (transitive verb) to cut an edge to (a board, a path, road or stone). ikeikei ngesi amor: she/he carves stones; she/he dresses stone. 
aikeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to lift, elevate, or raise for someone; to put high up. kikeik ibore ngin: raise that thing. 
aikeis (plural aikeisio) (noun F) a woodwork, joinery or carpentry workshop. cp. akeis, akeit: a frying pan for fermented dough destined for beer-making; a big frying pan made from a cut metal drum.
aikeit akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to keep looking far. aikeit akou: to lift up the head to see. ikeit ekesa ngol akou apaarasia kere: that guy always raises his head (i.e. wants to see everything). cp. aiicicit. 
aikeke ki-a (transitive verb) to sift (anything); to winnow. cp. aipyet
aikekear ki-a (transitive verb) to winnow (away from speaker); to blow the chaff away from the grain when winnowing. cp. apyetar
aikekeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to winnow (grain) for somebody. 
aikekema ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a bird, especially a laying hen) to cackle. ikekemas akokoroi: the hens are cackling (a sign that they are laying eggs). 
aikekemo ki-o (intransitive verb) to chatter; to laugh loudly as of women or children. ikekemos angor emasete ajon: the women chatter and laugh when boozing. aikekemokin: to laugh at or for. kikekemokinoi kaloto: let us have a laugh, and then go off. 
aikekes (plural aikekesia) (noun F) a sieve, sifter, colander. cp. ailepet. 
aikekiar ki-a (transitive verb) to disagree; to refuse. ikoto ijo aikekiar akakiro kere: you want to disagree with everything I say. 
aikemer ki-a (intransitive verb) to receive by chance; to receive unexpectedly; to be privileged; to be lucky. abu eong kekemer adumun ajakaanut: I was privileged to be appointed to a leadership position. cp. arerengikin. 
aikemerikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be lucky; to receive unexpectedly; to be fortunate. ekemerikit eong adumun aswam naejokuna: I was fortunate to get a good job. cp. arerengikin.
aiken ki-o (transitive verb) to curse; to blaspheme. abu papa kiken ikokuke: the father cursed his child. sirikiken ekiror ka Lokasuban: do not blaspheme (the name of God). cp. ailam, aigat. 
aikenetoit (plural aikeneta) (noun F) a curse; anathema; abomination.
aikeng1 ki-o (transitive verb) to walk with firm steps; to walk tight. emojong ngol ikengi alosit aikeng: that old man still walks firmly. 
aikeng2 ki-o (transitive verb) to put upright; to make to stand erect. kikeng ijo ipirin: put the poles upright. cp. aisip. 
aikengeng ki-a (intransitive verb) to remain firm; to stay put. 
aikengokin1 alosit ki-o (intransitive verb) to walk firmly to or for. ekengokis imakio lu alosit osokooni: these old veterans have walked firmly up to the marketplace. 
aikengokin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to put upright; to set up (anything) somewhere or for somebody; to make (a house) strong. kikengok ikoku ngina: make the child sit over there (on its bottoms). ikengokit ijo ekonitogo: you have built a strong house. 
aikeniken ki-o (transitive verb) to curse someone at heart by oneself without anybody hearing it. 
aikenitoit (plural aikenito) (noun F) a curse mark; an anathema. etelepat ngol ejai aikenitoit nakolo kapapake: that boy has a curse of his father. cp. ailametait. 
aikeosit (plural aikeosio) (noun F) a carving; a work of art. 
aikenokin (intransitive verb) to curse one at a distance; to wish one going for a journey or to battle not to return (wishing that she/he may be killed far off). isapa lueyario kojie edaunitai aikenokin koreriakec: men who die in battle are already wished bad luck in their own homes. 
aikeny ki-a (transitive verb) to strike; to hit. abu eong kekeny nges k’ebela: I struck him with a stick. aikeny akiro: to speak plainly; to speak loudly; to talk openly, clearly. okwe apese, kinyek aikeny akiro: oh girl, stop talking openly of others. 
aikenyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to tell straightforwardly. kekenyakit eong ijo ebe ikokolana: I tell you frankly (plainly) that you are a thief. 
aikenyikeny ki-a (transitive verb) to have throbbing pain; to have severe pain, gnawing pain. kekenyikenyi eong akit: I have a severe pain in my ear. aikenyikeny akiro: to open one’s mind, give one’s mind or opinion; to speak out boldly. 
aikenyun ki-a (intransitive verb) to speak openly; to speak frankly; to speak clearly, straightforwardly; to enunciate. 
aikeonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to chisel off into proper shape; to cut off unevenness; to finish off a piece of carving. 
aikeonor ki-o (transitive verb) to cut off unevenness; to finish off a piece of work, put finishing touch to a work of art. cp. atubonor.
aikep1 ki-a (transitive verb) to make a grinding stone rough by beating with a piece of iron when it is too smooth for grinding. 
aikep2 ko-a (transitive verb) to cut; to pare; to cut rings in the bark of a tree; to circumcise. aikep abelekeka: to pare nails of hand or foot. aikep amuk: to shape or make shoes or sandals at the cobbler’s or shoe factory. aikep anapet: to cut and shape the skin for carrying the baby on the back. aikep akeju: to walk long distances. cp. aikul.
aiker ko-a (transitive verb) to respect; to honour; to fear; to run in fear; to flee; to avoid. kokerite papakon: respect your father. 
aikerepikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to become mad; to become insane to be boisterous. cp. aibilerikin, aikajeikin. 
aikereponut1 (singular noun F) tending to insanity, madness, or lunacy. 
aikereponut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be mad; to be a lunatic; to be insane. ikerepono ngesi: she/he is mad, or crazy. ikerepoko kesi: they are crazy. 
aikes1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be firm; to be hard; to be obstinate; to insist; to be argumentative. eketa eong: I am insisting. iketasi kesi: they are obstinate, insisting. emina ngesi eikes egwelanari ikeboro: she/he sells her/his merchandise at high price i.e. allows little room for bargaining or haggling. iketa je cut: he insists absolutely (that I do it). 
aikes2 ki-o (transitive verb) (of a tall person) to stalk like an ostrich; to stride as one with long legs. ikesikesi ekuulu akwap: the ostrich strides along. cp. aikeng.
aikesa ki-a (transitive verb) to speak loudly; to lift one’s voice. ikesai einer (ikesai akiro, ikesai eporoto): she/he speaks loudly. cp. aikiar eporoto. 
aikesaar ki-a (transitive verb) to call away loudly; to emphasize. kolot kikesaa eporoto: go and shout out. aikesaun: to call out aloud. 
aikesakin1 (adverb) overhead. kiboi bian iso aikesakin elap: we sat out last night till the moon was right above us. kiswama lolo iso aikesakin akolong cut: we worked till midday. 
aikesakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to give a heavy blow; to call for loudly. abu eong kekesak nges akit kakan: I slapped him hard on the ear. (reflexive verb) to work in the heat of the sun. etyono aikesakin toma akolong: it is hard to work in the hot sun. 
aikeses ki-a (intransitive verb) to stand upright, tall and big. aikeses aibwo: to stand up; to be standing out above others; to be perpendicular. ikesesei Elgon adepar imor kere: Mt. Elgon stands out above all other hills.
aikesit ki-a (intransitive verb) to refuse; to say no; to decline, reject, snub, rebuff, turn down, or repudiate. cp. agirit. 
aikesitor ki-o (transitive verb) to refuse to let go; to raise price too high. ikesitotor imo lukane ikeceboro: the Baganda traders here sell their things at a very high price. cp. agiritor.
aiket1 ki-a (transitive verb) to pull tight; to stiffen as of rope or as strings of harps; to key up (guitar). aiket auno: to pull the rope tight; to drive a hard bargain. aiket akonye: to look into the face of, not to be shy; to be bold. kiket jo da akonye: you also look straight in people’s face, don’t be shy. aiket akuwan: to walk with full force or energy; to strain the body (as of a woman during childbirth). 
aiket2 ko-a (transitive verb) to break down; to pull down (as of a house); to pullout (as new clothes from a box or as of firewood from a bundle). ekesete kesi ekecetogo: they are pulling down their house. 
aiketakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pull tight; to hold tight; to become obstinate (reflexive verb) to become tight; to contract muscles of the body (as in a dying person). aiketakin ba: (of a person or something tied) to stay firm; to remain hard. aiketakin aki: to prick up one’s ears. aiketakin akanin: to hold arms rigid. aiketakin etau: to harden the heart or feelings towards. 
aiketar ki-a (transitive verb) to pull tight; to tighten, stiffen, constrict. 
aikeun ki-a (transitive verb) to raise up; to hoist; to uphold, support (of things and persons); to lift up (as of head). aikeun arwatat: to support a falling wall; to raise a wall (i.e. build it higher). aikeun akiro: to support a case, an argument. aikeun aswam: to work better and quicker. ekeun ekatau: I feel relieved. ikeu ijo ekatau: you have encouraged me.
aikiar ki-a (transitive verb) to lift up, push up, or extend; to boost, elevate, haul up, raise, or winch up. cp. aikear. 
aikic ki-o (intransitive verb) to run while jumping like children. ikicete idwe lai kore: the children hurtle homewards. cp. ailir akerit.  
aikicokin ki-o (intransitive verb) to run for; to run after. kikicok aomare akim: run and fetch me some fire. 
aikid ko-a (transitive verb) to kick; to punch with a fist; to beat with a stick. kocoite akiteng ngin ekidi itunga: be careful with that cow, lest it kicks people. cp. aidip.
aikidikid ki-a (transitive verb) to tickle or titillate. kekidikidi ekulam, akoto alosit ailwat: the urine tickles me, I want to go for a short call. 
aikidingikin ki-o (transitive verb) to reach the middle of; to reach halfway; to put in the middle; centralize. ekidingiki akolong akwap: the sun has reached midday; it is midday; it is equinox – the sun is overhead the equator. 
aikidiokikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be too little, too few for; to be insufficient, short, inadequate, lacking, or unsatisfactory. kekidiokikis eong isirigin: I am short of money.
aikidiokoor1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to become insufficient, short, inadequate, or little. 
aikidiokoor2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to become scanty, scarce, few, or rare. ekidiokooros akipi nuelaete kakwap: clean water has become scarce in the world. 
aikidiokun ki-o (intransitive verb) to be scarce, few, scanty, short (to speaker). ekidiokut eong acok: I am short of potatoes. 
aikidiokut (singular noun F) scarcity; fewness. 
aikij ki-a (transitive verb) to stab; to suck (as of a calf punching the udder of its mother to force the milk to come). 
aikijakin ki-a (transitive verb) to spear; to stab; to punch for somebody or some reason. cp. airem, aicum. 
aikil ki-a (transitive verb) to long for; to desire; to crave for; to gravitate. ekila eong akiring: I long for meat. ikilas itelepai abolia: the boys crave for a game. 
aikila itim ki-a (transitive verb) to comb hair thoroughly. ikilaete itelepai itimakec: the boys comb their hair well. aikila akimai: to clean millet (grain or crop) thoroughly. aikila edia: to prepare nice looking vegetables. 
aikilakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to long for; to desire;to crave for; to wish; to volunteer. ekilakin eong alosit ore: I now long to go home. ingai ikilakina aswam na?: who has volunteered for this work? 
aikilanar ki-a (intransitive verb) to writhe with pain. (reflexive verb) to suffer. 
aikilar ki-a (reflexive verb) to wish to someone something. inyo bo kikilatar yesi eong adumun?: what good thing do you wish me to get? aikilar alungar: to go away annoyed, disappointed. ekilar Takan alungar: Takan went away in annoyance. 
aikilikila ki-a (intransitive verb) to squirm with pain; to wriggle in or out; to try to escape from; to squirm in anger or pain; to become cruel or angry. ikilikila ekweny kakaninika: the bird is wriggling in my hands (trying to escape). aikilikila etengei: to complain of hunger. 
aikilikilakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to start wriggling in or out. 
aikilikilanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to throw oneself about; to cry bitterly; to like one another. cp. aipudapudanar, aibironor. 
aikilingikiling ki-a (intransitive verb) to tickle, amuse, entertain, delight, or please. 
aikiliokikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a woman) to be man-like; (of a man) to act as husband to (some woman); (of a woman) to be muscular or manly. kikiliokik ijo: (you) be manly. 
aikima ki-a (transitive verb) to boil or make porridge. cp. aima akima: to boil or make porridge. 
aikinga ki-a (intransitive verb) to go outside; to leave the room; to go to the places; to go for a ‘long call’. cp. aibobon. 
aikingan ki-a (intransitive verb) to go outside; to leave the room; to go to places; to defecate or have a ‘long call’. cp. aibobon. 
aikinganet (plural aikinganeta) (noun F) the anus; the outing or sojourn. cp. aikinganis
aikinganikin ki-a (transitive verb) to go out for a long call; to go to a certain place. aisikingakin: to help (a child or sick person) to make a ‘long call’. ekinganiki etunganan oruteka: somebody defecated before my gate. kisikinganik ikoku: help the child to discharge its bowels (defecate). 
aikinganis (plural aikinganesya) (noun F) the anus; a toilet; a latrine. 
aikingokikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to be like a dog; to behave like a dog; to be very poor. ikingokikit ngesi: she/he has become very poor, currish, or bitchy. 
aikipiikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be watery, aqueous, dilute, or runny. 
aikir ki-o (intransitive verb) to jump; to skip up and down; to come down with a noise. ikirete kesi akwap: they are jumping up and down. 
aikirijim ki-a (intransitive verb) to germinate; to begin to grow (of seeds or mushroom). ekirijimata akimai: the millet has germinated. 
aikirikir1 ki-a (transitive verb) to make or build artwork, craft, etc nicely. 
aikirikir2 ki-o (transitive verb) to run noisily, stamping with feet. 
aikirikirokin ki-a (intransitive verb) to hurry, scurry, dash, hasten, or rush. cp. aker. 
aikirokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall down, put down with a thud or noise. ekirokinos itelepai kwap: the boys fell down with a thud. 
aikis1 ki-a (transitive verb) to scrape (as of potatoes, cassava, or skin of anything); to rub; to rasp; to hack, vaccinate; to pare. aikis ekato: to vaccinate. emuron ikisi itunga ekato: the doctor vaccinates people. aikisar, aikisun: to scrape away, towards. aikisun: to jump this way (from a height).
aikis2 ki-o (transitive verb) to drop a sheaf of grass on its end or a child on its feet; to let fall (standing, not flat) of a pole. ikisonokini toto ikekoku: the mother bounces her child on her knee. 
aikisanar ki-a (transitive verb) to scrape off, rub off; to rasp off; to pare away; to plane off; to comb out (as of bird cleaning itself); to preen; to delete. cp. aikilaanar.
aikiset (plural aikiseta) (noun F) peelings; rind; scrap; the place or instrument for scraping. aikiseta nuk’acok: potato peelings. 
aikisetait (plural aikiseta) (noun F) instrument for scraping; a peeler of potatoes, etc; an adze. 
aikisikis ki-a (transitive verb) to scrape (as of pencil, finger nails); to rub, scratch, graze, scuff, abrade, chafe, grate, or scour. akoto aikisikis ekabela kokwangu: I want to scrape my stick to make it white.
aikisonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to lift up and down, as of mother lifting and dropping her child in play. ikisonokini ngesi arukit okisu: she/he rams the pestle down into the mortar (when pounding grain). cp. ailepanar.
aikisor ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall from height; to jump down; to topple over. kikisor ijo kwap: (if) you jump down. (transitive verb) to throw down (on its head or feet). 
aikisun ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall or jump down towards. 
aikit1 (plural aikita) (noun F) a carrying pad; a coil made of grass or cloth for carrying pots or gourds. 
aikit2 ko-o (transitive verb) to scrape food out of a pot; to make scraping noise; to scrape. 
aikiya1 ki-a (transitive verb) to propitiate; to pacify; to give a good example. toto ikiyai ikekoku kinyek aimony: the mother pacifies her child so that it may stop crying. ejok aikia luejios: it is good to make peace between people fighting. cp. aiyang.
aikiya2 ki-a (transitive verb) to persuade; to entice, draw by nice ways or means. akoto eong aikiya papaka kainak eong egaali: I want to persuade my father to give me a bicycle. cp. aijodo.
aikiya3 ki-a (transitive verb) to wait a long time, overnight. 
aikiyaar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to do without stopping; to do all night. 
aikiyaar2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to go on begging; to keep on asking for something; to persevere asking; to keep on dancing all night. ekiyaasi bian itunga ngina ekosio: the people danced all night over there. alot ngesi aikiyaun ibore neejai opaperoke: she/he has gone to her/his friend to beg for something. 
aikiyaar3 ki-a (transitive verb) to draw a person away; to entice one away; to attract, tempt, lure, allure, persuade, inveigle, beguile, or charm somebody. 
aikiyaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep asking a favour for something. (intransitive verb) to be busy all night with something. lukacuuma naka epaaba ikiyaikinete aswam kuare: those in the ginnery work all night. kikiyaik ailip, idumuni: keep on asking (praying), you will receive. (reflexive verb) to pass the night. ai bo kikiyaikit ijo?: where were you last night? 
aikiyakiya ki-a (transitive verb) to go begging; to soothe continually. cp. aimaima, aiyamiyam. 
aikiyaun ki-a (transitive verb) to convince, sway, win over, influence, or persuade carefully; to get something out of somebody. abu eong kekiau nges akokor: I managed to get a chicken out of her/him. 
aiko1 ko-o (transitive verb) to look for; to search; to find; to find out; to attempt. cp. aimo. 
aiko2 ko-o (transitive verb) to scratch; to itch as of jigger or scabies. ekoi ekingok akekuwan: the dog is scratching its body. cp. aikwac, aigwar
aikob1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to flock together; to gather; to come together from all sides; to be always on the move; to go from place to place. ikobete itunga luelwaka agwelar emaido k’Ocorimongin: the people from afar flock to Ocorimongin market in Katakwi to sell their groundnuts. ai bo ikobar ijo?: where are you off to now again? cp. aikop, airip.
aikob2 ki-a (transitive verb) to transcribe; to copy. cp. aigul. 
aikobakin ki-a (transitive verb) to transcribe for; to copy for; to hand over to; to pass on to; to take to. kikobakinai eong eitaabo je: pass me that book. 
aikobar1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to go across to. ekobar Ejakait Apunyo okekwa je: Mr Apunyo has gone to the other side of the lake. cp. aikopar. 
aikobar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to take away, hand to another, or pass on. kikobakisi etunganan ngol eitaabo lo: pass this book on to that man. 
aikobikob ki-a (intransitive verb) to hurry; to run (like a dog). ikobikobi ekingok apaarasia kere: the dog is always running. 
aikoc ki-o (transitive verb) to gnaw at (a bone or anything hard). ikoci ekingok akojo: the dog gnaws at bones. ariebo na esilim kekoci akakuwan: this AIDS disease gnaws at my body. esilim erai ariebo naikoci: AIDS is a gnawing disease. cp. aidok.
aikocokin ki-o (transitive verb) to clean the bone (cut off the meat from the bone) for somebody. 
aikocor ki-o (transitive verb) to make bare, lay bare (as of field eaten by locusts or goats); to pick bare (as of dog and bone). ekocosi itunga ekaboo kere: people have plucked my eboo vegetables bare. 
aikocun ki-o (transitive verb) to know well; to be clever at (of anything). ikocunit ijo Amusugun: you know English well. cp. ajenun, aidokudokun. 
aikod ko-a (transitive verb) to ask (somebody something); to lift (a thing) by a handle (like lifting a handbag). ejaas nuakoto aikod ijo: I want to ask you something. kokod adoobo ngin: lift that bucket. aikod loadekan arai ikoku: to lift or support a sick person or child by their arms. 
aikodakin ki-a (reflexive verb) (of plants only) to climb into, round, or creep round. 
aikodar ki-a (intransitive verb) to climb up as of a plant round a pole. 
aikode ki-o (transitive verb) to hook down a high branch in order to pluck fruit. cp. aiwope. 
aikodeikin ki-o (transitive verb) to hang up; to hook up or to take down by hook (of things high up). (reflexive verb) to remain hanging; to remain stuck on top. cp. aikaleikin. 
aikodeor ki-o (transitive verb) to lift with a stick and carry away (as of dead snake). aikodeor emun: to lift away a snake with a stick. 
aikodeun ki-o (transitive verb) to take down with a hook (of anything too high to reach with hand). 
aikodikod ki-a (intransitive verb) to climb, as of a plant round a pillar; to tie, entwine (a bed with ropes); to make a twine rope; to make a web (as of spider); to spread out on the ground, as of creeper plants like luffah and groundnuts, etc; to shoot out roots into the ground, as of creeper plants; to take root. atur ikodikodete epir: the flowers climb round a pole. aturot naikodikodi: a climbing flowering plant. aikodikod etunganan: to pester a man in order to make him angry; to nag a man. 
aikodil ki-a (transitive verb) to keep throwing up and down as a cat with mouse or of mother playing with the child. 
aikodilaar ki-a (transitive verb) to swing, take away; to cling, as of a child (catching it by the arm and slinging on the back, as women do). 
aikodomikin kwap ki-o (reflexive verb) (of a tall person) to fall down; (of a tall person) to sit or lie down exhausted. 
aikoikikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be abdominal. ikoikikit adekakon: your sickness is abdominal (is in the abdomen). ekoikiki aberu na: this woman is pregnant. cp. aigoloikin.
aikoj ki-a (transitive verb) to spoil a work (one does not know); to trifle, dawdle. cp. amunaar. 
aikojakin ki-a (transitive verb) to spoil a work for somebody; to dawdle at; to trifle at. ikojakinit ijo aswamuka: you have spoiled my work. cp. amunaikin.
aikojar ki-a (transitive verb) to be trifling about. 
aikojikoj ki-a (intransitive verb) to trifle; to waste time doing a thing one does not know how to do; to dawdle. ikojikoji ijo aswam namam ijeni: you waste your time over a job you do not know how to do; you waste you time over a job you do not understand. 
aikojoikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be bony, skinny, scrawny, lanky, lean, thin, emaciated, skeletal, or gaunt. ikojoikit akiring na: this meat is all bones. 
aikok ko-a (transitive verb) to guard or protect; to hurry on forward; to be intent on; to do with a will; to insist; to receive with pleasure, gratitude; to mind, pay attention to; to take care of. kokok ijo ikakoku: protect my child. sirikikok eong, mam eong asii: do not guard, I will not run away. akokit eong adaun aswam na lolo: I intend to finish this job today. akokit eong ajenun Ateso: I am intent on learning Ateso. akokit eong aswam ngin: I pay attention to that work. akokit eong adumun ikonibaluan: I like to receive your letters. kokok aswamukon: pay attention to your work. 
aikokoor ki-o (transitive verb) to finish off altogether, as of food, beer, etc; to deplete. ekokoosi kwi ajon kere: those fellows have finished all the beer. 
aikokor ki-o (transitive verb) to roll along (as of a bicycle or a wheelbarrow, etc). 
aikokoroor ki-o (transitive verb) to roll down or to roll away; to wheel along like bicycle or wheelbarrow (reflexive verb) to descend; to roll away by itself. 
aikokoruun ki-o (reflexive verb) to roll down this way (as a ball from roof). 
aikokoteonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to become nasty, spiteful, mean, vicious, malicious, cruel, horrible, malevolent, wicked. 
aikokoun ki-o (transitive verb) to finish (the contents of something) completely. sirikikokou edula kere: do not empty the whole granary. 
aikol ki-o (transitive verb) to nag; to irritate constantly; to blame repeatedly; to congest. aitokol: to contest (as of football). cp. aitepeg: to scramble for; to persecute. aitokokolit: to be always troublesome, quarrelsome, nagging, irritating, or rivalling. 
aikola alup ki-a (transitive verb) to scrape ground with a hoe; to weed with a hoe; to beat with a thin stick or a whip. aikolaar eduan: to weed with a stick or hoe; to scratch away the weeds. 
aikoler ki-o (intransitive verb) to be sleepless. kekoler eong bian akware kiya: I was sleepless all night last night. ikolerit esirikaalet: the night watchman is alert. ikolerito akonyeka: my eyes are wakeful.
aikolerit (singular noun F) insomnia; sleeplessness; wakefulness. 
aikolikol ki-a (intransitive verb) to have boils; to get boils, blisters, or sunburns. ikolikolit eong akan: I have blisters on my hand. 
aikolikolit (singular noun F) (a state of having) blisters; rashes; scalds. 
aikolikolun ki-a (intransitive verb) (of the skin) to break out into boils or blisters. 
aikoma ki-a (intransitive verb) to glide like a snake; (of animals, especially cattle) to walk in Indian file; to crawl; to make progress; to progress. ikomaete akituk odoot: the cattle walk in Indian file to the salt clay. 
aikomaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to glide (like a snake); (of cattle) to go in Indian file to; to make progress in. ekomaiki emorotot togoke: the python has gone into its shelter. 
aikomo ki-o (intransitive verb) to howl; to wail (of a person or animal). lukangai ikomoete aimony kangina?: who are wailing over there? 
aikomoikin ki-o (transitive verb) to howl at, wail for, shout for. 
aikomom ki-o (intransitive verb) to be very high, tall; to be outstanding. 
aikon ki-a (intransitive verb) to be like; to act towards; to look like; to do (has irregular conjugation) ikoni ai?: how is it? (plural) ikote yesi ai?: ikonete yesi ai?: what do you do? ikoni bo ai?: how is it? ekoni ijo akwap ai?: how did you find the weather? aikon ai? to do what? aikon nen: to be like that; to be thus.
aikonakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to act towards; to behave towards; to do to. ikonakini ijo akoniberu ai?: what will you do to your wife? how did you act towards your wife? ikonakit ijo eong erono: you treated me badly. ekonakini eong kwangin: I do thus; so do I. ikonakini ngesi nen: she/he does thus. ikonakinete kesi kwangin: they do thus; so do they. ekonakini bo ikwaikini nen ai?: how comes it happened thus? ekonakini eong ai?: what shall I do? how shall I behave? how shall I go about it? (transitive verb) to tackle; to treat. ikonakit ijo nges erono: you treated him badly.
aikone ki-o (transitive verb) (in Karamoja) to be friends; to make friends. aswam ekone: to make friendship. 
aikoneikin ki-o (intransitive verb) (in Karamoja) to become friends. cp. aipaperikin 
aikonenen ki-a (transitive verb) to do continually. kikonenen ne: keep doing it like this. 
aikong ki-o (transitive verb) to hammer; to fasten; to knock (once); to tap. 
aikongikong1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to run (as of an old man or cow which is very thin). 
aikongikong2 ki-o (transitive verb) to rap; to tap; to knock (as at door); to hammer. sirikiloma komam ber ikongikongit ekek: do not enter before knocking at the door. 
aikongokin ki-o (transitive verb) to knock on; to hammer on; to make a strong rule or command for; to make strong. kikongok eloit lo kwap: hammer this peg down. kekongokit eong ijo ekisil, mam ibuni oreka: I absolutely forbid you to come to my home. ikongokit ijo etogo lo ne: you built this house very strongly here. 
aikongonor ki-o (transitive verb) to beat hard with a hammer, one after another; to hammer hard; to loosen by hammering. 
aikony ko-a (transitive verb) to bite; to sting; to be sufficiently salted. kakonyit eong ao: a bee stung me. ekonyit inyamat abalang: there is sufficient salt in the food (literally, the salt has bitten the food). aitokony aberu abalang: (a ceremony of) introducing a woman to taste salted food (after giving birth). kokony ebokoritika lokawasia: bite my last finger so that my absence may not hurt you (as a sign of goodbye). akonyokony eong akou: I have a splitting headache. 
aikoodo1 (noun F) armed robbery; burglary. 
aikoodo2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to rob with the force of arms; to burgle. 
aikoowa (noun F) leisure; pastime. cp. ainyam ejanta: to enjoy or indulge oneself greatly.
aikoowa ki-a (intransitive verb) to be at leisure; to be at peace. ikoowai ijo eilat: you are walking at leisure. 
aikop1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to go from place to place; to be always on the move. aikop alosit: to be always going about; to go suddenly. (transitive verb) to pass on things; to hand over (as at table). 
aikop2 ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch; to seize quickly; to snap up. aikop alosit: to walk with quick steps. ekopi etoori imiyoi: the eagle snatches chicks. 
aikopa ki-a (transitive verb) to borrow. 
aikopaar ki-a (transitive verb) to lend out, pass on, devolve on. (reflexive verb) to move further on, spread; to go across; to jump; to go from one place to another (as of a monkey swinging from one branch to another). 
aikopaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to lend to. ekopaikit eong Otim isirigin ilukumin ikany: I lent Otim five thousand shillings. 
aikopakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hand on; to pass on. kikopakinai esukaali: pass the sugar on to me. 
aikopanakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to spread or to infect (as of disease). 
aikopaun ki-a (transitive verb) to borrow for oneself. 
aikor ko-a (transitive verb) to divide; to give away; to serve out (food), or dispense (medicine); to distribute, give out. kolot aikor inyamat: go and serve food. aikor apese: to hand a bride to her bridegroom at a marriage, wedding. cp aidut. 
aikorar ki-o (reflexive verb) to get on with difficulty; to scramble. abu eong bian kekorar osokooni: I trudged to the market yesterday. 
aikorikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to border on each other (of a plot, country or garden, etc). ekorikinos itunga lu: these people have become neighbours. ikorikino itunga lu: these people are neighbours.
aikorikorit ki-a (transitive verb) to drag along. aikorikor ikong: to force flying ants out by beating something hollow.
aikorobe ki-o (transitive verb) to gather people and align them near their work.
aikorobeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to put in a line; to align (as of men who are going to work or to be written down). kikorobeikis Imusugun ikecereria: the Europeans have built their houses in a line. 
aikorojong ko-o (intransitive verb) to remain stunned. abu ngesi kenom eong akou kekorojong eong: she/he stunned me with a blow on the head (literally, she/he hit me on the head and I remained stunned). 
aikoror ki-a (transitive verb) to winnow; to pour down slowly and let the wind blow away the chaff in the falling; to pour down (water, etc) from a high place; to gargle; to freewheel on a bicycle or motorcar. cp. apyetar: to winnow or blow away the chaff whilst winnowing. 
aikororoun ki-o (reflexive verb) to freewheel down; to come down. 
aikoroun ki-o (transitive verb) to tap with a stick; to hit a thing with a hard object; to make a noise with a stick. aikorounun: to keep tapping with a stick, (as of an anthill to force the flying ants to come out); to beat a hollow wood with a stick called agig. cp. ananganang; abaaba. 
aikoru ki-o (intransitive verb) to border on; to be neighbours. ikoruos Ikaramoja ka Iteso: the Karimojong border on the land of the Iteso. ikoruos ijo ka nges: you two are neighbours. 
aikosi ki-o (intransitive verb) to dance (with or without bells). aikosi adeudeu: to dance to a harp. 
aikosikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to dance to a song. 
aikosos ki-o (intransitive verb) to be gigantic. cp. aikeses.
aikot1 ki-a (transitive verb) to duck down (to evade a blow); to clear grass; to trim; to slash (as of grass). kikot erot lo: slash the grass on either side of this road. ekosete idwe anya: the children are slashing the grass. cp. aikat anya: to cut or slash the grass.
aikot2 ko-a (transitive verb) to brush off; to wave (goodbye); to flick away (flies or mosquitoes); to fan. aikot akopyo: to clear away the dew (with hand or stick). ekosi ngesi icuc: (she/he fans) she/he swats the flies. 
aikotar ki-a (transitive verb) to clean; to beat (the dew away); to slash away. ikotanarete itelepai anya: the boys slash (cut) the grass. 
aikotel ki-o (transitive verb) to prick up the ears; to raise the hat. 
aikoteloor ki-o (transitive verb) to prick up ears like a dog or animal, when hearing strange noise or seeing a stranger. nekaanyunia etom eong, kikoteloori akike: when the elephant saw me, it pricked up its ears. 
aiku1 ko-a (transitive verb) to escape, break loose; to get away with. akuata itunga kotuja: the prisoners escaped from the prison. abu ekapa kokoto aikamun emir konye abu koku: the cat wanted to catch a rat but it escaped. mam ekui: (it is) inevitable. aiku aitac esolo: to avoid paying tax (due to defects in the tax laws).
aiku2 ko-a (transitive verb) to pull out; to extract (a jigger or thorn). aiku ikukwa: to extract thorns from feet. aiku ipuusai: to extract jiggers (from feet, etc).
aiku3 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of soap) to foam; (of beer or vegetables) to boil over; to cause foam; (of milk, carbonated drink or beer) to curdle, effervesce. 
aikuar ki-a (intransitive verb) (of rain) to slacken or to stop. ekua edou: the rain has diminished (slackened). aikuar akiro: to be free from worry; to be free from trouble; to be carefree. ekua akuwan akiro: I am free from trouble. cp. aibuorar. ekuasi ipumu kakouke: her/his epileptic fits have ceased; her/his dizziness has gone. cp. adotor.
