aikub ko-o (intransitive verb) to rush; to dash. 
aikuc ki-o (transitive verb) to drill a hole; to make a hole in something; to start or kick off (a game, etc); to rub (soap). kikuc ajoroi ngin kanuka adumun akim: drill a hole in that ejoroi branch to make fire. aikuc asabuuni ogoen: to rub soap into clothes. aikuc ejie: to start a fight. 
aikuca ki-a (transitive verb) to persevere; to persist; to overcome difficulties; to do in spite of difficulties. cp. aikura.
aikucaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do with difficulty for someone else; to solve somebody’s difficulties. kikucaikit oni Iteso eitaabo lo: we met with great difficulties in publishing this book for the Iteso. ikucanakinete luk’auriak ikecedwe esomero: parents endure hardships to have their children educated. 
aikucaun ki-a (transitive verb) to acquire through difficulties; to do in spite of difficulties. kikucau akoniswam: do your work in spite of the difficulties. 
aikucokin ki-o (transitive verb) to kick off (as of football); to start off (as in a game of cricket or aile). 
aikuconokin ki-a (transitive verb) to take out (as pebbles in omweso or aileisit game); to rub on (as of soap on cloth); to keep starting off (in football); to start to kick off. 
aikucor ki-o (transitive verb) to take out; to take out (as of pebbles from the aileisit game). 
aikucukucoor ki-o (transitive verb) to make a hole; to penetrate; to bore a hole. ekucukucoosi icuc ajimi: the flies have eaten a hole into a sore. ekucukucoor ajimikon: your wound is getting deep. 
aikud1 ki-a (transitive verb) to nag at; to bore, rebuke. aberu ikudi okilenike aitodol naekeria ngesi: the woman nags her husband until he runs away. 
aikud2 ko-o (transitive verb) to bend (intransitive verb) to be warped; to be bent.  aikud alosit: to turn a corner. aikud ebela: to bend a stick (to the shape required). aikud akudet: to turn a corner. 
aikudio (noun F) annoyance; frustration; exasperation; anger; nuisance; irritation; harassment. 
aikudukuda ki-a (transitive verb) to long for; to desire ardently; to titter, laugh quietly. ikudukuda ekatau ajenun akiro ngun: I long to know those issues. 
aikudukudo ki-o (intransitive verb) to whisper. lukangai ikudukudos kane?: who are whispering here? cp. aiweweya, aiumuumo.
aikudukudokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to whisper to one another. 
aikujeor ki-o (transitive verb) to sky or volley. aikujeor emopiira: to volley a football.
aikujuikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to be like heaven; be heavenly. ikujuikit ekare: my home is like heaven. 
aikuk ko-o (transitive verb) to make to kneel or bend the knee of somebody; to supplicate. sirikikuk idwe kinga: do not make the children kneel outside. 
aikukuj ki-a (transitive verb) to tie (in general); to fold up (as of rope). aikukuj akiro: to talk illogically; to babble. ikukujai ijo akonikiro: there is no point in what you say: what you say is mere talk. 
aikukujakin ki-a (transitive verb) to tie up roughly; to insert (tie) a knot; to involve, complicate. aikukujakin akiro: to petty talk. cp. aiweniwenakin, ailokonyikin. 
aikukujaun ki-o (reflexive verb) (of words) to be entangled; to be inextricable; to be illogical, pointless, or mixed up. (transitive verb) to complicate (with akiro). 
aikukum ki-a (intransitive verb) (of thunder, train or plane) to make noise. cp. airurum. 
aikukumaar ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall down and away (as of a tree or rock). 
aikukwaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of seeds when germinating) to become pointed; (of hedge or animal like porcupine) to be thorny. 
aikul ko-a (transitive verb) to peel, pare, cut (to peel off bark). aikul aijar: to enjoy oneself; to indulge; to have a nice time. kokulata acok: peel potatoes. ekuli ngesi etwo: she/he pares (cuts even) the gourd. cp. aiwat.
aikula ki-a (transitive verb) to boil often; to beat up often. 
aikulaar ki-a (transitive verb) to heat a liquid to boiling point; to beat up once. 
aikulecer ki-a (intransitive verb) to be undercooked; (of food) to be undone; (of a person) to be unable to sleep; (of a person) to be obstinate. ekulecerata acok: the potatoes are undone. ikulecerito akonye: the eyes are unable to sleep. 
aikum ko-o (intransitive verb) to bend forward. ekumete Iteso ekoriete: the Iteso bend forward while cultivating. 
aikumem ki-o (intransitive verb) to be prominent (as of a rock or fat-bodied person or animal or buttocks); to rise up from (as of a mountain); to stick up in the air (as of a house, tree). ekumem emoru: the mountain is prominent. 
aikumemet (noun F) height; prominence.
aikun ki-a (intransitive verb) to lament; to cry a long time; to bellow (as of cows or bulls going home in the evening); to howl (as of hyena); to roar (as of lion). cp. aruo apak naepol. 
aikuna1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be misty, foggy, or hazy; to be constipated; to have indigestion. ekuna akoik: to be constipated. ikunai emoru ngol: it is foggy around that rock or mountain. 
aikuna2 ki-a (transitive verb) to hoard up; to store up; to amass (things). lokebit emina aikuna iboro: a miser likes to hoard up things or property. 
aikunaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hoard up for; to store up for (somebody or somewhere); to have fixed deposit account. ikunaikit ngesi isirigin oposita: she/he has a fixed deposit in the Post Bank. 
aikung ki-o (transitive verb) to knock (at the door). sirikimurwok aikungukung ekek ilosi aanyun lokapolon: do not forget to knock at the door when you go to an important man’s office or house. cp. aikong.
aikunget (plural aikungeta) (noun F) a rubber stamp; a coccyx (part of a skeleton; rudimentary tail. cp. ababai. 
aikungokin ki-o (transitive verb) to knock once only. ingai ekungoki ekakek?: who is there knocking at my door? cp. aikongokin. 
aikungukung ki-o (transitive verb) to knock repeatedly; to rap at the door (to call for someone to open). cp. aikongikong. 
aikuny1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to shift slowly; to go step by step; to change place. cp. aiwot. 
aikuny2 ki-a (intransitive verb) (Protestant church) to take part in a holy communion sacrament; to partake of bread and wine (in church).
aikunya ki-a (transitive verb) to sit down waiting for food silently. aikunya inyamat: to wait for food; to beg silently for food. cp. aibwany; aperun inyamat. 
aikunyakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to move towards; to shift to; to go and receive holy communion. kikunyakisi ngina: shift that way. 
aikunyar ki-a (intransitive verb) to move away; to draw back. 
aikunyukunya ki-a (intransitive verb) to shift backwards and forwards; to fidget; to move forwards and backwards (as of people in a row or when suddenly meeting danger); to prepare for a journey; to shift about in a chair, as a sign of discomfort or uneasiness. abu eong kadum emun kasodi aikunyukunya: I met a snake and I fidgeted. cp. aiwotiwot. 
kunyukuny (adverb) backwards and forwards; first in one way, then in another. 
aikunyun ki-a (intransitive verb) to approach the speaker; to move this way; to shift this way. 
aikupa ki-a (transitive verb) to dig out (as of groundnuts or potatoes left over in the garden); to find a way (for getting something). aikupa akwap tai: to look for in vain, to try in vain, to dig in vain (for potatoes, etc). 
aikupaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to dig for, look for in vain. kikupaikinai edimaido: try to dig up some groundnuts for me. 
aikur1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to slide a foot forward or backward. ekurete apesur: the girls slide feet forwards and backwards in edonga dance. ekuri ekosobwan karai ekoto asurokin etunganan: the buffalo stamps and scratches the earth before attacking a person. 
aikur2 ko-o (transitive verb) to catch fish with a hook; to roll away, as of cricket ball; to hit (as of tennis ball); to angle. 
aikur3 ko-o (transitive verb) to dig out (potatoes, cassava, groundnuts) using stick or hoe; to scold; to tell off continually; to rebuke, inveigh, or browbeat. ekurete angor acok: the women are digging out potatoes. cp. aikut, aikud. 
aikura ki-a (transitive verb) to do with difficulty; to face or meet difficulty. aikura akwap: to try and dig hard soil. 
aikuraar ko-a (transitive verb) (of hair) to shave off in one go; to finish ploughing a plot in one day. 
aikuraikin ki-a (transitive verb) to obtain a thing with difficulty for somebody. 
aikurakin ki-a (transitive verb) aikurakin enyure kibelai: to start the game of cricket. cp. aikucokin. 
aikuraun ki-a (transitive verb) to do with difficulty; to fight one’s way through; to persevere; to obtain with difficulty; to gain; to merit; to hammer out. abu ngesi kikurau ajakaanut aikuraun: she/he obtained a chieftainship (with difficulty) against a lot of opposition. kikurau akoniswam: do your work even though difficult. 
aikureanar ki-a (intransitive verb) to begin to be often thirsty. 
aikureanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be continually thirsty. 
aikurukur ki-o (transitive verb) to scratch surface of soil after sowing seeds; to cover sown seed with earth; to scratch ground (like a hen looking for food); to cultivate lightly. 
aikuruny ki-o (transitive verb) to roast or to melt fat from cows or fat of sheep’s tail. 
aikurunyikin ki-o (transitive verb) to mix pasted groundnuts with fat – akuruny - for someone (as a delicacy for visitors). 
aikusa ki-a (transitive verb) to dirty the floor with feet; to make a knife blunt. kinyek aikusa ekileng: do not make the knife blunt. ingai ikusai etogo lo?: who makes this house so dirty? cp. aipupusa. 
aikusaar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be bumpy. ikusaara erot: the road is bumpy. cp. ainginyinginyar. 
aikusaar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to make blunt (of a knife or spear); to trample down (make a path by constant walking over same spot). sirikikusaa ekakileng: do not blunt my knife. sirikikusaa ekatogo: do not dirty my house (or do not bring dust into my house). kinyekisi aikusaar amanaka aitaraun erot: do not walk over my plot and make a path through it. cp. aipupusaar. 
aikusanut1 (noun F) cheek, naughtiness, playfulness, etc. cp. ailolianut. 
aikusanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be cheeky, naughty, fidgety, etc. 
aikut1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to blow; to blow the whistle. ekusi ekwam: the wind is blowing. ekusi ngesi alamaru: she/he (blows) plays the flute or clarinet. ekusi aica: the hot season wind (the harmattan) blows. ekusi ngesi epiriigi: she/he blows the whistle. 
aikut2 ko-o (transitive verb) to burrow (a hole); to dig up by hand, (of animals) by paw; (of rats, etc) to make a hole; (Usuk) to refuse. ekusit emir ne: the rat has made a hole here. akut eong jik: I have refused altogether. 
aikuwaar akit ki-a (transitive verb) to give a strong blow (or slap) on the ear. 
aikwa1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of rainfall) to stop. ekwaa edou: it has stopped raining. 
aikwa2 ki-a (transitive verb) to boil or cook partly; to boil a little. kikwaa akiring kinyek aibos: boil the meat a little so that it may not go bad. aikwa iporotoi: to warm the throat (by drinking something hot); to soothe with; to lubricate, or to moisten the throat. koinakinai ekia kekwaa iporotoi: give me some medicine to soothe my throat. 
aikwa3 ki-a (transitive verb) to slap (the ears or face); to deal a blow; to hit with a stick. alosi eong aikwa ijo aki kakan: I am going to slap your ears (literally, to warm your ears). 
aikwaar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to clear up; (of rain) to stop. ekwaa edou: is has stopped raining. 
aikwaar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to give a blow. 
aikwac ko-a (transitive verb) (of a cat, an eagle, etc) to scratch; to write. kakwac eong ekapa: the cat scratched me. akoto aikwac ebalua: I want to write a letter. cp. aigwar, aigirigir. 
aikwad ki-a (intransitive verb) to clamber, climb with difficulty. 
aikwaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to behave to; to do to. ekwaikini eong ai?: what shall I do? how shall I behave? how shall I go about it? do bo nat eong aikwaikin ai?: what can I do? (a sign of helplessness) (transitive verb) to tackle; to treat. cp. aikonakin
aikwalikwal (intransitive verb) to bubble; to ripple. 
aikwam ko-a (transitive verb) to give a strong blow; to put or give or take too much of anything; to give too much; to put in too much. aikwam ajon: alcohol abuse. kinyek aikwam ajon: do not give too much beer. sirikikwam akipi akile: do not add too much water in the milk. 
aikwang ki-a (transitive verb) to row a canoe; (of a weapon) to graze; to touch slightly (as of a weapon). ajeni eong aikwang ataker: I know how to row a boat. 
aikwangakin ki-a (transitive verb) to row one over to; to row somebody across water in a boat; to graze; to touch slightly (as of weapon grazing, just missing its aim). akoto ijo aikwangakin eong okekwa je: I want you to row me across water. 
aikwangar ki-a (transitive verb) to row away; to ferry across water. (reflexive verb) to traverse (a river in a boat); to cross over (in a boat). ipedori ijo aikwangar eong okekwa je?: can you row me to the other side? can you ferry me across water? ekwangaros idwe juwai: the children have crossed over in a canoe.
aikwar ko-a (transitive verb) to copulate (of animals only); to cover (seeds in the soil); (in politics) to usurp or take over someone’s powers and privileges. aikwar aloboi: to sow during dry season. ageata itunga aikwar amanatakec: the people have started to sow their plots. luedisiak kotoma aswam kes ekwaritos luapolok aitamameunit angosibib ka abilarit apedorosio kec: those lower in the power hierarchy are the ones who have usurped powers of the leaders, rendering them useless.
aikwarun ki-a (intransitive verb) to return to consciousness by oneself; to revive oneself; to come to from hunger, after eating a little. kaarit eong etengei konye atap na ketakwaru eong: I was dead with hunger, but this food revived me. 
aikwat ki-a (transitive verb) to follow up. cp. aidap. 
aikwatar ki-a (transitive verb) to take apart; to take away. (reflexive verb) to lose weight. cp. aidapar.
aikwatikwataar ki-a (transitive verb) to chase away; to take away. 
aikwaun ki-a (transitive verb) to add more hot water; to finish beer; to warm up beer before finishing it. (reflexive verb) to be warmed up and then finished (of beer only). 
aikwec ki-o (intransitive verb) to walk with a forked stick (as support); to stumble along with a stick. cp. aicat. 
aikwecar ki-o (intransitive verb) to walk away with a stick as support; to stumble away with a support (usually a two-forked stick). 
aikwel ki-a (intransitive verb) to like; to long for. ikwela ekatau adumun egaali: I long to get a bicycle. cp. eikil. 
aikwelakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to like; to long for. ekwelakin eong alosit ore: I long to go home. cp. aikilakin
aikweny1 ki-a (transitive verb) to warn often. kekwenyit eong yes kere: I warn you all. 
aikweny2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be awake, not to sleep; to open eyes; to be sleepless; to see; to look out. akweny bian eong akware kia: I did not sleep the whole of last night. ekwenyi ngesi, mam emudukana: she/he sees, she/he is not blind. aikweny kia kia: to be awake the whole night. 
aikwenyar ki-a (transitive verb) to warn (somebody or many), admonish, bespeak, apprise, caution. akoto aikwenyar ijo: I want to warn you. 
aikwenyun ki-o (reflexive verb) to be on one’s guard, be warned. kikwenyunos yesi ebunit etengei: be on your guard famine is likely. 
aikwer1 ki-a (transitive verb) to stroke (a cat or animals); to caress; to make even or level. ekweri toto ikekoku: the mother caresses her child. aikwer aloboi: to smooth out, level the furrows (after ploughing). cp. aiyamiyam, aloyanar. 
aikwer2 ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch (like a hen); to spread out (as of millet in the yard), etc; to dry in the sun; to equalize. kolot aikwer akimai: go and spread out the millet to dry. cp. aidier.
aikwerakin ki-a (transitive verb) to rake, smooth out (soil or anything). aikwerakin akiria: to spread roasted dough to dry. aikwerikwer: to keep turning the roasted dough with fingers. cp. akwesikin, aloyaar.
aikwerikwer ki-a (transitive verb) to rake; to flatten; to smooth (the soil aloboi). cp. aikurukur
aikwet ko-a (transitive verb) to beckon (by hand); to call (by hand); to call many; to boil over; to give a tick or a cross. aikwet akibiriiti: to strike a match. 
aikwetikwet ko-a (transitive verb) to beckon (once or many times by hand). 
aikwic ko-a (transitive verb) to strangle; to catch in or with a hooped rope; to choke; to throttle; to brace. abu eong kekwic atapeng k’auno: I choked a guinea-fowl with a string. cp. aimyed.
aikwij ki-a (transitive verb) to suck; to make a sucking noise (as of child or calf, etc sucking breasts). aikwijikwij: to repetitively make a sucking noise. 
aikwikwia ki-a (intransitive verb) to laugh quietly. aikwikwia akwena: to laugh (but not aloud). 
aikwit ki-a (transitive verb) (in a bad sense) to cause ardent longing for; to give longing for; to cause ardent desire or strong feeling; to hanker after. 
aikwong ki-o (transitive verb) to put topsy-turvy; to put higgledy-piggledy; to confuse, not to put in order. ikwongit ijo ikaboro: you have put my things in disorder. 
aikwongakin ki-o (transitive verb) to put things disorderly; to put them higgledy-piggledy. 
aikwongolikin ki-o (transitive verb) to throw down an old man, or a big pole; to place awkwardly. (reflexive verb) (of anything or thin) to fall down haphazardly; to roll, fall (into bed) in a mess. 
aikyen1 (noun F) a curse. cp. ailam, aiken.
aikyen2 ki-o (transitive verb) to curse. abu edeke kikyen Kain: God cursed Cain. cp. aiken
aikyenetoit (plural aikyeneto) (noun F) a curse. ainakin etunganan aikyenetoit: to put a curse on somebody. abu Lokasuban koinak Kain aikyenetoit: God put a curse on Cain. cp. ailametait, aikenetoit
aikyenokin ki-o (transitive verb) to curse one with. abu papa kikyenok ikekoku atwanare: the father put a death curse on his child. 
aikyenor ki-o (transitive verb) to curse one to. akoto aikyenoor ijo bukus: I curse you at your home. 
aikyonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to make level, smooth (of floor, ground, board, etc). cp. aikeonokin
aikyonor ki-o (transitive verb) to level out; to smooth; to plane. cp. aikeonor. 
aila1 (singular noun F) avoidance; ostracism. 
aila2 (singular noun F) sanitation; hygiene; cleanliness. 
aila3 ki-a (transitive verb) to wash; to rinse (cloth or anything); to throw water on. ilaete kesi igoen: they are rinsing clothes. cp. ailot. 
aila4 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be clean; to be neat, or holy. elai eketogo: her/his house is clean or neat. 
aila5 ko-a (transitive verb) to shun; to hate; to avoid, or forsake. kalait ngesi eong: she/he avoids me. inyo bo kilaitor ijo eong?: why do you shun me? 
aila6 ko-a (transitive verb) to space (in planting trees or plants or letters in typing, in producing children, etc). 
ailaagan ki-a (transitive verb) to compete; to contest; to bet. 
ailaakin ki-a (transitive verb) to be irregular doing something; to space (leaving space in between when planting). 
ailaanakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to do irregularly; to do now and again. ilaanakini ijo aswam: you work irregularly (not everyday). (transitive verb) to plant at irregular distances (as of cotton, etc); to spaceto slap the face or ear repeatedly. ilaanakit ijo epaaba irae: you have planted your cotton at irregular (unequal) distances. 
ailaanar ki-a (transitive verb) to go irregularly; to do now and again. ilaanari ngesi ore: she/he goes home now and again (irregularly). cp. ailatoonor. 
ailaar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to visit, travel, stroll; to take a stroll; to take a walk. kilaa oiduka: take a walk to the shop. 
ailaar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to hit, slap on the ear; to deal a blow on the ear. kilaa ber nges akit: first give her/him a slap on the ear. 
ailaar3 ki-a (transitive verb) to wash what is not so dirty; to rinse with water. kilaasi akusiwat: wash yourselves. 
ailab ki-a (intransitive verb) to tell a lie; to boast or brag; to give away secrets (in delirium or drunkenness or otherwise). ailab akipi: to use too much water, etc. cp. ailap
ailaba ki-a (transitive verb) to widen; to make too wide; to level the wall or floor of a house. 
ailabaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to make too wide for, too big for; to level the house for someone. kilabaik ijo eong etogo ngol, mam apedori aiduk: you measured that house too big for me, I may not complete building it. 
ailabany ki-a (transitive verb) to make a thing too wide, like a pot, trousers, suit. abu lokadonyon kilabanya ekapale: the tailor made my trousers too wide. 
ailabanyaar ki-a (transitive verb) to make wide; to widen. 
ailabanyikin ki-a (transitive verb) to make an opening too wide for. ilabanyikit ijo amot na: you made this pot too wide, too big. 
ailabar ki-a (transitive verb) to widen an opening.
ailabilab ki-a (transitive verb) to chatter or to talk rapidly; to rattle out (words); to babble; to talk much; to prate, prattle or rant. ailabilab einer: to talk much and rapidly. ailabilab akipi: to draw a cup-full or bucket-full of water or other liquid; to take too much of water or other liquid. 
ailabilabanar ki-a (reflexive verb) (of previously taciturn person) to become talkative; to waste (especially liquids). elabilabanar etunganan ngol: that man has become very talkative. ailabilabanar akipi: to take or use too much water (as a bad habit). kilabilabanar akipi kere okale je: all the water was taken to the other house. 
ailabilabanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be talkative. 
ailac ko-a (transitive verb) to undress; to loosen screws, nuts or bolts, etc; to unfasten something tied tight; to comb, or untie unkempt or braided hair; to release, set free prisoners, etc jailed. kolac akinei: release or set free the goats. ailac igoen: to undress. 
ailada ki-a (transitive verb) to plaster (a wall); to smear; to daub. ailada ekume: to clean the nose with bare hands (like children). ailada ekori: to keep sitting in the same place, not to go away (literally, to plaster one’s tail on the seat). 
ailadaar ki-a (transitive verb) to plaster once. (reflexive verb) to go (and sit somewhere) waiting for beer or meat. eladaar ngesi neejai akiring: she/he has gone after meat. 
ailadaet (plural ailadaeta) (noun F) plaster; a thing for plastering. cp. amwiiko.
ailadaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to smear on; to plaster on or for somebody. ailadaikin ekia ajimi: to plaster medicine on a wound. 
ailagagam ki-a (intransitive verb) (of one who is old or sick) to become very thin, emaciated, or scraggy (with collar bones standing out). ilagagamit ikoku: the child is very thin, emaciated (with the clavicle bones protruding). 
ailagagamikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become progressively very thin (with prominent collar bones). elagagamikit eong: I have become very thin (with protruding clavicles). 
ailagilag ki-a (transitive verb) to make large, wide, big (of a house, a pot, or garden). ilagilagit ijo akonimana: you have made a big garden (plot). 
ailagilagaar ki-a (transitive verb) to build a big house or make something big in some place away from speaker. kilagilagaa ekonitogo ngina: build your big house over there. 
ailagilagakin ki-a (transitive verb) to make large, wide, big (of a house, a pot, or garden) for somebody. ilagilagakit ijo nges etogo loepol: you built her/him a big house. 
ailagoikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to curdle (of milk); to be dew-webbed; to be hazy (of eyes); to have dew-webs (as of grass overgrowing path and full of dew-webs). elagoikis akile: the milk has curdled. elagokis inya: the grass is full of dew-webs.
ailaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to wash slightly dirty utensils or clothes for somebody or somewhere; to rinse for. kilaikinai eong ikagoen: wash my clothes for me. 
ailaila1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to speak in a loud voice; to talk too loudly; to talk much and quickly, gabble. ilailai ekesa ngol bala loka ikerep: that guy gabbles like a madman. ilailai ikoku ngin: that child talks too much. cp. ailoilo.
ailaila2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to rinse (clothes, utensils, etc). ailaila imomwa: to rinse ash from the sorghum so that it germinates in preparation for beer making. cp. ailebileb.
ailair ki-a (transitive verb) to swear; to vow; to take an oath. cp. aikong. 
ailaj ki-a (transitive verb) to slacken (rope); to loosen; to sag; to unscrew; to untie. akoto eong ailaj akine, iketakit auno: I want to loosen the goat, the rope is too tight on it. 
ailajilaj ki-a (transitive verb) to slacken (rope); to untie, unscrew. ailajilaj akerit: to slacken pace. ailajilaj aswam: to work sluggishly. cp. aijarijar: to relax. ailajilaj akuwan: to relax the body, relax muscles. ailajilaj epale: to undo trousers or shorts. cp. aiyapar.
ailajilajakin ki-a (transitive verb) to loosen, slacken, etc for somebody. (reflexive verb) to be slack, loose (as of rope, a screw, etc). 
ailak ko-a (transitive verb) to undo, unfold; to redeem a mortgaged item of property. ailak aberu: to divorce a woman, to separate. ailak auno: to undo an entangled string. ailak egoe arai apapula: to unfold a cloth or paper. ailak itim: to comb hair. ailak etunganan: to free a prisoner; to redeem; to free a man from debt or prison. ailak etogo: to take off grass from the hut. ailak egaali: to redeem a mortgaged bicycle; to take a bicycle to pieces. ailak etau: to soften the heart; to be appeased. 
ailakakin ki-a (transitive verb) to shake off for somebody; to beat a mat for somebody or somewhere. kilakak ekonimukeeka ngina: go and shake your dusty mat over there. 
ailakar ki-a (transitive verb) to shake off (as of water, dust, etc) from mat, feet, hand, or of dog shaking ears. (reflexive verb) to have become loose; to shake loose. alakanaros ipetai luka egaalika: the nuts of my bicycle have become loose. 
ailakilak ki-a (transitive verb) to shake; to brandish; to agitate. kilakilak emukeeka ngol: shake that mat (to take out the dust). ailakilak ikur: (euphemism) to dance (literally, to shake off maggots). ailakilak akwara kikel: to become angry and daring (literally, to brandish a spear with the teeth).
ailakilakun ki-a (transitive verb) to loosen; to untie, undo; to select second hand clothes for oneself. (reflexive verb) to come loose. elakilakun adukokino kec: their marriage has come apart. 
ailakun ki-a (transitive verb) to shake this way. kilaku emaido: shake off the earth from the groundnuts. (reflexive verb) to come loose; to become free. 
ailala ki-a (intransitive verb) to sound the alarm. kilalaata, abu ekokolan: sound the alarm, a thief has come. cp. ailulu. 
ailalakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to shout for help; to beat the alarm for something; to raise alarm, call attention. nepe kidoluni iso kilalakinete itunga: as soon as we arrived, people sounded the alarm. cp. ailulukin. 
ailalarikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be in a place where one is in view of everybody; to be bare and visible to all; to be outstanding, as of high tree or house. cp. ailelerikin, aidelelikin. 
ailam1 ki-a (transitive verb) to curse. kelamit eong ijo: I have cursed you. ailam ikoku: to make the child ill, by the sexual intercourse of father and its mother (Teso culture forbids sexual intercourse with a breast-feeding woman). irwa kane, yes lukilamitai: go away from me, you cursed ones. 
ailam2 ki-a (transitive verb) to jump over; to hop over; to pass over. ailam kuju: high jump. ailam kwap: long jump. ailam erot: to go across the road; to pass a road. cp. aikalam. 
ailamalam ki-a (transitive verb) to step across things (considered bad manners to step over food). 
ailamasit (plural ailamesia) (noun F) a curse; an anthema. cp. ailametait
ailamet (plural ailameta) (noun F) a curse. cp. ailametait
ailametait (plural ailameta) (noun F) a curse; anathema; abomination. cp. aikenitoit. 
ailamilam ki-a (transitive verb) to clean sorghum from ashes when making beer. ailamilam imomwa: to clean sorghum germinated in ashes (in the preparation of ajon). ailamilam amuk: to throw sandals about in order to predict the future (especially by those embarking on a raiding mission). 
ailamilamaror ki-a (prepositional verb) to take through danger; to help to pass through (as of cows through quarantine regulations); to take through an adventurous journey; to smuggle through. ekoto ngesi ailamilamaror akituk Bugondo: she/he wants to smuggle cattle to Bugondo in Serere county, Soroti. 
ailamulamun ki-o (reflexive verb) to pass through danger; to get over difficulties. adeka koleje eong noi, konye elamulamun do: I was very ill recently, but I have got over it. elamulamun eong kotoma atwanare: I escaped death narrowly. 
ailamun1 (reflexive verb) to come across this way; to cross into the new year. elamunos akituk nuko Karamoja lailo, ayautu edeke: the Karamoja cows have come this way and have brought rinderpest. 
ailamun2 ki-a (transitive verb) (of the moon) to rise. elamu elap: the moon has risen; it is new moon. elap loelamunan: the new moon. 
ailang ki-a (transitive verb) to emit seminal fluid (of a man or animal). 
ailangakin ko-a (transitive verb) to emit semen humanum; to have an ejaculation. 
ailangar ki-a (transitive verb) to get hold of a very hot thing; to take away a very hot thing (like burning charcoal or very hot food) in bare hands. 
ailangilang ki-a (transitive verb) to juggle with the hand; to toss about (as of one carrying hot charcoal or hot food); to burn (the hand holding a hot thing). elangilangi eong inyamat: I am carrying or eating very hot food. 
ailangilangaar ki-a (transitive verb) to carry away (as of a hot charcoal or anything hot, juggling it in the hand). 
ailangilangakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give something hot to somebody, like a hot piece of charcoal or hot food, juggling it in one’s hand; to pick hot food. kilangilangakinai eong atotolet: bring me a bit of glowing charcoal by hand. 
ailango ki-o (transitive verb) to catch by opening the mouth, like a dog does food thrown at it; to catch with open hands; to catch in flight. ilangoi ekingok atap: the dog catches food in its open mouth. 
ailangoikin ki-o (transitive verb) to catch an airborne object for somebody; to be like the Langi people or their language and culture. kilangoikinoi eong emopiira ngol: catch that football for me. 
ailangoor ki-o (transitive verb) to catch in the mouth (like a dog catching food thrown at it); to catch by hand (as of a football); to catch in flight; to catch whilst running (like they catch handball at play). 
ailangoun ki-o (transitive verb) to catch at this location. 
ailany ki-a (transitive verb) to overtake; to be ahead of; to surpass in size or cleverness or speed. abu Olanya kilany Omer: Olanya surpassed Omer in running. abu ngesi kilany oni: (euphemism) she/he passed away; she/he left us - died.
ailanyar ki-a (transitive verb) to overtake; to keep ahead of somebody; to surpass. kilanyari ngesi ijo k’acoa: she/he is cleverer than you (will surpass you in cleverness). 
ailap ki-a (transitive verb) to spill; to tip out (liquids). sirikilap akipi: do not spill water. 
ailapad ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a person or an animal) to move freely. ailapad korot: to move aimlessly.
ailapadaanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be free.
ailapadaara (noun F) freedom of action; liberty; lack of restrictions; free will; choice. 
ailapakin ki-a (transitive verb) to pour a little on or into; to pour or spill on; to waste (liquids); to serve with (liquids). elapakit eong akipi akuwanaka kere: I spilled water all over my body. 
ailapanar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep spilling, pouring out; to inundate; to flood. (reflexive verb) to keep flowing over; to be in flood. 
ailapar1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to flow over; to overflow. elaparos akipi kataagi: the water in the tank is flowing over. 
ailapar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to spill (a little); to tip out (away). kilapa akonikipi ngina: spill your water that way. 
ailapilap ki-a (intransitive verb) to run or to lope. ilapilapi ngesi akwap atitai: she/he just goes about doing nothing (big as she/he is). 
ailapilapakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to run away. ai bo ilapilapakini ijo?: where do you lope to? 
ailapuk ki-a (transitive verb) to exchange; to uproot stalks from the garden. cp. ailopuk
ailapun ki-o (reflexive verb) to rise (of river or flood water); to overflow; to flood. elapunos akipi kotoma ocilet: the river has overflowed. 
ailar ki-a (transitive verb) to space; to leave space between. ailar epaaba: to space the cotton seeds (not to plant too near to each other). cp. ailor, ailer. 
ailarakin ki-a (transitive verb) to throw down on the head or side; to bump somebody’s head on the ground. (reflexive verb) to fall on one’s head; to fall headlong. 
ailarar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be bare; to be clean; to be shining, as of a washed clean face; to have a broad forehead; to be visible from afar. ilararai Olege: (Olege sits in an open place) Olege is in the open. ilararai elap: the moon is visible (not covered by clouds). 
ailarar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to throw down on the head (of a person or animal); to throw head first. abu eong kelarak emir kwap: I threw the rat head first on the ground. (reflexive verb) to fall head first or headlong. 
ailasia ki-a (transitive verb) to hit the ground with; to throw down. akoto ailasia ijo akwap: I want to throw you down (literally, I want to hit the ground with you).
ailasilas akituk ki-a (transitive verb) to flatter, sweet-talk, or cajole. 
ailasilasakin ki-a (transitive verb) to make nice, tasty, or nice looking. kilasilasakinai eong akima: make me some nice porridge. 
ailat ko-a (transitive verb) to throw down hard one after another; to swing arms about. kolata ngul kwap: throw them down. ailat akanin: to swing the arms backwards and forwards. ailat akeje: to make long strides. 
ailatalatatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to loaf, mooch or loiter about. 
ailatat ki-a (intransitive verb) to lie down spread-eagled and helpless (like a dead person or a drunk). apotu itunga kobilutu Akudo kojeera aibunga erono kokerete ajalakin ilatatai kanen koomitos ebe etwanit: a mob broke into jail and beat up Akudo severely, dispersing when they thought he had died.
ailate1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to hunt with spears. ilateete Iteso kinga na ere: the Iteso often hunt with spears (and call it going for a stroll). cp. eilat, eriga, amej.
ailate2 ki-o (transitive verb) to visit, call on; to pay a visit; to travel, hike (wander about). ilato ngesi (plural ilatos kesi) she/he is (they are) hiking. cp. ailaar. 
ailateor ki-o (intransitive verb) to go away on a visit or journey.
ailateun ki-o (transitive verb) to pay a visit here. 
ailaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to come to pay a visit. akoto ijo da ailaun neka: I want you too to pay me a visit. cp. ailateun. 
ailaunun ki-a (intransitive verb) to come and do irregularly, now and again. ilaununei ngesi lailo: she/he only comes here now and again. 
aile1 (plural ailei) (noun F) a large pot. cp. ayile. 
aile2 (plural ailei) (noun F) a species of bird - Florican. 
aile3 (singular noun F) prickly hairs of a plant or shrub. 
aile4 ki-o (intransitive verb) to play the game of omweso (a pea game played on a hollowed out board with 32 holes, each player taking 8*2 holes on one side). 
aile5 ko-a (transitive verb) to beat; to thrash; to strike; to castigate. 
aileb ki-a (intransitive verb) to talk too much; to talk too quickly. 
ailebileb ki-a (intransitive verb) to be talkative; to keep on talking, loquacious; to chatter; to talk nonsense or to moonshine. cp. arara einer. 
ailebilebanut (noun F) fond of talking; talkative, garrulous, chatty, or loquacious.
ailebilebitoi ki-a (intransitive verb) to go round chattering, talking nonsense. 
ailed1 ki-a (transitive verb) to smear (oil, butter or anything on the body). iledete Iteso akecewat ka akinyet: the Iteso smear their bodies with fat. 
ailed2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be occupied, busy, engaged in doing something. iledos itunga aimat ajon: people are busy drinking beer. 
ailedakin ki-a (transitive verb) to smear on or over once; to soil with something; to stain. ejai lokiledaki akinyet opaleka: somebody has stained my trousers with oil. 
ailediled ki-a (transitive verb) to smear all over (the body); ceremonial oiling of pregnant women. 
ailedokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be busy doing something; to be engaged in anything, as of working, talking, dancing, fishing, etc. ailedokin ejie: a free fight. eledokinos itunga amat: the people are busy drinking. 
aileerikin ki-a (transitive verb) to expose; to display or put in the open. 
aileg ki-a (transitive verb) to clean (as of nails or teeth, table, pot, etc). 
ailegakin ki-a (transitive verb) to clean for somebody or somewhere. 
ailegileg ki-a (transitive verb) to clean properly (of anything); to rub clean (as of teeth, etc). 
ailegilegaar ki-a (transitive verb) to rinse (a pot); to clean properly; to do spring-cleaning (reflexive verb) to have become quite well; to have completely recovered. 
aileicikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to become ashamed of, shy of; to become bashful. inyo bo kileicikitor ijo?: what are you ashamed of? 
aileiconor ki-o (intransitive verb) to become or be bashful, ashamed, shy, modest. 
aileiconut1 (singular noun F) bashfulness; shyness. 
aileiconut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be shy, bashful, modest, coy, timid, reserved, self-conscious, withdrawn, blushing. ileicono ngesi: she/he is shy, coy. ileicoko kesi: they are shy. 
aileikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to play the game of omweso for or at a certain place. aileor: to go away to play the omweso. aileun: to play the omweso game here. 
aileile ki-a (transitive verb) to carve smooth. 
aileilear ki-a (transitive verb) to go and tell. 
aileileikin ki-a (transitive verb) to tell to; to carve or whittle for. kileileikinai akiro nukorekon: tell me the news from your home. 
aileileun ki-a (transitive verb) to come and tell; to carve and bring.
aileisit (plural aileisio) (noun F) a board on which the pea-game (omweso) is played with 32 holes. 
ailej ki-a (transitive verb) to make soft (by cooking); to walk like a sick or tired person; to drag one’s legs along. 
aileja ki-a (transitive verb) to take away one by one; to dance (often with bells). kileja amor ngun: take those stones one by one. 
ailejaanar1 alosit ki-o (reflexive verb) to drag oneself along (like a lazy, a sick or drunken person). ilejaanaros kesi elosete: they drag themselves along. 
ailejaanar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to keep taking away one big one after another; to keep felling big ones. kilejaana itelepai osomero: take those big boys to school one by one. 
ailejaar ki-a (intransitive verb) to faint; to fell a big thing. ailejaar ajo: to be fall fast asleep. 
ailejakin1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to dance (often with bells on a string tied to the legs). cp. aicukokin. 
ailejakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to treat carelessly, be careless about; to lax about. sirikilejak ikoniboro eyangaarete ikokolak: do not be careless about your property, the thieves will steal them. 
ailejakin3 ki-o (reflexive verb) (of a big one) to be alone; to be by oneself. eong bon elejakina ore, emamei aberu: I am alone at home, there is no woman. 
ailejatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to slouch about; (of a tall and big person) to walk lazily and awkwardly. 
ailejilej ki-a (transitive verb) to make soft (as of meat or bread by cooking properly); to relax, loosen; to be sleepy; to be without strength; to be weak. 
ailejong (plural ailejonga) (noun F) a cloth or skin used to cover a child on the mother’s back to protect it from the sun. cp. anapet. 
ailek1 akwes ki-o (transitive verb) to throw the head back; to hold the head back (for communion or for pouring medicine in eye). ailek ikisin: to shake, to flap breasts when walking or running or grinding. cp. aijang. 
ailek2 ki-a (transitive verb) to waste, squander, fritter away, or to misuse. 
ailek3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to vomit; to be sick; to spew; to bring forth (only of a woman). ailek akiro: to say everything one knows. ailek aokot: to vomit blood. aberu ka Malinga abu koleku ikoku isapat: Malinga’s wife gave birth to a baby boy. aso ijo kolek akiro kere nuijeni: well then, tell us all you know about (this or that). 
ailekakin ki-a (transitive verb) to waste on or for or at. kilekakini ijo okoku kon ikoniboro: your son is going to waste your things (for you). alot ngesi Kampala ailekakin ikeboro ngina: she/he went to Kampala to waste her/his things. 
ailekek ki-o (intransitive verb) to sit alone and idly. 
ailekilek ki-a (intransitive verb) to retch; to feel like vomiting; to spit out. kelekileki eong etau: I feel like vomiting (transitive verb) to waste (things). ilekileki ijo ikoniboro atitai: you waste your things anyhow. ilekileki akokor abeei: the hen wastes her eggs (by not laying them in one place). (transitive verb) to be disgusted with; to pall. kelekilekata eong akonikiro: I am disgusted with your affairs (transitive verb) (of a girl) to shake breasts when walking. cp. aijorijor.
ailekoor akou ki-o (transitive verb) to throw or hold the head backwards; to look up. kilekoo akou: hold your head back (to drop ointment in the eye, etc). ailekoor akou: to dally, stay behind. elekoorit bian eong akou kore: I dallied at home yesterday. 
ailel1 (noun F) happiness; joy; cheerfulness. 
ailel2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be pleased; to be happy; to rejoice. apaarit naka ailel: the day of joy; happy day; a feast day. 
ailele ki-o (transitive verb) to sift groundnuts; to prepare nice vegetables; to make delicious groundnuts sauce. ileletoi edia lo: there is plenty of groundnuts sauce in these vegetables. 
aileleb ki-a (transitive verb) to fill in; to replenish; to put facts or answers in the spaces that have been left for them. kileleb akipi amot: fill the water in the pot. 
aileleba ki-a (intransitive verb) to be full. ka aileleba (adverb) in full; in detail. ileleba amoti: the pots are full.
ailelebikin ki-o (transitive verb) to fill up; to make something totally full; to add so as to make full. kilelebik ecaai oikopoka: fill the tea in my cup (it is not full). 
ailelebun ki-o (reflexive verb) to be full; to swell up. elelebun epikisit: my lower leg is swollen. elelebun eong: I am satisfied (satiated); I have had enough (food or drink). cp. ailub. 
ailelebwa ki-a (intransitive verb) to swing round and round (as of children); to revolve; to do the merry-go-round. 
ailelebwaun ki-a (transitive verb) to make dizzy, faint, giddy, woozy, wobbly, or light-headed. 
ailelebwaunet (plural ailelebwauneta) (noun F) dizziness; vertigo; faintness; wooziness; giddiness. cp. elelebo. 
ailelekej ki-a (intransitive verb) (of people) to take part in the rain-dance; to dance round; (of birds) to circle or hover around. ilelekejaete itunga: the people are dancing the rain-dance. 
ailelekin emaido ki-o (transitive verb) to make delicious sauce with groundnuts for someone. 
ailelem ki-a (intransitive verb) to bluster or be noisy. kinyekis ailelemat: stop making noise; stop shouting.
ailelemakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to make a noise somewhere or for something. elelemakis idwe kosomero: the children in the school are noisy. 
ailelerikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be bare, open in view of everybody. cp. aileerikin, ailalarikin.
aileliamit (noun F) limestone. 
aileliikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to become or be striped (of clothes or animals). ileliikit egoe lo: this cloth is striped. 
ailem1 ki-o (transitive verb) to pour too much water into (milk, vegetables or beer, etc); to adulterate. sirikilem akipi toma akile: do not pour much water into the milk: do not adulterate the milk. 
ailem2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to pick; to take; to reap (cotton); to subtract. koloto ailem epaaba: go and pick cotton. ailem esolo: to pay tax. ailem epaaba: to pick cotton from the garden. cp. aise epaaba: to sort cotton.
ailemilem1 ki-a (transitive verb) to adulterate by adding too much water to. 
ailemilem2 ki-o (transitive verb) to float; to move, flow away on the water. ilemilemi ekwam ataker: the wind floats the canoe. 
ailemilemo ki-o (intransitive verb) to float on the water or on any liquid. ilemilemos idwe kotoma akipi: the children are floating in the water. 
ailemilemoor ki-o (reflexive verb) to wriggle away or about (as a tadpole or mosquito larvae, or children playing in the water). elemilemooros atakerin okekwa je: the canoes have floated away to the other side of the lake. 
ailenge ki-o (transitive verb) to cut; to sever; (in tennis) to cut the ball (to hit it before it drops). ilengeete itelepai inya: the boys cut the grass (of the lawn). 
ailengoikin1 ki-o (transitive verb) to cut off for; to slaughter for. kilengoikinoi akakokor: slaughter the hen for me. 
ailengokin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to detach; to separate; to seclude; to put aside or apart by itself; to give one alone. kilengok emong bon: seclude the bull. (reflexive verb) to be or to be left by oneself, seclude oneself; to live in solitude. alengokin eong bon aswam: I am doing the work in isolation. 
ailengoor ki-o (transitive verb) to cut off (the head); (in cricket or tennis) to cut the ball; to flay. ailengoor akou: to cut off the head. abu esirikaalet kilengoo Yokana Lokebatisan akekou: a soldier cut off the head of John the Baptist. 
aileny ki-a (transitive verb) to cut (as of branches); to cut up; to break up (as of wood or bones which are too long). kileny akojo numam ilosikino amot: cut up the bones which are too long to go into the cooking pot. cp. aileng.
ailenyar ki-a (transitive verb) to cut off (as of branches); to prune (a tree). 
ailenyasit (plural ailenyasia) (noun F) a joint (as of wrist, elbow, knee, etc).
ailenyeleny akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to give someone a piece of one’s mind. 
ailenyet (plural ailenyeta) (noun F) the wrist.
ailep1 ki-a (transitive verb) to sift; to sieve; to filter. kilep akiria ngun: sift that flour. 
ailep2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to spout out; to milk; to have diarrhoea. elepi ikoku noi: the child has intense diarrhoea. ailep aokot: to have dysentery. ape kolep akiteng: go and milk the cow.
ailepaanut1 (singular noun F) impudence; cheek. 
ailepaanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be cheeky; to be impudent. 
ailepaikin1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be impudent; to become cheeky. ilepakit ikoku: that child has become cheeky. 
ailepakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to toss on; to lift on to. kilepak asaduku ngin omotoka: lift that box on to the motorcar. ailepanar kuju: to bounce up and down (as of a ball or a dancer).
ailepanut (noun F) a creeper or grass used for making granaries. 
ailepar ki-a (intransitive verb) to bounce (as of a ball or animal); to lift up; to bump about; to bounce. ailepar okekwa je: to run to the other side of the valley or lake; to rush over. ilepanar ngesi elosi: she/he has a bouncing gait; she/he gallops. 
ailepep ki-a (intransitive verb) to protrude; to project, stick up or out; to jut out. ilepepeete ikela kon kwape kaluka etom: your teeth protrude like those of an elephant. 
ailepet (plural ailepeta) (noun F) a sieve (for flour); a sift.
ailepilep ki-a (transitive verb) to sieve (as flour, sand); to toss up and down; to flay a person. ailepilep akwap: to run away. 
ailepun ki-a (transitive verb) to lift up, hoist. (reflexive verb) to bounce up; to emerge; to come up. ailepun akiro: to make known (secrets). elepunos akiro: secrets have leaked out. 
ailer1 ki-a (transitive verb) to tighten; to harden (as of floor or of rope). 
ailer2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to keep in the open; to be very visible; to follow the middle of the road. kiler erot ilosi Katakwi: follow the road going to Katakwi. kiler akito ngun ilosi okekwa je: walk on these two poles to cross over to the other side. cp. aider.
ailer3 ki-o (transitive verb) a corruption of ailore: to glitter or to dazzle. 
ailerakin1 ki-o (reflexive verb) to become hard, solid (of ground or anything). 
ailerakin2 kwap ki-a (transitive verb) to throw down hard. 
ailerar ki-o (reflexive verb) to drop dead; (euphemism) to die; to become hard. eleraros alup: the ground has become very hard. elerar esimit: the cement has become very hard. 
ailerer ki-o (intransitive verb) to be visible; to be plain; to lie naked or bare (without covering); to be obvious; (of an explanation) to be clear. emoru Elgon ilererei tupuruc: Mt. Elgon is very visible in the morning. 
ailererikin1 ki-o (reflexive verb) to expose oneself; to put oneself in the open for everyone to see. 
ailererikin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to put in sight; to put in the open for everyone to see; to expose. kilererik ekonitogo amukurat ngin: put your house on top of that hill, to make it visible. ailererikin esakarameetu: to expose the blessed sacrament. 
ailes ki-a (intransitive verb) to jump from one branch to another, like a monkey or a tree squirrel. ailesiles egaali: to jump (with one leg and then) on to the bicycle. ailes angabes: (of dancers) to dance like there are no bones on the waist.
ailesakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to jump on (as on a bicycle). elesakin ngesi ogaali: she/he jumped on her/his bicycle. 
ailesar ki-o (reflexive verb) to jump away; to run off at a gallop; to gallop away like a donkey or a horse. 
aileseikin ko-a (transitive verb) to stretch out (of mats, skins, cloth, etc) in the sun for someone. cp. alesikin. 
ailesikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to fit inside something; to suffice; to be sufficient for. cp. ailosikin
ailesun ki-o (reflexive verb) to jump down this way.
ailetileta ki-a (transitive verb) (of a drunken person) to be dizzy. iletileta lokameran: the drunkard is stupefied. 
ailetiletakin ki-a (transitive verb) to become dizzy; to become drunk, tipsy, throw down (of many) (reflexive verb) to be drunk, dizzy, tipsy; to lie down side by side (of many people). cp. ailatatikin
aileun ki-o (intransitive verb) to play the omweso game. 
aileya ki-a (transitive verb) to do in turns; to do one after another. 
aili ko-a (transitive verb) to pour out; to separate liquid from something unwanted; to sieve or filter. koli ecaai: pour out the tea. iboro lueliak: liquids. 
ailia ko-a (intransitive verb) to creep, or to crawl (of a snake, etc); (of a person) to be on all fours. eliai emun: the snake crawls. eliat etunganan loemera: the drunk man is on his hands and knees.
ailiak ki-a (transitive verb) to shake or nod the head (as of approval or when working). ailiak kokau: to straggle or lag behind. ailiak alosit: to go or to walk while shaking or nodding the head. ai bo iliaki ijo?: where are you going as if you are tired? 
ailiakakin ki-a (transitive verb) to nod to; to approve by nodding to. 
ailiakakinet (plural ailiakakineta) (noun F) a nod; an approval by nodding. 
ailiakar ki-a (intransitive verb) to go away; to go to somewhere. ailiak ekosio: to dance nodding head (up and down). 
ailiaketait (plural ailiaketa) (noun F) nape; back of neck. 
ailianet (plural ailianeta) (noun F) a flame (of fire). abu eong kaany ailianet naka akim: I saw a flame of fire. 
ailib1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be chilly; to be draughty. elibi akakuwan: I feel chilly. 
ailib2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to sprout out leaves (as of burnt grass or seeds or trees); (of sick people) to recuperate. egoe eliba: green cloth. naliba: green. loliba, lulibaik. 
ailiba ki-a (intransitive verb) to skim liquids (especially water); to scoop water slowly (without stirring the dirt up from the bottom). elibai eong akipi kokicoi: I am skimming water from a shallow well. 
ailibaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to skim liquids (especially water) for oneself; to scoop water slowly (without stirring the dirt up from the bottom) for oneself. elibaununutu angor akipi kokicoi: the women have skimmed water for themselves from a shallow well. 
ailic ki-a (transitive verb) to make (things and men) disappear. ejai yenilici ikaboro: someone is stealthily taking my things. 
ailicakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to disappear or to get lost somewhere (especially underwater). elicakin ataker ocor: the boat has sank in the lake. 
ailicar ki-a (transitive verb) to make to disappear, or to cause to disappear (reflexive verb) to vanish; to disappear; to be absent; to hide away. elicaros ikatunga: my people have disappeared. elicar elap: the moon has hidden. 
ailid ko-a (intransitive verb) to take hold of; to hold fast, or tight; to clasp; to fasten tight; to grip; to brace. elidit eturuturut angabet: the hornet has a narrow waist. 
ailiil1 ki-a (transitive verb) to swing round in a circle; to move round, swing, blow about; to move up and down. ekwam iiliili ikito: the wind swings trees.  
ailiil2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be very big, grotesque, tremendously big, or colossal (said of anything); to be horrible; to be awe-inspiring, terrifying; to be very dirty; to be afraid to touch; to be very big (like an elephant). eiliili emoru Masaba: Mt. Elgon is an awe-inspiring mountain. eiliili etom: the elephant is massive. eiliili abangaanutuke: her/his ignorance is too much. eiliili ates: the corpse is horrible. 
ailiilar ki-a (intransitive verb) to swing away. 
ailiili (plural ailiilin) (noun F) a water bird – the sacred ibis. 
ailiilikin ko-o (transitive verb) to cause fear to; to inspire awe; to make afraid, terrify. kailiiliki eong etom: the elephant scares me. 
ailiilior ko-o (reflexive verb) to become very big; to become awe-inspiring; to become very dirty (with akou, to become very proud, swollen-headed).
ailiilit (plural ailiilin) (noun F) a wild duck. 
ailiilun ki-a (transitive verb) to swing back; to bring back by force; to swing, shake tail. (reflexive verb) to come back in a hurry; to run back. 
ailij ki-a (transitive verb) to prick with a thorn or nail (of finger); to pierce easily; to bite (something soft). elij lolo eong emuebe: I have enjoyed mango fruits today. 
ailijakin ki-a (transitive verb) to bite at something succulent; to pierce easily; to prick. kelijaki bian eong ekukwai akeju: a thorn pierced my soft foot yesterday. 
ailijilij ki-a (transitive verb) to prick, peck (like a hen at a boiled potato).
ailijilijakin ki-a (transitive verb) to pierce (the skin); to penetrate deep; to suck (as of calf or child sucking breast of mother). 
ailik ki-o (transitive verb) to swallow; to gulp; to absorb. ailik eluwe: to swallow like a frog or one without teeth, like a child or like an old person; to devour. 
ailiketait (plural ailiketa) (noun F) an oesophagus; a gullet. 
ailikidianut1 (noun F) meanness with food; stinginess, etc. 
ailikidianut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be greedy, stingy, etc. 
ailikidikin ki-a (transitive verb) to covet; to long for, hanker after; to wish. (intransitive verb) to be covetous. elikidikit eong ekonigaali: I wish your bicycle was mine. (reflexive verb) to wish for; to desire. elikidikinos kesi aimat akecejon bonik: they want to drink their beer by themselves. cp. aibitiikin.
ailikilik ki-a (transitive verb) to tear out; to pull out by force; to drag out (as of a thing fixed, difficult to loosen or to get out). 
ailikilikun ki-a (transitive verb) to pull out, drag out; to force out; to pinch nose or cheeks. 
ailikonor ki-o (transitive verb) to swallow continually, morsel after morsel. 
ailikonut ki-o (intransitive verb) to swallow quickly or to swallow one morsel after another; to gobble up. 
ailikor ki-o (transitive verb) to swallow; to swallow up (like a hole or river swallowing a man or object thrown into it); to agree; to hold (as of a canoe, ship or church). kiliko ekia lo: swallow this medicine. eliko eong akonikiro: I understand what you say. ilikorit ataker ngin itunga ipu: that canoe holds many people. 
ailila1 akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to tell good news or stories; to tell jokes. ililai ngesi akiro: she/he tells interesting stories. elilai ngesi akiro nuka akwena: she/he was telling jokes. 
ailila2 ki-a (transitive verb) to take a thing secretly; to abscond; to pilfer. eja luililaete ikaboro: there are people who take my things secretly. cp. aidada.
aililaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away secretly; to smooth off; to sweep clean; to perfect. (reflexive verb) to abscond; to hide. cp. aidadaar.
aililaikin akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to tell good news to or somewhere. kililaikinai eong akiro nukorekon: tell me some good news from your home. 
ailili1 (plural aililin) (noun F) a species of wading bird of the duck family; a small wild duck. 
ailili2 ko-a (transitive verb) to envy; to be jealous of; to covet. kalilit eong ijo kanuka Ateso: I am envious of you because of Ateso. alili eong ekonigaali: I am envying your bicycle. 
aililia ki-a (transitive verb) to purify (adjective) pure. 
aililiam1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to become hard; to be clean. 
aililiam2 ki-a (transitive verb) to be hard; (of something polished) to shine (like a clear moon). cp. aililyam
aililiang1 (plural aililianga) (noun F) a striped field lizard. 
aililiang2 (plural aililianga) (noun F) the biceps and triceps; the muscle of the upper arm. 
aililiget (plural aililigen, aililigeta) (noun F) the umbilical cord; origin; beginning; element. aililiget nak’emaido (plural aililigen nuk’emaido) (noun F) the string or roots of the groundnuts after the plucking. aililiget nak’etaget: a flower of plantain. 
aililing1 (singular noun F) silence; hush; peace. 
aililing2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be silent, calm, quiet, not resounding when tapped; to be in retreat or seclusion. inyukutan luililingete: consonants. aisililing: to silence, soothe; to make to keep quiet. aliling ejose: to refuse to answer, to act deaf; to feign deafness. aililing tii ti: to be very quiet, absolutely silent. 
aililinganut1 (singular noun F) silence; taciturnity. 
aililinganut2 ki-a (transitive verb) to be often silent. 
aililingikin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep or be silent to one asking a question - not to answer somebody. inyo bo kilingikinia ijo eong?: why do not answer me? 
aililingun ki-a (intransitive verb) to become silent; to become quiet. 
aililyam ki-a (intransitive verb) to be very hard; to shine (like the moon or star); to be polished like a diamond. 
ailim1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of rain) to fall. ilimit edou epol: it rained very much. cp. aitep.
ailim2 ko-o (transitive verb) to say; to speak out; to tell. karai ejaas nuikoto, kolim: if there is anything you want, speak out. aitilim: to make to say; to cause to speak. 
ailimakin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of rain) to fall on; to rain once; to inebriate. ilimakinit ca ngol edou: it seems it rained on him, he appears tipsy or drunk. cp. atepakin.
ailimakinet (plural ailimakineta) (noun F) a spot or freckle; a stain; a drizzle (of rain). 
ailimanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to make spots; to freckle (reflexive verb) to have spots; to be freckled or have freckles. 
ailimanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to begin to rain (a few drops); to drizzle here and there. ilimanar edou: it is beginning to rain. 
ailimilim ki-a (intransitive verb) (of rain) to drizzle; (of dirt) to make spots on; to fleck; to mottle. 
ailing ko-a (intransitive verb) to be first; to be early there; to go there early. koling osomero: be early to school; be early at school. 
ailingiling ki-a (intransitive verb) to adorn; to decorate. 
ailingokin atap ki-a (transitive verb) to cook badly; to serve half-cooked or raw millet bread. ipoi ngesi elingo: she/he cooks badly (because she/he does not allow water for mingling bread to boil, or she/he over-boils it). cp. epule, engorojojo: badly cooked food; badly mingled half-cooked atap. 
ailiok1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to tell lies. iliokit ijo akiro: you have told lies. cp. aisab, aingalangal.
ailiok2 ko-o (transitive verb) to set on edge (of teeth); to make blunt (especially a cutting edge of a knife or an axe). ailiok ekileng: to make a knife blunt. ailiok ikel: to set teeth on edge. elioki emuebe ikel: a mango fruit sets teeth on edge. amoru elioki ekileng: a stone blunts a knife (by trying to cut a stone). cp. ailyok.
ailiokan (plural ailiokak) (noun F) a withy; a pliable branch or twig. 
ailip1 (plural ailipasia, ailipasinei) (noun F) prayer. ailip naka atupuruc: morning prayer; matins. ailip naka atibong: evening prayer; vespers.
ailip2 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a boil) to swell. 
ailip3 ki-a (transitive verb) to ask; to beseech; to beg; to pray. ejai ibore yenikelipit eong ijo: there is something I asked from you. ailip aswam: to ask for work; to apply for employment.
ailipanar ki-a (transitive verb) to beg and take away often. (intransitive verb) to become a beggar. 
ailipanut1 (noun F) begging often; asking persistently; petitioning often. 
ailipanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of asking; to be a beggar. 
ailipasit (plural ailipeta) (noun F) an asking prayer; a petition; a request. 
ailipesit (plural ailipesia) (noun F) head of sore; head of swelling.
ailipilip ki-a (transitive verb) to beg repeatedly; to pray continually; to beg from many people. 
ailipilipaar ki-a (intransitive verb) to grow a swelling. 
ailipilipitoi ki-a (transitive verb) to go begging. 
ailipilipun ki-o (reflexive verb) (of a boil) to swell; to come to a head. elipilipunos abusioka: my boils have swollen. 
ailipun1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a swelling) to come up; to swell up. 
ailipun2 ki-a (transitive verb) to ask for oneself. ailipun inyamat: to beg for food. 
ailir1 ki-a (transitive verb) to stamp hard (as of floor, gravel, cement, etc); to fix properly, securely; to press together, compress. akituk ilirete auryanet: the cows trample down their resting or milking ground. kilirata epir lo: fix this pole properly. 
ailir2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to run fast (as of a guinea fowl or a quail); to roll down; to go rolling fast, as of a ball or wheel. iliri atapeng kokwap: the guinea fowl runs fast in the ground. iliri emopiira: the ball rolls fast. 
ailirakin ki-a (transitive verb) to mingle just enough atap for a few people. akoto ber eong ailirakin ecokok atap adis: I want to first mingle a little atap for herdsmen.
ailiret (plural ailireta) (noun F) a lump of atap used to clean up the remnants of groundnut paste on the grindstone or mortar, afterwards eaten by the children.
ailirilir ki-a (transitive verb) to harden by rolling; to make hard (of soil, ground, food). akoto alirilir atap kanyam: I want to let the food get solid, then I may eat. ilirilirete akituk akamana: the cows are compacting the soil in my garden (by trampling). 
ailirilirakin ki-a (transitive verb) to make hard by rolling or trampling; to stamp (floor); to cook food solid (by adding enough flour, etc). cp. ailuruluraar. 
ailirira ki-a (transitive verb) to stand or to be dumbfounded, stupefied, stunned. 
ailirokin ki-a (intransitive verb) to fix securely, immovably; to run fast to. ilirokina akwara kwap: the spear is fixed immovably in the ground. 
ailisin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be foggy, misty. ilisinat lolo akwap: it is very foggy today. 
ailisinakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to look or be like mist or fog. elisinaki edou: the cloud looks like fog. 
ailit1 (plural ailin) (noun F) a nest for hens to lay eggs in; a cavity; a grave. cp. aigogo. 
ailit2 (plural ailin) (noun F) chain of iron; spiral rings worn round lower arm and leg. 
ailit3 iboro ki-o (transitive verb) to measure unequally; to distribute unevenly, unjustly. ilisit ijo ipirin luk’etogo erono: you have cut the poles of the house badly (too long). kinyek ailit akeje kingaren: do not out-walk me, do not walk so quickly. ailit akiro: to tell lies. ailit akeje: to out-walk or out-run somebody. 
ailit4 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of plants or trees) to be barren. alit ekitoi lo(plural alito ikito lu): this tree is (these trees are) barren. 
ailiya ko-a (intransitive verb) to shine (of sun or lamp, etc); to dazzle, or coruscate. iliyai elap kware: the moon shines at night. 
ailo1 ki-a (transitive verb) to excel; to surpass, overcome; to go against; to lose (a case). keloata eong akiro: I lost the case. keloit eong aswam ngin: that work defeats me. cp. aitelekaar.
ailo2 ko-a (transitive verb) to dry; to air, spread out in the sun. koya egoe lo ailo: take this cloth to dry in the sun. ailo akanin: to spread out hands (palms up) as sign of denial or in gesticulating when preaching. 
ailobo ki-o (transitive verb) to dig deep; to plough with oxen another time. iloboete Iteso akecemanat: the Iteso plough their plots twice before sowing. 
ailobokin ki-o (transitive verb) to dig in; to plant (seeds, etc). ailobokin emaido kwap: to dig in the groundnuts. 
ailoboor ki-o (transitive verb) to plough or to dig up a field once; to dig or plough the grass under. ailoboor amana: to plough a garden without planting anything in it. ailoboor inya: to plough in the weeds in the garden for mulch.
ailobwa ki-a (intransitive verb) to tie (a person or an animal) with a rope; to put behind bars. ilobwatai ikokolak kojeera Luzira: thieves are being held behind bars in Luzira prison. ejai ilobwatai: to be under arrest; to be a prisoner of the police or soldiers.
ailoc ki-o (transitive verb) to take from one place to another; to alter; to interpret, transfer. 
ailociloc ki-o (transitive verb) to change about or alter often. 
ailocokin1 (singular noun F) transfiguration; (chemistry) sublimation. 
ailocokin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to interpret; to translate; to change place for; to change manners; to dress in other clothes; to alter; to disguise. kilocok iponesiokon: change your manners. (reflexive verb) to be transfigured; to change appearance; to become something else. elocokin etelepat: that boy has changed. abu Yesu kilocokin kakonye ka ikiyakia: Jesus was transfigured before his apostles. elocokin Onyait araun esirikaalet: Onyait has become a soldier. 
ailoconokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to fluctuate. 
ailoconor ki-o (transitive verb) to change often; to keep changing; to exchange (as of money, cows, places, anything). iloconorio ngesi irwan ipu: she/he is transferred often. iloconor aberu ngin ikar kere: that woman changes husbands every year. cp. ailokony.
ailocor ki-o (transitive verb) to transport; to transfer (to another place); to change; to appoint to another place. 
ailod ki-a (transitive verb) to go or travel to many places; to roam or wander about. cp. ailood
ailodakin ki-a (transitive verb) to put (a rope, sheet, wire, etc) round something; to tie round. kilodak atipe omorosing: tie a string of beads round your neck. 
ailodar ki-a (transitive verb) to encircle; to surround (in hunting, etc); to go behind a house, granary, etc; to make the round of. luamejak egeete ber ailodar amonieik: the hunters first surround the thickets. cp. airimor.
ailodilod ki-a (transitive verb) to coil round; to go round and round. ilodilodi emun ekitoi: the snake is coiling round a tree. 
ailodilodakin (reflexive verb) to coil round something; to twine itself round somebody or something. emun ilodilodakin elope okitoi: the snake coils itself round a tree. 
ailodo ki-o (transitive verb) to beat; to lash (a person, animal, etc). abu esirikaalet kilodo etunganan k’eiboko: the soldier lashed a man with a whip. 
ailog ki-a (transitive verb) to search; to explore; to reconnoitre. akoto ailog ekonitogo: I want to search your house. irotin luilogas: a labyrinth of roads. ailogilog etau: to examine one’s conscience. cp. aigor. 
ailoga ki-a (transitive verb) to charm, bewitch with herbs, etc. cp. aipyed. 
ailogakin ki-a (transitive verb) to brandish a stick (in a dance) (reflexive verb) (of different things) to get mixed up. elogakinos akituk kotoma auj: the cows are mixed up in the cowshed or kraal. 
ailogar ki-a (transitive verb) to brandish a stick; to travel to many places. ailogar akwap: to go round visiting places; to travel about. 
ailogilog ki-a (transitive verb) to search repeatedly; to explore. ailogilog akiro: to investigate a case, examine, question. cp. aigorigor.  
ailoilo1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to eat like a toothless person; to chew food with difficulty (especially shifting food from side to side). cp. anwomok. 
ailoilo2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to speak very loudly; to speak in a loud voice. cp. ailaila. 
ailoilo3 ki-o (transitive verb) to cut up in lumps; to crush with a hammer into big lumps (said of stones, cassava, etc). ailoiloikin: to cut up in lumps for somebody. 
ailok1 ki-a (transitive verb) to redeem (cows, cattle); to pay for looking after cattle. iloki ngesi akituk: she/he redeems her/his cattle. 
ailok2 ki-o (transitive verb) to loosen, unfasten; to shake loose (a peg or pole or anything fixed); to persuade; to shake somebody in their plan; to get somebody round. 
ailok3 ko-a (transitive verb) to trap; to ensnare (of man or animal); to bait. alokit eong emir: I have set a trap for the rat. 
ailok4 ko-o (transitive verb) to knock out or to remove lower teeth. alosi eong ailok ikel: I am going to have my lower incisors knocked out. 
ailoka ki-a (transitive verb) to transfer (liquids, etc) from one container or place to another. kilokaa esisianakinan ngol aibois ace: transfer that teacher to another place.
ailokaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to change or put somewhere else; to paint in a different colour. kilokaik akiria toma amot: shift the flour into the pot. akoto ailokaikin arwatat na eceraagi: I want to paint this wall another colour. 
ailokar ki-a (transitive verb) to change colour; to change into; to repeat in other words; to transfer; to take or put somewhere else. akoto ailokar akituk nenice: I want to take my cows somewhere else. (reflexive verb) to fade. elokaros igoen ka: my clothes have faded. 
ailokaun ki-a (transitive verb) to change to this side (reflexive verb) to be changed to this side. 
ailokilok ki-o (transitive verb) to keep shaking (anything); to loosen. 
ailokilokoor ki-o (transitive verb) to loosen by shaking. 
ailokokin ki-o (transitive verb) to redeem for somebody; to pay for looking after something. 
ailokony ki-a (transitive verb) to go in the opposite direction; to ignore; to exchange things; to pass without greeting; to mix up, barter (with other things), put in disorder; to boycott. okwe kobongokinai akiro, kinyek ailokony: please answer me and stop ignoring me. 
ailokonyikin ki-a (transitive verb) to confuse; to dislocate; to put in disorder; to entangle a rope; to tie crosswise. ailokonyikin akiro: to spoil a discussion (by interfering or by illogical statement). (reflexive verb) to be entangled (of rope or case); to pass each other; to be intricate; (of teeth) to grow over one another. elokonyikinos ikekel: her/his teeth have grown over each other. ailokonyikin akeje: to cross legs. kilokonyikis akanin kus: cross your arms. 
ailokor ki-o (transitive verb) to buy back; to return. cp. ainyakar. 
ailokun1 ki-o (transitive verb) to bring back; to return. akoto ailokun ikaboro luabu eong kainak ijo aidar: I want to get back my property that I gave you to look after. cp. ainyakun.
ailokun2 ki-o (transitive verb) to talk round; to shake somebody in his opinion; to convince; to persuade. 
ailoli ki-a (transitive verb) to keep moving a thing about. ilolie ngesi ikeboro: she/he moves her/his things about. ailoli akuwan: to move oneself about; to be restless. ailoli akonye: to roll eyes; to be curious; to look right and left. ailolio: to be driven from pillar to post. ailoli akiro: to tell-tale; to newsmonger. ailoli iselio: to be alarmed (as of a thief caught suddenly); to tremble or quake or be in a panic. elolitoi eong kotoma aswam: I am fussy in my work. cp. akeritor akiro.
ailolianut1 (singular noun F) cheek, nerve, gall, effrontery, chutzpah; playfulness, mischievousness; fuss, to-do, bother, excitement. 
ailolianut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be cheeky, playful, fussy, frivolous, etc 
ailoliar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away (anything) immediately. kilolia akinei ngun ore je: take away those goats quickly to the other home. 
ailoliikin ki-a (transitive verb) to move one’s things about. eloliikis ikatunga awatekec: my people are fussing around. 
ailolit1 iselio ki-a (transitive verb) to be fussy; to hurry about different works, hurry up work. 
ailolit2 ki-a (transitive verb) to keep moving something. kinyek ailolit akonye: do not be so curious (literally, do not keep moving your eyes).
ailolitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to be fussy; to fidget; to be restless. 
ailoloar ki-a (transitive verb) to rinse away; to cleanse off; to wash out; to flush out. kiloloa amot ngin: cleanse or rinse out that pot. 
ailoloaret (plural ailoloareta) (noun F) ablution; rinsing; bathing. 
ailolog ki-a (transitive verb) to search; to find out; to be looking for. ilologaete lolo ipolisin itogoi: the police are searching houses today. 
ailologaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away (after searching); to steal; to rifle. ejai yenikilologaa akabalang: somebody has taken my salt ash away. 
ailologakin ki-a (transitive verb) to search for; to search in a certain place. kolot kilologak ikoku esukaali kotogo: go and search for some sugar in the house for the child. 
ailologaun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring all (after searching); to steal and bring; to mop up; to gather all. elologaun abenyak ko Teso: all rebels have been arrested in Teso. 
ailolom ki-o (intransitive verb) to be noisy; to make noise. 
ailolomonut ki-o (intransitive verb) to be in the habit of speaking in a loud voice; to be cantankerous, boisterous, raucous. elolomono eong, ilolomoko yesi: I, you are boisterous, noisy, loudspeaking. 
ailolomot ki-o (intransitive verb) to speak in a loud voice; to shout. sirilolomotos: do not shout. cp. ailelemat. 
ailolony ki-a (transitive verb) to be exhausted; to be very tired. ilolonyit kesi: they are exhausted (literally, it tires them). 
ailoloun ki-a (transitive verb) to wash out, purify, or rinse out. kilolou eikopo lo: rinse out this cup. 
ailom1 aberu ko-a (transitive verb) to commit adultery. ikamunitai Otwao elomit aberu: Otwao was caught in adultery. 
ailom2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to come out (of seeds or person, etc); to come in; to enter a newly built house. akoto eong ailom togoka: I want to enter (start staying in) my new house. age ekapaaba ailom: my cotton has come up. aitolom akiro: to cause trouble, to utter. 
ailong ki-a (transitive verb) to wash (the body); to bathe. mam ijo ilongit: you have not bathed. ilongarit ijo ainyinyir: you are sweating all over (literally, you are bathed in sweat). (note: ailot is used when washing hands, feet or any single part of the body is implied). 
ailongakin ki-a (transitive verb) to take a bath somewhere or to wash somewhere or in front of somebody. ailongakin ates: to bathe someone (who did not attend the funeral) at the graveside.
ailonget (plural ailongeta) (noun F) a bathtub; a bathroom or shelter. 
ailongilong ki-a (transitive verb) to shake or to disturb; to harass or agitate. kelongilongi eong amotoka na: this motorcar shakes me. cp. aijangijang.
ailongilonga ki-a (intransitive verb) to shake. ilongilongas ikito kanuka ekwam: the trees shake with the wind. cp. aijangijanga. 
ailongilongaar ki-o (reflexive verb) to be shaken about; to shake; to tremble. elongilongaaros akwi kanuka ekwam: the leaves shake in the wind. (transitive verb) to shake a thing so that it may fall away from speaker. cp. aijangijangaar.
ailongilongun ki-a (transitive verb) to shake a thing so that it may fall towards the speaker. (reflexive verb) to shake this way; to be shaken; to be upset; to feel shaky, feel sick. elongilongun adeka kanu kelongilongia amotoka: I feel sick with the shaking of a car. elongulongun ekatau kanuka ican: I feel upset on account of troubles; to be worried. cp. aijangijangun.
ailony ko-a (transitive verb) to miss the mark; to miss an appointment to a job; to pass over. ajakaanut abu kelony eong: leadership passed me by; I did not get the job. kilonya ijo akiro: you are unlucky. 
ailood ki-a (transitive verb) (of a politician) to go round campaigning for votes; to canvass; to electioneer; to drum up support. cp. ailod
ailoor ki-o (transitive verb) to reflect (as of windowpane reflecting sunshine). cp. ailore.
ailop ko-a (transitive verb) to deliver a child. ailop emong: to castrate a bull. ailop emaido: to draw or pull groundnuts by fingers. cp. airut emaido.
ailopa ki-a (transitive verb) to tell tales; to accuse; to report on (somebody). kilopai ijo eong apaarasia kere: you report on me always. ailopa itunganan: to accuse someone; to report on somebody. ilopai ngesi eong ebe akokot ekekalaamu: she/he accuses me that I stole her/his pencil. cp. alimor, aideide.
ailopakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to be or become the owner of; to own; to accuse each other. ekot Omayo ailopakin emeesa: Omayo wishes to own the table. 
ailopakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to put through (as of a rope through a loop); to make a loop. 
ailopilop ki-o (intransitive verb) (of a man with big genitals) to run (lope). 
ailopilopaar ki-a (transitive verb) to loop (as of a web). 
ailopilopoor ki-o (reflexive verb) (of males with big genitals) to run away awkwardly. elopilopoor etelepat: the boy ran away awkwardly (this word is used only of a man or male animals, not of women). 
ailopuk ki-a (transitive verb) to change; to exchange; to turn the soil; to loosen the ground; to change the soil by turning it with a hoe. ailopuk ekiror: to get a another name (as of baptism). ailopuk akiro: to discuss issues; to alter a statement. 
ailopuk ki-a (transitive verb) to exchange; to uproot stalks from the garden.
ailor1 ki-o (transitive verb) to close firmly. kilor erute, ekotos akituk alomun: close the entrance to the kraal well, the cows want to break out. kilor epiding kikukwa: close off the path with thorns. 
ailor2 ki-o (transitive verb) to know a language very well; to speak clearly; to speak distinctly, i.e. to be articulate. ilori ngesi Ateso ailor: she/he speaks Ateso distinctly. 
ailor3 ki-o (transitive verb) to leave space between; to space. kilor ikito irae: space trees when planting. 
ailor4 ki-o (transitive verb) to make hard. kilor epuko: stamp the sack hard (with millet, etc). ailor akoik: to eat too much (literally, to make the stomach hard). 
ailore ki-o (transitive verb) to blind (of the sun); to shine brightly; to shine into one’s face; to dazzle; to reflect the sunlight onto. iloreit akolong eong: the sun blinds or dazzles me. 
ailorilor ki-o (transitive verb) to space; to make clear (as of floor or field, etc). ailorilor alaro: to clear the compound of weeds, etc. ailorilor akou: to shave clean or cut hair very low; to keep rapping on the head with an object. cp. aitalapat.
ailoronokin ki-o (transitive verb) to leave spaces in between (as of rafters, etc). 
ailoror ki-o (intransitive verb) to be very hard; to be steady. iloror epeta lo: this screw is very hard. iloror kesi kotoma aswam: they are very steady in their work. cp. iketara. 
ailoroun ki-o (transitive verb) to strike on the head with a stick. iloroununei ngesi iso: she/he keeps rapping our heads. 
ailosikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to fit inside something; to be contained in; to be sufficient; to go into, be congruent. mam egaago lo ilosikin itunga kere: this shed cannot accommodate all people.
ailot ki-a (transitive verb) to wash (part of the body); to wash clothes or anything. ailot akanin: to wash hands. (note: ailong is to bathe or wash the whole body of a person). ailot igoen: to wash clothes. ailoloar igoen: to rinse clothes.
ailotakin ki-a (transitive verb) to wash for somebody; to wash (dirt) into something. sirikilotak ekonilos togo lo: do not wash off your dirt in this room. 
ailotar ki-a (transitive verb) to wash off; to wash clean. kolot ailotar igoeneka: go and wash my clothes. 
ailotun ki-a (transitive verb) to wash clean. ilotunit aberu ikoku: the woman brought forth a clean child. 
ailu ko-o (intransitive verb) to change into enemy; to attack. 
ailub ki-a (transitive verb) to fill up; to fill to the brim. kilub amoti ngun k’akipi: fill those pots with water. cp. aileleb. 
ailubakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fill up for, into, somewhere; to fill something with. kilubak amoti akipi: fill the pots with water. cp. ailelebikin.
ailubulubaar ki-a (transitive verb) to replete; to fill up to the top, to the brim. cp. ailelebaar.
