ailuc ko-o (transitive verb) to make a feast or rite to atone for the wrong done; to palliate or pacify the gods; to lessen pain; to mitigate. 
ailud ki-a (transitive verb) to block up holes with clay or cement; to stop a leak; to solder. cp. ainuok. 
ailudakin ki-a (transitive verb) to block up somewhere for somebody; to solder or stop a leak. kiludak emina toma amotika: solder my cooking pot (literally, stick latex of gum on my pot). 
ailudar ki-a (transitive verb) to block up completely; to stop what is inside from coming out. ailudar akiro: to keep a secret. 
ailugokin ki-a (transitive verb) to bend (as of a bow or stick, etc on striking its target). (reflexive verb) to be bent, crooked. cp. aimagulikin.
ailugokinet (plural ailugokineta) (noun F) a curvature, crook, turn, corner; a bend, a twist. 
ailuj ki-a (transitive verb) to eat soft fruit or food; to suck. iluji ikoku etaget: the child eats bananas. 
ailujakin ki-a (transitive verb) to take a good bite of something soft. kilujak atap: take a big mouthful of millet bread. 
ailujar ki-a (transitive verb) to eat and finish something soft. abu ngesi kiluja acokit kere: she/he finished off the whole potato. 
ailuk1 ki-a (transitive verb) to leave marks of food outside of mouth or on fingers. ilukit ikoku inyamat kakanin: the child has marks of food on its hands (before washing them). 
ailuk2 ko-a (transitive verb) (of an attacker) to encircle (the enemy); to surround; to catch fish by hand (to encircle fish); to weave a basket. ailuk etuo: to cut off the top of a gourd. ailuk adere: to cut a gourd in two, to make calabashes. 
ailuk3 ko-a (transitive verb) to leave patches uncultivated. iluki ijo inya icapi: you leave unweeded spots in the garden. 
ailukum ki-a (transitive verb) to make something round; to make a circle. kilukumu edula: make the granary round. cp. ajeun.
ailukumun ki-a (intransitive verb) to make rounded; to be in a circle; to sit round. ilukumunos itunga emasete ajon: people sit round the beer pot as they drink (sit in a circle). 
ailul ki-a (transitive verb) to surround; to fly round; to stand round in need of something. ekoto ao ailulu etuo lo: the bees want to swarm around this gourd. cp. ailulukin. 
ailulu1 ki-a (transitive verb) to crowd together in one spot (as of flies on wound, of men, animals, birds, etc). iluluete icuc ajimi: the flies swarm the wound. 
ailulu2 ki-a (transitive verb) to smooth; to make smooth; to plane. ailulu abaoi: to plane boards. 
ailulu3 ki-o (transitive verb) to raise an alarm or shout a warning (by repeating aloud the lu lu lu, keeping fingers on lips). inyo bo iluluoto yesi?: why do you sound the alarm? iluluete kesi atitai: they alarm for nothing. cp. ailala. 
ailuluar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to cover up altogether; to fill to the brim; to surround. kilulua amot: fill the pot. (reflexive verb) to be covered. eluluar etuja: the granary is full. eluluaros akonye: the eyes are puffy. 
ailuluar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to plane off; to smooth; to fill up a hole. 
ailuluikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to raise an alarm; to beat the alarm. keluluikisi kanuka ekokolan: let us make an alarm on account of the thief. 
ailulukin ki-a (reflexive verb) (of many) to swarm round meat, food, or beer. adum eong itunga ilulukina ajon: I found people sitting round the beer pot. 
ailulum ki-a (intransitive verb) to stir a liquid and make it dirty. alosi ailulum: I am going for a plunge. (transitive verb) to wet one’s bed. ilulumaete idwe aperitikec: the little children wet their beds. 
ailulumaar ki-o (reflexive verb) to go groping in the dark; to go out in the dark; to swim away. 
ailulumaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to soil the bed; to plunge or swim somewhere. alosi ailulumaikin osamai: I am going to plunge in the swamp. elulumaiki ikoku ebilaangitike: the child has wetted its blanket. 
ailuluonut1 (noun F) the habit of making alarm. 
ailuluonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be in the habit of sounding or beating alarm. 
ailuluor ki-o (intransitive verb) to beat the alarm while going away. 
ailulut ki-a (transitive verb) (of bees, flies, etc) to go and fly round something. ilulut ao amolig: the bees are flying round the beehive. 
ailuluun ki-o (transitive verb) to shout towards this way; to call by alarming. kiluluu ijo itunga: shout for the people. (reflexive verb) (of many together) to come around. 
ailum ko-o (intransitive verb) to swim in the water; to submerge; to go under (liquid); to sink. elumi etelepat kotoma akipi: the boy swims in the water. 
ailumokin ki-a (transitive verb) to plunge into liquid; to walk (in the mud). kilumok igoen toma akipi: soak the clothes in the water. 
ailumulum ki-a (transitive verb) to keep secret; to keep hidden (of anything). ejaas akiro nuilumulumit ijo kotaukon: there is something in your heart which you are hiding. cp. aibwa.  
ailumulumaar ki-o (reflexive verb) to become obscure; to get lost. elumulumaaros akiro nuk’lteso nukolo sek kasonya: the old history of the Iteso has become obscure. (transitive verb) to hide away; to cover up (as of a hole or a secret). 
ailumulumakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hide for somebody. inyo bo kilumulumakitor ijo eong akakiteng?: why do you hide my cow away. cp. aibwaikin. 
Ailung1 (singular noun F) Lent (the time from Ash Wednesday to Easter Sunday, kept as a fast in remembrance of Christ’s fast in the wilderness); fasting.
ailung2 ki-a (transitive verb) to make into round lumps (as of clay, etc). ilungulungete luadukok elupe: the builders of a traditional hut make lumps of clay. 
ailung3 ko-a (transitive verb) to refuse out of anger or spite; to abhor or abominate; to fast (go without food for religious reasons). alung ngesi inyamataka: she/he refused to eat my food (because she/he is angry). 
ailungakin ki-a (transitive verb) to make lumps for somebody (like a mother making lumps of food for her child). 
ailungulung ki-a (transitive verb) to make food or clay into round lumps or balls. ailungulung akiro: to harbour feelings of revenge; to harbour evil thoughts about someone. ailungulung akan: to clench the fist. ailungulungitoi akerit: (of a stumpy person) to run. 
ailungurikin ki-a (transitive verb) to make round (of anything); to collect, bring together in a body; to keep for absent person. ailungurikin akiro: to gather evidence. 
ailuny ki-a (transitive verb) to take off (as crust of a wound); to abrade; to take off (as of skin); to take off (feathers of chicken); to take somebody’s place (in their absence and without their knowledge); to replace someone. akoto ijo ailuny aiboisitika: I want you to replace me. ailuny alosit: to go straight on. cp. abuluc.
ailunyar ki-a (transitive verb) to abrade, etc. 
ailunyaret (plural ailunyareta) (noun F) abrasion; a scratch. 
ailunyasit (plural ailunyeta) (noun F) abrasion.
ailunyuluny ki-a (transitive verb) to bruise all over; to scratch all over. abu egaali kelunyuluny eong: the bicycle bruised me all over. cp. abulucanar. 
ailupud ki-a (intransitive verb) to swell (as of ant hill being built); (of things) to cover with clay before being eaten by ants. ilupudi atitipu akonyeke: the anthill’s ‘eyes’ are being covered up by termites. 
ailupudaar ki-a (reflexive verb) to drip away; to be covered; to be dirty (of nose). elupudaaros ikumesike: her/his nostrils are dirty. (transitive verb) to cover up (only of ants covering things, filling exits). elupudaasi ikok akonye nuka atitipu: the termites have covered the exits of the anthill (after white ants have swarmed). 
ailupudun ki-a (intransitive verb) to protrude; to drip (as of dirty nose or wound); to swell (as of a growing anthill). 
ailupur ki-a (transitive verb) to push out (like a man’s distended or swollen testicles). 
ailupurun ki-o (reflexive verb) to ooze out (as of resin); to come this way with something swollen. 
ailur1 ki-a (transitive verb) to be overcome by sleep; to doze. kelurete eong ajo: I am sleepy.
ailur2 ki-a (transitive verb) to harden; to make or stamp (of floor); to make smooth. 
ailur3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to bend the head; to look down; to bow down; to droop. elurete akimai kwap: the millet is drooping in the field (due to the sun’s heat). 
ailurakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to fall asleep; to fall, settle (on a chair, etc); to harden (the floor or anything) for somebody or somewhere. elurakin ngesi oicolong: she/he has fallen asleep on the chair. elurakin emaase mana: the locusts have settled on the crops. (reflexive verb) to become hard, smooth. 
ailuranar ki-a (reflexive verb) to doze; to be sleepy, or drowsy. 
ailuror ki-o (transitive verb) to let fall down (as of child) on hard ground (reflexive verb) to fall down (of child or anything). kiluror ikoku kwap: the little child fell down. 
ailuruluraar ki-a (intransitive verb) to be very hard and smooth (like cement or stone). (transitive verb) to make very hard (as of a floor). ailurulurakin: to make hard. 
ailurun ki-o (reflexive verb) to be exhausted, jaded; to be drooping (like a tree full of fruit); (of a dying person) to let her/his head droop down (reflexive verb) (of blood) to coagulate. 
ailusar ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall asleep quickly; to faint or have coma. abu eong kelusar naarai kapasit: I fell asleep at once because I was tired. 
ailusaret (noun F) a concussion. 
ailut ki-a (transitive verb) to overfill the mouth with food, adding more before swallowing the first; to gorge food. sirilusi acok ailut: do not gorge potatoes greedily. ailutulut: to eat greedily. 
ailutakin ki-a (transitive verb) to attack somebody in a crowd; to go to a place together with one aim. 
ailutar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to gorge; to eat too quickly, without masticating food. ailutar akituk: to close lips (in anger); to pout. 
ailutar2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to go away in a crowd for something. elutaros itunga toma akiring: the whole crowd have gone after meat. 
ailuterun ki-o (reflexive verb) to protrude; to bulge out. eluterunos akonyeke kanuka ajon: her/his eyes are bulging out on account of beer. cp. aneun akonye.
ailutun ki-a (prepositional verb) to come together for something. inyo bo ilutunotor yesi ne?: why have you gathered here? 
ailwaritoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to try and find some living, earn a living; to carry on work without strength; to be struggling on; to be destitute. elwaritoi eong aswam karaida emamei agogong: I must work, though I have no strength. cp. ailuaritoi.
ailwat ki-a (intransitive verb) to urinate; to piss; to pass out water. cp. ailuat
ailwatanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to urinate often (in bed or anywhere). 
ailwek ki-a (intransitive verb) to breed; to bring forth many children (said of father as well as mother); to have many children; to be the mother or father of many children. 
ailwer ki-a (transitive verb) to prune (a tree, etc); to clear by burning. 
ailwicar ki-o (reflexive verb) to disappear, get lost (in a cloud, in the cloud of dust, out of sight). cp. aolior. 
ailwom ki-a (transitive verb) to dip fingers or hand into thick liquids or soft unpleasant things. 
ailwomakin ki-a (transitive verb) to dip something somewhere unpleasant; to fall into sin. kilwomak igoen toma akipi: dip the clothes in the water. elwomakin eong toma akiro: I got into trouble. 
ailworakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fall upon somebody or something exhausted (reflexive verb) to fall, to drop dead tired. 
ailworar ki-a (transitive verb) to tire out. kelwora eong aswam na: this job has tired me out. 
ailworaun ki-o (reflexive verb) to become weak by sickness; to be dead tired; to be inert. cp. ailuorun
ailworun ki-o (reflexive verb) to become weak by sickness; to be dead tired; to become tired completely. 
ailya ko-a (intransitive verb) to climb; to creep (of plants); to crawl (of children or snake). cp. aliaar. 
ailyak ki-a (transitive verb) to nod (head). ailyak akor: to work with a hoe, with the head moving in rhythm up and down. 
ailyakakin akou (intransitive verb) to walk nodding; to shake up and down, nodding (like a cow wearing a bell round the neck); to start walking on again or working on. elyakakis akituk akwes: cows are just walking, and not grazing anymore. kelyakakis alosit: let us move on again (after resting). cp. aisodokin.
ailyok ko-o (intransitive verb) to set teeth on edge (after eating sour or bitter things). cp. ailiok
aima1 ki-a (transitive verb) to cook porridge; (of food or body or of anything) to dry or warm before the fire; to do a task slowly. cp. aipoore: to cook (in general); ailo: to dry in the sun. 
aima2 ko-a (transitive verb) to worship God; to praise or cheer a team vocally; to flatter by calling pet-names. aima ikiroria: to give names. koma imwatok ngul ikiroria: name those twins. cp. ailip, aitur.
aimac akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to dodge answering issues at hand by deliberately introducing new topics for discussion. 
aimad ki-a (transitive verb) to press or massage an aching part of the body. aimad ajimi: to apply poultice (i.e. bandage, heating pad, cold press, ice pack, or wrapping) on a wound; to dress a wound. 
aimadakin ki-a (transitive verb) to press or dab on (like mud, clay, paint, poultice). 
aimaderikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to hold fast onto; to hang on to, cling to; to stick on to (like plaster on wound, etc or like a dog to an animal in a fight or at football). emaderikin ekingok amor: the dog has clung onto the antelope. cp. aimakakin.
aimading ki-a (transitive verb) to kill; to harm; to hurt; to injure, be cruel to. sirikimading ikakoku: do not injure or hurt my child. aimadingikin: to deprive of; to do injury to; to hurt, do harm to. sirikimadingik ajakaanutuka: do not harm my chieftainship. kemadingikinos ikaboro lu: these things are lost to me. 
aimag ki-a (intransitive verb) to struggle; to fight (by boxing each other). akoto eong eimag ka nges: I want to fight with him. 
aimager ki-a (intransitive verb) to dawdle, be slow, walk lazily. 
aimages ki-a (transitive verb) to pretend, feign. aimagesikin: to feign to somebody. sirikimagesik adeka: do not pretend to be sick. cp. adeka eede, adeka isoswa.
aimagimag ki-a (transitive verb) to make crooked; to spoil (intransitive verb) to go unsteadily on the bicycle. imagimaga ijo kogaali: you ride precariously on the bicycle. aimagimag akiro: to speak awkwardly; to talk at random. aimagimagit: to make crooked habitually. cp. amunaun.
aimago ki-o (transitive verb) to work for beer or money; to do something for a long period of time. imagoete lolo kesi manaka: they are working in my garden for beer today. cp. aita 
aimagul ki-o (transitive verb) to bend (as of a bow); to warp (as of a piece of wood) (intransitive verb) to be bent, warped, or waved. ajai kolo etunganan Akajikaj loabakai Amaguli naarai emagulul: there was once a man called Amaguli in Akajikaj because he was knock-kneed.
aimagulikin ki-o (transitive verb) to bend, cause to be crooked, or to bend for. kimagulik akabwa: bend the bow. cp. alugurikin.
aimaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to warm a little near fire or in the sun; to warm up. aimaikin akima: to make porridge (for somebody). 
aimaima ki-a (transitive verb) to implore; to persuade, entice; to do slowly and carefully. cp. aingainga: to comfort; to be too lenient; to be too kind; to always look through fingers. aimaima aswam: to work slowly and carefully. aimaima akiro: to talk gently and carefully. 
aimajek ki-a (transitive verb) to give a stringent, bitter feeling. egeget emaidokoit, imajeki akituk: the cashew-nut fruit is astringent in the mouth. 
aimak ki-a (transitive verb) to stick things to (like stamp on envelope); to close; to press together. 
aimakakin1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to stand aghast; to be perplexed. emakakin nges akituk: she/he was tongue-tied. 
aimakakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to attack; to stick, fasten, paste on, adhere; to rest on, press against, or fix. kimakak asitaapu ngin abakaasa: stick this stamp on the envelope. 
aimakanakin (reflexive verb) to keep sticking to (as of food to teeth); to get blocked; to stay too long in one place; to be overdue. 
aimala1 ki-a (transitive verb) to covet (with the eyes); to long for. imalai ekingok akiring: the dog looks longingly at the meat. 
aimala2 ki-a (transitive verb) to greet, praise; to welcome, commend, or to thank. kimala lukore: greet your home people. cp. aima.
aimalalanut ki-a (transitive verb) to be cheeky or disrespectful. 
aimalaya ki-a (intransitive verb) to be a prostitute; to roam about like a harlot; to be a nomad or a nomadic. isirigin eraas imalayan: money circulates (literally, money goes round like prostitutes). 
aimalecikin ki-o (transitive verb) to dislocate; to overlap (as of teeth); to entwine. imalecikino ikelake: her/his teeth are overlapping. adum eong nges iboyei kimalecikite akejeke: I found her/him sitting with legs crossed. cp. ailokonyikin.
aiman1 ki-a (transitive verb) to be enemies, show hostilities; to threaten each other. imanas Ilok ka lteso: the Karimojong and the Iteso threaten each other, are enemies. 
aiman2 ki-a (transitive verb) to point at; to threaten by pointing at somebody; to warn by pointing with finger; to defy. 
aiman3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to roam about, wander about; to go round. (transitive verb) to go round something or somebody; to go round fighting. koman etogo: go round the house. 
aimanar kau ki-a (transitive verb) to put behind; to hide something behind one’s back. inyo bo ngin imanarit ijo kau?: what is it you are hiding behind your back? aimanar akanin kau: to hold hands behind the back. 
aimanasit (plural aimanasia) (noun F) a menace; a danger, threat. 
aimaneikin ki-o (transitive verb) to hang on; to clasp. (reflexive verb) to hold or clasp or hang oneself onto something, like a bat on a tree or a child on the mother’s back. cp. aimanerikin. 
aimanerikin ki-a (transitive verb) to put arms round the neck (as of a child with its mother). (reflexive verb) to hold arms round the neck. cp. aimaneikin, aineneikin. 
aimang ki-a (transitive verb) to blow over, knock down, knock over many; to kill many successively. kidau aimang itunga kitironikin konye araun amulookolet: after killing many people then you repent and get saved. (used with plural objects)
aimangakin ki-a (transitive verb) to knock one over; to kill by knocking somebody down. 
aimangingia (plural imangingias) (intransitive verb) to have a stiff neck; to walk or do as one with a stiff neck, act proud; to be proud; to be obstinate. 
aimangingiar ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk with a stiff neck; to have a stiff neck; to be proud. 
aimaniman ki-a (transitive verb) to inspect; to go round visiting. sirikimaniman akwap atitai: do not simply go round visiting. (intransitive verb) to meander; to go this way and that. 
aimanit ki-a (transitive verb) to threaten somebody; to bully; to persecute (continually). 
aimany ko-a (transitive verb) (of a man) to marry, pay dowry, or to become engaged; to espouse. ekoto ngesi aimany: he wants to get married. nuka emanyit: marital; matrimonial; conjugal. 
aimanyimany ki-a (transitive verb) to tease or rub a skin to make it supple; to tan. aimanyimany akapet: to tan leather.
aimar1 (singular noun F) arithmetics; mathematics. nuka aimar: mathematical. lumam imaras: lumam imarunos: a very big number, uncountable.
aimar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to count, or calculate; to reckon, compute. mam ijo ijeni aimar: you do not know how to count. aimar itunga: to take a census; to take a head count. aimar akeje: (of the police) to take measurements in a scene of a traffic accident to determine who is on the wrong.
aimarakin ki-a (transitive verb) to count, or calculate for somebody; to reckon, compute for. aimarakin isirigin: to compute costs for someone. aimarakin igaraaman: to detail or compute expenses for someone to pay.
aimaramar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep counting or reckoning. aimaramar apesenin: to list debts or liabilities one has. cp. aimaramaratoi
aimaramaratoi ki-a (transitive verb) to keep counting or reckoning. 
aimarananut (noun F) stubbornness; pig-headedness. cp. eja nges amaarana: she/he is intransigent (literally, she/he has ribs). 
aimarananut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be stubborn or pig-headed. 
aimaranar ki-a (transitive verb) to count up various things; to count up in little portions. 
aimaret (plural aimareta) (noun F) a thing to count with; a counter; a calculator. cp. aimaretait 
aimaretait (plural aimareta) (noun F) a thing to count with; a counter. cp. aimaret
aimarimar ki-a (transitive verb) to enumerate, itemise, detail, list, name, specify, or count one by one. 
aimarun ki-a (transitive verb) to count for oneself; to bring too few instead of sufficient; to single out. kanukinyo imaruna ijo acok adis?: why do you just bring a handful of potatoes? koyau ibukito iuni lumaruna: bring three single baskets. 
aimasakin ki-a (transitive verb) to throw at; to stone somebody. aimasakin engarot: to throw a stone at.
aimat ko-a (transitive verb) to drink; to aim; to absorb; to smoke (cigarettes). aimat etaba: to smoke tobacco. aimat amiidi: to smoke a pipe. aimat aokot: to suck blood; to drink blood. aimat akiro: to pay attention; to listen carefully in order to report; to bear trouble. 
aimatengaun ki-a (transitive verb) to slap on the temples (amatenget); to give a blow on the temple. 
aimatumatun ki-a (intransitive verb) to become stupid; to become deaf. cp. abangaanar. 
aimaumaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to placate, mollify, appease, calm, soothe, pacify, or conciliate and bring or get. 
aimaun1 ki-a (transitive verb) to warm up food; to warm anything for oneself. kimau akima kamatata: make a little porridge for ourselves to drink. (reflexive verb) to warm oneself; to be entirely worn out or dead tired. abongutu lukeswamak imauna: the workers returned dead tired. aimaun ideteta: to tune small drums by warming near fire or in the sun. aimaun akima: to prepare or make porridge. 
aimaun2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to become warm; to become very tired or weak, languid. emaun eong: I feel warm, very tired, or very weak. aitamanaun: aitamwanaun: to make warm. 
aime1 ko-a (transitive verb) to drive forward or away; to move (cattle, prisoners); to start from. amear akituk: to take cows to one’s father-in-law. 
aime2 ko-o (transitive verb) to lick with tongue. 
aimec ko-a (intransitive verb) to shelter; to take refuge. komecata edou: take shelter from the rain. alosi amecakin ngina: I am going to shelter over there. 
aimeda ki-a (intransitive verb) to give a little extra; to give baksheesh; to add. adumun ameda: to make a little profit. kimedakinai idikapun: give me a little money. 
aimedakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to give a little extra to; to give baksheesh to; to add to. elosio aimedakin itemwan ice obuku Usuk: they will add sub-counties to Usuk county.
aimedaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to get a little extra; to benefit from; to get a profit. imedaunenei ijo kaneejaas lukican: you profit from the poor. aimedaunit kaneejai: to benefit from; to be helped by something.
aimedel ki-o (transitive verb) to hold or show something tempting, but without giving it (like one showing a bone to a dog and not giving it); to tantalize; to give a present and take it back again soon after. inyo bo kimedelio ijo ekingok kakoit?: why do you tantalise the dog with a bone? 
aimeime ki-o (transitive verb) to plane wood; to make flat, smoothen (an object); to mould or polish earthenware. kimeime abao ngin: plane that board. imeimei ngesi amot: she/he is moulding the clay pot. 
aimeleked ki-o (intransitive verb) to toss food into the mouth. 
aimelekedoor ki-o (transitive verb) to finish off little food without waiting for others. 
aimen ko-a (transitive verb) to disobey, contravene; to despise; to rebel against, sniff at; to win (as in football); to consider (something given) too small or too little. aimen ekisil: to break the law. 
aimer1 ko-a (transitive verb) to fail to get; to escape one; to loose opportunity; to miss. kamerata eong ajon: (the beer missed me) I failed to get beer. kimer ijo ajakaanut: you just lost your chance to become a chief. (note here that, the object becomes subject). 
aimer2 ko-a (transitive verb) to stain; to blemish. sirikimer ekagoe k’ebwiino: do not stain my cloth with ink. 
aimi ko-o (intransitive verb) to be rich in, to abound in crops; to have plenty; to treasure. emiit ngesi akimai: she/he has plenty of millet. imii ijo akimai: you will have a good crop of millet. 
aimicakin ki-a (transitive verb) to put very close together. aimicakin akeje: to put feet closely together like a soldier standing to attention. cp. aidicidicakin.
aimid ko-a (transitive verb) to pull finger out of mouth with a click (whilst eating); to lick fingers; to prick with the pointed end of a spear. 
aimidic ki-a (transitive verb) to finish off many; to crush repeatedly between two hard things. aimidic apiyai: to misappropriate funds (perhaps corruptly). 
aimidiol ki-a (intransitive verb) (of eyes) to be runny or exuding; (of fruit) to discharge juice. imidiolitos akonye bala acok: the eyes are runny like sweet potatoes that have just been dug up. 
aimidiolikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (only of eyes) to be full with eye discharge. emidiolikis akonikonye: your eyes are full of discharge. 
aimidol ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a person’s body, clothes, etc) to become sticky, dirty, gluey (like glue, etc). cp. aimina, aimak.
aimidolit ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a person’s body, clothes, etc) to be sticky, dirty, gluey (like glue, etc). cp. aimina, aimak.
aimiimiit ki-a (transitive verb) to pamper (as of child); to use sparingly (of cloth, etc); to nibble, play with (food). imiimiit ijo ikoku ngin: you pamper (spare the rod on) that child. aimiimiit akiring: to nibble at meat. sirikimiimii ebela: do not spare the rod. 
aimik ki-a (transitive verb) to forbid to do; to refuse to give or to do; to hinder; to prevent from; to deny somebody something. ngai kimikit ijo abunere?: who prevented you from coming here? 
aimikar ki-a (transitive verb) to forbid someone; to refuse to do or to give; to hinder from doing; to prevent; to deny somebody something. aimikar Iteso apedor naka aimorikikin: to deny the Iteso the right to unite.
aimiketait (plural aimiketa) (noun F) hindrance; obstacle; encumbrance. 
aimil ki-a (intransitive verb) to shine; to flash. 
aimilia ki-a (intransitive verb) to flash, coruscate (as of lightning); to shine as of torch. imilia epaaba komanaka: the cotton is shining white in my garden. 
aimiliaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to spark; to flash (as fire from electric wire or lightning); to twinkle. 
aimima ki-a (transitive verb) to entice; to draw into a snare; to ensnare. imimai ijo ikasirigin: you are trying to get money out of me (under false pretence). imimai ajokit itunga aimima: the devil draws the people by deceit. aimimaar: to draw away deceitfully. cp. aingalaun.
aimimit (plural aimimin) (noun F) a small bee that picks wax from ears. 
aimin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to have illicit sexual intercourse. cp. aitep, aelo.
aimin2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to bear (underground fruit or tubers); (of termites) to swarm; (of animals or men) to escape; to do intentionally; to go and do. eminito lolo acok ekaru lo: the sweet potatoes have done very well this year. eminete acok kotoma olapio iuni: sweet potatoes bear within three months. 
aimina ki-a (intransitive verb) (of anything) to be sticky, gummy, viscous, gluey (like glue, etc). cp. aimidol.
aiminaikin1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to adhere to; to stick to; to cling to, be faithful to. 
aiminaikin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to stick to; to adhere or cleave to; to paste on, glue onto; to affix to, agglutinate. kiminaik asitaapu kuju abakaasa: put a stamp on the envelope. 
aiminganar ki-o (reflexive verb) to object to or refuse by shaking head or shoulders. cp. aitinitina, aijangijanga, aimingiminga. 
aimingiminga ki-a (intransitive verb) to object by shaking head or shoulders; to be peevish. imingiminga ijo bala ateran: you act peevish like a bride. 
aiminimin ki-a (transitive verb) to handle; to touch repeatedly; to fondle; to play with; to fiddle with things, rub oneself when cold; to finger. 
aiminiminit ki-o (transitive verb) to pamper, coddle, caress, etc.
aiminiminitoi ki-a (transitive verb) to go about feeling or touching everything; to fiddle with. siriminiminitoi: do not go about fiddling with things. 
aimo ko-a (transitive verb) to seek for; to search for; to go and look for; to probe. kimoete moi eong kopas: you will look for me tomorrow and get tired (not find me). amoot eong etogo loperot: I am looking for accommodation.
aimoc ko-a (intransitive verb) to converse; to talk; to joke; to have a pleasant chat; to have a sham fight. kimoca bian iso: we had a pleasant time yesterday. 
aimod1 ki-a (transitive verb) to stain; to sow in the wet season. cp. aimodimod. 
aimod2 ko-a (transitive verb) to cheat; to overcharge, or to deceive; to fool; to cozen. 
aimodimod ki-a (transitive verb) to sow in the wet season; to smear with dirt; to make dirty; to begrime. 
aimodol ki-a (transitive verb) to make thick (only of vegetables). imodolaete kesi edia: they thicken the vegetables. 
aimodolaun ki-a (transitive verb) to prepare nice thick vegetables; to dirty one’s body or clothes (said of thick substances dirtying or sticking to one’s clothes or body – not said of persons as subjects) (reflexive verb) to become thick or stained or dirty. 
aimodumodun ki-a (transitive verb) to make something thick (like porridge or vegetables). kimodumod ber edia: first make the vegetables thick and tasty. (reflexive verb) to become thick, stained or dirty. 
aimojimoj ki-a (transitive verb) to do badly, roughly; to botch. adukio naka isomeroi luimojumojuna: the building of substandard schools.
aimok ko-a (transitive verb) to turn inwards (cloth, etc). aimok akituk: to turn or press lips inwards. aimok adoobe: to put on adoobe, a tampon (passing it between legs and fastening it); to girdle. amokor ekori: to bend the tail inwards (between legs as of a subdued dog). 
aimokodanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fastidious, peevish, fractious, or testy. 
aimokorakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become a trickster, a cheat, con artist or a fraud. 
aimoligikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become or look like a beehive. 
aimom1 (adverb) at dead of night, i.e. the part of night when there is dead silence. 
aimom2 (plural noun F) short sleep; a nap; a siesta. aikamun aimom: to sleep soundly; to be fast asleep but for a short time; (noun) a nap. ajo nuka aimom: a short heavy sleep. 
aimomit (plural aimom) (noun F) a small insect found in old dry meat or fish; a small moth. 
aimomo ki-o (intransitive verb) to begin to ripen. emomooto imomwa: the sorghum has begun to ripen. 
aimomoet (singular noun F) (time of) ripening. apak nak’imomoet: the time of ripening. 
aimomot ki-o (intransitive verb) to be half ripe; to be yellowish. 
aimomoun (intransitive verb) to begin to ripen. 
aimon ki-o (intransitive verb) to be satiated; to be full of food; to have had enough; to be satisfied; to refrigerate; to cool. imokos idwe acok: the children have had enough sweet potatoes. emono eong (I am satisfied), imono ijo (you – singular – are sated), kimoko iso (we – exclusive – are satisfied). 
aimongimong ki-a (intransitive verb) to cake together; to catch; to congeal (of milk or blood); to go into seed as of millet, etc (when fingers or ears close in); to clot; (of hair) to be curly, fuzzy; to curdle; to coagulate. 
aimongong ki-o (intransitive verb) to sit down doing nothing. adum eong nges imongongoi kore bon: I found her/him sitting alone at home doing nothing. 
aimongoria ki-a (transitive verb) to have little swellings all over the body. imongoriat akakuwan: my body has swellings all over
aimongoriat1 (intransitive verb) (of the body) to have swellings or pimples. 
aimongoriat2 (plural aimongoria) (noun F) a pimple; a blackhead; acne; a swelling. 
aimonikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be satisfied; to have had (or eaten) enough; to be convinced; to be pregnant. emonikin emopiira: the football is inflated. aimonikin: to be drunk. imonikin ijo, kolot ore: you have had enough beer, go home. 
aimonis (plural aimonisyo) (noun F) a refrigerator; fridge. 
aimono ki-o (transitive verb) to store for the future. imonoete itunga akimai: people store millet for famine times. 
aimonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to make a food store; to store something for somebody. 
aimony1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to ooze out (as water or juice from potatoes or wounded tree or plant). emonyi acokit: the potato oozes sap. cp. icuwai, icwalat.
aimony2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to weep; to cry; to complain; to wail, to be ringing (of alarm clock); to weep or cry for. aimony akiyo: to shed tears. aimony naka etau: to crave or long for. emonyi eong etau alosit ore: I long to go home. mam ajeni nuemonyia ngesi: I don’t know why he/she weeps. mam ajeni nuemonyere: I don’t know why there is weeping. 
aimor1 ko-a (transitive verb) to partake of together; to do together; to share. aimor aswam: to work together. Aimor nakalaunan: (in the Protestant church) Holy Communion. komorata atap: share the bread (from millet). aimor angor: (of men) to share women; to have a free-for-all affair.
aimor2 ko-o (transitive verb) to offend; to abuse; to scold; to insult; to curse; to revile; to call names; to berate. cp. airat. 
aimori ki-a (transitive verb) to intermingle; to mix up; to take too many, join together; to add; to shuffle in; to blend. imoriei ijo agaria aimori: you take fish two by two instead of one by one. kimoriata asinge kalup: mix clay and sand. cp. ainyalinyal. 
aimorianakin ki-a (reflexive verb) (of married people) to make love often. 
aimorikikin1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to be mixed together; to be joined, or united; to fellowship or congregate; to have sexual intercourse in marriage. 
aimorikikin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to append; to mix together; to join together; to unite or to cooperate; to add (in arithmetic); to ally, compose, or connect. 
aimorikikinet (plural aimorikikineta) (noun F) sign of addition; plus sign; addition; connection; combination. 
aimorimor ki-a (transitive verb) to combine or to amalgamate. 
aimoriun1 ki-a (transitive verb) to uproot food crops; to bring along together. imoriu ijo eduan kede akimai da: you have pulled out the millet with the weeds. 
aimoriun2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to come together. emoriunos akimai kede eduan: the millet and weeds have been uprooted together. 
aimot ko-a (transitive verb) to drag, push further; to pour in with force. 
aimu1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to spit; to bring forth twins.
aimu2 ki-a (transitive verb) to long for; to hanker after; to crave for; to desire. imuit ngesi aanyun eong: she/he longs to see me. kemuit eong akiring: I crave for meat. aimue naka ere: homesickness. 
aimuanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to start raining; to drizzle; to spit often or repeatedly. sirikimuanar kokeresia: do not spit in the cathedral. emuanar akuj: it is drizzling. (transitive verb) to despise often; to scorn often. imuanari ijo akaswam duc: you always despise my work. 
aimuar ki-a (transitive verb) to spit at; to eject; to despise; to scorn; to defy; to disapprove. emua eong akoniswam: I have despised your work. 
aimuarit ki-o (transitive verb) to despise; to defy; to dare one laugh; to scorn; to disparage or disdain. kemuarit eong ijo mam ipedori aswam na: I defy you to do this work. 
aimuc ki-a (transitive verb) to cover completely (as of a hole or crack) (note: for other things, use airap) 
aimucakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fill up gaps; to plaster up cracks or holes in pot or wall, etc; to patch up. (reflexive verb) to close up, fill up by itself; to close; (of a wound) to heal up. emucakin akolong: the sun is overcast. 
aimucar ki-a (transitive verb) to close a hole; to fill up a hole or crack. (reflexive verb) to close up by itself, be filled up by itself; to heal up; to become covered, overcast (of sun). emucaros eong akonye: my eyes are closed up (by sickness). 
aimucumucakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to cover oneself in well; to wrap up. karai ideka eimidi, kimucumucakin: if you have a cold, cover yourself well. 
aimud ko-a (transitive verb) to gather into a store; to scoop up with hands (of solids only, like sand). aimud isirigin: to earn much money. 
aimudumudaar ki-a (transitive verb) to tuck in; to cover somebody or something completely, as of a mother covering her child against cold or to sleep. (reflexive verb) to cover oneself completely to sleep or on account of cold. 
aimudumudanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to smile without breaking into a laugh. 
aimudumudia ki-o (reflexive verb) to smile broadly without showing teeth. 
aimue (singular noun F) a longing, craving; ardent desire for something. aimue naka ere: nostalgia; homesickness; longing. 
aimugogol ki-a (transitive verb) (of road or soil or anything) to become uneven or rough. 
aimugogolit ki-o (intransitive verb) (of road or of hard soil) to be rough, uneven, pitted; (of a person) to be stupid. 
aimugole ki-o (intransitive verb) to be under training to become a nun; to undergo instruction as a bride or groom, etc. itunga luebeit aiwen epeta eloseneneete aimugole okanisa: couples who are about to wed go for instruction in church.
aimuikin ki-a (transitive verb) to spit at/on/in. 
aimuit ki-o (transitive verb) to excite one; to give longing for; to cause ardent desire or strong feeling. cp. aikwit: hanker after. kemuitos eong ajon: I long for beer. kemuit eong ikakoku: I long for my child. cp. aimu. 
aimuj ki-a (transitive verb) to eat; to relish; to eat vegetables; to eat (in general); to dine. alosi eong aimuj: I am going to take my food, to dine. aisumuj: to cause to eat; to feed. aimuj einer: to mumble (speak indistinctly like one without teeth). imuji ngesi Ateso inera: she/he speaks Ateso indistinctly. aimujio (passive infinitive of aimuj) to be eaten; edible. ibore yen mam imujio: a thing which is not edible.
aimujejel ki-a (intransitive verb) (of food served) to be insufficient, not to be enough; to be short of. 
aimujumuj ki-a (transitive verb) to rinse the mouth or clean the mouth after eating or after sleep in the morning; to lick round teeth with the tongue. aimujumujaar akituk: to rinse the mouth with water. kimujumujaa ber akituk kobu do ainyam: first rinse your mouth and then come to eat. imujumuji ngesi Amusugun inera: she/he mumbles English (speaks indistinctly). 
aimujuro1 (singular noun F) a frown; a scowl. 
aimujuro2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to frown; to look very cross; to scowl; to yawn after awaking; (of animals) to prepare to fight. cp. aijeruko. 
aimujuronut1 (singular noun F) frowning; glowering. cp. aijerukonut. 
aimujuronut2 ki-o (transitive verb) to frown, scowl often. 
aimuk1 ki-o (intransitive verb) (of the evening) to grow dark; (of vegetation) to overgrow. imuki akwap: it is getting dark. emuk akwap: it has grown dark; it is dark. 
aimuk2 ki-o (transitive verb) to cover with something. aimuk akonye: to cover face. kimuk edula naarai abu edou: cover up the granary because it is going to rain. 
aimuk3 ko-a (transitive verb) to take many at a time, as of a lorry or train; to scoop with hand or basin or anything; to gather a rubbish heap or other loose objects onto or into a container. komuk akimai k’odula: scoop the millet from the granary. cp. aimud. 
aimuke1 ki-a (transitive verb) to nurse; to treat medically; to take away a spell of witchcraft; to medicate. emukei eong, imukeete kesi: I/they treat. amukean: amukyan: therapy; treatment; medication. cp. aipolia.
aimuke2 ki-a (transitive verb) to try; to attempt; to face difficulties; to do with difficulty. kimukeata aisisia Amusugun: try to learn English. aimuke einer: to stammer, stutter. cp. aingejingej einer. 
aimukear ki-a (transitive verb) to finish with difficulty; to force away, send away by force. emukea eong nges togo: I have forced her/him to go in the house. (reflexive verb) to force oneself away; to drag oneself away. abu eong kemukear kore: I dragged myself from home. 
aimukeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to try for someone or somewhere; to nurse for; to cure. aimukeikin ekia: to force somebody (animal or child) to swallow medicine. kimukeikinai ikokuka: try to cure my child for me. 
aimukemuket ki-o (transitive verb) to try or attempt repeatedly. 
aimukeo (singular noun F) therapy; treatment; medication. 
aimukerikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to behave like a baby; to act like a baby. 
aimukes (plural aimukesia) (noun F) a treatment centre; clinic; sickbay; dispensary; health centre; hospital. cp. adekis. 
aimuket (singular noun F) an effort; evening, nightfall, sunset. aimuket naka akwap: twilight; dusk.
aimuket ki-a (transitive verb) to try; to make an effort; to do with difficulty; to attempt; to endeavour. imuketos kesi aisisia Amusugun: they are trying to learn English.
aimukeun ki-a (transitive verb) to get with difficulty; to cure. emukeuni eong Amusugun aimukeun: I learnt English with difficulty. (reflexive verb) to be cured; to come with difficulty. 
aimukokin1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to become dark; to become evening. emukoki akwap: it has become dark; it is evening. kobu imukokit akwap: come in the evening. 
aimukokin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to tuck in; to cover up (with something). aimukokin akonye: to cover the face; to blindfold. (reflexive verb) to cover oneself; to tuck oneself in; to bow (the head) in reverence; to bow head in order to evade a blow. 
aimukor ki-o (transitive verb) to cover up somebody or something; to play one a trick. kimuko nges kebilaangit: cover her/him with a blanket. (reflexive verb) to be covered; to be asleep or to go to sleep; to delay; to become uncivilised. alosi eong aimukor: I am going to sleep or to bed. emukoros itunga lu: these people have become uncivilised. 
aimukos (plural aimukosia) (noun F) a cover (sheet, shawl, etc). 
aimukun ki-o (transitive verb) to bring something covered (like food brought from afar) (reflexive verb) to cover oneself coming this way; to take shelter. kimukun lailo: take shelter here. 
aimula (plural noun F) saliva; spittle; dribble; sputum. 
aimulat (singular noun F) phlegm; excess or unhealthy saliva. 
aimuleny ki-a (transitive verb) to curtail, limit, restrain, hold back, cut back; to curb, rein in, shorten. 
aimuliamuliatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to grope in the dark; to wriggle like a snake; to play like a small child or like a leper trying to hold things without fingers. 
aimulukujaar ki-a (transitive verb) to swallow quickly, with noise in the throat. komulukujaa ekia ngol: swallow that medicine quickly. (reflexive verb) to be swallowed. 
aimululuar ko-a (transitive verb) to shave closely or bare; to pick off or bite off completely. 
aimulumul ki-a (transitive verb) to suck a sweet (like grown ups) or finger (like children); to make wet by keeping in the mouth; to smother with saliva, like a python does its prey before swallowing whole; to bite or nibble at (as one without teeth). 
aimumuor1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to do the old-time dance; to sacrifice for rain (cooking special food); to grow into seed; to begin to ripen. imumuorete itunga edou: people sacrifice for rain. cp. ailelekej.
aimumuor2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to disagree (by turning head away); to despise. emumoros kwi kiirasi nuka aswam: they shook their heads when told to work (despising the work as too difficult or too easy). 
aimumutaun ki-a (transitive verb) (of babies only) to pass bad air. cp. aiwu: (of big people or animals) to pass bad wind. 
aimung ki-a (transitive verb) to salute; to bow head; to shake the head; to nod. aimung akou: to shake the head (in agreement or when walking). aimungakin akou: to bow to; to agree; to salute (lifting hand and bowing head).
aimunganar ko-a (transitive verb) to shake head repeatedly (reflexive verb) to move or shake the head (as of one falling asleep); to doze off to sleep. imunganar ikoku: the child is dozing off to sleep. 
aimungar ki-a (transitive verb) to give a slight push on the head (as a warning or out of anger). 
aimungumung akou ki-a (transitive verb) to shake the head repeatedly (a sign of refusal or disagreement or displeasure).
aimunon ki-a (transitive verb) to conceal; to hide; to keep secret; to hush up. imunonit ijo ajon kotogokon: you are hiding beer in your house. imunonit ijo akiro nuka abeit: you are hiding the truth. 
aimunonikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hide something for somebody. kimunonikit ijo eong nuka abeit: you have hidden the truth for me. 
aimunonit ki-o (transitive verb) to be hiding; to be concealing something. 
aimunumuno ki-a (intransitive verb) to smile. 
aimununikin ki-a (transitive verb) to commit onanism (sexual intercourse where the penis is withdrawn from the vagina before ejaculation); to masturbate. 
aimuny ko-a (transitive verb) to break (of law, leg or arm, club, stick). cp. aibil (of stick, the law); aibwang (of pots); ainged (of rope). 
aimur ko-a (transitive verb) to cover; to seal; to bury; to bind (as of food). aimur akiria: to bury beer-dough (in preparing beer). aimur kede alup: to cover with soil (to ferment). aimur akituk (euphemism) to be dead and buried. abu eong kadum nges kemur akituk: I found her/him dead and buried. abu kadum kes kemurata akitukes: I found them dead and buried. cp. airap, aida, aipuc, ainuk.
aimurie akwena ki-a (intransitive verb) to smile without showing one’s teeth; to beam. 
aimuruj ki-a (transitive verb) to disturb sediment (in water, tea, coffee, beer, etc); to contaminate (of liquids, not of cloth). aimuruj akiro: to poison the words; to explain wrongly. cp. aipuruj
aimurujaun ki-a (transitive verb) to disturb sediments of coffee, tea, water, beer, etc. sirikimurujau ajon: do not disturb the beer. emurujaunos aomisioka: I am at a loss of what to say; I am nonplussed. emurujaunos ajon: the beer has been stirred. 
aimurumur ko-a (transitive verb) to cover completely. cp. airap. 
aimurumura akwena ki-a (intransitive verb) to smile slightly. 
aimurumuraar ko-a (transitive verb) to cover up completely (like a trap). cp. airapirapaar. 
aimurumuranar ki-o (reflexive verb) to smile continually; to have a quiet laugh. kimurumuranar: keep on smiling. 
aimurumuria ki-a (intransitive verb) to be smiling. imurumuria ngesi: imurumuriasi kesi: she/he is (they are) smiling. 
aimurwokin ki-a (transitive verb) to forget; to neglect. kimurwok ijo aswamukon: you have neglected your work. 
aimurwonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to become forgetful. 
aimurwonut1 (noun F) forgetfulness; oblivion; neglect; negligence; inattention; amnesia. 
aimurwonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be forgetful; to be inclined to forget; to neglect; to be inattentive. 
aimusik ki-a (transitive verb) to inherit; to succeed to a chieftainship or property. 
aimusoor ki-o (intransitive verb) to sit down brooding in silence; to muse. emusoosi kesi: they sit down musing, i.e. silently or quietly. cp. aumen
aimusumusoonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to turn away one’s face on account of smoke or laughing or bad smell, etc; to pull faces; to become angry. 
aimusung ki-a (transitive verb) to injure or to disable; to harm (of anything); to damage. imusung ijo ekagaali: you have damaged my bicycle. apotu kesi kimusungata akakeju: they injured my leg. 
aimusunganakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hurt, harm, damage repeatedly for (reflexive verb) to hurt one another; to damage one another. 
aimusungikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do harm to or somewhere or for somebody. (reflexive verb) to injure one another or oneself. emusungikinos idwe: the children have hurt one another. 
aimut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be or become dark, dim; to be overgrown. emusi akwap: it is dark. emusi etogo: it is dark in the house. 
aimutumuta ki-a (intransitive verb) to disagree by shaking the head or shrugging shoulders, with the mouth pouted. 
aimutunoor ki-o (transitive verb) to bargain; to sell. emutunoo ngesi egaalike: she/he has sold her/his bicycle. emutono akonilaro: your compound is overgrown.
aimutunun ki-o (transitive verb) to buy or bargain for oneself. 
aimutur ki-o (intransitive verb) to be nearly ripe; to be fat (as of head, cheek). 
aimutut ki-o (intransitive verb) to it down brooding in silence; to be alone; to sit idle. abu eong kadum nges imututei bon kore: I found her/him alone sitting silently at home. 
aimuun ki-a (intransitive verb) to bear twins; to spit out. imuunit akaberu: my wife has brought forth twins. 
aimwad akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to wink or blink with the eyes (as of half blind man). 
aimwadimwadun ki-a (intransitive verb) to come with blinking eyes. 
aimwaneikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to become greedy, etc for. 
aimwaneit ki-o (intransitive verb) to have the habit of greediness, gluttony, etc 
aimwaneonut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to being greedy. 
aimwang ko-a (transitive verb) to despise; to contemn, affront, override, or defy. amwangit Katoda: to disrespect God; impiety, wickedness, or transgression.
aimwangar ki-a (transitive verb) to deflect, turn aside, ward off; to repel, redirect, sidetrack, avert; to prevent, draw away. 
aimwar akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to blink eyes; to look fierce, look daggers. inyo bo imwaria ijo akonye?: why do you look so fierce? 
aimwat1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to degenerate (of crops); (of crops) to be a failure; to fail to get seeds. amwatata imumwa: the sorghum crop has failed. amwat epaaba lo: this cotton crop is a failure. 
aimwat2 ko-a (transitive verb) to brush; to rub off; to wipe off. amwasi eong akaninika: I am wiping my hands. emwasi ngesi akonyeke: she/he is wiping her/his eyes.
aimwaus ki-a (intransitive verb) to amount to; to be so many; to number. ijeni ijo aimwausukec?: do you know their number? imwaas kesi ikany: they are five. imwa ai?: imwaas ai?: how many? cp. etiai, atiaus.
aimwolimwol ki-o (transitive verb) to eat without teeth; to wash silks. 
aimyed ko-a (intransitive verb) to strangle; to throttle; to choke. kamyed eong akiring: the meat has choked me. abu auno komyed nges: the rope strangled her/him. 
aimyel1 ki-a (transitive verb) to lick, put out tongue. imyeli ekingok asaanit: the dog is licking the plate. abu akim kimyela etogo: the fire licked the house. cp. aidyel, aime.
aimyel2 ki-a (transitive verb) to long for; to hanker after; to desire ardently; to have proclivity. emyela eong alosit ore: I long to go home. imyela etauka: I desire, long for. imyela ijo ekagaali, mam idumuni be: you would like to get my bicycle, but you will not get it.
aimyelakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to desire; to wish for, get a craving for. emyelakin eong ajon: I got a craving for beer. 
aimyelar angajep ki-a (transitive verb) to pull out the tongue (to lick the lips or to ridicule someone). 
aimyelimyel ki-a (transitive verb) to eat a little. (intransitive verb) to be insufficient for. emyelimyeli eong ikatap kane: I am eating my little food here. kemyelimyelata eong inyamat lu: this food is not sufficient for me. kopotu kemyelimyelata idia yen: come and let us share this little food. 
aimyelun angajep ki-a (transitive verb) to pull out the tongue (to lick the lips or to ridicule someone). 
aina ko-a (transitive verb) to be used to; to frequent; to be accustomed to. ana ngesi ne: she/he frequents this place. inai rwaru ijo ne: you will get used to this place in future. 
ainac ki-a (transitive verb) to avoid; to make a detour; to dodge; to evade. kinac emun: avoid the snake. enac edou ne: the rain has gone past here. ainac aitac esolo: tax evasion (literally, to avoid or evade paying tax). (intransitive verb) to pass each other; to avoid each other. enacakinos amotokan: the cars have passed each other. 
ainace (singular noun F) moisture; moistness; humidity. 
ainak ko-a (transitive verb) to suck (breast or anything). ainak akwena: to laugh heartily. ainak ajo: to sleep soundly, deeply. ainak epii: to suck a beer tube (to drink beer). ainak ekisin: to suckle the breast.
ainakin ko-a (transitive verb) to give to or for; to cause to present; to offer; to cause (with infinitive); to actuate, induce; to reward. ikoto ijo ainakin eong adeka: you want me to catch your disease (or you want to infect me with your disease). 
ainakinet (plural ainakineta) (noun F) a gift; a present; a prize;a contribution. cp. einakina
ainam1 akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to crack jokes; to tell jokes. inami ijo akiro: you are a good joker. 
ainam2 ki-a (transitive verb) to cover; to patch (as of wound, tyre, tube, etc); to mend (a puncture). akoto ijo ainam akamopiira: I want you to mend my tyre. 
ainamakin ki-a (transitive verb) to mend; to affix; to patch, put on, stick things together. ainamakin akiro: to tickle one’s fancy; to crack a joke for. kinamak ijo eong akiro: you have told me a joke. 
ainamanut1 (intransitive verb) to have the habit of cracking jokes; to be good or clever at cracking jokes. 
ainamanut2 (singular noun F) cleverness at joking. 
ainaminam1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to chat; to talk. abuni eong kenaminamata korekon: I am coming to have a chat with you at your home. 
ainaminam2 ki-a (transitive verb) to press (as plaster on the wound); to press into position. 
ainaminamakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to come in crowds; to come quickly. enaminamakin emaase mana: the locusts has come down on the field in swarms. 
ainaminamun ki-o (reflexive verb) to come in great numbers or swarms. enaminamun emaase: the locusts have come in swarms. 
ainanakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to give continually, keep on giving. 
ainanakin2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to do in turns; to do in shifts. koinanakinos idarete: watch in turns. cp. ameanakin, abeanakin.
ainang1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to cease; to culminate; to stop; to end; to fade away. aijar namam enangi: eternal life. aitodol ainang nepe ekot: until it meets its wishes. cp. aisang.
ainang2 ko-a (transitive verb) to punch; to give a blow with a fist; to box. kanang ngesi eong: she/he gave me a blow with her/his fist. 
ainap1 ki-a (transitive verb) to put in order, one on top of the other; to pile up; to fold. ainap ainyam: to partake of every dish; to eat on steadily. 
ainap2 ki-a (transitive verb) to strike or to give a heavy blow with the hand or stick. abu ngesi kenap eong k’ebela: she/he beat me with a stick. 
ainap3 ko-a (transitive verb) to put on clothes; to wear clothes, shoes, ring, etc; to don (clothes), array. 
ainapaar ki-o (reflexive verb) to become polite; to be humble; to be gentle, well mannered. enapaaros Iteso: the Iteso have become polite. 
ainapaara ki-a (intransitive verb) to be polite, humble, gentle, or calm. inapaara ikonidwe: your children are polite, well mannered. 
ainapakin1 (singular noun F) a calm; quietness; peace. epol ainapakin kane: there is a lot of peace here.
ainapakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to knock (somebody) down with a thud; to smack one down. enapaki ngesi oupake kwap: she/he threw her/his friend down. (reflexive verb) to fall down heavily. 
ainapakin3 ki-o (transitive verb) to put in order; to calm down; to reconcile. (reflexive verb) to be at peace; to be quiet; to be peaceful; to be quiet (of wind or storm or sea). enapakinos itunga kere: everybody is quiet. 
ainapanap ki-a (transitive verb) to beat repeatedly. 
ainapap ki-a (intransitive verb) to be well folded; to be orderly, i.e. order. 
ainapasit (plural ainapata) (noun F) a layer; stratum, section, level. 
ainar ko-a (transitive verb) to take to; to bring to, take away; to give to someone absent. 
ainarinar ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to shake; to cause to tremble; to cause to vibrate. 
ainarur ki-o (intransitive verb) to swell (as a result of a beating or a bite). ainarurut: to be swollen.
ainat ko-a (intransitive verb) to sit motionless (as a cat watching a mouse); to take one by one. enasi ekapa keanyu emir: the cat sits motionless when it sees a rat. 
ainatakin ki-o (reflexive verb) (outside Usuk) to feign or pretend death; to sit without moving; to lie down motionless like a cat or snake ambushing its prey. cp. ainatokin
ainatokin ki-o (reflexive verb) (Usuk) to feign or pretend death; to sit without moving; to lie down motionless like a cat or snake ambushing its prey. cp. ainatakin
aine ko-a (transitive verb) to push, to press into; to cram, to force into; to hem in; to jam in. kinyek aine iboro ngul kere toma asaduku na nacici: do not cram all those things into this small box. eneete idwe akiro keyapuu aingito: children cram when examinations are near. 
ainebineb ki-a (transitive verb) to saturate, drench, inundate, soak, flood. 
aineine ki-a (transitive verb) to tire out sitting on, leaning on or hanging onto a person or animal. kineinei ijo eong kapasit: you lean on me when I am already tired. ineineete idwe itak: the children tire out the calves (by riding on them). cp. aicikicik. 
aineke ki-o (transitive verb) to desire; to wish for, long for, crave for; to need (of good or bad things). enekei eong aimat ajon: I have a strong craving for beer. cp. aineket
aineket ki-o (transitive verb) to desire; to wish for, long for, crave for; to look forward to; to think with pleasure about something that will happen. eneket eong aibunga ijo: I long to beat you. 
ainekokin etau ki-o (transitive verb) to set or put one’s mind or heart on (getting) something. enekokit eong ekatau agwel amotoka: I have set my mind on buying a motorcar. 
ainem adokar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go quickly up; to climb (a tree by stepping). 
aineminem ki-a (intransitive verb) to hasten off. kineminemata alosit oiduka: hasten to the shops. aineminem akwap: to run very fast; to walk quickly. 
ainene ki-o (transitive verb) to hang up (things) cp. aikaj. 
aineneikin1 ki-o (reflexive verb) to cling onto; to hang oneself, i.e. to commit suicide by hanging; to adhere. eneneikin ikoku omorosing loka totoke: the child is clinging to its mother’s neck. 
aineneikin2 kwap (reflexive verb) to hang down. 
aineniat ki-a (transitive verb) to hang and rest on mother’s back. ineniat ikoku totoke: the child hangs and rests on its mother’s back. 
aineno ki-o (intransitive verb) to be hanging; to depend. inyo ineno kanen?: what is hanging there? 
ainenokin ki-o (transitive verb) to hang something on something else. kinenok egoe lo kuju auno: hang this cloth on the rope. 
ainep ki-a (intransitive verb) to be alight; to be on fire. enepu akim: the fire is alight, burning. 
ainepun ki-a (intransitive verb) to be alight; to be glowing; to catch fire; to be on fire; to be clever; to be hot, have fever. enepu etogo: the house is on fire. inepunit ikoku ngin kotoma atukot: that child is proving hot (clever) in class. 
ainer1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to speak; to talk; to converse; to utter. enera eong: I am speaking. enerata kesi: they have spoken. enera ngesi: she/he spoke. inerit ngesi: she/he has spoken; she/he has said. einer atitai: to talk at random, talk nonsense; to rave. 
ainer2 ki-a (transitive verb) to spite; to backbite; to talk behind one’s back. kenera ngesi eong: she/he is backbiting me. mam alosi einer ijo: I won’t talk about you. 
ainer3 ko-o (transitive verb) to claim; to choose beforehand; to select, or engage. anerit eong emong ngol: I have chosen that bull over there before hand. 
aineraar ki-a (intransitive verb) to talk in the way of; to speak like. ineraarit ngesi Serere: she/he talks like they talk in Serere: she/he speaks the dialect of Serere. 
ainerakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to talk to; to discuss; to reason together, accost. kenerakinos ber nuka akirot kangin: let us first discuss that issue. 
aineranakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to talk to oneself or to one another; to talk to each other. 
aineranut1 (singular noun F) loquacity; garrulousness; talkativeness. 
aineranut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be eloquent; to be talkative, loquacious, communicative. 
ainerun1 (noun F) peace talks; dialogue; negotiations; parley; consultations; conspiracy. 
ainerun2 ki-a (transitive verb) to come to an agreement; to discuss; to consider; to conspire; to plan. kenerutu ber: let us first come to an agreement. (reflexive verb) to be settled. enerunos akiro ngun: that question is settled or has been discussed. 
aines (singular noun F) thinness of body; emaciation; skinniness; slenderness; slimness. 
ainesu1 (plural aine) (noun F) boorishness; rudeness; crudeness; vulgarity; stinginess; bad manners; gluttony; gourmand; greed or selfishness. ejai nges ainesu: she/he is uncouth. 
ainesu2 (singular noun F) half-cooked food; underdone food; unripe fruit. 
ainet ko-o (transitive verb) to put too much into (not of liquids); to bring in great quantities; to give a heavy blow with a club or fist on the body (but not on the face). cp. aibap: to give a blow with an open palm; to strike at an angle. ainet atap: to serve a big heap of atap. konetu alupot: make a big heap of mud or mortar. angesi nat eong ijo: I may clobber you later (plural enesete nat kwi yes kabotei: those guys might clobber you with clubs).
ainga ko-a (transitive verb) to open (as of door or mouth). kongaa ekek: open the door. kongaa akituk: open the mouth. 
aingac ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk with a straddling gait (as of a person with genital ulcer); to walk proudly; to strut (like a baboon); to walk with difficulty, with legs astride (on account of abscess, syphilis, etc). 
aingacac ki-a (intransitive verb) to stand astride; to bestride. aingacac ecelet: to quarrel for a long time. ingacacaete ikiliok ejiosi: the men stand astride when fighting. 
aingada ki-a (transitive verb) to keep in custody; to store away; to preserve or to put away; to conserve. ingadai ngesi anyunyura kitoni ainyangar: she/he keeps anger until revenge is done.
aingadaar ki-o (reflexive verb) to budge or to move away; to stow away; to cache. 
aingadakin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep for somebody; to store up for somebody; to put away for somebody; to reserve. aingadakin ates: to bury the dead; to inter (literally, to put the corpse out of reach). (reflexive verb) to hide oneself; to abscond. kolot kingadakin, abu amuran: go and hide yourself, your mother-in-law is coming. cp. aida, ainuk.
aingadakinet (plural aingadakineta) (noun F) a place to store or keep things safely; a bank; a cache; the keeping of things. 
aingadas (plural aingadasia) (noun F) a corruption of aingadis: a storehouse; a bank. 
aingadis (plural aingadisia) (noun F) a storehouse; a bank. 
aingainga ki-a (transitive verb) to entreat; to beseech; to pray; to soothe; to pacify; to quieten (as of a crying child); to implore; to disarm. kingainga ikoku: pacify the child; quieten the child. 
aingaingait ki-a (transitive verb) to keep entreating; to beseech; to petition; to implore, or adjure. kengaingait eong ijo: I beseech you. 
aingaingaitoi ki-a (transitive verb) to keep on beseeching, imploring or pleading. 
aingaingaun ki-a (transitive verb) to persuade (to come); to entice; to entreat; to get by imploring. 
aingakakin ki-a (transitive verb) to light upon, come upon unexpectedly. 
aingala ki-a (transitive verb) to deceive or to beguile; to lead astray; to lie to; to bamboozle. cp. aisab. ingalae: you lie. ingalaete ijo: they deceive you. siringalai: do not deceive. 
aingalaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take one away by deceit; to entice away. (reflexive verb) to be deceived; to be taken in. 
aingalakin ki-a (transitive verb) to tell or teach the wrong thing; to deceive; to take somebody in. aingalakin ekia: to poison. aingalakin eidada: aingalakin ecudet: to poison. aingalakin elweera: to give somebody consumption phthisis (tuberculosis). 
aingalangal ki-a (transitive verb) to cheat, mislead, or tell lies to repeatedly; to elude often. 
aingalangalakin ki-a (transitive verb) to take away by deceit; to take somebody’s food (or anything) by false pretence. 
aingalanut1 (singular noun F) deceit; deceitfulness; hypocrisy. 
aingalanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of lying, deceiving. ingalana ngesi: she/he is fond of deceiving. 
aingalaun ki-a (transitive verb) to allure; to get a thing by deceit. aingalaun ajo: to coax sleep (by sleeping-draught or singing a lullaby). 
aingamingam ki-a (transitive verb) to do quickly; to run or walk fast. aingamingam akeje: to run quickly. 
aingamingamakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to run quickly after; to rush at (used for many running together). engamingamakinos itunga omaido: people are rushing for groundnuts. 
aingany ko-a (intransitive verb) to probe; to examine carefully, look for carefully; to turn things over, looking for something. anganyakin akonye: to stare at. abu ngesi kanganyak eong akonye: she/he stared at me. 
ainganyosoor ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall down and reveal the behinds; (of a destitute) to die shamefully or miserably. eyapie ngesi ainganyosoor: she/he is nearly dying a miserable death. 
aingar ki-a (transitive verb) to give assistance to many; to help many. 
aingarakin ko-a (transitive verb) to help, abet, assist, aid, support, benefit, or be advantageous. kingarakinai: help us (me). aingarakinia: to be used for someone or something. aingarakin itunganan: to help someone; to come to someone's aid. (reflexive verb) to help one another; to be helped. kingaranakinos: help one another; support each other. 
aingarakinet (plural aingarakineta) (noun F) help, assistance; auxiliary; asset; backing up. ipupuuto aigarakineta: there are several advantages.
aingarar ki-a (intransitive verb) to stand out, be visible (as of pimples on the body or people far off, etc); to be on the alert (of many); to be ready to do together. aingarar: watching for something to happen; to be on alert. aigarar aiboi: (of a woman) to sit with legs apart, sit indecently. itunga kwi ingararaete kangina, lukai?: where are those people over there from? ingararaete ikok ekotos ejie: the ants (the soldiers of the anthill) are on the alert (ready to fight). 
aingaren ki-o (intransitive verb) to be or go in front, lead the way, precede. aingarenikit: to be in front of; to be better than another in work, etc.
aingarenikin ki-o (transitive verb) to guide; to lead; to precede. 
aingarenikinet (plural aingarenikineta) (noun F) leadership; management; headship. 
aingaringar ki-a (transitive verb) to gang up for; to do in turns. kengaringarata acok: let us herd in turns. 
aingaringarun ki-a (transitive verb) to have in common, have shares in, do in common. kengarungarutu etogo lo: let us share in building this house. 
aingat ko-a (transitive verb) to plunder; to rob; to raid; to rustle; to pillage, or loot. apotu Ilok kongatata akituk nuka Iteso: the Karimojong raided the cows of the Iteso. cp. airurwo, aijore. 
aingeb ki-a (transitive verb) to nibble. 
aingebingeb ki-a (transitive verb) to be nibbling. ingebingebi akine ekapaaba: the goat is nibbling at my cotton. ingebingebi ikoku akiring: the child nibbles at the meat. cp. aireb. 
aingecel ki-o (transitive verb) to overlap (used with plural object). ingeceli ijo abaoi: you are overlapping the boards. 
aingecelikin ki-o (transitive verb) to place in an overlapping position. (reflexive verb) to be overlapping each other. ingecelikino ikonikel: your teeth are overlapping. 
ainged ko-a (transitive verb) (of rope or thread) to break; to snap. ainged epaperone: to break off friendship. cp. aicil (of cloth); aibil (of wood); aibwang (of crockery). 
aingedinged ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk as one who has pain in the lower back or waist or loin. 
aingejingeja ki-a (intransitive verb) to jabber; to stammer; to stutter. cp. angajepanut. 
aingek ki-a (intransitive verb) to waddle (like a fat duck); (of cow or other animal) to have a big udder; to walk with legs far apart; to come quickly across anything looked for. ingeki ngesi alosit: she/he waddles. ingekit akiteng: the cow has a very big udder. 
aingekingek ki-a (intransitive verb) to find many together. aingekingek acok: to find many potatoes in one heap. 
aingekun ki-a (transitive verb) to find quickly and bring a thing looked for. engeku eong ikasirigin luaolioritos: I soon found my lost money. 
aingel ko-a (transitive verb) to break (as piece of pot or crockery). ingel ijo akasaanit: you broke off a piece of my plate. engeli ngesi atap enyami: she/he takes food in big lumps: she/he is a glutton. cp. aiwak, aiwal. 
aingem ki-a (transitive verb) to touch with the tongue; to taste; to take a little with the tongue (used for solid things like simsim, salt, sugar). cp. aiir, acibun (of liquids) 
aingemingem ki-a (transitive verb) to keep on biting (as of bugs or ants); to keep on paining or stinging; to have pains; to tingle. kengemingemi eong akoik: I have pains in my stomach. aingemingem akwap: to run. aingemingem etau: to hurt one’s heart. kengemingemete eong akiro ngun etau: those words pain me, hurt me, are biting my heart. 
aingeny ki-a (transitive verb) to be busy with; to be occupied with; to work hard; to be busy at. eingeny amat: to drink very much. ingenyas kesi ejie: they are busy fighting. aingenyakin amat (reflexive verb) to be having a big beer party. eingeny ejie: to be in a hot fight, fighting furiously. cp. ailedokin.
aingenyar ki-a (transitive verb) to fight for, about, with or somewhere. ikaboro ingenyatar yesi: you are fighting for my property. 
aingenyun ko-a (transitive verb) to take a little (of anything). 
aingepes ki-a (transitive verb) (of door) to put ajar; to put in an overlapping position (so that it may fall). aingepes akiro: to hide the exact truth. 
aingepesikin ki-a (transitive verb) to put in an overlapping position; to beat slightly; to overlap a little. 
ainger1 ko-a (transitive verb) to cut the top of plants above the roots; to mow; to shave hair. ainger itim (akou): to cut hair. ainger anya: to cut grass for thatching. ainger akiro: to tell only part of the truth. 
ainger2 ko-o (transitive verb) to refuse or to renounce; to deny or to decline; to withhold; to object; to disagree. anger ngesi: she/he refused. engerit ngesi: she/he is refusing or she/he refuses. angeroto kesi: they have refused. engerit ngesi: she/he is obstinate. 
aingereteny ki-a (intransitive verb) to be thin so that lower ribs stand out. 
ainges ko-a (transitive verb) to do suddenly; to do all of a sudden; to attack by surprise. sirikinges alosit: do not go all of a sudden. 
ainget ko-a (transitive verb) to finish (of work or holiday); to end. anget eong akaswam: I have finished my task (work). 
aingi ko-a (intransitive verb) to show teeth; to bare teeth; to grin; (of cotton) to show white, to blossom; (of growing tooth) to appear; to pull a sneering face. engii epaaba komisiri: the cotton is blossoming white in the garden. 
aingic ko-a (transitive verb) to examine closely; to spy on; to look at carefully; to diagnose; to scrutinize; to search, inquire about matters; to examine (a case); to explore; to cross-examine; to canvas. 
aingil ki-a (intransitive verb) to pain; to give a biting, sharp pain. 
aingilakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to feel sudden sharp pain (usually in the knee or joint). 
aingilar (transitive verb) to cause sharp pain. kengila eong ibore kosyep: something is pricking my side.(reflexive verb) to feel pricking pain in the side. 
aingim ko-a (transitive verb) to pare; to cut into small pieces (of anything). kongim apapulai ngun: shred those papers; cut those papers into small pieces. aingim akiring: to cut meat into small pieces. aingim akonye: to slit the eyes; to blink; to twinkle. cp. aiyed akonye, aier akonye. 
ainginimikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hold insufficiently, lightly; to place something so that it can easily fall or break. inginimikinit ijo ikakoku, elosi aibiror: you hold my child very precariously, it will fall. cp. aingepesikin. 
ainginy ki-a (transitive verb) (of beans, vegetables or potatoes) to mash; to crush; (of eyes) to rub; to eat a lot (of anything); to be gluttonous. ainginy einer: to talk behind one’s back; to slander; to spoil somebody’s name. ainginy acok: to eat potatoes by oneself or alone. 
ainginyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to rub for, somewhere; to rub in; to mix in; to add in, put in. kinginyak emaido odia: mix groundnuts in the vegetables. 
ainginyanut1 (noun F) gluttony; fondness of backbiting, etc. 
ainginyanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of backbiting, eating too much, etc. 
ainginyar ki-a (transitive verb) to crush (by foot or car or heavy thing); to smash, annihilate; to eat all. abu amotoka kinginya ekingok: the motorcar crushed a dog. 
ainginyinginy ki-a (transitive verb) to rub (like rubbing tobacco between hands). ainginyinginy ekume: to rub the nose.
aingisenen ki-a (transitive verb) to ask often; to keep asking, inquiring. 
aingiset (plural aingiseta) (noun F) a question mark; a question; a quiz; a query. 
aingisio (singular noun F) a questioning; an examination; a test; an inquiry. 
aingit ki-a (transitive verb) to ask, enquire, request; to question; to examine; to give an examination. eong engisi: I ask; I am asking. yes ingisete: you are the ones going to ask. kingit (plural kingitata) (imperative) inquire; make an inquiry. kogeata ber aingit: first make an inquiry. 
aingitanar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep asking; to keep questioning, make an inquiry; to inquire. (reflexive verb) to ask one another; to debate. kengitanasi: let us make an inquiry. kingitanaros: ask one another. 
aingitar ki-a (transitive verb) to ask for and take away; (at school) to pass somebody into another class. (reflexive verb) to be passed or to pass; to get permission for. engitaros idwe ikany toma atukot naikanyet: five children have passed into the fifth class. 
aingitingit ki-a (transitive verb) to interrogate; to quiz; to cross-examine; to grill. 
aingito (singular noun F) a school examination; a questioning; a test; an inquiry; a quiz. 
aingitun ki-a (transitive verb) to ask for; to inquire about. aingitun ibore: to ask for something; to say that you want someone to give you something. 
aingitunun ki-a (transitive verb) to keep asking for information; to keep inquiring. 
aingo1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to get annoyed; to become angry. ikoto ijo aingo: you want to become angry, offended (without reason). 
aingo2 ko-a (transitive verb) to stir food (as of atap); to mix and mash together; to knead. engoi aberu aketap: the woman mingles and mashes her atap. aingo ekori: to walk like a lion or dog, i.e. sway or twist the buttocks proudly. cp. aigur. 
aingob ko-a (transitive verb) to drink something thick (making a sucking noise). aingob akima: to drink thick porridge. 
aingobel1 (singular noun F) a desire; a lust; a craving; a longing. 
aingobel2 ki-o (transitive verb) to covet; to desire; to lust after; to crave for; to long for (good or bad). 
aingobelikin ki-o (transitive verb) to desire for someone; to wish for. ingobelikit toto ikekoku inyamat: the mother wants food for her child. 
aingobelonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to become covetous; to become lusty. ingobelonor kwana ijo: you have become covetous, lusty. 
aingobelonut ki-o (intransitive verb) to be inclined; to be covetous, have a longing for; to be fond of; to be lusty. 
aingobingob ki-o (transitive verb) to eat hurriedly, quickly; to gobble down.. 
aingod ki-o (transitive verb) to diminish, take from. 
aingodol ki-o (intransitive verb) to tantalise; to make dips or potholes (as of motorcars on road). sirikingodol eong kakonikiring: do not tantalise me with your meat. 
aingodonor ki-o (transitive verb) to take from. iboro kon mam ingodonorio: nothing will be taken from you. 
aingodor ki-o (transitive verb) to minimise, shorten. aingodor aibuses: to discredit, abase. 
aingol (plural angolia) (noun F) a wooden spoon for mingling or stirring food; a paddle for rowing; an oar. cp. akingol
aingom ki-o (transitive verb) to eat quickly; to gobble. ingomingomi ngesi inyamatake: she/he gobbles up her/his food. 
aingomingomoor ki-o (transitive verb) to finish solid food quickly (not used of drinks). (reflexive verb) to be finished. kingomingomooros nan acok sek: the potatoes have been gobbled up sometime ago. 
aingong ki-a (transitive verb) to diminish (anything), make little; to decrease, make less; to lessen, cut off a piece. kageutu aingong erot: let us start (shorten) our journey (by going on). ileleba edula, kingongu: the granary is full, spill off some of its contents. 
aingongakin ki-a (transitive verb) to separate; to take from for somebody; to give a part to. kingongakinai eong da adikimai: give me also some millet from your full granary. (reflexive verb) to become less; to decrease. 
aingongar ki-a (transitive verb) to take off a part; to diminish or to abate. kingonga ipakasin ice: take away some of the porters. (reflexive verb) to decrease; to diminish; to abate; to be half full. engongaros akimai kotoma odula: the millet has decreased in the granary. engongaros amoti: the pots are only half full. cp. aingorar.
aingoninia ki-a (intransitive verb) to have a high opinion of oneself; to go very slowly (when told to do something); to swagger, disdain. ingoninia ngesi: she/he is haughty. (plural ingoninias kesi: they are haughty). 
aingop ko-a (intransitive verb) to hide oneself; to be hidden; to be a mystery. aingop duu du: to be completely hidden, obscure; to be lost. engopit akirot ngin: that is a mystery. angop ikabore: my thing is lost. aitongop ki-a (transitive verb) to hide. cp. aibwa. 
aingor ki-a (transitive verb) to take off a little; to decrease amount of; to leave half full; to lessen; to make insufficient. ingori ijo akimai: you are reducing the millet. cp. aingong. 
aingorakin ki-a (transitive verb) to bring something half full; to bring part of the quantity required. 
aingorar ki-a (transitive verb) to lessen; to decrease the amount; to take off the superfluous; to diminish. (reflexive verb) to be lessened; to be insufficient. engoraros akipi: the water has decreased. 
aingorianut1 (singular noun F) fondness for women; womanising. 
aingorianut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of women. 
aingoror ki-a (intransitive verb) to roar (of airplane); to snore (of someone sleeping soundly); to growl, make a rumbling noise (as of dog, person, engine, aeroplane, thunder, etc); to wheeze (of an asthmatic). ingororoi edege: the aeroplane is roaring. 
aingororoun ki-o (reflexive verb) to come rushing towards; to come full speed towards. engororoun amotoka neajai eong: the motorcar has come full speed towards me. 
aingotiloor ki-o (transitive verb) to cut off a big piece of something. cp. atubor. 
aingotol ki-o (transitive verb) to disfigure; to spoil (used with plural object). kinyek aingotol akamoti: do not disfigure or spoil my pots. 
aingotolikin ki-o (transitive verb) to disfigure for or somewhere (as by a deep scar, etc) (reflexive verb) to be disfigured. engotolikinos nges akonye: her/his face is disfigured. 
aingu ki-o (transitive verb) to smell something by putting the nose to it. kingu asabuunyu na: smell this soap. cp. aures.
aingub ko-o (transitive verb) to cut off a piece, break off a piece. cp. aitub, aingul. 
ainguc ki-o (transitive verb) to make a knot. 
ainguit ki-o (transitive verb) to keep on smelling; to have smelled. inguit ekesa ngol amot: he is not sober (literally, he has smelled the beer pot). 
aingul ko-o (transitive verb) to cut. kongul akiring na: cut this meat. cp. aingub.
ainguleny ki-a (transitive verb) to cut up into small pieces; to make too short; to cripple; to curtail. 
ainguleteny ki-a (intransitive verb) to be cut off; to be short (after cutting off a piece).
aingungu ki-o (transitive verb) to smell; to go smelling (as of a dog, etc). ingungui ekingok epejonon: the dog is giving the visitor a sniffing. 
aingunguya ki-a (intransitive verb) to corrode; (of wood) to rot and fall off easily. cp. amasikin. 
ainguny ki-a (transitive verb) to sprain, twist. ainguny ekume: to turn up or screw up one’s nose; to dislike; to disdain by turning up one’s nose. abu eong kanyarau nges ainyam, kosodi ngesi ainguny ekume: she/he turned up her/his nose when I called her/him to eat.
