aingunyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to sprain one’s ankle or wrist; to dislocate. (reflexive verb) to be sprained; to turn the body suddenly as by surprise at hearing or seeing. engunyakin eong akung: my knee is sprained 
ainguonor ki-o (transitive verb) to go about smelling (like a dog). cp. asupor, aingungu. 
ainguor ki-o (transitive verb) to sniff up; to smell. enguo ekingok egwang: the dog smelled the wild cat. cp. asupor. 
aingur ko-a (intransitive verb) to be stained, painted or spotted; to be irate, angry, or furious; (of a bull) to prepare for a fight by raising dust. aingur alup: to die (literally, to bite the dust). engurit ngesi alup: (she/he was stained by earth) she/he is very angry. angur kolo papaka alup sek: my father died long ago (literally, he was stained with earth long ago). aitungur: to stain anything. 
ainguruj ki-a (transitive verb) (of liquids only) to contaminate; to spoil; to make dirty or foul; to mix up; to jumble. sirikinguruja akipi: do not dirty the water by stirring. cp. aipuruj, aicok, aigur. 
aingurujaun ki-a (transitive verb) (only of liquids through stirring) to spoil; to make dirty; to contaminate. ingurujau jo akipi: you have contaminated the water by stirring it. (reflexive verb) to be contaminated, spoiled (of liquids only). cp. aipurujaun, aicokun, aigurun. 
aingurungura1 einer ki-a (intransitive verb) to talk through the nose. 
aingurungura2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to grumble, rumble, to murmur. 
ainguun ki-o (transitive verb) to smell something (not necessarily by putting nose to it). enguu eong ajon: I smell beer. aures: to smell after something. iur jo ajon: you smell after beer. cp. asupun. 
aingwal1 ki-a (transitive verb) to set out in fine colours; to emblazon. ingwalal: flamboyant. 
aingwal2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become lame; to become crippled, disabled. engwali ngesi: she/he will be crippled. engwalit ngesi: she/he is a cripple. 
aingwar akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to look fiercely; to glare; to glower; to look at angrily.
aini ko-o (transitive verb) to dent; to make potholes (as in the road), push inwards (making dents); to press inward, indent. 
ainia ki-a (transitive verb) to push aside, away (with plural objects); to pull down (something aloft, such as tree branches) (only of things). kinia atenueik ngun: pull those branches lower or aside. 
ainiaar ki-a (transitive verb) to push or pull out of.the way; to pull or push aside (of things that are flexible but do not move, and not of people). kiniaa atenueik ngun: push those branches away. (reflexive verb) to recline; to yield, give way, go aside; to fall to one side, heel or lean over; to keel. kiniaar awai katubor eong: lean aside and I pass. eniaar ngesi koicolongoke: she/he is reclining on her/his chair. cp. aigalior. 
ainiaga ki-a (transitive verb) (of anything weak or soft) to swing or sway to and fro. 
ainiagaanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to bend or move from one side to another (as of one climbing a swaying tree or on an unstable bicycle); to oscillate. 
ainiagaar (reflexive verb) to push aside; to fall or bend to one side, as one falling asleep. 
ainiaginiaga ki-a (transitive verb) to waggle. 
ainiaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to push or pull down for. kiniaik akinei ngun atenueik konyamata akwii: push or pull down the branches for those goats to eat the leaves. 
ainiaun ki-a (transitive verb) to bend this way; to bend down towards oneself. (reflexive verb) to become weak; to become tired; to become powerless; to become exhausted. ajioto ikokoroi eniaunos: the cocks have fought until they are exhausted. 
ainic ki-a (transitive verb) to put close together; to weave close together; to plait nicely. kinic abwas ngin: put the poles of that fence close together. 
ainicanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fill up gaps in anything; to put closely together, to compact. ainicakin akeje: to stand to attention or put feet closely together. (reflexive verb) to be close together. 
ainiem ko-a (intransitive verb) to be long in doing; to stalk; to walk on tiptoe. iniemi ijo ilosi: you move silently on tiptoe. cp. aiced.
ainieminiemakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to stalk very fast (as of stalking on an animal or a thief); to go stealthily and quickly after. enieminiemakin ekapa emir: the cat has gone stealthily (quickly) after the rat. cp. aicedicedakin. 
ainiep ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a squirrel, a person, monkey) to go or jump or climb from branch to branch or from tree to tree. 
ainiginiga ki-a (intransitive verb) to quiver; to object (by shaking head or shoulders); to show unwillingness (often feigned, as of a bride); to do as if objecting. iniginiga ateran bala mam ekoto alosit: the bride feigns not to want to go (to her new home). 
ainik ki-a (transitive verb) to suck; to drink. cp. aimat, ainak, aidika. 
ainikakin ki-a (transitive verb) to suck somebody or something. kenikaki eong esirut: a mosquito bit me. 
ainim ki-a (transitive verb) to sew nicely or well; to weave nicely or well; to plate nicely or well; to darn nicely. inim ijo ekasaati: you have sewn my shirt well. 
ainimakin ki-a (transitive verb) to sew, plait, darn finely for somebody. 
ainiminim akwap ki-a (transitive verb) to race, to run fast with short paces. iniminimete itelepai akwap: the boys are racing. 
ainiminimun ki-a (reflexive verb) to race this way with short paces. 
ainimun ki-a (transitive verb) to plait, to darn for oneself. akoto ainimun ekasaati: I want to sew my own shirt nicely. 
aining ki-o (transitive verb) to judge the weight of things by lifting or the strength of a person by wrestling; to balance (a weight on something); to test, assess, or put on trial; to try. ening eong epuko lo, elangir tii ti: I tried to lift this sack load, it is too heavy. cp. aigim.
ainingining ki-a (transitive verb) to carry a heavy weight. mam eong apedori ainingining epuko ngol: I cannot carry such a heavy bag or sack load. 
ainingokin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to weigh for; to judge weight for. (reflexive verb) to wrestle with. akoto eong ainingokin kajo: I want to wrestle with you (I want to try your weight or strength). cp. aigimokin.
ainingokin2 ki-o (reciprocal verb) to wrestle with one another; to wrestle often. 
ainingor ki-o (transitive verb) to lift up; to try; to try weight (of anything). kiningo asaduku na: try the weight of this box. 
ainip ko-o (transitive verb) to give a disgusting feeling; to satiate (as of honey or fat or butter). kanipit eong akinyet: fatty or oily food satiates me fast. cp. ainir, aiid. 
ainir ko-o (transitive verb) (of fatty food, honey and butter) to give a nauseating feeling. kanir eong esik: honey gives me a nauseating feeling (after eating too much of it). cp. ainip.
ainira ki-a (intransitive verb) (of an object or surface being cleaned) to be oily. 
aino ko-o (transitive verb) to dent; to press in. 
ainoino ki-a (transitive verb) to keep pressing; to test by pressing; to find out by pressing or feeling. 
ainoinoikin ki-a (transitive verb) to test by feeling or pressing (as of food to know if it is done) for somebody; (as of fruit) to see if ripe. 
ainok1 (noun F) combustion. 
ainok2 ki-a (transitive verb) to kindle; to burn; to set alight; to put on fire (as of small things). kinok akim: light the fire. inoki ijo akito numam eraas nukon: you burn the firewood which is not yours. ainok iiriir: to blaze. (intransitive verb) to be aflame or afire 
ainok3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be ablaze; to be on fire; to be alight. enoki akim: the fire is burning. 
ainok4 ko-o (transitive verb) to follow closely; to press in upon (as on enemy or on animal in hunting); to harass; to rage. enoki ejie ko Bulaya: the war is raging in Europe. 
ainokaar ki-a (transitive verb) to beat, slap, to deal a heavy blow (with the hand or club). kenokaasi kesi eong k’ebela: they gave me a resounding blow with a stick. 
ainokokin ki-a (transitive verb) to kindle; to light; to burn, put on fire; to inflame. kinokok etaala: light the lamp. kinokok akim: kindle or stir the fire. (note: to mean to burn a house or a bush, use aicweikin or aicwe). ainokokin akit: to give a heavy blow on the ear; to warm somebody’s ears. ainokokin ecelet: to intensify a quarrel. 
ainokos ki-a (intransitive verb) to begin to fester; to swell (after a hurt or bruise); to become painful. enokosa akakan: my hand is swollen. 
ainom1 ki-a (transitive verb) to beat; to strike. ainom epaasi: to iron clothes. ainom ejenunet loka emusalaba: to make the sign of the cross. ainom aput: to take a photo; to picture; to draw a picture. ainom isigira (or epiki): to gamble. ainom epuoso: to drink in one go. ainom akwap: to go far away. ainom awaragat: to narrate a parable. ainom atapuraita: to type. ainom amatapaalin: to make bricks. ainom etogo: to measure a house, etc. ainom ates esimit: to cement a grave. ainom eitaabo: to print a book. ainom emong: to pay a fine or dowry with a bull. ainom esimu: to make a telephone call. ainom epiiso: to inject; to inoculate. ainom eraagi: to paint.
ainom2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be burned; to burn; to be on fire. anom erekosi: our home is on fire. enomete ikitwo: the bushes are on fire. 
ainomakin ki-a (transitive verb) to drive into; to beat for or into; to hammer. ainomakin esumaalit: to drive a nail into. ainomakin awaragan: to teach in parables; to tell somebody a parable. ainomakin ejenunet loka emusalaba: to make a sing of the cross for or on. kinomak ikoku ejenunet loka emusalaba: teach the child to make the sign of the cross. ainomakin esulut: to salute somebody. 
ainomar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to beat off; to strike off; to beat away; (in tennis) to serve, service. kinoma akituk ngina: drive the cows that way. 
ainomar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to imagine; to forecast; to photograph. kinomaa Teso naebarit, kijamamai, kongalei: imagine a rich Teso, peaceful and healthy. ainomar iputo yenididi: to take a snapshot or passport-size photograph.
ainomonom ki-a (transitive verb) to lash (as tall grass lashing face); to give a beating. ainomonom akwap: to travel a long way; to make a long journey. 
ainong ki-a (intransitive verb) to be hopeless, downhearted, dejected; to flinch, baulk, recoil, cringe; (of scrotum) to shrink due to cold or fear. abu ngesi kobong ore inongit: she/he went home dejected. 
ainot1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to flock together; to be in a big crowd, in swarms. inosito itelepai aipet emopiira: there is a big crowd of boys on the football field. 
ainot2 ki-a (transitive verb) to sweep clean (as of room, etc). 
ainotakin ki-a (transitive verb) to put together in one place; to put too many together; to congest. inatakina itunga toma okooti: there is a big crowd of people at the court. (reflexive verb) to crowd together; to swarm together, flock together. enotakinos itunga toma okooti: there is a big crowd of people at the court. 
ainotar ki-a (transitive verb) to take too many of (food, men, clothes, etc). ai bo inotarete yesi inyamat ngul kere?: where are you taking all that food to? (reflexive verb) to go in crowds, swarms. 
ainotun1 ki-a (transitive verb) to bring in crowds, in swarms, too many of. (reflexive verb) to come in crowds, in swarms. enotunos itunga osokooni: crowds of people have come to the market. 
ainotun2 ki-o (transitive verb) to clean out thoroughly. kinotu ekatogo: clean my room thoroughly. 
ainu1 ki-a (transitive verb) to overpower by weight; to overcome by weight; to weigh down on. kenuut eong ajo: I am overpowered or overcome by sleep. cp. alangirikin.
ainu2 ki-a (transitive verb) to press, kiss, press against. inui toto ikedwe: the mother kisses her children. 
ainu3 ki-o (transitive verb) to hammer; to pound; to give a hammering. alosi eong ainu emuogo: I am going to pound cassava. 
ainuakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be too heavy to lift. kenuaki eong asaduku ngin: that box is too heavy for me (to lift or to carry). 
ainuar ki-a (transitive verb) to bend down by weight. enua emucuuga atenu: the weight of the oranges bent the branch. (reflexive verb) to bend down by itself (of things); to droop (head as of plant in the sun or of man with heavy load); to stoop. 
ainuit ki-a (transitive verb) to bear the burden of; to resist pressure. inuit ijo akou: you have a big head (an insult). 
ainuk ko-a (transitive verb) to cover over; to fill in a hole; to bury (only of covering with earth). ainuk aipany: to fill a hole. 
ainukusa ki-a (transitive verb) to sleep a long time; to sleep too long; to sleep in. inukusat lolo ngesi: she/he slept long today. 
ainukusanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to have the habit of sleeping too long; to be sleeping too long. 
ainumunum ki-a (transitive verb) to feast; to celebrate (marriage, harvest or any other occasion). ainumunum ekaru loitetet: to celebrate the new year anniversary. kenumunumata apaarit naka auriokon: let us celebrate your birthday. 
ainun ko-a (transitive verb) to bring and give; to bring, fetch for somebody here. koinunai eicolong: bring me a chair or seat. cp. ayaun: to bring, afford. 
ainup ko-a (intransitive verb) to believe, follow what is said; to be obedient; to be amenable; to listen to. idwe enupete akiro nuka lukauriakakec: children listen to what their parents say. 
ainut ki-a (transitive verb) (only of things) to make smooth; to make nice (as of a pot or a table, etc). inusi ngesi amoti: she/he makes the clay pots nice and smooth. 
ainuun ki-a (transitive verb) to encumber; to make difficult. 
ainwak ki-a (transitive verb) to light up (as with a lamp or torch); to illuminate; to x-ray; to scan with a radar or telescope. ainwak itunganan: to x-ray a person. 
ainwakakin ki-a (transitive verb) to enlighten; to illuminate; to make light for somebody; to show the way by lamp or torch. kinwakakinai eong erot: show me the way (by light or torch). 
ainwaket (plural ainwaketa) (noun F) an x-ray machine; a flashlight; a radar. 
ainwakitor (relative prepositional verb) to light up with. etabaasa loenwakitor eong etogo: the lamp with which I light up the room. 
ainwok ko-a (transitive verb) to block a hole or anything; to stop a leakage. konwok erot lo: block up this path. ainwok aki: to block or close up one’s ears; to put fingers in ears; to turn a deaf ear to.
ainwom ki-o (intransitive verb) to eat like a toothless person; to bite ineffectively (like biting rubber). cp. ailoilo. 
ainya ko-a (transitive verb) to widen; to enlarge; to stretch, open out, push aside, make a passage. ainya akoik: to widen the stomach; to expand the belly (as by over-eating or pregnancy). ainya ejungula: to become rich. 
ainyabuk ki-o (transitive verb) to grind again. kinyabuk akiria: grind the flour again. ainyabuk akiro: to be illogical in talking; to talk illogically. inyabuki ijo einer: you talk without any sense (illogically). cp. aisudup. 
ainyabukoor ki-o (transitive verb) to grind again for or somewhere away (reflexive verb) to be ground fine. enyabukooros akiria: the flour is ground fine. 
ainyaga ki-a (transitive verb) to rob; to take by force; to raid; to plunder; to rob and take away by force; to cheat in buying and selling.
ainyagaar ki-a (transitive verb) to rob and take away by force. cp. ademar, airurwo. 
ainyaiyo ki-o (intransitive verb) (with negative connotations) to be fastidious; to be particular (about anything). 
ainyaiyonor ki-o (reflexive verb) (with negative connotations) to become fastidious. 
ainyaiyonut (singular noun F) fastidiousness; meticulousness; carefulness; neatness; preciseness; fussiness. 
ainyak ki-a (transitive verb) to give back; to return (used with plural objects). kinyak ikaboro: return my things. ainyak ekume: to sniff up. ainyak akwap kau: to retard national or world progress. cp. aisuny ekume.
ainyakakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give something back to; to replace; to return to; to answer; to retaliate; to reply. kinyakakinai akiro: give me (send me) an answer. 
ainyakakinet (plural ainyakakineta) (noun F) an answer; a reply; a response. cp. abongokinet. 
ainyakanakin atap ko-a (transitive verb) to repeatedly bite off a piece of food and dip it every time in the same vegetable dish (considered bad manners in Teso). 
ainyakar ki-a (transitive verb) to take back to; to restore; return to; to make a restitution. (reflexive verb) to become taken back, returned, restored, released. enyakaros itunga kere: all the people were sent back, released. 
ainyakinyak ki-a (transitive verb) to make rags or smithereens. inyakinyakaarit eboomu etunganan akeju: a bomb has totally shattered a man’s leg.
ainyakun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring something back; to return, or restitute; to recall; to lower; to decrease, reduce; to reply. alosi eong ainyakun eropiti kon kwap: I am going to reduce your wages. 
ainyal ki-a (transitive verb) to mix (anything); to mingle, amalgamate, concoct. 
ainyalakin ki-a (transitive verb) to mix up; to put or mix together; to adulterate. kinyalak akile ocaai: mix milk in the tea. (reflexive verb) to be mixed; to be adulterated.
ainyales (plural noun F) yeast; leaven; malt. 
ainyalinyal ki-a (transitive verb) to mix up; to confuse; to mix many things, concoct. sirikinyalinyal ikoniboro ka luka: do not mix your things with mine. 
ainyalio (singular noun F) admixture; a combination; a mix; a blend; an assortment; a concoction; a fusion; a jumble; a muddle. 
ainyam1 ki-a (transitive verb) to accompany; to escort; to guide. kinyamata kes: escort them. 
ainyam2 ko-a (transitive verb) to eat; to consume (of solids); to take possession of. anyam etengei: to be hungry. kanyam eong etengei: I am hungry (literally, hunger has eaten me). ainyam eul: to become cheeky (literally, to eat impudence). anyam ngesi eul: she/he has refused, or she/he is cheeky. ainyam eropit: to receive pay. anyam emusaago: to lose a case; to get into a case. anyam (nes) ecor: she/he was drowned. anyam nges akim: she/he was burnt. ainyam ekia: to be poisoned. ainyam etau: to worry one, make angry. kanyamata eong akiro ngun etau: that made me very angry. anyam nges akwap: she/he was buried; she/he died. enyami ngesi akwap: she/he runs very fast. anyam lowok akwap: she/he lost the case. ainyam ajakaanut: to be elected into leadership. enyami ibore yen isirigin: this thing is expensive. ainyam edus: to eat without working. ainyam kepali: to cheat. ainyam apese: (of girl’s relative) to get part of her dowry. ainyam k’akou kice: to live on somebody else; to be a parasite or a hanger on. ainyam eding: ainyam ekolo: to be enemies; to be at loggerheads. anyam erot ikaboro: I lost my things on the way. ainyam kokwap: to undermine; to plot against. ainyam iboro: not to pay back. enyami ngesi ekulukulu (enyapedo): she/he lives on the dole or lives on begging. aipet ainyam: to eat from everywhere or at every house; to partake of every meal. 
ainyamakin ki-a (transitive verb) to escort or to accompany somebody on the way. kinyamakinai oreka: accompany me to my home. 
ainyamar ki-a (transitive verb) to go with a friend (somewhere); to go as a guide; to accompany. 
ainyamun ki-a (transitive verb) to accompany this way. (reflexive verb) to be accompanied; to accompany one another. enyamunos ipapero: friends have accompanied each other. 
ainyamur ki-o (intransitive verb) to hang on waiting for food or drink, etc; to be a tramp; to be a gatecrasher. inyamurei ngesi: she/he is a hanger on, etc. 
ainyang1 (noun F) vengeance; revenge; retribution; reprisal; settling of scores; retaliation. 
ainyang2 ki-a (transitive verb) to avenge; to take vengeance; to give tit for tat; to hit back, take revenge, or to retaliate. 
ainyangakin ki-a (transitive verb) to take revenge for; to retaliate for. alosi eong ainyangakin ikakoku: I am going to take revenge for my child. (reflexive verb) to be spiteful, revengeful.
ainyanganut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be vengeful, spiteful. 
ainyangar ki-a (transitive verb) to hit back; to revenge, retaliate. (intransitive verb) (of food) to be very hot. inyangarit atap na: this food is very hot (literally, this atap has taken revenge). 
ainyanyisaun ki-o (reflexive verb) to be crumpled. 
ainyapal ki-a (transitive verb) to command; to urge on (of a foreman) (intransitive verb) to be a headman or an overseer. 
ainyayi ki-o (transitive verb) to be particular about; to be fussy, finicky, faddy, picky, choosy, pernickety, hard to please; to do as if one does not like; to pretend dislike; to dawdle. (not often used in simple form, usually used is ainyaiyo). inyayios idwe enyamete: the children are fastidious in their eating habits. 
ainyekikin ki-a (transitive verb) to leave to; to abandon for; to leave with; to entrust, discontinue, omit. kinyekik inyamat ngul konyam ngesi da: leave her/him some food. 
ainyekikinia ki-a (prepositional verb) to leave with somebody; to entrust; to bequeath. 
ainyekin ki-a (transitive verb) to leave, abnegate, let alone; to allow; to wait; to abandon, cease, or resign; to abstain, let off, or forsake (also used for the negative imperative: kinyek). kinyek ber alosit: do not go yet. kinyek kwangin: stop. kinyek nges kolot: allow her/it/him go; let her/it/him go. ainyekin ngun (adverb) besides that. 
ainyekoonut1 (abstract noun F) jealousy; envy. 
ainyekoonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be inclined to jealousy or envy 
ainyer ki-a (transitive verb) to do badly, clear badly, shave badly, weed badly, sweep badly, etc (used with plural objects, or with often, always). inyeri ijo ekatogo apaarasia kere: you sweep my room always badly. 
ainyerinyer ki-a (transitive verb) to do badly; to clean, sweep, weed, shave badly, etc. ainyerinyer akiro: to explain wrongly. ainyerinyer atap enyamio: to dirty the millet bread (by eating like birds pecking everywhere). inyerinyeri ngesi akemana: she/he cultivates only the top soil of her/his garden. 
ainyigolit (plural ainyigol) (noun F) a tonsil. 
ainyik ki-a (transitive verb) to vex; to haze; to become gloomy (intransitive verb) to sob. sirikinyik lucetunga: do not vex other people. 
ainyikil ki-o (transitive verb) to cause to look gloomy; to make gloomy (of face); to make dark (of weather); to make sombre. 
ainyikilikin ki-o (transitive verb) to make somebody look gloomy. apotu akiro ngun kenyikilikis eong: what I heard made me gloomy. 
ainyikokin ki-a (transitive verb) to persevere; to carry on, hold on, to become persistent; (of suffering, rainfall) to become worse; to be diligent; to go on, keep on with something; to harass, keep troubling. kenyikokit eong akou: the headache keeps troubling me. 
ainyikokinonut (singular noun F) perseverance; assiduity; determination; diligence; resoluteness. 
ainyil ko-a (transitive verb) to tear off (as of meat, cloth, paper, etc). sirikinyil ekagoe: do not tear my cloth. cp. aicil egoe. 
ainyinyir1 (plural noun F) (outside Usuk) sweat; perspiration. 
ainyinyir2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to perspire; to exude; to sweat; to be very busy at. inyinyirit ngesi aswam: she/he is hard at work, she/he is very busy. ainyinyir aokot: to be in agony (literally, to sweat blood). 
ainyo ko-o (intransitive verb) to stand up often; to rise often. ainyo ape: ainyo eku: to rise slowly. 
ainyogo ki-o (transitive verb) to do again; to repeat; to go over again. ainyogo einer: to repeat what was said. cp. abongokin, airucakin. 
ainyogokin ki-o (transitive verb) to repeat to or for; to do again for. kinyogok: do it again (what was just done). 
ainyogokinet (plural ainyogokineta) (noun F) repetition; tautology. 
ainyogonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to reiterate; to keep repeating. 
ainyogonyog ki-o (transitive verb) to reiterate; to repeat often. 
ainyogoor ki-o (transitive verb) to do again; to reconsider; to revise. kinyogoo amanakon: plough your field over again. cp. aipopoun.
ainyogoun ki-o (transitive verb) to rake up; to dig up (as of old quarrel). 
ainyoiro ki-o (intransitive verb) to pull faces; to grimace. 
ainyong ki-a (transitive verb) to knead, or mix clay, flour, dough with a little water to make a thick paste; to mix paste for beer. ainyong akiria nuka emugaati: to knead dough. 
ainyongakin ki-a (transitive verb) to knead for; to mix for or somewhere. 
ainyongar ki-a (transitive verb) to tire out; to exhaust through work; to weaken by finishing strength of. kenyongasi eong aroma: the blows have weakened me. 
ainyonyo ki-a (transitive verb) to initiate a newly married woman into the clan by smearing her with ghee mixed with shavings of esas sticks in her mother-in-law’s house; to anoint or smear. 
ainyonyoanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to smear on often; to anoint often with. 
ainyonyoet (plural ainyonyoeta) (noun F) ointment; instrument for smearing. akinyet nakinyonyoet: oil for smearing or anointing. 
ainyonyoikin ki-a (transitive verb) to anoint somebody or somewhere. ainyonyoikino naka lukadekak: extreme unction (before someone dies). ainyonyoikin akiro: to incriminate.
ainyonyoikino (singular noun F) unction; annointing. 
ainyool ki-a (transitive verb) to turn, twist; to pump (as of a borehole). ainyool amotoka: to drive a motorcar. 
ainyoolaet (plural ainyoolaeta) (noun F) a steering wheel; a starter (of a motorcar); any instrument used for turning; a screw driver. 
ainyoolakin ki-a (transitive verb) to turn once, as of door knob; to switch on, as of electric light; to twist. 
ainyopidaar ki-o (transitive verb) to grind fine (reflexive verb) (of flour) to be ground fine. enyopidaaros akiria: the flour is ground fine. cp. ainyabukoor.
ainyor ki-a (transitive verb) to mix; to combine; to add; to confuse, intermingle. 
ainyorakin ki-a (transitive verb) to combine; to mix; to make a stew; to add together. ainyorakin akiro: to talk nonsense (reflexive verb) to be mixed, combined, added. enyorakinos inyamat: the food is mixed. 
ainyorinyor ki-a (transitive verb) to mix up; to mix together; to combine; to add up (of anything). cp. aimorimor
ainyud ki-a (transitive verb) to put close together. 
ainyudakin ki-a (transitive verb) to put many together; to cram into. sirikinyudak ikito irae: do not plant so many trees close together. 
ainyudunyud ki-o (transitive verb) to do slowly; to go slowly; to smoulder (of fire). inyudunyudi akim agugu: the fire is slowly burning the chaff. ainyudunyud ekitwi: to cultivate slowly, i.e. on account of bushes or high grass the cultivation goes slowly. 
ainyuk ki-a (intransitive verb to draw back; to recoil; to withdraw; to refrain; to refuse, be dismayed; to flinch; to retreat. enyuk emir ngol: that rat drew back (when it saw the cat). cp. aigir alomun. 
ainyul ki-a (transitive verb) to pluck (a hen, or hair). kinyul akokor ngin: pluck that hen. cp. aicap. aidot akokor. 
ainyum ki-a (transitive verb) to be very compact. 
ainyumit ki-o (intransitive verb) to be very compact, hard, dense, pudgy. inyumit ekitoi lo: this is a very hard tree.
ainyunyu ki-o (transitive verb) to scrape together; to mop up (as of remnants of food or anything). ainyunyu aidoole: to clean the behind by rubbing it on the ground  (as of a dog does). 
ainyunyuikin ki-o (transitive verb) to contaminate (by smearing on); to make dirty; to stain; to sully; to implicate; to involve. abu kolo Adam kinyunyuik oni aronus: Adam implicated us all in his sin: soiled us all. ikoto ijo ainyunyuikin eong akirokon?: you want to implicate me in your case. (reflexive verb) to be implicated, contaminated. 
ainyunyus ki-a (transitive verb) to crumple (of paper, cloth) in order to soften it. 
ainyuses (singular noun F) thickness (of dough, clay). 
ainyusor ki-o (reflexive verb) to become too thick (as of clay, dough). 
ainyut ki-a (transitive verb) (of many) to huddle; to crowd or swarm around. 
ainyutunyutakin ki-o (reflexive verb) (of many) to huddle together; to crowd together.
aipa1 ki-a (transitive verb) to do one thing after another. aipa alosit: to be always on the move. aipa inyamat: to swallow food quickly; to gorge. aipa einer: to talk at random; to talk quickly. ipai ngesi einer: she/he talks quickly. 
aipa2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to go aside, give way; to swerve away; to branch off; to deviate. epai erot lo ai?: where does this road branch off to? ipaa ijo noi: you have made a big mistake. mam ngesi ekoto aipa: she/he does not want to deviate. 
aipaagis ki-a (transitive verb) to rent; to hire. aipaagis emotoka: to hire a motorcar. aipaagis etogo: to rent a house. 
aipaagisaar ki-a (transitive verb) to rent away; to hire out. aipaagisaar eiduka: to rent out a shop. 
aipaagisakin ki-a (transitive verb) to rent for someone; to hire to. aipaagisakin apae etogo: to rent a house for a girlfriend. 
aipaanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep doing, beating. abu ngesi kepaanak eong kakan: she/he kept on slapping me. 
aipaar ki-a (transitive verb) to send after; to send away after another.
aipac1 ki-a (transitive verb) to make bare; to lay bare. aipac emukule: to scrape off fat or meat from a skin or hide. kipac emukule ngol: scrape that skin or hide. 
aipac2 ko-a (transitive verb) to shell (groundnuts or beans); to peel (the bark of); to hull (coffee). kopacata emaido: shell the groundnuts. 
aipad ki-a (transitive verb) to flatten; to increase in number or amount (the usual word is aipadar). 
aipadar ki-o (reflexive verb) to increase in number or quality (of anything). epadaros ikedwe: her/his children have increased in number. 
aipadipad ki-a (transitive verb) to flatten out, as of pastry or dough or clay. 
aipado ki-o (transitive verb) to ignore or do sluggishly; to show no morale in doing something; (Ateso Atororo) to console; to say condolences. cp. ailokony, aipapel, aitim
aipagag ki-a (transitive verb) (of a person) to be short and bow-legged; to be stout and strong. 
aipaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do immediately; to do quickly (once); to give tit for tat at once; to take revenge at once. abu ngesi kipaik agaria: she/he cooked the fish at once. abu je kipaik adodikin nges emuudu: the other guy proceeded to aim a gun at him/her.
aipak1 ki-a (transitive verb) to bale out water; to clean or to wash (as of wound or sore, or as women do their genitals); aipak ajimi: to clean or wash a wound or sore. aipak ataker: to bale out water from a boat. aipak atan: to bale out dirty water from the well. 
aipak2 ko-a (transitive verb) to break (as of cobs, cassava or potato tuber, etc); to pick maize cobs or break off a branch of a tree, etc kopak ekirididi: pick the maize cobs. (used only of things that grow together). aipak akiro: to say something big; to use high flowing language. 
aipakakin ki-a (transitive verb) to pour water on; to bale water on something or for somebody. 
aipakar ki-a (transitive verb) to splash, to bale away; to draw away by deceit; to clean a wound; to lure or decoy away. abu je kepaka eong okitui aibunga: she/he lured me away into the bush to beat. 
aipakas ki-a (intransitive verb) to labour for hire; to do work for daily or monthly pay. cp. aote, eitai. 
aipakipak ki-a (transitive verb) to catch many fish (especially mudfish); to separate scum or dirt on top of water (when going to drink). kipakipak ber epiria ilosi aiwok akipi: first separate the moss (on top of water) before you fetch the water. 
aipal ko-a (transitive verb) to give up; to part with something; to concede, sacrifice, give place to, or to forgive (a debt); to back out; to let go. aipal naka etau: not caring; indifference. 
aipali ki-o (intransitive verb) to be cheeky, arrogant, insolent, stubborn, obstinate. ipalie (plural ipaliete): she/he is (they are) arrogant, insolent, stubborn. 
aipaliikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to rebel against; to become cheeky; to be insolent to; to become obstinate; to become stubborn, arrogant. epaliiki etelepat ngol: that boy has become rebellious.
aipalionor ki-o (intransitive verb) to become stubborn; to become cheeky, etc 
aipalionut1 (singular noun F) cheek; insolence; contumely; arrogance; obstinacy; stubbornness. cp. eul, epali. 
aipalionut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be insolent, arrogant, stubborn, unruly, cheeky, obstinate, or insubordinate 
aipam ki-a (transitive verb) to pommel; to compress; to press (as of food); to heap or press one upon another. ipami ngesi alupot arwatat: ipami ngesi arwatat: she/he presses the clay on the wall. (intransitive verb) to grow, to increase (of an anthill). cp. aibam. 
aipang ki-a (transitive verb) to hit (especially of cricket ball). aipang einyure: to hit the cricket ball. aipang(akin ice) akiro: to shift guilt on somebody else. (reflexive verb) to be implicated in a case. aipang aijar: to live a hard life or life full of difficulties; to just survive.
aipangar ki-a (transitive verb) to beat or push away, aside; to turn aside (reflexive verb) to turn or go or bounce away; to turn aside. aipangar aki: to turn a deaf ear to; to ignore. epangar emopiira awai: the ball bounced away, aside. 
aipanipan akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to try to talk oneself out of a difficult situation.
aipany (plural aipanya) (noun F) a pit; a hole (in the ground); a pit latrine; a ditch; a trench. aibok aipany: to dig a hole or a pit; to put oneself in problems. alosit aipany: to go to the toilet. abokikin ice aipany: to set a trap against somebody; to plot against; to entrap. cp. ecolooni
aipapa ki-a (transitive verb) to revive (by pouring water on somebody). epapai eong: I am pouring cold water over. aipapa einer: to spread news, tell secrets; to tell tales. 
aipapaar ki-a (transitive verb) to bathe a sick person; to waste water. aipapaar akipi: to waste water. 
aipapel ki-o (transitive verb) to ignore; to pay no attention to; to disregard; to take no notice of. kepapel lolo je eong kopucit ke: the guy ignored me at his party. cp. ailokony, aikamesikin
aipaperikin ki-a (transitive verb) to make friends. kipapero iso: we (exclusive of person spoken to) are friends. ipaperos kesi: they are friends.
aipapero ki-o (intransitive verb) to be friends. 
aipaperonut ki-o (intransitive verb) to be friendly, sociable or affable. 
aipar ko-a (transitive verb) to show what is white; to expose the white or shining part of something; to expose a white or shiny object. kipar igoen omuria: put the white clothes out on the grass. aipar akonye: to show the white part of the eye. 
aiparar ki-a (intransitive verb) to burst open (of flower or mushroom); to spread out (wings of birds or ears of elephant); to effloresce. ipararaete akweny koitolima: the birds spread out their wings on the river bank (shore). 
aiparaun ki-a (intransitive verb) a corruption of aiparun: to appear in the distance; to emerge and come this way. 
aiparun1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to appear in the distance; to emerge (with a glitter); to face this way from afar (with a flash). 
aiparun2 ki-o (reflexive verb) (outside Usuk) to infiltrate, penetrate, or permeate. cp. aipelun.
aipas ko-a (intransitive verb) to be tired, weary, fatigued, or exhausted. kapas eong: I am tired. 
aipasipasakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fill to the brim. ilot ijo aipasipasakin akipi amot tetere do ilapanaros: you went and filled the pot to the brim such that it now spills.
aipat ki-a (transitive verb) to heap up one on top of the other (as of dung or clay). ipasi akiteng aoret: the cow heaps up the cow dung. cp. aipam. 
aipatat ki-o (intransitive verb) (of a big person) to lie or sit idle, do nothing; to lie or sit in a big heap; to be a big heap. ipatatai (plural ipatataete): she/he is (they are) sitting idle. inyo bo ipatataa ijo kane?: why are you sitting here idle? ipatataete igoen kotogoke: there is a big heap of clothes in her/his house. ipatatai ngesi kore: she/he lies idle at home – big as she/he is. ipatatai tai: dormant. cp. aidulel, aikumem, aipetet.
aipatipat ki-a (transitive verb) to keep heaping up (as of clay or cow dung). 
aipaun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring at once; to bring immediately. (reflexive verb) to be brought at once; to come at once. kipaunos kesi: let them come at once. aipaun akoik: to miscarry. aipaun inyamat: to vomit immediately (after eating something). 
aipe1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to run away; to escape. kopeata yesi: you escape! you run away! 
aipe2 ko-o (transitive verb) to toast; to roast over a fire; to scorch. kolot kope acokit: go and roast a potato. kope akiring: roast the meat. 
aipec ki-a (intransitive verb) to struggle; to try hard, contend, or scrimmage. ipecas itelepai ka Ateso: the boys are struggling with their Ateso lesson. 
aipecar ki-o (reflexive verb) to fight, have a skirmish. epecaros bian Kony ka ajore: the (Joseph) Kony rebels had a fight with the Uganda army yesterday. 
aipecipec ki-a (intransitive verb) to try repeatedly; to try hard; to try the impossible; to persevere; to struggle; to flounder. 
aiped1 ki-a (transitive verb) (of sickness, worry) to tire one out; to worry to death; to make thin by worries or pain. keped ajimi na eong: this wound makes me thin, or worries me. 
aiped2 ko-o (transitive verb) to pierce (someone or something); to puncture; to bore into something; to make or cause a leak (on a vessel); to give (a person or animal) an injection. epedi emuron itunga: the doctor injects people. 
aipedar ki-o (transitive verb) to worry, make thin. kipedi ijo eong kakonikiro: you tire me out with your talk. (reflexive verb) to be thin through worries. epedar eong noi: worries have made me thin or I am worried very much.
aipede ki-a (transitive verb) to open (as of a book); to cut open (as of fish or anything). ipedee ngesi eitaabo: she/he opens the book. cp. apukor.
aipediar ki-a (transitive verb) to open and clean (as of fish); to open a book wide; to stretch out. aipediar etau: to open one’s heart, to say everything one has to say. 
aipeg ko-a (transitive verb) to oppose, or wrangle; to contradict or to dispute; to deny; to argue; to object; to disagree; to differ. apeg kotoma agwelet: to haggle, bargain, or negotiate in the market. 
aipejo ki-o (intransitive verb) to visit; to go visiting. ipejoi ngesi (plural ipejoete kesi): she/he is (they are) visiting or holidaying. 
aipejokin ki-o (transitive verb) to pay a visit to; to visit somebody or somewhere. 
aipejonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to haunt; to keep on visiting. 
aipek ki-a (intransitive verb) to flap wings (as of a cock or birds on the ground). 
aipekesen ki-a (transitive verb) to inspect a suspect’s premises; to examine a possible crime; (of the police) to investigate; (of a law enforcer) to search. apotu ipolisin kipekesenata ereka: the police personnel came to search my home. 
aipekipek ki-a (intransitive verb) to flap wings (as of a cock or birds on the ground). 
aipelakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to stand on edge; to be warped; to be in danger of falling; to be slanting, not straight. (transitive verb) to put on edge; to warp, put in falling or wrong position. 
aipelipel ki-a (transitive verb) to give a contemptuous sign with the finger, hand or knife (with anything). kepelipeli ngesi eong: she/he points at me with contempt. 
aipelor ki-o (transitive verb) (Usuk) to pierce through; to poke; to impale or transfix. abu eong kecum etyang aipelor cut: I speared the animal right through its body. 
aipelun ki-o (transitive verb) to pierce through this way; to puncture this way (reflexive verb) (of anything) to protrude, project, stick out. 
aipemipem ki-a (intransitive verb) to run away, especially of children slapping feet on the ground. 
aipen1 ki-a (transitive verb) to sharpen (a panga, an axe, or a knife); to whet (a knife, a spear); (of birds) to clean the beaks. kipenata akusikwaras: sharpen your spears. aipen akwaras: to get ready for war or hunting (by whetting the spears). 
aipen2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of underground crops like sweet potatoes or cassava) to bear fruit; to develop; (of white ants) to swarm. apenata acok: the potatoes have developed or have become big. apenata ikong: the white ants have swarmed. apenata abulon toma ajimi: the pus has developed in the wound. cp. aimin.  
aipen3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to accrue; (of coins, children, etc) to amount, to number, be so many. apenata ikonidwe idi?: how many children do you have? or what is the number of your children? answer: apenata kesi iuni: they number three. kapena kaloto: let us get going. cp. aimwaun.
aipenakin ki-a (transitive verb) to sharpen for. aipenakin akwara: to make or get ready to spear; to plot against. sirikilot ngina naarai kipenakitai ijo akwara: do not go there, for they have plotted against you.
aipenet (plural aipeneta) (noun F) a grindstone for sharpening or whetting; an oilstone; a whetstone 
aipeny ko-a (transitive verb) to start or initiate doing; to be the first to do. kopeny aswam: start work.
aipepe ki-a (transitive verb) to select (seeds); to select cultivation; to improve seeds. aipepe ikinyom: to select seeds; to improve cultivation; to breed purebred animals. aipepe akiro: to revive or renew a quarrel; to rake up an old quarrel. 
aipepeunet (singular noun F) a culturing; a revival; a renaissance. 
aiperen ki-o (transitive verb) to defer; to postpone, send away empty-handed, put off, refuse to give. sirikiperen lokican: do not send a poor man away empty-handed. 
aiperikin ki-o (transitive verb) to lay down on; to put to bed; to put to sleep (as of a child). aiperikin yenikadekan adekis: to admit a patient in hospital.
aiperiper ki-a (transitive verb) (of young birds, white ants) to flutter in small numbers. iperiperete ikong: the white ants are flying in small numbers. cp. aimin, aipen. 
aipeseikin ki-o (intransitive verb) (of a baby girl) to reach marriage age; to become a girl. epeseiki do ikoku ngin: that child has become a big girl. cp. aiburun, atumun. 
aipesekin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a boy, man or woman) to act or be like a girl; to be girlish; to behave like a girl. ipesekit etelepat ngol: that boy acts, behaves like a girl. 
aipet1 ko-a (transitive verb) to spread out. aipet akapet: aipet ejamu: aipet aperit: to make a bed; to put the coverings neatly onto a bed. aipet edula: to make a platform for a granary. aipet akiro: to discuss; to talk things over; to go into details; to try to come to an agreement. aipet ainyam: to eat from every dish or at every house. 
aipet2 ko-o (transitive verb) to kick. aipet emopiira: to play football. aipet erot: to stop on the way and not reach the expected destination. 
aipetet ki-o (intransitive verb) to sit or lie idle, doing nothing. ipetetei (plural ipeteteete): she/he is (they are) sitting idle. inyo bo ipeteteo ijo kane?: why are you sitting (lying) here idle? 
aipetipet ki-a (transitive verb) to put or spread out near one another, as of dry potatoes or beans or anything. 
aipetipeta ki-a (intransitive verb) to have convulsions; to writhe; (of an epileptic or dying person) to struggle. ipetipeta ngesi, ipetipetas kesi: she/he is (they are) writhing or convulsing.
aipetipetakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to convulse; to writhe; to twist and turn. epetipetakin lokadekan, etakani eridaki: the patient has writhed, it seems he has died.
aipi1 (noun F) (Usuk) colloquial form of akipi: water. 
aipi2 ki-a (transitive verb) to itch; to irritate (the body). kepii eong akakuwan: my body itches me. aipi naka akiyo: to look for trouble. kipiete jo akiyo: you are looking for trouble; you are looking for a cause to cry. kepiete eong akiro: I am anxious to speak. 
aipic ki-a (transitive verb) (used only with plural objects) to knead with fingers; to crush; to press. aipic akoik: to procure abortion. angor nueroko ipicete akoikes: bad women procure abortion (i.e. by pressing their wombs). aipic esigala: to extinguish a cigarette by crushing it; to crush, destroy a cigarette. cp. aicik.
aipicar ki-a (transitive verb) (used with singular object) to crush, squash, squeeze, compress, or to defeat. (reflexive verb) to be crushed, defeated, compressed, or squeezed. 
aipicipic ki-a (transitive verb) to crush (into pulp); to rub or squeeze with fingers or hands (note: for bread, use ainyong); to keep pressing with hands. ipicipici ikoku ikisin katotoke: the child is squeezing its mother’s breasts. kipicipic egoe ngol ejok: rub that cloth in water well.
aipid ki-a (transitive verb) to hit slightly (anywhere); (of many things) to smack, strike; to slap often; to beat. ipidai esisianakinan idwe: the teacher smacks the children (at school). 
aipidaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to smack or hit somewhere. 
aipiding ki-a (transitive verb) to make a back entrance in a fence or an enclosure (of a home). epidingete kolo Iteso ikecereria: in the past the Iteso made a back entrance to their homes. 
aipidipid ki-a (intransitive verb) to grow very tall; to go far away, go on a long journey, travel far. ipidipidete Iteso Bulaya: the Iteso travel as far as Europe. 
aipidipidiar ki-o (reflexive verb) to go far away; to disappear. epidipidiaros kesi ngina: they have gone off far away. 
aipiipi ki-a (transitive verb) (of a breeze) to stroke or caress the body; to blow gently. epiipii ekwam akakuwan: the breeze blew gently on my body. epiipii ekwam akipi: the breeze ripples the water, blows gently over the water, hence cooling the water. 
aipik ki-o (transitive verb) to squirm; to wriggle; to try to get loose by wriggling.
aipikakin ki-a (transitive verb) to place somewhere on or in; to put somewhere on or in. (note: aipiikin is a corruption of aipikakin). kipikakis kes ngina: put them over there. aipikakin etau: to take to heart, put the mind to. kipikakis akiro nu otawonokus: take these words to heart. 
aipikipiko ki-o (intransitive verb) to squirm; to wriggle; to try to get loose; to have convulsions. ipikipiko ekweny: the bird is struggling to escape. 
aipikor ki-o (transitive verb) to overpower; to surpass (one’s strength); to be too difficult for; to overcome; to conquer or defeat. aswam na kepiko eong: this work is too difficult for me.
aipikoret (plural aipikoreta) (noun F) a conquest; a takeover; an invasion; an occupation; a defeat; a subjugation; a downfall.
aipilaar ki-a (transitive verb) to enjoy or relish food as others watch. ipilai ngesi aketap: she/he relishes her/his food. epilaasi kesi akiring: they have enjoyed the meat. cp. anyamaar. 
aipilil ki-o (transitive verb) to make groundnut sauce or a relish with groundnuts or simsim. 
aipilitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to run fast, go at full speed. 
aipima ki-a (intransitive verb) to measure; to weigh; to survey. ipimai (plural ipimaete kesi) epaaba: she/he (they weigh)s the cotton. aipima edou: to measure rain (using a rain gauge). cp. aitem.
aipinipin ki-a (transitive verb) to pour out drop by drop (as of medicine in the eye). (intransitive verb) to leak slowly. 
aipiny ki-a (transitive verb) to eat, overeat; to gorge; to cram with food (an insult); to dine. kolot kipiny akonitap: go and gorge your food. 
aipinyanut1 (noun F) tendency to gorge or overeat. 
aipinyanut2 ki-a (transitive verb) to be fond of gorging, eating ravenously (intransitive verb) to gorge, overeat. cp. ailikonut.
aipior (reflexive verb) to be finished. epioros ikasirigin: my money is finished completely. 
aipipa ki-a (transitive verb) (of a woman) to pacify a man by using charms or tricks.
aipir1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of wood or dried potatoes) to be eaten by weevils; to rot; to crumble to dust. 
aipir2 ki-a (transitive verb) to pierce (by drilling); to drill; to bore with drill. ipiri ngesi abao: she/he drills a hole in a board. aipiripir: to drill, etc. aipiripir akim: to twist a stick for making fire, i.e. to twist a splint. aipiripir alupot: to shape clay into a sausage. aipiripir akit: to poke into the ear. aipiripir edek: aipiripir emaagira: to crush cooked beans with emodu or eipiret (stirring stick). aisipir: to cause to pierce or bore. 
aipirakin ki-a (transitive verb) to bore for. aipirakin akim: to make fire for. 
aipiric ki-a (transitive verb) to keep crushing; to continue squashing or pressing out (as of juice). kipiric emucuuga lo: squash this orange. (reflexive verb) to be crushed, squashed, or pressed out. cp. aipiricaar
aipiricaar ki-a (transitive verb) to crush once; to squash or press out (as of juice) once. kipiricaa emuebe ngol: crush that mango. 
aipirionor ki-o (reflexive verb) to lope or take a long jump. 
aipiripir ki-a (intransitive verb) to drill; to bore a hole; to twist.
aipiripirun ki-a (transitive verb) to drill or bore this way. (reflexive verb) to bore its way through (this way). epiripirun akolong kodowon: the sun light has pierced its way through the clouds. 
aipiris ki-a (transitive verb) to crush; to dissolve; to melt; to make soft. kinyek aipiris acok ipoi: do not cook the potatoes too soft. cp. aipiric, aipic.
aipirisaar ki-a (transitive verb) to crush; to dissolve; to soften; to squash (reflexive verb) to be dissolved; to be crushed; to decay; to soften; to sink (of heart); to be overdone. epirisaar ekatau aiirar ngun: my heart has sunk on hearing the sad news. 
aipirisakin ki-a (transitive verb) to dissolve into. kipirisak abalang odia: dissolve the salt in the vegetables. (reflexive verb) to be dissolved. 
aipisakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fill to the brim, absolutely full. kipisak akipi toma amot: fill the pot to the brim with water. ileleba amot pisi pis: the pot is absolutely full. (reflexive verb) to be absolutely full; to be complete)y full. episakinos akipi toma amot: the water has filled the pot completely: the pot is quite full of water. 
aipisio (singular noun F) breeding; rearing; nurturing. 
aipit1 ki-a (transitive verb) to grow; to breed; to develop wealth (of living things); to rear. aipit apese: to refuse to give a girl in marriage (literally, to fatten a girl). 
aipit2 ki-a (transitive verb) to tie (anything); to tie in a loop. ipisi ngesi akito: she/he is tying the firewood together, i.e. binding the firewood in a bundle. aipit amuk: to tie the shoe laces. 
aipit3 ki-o (intransitive verb) to grow long, high, or tall; to spread branches. ipisit ekitoi ngol: that tree has spread out its branches. 
aipitakin auno ki-a (transitive verb) to tie on; to tie up; to lash. kipitak esibet auno: tie the prisoner up. loipitakitai auno: he who is tied up. 
aipitinakin ki-a (transitive verb) to be spiteful to; to be inimical to; to hate; to show antipathy to. 
aipitinanut1 (singular noun F) maliciousness; ill-will. 
aipitinanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to malice; to be ill-willed; to be malicious. 
aipitinat ki-o (transitive verb) to have ill-will against; to be hostile to; to hate. kipitinatos kesi ijo: they do not like you. 
aipitipit ki-a (transitive verb) to wind round; to coil, wrap, or twist round. 
aipiun ki-a (transitive verb) to haunt, preoccupy, irk, trouble, disturb, or worry. 
aipiyoor ki-o (transitive verb) to make thin; to tire out; to worry (by begging or any other way); to exhaust; to suck dry. kepiyoorit eong aswam na: this work exhausts me (or surpasses my strength). epiyoo ejakait imukopin: the chief has exploited the common people (by grabbing their things, for example). 
aipo1 ki-o (transitive verb) to bake on fire; to cook; to boil. 
aipo2 ko-a (transitive verb) to tear off (as of the bark from a branch); to strip off; to pull off skin (of an animal). aipo akopit: to pull off fibre. 
aipoc ki-a (transitive verb) to go over soft muddy ground; to mash. aipoc erit: to walk in or on the mud or cow dung. 
aipoikin ki-o (transitive verb) to cook for; to boil for; (of a woman) to marry (reflexive verb) to be married. ipoikino: (of a man) married (therefore they cook for him). 
aipoit (verb) to have cooked. ipoit ijo inyo?: what have you cooked? 
aipok1 ki-a (transitive verb) to catch in a trap; to be ensnared. aunoi kere ipokitos: all the snares were successful in trapping something. 
aipok2 ko-o (transitive verb) to take in big lumps (of food, etc); to give a big hard blow. aipok akiro: to tell a great secret; to speak indecently; to tell big lies. aipok atap: to take big lumps of millet bread. aipok akit: to hard on the ear. cp. aibap akit, aicar akit. 
aipokakin1 ki-o (reflexive verb) to get caught in; to become ensnared. epokaki emir togo: the rat was ensnared in the house. 
aipokakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to get cramps (in the arm or legs); (of a vehicle) to get stuck (somewhere). epokakin eong akeju: I have cramps in my leg. 
aipokaun ki-a (transitive verb) to slap heavily; to give a sound beating once. 
aipola ki-a (transitive verb) to be bashful; to be ashamed (the usual word is aipolakin). 
aipolakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be or become ashamed; to become bashful. 
aipolia ki-a (transitive verb) to counter evil; to make an offering to counteract witchcraft; to disenchant. aipolia idwe: a traditional ceremony for praying for a barren woman to become fertile, or for a woman whose children die in infancy or are aborted. 
aipom (plural aipomia) (noun F) a puff adder snake. cp. asigirikolong. 
aiponga ki-a (transitive verb) to beat with a heavy object often; to thrash, wallop many times. kiponga ijo nges: you beat him. 
aipongaun ki-a (transitive verb) to give a whack once; to thump once. cp. aiponga. 
aipoonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to always cook for somebody. 
aipoore ki-o (transitive verb) to cook; to boil. ipoi ngesi: she/he is cooking. epo: she/he has cooked. epooto kesi: they have cooked. 
aipooro ki-a (intransitive verb) (of eyes, wound) to be red. ipooro nges akonye: her/his eyes are red. 
aipopol ki-a (intransitive verb) to talk loudly; to be noisy, raucous. ipopolaete: they talk aloud; they are noisy. 
aipopolanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be noisy, raucous, rowdy, etc 
aipopolat ki-ao (intransitive verb) to be noisy; to be talking aloud. ipopolat ngesi, ipopolato kesi: she/he is (they are) rowdy, cantankerous. 
aipopony ki-a (intransitive verb) to act rough. 
aipoponyatoi ki-a (intransitive verb) to move like a rhino in bushes. 
aipor ko-o (intransitive verb) to fly; to take to the air. eporete ikweny kede idegei: birds and aeroplanes fly. 
aiporo1 (noun F) wet season. apaarasia nuka aiporo: the days of or the time of the wet season; springtime. 
aiporo2 ki-o (transitive verb) to elope with. abu ngesi kiporo akaberu: he eloped with my wife. alot akaberu eporo: my wife has eloped, run away. eporo (noun M) elopement.
aiporor ki-o (transitive verb) to pierce through. ecum eong ebileng aiporor: I speared the mudfish right through. 
aiposi ki-a (transitive verb) to drive or run into the bush or far away; to chase, make to run (used with plural object). iposie ngesi akituk okitui: she/he chases the cows into the bush. 
aiposiaar ki-o (reflexive verb) (of living things) to run and get lost; to rush away or out. eposiaar mamaika: my uncle got mad and ran away. 
aiposikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to rush at; to do rashly. eposikin ekapa emir: the cat rushed at the rat. 
aiposipos akiro ki-a (intransitive verb) to talk a lot in anger; to complain or quarrel a lot. iposiposi ngesi akiro: she/he keeps on quarrelling. 
aipot1 ki-a (transitive verb) to lash, beat up, thrash, drub, belabour, or bash. eposi eong, iposete kesi: I am beating, they are beating. 
aipot2 akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to talk much, say much; to prate. aipot einer: to talk at random, be talkative. abu ngesi kipot akiro: she/he talked a lot. akiro nukipota tai: sheer nonsense, bunkum, hogwash. iposi ngesi aswam: she/he works hard: she/he toils. cp. aida, aile, ainom.
aipotor ki-o (transitive verb) to lead away, astray; to cut off. abu ngesi kepoto eong: she/he led me astray (showed me the wrong road) (not used figuratively) (reflexive verb) to go wild or astray; (of a woman) to go after another man. cp. ailocor, aiporo. 
aipoun ki-o (transitive verb) to cook for oneself a little food. 
aipu1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to escape by breaking through the crowd, etc. cp. aiku. 
aipu2 ko-o (transitive verb) to butcher; to slaughter; to kill (of animals). kopuoto emong konyamata: slaughter a (healthy and non-problematic) bull and eat it. 
aipua akipi ki-a (transitive verb) to pollute the water. 
aipuakar ki-o (reflexive verb) to become many or numerous. cp. aipuar.
aipuar ki-o (reflexive verb) to increase in number; to become many; to abound. epuaros idwe kosomero: the children in school have increased in number. 
aipuc1 (singular noun F) peace; harmony. 
aipuc2 ki-a (transitive verb) to seal, close completely; to cover completely; to block up; to plaster; to close hermetically; to hide (the truth). kipuc amot: seal the pot. ekoto ngesi aipuc akiroke: she/he wants to hide the real truth. aipuc edula: to build a big clay-and-grass granary. 
aipuc3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to have peace; to be peaceful. epuci, epucete: she/he is (they are) at peace. aipuc naka etau: composure; equanimity. 
aipucakin ki-a (transitive verb) to lock up for; to fasten (a box); to plaster over (a hole). aipucakin edula: to build a granary for someone or for something. aipucakin erot: to close or block up the road. (reflexive verb) to be blocked up; to be fastened, locked, closed up, plastered. epucakinos eong iporotoi: my throat is blocked. 
aipucanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to patch up cracks or holes often (not used of cloth). 
aipucet (plural aipuceta) (noun F) a thing for blocking a hole or crack. 
aipud1 ki-a (transitive verb) to desire; to like. ipuda ngesi (plural ipudas kesi) inyo?: what does she/he (they) desire? kwape ipudar ekisil: as required by the law. aswam kwape ipudatar ikisila: to do as the laws or rules require.
aipud2 ki-o (transitive verb) to bring out; to expose. kipud iboroka kinga: bring my belongings outside. 
aipud3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to go out very early. ipudoro lolo jo kinga sek: you went out early today.
aipuda ki-a (transitive verb) to tread on; to trample on repeatedly. ipudaete kesi akakimai: they are trampling on my millet. 
aipudaar ki-a (transitive verb) to tread underfoot thoroughly; to trample on completely. aipudaar erot: to make a path (by constantly walking over the same ground). 
aipudakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to decide on; to desire; to want. aipudakin: to prefer; to want; to be attached to. epudakin ekatau alosit kwapekwana: I have decided to go immediately. cp. akotokin, angasikin. 
aipudanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to desire each other; to love each other, be of one mind. 
aipudel ki-o (transitive verb) to tantalize. cp. aitilil.
aipudokin ki-a (transitive verb) to expose; to show; to bring out for. kipudokinai iso atenus: bring out the drum for us (to dance). 
aipudor ki-o (transitive verb) to take outside; to show; to expose. kipudosi iicolongo kinga: take the chairs outside. (reflexive verb) to go outside; to show oneself outside. 
aipudun ki-o (transitive verb) to bring outside; to make to appear (of woman); to bring a baby outside from confinement in the house after being born; to reveal (a secret). (reflexive verb) to come out (as of secret); to appear. 
aipudunio (singular noun F) a traditional ceremony of bringing a baby outside from confinement in the house after being born; a ceremonial bringing of the corpse of the dead out of the house for burial.
aipues1 (singular noun F) quantity; multitude; amount. 
aipues2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be many; to be numerous; to abound; to be great in number. kipu iso, ipu yesi, ipu kesi: we, you, they are many or numerous. cp. atiaun, aimwaus. 
aipuga ki-a (transitive verb) to rule; to dominate, or to control; to govern. ipugai nesi, ipugaete kesi: she/he rules, they rule. cp. ayait. 
aipuk1 ki-a (transitive verb) to give a slight blow under the chin. 
aipuk2 ki-o (transitive verb) to fan (face or fire); to flap wings; to increase. aipuk isiru: to fan or drive away the mosquitoes. aipuk k’akokor: to fan twins (on new moon) or to fan sick person with a chicken (something like incensing). aipuk elutaari: to incense the altar. aipuk itunga: to fan people. aipuk akim: to fan the fire. aipukor itunganan: to fan a person; to bewitch a person. ipukoritai ijo: you are bewitched. 
aipuk3 ko-o (transitive verb) to keep opening (as of book, box, etc); to keep uncovering (used with plural object). 
aipukakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give a slight blow to; to chuck. kepukaki ngesi eong: she/he gave me a slight knock or blow. 
aipukanar ki-o (reflexive verb) to box on the jaws often; to chuck again and again. 
aipukaun ki-a (transitive verb) to box or knock on the jaws once. 
aipuke (transitive verb) (of melted fat or oil) to solidify.
aipuket (plural aipuketa) (noun F) a fan (for stirring air); a blow pipe; a bellows.
aipukupuk1 ki-o (transitive verb) (of heart) to palpitate or to beat quickly; to throb. ipukupuko ekatau: my heart throbs. 
aipukupuk2 ki-o (transitive verb) to keep fanning; to keep incensing, shaking. ipukupuki ngesi akim: she/he fans the fire. 
aipul ki-a (intransitive verb) to grow (as of anthill or wound); to ooze out (as of resin); to protrude (as of mucus of nose). ipulit ikoku ekume: the child has a dirty nose. ipulit ajimi: the wound is festering. ipulas ajon eipul: the beer is just bubbling over. 
aipulaar ki-a (transitive verb) to reverse the motion of something; (of action, such as speech) to change into something else, such as a quarrel. aipulaar emopiira: to kick the ball backwards overhead. aipulaar acel: to raise a quarrel; to turn into a quarrel. (reflexive verb) to be turned into; to be changed into. epulaaros akiro: the conversation has changed (into a quarrel or to another topic). 
aipular ki-a (transitive verb) (of termites) to cover things to be eaten (intransitive verb) (of a sore) to be covered by dirt. epulasi ikok ebela: the ants have covered up the stick (to eat it) (reflexive verb) to be covered by soil or dirt (through the action of ants or termites). 
aipule (plural aipulei) (noun F) a navel; umbilicus. cp. akapul.
aipulupul ki-a (intransitive verb) to rise to the surface (like bubbles); to grow like an anthill. 
aipum ki-a (transitive verb) to throw down with thuds (of anything heavy). 
aipumupum ki-a (transitive verb) to strike (of lightning); to throw down many times or often. ipumupumit eipyei etunganan kanen: the lightning struck a man in that area. 
aipun ki-a (transitive verb) (used with plural noun) to throw dust, flour, powder; to cover with dust, etc aipun itunga: to cover people with dust. aipunupun: to keep throwing dust, etc 
aipunakin ki-a (transitive verb) to throw dust or powder or flour at somebody. cp. aipurakin.
aipunanar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep throwing dust; to knock the earth off the grassroots after hoeing; to beat one right and left, and pushing them down. 
aipunar ki-a (transitive verb) (Usuk) to knock over (as of a car knocking a person, an animal or a bag of flour); to hit something so that it falls over. 
aipung ki-o (transitive verb) to place a thing slanting; to turn sideways, to tilt up (intransitive verb) to be slanting, tilted, turned sideways; (of ship) to list, to be lopsided. aimat ajon aipung: to drink beer and get drunk (literally, to drink up to the slanting position).
aipungokin ki-o (transitive verb) to put slanting for; to tilt over for; to make to lean over (reflexive verb) to lean over; to be slanting. cp. alurokin, akumokin.
aipungor ki-o (transitive verb) to turn away from; to turn towards somebody or from somebody; to turn one’s back to (used with epura). 
aipunupun ki-o (transitive verb) to soil (hands or body or anything) with dust, flour or powder. cp. aidupudup, aimodimod: to soil with mud. ipunupunete idwe alupok: the children are throwing dust about. 
aipunupuno ki-o (reflexive verb) to roll in the sand, ashes or dust like chicken; to play in the sand; to cover oneself with dust. ipunupunos idwe kotoma asinge: the children play (roll) in the sand. 
aipunyar ki-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to knock over. abu akiteng kipunya elepit: the cow knocked over the milking can. cp. anangar, aitunyar, aipunar.
aipup ko-o (transitive verb) to hear; to listen; to understand; to know; to feel. 
aipupuk ki-a (intransitive verb) to shake (as of cloth); to slap wings (as of cock starting to crow or of hen going to fight); to attack furiously (of cock or hen). ipupukat ekokor itunganan: the cock attacked a man. (figurative) to attack fiercely. ipupukatos ajokin itunga: evil spirits attacked people.
aipupukatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to writhe; (of a bird) to struggle to get away from a trap. 
aipupung ki-a (transitive verb) to tie into a big knot so as to make it difficult to untie. 
aipupungakin ki-a (transitive verb) to bundle up, tie together for. 
aipupus ki-a (transitive verb) to trample upon or down; to walk on or over. apotu akituk kipupusata ekapaaba: the cattle trampled down my cotton. 
aipupuut ki-o (intransitive verb) to be rather many. ipupuuto itunga kangina: there are rather many people over there. cp. aipues.
aipur1 ki-a (transitive verb) to sprinkle dust, sugar, salt, powder, etc on; to strew with dust, etc. 
aipur2 ko-o (transitive verb) to intercede, mediate, or arbitrate; to speak in favour of; to pacify; to reconcile; to placate. 
aipurakin ki-a (transitive verb) to sprinkle on, etc (of dust, etc but not of liquids). cp. abwat (of liquids). 
aipuri ki-o (transitive verb) to smoke out; to fill with smoke. ipurie ngesi eketogo: she/he smokes out her/his house. epurie elulu: there is hullabaloo. aipuri emome: to smoke out flying ants. 
aipurikin1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be busily engaged; to be occupied with any action. aipurikin amat: to be busily engaged in drinking; to have a beer party. 
aipurikin2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to smoke out. aipurikin ikumes: to blow smoke into nostrils; to revive (by blowing smoke into nostrils) (intransitive verb) to be smoky; to smell after smoke; to taste after smoke; to look brown with smoke. epurikitos acok: the potatoes have a smoky taste. epurikitos igoenekon: your clothes are dirty (brown) from the smoke. 
aipuripur ki-a (transitive verb) to sprinkle powders or crystals on; to strew salt, sugar, etc 
aipuris ki-o (transitive verb) to spear, spike or impale.
aipuruj ki-a (transitive verb) to disturb (liquids); to contaminate (liquids); to stir or make dirty (liquids only). aipurujaun akipi: to dirty the water by stirring; to adulterate. epurujaunos akipi: the water has been stirred dirty. 
aipurusoor ki-o (transitive verb) to spear or impale through. 
aipuruun ki-a (transitive verb) to drive out by smoke. 
aipuseronut (singular noun F) widowhood; losing one husband after another. 
aipuset (plural aipuseta) (noun F) a mop; a duster; a wipe. 
aipusor ki-o (transitive verb) to throw down heavily with a thud; to let slip or fall (reflexive verb) to fall down with a thud; to slip. cp. aibusor
aiput1 ki-a (transitive verb) to furbish; to wipe, shine, buff, polish. kiput emeesa: polish the table. cp. aipwat. 
aiput2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be like; to become like, resemble. eputos aberu kikokuke: the mother looks like the child. epusit ngesi ngai?: eputos ngesi ka ngai?: whom does she/he resemble? 
aiputar ki-a (transitive verb) to wipe out, polish, or expurgate. 
aiputiikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a child) to become stunted in growth. 
aipuwaun ki-o (reflexive verb) to become dusty; to become dusty (of water or liquids). epuwaunos akipi nu: this water has become dusty. 
aipwak ko-a (transitive verb) to start something new; to annoy someone without reason; to tease. aipwak aswam: to create your own work (not what one was told to do). kopwak erot kane: make a new road here. aipwak akiro: to start another topic (of conversation). aipwak ere: to build a new home.
aipwat ko-a (transitive verb) to wipe, buff, polish. epwasi epolisit emuudu: the policeman is polishing the gun. apwata kesi: they have polished. 
aipwok ki-a (transitive verb) to soil or dirty (solid objects) with. epwokata idwe ikagoen: the children have soiled my clothes. (note: aicok, aipuruj: to make liquids unclean or polluted). 
aipwokakin1 kwap ki-a (transitive verb) to throw down carelessly so as dirty; to dump or plonk down. 
aipwokakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to become dirty, soiled somewhere. 
aipwokun ki-o (reflexive verb) to become dirty or soiled. 
aipwony ki-a (transitive verb) to push back the foreskin. 
aipwonyar ki-a (transitive verb) to pierce with something sharp (as with thorn or pointed object). kepwonya eong ekukwai akeju: a thorn pierced my foot. 
aipyalal akwap ki-a (intransitive verb) to run very fast; to take to one’s heels. ipyalalaete kesi akeju: they run very fast; they are taking to their heels. 
aipyalalaar ki-a (reflexive verb) to run away very fast; to race, to run off quickly. 
aipyang ki-a (transitive verb) to fetch a little of (liquids only); to shake, move liquids in a container. aipyang akipi: to bring a little water. 
aipyangar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away a little of (a liquid) in a big vessel (so that it sloshes from inside)(reflexive verb) to be taken away (of a small quantity of liquid). aipyangun akipi: to bring a little or too little water. 
aipye ko-a (transitive verb) to sweep (the house or compound); to clean with a broom. kopyeata etogo: sweep the house. cp. aiput: to dust.
aipyed1 ki-a (transitive verb) to bewitch (by night dance or by cries) to bewitch; to cast an evil eye on; to curse. ekacudan ipyedi itunga: the witch bewitches people. kipyedi bian kia: somebody bewitched us last night by dancing round our house. cp. ailam, aiken: to curse.
aipyed2 (singular noun F) bewitching; witchcraft. koyanga aipyeda kon ngina: go and do your witchcraft somewhere else. 
aipyed3 ki-a (intransitive verb) to do witchcraft; to practice witchcraft. alot ngesi aipyeda: she/he has gone to practice her/his witchcraft. koyanga aipyeda kon ngina: away with your witchcraft! 
aipyel ki-a (transitive verb) to hanker after; to be addicted; to feel a craving for; to long for; to desire; to lust. kepyel eong akiring: I long for meat (note that akiring is the subject). ipyelit ngesi etelebision: she/he is a telly addict. ipyelit ngesi emopiira lopetot: she/he is a football addict. cp. aimuit.
aipyer ki-a (transitive verb) to warm oneself (near the fire or in the sun); to bask. ipyerete itelepai enyango: the boys warm themselves in the morning sun. aipyer akim: to warm oneself near the fire. aipyer akolong: to warm oneself in the sun. 
aipyet ko-a (transitive verb) to winnow; to sift. epyesete angor akimai: the women are winnowing the millet. 
aipyetar ko-a (transitive verb) to winnow away; to sift away. apyetar inyamat: to finish the food. (reflexive verb) to be winnowed; to be finished (of anything). apyetar aswam: the work is finished. apyetar akeje: kapyetasi akeje: let us go away. cp. aipyalal akeju, aiting emaget, aikamun erot, aikamun akeju or aikamun erot: to run away, take to one’s heels, hasten. 
aira1 ki-a (transitive verb) to plant; to transplant. irae ngesi epaaba: she/he plants cotton. cp. aiwe: to sow.
aira2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a plant) to bear fruit; to be prolific. ekitoi ngol erae noi: that tree bears well. 
airab1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to discuss; to debate; to argue, discourse. iraba ngesi (plural: irabasi kesi): she/he is (they are) discussing, debating, or taking part in a discussion. 
airab2 ki-a (transitive verb) to plead for; to endeavour; to settle differences. airab asurup: to settle a feud, a quarrel. 
airab3 ki-a (transitive verb) to sharpen (as knife, etc). irabi epuudit icuumanake: the carpenter sharpens her/his tools. 
airabes (plural airabesia)(noun F) a place of discussion; a parliament; a courtroom. airabes nakapolon: high court; the national assembly. cp. airabet
airac ko-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to multiply; to do many; to throw away many, or much, or big. alosi eong airac akonijon: I am going to throw your beer outside. airac akiro: airac einer: to talk a lot; to say much, be talkative. airac isirigin: to pay too much; to pay through the nose. airac edia: to spill vegetables.
airacirac ki-a (transitive verb) to have too many irons in the fire, do too many things at once. iraciraci ijo aswamusinei, mam eong apedori: you bring so many jobs, I cannot manage them. airacirac edia: to spill vegetables on something. iraciracete idwe edia: the children are spilling vegetables. airacirac apesenin: to have many debts. 
airadad ki-a (transitive verb) (of anything inactive) to be numerous or many together. iradadaete itunga koreka: there is a crowd of people in my home, just sitting. 
airadirad ki-a (transitive verb) to produce in great numbers; to put many together or near each other (of anything); to do many things, works at once. kiradiradata apanya: dig the potato-heaps near one another. airadirad aswamusinei: to do many jobs at the same time. cp airacirac.
airag ki-a (transitive verb) to grind badly or coarsely; to husk (beans or peas). imare luiragag: crushed peas. 
airagirag ki-a (transitive verb) to grind badly or coarsely; to husk (beans or peas). akiria nuiragiraga: meal flour poorly ground. 
airaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to plant somewhere or for somebody; to transplant. 
airaj ki-a (transitive verb) to tie loosely; to make loose (used with a plural object). irajit ijo akituk ngun: you have tied those cows too loosely. 
airajaj ki-a (intransitive verb) to sit idly (especially of a fat person). irajajai ngesi kore: she/he sits at home doing nothing. 
airajiraj ki-a (transitive verb) to tie loosely (used with singular or plural object).
airam ko-a (transitive verb) to pulsate; to beat (a drum); to play a musical instrument; to thresh grain. erami ngesi atenus: she/he beats the drum. airam itunga: to call people together (in olden times by drum, but these days a person can move from home to home telling people to attend a gathering, or simply place a radio announcement). airam adeudeu: to play the harp (musical instrument). airam edongot: to ring the bell. aram naka etau: heartbeat, pulsation. airam erot: to beat road level. airam itunga origa: to call people away for a hunt. airam emome: a method of catching flying ants (emome) by beating a dry log with two small sticks (the ants mistake the sound drops and swarm up a tube which leads into a pot where they are trapped). airam imu: a traditional ceremony after the birth of twins, involving wearing ebomo, emuria and egwangira plants on the head and waist, dancing emidiiri, beer drinking and a lot of other observances.
airamakin ki-a (transitive verb) to interfere; to meddle; to rush at. 
airamam ki-a (intransitive verb) (of wound, eyes) to be very red, crimson. iramamaete akonye bala etukuri: your eyes are red as those of an owl. iramamai: it is red, crimson. iramamaete: they are red, crimson.
airamiram ki-a (intransitive verb) to take out cattle to graze in the morning before milking them (believed to increase milk yield).
airanga ki-a (intransitive verb) to become greedy, gluttonous (with food). 
airangaanut1 (singular noun F) gluttony; greed; ardour. 
airangaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be greedy, gluttonous, or given or inclined to greed. 
airangang ki-a (intransitive verb) to be red all over (of anything). ayaun esaati irangangai aokot bon: a shirt was brought red all over with blood. 
airany ki-a (intransitive verb) to ride (on an animal or vehicle). 
airanyakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to make to sit down (reflexive verb) to sit down. cp. aibanyakin.
airanyar (reflexive verb) to ride away. 
airap ko-a (intransitive verb) to cover or wrap; to hide (by covering); to make dark (by covering); to envelope. 
airapakin kwap ki-o (reflexive verb) to duck or stoop suddenly. 
airar ki-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to pick up; to levy. irarete idwe ingaroi: the children are picking up pebbles. 
airarun ki-a (transitive verb) to find, discover or pick up; to select. 
airas ko-a (intransitive verb) to continue, carry on, go straight on, or do immediately. 
airat ko-a (transitive verb) to abuse often; to revile often; to offend often; to insult. abu nges karat eong: she/he offended me, or abused me. 
aire1 ki-o (transitive verb) to peer or stare at. cp. airere. 
aire2 ko-a (transitive verb) (of many things) to push aside far apart. areikin: to push for or somewhere. cp. areikin akiro: to put guilt on somebody else. 
aire3 ko-a (transitive verb) to hate, detest, dislike, be spiteful, be hard on, or to have something against one. (the word more often used is areit). 
aireb1 akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to say something hurting; to be sarcastic; to complain bitterly. irebi Austin Ejiet akiro iwadikai: Austin Ejiet writes sarcastically. airebireb einer: to talk quickly.
aireb2 ki-a (transitive verb) to mince (meat); to cut, nibble, cut up small (vegetables or hair with a knife or scissors). cp. aibet: to cut (with an axe or a panga), split; to chip, splinter. irebi aberu ecaboi: the woman is cutting up the ecaboi vegetable. airebireb akiring: to cut meat into small pieces. akiring nairebirebitai: minced meat. cp. aitebiteb.
aireb3 ki-o (transitive verb) (used with a plural object) to stop the progress or advance of; to bring to a standstill. aireb ibaren: to stop cattle (from going further). 
airebar ki-a (transitive verb) to nibble away at. abu emir kirebaa auno: the rat nibbled the rope. 
airebireb ki-o (transitive verb) to keep in check, persuade to stay, dissuade, curb, stop from going, keep preventing from going (of living beings only). 
airebokin ki-o (transitive verb) to oppose; to stem, resist, stop one from going or doing; to stop progress; to intercept; to prevent, keep back (from going); to hinder, obstruct, rail. ejaas akiro nukerebokinitos eong: something prevents me (from going or doing).
airebokinet (plural airebokineta) (noun F) hindrance; obstacle; barrier. 
airebonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to obstruct constantly, keep refusing, keep putting obstacles in the way, keep preventing. kerebonokini ngesi eong akalosit: she/he keeps refusing to allow me to go. 
airebor ki-o (transitive verb) (only of living beings) to push back, repulse, parry, ward off, deflect, circumvent. 
airebun ki-o (transitive verb) to fetch back; to lead back, drive back (only of living beings). kirebutu akituk: drive the cattle back. 
aired ki-a (transitive verb) to make or brew plenty of beer. 
airedakin ki-a (transitive verb) to brew much beer for, or somewhere. ireded ajon kotogo: there is plenty of beer in the house. iredakit amuran iketunga ajon: the mother-in-law has made a lot of beer for her people. 
aireg ki-a (transitive verb) to scrape (of anything); to clear ground of weeds; to clean (as of road, compound) by scraping the soil. 
airegegear (singular noun F) palsy; paralysis - adeka naka airegegear
airegem ki-a (intransitive verb) to have dirty eyes. 
airegireg ki-a (transitive verb) to scrape clear or scrape off (of ground or anything). 
aireikin ki-o (transitive verb) to peep at; to look through; to examine. akoto aireikin asaduku ngin: I want to look into that box. 
aireire ki-a (transitive verb) to canvass; to converse. 
airem1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a dog or fox) to bark; to be barking. irema ekingok: the dog barks. 
airem2 ko-o (transitive verb) to push or shove. korem amotoka: push the car. 
airem3 ko-o (transitive verb) to spear, stab, or transfix; to puncture; to thrust (spear) into; to gore. arem esumaalit amotoka: a nail punctured the motorcar tyre. cp. aigum (to shoot with an arrow).
airemaar ki-a (intransitive verb) to bark away; to bark in a distance. 
airemakin ki-a (transitive verb) to bark, howl, woof at once. eremaki ekingok ekokolan: the dog has barked at the thief. 
airemanut ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a dog) to be a good barker. iremana ekingokoka: my dog is a good barker. 
airenge ki-a (transitive verb) to beat, or to overcome (in a fight); to drive (motorcar or motorcycle); to discharge or sack. 
airengear ki-a (transitive verb) to dismiss, excommunicate, expel, send away, chase away, drive away, or to depose. airengear kotoma akwap: to deport, extradite. kirengea ekingok ngol: chase that dog away. abu Okello Lutwa kirengia Milton Obote kokaru 1985: Okello Lutwa deposed Milton Obote in 1985.
airengeenen ki-a (transitive verb) to keep on dismissing; to dismiss often; to drive a car, be a driver. irengeenenei amotoka: she/he drives a car.
