airengeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to drive for somebody; to chase away, to send away for, drive into. airengeikin ekiliokit: to send away a girl (who refuses) to her husband. 
airengeun ki-a (transitive verb) to send, expel, or drive this way. kirengeutu akituk (lailo): drive the cattle this way. 
aireonokin ki-a (transitive verb) to look at constantly, scrutinise repeatedly. cp. airo: to go to have a look. aibwap: to go to look for. 
aireor akou ki-a (transitive verb) to look out (as snake from a hole or a person out of a window). 
airep ki-a (intransitive verb) to run with short steps; to trot (as of animal).
airepirep ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a short person) to trot; to trip. airepirep akeje: to walk, go at trotting pace. 
airepun ki-a (intransitive verb) to come running (slowly). 
airere ki-o (transitive verb) to examine; to observe; to look at sharply; to enquire. inyo bo irerei ijo kanen?: what is there you are looking at so curiously, so closely? cp. aingic.
airereonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to choose for; to select for. 
airereonut1 (singular noun F) inquisitiveness; fondness for research. 
airereonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be fond of looking at, for, in; to be inquisitive. 
airereor ki-o (transitive verb) to look round for something (lost). 
aires (singular noun F) beer for tasting. 
airet ko-o (transitive verb) to give a heavy blow (with a stick or hand); to bang (doors); to belabour; to rattle. airet ikekia: to rattle doors. airet adere: to drink beer greedily from a calabash. 
airetakin ki-a (transitive verb) to shout at, rebuke, scold, reprimand, or chide; to balk strongly, reproach, or warn; to dress down. abu ngesi kiretak eong kanuka aswamuka: she/he scolded me on account of my work. (reflexive verb) to be scolded, reproached, reprimanded. 
airetun ki-a (intransitive verb) to thunder (once).
airi1 ki-a (transitive verb) to pull, drag along; to draw (used with plural subject or object). airi anaaga: to ride a bicycle hard. iriete kesi edula: they are dragging the granary along. airi emusaago: to drag a case on (without coming to the conclusion or final judgement).
airi2 ki-o (transitive verb) to cross or put in one’s way; to bar the way. alosi eong aikam lukecor, ido mam akoto ijo airi eong: I am going to fish and I don’t want you to spoil my good luck (prevent me).
airi3 ki-o (transitive verb) to look or search for; to sponge for food. airi inyamat: to look for food. airiikin: to look for, go and find for somebody or somewhere. airiikin ajon: to have a long drag at a beer tube (to drink ravenously). 
airi4 ko-a (transitive verb) to crack, split, or tear along seams. 
airi5 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be crooked, twisted (as of board, tree, manners, house, rows of cotton plants, or anything abnormal, but not of road). eriete ikoniponesio: your manners are crooked. eriete nges akeje: she/he is knock-kneed. eriete akiro: it is a contradictory statement. erie eketau: eriete akeomisio: she/he is corrupted in thought. eriitos akonye: she/he has a squint. cp. ekudukudo: to be winding or twisted (of other things).
airi6 ko-o (intransitive verb) to straighten, make straight (as of a crooked stick, board, etc or of a case in question); to stretch out. kori ebela: make that stick straight. 
airiac ko-a (transitive verb) to split, fissure. 
airiad ki-a (intransitive verb) to shamble along, walk like one with weak knees, that is, awkwardly; to trudge. 
airiak ki-a (intransitive verb) to hurry to, assemble together, or run to. ai bo iriakete yesi?: where are you hurrying to? 
airiakanara ko-a (intransitive verb) (of two or more things being compared) to be equal (in size or age), or to be commensurate. eriakanara papa ka okoku: iriakas papa ka okoku: the father and son are the same size. iriakanara iponesio: (of manners, behaviour) congenial. cp. aputonoro.
airiakuun ko-a (intransitive verb) to have the same height; to reach the same height; to be equally big. eriakuut kesi: they are the same height or size. 
airiam1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to meet, come together, or to encounter. bia keriama oreka: come, let us meet at my home. 
airiam2 ki-a (reflexive verb) to be sufficient or enough to go round. inyamat lu mam elosete airiam itunga kere: this food will not be enough for all the people. 
airiamakin ki-a (transitive verb) to join; to put together; to tie together; to surround; to converge; to link. kiriamak aunoi: join the (two) ropes. apotu kesi kiriamakis etogo: they joined the house. (reflexive verb) to meet, come together, collide, or to encounter. keriamakinos ka nges ngina: let us meet him there. 
airiamakinet (plural airiamakineta) (noun F) a meeting (place); a collision; a rendezvous. 
airiamar (reflexive verb) to meet at a distant place. 
airiamet (plural airiameta) (noun F) a junction; an angle; an abutment; the intersection. 
airiamun ki-o (reflexive verb) to get together; to meet at one place, converge, or to concur. 
airian1 (singular noun F) a blazing heat. 
airian2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of fire) to be ablaze; (of body) to be very hot, feverish; to glow, be aflame, ablaze. eiriani akakuwan kanuka eimidi: I am feeling feverish. eiriani ekatogo: my house is ablaze. koanyu, eiriani etogo loka Aanyu: look, Aanyu’s house is ablaze.
airianar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep pulling, dragging away or out (reflexive verb) to be dying, gasp for breath; to sigh. kenyek eong nges irianar: I left him gasping. 
airiang ki-a (intransitive verb) to stagger; to sway like a sick or drunken person, walk unsteadily. 
airiangakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to stagger into or somewhere or against someone. 
airianganar ki-o (reflexive verb) to stagger against one another; to lurch; to keep swaying. 
airiangitoi ki-a (intransitive verb) to keep staggering (like a drunkard). 
airianikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to stir fire; to be ablaze; to glow on account of. 
airiapakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to be surprised, give a surprise, come upon suddenly. eriapakin ngesi keanyu eong: she/he was startled on seeing me. 
airiare ki-a (transitive verb) to grind (only used in infinitive). alosi eong airiare: I am going to the flour mill. 
airiaun ki-a (transitive verb) to make dizzy, giddy. keiriaunit eong etengei: hunger is dizzying me. 
airib ko-o (intransitive verb) to become dark; (of sky) to be overcast; (of weather) to be dull. 
airic ko-a (transitive verb) to hold fast, hold tight; to observe law, or to follow advice; to heed, obey law, or keep a promise. koric iicorakinaka: keep my commandments. 
airid1 ki-a (transitive verb) to tighten the noose, etc. 
airid2 ki-a (transitive verb) (of a dying person or animal) to gasp 
airid3 ko-a (transitive verb) to tuck in; squeeze, press between two bodies. 
airidakin1 (noun F) take a dying breath. 
airidakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to tie for; to fasten (intransitive verb) to die (reflexive verb) to be tightened; to be properly fastened. 
airidid ki-a (transitive verb) to gulp down noisily; to drink like cows. 
airie ki-a (transitive verb) to grind (between two stones); to pulverise. 
airieb ko-a (transitive verb) to ache, pain, or hurt; to be sore; to make sore. kariebi eong akou: my head aches (pains me). kariebi eong akan: my arm aches. kariebi eong etengei: I am hungry.
airiec ko-a (transitive verb) to pound, crush, squash, ravage; to kill in great numbers. erieci eong acok: I am crushing potatoes. cp. aicang. 
airiecakin ki-a (transitive verb) to crush, squash, pound for. eriecak eong ekabokorit: I crushed my finger. (reflexive verb) to be crushed, pounded, squashed. cp. aidecakin.
airieng ko-a (transitive verb) to avoid for fear or surprise. 
airieny ki-a (transitive verb) to dig up, root up, uproot; to clear the bush. airieny ariang: to clear away stubble from where millet was harvested. airieny erot: to clear the road of grass. cp. aireg.
airiet (plural airieta) (noun F) a grinding stone; a mill. 
airieun ki-a (transitive verb) to grind a little for oneself (reflexive verb) to be ground. erieun alos edit: only a little flour was ground. 
airiga1 ki-a (transitive verb) to hunt (especially wild game). 
airiga2 ki-a (transitive verb) to rub, file (with an iron file); to sharpen with a metal file; to grate. airiga ikel: to grind teeth, gnash teeth. airiga ekia: to rub on medicine. airiga k’emusumeeni: to saw. 
airigaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hunt for or somewhere. 
airigakin ki-a (transitive verb) to surround (as of hunters surrounding animals); to fence in; to rub for. 
airigasit (plural airigata) (noun F) a hunting ground. 
airigaun ki-a (transitive verb) to hunt out from a place; to rub this way; to rub for someone. alosi eong airigaun tata epur: I am going to rub grandma’s back (as she bathes).
airiget (plural airigeta) (noun F) a gathering of elders for a discussion; (formerly) a cabinet or assembly; a meeting. 
airigiikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of food, for want of water) to be burnt. erigiikis acok: the sweet potatoes have burnt (because all the water evaporated from the saucepan). 
airigionokin ki-o (transitive verb) (of anything) to rub on, into. 
airigior ki-o (transitive verb) to saw (once); to abrade. 
airigioret (plural airigioreta) (noun F) abrasive; sandpaper; metal file. 
airigirig (abawoi) ki-a (transitive verb) to saw (timber). 
airiikin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to have a long pull, to drag or pull for, or somewhere. airiikin ajon: to have a short, good pull at a beer tube; to have a good short drink. kiriik ber ajon kolot: have a good drink (of beer) before you go. cp. airianakin ajon: to have a beer party (a long drink). 
airiikin2 ki-o (transitive verb) to put across, tie crosswise, or put in the way of; to bend sideways. airiikin akonye: to squint. airiikin akeje: to tackle (in a football game); to trip a person. iriikit ngesi akonye: she/he squints. cp. airiokin
airiir1 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of fire) to be ablaze; to be aflame, in flames. 
airiir2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of depth) to be abysmal; to cause giddiness, dizziness; to be precipitous. aipany ngin eiriiri: that hole makes one dizzy (because it is very deep). 
airiiri ki-o (transitive verb) to put crosswise; to put in the way, obstruct, intervene, prevent, spoil. iriirit ijo alositeka: you have spoiled my journey or my luck. 
airiirikin ko-o (intransitive verb) (of fire) to start blazing. airiirikin akim: to start a blazing fire. 
airiit ki-o (transitive verb) to drag along; to tow; to trail. iriit eris ekekori kokwap: the leopard drags its tail on the ground.
airiitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to be elastic; to be creeping (as a snake); (of a person) to drag oneself along. 
airik1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be last. eong eriki: I am the last. 
airik2 ki-a (transitive verb) to finish; to end. kirik inyamat ngul: finish off that food.
airik3 ko-o (transitive verb) to lead with rope or stick or by hand (as of a blind person). loemudukana erikio k’ebela: a blind man is led by the stick. 
airika ki-a (transitive verb) (of a child, calf, etc) to suck the last milk; to keep suckling. 
airikakin ki-a (transitive verb) to finish, complete, consummate, end, or to accomplish (reflexive verb) to be finished, completed, or accomplished; to die. akoto airikakin aswam na: I want to finish this work. ikar lumam irikakinos: for ever and ever. cp. edaunos. 
airikakinet (plural airikakineta) (noun F) a limit; an end; a boundary; a border; a full-stop. 
airikar ki-a (transitive verb) to exterminate; to finish off (eating, spending, etc); to complete; to deplete. (reflexive verb) to be finished off; to get finished. erikaros inyamat: the food is finished. 
airikirik1 ki-o (transitive verb) to cut meat or anything into long strips. 
airikirik2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of part of the body, due to reflex action) to quiver; to twitch; to tic. 
airim ki-o (intransitive verb) to go round; to spin or revolve round; to wander about; to roam about; to hover over. irimi kereka akwap na: note that the fortunes of this world change fast (literally, by the way this world revolves). irimi ijo airim: you just wander about. irimi elap akwap, ido bobo irimi akwap da akolong: the moon rotates round the earth, and the earth in turn revolves round the sun.
airimirim ki-o (transitive verb) to go round something; to wander about aimlessly; to hover round. 
airimokin ki-o (transitive verb) to round up, or to surround; to tour; to enclose, or encircle (of anything). kirimok ekonitogo k’abwas: surround your house with a hedge or fence. (reflexive verb) to be surrounded, encircled, or rounded up. irimokini akwap akolong irwana tipe kangolikaru: the earth revolves round the sun once every year.
airimor ki-o (transitive verb) to go round something; to surround, or to encircle. airimor akwap: to round the country or world. (intransitive verb) to make an excursion or expedition. 
airing ki-a (intransitive verb) to become stout, fat, or muscular. iringit ekesa ngol: that man is very muscular. cp. aitum.
airinga ki-a (transitive verb) to take, carry, or catch something big. iringaete angor ibilenga k’ocor: the women catch big mudfish in the lake. 
airingaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away something heavy or big; to throw away or fly away with something big. eringaa etori aculot: the kite has managed to snatch away a young hen. 
airiny ko-o (intransitive verb) to lose freshness; to droop (with heat of sun); to become thin (of body of a person). erinyit acokit na: this potato is shrivelled. 
airioc ki-a (transitive verb) to split (as of wood); to husk (groundnuts); to shell nuts, etc. 
airiong ko-a (transitive verb) to carry a load on the shoulder. inyo bo iriongit ijo?: what are you carrying on your shoulder? ariongar: to carry away on the shoulder. 
airioniar ki-o (reflexive verb) (plural airiokiar) to become black, dark. cp. aroniar: to become bad. 
airionokin ki-a (transitive verb) to put or do crosswise; to put horizontally, put obstacles in the way. airionokin amisirin: to plough across the slope. airionokin akito togo: to put struts or rafters crossways or horizontally in the house. 
airionut1 (singular noun F) darkness; blackness. 
airionut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) (plural airiokus) to be black, dark. iryono akware na: it is very dark tonight. iryoko Iteso; Imusugun ekwangak: the Iteso are black people; Europeans are white. 
airior ki-o (transitive verb) to go to search for; to go to look for. erio ngesi amerekekin akan ngin: she/he went that way looking for the sheep. 
airioronut1 (intransitive verb) to be talkative, inclined to talk much 
airioronut2 (singular noun F) talkativeness; chattering. 
airip1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to come slowly; to fall slowly (as of tree or anything). airipokin: to come or go slowly to. iripuneneete itunga luka Acowa okison loko Ocorimongin: the people from Acowa (in Kapelebyong county in Katakwi) come slowly (often sleeping on the way) to Ocorimongin cattle market in Usuk county.
airip2 ko-a (transitive verb) to follow, come to, go after, go together, or to go in a crowd. cp. aidip. 
airip3 ko-o (transitive verb) (of liquids) to sip a little; to draw a little water from a tap. korip adijon kolot: sip a little beer, and go on. aripokin: to sip somewhere or for something. 
airipun ki-o (intransitive verb) to come to a place in the evening (with the hope of sleeping). ai bo iripunito yesi?: where are you coming to this late? (implication: there is no room for you here). 
airiri ki-a (transitive verb) to cut round; to cut into strips; to circumcise; to cut to shape. (intransitive verb) to walk along, go along the edge or along a wall; to go along a boundary or shore; to pass near. 
airirikin ki-a (transitive verb) to put or place near. kiririk ekonitogo moru ngol: build your house near that rock. (reflexive verb) to be near; to border on; to be opposite. 
airirim ki-a (transitive verb) to drive or lead a big herd of cattle or crowd of people; to round up cattle or people. 
airirior ki-a (transitive verb) to sidle about; to walk past, but near (an object). 
airiritoi ki-a (transitive verb) to go about searching for (anything) in a sly way; to look for (anything) surreptitiously. iriritoi ngesi ajonio: she/he goes surreptitiously looking for free beer. cp. amomootoi
airit ki-o (transitive verb) to gather, collect, store up, bring one by one. 
airitit ki-a (intransitive verb) to be sitting together in a crowd; to be crowded together (of men or anything); to be many. irititiete itunga kore ka ejakait: crowds of people are gathered at the chief’s home. 
airitokin ki-a (transitive verb) to take away; to gather for, collect for or somewhere. 
airitor ki-o (transitive verb) to take away one by one; to carry off one by one. 
airiun ki-a (transitive verb) to allure; to attract, draw towards one, conduce; to pull this way; to suck (reflexive verb) to hand down; to flap (as of breasts). airiun ajon: to suck beer. airiunun: to pull repeatedly. iriuni: conductive (of an electric conductor). 
airiyar ki-a (transitive verb) to drag away; to pull away, or up; to tug at, or draw away; to induce.  (reflexive verb) to crawl away (as of a sick person); to pull oneself along. abu eong keriyar okelesia: I dragged myself to the cathedral. iriye nges adeka: she/he is dying slowly (the disease is dragging her/him along). 
airo1 ko-a (transitive verb) to examine; to look at; to inspect; to oversee; to pore over. eroi ejakait iitaaboi luk’esolo: the chief is examining the tax revenue books. airo amuk: (of raiders) to consult the foreseer (who shuffles sandals) to find whether the raiding excursion will be a success. cp. aiany.
airo2 ko-o (transitive verb) to make narrow or arched; to cause shrinkage. 
airoc ko-a (transitive verb) to lasso; to trip, catch, tie up. 
airod ko-a (transitive verb) to usurp; to appropriate, encroach, cheat, defraud. erodi ngesi itunga: she/he cheats people. 
airog ki-o (transitive verb) to prod with a stick; to open a blockage (as when cleaning a pipe, etc); to hollow out (of boat); to bore holes in (intransitive verb) to have a sharp pain (anywhere). airogirog epopong: to hollow out the cactus (to make the long drum called emidiiri). 
airoga (intransitive verb) (of any living thing) to be dying by wasting or growing thin; to become infirm. 
airogor ki-o (transitive verb) to spear through.
airojim ki-a (transitive verb) to massacre (or many); to slaughter (of living things); to finish off (of hens by a thief, or of animals by sickness); to destroy; to play havoc with. 
airojo ki-a (transitive verb) to round up (people or animals); to gather together into a trap; to summon. airojoun akituk: to round up cattle. airojoun imirio: to drive rats out of their holes into snares. 
airok ko-o (transitive verb) to adapt or copy; to acquire, collect. airok iponesio: to acquire habits. airok iraan: to collect plants. 
airom ki-a (intransitive verb) (of throat) to swell or be inflamed. 
airomar ki-a (reflexive verb) to become swollen or inflamed. cp. abuun. 
airomirom ki-a (transitive verb) to massacre, slaughter, or bite all over; to finish off. abu eris kiromirom akinei ipu: the leopard ate several goats. cp. airojim (used with plural objects).
airong1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of fruit) to become ripe; (of weather) to become dark or gloomy; to darken, or become sombre. erongit akwap: the weather is cloudy, gloomy. 
airong2 ko-o (transitive verb) to carry with the mouth; to have sticking in the mouth (as of lump of meat or potato, or cigarette) without eating. koinakinai eong da akiring karong: give me also a piece of meat to stick in my mouth. 
airongakin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of weather) to become gloomy, dark, or sombre. 
airop ko-a (transitive verb) to reward; to award; to pay wages; to recompense; to remunerate or give a present to. airop ikoku: to give a present to a child. aropakin: to pay out for someone else. 
airoromaara ki-a (intransitive verb) to be gigantic and very tall. iroromaara ngesi (kesi): she/he/it is (they are) very tall. 
airot1 ki-a (transitive verb) to take two or more together; to do together; to have more than one; to hold two or more at one time. airosit angor: to have two or more wives. airot angor: polygamy; bigamy.
airot2 ko-a (transitive verb) to spy upon; to investigate; to detect, reconnoitre. erosete isirikaalei ere ngol: soldiers are spying on that home. 
airotakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give two; to give double; to put, hold two together. kerotaki eong Eluga ipalei: the Indian trader gave me two pairs of trousers or pants. (reflexive verb) to be two together; to be in a pair or in two pairs. erotakinos kesi oicolong: they both sat on one chair. 
airouroun ki-o (intransitive verb) to become mouldy, dusty, or mildewy. 
airu1 ki-a (transitive verb) to give animals (especially cattle, goats and sheep) water in a trough.
airu2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to sound; to make a noise; to crow, or croak; to roar, low, or grunt. aru atenus: the drum has sounded. aru edongot: the bell has rang. eruos aki: the ears are ringing. eruo engatuny, eris, ekokor, emong: the lion roars, the leopard purrs, the cock crows, the bull lows (bellows). 
airu3 ko-o (transitive verb) to spit at; to spit out (as of a snake or person). erui emun aimula: the snake spits its venom. 
airub ko-a (transitive verb) to settle down (as of sediments); to begin to congeal; to calm down; (of wound) to heal up, join up; to freeze (of water); to remain intact. erubit edula: the granary or store is intact (nothing has been taken out). 
airuc1 ki-a (transitive verb) to do again; to repeat. mam eruci bobo: I shall not do it again. cp. abongokin; aiyatakin; ainyogokin. 
airuc2 ko-o (transitive verb) to join or mend ropes; to knot (rope). 
airucakin ki-a (transitive verb) to do again; to repeat. 
airucuruc ki-a (transitive verb) to do repeatedly, be redundant; to repeat. mam eong akoto airucuruc akiro: I do not want to repeat what I said. 
airud ki-a (transitive verb) to polish, rub, or buff up. 
airudakin ki-a (transitive verb) to rub on. kirud emeesa: polish the table. 
airudokin ki-o (transitive verb) to prick intentionally with (as with a needle). 
airudud ki-o (transitive verb) to pierce, push in or down (accidentally) (as with a needle or pin). abu ekukwai kirudud akakan: a thorn pierced my hand. cp. aicum, aiped.
airududokin ki-o (transitive verb) to pierce, push in. 
airugag ki-a (transitive verb) to encrust; to develop a hunch-back.
airugu ki-o (transitive verb) to grind a little flour noisily; to make a grinding sound. ingai irugui amoru ngin?: who is grinding there? airugurug: repetition of airugu. 
airuj ko-a (transitive verb) to cause to contract; to hit with an arrow; to make narrower; to fold up; to cover over. eruji ngesi emir: she/he is shooting a rat (with an arrow). 
airuja ki-a (intransitive verb) to dream; to imagine; to think; to consider; to have a nightmare. aisuruja: to cause dreams; to give one a nightmare. 
airujakin ki-a (transitive verb) to think about; to suspect; to forecast for. 
airujaruj ki-a (intransitive verb) to meditate, reflect, consider, or ponder over. cp. aomoom. 
airujasit (plural airujasia) (noun F) a dream; a nightmare; an imagination; a thought; a sentance. cp. aomisioit. 
airuk1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to sing, hum. aloto itunga eiruk: people have gone to dance. cp. ekosio 
airuk2 ko-o (transitive verb) to crush; to pound in a mortar (as of groundnuts, herbs, etc); to stamp with the feet, etc; to batter. cp. aicuk (of akimai – millet or sorghum, to clean it in a mortar without crushing the grain), aicur or aicang (to crush cassava or dry potatoes). erukete angor emaido: the women pound groundnuts. 
airukaun1 ki-a (transitive verb) to bombard with shells (grenades or cannons). cp. aidupaun 
airukum2 ki-a (transitive verb) (of a bird) to hatch, brood, sit on eggs; to incubate; to follow closely; to overtake nearly; to be on somebody’s heels. irukumit akokor (abeei): the hen is sitting on the eggs. 
airukutaar ki-a (transitive verb) to drive away, throw away, expel; to dismiss, force away (by shouting or beating). cp. airutar
airum ki-a (transitive verb) to inherit; to succeed; to take over; to adopt; (Ateso Atororo) to take possession of; to seize. airum ajakaanut: to take over power or leadership. erum ngol atapon: he has contracted leprosy. erum nges adeka: she/he has caught a disease. erum nges etida: she/he has become hysterical. erumata nges ileic: she/he is ashamed or shy. erum nges asulyany: she/he is lucky, has a stroke of luck; she/he is fortunate. aisurum: to make to seize; to make to succeed; to make to inherit. aisurum ileic: to make ashamed or disgraced. aisurum adeka: to infect; to give disease; to convey disease. aiturumun: to hand over. 
airumiar ki-a (transitive verb) to appropriate, seize, embezzle; to take possession of. 
airumit ki-a (transitive verb) (Ateso Atororo) to possess; to hold, keep, or own; to reign over. irumitos esapat ileic: the boy is ashamed; the boy is shy.
airumun ki-a (transitive verb) to take possession of; to chase and be at par; to succeed to or to inherit; (Ateso Atororo) to take hold of. 
airumurum ki-a (transitive verb) to handle (of anything). kinyek airumurum ikaboro: don’t handle my things. cp. aiminimin, aitingiting: to finger.
airung ki-o (intransitive verb) to rest; to have a rest. 
airungosit (plural airungeta) (noun F) a resting place; a stopover. 
airuny ki-a (transitive verb) to urge, incite, encourage; to impel, press; to stimulate, goad, drive to. ejeni etelepat ngol airuny imongin: that boy knows how to drive oxen. 
airunyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to urge for, incite; to drive for, etc. cp. aisuny. 
airunyar ki-a (transitive verb) to urge away; to jostle, propel, take away quickly; to expedite; to drive away; to cast, goad away, send away; (of a car) to accelerate; to drive fast; to hurry on; to spur. (reflexive verb) (of a car) to go fast; to accelerate. airunyar akeju: to run fast. airunyun akeju: to come quickly, bring quickly. erunyun amotoka kwap: the car free-wheeled down the hill at great speed. 
airunyitoi (intransitive verb) to rush about; to run about, be fussy. irunyitoi ngesi bala edaan akain: she/he rushes about like one who is going to bury a co-wife. cp. aitunyitoi, aiilitoi.
airup ki-a (transitive verb) to put inside; to insert, or tuck in. eja luirupete akanin oisawon: there are pick-pockets about. 
airupakin ki-a (transitive verb) to insert, push in, stick in, thread through (as thread through eye of the needle or a ring through the nose of an animal). 
airupar ki-a (transitive verb) to push or put through; to push in or tuck in. (intransitive verb) to wrestle. airupar akonye: to look through a hole. akoto eong airupar kajo: I want to wrestle with you. 
airupe ki-a (intransitive verb) to report; to disclose hidden crime; to tell on, tell tales about, be tale-bearer; to be a sneak, a tell-tale; to agitate. irupei ijo: you are an agitator (reporter). 
airupeanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fond or inclined to duplicity or double-standards. cp. airupe. 
airupurup ki-a (transitive verb) to push in or into (as of potato into fire). cp. airupakin. 
airuru ki-o (transitive verb) to plunder, steal; to raid, rob; to burn quickly or for a short time; to burn something very quickly; to roast quickly. kiruruoto emaido ngol: quickly roast those groundnuts. 
airuruakin ki-a (transitive verb) to eat a little; to sip a little; to snatch a little food; to have a snack. cp. aisoswakin.
airurum ki-a (intransitive verb) to sound in a deep voice; to groan; to grumble, rumble, roar, growl, purr, thunder, murmur, or buzz. irurumai akuj: it thunders. cp. airetun: to peal, i.e. make a high-pitched sound once. 
airurumakin ki-a (transitive verb) to throw at (of anything), pelt with. airurumaun: to throw this way or down. (reflexive verb) to fall down from. 
airurwo ki-o (transitive verb) to raid; to plunder; to pillage and ransack. 
airurwokin ki-o (transitive verb) to help in a raid; to raid for; to plunder somewhere. 
airurwonut1 (noun F) fondness of plundering, stealing, or robbing. 
airurwonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be fond of or inclined to rob. 
airut1 ki-a (transitive verb) to dismiss, expel, or send away; to discard, reject; (of a car driver) to drive fast. 
airut2 ko-o (transitive verb) to uproot, pull up by the roots, or force out. karusi eong etengei: hunger is tugging at my entrails. 
airutakin ki-a (transitive verb) to fling at or down (as of a stone); to drive towards somebody; to throw at; to throw down with a thud. 
airutar ki-a (transitive verb) to drive away, throw away, expel; to dismiss, force away (by shouting or beating). cp. airukutar
airuturut ki-o (transitive verb) to run (of many people together). ai bo iruturuteete itunga?: where are people running to? 
airwa ko-a (transitive verb) to wear on shoulder (as of a blanket or sheet); to put (clothing) on over the shoulder. 
airwad ko-a (transitive verb) to make dirty; to dirty. 
airwairwa ki-a (transitive verb) to besprinkle; to bedew; to spray. airwairwa apua: to lay the dust by sprinkling water (intransitive verb) (of rain) to drizzle. 
airwait (noun F) a drizzle. cp. akarwait, elimilim.
airwak ki-a (transitive verb) to blink; (of eyes) to wink. airwak akonye: to blink eyes. 
airwakakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to blink at somebody or something. 
airwakakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to overlook. arwakak eong ekakalaamu: I overlooked my pencil (did not notice it, though it was there). 
airwakirwak ki-a (transitive verb) to keep blinking eyes; to riddle with holes. 
airwana ki-a (transitive verb) to multiply; to do multiplication. irwana atipet: once. irwana aare: twice; double. irwana akany: five times. irwana ipu: many times; often. kirwanaata 2 ka 2: multiply 2 by 2.
airwang ko-a (transitive verb) to bite painfully; to sting. cp. aikony. 
airwap ki-a (transitive verb) to give a hard blow; to box; to beat, club. airwap akit: to slap the ear. cp. aibap.
airwat ki-a (transitive verb) to plaster (a wall). irwasi ngesi etogoke: she/he is plastering her/his house. airwatakin: to plaster on, throw mud on (the wall). 
airwet ko-a (transitive verb) to pull off (as of button of shirt or anything); to snap at; to tear bits off something; to snatch, pull off, seize hastily. abu emir korwet emukule: the rat tore bits of the hide. kolot airwet anya: go and pull the grass (from the roof). arwetar: to pull away, snatch away, snap away; to disrupt. 
airwodorwod ki-o (transitive verb) to prod in vain, prick in vain (as one looking for a jigger). 
airwoirwo ki-o (intransitive verb) to become mouldy; to become mildewy. 
airwopokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to become empty (of stomach or tyre). cp. aidwopokin. 
airyan ko-a (intransitive verb) to be on fire; to be ablaze. cp. aiirian. 
airyear ki-a (transitive verb) to grind into bits or smithereens. 
airyoronut ki-o (intransitive verb) to be talkative; to be garrulous. 
ais (singular noun F) open uninhabited area; the wilderness or bushes. 
aisa1 (noun F) a perfume (cologne, essence, incense, scent). 
aisa2 ko-a (transitive verb) to have a nice smell; to be fragrant; to smell sweetly; to have a nice odour; to be odoriferous. eur ngesi saa: she/he smells nicely. 
aisa3 ko-a (transitive verb) to nurse; to rear a child. aisa idwe: to rear or take care of children; to baby-sit. esae akokor ikemiyoi: the hen is feeding its chicks.
aisab ko-a (transitive verb) to exceed the measure; to give too much. aisab akiro: to tell a lie; to fib; to lie. cp. alyokon; aidep; aikwam. 
aisac ko-a (transitive verb) to forsake; to refrain from (sexual intercourse); to leave alone, desert, abandon, renounce, or reject; to avoid; to get fed up with. atemonon esacit okilenike: a woman who has just given birth refrains from sexual intercourse. asac akokor ngin akebeei kodula: that hen has abandoned its eggs in the granary.
aisag ki-a (transitive verb) to thrust thorns or pointed objects on or into; to treat roughly. 
aisagakin ki-a (transitive verb) to give rough treatment. apotu isirikaalei kisagakis Yesu aboko naka ikukwa: the guards pressed the crown of thorns on Jesus’ head. 
aisagisag ki-a (transitive verb) to tie loosely, slacken (as of something well-tied). cp. ailajilaj; aijarijar. 
aisagisagun ki-o (reflexive verb) to get loose; to slacken. 
aisak ko-a (transitive verb) to reap, harvest, or cut millet or sorghum. cp. aitob: aidweny: to harvest sorghum. aideng emaido: to harvest groundnuts. aikur acok arai emuogo: to harvest potatoes or cassava.
aisal ko-a (intransitive verb) to be missing; to be absent from; to be left over; to play truant; to abide, remain, survive, or stay away. esalit ngesi ore: she/he remained at home. cp. aidong.
aisam ki-a (transitive verb) to prickle, itch (like nettles), or to smart (the popular word used is aisamisam). 
aisamisam ki-a (transitive verb) to prickle, itch (like nettles), or to smart; to eat sour vegetables (especially emalakang) without groundnut or simsim sauce. 
aisang ko-a (transitive verb) to end, come to an end, terminate, or culminate; to cease, conclude, or close. cp. ainang 
aisangang ki-a (intransitive verb) to be on pins and needles, be anxious, or tremble; to be on the alert, be ready (as of thorns to prick, or of soldiers to attack, or of hornets to sting). cp. amaran. 
aisany ki-a (intransitive verb) to tease or fluff (as of cotton) cp. aidu. 
aisanyakin kwap ki-o (reflexive verb) (of a shabby, decrepit or ragged person) to fall down. 
aise1 ko-a (transitive verb) to pick out or select; to choose; to sort out; to elect. aise epaaba: to sort cotton. aise ikur kobaale: to segregate; to be unfair; to be biased (literally, to pick out maggots from mushrooms). komam aise ikur kobaale: without discrimination or segregating; at random.
aise2 ko-o (transitive verb) to stretch out a skin to dry; to peg out a skin or hide. aise emukule: to peg out an animal skin or hide to dry. cp. aimanyimany emukule: to tease (fold and twist) a dry animal hide in order to soften it.
aiseer ki-a (transitive verb) to cheat; to deceive. aiseer iboro igwelanari: (of a trader) to cheat buyers by underweight or not filling to capacity.
aisej ki-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to provoke into a quarrel or a fight (through bad acts or harsh words). aisej einer: to incite or provoke with bad language. 
aisejakin ki-a (transitive verb) (used with singular or plural object) to provoke, vex, affront, aggravate, anger, annoy, chafe, or enrage by words or actions. aisejakin akiro: to provoke someone with harsh language.
aisek ko-a (transitive verb) to pick, select, choose, or take out of. cp. aise.
aisekek ki-a (transitive verb) to beg (like a dog – with paws up); to stand outside (like a beggar); to humble oneself. ibusakinit oni aisekek kakonye Edeke: we should humble ourselves before God (stand like beggars). 
aisekel ki-o (transitive verb) to mock or ridicule (as by putting out tongue, telling off in public, or any other way). inyo bo kisekelio ijo eong?: why do you ridicule me? cp. aisekisek, akwenar. 
aisekelikin ki-o (transitive verb) to disappoint; to refuse (with some boasting or bragging involved); to put to shame. kesekeliki ngesi eong: she/he said she/he could do without me, i.e. she/he has told me off. cp. ainyakin. 
aisekelonut1 (noun F) mockery; derisiveness; ridicule; contempt.
aisekelonut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of mocking or putting someone to shame. 
aisekelor ki-a (transitive verb) to show off, mock at, grouse at, insult. isekelor ijo akonibar: you show off your riches. 
aisekisek ki-a (transitive verb) to lash with the tongue; to browbeat; to tell off (a beggar); to mock (a beggar). ‘ekot Iteso kimurokis nuka aitaraun eong ekirigi kec karai mam kesi epedorete aitac eong,’ ebala je isekelo: the Iteso should forget the idea of making me a prime minister if they cannot pay for my services, he told them off.
aisen ko-o (transitive verb) to deal a heavy blow; to thump. 
aiseny ko-a (intransitive verb) to be or become thin; to lose weight; to grow thin or lean; to be emaciated; (of body) to wither or be meagre. 
aisi1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of grain) to germinate; to sprout or take root. 
aisi2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to escape secretly; to run away; to disappear; to abscond. asiata ipakasin: the porters have run away. 
aisial ki-a (transitive verb) to badger, harass, bother, hector, or harry; to pain, pester, scold, persecute, or to blister. kesial eong amusenu: the hoe blistered me. cp. aisiyal: to amuse.
aisialar ki-a (transitive verb) to blister. kesial eong aswam na: this work distresses me (or is painful). cp. ailunyar, aisial.
aisialasit (plural aisialas) (noun F) a blister; an irritation, pique, displeasure, distress. 
aisiba ki-a (intransitive verb) (of Muslims) to fast or abstain from food; to do without food (for religious reasons). 
aisibak ki-a (causative verb) (to cause) to line up; to put in line, abreast. 
aisiboikin ki-a (causative verb) to seat; to cause to sit down. 
aisicakun akiro ki-a (causative verb) to get somebody into trouble; to bring trouble upon. 
aisicaset (plural aisicaseta) (noun F) an anchor; a support; a prop. 
aisicasit ki-a (causative verb) to strengthen; to confirm. esicasit eong nuinera ngesi: I confirm (what she/he says) her/his statement. 
aisicat ki-a (causative verb) to educate; to confirm; to strengthen, fortify, or consolidate. 
aisidel ki-a (transitive verb) to make, to cause to show off, etc; to display or tantalize to. aisidel akanin: to manicure. 
aisidelel ki-o (causative verb) to make conspicuous; to expose. 
aisididiar ki-a (causative verb) (of troops, an instrument, etc) to penetrate very deep into. 
aisidik ki-o (causative verb) to make to be thick; to thicken; to make matters worse; to intensify. aisidik akiro: to make matters worse.
aisidik ki-o (intransitive verb) to make a person to drink much. 
aisidony ki-o (intransitive verb) to pound fine; (of cattle, goats, sheep, etc) to ruminate, chew the cud. akiteng isidonyi inyamat: the cow ruminates its food. aisidony emuogo: re-pound cassava, to grind fine. 
aisidoun ki-o (transitive verb) to help a woman deliver. 
aisidounet (plural aisidouneta) (noun F) maternity; labour ward; delivery room. cp. aidois
aisieb ki-a (transitive verb) to hack with hoe, big knife, or axe; to cut off; to dig spaced holes. aisieb epaaba: to cut away the old cotton stalks. 
aisiebanar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep slashing off; to chop off much. 
aisiebunun atap ki-a (transitive verb) to take big lumps of posho or bread. 
aisiec ki-a (transitive verb) to exchange, barter; to give tit for tat; to pay in kind, barter. 
aisiej akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to be rude, impolite; to use rough language. cp. aisej
aisiejakin akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to treat in a rude manner; to be rude to; to provoke, seek a quarrel; to rant. 
aisiejun akiro ki-a (transitive verb) to speak sharply; to rant, storm, insult. akiro nukisiejuna: rough, impolite, insulting language. 
aisiep ki-a (intransitive verb) to go through high grass (where there is no path). auta eong aisiep: I am going through the high grass. isiepi ngesi kais: she/he walks through the tall grass. 
aisiepakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to put something in the high grass; to throw, build in the high grass. inyo bo isiepakinia ekonitogo nen?: why do you build your house there in the wilds? aisiepakin akonye: to look askance at. 
aisiepakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall into high grass; to drop in high grass. 
aisig ki-a (intransitive verb) to have a hiccup; to jam or wedge often. isigi ngesi noi: she/he has a terrible hiccup. 
aisigakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to shut door with rubbing noise.  
aisigakin2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to get stuck suddenly. esigakin emeleku okomyo: the plough got suddenly stuck in a tree stump. esigakin bian akosimotoka orit: our car got stuck in the mud yesterday. aisigakin kwap: to be grounded (of ship or car, unable to move).
aisigakinet (plural aisigakineta) (noun F) a hitch; a glitch; a minor malfunction; a setback. 
aisigal ki-a (causative verb) to help, assist, take part in, share (work); to give a helping hand. 
aisigalikin ki-a (causative verb) to assuage, alleviate, mitigate, lessen; to relieve, soothe, ease, palliate, or moderate; to help (in work). konyam idia yen kisigalikinor etengei: eat this little food to alleviate your hunger. kocakakinai idiodapaic kesigalikinor aterot: give me some old piece of cloth (rag) to lessen the cold. emamei yenikesigalikit eong aswam: there is nobody to give me a helping hand with my work.
aisiganar (reflexive verb) to have a persistent hiccup. 
aisigar ki-a (intransitive verb) to have a hiccup (once only). 
aisigeg ki-a (transitive verb) to cause, bring astringency or constipation. 
aisigir ki-a (causative verb) to cause to refuse, deny, object, etc; to cause to fail, to be unsuccessful, difficult. 
aisigira ki-a (transitive verb) to move slowly, lazily (by intention); to be sluggish (in movement); to show unwillingness by slow movement. 
aisigirokin ki-a (causative verb) to make to resist, to be hard. aisigirokin elopet bon: to deny oneself. 
aisiguikin ki-a (causative verb) to scandalise; to make to stumble. 
aisiig ki-a (intransitive verb) to wager as a guarantee of payment; to mortgage.
aisiigakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to mortgage to; to give as security for a debt (especially in gambling).
aisiigaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to get as mortgage from; to receive as security for a debt (especially in gambling).
aisiilior ki-o (intransitive verb) to make unconscious or put under anaesthetics. 
aisiiloor ki-o (causative verb) to cause to suffocate; to stun; to give anaesthetics to. 
aisiilooret (plural aisiilooreta) (noun F) anaesthesia. 
aisiinaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to make moist; dampen; make mouldy. 
aisiir ki-a (causative verb) to give to taste. cp. aisiirikin: to inform, instruct; to notify, give message. alosi eong aisiir ijo ekabela: I am going to make you taste my cane (give you a beating). 
aisiiraar ki-a (causative verb) to inform, warn, acquaint; to let know; to notify; to cause to hear. 
aisiiraaret (plural aisiiraareta) (noun F) a message; a communiqué; a note, letter, missive; a memorandum; notation. cp. aitejenaaret. 
aisiiria ki-a (causative verb) to make dizzy, giddy; to swing round, drive round; to make frivolous. kesiiriai eong esigala: smoking makes me giddy, dizzy. 
aisiiriar ki-a (reflexive verb) to spin round. 
aisiirikin ki-a (causative verb) to inform, communicate, let known, notify. cp. aitejenikin. aisiiraar
aisiit1 (singular noun F) pains of prolonged childbirth; prolonged labour. 
aisiit2 ki-o (transitive verb) to cause to need, desire or long for.
aisiitikin ki-a (causative verb) to remind someone; to cause someone to remember; to prompt somebody. aisiitikin itunganan iponesio luajokak: to remind a person of good manners or etiquette.
aisiitoor ki-a (causative verb) to remind of something in the past; to cause to reminisce. 
aisiitun ki-a (causative verb) to remind; to jog your memory. 
aisiiya ki-a (intransitive verb) to fizz; to fizzle; to steam food; to exhaust through working long. 
aisiiyakinet (plural aisiiyakineta) (noun F) a crust of bread; a simmering. cp. emurududu: a crust. 
aisijenikin ikoku ki-a (causative verb) to humour a child; to pamper a child. 
aisijoga ki-a (causative verb) to excite, incite, provoke, urge on, kindle; to fluster, churn, agitate. 
aisijopijop ki-o (causative verb) to gradate, rank, or classify. cp. aijopijop
aisik ki-a (transitive verb) to ram or press in (as of cotton in bag); to blow up, or inflate (tyres, football); to fill up (holes); to block up (anything); to stamp down earth or cotton. aisik aki: to block ears; to play deaf. isikik ngol aki: he is deaf. aisik amopiira: to inflate a tyre. 
aisika ki-a (transitive verb) to threaten, hesitate to slap; to feign a slap or a blow. abu ngesi kesikaa eong: she/he feigned to strike me. 
aisikaar ki-a (transitive verb) to threaten or feign to beat; to hesitate. aisikaar alimun akiro: to refrain from saying anything. esikaasi kesi etelepat ngol: they threatened to beat that boy. 
aisikad ki-a (causative verb) to lessen, make less, or make insufficient. 
aisikadikin ki-a (causative verb) to make less for; to bargain; to pay less. 
aisikakin ki-a (transitive verb) to stamp down (as of cotton in bag); to ram in, block, inflate. kisikak ekagaali: inflate the tyre of my bicycle. esikakit eong aola eporoto: I am hoarse from a cough (reflexive verb) to be blocked. esikakinos eong ikumes: my nose is blocked (due to flu). 
aisikamun ki-a (causative verb) to infect; to make to catch. aisikamun ileic: to make ashamed. cp. aisurum (ileic, adek). 
aisiket (plural aisiketa) (noun F) (Usuk) a bicycle pump. cp. apoopi. 
aisikin ki-a (transitive verb) to allow; to permit. 
aisikisik ki-a (transitive verb) to press down very hard, pump up hard; to beat up with closed fists thoroughly. kisikisik akamopiira: pump my tyre hard. 
aisikun ki-a (transitive verb) to press down; to hold back, halt. cp. atikun. 
aisikwarun ki-a (causative verb) to revive someone else (from fainting or exhaustion). 
aisikweny ki-a (causative verb) to cause to warn; to cause to wake up; to cause to remain awake. 
aisil ki-a (intransitive verb) to whistle.
aisilakin ki-a (transitive verb) to forbid, stop from doing; to whistle at, catcall. kisilak idwe aponenen ne tai: forbid the children from coming here without reason. 
aisilar ki-a (intransitive verb) to consider bad; to abstain from; to stop doing; to resolve never to do a thing again; to be sorry for; to repent; to abominate. esila eong akaronusio: I am sorry for my sins. 
aisilel ki-a (causative verb) to make happy, gladden, animate, cheer up, console; to make a proper drain; to drain properly. kitelel aleles ejok: make a proper drain. cp. aitelel.
aisiliil ki-a (causative verb) to cause to swing round. cp. ailiil. 
aisililing ki-a (causative verb) to hush; to silence, muffle, or suppress; to mute, stifle, or deaden. 
aisilit ki-a (intransitive verb) to make up one’s mind not to; to make a rule not to. esilit eong alosit ngina: I made up my mind never to go there. 
aisiloc ki-o (transitive verb) to juggle; to tie crosswise. 
aisilok ki-o (causative verb) to help to redeem; to help to pay back; to cause to redeem. 
aisilokin1 ki-o (transitive verb) to have in between; to hide in between, or on (reflexive verb) to disappear in or between things; to hide between. abu eong kesilok ekakalaamu toma onya: I threw my pencil into the high grass. esilokin akakwara toma okitwi: my pen dropped in the bush (and disappeared). 
aisilokin2 ocor ki-o (reflexive verb) to disappear in the water (to drown); to dive. 
aisilokony ki-a (transitive verb) to cause entanglement; to cause confusion, disorder. 
aisilolony ki-a (causative verb) to disable; to disqualify. 
aisim ki-a (intransitive verb) to perspire, sweat, swelter. 
aisimaar ki-a (intransitive verb) to approve, agree, take fancy to; to like, be pleased with; to compliment, congratulate, extol, or eulogise. 
aisimaaret (plural aisimaareta) (noun F) a compliment; a congratulation; an eulogy, commendation, endorsement, praise, tribute, homage, panegyric, or honour. 
aisimam ki-a (intransitive verb) to be a waiter or waitress; to serve at table or to wait upon (at table). cp. aijaanakin. 
aisimik ki-a (causative verb) to prevent; to cause to refuse; to ban. kesimik eong adeka ainyam: sickness prevents me from eating. 
aisiminun ki-o (causative verb) to lure, attract, entice, or seduce. 
aisimisim ki-a (intransitive verb) (of the body) to have goose flesh; to begin to perspire; to begin to sweat (beads of perspiration breaking out). 
aisimon ki-o (causative verb) to satisfy, assure, appease, or content. 
aisimonikin ki-a (causative verb) to satisfy with food or anything; to convince somebody; to satisfy, assure, appease, or content. kisimonik ijo eong: you have convinced me, satisfied me. 
aisimorikikin ki-a (causative verb) to reconcile, bring together or patch up in a relationship. 
aisinapikin ki-o (causative verb) to appease; to placate; to settle. 
aisinepun ki-a (causative verb) to kindle a fire; to start a fire; to set alight or ablaze; to fire up (a car), i.e. to accelerate. enepu einer: the conversation is getting hot; they are quarrelling. eneput akiro: matters are becoming serious. inepunit ejakait kore: the chief is raging at his home. cp. ainokokin.
aisiner ki-a (causative verb) to cause to talk; to seduce; to engage somebody; to betroth; to woo; to persuade. aisiner apese: to ask a girl for marriage or fornication; to court a girl; to betroth; to woo. 
aisinerikin ki-a (causative verb) to intercede for; to pray for; to seduce for somebody; to arrange for. aisinerikin apese: to seduce a girl for somebody. 
aisinga ki-a (transitive verb) to deal blows; to thump (many times, often). kesinga bian ejakait eong: my husband thumped me up yesterday. cp. aibunga.
aisingaren ki-o (causative verb) to push forward, cause to lead, promote, make one the leader. 
aisingaun ki-a (transitive verb) to deal a heavy blow; to beat once only. 
aisingaunun ki-a (transitive verb) to deal heavy blows; to thump many times, often. kesingaununit bian ejakait eong: my husband thumped me up yesterday. 
aisingoror ki-o (transitive verb) to deprive; to cause loss of; to cause to miss. 
aisinokokin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to put on fire; to cause a fire. 
aisinye ki-o (transitive verb) to become greedy, stingy, selfish. 
aisinyeonor ki-o (transitive verb) to become greedy, stingy, selfish. 
aisinyeonut1 (noun F) greed; voracity; selfishness; stinginess; avarice. 
aisinyeonut2 ki-o (transitive verb) to be greedy, selfish, stingy, avaricious. 
aisinyikokin ki-a (causative verb) to encourage; to make persevere; to urge on, goad on; to prod or spur on; to cause to become worse (suffering, etc). esinyikoki emuudu Ikaramoja aingat: the gun has encouraged Karimojong to raid.
aisiok ki-a (intransitive verb) to go early; to be early; to do early. kisiok atan: go early to the well. kisiok ore: go home early. cp. aidil.
aisiokun ki-a (intransitive verb) to come early; to wake up early. cp. adilun.
aisiol ki-o (intransitive verb) (of a person) to rape (criminal and forceful carnal knowledge); to force a woman to have sexual intercourse against her will. esiol esapat loka ikar 30 amojong naka ikar 52: a man of 30 rapes a woman aged 52.
aisiom1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to read (a book, etc); to school.
aisiom2 ko-a (transitive verb) to talk behind someone’s back; to slander; to backbite; to disparage; to malign. 
aisioni ki-o (transitive verb) to give, distribute to many; to forgive (one or many), pardon; to have pity on; to have mercy on, absolve. aisioni aronusio: to forgive sins. esionie eong luk’ican ikaboro: I distribute my things to the poor. kisionioi eong aronusyoka: forgive my sins. cp. aitim.
aisionikin ki-a (transitive verb) to give to out of pity; to give alms; to donate, distribute to; to give, present to; to pardon or have mercy on. kisionikinai eong da idinyamat: give me also a little food. cp. aitimokin. 
aisip ko-o (transitive verb) to deal a blow; to put into the ground (as of poles); to erect, set up, put up. aisip epur: to give a heavy blow in the back; to hit somebody in the back. aisip etogo: to start a new house by putting in the poles; to build a foundation. cp. aidip, ainang.
aisipan ki-a (intransitive verb) to be many; to have a gathering; to meet together; to crowd together; to be in a crowd; to flock together. isipanitos ikweny: the birds flock together. isipanitos ijaka oreka: many chiefs have gathered at my house. 
aisipaper ki-o (causative verb) to befriend; to make a friend; to court, woo, allure, or attract. 
aisipej ki-a (causative verb) (of the host) to entertain visitors; to host visitors to a party. aisipej ipejok: to host visitors.
aisipiran ki-a (causative verb) to go in crowds. isipiranitos itunga agwelanaret: a crowd of people went to the market. 
aisir1 ki-a (transitive verb) to adorn, wear, or cover oneself with (not with cloth, but with ornaments); to decorate; to embellish. isirit nges imidaalin akuwan: she/he adorns herself/himself with medals. 
aisir2 ki-a (transitive verb) to knead bread with a mingling stick (where a little more than enough flour was added); to press together; to trample, ram. ingai kebuni ameikin akituk aisir akamana?: who brought cows to trample my garden? cp. ainyong: to knead bread by hand. cp. ailir.
aisirab ki-a (causative verb) to accuse; to summon to court; to make talk. 
aisirakin ki-a (transitive verb) to make hard for; to stamp hard for; to trample for. 
aisirereng ki-a (causative verb) to bless; to make lucky; to wish luck to. 
aisiriam ki-a (causative verb) to go to meet (and say welcome or to help to carry luggage); to cause to meet; to cause to clash or comflict. 
aisiriamikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to meet with, put together, about; to cause to surround; to surprise. abu eong kesiriamik ikokolak ejengete ekamong: I caught the thieves skinning my bull. 
aisiriamun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to come upon; to cause to encounter or to face.
aisiric ki-a (transitive verb) to spout; to spit or spew often. emoru loisirici ekuron kede akim: an active volcano.
aisiricaar ki-a (transitive verb) to spout away; to spit or spew through the teeth. 
aisiricikin ki-a (transitive verb) to inject or ejaculate; to spit at somebody. 
aisiridikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to die; to cause to expire. 
aisirieb ki-a (causative verb) to cause pain or sorrow; to hurt, inflict pain, or to cause to be painful. 
aisiriengun ki-a (causative verb) to startle or to frighten; to take aback; to discomfit; to excite, foment trouble, thrill. cp. airiengun. 
aisirim ki-o (causative verb) to cause to go round; to wind up (as of gramophone player); to whirl; to swing round. 
aisirimet (plural aisirimeta) (noun F) something to turn with; a hinge; a spindle; a gyroscope; a handle of a gramophone.
aisirimikin ki-o (causative verb) to turn round; to wind up (as of gramophone player); to whirl. 
aisirion ki-o (causative verb) to besmirch; to make black or dirty; to disapprove. 
aisisia1 (singular noun F) education; teaching and learning; enlightenment. 
aisisia2 ki-a (transitive verb) to study; to learn; to imitate; to mimic. isisiai ngesi Agereesan: she/he is learning English. isisiaete idwe engwalas: the children are imitating the lame man. 
aisisiakin ki-a (transitive verb) to show or try (not of things); to point out to; to teach once, acquaint with; to lecture. kisisiakinai eong ekosio ngol: teach me that song. cp. aitoodikin (to show – of things only). 
aisisianakin ki-a (transitive verb) to teach, coach, or instruct; to show often; to point out often; to preach; to educate. 
aisisiar ki-a (intransitive verb) (of road, braches) to split into two; (of road) to fork out; to junction, spread out (as of a tree branch). 
aisisias (plural aisisiasia) (noun F) a school classroom; a lecture room. cp. atukot. 
aisisiaun1 (singular noun F) edification; enlightenment. 
aisisiaun2 ki-a (transitive verb) to learn for oneself; to learn something by asking or studying. adau eong aisisiaun Agereesan: I have learned or I have known English. 
aisita ki-a (causative verb) to hire; to employ labour. cp. eitai, aita.
aisiwotokin ki-o (causative verb) to push further away (of anything); to push a little forward or aside.  
aisiya1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of carbonated liquid) to fizz, bubble, or effervesce; (of bread, potato on fire) to fizzle; to frizzle. 
aisiya2 ki-a (transitive verb) to bear patiently; to starve; to go a long time without food; to bear hunger bravely. cp. aikany etengei. 
aisiyal ki-a (causative verb) to entertain or amuse; to humour; to cause delight or pleasure to. aisiyala bon: to amuse yourself.
aisiyalaet (plural aisiyalasia) (noun F) amusement; entertainment; recreation; fun. 
aisiyalamikin ki-a (causative verb) to gratify, congratulate, acclaim; to please; to humour; to thank; to cause delight or pleasure to. 
aisiyalongong ki-o (causative verb) to disquiet; to cause to worry; to grieve, make anxious, long for, etc. 
aisiyap ki-a (causative verb) to delay, defer. 
aisiyapaar ki-a (causative verb) to cause to slow up; to cause delay. 
aisiyekaar ki-a (causative verb) to make to go away; to remove, carry away; to disperse, push forward. 
aisiyengun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to retire from work; to relieve from tension; to suspend or lay off (from work); to give a holiday; to give a rest to; to cause to rest.
aisiyuun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to believe; to persuade, entice; to cause to get saved, i.e. to cause to accept some Christian teaching or doctrine; to cause to accept jesus christ as a saviour. 
aisobwa ki-a (transitive verb) to make use of the eisobwa (fishing basket) in fishing (moving it in and out of water). kesobwai eong akou: I have got a throbbing headache. 
aisod ko-o (transitive verb) to begin, start, commence. kasodoto alosit: let us start off on our journey. 
aisogo ki-o (transitive verb) to catch fish by repeatedly plunging down a bottomless basket (eisobwa) at random. isogoete ikiliok ibilenga: the men are catching catfish with iisobwan baskets.
aisok ki-o (intransitive verb) to arrest progress; to halt; to desist from; to die out; to stop doing, going, leaving off; to discontinue. mam lolo edou esoki: the rain will not stop today. 
aisokisok ki-o (intransitive verb) to leap (as of a bull). 
aisokok ki-o (intransitive verb) to hold the hand ready to grasp something; to be on the point of catching. 
aisokor ki-o (intransitive verb) (of rain) to clear up; to cease raining (going to stop, leave off); (of white ants) to stop swarming. esoko edou: the rain has stopped. esokosi ikong aimin: the white ants have stopped flying out.
aisokot ki-a (transitive verb) to twist (rope, etc); to roll tobacco. aisokot etaba: to roll tobacco in leaves or paper for smoking. isokotaete amojongik esigala: the old women roll tobacco for smoking. 
aisolet (plural aisolen) (noun F) a black-and-white weaverbird, Masked weaver. 
aisolimod ki-o (intransitive verb) (of a gap in the teeth) to be very wide. isolimodot angaarany: the gap (in the teeth) is very wide. 
aisom ko-a (intransitive verb) to dance; to jump up and down; to bounce. esomete itelepai edisiko: the boys are dancing disco music. 
aisongolaar ki-a (intransitive verb) to go somewhere in vain. 
aisongolanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to go or do in vain. 
aisoni ki-o (transitive verb) (used with plural objects) to give as a present; to forgive, pardon, spare, or excuse. kisonioi aronusyoka: forgive my sins. kisonioi: forgive me. 
aisonikin ki-o (transitive verb) to present to; to give to; to forgive. kisonikinai adikiring: give me a little meat. 
aisonio (singular noun F) forgiveness; pardon; amnesty; mercy; pity. cp. aitimio
aisonionut1 (singular noun F) forgiving; leniency; kindness. 
aisonionut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be lenient, forgiving 
aisonyaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of behaviour or dress) to become ancient or outdated. 
aisonyaikit ki-a (intransitive verb) to be ancient or belonging to the far past; to be archaic or outdated. 
aisorir ki-o (intransitive verb) to desist from, cease doing, forbear. akoto eong ainom nges konye abu kesorir: I wanted to beat her/him, but I desisted. (note: not followed by infinitive of verb).
aisorit1 (plural aisorin) (noun F) a circular mark on the skin due to ringworm, eczema, or syphilis. 
aisorit2 (plural aisorito) (noun F) a snake venom (poison). 
aisosolikin ki-o (transitive verb) to overreach, surpass, outdo, or outsmart. 
aisosolo ki-o (transitive verb) to try the impossible. cp. aiwongo.
aisosolonut1 (singular noun F) self-confidence; self-importance; pretentiousness. 
aisosolonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be too daring, too self-reliant, too self-confident; to be too overbearing. 
aisoswa ki-a (intransitive verb) to pretend not to know; (of groundnut plants) to fail to bear seeds. isoswakit lolo emaido okaru lo: the groundnuts harvest is poor this year. cp. einer ejose: ajoseikin akiro.
aisoswakinet (plural aisoswakineta) (noun F) a snack; a bite of food. 
aisotoikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to look like the roof of a granary; to look like an umbrella; to look like a hat. 
aisu ko-a (intransitive verb) to hiss; to make a hissing sound, louder than aisiar. 
aisuar ki-a (intransitive verb) to hiss at; to fart away. 
aisub ko-a (transitive verb) to make or to do; to create; to mould; to form, or to shape. aisub amoti: to mould pots. asubit bala: to pretend, behave like, or resemble; to look like. esubit ngesi bala etyang: she/he is like an animal. esubit bala nyo?: what does it look like? esubit ngesi bala ngai?: whom does she/he resemble (look like)? (the answer can only be followed by a noun, not a pronoun). emong losubet: the sacrificial bull. esubitai ka: it consists of; it is composed of. 
aisuburaar ki-a (transitive verb) to bring trouble; to put in a fix; to urge someone away. 
aisuburiar ki-a (transitive verb) to urge on; to force away; to command, impel, goad, compel, hurry on; to harass, importune (reflexive verb) to be urged on; to be commanded, impelled, compelled, hurried on, importuned. 
aisuburikin ki-a (causative verb) to make to hurry; to hasten; to push on; to goad on, urge forward; to force. esuburiki ejakait adeka kwapekwana: my husband has been taken ill just now. 
aisud1 ki-o (transitive verb) to shove in (anything); to plunge a fishing spear in water (in the hope of spearing a fish). kisud acok toma akim: plunge sweet potatoes in the fire. aisud akiro: to speak nonsense. aisud agaria: to spear fish randomly. 
aisud2 ko-o (transitive verb) to mix; to knead together; to intermingle. aisud akiria: to mix malt, yeast and water in the preparation of beer. aisud emaido: to mix groundnut paste and water in the preparation of sauce. 
aisude ki-o (transitive verb) to push over; to upset, overturn, or upend. 
aisuded ki-o (intransitive verb) to stand on the head; to be upside-down (of objects); to bend down very low. isudedei amot: the pot is upside-down. isudedei amatapaalit: the brick is not horizontal, not spirit-levelled. 
aisudeor ki-o (transitive verb) to upset; to tip, turn or push over (reflexive verb) to topple over; to fall down; to turn a somersault. 
aisudokin ki-a (transitive verb) to push inside; to force into. isudokini lokatatan asuat akim: the blacksmith thrusts the iron into the fire (reflexive verb) to force oneself into or amongst; to intrude or gatecrash. 
aisudonokin ki-a (transitive verb) to accuse falsely; to accuse at random (rightly or wrongly). 
aisudun ki-o (transitive verb) to speak at random; to say something not to the point; to assert suddenly, unreasonably; to do accidentally. mam eong esudunit ngun: I am not saying this at random (without reason). 
aisuduny ki-a (causative verb) to put close together; to put near one another. 
aisudunyikin ki-a (causative verb) to put close together; to arrange. kisudunyinik itelepai: put the boys near each other. 
aisudup ki-o (causative verb) to reduce to powder; to pulverise or grind fine; to grind again. cp. ainyabuk. 
aisudupuk ki-o (causative verb to grind finer; to pulverise. kisudupuk akiria: grind the flour fine. cp. ainyabuk. 
aisudupukoor ki-o (causative verb to grind finer. kisudupukoo akiria: grind the flour fine. cp. ainyabuk. 
aisuguikin ki-a (transitive verb) to scandalise; to make to stumble. 
aisuguikinet (plural aisuguikineta) (noun F) a stumbling block. 
aisugul ki-a (causative verb) (of a man) to flirt with a woman with no intention of marrying; to make love to; to court or woo. 
aisugulokin ki-a (causative verb) to make round (as of a pot); to make to bulge. kojie amot kisugulok akoik: make the pot round (bulge out) (reflexive verb) to make round or pregnant (a woman). cp. asukokin. 
aisuguranut1 (singular noun F) sluggishness; slowness; unwillingness; reluctance. 
aisuguranut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to show unwillingness by slow movement; to be phlegmatic; to be slow; to be sluggish; to show reluctance 
aisujaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away; to take at random. 
aisuk1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to leap, jump, dance, or hop. 
aisuk2 ko-o (reflexive verb) (of body) to be bent up, stooped (as of an animal mounting another). cp. alugurikin. 
aisuk3 ko-o (transitive verb) to bend, fold, or crumple. 
aisukuny ki-a (transitive verb) to push near; to put near; to draw near; to shift near; to move near. 
aisukunyaar ki-a (transitive verb) to push away; to put away; to draw away; to shift away (from speaker); to remove; to take away (causative verb) to cause to move away; to move something or someone away.
aisukunyikin ki-a (transitive verb) to move near to; to push near to; to draw near to; to shift near to; to put near to; to promote (reflexive verb) to be move near to; to be removed. aisukunyikin akeju: to move away stretched legs. 
aisukunyun ki-a (transitive verb) to welcome a visitor; to greet or receive a guest. aisukunyun ipejok: to welcome guests.
aisukunyuun ki-a (transitive verb) to pull near; to draw near; to shift this way (towards speaker); to bring near; to befriend. 
aisulyanyikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fortunate, lucky with; to be blessed with, prosperous in. kasulyanyiki eong adumun ijo kane: I am lucky to find you here. 
aisumun ki-a (causative verb) to promise; to pledge; to assure. cp. aitumun. 
aisumunet (plural aisumuneta) (noun F) a promise; a pledge; an assurance. cp. aitumunet
aisunup ki-a (causative verb) to cause to listen; to cause to obey; to cause to consent, etc. 
aisuny ki-a (intransitive verb) to hasten; to be quick; to hurry; to do quickly; to sniff up. aisuny ekume: to sniff up. 
aisunyakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to do quickly; to do something in a hurry; to prepare quickly. kisunyak atap kanyamata: cook some bread quickly so that we eat. 
aisunyar ki-a (intransitive verb) to do in a hurry; to do quickly; to hasten. kisunyas emaido ngol aipac: shell that groundnuts quickly. aso ekileng lo kisunyariata aijeng emong: here is a knife for you to hurry up skinning the bull. 
aisunyit ki-o (transitive verb) to do hurriedly; to do quickly. isunyit ngesi ainyam bala ekingok: she/he eats quickly like a dog. mam idwe isunyito aikamun akiro: the pupils are slow in understanding. (imperative: kisunyite; plural kisunyitosi: hurry up). 
aisunyun ki-a (transitive verb) to improvise (anything). 
aisup1 ki-a (transitive verb) to woo; to flirt; to take a fancy to (a person); to cuddle. 
aisup2 ko-o (transitive verb) (of a dog) to look for; to track down; to ferret out; to seek (by smell). esupi ekingok etyang: the dog is sniffing up the animal’s scent. 
aisupar ki-a (transitive verb) to woo away, enamour, infatuate. sirikisupaa apese ngin: do not woo away that girl. (reflexive verb) to elope; to be enamoured with. 
aisupu ki-a (causative verb) to make many; to cause to be many. ekoto ikoku ngin aisupu akiro: that child wants to make many excuses. 
aisupun ki-a (transitive verb) to attract; to allure (as boy and girl); to do amorously; to woo for oneself. 
aisur1 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of cereal plants) to flower; to grow seed; to begin to ripen (of cereals). 
aisur2 ko-o (transitive verb) to attack, hit, and scatter; to put to flight. abu eong kasur ikokolak: I scattered the thieves. 
aisurit (plural aisurin) (noun F) an orange weaverbird. 
aisurukuny ki-a (transitive verb) (archaic) to approach closely; to come near; to follow closely. cp. aapikin. 
aisurukunyaar ki-a (transitive verb) (archaic) to interrupt (any activity but not speech); cut short (any action but not of speech); to expedite; to hurry on; to make to hum. 
aisurum ki-a (causative verb) to infect; to shame. aisurum ileic: to embarrass; to make ashamed; to abash. 
aisurunyaar ki-a (transitive verb) to exhort; to cause to go away. 
aisusu ki-o (intransitive verb) to defecate (to go to the urinal or toilet); to piss or urinate; to shit; to pass urine or stool. 
aisusua ki-a (transitive verb) to disguise bitter medicine by drinking something sweet; to counteract bitterness. 
aisusuar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away bad taste by eating something sweet; to remove ill-feelings from someone by giving them something pleasant. cp. aisuswaar
aisusum ki-a (intransitive verb) to go up in smoke; to belch out smoke; to be smoky. adum eong etogo isusumai: I found the house on fire or belching smoke. 
aisusuor ki-o (intransitive verb) to kill by physical attack. ebungaata kwi je aisusuor: they beat him to death. 
aisuswaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away bad taste by eating something sweet; to remove ill-feelings from someone by giving them something pleasant. cp. aisusuar 
aisut1 ki-a (transitive verb) to smear; to rub on; to paint. kisut ekia akuwanakon: smear your body with medicine (embrocation). aisut agweeret: to cane someone; to give somebody a serious beating.
aisut2 ko-o (transitive verb) (of in-laws) to come and demand dowry; to claim. aisut apese: to partake of a girl’s dowry. 
aisutakin ki-a (transitive verb) to rub on; to smear on or in; to paint. aisutakin agweeret: to cane; to beat.
aisutar ki-a (transitive verb) to wipe away or off; to rub off. cp. aiputar.
aisuubus ki-a (transitive verb) to trade; to buy and sell. 
aisuuka (plural aisuukai) (noun F) (Usuk) a shawl; a bedsheet. 
aisuulaar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to fart or pass wind quietly. 
aisuulaar2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to overgrow weeds or bush. isuulaarit ekonire: your homestead is overgrown with bushes. 
aisuurikin ki-a (causative verb) to let somebody smell or sniff a thing. cp. aituurikin.
aisuwa ki-a (intransitive verb) (of fire) to smoke; (of smoke) to rise. 
aisuwa ki-a (intransitive verb) to emit thick smoke. isuwai eketogo: her/his house is belching smoke; her/his house is smoky. cp. aisusum. 
aisuwaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to fart or pass wind, to blow smoke on somebody or something; to smoke out. cp. awuikin
aisuwakin ki-a (transitive verb) (of white ants) to swarm; to smoke out; to cook a short time; to make smoke for; to cause smoke to rise. aisuwakin etogo: to smoke out a house. aisuwakin atitipu: to smoke out an anthill. 
aiswag ki-a (transitive verb) to rub clean; to rub bright; to polish metal; to scrub hard. aiswag ikel: to brush or clean the teeth. aiswag akuwan: to rub the body (with soap and sponge).
aiswagar ki-a (transitive verb) to scour or scrub; to clean; to polish a metal object (reflexive verb) to become clean; to be rubbed off; to be polished. 
aiswajakin ki-a (transitive verb) to put anywhere carelessly; to put something in a dirty place; to dump; to put at random; to put topsy-turvy (reflexive verb) to commence blindly; to start blindly; to do unprepared; to do blindly (without thinking of the outcome). eswajakin ngol toma akiro: he got himself into trouble (blindly). 
aiswak ko-a (intransitive verb) to fail; to miss. mam eswaki abunere: she/he will not fail to come. aswakar k’akongu: to have a glimpse at. cp. ainyekin.
aiswal ko-a (transitive verb) to hit or beat with something small but painful. aiswal akiro: to crack a joke; to tell a good joke. aiswal acin: to pass out very stinging wind; to fart terribly.
aiswama ki-a (intransitive verb) to work; to act; to labour (transitive verb) to do; to make, fabricate, fashion, or form. aiswama ibore: to go about something; to do something.
aiswamakin ki-a (transitive verb) to do for; to work for; to labour for; to serve; to make for; to act for. aiswamakin erono: to ill-treat or do bad to; to maltreat. aiswamakin ejok: to do good to; to do a good turn (to repay bad with good actions).
aiswamar ki-a (transitive verb) to surprise or catch on the wrong footing. eswamar ijo mam iswamat: you have been caught idling or having not worked. 
aiswamaroroi ki-o (transitive verb) to get on with something; to go on doing something.
aiswamas (plural aiswamasia) (noun F) a workplace; workshop. 
aiswamaun ki-a (transitive verb) to form, shape, fabricate, mould, fashion for oneself (reflexive verb) to form itself; to come into being; to shape oneself; to be done. mam iboro kere epedorete aiswamaun bonik: all things do not just happen by themselves (some are made or created). 
aiswamun ki-a (transitive verb) (of a guest) to come suddenly and unexpectedly; to be impromptu; to do or say spontaneously or off the cuff. 
aiswap ki-a (transitive verb) to thatch or cover with grass or with anything (intransitive verb) to be overgrown with weeds; to look angry or annoyed; (of weather) to be cloudy. 
aiswapit ki-a (intransitive verb) to be overgrown. iswapit erot: the footpath is overgrown. 
aiswec ki-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to exchange, barter; to give tit for tat; to pay in kind, barter. cp. aisiec
aisweikin ki-a (transitive verb) to send dogs after an animal or man; to incite; urge on. 
aisweiswe ki-a (intransitive verb) to drizzle; to spray or shower. 
aiswet ko-a (transitive verb) to cut off a little; to strike lightly; to flick or snip. 
aiswiswiya ki-a (intransitive verb) to snuffle, snivel. 
aiswogo ki-o (transitive verb) to fish with bottomless basket called eisobwa. 
aiswola ki-a (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to fart or pass wind or gas often. aiswolaar: to pass wind or fart once. cp. aisuulaar.
aiswolol ki-o (intransitive verb) (of hole or door) to be wide open. 
aiswop ki-a (intransitive verb) to look angry; to frown; to be sulky; to be gloomy; to look serious. 
aisworiswor ki-o (transitive verb) to do carelessly or hurriedly. 
aisya1 ki-a (transitive verb) to do for the first time. isyae ngesi alosit naelwana: she/he is going for the first time on a long journey. 
aisya2 ki-a (transitive verb) to make thin; to exhaust, emaciate, wear down (on account of work, worries, etc). isyaunit nges aswam ngin: that work exhausts her/him. cp. aiped. 
aisyaar ki-a (transitive verb) to wear down, exhaust, or make thin (with work or worry). 
aisyaj einer ki-a (transitive verb) to retort, quip, or rebut. 
aisyar ki-a (transitive verb) to scatter, disperse, spread, diffuse. cp. aisiar
aisyarakin (causative verb) to disperse in all directions; to spread all over, scatter about, disband, divulge (of anything), diffuse. aisyarakin akipi: to splash water. aisyarakin iyemuto: to broadcast news; to disseminate (reflexive verb) to be scattered, dispersed, diffused, dissolved, broadcast. cp. aisiarakin
aisyarakina ki-a (reflexive verb) to be scattered; to be dispersed; to be spread. esyarakinos Imusugun akwapin kere: the Europeans are scattered all over the world. cp. aisiarakina
aisyarar ki-a (transitive verb) to put to flight; to rout; to spread further, scatter abroad, scatter away (reflexive verb) to be spread further, be scattered, be spent, be gone. esyararos ikakapun kere: all my money has been spent. aisisyarakin: to disperse, squander, waste. cp. aisiarar
aisyaun1 ki-a (reflexive verb) to cause to become thin; to cause to be emaciated. 
aisyaun2 ki-a (transitive verb) to begin, start with, commence. esyaunit eong adeka: I feel unwell (i.e. the disease is starting me). (reflexive verb) to be started. esyaunos itogoi ngul adiopepaarit: those two houses were started on the same day. cp. ageun, apeleun. 
aisyaunet (plural aisyauneta) (noun F) the beginning; an initiative. cp. ageunet, apeleunet. 
aisyepaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fatty; to be full of fat; to be oily, greasy, fatty. isyepaikinit epege ngol: that pig has grown fat (is full of fat, has developed). isyepaikinit akonikituk: your lips are oily. 
aisyepokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to stand aside. 
aisyom ko-a (transitive verb) a corruption of aisiom: to read; to backbite; to talk behind one’s back. cp. aisiom
aita1 ki-a (transitive verb) to pour out all; to say several times; to repeat (what is said); to din; to iterate; to keep repeating. kita akile: pour out the milk. aita alimonokin: to keep preaching to. cp. aimago: to keep repeating.
aita2 ki-a (transitive verb) to work for wages; to work for beer; to do communal work for reward; to dig or cultivate for beer. aita ajon: to work for beer.
aitaany ki-a (causative verb) to cause to see; to make to realise. aitaany ican: to cause trouble or problems to. 
aitaanyikin ki-a (causative verb) to present to; to cause to see; to cause to experience. aitaanyikin ican: to cause to see trouble; to cause trouble to. aitaanyun ican: to cause trouble to. 
aitaanyun (causative verb) to cause to see, experience, etc; show; point out. 
aitaar ki-a (causative verb) to make one die; to cause to kill; to tire out. ketaar ngesi eong akwena: she/he makes me tired (die) with laughing. ketaarete eong idwe lu einer: these children will tire me with talking. kinyek aitaar eong etengei: do not let me die (here) of hunger (by delaying me).
aitaar ki-a (transitive verb) to drink off; to drink in great quantities; to quaff beer. 
aitab ki-a (intransitive verb) to walk with a stick; to totter; to dodder; to hobble; to waddle (as of an old person or an infant); to walk by holding a wall (as of a child learning to walk). 
aitaba ki-a (causative verb) to make soft, wet, loose (as of a tied nut by oiling it); to moisten. cp. aitabaun. 
aitababa ki-a (causative verb) to make hard; to make difficult. 
aitabangaanar ki-a (causative verb) to make or cause to be stupid, deaf, foolish, silly, mad, etc.; to make a fool of someone aibangibang k’ekia: to drug a person; to craze. cp. aitababang. 
aitabar ki-a (causative verb) to enrich; to make rich or wealthy. 
aitabaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to make to dissolve; to make wet; to soak; to moisten; to dampen; to warm up (by adding water). 
aitabir ki-a (transitive verb) to sacrifice; to offer sacrifice.
aitac1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to dance with joy; to exult; to rejoice; to be glad; to jump for joy; to be pleased; to be full of beans. etac ngesi noi: she/he is very pleased.
aitac2 ko-a (transitive verb) to pay; to hire; to repay; to expiate or reward; to remunerate; to refund or disburse; to compensate. kotaci akusipesenin: pay your debts. iboro lutacet: things with which to pay or to return; compensation. aiku aitac esolo: to avoid paying tax. ainac aitac esolo: tax evasion. 
aitacaanakin ki-a (causative verb) to light up; to enlighten or educate; to please somebody. 
aitacaikin ki-a (causative verb) to illuminate; to make to shine (for someone); to explain something to someone. 
aitacamun ki-a (causative verb) to convince; to persuade; to cause to agree. 
aitacaun ki-a (causative verb) to enlighten (literally); to shine on; to make bright, light; to throw light on; to inform; to instruct. aitacaun akiro: to throw light on a subject. aitacaun etabaasa: to turn the lamp up (for better light); add fuel to fire. iboro kere etacaunos: everything is clear. 
aitad ki-a (transitive verb) to plant (poles of house, etc); to loosely put poles in holes; to put poles in order. kitadataber etogo kopaarete aisik: first put the poles down and then ram the earth round them. 
aitada ki-a (causative verb) (outside Usuk) to moisten or to soak; to make wet; to make damp. itada ijo akiria nuekamule?: have you soaked the beer malt? cp. aitaba
aitadaikin ki-a (causative verb) to help to finish for; to consume another person’s food. ketadaikis ipejok eong ikanyamat: the visitors have made me finish my food (by cooking for them). 
aitadakin ki-a (transitive verb) to build for somebody; to put up poles (of a house) for somebody or somewhere. 
aitadasit (plural aitadasia) (noun F) a frame or structure of something being built.
aitadaun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to finish; to end. 
aitaditada ki-a (intransitive verb) (of teeth, poles, or anything) to be loose. 
aitagal ki-a (transitive verb) to do carelessly; to put in the way; to place carelessly; not to cultivate or plough deep enough. itagali ijo ikaboro aitagal: you pack my things carelessly.
