aitagalikin ki-a (transitive verb) to hold lightly (with hand); to cultivate lightly; to fasten lightly (as of a nut); not to plant deeply; to leave things about carelessly. aitagalikin akiro: to talk without seriousness or intention to do what one says (reflexive verb) to be left about carelessly in disorder. 
aitagior ki-a (causative verb) to beatify; to make holy or saintly.
aitagitaga ki-a (intransitive verb) to be loose (especially of teeth); to toddle.
aitagwaikin ki-a (causative verb) to enhance; to add; to increase; to cause. ikoto ijo aitagwaikin eong akiro: you want to cause or add me problems.
aitaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do communal work for or somewhere; to pour out (liquids) for. 
aitajarun ki-a (causative verb) to save; to bring back to life; to revive; to give life or to rescue. ajaru ngesi kotoma kalukatwak: she/he rose from the dead 
aitak1 ki-a (transitive verb) to break down (as of house); to remove plaster from a wall; to remove a scab from a wound; to copy verbatim. aitak etogo: to break down a house. 
aitak2 ko-a (transitive verb) to beat; to slap on the ears; to copy; to take off (something fixed). akoto eong aitak ijo akit: I want to slap your ears. kotak akiro ngun: copy those words. aitak ajon: to have a long drink or drag of beer. 
aitakadanut (singular noun F) disappointment; frustration; disillusionment; cynicism. 
aitakadikin ki-a (causative verb) to annoy; to vex; to worry; to provoke; to disconcert; to displease; to gall. 
aitakadikinet (plural aitakadikineta) (noun F) annoyance; vexation; worry; trouble; provocation. 
aitakadio inyamat (singular noun F) malnutrition; underfeeding; starvation. 
aitakitak ki-a (transitive verb) to beat off mud or plaster from floor or wall; to break down (a house). aitakitak arwatat: to take off mud or plaster from wall or floor; to dig up the floor and level it. kitakitak kwap k’etogokon: dig up the floor of your room and make it level. etakitakata acok apanya: the potatoes have cracked the ground (hence they are ready to be harvested). 
aitakwang ki-a (causative verb) to bleach; to make white; to whitewash.
aitala1 ki-a (causative verb) to clean up; to tidy; to smarten; to purge. 
aitala2 ki-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to roast a thing; (of meat) to dry by hanging out; to smoke. akiring naitala: smoke-dried or roasted meat. cp. aitola
aitalag ki-a (transitive verb) to stained; to rust. 
aitalakaar ki-a (causative verb) to please someone; to cheer up; to console; to enliven; to gratify; to comfort. 
aitalakaaret (plural aitalakaareta) (noun F) a gift; solace; a gratuity; relief; a consolation; an amenity. 
aitalakanut1 (singular noun F) consolation; compassion; condolence. 
aitalakanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be consoled or condoled 
aitalakin ki-a (transitive verb) to gamble; to stake money or anything in gambling; to bet. etalakinit eong isirigin elukumit, kinomasi: I stake one thousand shillings, win it; I gamble for one thousand shillings. 
aitalal ki-a (causative verb) to enlarge; to widen, extend. 
aitalalaar ki-a (causative verb) to widen; to broaden. 
aitalanyaar ki-a (causative verb) to help or cause to surpass. 
aitalaun ki-a (transitive verb) to make clean; to make holy; to purge; to clean. 
aitale ki-o (transitive verb) to refrain from; not to partake of; to abstain from; to be taboo. italei ngesi akiring: she/he abstains from meat. etaleete kolo angor abeei: in the past, women used to abstain from eating eggs. kitalee iso ederit kateker kosi: our clan does not eat the meat of a bushbuck (it is believed to cause semi-albinism).
aitaleor ki-o (intransitive verb) to begin to abstain from; to begin to be taboo; to become taboo. akoto eong aitaleor akiring: I want to stop eating meat. 
aitam ko-a (transitive verb) to try; to essay; to strive; to attempt; to endeavour; to test; to dare; to perceive; to venture. aitam aswam: to have a go at; to try to do something. atam edou akwap: it rains very heavily or it rains cats and dogs. aitam nuipedori kere: to do your best; to do what you can; to try hard.
aitamameun ki-a (causative verb) to abolish; to destroy; to abrogate; to repeal; to cancel; to annihilate. 
aitamameunet (plural aitamameuneta) (noun F) abolition; destruction; abrogation; annihilation. 
aitamasikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to rust; to stain or daub; to cause to drink or to absorb. 
aitamat ki-a (causative verb) to cause to drink; to score a goal (in a game of soccer). 
aitamwal ki-a (causative verb) (outside Usuk) to deform; to disable; to impair; to cripple; to make lame. cp. aitangwal
aitamwanuun ki-a (causative verb) to warm up; to cause to warm up or get heated. 
aitan ki-a (transitive verb) to feed; to nourish; to rear (children). 
aitana ki-a (causative verb) to train; to teach; to accustom to; to acclimatise.
aitanaikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to be familiar, etc; to practice; to make accustomed to; to acquaint with; to make used to; to tame; to train. aitanaikin akuwan: to train the body; to do physical training; to take exercise. kitanaik ikonidwe ailip nepe elosete ainyam: teach your children to pray before meals. 
aitanak ki-a (causative verb) (of a mother) to suckle the young; to give breast milk to a child or the young one. 
aitanakikin ki-a (causative verb) (like a mother to a child) to suckle for; to give to suck. kitanakik ikoku ekisin: give the child the breast to suck; suckle the child. 
aitanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to feed for somebody; to nurture for; to bring up for; to get food for; to rear for.
aitanang1 (adverb) as far as; until; upto. aitanang Soroti: upto Soroti. 
aitanang2 ki-a (causative verb) to abolish; to end; to stop; to abrogate.
aitanap ki-a (causative verb) to dress somebody else; to adorn or bedeck; to decorate militarily. kitanapata ikusidwe: dress your children.
aitanapakin ki-a (causative verb) to pacify; to placate; to mollify. cp. aisinapikin.
aitanapikin ki-a (causative verb) to dress somebody else; to adorn or bedeck; to decorate militarily.
aitang ki-a (transitive verb) to perform rites or rituals on children to counter evil. 
aitangakin ki-a (transitive verb) to smear children with a mixture of flour and water for ritual purposes; to perform religious rites. 
aitangaleun ki-o (causative verb) to heal or cure someone else; to make healthy or to cause to recover. 
aitangar ki-a (transitive verb) to perform rites or rituals to bless the hoe (by throwing grain over it at the traditional shrine – abila) as a sign of the official beginning of the planting season. 
aitangwal ki-a (causative verb) (Usuk) to deform; to contort; to disable; to make lame or maimed. 
aitanun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring up (to maturity); to adopt; to rear a child; to cater for. aitanun ikoki: to adopt or nurture an orphan. 
aitanyam ki-a (causative verb) to feed; to give food to; to entertain. aitanyam akiro: to incriminate. aitanyam akonye: to entertain the eyes; to view for pleasure; to admire.
aitanyamenen ki-a (causative verb) to cater; to feed often or always; to nourish.
aitanyany ki-a (causative verb) to extend; to widen; to enlarge.
aitap1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (only used in future tense) to be common; to be usual; to be ordinary; to be customary; to be seen commonly, usually as a rule. (note: for present tense, use atapit. etapit ngesi alosit ore: she/he goes home as a rule). 
aitap2 ko-a (transitive verb) to dip lightly; to touch lightly; to touch lightly with the hand; to mop; to dab; to lay (hand on shoulder or head). kotap edia aitap: just dip atap into the vegetables, do not scoop. cp. aicuny.
aitapaar ki-a (causative verb) to lead astray; to mislead; to seduce a girl; to misguide; to cause to go astray; to misuse; to misappropriate funds. 
aitapaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to leave over; to cause to stay; to arrest progress; to stop or halt (a vehicle); to detain; to delay.
aitapaikinet (plural aitapaikineta) (noun F) a brake; a stop; an impediment; a barrier. 
aitapakas ki-a (causative verb) to employ for wages or salary. 
aitapal ki-a (causative verb) to cause to give up; to cause to let go, to concede; to dispense with. 
aitapalaar ki-a (transitive verb) to stop; to cause to neglect; to cause to remain quiet. etapalaa aswam akaisisia: work has caused me to neglect my studies. 
aitapalikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to give up; to cause to sacrifice to. (reflexive verb) to lose heart, lose courage, be disappointed; to despair. 
aitapapal ki-a (causative verb) to make wet; to moisten; to cause to be damp. 
aitapas ki-a (causative verb) to tire out; to make one fed up; to bother; to trouble; to cause trouble to; to worry, to make anxious. 
aitapasio (noun F) boredom; bother; vexation; irritation; fuss. 
aitapatan ki-a (causative verb) to make easy; to pretend to be easy; to tame or facilitate. 
aitapoet (plural aitapoeta) (noun F) (Biblical) a vision; an appearance; an apparition. 
aitar ki-a (transitive verb) to marry off a girl and receive dowry in return; to engage; to wait for (as of boy waiting to marry his fiancée). cp. aidar. 
aitarakin ki-a (transitive verb) to wait for (as of boy waiting for girl to grow up and marry). 
aitarasikin ki-a (causative verb) to put (a thing) somewhere at once; to get direct from one place or use to another. aponi kitarasikinai isirikaalei luajore luenyakunio ko D.R. Congo alosit Sudan aitiji Joseph Kony: the Ugandan soldiers (UPDF) who returned from the war in the D.R. Congo were rushed straight to the Sudan to fight Joseph Kony’s Lord’s Resistance Army rebels.
aitaraun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to become; to appoint. aitaraun itunganan adakai: to minimise someone (literally, to make someone beer dregs).
aitare ki-o (transitive verb) to wait for; to be waiting a long time for. kitareoi: wait for me; wait there for me. cp. aidare.
aitareun ki-o (transitive verb) to wait here for; to abide. cp. aidareun. 
aitarwaun ki-a (transitive verb) to excite; to cause to run this way suddenly. 
aitasac ki-a (causative verb) to cause to forsake; to cause to refrain from (sexual intercourse); to make to leave alone, desert, abandon, renounce, or reject; to cause to avoid. imukeru itasacit atemonon okilenike: it is the newly-born baby refraining the woman from sexual intercourse with her husband. etasac ebulolo akokor ngin akebeei kodula: the fleas have caused that hen to abandon its eggs in the granary.
aitasal ki-a (causative verb) to cause to be absent or to remain; to hold up; to retain or to detain. 
aitasang (causative verb) to end; to abolish; to abrogate; to limit, cause to cease, bring to an end, stop, terminate. cp. aitanang.
aitasionikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to humble oneself; to be sorry; to take the blame. 
aitasiono1 (singular noun F) humility; modesty; temperance.
aitasiono2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be humble; to be meek; to be repentant; to be sorrowful; to beg humbly. abuni eong aitasiono kakonyekon: I am coming to you to beg humbly. (reflexive verb) to humble oneself. ketasionos: let us be humble. 
aitasionoor ki-o (reflexive verb) to become humble. 
aitaswam ki-a (causative verb) to cause to work or do; to use, to make, to spend, etc; to employ; to conscript or draft labourers; to make use of; to apply, exercise, adopt, operate, or utilise. akirot ngin mam itwasamao: that word is not used. aitaswam isirigin: to spend money (in order to get something); to bribe with cash payment. aitaswam akanin anyamia: to use hands for eating (as opposed to using spoons and forks). itaswamai ngesi emotoka alosio Kampala: she/he uses a motorcar to go to Kampala.
aitatakanun ki-a (causative verb) to put forward; to show off. etatakanu ngesi akemuk: she/he shows off her/his nice shoes (reflexive verb) to be showy; to show off; to be very prominent. atakanunos akemuk: her/his new shoes are very showy. 
aitataleor ki-o (causative verb) to cause to abstain from (a certain food); to make taboo; to forbid from. ketataleo eong adeka ikole: sickness caused me to abstain from eating mud-fish. 
aitatam ki-a (transitive verb) to explain; to narrate; to tell a story; to lecture; to give an account of; to recite or describe. kitatam nukobukus: talk about your home region. aitatam apak epol: to dwell on or to persist on the same theme or subject. 
aitatamikin ki-a (transitive verb) to tell story to; to tell a fable to. kitatamikinai iso akiro nuka ngina: tell us what you saw or found there. 
aitatwaniar ki-a (causative verb) to mortify, annul or abolish; to disgrace, desecrate, or dishonour; to cause to bear no fruits or results; to cause to lose; to cause to forfeit. cp. aiyar: to kill; to cause to die.
aitaun ki-a (transitive verb) to earn for oneself; to pour out for oneself; to work for beer. akoto eong aitaun idisirigin: I want to earn a little money. 
aitawalaar ki-a (causative verb) to cause to burst open; to cause (day, mushroom, flower bud, etc) to break open. aitawalaar akwap: to make to dawn; to do until dawn. aitawalaar atap: to cause water for bread to boil (before putting flour in). aitawalaar akipi: to cook water to boiling point.
aitawonut1 (singular noun F) greed; selfishness; egoism. cp. ebit
aitawonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be greedy, selfish, or egoistic 
aitaya ki-a (causative verb) to cause to take away; to let somebody take away. ingai kitayai egwang akakokor?: who let the wild cat take away my chicken? 
aitayamakin ki-a (causative verb) to quieten down, pacify, conciliate, appease, or placate.
aite ki-o (transitive verb) to look at; to see; to watch; to look after; to tend. kite ekatogo: look after my house. kiteoto akakinei: look after my goats. 
aiteb ki-a (transitive verb) to trim; to cut off edges; to pare. 
aitebe ki-a (causative verb) to put to its proper place or use; to apportion or appropriate. aitebe akiro: to make a positive statement; to speak out; not to beat about the bush; to make sure. 
aitebeanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to speak or tell the truth to. 
aitebeikin ki-a (transitive verb) to put in the right place. aitebeikin akiro: to hit the point; to talk ad rem; to tell the truth. itebeikinit ijo akiro: you have said it, you have hit the mark or spoken to the point.
aitebeikinet (plural aitebeikineta) (noun F) a long-term direction or mission; coincidence; likeness; similitude; accord; harmony; correspondence; consonance; parallelism.
aitebenen ki-a (causative verb) to lighten a load or burden; to make easy. 
aitebeun (intransitive verb) to speak the truth. aitebeun akiro: to speak out; to tell the truth.
aitebiteb ki-a (transitive verb) to cut into small pieces; to make cuts (as in ear); to dig along the edge (as of a path); to clip. aitebiteb aki: to cut edges of ears; to make cuts on the earlobe. 
aitebitebet (plural aitebitebeta) (noun F) an incision; a tattoo; earmark. cp. agerasit.
aitebukin ki-o (intransitive verb) to become swollen up as a result of eating much (usually accompanied by belching); to be distended from overeating. ketebukit eong akoik: my stomach is swollen up or distended. 
aitebwo ki-o (intransitive verb) to be swollen; to swell up. etebwo akakeju (plural etebwoto akakeje): my foot is (feet are) swollen.
aitecel ki-a (transitive verb) to scold, abuse; to chide; to make to quarrel; to blame; to cause to make noise. etecel ejakait iketunga: the chief has scolded his people. 
aitecelenen ki-a (causative verb) to nag at repeatedly; to keep nagging at. sirikitecelenen eong kwangin: do not keep nagging me like that. 
aited ki-o (transitive verb) to make small cuts or notches in a tree or wood; to do one after another; to spell (words). aited inyukutan: to write script. aited akiro: to speak very distinctly; to articulate.
aitedek ki-a (causative verb) to nurse; to take care of someone sick (in hospital); to make or cause the penis to be erect (through pornography, nudity, stimulation, etc). 
aitedekakin ki-o (causative verb) to pretend to be ill, sick, etc. cp. aijoseikin adeka. 
aitederer ki-o (transitive verb) to make straight (of road), speak the truth (akiro). 
aiteelo ki-o (transitive verb) to have unlawful sexual intercourse with a woman.
aiteer ki-a (transitive verb) (of soldiers or anything) to put in line; to line up. 
aiteerikin ki-a (causative verb) to put in line; to put next to one another (reflexive verb) to be in line; to stand next to one another.
aiteg ki-a (intransitive verb) to be too tired to do; to get tired or fatigued; to be tired; to become weak. keteg eong aswam na: I am tired of this work. cp. aipas. kapas eong: I am tired.
aitega ki-a (transitive verb) to trip up (in football); to ensnare or to bewitch (by poisoning the path where one passes). cp. ailoga.
aitegaet (plural aitegaeta) (noun F) a poison trap; a poison snare; a trap.
aitegakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be tired somewhere; to become weak in. ketegaki eong ne, mam apedori alosit: I am tired, I can’t go on from here. 
aitegear ki-a (causative verb) to do for the first time; to initiate. ikakoku yenikitegearet aur: the first born: the child born first. 
aitegel ki-a (causative verb) to fine; to cause to pay a fine; to make to compensate; to impose a fine. abu ejakait ketegel eong akiteng: the chief fined me a cow. 
aitegelikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to change; to cause to differ; to vary. 
aitegelikina ki-a (intransitive verb) to be anomalous, strange, mysterious, or extraordinary. 
aitegit ki-a (intransitive verb) to be too tired to do; to be tired or fatigued; to be weak. 
aitegwel ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to buy; to sell. 
aiteikin ki-o (transitive verb) to look at for somebody; to nurse for; to guard or watch for; to be guardian for. kiteikinoi ikakoku: look after my child (reflexive verb) to face one another; to stand or sit face to face. eteikinos itogoikosi: our houses now face each other. 
aiteite ki-a (transitive verb) to smash (nuts or seeds with a stone or hammer); to shatter (glass, etc into small particles); to break up (as of hen breaking shell). 
aitejenaaret (plural aitejenaareta) (noun F) a sign; a symbol causing someone to know; an indication; a symptom; a warning; a precursor; a notification; a mark. 
aitejenikin ki-a (causative verb) to announce to; to demonstrate; to let know; to explain. 
aitejenun ki-a (causative verb) to let know; to inform; to witness; to certify. 
aitejenunet (plural aitejenuneta) (noun F) a message; a memo; a note; a notice.
aiteka ki-a (transitive verb) to cut sticks for a traditional house. itekai ngesi etogo: she/he is cutting sticks and poles for a hut. 
aitekaar ki-a (transitive verb) to go to cut wood for a building. 
aitekaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to cut wood for a house somewhere or for somebody. 
aiteker ki-a (causative verb) to drive (a vehicle); to cause to run. 
aitekiteko ki-a (intransitive verb) to be shaking; to be unsteady; to be shaky (as of an old chair or leg). itekiteko eicolong: the old chair is rickety. 
aitekoor ki-o (intransitive verb) to turn or throw the head back; to look upwards. cp. ailekoor.
aitekwen ki-a (causative verb) to cause to laugh; to tickle or to amuse. aitekwen etau: to console (the heart). 
aitekwenyun ki-o (causative verb) to awaken someone else; to wake up somebody. cp. aikweny, aitwekenyun. 
aitel ki-o (transitive verb) to cut off (side branches); to lop off; to put or produce one by one (not in pairs or many). aitel angabet: eteli akaberu idwe eurie: my wife produces children one at a time.
aitelarikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become adolescent, etc. cp. aitelepaikin.
aitelek ki-a (causative verb) to make to vomit, cause to vomit; to be emetic; to bring forth.
aitelekaar1 (adverb) very; exceedingly; awfully; extremely; intensely; greatly; severely. ejok ngesi aitelekaar: she/he is very good. kere aitelekaar: above all; more than anything else.
aitelekaar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to overcome; to surpass; to conquer; to get the better of; to surmount. 
aitelekaaret (plural aitelekaareta) (noun F) conquest; triumph; success; victory; feat.
aitelekaarit ki-o (intransitive verb) to be better than; to be superior to. itelekaarit ngesi kere: she/he/it is the best of all: she/he/it surpasses all; she/he has vanquished all.
aitelel ki-a (causative verb) to make happy or joyful; to bring joy to; to please, flatter or to delight; to cheer; to welcome; to enchant; to fascinate; to make the water flow; to irrigate; to drain water. 
aitelemun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to produce something hidden; to make someone to pick or select; to use force to extract something. apotu ipolisin kikamutu ekokolan koreke tupuruc kosodete aitelemun emuudu loebwait ngesi kokitwi: the police arrested a robber at his home early in the morning and forced him to produce the gun he had hidden in the bush. 
aiteleng ki-o (causative verb) to put (many) things in such a way that they can easily fall; to poise or balance on the head. 
aitelengikin ki-o (causative verb) (of one thing only) to put a thing in such a way that it can easily fall. kinyek aitelengikin amot: don’t put the pot so that it can fall over. 
aitelepaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of boys) to become adolescent; (of an adult man, a girl) to act like or look like a boy. 
aiteletel ki-o (transitive verb) to cut up (many times); to make a mark by cutting (often). 
aitelitela ki-a (intransitive verb) to tremble; to shiver; to shake (of anything). itelitela akwap: the earth is trembling. cp. amaran
aitelitelo ki-o (intransitive verb) to shake; to be shaky; to be unsteady. 
aiteliun ki-a (transitive verb) to look from afar at things here. 
aitelokin ki-o (transitive verb) to prune or cut one for; to prune (a tree) for someone. 
aitelokino ki-o (intransitive verb) to be alone (anywhere). adum kes itelokino oitela kec bon: I found them living in a lonely place by themselves. 
aitelor ki-o (transitive verb) to upset (once) by accident. (reflexive verb) to fall (once) by accident by itself. abu eong keteloo ekegilaasi lomaset: I accidentally knocked over his drinking glass.
aitelu ki-o (transitive verb) to view many distant places. 
aiteluor ki-o (transitive verb) to envision; to observe at a distance; to see a thing or person far off; to look far into the future. (intransitive verb) to look far; to have a wide view. apedori eong aiteluor etaun loko Katakwi komoru Abela: I can see Katakwi town from Abela rock (in the distance). 
aitem ki-o (transitive verb) to measure or weigh (to find height, weight, strength or depth); to survey; to compare; to test or to tempt; to examine. kitem etogo: measure the house (demarcate the foundation or ground plan). 
aitemec ki-a (transitive verb) to give shelter to, harbour. 
aitemer ki-a (transitive verb) to make or cause to be drunk. 
aitemerikin ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to be or make rusty, stained. 
aitemis (plural aitemisio) (noun F) a measure; a weigh balance; weighing scales; a weighing machine; a metre rule; a tape measure. 
aitemitem ki-o (transitive verb) to plan; to discuss; to narrate. cp. aitetem, aitatam. 
aitemokin ki-o (transitive verb) to put in order; to arrange; to adjust; to repair; to prepare; to put right; to measure for; to clean; to justify. (reflexive verb) to get ready for; to get better; to prepared or justified; to settle. kitemok emeesa: lay out the table; prepare the table. 
aitemon ki-o (intransitive verb) to be confined at childbirth; to be taboo at childbirth; to look after a newly-born child. itemoni aberu ngin: that woman is in confinement (she has a newly-born baby). aitemon ikoku: to look after a newly-born baby. cp. aisa.
aitemonis (plural aitemonisyo) (noun F) a maternity hospital. 
aitemonokin ki-o (transitive verb) to keep putting in order; to arrange often; to adjust more than once; to repair many times; to be preparing; to put right always. kitemonok emeesa: lay out the table; prepare the table. 
aitemun ki-o (transitive verb) to do again or to repeat; to reform. aitemun bobo: to start all over again. cp. aiteteun. 
aiten1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to drink very much (of liquids); to put straight; to organise; to prepare to deal a heavy blow; to beat somebody. iteni ngesi ajon: she/he drinks much beer. cp. aitotom: to gorge; to gulp down; to swallow in big lumps. iteni ijo ikoninyamat bala ebu: you gulp your food like a hyena. 
aiten2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to level; to direct; to turn (left or right); to face (somewhere). 
aitenakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to go straight ahead; to beeline or to take a short cut (as the crow flies); to cut lengthwise. 
aitenar ki-a (transitive verb) to set upright; to put straight; to up vertically; to erect (reflexive verb) to stand upright; to be erect or vertical. 
aitenara ki-a (intransitive verb) to be straight, vertical, or upright; to be truthful, righteous, or just. 
aitengeanut1 (singular noun F) continual hunger.
aitengeanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of eating; to be always hungry 
aiteny ko-a (transitive verb) (with plural object) to touch a sore or a wound; to touch a painful spot (on the body); to chafe a healing wound or sore. 
aiteo ki-o (intransitive verb) (only in plural) to be opposite each other; to face each other. iteos itogoi: the houses face each other. aiteo ka ejakait: facing the chief or the boss.
aiteor ki-o (intransitive verb) to look away; to look aside.
aiteororoi ki-o (transitive verb) to watch or guard meanwhile; to look after in the meantime; to look out meanwhile. kiteororoi ber akinei, alosi eong ore: look after the goats whilst I go home. 
aitep1 ki-a (transitive verb) to fornicate; to cohabit; to have sexual intercourse or to penetrate (in coitus); to enter or access the vagina. cp. aidur. 
aitep2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of rain) to fall. etepi akiru: etepi edou: it rains. 
aitepedoor ki-o (causative verb) to enable; to empower. 
aitepeg ki-a (causative verb) to argue; to challenge; to oppose; to dispute; to contradict; to rebut; to contest. ingai ketepegi eong kanuka aronus?: who will argue with me about sin? 
aitepej ki-o (transitive verb) to entertain; to treat, receive as a guest. 
aitepelor ki-o (causative verb) to cause to protrude, become visible; to exalt. 
aiteper ki-o (causative verb) to cause to lie down; to lay out, stretch out; to put one up; to give a bed to; to fornicate; to commit adultery; to cause to sleep on the floor.
aiteperoor ki-o (transitive verb) to omit; to postpone until the next day; to leave a day over; to set aside for the next day; to make a person, etc to sleep elsewhere. 
aitepesen ki-a (causative verb) to demand payment of a debt; to fine in a court of law; to make indebted; to claim a debt; to hold responsible. cp. aibura. 
aitepitep ko-a (intransitive verb) to drizzle. cp. aitipitip. 
aiter ko-a (transitive verb) to throw about; to bandy. 
aiteran ki-a (intransitive verb) to be newly-married. eterani ngesi: she/he is newly-married (thus she/he is on a honeymoon). 
aitere ki-o (transitive verb) to look at; to gaze at; to stare at. 
aitereg ki-a (causative verb) to make rigid; (to cause) to stiffen; to make stiff (of anything); to paralyse; to cause meningitis. 
aiteregegiar ki-a (reflexive verb) to become stiff or paralysed; to have meningitis. alosit eiteregegea: to do the goose-step; to goose-match.
aiteregegiara (noun F) stiffness; paralysis; rigidity; meningitis; inflexibility. 
aitereng ki-a (causative verb) to redden; to make red; to make to glow; to burn. iterengi akolong inya: the sun burns the grass (makes it brownish). 
aiterer ki-a (transitive verb) (of soldiers or anything) to put in line; to line up; to balance on the head (as of a woman carrying a pot or such without touching same). aiterer idwe: to produce many children here and there. itererei ikoku: the child stands up straight. cp. aibwo.
aitererikin ki-a (transitive verb) to put in line; to put in a row; to line up (reflexive verb) to be lined up; to be in a line. 
aiteriboor ki-o (transitive verb) to obstruct the view, stand in the light; to screen; to obstruct sight; to prevent from seeing; to shade. kiteriboorit ijo eong: you obstruct my view.
aites ki-a (transitive verb) to deliberate; to consider; to talk over; to ponder over. cp. aipet akiro.
aiteseg ki-a (causative verb) to tidy up (a room); to clean up; to cause to be tidy, neat, clean. 
aitesoikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to look like Iteso or their culture; to behave like an Etesot or Atesot person; to become like an Etesot or Atesot, or Teso land. 
aitete ki-a (transitive verb) to repair; to renew or refresh; to make new; to rejuvenate. itetei ngesi etogoke: she/he is repairing (renewing) her/his house. 
aiteteg ki-a (causative verb) to tire out; to fatigue. 
aitetem ki-o (transitive verb) to try; to test; to practice; to do physical exercise; to state the cause; to give an account of; to describe; to explain; to discuss; to plan. aitetem ekia: to prescribe medicine. aitetem akiro: to state a case; to discuss an issue.
aitetemikin ki-o (transitive verb) to advice; to give advice; to show how to do; to make to fit; to adapt to; to plan for; to comment; to explain to; to account for. kitetemikinoi epale: make these trousers or shorts to fit me. kodonyokinoi epale: make me a pair of trousers or shorts. 
aiteten ki-a (causative verb) to make straight; to make level; to straighten; to settle (a case in court); to correct or rectify; to put right side up. aiteten akiro: to straighten or clear a matter. etenete: alright. akoto aiteten akeju ore: I want to go homeward. aiteten aomisio: to disillusion; to disabuse, to clarify, to inform. 
aitetenaar ki-a (causative verb) to make straight or to straighten. cp. aitukud: to bend.
aitetenit ki-a (transitive verb) to keep in order; to keep steady; to keep straight. cp. aitiriit: to curve.
aiteteor akonye ki-o (causative verb) to direct eyes to; to look towards. kiteteo akonye orekon: look towards your home. aiteteor akeje ore: to go homeword. 
aitetes1 (noun F) newness; freshness.
aitetes2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be new, recent, or fresh; to be young. kitetiak oni: we are young, new, or inexperienced. cp. amojongit: to be old, archaic, etc
aiteteun ki-a (causative verb) to bring something new; to make an innovation; to renew or repair; to refresh or reform; to repeat; to straighten (towards the speaker); to do over again. aiteteun ekiror: to be enrolled again; to start again. cp. aitomojong: to make old or derelict. 
aiteteunio (singular noun F) renovation; reformation; renewal; rebirth.
aitetianut (singular noun F) newness; renovation. 
aitetiar ki-o (reflexive verb) to become new, fresh, recent, or young. itetiar ijo: you have become young again.
aiteun ki-o (transitive verb) to look carefully before doing something; to be on the look out before acting. 
aiteunet (plural aiteuneta) (noun F) a pattern; an example; a prototype; a model. 
aiti1 ki-o (intransitive verb to be late; to come late; to go late. 
aiti2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be oily; to be greasy. asaanin ngun itiete: those plates are greasy. cp. aititil
aitibilikin ki-a (causative verb) to wish evil or misfortune to someone; to cause to break, cut, etc. 
aitibitib ki-a (transitive verb) to have biting pain; to prickle; to have pins and needles. ketibitibi eong eimidi: I have a prickly feeling (on account of fever). 
aitibong ki-a (causative verb) to make it evening; to do till nightfall; to become or be dusk. etibong akwap, mam eong apedori alosit ore: it is too late for me to go home. abonguni eong itibongi: I shall come back towards evening. (transitive verb) to make to become evening, dark, dusk. sirikitibong akwap: do not make it evening (i.e. before you come back). 
aitican ki-a (transitive verb) to afflict; to maltreat or mistreat; to cause misery, trouble to; to inflict misery, sadness, etc. to; to cause or make mischief on; to pester or disturb. 
aiticanet (plural aiticaneta) (noun F) a punishment, penalty; an inconvenience, nuisance, bother; a disturbance. cp. aitisilaario.
aiticanio (singular noun F) punishment; penalty; sentence. cp. aitisilaario
aitida ki-a (intransitive verb) to dance to etida drum. 
aitidic ki-a (causative verb) to cause to grind well (fine). aidic amuk: to walk on tip-toe. 
aitididior ki-o (transitive verb) to cause to delay; to make smaller, to be long time after. mam itididior: she/he won’t be long; she/he will be coming shortly; do not delay. 
aitidil ki-o (causative verb) to make plentiful, make abundant; to cause to go or leave early in the morning. Edeke itidili inyamat kere: God gives abundance of all kinds of food. 
aitidisiar ki-a (causative verb) to diminish, lessen, extenuate, or abase; to allay; to minimise; to abate; to alleviate or assuage; to make smaller; to abbreviate, make less. kitidisia etogo: make the (plan of the) house smaller. 
aitiditeun ki-a (causative verb) to humble; to humiliate, make small, make little; to decrease (the size). 
aitidyak ki-a (causative verb) to mislead, or lead astray. 
aitidyakalal ki-a (causative verb) to make soft by cooking or adding too much water. 
aitielo ki-o (transitive verb) to have intercourse with a woman or girl. cp. aitep
aitieny ki-a (transitive verb) to ignite a match (to cause a fire); to bump (as of bicycle going over ruts). aitieny ikorio: to show greed; to try to prevent; to show discontent. 
aitienyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to bump up against (once only) (intransitive verb) to shake or rattle (as of bicycle). 
aitienyanakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to bump up and down (as of vehicle going over rough ground). 
aitienyaun ki-a (transitive verb) to bump off; to shell with big guns; to bombard a little with artillery. cp. aidupaun
aitienyitienyit (plural aitienyitieny) (noun F) a spark; embers.
aitigiris ki-o (causative verb) to cause bruises, chafes, etc. 
aitiiba (plural aitiiban) (noun F) a net (especially a mosquito or fishnet). cp. aceederuwa
aitiikin ki-o (transitive verb) to be late in doing; to delay action. aitiikin aidoun: to conceive after many years. itiik ijo abunere: you (singular) have come late. 
aitiin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to grow thin or emaciate; to cause food to be undone or fail to get ready. adeka na ketiin eong: this disease has made me thin (emaciated me). 
aitiina ki-a (causative verb) to make damp; to make moist; to moisten. 
aitiirian ki-a (causative verb) to make equal; to level; to compare; to equalise; to adjust; to contrast. 
aitiirianakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to be equal; to be level with; to be compared with; to be equal; to be adjusted; to make equal to; to make level; to compare with; to equalise to; to adjust to. 
aitiirianet (plural aitiirianeta) (noun F) analogy; comparison; parallel; resemblance.
aitiit ki-o (transitive verb) a corruption of aitingit: to hold or keep in the hand; to possess. 
aitiji ki-a (causative verb) to fight someone or something; to attack; to fight somebody or something. aitoji: to beat; (of insects, such as bees, wasps) to sting somebody.
aitijijim ki-a (causative verb) to make tasty; to flavour; to spice; to season. 
aitijijimikin ki-a (causative verb) to make one pleased with. akoto aitijijimikin ijo aswam na: I want to make you pleased with this work. 
aitijon ki-a (causative verb) to cool something; to chill or or put in a fridge. 
aitik ko-o (transitive verb) to hold up; to enchant; to press down; to push against; to jostle; to obstruct; to hypnotise; to fascinate. aitik eiyengane: to hold breath. aitik etau: to determine in one’s heart not to; to hold back oneself. aitik eibel: to be continent; to abstain from. 
aitikidiokor (causative verb)  to reduce, decrease; to make less, fewer, etc 
aitikitik ki-o (transitive verb) to prevent; to obstruct constantly. ipu kwana ikee luitikitiket eimidi: there are many drugs to prevent malaria fever these days.
aitikitikio (singular noun F) prevention; deterrence; controlling. 
aitikitikun ki-a (transitive verb) to prevent. cp. airebireb: to obstruct. 
aitikokin ki-o (transitive verb) to prevent; to hinder; to dissuade; to ban; to obstruct. 
aitikun ki-o (transitive verb) to prevent from going further; to stop from going further; (of cattle) to drive back.
aitili ki-a (causative verb) to make watery; to dilute. 
aitilil ki-a (causative verb) to tantalise; to taunt; to make envious; to irritate. itilili ikoku ekapa: the child is teasing the tomcat. cp. aipudel
aitililim ki-a (causative verb) to cool; to freeze; to make cold.
aitilitila ki-a (intransitive verb) to be loose; to be shaky; to be unsteady. itilitila emeesa ngol: that table is unsteady (it shakes). 
aitilon ki-o (intransitive verb) to be deep or abysmal. 
aitilor ki-o (transitive verb) to delay somebody (reflexive verb) to be late; to linger; to delay. cp. aitumor.
aitim ki-o (transitive verb) to pardon or to forgive; to absolve; to spare; to have mercy on; to pity; to have pity on. kitimoi: have pity on me. 
aitima (plural aitiman) (noun F) a valve (a tiny rubber that controls air pressure in a tyre). 
aitimaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to look like a hair; to be hair-like.
aitimatim ki-a (intransitive verb) to waver; to be fussy; to rush about. 
aitimatimatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to mess or fuss about. 
aitimet (plural aitimeta) (noun F) compassion; sympathy; kindness.
aitimilimil ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to shine; to polish; to glisten or cause to glitter.
aitimin ki-a (causative verb) to endear; to charm, captivate, or enamour.
aitimio (singular noun F) forgiveness; pardon; amnesty; mercy; pity. cp. aisonio
aitimokin ki-o (transitive verb) to show mercy to; to have pity for; to feel pity for. 
aitimonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to forgive one another. 
aitimonut1 (singular noun F) leniency; mercy. 
aitimonut2 ki-o (transitive verb) to be inclined to forgive; to be lenient to; to be merciful. 
aiting ki-a (transitive verb) to hold; to take hold of; to catch hold of; to grasp. aiting akan: to shake hands or ask in marriage; to propose marriage. aiting akiro: to grasp (mentally); to understand. 
aitinga ki-a (transitive verb) to persuade; to constrain; to force. 
aitingaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away by force or with difficulty; to persuade to go or to do; to go or do unwillingly. abu ketingaa nges alosit aswam: I persuaded (constrained, forced) her/him to go to work. 
aitingaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to force; to begrudge; to persuade; to constrain; to convince; to hold for somebody. kitingakinai ekagaali: hold my bicycle for me. 
aitingaun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring by force; to compel; to force out; to pull out forcibly; to extract by force, i.e. to coerce. aitingaun akiro: to say unwillingly; to say with difficulty (transitive verb) to force somebody to speak. 
aitinget (plural aitingeta) (noun F) a handle; a forceps; a pincers; a quiver for arrows. 
aitingirikin ki-o (causative verb) to cause to endure; to frown on. 
aitingit ko-a (transitive verb) to have hold of; to hold in custody; to contain; to be looking after somebody’s goods as guarantee. 
aitinitina ki-a (intransitive verb) to pretend to be coy; to turn head in pretended shyness. 
aitip ki-o (transitive verb) to dip; (of food or vegetables) to take little by little. 
aitipipil ki-a (causative verb) to hurt; to cause to be painful. 
aitipitip ki-a (intransitive verb) (of rain) to drizzle. cp. ailimilim. 
aitir ko-o (transitive verb) to touch (many); to feel; to handle; to finger.
aitiri ki-o (causative verb) to cross-cut; to cause to bend, twist or curve. 
aitirikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do daily or continually; to do many times; to do constantly; to persevere. 
aitiriong ki-a (causative verb) to make someone carry a load on the shoulders. aponi kitiriongai Yesu emusalaba: Jesus was made to carry a cross.
aitiripakin ki-a (causative verb) to make or cause to stand in a row; to line up. 
aitirir ki-a (intransitive verb) to be speechless, mute, confounded, or dumbfounded; to stand in a row. itiriraete: they are standing in rows. 
aitironikin ki-o (transitive verb) to apologise; to own up; to be penitent; to say sorry; to ask for forgiveness. 
aitisi ki-a (causative verb) to let escape; to cause to escape, run off, run away; to rescue clandestinely. 
aitisil ki-a (causative verb) to humble, humiliate, disgrace; to put to shame, embarrass; to shame, degrade; to desert a village, i.e. leave without people. itisilitoi ejakait kajakaanut: the chief was degraded. 
aitisilaar ki-a (causative verb) to punish, censure; to chastise; to mortify; to penalise; to castigate. 
aitisilaario (singular noun F) punishment; penance; chastisement; penalty. aitisilaario naka aijaanakin ateker: community service.
aitisiom ki-a (causative verb) to cause to read (a book, etc); to pay school fees for; to cause to study (intransitive verb) to educate (by sending to school to learn to read and write, etc). 
aitisis ki-o (causative verb) to burn (of food only); to parch or scorch.
aitisyepaikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to become fatty or oily; to fatten (an animal for slaughter). cp. aitutum.
aititi1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to become oily or greasy. etitie akonikituk bala inyamit akinyet: your mouth is greasy as if you had eaten oil. 
aititi2 ki-o (transitive verb) to stop from running away. emong etitie akituk: the bull was the one stopping the cows from running away. cp. aitikitik.
aititil ki-o (intransitive verb) to become very dirty (usually with soot or black dirt). ititilat ngesi: she/he/it is very grimy or full of dirt. cp. aiti, aititi
aititilaikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to become dirty or covered with soot. 
aititimanut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be vacillating, fussy, hesitating, or unable to decide. 
aititing ki-a (causative verb) to hand over to; to give charge of; to lend; to cause to adopt; (of sickness) to infect; to bestow on; to commend. 
aititingikin ki-a (causative verb) to bail; to give to be in charge; to pledge; to pawn; to deliver to; to guarantee. 
aititingikinet (plural aititingikineta) (noun F) a guarantee; a pledge; a pawn; bail. 
aitiun ki-o (transitive verb) to come too late; to be late in doing; to come when work is over. itiunit ijo aipoore: you started cooking late. 
aitob ki-o (transitive verb) to harvest or garner (especially sorghum); to cut tops of grain; to reap. cp. aisak, aidweny.
aitobitob ki-a (transitive verb) to bite all over; to munch; to nibble (as of a rabbit). 
aitobong ki-a (causative verb) to cause or force to return; to force to go back; to make a profit. cp. aitibong (causative verb) to make it evening; to do something till evening.
aitobongun ki-o (causative verb) to reclaim; to cause to come back or return.
aitobwo ki-a (causative verb) to accuse; to cause to stand; to prop or support.
aitobwok ki-a (transitive verb) to make to carry; to put on the head; to load a person or car. 
aitobwot ki-a (causative verb) to evacuate or relocate; to evict; to expel; to cause to shift homes or emigrate.
aitobwotun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to immigrate to this place. 
aitoc ki-a (intransitive verb) (of leaves and branches of a cut plant)to regrow; to sprout out again. 
aitoco akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to try to see everything (intransitive verb) to be curious; to look around. 
aitocoliar ki-a (causative verb) to make watery. itocolia ijo akile ngun: you have added water to that milk. 
aitocoun ki-a (causative verb) to make wise, shrewd or careful; to enlighten; to make clear to; to caution or warn. akirot ngin ibusakinit aitocoun ijo: this case ought to make you careful, wise, etc.
aitocun ki-a (intransitive verb) (as of leaves and branches of a cut plant) to sprout out again. 
aitod ko-o (transitive verb) to peck once; to strike (as a snake does). 
aitoditod ki-a (intransitive verb) to shamble; to totter (like one who is tired); to go slowly (as of a weak person). 
aitodo ki-o (causative verb) to lose or to drop; to let fall; to cause to fall. sirikitodo ikoku: don't let the child fall. 
aitodoikin ki-o (causative verb) to make to drop into or on; to drop into; to drip into; to let fall into or onto; to get someone into trouble or case. ibu ijo kitodoik eong toma akiro: you got me into trouble (case). 
aitodok ki-a (causative verb) to lift i.e. to help to climb up or down; to make to climb; to help to climb; to let climb. 
aitodokaar ki-a (causative verb) to lift up i.e. to help to climb away; to make to climb away; to help to climb away; to let climb away. 
aitodokun ki-a (causative verb) to lift down i.e. to help to climb down or force down; to make to climb down; to help to come down; to let climb down towards oneself. 
aitodol1 (preposition) upto; until; till. eboi eong aitodol nges abongun: I have stayed until her/his return. cp. toni, kitoni.
aitodol2 ki-o (causative verb) to achieve; to effect; to fulfil or to uphold. etodol ngesi eipudake: she/he has achieved her/his ambition or desire.
aitodolikin ki-o (causative verb) to attain; to cause to reach; to fulfil. etodolik eong akapeleikinet abitun eitaabo loka Ateso: I have achieved my aim of writing a book in Ateso.
aitodolikinet (plural aitodolikineta) (noun F) an achievement; attainment. 
aitodolun ki-o (causative verb) to satisfy; to cause to arrive here; to make to arrive there where you are. 
aitoduun ki-o (transitive verb) to show (us); to indicate (to us).
aitogogong1 ki-o (causative verb) to endorse; to invigorate; to affirm; to fulfil; to confirm; to corroborate; to certify; to sanction; to ratify; to make good; to fortify. kitogogong aitumunetakon: fulfil your promise. 
aitogogong2 ki-o (causative verb) to strengthen; to harden; to encourage, insist, prove, or approve. kitigogongoto arwatat ngin: strengthen that wall. 
aitogogonget (plural aitogogongeta) (noun F) an affirmation; a ratification, etc. 
aitogogongoor ki-o (causative verb) to enforce; to impose; to inflict; to effect; to fulfil.
aitoikin ki-o (transitive verb) to put sideways; to put on its side; to turn sideways. aitoikin aki: to listen attentively.
aitoilikin ki-o (causative verb) to look like a wraith or a ghost (spirit of the dead). 
aitoito ki-o (transitive verb) to dig along a rope or a line; to trim a hedge; to cut off inequalities. 
aitoitois (plural aitoitoisyo) (noun F) an instrument for digging, cutting off edges, or trimming (hedge or ditch); a dibble. 
aitojaar ki-a (causative verb) to hit hard on the head. 
aitojok ki-a (causative verb) to make good; to bless; to praise; to speak well of; to commend. cp. aitur. 
aitojokaar ki-a (causative verb) to recommend; to appreciate; to approve; to commend; to compliment. abu Okello kitojokaa aikopakin Omoding polis kanu aswamisineike nuka aimokoraikit: Okello recommended handing Omoding to the police for his unbecoming acts.
aitojokianakin ki-a (transitive verb) to praise always; to approve always; to benefit always. 
aitojokiar ki-a (causative verb) to amend; to improve; to recommend; to ameliorate; to appreciate; to approve; to commend; to compliment; to make good, nice, right, etc. aitojokiara bon: to be complacent, smug, self-satisfied, docile, submissive, or apathetic. 
aitojonaar ki-o (transitive verb) (of angry person, weather, or a hot thing) to calm down, let cool down, put at ease, or put at rest; to sooth. 
aitojongoor ki-o (causative verb) to prevent, abolish, cause to cease, or stop. 
aitojor ki-o (causative verb) to make to sit on haunches (as of holding a child when pissing or defecating). 
aitok ko-o (transitive verb) to hem; to make a hem (as of mat or cloth, etc); to limit. kotok emukeeka lo: hem this mat. etokit aberu ngin akiro: that woman is strict (she cannot stand nonsense). 
aitoka ki-a (transitive verb) to beat on the back many times; to strike the back many times; to gulp or guzzle. kinyek aitoka idwe: stop beating up the children. 
aitokaar ko-a (transitive verb) to strike on the back once; to beat the back once; to drink greedily. ekoto ekamejan aitokaar etyang: the hunter wants to hit the animal (reflexive verb) to rush away quickly through the bush. 
aitokakin ki-a (transitive verb) to explode in the direction of or towards. kinyek aitokanakin eong ekonimuudu: stop exploding your gun in my direction (towards me). 
aitokaun ki-a (transitive verb) to strike; to hit; to beat (somebody or something) (reflexive verb) to rush blindly towards the speaker. 
aitokimaar ki-a (transitive verb) to pour out completely. 
aitokimaaret (plural aitokimaareta) (noun F) effusion (a pouring or flowing out). 
aitokokol ki-o (transitive verb) to be an enemy of; to rival; to underbid; to impinge on. inyo bo kitokokolitor ijo eong?: why do you rival me? 
aitokol ki-o (transitive verb) to cause a quarrel; to cause enmity; to thwart; to contest; to rival; to outdo; to overbid (said of anything). itokolit ijo eong: you thwart me. ekolosi ngesi kapapake: she/he is at loggerheads with her/his father.
aitokolit ki-o (transitive verb) to accuse; to rival. cp. aitokokolit
aitokon ki-o (causative verb) to cause to be cooked, done, or be ready (to eat, to be eaten); to cook properly; to make food done.
aitokony1 atap (noun F) a ceremony for blessing and giving food to women after childbirth. 
aitokony2 atap ki-a (causative verb) to let people partake of first fruits of harvest; to give a woman the offals (entrails of a cow) to eat after childbirth. cp. aikony atap: to eat first fruits of harvest 
aitokony3 ki-a (causative verb) to cause to bite; to let someone taste something. 
aitokot ki-o (causative verb) to endear; to charm, captivate, enamour, or attract. 
aitola ki-a (transitive verb) to dry meat or fish by smoking over fire. 
aitoliokokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to hesitate; to be in doubt. 
aitololoar ki-o (transitive verb) to drink up completely (as of a drunkard). 
aitolom ki-a (transitive verb) to cause many to enter; to employ or to take on new staff (for work); to engage new workforce. 
aitolomaar ki-a (causative verb) to cause to enter into, cause to go out or into; to put into. 
aitolomikin ki-a (causative verb) to enrol, register, or sign up. 
aitolomun ki-a (causative verb) to cause to come in or out; to cause a seed to germinate; to make successful. ijo ibu kitolom akiro nubian: you caused yesterday’s trouble. 
aitolomunet (plural aitolomuneta) (noun F) an edition (of a newspaper or a book); a production or print.
aitolomuun ki-a (causative verb) to introduce or to lead into; to pass out people who have been on training. 
aitolony ki-a (causative verb) to cause to miss; to be passed over. 
aitolot ki-a (causative verb) to set in motion; to impel; to cause to move or to cause to walk. 
aitomonikin ki-a (causative verb) to do for the tenth time; to add in order to bring up to ten; to add to make ten. kitomonik ipakasin ngul: bring the number of those porters to ten. 
aitomony ko-a (causative verb) to make to weep; to cause to cry; to make to complain. aitomony akiyo: to cause to shed tears. etomony aingito esisiak: the exams caused the students to cry (because it was very hard).
aiton ki-a (transitive verb) (of liquids) to drop; to let drop. aiton abalang: to make salt from plant ash; to filter ashes for salt; to distil. itoni aberu abalang: the woman makes salt (from plant ashes). 
aitonakin ki-a (transitive verb) (of liquids) to drop on; to let drip on (in); to put drops on (into). kitonakinai ekia akongu: put some drops of medicine in my eye. 
aitonanakin ki-o (reflexive verb) (of liquids) to fall in drops onto or into; to put in drops in. 
aitong ki-a (transitive verb) to take too much; to exceed measure. 
aitongong ki-a (intransitive verb) to sit around doing nothing or to sit in anger; to sit mooching. 
aitonok ki-a (causative verb) to cause to burn; to cause a fire (intransitive verb) to be near; to be close to. 
aitononok ki-a (causative verb) to weaken, soften; to dilute, to add water to calm down; to mollify. kinyek aitononok ajon: do not make the beer weak (by adding too much water). 
aitonyoun ki-a (causative verb) to arouse or stir up; to awaken; to cause to stand up; to set in motion or to start off an engine; to expel somebody from a place; to cause to go away (of woman getting divorced). 
aitoodi ki-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to show; to point out; to indicate.
aitoodiar ki-a (transitive verb) to show; to demonstrate; to proclaim; to display; to exhibit; (of the groom and his relatives) to get introduced in marriage to the future in-laws. 
aitoodiaret (plural aitoodiareta) (noun F) an example; a trade show; a trade fair. 
aitoodikin ki-a (transitive verb) to show to; to indicate to; to point out to; to explain to; to direct; to advertise; to publish; to command; to exhibit. 
aitoodikinet (plural aitoodikineta) (noun F) an example; a programme; a registration number of a vehicle; a vehicle indicator; a sign to show direction, etc; a pointer. 
aitoodiun ki-a (transitive verb) to manifest; to introduce; to publish. akoto aitoodiun ejakait loitetet: I want to introduce the new chief (reflexive verb) to appear; to manifest oneself; to show oneself; to introduce oneself. 
aitooj ki-a (causative verb) to make tall, high, or long; to elongate.
aitoojaar ki-a (causative verb) to extend; to lengthen; to elongate. 
aitoolikin ki-o (transitive verb) to bewilder; to lose; to waste; to mix up (as of rope - not knowing where the end is); to mislead; to confuse, upset, or interfere with; to cause to get mixed up. 
aitoolior ki-o (causative verb) to lose; to waste; to lead astray, lose, or cause to be lost; to forfeit; to cause to go astray. 
aitoom ki-a (causative verb) to cause to think, consider, or to ponder. 
aitoon ki-o (causative verb) to dry up, make dry (by the sun or wind). 
aitoongor ki-o (causative verb) to bronze; to make or colour dark brown. 
aitoonikin ki-o (causative verb) to drain (land, well); to finish something for someone.
aitoos ki-a (causative verb) to accuse; to take to court; to cause to plead. cp. aisirab. 
aitopol ki-o (transitive verb) to make big, proud, or important; to bring up or to rear; to dignify; to promote; to develop. cp. aitopoloor. 
aitopolo (singular noun F) pride; conceit; arrogance; superiority complex. 
aitopolonut1 (noun F) self-importance; haughtiness; arrogance; conceit.
aitopolonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be proud; to be haughty or arrogant; to be inclined to be conceited; to be inclined to be proud. 
aitopoloor ki-o (causative verb) to make big, proud, or important; to bring up or to rear; to dignify; to promote; to magnify. (reflexive verb) to become big, proud, haughty, or arrogant. sirikitopoloor: do not become proud. cp. aitidisiar: to lessen; to minimise.
aitopoloorit (intransitive verb) to celebrate or honour; to commemorate, observe or remember an event or an occasion. 
aitopolooro ki-o (transitive verb) to be arrogant; to think much of oneself; to be conceited. 
aitopoloun (intransitive verb) to educate or adopt another’s child as one’s own; to bring up; to educate; to extol. 
aitor1 ki-a (transitive verb) to trample down; to stamp hard (as of soil or contents of a bag). ingai kitori akamana?: who trampled down my garden? 
aitor2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to pass; to go by, past. aitor toma ationis naepol: to pass through great difficulties (hardships). kitor awai: go alongside; pass by one side. 
aitor3 ko-o (transitive verb) to tie round (something). aitor akou: to tie a scarf or a band round the head (because one is feeling headache, in mourning, etc).
aitoris (plural aitorisyo) (noun F) a passport; a permit for passing somewhere.
aitorit ki-a (transitive verb) to be passing or to have passed somewhere; to go by; to have experienced some unpleasant things. 
aitoron ki-a (causative verb) to spoil, make bad, defile, chide, find fault with, deprecate; (of a girl) to jilt; to blame; to spoil; to disapprove; to aggravate; to mar; to abominate. 
aitoronaar ki-a (causative verb) to spoil, make bad, defile, blame, chide, find fault with, deprecate; to blame; to mar; to abominate. 
aitoronikin ki-o (transitive verb) to apologise; to express regret; to be penitent; to own up; to repent, apologise, or admit guilt. 
aitoror ki-o (transitive verb) to pick something along the way on a journey; to pass by and pick. 
aitorubeikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to look like a shadow. 
aitorun ki-o (transitive verb) to bring something along on the way back. 
aitosom ki-a (causative verb) to cause to jump, bounce, or dance. aitosom etau: to surprise, astound, or to astonish. cp. aitaswam.
aitotolikin ki-o (causative verb) to disarrange; to disorganise; to interrupt; to upset; to thwart. (transitive verb) to be deformed. 
aitotom ki-a (transitive verb) to pour liquids down the throat in great quantities; to guzzle. aitotom ajon: to drink a great quantity of beer. aitotom akiyo: to shed a lot of tears.
aitotomitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) (of flowing liquid) to gurgle, burble, or spurt. 
aitotwa ki-a (transitive verb) to beat (as of carpet); to shake off dust (by beating); to shake out dust from a vessel.
aitotwaar ki-a (transitive verb) to shake out dust from cloth, carpet or vessel; to dust by beating out. 
aitub ko-o (transitive verb) to cut; to amputate; to referee (at football); to arbitrate; to decide; to cancel acheque; to pass an examination. aitub akiro: aitub emusaago: to settle or judge a court case; to arbitrate. aitub acoa: to play a trick; to devise a plan. aitub etau: to hurt one's feelings; to say something derisive; to be sarcastic; to gibe at. ketub apak edit: after a short while. 
aituburuun ki-a (causative verb) to make anxious; to make disquiet; to molest. 
aitubus ki-a (causative verb) to decorate; to honour; to beautify; to bear or keep company; to entitle. bia aitubus eong: come and keep me company. epejonon itubusi akaika: a visitor is coming to stay in my house. 
aitubusian ki-a (causative verb) to enslave; to make to work like a slave; to engage; to take into service; to exploit. luitubusianitai (plural noun M): slaves. aitubusian itunganan: to take advantage of somebody and make him/her work like a slave; to exploit a person.
aitubusikin ki-a (causative verb) to make better; to increase. kitubusikisi aboliakus: put more vim into your game and make it interesting. 
aitubuun ki-o (causative verb) to distend; to leaven; to cause to swell. 
aitud1 akonye ko-o (transitive verb) to drop medicine into the eye. cp. aidonakin akongu. 
aitud2 ki-o (transitive verb) to tie up or to knot.
aitud3 ko-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to plant in little groups.
aitudeng ki-o (causative verb) to extinguish; to put out fire; to cool down. akim namam edungee: hell, eternal fire.
aitudokin auno ki-a (transitive verb) to make a knot; to insert a knot. 
aitudum ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to receive, get, or procure. 
aitudumikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to get for someone, etc. 
aitudumun ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to receive, get, or procure. 
aitudupuk ki-o (causative verb to grind finer. kitudupuk akiria: grind the flour fine. cp. ainyabuk. 
aitujul ki-a (causative verb) to cause to change, modify, modulate, alter, vary, convert, or turn. aitujul ediini: to convert to another faith. 
aituk1 ki-a (transitive verb) to tie hard; to bind much. kituk akiteng oloit: tie the cow onto the peg hard. 
aituk2 ko-a (transitive verb) to fill the mouth with water (or other liquids); to hold something in the mouth. etukit nges akipi: she/he has her/his mouth full of water. aituk isinyok: to drink beer (ajon ekamule). 
aituk3 ko-o (transitive verb) to gather; to assemble; to heap up; to collect. 
aituku1 ki-a (causative verb) to let escape; to rescue; to redeem; to save; to snatch away from danger. 
aituku2 ki-o (causative verb) to cause to froth or foam; to make to froth or foam. kituku asabuuni: make the soap foam or lather. 
aitukul ki-a (causative verb) to cause to peel or pare. 
aitukula ki-a (causative verb) to make to boil; to boil; to allow to evaporate. 
aitukulaun ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to start boiling. 
aitukum ki-a (transitive verb) (of anything) to cause to bend forward; to overturn many face first. 
aitukumikin ki-o (causative verb) to bend forward (as of head or anything); to adore; to bend for; to make a bow for; to empty by holding vessel upside-down. aitukumikin akipi amot: to pour out all the water into the pot by turning vessel upside-down. (reflexive verb) to bend oneself down (in reverence, worship, adoration). itukuminikinos itunga Lokasuban: people adore God by bending themselves. 
aitukumoor ki-o (transitive verb) to upset, overturn, push down; (of a person) to fall down headlong; to topple down. (reflexive verb) (of liquid) to be spilt. etukumooros akile: the milk has been spilt, upset. 
aitukurian ki-a (causative verb) to frighten; to horrify; to discourage; to deter; to cow; to scare. 
aitukurwoor ki-o (causative verb) to cause to fail; to cause to give up (a task, a work); to disable. aitukurwoor etyang: to run down an animal to death. 
aitukusiar ki-a (causative verb) to cause to dry up a little; to make to heal (a wound). 
aitukutuk ki-a (transitive verb) to tie up hard; to bind in a big knot. kitukutukata akaninike: tie up her/his hands. 
aitukuun ki-o (causative verb) to make to foam (by adding salt to vegetables or adding baking soda to dough, or stirring soap and water). 
aitule ki-o (transitive verb) to blow (fire); to accelerate (a vehicle). itulei ngesi akim: she/he is blowing into the fire. aituleikin akim: to stir up or kindle the fire; to light up (by blowing). 
aituleor ki-o (transitive verb) to blow away; to somersault or tumble. 
aitulum ki-o (causative verb) to throw; to force to dive; to force to submerge; to immerse. 
aituluor ki-o (transitive verb) to alter; to convert; to change; to transform; to cause to change colour, manners, etc. aituluor inyamat kotoma akoik: to digest food in the stomach. 
aitulutul ki-o (transitive verb) to pour out from a narrow container (as from a bottle or gourd). 
aitum ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fat; to be stout or thick; to swell. itumit ijo: you are stout and corpulent. 
aitumor ki-o (intransitive verb) to delay; to prevent; to divert; to distract; to detain. ketumo eong aswam: work has delayed me (reflexive verb) to dally; to delay; to linger; to trifle; to dawdle; to be distracted. itumor ijo korot: you have lingered on the way.
aitumudak ki-o (causative verb) to make blind; to command to shut the eyes. amuton itumudaki itunganan: darkness makes one partially blind. 
aitumun ki-o (causative verb) to cause to hope; to promise; to pledge; to engage. cp. aisumun
aitumunet (plural aitumuneta) (noun F) a promise; a vow; a gentleman’s agreement or engagement; a pledge; an engagement. cp. aisumunet
aitumur ki-o (causative verb) (used with plural object) to surprise; to take by surprise; to take unawares; to startle.
aitumurakin ki-a (causative verb) to make to ripen or ferment by covering (usually in a pot to ripen); (of corpse) to cause to decay. etumurakis alup lokatwan: the earth has caused the corpse to decay.
aitumurikin ki-a (transitive verb) to take by surprise. abu eong ketumurik nges ekokoi ikaboro: I took her/him by surprise stealing my things. (transitive verb) (used with singular or plural object) to surprise; to take unawares; to startle. abu atwanare naka totoka ketumurik eong: the death of my mother took me by surprise. 
aitumurwokin ki-o (transitive verb) to cause to forget. 
aitumusumus ki-o (causative verb) to dim; to make dark; to do till evening. aitumusumusio naka akolong: eclipse of the sun
aitun ko-a (transitive verb) to embrace; to put hands round; to hug; to hold in two hands; to press to heart; to fondle. cp. aiitun: to remember.
aitung ki-a (transitive verb) (of a woman) to stunt the growth of children by conceiving before the child is weaned. 
aitungakin ki-a (transitive verb) (of a woman) to stunt the growth of child before it is weaned by too early conception; to nip in the bud.
aitungananikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to act or look like a person. 
aituny1 ekileng ki-o (transitive verb) to make a knife blunt or dulled. 
aituny2 ki-a (transitive verb) to knock against; to bump against; to clash with.
aituny3 ki-o (transitive verb) to stir up; to poke fire; to feed the fire.
aitunyakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to push over, on, or somewhere; to knock or bump against something; to clash with one another. etunyakinos amotokan: the motorcars crashed or bumped against each other; the cars collided with each other. 
aitunyar (reflexive verb) to be in a hurry; to go away in a hurry. 
aitunyit ki-o (transitive verb) to speed up; to urge on; to push ahead; to drive on (only of visible things). akoto eong aitunyit: I want to speed up (the motorcar). 
aitunyokin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to add firewood (to a fire); to put on fire; to stir fire. 
aitunyokin2 ki-o (transitive verb) (of knife or an axe) to make blunt on or somewhere. abu ngesi kitunyok ekileng amoru: she/he blunted her/his knife on a stone. 
aitunyonokin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep the fire burning (by adding firewood). 
aitunyunyurikin ki-a (causative verb) to make angry with; to enrage; to annoy with; to provoke. 
aitup ko-a (transitive verb) to follow; to imitate; to succeed (another as heir); to obey. atupi eong akonikiro: I shall do as you request. 
aitupuc ki-o (transitive verb) to reconcile; to bring or make peace between; to reunite; to bring together. 
aitupurucikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to become or look like early morning. etupuruciki akwap: it is dawning. 
aitupuset (plural aitupuseta) (noun F) similitude; likeness; a contrast; a model; an analogy. 
aituput ki-o (causative verb) to make like; to shape like; to imitate; to form like; to compare; to cause to resemble. 
aituputoor ki-o (intransitive verb) to copy; to compare; to make like; to imitate. 
aitur1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to pour into through a narrow neck. kitur akile otuo: pour the milk into the gourd. 
aitur2 ki-o (transitive verb) to praise; to glorify; to exalt; to extol; to applaud. kituritete Edeke: praise God. 
aitur3 ko-o (transitive verb) to cut into big pieces; to take (food) in big lumps. 
aiturakin ki-a (transitive verb) to pour into (through a narrow neck). cp. abukokin: to pour into (from any vessel). 
aituraun ki-a (transitive verb) to butt; to bump; to ram against.
aituret (plural aitureta) (noun F) a praise; an applause; a funnel. cp. aijililet
aiturit ki-o (transitive verb) to be praising; to praise constantly. ituritos itunga akecoa: people praise her/his wisdom. 
aituro ki-o (intransitive verb) to boast; to brag; to exult; to applaud or vainglory; to bluster; to bluff. 
aituroikin ki-o (intransitive verb) to flower; to bloom. 
aiturokin ki-o (transitive verb) to recommend by praising; to be proud of (reflexive verb) to praise oneself; to boast; to brag; to glory; to vaunt; to bluster. 
aituronut1 (singular noun F) fondness for praising; tendency to praise; bragging. 
aituronut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be fond of praising; to be fond of exalting; to brag often. 
aiturur1 (singular noun F) sadness; grief; melancholy; sorrow. 
aiturur2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to grieve; to regret; to mope; to mooch; to fret; to be sad or sorry; to be downcast. (transitive verb) to bemoan. 
aitururum ki-a (causative verb) to cause to groan; to spread rumour; to spread lies abroad. 
aiturutur ki-o (transitive verb) (of wound on the leg) to be made worse by walking or dancing too much, etc. 
aitus ki-a (intransitive verb) to snort (as of pig, sheep, or goat); to sniff. 
aitusar ki-a (transitive verb) (of a calf, lamb or kid) to suck the udder while making a snorting sound. 
aitusub ki-a (causative verb) to cause to be like; to cause to make. sirikitusub eong ebang: do not make me a fool. 
aitusuba ki-a (intransitive verb) (of oneself) to act like. siritusuba bala lokabaran: do not act like a rich man. 
aitusulianyar ki-a (causative verb) to bless; to wish good luck to. 
aitutu ki-o (transitive verb) to beat (the ground) hard; to stamp down; to raise the level of floor. 
aitutub ki-o (causative verb) to transmit; to let pass; to cause to cut.
aitutuk ki-o (intransitive verb) to make a vow; to vow; to promise; to insure; to pledge; an indenture. cp. aitumun: to promise. 
aitutuket (plural aitutuketa) (noun F) a testament; a promise; a vow; a covenant; a pledge. Aitutuket Nakitetet: the New Testament. Aitutuket Namojong: the Old Testament.
aitutukin ki-o (transitive verb) to beat flat for; to stamp down for or somewhere; to shoot with a rifle. aitutukin aipany: to fill a hole (stamp down the earth of). 
aitutukokin ki-o (causative verb) to cause to gather or to assemble. 
aitutum ki-a (causative verb) to fatten (transitive verb) (of a fireplace) to belch out smoke. 
aitutun ki-a (causative verb) to allow to take hold of; to cause to embrace. 
aitutupikin ki-a (causative verb) to cause to succeed each other; to allow to follow after; to bring close behind. 
aituturum ki-o (transitive verb) to cause trouble to; to instigate to do bad; to incite; to influence negatively. 
aituturur ki-o (causative verb) to sadden; to make sad; to grieve.
aituu ki-a (transitive verb) to take many; to call many. 
aituuar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away many. ai bo ituuari ijo idwe lu?: where are you taking all these children to? 
aituumokin ki-a (causative verb) to astonish; to flabbergast; to surprise; to amaze. 
aituur ki-o (causative verb) to cause to smell of; to cause to miss or omit.
aituurianet (plural aituurianeta) (noun F) a corruption of aituuryanet: abbreviation.
aituurikin ki-o (causative verb) to allow somebody to smell something. 
aituuryan1 ki-a (causative verb) to shorten; to abbreviate; to cut short; to abridge; to condense. 
aituuryan2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to curdle (fresh milk by mixing with sour milk). 
aituuryanar ki-a (causative verb) to make shorter or lower; to become brief. 
aituuryanet (plural aituuryaneta) (noun F) an abbreviation; a brief; a summary.
aituut ki-o (transitive verb) to teach; to initiate into a craft (used with plural object). kituut itelepai aiwadik: teach the boys the rudiments of writing. 
aituutoor ki-o (transitive verb) to instruct; to train; to initiate a person into anything; to tutor.
aituuwaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to call together; to put many together; to cram together. sirikituuwaik iboro ngul kere toma asaduku: don't cram all those things into the box. 
aituwuor ki-o (causative verb) to deflate or puncture. 
aitwa ko-a (transitive verb) to thrash; to beat out (lumps of earth); to knock down (fruit) with a stick. aitwa aloboi: to clear lumps of earth from furrows (by beating them). aitwa araito: to knock down fruit (with stick). aitwa emaido: to shake uprooted groundnuts. aitwa akiro: to talk much. 
aitwal ki-a (transitive verb) to mark in different colours anyhow; to stain, tinge; to paint roughly.
aitwalitwal ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to be speckled; to blemish; to stain; to cause to be spotted. ngai kitwalitwali ekagoe?: who has made these stains on my dress (cloth)? 
aitwam ko-a (intransitive verb) to talk at random. 
aitwap ko-a (transitive verb) to walk blindly; to walk without caring where one treads. cp. aitwal.
aitwar ko-a (transitive verb) to dismiss; to send away; to say goodbye to; to release to go away. akoto aitwar ijo: I want to bid you farewell. ibore yenitwaret: a parting gift. 
aitwekenyun ki-o (causative verb) to awaken someone else; to rouse from sleep. ajotoi sek papa, konye adaun aitwekenyun: daddy was asleep earlier on, but he has been awoken. cp. aikweny, aitekwenyun. 
aitwel ki-o (intransitive verb) to stagger; to walk unsteadily (as if passing over potholes). etwelitoi ngesi emera ajon: she/he staggers when she/he is drunk. 
aitwelitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to keep staggering along. 
aitwelor ki-o (reflexive verb) to stagger away; to go in a hurry.
aitweny ko-a (transitive verb) to make sparks; to make fire with a flint. aitweng ekori: to be greedy (literally, to spark the buttocks). atwenyun akibiriiti: to strike a match. atwenyun akiro: to spark trouble. 
aityak ko-a (transitive verb) to divide; to share; to separate; to make a distinction; to distinguish. atwanare kityaki oni: it is only death that will do us part. kotyak kojokan: distinguish well. eraas kesi ipapero lumam etyakas: they are inseparable friends.
aityangaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be, do or look like an animal; to be beast-like. 
aiwa1 akipi ki-a (transitive verb) to ford a river; to wade across water; to scoop out water. aiwaar ecor: to wade through; to ford a river or lake. 
aiwa2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to joke; to jest; to tell a joke; to talk in a friendly fashion. 
aiwaca ki-a (intransitive verb) (of cow) to be in-calf. iwacas akituk ngun: those cows are in gestation. 
aiwacun ki-a (intransitive verb) (of cow) to conceive; (of udder) to swell. 
aiwad ko-a (transitive verb) to scoop out something thick; to scrape off something thick with fingers or an instrument. aiwad esik: aiwad amolig: to take honey from the beehive. aiwad amolig: (slang) to have an illicit love affair. aiwad atap: to take big lumps of atap with fingers. aiwad aoret: to scoop cow-dung. aiwad atan: to clean a water well by taking away mud from the bottom. aiwad ecor: to dredge a river or a well. 
aiwadik ki-a (transitive verb) to write, inscribe, scrawl, scribe or print; to record; to register. aiwadik ebaluwa: to write a letter. cp. aigirigir. 
aiwadikaet (plural aiwadikaeta) (noun F) a written permit; a written agreement; a document; endorsement. 
aiwadikakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to write to (somebody). 
aiwadikao (singular noun F) enrolment; registration. 
aiwadikaun ki-o (intransitive verb) to get oneself enrolled or registered; to give your name for a competition, examination, etc. 
aiwaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to help someone to scoop out water; to bale out water from or for. 
aiwak1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of cow’s udder) to be big with milk.
aiwak2 ko-a (transitive verb) (used with plural objects) to break off; to knock out; to take off (a big piece of something hard); to give a heavy blow. 
aiwal1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to begin to boil. ewalasi akipi: the water is beginning to boil.
aiwal2 ki-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to open wide; to take off; to uncover. aiwal akonye: to raise eyebrows; to open eyes wide.
aiwal3 ki-a (transitive verb) to separate something stuck; to make loose something stuck (as of stamp on envelope, etc). 
aiwalakin1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to open for; to uncover for; to dawn upon (in the literal sense); to do the whole night until dawn or until morning. 
aiwalakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to loosen or separate something stuck for somebody. 
aiwalar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be boiled. ewalasi akipi: the water has boiled. koyautu akipi nuiwalarito: bring boiling water. 
aiwalar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to open out (intransitive verb) (of flowers, ear of grain) to blossom; (of day) to dawn. ewala akwap: it is morning (literally, the earth has burst open) (reflexive verb) (of crust on wound) to come off; to peel off. 
aiwalar3 ki-a (transitive verb) to take off something stuck (as stamp, etc). cp. apacar
aiwalaret (plural aiwalareta) (noun F) aurora; sprouting (of mushroom or buds). aiwalaret nakakwap (noun F) daybreak; dawn.
aiwaliwal1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of cloudy sky) to clear. ewaliwal akuj: the sky has cleared. 
aiwaliwal2 ki-a (transitive verb) to cleanse surface of water before drawing water (intransitive verb) (of liquid on fire) to bubble; to boil.
aiwaliwalaar ki-a (transitive verb) (of the sky) to become clear or to become cloudless; to separate shelled groundnuts from the shells; to push away dirt on surface of water; to cleanse surface of water before drawing water. ewaliwalaar akuj: the sky has become clear. 
aiwalun ki-a (transitive verb) to take off (as stamp off an envelope); to peel off (as of bandage); to shell (reflexive verb) to come off; (of something fixed) to come loose; (of skin) to peel off; to fall off. cp. atakun. 
aiwan ko-a (transitive verb) to wound; to lacerate; to rip open; (as of bull with horn) to gore. kawanit ngesi eong: she/he has wounded me. 
aiwanganut1 (singular noun F) greed (eating hot food).
aiwanganut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be greedy (by eating hot food fast). 
aiwany ko-a (intransitive verb) to see. cp. aiany.
aiwar1 ki-a (transitive verb) to go in front and block progress of; to cut off one running away; to intercept. 
aiwar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to skim (as of milk, etc); to take off surface. 
aiwar3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become evening; to grow dark. awar akwap: it is evening; it is dark. 
aiwar4 nak’akwap (noun F) the evening or dusk. abuni eong kewar akwap: I shall come at sunset. 
aiwarag ki-a (transitive verb) to speak about in parables; to talk about someone. aiwarag itunganan: to talk about someone in parables; to propound a riddle. sirikiwaragak eong: do not talk about me in parables. 
aiwaragatoi ki-a (transitive verb) to keep telling untrue stories about someone. ejaas luiwaragatos lucetunga: there are people who go about telling untrue stories about others. 
aiwaragaun ki-a (transitive verb) to hint; to take a hint from. 
aiwaragikin ki-a (transitive verb) to tell a story, a fable, a parable to; to talk about someone. kiwaragik idwe akiro: tell the children a story. 
aiwarakin ki-a (transitive verb) (of anything) to go round to intercept for; to skim for. 
aiwaranar ki-a (transitive verb) to shave off often; to take off (many bad portions). 
aiwarar ki-a (transitive verb) to slice off; to skim; to take off the top of anything. 
aiwasi ki-a (intransitive verb) to be at the end of a row or a queue; to be the last on one side; to be at the border or edge. ingai iwasie?: who is the winger (in football)? who is the last in the queue?
aiwasit ki-o (intransitive verb) to stay alongside; to stay on the border; to remain at the side; to remain aloof. inyo bo iwasitor ijo?: why do you stay aloof (aside)? 
aiwasiwas ki-a (intransitive verb) to try to get away by sidling; to move away in fear or shyness; to go away in fear; to back away; to move away backwards. inyo bo iwasiwasia ijo?: why are you trying to get away? cp. aibwat. 
aiwaun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring something by carrying it through the water (reflexive verb) to come through water. awaun edou: it is raining. 
aiwe ko-a (transitive verb) to sow; to disseminate; to spread; to broadcast.
aiweiwea1 (singular noun F) a whisper; a secret. nukaiweiwea: secrets. iweiweasi nunyoika?: what are you (plural) whispering about? inera ngesi nukaiweiwea: she/he is divulging or telling secrets. 
aiweiwea2 ki-a (transitive verb) to whisper; to tell a secret.
aiweiwear ki-a (transitive verb) to talk in whispers about. kocoite ecudeteke loiweiweare: be careful or wary of her/his witchcraft people whisper about. 
aiweiweikin ki-a (transitive verb) to whisper to someone. 
aiwek ki-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to shake; to cause to rattle. cp. aiyek: to disenchant. aiwek akaen: to shake the rattle (a gourd with pebbles in it, used in traditional ceremonies). 
aiwel ki-a (transitive verb) to spatter; to scatter (as of hen searching for food in the soil). 
aiwelanar ki-a (transitive verb) to scatter in all directions; to spill all over (reflexive verb) to be scattered in all directions; to be spilled all over. 
aiwelar ki-a (transitive verb) to throw out things or liquids; to spill out or abolish; to scatter; to throw about. (reflexive verb) to come or fall into bits; to break into pieces. ewelaki ekwam akapapulai toma otogo kere: the wind has scattered my papers all over the house. (reflexive verb) to be scattered; to be dispersed or be spilled; to be thrown out. 
aiweliwel ki-a (transitive verb) to scatter; to break into fragments; to disarrange; to shatter; to squander; to lay waste; to abolish. eweliwel ekwam etogo: the wind has blown down the house. iweliweli akokor alupok: the hen is scattering the dust. iweliweli ijo ikoniboro atitai: you squander your property or assets for nothing.
