aiweliwelun ki-a (reflexive verb) to fall to bits; to fall to pieces; to shatter; to break to pieces. 
aiwelun ki-a (transitive verb) to scatter this way; to spill out (liquids or solids) this way; to peel off in the direction of the speaker. 
aiwen ko-a (transitive verb) cp. aiyen: to tie. aiwen ekingok: to guard your tongue; to be cautious of what one says (literally, to tie the dog).
aiweniwen ki-a (transitive verb) to twine or tie round; to spool. 
aiweniwenakin ki-a (transitive verb) to tie round something (reflexive verb) to tie oneself round. eweniwenakin anyunyura otauka: I am very angry (literally, anger has entangled itself round my heart). 
aiweriwer ki-a (intransitive verb) to go quickly through dry leaves; to rustle or to wear swishing clothes. kiweriwer ore: go home quickly. 
aiwet1 ki-a (transitive verb) to sip (hot tea or something bitter, hot, etc). iwesete kesi ecaai: they are sipping tea. 
aiwet2 ko-a (transitive verb) to peel (as of potatoes). 
aiwetar ki-a (transitive verb) to finish off (as of tea, etc). 
aiwiny ki-a (intransitive verb) to whistle. iwinya ngesi (plural iwinyas kesi) she/he is (they are) whistling.
aiwinyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to whistle for; to call by whistle. 
aiwo1 ki-o (transitive verb) to catch or trap dripping water or any liquid with some vessel. 
aiwo2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to leak; to drip. ewoete akipi: the water is dripping. ewoi etuo: the gourd is leaking. ewoi akai: the house (roof) is leaking. 
aiwo3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to sing a song or hymn; to talk often; to tell often. 
aiwo4 ko-o (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to take down loads from the head. 
aiwod ko-o (transitive verb) to scoop; to ladle out (as of vegetables or atap). aiwod atap: to serve food (specifically millet bread). 
aiwodiwod ki-o (transitive verb) to poke something blunt into a hole many times; to hollow out. iwodiwodi ikoku ekume: the child is poking at its nostril (with its finger). 
aiwoikin ki-a (intransitive verb) (of cow’s udder) to be heavy with milk. ewoiki akiteng: the cow's udder is heavy with milk (transitive verb) to keep, stop milk for. ewoiki akiteng akile: the cow has given up the milk (to the suckling calf). ewoikis ikisinake: her breasts are heavy with milk. 
aiwoiwo ki-o (intransitive verb) to progress slowly. 
aiwok ko-o (transitive verb) to draw (liquids); to scoop (liquids or flour). alosi aiwok akipi: I am going to fetch water, i.e. I am going to the well. aiwok akiria: to scoop up flour. 
aiwokiwok ki-a (transitive verb) to shake up and down (as of bottle, jerry-can or gourd). cp aijang: to shake vertically.
aiwol ki-o (transitive verb) to dig out; to dig up; to plough up; to lift up (a dress, etc) to expose. iwolete imongin akacok: the oxen are digging up my potatoes. 
aiwolongikin ki-o (reflexive verb) to undertake something sizable without any chance of success; to try something big. sirikiwolongikin numam ipedori: do not attempt what you cannot manage. cp. awongaikin.
aiwolor ki-o (transitive verb) to uncover; to raise up and take away; (of wind) to throw off. abu ekwam kiwolo akasoto: the wind blew off the dome of my food store. (reflexive verb) to come off; to peel or fall off. 
aiwolun ki-a (transitive verb) to lift up (roots and all); to dig up (stones or big things); to excavate (reflexive verb) to peel off; to come unstuck. ewolun eong amuny: my skin has peeled off. 
aiwolunet (plural aiwoluneta) (noun F) a lever or crowbar. 
aiwom ko-a (transitive verb) to fetch; to go and fetch; to bring. kowom akipi: fetch water. 
aiwona ki-a (intransitive verb) (of child) to be delivered; (of female) to bring forth; (of female) to give birth to. ewona akaberu: my wife has been delivered, i.e. she has been helped to give birth. cp. aijar; aidoun. 
aiwonet ki-o (transitive verb) to long for; to desire; to be passionate. ewonet eong alosit aiyeng: I long for a holiday. cp. aineket, aingobel. 
aiwong ko-a (intransitive verb) to yawn; to open (the mouth); to gape. 
aiwonga ki-a (transitive verb) to take or carry big loads. iwongai ipese ngin ikiliok lutiok: that little girl prefers getting huge men.
aiwongaar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away a big thing (reflexive verb) to go as a big person among children. 
aiwongaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to give something big to. 
aiwongatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to go about carrying big things; to go about like a big man. ai bo iwongatoi ijo?: where are you going with your heavy load, or as big as you are? 
aiwongonut1 (singular noun F) self-conceit; vain-glory; presumption; bombast. 
aiwongonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be opinionated, self-conceited; to be vainglorious; to be presumptuous; to boast, brag, vaunt 
aiwony ki-a (intransitive verb) (of moving on foot) to hurry; to be quick; to hasten; to get on. kiwonyete: hurry up (plural).
aiwonyakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hurry up to somebody or somewhere; to go quickly to do; to hasten to. kiwonyak atan: go quickly to the well. 
aiwonyanut1 (singular noun F) quickness; celerity; haste; alacrity; swiftness; speed. 
aiwonyanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fast, quick (in walking only, not in running). cp. atironu: fast in running. cp. aisunyit: quick at anything 
aiwonyun ki-a (intransitive verb) to come quickly; to hurry (hasten) this way. 
aiwoor akile ki-o (transitive verb) (said of a cow) to keep back milk; to withhold milk. ewoo akiteng akile: the cow withheld its milk (has kept it back). 
aiwope ki-o (transitive verb) to stretch for something; to try to reach or catch a high target; to aim at attaining an end; to aspire to. iwopet ngesi adumun ajakaanut: she/he aspires becoming a leader. iwopet ekatau: I long to. ewopei eong adolore Jinja: I am wishing I could reach Jinja. 
aiwopeor ki-o (transitive verb) to grasp; to try to reach; to reach for something; to try to catch by stretching out the arm. kiwopeo akan: stretch out your arm and get or hit. 
aiwor1 ki-a (transitive verb) to manure; to pour compost manure on land. 
aiwor2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of soil or earth) to split; to crack; to fissure. eworitos acok ngun: those potato heaps have split (implying the roots are mature for harvest). 
aiwor3 ko-o (transitive verb) to scoop out; to take out by handfuls. 
aiworiwor1 ki-a (transitive verb) to smear with cow-dung; to plaster with cow-dung. kiworiwor ekatogo: smear my house with cow-dung. alup nuiworor: humus.
aiworiwor2 ki-o (intransitive verb) (of wound) to fester. iworiwori akajimi: my wound has festered. 
aiworo ki-o (transitive verb) to call out names; to call someone; to shout at; to invite (intransitive verb) to shout. aiworo eporoto: to shout; cry out. 
aiworokin ki-o (transitive verb) to call for somebody; to shout for someone; to scoop up soil or earth and pour into (once). aworokin alup akonye: to scoop up soil and throw into someone’s eyes.
aiworoor ki-o (transitive verb) to call somebody away. adau Lokasuban aiworoor nges: the Creator has called her/him away (i.e. she/he is dead). 
aiworot ki-o (transitive verb) to be calling somebody; to invite. 
aiworoun ki-o (transitive verb) to call somebody to come; to summon or invite. kiworou etelepat: call the boy. 
aiwosa ki-a (transitive verb) to accuse; to sue; to call to court; to go to court. iwosai ngesi: she/he has gone to court (to seek redress). 
aiwosakin ki-a (transitive verb) to plead for somebody; to take up somebody's case; to take each other to court.
aiwosis (plural aiwosisyo) (noun F) a toll gate; a revenue checkpoint. 
aiwot1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be advanced in age; to become weak due to old age. ewotosi ngesi ikar: she/he is advanced in age.
aiwot2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to shift; to go slowly; to move step by step; to fall slowly; to go slowly down; to grow slowly. iwosi etogo ngol: that house is slowly falling. 
aiwotor kau ki-o (intransitive verb) to move slowly backward. 
aiwotun ki-o (intransitive verb) to come forward step by step. 
aiwote ki-o (transitive verb) to hire labourers; to be engaged for a wage or anything; to work for anything, even for food or beer. iwoteete kesi emaido: they work for groundnuts. iwotei ngesi akiro: she/he is looking for trouble. 
aiwoteun ki-o (transitive verb) to deserve; to earn. akoto aiwoteun idisirigin: I want to earn a little money. 
aiwotokin ki-o (intransitive verb) to shift forward to; to advance; to gain ground. nepe kiwotoki akwap: when it was getting towards evening. 
aiwoun akipi ki-o (transitive verb) to catch dripping water, etc. 
aiwowa ki-a (transitive verb) to roast; to fry. iwowai ngesi ikong: she/he is frying white ants. 
aiwowaet (plural aiwowaeta) (noun F) (Usuk) a frying pan; a griddle; a grid-iron. cp. aiwowas.
aiwowaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to fry in, for, or somewhere. 
aiwowas (plural aiwowasia) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a frying pan; a griddle; a grid-iron. cp. aiwowaet.
aiwu1 ki-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to empty liquids. 
aiwu2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to fart or pass wind; to gas or break wind.
aiwuc1 ipon ki-a (transitive verb) (used with plural objects or repeated action) to purse lips. iwuci ngesi ipon: she/he purses her/his lips. 
aiwuc2 ki-o (transitive verb) to throw (things more than once); to fling. sirikiwuc iboro ngul kinga: do not throw those things outside. kiwuc amor ngun kinga: throw those stones outside. 
aiwucakin ipon ki-a (transitive verb) to purse lips at somebody. 
aiwucar ki-a (transitive verb) to purse lips.
aiwucokin ki-a (transitive verb) to throw in, at, or to. 
aiwucor ki-o (transitive verb) (used with singular or plural object) to throw away; to fling away; to toss; to throw (a ball). kiwuco acokit na: throw away this potato. 
aiwucun ki-a (transitive verb) to throw this way. 
aiwud ki-o (transitive verb) to prod; to insert (a needle); to poke. iwudi ngesi eswam: she/he prods the rat-hole (to force the rat out). 
aiwudet (plural aiwudeta) (noun F) (Usuk) a bicycle pump. cp. aisiket. 
aiwudokin ki-o (transitive verb) to poke in (just once); to insert (a needle or any piercing instrument); to inject; to inoculate or vaccinate; to pump up. 
aiwuduka ki-a (intransitive verb) to show discontent, displeasure, or dissatisfaction; to complain; to sigh. koyanga ekoniropit, siriwudukai: take what you’ve earned and don't complain. 
aiwuduwud ki-o (transitive verb) to poke repeatedly; to keep prodding; to look for a hole (by prodding). 
aiwuk ko-o (transitive verb) to pull up or uproot heavy things. aiwuk ibilenga: to catch big mud-fish.
aiwukek ki-o (intransitive verb) to be gigantic; to be outstanding; to be prominent (as of high tree or mountain). iwukekei emoru Masaba: Mt. Elgon is prominent. 
aiwukuukun ki-o (intransitive verb) to raise up a heavy or difficult thing (from the soil); to lift with difficulty; to pull up (something heavy from the soil) (reflexive verb) to rise from the dead; to rise with difficulty. 
aiwulakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to refuse to obey someone; to disobey. sirikiwulak papakon: don’t disobey your father (reflexive verb) to go on strike. ewulakinos ipakasin: the porters have gone on strike.
aiwulanut1 (noun F) disobedience; obstinacy; stubbornness. 
aiwulanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be disobedient or insubordinate. 
aiwulor ki-o (transitive verb) a corruption of aiwolor: to blow off open; to lift up and away (as of wind). abu ekwam kiwolo asoto: the wind blew the dome of the granary away. 
aiwum1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to begin to smell; to begin to rot or corrupt; to putrefy. ewum akiring na: this meat is beginning to smell. 
aiwum2 ki-a (transitive verb) to give a beating to; deal blows to; to maul; to maltreat; to contuse. cp. aium. 
aiwum3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to wonder; to stand aghast; to be astonished or surprised (not often used in its simple form). 
aiwumun ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall heavily from a height. 
aiwumuumo ki-o (intransitive verb) to mutter; to confer together in low voices; to talk together in low tones. iwumuumos itunga kotogo: people are murmuring inside the house. 
aiwumuwumo ki-o (intransitive verb) (of bees) to drone; (of people) to murmur. 
aiwuni ki-o (transitive verb) to make three; to make a third. 
aiwuniikin ki-o (transitive verb) to make a third; to do for the third time; to make three for. 
aiwuny1 ki-o (transitive verb) to push up; to pull up (of anything); to raise up; to lift up. aiwuny ekume: to pull up the nose. aiwunyokin ipon: to pull up the lips; to show with lips or to point to with lips. 
aiwuny2 ko-a (transitive verb) to snort; to blow the nose; to sneeze. awunyar ekume: to blow out the nose; to dilate nostrils i.e. make them wider. 
aiwunyonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to keep lifting or raising up; to pout. awunyor ekume: to show contempt (by turning up nose or lips). 
aiwup1 ko-a (transitive verb) to thread (beads, etc); to string. 
aiwup2 ko-a (transitive verb) to satiate; to wear or fatigue. kawupit eong aswam na: this work has tired me out. kawupata eong ajon: I am sated by beer: I have had enough beer. kawup eong cut ainyam: I have really had my fill of food. 
aiwupaun ki-o (reflexive verb) to fall from a height. 
aiwur ko-a (intransitive verb) to go to bed hungry; to sleep hungry overnight. cp. aurakin
aiwurut ki-o (intransitive verb) (in Karamoja) to have diarrhoea. aiwurut aokot: to have dysentery. iwurusi ngesi: she/he has diarrhoea. cp. ailep. 
aiwuruwuro ki-o (intransitive verb) to murmur; to mutter, rumble, etc. iwuruwuro akwap: the earth rumbles. inera ngesi kiwuruwuro: she/he speaks in a low tone. 
aiwut ko-o (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to pull out (teeth, testes, or anything from ground, etc); to pull out of a hole or socket; to castrate. aiwut ikel: to pull out teeth. aiwut emong: to castrate a bull. aiwut etunganan: to take out power (by witchcraft). 
aiwuti1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to sigh. iwutiei ngesi: she/he sighs. iwutiete kesi: they are sighing. 
aiwuti2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to sob; to blubber. iwutie ikoku: the child sobs. 
aiwutionut1 (singular noun F) niggardliness; miserliness; stinginess; close-fistedness. cp. aibityonut.
aiwutionut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be niggardly; to be ungenerous 
aiwuwor ki-o (transitive verb) to empty or drink out altogether. 
aiya ko-a (transitive verb) to take away; to lead away; to rule; to govern. 
aiyaga ko-a (transitive verb) to loosen or unfasten; to untie. cp. ailac. 
aiyagiyag ko-a (transitive verb) to loosen often; to make very loose. 
aiyaki ki-a (transitive verb) to send on errands; to use; to commission. ai bo iyakie ijo etelepataka?: where are you sending my boy to? 
aiyakianut1 (singular noun F) obedience; submissiveness; service.
aiyakianut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be obedient; to be dutiful or submissive 
aiyakiar ki-a (transitive verb) to consign to; to send somebody; to despatch; to delegate; to commission. cp. aijukar. 
aiyakikin ki-a (transitive verb) to send to or somewhere (on errand). 
aiyakitoi ki-a (transitive verb) to serve; to minister to; to be obedient to; to be dutiful. ateker ekoto idwe luiyakiaka: the clan loves obedient children. 
aiyakitonut1 (singular noun F) utilitarianism; submissiveness. 
aiyakitonut2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to be useful, submissive, etc 
aiyakiun ki-a (transitive verb) to send this way (on errand). 
aiyala ki-a (intransitive verb) to joke; to chat. 
aiyalaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to tell a joke to; to joke to; to converse with. 
aiyalakin ki-o (reflexive verb) (Serere) to become negligent. 
aiyalama ki-a (transitive verb) to be glad; to be pleased or jocose; to be grateful; to be delighted or happy. iyalamas kesi aanyun ijo: they are glad to see you. aswam naiyalamare: pleasant work. eyalama: I am glad; thank you. cp. aiyalama
aiyalamikin ki-a (transitive verb) to thank; to be grateful for (reflexive verb) to be thankful; to become happy, glad, or grateful. eyalamikinos kesi: they are grateful or thankful. 
aiyalamikinet (plural aiyalamikineta) (noun F) compliment; a thank you; gratitude; amenity. 
aiyalanut1 (singular noun F) tendency to converse; chitchatting. 
aiyalanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of chatting; to be good at telling jokes 
aiyalaun ki-a (intransitive verb) to speak out (in jest).
aiyalayalatoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to chatter; to jabber. 
aiyalongong ki-o (intransitive verb) to be anxious; to fret; to worry or to be worried; to be troubled about. iyalongongoi ijo atitai: you are worried for nothing. 
aiyalongongoet (plural aiyalongongoeta) (noun F) anxiety; worry; dread; melancholy; trepidation. 
aiyam ki-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to take gently or carefully; to handle gently; to put carefully; to mollify; to do cautiously; to lift gently; to treat gently. kiyam ikaboro: treat my belongings (things) with care. aiyam akonye k'ajon: to wash the face of a young child with beer (a traditional ceremony practised on the child when 1-2 years old purportedly to prevent sickness). 
aiyamakin ki-a (reflexive verb) to calm down or become quiet, peaceful (as of anything disturbed or painful). 
aiyamakina ki-a (intransitive verb) to be at peace. 
aiyamakit ki-o (transitive verb) to do carefully or gently; to take, carry, or treat carefully. kiyamakite asaduku na: treat this box carefully. 
aiyamam (intransitive verb) a corruption of aijamam: to be comfortable; to keep calm; to sit idly; to be gentle. ijamamaete kesi: they are comfortable. 
aiyamar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away or to put away gently, quietly; to take wholesale (i.e. everything). (reflexive verb) to go away softly (without disturbing anyone). abu ngesi kiyamar: she/he went away quietly. 
aiyamitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to walk or do things cautiously or carefully; to walk gently. 
aiyamiyam ki-a (transitive verb) to persuade; to entreat; to beg gently; to soothe; to pamper; to placate; to please; to humour. 
aiyamun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring gently or quietly. kiyamu amot ngin: bring that pot carefully (reflexive verb) to come quietly or gently. kiyamunos togo: come softly inside the house. 
aiyany ko-a (transitive verb) to see; to look up; to visit; to inspect; to pay a visit; to guard. abuni aiyany ijo: I shall come to pay you a visit. 
aiyap ki-a (intransitive verb) to be slow; to hesitate; to go slowly; to delay or be late; to loiter; to lag behind. ibu ijo kiyap k’orot: you delayed on the way. 
aiyapakin ki-a (transitive verb) to hit lightly (once only); to alleviate. 
aiyapar ki-a (transitive verb) to slow down. kiyapaa amotoka: slow down the car i.e. reduce its speed (reflexive verb) to go last of all. 
aiyapepera ki-a (intransitive verb) to be humble; to be gentle, meek, mild; to be polite or merciful. iyapepera apese ngin: that girl is good and gentle. 
aiyapeperanut (singular noun F) courtesy; gentleness; humility; meekness, etc. 
aiyapeperikin ki-a (reflexive verb) to humble oneself for. 
aiyapiyap1 ki-a (transitive verb) to do carefully, slowly, lazily; to go somewhere slowly. ilosi iyapiyapi: you go or do carefully, slowly. cp. aiyapiyap
aiyapiyap2 ki-a (transitive verb) to tap or strike gently or lightly (many times); to beat slightly (more than once). kiyapiyap ikoku naarai edit: beat the child lightly for it is young. 
aiyapo ki-o (intransitive verb) to swear or take an oath; to vow; to abjure. iyapoi ngesi (plural iyapoete kesi): she/he is (they are) swearing. abu ngesi kiyapo ebe mam icaki ore: she/he swore never to go home again. 
aiyapoet (plural aiyapoeta) (noun F) abjuration, refusal; swearing. cp. aiyapoet
aiyaponut ki-a (intransitive verb) to be given to swearing; to be inclined to make vows. 
aiyapun1 ki-a (transitive verb) to take a little off; to encroach slightly. 
aiyapun2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to come last of all (slowly); to come slowly this way. 
aiyapunun ki-a (intransitive verb) to eke out; to remove a little at a time; to be thrifty, economical. kiyapununei ikapunukon: be frugal, thrifty, or economical with your money (singular).
aiyar ko-a (transitive verb) to kill; to slaughter; to murder; to slay. eyari: she/he/it kills or is lethal, deadly. eyarete: they kill, they are fatal or deadly. aiyar luipu: to massacre. aiyar ebole: to break a promise; to breach a contract or a vow. aiyar etau: to disappoint; to break somebody’s heart. cp. aidongor, aiar
aiyareikin ki-a (transitive verb) to do a second time; to repeat; to add to make two; to double. eyareiki nges aberu: he took a second wife. aberu naiyareikina (adjective) the 2nd wife. 
aiyaror ki-o (intransitive verb) to beg sorrowfully. 
aiyarorotoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to keep on begging sorrowfully; to live on alms or by begging. inyo bo iyarorotoi ijo?: why do you go about begging? 
aiyasetait (plural aiyaseta) (noun F) an appendix (in a book); an annex; an addition.
aiyat ki-a (transitive verb) to accrue; to increase; to augment; to add; to increase, by adding; to annex; to extend (power or riches); to say further; to give more. aiyatakin: to add to. aiyatun: to make bigger, greater. aiyat akiro: to exaggerate. iyatunitos ikoku ngin igoen: clothes make that child look bigger. cp. eias. aiyat 
aiyatakin ki-a (transitive verb) to do again; to repeat; to add to; to increase; to augment; to extend (power or riches); to annex; to give more to; to proceed; to appeal (in court). kiyatak abeei auni: add three eggs.
aiyatakinet (plural aiyatakineta) (noun F) an increase; the addition; the repetition; the increment.
aiyatanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to keep adding; to keep exaggerating; to do continually. iwuta ijo da aiyatanakin amuunyu (esukaali) akiro: you (singular) are also exaggerating the story. 
aiyaya1 agaria (singular noun F) a way or method of fishing. 
aiyaya2 agaria ki-a (transitive verb) to fish. 
aiye1 cp. aije: (Serere) to plait grass pad or to mould a pot. 
aiye2 cp. aiwe: (Serere) to sow. 
aiye3 cp. aiwo: (Serere) to sing. 
aiyecun cp. aijecun: (Serere) to abort or miscarry a pregnancy. 
aiyed ko-a (transitive verb) (of eyes) to blink; to crush lice. aiyed akonye: to screw up eyes; (of eyes) to blink or twinkle. 
aiyedar ki-a (transitive verb) to suck in the abdominal muscles; to work very hard; to be bent on finishing work; to have one’s whole mind on the work. iyedarit ikoku: the child has refused to eat. kiyeda adaun aswam kon lolo: work hard to finish your work today. aiyedar akoik: to pull in or to contract the stomach. 
aiyediyedo ki-o (intransitive verb) to be inactive, feel lazy (after overeating). 
aiyeduko ki-o (intransitive verb) (as of a sick person or dying animal) to be breathing slightly. iyeduko ngesi: she/he/it is breathing faintly. 
aiyek1 ki-a (transitive verb) to postpone; to put off matters; to remove or to move out of reach. kiyeka ekonitogo ngina: build your house there (i.e. remove it from here). kinyek aiyek akiro: don’t postpone matters. kinyek aiyek emusaago: don’t postpone the case. 
aiyek2 ki-a (transitive verb) to shake; to rattle (anything). aiyek akaen: to shake a rattle (a gourd with pebbles - as a charm by witchdoctors). 
aiyekakin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to take further away.
aiyekakin2 ki-a (transitive verb) to reach something to somebody; to hand over to; to promote (in rank or level). kiyekakinai ekalaamu: reach me the pencil. 
aiyekanar ki-a (transitive verb) to keep postponing. 
aiyekar ki-a (transitive verb) to take away from here, remove, carry away; to alienate; to send or put further away. kiyeka ikoniboro acekwap: take your things elsewhere. eyeka ngesi etauke kaneka: she/he has alienated her/his affections from me. kiyeka eicolong ngina: put this chair over there.
aiyeket (plural aiyeketa) (noun F) a rattle; anything that makes a rattling noise. 
aiyekun ki-a (transitive verb) to bring near. kiyekutu akinei ne: bring the goats near here. 
aiyel ki-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to strew; to scatter. cp. aiwel
aiyelar1 ki-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to destroy; to pull asunder; to scatter; to disperse, strew. kiyelasi etogo: pull that house down. 
aiyelar2 ki-o (reflexive verb) (Serere) to disperse; to scatter; to break up (as of clouds, etc). eyelaros idowon: the clouds have dispersed.
aiyeliyel ki-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to scatter; to disperse. cp. aiweliwel. 
aiyem ko-a (transitive verb) to make or cut a way through the bush or high grass. aiyem abwas: to break through the hedge or enclosure. aiyem ekitwi: to break through the bush; to cut through the bush. koyem ekitwi karai ikoto adumun inyamat: clear away the bush (make a new garden) if you want food. aiyem etogo: (formerly) to break open the roof of a house at twin dances when the uncle of twins cannot get in through the door. 
aiyen ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to tie; to knot; to bind (as when making a roof or granary); to fasten; to bind (to a promise or to secrecy); to pack up; to bind (as of certain foods), cause constipation. aiyen baa ba: to tie firmly or tightly. aiyen ekingok: to say nothing about what you know. koyen iboro kon kolot: pack up and go. ejaas nuk’ayenitos eong angajep: I am bound to secrecy. emuogo ejeni aiyen akoik: cassava is good food for diarrhoea, that is, it binds the stomach. aiyen otuja: to imprison. eyenit lolo aberu etau: the woman has tied a rope round herself on account of pain. aiyen imugug: to die; to pass away. cp. aimur
aiyeng1 (singular noun F) a rest; a breath; a pause; a holiday or vacation. 
aiyeng2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to breathe. eroko ngesi iyenga: she/he/it is still breathing. iyengi ngesi: she/he/it is having a rest. iyenga ngesi: she/he/it is breathing (plural: iyengas kesi). 
aiyeng3 ki-a (intransitive verb) to rest; to pause; to take a holiday. aloto idwe aiyeng: the children have gone on holiday. alosi aiyeng: I am going for a holiday.
aiyengakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to breathe over; to pant; to take a holiday or a rest somewhere; to pause somewhere. 
aiyenganakin ki-o (reflexive verb) to pant; to gasp. 
aiyengar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to breathe aside. kiyenga awai, erono eiyengane kon: breathe aside, your breath is bad. 
aiyengar2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to breathe in (inhale); to draw breath. aiyenganar apuru naemasiatar ice esigala: to passive smoke.
aiyengun ki-a (intransitive verb) to relax; to breathe out (exhale); to pause; to give oneself a respite, retire from work. kiyengu ber (singular); kiyengutu ber (plural): have a rest (relax awhile). 
aiyengunet (plural aiyenguneta) (noun F) a comma; a resting-place or point; the interlude; a sigh; a rest. 
aiyeniyen ki-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to tie round; to coil round; to entwine; to wind by coiling. aiyeniyen ausi akeju: to tie a bandage on the leg. cp. aiweniwen
aiyeniyenakin ki-a (reflexive verb) (Serere) to be tangled up. eyeniyenaki ikalol auno bon: the kid has entangled itself with a rope. (transitive verb) to tie several things together for someone. 
aiyep cp. aijep: (Serere) to fell; to cut a tree. 
aiyer1 cp. aijer: (Serere) to twist rope, etc. 
aiyer2 ko-a (transitive verb) to take or to cut a small piece of cloth or hair, meat; (of eyes) to close a little; to nibble at (like goats, etc). koyer akonye ikwenyi: close the eyes a little. koyerutu akiring itubete: cut the meat into small pieces. ayerun: cut towards. ayerar: cut away, off. ayerakin: to cut for someone. koyerakinai edimaido kape: give me some groundnuts to roast. cp. aswetun.
aiyet1 ekiror ko-o (transitive verb) to give a name; to nickname. cp. aidung ekiror.
aiyet2 ki-a (transitive verb) to sip hot tea, soup, etc; to suck through teeth or from hand. iyesi ngesi ecaai apaarasia kere: she/he always sips tea. kinyaritai ijo aiyet ecaai lok'epucit: you have been invited to a tea party. 
aiyet3 ko-o (transitive verb) to cut from the surface (as of meat); to slice; to cut from top; to carve. apupi bala eyesete akimai: I hear a noise as if they were harvesting millet. cp. aiwet
aiyetanar ki-a (transitive verb) to sip repeatedly; to take snuff. iyetanari ijo ijon idis idis aitodol amerikin: you will sip that beer till you get drunk. 
aiyetar ki-a (transitive verb) to draw in (liquid); to sip, suck up; to make a sucking or a sipping noise. iyetarit lolo etunganan ngol: he has been sipping (beer) today; he is tipsy or drunk. sirikiyeta asupu: do not drink the soup. 
aiyetun ki-a (transitive verb) to suck up (snuff, beer, tea, etc); to sip by oneself; to draw in smoke or one’s breath. 
aiyeyea1 (noun F) whispers; secrets.
aiyeyea2 ki-o (reflexive verb) to whisper; to speak softly; to do secretly. cp. aididia. 
aiyi1 aokot ko-a (intransitive verb) (of blood) to flow; to bleed. eyiete aokot: the blood is flowing. eyiete ikumesika: my nose is bleeding. eyiete eong ikumes: I am bleeding through the nose: my nose is bleeding.
aiyi2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to agree; to answer; to echo; to reply; to acknowledge one’s presence when called; to respond to a call. mam ijo iyii karai kinyaritai: you don’t answer when called. iyiete imor: the hills echo. 
aiyi3 ki-o (transitive verb) to cool by fanning, stirring or blowing on. iyie ekwam amwanus: the wind lessens the heat. kiyi akima komat lokadekan: cool the porridge and let the sick man drink it. aiyiikin: to cool for. kiyiik ikoku akile: cool the milk for the child (to drink). 
aiyi4 ko-a (transitive verb) to favour; to speak in favour of; to side with, protect, guard against; to separate fighters; to rescue. koyiata luejios ngul: separate those fighters. aitiyi: to cause, make to rescue, guard, etc.
aiyiar ko-a (transitive verb) to save from, rescue from, protect from, guard from. koyiarai kanekaronon: save me from evil. 
aiyiciic akonye ki-a (transitive verb) to look around, be curious. 
aiyid1 ki-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to wag; to shake the tail; to flirt. aiyid ekori: to wag the tail. iyidi ekingok ekori: the dog wags its tail. aiyid iselio: (of a very fussy person) to rush here and there. aiyid iselio bala nak'edaan akain: to be rushing about nervously like a wife going to a co-wife’s burial.
aiyid2 ki-a (transitive verb) to put away quickly; to hide quickly. eyidi ngol atap: he eats the food quickly. aiyidakin: to hide for. aiyidar: to hide away quickly. 
aiyid3 ko-o (transitive verb) to be satiated, full up with food; to satiate. esik lok'ao kisunyari aiyid: honey is very satiating. 
aiyidiyid ekori ki-a (transitive verb) (of a dog) to keep wagging the tail. 
aiyidiyidaar ki-o (reflexive verb) (of a person) to be very tall; (of hill, tree, etc) to be very high. emoru Masaba iyidiyidaara kuju: Mt. Elgon is very high. Odele iyidiyidaara noi: Odele is very tall. 
aiyiikin1 ki-a (transitive verb) to allow by saying yes; to permit by saying yes. kiyiikis ngul alosit: let these people go free. eyiikitos: they allow. aiyiikin alosit: to set free. 
aiyiikin2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to acknowledge a call; to agree; to answer when called. eyiikis idwe iworotoi: the children have answered when called. 
aiyikinyiny ki-a (intransitive verb) to have big fat cheeks. iyikinyiny nges: she/he has fat cheeks. 
aiyil ki-a (transitive verb) to swing things round. aiyil akuwan: to swing the body (being very busy or in dancing). aiyil iselio: to be alarmed. 
aiyilakin ki-a (transitive verb) to return, go back at once or quickly; to rush back; to hide quickly. abu ngesi kobu kosodi aiyilakin ore: she/he came and went back home quickly. eyilakin emir kaike: the rat rushed back into its hole (on perceiving danger). 
aiyilar1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to run away, turn away quickly. abu ngesi kobu kosodi bobo aiyilar: she/he/it came and then turned away quickly. 
aiyilar2 ki-a (transitive verb) to fling or throw away. kiyila ibore ngin kinga: throw that thing away. (reflexive verb) to turn away quickly. 
aiyilarar ki-a (intransitive verb) to be thin, emaciated, with a big head. 
aiyiligaar ki-a (transitive verb) to swing and throw away. 
aiyililitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to rush about; to dribble about (as with football); to wander about; to be restless. iyililitoi ikoku ngin: that child is restless. 
aiyilitoi ki-o (intransitive verb) to move about quickly, turn from place to place; to be fussy. 
aiyiliyil ki-a (transitive verb) to swing the of body, arms or things round. iyiliyilete idwe akanin ekerete: the children swing their arms when running. 
aiyilonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to have palsy; to keep collapsing or becoming unconscious. 
aiyilor1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to faint; to be unconscious (from beer, sickness, etc); to get fits; to be epileptic. aiyilor etida: to be frenzied with dancing. iyilorit aberu etida: the woman is frenzied by the healing dance. aiyilor amat ajon: to be drunk and unconscious with beer drinking. aisiiloor: to cause to faint; to drown; to be under anaesthetics. 
aiyilor2 ki-o (transitive verb) to knock or give a knock on; to hit or crack; to be stunned. cp. aiba. 
aiyilun ki-a (transitive verb) to hurry back this way, return at once. kiyilu emopiira atipet: be quick, kick the ball this way. eyilunos kesi naarai adumutu akiro kangina: they have returned at once because they got into trouble over there. 
aiyim ki-a (transitive verb) (of anything) to press down. cp. aimad. aicik. 
aiyin1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of tuberous food, such as potatoes or cassava) to be underdone; to fail to get cooked properly. eyinitos acok: the potatoes are not completely boiled or roasted. ayinata, ayina acok: the potatoes are underdone.
aiyin2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to waste; to wither away; to become thin, emaciated. aiyin ikoku ngin akuwan: that child has become thin. 
aiyin3 ko-a (transitive verb) to give many things to; to give too many. 
aiyina ki-a (intransitive verb) to become moist, wet, damp, mouldy. iyinatos igoeneka: my clothes are damp, moist. elupe loiyinat: wet clay. 
aiyinaikin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be too moist, damp, mouldy for. keyinaikit eong etogo: this house is too damp for me. 
aiyinat ki-o (intransitive verb) (Serere) to be damp, humid; to be moist; to have moisture. iyinat ne: it is damp here. iyinatos itogoi luka Iteso: the houses of the Iteso are damp. iyinat ngol akan: he is rich, well to do. iyinatos ikagoen: my clothes are damp (singular: iyinat egoe: the dress is damp). cp. aiinat
aiyinaun ki-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to become damp; to become moist; (of a naturally thin person) to grow fat a little.
aiying ki-o (transitive verb) to look for something by thrusting a stick or spear where it is expected to be; to fish with spear, as for mudfish - spearing the mud at random. aiyingiying ekori: to sit uneasily. 
aiyingiying ekori ki-o (transitive verb) to shake body as of one sitting restlessly; to sit restlessly. iyingiyingi ngesi ekori iboyie: she/he sits restlessly (literally, she/he sits shaking her/his tail). aiyingiying epii: to shake the drinking tube in the beer-pot (in order to clear it). 
aiyingokin (transitive verb) to fish with spear for someone or somewhere. alosi aiyingokin ikakoku ebileng: I am going to catch a mud-fish (with a harpoon) for my child. 
aiyingor ki-o (transitive verb) to feel with a stick or spear under water (as of one looking for fish or a rower of boat piercing the mud when rowing with a pole). 
aiyiniyina ki-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to whimper; to cry softly. cp. ainginingina. 
aiyiny1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to whistle. 
aiyiny2 ki-o (transitive verb) a corruption of aiying: to fish with spear by spearing. 
aiyiny3 ko-a (transitive verb) (used with plural object) to tell off; to ridicule. sirikiyiny itunga: don't tell off or ridicule people. 
aiyinyakin ko-a (transitive verb) (used with singular or plural object) to tell off someone; to ridicule someone.
aiyinyiyiny ki-a (intransitive verb) to feel cold; to feel itchy. keyinyiyinyi eong akuwan, akoto neemwana: I feel cold, I want a warm place. kakoto eong akuwan aipi naarai keyinyiyinyi: my body is itching, I want to scratch myself. 
aiyir ki-a (transitive verb) to taste something. kiyir ber ajon: first taste the beer. cp. aiir. aiyirakin: to taste for or somewhere; (of people) to taste each other (obscene).
aiyiria1 ki-a (intransitive verb) to look all round, go round in circles, to be confused; to be giddy or dizzy. ; (of earth) to turn round or revolve; (of head) to turn, be dizzy. iyiriai akou: she/he is confused. iyiriai emaase: the locusts fly round in circles. aiyiria akou: to be dizzy. iyiriai lo bala ebang: this man here is like a fool. iyiriai akwap: the earth revolves. akakou iyiriai: I am dizzy. aiyiria ajo: to be drunk with sleep; to be overcome with sleep. iyiriai ngol adeka: the sickness confuses him, causes him to roam about. 
aiyiria2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to wander about aimlessly; to roam about; to rove 
aiyiriar ki-a (transitive verb) to cause to roam about; to confuse. 
aiyiriayir ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a person, wind or water) to whirl round; to be stupid. 
aiyiriyir1 ki-o (intransitive verb) to appear as a mirage; to be deep down; to be precipitous, abysmal; to have a big view. ejai ayiriyir kwap: there is a deep abyss below. kongolia ngina elwana ngina, eyiriyiri ecor: look over, there is the mirage of the lake far off. karai kibwo kane komoru Apesur, eyiriyiri Serere noi: if you stand here at Moru-Apesur rock, you have a good view of Serere. 
aiyiriyir2 ki-o (intransitive verb) to walk quickly; to walk fast. 
aiyiror ki-o (reflexive verb) to disappear utterly. amoot eong akabore, konye ayiror: I looked for that thing of mine, but it is lost completely. eyiroros ikaboro kakonye: my things got lost under my eyes. cp. aolior.
aiyisinit (plural aiyisinin) (noun F) an armlet, bangle, wristlet made of iron; wire in general; brass bangle. 
aiyisit ki-o (transitive verb) to be in want (of anything); to be in need of. apoloor etelepat, iyisit do aberu: the boy is big, he wants to marry. eyisit eong isirigin: I am in want of money. 
aiyisiyisonor ki-o (reflexive verb) to swing head from side to side to show dislike or disgust (at something bad). 
aiyisokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to sit in the middle of people; to sit in the centre of anything. kiyisokin ijo amotoka: sit in the middle of the car. 
aiyit1 akituk ki-a (transitive verb) to pay dowry. iyisi ngesi akituk: he is paying the dowry.
aiyit2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to flow, well up; to leak; to seep out, trickle down. eyisi ecor: the water wells up from the well. eyisi amot: the pot leaks. 
aiyit3 ki-o (transitive verb) to remember; to keep in mind; to bring to mind, recall to mind; to recollect. 
aiyit4 ki-o (transitive verb) to wish; to want; to like; to desire; to require, request. eyit ikoku ajo, koyangaasi: the child wants to sleep, take it away. iyisito idwe abolia: children want to play. aisiyit: to cause to want to. isiyit ekooti aitwar ngesi: the court requests that she/he should be set free. 
aiyit5 ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to sharpen; to point (as of pencil or spear). eyisi ngesi ekekalaamu: she/he sharpens her/his pencil. koyit ekalaamu ngol: sharpen that pencil. eyisi ngesi ekalaamu: she/he sharpens the pencil. 
aiyitar akituk ki-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to pay away bride price; to show cows for dowry to in-laws. cp. aimany. 
aiyitokin ki-a (transitive verb) to do, start work late (after others). aiyitokin apotuun: to be pregnant after years of barrenness. aiyitokin abunere: to come late. eyitokis idwe aponere osomero: the children are late for school. (transitive verb) to call somebody for a job. keyitokinit lokapolon eong aceswam: the boss has given me another job. (transitive verb) to remember, call to mind. aiyitokin apotuun: to be pregnant after years without bearing a child.
aiyitor1 ki-o (transitive verb) to invite somebody to go away; to call apart, away. emamei Opejo, iyitorit nges inacike: Opejo is not there, his sister called him away. (reflexive verb) to call one another for some reason. 
aiyitor2 ki-o (transitive verb) to remember things or persons far off or left behind (intransitive verb) to become homesick. 
aiyitun ki-o (transitive verb) to remember, recollect, keep in mind, bring to mind, or recall to mind; to call hither. kiyitutu akiro nuka atukot: remember what was said in the meeting. kolot kiyitu ngesi kobu atipet: go and call her/him to come at once. 
aiyitunet (plural aiyituneta) (noun F) remembrance; commemoration; nostalgia. 
aiyiya1 ki-a (transitive verb) (of a person, fire, wind) to calm down.
aiyiya2 ki-a (transitive verb) to plane, smooth; to make level. aiyiya akiro: to smooth, settle matters. kiyiya erot: level out the road. 
aiyiyaikin ki-a (transitive verb) to level the floor or anything. 
aiyiyakin ki-a (reflexive verb) (of man when excited, of fire too hot, of wind or of liquids too hot) to calm down. (transitive verb) to make level, even; to plane. adau edou aiyiyakin: the storm has calmed down. 
aiyiyakina ki-a (intransitive verb) to be flat, even; to remain quiet. kiyiyakin ijo: (you) be quiet. 
aiyiyi ki-o (transitive verb) to cool by ladling up and down, or by blowing or fanning. kiyiyi akima: cool down the porridge.
aiyiyo ki-a (transitive verb) to console; to soothe (as of person in grief). 
aiyiyoit (plural aiyiyoi) (noun F) a variety of small fish. cp. omeena
aiyod ki-a (transitive verb) (of stick, wood) to break into pieces. cp. abilibil. 
aiyodo ki-o (transitive verb) (Serere) to get by flattery; to gatecrash. iyodoi ngesi esigala: she/he is trying to get a cigarette by flattery. cp. aijodo
aiyodoikin ki-o (transitive verb) to get a thing for someone else or somewhere by flattering or by being nice. 
aiyodoun ki-o (transitive verb) (Serere) to take or get something for oneself by flattery. cp. aijodoun
aiyog ki-a (transitive verb) to make loose; to cause to be shaky. cp. aiyogiyog
aiyoga ki-a (transitive verb) to greet; to welcome; to salute; to thank; to accost. 
aiyogakin ki-a (transitive verb) to greet for; to salute on behalf of; to thank for (reflexive verb) to greet one another. keyogakinos ber: let us first greet each other. 
aiyogiyog ki-a (transitive verb) to loosen; to cause to be shaky. 
aiyogog1 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to be dressed or ornamented. iyogogoi aberu ngin noi: that woman is well-dressed or wears many ornaments. 
aiyogog2 ki-a (intransitive verb) (of a plant) to be laden with fruit. iyogogoi emucuuga: the orange-tree is laden with fruit. 
aiyokiyok ki-a (intransitive verb) to rattle; to tinkle (as of bells or coins in the pocket). iyokiyokas isirigin koisaoke: the money rattles in her/his pocket.
aiyom ki-a (transitive verb) to break to pieces; to crush with the feet (something dry); to smash to bits; (of a person) to wash the face. 
aiyomiyom ki-a (transitive verb) to smash completely; to break completely. 
aiyong ko-a (transitive verb) to fear; to stand in awe of; to be dismayed; to be afraid of; to revere; to dread. 
aiyoyo ki-o (transitive verb) to encourage or urge on (so that she/he performs better); to praise or cheer. cp. aima: to praise. 
aiyu ki-a (transitive verb) to agree; to allow; to suffer; to let; to tolerate. 
aiyud ko-o (transitive verb) to satiate; to reduce a gap; to narrow. kayud eong emaido: I have eaten enough groundnuts (the groundnuts have sated me). 
aiyudakin epelu ki-a (transitive verb) to lessen; to slacken a work; to decrease or diminish a task; to cut a task; to lighten a task. kiyudak ekapelu: lighten my task (work). 
aiyug ki-a (transitive verb) to run while stooping with arms moving up and down. aiyug ikeperin: to shrug (move shoulders up and down, as a sign of helplessness or refusal). 
aiyuk ki-o (transitive verb) to burn slightly (as with hot iron); to singe; to sear; to cauterise (as burning of rotten flesh with hot iron). 
aiyup1 ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to weary; to wear out; to tire out; to fatigue. kayupit eong aswam na: this work has fatigued me. cp. aiwup.
aiyup2 ko-a (transitive verb) to string beads, fish, or bits of meat. aiyup atip: to string beads. aiyup agaria: to string fish. aiyup akiring: to string pieces of meat. aiyup ikel: to pick or clean teeth. 
aiyuun ki-a (transitive verb) to believe; to agree to; to accede to; to abide by; to accept; to comply with. 
aiyuunanut1 (singular noun F) credulity; naivety; gullibility; submissiveness.
aiyuunanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be credulous, unsuspecting, gullible, or amenable 
aiyuunet (plural aiyuuneta) (noun F) approbation; belief; faith; conviction.
aiyuunit (singular noun F) faith; belief; conviction; creed; doctrine; dogma; persuasion. emamei nges aiyuunit: she/he has no faith. 
ajaagi (plural ajaagin) (noun F) a jug; a jar; a flacon; a carafe. 
ajaanakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be often present, attend at a meeting or at school. ejaanakin ngesi duc toma aisisias: she/he is always present in school: she/he attends. 
ajaanara ko-a (intransitive verb) to be related to, have relations (to be lovers); to be acquainted. kijaanara ngesi ka eong: we know each other. 
ajai, ijai or ejaas (adverb) I am, you are, or they are present. 
ajaikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be with; to have; to be present. ajaikinos itelepai osomero: the boys are at school. cp. aijaikin: to give. 
ajaikina ko-a (transitive verb) to have; to be with. aberu ngin ejaikina k’akoik: that woman is having a pregnancy. 
ajakaanut (plural ajakaanuto) (noun F) chieftaincy; reign; kingdom; government; regime; rule; administration; management. 
ajakait (plural ajaka) (noun F) a mistress; madam; mrs (used in addressing a woman). cp. amucaalat.
ajakakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pull the mouth open, pull asunder. kojakak lokadekan ekia: open his mouth and pour medicine down the sick man’s throat. 
ajakar ko-a (transitive verb) to drag; to tear off or tear open; to stop a calf or child from suckling (to wean). (reflexive verb) to tear oneself away; to drag oneself away. ajakar eong kane: I have torn, dragged myself away from here. ajakar ikoku: to wean a child from suckling. 
ajaket (plural ajaketa) (noun F) pincers, tongs, or forceps; a bridle. cp. anguc. 
ajakilil ko-o (intransitive verb) to have thick, drooping, sagging, or flabby lips. 
ajakun ko-a (transitive verb) to extricate, force open, tear open, tear off towards speaker; to save from. ajakun aunoi: to untie, undo, release the ropes. ajakun itunganan kotoma aunoi: to untie, release a person. ajakun akiro: to break silence. ajakun amisiri: to clean a plot of weeds by weeding properly. ajakun akituk: to restart conversation after silence. 
ajakus ko-o (intransitive verb) to be present; to have; to be with. ejok ajakus k’isirigin: it is good or necessary to have money. cp. ajaus or ajakut
ajakut ko-o (intransitive verb) to continue to exist. akoto ajakut k’idwe k’itunga: I want to be with people’s children. ajakut ka: to have. cp. ajaus.
ajalakin ko-a (transitive verb) to let; to allow; to suffer; to permit, laissez faire; to release; to forsake or surrender. ajalakin akuwan alelasia: to indulge oneself, spoil, treat, pamper, pander to. kojalak eenat ngol kolot: release that prisoner, let him go. 
ajalamuun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become warm; to be lukewarm. aitajalamuun: to warm up. akipi nuajalamak: lukewarm water. 
ajalijal ko-a (intransitive verb) to have one’s mouth watering; to dribble, drool, or slobber; to let saliva leave the mouth; to salivate (like a dog or child, old people); to let the tongue hang out. ekingok ejalijalete aimul: the dog salivates, slobbers - its mouth waters. 
ajamak ko-a (intransitive verb) to waddle; to walk like a fat goose or a fat man. ai bo ijamakete yesi?: where are you fat people waddling to? 
ajamat (plural ajaman) (noun F) a quagmire, swamp, marsh, or bog. 
ajanit (plural ajan) (noun F) a broom made of grass; a grass used for sweeping, Sporobolus pyramidalis. 
Ajapadolait (plural Ajapadola) (noun F) a Jopadhola woman (the Luo speakers of Tororo district); a word in the Adhola language. Ajapadola: the Jopadhola women; the Adhola language. 
ajar ko-a (reflexive verb) (of rope, trousers or anything tight) to get loose; to become unfastened. 
ajarar ko-a (transitive verb) to loosen (rope, trousers or anything tight). kojara auno naka akine: loosen the rope of the goat. ajararos ajon: the beer has become thin (not too thick, not too watery). 
ajararoroi ko-o (intransitive verb) to survive, subsist or to exist just in a needy state.
ajarosikin ko-a (transitive verb) (of trousers, cows, etc) to tie; to fasten.(reflexive verb) to be tied; to be tight. 
ajarotor ko-o (transitive verb) to unfasten; to loosen, untie. kojaroto auno koloit: loosen the rope from the pole. 
ajarujarun ki-a (intransitive verb) to become loose, slack; to be loose, slacken. ajarujarun akoik kanuka etengei: the stomach has become slack with hunger. 
Ajarun1 (singular noun F) the Resurrection (Christ’s coming back to life three days after his death on the cross; or the coming back to life of all the dead at the Last Judgement). ajarun naka lukatwak: the resurrection of the dead. eketajaran: a saviour; rescuer; reviver. 
ajarun2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to come back to life; to resurrect; to revive. 
ajarun3 ko-a (transitive verb) to spread out millet, groundnuts, etc. to dry. cp. ajerar; ajorar. 
ajarun4 ko-a (transitive verb) to loosen, disentangle, unfasten, slacken, widen. kojaru auno, eketaki itaok: loosen the rope, it is strangling the calf. 
ajarunet (plural ajaruneta) (noun F) a new grain (literally, that which brings back life); new food; a new harvest meal. cp. agwei 
ajarus (plural ajarusio) (noun F) a slipknot. cp. ejaroto. 
ajaus ko-a (intransitive verb) to be present; to exist; to attend at. ajai: I am present. ejaas: they are present. abu kajai: I was present. ajai eong togo: I am in the house. ejaas kesi togo: they are in the house. kojai Lokasuban mamakus: God be with you all. (note: when followed by an adjective or verb, ajaus is not translated). ajok: I am ok or good. ajaus ka: to have; to contain; to own; to be with; to possess; to be or to belong to. ejai eong aberu: I have a wife. kija eong ka aberu: I am with a wife. ejai eong etogo: I own a house (plural: ejaas eong itogoi: I own houses). ejaas kesi k’angor: they have women; they are with women. ejaas kesi ka ekingok or ejai kesi ekingok: they have a dog. cp. araus: to be or to exist (in the sense of ‘to be’ only used with nouns). iboro luejaatar ngesi: her/his belongings. ejaas swii: they are plentiful; they are abundant.
ajean (plural ajeak) (noun F) a potter; a weaver; a mat-maker; a builder or maker of grass-and-mud barns. 
ajees (plural lukajees) (adjective) military; relating to the armed forces. igoen lukajees: military clothes – army uniforms. cp. raya, polis
ajeikin ko-a (transitive verb) to coil for (as of rope or carrying pad); to make round, folded, coiled (as of a pot, Indian head-dress). (intransitive verb) to be round; (of a snake) to coil; to lie in folds or coils. adum eong emun ejeikit aikit toma amot: I found a snake coiled in a pot. (reflexive verb) to lie or stand or sit round something. ajeikinos ikiliok amot k’ajon: men have sat round the beer pot. 
ajejait (plural ajejai) (noun F) a niece. cp. ocenio (plural icenion): nephew on sister’s side. acenika: my niece. Ocen and Acen are children of a sister. 
ajeje (plural ajejei) (noun F) a honey-guide bird, Melichneutes robustus. 
ajele (plural ajeleik) (noun F) (Usuk) a ring-neck dove; a wild pigeon. cp. ayele.
ajeluukot (plural ajeluuko) (noun F) a valley; a vale; a dale; a dell. cp. ajesumot, ajesa. 
ajen ko-a (intransitive verb) to be related; consanguine. itunga luejenas mam etiakas: people who are related do not separate. 
ajena (noun F) affinity; kinship; blood relationship. 
ajenereita (plural ajenereitan) (noun F) an electric power generator. 
ajengan (plural ajengak) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a medical surgeon; a skinner or flayer of animals.
ajengetait (plural ajengeta) (noun F) a surgical wound or scar; an incision; a suture.
ajengio (singular noun F) a surgical operation; surgery. 
ajenikin ko-a (transitive verb) to foresee, notice; to know by; to take to heart. ijenikini ijo biai ebe etepi lolo edou?: how did you know that it would rain today? kojenik akakiro: take my words to heart. aitejenikin: to inform, send a message. aitejenunet: a message, sign. 
ajenun1 (noun F) cognition; discerning; comprehension.
ajenun2 ko-a (transitive verb) to get to know; to learn; to experience, fathom, comprehend. (intransitive verb) to know; to find out. mam ngesi epedori ejenun: she/he cannot know. (reflexive verb) to know one another; to be acquainted with one another. kijenun eong ka Oromait: Oromait and I have got acquainted. ajenun cut: certitude. 
ajenunet (plural ajenuneta) (noun F) a sign; trademark; a mark; a token; a wonder; a miracle; an omen; a symbol; a musical note. 
ajenyar ko-a (transitive verb) to finish off killing, or to finish off eating food. kojenya inyamat ngul kaloto: finish off that food and we go. cp. aicutar, aicid, aidweny. 
ajepaanut (singular noun F) a habit of cutting; a habit of cheating; a habit of plotting. ajokit epol nges ajepaanut k’otunga: the devil is in the habit of cheating (plotting against) people. 
ajepakin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut, fell a tree for somebody; to kill somebody on behalf of or by order of somebody. 
ajepar ko-a (transitive verb) to cut away, lop off; to fell; to intrigue or plot against the life of somebody (by poison or otherwise). ejai loekoto ajepar aijarakon: somebody is plotting to kill you. 
ajepasit (plural ajepasia) (noun F) a cut; a gash; a wound.
ajepejep ko-a (transitive verb) to keep on cutting; to keep on cheating; (of heart) to keep throbbing; (of head) to keep paining; to pulsate. 
ajepunun ko-a (transitive verb) to cut for oneself; to prune, clear a tree of its branches. ajepunun atap: to take very big lumps of food. ajepunun etunganan: to keep on cheating (or plotting against) a person. 
ajeret (plural ajereta) (noun F) a lasso; a rope; a loop. cp. arocet
ajerikan (plural ajerikanin) (noun F) a 5-20 litre plastic container for liquids; a jerry can. cp. adomola
ajesa (plural ajesai) (noun F) a valley; a slope; a declivity. 
ajesan (adverb) down there; on the slope; in the valley. 
ajesat (plural ajesan) (noun F) a valley; a slope; acclivity. 
ajesumot (plural ajesumo) (noun F) a valley; a vale; a gorge; a dale; a dell. cp. ajelukot, ajesa
ajet (plural ajeta) (noun F) a small slope; a small dip. cp. ajesa: a valley. 
ajetakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pull the trigger of a gun; to fire (a gun); to light match (a pipe); to set fire (to grass); to start (a car or motor cycle); to fold (a chair). cp. agwetakin. 
ajeun ko-a (transitive verb) to make round; to mould with clay. cp. alukum. 
ajiikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to fight for somebody; to race for. ajiikini eong Iteso akecepolou: I will fight for the honour of the Iteso. ejiikinit ngesi aijarake: she/he fights for her/his dear life. 
ajiis (plural ajiisio) (noun F) fighting place; arena; battle field; a fight. ajiis nasodit: the first fight or battle.
ajijim1 (singular noun F) sweetness; taste; tastiness. 
ajijim2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be sweet, tasty, or pleasant. iboro ngul kere ajijimata: all these things are sweet (tasty). 
ajijimikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to taste nice; to be tasty to; to be savoury. 
ajijimun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become sweet, tasty, nice to. 
ajikilil ko-a (intransitive verb) to have swollen or fat cheeks; to be or become cloudy, overcast; to be sulky, down-hearted, miserable. ijikilil nges eketau: she/he is sulky, down-hearted. 
ajikitu (singular noun F) deafness. 
ajimi (plural ajimis, ajimii) (noun F) a wound; an ulcer; a sore. 
ajingirir (plural ijingiriras) (adjective) (of a bull or a man) thick-necked. ajingirir emorosing (intransitive verb) to be thick-necked. ajingiriki emong: the thick-necked bull is swaying its head as it walks. 
ajio (noun F) war, conflict, combat, warfare, confrontation, hostilities; battle, encounter, skirmish, melee; fight, brawl, struggle. cp. ejie (the usual word)
ajionokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to fight often, keep fighting; to fight each other. 
ajionut1 (noun F) war-like; warring; fondness of fighting.
ajionut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be war-like or fond of fighting 
ajior ko-o (intransitive verb) to fight for or about, contend for, race for (something). ejiosi ingokwo kanuka akojo: the dogs are fighting for bones. 
ajipakin ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to look at in the distance; to go and find out; to look into the distance. cp. agipakin
ajipar ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to look at sharply; to look carefully at somebody or something far off; to discern. kojipa ngina karai ebunit ngesi: go and see (or find out) if she/he is coming. cp. agipar
ajisakin ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to make something big. ejisakit etunganan ngol etogo (lopeti): that man has built a big house. ejisakitai ngesi ajakaanut: she/he has been given a big job or post. cp. agisakin.
ajo1 (plural noun F) sleep; rest. adeka naka ajo: sleeping sickness. 
ajo2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to sleep, nap, or to have a siesta (only used in infinitive). alosi ber ajo aimom: I am going to rest awhile. cp. ajoto
ajoikin ko-a (transitive verb) to straighten for; to stretch out for; to spread out. kojoik akiro ngun: find out about it, straighten that case. kojoik egoe omeesa: spread the cloth on the table. 
ajokak (plural ajokesia) (noun F) advantages; usefulness; the value or worth. mam eong adumunit ajokak kotoma aswam kangin: I have not found the value of that work. cp. ajokis
ajokeiko (plural noun F) a sickness causing a sudden short term aching or itching. 
ajokianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to approve of always; to agree to always; to benefit always (intransitive verb) to be good always; to be nice always; to be kind always; to be just always. 
ajokiar ko-a (reflexive verb) to become good; to become nice; to become just; to become right; to become cured; to become healed (transitive verb) to amend. kojokiar k’otunga kere: become or be nice to everybody. akajimi mam ekoto ajokiar: my wound will not heal up. 
ajokikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be good, nice, kind to, just for. kajokikitos eong ajon: beer is good for me. kijokikit ijo eong: you are kind to me. (transitive verb) to benefit; to profit. aswam ngin mam epedori ajokikin eong: that work cannot benefit me. (transitive verb) to approve of. mam kajokikini eong aswamukon: I cannot approve of your work. 
ajokikinet (plural ajokikineta) (noun F) approval; endorsement; sanction; consent; say-so; support. 
ajokis (plural ajokisyo) (noun F) goodness; kindness; benefit; usefulness; advantage. 
ajokit1 (plural ajokin) (noun F) a blind worm (believed to be the residence of a demon); a small black snake without a visible head. cp. amurumuron.
ajokit2 (plural ajokin) (noun F) the devil; Satan; a bad spirit; a demon. 
ajokokan (plural nukajokokan) (noun F) benefactress; a generous woman. 
ajokot (plural ajokon) (noun F) an ox yoke; a harness.
ajokotau (plural nuajokotau) (noun F) a kind-hearted woman; a donor. cp. ojokotau
ajokus (plural ajokusyo) (noun F) goodness; kindness; advantage; usefulness; merit. ajokus naka akuwan: angaleu: health. (note: kijokis in Ateso Atororo means ‘all’. akoto kes kijokis: I want them all). 
ajoliar ko-o (reflexive verb) to be insipid, tasteless (as food without salt, tea without sugar); (of conversation) to be untruthful, talk nonsense. ajoliaros akonikiro. cp. acoliar. 
ajon1 (uncountable noun F) beer; alcoholic drink; booze; brew. cp. aisub ajon: to make beer, to brew beer. aita ajon: to work for beer. amuna ajon: to prepare or make beer, i.e. to brew beer. airedakin ajon: to make much beer. ireded (ajon) (adjective) (of beer) much. ireded ajon kangina?: (of beer) is it brewed much over there? acuc (uncountable noun F) ‘ajon nuka adakai’ when it is nearly finished - watery and having lost ability to make one drunk. ajon nukadwarak (noun F) brew with strong alcoholic content. ajon nuewiiny (singular noun F) sweet brew or gruel - one day old. ajon arasai (noun F) beer that is a little bitter or alcoholic - two days old brew. ajon aperoi or ajon abeitok (plural noun F) beer ready to drink - three days old brew. ajon aupaupan (uncountable noun F) brew that is better than ‘aperoi’ - four days old brew. ajon nuasosolok; ajon nuesosol; ajon nuesasamito (noun F) beer that is overdue for drinking and has gone bad – bad smelling beer. ajon ekamule (noun M) brew made for sale to the public (commercially) and is not very thick like that for own consumption. ajon ecuwat or ecuat (noun M) sweetish beer which has been squeezed from the thick beer and sold commercially. adakai (singular noun F) dregs or leftovers of beer after drinking, consisting of particles of grain. emanit or epii (noun M) a tube for sucking beer. ajon nuebabar (noun F) bad beer not good for drinking (because it is insipid or astringent). esosol ajon nu: this beer is too old and smelly. aibwany ajon: to drink beer uninvited or by gate-crashing. aidika ajon ki-a (transitive verb) to drink much beer. aibwony ajon: to drink beer ravenously or greedily with a beer tube– with the throat making a racket (noise). aidinga ajon: to drink much beer alone. asip (plural noun F) germinated sorghum or millet ready to be ground into the flour that will be fermented and roasted for beer making. aicop ajon: to serve fresh or thick beer to drinkers in a pot or calabash. aimur akiria: to ferment flour (mixed with water into a thick paste, put into a big saucepan or clay pot or just wrapped in banana leaves and buried in the ground, for a period of five days or one week) for beer making. akeit (noun F) a huge frying pan of clay or steel in which fermented dough (amurat) is roasted in the process of beer making. aberu nakamunan ajon (noun F) a beer brewer or hostess serving beer. aidwom ajon: to eat thick beer without adding water. aike akiria: to fry the fermented dough. aical ajon: to put yeast (ainyales) into sweet thick one-day-old brew to cause fermentation and also to thin it (acalar). ainyales (plural noun F) millet or sorghum germinated, dried and ground as yeast for beer making. 
ajon2 nukakebe (plural noun F) tinned beer; tinned brew. 
ajon3 nukacupa (plural noun F) bottled beer; bottled brew. cp. ebiya 
ajonere ko-o (intransitive verb) to concede; to become cool; (of angry person or animal) to cool down; to be unripe, raw, uncooked. adau atap ajonere: the millet bread has cooled. elosete inyamat ajokere: the food is getting cold. (note how ajonere becomes ajokere in plural)
ajongo ko-o (intransitive verb) to stop, cease, or leave; to end. kojongo (plural kojongooto) aimat ajon aipung: stop drinking beer excessively. 
ajongoikin ko-o (transitive verb) to leave some for somebody else. kojongoikinoi eong da edicaai: leave me also some tea. cp. ainyekin, aideikin.
ajongoor ko-o (transitive verb) to stop; to prevent, abolish, forbid. ekotoi ajongoor itunga aimat ajon: they want to stop people from drinking beer. alosi eong ajongoor apero paran: I am going to stop taking my siesta. cp. ainyekin, aipal. 
ajoniar1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of fire, sun or hot liquids) to become less hot, cool down; (of weather) to calm down, to become calm; (of meat) to remain undone even though being cooked; (of men) to surrender after a fight, to be easy, to be impassive. kipas iso ejie, kikoto ajokiar: we are tired of war, we want a ceasefire. ajokiasi akipi: the water has cooled. cp. ainapakin, aiyamakin. 
ajoniar2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to be raw or not cooked sufficiently. ajoniar akiring na, kinyaka ngesi akim: this meat is not done, boil it again or put it back on fire. (note: the plural of ajoniar is ‘ajokiar’, and happens to be spelled the same as ajokiar: to become good) 
ajoniarit ko-a (intransitive verb) (of weather) to be calm; (of men) to be easy, impassive.
ajonio (plural noun F) beer (a sarcastic or abusive reference) 
ajonis (singular noun F) immaturity; rawness (both of food and of a person’s mental or physical development). cp. ajonus
ajonit ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a person) to be dense, naïve, stupid, inexperienced, or unsophisticated; (of food) to be uncooked, raw; (of fruit) to be unripe.
ajono (plural ajoko) (adjective) calm; calm down; restful; peaceful; cooled down. 
ajonore (plural ajokore) ko-o (intransitive verb) to concede; to become cool; (of angry person or animal) to cool down; to be unripe, raw, uncooked. ajono atap: the millet bread has become cold. ekotos inyamat ajokore: the food will be cold. aitojonaar: to allow to cool; to appease (an angry person or animal). cp. ajonere
ajonus (singular noun F) immaturity; rawness (both of food and of a person’s mental or physical development). 
ajoola (plural ajoolai) (noun F) a roll of cloth (new and uncut); a piece of cloth not yet cut and sewn into a dress or tablecloth.
ajoora (plural ajoorai, ajooran) (noun F) a penthouse; a chicken hut. 
ajore (plural ajoreik, ajoresinei, ajoresio) (noun F) the military; the armed forces; the defence forces; militia; a territorial army; soldiers; an army (of men or fighting ants); a crowd; a raiding force; the Teso army. 
ajoris (plural ajorisyo) (noun F) a perch; a place or something to squat on. 
ajorit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be perched on; to be squatting down. 
ajoroi (plural ajoro) (noun F) a branch, twig, or leaf of ejoroi tree. 
ajorokin ko-a (intransitive verb) to squat down to work; to do something. ajorokin aiboi: to sit down to rest. ajorokin aswam: to get down to work. kojorok ijo aswamukon: you get down to work. adum eong nges ejorokit aimat: I found him seated to a good drink (perhaps at a wrong time or wrong place). 
ajosi (noun F) an important dance in Soroti and Katakwi accompanied with a drum beat from one atenus (big drum) and four ideteta (small drums); a war drum. 
ajotakin ko-a (intransitive verb) (of moon or sun) to set, go down; to clear throat; to sink. ejotakinit akolong erono lolo: the sun set when it was still blazing hot today. 
ajotet naka akolong (noun F) early afternoon, 2:00 pm to 3:00 pm. cp. alomar akolong otuo: setting of sun; late afternoon, 4:00 pm to 6:00 pm. abuni eong toma apak nak’ajotet akolong (naka ajotakin kakolong: abuni kapak naka alomar k’akolong otuo: I shall come in the early afternoon, I shall come in the late afternoon or late in the afternoon or towards sunset. 
ajoto ko-o (intransitive verb) to sleep, rest awhile, have a siesta (only used in infinitive). alosi ber ajo aimom: I am going to rest awhile. 
ajotoet (plural ajotoeta) (noun F) a place where to sleep; drool from the mouth during sleep. ekoto ngesi ajotoet, mam ekoto ace: she/he wants a sleeping place, she/he does not want anything else. 
ajotokin ko-a (intransitive verb) to sleep somewhere. kojotok ijo lolo oreka: sleep at my home tonight. (transitive verb) to make to lean over, put on its side. (intransitive verb) to sit on one side, lean over, lie on side. 
ajotoor ko-o (intransitive verb) to go to sleep; to be asleep. ajotoor: ejotoi: she/he is asleep, sleeping (plural ajotooros: ejotoete: they are sleeping: they are asleep). akoto ajotoor: akoto ajo: I want to go to sleep, or she/he had wanted to sleep. ajotooros: they have slept. ejotoete: they are asleep. 
ajototo (plural ajototoi) a large wading bird, with grey and white feathers, long legs and along neck, Heron. 
ajoyiar ko-a (transitive verb) (of a liquid) to cool down; to stretch (of anything, as of baby for rest or sleep; as of a mat - to pull straight); to straighten. kapas eong, akoto ajoyiar akuwan: I am tired, I want to stretch myself. kojoyiasi akanin: stand to attention. (reflexive verb) to rest, stretch oneself. ekeri emun ejoyiara akuwanake: a snake moves with its body stretched. ajoyiaros itelepai kotolim: the boys are resting in the shade. ajoyiar akiro: to straighten out a case. cp. arior.
ajuket1 (plural ajuketa) (noun F) a brush or instrument for painting. 
ajuket2 (plural ajuketa) (noun F) colouring; painting. akoto ajuket naka emodi: I want paint for hair dressing. 
ajukokin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to stain, smear with; to mark. kojukonok ngesi akuron: smear him with ashes. 
ajukokin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to refuse to. ejukokit ngesi akonikiro: she/he refuses to accept your message. cp. angerokin, agirokin.
ajukujuk ko-o (transitive verb) to stain with anything. ajukujukit eong ekakaaso kebuino: I stained my cassock with ink. 
ajulong (plural ajul) (noun F) hair on fingers or body. cp. etimat. 
ajulongit (plural ajul) (noun F) hair on fingers or body. cp. ajulot. 
ajulot (plural ajul) (noun F) a feather; hair on the body (not on the head); eiderdown; fine feathers of birds. ajul nuk’openek (plural noun F) a beard; moustache; sideburns. ajul nuk’oponoi: a moustache
ajulut (plural ajului) (noun F) a species of bird, a male crimson-breasted shrike. 
ajungula (plural ajungulai) (noun F) a branch or a leaf of ejungula plant. 
ajupakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pick out for somebody. ejupakini toto ilac kakou k’ikoku: the mother picks lice from the child’s head. 
ajurakin ko-a (transitive verb) to lick off; to drink, sip off; to finish drinking liquid for. kojurakinai eong edia ngol: finish the vegetables for me. 
ajurar ko-a (transitive verb) to suck up; to sip away; to lick clean; to finish off (cigarettes). cp. aiyetar: to sip hot drinks. ejurari ekapa akile: the cat licks off the milk (from the plate). 
ajuri1 (plural ajurio) (noun F) a kind of vegetable or beans. 
ajuri2 (plural ajurio) (noun F) a syphilitic scar on body (after the syphilitic wounds have healed). 
ajurung ko-a (transitive verb) to hang head; to be despondent; to lose heart (as of one who is in trouble); to roam about (despondently or in despair); to wander about. ejurungi ngesi akwap bala ikerepikit kanuka atwanare k’aberuke: he roams about in despair about the death of his wife. 
ajurungikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to wince, flinch, cringe, recoil, grimace, or make a face. 
ajurungit ko-o (intransitive verb) to sit bent up, huddled up (on account of cold or rain). ejurungitos akokoroi kere kanuka aterot: the hens sit huddled together on account of the cold. 
ajurungung ko-a (intransitive verb) to grow despondent; to be despondent, hopeless, low, dejected, downhearted, downcast, unhappy, sad, or pessimistic. ejurungungit ngesi koreke: she/he sits at home full of pessimism about her/his future prospects. 
ajuruset (plural ajuruseta) (noun F) a plane; sandpaper; an instrument for smoothing things like a pot or granary, or wall or board.
ajurusiar ko-a (transitive verb) to strip off (as of leaves); to make smooth; to plane, make even, polish wood (with sandpaper). (reflexive verb) to be slippery, smooth, even, polished; to slip; to slide down. 
ajurusikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to attack; to approach; to catch; to get hold of. ajurusikin ekapa emir: the cat has caught a rat. inyo bo kijurusikinor ijo eong?: why have you attacked me? 
ajurut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be slippery. ejurut erot: the road (path) is slippery (transitive verb) to make smooth (as of board or wall or granary). 
ajurutaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to be slippery; to slip away, slip a bow knot. akoto ajurutaar (aisi): I want to slip away (to call my friend, etc). cp. ageret, aililaar. 
ajurutaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to slip (of feet or of things from hands); to miss; to escape, slip away. akoto ekapa aikamun emir, konye aburucaar emir: the cat wanted to catch a rat but it escaped. cp. aburucaar.
ajurutaaret (plural ajurutaareta) (noun F) a slippery place; a bow (tie a bow); a bow-knot (of shoes); a loop knot. kocoite erot ejaas ajurutaareta: be careful there are slippery spots on the road. 
ajurutun ko-o (transitive verb) to strip off (as of leaves from a branch) (intransitive verb) to come outside for freedom; to slip towards (reflexive verb) to come; to go at once to speaker. kojurutunos yesi kere: clear out all of you and come this way. 
ajutor ko-o (intransitive verb) to sit with an angry face, fed up; to mope, sulk, brood, pine, or pout (transitive verb) to clean the place where a child, a dog, cat has defecated; to clean away; to refuse altogether. ejutorit ngesi kore: she/he sits at home moping, mooching, or sulking. ajuto ngesi akonikiro: she/he has refused your request entirely. cp. apalar.
ajwatakin ko-a (transitive verb) to beat once, give one light blow or stroke. cp. aidwat. 
ajwele (plural ajweleik) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a ring neck dove; a pigeon. cp. ajele, eluke
ajwenyar ko-a (transitive verb) to sweep clean; to clean thoroughly; to rub off; to polish; to finish off. kojweny asaanit: finish (the food on) the plate. adau aberu ya ajwenyar edia kosepuria: the other woman has finished off all her sauce from the pot (using her index finger to gather remnant of food and leaking the finger). cp. ainot, aipye, aijwatar. 
akaadi (plural akaadin) (noun F) a postcard; any hard piece of paper with one’s picture, etc for identification or containing other information; an immunisation card (given to mothers or prospective parents); a communal drinking, eating and dance party for young adults (especially in Katakwi during Christmas, New Year and Uhuru).
akaalait (plural akaala) (noun F) a camel; a dromedary.
akaale1 (plural akaalei) (noun F) a serving spoon; a ladle; a scoop. cp. aijiiko
akaale2 (plural akaalen) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a flood; a deluge; a torrent; an overflow; a downpour. 
akaam ko-a (transitive verb) to break up the soil for cultivation with a hand hoe; to prepare the soil for early cultivation using a hand hoe; to munch dry food or tough fried meat; (of ruminants – cows and goats) to chew the cud. ekaamete Iteso aloboi: the Iteso prepare gardens for sowing. 
akaamar ko-a (transitive verb) to go and prepare soil over there. akaami eong ne, kokaama ijo ngina: I prepare the field here and you over there. 
akaamikin ko-a (transitive verb) to prepare soil for somebody or somewhere; to hoe crops. kokaamikinai amanaka: prepare my plot for sowing. ai bo ikaamikini ijo imarekon?: where are you going to break up the soil for sowing your peas? 
akaawa (singular noun F) coffee beverage. cp. emwaanyi: coffee plant or berry.
akabaka (plural akabakan) (noun F) (any) queen or female hereditary ruler.
akabakanut (singular noun F) a king’s reign; a kingship; monarchy; kingdom; sovereignty.
akabeera (plural akabeerai) (noun M) a polythene paper bag. 
akabo1 (plural akaboi) (noun F) a diaphragm. 
akabo2 ko-a (transitive verb) to catch with hand or mouth; (as of a football) to catch it by hand or stop it with feet; (of a dog) to catch a piece of food thrown into its mouth. cp. ailango
akabul ki-o (intransitive verb) to burst, rupture, split open, break open, rip open. 
akabwa (plural akabwai) (noun F) a bow (for shooting arrows). cp. emal (plural imalia) short arrow for bleeding cattle. ekojo (plural ikojoi) long arrow for shooting birds, etc. 
akacar ko-a (transitive verb) to lead or drive a man or animal between two or more people, like a bull to the slaughter house. kokacasi emong lo aiyar: take this bull to be killed (lead it, with one man on each side). 
akadakin1 etau ko-a (intransitive verb) to be disgruntled with; to be sad or disgusted with; to be discouraged or regretful. akadakit eong: I am downhearted; I am sad, feel disgusted. kakadak eong etau: I feel downhearted. 
akadakin2 ko-a (reflexive verb) to be dismal; to be too few, too little, insufficient, or not enough. akadakinos ikasirigin: I have not got enough money. 
akadakinet (plural akadakineta) (noun F) anxiety; annoyance, irritation, infuriation, exasperation, bother, anger, frustration, displeasure. 
akadakit (singular noun F) melancholy; sad, depressed, downhearted, miserable, down, low, glum. 
akadapao (plural akadapaon) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a veranda; porch; terrace; balcony; loggia; portico. cp. ebalaasa.
akadit ko-a (intransitive verb) to be lacking, insufficient; to be wanting, deficient, not enough. ekaditos etogo anya: the grass for the house is insufficient. ekadakina eong isirigin: I have inadequate funds. kakadit eong aswam na, akoto ace: this work is not enough or too small for me. 
akadot (plural akadon) (noun F) salty clay licked by cattle. 
akae (plural akaen) (noun F) a witchdoctor’s gourd containing pebbles; a rattle. 
akaguba (plural akaguban) (noun F) a harlequin quail. 
akai (plural akais) (noun F) a hut, a house, a cabin, a shelter, or a shed; a nest; a pen, a sty, a cage, a stall, or a paddock; a halo round the moon. akai naka ikwenyit: a bird’s nest. 
akai kadidi (noun F) a grass, Sporobulus. 
akaideit (plural akaidei) (noun F) a kind of vegetable marrow or edible gourd; (in Karamoja) a pumpkin. 
akain (plural akainon) (noun F) a co-wife; a fellow wife. 
akais- (numeral prefix) tens of. akais akany: tens of five; fifty. akais aare: tens of two; twenty. akais akany kaare: tens of five and two; seventy.
akaje (singular noun F) madness; delirium, fever, hallucination, restlessness, confusion, frenzy, ecstasy, elation, insanity, or disorientation. cp. ikerep, abangaanut, akaye
akaka ko-a (transitive verb) to gather weeds or leaves; to clear up weeds, grass; to get a very big wage. akaka akiro: to talk rubbish or nonsense. ekakaete kesi anya: they are gathering grass (rubbish). 
akakaar1 ko-a (reflexive verb) to hasten away from; to run away in fright; to rush pell-mell in flight. cp. agiriar akerit. akakaar eong akerit emun: I ran away in fright from a snake. 
akakaar2 ko-a (transitive verb) to clean (a plot by taking away grass); to clear rubbish (from compound etc). 
akakaet (plural akakaeta) (noun F) a rake; an implement for gathering rubbish. 
akakakin ko-a (transitive verb) to run suddenly after. cp. agiriakin
akakany ko-a (transitive verb) to clear the throat; to cough and spit. 
akakanyaar ko-a (transitive verb) to clear the throat. akakanyaar erokokonyit: to spit out phlegm. akakanyaar akiro: to show disgust for what is said. 
akakanyun akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to spit out; to despise offensive language of others; to show disgust at bad language. cp. aimuar. 
akakas ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk with big long strides or steps; to hurry. ai bo lolo ikakasi ijo?: where are you off to, with your long steps?
akako (plural of akakot) (noun F) hailstone; ice; frost; a bead (resembling hailstone, but transparent). ikakoikit: icy; glacial; polar. 
akakot (plural akako) (noun F) hailstone; ice; frost; a bead. 
Akakwat (plural Akakwa) (noun F) a Kakwa tribeswoman; a woman native to parts of Arua district of Uganda west of the Nile; a word in the Kakwa language. Akakwa: the Kakwa language; the Kakwa women. 
akal (plural akalia) (noun F) a reedbuck, Redunca fulvorufula. cp. emaara. 
akalaani (plural akalaanin) (noun F) a clerk; a secretary; amanuensis. 
akalabata (plural akalabatan) (noun F) a wooden sandal; a clog. cp. akorwa.
akalanyanut (singular noun F) laziness, idleness, indolence, lethargy, sluggishness. 
akalas (plural akalasia) (noun F) a grass torch; a flat-topped grinding stone. cp. akangas. 
akalaya (plural akalayan) (noun F) (formerly) a metallic utensil mostly used for carrying bathing water; a trough. cp. abeseeni
akaleeda (plural akaleedan) (noun F) a calendar; a chart or an adjustable device showing days and months of the year
akalel (plural akaalei) (noun F) a young female goat; a young hen about to start laying eggs. cp. akine, akalol; aculot 
akalele (singular noun F) (Usuk) a flood; a deluge; a river current. cp. akaale
Akaliait (noun F) (title of) Her Worship the wife of Emorimor (the cultural leader of Iteso); a queen consort of a reigning emorimor. 
akalol (plural akaaloi) (noun F) a young goat. cp. akalel 
akambak (plural akambakin) (noun F) a retrenched, laid off, or deserting army woman now living a civilian life in the village; a come-back; rustled or raided livestock that gets lost within Teso before reaching its destination (Karamoja). erai amerekek ngin akambak: that sheep is a come-back, i.e. it got lost in the bushes of Teso while being driven away by rustlers. cp. ekambak.
