akamera (plural akameran) (noun F) a camera (a gadget for taking photographs). 
akamole (plural akamolen) (noun F) a girl pretending to work. 
akamu (plural akamusinei) (noun F) the dry season; summer. 
akamuran (plural akamurak) (noun F) (Usuk) a sister-in-law; a mother-in-law; the wife’s sister. akamurak: all female in-laws generally. cp. amwi: a sister-in-law (as called by aberu – wife); a sister of one’s husband.
akan (plural akanin) (noun F) a hand; an arm; a signature; a handwriting; a thieving habit. akoto aikwac akan: I want to write (to scratch the handwriting). cp. aigirigir. etau k’akan: palm of the hand. toma akan: in the hand. akan k’etom: an elephant trunk. ejai ikoku ngin akan: that child is a thief. cp. eojak ibokor: she/he has long fingers (hence, is lazy or thieving). kolot akan ya: go to the other side. akan k’emeleku: the handle of a hoe or plough. eokitos akanin: to have nothing in the hands; to be empty-handed. abunit eong eokitos akanin: I have come empty-handed i.e. without money, poor at that time. 
akang F (adverb) my friend; my dear; dear me. okwe akang konyou, nukon nupe inerai: my dear lady go away, it is you they are talking about. (akang used in a salutation or beginning a letter to a woman: Dear Madam). itunganan: my dear. akang atunganan ngin erono!: that wife of mine is bad news! 
akanga ko-a (transitive verb) to speak openly; to speak straight out; to do deliberately; to do openly; to do purposely; to do knowingly. abu eong akanga ainyam akiring apaarit naikanyet: I ate meat on Friday deliberately. ibu kokanga akanga?: did you do it deliberately? cp. apele. 
akangaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to go or to do uninvited. akangaar ekesa ngol togoka atitai: he went into my house uninvited, uncalled for. akangaar ngesi aimat ecaai: she/he went off for tea (by herself/himself) uninvited. 
akangaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to do deliberately; to tell deliberately, openly, in his face. alimokin akangaikin: to tell straight into somebody’s face; to tell deliberately. 
akangas1 (plural akangasia) (noun F) accident, mishap, misfortune, disaster, calamity, catastrophe, mistake; hazard, danger, risk, peril, vulnerability. adumun akangas: to have or be involved in an accident. akangas naka amotoka: a car accident. earit akangas naka agaali itunga luipu ko Kachumbala: a train accident killed many people at Kachumbala. cp. aibuc. 
akangas2 (plural akangasia) (noun F) the lower and bigger of the two traditional grinding stones. cp. atapen: the smaller of the two grinding stones (kept in the hands of person grinding). 
akangaun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come uninvited, uncalled for; to do without notice. inyo bo ikangaunor ijo ne?: why did you come here without notice? 
akansila (plural akansilan) (noun F) a local administrative council female representative.
akany (noun F) five. ikany (noun M) five (note: numerals follow masculine and feminine prefixes of nouns they refer). itogoi ikany: five houses. amor akany: five stones. idwe ikany: five children. akany kape: six. akany kaare: seven. akany kauni: eight. akany kaongon: nine. 
Akanyangit (plural Akanyanga) (noun F) a woman native of former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts); a Mugisu woman or word in Lumasaba (the language of the Bagisu people). Akanyanga: the Lumasaba language. cp. Amaikokoit, Amugisut.
akanyeret (plural akanyeren) (noun F) a bracelet; a bangle; an armlet; a wristlet. 
akanyumit (plural akanyumo) (noun F) a wild simsim (not traditionally eaten by Iteso men) used as medicine for gallstones in the kidneys; a leaf or a stem of a simsim plant.
akao (plural akaon) (noun F) a small seasonal swamp for communal grazing. cp. eitela; aro: a wild and dry forested region. 
akapakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to equip, prepare. (reflexive verb) to prepare oneself; to make immediate preparations, equip oneself. abu ejakait Ekapa komam eong akapakina: Mr. Ekapa has come when I am not prepared or ready. 
akapanakin (reflexive verb) to gather for oneself things necessary for; to gather equipment for (feast, fight, journey, etc). 
akapanakina ko-o (reflexive verb) to be prepared for; to be ready (for anything). ekapanakinos itunga alosit ojie: the people are prepared to go to war. 
akaparar ko-a (intransitive verb) to have large wide ears, stiff and pointed (not soft like of some people, or dogs, cows, cats, etc); (of new cloth) to be full of starch. ikapararas akike: her/his ears are long and stiff. ikaparar egoe lo, ekot ber ailosio: this cloth is stiff with starch, it needs washing first. 
akaparikin alosit (reflexive verb) to go along with long stiff ears (an insult). akaparikin kekegoe: she/he walks along with her/his stiff cloth (or stiff hide). 
akapet1 (plural akape) (noun F) a cowhide or animal skin to sleep on; a honeycomb; a leather ball. ailangilang akapet: to play football; (slang) to have sexual intercourse. aipet akapet: to lay out the bed.
akapet2 naka ao (plural akape nuka ao) (noun F) a honeycomb. 
akapilaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to take away bad luck. 
akapilanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to bewitch; to bring ill luck to or for somebody. ikapilanakini ijo itunga: you bring bad luck to people. 
akapilanut (singular noun F) ill luck; evil. iyau jo akapilanut: you have brought ill luck. ekapilana ngesi: she/he brings ill luck. ekapilaka kesi: they bring ill luck. 
akapilaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to bring bad luck here. 
akapit ko-a (transitive verb) to be ready with; to be prepared for; to be ready for eventualities; to be armed. akapit eong adita agwelakin emuogo: I am ready with a basket in case I have to buy cassava. 
akapul (plural akapulei) (noun F) (Usuk) a navel; umbilicus. cp. aipule
akar (plural akaria) (noun F) a river; a side river; a small lake (like Bisina, Agu). 
akarab ko-a (intransitive verb) to give imitative sound of running cows or horses (galloping, first with front and then hind legs). ekarabete akituk osamai: the cows are galloping to the swamp (to drink). 
akarac alosit (transitive verb) to walk bow-legged. ikaracacas itulin: the hip bones are sticking out as of a deformed person. 
akaracac ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bowlegged; to stand or walk like a skeleton, bowlegged but erect. ikaracac ecom ebwoie: the baboon stands bow-legged.
akarad ko-a (transitive verb) to beat with a heavy object. apotu kesi kokaradata etyang k’abotei: they clobbered the animal with the clubs. 
akaradikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to lurch forward; to fall down; to fall on top of; to protect with one’s body. akaradikin emong kwap akurwoki aswam: the ox fell down unable to work. 
akarapan (plural akarapak) (noun F) a nose ornament; ring for ear, lip, or tongue. cp. etetioit
akaras ko-a (transitive verb) to spear. ekarasete kesi ekokolan kotogo: they are spearing a thief in the house. akarasaar: to spear without releasing the hold on the spear. akarasun: to stab. cp. aicumucum.
akarasikin ko-a (transitive verb) to spear with big spear or stab with big knife. akarasik eong emong: I speared a bull with a big spear. cp. aicum.
akarata (plural akaratan) (noun F) a playing paper card.
akarataasi (plural akarataasin) (noun F) a paper for rolling cigarettes. cp. apapula. 
Akareut (noun F) a woman from Ikarebwok clan of Iteso. 
Akarimojongait (plural Akarimojong) (noun M) a woman native to former Karamoja (the present day districts of Moroto, Kotido and Nakapiripirit); a word in Ngakarimojong (the language of the Karimojong). Akarimojong: the Karimojong women; Ngakarimojong language.
akarukwait (plural akarukwa) (noun F) round edible fruits (black when ripe) from eelu or ekarukwei tree, Vitex doniana. 
akarwait (noun F) a drizzle of rain. cp. airwait, elimilim
akasision (singular noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a billion. 
akata (plural akatai) (noun F) a saucer (on which a tea cup is placed).
akataasa (plural akataasan) (noun F) a metallic or plastic tray. cp. asiniya
akatalang (plural akatalanga) (noun F) a black large biting ant. cp. esuunyoit
akatale (plural akatalen) (noun F) a marketplace. cp. esokooni. 
akatapan (plural akatapana) (noun F) (in Karamoja) a small black termite. cp. amijiiri, amijimij. 
akatar ko-a (intransitive verb) to gallop; (of animals) to canter. cp. atakar. 
akatarikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall down on hands and feet i.e. not fall down altogether; to canter, fall forward (as of a child). akatarikin ikoku kwap: the child has fallen forward on its knees. 
akatenak (plural noun F) occasions; times. akatenak aare: twice. cp. irwana, atenak 
akau (plural akauloros) (noun F) the back (of a person, animals, etc). akauka: my back. 
akaulo1 (adverb) after that; later on. kilosi konye oni akaulo naka ailong: we shall go later on after bathing. cp. ekaulo
akaulo2 (plural akauloros) (noun F) a back of man or animals, etc 
akaurian (plural akauriak) (noun F) a female parent; a female bearer; a female begetter; a primogenitor; a progenitor; a female forebear.
akayoit (plural akayoi) (noun F) a small fish - pounded when dry and eaten in groundnut sauce, and famed for being a remedy for measles. cp. iyoit (plural iiyo).
akebat (plural akeban) (noun F) a trimmed forehead (especially of girls). 
akebe (plural akebei) (noun F) a tin can; a small metallic container or vessel. 
akebun ko-a (transitive verb) to trim a little. akebun akiro: to talk nicely for a short time and then keep silent.
akedekede (plural nukedekede) (adjective) (colour of cows or birds with many colours) banded; hooped; lined; striped. cp. nakedekede.
akediany (plural akedianya) (noun F) the left hand; the left side. lokediany (noun M): the left one. akan nakokediany (noun M): the left hand; left side, on the left. 
akeero (singular noun F) a playground; a green park; an open space; a playing field; a recreational area; a theatre. cp. eisaawe, abolet
akeeyarit (plural akeeyarin) (noun F) a woman soldier; an army woman. cp. apolisit, asirikaalet
akeit (plural akeito) (noun F) a big steel frying pan or earthenware pot for baking beer dough. 
akeju (plural akeje) (noun F) a root; a foot; a leg (of man, animal, or table, chair, etc); a pedal (of a cycle). cp. alias (roots of plants). 
akekesiar ko-o (reflexive verb) to be strong, obstinate, difficult, or hard. akekesiar akirot na: this is a difficult case. 
akekesikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to become strong for, difficult for, obstinate to. ekekesikit eketau akirot ngin: she/he finds this case difficult. 
akekesu (singular noun F) power; strength; trouble; swiftness. cp. ekekes, agogong. 
akele (plural akelei) (noun F) (rarely used) a man’s penis. cp. elomocor: a penis of a big animal such as a bull; elongot: head of penis; the glans. cp. edino.
akelesia (plural akelesian) (noun F) the Roman Catholic church or the Catholic religion. cp. ekeresia
akelot (noun F) a girl child born after twins.
akelyo (plural nukakelyo) (noun F) a plant eaten as a vegetable and from which salt is made, Colosea argentea. 
akemer (plural akemerin) (noun F) a birth mark; a skin mark on body of a leper; a syphilis mark on forehead; a freckle; white hair on a young person. 
akeo (noun F) a vegetable, Gynandropsis pentaphyll. cp. ecaboi, ecadoi.
akep (plural akepia) (noun F) the jugular vein; a blood vein in the neck or on forehead; a blood vessel in neck or forehead. 
akepar ko-a (transitive verb) to pare away; to circumcise. 
akepio (singular noun F) circumcision. 
akepun ko-a (transitive verb) to cut for oneself. 
akeraar ko-a (intransitive verb) to run away; to take refuge somewhere. 
akeria ko-a (transitive verb) to run off with. akeriata kesi ekabore: they have run off with my thing. akeria ngesi aberuka: he eloped with my wife. 
akerianut1 (noun F) riches; wealth; treasures; affluence; prosperity. aiwot naka akerianut: economic development. apol naka akerianut: economic growth. iitaabon luka akerianut: business records. aibois naka akerianut: a business premises.
akerianut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be rich, developmental or skillful. (ekeriana ngesi) ekeriaka kesi: (she/he is) they are developmetal, skillful, or rich. 
akeriar ko-a (intransitive verb) to run towards; to make off. abu ekokolan kokeriaa okekwa je: the thief ran off across the swamp to the next village/hill. 
akerikin ko-a (transitive verb) to go and fetch quickly; to run to help or relieve somebody; to run to the rescue; to run after someone. kokerik akipi: run to fetch water; run for water. abu etunganan kakerik eong korot: somebody ran after me on the road. 
akerit1 (singular noun F) a flight; an escape (by running away); a getaway, or a departure; a trip, a journey, a voyage, or air travel; an athletic event (especially a race). 
akerit2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be running; to be afraid; to honour. cp. aiyong. kokerite lukapolokokon: respect or honour your superiors. akerit kede egaalit: to move on bicycle. akerit kede emotoka: to drive a car. akeritor akiro: to telltale, rumourmonger, gossip, or to inform on. cp. ailoli. 
akerun ko-a (intransitive verb) to run this way; to come to the rescue. 
akesa (plural akesa) (noun F) a colleague; a member of an age group. akesa ngin: that woman over there. akesa kwa: those women over there. akesa na: this woman here.
akesisianakinan (plural akesisianakinak) (noun F) a teacher; a schoolmaster; a professor. 
aketar ko-a (transitive verb) to pull out, take away (as of a house, etc). 
aketekete (singular noun F) a distance. ajena naka ketekete: a distant relation i.e. no relation at all.
aketun ko-a (transitive verb) to pull out (anything) towards the speaker. 
akewat (plural akewas) (noun F) (Usuk) forefoot (of an animal); foreleg or front limb. 
akeyiar ko-o (reflexive verb) to melt; to be completely overcast; (of meat) to be very fatty; (of milk) to become watery; to rebuke, become nasty. adau akinyet akeyiar kotoma otwo: the butter has melted in the gourd. akeyiaros idowon: the sky is overcast. cp. akweiar, aresiar.
akibiriiti (plural akibiriitin) (noun F) a match; stick of matches; a flare. 
akideit (plural akidea) (noun F) a bow harp from the east. 
akidiar ko-a (transitive verb) to hurt; to pain (of a blow); to smart with laughter or coughing. kakidiarit eong aromait na: this blow hurts me. kakidiarit eong akwenekwenetoi na: this constant laughing pains me (hurts my sides). 
akididi ki-a (transitive verb) (Ateso Atororo) to make small strips of leather or anything; to make a string for a harp, etc or to make bootlaces from a hide. akididiun: to cut a small strip from anything. 
Akiding (plural Akidingon) (noun F) (in the Teso week) Wednesday. cp. Nakiuniet
akidingot (plural akidingon) (noun F) the middle; the core; the main part. akidingot nak’ecor: etau lokecor: the middle of the lake. cp. etau.
akido (plural akidoi) (noun F) a green jumping frog found in swamps. 
akijar (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) cp. aijar: life
akijiiko (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) cp. aijiiko: a spoon; a ladle
akikerep ki-a (transitive verb) (Ateso Atororo) to become mad; to go insane; to run mad. cp. aikerep
akikisenar (intransitive verb) (Ateso Atororo) to mock. 
akikomo (plural akikomon, akikomoi) (noun F) brass or copper (metal or bracelet). 
akikum (plural akikumo) (noun F) a rubber stamp. cp. aikunget. 
akikunget (plural akikungeta) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a rubber stamp. cp. aiciket, aikunget
akilar ko-a (reflexive verb) to go bald-headed. ekilari ngesi alosit: she/he is walking bald-headed. 
akilarikin1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk or go bareheaded. kinyek akilarikin, ededeng akolong: do not walk bareheaded, it is too hot. 
akilarikin2 kwap ki-a (intransitive verb) to fall heavily with the head hitting the ground; to strike the ground with back of the head. cp. aidusor. 
akilauri (plural akilaurin) (noun F) a hurricane lamp glass. ejaatar etabaasa kede akilauri, konye itodooma emameotor akilauri: a hurricane lamp has a glass, but a candle does not.
akile (uncountable noun F) milk; white latex; sap; juice. akile nuk’epopong: juice or latex from a cactus plant. akile nuk’eligoi: latex from eligoi hedge. 
akilekan (plural akilekana) (noun F) a plant used for making salt. 
akiling (plural akilinga) (noun F) the upper arm; biceps muscle. cp. aitinget. 
akim (plural akimian) (noun F) a fire; lighta flame; a blaze; a bonfire; a conflagration; an inferno; a gunfire. akim naka ekipyei: electricity. ailikor akim: to become angry (literally, to swallow fire).
akima (plural noun F) porridge or gruel made from finger millet or flour from any other grain; liquid volcanic lava; the porridge-like waste product in the distillation of crude alcohol (ewaragi or ejuge). cp. acocora: the porridge-like waste product in the distillation of crude alcohol. aicom akimai: to thresh finger millet. atap: cooked millet bread. alos: millet or flour destined for eating as bread.
akimai (plural of akimait) (noun F) finger millet in the granary or store. aicom akimai: to thresh finger millet. alos: threshed finger millet destined for making flour for eating. airiar alos: to grind millet or sorghum to use for bread. 
akimait (plural akimai) (noun F) a grain or a plant of finger millet, Eleusin corocona. 
akimat (plural amakio) (noun F) an old woman; a crony; (Ateso Atororo) a million. 
akiminganar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become deaf; to be deaf. akiminganaros akaki: my ears have become deaf or no longer hear properly. 
akiminganut1 (noun F) deafness; hard of hearing. cp. akinangang
akiminganut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be deaf. 
akimingikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be deaf to. akimingikis kesi akakiro: they have turned a deaf ear to what I say. 
akimirait (plural akimirai) (noun F) a necklace or bracelet made of pieces of ostrich eggshell. cp. amirait.
akimul (plural noun F) (Ateso Atororo) saliva; spittle; dribble; sputum. cp. aimula
akinang ko-a (intransitive verb) to go, to behave, to pass like a deaf man i.e. to pay no attention to one’s environment or the information it offers. kiriamun eong kikimingiok ekinangete oidukai: I met deaf people going to the shops. 
akinangang ko-a (intransitive verb) to be deaf; to hear and refuse to answer; to act as a deaf man. inyo bo ikinangangar ijo keworot?: why do you not answer when I call you? cp. aliriangang. 
akinangikin alosit ko-a (intransitive verb) to go as of a deaf man; to act like a deaf person. cp. aliriangikin. 
akine (plural akinei) (noun F) (Usuk) a female goat; a she-goat. cp. ekoroi: a he-goat; a billy-goat.
akinei (plural akinei) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a female goat; a she-goat. cp. ekoroi: a he-goat; a billy-goat.
akingarenikinet (plural akingarenikineta) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) leadership; management; headship. cp. aingarenikinet.
akingok (plural angokwo) (noun F) a bitch; a female dog; a loose woman (i.e. a prostitute); a very poor woman (living a dog’s life – i.e. miserably). 
akingol1 (plural akingolia) (noun F) a beige-coloured grasshopper. 
akingol2 (plural akingolia) (noun F) a ladle; a paddle or oar (of canoe); a spoon. cp. alutukony.
akinyang (plural akinyanga) (noun F) a small crocodile (whose anus is ground and powdered as a love potion); a pigmy crocodile. cp. epiu (plural ipiwan): big crocodile. akiru: a young crocodile. 
akinyet (plural akinyeta) (noun F) fat; oil; butter; petrol; paraffin; grease. akinyet nak’ikanyum: simsim oil. akinyet nak’etaala: paraffin; kerosene oil. akinyet apeteloori: petrol. akinyet naapotik: grease. akinyet nak’akiteng: butter. akinyet nak’asyepai: cow fat or lard. akinyet nakajonon: uncooked (raw) fat. 
akipi (uncountable noun F) water; juice; liquid; amniotic fluid (in humans). aiyat akipi akuwan kayen edeka: to administer fluids intravenously to a patient. aiga akipi nuedou: to trap rain water.
akiporo (plural akiporosinei) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) wet season. cp. aiporo 
akiria (noun F) flour; meal; powder. akiriat: a big heap of flour. eriata kesi akiriat: they have ground a lot of flour. ejukonokina ijo akiria: you are white (smothered) with flour. akiria nuka emuogo: cassava or tapioca flour. 
akiriap ko-a (intransitive verb) to roam about (looking for the road or anything else wanted). akiriap eong erot loka adumun ikaboro, kaoliki: I looked for the way to find my things in vain. 
akiriapikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to find by chance, by good luck. abu eong akiriapikin ajon: I got some beer by chance; I was lucky to get some beer. cp. aturiaikin.
akiriapitoi ko-a (intransitive verb) to go about looking for something. cp. aturiatoi. 
akirib ko-o (transitive verb) to stamp feet; to dance, stampede. akirib ekosio: to dance. akirib akeje: to stamp feet on the ground as in dance or military drill. 
akiribikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to walk together or dance together in step or in unison. 
akiriboor ko-o (reflexive verb) to walk away in step. 
akirididi (plural akirididin) (noun F) the armpit; a maize stem, stalk or leaf.
akirimait (plural akirim) (noun F) necklace of ostrich eggshell. 
akirimat (plural akirima) (noun F) bits of ostrich eggshell. 
akiring (plural akiringo) meat generally (beef, pork, lamb, mutton, chicken); flesh or tissue; muscles; fleshy part of fruit. ejijim akiring naka emuebe: the fleshy part of the mango is nice or a mango is sweet. akiring nak’akiteng: beef. akiring nak’amerekek: mutton; lamb. akiring nak’epege: pork. akiring nak’akokor: chicken.
akiro (plural of akirot) (noun F) words; affairs; cases; news; difficulty. akiro nyo? (greeting): what is the news? how are you? akiro nuamwakak: bitter, or hot, words; a difficult situation. akiro nukakwapin kanukokinga: international affairs.
akirosinei (plural noun F) list of words; words in general matters; affairs; news; difficulties; cases. 
akirot (plural akiro) (noun F) a word; an affair; a case; an incident. akiro: news; difficulty. akiro nukajokak: the good news.
akiru1 (plural akirui) (noun F) a young crocodile. 
akiru2 (singular noun F) rain; precipitation; rainfall. etepi akiru: it is raining. cp. edou
akisicaset (plural akisicaseta) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) an anchor; a fastener; brakes; a prop; a strut. cp. aitapaikinet
akisinit (plural akisinin) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a bracelet; a bangle; a wristlet; an armlet. cp. aisinit.
akit (plural aki) (noun F) the ear. ekit loka emeleku: the ear-like bit of a worn-out traditional hoe. ekit: a big ear as of an elephant. ikit yenika akimait: (plural) iki luka akimai: the earlike leaves of millet. 
akitegaet (plural akitegaeta) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a poison trap; a poison snare; a trap.
Akiteng1 (noun F) a woman’s name. 
akiteng2 (plural akituk) (noun F) a cow. cp. itaok, emong, ataok, akumukiliok. akituk: cows; cattle; a herd of cattle. cp. esipani. 
akitimir (singular noun F) a vegetable, Oxigonum atriplicifolium. 
akitiyo (plural akitiyon) (noun F) a spade; a shovel. 
akito (plural of akitoi) (noun F) wood; timber; firewood. aijep akito: to fell or cut firewood. 
akitoi (plural akito) (noun F) a piece of wood; a small stick; a cane. akito: firewood. arara akito: to gather or collect firewood. 
akitor ko-o (transitive verb) to scoop out or away completely; to finish all; to scrape out. 
akituk1 (plural akitukes) (noun F) mouth; lip; opening; language. akituk nak’amot: the mouth of the pot. akituk nak’ecilet: a river mouth. ejai ekesa ngol akituk: that man is a big liar (has a mouth); he is a tale-teller; he is sharp-tongued. Kolimokinai ikabore: karaida kemutono akwap, mam ipedori aolikin? Akituk: (a riddle) tell me a thing that you cannot miss even if it is very dark? A mouth.
akituk2 (plural of akiteng) (noun F) cattle; cows. 
akitun ko-o (transitive verb) to exhaust; to scrape out, when almost finished; to scoop out, finish all. akitun etau: to search the heart. akitun akipi: to scoop out (what is left of) water or liquid. (reflexive verb) akitunos ajon kio kiot: the beer is completely finished. akitun: to make a scraping noise as of drawing water from a drying well. akitun akipi: to draw water from a shallow well or nearly empty pot (making a scraping noise). cp. apyeun.
akiyai (plural nuakiyai) (noun F) firstborn girl. cp. nakiyai, yenikiyai
akiyo (plural noun F) a tear; lachrimose. aimony akiyo: to shed tears. 
akiyot (plural akwi) (noun F) a leaf (of vegetation). cp. akionit.
akobo (plural nukakobo) (noun F) a divorcee (once) or a woman divorced several times. inyo bo ikotor ijo aimany akobo, kojaas apesur?: why do you want to marry a divorcee when there are other girls? cp. ebwaade: man who cannot stay at home; a vagabond. 
akoboit (plural akoboi) (noun F) a banknote; paper money or currency. cp. akobwat.
akobokobot (plural akobokob) (noun F) a cucumber fruit. cp. akolilit
akobwat (plural akobwa) (noun F) a banknote; a currency note; paper money. 
akoc (plural akocio) (noun F) (a reference among friends) a tough woman; an iron lady. cp. abok
akocol ko-o (intransitive verb) to go about with hairless patches on the head; to have hairless patches. 
akodakin ko-a (transitive verb) to fasten (as of buttons); to link or to join (things) together. akodakinit akanin: to be arm in arm; with your arm holding another person's arm. kokodanak apeesan nuk’epalekon: fasten the buttons of your trousers. 
akodanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to make a chain; to fix here and there (as of a spider fixing or fastening its web). akodanakin aunoi: weaving rope (as for a bed frame). akodakin ibokor: to hook fingers. akodanakin irikoi: to join links of a chain. 
akodar ko-a (transitive verb) to carry away with a handle as of bucket or light object. kokoda ijo ikatuo da ocor: take my little gourd with you to the well. kokoda ikimat adekis: take the little old woman to the hospital. (note: akodar goes with the idea of a little load) 
akodet (plural akodeta) (noun F) a handle (of a cup, a bucket, etc). akodet nak’akiro: akodeta nuk’akiro: reasons for causing trouble, source of trouble. 
akodit ko-a (transitive verb) to carry in the hand; to hold (as one goes along) as of a lamp. ekodit ngesi etabaasa: she/he carries the lamp. akodit adoteu: to love many at once. (note: to carry big objects is aibwokit, adakit; to carry small objects is akodit). 
akodol ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a tall person) to be exhausted and sagging; to go about exhausted and stooping. 
akodolikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to lie down or sit down exhausted; to fall down exhausted. ekodolikin emong kwap kanuka apasit: the (ploughing) ox fell down exhausted. cp. aidodolikin.
akodomom ko-a (intransitive verb) to be round-shouldered (like old and tall people); to be tall and thin. 
akodun ko-a (transitive verb) to lift up by handle; to pull up by a hook; to tempt; to pull up (as of suspenders, braces). 
akoeded ko-o (intransitive verb) to be slender, slim, slight, lean, trim, or willowy. ikoeded ngesi: she/he is slender, thin. ikoededos kesi: they are slender. 
akoik (plural akoikes) (noun F) abdomen; womb; stomach; belly. ajaus k’akoik: epotie akoik: she is pregnant. arinyo akoik: the belly is wrinkled: to be hungry. arinyo akimat: the old woman is wrinkled or has wrinkles. 
akoikin ko-o (transitive verb) to find for, look out for; to search for; to attempt for. kolot kokoik eong akiring k’osokooni: go and look for some meat for me in the market. kokoikinoi akwara ka naolio: go and find my lost spear. 
akoit (plural akojo) (noun F) a bone; a piece of skeleton. 
akojo (plural of akoit) (noun F) bones; a skeleton. 
akojop (plural akojopa) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) an axe-handle. cp. akujup
akokakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to attend to very much; to pay especial attention to. 
akokit ko-a (transitive verb) to do frequently, regularly; to put one’s mind on, not to forget. akokit eong ailipasineika: I pray regularly, frequently, often. isirikaalei ekokitos iwenan: the soldiers guard the prisoners.
akoko1 (noun F) larceny; theft; robbery; stealing; burglary; shoplifting; thievery; pilferage. ekokoi ngesi: she/he steals. akoko tiritir: to steal everyday; perpetual thieving; kleptomania. 
akoko2 ko-a (transitive verb) to steal; to thieve, pilfer. akokoar: to steal away; to take away; to steal and take away. 
akokolanut1 (noun F) kleptomania; thieving. ekokolana ngesi: (plural ekokolaka kesi): she/he is (they are) fond of stealing. 
akokolanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be a thief; to be fond of stealing. 
Akokolemwoit (plural Akokolemwo) (noun F) a Kumam woman; a word in the language of the Kumam people of Kaberamaido and parts of Soroti district. Akokolemwo (noun F) the language of the Kumam people of Kaberamaido and parts of Soroti district.
akokor (plural akokoroi) (noun F) a hen; a fowl; a chicken; a female bird. 
akokore ko-o (transitive verb) (of fruits) to ripen; (of water) to boil; (of brew) to ferment; (of food) to be done (only used in the plural, singular is akonore). akoko acok: the potatoes are done (well cooked). akoko akimai: the millet is ripe. 
akokoro (plural akokoron) (noun F) a bicycle wheel. 
akokos alosit ko-a (intransitive verb) to go in a hurry; to hurry. abu ngesi kokokos alosit: she/he went off in a hurry (with heavy long strides). cp. akakas alosit. 
akokosan ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very old; to become very old. cp. amojong. 
akokosanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become old. 
akokosanut1 (noun F) great age. akokosanut ke emik nges aswam: her/his old age has prevented her/him from working. cp. amojong. 
akokosanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become very old. 
akokosikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to hurry off on foot somewhere or for someone. kokokosik akeje aomare papakon, atwana toto: hurry off to call your father, mother is dead. 
akokoyo (uncountable noun F) tallow i.e. hard fat from sheep or cattle. 
akoku1 (plural adwe) (noun F) a female child; daughter. cp. edweet: edweit: edwesisit: a crowd of children. koany edweet ngol: look at that crowd of children. 
akoku2 kajokotau (plural adwe kajokotau) a girl of good-hearted mother. (a term complimenting a good girl). cp. okoku kojokotau. akokuke: akokukec: her/his or their daughter. 
akoku3 kapapaka (plural adwe kapapaka) (noun F) my father’s daughter; my step-sister; my half sister (different mother). cp. inac: sister (same father and mother). 
Akol1 (noun F) a pet name for a cow with large white patches in a generally black body; a person’s name. 
akol2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be at loggerheads; to be constantly in opposition; to rival; to quarrel. 
akoli (plural akolin) (noun F) a cup, gourd or a small calabash for drinking water. 
akolicic1 (noun F) albinism. cp. aderit. 
akolicic2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to have red or white spots on the body; to be half albino. cp. aderit. 
akolilit (plural akolil) (noun F) cucumber fruit or plant. cp. akobokob
akolip (plural akolipa) (noun F) a barren woman or a barren animal. cp. adonge. 
akolipan ko-a (intransitive verb) to be barren; (of women or animals) to become barren. akolipan akakiteng: my cow has become barren. cp. aidongeikin. 
akolipanut1 (noun F) (in males) sterility; barrenness.
akolipanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be sterile; to be lazy; to be impotent. ikolipana ijo: you are impotent. 
akoloboc (plural akoloboco) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a fork (an eating implement with prongs). cp. auma, asereseeti 
akolodong (plural akolodongo) (noun F) a round scale used for weighing cotton, etc; a tortoise, Trionix nilotica. cp. akuma.
akolokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to quarrel about, dispute about. akolokinos itelepai kanuka inyamat: the boys are quarrelling about food. 
akolong (plural akolong) (noun F) the sun; a clock; daylight; the sun’s heat. ebala akolong ai? what is the time (what does the sun say)? 
akolongit (plural akolonga) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) the hour. ekolongit: the day. ekolongit: day. ekolongit lokadumunia: the day I meet you. ngol kolongit: every day. akolongisinei: days. cp. esaawa
akolonor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become difficult, severe, harsh. akolonor ejakait kwana: the chief has become very difficult to deal with these days. 
akolor ko-o (intransitive verb) to be at loggerheads; to be enemies. ekolos papaka k’onaceka: my father and my brother are at loggerheads. 
akoloror (singular noun F) bald-headedness. cp. akularar, apacolol. 
akomolianut1 (singular noun F) pie-baldness; brown-spottedness; albinism. 
akomolianut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be pie-bald, coloured, spotted dark brown. ekomoliana akine: the goat has a dark brown colour or spots. egoe loekomoliana: a dirty-brown coloured cloth. 
akomot (plural akomoi) (noun F) armlet. 
akompiuta (plural akompiutan) (noun F) a computer; a laptop; a personal computer (PC). acuuma naebakai akompiuta ejulaki eiswamae loka eyapeesi noi: a computer has revolutionized office work so much.
akone (plural akonei) (noun F) (in Karamoja) a female lover. irai ijo akoneka: you are my friend. cp. apapero. 
akong (plural akongin) (noun F) a knee or other joint. cp. esonget: in plants. akung nak’ebokorit: finger-joint, or knuckle. cp. akung.
akongoror ko-a (intransitive verb) to lose weight. 
akongu (plural akonye) (noun F) an eye; a spring (of a well). akongu nak’atitipu: an opening (hole) in an anthill. akongu nak’ekicoi: the spring of a well.
akonore ko-o (intransitive verb) (of food) to be done; to be cooked; (of fruit or an abscess) to be ripe; (of food) to be ready. akoko inyamat: the food is ready (is cooked and can be eaten). 
akonyakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to clench or grit teeth, as of dying person. Okanya elosi atwanare naarai ekonyanakini do ikel: Okanya is going to die because he is now gritting his teeth. 
akonyar ko-a (transitive verb) to bite off (away). 
akonyaret (plural akonyareta) (noun F) a mouthful (of food); a bite; a morsel. koinakinai adiopekonyaret naka atap: give me one mouthful of food or just a morsel. 
akonye (plural of akongu) (noun F) eyes; faces. kakonyeka: in front of me; before me. kakonye: later on; in the future; before; in front of. kidareu kakonye: wait, you’ll see or get it later. 
akonyetait (plural akonyeta) (noun F) a bite; a sting. 
akonyokony ko-a (transitive verb) (of body) to ache; to keep biting (as of fleas or anything). akonyokonyata eong iidep: fleas have bitten me. 
akonyun ko-a (transitive verb) to bite off; to have a bad ache. kakonyununei eong akou: I have a constant headache. kakonyununei eong akoik: I have a constant stomach-ache.
akoodakita (plural akoodakitan) (noun F) a conductress; a woman who collects fares from passengers on a bus, taxi, etc. cp. akoodakita. 
akoodom (plural akoodomun) (noun F) a condom; a thin rubber sheath worn on the penis during sexual intercourse, to prevent the release of sperm into the vagina and so avoid pregnancy, and to prevent the spread of disease. cp. amopiira. 
akoogo1 (plural akoogoi) (noun F) a chicken breed with bare necks; a hen without feathers round the neck. 
akoogo2 (plural akoogoi) (noun F) a percussion reed instrument or accompanied dance to its sound; a thumb piano. 
akoomat (plural akoomai) (noun F) a bracelet; a plectrum of a percussion instrument called akoogo.
akoonokin ko-o (transitive verb) to be continually scratching or rubbing oneself; (of a bird) to preen feathers. 
akoor ko-o (transitive verb) to scratch off. akoo ikoku akejimi: the child has scratched the scab on its wound. kokooroi epura, kepii: scratch my back, it itches. 
akopa (plural akopai) (noun F) a woman who has had several husbands. cp. akobo.
akopiira (plural akopiiran) (noun F) a hat – a cap, a trilby, a panama, or a sunhat. cp. acooro, asepeo. 
akopirot (plural akopir) (noun F) a large feather (of birds). akopirot nak’ekuulu: an ostrich feather. 
akopiton (plural akopit) (noun F) a bark fibre used as rope, string; a strip of bark. 
akopokin ko-o (transitive verb) to dash at; to attack somebody suddenly; to snatch something away for somebody. akopokin ekapa emir: the cat has suddenly attacked a mouse or rat. 
akopor1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to wear a stiff skin or cloth (as unwashed khaki). 
akopor2 ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch a thing away; to tell tales of other people. akopo etoori imiyot: the eagle snatched a chick away. (reflexive verb) to get up quickly and go away; to get off suddenly; to start suddenly. 
akoporikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to start off dressed in stiff cloth or skin. 
akoporor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become stiff; to become tough, dry, hard (as of a skin, dried meat, etc). 
akoposoor ko-o (transitive verb) to hasten away; to hurry off.
akoposun ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch off, drag off, or away. cp. akopun. 
akopun ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch up, towards speaker; to seize. (reflexive verb) to start all of a sudden. akopun ngesi togo: she/he has come into the house suddenly. 
akopyot (plural akopyo) (noun F) dew; fine drops of water from grass and trees; (Ateso Atororo) a court registration fee. ekitoi eisi akopyo: the tree rains dew-drops. atikor akopyo: to go very early. 
akor ko-o (transitive verb) to cultivate (soil); to dig (in general); to farm. ekoriei ngesi akemisiri: she/he cultivates her/his garden. cp. aidat: to turn the soil roughly; to plough raw soil. ailobo: to level out; to equalize the soil or plough the second time. aibok acok: to make little heaps for planting sweet potatoes. aiwe: to sow (seeds). aikurukur: to rake under the seed or cover the seed with earth by driving a herd of cattle through the sown field. aicap eduan: to weed. aisak: to harvest grain (such as millet, sorghum, rice). aikut emaido: to harvest groundnuts - to dig up groundnuts. aikur acok: to dig out sweet potatoes. ailem epaaba: to pick cotton. aipac emaido: to unhusk the groundnuts; to shell. 
akorakin ko-a (transitive verb) to allot; to distribute to; to share out to; to divide for. kokorakinai eong da: give me also something. 
akoranakin ko-a (transitive verb) to distribute often or to many persons. 
akorar ko-a (transitive verb) to give something away; (of many) to finish quickly. akorar apese: (of in-laws) to hand a bride to her bridegroom at a marriage. akoras itunga inyamat kere: the people finished the food quickly. akorar ajon kosokooni: the beer has been finished in the market quickly. 
akorasit (plural akorasia) (noun F) a serving; a portion; a share; a piece. akorasit naka inyamat: portion of food. 
akoraut (plural akorau) (noun F) a bush, Mimosa aspera. 
akoret (plural akoreta) (noun F) a place where food is distributed; the hatches of a cafeteria; the instrument with which food is served. 
Akori1 (noun F) a pet name for a white and brown flecked cow; a woman’s name. 
akori2 (plural akorio) (noun F) a woman or animal slow in conceiving; a female giraffe. cp. awosianut, awoosian. 
akorikin ko-o (transitive verb) to cultivate for someone. 
akorio (singular noun F) distribution; division; allotment; allocation. 
akorior ko-o (transitive verb) to plough away or hoe away (weeds, etc). cp. airienyar, aisiebar. 
akorisit (plural akorisio) (noun F) a plot (of food or cotton); a cultivated piece of land. 
akoro (singular noun F) (in Karamoja) hunger; starvation. kaar eong akoro: I am very hungry. kanyam eong akoro: I am starving. 
akoroc ko-o (intransitive verb) to bail water from a gravely well (making the above sound). 
akorococ ko-o (intransitive verb) to be uneven; to be rough (of road); to be hard (as of ground or soil); (with akou) to be stupid. cp. aimugogolit. ikorococos alup: the ground is hard, uneven. ikorococ eguudo: the road is uneven. 
akoroi1 (plural noun F) self-sprouting potatoes (left in the ground and sprouting out). cp. arinyot. 
akoroi2 (plural akorwa) (noun F) a branch of ekoroi bush, used to close the gate of a kraal or goat hut, or house; a piece of wood from the above bush used for a toe-holder of sandals and for a nose clip for an obstinate cow or bull. 
akoromit (plural akorom) (noun F) a species of bird also called lily-trotter bird. cp. acoe. 
akorun ko-o (transitive verb) to serve up. akorun inyamat: to serve up food. cp. adutunos. 
akorwa (plural noun F) wooden or skin sandals; clogs. cp. akalabatan.
akorwoit (plural akorwo) (noun F) a grey hair. 
akoset (plural akoseta) (noun F) a fly swatter or whisk (made of cow- tail or of twigs); a fan. akoto aikot icuc kakosetait: I want to drive flies away with a fly-swatter. cp. aipukupuket.
akosong (plural akosonga) (noun F) a bone joint; thigh-bone or femur; joint of meat. 
akotar ko-a (transitive verb) to chase away once with a fan or similar instrument; to swat (flies, etc) with a swatter. 
akote1 ko-o (transitive verb) to like; to love; to need; to want; to wish. akoto eong inyamat: I want food. akoto eong: I want. ikoto ijo: you want. kikoto oni: we want (or need). ikotos yesi: you (plural) want. ekotos kesi: they want. ekoto ngesi: she/he wants.
akote2 naejok (singular noun F) goodwill; wellwishes. kitoodikinai akonikote naejok: show me your goodwill. 
akote3 nakaronon (singular noun F) bad will; bad wishes. kikotor ijo eong erono: you have bad-will against me.
akotonokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to love, like one another. kokotonokinos bonik: love one another. 
akotor1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to walk, to go with a thin body. ekotori (lokadekan) oiduka: the thin person goes to the shop. plural: ekotorete kesi: they go with thin bodies: they have thin bodies. 
akotor2 ko-o (transitive verb) to wish to somebody something. akotor eong ijo aswam ace: I wish you to do another work. 
akotoraar ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a thin person or animal) to die. akotoraaros akakituk bian: my emaciated cows died yesterday. 
akotorikin ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a thin person or animal) to fall; to die somewhere. ekotorikin ekimat kwap: the thin old man fell down. akotorikinos akakituk osamai: my cows died in the swamp (from starvation); the cows in the swamp became so emaciated that they died. 
akotoror ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very thin; to be very small; to be tiny (of men and animals). akotoror ikoku ngin, edeka apaarasia kere: that child is very thin, it is always ill. 
akou1 (plural akwes) (noun F) head; top of; ruler; headman. ijo nges akou naka itunga kere: you are the head of all these people. akou k’amukat: point of shoe. egogong akou: stubborn, stupid. ejai ijo akou: you are proud. 
akou2 atapengo (singular noun F) a vegetable, Justicia insularia. 
akoun ko-o (transitive verb) to look for; to find; to search for. kokoutu ibore yen aolio: find the thing which was lost. cp. amoun.
akoyior ko-o (transitive verb) to go and look for; to go and find somewhere, over there; to attempt; to try to be going to. akoyiosi idwe ngul papakec: those children have gone to look for their father. akoyiosi akipi ayangaar eong: the water current was going to take me away. 
akoyokoyot (plural akoyokoyon) (noun F) uncooked beeswax tallow. 
Akristayot (plural Akristayon) (noun F) a Christian woman. 
akuar ko-a (transitive verb) to extract (and throw away). 
akuare (plural akuaresia) (noun F) night. 
akubai (plural akubain) (noun F) a water beetle. cp. emerekek. 
akubany ko-a (intransitive verb) to stride away; to make big strides; to walk proudly. ikubanyi ijo bala isot: you stride away like a gentleman (like a proud man or boy). cp. angoid. 
akube (plural akubei) (noun F) a small gourd for water and butter oil. 
akubitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to rush round; to dash around. 
akubokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to dash at; to rush at, pounce on, jump at. akubokin ekapa emir: the cat has rushed, dashed at the rat. 
akubor ko-o (reflexive verb) to rush or dash out or away; to dart away. akubor ekokolan: the thief scurried away. 
akubun ko-o (reflexive verb) to rush into; to dash into. akubun ekingok togo: the dog rushed into the room. 
akucakin ko-a (transitive verb) to hang; to strangle or to choke. (reflexive verb) to hang oneself. 
akudet (plural akudeta) (noun F) a corner (of a road, street); angle. 
akudi ko-a (intransitive verb) to cough aloud; to laugh aloud; to double up with laughter or coughing. 
akudianar ko-o (reflexive verb) to cough persistently. 
akudo ko-o (intransitive verb) to sit bent or drawn up (like a man full of pain). ekudo ngesi kanuka amojongu: she/he stoops or hunches due to old age. 
akudoit (plural akudo) (noun F) churned sour milk and good or fresh milk mixed together (producing lumps). aleposi akudo idwe: the children got diarrhoea by drinking akudo. 
akudokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to fold (cloth, etc); to bend down or up (as of elbow or old person). ekudokina loaraman airam atenus: the drummer has bent to beat her/his drum. akudokin akeje: to bend the knees, draw up the legs. akudokin aswam: to put your back into work; to work hard at something. cp. asukokin. 
akudokinet (plural akudokineta) (noun F) a corner; a bend; a loop. 
akudolikin ko-a (transitive verb) to bend double; to double up. 
akudud (singular noun F) agriculture, especially crop husbandry in its traditional form using a hand hoe. cp. akor.
akudukud ko-o (intransitive verb) to wind (as of a road); to meander. ekudukudei erot lo noi: this road meanders very much. 
akudukudet (plural akudukudeta) (noun F) wrinkles on the face or body. 
akudukudo ko-o (transitive verb) to twist; to warp; to fold, crease. akudukud akolong emukule: the sun has warped the hide. (intransitive verb) to be twisted; to warp;to crease. ekudukudo apapula: the paper is creased (folded). ekudukudo irotin bala emun: the roads are twisting like a snake (are full of turns). 
akuet (plural akueta) (noun F) remnants of froth of milk; remnants of foam (after frothing or foaming). 
akuikin1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to escape from. (transitive verb) to elude, escape, avoid, or dodge. kakuikis eong ityang kere kokitwi: all the animals escaped in the bush. 
akuikin2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to boil over on to or into; to bully; to hector; (of big person to small one) to domineer. akuikis akile akim: the milk has boiled over into the fire. sirikikuik ikoku: do not bully a little child. 
akuj (abstract noun F) sky; heaven; summit; to top of. (in Karamoja) God: Akuj. ejai toma akuj: she/he/it is in the sky; she/he/it is in heaven. 
akujup (plural akujupa) (noun F) an axe-handle. cp. amusenu: a hoe handle
akuk (plural of akuku) (noun F) charcoal. cp. akukut. akuk nuk’okwap: coal. 
akuko ko-o (intransitive verb) to be kneeling; to revere, worship. (plural ekukosi kesi: they are kneeling). kicorakitai oni akuko kakonye ka Edeke: we are obliged to kneel before God (to revere and worship God). 
akukokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to kneel down to; to kneel at or for. kokukokinos ngina: kneel down over there. 
akuku (plural akuk) (noun F) charcoal. cp. akukut. akuk nukakwap: coal. 
akukum ko-o (intransitive verb) to bend forward, bow, stoop (as of one touching toes or ground). 
akukumikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to bend down for somebody or something. 
akukumit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be bending down. ekukumit ngesi iswamai: she/he works bending down. akukumit ilosi: to walk with a stoop. cp. alolot. 
akukumor ko-o (reflexive verb) to bend down on hands and knees, also on hands and knees touching the ground with forehead (like Mohammedans). cp. aitukumonor. 
akukunya1 (noun F) application; diligence; exertion. cp. akukuranut. 
akukunya2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be diligent, very busy, active, or restless; to exert oneself; to be in a hurry. ekukunya ngesi aswam: she/he works diligently. cp. aikok.
akukunyaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to hurry away; to go quickly to. kokukunyaaros aswam: hurry away (go off quickly) to your work. cp. aiwonyar
akukunyikin ko-o (reflexive verb) (with negative connotations) to do quickly, diligently; to be quick, diligent in doing; to exert oneself in doing; to strive after. akukunyikinos itelepai aiwadik kojokan: the boys have exerted themselves in order to write nicely. 
akukunyor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become sweet to the smell; to become tasty. edia kon akukunyoor noi: your vegetables (have become) are spicy or nice smelling. 
akukur ko-a (intransitive verb) to be busy, active; to do quickly; to do zealously; to make an effort. ekukuri ngesi aipoore: she is busy cooking. Marita, Marita, ipu iboro lukiinakinete ijo akukura: Martha, Martha, many things will keep you busy. 
akukuranar ko-a (transitive verb) to work hard and to work zealously; to do anything with heart and soul. 
akukuranut1 (singular noun F) zeal; perseverance; efficiency; diligence. ejai ngesi akukuranut toma aswamusinei ke: she/he is efficient in all she/he does. cp. akokanut. 
akukuranut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be busy, zealous, efficient. 
akukurikin ko-a (transitive verb) to do one’s best for; to work hard for. akukurikin eong aiswamakin ikadwe: I do my best working for my children. 
akukuse (plural akukusen, akukusei) (noun F) a small grinding stone. cp. akangas, atapen. 
akukusiar ko-a (transitive verb) to go straight; to run quickly, without deviating, without stopping; to continue. kokukusia ijo alosit oiduka: go quickly to the shops. cp. arurukaar. 
akukusikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to hasten; to do quickly; to rush at a work. akukusikinos kesi aitudeng akim: they rushed to extinguish fire. 
akukut (plural akuku) (noun F) charcoal; embers. cp. atotolet
akula ko-a (intransitive verb) (of beer, etc) to ferment; (of water, etc) to boil; (of iron) to rust; to rise (as of dough); (of iron) to become red hot. ekulaete akipi: the water is boiling. ekulai edia: the vegetables are boiling up. 
akulaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to ferment; to boil over; to become red hot (of iron in fire). akulaasi akile: the milk has boiled over. 
akulaet (plural akulaeta) (noun F) resin of plants; dross of beer or boiling food; bubbles of liquid. 
akulaikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to boil or to bubble into; to rust, become rusty. ekagaali akulaiki kere: my bicycle has become rusty all over. akulaikisi akile akim: the milk has boiled over into the fire. cp. amasikin, amerikin.
akulaikinet (noun F) burnt or black part of meat or food. ipoit ijo acok erono, ileleba akulakineta: you cooked the potatoes badly, they are burnt. cp. airigikinet. 
akulakin ko-a (transitive verb) to peel for someone; to pare for; to corrode. cp. airigikin: to get burned (as of food or meat sticking to the pot, by not turning). kekulaiki akiring: the meat is burned. 
akularar ko-a (reflexive verb) to be bald-headed; to grow bald. ekularaar ngesi: she/he has grown bald. 
akulaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to bubble up; to boil; to evaporate; (of iron in fire) to become red hot; to fizz. ekulaununete akipi k’atan: the water bubbles up in the well. cp. ailepunun; aibwelibwel. 
akulep1 (plural akulepo) (noun F) a handle of a knife, an axe, or a hoe; a haft or hilt of a sword. 
akulep2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to run or jump (like a frog); to leap; (of horse) to gallop; to abuse; to scold. ekulepete atyang akwap: the animals are leaping. akulep aberu okilenike: the wife scolded her husband. cp. aikur, amoromor. 
akulepikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to run off; to gallop; to leap away for or to. 
akulepoor ko-o (intransitive verb) to gallop or leap away (as of horses or animals or frogs). 
akuletait (plural akuleta) (noun F) a peeling or flake (as potato or cassava-peels, etc) 
akuleut (noun F) a prickly plant burnt for salt making. 
akuluma (plural akuluman) (noun F) a clap trap or rat-trap (for catching rats); the gallows; a cover on a granary; a dangerous structure that may collapse anytime (possibly endangering its inhabitants). 
Akum k' Oumo (proper noun) the old name of Kumi. (literally, Akum of Oumo, Oumo being the founder) 
akuma (plural noun F) (outside Usuk) a corruption of akima: porridge, millet, gruel. 
akumac (plural akumacia) (noun F) (Usuk) a big edible tortoise or turtle found in aro (wilderness). 
Akumamait (plural Akumama) (noun F) an Atesot woman, so called by the Karimojong; a Kumam woman (a native of Kaberamaido district) who speaks a language akin to Luo and Ateso. 
akumioit (plural akumio) (noun F) an edible fruit from ekum tree, from which Kumi derives its name. 
akumonokin ko-a (transitive verb) to turn one’s behind on to (somebody) (considered bad manners). ekosio lok’akumonokin imu: an obscene dance for twins (where behinds are turned to one another).(note: bearing twins was considered aicud or ecudet, a form of wizardry) 
akumor ko-o (intransitive verb) to turn back away from. ekoto ngesi ereka kokumorite laije: she/he wants my home to be built facing this way (with the back looking, turned that way). kokumosi laije: turn your behinds that way. 
akumukiliok (plural nukakumukiliok) (noun F) a heifer. cp. ataok 
akumun ko-o (intransitive verb) to point your backside this way; to turn the backside this way. kokum lailo: turn your backside this way. 
akung (plural akungin) (noun F) a knee or other joint. cp. esonget in plants. akung nak’ebokorit: finger-joint, or knuckle. cp. akong
akungurit (singular noun F) sheanut oil made from the seeds of ekungur tree. cp. alinyo
akungurot (plural akungur) (noun F) a fruit of ekungur tree. cp. adanyot
akungurut (plural akungurun) (noun F) (formerly) a 5-cent copper coin. cp. agungurut
akuor ko-o (intransitive verb) to foam over, out, into; to boil over; to bubble over the edge of the pot, etc. akuosi akile kakim: the milk has boiled over into the fire (foams on to the fire). 
akur (plural noun F) honeycomb with bee larvae. 
akuraru (plural akurarun) (noun F) a leather scabbard for a spear blade; a leather sheath; a leather casing, a leather cover; a leather case for a weapon; a holster. 
akure (singular noun F) thirst; need for liquids. ajak akure: to be thirsty. kajak eong akure: I am thirsty (literally, thirst has made my jaws hang). cp. ekure
akuret (plural akureta) (noun F) the handle of (ekuret) a large fishing hook; a rake. 
akurian1 (singular noun F) fright; timidity; fear; cowardliness; sensitiveness; threat. 
akurian2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be frightened; to be sensitive; to be afraid; to be timid; to be a coward, craven; to be ticklish, affright, diffident. ekuryana ngesi: she/he is cowardly, etc. ekuryaka kesi: they are timid, etc aitukurian: to frighten; to make afraid, timid, etc; to threaten. 
akurianaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become afraid; to fear; to be scared, etc. 
akuriei (plural akuriesik) (noun F) a timid woman; a coward, etc
akurokin ko-a (transitive verb) to dig (potatoes, etc) for somebody or somewhere. 
akurub ko-o (transitive verb) to munch, chew, masticate, crunch, chomp or grind with teeth. ekurubi apese emuogo loajonon: the girl is munching raw cassava.
akurun1 ko-a (transitive verb) to bring near with a hook or stick. cp. akwerun. 
akurun2 ko-o (transitive verb) to call insulting names. inyo bo kikurunitor ijo kiworot?: why do you use those insulting names on me? cp. amorun.
akurungan ko-a (intransitive verb) (of old man) to be old but strong enough to marry; (of a man) to be virile at an old age; (of a man) to be active sexually or otherwise. amojong ngesi konye eroko ekurungani: he is old but still making love or wooing. 
akurunganut (singular noun F) (of men) making love in old age; virility; old age libido or nymphomania. 
akuruny (singular noun F) edible melted fat; lard from sheep’s tail. cp. arurwak
akurup ki-o (transitive verb) to snatch away. cp. aurup.
akurur ko-a (transitive verb) to work diligently in the field for hours; to scratch somebody with thorns as of a cat scratching a person; to scrape fat and hair of a skin; to rake. 
akururaar ko-a (transitive verb) (of hair) to shave off in one go; to finish ploughing a plot in one day. 
akurureet (plural akurureeta) (noun F) a rake. cp. akuret
Akurut (noun F) a name of a woman. 
akurwoit (plural akurwo) (noun F) a corruption of akorwoit: a grey hair. 
akurwokin ko-o (intransitive verb) to fail to, not be able to manage; to be unable, too difficult for. kakurwokit eong aswam ngin: that work is too difficult for me. cp. aipikor. 
akurwoor ko-o (transitive verb) to fail to do; to be or become impossible; to be unable; to be too difficult; to be too much for. kakurwo eong aswam ngin: that work is too much for me. akurwo aberu adeka: the illness has overcome the woman (she won’t live long or she will not survive it). 
akuset (plural akuseta) (noun F) a burrow; a hole in the ground; instrument for burrowing or making a hole. 
akusiar ko-a (intransitive verb) to dry up a little (as of road, cloth, of body after washing, etc); to heal up; (of a wound) to dry up a little; to be delayed; to delay. akusia erot: the road has dried up a little. akusia akajimi: my wound has healed up a little. inyo bo ikusiarata yesi kangina?: why do you delay over there. akusia akwap: it is fairly dry. 
akuta (plural akutai) (noun F) a digging stick with a metal dibble (popular in Lango as a hoe). cp. engiti, emeleku, eboket
akutakin ko-a (transitive verb) to blow on or for or into; to shoot with a gun. akutakin etwo: to ostracise. 
akutakinet (plural akutakineta) (noun F) a blast (with a horn or a flute); a gust of air; a flurry. 
akutapap ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very dirty (especially of fingers and toes). kekutapapa: they have become altogether dirty. 
akutapapaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become dirty. akutapapaaros akaninika: my hands have become dirty. 
akutar ko-a (transitive verb) to blow out (fire, etc); to blow away; to extinguish. akuta ekwam ataker okekwa je: the wind has blown the boat to the other side of the lake. kokuta etabaasa: blow out the lamp. 
akutor ko-o (transitive verb) to dig out (as of groundnuts) or potato tubers from the fire. 
akutukanut1 (noun F) truculence; aggressiveness; hot-temper. 
akutukanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be quarrelsome; to be rude; to be hot-tempered, fretful, strict, unruly, harsh, aggressive. ikutukana ijo (plural ikutukaka yesi): you are hot-tempered, etc. 
akutun1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to blow this way. (transitive verb) to summon by horn; to call by whistle or bugle. 
akutun2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to dig out of the fire (roasted potatoes); to dig out groundnuts or millet from the granary; to give a dig in the back with the fist or with a club. abu ngesi kokut akangabet: she/he hit me on the back. kolot kokut emaido: go and dig up groundnuts. 
akutunet (plural akutuneta) (noun F) a blast of wind; an exhumation. 
akuudian1 (singular noun F) trials or tests (of faith); tribulations; great suffering (like the biblical Job).
akuudian2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to grieve too much (like the biblical Job); to mourn for long; to weep continually. ekuudiani aberu ikekoku yen atwani bian: the woman is grieving over her child who died yesterday. cp. aigworo; aibworo.
akuudianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to keep mourning over; to keep grieving for someone or something. 
akuuguto (plural akuugutoi) (noun F) a sift. cp. aijililiet, ailepet
akuulu (plural akuului) (noun F) an ostrich feather. 
akuun1 epali ko-o (intransitive verb) to become ill-mannered; to become obstreperous, or cheeky. ikuu ijo epali kwana: you have become cheeky these days. 
akuun2 ko-a (transitive verb) to pick out (jiggers or thorns); to extract. 
akuun3 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of mouth or of soda or beer or soap) to foam; to boil up. akuu asabuunyu dau dau: the soap has foamed very much. 
akuwaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to escape in a certain direction (away from speaker). akuaasi ngina: they escaped in that direction. 
akuwamikin ko-a (transitive verb) to make rough. (reflexive verb) to become rough. 
akuwan (plural awate) (noun F) the body; a cadaver or corpse. adeka naka akuwan: body malais. akuwan naka aberu (plural awate nuka angor) (noun F) (euphemism) the female genitalia; a woman’s body; (polite reference to) the woman’s private parts. akuwan naka ekiliokit (plural awate nuka ikiliok) (noun F) the male body; the male genitals; (polite reference to) the man’s private parts (the penis, the testes and all). 
akuwe (plural akuwei) (noun F) a hydrocele (lymphatic filariasis transmitted by a culex mosquito); enlarged testicles (i.e. elephantiasis of the testes). cp. erojiroj
akuyum ko-o (transitive verb) to eat something soft; to walk on soft sand or soft ground; to dig soft soil or sand. kokuyum emugaati: eat soft (fresh) bread. kokuyum asinge: walk on the sand. 
akuyumikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to go on loose sand or on soft soil. (transitive verb) to break a dry thing once (like a pot, biscuit or a granary). kokuyumik edula k'ebela: break up that granary with a cane. 
akuyumoor ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a dry and floury thing) to become soft or loose (like a biscuit). akuyumooros alup: the dry soil has become soft (loose). 
akuyumum ko-o (intransitive verb) (of cake or boiled potatoes) to be soft; (of soil or sand) loose. ikuyumum emugaati lo: this bread is soft (fresh). 
akwacakin ebalua ko-a (transitive verb) to write or scribble a letter to somebody or someone. 
akwacakwac ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch all over. abu egereger kakwacakwac eong noi: the monitor lizard scratched me all over. 
akwacar ko-a (transitive verb) to claw away. 
akwacet (plural akwaceta) (noun F) a scratch; a graze; a grate. 
akwacun ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch (this side); to write. 
akwadar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go about with a weak thin body. aanyu eong lokadekan ikwadar adekis: I saw the sick man struggling (stumbling) to the hospital. 
akwadarar ko-a (intransitive verb) to waste away (from illness); to become emaciated. 
akwadarikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to straggle (as of a sick person or animal); to stumble along.
akwalikwal (plural akwalikwalia) (noun F) midriff; peritoneum. cp. akabo. 
akwamakin ko-a (transitive verb) to glut, give or put too much. akwamakin amuunyu odia: to put too much salt in vegetables.
akwangalu1 (noun F) lightness; thinness. 
akwangalu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be thin; to be light; not to be heavy. 
akwangarar (intransitive verb) to waste away. cp. akangarar, akongoror.
akwangiar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become white. kinyek kes kokwangiaros: let them become white. 
akwangis ko-a (intransitive verb) to be white, grey, ashen, or pale.
akwangus (noun F) whiteness; brightness; paleness. akwang eong: I am white. kikwangak iso: we are white. aitakwang: to make white. 
akwangus ko-a (intransitive verb) to be white; to be grey or ashen, pale. 
akwanguun ko-a (intransitive verb) to be or become thin, become white, emaciated, waste away; to bleach, blanch. akwanguutu itunga kanuka etengei: the people have become thin on account of famine. akwanguu epaaba: the cotton has become white (has blossomed). 
akwaniar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become sharp. 
akwanikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be sharp for; to cut sharp. ekwanikit ekileng akiring: the knife is sharp enough to cut meat. mam ekwanikit akojo: it is not sharp enough for cutting bones. 
akwanis ko-a (intransitive verb) to be sharp, keen, acute. ekwana: it is sharp (plural ekwaka: they are sharp). ekwaka akonye: sharp or eagle-eyed. ekwaka nges iwos: (of a boy) wearing shorts off very fast (literally, he has sharp buttocks). 
akwanus1 (noun F) (of a cutting instrument) sharpness; keenness; cutting. 
akwanus2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a cutting instrument) to be sharp, keen, acute. ekwana: it is sharp (plural ekwaka: they are sharp). ekwana angajep: sharp-tongued; sarcastic; vitriolic. ekwana nges akituk: she/he has a sharp tongue. cp. akwanis
akwap (plural akwapin) (noun F) the earth; country; land; mainland. akwapin nuicanas (noun F): poor nations. akwapin nuepoloete (noun F): developing countries. akwapin nuabarak (noun F): developed, wealthy, or rich nations. ibore kakwap (noun neuter): sickness, smallpox, measles. ibore yen emamei ilope (noun neuter): public property. aberu kakwap (noun F): a prostitute; a public woman. 
akwapusinei (plural of akwap) (noun F) the world; all countries. 
akwar (noun F) sexual intercourse in animals; mating; copulation. cp. adur
akwara (plural akwaras) (noun F) a 7-foot spear with a narrow blade; a lance; a javelin; a writing pen. ebiti: small spear; edomo, edobo: spear with a hook for spearing hippo. ituria: a small spear for boys. akwara nak’igirigiret: a pen-nib. ipejel: a spear like arrow. cp. aliru
akware (plural akwaresa) (noun F) night. akware na: tonight. kiding kuare: midnight. 
akwasia ko-a (transitive verb) to follow up (a person or animal into a secret spot in order to kill). 
akwat (plural akwas) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a forefoot (of an animal); a foreleg or front limb. cp. akewat
akwatam ko-a (intransitive verb) to have eczema; to be dirty, rough, soiled. akwatam alosit: to go about with a dirty, soiled, rough body. 
akwatamaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go away unclean, unwashed. sirikikwatamaar osomero: don’t go to school unwashed and unkempt. 
akwatamikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to start off, go off with a dirty, unwashed body. 
akwatat1 (plural akwat) (noun F) a hundred. akwatat kere: all; a hundred per cent. ikar akwatat: a century. akwat akwat: hundreds and hundreds.
akwatat2 (plural akwat) (noun F) a string of beads worn by women round their waists. cp. asid. 
akwe (plural akuwei) (noun F) a corruption of akuwe: enlarged testicle (of men only). 
akweetet ko-a (intransitive verb) to have swollen testicles; (of ground) to be very dry. 
akweikin ko-a (transitive verb) to roast fat for somebody. abu papa kokweik okokuke asyepai: the father roasted the fatty meat for his son. 
akweikwe ko-a (intransitive verb) to be white; to effloresce; to be fat (only of meat, not of living animals). ekweikwei epaaba lo: this cotton is quite white. ekweikwei akiring na: this meat is nice and fat. 
akweleu1 (singular noun F) paleness; anaemia. 
akweleu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be pale; to be anaemic. 
akwelianar ko-o (reflexive verb) to writhe (with pain); to twist the body about; to flounder. ikwelianar ngesi kanuka arieboke: she/he writhes (twists about) with pain. cp. aikilanar. 
akwena ko-a (intransitive verb) to laugh. sirikwena: do not laugh. aitekwena etau: (to cause the heart to laugh) to console.
akwenar ko-a (transitive verb) to laugh at; to ridicule, make fun of, deride, mock. mam akoto ijo akwenar eong: I do not want you to ridicule me. 
akwenikin ko-a (transitive verb) to laugh for. 
akweny (plural noun F) birds. 
akwenyar ko-a (intransitive verb) to look away (in the distance); to turn eyes away. 
akwenyikin ko-a (transitive verb) to look out for; to be watching; to be awake for. akwenyikit eong akoniswam: I have been looking at (observing) your work. 
akwenyun ko-a (intransitive verb) to wake up; to get up. etyono akwenyun elilim akwap: it is difficult to get up on a cold morning. 
akwerakin ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch in a certain place or for. 
akwerar ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch away. 
akweret (plural akwereta) (noun F) a rake. 
akweretaar ko-a (transitive verb) to scrape (meat and fat off a skin). akweretaar emukule: to scrape a skin, scrape off anything; to clean, take away all. kokwereta agar: scrape scales from the tilapia fish. cp. apoiar, aipediar, acilar. 
akwerun ko-a (transitive verb) to scratch this way.
akwes (plural of akou) (noun F) heads; corn ears. aibil akwes: to count (heads of) people. 
akwesi ko-a (transitive verb) to spread (as of potatoes, millet, etc); (of cloth) to dry. ekwesiete kesi inyamat: they spread foodstuff to dry. 
akwesikin ko-a (transitive verb) to spread out for or somewhere. kokwesik igoen atiida: spread these clothes on the rock (to dry). 
akwetakin ko-a (transitive verb) to call or beckon for somebody or to somewhere. abu papa kon kokwetak ijo epejonon: your father beckoned you to come to a visitor. 
akwetar1 ko-a (transitive verb) to tick away; to mark as correct. 
akwetar2 ko-a (transitive verb) to beckon away; to take away; to beckon to go. 
akwetar3 ko-a (transitive verb) to pain; to hurt; to smart. kakweta eong akoik: my stomach hurts me. akweta naka akoik (noun F): stomach-ache. 
akweterer ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very skinny and short, or walk like a very skinny short person. ekweterete adekis: the skinny short people are going to the hospital. 
akweterikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to go or walk like a dwarf or a skinny person. 
akwetun ko-a (transitive verb) to beckon to come, give one a dig. 
akweyiar ko-a (transitive verb) to roast the fat meat, extract fat; to melt fat (intransitive verb) to flare up, to become suddenly angry, etc (reflexive verb) to melt (as of butter in the heat). cp. atarionor.
akwi (plural of akiyot) (noun F) leaves. 
akwicakin ko-a (transitive verb) to hang, suspend on, for or at (a place). ikwicanakinio itunga lueroko ojeera Luzira: bad people are hung in Luzira prison. (reflexive verb) to hang, suspend oneself on (a tree). kanukinyo akwicakinor ngesi?: why did he hang himself? 
akwicar ko-a (transitive verb) to hang one in a place away from speaker. elosi ngesi akwicario Kampala: she/he is going to be hung at Kampala. 
akwidi ko-a (intransitive verb) to laugh slightly; to grin; to laugh forcibly. cp. akudi
akwidiar ko-a (intransitive verb) to shriek with laughter or coughing, cachinnation. akwidiaros idwe kanuka alakar: the children shrieked with laughter. cp. akudiar, akikiar.
akwidiikin ko-a (transitive verb) to laugh much at something; to cough excessively. cp. akidiikin, akudiikin. 
akwongolol ko-o (intransitive verb) to waste away; to be thin, tall, emaciated, wasted (as of sick person or animal). ikwongolol akiteng ngin: that cow is emaciated. cp. akangarar, akongoror.
akyenanut1 (singular noun F) inclination to laugh. 
akyenanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to laugh. 
akyenar ko-a (intransitive verb) to laugh at; to make fun of; to mock or to ridicule. cp. akwenar
Akyenyunet (noun F) (in the Teso week) Sunday. cp. Esabiiti
alaanakin ko-o (reflexive verb) (of things) to space; to put or place wide apart. alaanakin aur: child spacing.
alaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to be spread out; to be wide spaced. alaaros amugog: the banana plantains have spread out. 
alabajang (plural alabajanga) (noun F) an edible grasshopper (long and green body); a cricket bat (in the game of einyure, made from eikiiki tree). cp. akokole, esenene. 
alabira (plural alabirai) (noun F) a mirror; a looking glass. cp. aroet; aanyet
alaboro (plural alaboron) (noun F) a plantain snake; a banana plant. cp. oliborit, acak. 
alaborot (plural alaboron) (noun F) a banana leaf. cp. aliborit. 
alacakin ko-a (transitive verb) to set free from; to release from; to divorce from; to loosen from; to unfasten from; to untie from. alacakin angajep: to talk freely (literally, to release or loosen the tongue). cp. aiwen ekingok: to be careful of what one says and to whom it is said (literally, to tie the dog). alacakin akeju: let oneself go; to add on speed; to hurry (literally, to release or loosen the legs). alacakin amotoka: to add speed (literally, to release or unfasten the car). (reflexive verb) to loosen itself; to come loose, etc; to come free; to escape; to break loose. 
alacakinio (singular noun F) release from prison or custody; liberation; discharge; the letting go.
alacar ko-a (transitive verb) to loosen (screws or harness); to untie; to end (captivity or imprisonment); to stop (as of quarantine); to release (from quarantine); to open (box or bottle, door etc); to undo (as of a rope). alacar ajimi: to untie a bandage on a wound; to uncover a wound; to make a wound bigger by using wrong medicine, etc. (reflexive verb) to come loose; to be unlocked; to become bigger. 
alacet (plural alaceta) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a hair comb. cp. alaket
alacun ko-a (transitive verb) to loosen, untie; to undress. alacun egoe: to undress. alacun amuk: to loosen or remove shoes. 
alado (plural nualado) (noun F) a wild cat-like animal. 
aladot (plural aladoi) (noun F) papyrus, Cyperus papyrus. 
alaga (plural alagai) (noun F) a roundabout way; a detour; diversion; deviation; a bypass. cp. asogol. aomare alaga (asogol): to go the long way round. 
alaikin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to give a slap on the ear hard. ailaikin akit: to give a slap on the ear; to strike somebody’s ear.
alaikin2 ko-o (reflexive verb) (of things) to be spaced; to be wide apart; (of people) to be at loggerheads; to dislike each other; to hate one another. alaikinos itunga lu: these people are now enemies. 
alaire (noun F) a vegetable resembling simsim plant, Sesamum; a mixture of groundnut sauce and leaves of the alilot plant. cp. alele. 
alait1 (plural alain) (noun F) the fibre of a papyrus plant. 
alait2 ko-a (transitive verb) to hate; to avoid; to have a grudge against somebody. 
alaita (plural alaitan) (noun F) a ferry (water vehicle). cp. apotipot
alakakin ko-a (transitive verb) to set free; to acquit (of prisoner); (of rope) to disentangle; to let go or speed up (as of motorcar, giving gas); to divorce or to separate. 
alakar1 ko-a (transitive verb) to spread out; to unroll (of cloth or skin); to loosen, disentangle. alakar etunganan: to set a man free; to redeem a debt to ransom. 
alakar2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to loosen itself; to free itself; to become loose or free (of things); (of man) to free oneself; to rejoice; to be glad, be cheerful, be jocund, convivial. kalakaros: let us be merry (happy, glad, cheerful). 
alakara (singular noun F) happiness; joy; gladness; beatitude; bonhomie. 
alakas (plural alakasia) (noun F) a bundle of dry grass used for catching flying ants and as a torch 
alaket (plural alaketa) (noun F) (Usuk) a hair comb. cp. alacet
alakun ko-a (transitive verb) to save life or soul, etc; to unfold, deliver, redeem; to slacken (rope or a belt), unroll. kolaku emukeeka, akoto aiboi: unroll the mat, I want to sit down. 
alakunet (plural alakuneta) (noun F) a deliverance; salvation; redemption. cp. alakunio
alakunio (singular noun F) deliverance; salvation; redemption. 
alalaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to be or become wide, spacious, broad. alalaar etogo ngol: that house is becoming spacious, i.e. the number of people or things in it is reducing. 
alalau1 (singular noun F) width; breadth. 
alalau2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become broad; to become wide; to become spacious. aitalal: to make wide or widen; broaden, make spacious. elal erot: the road is wide (plural elalak irotin).
alamai (plural alama) (noun F) a branch of elamai tree. 
alamaru (plural alamarun) (noun F) a reed or sorghum-stem flute with four or six stops blown as a solo instrument by herdsmen or as accompaniment to akoogo dance; a fife; a clarinet; a recorder. 
alamat (plural alama) (noun F) edible fruit of elamai tree; a ripe fruit, especially of a mango. 
alamulamu (plural alamulamun) (noun F) a mirror; ray bans or shades. cp. alabira, aanyet, aroet
alangirikin ko-o (transitive verb) to encumber; to overburden; to weigh down; to weigh heavily on. kalangirikinit eong aswam na: this work weighs me down. kalangirikinit eong anyoun kane: it is hard for me to leave this place. kalangirikinit eong ekatau: I feel very sad, depressed, burdened. 
alangirior ko-o (reflexive verb) to become heavy; to become weighty; to become important. alangirior aswamuke: her/his work has become heavy, more important. 
alangiron (plural alangirok) (noun F) a pregnant woman or animal; (anything) the heavy one. amoru alangiron: a heavy stone. 
alangiru1 (singular noun F) heaviness; weight; difficulty; gravity. 
alangiru2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to become heavy, difficult, weighty; to become pregnant (of woman or animal). alangiru kon etia ai?: how heavy are you? alangirioros (alangirioto) iboro lu: these things have become heavy. aberu ngin elangir akuwan: that woman is pregnant. 
alango (plural alangoi) (noun F) a species of antelope. cp. abebe. 
Alangot (plural Alangoi) (noun F) a word in the Langi language; a Langi woman or thing. Alangoi: the Langi women; the Langi language. cp. Anyakoit: a northern woman.
alapak ko-a (intransitive verb) (of men only) to go or walk naked (literally, to dangle about). kolo sek alapakete Iteso: long ago the Iteso men walked naked. 
alapakaar ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a man) to go away naked; to become long. alapakaar auno: the rope has become long enough. 
alapakikin ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a man) to go about naked; to go naked, start off naked. ingai elapaki kangina?: who goes there naked? 
alapataar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become bare (as of place with no trees, as of table or house with nothing on or in); to become clear (as of compound). alapataar akalaro: my compound is clear, clean. 
alapatanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to be clean (of road, compound, of shaven head).
alapatikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be open; to be clear; to be bare of grass, of a table with nothing on, of hands with nothing in them. 
alapatu1 (singular noun F) emptiness, vacancy; open ground; an open plain; a compound; a firmament. 
alapatu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bare; to be empty, vacant, destitute. elapat asaduku: the box is empty. abunit eong elapat akan: I have come empty-handed. 
alapodo (plural alapodon) (noun F) a species of wide-mouthed fish (tilapia). cp. elopodo
alapuru (plural alapurun) (noun F) a frying pan. cp. aiwowaet. 
alari (plural alarieik) (noun F) a nape; the back of neck; the scruff of the neck. 
alarilar ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bare, clear; to be wide and open (like a sea or a plain or sky) , elarilari akwap, mam lolo edou etepi: it is all clear, it won’t rain today (there is no cloud).
alaro (plural alaroik) (noun F) a courtyard; a park; a compound. alaro nak’etogo: the floor of a house. alaro naka edege: an airfield or airport. alaro naka ere: a front-yard of a home.
alarong ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a bald head. elarongi ngesi: she/he walks about with a bald head. alarongun: to come with a bald head. alarongokin: to go about bald-headed.
alasiisi (plural alasiisin) (noun F) a license; a permit; letter of authorisation; letter of accreditation. 
alasilas (intransitive verb) to be nice or tasty; to be nice looking (of food or person or animal). elasilasi etelepat ngol: he is a nice, smartly dressed boy.
alasit (plural alasia) (noun F) a little black tilapia fish. 
alatakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall; to apologize for. alatakin ngesi kwap: she/he has fallen down; she/he apologized for. cp. aibirokin. 
alatar1 ko-a (transitive verb) to throw down. (reflexive verb) to fall down; to apologize. ibusakinit ijo alatar neejai ngesi: it is imperative that you go and apologize to her/him. cp. anear.
alatar2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to flop down, collapse, fall down, cave in, give way, crumble, disintegrate. 
Alatin (singular noun F) the Latin language.
alatun ko-o (reflexive verb) to drop; to come and apologize. (transitive verb) to let fall. alatun etau: to accept an apology. 
alaun1 ko-a (transitive verb) to disregard, not to heed; to disobey; to pay no attention to. sirikilau akakiro: do not disobey my instructions. (reflexive verb) to come away from. alaun emir awai epatana do aiyar: the rat has come out from its hiding place, it is now easy to kill it. alaun awai: to come away. 
alaun2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to become hateful; to avoid; to divorce or separate from. 
alaun3 ko-o (reflexive verb) to become clean, holy. alautu igoen: the clothes are clean. 
alaunanut1 (singular noun F) obstinacy; disobedience. elaunana etelepat lo: this boy is disobedient. 
alaunanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be obstinate. 
alaunitor ko-a (prepositional verb) to disregard, pay no heed to. iswamai ijo ngun kanuka alaunitor akakiro: you do that in disregard of what I say. 
alean ko-a (intransitive verb) to be aflame; to be burning. eleani ekonitogo: your house is aflame. 
aleat (plural alean) (noun F) a strip of meat of fish; a fish fillet. aleat naka akiring: a fillet. 
alecokin ko-o (transitive verb) to punish for or somewhere. abu etengei kalecok eong Soroti: I was very hungry in Soroti (literally, hunger punished me in Soroti).
alecor ko-o (transitive verb) to trick; to con by being cunning to; to isolate and punish; to pain solely; to subdue; to infatuate. kaleco lolo eong etengei: I am very hungry today (literally, hunger is paining me today). cp. abwalar.
alede (plural aledei) (noun F) (Usuk) a small striped brown garden lizard. cp. aledi. 
aleega (plural aleegai) (noun F) a brassier; a bra. cp. oidoolei: knickers.
