alegetet ko-a (intransitive verb) to be clean, spotless, chaste, pure, beautiful, immaculate. ilegetet ngesi: ilegetetas kesi: she/he (they are) spotlessly clean. 
alegetu1 (singular noun F) cleanliness; chastity; beauty; justice. 
alegetu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be clean, chaste, beautiful, just. eleget nges ikeponesio: her/his manners are good; she/he is a clean living person. erai ngesi etelepat loleget: he is a clean boy 
aleikin ko-a (transitive verb) to beat for somebody or somewhere. 
alejat1 (plural alejai) (noun F) an iron ring formerly worn in the lower lip. 
alejat2 (plural alejai) (noun F) the hammer or the tongue of a bell. 
alejekaar ki-a (intransitive verb) to become soft, weak. 
alejekek ko-a (intransitive verb) to be weak, puny, pathetic, fragile, scrawny, soft. 
alejeku1 (noun F) weakness; softness; suppleness; pliability. 
alejeku2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become weak, feeble, frail. cp. anonokiar. 
alekakin ki-a (transitive verb) to vomit on or to vomit in or at. kinyek alekakin togoka, kolot alekakin kinga: do not vomit in my house (room), go and vomit outside. 
alekan (plural noun F) the vomit (of a person or an animal); puke. 
alekar ko-a (transitive verb) to vomit away; to bring forth. kolot alekar ngina: go and vomit over there. alot aberu alekar adekis: the woman has gone to deliver in the hospital. 
alekun ko-a (transitive verb) to vomit (this way); to say all one knows; to give birth or deliver (reflexive verb) to come out by itself (of food from stomach); to feel like vomiting. inyamat kere ekotos alekun: all the food wants to come out (from my stomach). alekun akiro: to say all one knows. alekun icel: to tell secrets; to speak insulting language. kinyek ber kalek eong ikacel: let me first reveal my secret things. 
alelakin ko-a (transitive verb) to welcome; to appreciate; to enjoy. ejok alelakin epejonon: it is good to welcome a visitor. 
alelakinet (plural alelakineta) (noun F) appreciation; approval; admiration; positive reception; thanks; gratitude. 
alelasit (plural alelasia) (noun F) pleasure; joy; happiness. 
alele1 (noun F) a vegetable shrub, Oldenlandia. cp. alelot. 
alele2 (singular noun F) effluent; waste matter; sewage; bilge water; overflow.
alele3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to flow; to freewheel. eleleete akipi kosamai: the water flows in the swamp. aitelel: to make the water flow; to irrigate; to drain water. elelei ekume: the nose is (flowing) running. elelei ajimi: the sore is running. eleleete aimul: the saliva is flowing from the mouth. 
alelear ko-a (intransitive verb) to flow away; to float away. 
alelebo (plural alelebon) (noun F) the merry-go-round; a seesaw. 
aleleikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to flow into. aleleikis akipi kai: the water has flowed into the house. aleleikis akipi togo: the water has flowed into the house. 
alelema (plural alelemai) (noun F) a noisy, quarrelsome woman. 
aleleng1 (plural noun F) hard stool or droppings of animals such as goats; goat dung. 
Aleleng2 (singular noun F) (the Jewish or Christian feast of) the Passover. 
aleleng3 ko-o (transitive verb) to leave out; to leave untouched (as in weeding, not touching the main plant); to pass over or to omit. kalelengitoi eong kane bon: I was left out here alone (from the invitation). cp. ainyekin.
alelengikin ko-o (transitive verb) to leave out; to pass by (a person when selecting); to ignore. kocap eduan bon kolelengik akimai: take out the weeds only, leave the millet (untouched). inyo bo kilelengitere ijo?: why are you ignored? 
alelengoor ko-o (transitive verb) to leave out; to choose and take away. kolelengoo kwi, kolelengu nuwok bonik: leave out those, take ours only. 
alelengun ko-o (transitive verb) to choose for oneself, select for oneself. kojep ikito lueroko, kolelengu luejokak: cut the bad trees and leave the good ones for us. 
aleles (plural alelesia) (noun F) a ditch; a stream; a river; flowing water; a gutter; a current; an empty drain; a dry water course. 
aleleuro (plural aleleuron) (noun F) a mountain pigeon. cp. alolouro. 
Aleli (noun F) a pet name for a cow with brown and black stripes. 
aleliar ko-o (transitive verb) to erode; to wear away; (of wealth or riches) to get wasted. 
alelio (plural noun F) a fruit of ekalelyoi tree, Carissa edulis. cp. akalyo, akalelyoi
alelioit (plural alelio) (noun F) the fruit of a hooked-thorn tree, Carissa edulis. cp. ekalyoi, ekalelio. 
alelot (plural alelota) (noun F) a vegetable used to give eboo vegetables the slimy feel. cp. atigo, alilot
alem1 (plural alemwo) (noun F) a headdress used in dancing (by men or women); a cow, goat, etc without horns.
alem2 (plural alemwo) (noun F) a plant, Leonotis nepetaefolia. cp. acugia.
alemar1 (preposition) excepting; with the exception of; apart from.
alemar2 ko-a (transitive verb) to take away, or to abrogate; to subtract; to make free; to except; to take off. alemar na: besides. koge ber alemar lukon iboro: first take away your things. (reflexive verb) to be taken away; to be finished; to die out, abate. 
alemelem1 akeje (transitive verb) to bewitch. kelemelem ecudan adaeka: the witch has bewitched my foot prints (i.e. she/he took the dust of my foot prints home and mixed the dust with medicine, cursed me who stepped on the above dust – causing pain on my legs). 
alemelem2 ko-a (transitive verb) to steal; to pilfer; to bewitch. alemelemetoi iboro: to pilfer; to steal small things often (noun F) pilferage.
alemikin ko-a (transitive verb) to pick for somebody (something); to pay for somebody (taxes, dowry, etc); to take up for somebody; to choose for somebody. alemikin akerit (reflexive verb) to get up and run away (off); to rush away; to vanish. alemikinos ikokolak akerit: the thieves ran off, vanished. 
alemilem ko-a (intransitive verb) to enchant, put a magic charm on; to bewitch. 
alemokin ko-o (transitive verb) to pour out, into, too much (of any liquid). mam akoto ijo alemokin akile toma ocaai: do not pour too much milk into the tea. 
alemun ko-a (transitive verb) to choose; to select; to pay (fine); to subtract. akoto alemun ber luka: I want to take out or choose my things; to pick up, abstract. alemun etau: to agree entirely. alemar etau: to cease to love or like, be indifferent. adau eong alemar etau kane ejai ngesi: I do not like her/him anymore. alemun eluk: to pay for adultery. (reflexive verb) to be chosen; to be paid, etc; to be picked; to come off. alemum epaaba kere: all the cotton has been picked. alemun apeesa: the button has come off (my shirt). 
alemunyang (plural alemunyanga) (noun F) a donkey; zebra. cp. asigiria. 
alemura (plural alemurai) (noun F) the only child (female) born to a woman. cp. anume. 
alemwoit (plural alemwo) (noun F) a desert-rose bush, Adenium globosum. 
alenger ko-a (intransitive verb) (to walk or go) to be circumcised. 
alengerikin ko-a (transitive verb) (of a circumcised person) to run off.
alepon (noun F) semen. cp. adua, adwa. 
alepor1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to pour out; to have diarrhoea. alepor eporododo: to suffer from very noisy diarrhoea. alepor esiric: to have uncontrollable diarrhoea. alepor aokot: to suffer from blood diarrhoea; to have dysentery. ekia loka alepor: medicine for dysentery. 
alepor2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to start and rush off. alepor je akurianaar ejie: the other guy has run off fearing a fight.
alepun ko-o (reflexive verb) to jump out; to rise; to come up suddenly; to come to the surface; to spout out. alepun emir kotogoke: a rat jumped out of its hole. alepunos akipi kotoma atan: the water spouted up from a well. 
alero (plural aleroi) (noun F) a blue gem worn on ears. 
aleru (plural alerun) (noun F) a large spear; a plant, Cucumis. 
alesi ko-a (transitive verb) to stretch out (of mats, etc) (only used with noun object in plural: elesie ngesi imukuleneke: she/he is busy stretching her/his hides to dry). 
alesiar ki-o (reflexive verb) to lie down; to stretch oneself out (dead tired). cp. arior: to loll. kapas eong, akoto alesiar: I am tired, I want to stretch myself out. 
alet (plural aletio) (noun F) a small silver fish, Engraulicyprus argenteus. 
aletenyeny ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a vessel) to be shallow; to be flat (of buttocks). iletenyeny atiida mam ibwauni akipi: the hole in the rock is shallow, it does not hold much water. 
aletenyikin ko-a (transitive verb) to make shallow (as of a pot). iletenyikina amoti ngun: those pots are shallow (flattish), not deep. 
aleun ko-a (transitive verb) to tire out; to get by force of beating; to overcome. cp. aile. kaleu eong aswam na: this work has tired me out. (reflexive verb) to be very tired. cp. aiteg, aipas. 
Aleya1 (plural Aleyan) (noun F) (in the Teso week) Tuesday. cp. Naiyareit
aleya2 (plural aleyan) (noun F) a turn; a rota; a roll. erai kwana aleyakon: it is now your turn. 
ali? (interrogation, M) which? who? ali bo?: where is he? which one? ali bo ngesi?: where is he? cp. alu?: which ones? where are they? ali? (interrogative pronoun masculine singular): where is he? which one? (plural alu?: where are they? which ones?) 
aliabong (plural aliabonga) (noun F) a white egret (shines white in the evening); a snow-bird. 
aliagam ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a tall person or animal, bird) to move or walk. iliagami ijo alosit: you are very tall (you go, walk like a very tall man). 
aliagamikin ko-a (transitive verb) (of a tall person or tree) to fall down. 
alian ko-a (intransitive verb) (of fire) to flame up; to be on fire; ablaze; to be burning. alian akim kokekwa kaje: there is a fire over that hill. alianata itogoi: the houses are on fire. 
alianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pour from for, somewhere; to pour little by little. (reflexive verb) to flow from. 
alianikin ko-a (transitive verb) to kindle the fire (by blowing); to set ablaze; to stir the fire into a flame. (reflexive verb) to be on fire, aflame. alianiki ekatogo: my house is on fire. 
alianis ko-a (intransitive verb) to smell as of fresh milk, meat, fish, newly born baby; to be smelling like fresh milk, meat, fish, or a dog which has been in the rain. 
alianus ko-a (intransitive verb) to smell as of fresh milk, meat, fish, newly born baby; to be smelling like fresh milk, meat, fish, or a dog which has been in the rain. cp. alianis.
aliar1 ko-a (transitive verb) to creep or crawl away (of a snake, an insect, etc). 
aliar2 ko-a (transitive verb) to pour away (water, etc). koliaa ajon ngun nueroko: pour that bad beer away (reflexive verb) to be poured away (as of dirty water, etc); to be soft; to dissolve (like sugar or salt in water); to be watery. aliaros ajon: the beer was poured out, away (as useless). 
aliasit (plural alias) (noun F) root (of a plant); the cause or origin of. aliasit naka emusaago: the cause of accusation. 
aliat ko-a (intransitive verb) to creep, or to crawl (of a snake, etc). eliat emun: the snake is crawling. 
aliatok (plural of aliaton) (noun F) flowing water; any creeping creatures. akoto aliatok: I want water. cp. akipi. 
aliaton (plural aliatok) (noun F) any creeping creature. erai emun aliaton: a snake is a creeping creature. 
aliaun ko-a (transitive verb) to creep or crawl this way or towards the speaker (of a snake, an insect, etc) 
alibaanut1 (noun F) greenness; verdure. 
alibaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be green, emerald, lime, jade, olive. elibaana ekitoi ngol: that tree is green. 
alibakin ko-a (transitive verb) to feel or make cold, chilly. kalibakit eong aterot: I feel chilly, cold (literally, the wind makes me feel cold). 
alibat (plural alibai) (noun F) a bird - golden oriole. 
alibet (plural alibeta) (noun F) a shoot (of a plant or a tree); bud. 
alibilib ko-a (intransitive verb) to grow or be very green, blue. elibilibete inya: the grass is verdant and lush. iporo ngesi elibilibiata inya: it is during the rainy season that the grass becomes emerald green. 
alibit (plural alibin) (noun F) a diving wild duck; a darter. 
aliborit (plural aliborin) (noun F) a banana plantain or leaf, Musa paradisiaca. Its leaves and stems are used as fodder, thatch, fibre, and food wrapping, while the fruit is made into beer, banana juice and food. cp. amugogot. 
aliboro (plural aliboron) (noun F) a species of bird - a redwing shrike. 
alibosit (plural alibos) (noun F) a shoot of potatoes that sprouts from the tuber itself. cp. alibet. 
alibulibun ko-o (intransitive verb) to sprout; to become green. 
alibun ko-a (intransitive verb) to bud; to sprout; to shoot out; to become green; to develop; to revive (after dry season). alibutu inya bobo: the grass has sprouted out again. 
alibunet (plural alibuneta) (noun F) a shoot (of a plant or tree); a source (of river); a cause; a beginning; an origin (of a dispute). alibunet naka ekek: the beginning or origin of a clan. alibunet naka iboro: an element; a fundament; the origin of things. 
alicait (plural alica) (noun F) white gravel; marble; flint-stone; mica; crystal. 
alidakin ko-a (transitive verb) to fasten round for; to tighten (reflexive verb) to be too tight. alidakin akarokoba: my belt is too tight. 
alidar ko-a (transitive verb) to take away, fastening tight; to catch hold of.
alidioar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become unripe, undeveloped. alidioar emaido: the groundnuts are not seeded. alidioar ikoku: the child is premature. 
alidiou1 (noun F) prematurity; rawness; freshness.
alidiou2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be unripe; to be premature; to be very young, fresh, raw. alidiou: premature; rawness; freshness.
alidok ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a man or boy) to be naked or nude; to be in Adam’s suit; to have one’s penis dangling about. cp. animok
alidongong ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a thin body and thin waist; to be slim; to be thin. 
alidun ko-a (transitive verb) to get hold of; to catch hold of. alidun akiro: to pay attention; to listen attentively; to mind what is being said. alidun iponesio: to take over habits; to catch, acquire habits. 
alies1 (noun F) softness; liquidness; wateriness (of food). eli ekatau: I am upset. 
alies2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be too soft, too watery, too wet. eli atap na: this millet bread is too soft. eliak acok ngun: those potatoes are too watery and soft. 
aliet (plural alieta) (noun F) a spout, etc for pouring out; a funnel. 
aligim ko-a (intransitive verb) to have or move about with a distended belly. 
aligimikin ko-a (transitive verb) to poison the stomach so that it distends; to impregnate. 
aligimim ko-a (transitive verb) (of stomach) to be distended; (of a woman) to be pregnant. 
aligirikin ki-a (transitive verb) to distend; to impregnate. 
aligot (plural aligo) (noun F) a young pea (still in a pod); a young bean pod. 
aliik ko-a (intransitive verb) to have or to go with a large head. 
aliikik ko-a (intransitive verb) to be large-headed; to be fat-headed. 
aliikin ko-a (transitive verb) to pour out; to instil; to pour into; to pour out for. koliikinai ajon keriik: pour out some beer for me to gulp. koyau eikopo kaliikinia ecaai: bring a cup I pour out some tea for you. 
aliit (plural aliin) (noun F) a plant used for rafter; a long straight pole. cp. asiinit. 
alili1 (singular noun F) jealousy; envy; covetousness. 
alili2 ko-a (transitive verb) to pine for; to desire; to go on a journey; to be jealous of. elilito kesi ekagaali: they are jealous of my bicycle. 
aliliikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be jealous or to be envious; to envy. aliliikit eong akoniswam: I envy your work. 
alilikin ko-a (transitive verb) to do in excess; to overdo; to do too much. alilikin aimat ajon: to drink too much beer; to debauch; to indulge in. sirikililik aswam: do not work too hard. alilikin ainyam: to eat too much. 
alilimior ko-o (reflexive verb) to cool; to become cold; to become cool; to grow cold, cool. alilimioros akipi: the water has become cold. 
aliling ko-a (transitive verb) to paint in different colours. 
alilio (singular noun F) jealousy; envy. 
alilit ko-o (transitive verb) to desire (intransitive verb) to be envious of; to be jealous of. alilit eong akoniswam: I envy your work. cp. alilio.
alilot (plural alilota) (noun F) a plant used for making eboo vegetable sauce slimy; the slimy sauce made with alilot plant, Corchorus trilocularis. cp. alaire, atigo. 
aliluar ko-a (intransitive verb) to emigrate; to go far away; to go and settle down far away; to go on a journey and stay for a long time. akoto aliluar Bulaya: I am going to Europe. 
alim (noun F) iron sheet; corrugated iron sheet. asaduku alim: a metallic box. ibore yenilim: an iron thing. iboro lulim: iron things. 
alimokin ko-a (transitive verb) to tell; to inform; to say to; to confess to; to announce; to report; to invite, mention, admonish, apprise. kolimokinai nuijeni: tell me what you know. 
alimokinet (plural alimokineta) (noun F) an order; a command, precept, advice, counsel. 
alimonokin ko-a (transitive verb) to preach; to admonish; to keep telling, or saying to; to advice (reflexive verb) to meditate; to ponder over. 
alimonokinet (plural alimonokineta) (noun F) an order, command, precept or teaching, advice, counsel. 
alimor ko-o (transitive verb) to speak out; to report about; to confess; to betray another; to say, utter; to declaim, declare, aver; to prosecute. kolimo nuejaas otaukon: say what is on your mind (literally, say what is in your heart). 
alimoret (plural alimoreta) (noun F) an announcement; an advertisement; an ad. aipikakin alimoret oredio arai apapulai: to place an announcement in the radio or in the newspapers. ilimoreta ludidik: classified ads.
alimun ko-o (transitive verb) to confess; to speak out; to pronounce; to utter. alimun ekiror: to nominate somebody; to name; to say the name. Sirilim: (a pun, literally ‘Don’t say’) Slim (AIDS).
alingakin ko-a (transitive verb) to be early at; to be before time; to paint in a different colour once. akoto alingakin aswam: I want to start work early. elingakin ngesi alosit okeresia: she/he goes to the cathedral before time. 
alingar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go first; to go early. elingaros idwe ajo: the children go early to bed. 
alingiling ko-a (transitive verb) to mark often (the body or anything); to put marks on; to paint in different colours. alingiling itunganan k’ebela: to mark a person with marks of beating. 
alinyo (singular noun F) baby lotion from simsim or sheanut butter; sheanut oil made from the seeds of ekungur tree. cp. akungurit
aliogotot ko-a (intransitive verb) to be immaculate; to be very clean; to be without blemish; to be without fault. 
aliokokin akiro ko-o (transitive verb) to tell lies about somebody; to calumniate; to slander. 
aliokokinet (plural aliokokineta) (noun F) calumny; slander; denigration. iliokokinit ijo eong akiro: you calumniate me. 
aliokon (singular noun F) deceit; a lie; a fib; a hypocrisy. 
aliokonor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become a liar; to become deceitful. aliokonor etelepat ngol: that boy has become a liar. 
aliokonut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be fond of deceiving; to be deceitful. aliokono eong, iliokono ijo, kiliokoko oni, iliokoko yesi: I, you, we, you are deceitful/liars. 
aliokor ko-o (intransitive verb) to go and tell lies somewhere. kolioko ijo akonikiro nenice: go and tell your lies somewhere else. 
alior ko-a (intransitive verb) to be thin with protruding belly (to go with a thin body, etc). 
alipan (noun F) a begging; the asking. alosi alipan: I go begging. 
alipong (plural aliponga) (noun F) vagina; the external sex organs of a woman; private parts of a woman; female genitalia. ipon luka alipong: the genital labia (majora and minora). 
alir (plural aliria) (noun F) a very deaf woman; a total hearing-impaired female; a very dense or daft woman. cp. abang.
aliriangang (abstract noun F) deafness; dumbness; foolishness; daftness. cp. akiminganut, abangaanut.
aliru (plural alirweik) (noun F) a short stabbing spear with a large blade; an assegai. cp. aleru
alitar ko-o (reflexive verb) (of trees or plants) to shoot up without getting time to grow many branches or leaves. 
alitokin ko-a (transitive verb) to make too long (reflexive verb) to be too long, too far. alitokin auno: to make the rope too long. alitokin ainyam: to eat before others; to eat before time. alitokin akiro: to say more than necessary; to say too much. alitokin ingaren: to go too far ahead. 
alitor akeje ko-o (transitive verb) to make long strides (reflexive verb) to go too far ahead. kolito akeju ingaren: stretch the leg forward (making big strides). ilitor ijo ingaren, kobongu ber kau nepetai: you go too far ahead, come back a little. 
alitoro ko-o (transitive verb) to be too far ahead, advanced. 
alitun ko-a (intransitive verb) to shoot out (of the ground, as of plants). cp. alomun, alibun. 
aliyan (noun F) fire flame. 
aloanakin akolong ko-a (transitive verb) to dry things in the sun; to spread in the sun. 
aloboi (plural of alobot) (noun F) ploughed field before crops are planted. 
alobot (plural aloboi) (noun F) a furrow; a dug-up garden or ploughed field. aitwa aloboi: ailakilak aloboi: to clean the field (of grass and rubbish). cp. ailakilak, apuleje. 
aloet (plural aloeta) (noun F) place for drying in the sun; a string for drying on. 
alogec ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bandy-legged; to be bow-legged. elogeci ngesi ore: she/he goes home bow-legged. 
aloger ko-a (transitive verb) to put a spoke in the wheel; to trip a person (as in football) or an animal (by putting hand between legs when milking); to hamper. aloger akiro: to thwart a plan. aloger itunganan: to try to trip someone; to obstruct someone's progress.
alogereun ko-a (transitive verb) to trip this way. 
alogerikin ko-a (transitive verb) to trip someone; to make a person angry; to embarrass; to thwart; to hinder. karai komam ijo alogerikin eong, ti kadum ajakaanut: had you not thwarted me, I would have been appointed to leadership. 
aloikin ko-a (transitive verb) to air; to spread out to dry; to put in the sun. koloik igoen ngul: spread out those clothes to dry. 
Aloka (plural Alokai) (noun F) (in the Teso week) Friday. cp. Naikanyet
alokanakin aki ko-a (reflexive verb) to pay attention; to listen carefully; to give ear to, attend to. 
alokar ko-a (transitive verb) to trap and take away; to catch. akoto alokar akweny: I want to catch birds (with a trap and take away). 
Aloket1 (plural Aloke) (noun F) (an Ateso reference to) a Karamojong tribeswoman.
aloket2 (plural aloketa) (noun F) a trap; a snare. aloketa nuka ajokit: the devil’s tricks or temptations. 
alokikin ko-a (transitive verb) to put a trap for somebody or somewhere. kolokik eic nen: put the trap there. 
alokor ko-o (transitive verb) to knock off, away; to extract tooth; to knock off (as of a piece of a pot or anything). 
alokot (plural alokoto) (noun F) a place where teeth have been extracted or are missing. cp. agilo. 
alokun ko-a (transitive verb) to entice this way; to draw into a trap. alokun etunganan: to pay back in the same currency; to give tit for tat. (intransitive verb) to reach age of puberty (of boy). 
alokunet (singular noun F) puberty (of boys only).
alolo ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk in a crouching way (as a thief or hunter); to slouch. ekamejan eloloi keanyu etyang: a hunter crouches when she/he sees a hunted animal. 
aloloar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go down (as of sun); to creep away; to sneak away (as of a thief) ; to go on a long journey. aloloa akolong: the sun has gone down. 
alolokin ko-a (transitive verb) to creep towards. alosi eong alolokin akweny: I am going to creep towards a bird (to catch it). 
alolot ko-o (intransitive verb) to walk with a stoop; to go away secretly. elolot ekokolan: the thief walks with a stoop, secretly. 
alolotoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to keep sneaking round to do in an obscure way, sneaking way. elolotoi egole duc: the hawk flies low and shuns people. 
aloloun ko-a (intransitive verb) to creep this way; to slouch this way. 
alolouro (plural alolouron) (noun F) a big pigeon; a mountain dove. 
alomakin ko-a (transitive verb) to go into; to attack; to enter into; to start (work or anything); to invade. alosi alomakin akirokus: I am going into your case. kolomakisi aswam: start your work. (reflexive verb) to be started; to attack each other. 
alomar ko-a (intransitive verb) to enter a place or to go out (away from speaker); (of something sharp or pointed) to penetrate; (of sun) to go down, to set. alomar ataker: to embark, go in a boat; to go on board a boat. alomar akiro: to go into a case, examine a case, interfere, meddle. sirikiloma: no admittance. esineema ngol elomario aite atitai: that film is for free entry. 
alomarit ko-a (transitive verb) to be connected with; to terminate in. erot lo elomarit orot loko Soroti: this road is connected with (terminates in) the Soroti road. 
alomun1 (adverb) by chance. 
alomun2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to come outside; to come inside; to enter; to come towards; to appear above ground. ekoto epaaba alomun: the cotton is about to germinate (above the ground). alomutu aokot: the blood is oozing out. aitolomun akoik: to procure abortion. alomun akoik (intransitive verb) to have abortion.
along (adverb) (to do) simply; for nothing; just. acupa along: just a bottle only. cp. titai. aiboi along: to be alone; by oneself; to go naked. 
alonga (plural noun F) a plant, Malvaceae. 
alongalong (adverb) (to go somewhere) in vain; for nothing. cp. atitai
alongor ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a thick deformed penis or big eyeballs. 
alongorikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to run off with a thick deformed penis or big eyeballs. 
alongoror ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a thick penis or large eyeballs. 
alongwaanar ko-a (intransitive verb) to become lazy. 
alongwaanut1 (singular noun F) idleness; lethargy; indolence. 
alongwaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very lazy, idle. alongwaana, ilongwaana (plural ilongwaaka) I am, you are, lazy. cp. akalanyanut.
alongwau (singular noun F) laziness; lethargy; indolence; awkwardness. 
alonyakin ko-a (transitive verb) to miss a mark. abu eong kalonyak etyang kosamai: I missed (hitting) the animal in the swamp. 
aloorit (plural aloorin) (noun F) a sandal made of a rubber tyre of a car. 
alopan (plural alopak) (noun F) a midwife. 
alope1 (plural akulepek F) (adverb) by herself; alone; the very one. iboyie ngesi alope bon: she lives by herself. ngesi ajakait alope: she is the boss herself (no other person). eong alope akituk: I am the owner of the cows. ijo alope: you yourself.
alope2 (plural akulepek) (noun F) the owner. alope akiro: the woman or female in question; the accuser. alope akwap: a female native or inhabitant of a region or country. ilope (neuter): the owner (general). cp. toto.
alopolop ko-a (transitive verb) to intertwine or plait (as of a mat); to strap (as of a belt, etc). alopolopit eong emukeeka: I plaited or weaved a mat. alopolop atenus: to string a drum; to plait strings on the side of a drum; to kick or punch one on his side. abu eong kalopolop emopiira kakeju: I kicked the ball. 
alos (singular noun F) threshed finger millet or sorghum grain (or flour from it) for the preparation of atap bread; millet and/or sorghum grain mixed with cassava and ground into flour for eating as atap. 
alosenen ko-o (transitive verb) to go out repeatedly; to keep going to often. 
alosikin ko-o (transitive verb) to approach; to intend; to go nearer somebody; to do intentionally; to do purposely; to go and attack. alosikinit eong ejakait ailip ibore: I approached the chief to beg. alosikinit eong ajon: I am on a drinking spree. 
alosikinet (plural alosikineta) (noun F) an intention; an objective, a goal; mission (the purpose for which one feels one was born). 
alosikinit ko-o (transitive verb) to make up one’s mind; to intend; to do intentionally; to do purposely; to go and attack. alosikinit eong ejakait aibunga: my husband has intended to attack me (even when I have done no wrong). 
alosior ko-o (intransitive verb) to go towards. alosio ngesi okekwa je: she/he has gone to the other side (of the swamp). 
alosit1 (plural alosito) (noun F) a trip; itinerary. abu eong kalot alosito aare: I made two trips. 
alosit2 (singular noun F) journey; transport; travelling. aroniar alosit na: this journey is getting hazardous or fraught with hardship. alosi: I (shall) go/do; I am about to (go/do); I intend to; I shall soon. alosi eong ainyam: I am about to eat some food: I am going to have some food. 
alosit3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to go away; to depart, leave; to be about to do. alosit kwangin: to go naked or nude. alosi eong aswam ibore: I shall or will do something.
alot1 (singular noun F) the goings; an affair or amorous relationship. aroniar alot na: this affair is going awry or sour. 
alot2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to go (seldom used as infinitive except as noun). alosi: I go (plural elosete: they go). 
aloun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come out into the open; to appear outside. aloun ekokolan kinga: the thief has come out from her/his hiding place. cp. abwalun.
aloyianar ko-o (reflexive verb) to sprawl; to loll about. 
aloyiar1 ko-a (transitive verb) to take away; to spread out in the sun. 
aloyiar2 ko-o (reflexive verb) (of people, animals, birds) to be scattered; to spread out; to be dispersed. aloiaros angor komana ecapete: the women are scattered over the field weeding. aloiaros Iteso akwapin: the Iteso have spread over various countries. 
aloyio ko-a (passive verb) to be spread in the sun. ekaaso lo ekot aloyio: this cassock needs to be spread in the sun to dry. 
Aluga (plural Alugai) (noun F) an Indian woman, or a word in any Indian languages (Hindi, Sinhales, Tamil, etc).
alugum ko-a (transitive verb) to round; to blow out (as of stomach); to make corpulent. 
alugumum ko-a (transitive verb) to be round (as of a pot, stomach, etc); to be corpulent. 
alugura ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bent like a bow; to stoop; to crouch down. alosi alugura otida: I am going to bend down beating the etida drum. 
alugurikin ko-a (transitive verb) to bend (something like a bow) (reflexive verb) to be bent; to stoop itself. 
alugurur1 (singular noun F) curvature; twisting. 
alugurur2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bent. ilugurur ekaraman k’atenus: the drummer bends when beating the drum. 
Alugwaarat (plural Alugwaaran) (noun F) a Lugbara woman; a woman native to Arua district; a word in Lugbara. Alugwaaran: the Lugbara women; the Lugbara language.
aluikin ko-o (transitive verb) to turn into an enemy. iluikit ijo opaperokon: you have become an enemy to your friend: you have turned your friend into an enemy. 
alujukuk ko-o (intransitive verb) to be weak, bendable, flexible, soft, limber, supple. alujukuk bala emun: lithe as a snake. lujuluj bala emun: lithe as a snake. 
alukakin ko-a (transitive verb) to enclose; to go round something; to surround; to make round. kalukakisi ityang kiding: let us surround the animals (i.e. let us put the animals in the middle). 
alukar einer ko-a (transitive verb) (of many people) to talk about a person present. inyo bo kilukariata yesi eong einer?: why have you besieged me with your gossip? (note: talking about absent person is aisiom). cp. aigalun.
alukuj ki-a (transitive verb) to go round something; to go round bends in road. ilukujai ngesi alosit mam itenarit erot: she/he goes round about, she/he does not keep to the road. 
alukujuj ko-o (intransitive verb) to be round. ilukujujos ikekitinyo: her/his cheeks are round. 
alukuluk ki-a (transitive verb) to peck here and there (as of a bird). ilukuluki akokor alos: the hen pecks millet here and there. 
alukumet (plural alukumen) (noun F) a circle. kiswama alukumet: make a circle. alukumet naka etogo: the circle of a house. 
alukun1 einer ko-a (transitive verb) (of many people) to talk about a person present. inyo bo kilukuniata yesi eong einer?: what are you saying about me? (note: talking about an absent person is aisiom) cp. einer, aigalun einer.
alukun2 ko-a (transitive verb) to surround, encompass; to encircle; to sit round (food or beer pot); to weave, centralize. kalukutu ikole: let us encircle the mudfish (to catch them by hand). kolukutu emukeeka: weave the mat (hem it). cp. aije. 
alukunet (plural alukuneta) (noun F) a circle; a loop; a ring; a circumference. 
alukuren (noun F) a grass, Chloris. 
alulu ko-a (intransitive verb) to go far away; to vanish, clear off. eluluete kesi: they vanish. 
aluluar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go on a journey; to vanish; to clear off; to go far away. alulua ngesi acekwap: she/he has gone off to another country. 
alumangang (intransitive verb) to be hornless, handle-less, or round. cp. iluumum, elumang.
alumangangat ko-a (intransitive verb) to be blunt; to be hornless; to be dull or stupid. ilumangangas itelepai lu kere: all these boys are dull. 
alumokin ko-a (transitive verb) to dive for (saving) somebody or something; to dive after; to plunge into. 
alumor ko-o (transitive verb) to dive and swim away. 
alumusus ko-a (transitive verb) to be hornless. 
alung (plural alungia) (noun F) a piece, a cutting or chunk (of meat, food or soap). alungia nuka akiring: chunks of meat.
alungakin ko-a (transitive verb) to refuse to have food with; to refuse to take back a thing (because someone spoiled it); to refuse payment, etc (when dissatisfied) (reflexive verb) to do a thing in spite of anything; to pour out suddenly and quickly. alungakin ngesi akoko: she/he steals in spite of the consequences. alungaki papa okokuke inyamat: the father has refused to eat with his son
alungar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go away angrily, shake the dust off one’s feet. alungar epejonon kane: the visitor went away in a bad mood. (transitive verb) to pour out quickly. 
alungit (singular noun F) abhorrence; loathing; revulsion; repugnance. 
alungitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to go very fast, tear along, or gravitate. 
alunguret (plural alunguren) (noun F) an ear of grain; a lump of (bread or food); a crowd of (people or anything); a mass of anything; a team (of players); a bunch of bananas. cp. apanasiat. 
alungurur ko-a (intransitive verb) to be round (as a ball, an orange or tree trunk). cp. alukumum: to be round, circular (as of a traditional hut). ilungurur: round shouldered; stooping. 
alunguur (singular noun F) roundness (adjective) round and fat (as a bull). ilunguur emong ngol: that bull is fat and round, or plump. 
aluomod ko-a (transitive verb) to eat something soft (in the form of porridge). 
aluor ko-o (reflexive verb) to change into; to discolour; to fly into a rage. aluoros ikeponesio: her/his manners have changed. aluonor: to change often. eluonor agougou: the chameleon often changes colour. 
alup (plural noun F) earth; soil; land. 
alupok (plural noun F) earth; soil; land. cp. alup:
alupot (plural alup) (noun F) mud; clay used for building houses (stamped and mixed with water). 
aluriluritoi ko-o (transitive verb) to hang one’s head; to cower. 
alurokin ko-a (intransitive verb) to keep (working, etc); to be bent (on doing). alurokin alosit: to keep on walking. alurokin aisisia: to keep on, to be bent on learning. 
aluror ko-o (intransitive verb) to bend forward; to look down, droop, or bow. elurorete kesi kanuka ileic: they look down with shame. 
aluru (plural alurweik) (noun F) a quail. 
alurugut (plural alurugui) (noun F) a species of fish, Haplochromis. 
alurukene (plural alurukenei) (noun F) a bird - a black crake. cp. aluru. 
alusumum ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a club) to be round-headed; (of a sheep, cow) to have a round head, be hornless. 
aluterer ko-a (intransitive verb) to have protruding frog-like eyes. 
alutukony (plural alutukonyo) (noun F) a stick for stirring porridge or mingling atap (bread). cp. aingol, akingol, aiguret, angoet. 
Aluurut (plural Aluurun) (noun F) an Alur tribeswoman from the district of Nebbi and speaking a Luo dialect called Alur; a word in Alur language. Aluurun: the Alur women; the Alur language (a Luo dialect spoken in Nebbi).
aluut (plural aluun) (noun F) a cow-horn or side-blown trumpet to warn people of danger (especially after Karimojong raiders have been sighted). 
alwak (singular noun F) a corruption of alwek: a swarm; a brood; a crowd. toto nak’alwak: mother of many children. cp. alwek, edep, edepit. 
alwanikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be too far for. kalwanikit eong bukus: your home is too far away for me. 
alwanus1 (noun F) distance; remoteness. 
alwanus2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be far; to be distant. alwana eong: I am far off. kilwaka iso: we are far off. 
alwek (singular noun F) a swarm; a brood; a crowd. toto k’alwek: mother of many children. cp. alwak, edep. 
alyaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to crawl or creep or climb away. 
alyaat ko-a (intransitive verb) to creep, crawl; to be creeping. 
alyaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to creep to; to twine round; to encircle. abu emun kolyaik ikoku: the snake twined round the child. 
amaapu (plural amaapun) (noun F) a map; atlas; a chart. 
amaaran (plural amaarana) (noun F) (Usuk) a rib (figurative) a wife. 
amabaati (plural amabaatin) (noun F) a corrugated iron or zinc sheet; a roof made of iron sheets. cp. abaati
amabuikin ko-o (transitive verb) to dislocate; to sprain. (reflexive verb) to become or be dislocated; to become or be sprained. 
amabuusu (plural amabuusun) (noun F) a prison; a jail. 
amacakin ko-a (transitive verb) to tell lies about somebody. 
amacar ko-a (transitive verb) to make a mark by beating or burning, or branding with a hot iron; to draw or write in a stylish way. 
amacigo (plural amacigoi, amacigin) (noun F) a worm used as fishing bait. 
amadaala (plural amadaalai) (noun F) a ladder; steps; a rung; a hierarchy; a ranking. cp. adoketait
amadet (plural amad) (noun F) earwax. cp. epipyot. 
amadit1 (plural amadi) (noun F) (formerly) a small but courageous bantam hen imported from Java.
Amadit2 (plural Amadi) (noun F) a small stumpy woman; a dwarf; a Madi woman; a woman native to Moyo or Adjumani districts on the north-western tip of Uganda; a word in the Madi tongue. Amadi: the Madi women; the language of the Madi.
amaduli (plural amadulin) (noun F) a hat; a turban; a cap. cp. acooro, adaduli
amaet (plural amaeta) (noun F) a litany; an eulogy; an oration; a praise. 
amagaalit (plural amagaalin) (noun F) a farm wagon; ox wagon or cart; a trawler. cp. agadigadi
amagarait1 (plural amagara) (noun F) a bow-harp of Busoga origin. 
Amagarait2 (plural Amagara) (noun F) a Musoga or Mugwere woman or word. Amagara: Basoga, Bagwere women or their language. 
amagoro (plural amagoron) (noun F) an uninhabited region; a desert; a wild forested area; the bush. iboiete ityang kamagoro: animals live in the bush. 
amagulusio (plural noun F) tribulations; the ups and downs; the twists and turns of fate. 
amaikin ekiror ko-a (transitive verb) to give name to; to call; to name. kamaikit eong ijo ekonikiror Petero: I call you, I give you the name of Peter. 
Amaikokoit (plural Amaikoko) (noun F) a Mugisu tribeswoman; a word in Lumasaba – the language of the Bagisu people; a woman native to Bugisu, i.e. the present day Mbale and Sironko districts in eastern Uganda. Amaikoko: the language of the Bagisu or Bamasaba people; the Lumasaba language. cp. Akanyangit. 
amairo (plural amairon) (noun F) a mile (distance measure). cp. emita, ekilomita.
amaisa (adverb) (of a prison term) for life. aiwen amaisa: to imprison for life. awenio amaisa: life imprisonment.
amajaani (noun F) tea leaves. 
amajing ko-a (intransitive verb) to go like a deaf man. 
amajinging ko-a (intransitive verb) to be deaf. imajinging ijo: imajingingas yesi: you are deaf.
amajingingaar (reflexive verb) to become deaf. 
amajokot (plural amajokon) (noun F) (outside Usuk) an ox yoke; a harness. cp. ajokot.
amakacac ko-a (intransitive verb) to be splay-footed. 
Amakadait (plural Amakada) (noun F) a Muganda tribeswoman from the Baganda tribe – one of the Bantu-speaking tribes of central Uganda; a word in Luganda language; a woman native to Buganda – the present day Masaka, Mukono, Mpigi, Luwero, Kampala, etc districts. Amakada: Baganda women; the Luganda language. cp. Amugaanat. 
amakadi (plural amakadin) (noun F) rock salt; salt lick (for livestock); sodium bicarbonate; Magadi salt. cp. amuunyu, acuubu. 
amakajan (plural noun F) syphilitic swellings. 
Amakenyit (plural Amakenyin) (noun F) a woman from the Bakenye tribe (a Bantu-speaking fishing community mostly found at the shores of Teso lakes).
amakereeda (plural amakereedan) (noun F) (in Pallisa) a tablet (of medicine); a pill. cp. ekia, ekulony
amakesit (plural amakesin) (noun F) (school) marks; a correct tick; results; a grade. 
amalan1 (interjection) I greet you!; greetings! 
amalan2 ki-a (transitive verb) to greet, salute, or to welcome; to thank; to congratulate. alosi amalan ejakait: I am going to pay my respects to the chief or to my husband, master, boss. 
amalayat (plural amalayan) (noun F) a prostitute; a harlot; a whore; a sex worker. 
amaliongong ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a miserly, sickly look. 
amaluguguonor ko-o (reflexive verb) to undulate; to roll, ripple, or rise and fall; to heave or surge. 
amame ko-o (intransitive verb) to be absent, not to exist; not to have or possess. amamei eong (I am absent), emamei ngesi (she/he is not there), imamei ijo (you – singular - are absent), kimamei iso (we – exclusive – are absent), imameete yesi (you – plural – are not there). past: amameete (they were not there), imameete (you – plural – were absent), emamei eong aberu: I have no wife. emameete ileic: she/he is unashamed, barefaced, or shameless.
amamean (plural amameak) (noun F) the absent one(s); absentee; absconder. akiro nuamameak: fiction. nuinera ijo eraas nuamameak: what you say is not there: is not true: it is fiction. 
amamear ko-o (reflexive verb) not to be there. amamearos kangina: there are none over there. 
amameikin ko-o (transitive verb) to lack; to be without; not to have. kamameiki eong acoa: I am at a loss, I cannot decide. amameiki eong akine: I have no goat. imamekinete ijo inyamat: you will have no food. 
amameu (singular noun F) annihilation; absence; vacancy. kotoma amameu k'ejakait: in the absence of the chief. cp. amamus
amameun ko-o (intransitive verb) not to be there; not to have, be devoid of. amameutu isirigin: there is no money. amameunos isirigin: there is no money. cp. amamuun. 
amamian (plural amamiak) (noun F) the missing; an absentee. kideikis loamamian: leave something for the absent one. edar ngol da amamiak: I waited for him in vain. cp. atitai. 
amamikit (plural amamikitos) (verb) to need, be in want; to be without. kamamikit eong egoe: I am in need of cloth. 
amamus (singular noun F) absence; nothingness. cp. amameu
amamuun ko-o (intransitive verb) to be absent, etc 
amana (plural amanat) (noun F) a cultivated plot; a garden; a farm. amanaka: my garden. cp. emanikor.
amanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to go and find for; to go round something. komanakinai inyamat: go round and find me some food. (intransitive verb) to hide soon; to turn into a certain direction. ai bo amanaki akine na?: where has this goat gone to. ai bo ibu ijo komanak?: where did you hide yourself? 
amananakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be going round and round; to be hidden; to keep hiding. 
amananut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of roaming about (noun F) a roaming spirit. 
amanar (transitive verb) to pass, to go round something. 
amaneja (plural amanejan) (noun F) a manageress. cp. akengarenikinon
amanun ko-a (intransitive verb) to come (from abroad); to come from around somewhere (as from a house). komanu lailo: come round this way. (transitive verb) to find by going round. 
amanyaar ko-a (transitive verb) (of a woman or girl) to get married away.
amanyakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pay dowry for somebody; to get married. cp. aiitar akituk. 
amanyanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to marry many women; to pay dowry for more than one woman (on behalf of or for somebody). 
amanyat (plural numanyat) (noun F) a fiancée; a bride-to-be; a marriageable girl. 
amaragait (plural amaraga) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a rib. cp. amaaran. 
amaran ko-a (intransitive verb) to tremble; to shake; to quake; to shiver; to be nervous; to be in a hurry to get off, thrill, vibrate. amaran aterot: to shiver with cold. emarani ngesi akuwan enyami: she/he is very greedy (literally, shaking with greed while eating). emarani akwap: there is an earthquake. imarani bo ai, eapie nen?: why such a hurry, that place is nearby? emarani ngesi bokobok (teletel): she/he trembles all over (her/his body). cp. aitelitela.
amaranaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to hurry away. amaranaar ngesi ore: she/he has hurried home. 
amaranun ko-a (intransitive verb) to begin to tremble or shake. 
amaratoit (plural amaratoi) (noun F) a brass armlet. cp. itugai: armlet made of plant roots. cp. akomot: armlet made of ivory. 
amaria ko-a (transitive verb) to scramble, rush for; to claim; to fight for, vie with; to grab, contest. 
amariamaria1 (noun F) confusion, disorder; a mix up. 
amariamaria2 ko-a (transitive verb) to keep grabbing; to rush (of water); to race; to contend. 
amariar (plural amariaros) (transitive verb) (of many) to quickly finish; to vie, fight for. amariasi itunga akiring: people are fighting to buy a piece of meat. amariaros itunga togo: people have struggled to get into the house. 
amasabu (plural amasabun) (noun F) soap. imasabu: a little soap; a piece of soap. amasabu nak’iloset: washing soap. amasabu nak’ilongis: toilet or bathing soap. atekat naka amasabu: a bar of soap. apeelet naka amasabu: a flake of soap. amasabu akiria: powder soap. cp. asabuunyu, asabuuni.
amasakaliat (plural amasakalia) (noun F) a species of bird. 
amasikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to rust; to corrode; to stain (of teeth); to be dirty; to drink on behalf of someone. emasikito ikel: the teeth are stained. amasikin itunganan ekia: to recieve medication because of someone’s beating (the police will need a medical report of injuries incurred in order to prosecute someone for an assault case).
amasiribut (plural amasiribun) (noun F) a moustache; a beard; sideburns.
amataar ko-a (transitive verb) to drink up; to empty out; to soak up; to drain. (reflexive verb) to have no strength left; to be near death; to feign death. 
amatabwino (plural amatabwinon) (noun F) blotting paper; a fountain pen. 
amatagulat (plural amatagulan) (noun F) a roofing tile. 
amatapaalit (plural amatapaalin) (noun F) a brick; a block. 
amateeka (plural amateekai) (noun F) a book of basic religious teachings. 
amatenget (plural amatengen) (noun F) the side of the head; the cheek; the temple. 
amatet (plural amateta) (noun F) a pub or public house. 
amatong ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a thin bony face with prominent jaws. 
amatongongoor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become thin-cheeked and bejawled. 
amatun1 akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to investigate; to elicit. 
amatun2 akituk ko-a (intransitive verb) to pout, protrude lips on account of anger or sickness. 
amatuta (plural amatutan) (noun F) a break-water; drainage; a dam; a small dyke; separation between gardens. 
amaukuk ko-o (intransitive verb) (literally) to be bigheaded; to have a big head. cp. aliikik, aridangang. 
amaut (plural amauta) (noun F) a treasure; a gift. 
ameanakin (reflexive verb) to reciprocate. ameanakin einer arai aswam: to speak or do in turns. komeanakinos einer: speak in turns (not all together). cp. abeanakin einer: to speak in turns.
amear (adverb) from here on. amear kane aitodol osamai: from here on to the swamp. 
amearit (adverb) from now onwards. 
amecat (plural amecata) (noun F) a shelter; a harbour. 
ameda (plural amedai) (noun F) a profit, gain, fruit, premium. cp. adumunet. 
amedel ko-a (intransitive verb) to be kind, gentle, merciful, clement, benign, gracious, or magnanimous. ebokorit lomedelit: the little finger. 
amedelanut (singular noun F) magnanimity; generosity. 
ameegi (singular noun F) (in Pallisa) yellow bananas (ripes). cp. ameepu
ameepu (singular noun F) ripe, sweet bananas, Musa sapientum. cp. etaget loakonon
ameeri (plural ameerin) (noun F) a ship; a steamer; a liner; a big ferry. 
amegerer ko-a (intransitive verb) to be thin, emaciated; to be under-grown (of man, animals and plants). 
ameikin ko-a (transitive verb) to drive (cattle or goats or prisoners to their stable or to prison); to stalk. ameikin aimany: to wait for elder brother to get married first. ameikin acok: to herd in turns; to pass on one’s turn of herding to someone else; to do in turns. cp. ameanakin. 
amej ko-a (transitive verb) to hunt; to persecute. amejai: I hunt. emejaete: they hunt. cp. airiga. 
amejaar ko-a (transitive verb) to hunt far away; to be hunting and take away; to kill and take away. 
amejal (plural amejala) (noun F) a red anthill. 
amejaun ko-a (transitive verb) to surround in hunting, kill, and bring this way. 
ameje (plural amajeik, amejeiko, amejei) (noun F) an abandoned home or village. cp. ejeburu. 
amekek (plural amekekin) (noun F) a pangolin or scaly ant-eater, Manis temminckii. 
Amekenyit (plural Amekenyin) (noun F) a woman from the Bakenye tribe, the fisher tribe of Bantu origin that lives near lakes in Teso; a word in the language spoken by the Bakenye. Amekenyin: the Bakenye women or their language.
amekimek (plural amekimekia) (noun F) armlet or wristlet made from pieces of ostrich eggshell. 
amelejang (plural amelejanga) (noun F) a green grasshopper. cp. alabajang
amelo (noun F) young grass after grass fire; green pasture. idila amelo: there is plenty of new grass.
ameme ko-o (transitive verb) to spear; to aim at with a spear. amemei eong akingok nakokolan: I am aiming at a thieving dog (bitch) with a spear. abu eong kameme ekue: I speared a fox. 
amemeon (plural amemeok) (noun F) one who hunts with spears. 
amen (interjection) (usually said after a prayer) so be it; Amen. cp. kikote nepenen.
amenanut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be rebellious. (noun F) dissatisfaction; rebelliousness; unruliness; insubordination. 
amengeranut1 (singular noun F) disobedience; defiance; rebelliousness; mutiny. 
amengeranut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be defiant; to be disobedient, insolent. amengerana eong, imengerana ijo, imengeraka yesi: I am/you are defiant, disobedient, insolent. 
amengerikin ko-a (transitive verb) to disobey; to cause trouble or sorrow; to sabotage. kimengerik ijo eong kanuka airengiar ikakoku kosomero: you upset me by dismissing my child from school. 
amenit ko-o (transitive verb) to disobey someone with authority; to have a dislike for; to have a grudge against; to be too little for. amenit eong ajon ngun: I consider that beer not worthwhile, it is too little for me. 
ameniton (plural amenitok) (noun F) a rebel; a law-breaker. 
amenitonut (singular noun F) insolence; impudence; disrespect; cheek; audacity; impertinence; rudeness. 
ameonor ko-o (transitive verb) to keep licking something (like a cat with its kittens). (reflexive verb) to keep licking itself like a cat or dog; to smack lips. 
ameor ko-o (transitive verb) to lick off; to finish off. cp. aidyelar. 
amera1 (noun F) drunkenness; intoxication; rustiness. 
amera2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be drunk; to be foolish on account of drinking too much. (lst person amera) (plural emeras).
ameran (plural amerak) (noun F) a drunken person; a drunkard; a sot. 
ameranut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be in the habit of getting drunk. 
amerekek (plural amerekekin) (noun F) an ewe; a sheep. cp. adiiga.
amerekekin (noun F) a group of stars appearing between November and February.
Ameri (noun F) a pet name for a white and bluish flecked cow. 
amerianut (singular noun F) tarnish; stain. 
amerikin1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be stained; to become rusty, tarnished. ameriki ekakileng: my knife is rusty. amerikin enyel: to become rusty. 
amerikin2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to become or be drunk or intoxicated. amerikinos kesi: they are drunk or inebriated. emerikinos kesi: they will become drunk. 
ametar ko-a (transitive verb) to take all. cp. apetar, amear
ameturat (plural ametura) (noun F) ashes as blown up from grass fire or of a house on fire. 
ameun1 (adverb) starting from; hence; since. ameun …aitodol: from … to. ameun eiditeuka: from or since my childhood. 
ameun2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to drive (cattle, etc) this way. 
amiam (plural amemia) (noun F) a small antelope, oribi, Ourebia ourebi. 
amidakin ko-a (transitive verb) to eat by dipping finger into food or sugar, etc; to taste food by dipping finger into food and licking it. aisimidanakin ikoku inyamat: to feed a child with one’s fingers. 
amidilil ko-a (intransitive verb) to have small slit eyes; to be slit-eyed. imidililas akonye: imidiolitos akonye: having small slit eyes. 
amidiolit (plural amidiol) (noun F) eye discharge or exudates. cp. adomelait.
amiidi (plural amiidin) (noun F) a tobacco or opium pipe. 
amiit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be wealthy; to have plenty of anything, especially food. cp. abarit. 
amijiiri (plural imijiirin) (noun F) a small termite, different from amijimij. cp. aswei. 
amijimij (plural amijimijin) (noun F) a small termite. 
amilimil ko-a (intransitive verb) to shine or glisten as of mica, or corrugated zinc sheets. 
amimiru1 (singular noun F) rancidity (of urine); staleness; rottenness (of butter). 
amimiru2 ko-a (transitive verb) to become rancid. 
amin (singular noun F) love; liking; adoration; charity; kindness. 
amina ko-a (transitive verb) to love, affect, or to care for; to be used to; to be fond of; to take a fancy to; to delight. eminas itunga epapaali: people like pawpaw fruit. emamei nges amin: she/he has no charity, kindness. amina itunganan: to be attached; to love someone.
aminakin ko-a (transitive verb) to take a fancy to; to like. aminaki etelepat esomero: the boy likes school. 
aminanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to love one another. kominanaros bonik: love one another. 
aminanut ko-a (reflexive verb) to be kind-hearted; to be charitable. 
aminar ko-a (transitive verb) to captivate; to fancy; to tickle one’s fancy; to be amused. aminasi ngol akirokon: what you say has tickled his fancy, amuses him. 
aminat (plural aminan) (noun F) dear; beloved; dear one; popular; darling (used in opening or closing address, letters - translated as ‘yours dearly’). 
aming (collective noun F) small inedible termites. cp. aminyine.
aminit (plural aminito) (noun F) a branch or wood from eminit tree; the place where iminito trees grow. 
aminun ko-a (transitive verb) to fall in love with; to begin to like; to begin to like; to be in favour of. aminutu ijako nges: the chiefs like her/him. abu etelepat kominu apese: the boy fell in love with a girl. (reflexive verb) aminun: to be reconciled. 
aminyine1 (noun F) a generic name for small inedible white ants. 
aminyine2 (plural aminyinei) (noun F) syphilitic lesions, Condylomata. 
amio (singular noun F) plenty; wealth; treasure (not of cows, etc but in food); high living. edumunit ngesi amio kakimai: she/he has got plenty of millet. cp. aimi. 
amion1 (plural amiok) (noun F) a very small field mouse. 
amion2 (plural amiok) (noun F) one who is wealthy in food or crops. 
Amiroit (plural Amiroi) (noun F) a Lango woman; a word in the Langi language. cp. Alangot, Anyakoit.
amisa (plural amisai) (noun F) a big stick; cudgel. (transitive verb) to beat with a big stick. 
amisianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to know well; to understand; to comprehend. cp. amisiikin.
amisianut1 (noun F) shrewdness; astuteness; wisdom; intelligence; acumen. 
amisianut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be shrewd; to be observant; to be discerning 
amisiikin ko-a (transitive verb) to know well; to understand thoroughly. 
amisiri (plural amisirin) (noun F) a cultivated plot; a garden. cp. amana, emanikor. 
amitirir ko-a (intransitive verb) to be small and thin, slender. 
Amo (plural of Amoit) (noun F) the Luganda or any Bantu language; any foreign language, i.e. any language that is not Ateso; non-Ateso women.
amoar ko-a (transitive verb) to go and look for; to go in search of. 
amocakin ko-a (transitive verb) to crack a joke at somebody or something; to joke; to jest. 
amocanut1 (singular noun F) fondness of joking; jesting. 
amocanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of joking, teasing or wit-cracking. 
amocar ko-a (transitive verb) to make fun of; to joke at the expense of somebody; to laugh at someone in an unkind way; to have a joke with; to make a farce of; to ridicule. mam akoto amocar eong: I don’t want you to make fun of me. sirikimocar akiro nuka ediini: do not ridicule religion. 
amodakin ko-a (transitive verb) to cheat for somebody or somewhere. cp. aijep. 
amodar ko-a (transitive verb) to send astray; to deceive. kimodas ijo imo: the foreigners have conned you. 
amodet (plural amodeta) (noun F) a deceit; cheating; a trick; a ruse. 
amodia ko-a (transitive verb) to obtain bit by bit; to obtain one by one; to acquire slowly. akoto amodia isirigin agwelia egaali: I want to find money slowly sufficient to buy a bicycle. 
amodiaar ko-a (transitive verb) to obtain and take away by cheating; to overcharge and take away someone’s money. 
amodianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to find for. ape komodianakinai inyamat: go and find some food for me. 
amoding (plural amodingon) (noun F) a wilderness; a hot desert; uninhabited country.
amodingot (plural amodingo) (noun F) a kind of snake (one cannot specify or identify). 
amodio- (adverb) (prefix used with feminine nouns) some. akoto amodiocok: I want some sweet potatoes. amodiojon: a little beer. cp. adis. 
amodo (plural amodoi) (noun F) a hollow reed or stick used as a case for keeping a beer tube. cp. amokodo. 
amodok1 (plural noun F) thick beer before water is added. 
amodok2 ko-a (transitive verb) to eat thick food or vegetables. abu bian eong kamodok emagira koreka: I ate thick peas pudding at home yesterday. 
amodokok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of clay or food or beer) to be thick; (of road or courtyard) to be dirty, muddy. cp. apotokok
amodokun ko-a (transitive verb) to pick up something thick. cp. aimodolaun. 
amodomod ko-a (transitive verb) to deceive, cheat repeatedly; to overcharge constantly. 
amodyalat (plural amodyalan) (noun F) a small swallow (bird) that builds its nest out of mud. cp. omeleku. 
amoeten (plural amoetena, amoeteka) (noun F) an intestine or entrail (of a person or animal); a bicycle or motorcar tube; a rubber tube. amoeten nadidi: a small intestine. amoeten napolon: a colon; a gut.
amogor ko-a (transitive verb) to fold and push or press a long thing into narrow opening. abu eong kadum aberu emogori ibilenga toma amot: I found a woman folding and stuffing mudfish into the cooking pot. 
amogorikin ko-a (transitive verb) to huddle or smuggle and push in or against (when too long) (reflexive verb) to hide oneself in a narrow opening.
amoikin ko-a (transitive verb) to search something for somebody. amoikin acoa: to give advice to; to plan for; to find a way of doing. 
amoit (plural amo) (noun F) a female foreigner, especially of Bantu origin; a non-native; a foreign word (euphemism) a placenta or afterbirth. cp. angasiep.
amoiten (noun F) a corruption of amoeten: a gut; bowels. 
amojir ko-a (transitive verb) to twist; to turn (a tap); to wring out; to wrench. amojir akiro: to twist words or a case. kamojir eong akoik: I have colic. kamojir eong etau: I feel like vomiting. kamojirata eong akiro ngun: I am sorry for that. amojir anaaga: to wind up a gramophone. amojir naka etau: a feeling of nausea. amojirit ekatau: I am very sorry. 
amojiraar ko-a (transitive verb) to wrest away; to take by threats; to wrest, extract, wring; to take under duress. 
amojirikin ko-a (transitive verb) to twist or turn or contort, once. cp. aijerakin. 
amojirun ko-a (transitive verb) to extort; to obtain by threat; to wrest, extract, wring; to obtain under duress. 
amojong1 (plural amojongik) (noun F) an old woman above 66 years of age. cp. akimat. 
amojong2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become old (adjective) old. amojong ngesi: she/he has become old or she/he is old. 
amojongaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become old; to grow old; to age. 
amojonganut1 (noun F) ageing or looking old fast. 
amojonganut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to get old fast. 
amojongit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be old, elderly, mature or aged. 
amojongu (singular noun F) old age; maturity. 
amokodo (plural amokodon) (noun F) a hollow reed or stick for keeping a beer drinking tube in. cp. amodo. 
amolig (plural amoliga) (noun F) a beehive; a hole in the tree (as bee-hive) (slang) the vagina (of a woman). aiwad amolig: to extract honeycombs from a beehive; (slang) to have illicit sexual intercourse.
amolo (plural amolon) (noun F) a curved knife; a scythe. cp. eriiga.
amongoriat (plural amongoria) (noun F) a species of fish. 
amoni (plural amonieik) (noun F) a thicket; a bush; an overgrown anthill; a forest where animals roam; a coppice. 
amonukuk ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a distended belly; to have a protruding belly. 
amonyakin ko-a (transitive verb) to beseech; to ask for something. cp. aingainga, aingaingaikin.
amonyo naka itaok (singular noun F) the yellow sticky droppings of a young calf. 
amonyukuk1 (noun M) brittleness; frailty; fragility. 
amonyukuk2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of bones)to be frail, fragile, brittle. 
amoorit (plural amoori) (noun F) a nerve; an artery; blood vessel; a tendon; a sinew or muscle. amoorit naka apokipok: a hamstring. amoori nuebutunitos: varicose veins. amoori nuka aokot: blood vessels.
amoot ko-a (transitive verb) to be looking for; to seek diligently; to search. amoot akiro: looking for trouble. imoot ijo akiro: you are trying to annoy me, to get me into a temper. 
amopiira (plural amopiiran) (noun F) a rubber tube; a plastic thing; a car or bicycle tyre; a rubber sheath or condom. 
amor (plural amorio) (noun F) a common duiker, Cephalophus grimmia. cp. amiam
amoranar ko-a (reflexive verb) to share with one another. komoranaros: join up together; do not be enemies, make friends together , be of one mind. 
amorenen ko-a (transitive verb) to share together always. komorenenete eperot: sleep together in the same dormitory. 
amoris (plural amorisyo) (noun F) an offence; an insult; an abuse. cp. amorosit.
amorok (plural amorokin) (noun F) a shaft of spear; a penholder; haft. 
amorokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to revile each other; to scold one another; to insult one another; to offend one another; to curse one another.
amoromor ko-o (transitive verb) to insult; to curse, scold, etc often or repeatedly. amoromor itunganan: to abuse or insult someone. amoromoroo naka apedorosio nuka itunga: human rights abuse.
amoronor ko-o (reflexive verb) to grouse by oneself; to grumble; to utter threats; to fret. inyo bo imoronoror ijo?: what are you (grousing) growling, grumbling about? 
amoroonut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be fond of scolding. aimor: to scold, insult, etc 
amoror (plural nukamoror) (noun F) the wife of the maternal uncle. 
amorosit (plural amorosio) (noun F) an offence, abuse, insult. cp. amoris.
amoru (plural amor) (noun F) a stone; rock. amoru naka irieet: a grinding stone. amoru nainingere: a stone for weighing. (noun F) a weight (for weighing). 
amosimos (plural amosimosia) (noun F) a waterbuck, Kobus ellipsiprymnus; a praise word for a man; a kind of vegetable plant. 
amosing (plural amosingo) (noun F) a rhinoceros (animal), Diceros bicornis. 
amositoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to run fast, as of a motorcar or of water; to be impetuous, impulsive, bumptious; to be cursive in planning. abu amotoka ngin emositoi: that car came rushing on. amositoi inera: to be rash in speaking. 
amot (plural amoti) (noun F) an ordinary pot for carrying water or for cooking, made of clay; a crock. amot naka etaba: a pot of a tobacco pipe. imot: a little pot; a cruet. amot nak’ejaae: a hemp pipe. ejaas akipi amot: there is water in the pot.
amotakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to dash at; to rush at or after; to fall upon. amotakin ikapa emir: the cat dashed at the rat. (transitive verb) to do or work blindly at. 
amotar ko-a (reflexive verb) to dash off or run away; to rush headlong, roll down, move quickly aside, or move aside. amotaros itelepai amej: the boys dashed off to hunt. 
amotoka (plural amotokan) (noun F) a motorcar; an automobile; a car. 
amotot (plural amototin) (noun F) a pool of deep water in the swamp. 
amotun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come quickly this way; to rush this way. 
amoun ko-a (transitive verb) to look for and bring; to look for oneself. akoto amoun akile: I want to go and look for some milk. amoun etiai: to compute or estimate the price or value. 
amu (plural of amuut) (noun F) twins. cp. abangit. 
amuatonit (plural amuatok) (noun F) a twin. cp. amuut. 
amucaalat (plural amucaalan) (noun F) a lady; a wife; a mistress. cp. aberu.
Amucigat (plural Amuciga) (noun F) a Mukiga tribeswoman; a woman native to Kigezi (the present day Uganda districts of Kabale and Kisoro), speaking a Bantu language called Rukiga; a word in Rukiga. Amuciga: the Bakiga women; the Rukiga language.
amucogolot (plural amucogolon) (noun F) a species of bird, Bulbul. cp. apejulu, amujulut. 
amudanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to store up in something or gather and put into some container. 
amudang ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk or go with small ears; to have cuts in the ears (because of sickness or superstition). 
amudangang ko-a (intransitive verb) to have small ears; to have cuts in the ears (because of sickness or superstition). 
amudar ko-a (transitive verb) to gather and take away (as of sweepings). amudar akeje: to bewitch foot prints or, rather, to bewitch a person by taking the dust of his foot prints. 
amudianar akonye ko-a (transitive verb) to blind the eyes (as of sun); to dazzle. emudianari akolong akonye: the sun blinds the eyes. amudiaun akonye: to close someone’s eyelids (as of a dying person or a very hungry one). (reflexive verb) to close one’s eyes with pain, tiredness or hunger. 
amudiar ko-a (transitive verb) to destroy, annihilate, or devastate; to rob or kill and take away; to play havoc with. 
amudiario (singular noun F) destruction; annihilation; devastation.
amudokolo (plural amudokolon) (noun F) leaves or shoots of potatoes after the potatoes have been dug out. cp. ailibosit (aalibos).
amudongong ko-o (intransitive verb) to have ears with small pinnae or crumpled backwards. 
amuduk ko-o (transitive verb) to close the eyes by oneself; to shut the eyes. komuduk (plural komudukoto) shut your eyes. 
amudukanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become blind; to lose sight. 
amudukanut1 (singular noun F) blindness; sightlessness; loss of sight. 
amudukanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be blind; to be sightless. 
amudukikin ko-o (transitive verb) to shut the eyes for; to close the eyes; to endure. komudukik: close the eyes. amudukikin erot: to go or walk on steadily without resting. amudukikin adere: to go on drinking without stopping, with eyes closed. 
amudun ko-a (transitive verb) to grasp by hand; to scoop up and bring this way (solid things); to collect and bring together by hand, take a handful (of anything solid). 
amudye ko-a (transitive verb) to destroy; to ruin; to annihilate. 
amudyeikin ko-a (transitive verb) to cover up completely for; to destroy utterly for or somewhere. (reflexive verb) (of many) to become dark; to get into trouble. amudyeikinos kesi omusaago: they all got into trouble. 
amudyeun ko-a (transitive verb) to reflect sunshine on to somebody’s eyes with a mirror. cp. aidem akonye. 
amue (plural amuwei) (noun F) a firefly; a glow worm. 
amuebe (plural amuebeko) (noun F) the leaf or wood from a mango tree.
amug (plural of amugit) (noun F) creeping plants producing gourds, Cucurbita maxima, Lagenaria vulgaris. 
Amugaanat (plural Amugaana) (noun F) a Muganda woman; a woman native to Buganda (central and southern Uganda districts such as Kampala, Mukono, Masaka, Entebbe, Mpigi, etc); a word in Luganda (the language of the Baganda people). Amugaana: Baganda women; the Luganda language. cp. Emakadait.
Amuge1 (noun F) a pet name for a dark brown (nearly black) cow; a common name for a woman. 
amuge2 (plural nukamuge) (noun F) a harmless brown centipede with a repulsive smell; also called totokamuge. 
amuget (plural amugei) (noun F) a topi antelope, Damaliscus korrigum. 
Amugisut (plural Amugis) (noun F) a woman native of former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts); a Mugisu woman; a word in the Lumasaba language. Amugis: the Bagisu or Bamasaba women; the Lumasaba language. cp. Amaikokoit, Akanyangit.
amugit (plural amug) (noun F) a creeper producing gourds, Cucurbita maxima, Lagenaria vulgaris.
amugogot (plural amugog) (noun F) a banana plant; a banana leaf or banana fibre, Musa spp. Its leaves are used as thatch, fibre, wrappers, and fodder, and the fruit is made into banana beverage and food. cp. abubui: banana fibre. 
amugolet (plural amugolen) (noun F) a female initiate into a religion; a Roman Catholic nun; a bride (a woman to be wed).
amugur ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk with stooping shoulders or back; to be hunched. 
amugurur1 (noun F) a stoop; a bent back; a hunchback. cp. arugamo
amugurur2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a bent back; to be stooping. 
Amugweriot (plural Amugwerio) (noun F) a woman native to Budaka and Kibuku counties of Pallisa district; a word in Lugwere language; a Mugwere tribeswoman. Amugwerio: the Bagwere women; the language of the Bagwere.
amujaj (plural of amujajut) (noun F) sisal fibre. 
amujajut (plural amujaj) (noun F) a woody herb with whorls of spiny leaves at ground level; a sisal plant, leaf or fibre, Agave sisalana. It is used for live fence, while its fibre is used for strong ropes, sacking, and mats.
amujalal (noun F) nakedness; nudity; state of undress; exposure. 
amujuulut (plural amujuulun) (noun F) a bird, Laurie. kiany amujuulut epodo, eanyunit emun: if you hear the amujuulut bird complaining, it has seen a snake (Ateso version of the saying: where there is smoke there must be fire). 
amukar ko-a (transitive verb) to scoop away. 
amukat (plural amuk) (noun F) a leather sandal; a shoe; a boot. 
amukean (singular noun F) medical treatment; therapy; medication. 
amukebe (plural amukeben) (noun F) a tin can. cp. akebe
amukeket (plural amukeke) (noun F) a dried sliced sweet potato. 
amuket (plural amuketa) (noun F) dust-pan; a scoop; any instrument for scooping. cp. amuketait
amuketait (plural amuketa) (noun F) a syllable. 
amukono (plural amukonon) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a roll of cloth in general; a sheet; a bed sheet. cp. ajoola.
amukoro (plural amukoron) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a hollow reed or stick for keeping a beer drinking tube in. cp. amokodo.
amukun ko-a (transitive verb) to scoop up; to pick up (of many together); to bring many together; to hold many (reflexive verb) to come together; to be scooped together; to be too many. amukunos itelepai osomero: too many boys have come to school. 
amukunet (plural amukuneta) (noun F) a syllable; a scoop. cp. amuketait.
amukurat (plural amukuran) (noun F) a gradient or slope; a steepness; an acclivity; a high rise; a hill. 
amula ko-a (intransitive verb) (of waves, froth, or anti-peristalsis in the stomach) to roll or to swell. 
Amulaalot (plural Amulaalo) (noun F) a Muhima or Munyankole woman; a woman native to Ankole (the present day districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo); a word in Runyankore. Amulaalo: the Banyankole women; the Runyankore language.
amulangang ko-a (intransitive verb) to be hornless. 
amulaun ko-a (intransitive verb) (of anger or the contents of the stomach about to vomit) to come like a wave; to surge (like fits). 
amuleete (plural amuleetei) (noun F) a football made from rags or banana fibre and used by village children. 
amuleget (plural amulegen) (noun F) a species of bird, African open-bill. 
Amulubit (plural Amulubin) (noun F) a Nubian woman native of Bombo, parts of West Nile, and Southern Sudan; a word in Nubian (the language of the Nubian people). Amulubin: the Nubian women or their language. 
amulukujut (plural amulukujun) (noun F) a crimson breasted shrike. 
amulut (plural amulun) (noun F) the mucous of the intestines; intestinal worm that attaches on the mucosa. 
amumu (singular noun F) lawlessness; violence; anarchy; chaos; disorder; mayhem; free-for-all fight. 
amumuikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to do or behave like a wild animal to somebody. kamumuikinit akiteng ngin eong: that cow is vicious to me. 
amumuor ko-o (reflexive verb) (of animals, seldom of man) to become violent. amumuor emong ngol: that bull is violent or has become wild. 
amumut (singular noun F) the smell of a baby’s excrements. 
amumutaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to smell like a baby’s excrements.
amumwarat (plural amumwar) (noun F) a horn (of an animal); a snuffbox made of horn. amumwarat naka ebeere: a tentacle of a grasshopper. 
amuna ko-a (transitive verb) to lay waste; to ruin or spoil; to do harm to (transitive verb) to brew beer; to ferment. alosi eong amuna ajon: I am going to brew beer. cp. aibwaikin ajon (akiria). 
amunaar ko-a (transitive verb) to spoil; to lay waste; to wipe out; to do harm to (of something away from speaker); to make dirty. sirikimunaa ikaboro: do not spoil my things. (reflexive verb) to get spoiled; to get dirty; to get ruined. amunaar ekatogo: my house is ruined. 
amunaaret (plural amunaareta) (noun F) a damage; a ruin; a wreckage; a devastation. 
amunaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to brew beer for somebody or somewhere. 
amunan (plural amunak) (noun F) the one who makes the beer; a waiter (of beer only); sponsor of a beer party; the hostess at a beer party. 
amunaun ko-a (transitive verb) to spoil; to corrupt; to waste; to mar, befoul. amunaun ekisil: to transgress. sirikimunau ekisil loka Lokasuban: do not sin. amunaun akoik: to abort; to miscarry. amunaun aiboi: to cause trouble at home; to disturb the peace (literally, to spoil the stay or sitting). (reflexive verb) to get spoiled or stained; to have premature birth (of woman or animal). amunaun aberu: the woman has had premature birth. 
amunaunet (plural amunauneta) (noun F) a damage; ruin; a miscarriage. 
amuno (singular noun F) hope; trust; expectation; assumption; confidence. 
amuno ko-o (transitive verb) to hope; to trust; to expect; to be confident. emunos kesi adumun inyamat: they hope to get food. kamunos Lokasuban: let us trust in God. emunoi: it is hoped.
amunokin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to hope for; to put trust in; to wish to; to depend on. kamunokinit eong ijo angaleun atipet: I wish you a quick recover. 
amunokin2 ko-a (transitive verb) to put one’s mind on doing something; to go on doing; to continue to pay attention (reflexive verb) to be confident; to be hopeful. emunokina itunga adumun akimai ipu okaru lo: people hope or expect to get a good (much) millet crop this year. 
amunor ko-o (transitive verb) to wish good or bad to someone. kamunor eong ijo aijar namam edaun: I wish you eternal life. emameete nukajokak nukimunor ngesi ijo: she/he wishes you no good (things). 
amunot (plural amunon) (noun F) a trustworthy, dependable, reliable, or honest woman. 
amuny (plural amunyin) (noun F) skin (of a person); a piece of leather of an animal; a cuticle; the bark of a tree; a strap of leather; a leather thong; a bootlaces. amuny naka eris: a strip of leopard skin (used as an amulet or talisman). cp. emukule.
amunyakin ko-a (transitive verb) to break for or to break in (reflexive verb) to break off by itself (like a rotten twig). amunyakin etirir toma akeju: the etirir thorn has broken off inside the foot. 
amunyar ko-a (transitive verb) to break off (as of a rotten twig, etc). sirikimunya atenu: do not break off the branch. 
amunyelet (plural amunyelen) (noun F) a skin used for sleeping on; a leather; a football game or leather ball; (Ateso Atororo) a shirt. cp. akapet.
amunyir (singular noun F) a kind of grass burnt to extract salt. cp. amusala: another kind of grass for salt-making. 
amunyokin ko-o (transitive verb) to patch up (a hole in a skin or in cloth). cp. aimucakin 
Amunyoorot (plural Amunyooro) (noun F) a Munyoro tribeswoman; a woman native to Bunyoro (the present day Uganda districts of Hoima, Masindi, and parts of Kibale and Mubende), speaking a Bantu language called Runyoro; a word in Runyoro. Amunyooro: the Banyoro women; the Runyoro language.
amunyor ko-o (transitive verb) to cut off (as of tail or ear of sheep); to break off (a piece of bar soap). 
amunyumuny ko-a (transitive verb) to break to pieces (of stick or bar of soap); to transgress, break law. imunyumunyei ijo ikisila apaarasia kere: you are always breaking laws. cp. abilibil.
amunyumunyet (plural amunyumunyeta) (noun F) a scrap; a crumb; a fragment.
amunyurur ko-o (intransitive verb) to have badly shaped ears (turned down). eitaabo loemunyuritoi: a dog-eared book. 
amuogo (plural amuogon, amuogoko) (noun F) a cassava stem, leaf or cutting. 
amuokol ki-o (intransitive verb) to pull faces; to frown. 
amuokolikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to roll itself up (as of hedgehog). 
amuokoloor ko-o (reflexive verb) to pull sour face, turning the head away. imuokoloor apupu keanyu jo: the hedgehog rolls itself up when it sees you. 
amurake (noun F) a home of an in-law. alot ngesi amurake: she/he has gone to (visit) his relatives in-law. 
amurakin ko-a (transitive verb) to cover the millet to let it ripen quickly. amurakis akima: the cut millet was covered in order to ripen. amuraki akoik: dysentery has ceased. (reflexive verb) amurakin: (of millet flour) to be covered in one basket to ferment. amurakinos akiria kere toma obukit ediopet: all the flour due for fermenting has gone into one basket. 
amuran (plural amurak) (noun F) a sister-in-law; mother-in-law; the wife’s sister; all in-laws generally (male or female). 
amuranut1 (singular noun F) astringency; ascerbity; severity (of stomach). 
amuranut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of food when eaten) to be astringent, binding. 
amurat (plural amuran) (noun F) a basket or pot for fermenting beer dough; fermenting dough. 
amurenget (plural amurengen) (noun F) anything tied together; a bundle; a parcel. 
amuriat (collective noun F) the swarming brown biting ants. cp. emukuny
amuro (plural amuroi, amuros) (noun F) a thigh; a hind leg (from the knee to the hip). cp. akewat: a foreleg. cp. amurwo.
amurok (plural amurokia) (noun F) a wooden part of an arrow. cp. amorok: a haft of a spear. 
amuron1 (plural amurok) (noun F) a centipede. cp. agoolu; amuge.
amuron2 (plural amurok) (noun F) a traditional priestess or medicine woman (knowledgeable in herbal medicine or cure for witchcraft). amuron naka adekis: a female doctor (who administers western medicine). amuron nakokou: a traditional doctor (who administers herbs and potions).
amuronot (singular noun F) beneficial witchcraft; the work of a traditional doctor (magic, healing, or prophesying, etc). 
amurut (plural amurun) (noun F) a small barn or granary; a decayed barn, washed away partly by rain. 
amurwo1 (plural amurwos, amurwoi) (noun F) a thigh; hind leg. akewat: foreleg. 
amurwo2 ko-o (transitive verb) to prophesy; to divine; to do the work of a traditional priest or doctor. emurwoi ngesi: she/he prophesies or divines.
amurwon (plural amurwok) (noun F) a traditional doctor or priestess; a health officer or woman doctor. 
amusala (noun F) a grass, Pennisetum. 
amusaot (plural amusaon) (noun F) a midwife. 
amuseit (plural amusein) (noun F) an old woman; an old lady; a dame. cp. amojong, akimat, toto. 
amusenu (plural amusenun) (noun F) a hoe handle or shaft. cp. akujup.
amuseset (plural amusesen) (noun F) a coly bird. cp. ewojakori, epitakori, ediriakori. 
Amusog (singular noun F) Palm Sunday before Easter, commemorating Christ’s journey into Jerusalem. 
Amusogat (plural Amusoga) (noun F) a woman native to Busoga (present day districts of Jinja, Iganga, Kamuli, Mayuge and Bugiri); a word in Lusoga language; a Musoga tribeswoman. Amusoga: the Basoga women; the Lusoga language. cp. Amagarait: a Musoga or Mugwere tribeswoman.
