amusogot (plural amusogon) (noun F) a palm leaf; a palm frond. 
Amusugut (plural Amusugun) (noun F) a European or white woman; a word from a European language. akesa namusugut: a European woman. einer Amusugun: to speak a European language, especially English.
amusumus1 (singular noun F) semi-darkness; twilight; late evening; penumbra. 
amusumus2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be or to become half dark; to be twilight or dim. 
amusungut (plural amusungun) (noun F) an injury; a harm; an accident; a mischief; a wound; a mishap. cp. akangas, aromwait
amusus (singular noun F) smut; dirt; lewdness; rudeness; immorality. 
amutaru (noun F) a truss; a heap (of something tied in a bundle). 
amuteete (plural amuteeten) (noun F) a headrest, cushion or pillow. cp. aicolonget
amutego (plural amutegon) (noun F) a clap trap. cp. atego; eic; akuluma. 
amutojoj ko-o (intransitive verb) to be naked or nude; to be in Adam’s suit.
amuton (singular noun F) darkness; night; gloom; obscurity. 
amutonoor ko-o (intransitive verb) to become dark; to become gloomy, mysterious, or sinister; to become overgrown. (plural amutokoor)
Amutoorot (plural Amutooro) (noun F) a Mutooro tribeswoman; a woman native to Tooro (the present day western Uganda districts of Bundibugyo, Kabarole, Kyenjojo, Kamwenge and parts of Kibale and Kasese); a word in Rutooro (the language of the Batooro). Amutooro: the Batooro women; the Rutooro language.
amutujuj ko-o (intransitive verb) to be dirty; to be black all over; to be dirty all over. imutujujos idwe etulia: the children are dirty all over with soot. 
amuturu (plural amutur) (noun F) a mature fresh sweet potato tuber just harvested; any freshly harvested tuber (potato, cassava, yam, etc). 
amuturur ko-a (intransitive verb) to be big, fat. imuturur akou: imuturur emorosing: fat or big-headed; thick-necked. 
amuulet (plural amuulen) (noun F) an unmarried woman staying alone; a poor woman living in solitude; a widow. cp. apuserut
amuunyu (uncountable noun F) table salt; common salt (sodium chloride). cp. abalang, amakadi. 
amuut (plural amu) (noun F) a twin girlchild. cp. emuut. 
amuya ko-a (transitive verb) to take many together randomly (as of people, animals or anything); to uproot together (without segregation). emuyai ngesi eduan ka akimai da: she/he uproots the millet together with the weeds. amuya ejakait itunga ipu: the chief has taken many people. 
amuyonor ko-o (intransitive verb) to pout, sneer; to smile; to grin; to despise by turning head away (with mouth closed as one in a smoky or smelly place).
amuyonor ko-o (reflexive verb) to grin; to smile broadly. 
amwalat (plural amwalan) (noun F) spiral bracelet or earring; a bangle; a nose ring; an ankle chain; iron in general. cp. asuwat.
amwalimu (plural amwalimun) (noun F) a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer. cp. akesisianakinan
amwangit ko-a (transitive verb) to despise; to contemn, or to scorn; to disobey, affront, override, or defy. amwangit Katoda: impiety, wickedness, transgression.
amwaniar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become hot. amwaniar akolong: the sun has become hot. 
amwanikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to become hot for or somewhere; to become sick or feverish. kamwanikinit eong etogo: it has become too hot for me in the room. emwanikina ngesi akuwan: she/he is slightly indisposed; she/he has fever. 
amwanus (plural amwakus) (noun F) heat; warmth; temperature. amwanus naka etau (noun F) greediness; gluttony; stinginess. amwanuu nges etau: she/he has become greedy, stingy, closefisted. 
amwanuun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become hot; to be hot. amwakuutu akipi: the water has become or is hot (plural amwakuun)
amwaset (plural amwaseta) (noun F) anything to wipe or rub with. egoe lomwaset ereet: a handkerchief; a face mop. 
amwatar ko-a (transitive verb) to expunge; to wipe away; to efface; to rub away or out; to brush away. komwata ekumekon: wipe your nose. 
amwatun akonye (noun F) (formerly) a traditional ceremony performed by a son-in-law after looking by accident at his mother-in-law, ostensibly to cleanse his eyes. amwatun akonye ko-a (transitive verb) to wipe the face 
amwe (plural amwei) (noun F) a bush, Lantana. 
amwekimwek (intransitive verb) to be polished like gold or copper; to shine; to be bright, dazzle, be iridescent.. cp. amilimil.
amwi (plural amwiyok) (noun F) a sister of one’s husband. amwika ngin: that is a sister of my husband. [note: a) sister-in-law is called akamuran by the sister’s husband. b) the young sister of one’s husband is called amwi nadidi by the wife. c) elder sister of the husband is called toto by wife]. 
amwiiko (plural amwiikon) (noun F) a trowel. 
amwokol ko-o (transitive verb) (of a hedgehog or tortoise) to pull in or lower one’s head in anger; to draw in the head or hide the head (on account of fear); to introvert. aimwokolikin etau: to dishearten, discourage; to resent. 
amyedait (plural amyedai) (noun F) old time iron neck rings; an iron necklace. 
amyedakin ko-a (transitive verb) to strangle for or somewhere. (reflexive verb) to hang oneself; to commit suicide by hanging. 
amyedanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to belch; to retch; to feel like vomiting. 
amyedun akonye ko-a (transitive verb) to stare with eyes bulging with astonishment; to ogle or eyeball. 
amyeedu (plural amyeedun) (noun F) a big rope for holding bulls or for anything else (6-10 plaits). 
amyetar1 iwos ko-a (intransitive verb) to have flat buttocks. cp. animokok. 
amyetar2 ko-a (transitive verb) to consume (of anything); to finish. amyetasi ipejok inyamat kere: the visitors have finished all the food. 
-an (plural –ak) a noun suffix denoting agency: ekelipan (plural ikelipak): one who asks, prays, begs for; ekaanyanaran (plural ikaanyanarak): one who examines often; an examiner (ex professo) 
-ana (plural –aka) suffix of quality verbs or adjectives denoting habit - ilipana: she/he is fond of prayer, asking, begging. enyamana: she/he eats a lot or is a glutton. epeipeyana emaido kamisiri: the groundnut crop is sparse in the garden. esilyana aberu ngin: that woman is dirty always. cp. -on 
anaaga1 (plural anaagai) (noun F) (a music instrument) a harmonium; accordeon; mouth organ. 
anaaga2 (plural anaagai) (noun F) a shawl (as worn by Karimojong warriors), i.e. a sheet of cloth tied over the shoulder. 
anaaga3 (plural anaagai) (noun F) the larger of the cog-wheels of a bicycle (where the pedals are attached). cp. ekiiwa, epiororo. 
anaanar ko-o (reciprocal verb) to be comrades; to be friends; to be familiar to each other; to be devoted to each other. enaanara kesi noi: they are great friends. enaanaros kesi rwaru: they will be friends. 
anaanut1 (singular noun F) a habit; a routine; a practice; a tendency. cp. anaikinet
anaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to have the habit of. anaana ngesi akoko: she/he has the habit of stealing. 
anaaror ko-o (prepositional verb) to get into a habit. ikoto ijo anaaror adoteu: you are getting into the habit of having multiple sexual partners. 
anaasit (plural anaasin) (noun F) a nurse; a medical aid; a nursing sister 
anaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to become used to; to become acquainted with; to become familiar with; to become accustomed to. anaiki aberu ekeere: the wife has got familiar with her home. kinaikina oni: we know each other. 
anaikinet (plural anaikineta) (noun F) a habit; a second nature; a practice. cp. eipone: a custom. 
anaikinit ko-a (transitive verb) to be used to; to be acquainted; to be familiar with; to be devoted to; to be accustomed to. 
anait ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to; to be accustomed to; to be in the habit of. inait ijo apeg: you are inclined to argue. 
anakanar ko-a (transitive verb) to suck often. anakanar akwena: to laugh often.
anamo ko-o (transitive verb) to press down something hollow; to close or to fold (as of book, lips or paper). cp. aisuk, asukokin, 
anamoikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to close, press down; to fold (as of book or lips or paper). anamoiki ngesi eitaabo: she/he has closed the book. 
anamusiga (plural anamusigan) (noun F) a metal that holds the tyre of motorcar or bicycle; the part of a bicycle holding spokes on the outer side of a wheel, i.e. the rim. cp. ayooya.
anangakin ko-a (transitive verb) to beat or give a punch for or somewhere. anangakin akou: to bang the head against. (reflexive verb) to collide, crash; to box each other; to come across; to meet unexpectedly; to meet by accident. abu eong kanangakin nges: I met him unexpectedly; I collided with him. 
anangakinet (plural anangakineta) (noun F) a collision; a crash; an accident; a confrontation. 
anangan (plural anangak) (noun F) a boxer; a pugilist. anangan eguumi: a boxer; a pugilist. anangan emopiira: a basketball player.
ananganang ko-a (transitive verb) to beat about with the fists; to beat at random with fists. ananganang atenus: to beat a large drum with the fists. 
anangar ko-a (transitive verb) to knock down; to throw down. abu amotoka konanga ikoku korot: a motorcar knocked down a child on the road. anangar idowon: (euphemism) (of a person) to die.
ananget (plural anangeta) (noun F) a conclusion; a closure. 
anangirir ko-o (intransitive verb) to be thick, fat (as of a skin or bark of anything). inangirir emukule ngol, eroko epalal: that hide is very thick, it is not yet dry. 
anangit (plural anangin) (noun F) a small fish; a very small tilapia, Ngege haplochromis. 
anangun ko-a (transitive verb) to knock out or up (like knocking one awake or out of bed). 
anapakin ko-a (transitive verb) to dress for; to clothe for somebody; to give a lift (in a car or on a bicycle). 
anapar ko-a (transitive verb) to give a lift on a vehicle; to take away anything with a vehicle. konaparai eong oidukai: give me a lift to the shops. (reflexive verb) to go together on a vehicle. 
anapet (plural anapeta) (noun F) dress, cloth or skin with which to carry a child on the back. mam ikepi anapet eringa ikoku kidouno: (proverb) you do not make anapet before the baby is born – (Ateso equivalent of ‘do not count your chicks before they are hatched’.
anapi (plural anapin) (noun F) a small drinking calabash or half gourd; a plastic bowl for scooping water. 
anapit ko-o (intransitive verb) to dress; to be dressed in; to wear. enapit ngesi igoen: she/he is dressed in cloth: she/he wears cloth. 
anapito (plural noun F) clothes in general; apparel; attire; garb. apesur, konapete anapito namam eyauni ileic: girls, wear clothing that does not bring shame, embarrassment or ridicule. 
-anar a verbal suffix used with bi-syllabic –ar verbs to denote a repeated action away from the speaker. alemar: to remove or take away (once only); alemanar: to keep taking away (often). anyaraar: to call away (once only); anyaraanar: to keep calling away (often). 
anaranar ko-a (intransitive verb) to be shaking, springy, trembling; to thrill. 
anatar ko-a (intransitive verb) to remain quiet (transitive verb) to go carefully through one by one, calling out names one after another, i.e. to call a roll; to keep quiet and yet hear and understand what is being said or what is happening. anatar ekaru kere: to go through the whole year, month after month. konatas ikiroria: call out names. aso yesi kere konatasi: keep quiet all of you. 
anear ko-a (transitive verb) to push in or into; to push out; to intrude. koneata akwi ococot: push the grass or leaves into holes beside the anthill. (reflexive verb) to intrude; to push oneself forward; to project into. 
anebek ko-a (intransitive verb) to go or walk with a flexible body; to amble; to walk gracefully. 
anebekek ko-a (intransitive verb) to be flexible and soft, cosy, smooth. inebekek atenu ngin: that branch is soft and flexible. 
aneikin ko-a (transitive verb) to push in (something into a hole or people into a house); to constrain (by force); to crush. koneik itunga togo: congest the people into the house. (reflexive verb) to push oneself into a crowd or a small space. 
aneitoi1 (noun F) presumptiousness; temerity; audacity; impudence. 
aneitoi2 ko-o (transitive verb) to presume, to brave (even if there is opposition). 
anemar ko-o (reflexive verb) to rise and go at once; to rise and go promptly; to go at once on command; to obey instantly. konemar toma aswamukon: go at once to your work. cp. atepor.
anemesaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to step quickly away; to run off quickly and quietly. anemesaaros itunga aitudeng akim: people have run quickly to extinguish the fire. cp. anemar. 
anemesikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to dash at; to rush at; to jump at. anemesikin ikapa emir: the cat rushed at the rat. 
anemesun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come quickly and silently this way. 
anemitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to be hasty; to be in a hurry; to rush about. enemitoi ngesi toma aswam namam erai nake: she/he rushes to do the work which is not hers/his. 
anemun ko-a (reflexive verb) to get up quickly and come. cp. atepun. 
anepukuk ko-o (intransitive verb) to be soft; to be cosy, spongy, or downy. inepukukos igoen lu: these clothes are soft or downy. 
anerokin ko-o (transitive verb) to wish somebody good or bad; to claim, choose, select for. kanerokit eong ijo ajakaanut: I wish you to get a leadership position. kanerokinit eong ijo arereng: I wish you good luck. cp. akotor: to bless.
aneror ko-o (transitive verb) to claim and take away; to select and take away. anero ngesi akakokor: she/he claimed my hen and took it away. 
aneseikin ko-a (transitive verb) to lead into trouble; to treat badly; to maltreat; to chase into the bush. eneseikit ngesi akeberu: he is always maltreating his wife. aneseikin akonye: to hate. eneseikinit ngesi akeberu akonye: he hates his wife, or he cannot stand the sight of his wife. 
aneseun ko-a (transitive verb) to press upon; to crowd upon. (reflexive verb) to come in without permission; to come to attack, to rush to the attack. 
anesiar ko-o (reflexive verb) to enter without permission; to wander about; to go into; to scamper. aany eong nges enesiar okitui: I saw her/him running into the bush; I saw her/him scamper into the bush. 
anetokin ko-o (transitive verb) to serve somebody with a big quantity of (solid) food; to deal a heavy blow for somebody or somewhere; to clobber for somebody; to serve somebody (in general). konetokinoi eong ekesa ngol: clobber that fellow for me, give her/him a hammering. 
aneun1 ko-a (transitive verb) to compel; to force. kaneunit eong etengei ne: hunger has forced me this way. aneunos iponesio lueroko toma akwapuwok: bad customs have forced their way into our country.
aneun2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to intrude oneself; to push in towards the speaker; (of eyes) to protrude. aneun akonye: to protrude eyes.
angaar ko-a (transitive verb) to open wide; to open or put back (a curtain). angaar ekek: to open the door; to answer the door. angaar akituk: to open the mouth. cp. ailabaar.
angaarany (plural angaaranya) (noun F) a gap in teeth resulting from unintentional or accidental removal of teeth; a notch. 
angaarwe (plural angaarwei) (noun F) a gland in the armpit, neck or groin; a lymph gland; a swelling in the groin. adeka naka angaarwei: east coast fever (a disease of cattle spread by ticks). 
angabar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go (as one with thin buttocks and wide hip-bones). angabararat: to be with thin buttocks and wide hip-bones; to run (as one with thin buttocks and wide hip-bones does).
angabet (plural angabes) (noun F) the waist; the loin; the small of the back. 
angabinyaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go away with one’s thin buttocks and bow-legs; to slip away swaying or in an excited manner. 
angabinyiny ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a small person) to have flat buttocks and bow legs. 
angabu ko-o (transitive verb) to sprain or twist (somebody’s leg or arm); to dislocate. 
angabuikin ko-o (transitive verb) to sprain somebody else’s leg or arm, etc; to contort.(reflexive verb) to be sprained, twisted or bruised. 
angabuor ko-o (intransitive verb) (of an ankle) to twist away from speaker. 
angac (plural angacia) (noun F) (in Karamoja) a venereal disease (in general).
angacar ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a fat wide-hipped woman) to walk nude or naked; (of a fat wide-hipped woman) to be scantily dressed; (of a woman wearing see-through dress) to move about with no nickers on (in full view of many people). cp. animok, angecer.
angaet (plural angaeta) (noun F) a door-knob; the locking or opening mechanism of anything. 
angaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to open for. angaikin erot: to allow to come or to go; to open the way. angaikin akiro: to open the conversation; to speak out; to open one’s heart. cp. agear akiro. 
angajep (plural angajepa) (noun F) a tongue (the taste organ in the mouth); language; dialect. angajep naka akwara: a pen nib. angajep kakim: a flame. kimyelu angajep: push out your tongue. ejai ngesi angajep: she/he has a tongue, i.e. she/he gives away secrets (by being talkative); she/he has a bad tongue (i.e. fond of using abusive or obscene language). 
angalakimak (adverb) in the south; to the south; southerly; southern.
angale ko-a (intransitive verb) to be well; to be healthy. angalei eong: I am well. ingaleete yesi?: are you well? eebo, kingalei: yes, we are well. 
angaleikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to get better health-wise; to be fat; to become fit; to become healthy, improve in health. angaleki akonijimi?: is your sore or wound better? 
angaleu (singular noun F) health; the state of health. edit angaleuke: her/his health is poor: she/he is in poor health. 
angaleun ko-o (intransitive verb) to recover from illness by oneself; (of a wound) to heal; to recuperate; to become better. 
angalom ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a gap (in the teeth). ingalomi ijo ai?: where are you going with your gaping teeth?
angalomom ko-o (intransitive verb) to have few teeth left; to have a gap (between teeth or anything). ingalomom akonibwas: your fence has gaps. 
anganga ko-a (intransitive verb) to fuss about; to do in a hurry; to be too anxious; to like to do something and find it impossible. engangat ngesi alosit: she/he is anxious to go; she/he is in a hurry to go. 
angangaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to rush away or run away anxiously.
angangakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to rush at blindly; to do blindly. angangakinos ingokwo amaria akoit: the dogs have rushed blindly to fight for the bone. 
angangamit (plural angangam) (noun F) gravel soil. cp. engarot, ekokot. 
anganganakin ko-a (transitive verb) to try hard; (of food) to eat quickly; to gorge; to gourmandise (with ainyam). (reflexive verb) to be anxious to do or go; to do in a hurry. anganganakin eong agwel egoe, kwabo erono: I bought this cloth in a hurry, and found it is bad. 
angangat ko-o (intransitive verb) to be very anxious to do; to be eager to do, solicitous, try in vain the impossible. engangat ngesi alosit: she/he is very anxious to go. 
angangatoi (intransitive verb) to be over-zealous; to be over-anxious, bumptious, agog, avid, solicitous, or temerarious. engangatoi ngesi toma aswamusinei nuipu: she/he is anxious to try all kinds of work. 
angangatonut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be inclined to hurry. 
anganit (plural anganin) (noun F) a bunch of grain selected for seeds; choice seeds. cp. egegit.
anganyanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to lie, loll, sprawl carelessly while exposing the bottoms. 
anganyar ko-a (intransitive verb) to make a gap or opening; to lift something in order to look what is underneath; to remove, to push away and look for. konganya anya ngun, ejai emir toma: remove that sheaf of grass, there is a rat underneath. anganyar akeje: to kick into space (i.e. to miss the ball); to sit with legs spread out; to lift one’s foot or leg too high and reveal private parts. 
anganyit akonye (intransitive verb) to have eyes wide open; to stare; to look fierce; to threaten. 
anganyun ko-a (intransitive verb) to reveal; to find out; to discover a lost thing; to recover a thing lost somewhere; to unearth. abu eong kanganyu ekanusu: I found my shilling hidden within. (reflexive verb) to come out from a hiding place; to appear after a long absence. anganyun akiro: to reveal a secret.
angar (noun F) hatred; dislike; animosity. 
angar ko-a (transitive verb) to hate; to dislike; to despise; to detest. engara ngesi akeberu: he hates and beats his wife.
angarabab ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a complete set of teeth. cp. angarebeb. 
angarany (plural angaranya) (noun F) a gap (in the hedge or between teeth, etc). ejai ijo angarany: you have a gap between your teeth. (intransitive verb) to have a gap. ingaranyany ijo: you have a gap in your teeth. 
angarin (plural noun F) a constellation also called the Plough. 
angaromit (plural angarom) (noun F) red stony soil; gravel. 
angasab ko-a (transitive verb) to gorge food, eat quickly. 
angasabaar ko-a (transitive verb) to bite off a big piece or lump. angasabaa ekingok akakiring: the dog bit off a large piece of my meat. 
angasabab ko-a (intransitive verb) to laugh with the mouth wide open, i.e. to laugh heartily. angasababat eong, engasababatos kesi: I am, they are laughing heartily. engasababat ngesi akwena: she/he laughs with open mouth; she/he is having a hearty laugh. 
angasianakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to try repeatedly, but ineffectually; to start again and again. 
angasiep (plural angasiepa) (noun F) a placenta; an afterbirth. cp. amoit
angasikin ko-o (reflexive verb) (with negative connotations) to volunteer hurriedly; to try, start to do in a hurry (without much planning or thought); (of rain) to threaten. angasikinos itelepai alosit ojie: the boys volunteered to go to war (without thinking of the risks they are putting themselves into). sirikingasikin aiwadik eitaabo komuno aikamun enyadu katipet: do not rush to write a book with the hope of getting rich quickly.
angasingas ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very big; to be gigantic; to be awe-inspiring. 
angat ko-a (transitive verb) to want; to like; to desire; to wish for. angata eong alosit ore: I want to go home. engatunit edou: it wants to rain; rain is threatening. cp. akot.
angatar ko-a (transitive verb) to rob and take away; to pillage; to raid. 
angatun ko-a (transitive verb) to rob and bring; (of rain) to threaten. 
angatuny (plural angatunyo) (noun F) a lioness; a brave woman; a woman member of the Lionesses Club.
angatunyoit (plural angatunyo) (noun F) (formerly) a bullet; a lead shot. cp. emuudu 
angaun ko-a (transitive verb) to admit; to allow to come in; to open the door and allow someone to come in.(reflexive verb) to be admitted; to come out (of cows); to come in. angaunos akituk: the cows have broken out (from the kraal). 
angeberaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go with a miniskirt or short trousers somewhere. 
angeberer ko-a (intransitive verb) (of dress, cloth, or trousers) to be short. 
angecel (plural angecelin) (noun F) a natural gap between a person’s lower incisor teeth.
angecer ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a thin wide-hipped person) to walk nude or naked; (of a slender woman) to be scantily dressed; to move about like a ghost. cp. aceger.
angecerer ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very thin (after illness) or (of a thin person) to be naked. cp. acegerer: to stand with thighs wide apart (being weak and thin, or naked); (of house) to stand with unplastered sticks. adum eong ekatogo ingecerer: I found my hut not yet plastered. 
angeda (plural angedas) ko-a (intransitive verb) (of rope or thread) to snap, break; (of a crowd) to break up. angedas itunga kotoma atenus: the people ran away from the (drum) dance. angeda eipaperone: the friendship is broken. angeda ekatau: my heart is broken. cp. aduo.
angedakin ko-o (reflexive verb) (of something chained, tied, or linked) to escape or to break loose. 
angedar ko-a (transitive verb) to break off; to snatch away, disrupt, pull or tear apart. angeda ngesi atipeka: she/he snatched away my beads. 
angedengedeun ko-o (reflexive verb) (of anything sewn or stitched) to become worn out (by itself). angedengedeunos akamuk: my shoes are worn out (threads have snapped). 
angedun ko-a (transitive verb) to break off this way. (reflexive verb) to separate oneself with difficulty. angedun eong kore: I tore myself away from home. 
angeemait (plural angeema) (noun F) the faecal remnants on the uncleaned anus; the anus.
angeemem ko-a (intransitive verb) (of food) to be gritty. 
angejepanut1 (singular noun F) stammering; lisping; stuttering. 
angejepanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to lisp; to stammer; to stutter. epol nges angajepanut: she/he lisps or stammers very much. 
angelakin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut off or break off a big piece (as of an earthenware pot, a ceramic utensil or bread). (reflexive verb) to fall off, break off (by itself). angelakin amot orot: a big piece of the pot broke off on the way. 
angelar ko-a (transitive verb) to bite off (a piece of anything). 
angelejaar ko-a (transitive verb) to bite off a big piece (as of half-ready mango); to make a wound bigger. abu ekingok kongeleja akakeju: the dog bit off a big lump of my leg. (reflexive verb) (of wound) to become very much bigger. 
angelengel ko-a (transitive verb) to tell tall stories; to cut or bite into big pieces. 
angelun ko-o (reflexive verb) to break off and bring. angelun amot: a piece of the pot has come off. 
angengear ko-o (reflexive verb) to become rough, coarse, harsh. koyau apapula naengenge: bring some sandpaper. engenge etunganan ngol: that man is a ruffian, a barbarian. aitengengear: to make coarse, harsh, rough. 
angengeu1 (noun F) roughness; coarseness; discourtesy; asperity; austerity. 
angengeu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be rough; to be coarse (like sandpaper). 
angereb ikel ko-a (transitive verb) to make noise with teeth; to grind teeth. angereb: to crush hard food with teeth (as of dried potatoes or popcorn). 
angerep (plural angerepo) (noun F) a kind of anthill from which white ants (called ingerepo) fly in the morning (about 7:00am). 
angerer ko-a (transitive verb) to cut open fish; to cut into strips; to shred. 
angereriar ko-a (transitive verb) to tear completely; to rip. (reflexive verb) to be completely torn. angereriar ekasaati: my shirt is completely torn. 
angerokin ko-o (transitive verb) to refuse to somebody something or somewhere; to rebel against. (reflexive verb) to mortify oneself; to refuse one another; to separate (in marriage); to fall out with each other; to be at loggerheads. cp. agirokin. 
angeronut1 (singular noun F) fondness to refuse; stubbornly refusing; rebelliousness. 
angeronut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be used to objecting; to be stubbornly refusing or rebelling. 
angerun ko-a (transitive verb) to cut (grass or hair) and bring; to mow. alosi eong angerun anya: I am going to cut some grass. 
angeruno ko-o (transitive verb) to refuse to give. angeruno ngesi ekakalaamu: she/he refuses to return my pencil or she/he refuses to give me my pencil. 
angesan (plural angesak) (noun F) suddenness. adeka naka angesan: a sudden illness; epidemic. atwanare naka engeso: sudden death. 
angesanar ko-a (transitive verb) to take often unawares; to surprise often. engesanari kwana atwanare itunga kobuku kangol: many people die suddenly these days in that county. 
angesar ko-a (transitive verb) to surprise; to come upon unawares, take a thing before somebody has had a chance. abu eong kangesa ekokolan: I took the thief by surprise. abu eong kadum itunga kedautu angesar akimai: I arrived when the millet was sold. engesarit nges atwanare: she/he has died suddenly. angesa nges adeka: she/he fell ill suddenly. (reflexive verb) to die suddenly; to go early. cp. atular.
angeset (plural angeseta) (noun F) the end; a place where something happens suddenly. 
angesun ko-a (transitive verb) to do all of a sudden; to befall on suddenly; to take by surprise; to surprise. kingesutu yesi eong: you have taken me by surprise. (reflexive verb) to arrive suddenly; to come suddenly; to happen unexpectedly, casually. angesun akiro: to say quickly; to say unexpectedly; to improvise. kongesu atipet: say it quickly. ngai angesu?: who said it so quickly? ngesi angesu: she/he said it. 
angetakin ko-a (transitive verb) to complete for; to finish for; to finish off; to achieve. (reflexive verb) to come to an end; to be finished. angetakin akaswam: my work is finished; my work is over. 
angetet (plural angeteta) (noun F) the end; the limit. cp. asanget, angeset: the end. esange: the extremity; the finish. ameun kageunet aitodol angetet: from the beginning to the end; from the first to the last. 
angeyaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become worse; to flare up; to get excited. angeyaar akim: the fire flares up. angeyaar atap: the atap has become very thin. angeyaar ajimi: the wound has become very big. angeyaaros akiro: the case has become worse. angeyaar etauka: I am very annoyed. cp. akwear.
angianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to face bravely; to bear bravely; to suffer bravely. cp. atitingikin. 
angianar ko-a (transitive verb) to show teeth often; to show teeth repeatedly.(reflexive verb) to show teeth as sign of indifference, carelessness. 
angiar ko-a (transitive verb) to show; to disclose; to uncover. kongia ikonikel ngina: show your teeth the other way (not to me)(an insult). 
angibirir ko-a (intransitive verb) to run fast; to be fast; to run like mad. 
angibiriranut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fast (in running); to be a fast runner. ingibirirana ijo: you run fast (plural ingibiriraka yesi). 
angibiririt ko-a (intransitive verb) to be running very fast. 
angibiriruun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come running quickly. kongibiriruun lailo: run quickly this way. 
angicakin ko-a (transitive verb) to find out for someone else, or to find, discover somewhere. koyanga kongicak kangina: take it and examine it closely over there. 
angican (plural angicak) (noun F) a spy; a detective; inspector; scrutiniser; searcher. 
angicar ko-a (transitive verb) to discover and take away; to find and take away; to go and find out. 
angicun ko-a (transitive verb) to find out for oneself, examine for oneself; to discover for oneself; to detect. angicun ediini: to learn religion well. kengicu ngesi ekediini: she/he knows her/his religion well (she/he learnt her/his religion well). 
angiikin ko-a (transitive verb) to show teeth to; to pull faces (in pain); to grin and bear. kangiiki eong ekingok ikel: the dog bared me its teeth (a threat). abu eong kangiik ikacan: I gnashed and bore my troubles. 
angiingiit ko-a (intransitive verb) to keep showing teeth; to fawn on; to grin continuously. engiingiit apese kede ikiliok: the girl is smiling lecherously with men (as a loose woman does). 
angiingiitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to grin; to go about laughing foolishly; to simper, smile in a silly way. inyo bo ingiingiitor ijo?: why this silly laughing? 
angiirit (plural angiirito) (noun F) the gum (flesh around the teeth); the palate. 
angiit ko-o (intransitive verb) to grin, smile (usually in a silly manner). 
angimakin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut a small piece or a little for somebody; to beat lightly. kongimakinai akiring: cut me a small piece of meat. 
angimar ko-a (transitive verb) to cut off a small piece. 
angimun ko-a (transitive verb) to cut a small piece for oneself; to nibble at. (reflexive verb) to come off in small pieces; to break off in small pieces; to crumble off. 
anginamam ko-a (transitive verb) (of a person or animal) to have no teeth. 
anginga ko-a (transitive verb) to rub the eyes because they are itching. kinyek anginga akonye: stop rubbing your eyes.
angingaun ko-a (transitive verb) to bring out from a hiding place (of anything); to take something out of the eye by rubbing. (reflexive verb) to come from a hiding place; to appear. angingaun do ngesi: she/he has made her/his appearance. 
angingiikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to be too blunt for (cutting something). angingiiki ekileng lo akiring na: this knife is too blunt to cut this meat. 
angingior ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a knife, axe, etc) to become blunt. angingioros aepei nu: these machetes have become blunt. 
angingitor ko-o (transitive verb) to deride, gibe, or grin. 
angingiu1 (singular noun F) bluntness (of a knife, an axe, etc). 
angingiu2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a knife, an axe, etc) to be blunt 
angiol (plural angiol) (noun F) a woman with protruding teeth; anything protruding. 
angiolol ko-a (intransitive verb) (of teeth or anything) to be protruding; to have a harelip; to have protruding (teeth). cp. angisolol. 
angirabab ko-a (intransitive verb) (of teeth or of teeth of saw; of hoe or knife edge) to be chipped; (of teeth) to be broken. 
angiribib ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a set of small teeth; (of teeth) to be jagged. ingiribibas ikonikel: your teeth are short and small.cp. angarabab. 
angirijanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to gnash the teeth (with pain). engirijanakini ngesi ikel kanuka ariebo: she/he gnashes her/his teeth with pain. cp. akonyanakin ikel. 
angirikin ko-o (transitive verb) to suffer bravely; to endure; to bear; to be patient with, be determined; to dare. angirikinit eong adeka na: I am enduring this sickness. 
angirikinet (plural angirikineta) (noun F) endurance; sufferance; staying power; stamina. 
angiriony (plural angiriony) (noun F) a woman with a bruised face; a woman with broken teeth.
angirionyikin ko-o (transitive verb) to fall forward (of a person or animal); to throw headlong and break the teeth. (reflexive verb) to fall forward and injure the mouth; to bruise the face by falling forward. 
angirionyony ko-a (intransitive verb) (of face) to be bruised; (of teeth) to be broken. 
angirit (plural angirito) (noun F) a palate; gums of teeth. 
angironyor ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall forward; to die suddenly. 
angisibib ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a child) to laugh; to smile; to grin. engisibibit ikoku eanyuni totoke: the child grins on seeing its mother. 
angisolol ko-a (intransitive verb) to have protruding teeth (that do not allow the lips to close). cp. angiolol.
angiun ko-a (transitive verb) to show teeth; to rise or show light (of sun). (reflexive verb) to become visible; to appear; (of teeth) to be bare. 
angoanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to mash often for; to become often angry with each other; to be often angry with. 
angobar ko-a (transitive verb) to drink (thick food, etc making a slobbering noise). angobar: to drink at one go.
angobun ko-a (intransitive verb) to sip little (something thick). angobun ajo: to sleep a little; to doze a little. angobun sarab: to drink noisily. 
angodial (adverb) the left. (noun F) left hand, leg, etc. akeju nangodial (noun F) left foot. lok’ongodial (noun M) the one on the left. longodial: a left-handed man; a southpaw. 
angodidi (plural angodidiak) (noun F) a Coucal bird. 
angoes (plural angoesia) (noun F) a place or pot in which food is stirred; the implement (spoon, stick, ladle) with which to stir. 
angoet (plural angoeta) (noun F) a stick for stirring (porridge, atap, etc); a paddle or an oar for rowing a boat or canoe. cp. alutukony. 
angoid ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk like a lion or king; to strut or walk proudly; to swagger or swank. cp. aingo ekori.
angoikin ko-a (transitive verb) to mingle atap for; to mash food for; to get angry with; to get cross with; to get annoyed with. (reflexive verb) to become enemies; to fall out with one another. angoikinos kesi: they have become enemies: they fell out with one another. cp. anyunyurikin.
angoit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be annoyed; to be vexed; to be angry. 
angokwaanut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very poor. ainyam naka angokwaanut: to lead a dog’s life; to live from hand to mouth. 
Angole1 (noun F) a pet name for a black cow with a white patch on its face. 
angole2 (plural angolei) (noun F) a head injury; a bald patch on the head; a scar on the head (after a blow).
angole3 akide (plural angolei akide) (noun F) a species of eagle - a black crested eagle (looks to the east or west in response to a person’s call). 
angole4 angor (plural angolei angor) (noun F) a species of bird, wattle starling. 
angolemoru (plural angolemoruo) (noun F) a mountain pigeon. cp. alolouro
angolemuge (plural angolemugei) (noun F) a lulu bird. 
angolengol ko-o (intransitive verb) to look around; to look from side to side. kinyek angolengol kokeresia: do not look around in the cathedral. 
angoleonut ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a bald patch (on the head) or a scar on the head after a blow. 
angoleun1 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of fruit) to become yellow; to ripen, be nearly ripe. 
angoleun2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to look this way; to eskew. kongoleutu lailo: look this way (plural). 
angoli ko-a (intransitive verb) to look; to glance; to beware; to look out (rarely used in infinitive and present indicative, instead say angoliar, angoleun, angolengol). 
angolianakin ko-a (transitive verb) to look around constantly; to have a good look at; to keep looking at, glancing at often.(reflexive verb) to look at one another. 
angoliar ko-a (transitive verb) to behold; to see; to look round at; to look away (reflexive verb) to behold or look at one another. 
angolikin ko-a (transitive verb) to look at, glance at, look round at. kongolikinai eong: look at me. (adverb) behold. 
angoliun ko-a (transitive verb) to look this way; to glance this way. 
angolol (plural angololin) (noun F) a lake; a sea; a broad river; an ocean. 
angolop ko-a (transitive verb) to take amiss; to take offence; to be annoyed. abu eong kebap ikoku, kongolopi totoke: I slapped the child and the mother took it amiss. 
angolopa1 (singular noun F) a disagreement; a quarrel; a verbal conflict (without physical fighting). epol angolopa kangina: there is a lot of quarrelling over there: they have many squabbles. angolopa tai: to bicker. angolopa naka angor: the squabbling of women (especially co-wives).
angolopa2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be quarrelling; to be squabbling; to find fault; to have a row; to altercate, contend. engolopas kesi apaarasia kere: they are always quarrelling.
angolopanakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be constantly quarrelling with one another. 
angolopanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become quarrelsome; to be regular quarrellers. (intransitive verb) to quarrel with one another. 
angolopanut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be quarrelsome; to be fond of quarrelling, squabbling. 
angolopar ko-a (transitive verb) to quarrel because; to squabble about; to have a row about. kinyekis angolopar ikakoku: stop arguing over my child. 
angolopikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to pick up a quarrel; to start a squabble, a row. ikoto ijo angolopikin ka eong: you want to start quarrelling with me. (reflexive verb) to get into a quarrel; to begin to quarrel. 
angoloror ko-o (reflexive verb) to have a cataract in the eye. ingoloror ngesi: she/he has a cataract in her/his eyes. 
angon ko-a (intransitive verb) to be proud; to strut; to walk like a lion; to have a high opinion of oneself; to walk slowly; to saunter. engonas itelepai lu: these boys walk like peacocks. cp. angoid.
angonakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to feel proud; to swagger; to realise one’s importance; to start to walk with a proud gait.
angoobe (plural angoobei) (noun F) a horn of a car or motor cycle. aicikakin angoobe: to press the horn. akutakin angoobe: to blow the horn. cp. arupepe, ekeegere.
angooresia (noun F) dried up drool, i.e. saliva around the mouth and cheeks during sleep. cp. ajotoet
angoorit (plural angoorito) (noun F) the last-born girl child. cp. akiyai.
angopes (plural angopesia) (noun F) a hiding place; a refuge; safe haven; sanctuary; asylum; bolt hole; harbour. cp. angopet, angopis
angopet (plural angopeta) (noun F) a hiding place; a refuge; safe haven; sanctuary; asylum; bolt hole; harbour. cp. angopes, angopis
angopikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be hidden to; to be a mystery to; to be too learned; to be too difficult to understand; to be beyond one; to lurk. angopikis kes akiro ngun: it was above their understanding; it was beyond them. (transitive verb) to ambush; to lie in wait for; to waylay. abu engatuny kangopik eong: the lion laid an ambush for me. angopikinit itunganan: to do something and not tell someone; to go behind someone's back. angopikin aswam: to dodge work. 
angopis (plural angopisia) (noun F) a hiding place; a refuge; safe haven; sanctuary; asylum; bolt hole; harbour. cp. angopet, angopes
angopit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be hiding; to be hidden, abstruse. angopit dii di: to be completely hidden. cp. aibwait ikinyom. 
angor (plural of aberu) (noun F) women; females; wives. 
angorit (collective noun F) a crowd of women. 
angorokin ko-o (transitive verb) to gorge food; to overeat. cp. arongokin. 
angorom (adjective) ochre; yellowish-brown; orangey; tawny; orange colour. 
angorom (singular noun F) brown stony soil; murram; a place having yellowish-brown soil. 
angoronyony ko-a (intransitive verb) to be dirty (with earth, mud or road dust). ingoronyonyas idwe: the children are dirty (with dust). 
angoror ko-o (transitive verb) to miss (food or anything); to happen in one’s absence; to be lost to. kangorosi eong inyamat: the food was finished during my absence (literally, the food missed me). 
angorot (singular noun F) old millet grain (from the previous harvest). cp. agwei.
angosibib1 (singular noun F) honour; glory; dignity; lustre; majesty; renown. epejonon lokangosibib: a male guest of honour. apejonon nakangosibib: a female guest of honour.
angosibib2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be honourable; to be glorious, look dignified; to be awe-inspiring. epol angosibib: eminent; estimable. ingosibibos ijaka ngul: those chiefs look dignified. 
angosobob ko-a (intransitive verb) to have protruding teeth; to be toothy. 
angosolol ko-o (intransitive verb) to have protruding teeth due to a harelip. 
angosoorot (plural angosooron) (noun F) a branch or leaf of engosoorot tree. 
angoti (singular noun F) leprosy; skin cancer; chronic ulcer. angoti n’atom: nodular leprosy. 
angu (plural anguon) (noun F) a man-eating lion. 
angubokin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut off a piece for somebody. cp. atubokin. 
angubonokin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut off piece after piece for somebody. 
angubor ko-o (transitive verb) to cut away a little. 
angubungubet (plural angubungubeta) (noun F) a piece of something or anything; something incomplete. angubungubet naka acokit: a piece of a potato. cp. atutubet.
anguc (plural angucio) (noun F) a bridle. 
angucoit (plural angucio) (noun F) a natural gap in the side teeth. cp atoet – natural upper; agilo: not natural lower. 
angularar ko-a (intransitive verb) to be maimed or crippled. 
angularikin ko-a (transitive verb) to make too short (by cutting); to maim; to cripple. (reflexive verb) to become or be short; to be maimed or crippled. 
anguletait (plural anguleta) (noun F) a piece cut off.cp. atubetait. 
angulor ko-o (transitive verb) to cut off and take away. cp. atubor. 
angulot (plural anguloi) (noun F) a female leper; a maimed woman (with a limb or part of a limb cut off).
angulungul ko-o (transitive verb) to cut up into pieces; to amputate; to mangle; to dismember. 
angulutuny (plural angulutunyo) (noun F) stump of hand; stump of foot. 
angung ko-a (intransitive verb) to grumble; to growl, grouse. 
angungakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to disagree with; to become enemies; to fall out with; to be angry with; to dissent. angungakinos aberu k’okilenike: the wife fell out with her husband. 
angurub ko-o (transitive verb) to eat something hard; to crunch; to munch; to eat hard food. engurubi ngesi amukeke: she/he munches dried potatoes. 
angurubikin ko-o (transitive verb) to crunch; to bite a hard object; to munch (once only). 
angurubub ko-o (intransitive verb) to have sores around the mouth. 
anguruc ko-a (transitive verb) to munch something rubbery. enguruci ikoku amopiira kocupa lo akile: the child is biting the rubber teat of the feeding bottle.
anguurian ko-a (transitive verb) to complain; to be jealous of; to show dissatisfaction; to be discontent; to grumble. enguuriani ngesi ikenyamat: she/he is complaining about her/his food (too little or eaten by someone else). 
angwalit ko-a (intransitive verb) to be crippled; to be lame. 
angwalu (singular noun F) a permanent defect (as harelip, one eye, born blind, etc); lameness; being a cripple; deformity; disability. 
ani? interrogative relative pronoun feminine singular referring to feminine nouns: which one? where? (plural anu?: Where are they? which ones?) aberu bo ani ibala ijo?: which woman do you mean? ani bo akine?: where is the goat? cp. ali?: for masculine nouns. 
anibikik ko-o (intransitive verb) to be nice and soft to lay a hand on. inibikikos igoen lu: these clothes are nice and soft to touch. 
anibinib ko-o (intransitive verb) to look nice; to look beautiful; to look nice and green; to look fine. ejok aite akimai enibinibete: it is nice to look at the verdant (lush green) millet crop in the field. enibinibete akonikonye: you have a fine complexion (facial appearance). 
anicikik ko-a (intransitive verb) to be compact, finely woven; to be finely plaited (of cloth, mat, or rope); to be thick, as of mortar (a mixture of sand, cement or lime and water). 
anielet ko-a (transitive verb) to smear on; to plaster. anielesi eong ekume arwatat: I am smearing mucous on the wall. enielesete kesi aoret orite: they are smearing cow-dung on the winnow.
anieletikin ko-a (transitive verb) to plaster or smear on or somewhere. tiki tiki, kinyek anieletikin ekume ogoe!: gosh, don’t smear mucous on the dress!
aniemakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to go stealthily or on tiptoe to something; to stalk; to catch by surprise. kaniemakinos ber oni ekesa ngol: let us go quietly after that fellow (let us catch him by surprise). cp. acedakin. 
anieret ko-a (transitive verb) to smear on; to plaster. cp. anielet.
anieretikin ko-a (transitive verb) to plaster or smear on or somewhere. cp. anieletikin. 
aniikin ko-o (transitive verb) to dent or dint or pierce by pressure (as of foot by stepping on gravel); to hurt by pressing. kaniiki eong engarot akeju: a bit of gravel hurt my foot. 
aniikinet (plural aniikineta) (noun F) a dent; dint; a dimple; a damage; indentation; a hollow; a dip; an impression. 
animok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a girl or woman with small buttocks and narrow hips) to move about naked and exposing one’s private parts; (of a narrow-hipped woman) to wear no nickers. cp. alidok.
animokok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a woman or girl) to have small or tiny buttocks and narrow hips. cp. aripidid.
anina ko-a (transitive verb) to rub vigorously between hands (as one rubbing grains out of cob or fried/roasted groundnuts to remove husks); to have a rubdown of the body. akoto aninaanar akuwan: I want to have a rubdown. 
aninaanar ko-a (transitive verb) to rub off dirt, etc; to unhusk fried groundnuts, etc. 
aninaar ko-a (transitive verb) to rub off (once), as of fine shell from fried groundnuts. (reflexive verb) to rub oneself; to have a rubdown. 
aninaaret (plural aninaareta) (noun F) attrition, abrasion; a rubdown, massage, manipulation, reflexology. 
aninaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to rub in (as of oil onto the skin). 
aninikaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become tough, become hard. aninikaar etau: the heart has become brave, courageous, hardy. aitininik etau: to harden one’s heart. aitininik: to harden; to toughen. 
aniniku1 (singular noun F) toughness; hardiness; fortitude; endurance; constancy. 
aniniku2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be tough. aniniku naka etau: hardheartedness. 
anionokin ko-a (transitive verb) to dent repeatedly or make many dents. anionoki ngesi akamotoka: she/he badly dented my car. 
anior ko-o (transitive verb) to push down (food stuck in the throat, being pushed down by drinking) or push back (a protruding object). (reflexive verb) to go down; to be pressed down. anior acokit na nan kamyedit eong: the potato, that choked me, has gone down. 
aniosit (plural anion) (noun F) a dint; a dent; impression; indentation. 
anironut ko-o (intransitive verb) to have the property or quality of giving a satiating feeling (as of honey, fat or butter). 
Ankole (noun F) the land of the Banyankole people; the former kingdom ruled by the Omugabe (king); the present day Uganda districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo.
anoikin ko-o (transitive verb) to make a dent; to press in; to cut into (as of narrow finger ring). (reflexive verb) to be pressed in; to be hollow (as of cheeks); to be falling in; to have a dip. enoikino nges ikitinyo: her/his cheeks are sunken. 
anokiar ko-a (intransitive verb) to burn out or down. anokiasi akito: the firewood has burnt out (without anything being done with the fire). 
anokit ko-o (transitive verb) to be continually posing a threat on; to be harassing; to be near; to be close by (somebody or something). 
anomonor ko-o (transitive verb) to keep scorching. kanomono eong akolong k’orot: the sun kept scorching me on the way. 
anomor ko-o (transitive verb) to scorch; to burn; to build (a house); to pain; to be concerned about; to hurt (one cannot stand). enomorit nges aberu: he worries about his wife. kanomo eong akolong: the sun is scorching me. anomor etogo: to build a very nice house. kanomorit eong ikakoku ibungao: it hurts me to see my child being beaten. cp. apipilikin.
anomorit ko-o (transitive verb) to keep hurting; to give pain; to pain one. kanomorit eong atwanare naka totoka: the death of my mother pains me very much. 
anomot (plural anomota) (noun F) a burnt out place or plain. 
anonok1 (noun F) weakness; tenderness; ripeness, etc. 
anonok2 ko-a (transitive verb) to be soft, tender; to be weak, flimsy, flexible, yielding, overripe, easy, limp. enonok akuwan: the body is weak. 
anonokaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become soft, pliable, weak, flexible, languid, bendable; to yield, give in, stop trying to do something (because you are not strong enough, etc). anonokiar etau: to become obedient, pliable, amenable, docile. anonokaar akapet leje lej: the hide is now very soft.
anoono ko-o (transitive verb) to make many dents on; to dent repeatedly. inoonoit ijo akakopiira: you badly crumpled my hat. 
anoonokin ko-o (transitive verb) to keep denting something; to keep pressing and hurting. kanoonokis eong ingaroi: the gravel keep hurting (my feet when I tread on them). cp. anionokin.
anooti (plural anootin) (noun F) a banknote; paper money or currency note. 
anuikin ko-a (transitive verb) to press on or against; to kiss; to osculate. abu Yuda konuik Yesu, kidupori nges: Judas betrayed Jesus by kissing Him. 
anuikinet (plural anuikineta) (noun F) a kiss; a peck. 
anuk1 (plural anukia) (noun F) a sty or a pen for goats or sheep. cp. auj 
anuk2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to stay inside or indoors (of men or animals). enukas kesi kotogo duc: they always stay inside the house. 
anuka ko-a (transitive verb) to fold up or crumple (cloth, paper or anything); to eat something tough (like leather or tough meat). enukai ekingok emukule: the dog eats the tough hide. 
anukaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to dent once; to crook; to crinkle up; to crunch; to fold together (as of mat); to bend over (as of nail when being hammered down). konukaik emukeeka ngol: roll up that mat. (reflexive verb) to bend, roll up itself. anukaikin ekameleku: my hoe has bent itself (after hitting something hard). kanukaiki eong amojongu kwap: I am stooped by old age. 
anukakin ko-a (transitive verb) to bury somewhere; to fill a hole somewhere or for somebody. (reflexive verb) to stay somewhere for a long time (literally, to bury oneself). alot ngesi anukakin oidukai: she/he has gone to the shops and stayed there (literally, she/he has gone to bury herself/himself at the shops). 
anukar ko-a (prepositional verb) to stay with; to take and keep a thing for too long a time. inyo bo inukar ijo ekakalaamu?: why do you keep my pencil (borrowed from me)? 
anukio (singular noun F) a burial; interment; funeral. 
anukur ko-o (transitive verb) to roll up; (of one’s statement) to bend or fold up; to twist, not to be straightforward. anukur akiro: to twist words. 
anukurikin ko-o (transitive verb) to roll up; to fold up; to fold together. konukurik emukeeka ngol koyanga: fold up that mat and take it away. (reflexive verb) to roll up itself; to wind up itself; to coil up itself; to bend up; to cuddle. anukurikin etogo: to build a small round hut. anukurikin apupu: the hedgehog has rolled up itself. cp. anunukikin. 
anumuk ko-a (transitive verb) to eat something soft, floury, spongy (like a potato or cake). anumuki eong acokit: I am eating a nice soft potato. 
anunuk ko-o (transitive verb) to fold or crumple up. cp. anukur. 
anunuket (plural anunuketa) (noun F) a fold; a crease. 
anunukon (plural anunukok) (noun F) a person who folds or creases. 
anunukonokin ko-a (transitive verb) to entangle; to mix up; to twist (words). inunukonok ijo akapapulai: you have crumpled my papers. (reflexive verb) to be entangled; (of words) to be twisted; to be mixed up. anunukonokinos akirokon: your case is mixed up. 
anunut1 (singular noun F) silkiness (of complexion); softness (of skin); smoothness; velvetiness (of feel). 
anunut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person’s skin) to be smooth, even, velvetty, or silky. 
anupakin ko-a (transitive verb) to listen to; to obey; to hearken; to believe. sirikinupak nuineras lukasabak: do not take any notice of what liers say. 
anwac (singular noun F) an enlarged spleen (malady). 
anwokorikin ko-a (reflexive verb) (of a person) to double up or fold up as if feeling pain in the stomach; to collapse or to crumple (as if in great pain).
anwomok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a toothless person) to eat; to eat like a toothless person 
anya (plural of anyait) (noun F) grass (generally). cp. inya: weeds. 
anya anya (adverb) (of things or crowds of people) uncountable; numerous; too many. ejaas itunga osokooni anya anya: there are too many people in the marketplace. 
anyaar ko-a (transitive verb) to widen out; to unroll (of cloth, etc), dilate; to open wide as of a bag or mouth (not of door); to enlarge; to widen a circle. konyaa epuko: open the jute bag. konyaa akituk: open the mouth wide. cp. angaar.
anyadakak ko-a (intransitive verb) to have dirty teeth; to be dirty (in general). 
anyadakikin ko-a (transitive verb) to put or throw something in a dirty place. sirikinyadakik ekagoe orit: do not (throw) put my cloth in the mud. 
anyaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to make room for, open out for, stretch for. konyaikinai erot: make room for me. 
anyait (plural anya) (noun F) a blade of grass. cp. inya: weeds. adak inya: to graze. edakas akituk (inya): the cows are grazing. anya nueokito: dry grass; hay. cp. enyait
anyaitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to be elastic; to stretch (as of woven things or of elastic). asokosin enyaitos: socks stretch themselves (when pulled). 
anyaka ko-a (transitive verb) to chew; to munch; to masticate; to ruminate; to chew the cud. anyaka einer: speak at random; to stutter. enyakai: she/he chews. enyakaete: they masticate. cp. angajepanut.
anyakaanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to chew for; to masticate for (as mother for child); to pretend to chew, moving jaws to the right and left (as of old people). 
anyakaet (plural anyakaeta) (noun F) a jaw or a jawbone (as an instument for masticating). cp. abokony: lower jaw. aijak anyakaeta: to be exhausted. 
anyakinyak (plural anyakinyakia) (noun F) the third stomach of a cow or grazing animal (a ruminant’s stomach); (slang) vagina. yeninyakinyakitoi: a tatterdemalion; one dressed in rags. cp. asanyisany.
Anyakoit (plural Anyakoi) (noun F) a woman coming from the north; a northerner; a Nordic. ebunit ngesi konyakoi: she/he comes from the north. Nyakoi nako Uganda – Acholi, Lango kede Karamoja: northern Uganda. Nyakoi naka Africa: north Africa – Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco. Nyakoi nako Bulaya: northern Europe – Norway, Sweden, Finland and Russia.
anyala ko-a (transitive verb) to uproot enmasse; to pull suddenly (of bandage, of plants out of ground or of something caught or stuck on). konyalaa anya: pull out the grass. 
anyalaar ko-a (transitive verb) to pull and take away enmasse; to uproot. (reflexive verb) to widen (as of sore); to spread (as of fire); to flare up (as of a quarrelling person). 
anyalaun ko-a (transitive verb) to pull up or out enmasse; to uproot (of things stuck, or of plants). (reflexive verb) to rise quickly and run this way; to get up quickly and come running. konyalaun: rise quickly and come running; pull yourself up and run this way. 
anyalikik ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very soft; to be unpleasantly soft as of atap or the skin of an old person; to be downy like the fur of a cat. 
anyalikikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be unpleasant for somebody to taste; unpleasant to the touch. kanyalikikit eong akiring ngin: I do not like that meat, it is tasteless, not properly cooked. 
anyamaanut1 (singular noun F) gluttony; gourmand. 
anyamaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be gluttonous, greedy. 
anyamia ko-a (intransitive verb) to eat with; to take advantage of. enyamia ngesi lucetunga: she/he takes advantage of other people; she/he exploits other people for selfish gain. 
anyamaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go out to eat; to eat all of something. lolo alosi anyamaar orekon: today I am going to have food at yours. anyamaar ibore: not to return a thing borrowed. 
anyamun ko-o (reflexive verb) to get consumed or worn out, used up; to quarrel violently; to fight. anyamunos aberu k’okilenike: the husband and wife are quarrelling. 
anyamunor ko-o (transitive verb) to cheat. kinyamunor ijo eong: you have cheated me. 
Anyang (noun F) a pet name for a brown cow. 
Anyanya (plural Lukanyanya) (noun F) a derisive reference (by the Bantu tribes) to any of the tribes of northern Uganda after 1986; (an insult) a northerner (Ugandan) or any person who is tall and dark-complexioned. 
anyanyaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to fester (of wound); to become bigger (of a sore); to spread (of fire); to flare up; to expand (of power). anyanyaar akajimi: my wound has become bigger. anyanyaar akim: the fire has spread. anyanyaar ecelet: the quarrel has become serious. anyanyaaros akiro: the matter has become grave. anyanyaar je: he has flared up. 
anyara ko-a (transitive verb) to call, summon, or to invite by name (call often or many). 
anyaraar ko-a (transitive verb) to call away; to ask someone to something. ingai kinyaraarit ijo?: who called you away? 
anyarao ko-o (transitive verb) to be called; to be known as; to be named as. enyarao: she/he shall be called thus; they shall be known as. kinyarao: you shall be called thus. kanyarao: I shall be called thus.
anyaraun ko-a (transitive verb) to call this way; to summon here; to invite. anyaraun itunganan: to invite someone to a place, happening, etc. konyarau etelepat: call the boy. (reflexive verb) to be called, be invited, or summoned. anyaraunos itunga ipu: many people have been called. 
anyarit ko-o (transitive verb) to be calling; to be summoning; to be calling a name. inyarit ijo nges ngai?: what, whom do you call her/him? 
Anyarwaadat (plural Anyarwaada) (noun F) a Rwandese tribeswoman; a woman native to Kisoro district at the extreme south-west of Uganda and the Republic of Rwanda; a word in Kinyarwanda (the language of the Rwandese people). Anyarwaada: the Rwandese women; the Kinyarwanda language.
anyaun ko-a (transitive verb) to make way for oneself; to bend this way. konyau erot: make way for me or for us. anyaun erot: the road is open; the road is clear. anyaun erot: to fight to clear the way from enemies or bandits.
anyidik ko-a (intransitive verb) to go in crowds; to be many. enyidikete ikur kaikec: the worms are going in crowds into their house. 
anyidikaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to go away in crowds. 
anyidikik ko-a (intransitive verb) (of armyworms or maggots) to be numerous. inyidikikas ikur kotoma akiring: there are too many maggots in the meat. 
anyidikun ko-a (reflexive verb) to come in crowds, swarms or throngs. 
anyidok (noun F) a kind of plant - a sedge. 
anyigolit (plural anyigol) (noun F) a tumour or tonsil at the back of the tongue. 
anyilakin ko-a (transitive verb) to give a little (of something to somebody). konyilakinai adikiring: give me a little meat; to give too little; to give short weight. kanyilakis eong Ilugai esukaali: the Indians gave me too little sugar. (reflexive verb) to be given little or short weight; to be thrifty. kanyilakin eong esukaali: they gave me too little sugar. anyilakinos akipi toma amot: a little water has been poured into the pot. 
anyilar ko-a (transitive verb) to take away a little; to tear off. sirikinyila ikakoku: do not tear off (the arm of) my child (by lifting it roughly). 
anyilil ko-a (intransitive verb) to be torn; to be worn. enyilil ekagoe: my cloth is torn. 
anyilinyil ko-a (transitive verb) to tear to pieces. 
anyilinyila ko-a (intransitive verb) to be torn; to be worn out; to be spoiled (by tearing). 
anyilun ko-a (transitive verb) to tear off (once); to tear off or break of a little piece once. 
anyilunun ko-a (transitive verb) to keep tearing off; to use carefully; to use sparingly; to be thrifty with. konyilununei ikonisirigin: use your money sparingly. (reflexive verb) to come off little by little. enyilununos akipi toma ajon nu: too little water is poured into this beer. 
anyiporit (plural anyiporin) (noun F) a White Nile sparrow. 
anyodokok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of teeth) to be dirty with tartar. 
anyoikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to rise for; to rise (to do something); to rise and start. kanyoiki eong aberu: my wife went away and left me alone. kanyoikisi alosit: let us rise and go; let us start our journey. 
anyongait (plural anyonga) (noun F) a stalk of sorghum eaten like sugarcane. 
anyongirir ko-o (intransitive verb) to be thick; to be difficult to please; to frown. 
anyoor ko-o (intransitive verb) to rise and go away from here. konyoo ngina: rise and go away. 
anyoridid ko-o (intransitive verb) to be dirty; to be filthy (of the body or shoes, plates, cloth); (of room) not swept; sour-faced; grim. inyorididas igoen lu: these clothes are dirty.
Anyoun1 (noun F) the Exodus (one of the books in the Old Testament in the Bible). 
anyoun2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to get up, to rise up; to depart; to go away; to stand up (as of child) anyou akaberu: my wife has left me. 
anyounet (plural anyouneta) (noun F) a departure; an exit; an exodus; the going away. 
anyul (plural anyulia) (noun F) a hammer; anvil. cp. enyoodo
anyulaun ko-a (transitive verb) to pluck out (weeds); to pull out (feathers). (reflexive verb) to come out easily. 
anyuluk ko-a (transitive verb) to take off easily (like well-cooked meat from a bone). (intransitive verb) to be soft, easy to pluck out, easy to take off. 
anyunyu ko-o (intransitive verb) to be unlucky; to have bad luck; to be unsuccessful, unskilful, inapt. anyunyu eong kotoma amej: I am unlucky in hunting. enyunyu eong akan: enyunyu eong ereet: I am unlucky. 
anyunyura1 (singular noun F) anger; annoyance; fury; irritation. 
anyunyura2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be angry; to be annoyed; to be hot-tempered; to be irritated. aitunyunyur: to make angry; to annoy; to upset; to vex, provoke. 
anyunyuranut1 (noun F) irritability; tetchiness; bad temper. 
anyunyuranut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be short-tempered; to be inclined to become angry; to be irritable; to be touchy; to be hot-tempered 
anyunyurikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be angry with; to flare at; to be annoyed with or on account of (reflexive verb) to become angry; to become annoyed; to become offended. 
anyura ko-a (transitive verb) to pull up (something fixed, like roots); to uproot many. enyurai ngesi eduan: she/he pulls up weeds. 
anyuraar ko-a (transitive verb) to pull away (grass, hair, feathers, etc); to disrupt. 
anyuraun ko-a (transitive verb) to uproot; to pull out (something soft). 
anyusa ko-a (transitive verb) to eat (meat, bread, etc) in mouthfuls. anyusa akiring: to chew meat in mouthfuls (like a cow eats grass). 
ao (singular noun F) (Usuk) honey bee(s). cp. awu. 
aog ko-a (intransitive verb) to swagger; to bluster; to strut with defiant air; to be proud. cp. apog, asog. 
aogakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to become proud, arrogant, or defiant; to show off. 
aogar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go away proudly (prepositional verb) to pride oneself on. eogatar kesi ekecegaali: they pride themselves on their bicycle. 
aojaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become tall; to become long; to become high. iojaar ijo: you have become tall. 
aojat (plural aojai) (noun F) a kind of grasshopper. 
aojau1 (noun F) length; height; tallness; altitude. aojau kuju na angolol: height above sea level. cp. aidules.
aojau2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be tall, long, high. aojau akan: to be a thief (literally, to have a long hand). eoj nges akan: she/he is a thief; she/he has a long hand. lo eoj akan: a thief (plural lu eojak akanin). 
aoji ko-o (transitive verb) to twist, or to spin; to twine or to interlace. eojie ngesi auno: she/he is making a rope. eojie ngesi akiro: she/he is twisting words; she/he exaggerates. 
aojikin ko-o (transitive verb) to twist, spin for. koojikinoi auno: make or twist a rope for me. cp. aicipakin, amojirikin. 
aojior ko-o (transitive verb) to make longer; to twist away. 
aoke (plural aokei) (noun F) a branch or leaf of eoke tree. 
aokit (plural aokito) (noun F) a vessel for drawing water or for measuring commercial beer (ajon or ekamule). 
aokor ko-o (transitive verb) to scoop away. cp. awokor
aokore ko-o (transitive verb) to dry up; to wither or become parched. aokikisi akipi kotoma atan: the well has dried up. (plural of aonore)
aokosit (collective noun F) a great quantity of blood. abu ngesi koii aokosit: she/he lost a great quantity of blood. 
aokot1 (plural aokoi) (noun F) devil's yam, Smilax anceps. 
aokot2 (uncountable noun F) blood. aiyat aokot: to give blood by transfusion.
aokun ko-a (transitive verb) to ladle, draw water from a well. 
aol1 (plural aolia) (noun F) the skin underneath the throat; the dewlap. 
aol2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to do the big; to boast; to be proud; to feel very strong, big, important. eola ngesi: she/he is proud. 
aola1 (uncountable noun F) a cough; a boast, a brag, or a swank. 
aola2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to cough; to boast. eolas kesi ebe kitelekaarete oni: they boast that they will beat us (at a football game, etc). 
aolaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become adolescent (literally, to cough); to become proud; to become strong again, get courage again. 
aoli ko-o (intransitive verb) to get lost; to perish; to roam about; to disappear. aolio ebarenitika: my razor blade is lost. eoliete akituk kosamai: the cows will get lost in the swamp: they roam about. aoliosi akituk: the cows are lost. 
aolikin ko-o (transitive verb) to lose; to forget; to lose sight of, not to remember. (reflexive verb) to fail to recognise each other. (intransitive verb) to be beyond one; to be difficult for one. kaolikitos eong nulimuno: I am at a loss what to say. 
aolior ko-o (intransitive verb) to disappear; to get lost; to escape, go astray, or be missing. aoliosi akamerekekin: my sheep are lost. 
aolit1 (singular noun F) ignorance; not knowing. epol aolitekon: your ignorance is great. 
aolit2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be ignorant, not to know. aolit eong Ateso: I do not know Ateso. kanu iolitor ijo nu, nges etiokototor: because you do not know this, therefore it is difficult. 
aoliun ko-o (intransitive verb) to stray this way; to get lost here. 
aolobob ko-a (intransitive verb) to brag, vaunt, boast, or bluster. 
aolobobot ko-o (intransitive verb) to boast; to brag; to bluster. eolobobot etelepat lo tai: this boy is a braggart for nothing. 
aolokok1 (noun F) light emptiness; hollowness. aolokokor: to become empty, vainglorious. 
aolokok2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be hollow; to be empty (of anything); to be vainglorious. 
aolokonyoi (plural aolokonyo) (noun F) eggshell.
aolong ko-a (transitive verb) to do the big; to be too optimistic about, pretend to be able to. 
aolongikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to try to do the impossible; to pretend to be able; to do in a hurry. aolongikin ngesi agwel amotoka: she/he has hurried to buy a motorcar. 
aomaar ko-a (transitive verb) to sign, take a deep breath. aomaar etau: to take a deep breath; to sigh. 
aomare ko-a (transitive verb) to fetch, go and fetch; to indent, order for goods. 
aomiar erot ko-a (transitive verb) to go the long way round. 
aomikin ko-a (transitive verb) to fetch for or somewhere; to measure or make too big. (reflexive verb) to become or to be too big. aomikin etogo lo: this house is (measured) too big. aomikin erot: to go the long way round (not taking short cut); to circumnavigate. 
aomisioit (plural aomisio) (noun F) a thought; a conjecture; a concept; a consideration. 
aomit (singular noun F) a conjecture; inference; a guess; imagination; supposition; assumption; speculation.
aomit ko-o (transitive verb) to have in mind; to think, be of opinion, consider. 
aomoom ko-a (transitive verb) to think over; to consider; to discuss in one’s mind; to ponder over; to meditate, or cogitate; to deem,; to imagine. aomoom ketau: to consider; to meditate; to ponder over in one’s heart. 
aomun ko-o (transitive verb) to come and fetch; to come and call; to come and take away. (note: koom: go and fetch. koom: come and fetch. koomunoi: come and fetch me; call for me). 
aongakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to yawn for or on account off. 
aonganar akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to drawl, pronounce, inflect, intone, enunciate, or brogue. 
aongon (noun F) (the number) four. lokiwongonet M (adjective) the fourth. aiwongonikin: to do a fourth time; to make four. kiwongonik itunga: add a fourth man, bring their number to four. 
Aongor1 (noun F) a pet name for a dirty-brown cow. 
aongor2 (plural nukaongor) (noun F) a wading bird with a dirty brown colour, Hammer-head. 
aongor3 ko-a (intransitive verb) to make purple-brown; to make dark-brown. 
aongoraar (reflexive verb) to become dark or purple brown. 
aongoranut1 (noun F) dark or purple brown colour. 
aongoranut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be dark or purple brown. 
aongoriat (plural aongoria) (noun F) a species of bird, Hoopoe. 
aonikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to dry up; to shrivel up; to evaporate. aoniki esamai: the swamp has dried up. 
aonit ko-a (intransitive verb) to be dry, shrivelled; to be withered. eonit nges akuwan: she/he is shrivelled, has withered (by age or illness). eonit nges akan: she/he is poor: her/his hand dry. eonit nges akituk: she/he is hungry. eonit nges etau: she/he is thirsty, parched. eonit nges akou: she/he is thick-headed. eonit nges egur: she/he is very thin, bony. eonit ngesi kotoma Amusugun: she/he speaks English very well. kane eonit: on the dry land. 
aonon (plural aonok) (noun F) the dry one. 
aonore ko-o (intransitive verb) to become dry. aono ngesi: she/he/it is dry. aoko: they are dry, arid, thin. aokoto: they have become dry, slender, thin. aono ngesi de de: she/he/it is very dry, thin-bodied. aono atan: the well has dried up. aono eong etau: I am thirsty. aono nges akan: she/he has become poor, she/he is empty-handed. eringa egoe keono: the dress is not yet dry. eringa akwap eonit: the land is still dry. (plural aokore)
aoret (singular noun F) cow-dung. cp. aleleng: droppings of goats or sheep. amonyo: the dung of a calf. 
aorikin ko-a (transitive verb) to neglect, leave alone; to wean; to let go; to let free. aorikin aswam: to resign. cp. aosikin, alakakin, ajalakin, ainyekikin.
aorokonyit (plural aorokonyo) (noun F) phlegm in the throat. akakanyaar aorokonyit: to clear the throat. 
aoror ko-o (intransitive verb) to be hollow; to be open; to be split; to be cracked, empty, or devoid of. eorori arwatat na: this wall is cracked or the wall is hollow. eorori akoik: the stomach is empty. eorori akekituk: she/he talks a lot; she/he reveals secrets; to talk a lot. aoror swo swo: to be very hollow. 
aororikin ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person’s voice) to become hoarse. 
aororikit ko-o (intransitive verb) (of person) to speak hoarsely; (of voice) to be hoarse. eororikitos kesi: they are hoarse, they speak hoarsely. 
aosianut1 (singular noun F) menorrhagia in animals or women. 
aosianut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to have menorrhagia. 
aosiar ko-a (intransitive verb) (said of woman or animals) to take a long time without producing. eosiarit aberu na: this woman has been a long time without conceiving. 
aosikin ko-a (transitive verb) to give permission; to let go; to resign; to set free or liberate; to stop doing or saying. aosikin erot: to get out of the way. 
aosinoit (plural aosino) (noun F) the vagina and the rectum of a big animal such as a cow. 
aosomit (plural aosom) (noun F) elephant-snout fish, Carcusenius. 
aote ki-o (intransitive verb) to work for wages; to labour. cp. aipakas, eitai. 
aotok (plural aotoko) (noun F) a florican bird. cp. atakura. 
apaade (plural apaadei) (noun F) a (road) signpost; a billboard. 
apaaga (plural apaagai) (noun F) a big knife; a cleaver; a panga; a machete. 
apaagait (plural apaagin) (noun F) a door post; a pillar or support. 
apaanakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to stay with someone often; to loiter; to go and stop at somebody’s or somewhere often. akoto apaanakin neijai ijo: I want always to stop where you are. 
apaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go astray or to diverge; to err; to make a mistake; to become bad; to turn aside; to go off the road; to be tasteless. epaarit akiring na: this meat is tasteless. apaar awai: to go aside; to go off the touch-line (in football). apaar naka akituk: abu akakituk kopaa: I had a slip of the tongue. epaarit akakituk: I have no taste. epaarit eong akituk kanyam eitola kasodi aimat ajon: I have no taste for beer after eating sugarcane.
apaaran (plural apaarasia) (noun F) a day; daylight; a date. apaarasia kere: always. apaarasia nu: nowadays. cp. apaarit: a 24-hour day. apaaran kere: all day; the whole day. kapaarasia: from time to time. nace paaran: the following day. cp. moi kace: the day after tomorrow. acepaaran: another time. inyamat lukapaaran: daytime food or meals; lunch. apaarasia nuka aburun: hard times. apaarasia nuka Rogasio: Rogation Days (the three days before Ascension Day).
apaarit (plural apaarasia) (noun F) a day (24 hours); a date. acepaarit: another day; another time. 
apacanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to make slips (of the tongue) often; to err often; to make mistakes often. epacanar akakituk: I often make slips of the tongue; I say often the wrong thing; I often make mistakes. 
apacar1 ko-a (transitive verb) to burst open; to shell; to unhusk. (reflexive verb) to be peeled, unhusked, shelled. 
apacar2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to go off the beaten track; to take another way; (of a missile) to ricochet, to divert. abu eong kapacar: I went off the right road; I took the side road or path. apacar awai: to deflect away (of a blow); to graze. 
apacara (adjective) unhusked; shelled; peeled. 
apacet (plural apaceta) (noun F) a husk, peelings, rind, the bark; a shell; a hull. 
apacetait (plural apaceta) (noun F) a husk; a shell; a hull; bark. apaceta nuka emaido: groundnut-shells. 
apacolol ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a bald (hairless) or scarred head. 
apacoloor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become bald (hairless) or scarred on the head. 
apacun ko-a (transitive verb) to take off, shell; to unhusk. (reflexive verb) to come off (as of shell or bark of tree). cp. aiwalun (of wall plaster). 
apadalal ko-a (intransitive verb) to be flat (of foot or head; of stool). 
apadalu (noun F) flatness; evenness; smoothness. 
apadinganut1 (noun F) enmity; hostility; unfriendliness. 
apadinganut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be enemies; to be unfriendly. 
apae (plural apaelon) (noun F) a female friend; a female lover. cp. apaelot
apaelot (plural apaelon) (noun F) a female friend; a female lover. cp. apapero.
apagal ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a situation) to be clumsy or awkward; to be difficult, awkward to handle. 
apagalal ko-a (intransitive verb) to become clumsy, awkward. 
apagalikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be awkward for, clumsy for. kapagalikinit eong ainyam kakediany: I find it awkward to eat with the left hand. 
apagalu (singular noun F) awkwardness; clumsiness; difficulty. 
apaikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to halt; to stop; to wait; to stay; to abide (used in narrative form and infinitive) kopaikini (adverb) and then; after that. 
apaipo (plural apaipon) (noun F) a pipe; a tube; a cylinder; a conduit; a pipeline. 
apajangang ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a flat head; to be flat-headed. 
apak (plural apakio) (noun F) space; room; time; period of time; opportunity; turn; duration. apak naabunio: when I come. apak naka ailok: the time for trapping or catching (animals); time for removing teeth. apak alopet: the right time; the exact time. apak naewoj: a long time; at long intervals; for a long time. apak na kere: all this time. apakio nukolo: far distant times (in the past); a long time ago; in olden times. 
apakapak ko-a (transitive verb) to break into pieces; to separate; to give strong blows; to break down (a wall). 
apakar ko-a (transitive verb) to take off a piece; to break off; to separate (of things usually joined). (reflexive verb) to break off (as of a clod of earth, piece of potato, etc); to separate. 
apakasit (plural apakasin) (noun F) a female labourer; a porter; a maid-servant. 
apaket (plural apaketin) (noun F) a packet (of cigarettes, tobacco etc). 
apaketait (plural apaketa) (noun F) a (broken off) part of something. 
Apalaasat (plural Apalaasan) (noun F) the French language or word; a French woman. Ipalaasan ineras Apalaasan: the French speak French. 
apalakac (plural apalakaca) (noun F) tough meat. 
apalalu1 (singular noun F) dampness; wetness; moistness. 
apalalu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become fresh; to become damp; to become wet, moist, or clammy. 
apalanut1 (singular noun F) capitulation; surrendering; forfeiting. cp. apalunanut.
apalanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to give up or concede easily. 
apalapalat ko-o (intransitive verb) to go round shyly; to be shy, bashful; to be perplexed; to be disappointed. abu ikoku kobu epalapalat: the child came round shyly, bashfully. apalapalat tai: to go about aimlessly. cp. airim tai; aiiria tai. 
apalapiano (plural apalapianon) (noun F) a frying pan. 
apalar ko-a (intransitive verb) to stop doing, using, or eating something; to give up something; to be quiet, motionless, restful; to stop by oneself. epalarito akipi: the water is calm, motionless. epalarit etauka: nothing worries me; I am at peace. 
apalaret (plural apalareta) (noun F) a deadlock (in a tug-of-war). 
apale (plural apalei) (noun F) a woman’s skirt or petticoat. cp. apeeti, asaati
apalet (plural apaleta) (noun F) forfeiture; giving up; discontinuation.
apalikin ko-a (transitive verb) to neglect; to desert; to leave alone, sacrifice to; to refuse to press a debtor. apalikin aibois: to give up a seat or place for somebody. apalikin inyamat: to sacrifice one’s share of food to someone else who does not have. apalikin etau: to procrastinate. apalikin aswam: to give up work for someone else. 
apalisi (plural apalisin) (noun F) a mattress (in general); a wire or sponge mattress: apalisi naka asinin. 
apalisionor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become a procrastinator, a foot-dragger, etc 
apalisionut1 (singular noun F) humble, polite; procrastination; delaying action. 
apalisionut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be humble, polite; to be deferring or delaying action; to procrastinate. 
apalococ ko-o (intransitive verb) to have hairless patches on the head. 
apaloror ko-o (reflexive verb) to be bald-headed; to be clean-shaven; to be bare.
