apalun1 ko-a (transitive verb) to leave alone; to desert; to neglect; to give up; to back out. apalunit eong aswam na: I dislike this work; I do not care for this work. apalu ngesi akeberu: he has deserted or neglected his wife. apalun akiro: to let well alone; to put aside bad blood.
apalun2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to become obsolete; to become neglected, abandoned; to take away worries. apalun esomero ngol: that school has been neglected. epalunit ekatau: I am not worried about it, leaves me at ease. (reflexive verb) to be put at ease. 
apalunanut1 (singular noun F) level-headedness; equanimity; self-control; restraint. 
apalunanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be level-headed, restrained, or not easily disturbed, disciplined, detached, calm. 
apama (plural apamai) (noun F) a (brick or mud) wall. cp. arwatat.
apanamu (singular noun F) scarcity; shortage. inyamat lukapanamu: last-resort food; relief food; giffen goods. 
apanasiait (plural apanasia) (noun F) a cluster of banana fruits, i.e. a part of a bunch. 
apanyait (plural apanya) (noun F) a potato mound; a potato heap. aibok acok: to dig potato heaps; to plant potatoes; (slang) (during the Teso insurgency of 1987-1991) to dig one’s own grave before being killed. 
apapan ko-a (transitive verb) to try in vain; to hum and haw; to bustle. cp. aimen. 
apapangu1 (noun F) astringency; sourness like half-ripe bananas.
apapangu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of fruit) to be sweet-sour; to be astringent, sour, acerbic. 
apapu (singular noun F) nothing; a wraith; a phantom; something unseen, invisible; a ghost or spirit. ekwam erai apapu tai: air or wind is some invisible thing.
apapula (plural apapulai) (noun F) a paper; a page; a document; an academic qualification; a newspaper.
aparadad (noun F) plumpness; obesity around the waist. 
aparipar ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very shiny; to dazzle. eparipari angolol ya: that lake dazzles or gleams. 
aparis (plural aparisa) (noun F) a branch, leaf or fibre of eparis tree. ajon nuka aparis: beer given to those who bring the dowry (named so because cows are beaten with the aparis branch on the way). 
apason (singular noun F) tiredness; fatigue; weariness; exhaustion. aara nges apason: she/he is very tired (literally, she/he died of weariness). cp. eitegane. 
apatakak ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very fat, obese. 
apatanikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be convenient to; to be easy for. kapatanikit eong aimar: mathematics or arithmetics is easy for me. 
apatanu1 (noun F) tameness; ease; gentleness; convenience; affability. 
apatanu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become easy, convenient, tame, cheap, or gentle. 
apaun ko-a (intransitive verb) to reroute oneself hither; to divert and come towards. 
apaup (noun F) a female companion or friend; one of a pair of female things. 
ape1 (adverb) (of an action) taking a long time. iswamai ngesi ape: she/he works slowly. iboyie ngesi kore ape: she/he sits all the time at home. inera ngesi ape: she/he talks for a long time. 
ape2 (imperative) expression, ‘go’; ‘get away’; ‘be off’. ape ape! (interjection): go away! be off! 
apecelut (plural apecel, apecelun) (noun F) a lily plant. 
apedekek ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a football or tyre) to be empty or deflated. 
apedelel ko-a (intransitive verb) to be flat or a little shallow (like a meat plate). cp. adukulul: shallow, like a soup plate or saucer. 
apedelu (noun F) flatness; shallowness (of a vessel); thinness. 
apedeped ko-o (transitive verb) to riddle with holes; to bore or make many holes. 
apedis (plural apedisyo) (noun F) the brace and bits. cp. apedot.
apedokin ko-o (transitive verb) to make a hole through; to pierce through; to drill something (reflexive verb) to be pierced; to have a leak. 
apedonor ko-o (transitive verb) to be almighty. Edeke Lokapedor kere: God the Almighty; the all powerful; the omnipotent. mam eong apedonori nuetia nen: I cannot be bothered about all those things; I am unable to do so much. 
apedor1 (plural apedorosio) (noun F) ability; legal right; competence; power; permission; admittance; capacity. adumun apedor aswam ibore: to get permission to do something. apedorosio nukidwe (kwape nat aisiom, aidario ejok): child rights (such as the right to education and protection). apedorosio nukitunga: human or peoples’ rights. apedorosio nukidwe (kwape nat aisiom, aidario ejok): child rights (such as the right to education and protection). apedorosio nukitunga: human or peoples’ rights.
apedor2 ko-o (transitive verb) to be able, be competent, or to have power over; to manage; to get permission, admit. adumu ngesi apedor: she/he has got permission. koge ber adumun apedor: first go and get permission. apedori eong: I can. apedorit aswam ibore: to be able to do something.
apedor3 ko-o (transitive verb) to pierce through. abu eong kapedo ebileng: I pierced the mudfish. 
apedorit (singular noun F) ability; competence; capacity. 
apedosit (plural apedono) (noun F) a hole (in a substance); a fissure; a puncture; an aperture. 
apedot (plural apedono) (noun F) a hole (in a substance); a gap; a crevice; an aperture. apedot naka ekume: the nostril. apedot kotoma arwatat: a chink; a crevice. 
apedun ko-o (transitive verb) to dig (for water) (reflexive verb) to come out; to appear this way. ebunit lokabokan atanin apedun akipi: the well-driller has come to dig for water. apedunos akipi: the water has gushed out (has spurted out). 
apeduro (plural apeduroi) (noun F) a kind of cactus plant, Euphorbia laterophylia.
apedurot (plural apedur) (noun F) the fruit of epeduru tree, used as a flavouring for some vegetables and atap, and also placed in the gourd with the millet seeds just before planting the millet (to bless the millet crop). 
apeduru (plural apedur) (noun F) a branch or leaf of epeduru tree.
apeelet (plural apeelen) (noun F) a slice or a flake (of anything, especially of bar soap). 
apeero (plural apeeron) (noun F) a grassy plain (i.e. grassland); a sod (i.e. grass); a sward (i.e. meadow or pasture). 
apeesa (plural apeesan) (noun F) a (cloth) button. 
apeesan (plural noun F) money; cash; cloth buttons. 
apeeti (plural apeetin) (noun F) a woman’s silk underwear resembling a skirt, often with ornamentation at the fringes; a petticoat; underskirt; a slip. 
apega1 (noun F) argument; discussion. 
apega2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to argue; to bargain; to discuss. epegas itunga ka Ilugai: people bargain with the Indians. apega eong (plural epegas kesi): I (they) deny it; I (they) disbelieve. 
apegakin ko-a (transitive verb) to quarrel with; to contradict; to disagree with; to answer back. mam ejok apegakin emuronikon: it is not good to contradict your doctor. 
apegakinet (plural apegakineta) (noun F) an objection; a protest; abnegation; a rebuttal. 
apegan (plural apegak) (noun F) one who contradicts; a debater; one who objects. cp. ekapegan
apeganakin ko-a (transitive verb) to contradict often; to bargain with. 
apeganar ko-a (transitive verb) to deny everything; to refuse to own up; to refuse to confess. siripeganari akiro: do not refuse to own up or to confess (the truth). 
apeganut1 (noun F) protestation; contradiction; objection. 
apeganut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to argue, to contradict, deny, or discuss. 
apege (plural apegei) (noun F) a female pig; a sow; a woman wallowing in filth. 
apeikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to run away from somebody. kapeiki eong akingok: the bitch ran away from me. (transitive verb) to roast, brand, scorch for somebody. 
apeipeyanut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be scarce; to do seldom, be difficult to get; to do occasionally. epeipeyana ngesi abunenen ne: she/he comes here seldom. cp. mam etapit. 
apeis (noun F) abore napeis: a gridiron. 
apejo (singular noun F) a visit; a call on; a stopover; a trip; a vacation. 
apejonon (plural apejok) (noun F) a female guest; a female visitor; a female caller; a female tourist. 
apekipok (plural apekipokia) (noun F) a hamstring i.e. a tendon at the back of the knee: amoorit naka apekipok. cp. apokipok.
apel (plural apelia) (noun F) armlet or arm band (of ivory, bone or wood carving) formerly worn by men above the elbow, especially when dancing or getting initiated to elders. 
apele ko-a (transitive verb) (followed by infinitive) to do badly, openly, on purpose, deliberately; to resolve; to do intentionally. ibu ijo kopele ainom nges: you beat her/him deliberately. cp. akanga, aijece.
apeleanut (noun F) initiative; inventiveness; enterprise; creativity. 
apeleikin ko-a (transitive verb) to intend; to mean to do something; to do on purpose, intentionally, or deliberately; to resolve to do. 
apeleikinet (plural apeleikineta) (noun F) a strategic goal; an objective; an intention; an initiative; a programme; a plan; a scheme; a project; a proposal. 
apeleun ko-a (transitive verb) to start something new; to improvise; to invent, extemporise. (reflexive verb) to start by itself; to come by itself. apeleun atan kane: a well sprung up or started here. apeleun einer: to introduce a new subject; to talk beside the point; to dodge a question. 
apemer ko-a (intransitive verb) to go with or have a distended stomach; to go with a protruding stomach (as of children or small men, not of big fat man). 
apemerer ko-a (intransitive verb) to have or having a protruding stomach. 
apengo (adverb) (of time in the past) long ago. kolo apengo: very long ago. 
apenyakin ko-a (transitive verb) to do at once; to do immediately, rashly, in a hurry. (reflexive verb) (in narrative tense) ‘and then; immediately, forthwith.’ cp. kopari. 
apenyun ko-o (reflexive verb) to appear suddenly and head for the speaker. abu emir kopenyun kotoma anya: the rat came out of the grass. 
apeor ko-o (transitive verb) to brand, scorch; to roast (a little), parch. (reflexive verb) to be roasted, scorched, branded, burnt, parched. apeoros inya: the grass is scorched (by the sun). 
apepeanut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be quick in deciding; to be impatient. 
apepeu1 (singular noun F) sensitiveness; susceptibility; guilt-conscience.
apepeu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (used with etau) to be impatient, easily influenced, vulnerable, easily moved, easily affected, irritable, or edgy. 
aper ko-a (intransitive verb) to lie down; to sleep, or to spend the night; to inhabit; to dwell; to stay. eperete kesi togo ngol: they are sleeping in that house. 
aper nen! (adverb) it is over!; it is finished!; kaput! kalas!
aperiat (plural aperiai) (noun F) a bride’s escorts to the new home after the marriage ceremony. 
aperikin (transitive verb) to do the whole night. aperikis kesi atenus: they danced to the drums all night. cp. aiwalakin.
aperis (plural aperisyo) (noun F) bedding; bed; a place for sleeping; sleeping hut; abode. cp. ejamu; aperit.
aperit1 (plural aperito) (noun F) bedding; a bed; a place for sleeping; a sleeping hut; an abode. cp. ejamu; aperies.
aperit2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to have slept; to pass the night. iperit biai? (the morning greeting): how did you sleep? did you have a good night? cp. ikwenyunit biai?:Good morning.
aperoi (plural noun F) good millet beer (four or five days old). acok nuperoi: potato mounds prepared for the following year. 
aperonor ko-o (intransitive verb) to sleep away from home often; to spend nights elsewhere many times. aperonosi ipejok apejo: the guests stayed overnight at the party (more than once).
aperor ko-o (intransitive verb) to sleep away from home; to spend the night elsewhere; to remain overnight; to sleep over. alot ngesi aperor ngina: she/he went to sleep over there. eperorit akim koreke: the fire kept burning all night at her/his home. eperorit akakoik: I slept with a full stomach. aperosi akiro ngun bobo: that case was again deferred or left undecided. 
aperosit (singular noun F) remnants of food kept overnight. koyau aperosit, kariebi eong etengei: bring me last evening’s food leftover, I am hungry. 
aperun ko-o (transitive verb) to lie in wait for; to lurk; to ambush. akoto aperun ekesa ngol aibunga: I want to ambush that fellow to give him a beating. 
apese (plural apesur) (noun F) an unmarried girl of 18–26 years of age; a spinster; a maiden; a damsel. cp. aberu: a woman.
apesen (plural apesenin) (noun F) a debt; a loan; a mortgage; an advance; an obligation. ejai eong apesen kajo: I have a debt with you.
apesiaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to open out; to spread out, increase. 
apesiar ko-a (transitive verb) to open out; to spread (as of a mat), increase. 
apesikin ko-a (transitive verb) to spread out. apesikin ejamu: to make the bed. apesikin akiro: to discuss; to talk things over; to go into details; to try to come to an agreement. 
apesikinet (plural apesikineta) (noun F) a structure (the way in which the parts of a thing are arranged or organised); topography; the lie. cp. aitadasit, epureemu, eripipi
apetakin ko-a (transitive verb) to spread out for. apetakin icetunga akiro: to discuss, explain for; to plead for. 
apetar ko-a (transitive verb) to do one by one. alosi apetar aanyanar ikatunga: I am going to visit my people one after the other. alosi apetar aiteten akiro ngun: I am going to explain those matters one by one. apetarit: not to miss one, take one by one. 
apetecor (plural apetecorin) (noun F) a plant, Solanum. 
apetek ko-a (intransitive verb) to jump about like a kid; to prance. cp. acetek
apetepet ko-o (transitive verb) to kick often; to give many kicks. 
apetetait (plural apeteta) (noun F) layers of sticks on which a granary rests; a foundation (of anything). apetetait naka apedorosio nuka itunga: a foundation of human rights.
apetokin ko-o (transitive verb) to kick towards or for; to hit by kicking; to kick each other. kipetok ijo eong emopiira akongu: you hit my eye with the ball. 
apetonut1 (noun F) skilled at kicking (football, karate, etc); fondness of kicking. 
apetonut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be skilled at kicking. 
apetor ko-o (transitive verb) to kick off; to kick away; to leave alone; to reject; to abandon (as of hen kicking away her chicks). apeto akiteng elepit: the cow has kicked over the milking can. (reflexive verb) to refuse to pay a debt. ekopaarit ngesi akapeesan, konye apeto: she/he borrowed some money but she/he has refused to pay back. 
apetun ko-o (transitive verb) to kick this way; to make to bulge out; togive a full account of an event. apetun epur: to stoop. apetun ngesi togo: she/he forced or kicked open the door; she/he entered by kicking the door open. 
api (plural apion) (noun F) a small shallow basket. 
apiar ko-a (transitive verb) to carry away all, rob all; to sweep away; to finish all. apiasi ikokolak ikaboro: the robbers have swept away all my belongings. apiar akan: to become poor; (of hands) to become empty; to be all finished. apiar eong akan: I have become poor. 
apie (plural apien) (noun F) leftovers of food on the table; remnants or residues of food at the dinig area. cp. ararasia, aperosit
apieet (plural apieeta) (noun F) a broom; besom. cp. ajanit, agweeret 
apieeta (plural noun F) sweepings; rubbish; chaff. 
apii (plural apiin) (noun F) a water-cooled smoker’s pipe. cp. amiidi.
apiila (plural apiilai) (noun F) groundnut sauce. aitokony apiila: to let a woman taste salt for the first time after birth. 
apiipi (plural noun F) stained cotton fibre in sorting (used to stuff pillows and mattresses). 
apiirianar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become wise, clever, witty. 
apiirianikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to understand; to see through; to comprehend; to follow (with the mind); to grasp; to fathom. ipirianik ijo akiro nu?: do you grasp these issues? 
apiirianut1 (singular noun F) expertise; insight; experience; sharpness (of intellect); knack. apiirianut naka akanin: skilfulness; talent; dexterity; expertise. 
apiirianut2 ko-a (transitive verb) to be sharp-witted; to be wise, clever, experienced; to have a knack of, be adept, adroit. 
apiirikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to understand.
apiitit1 (singular noun F) slight stature; slenderness; smallness (in stature). 
apiitit2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person or an animal) to be slight, slender, or under-developed. 
apiku (plural apikui) (noun F) (in the Teso game of aibic) a small flat and round stone for hitting a nut outside the hole as chosen by the opponent (hitting that nut alone means you win all the nuts; hitting more than one nut means you lose your turn and the chance goes to the opponent; nuts entering the hole belong to the person who threw them in; apiku entering the hole having nuts means that player will lose those nuts i.e. the nuts continue in play). 
apinat (collective noun F) fowl fleas; chicken lice. cp. ebulolo. 
apinyait (noun F) a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis. cp. anya. 
Apio(t) (noun F) name of the first born girl twin. [note: the second born girl is Adong(ot)] 
apipa (plural apipai) (noun F) a barrel; a plastic tank or drum for storing liquids. 
apipilikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be painful to; to be hurtful; to hurt; to sympathize with; to be attached to. kapipilikit eong ebela: the idea of being beaten frightens me. epipilikit nges ainyekin ere: the idea of leaving home is painful to her/him. (note: kariebi akou: my head is aching). epipilikit nges aberuke: he is attached to his wife. cp. anomor.
apipilu1 (singular noun F) pain; soreness; hurt. 
apipilu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become painful to; to become sore; to be a sore point to. epipil ngesi inusio: she/he is mean with her/his money. 
apiripir ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a lake or a road mirage) to glitter; to dazzle; to shine. epiripiri ecor: epiripirete akipi: the lake glitters in the sun. epiripiri akekou: her/his head is shines (because it is clean-shaven). 
apirit (plural apirin) (noun F) a plant formerly used for extracting salt, Cyperus distans; one of the two 'thighs' of the cycle or an ox plough where the wheel (hub) is fixed.
apiriun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become clever. apiriutu kesi: they have become clever. 
apiupiu (singular noun F) the grapevine; rumours. akiro nu aarere ngesi mam ecaete, konye apiupiu naenerasi itunga ice nges abala ebe amariao apese: the reason why he was murdered is not clear, but rumour has it that it was rivalry over a girl.
apiyai (plural noun F) money; cash; currency. 
apoar ko-a (transitive verb) to pull away (as of bark of a tree); to pull the skin off; to strip off, peel off; to pull off and take. kopoa akopit koyanga: pull off a few fibres and take them away. 
apod ko-o (transitive verb) to grouse; to complain; to grumble; to lament; to be in distress; to worry; to care; to deplore, be anxious, or to mind. inyo bo ipodo ijo?: what are you worried about? apodo eong: I mind very much. apodo eong etengei: I am complaining of hunger. epodo ngesi ejose: she/he pretends to be vexed: she/he worries about nothing: she/he has no reason to worry. mam nges epodo: she/he is carefree or unperturbed.
apodokinit (singular noun F) concern; worry; grouse; complaint. 
apodonokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be constantly worried or concerned about something or somebody. epodonokinos kesi kanuka inyamat: they are complaining about food. 
apodonut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be fond of worrying, grousing, complaining. 
apodor ko-o (transitive verb) to complain about something. epodotor kesi ikecekoku inyamat: they are worried about the food for their child. 
apog ko-a (intransitive verb) to swagger; to strut about; to boast; to be proud; to walk proudly; to put on airs; to flaunt. 
apogakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to swagger about; to be arrogant for or to. 
apoganut1 (noun F) vanity; pride; conceit; arrogance. 
apoganut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to be haughty, proud, arrogant. 
apogot (plural apogoi) (noun F) armlet; wristlet; bangle; bracelet. 
apokare (plural of abunere) (transitive verb) (of many) to come. agiroto kesi apokare: agiroto kesi aponere: they have refused to come. 
apokipok (plural apokipokin) (noun F) the back of the knee-joint; (formerly) a rifle; a gun. amoorit naka apokipok: a hamstring; tendons holding the femur and the tibia at the posterior end. 
apokirir ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fat (of anything).
apokokin1 ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a big person) to do a work which is too trifling, or fit for little ones; to be too big, not to fit in. apokokin ejakait toma abolia naka idwe: the chief took part in a children’s game. apokokin icetunganan akonye: to stare at someone. ipokokino ijo aitiji ikoku ngin: you are too big to fight that child. epokokino ngesi aiboi kosomero: she/he is too big or too old to be resident at school. 
apokokin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to give somebody a big piece or lump or share of something 
apokonut1 (noun F) greediness taking big morsels; ravenousness. 
apokonut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be greedy or ravenous by taking big morsels. 
apokopok1 ko-o (transitive verb) to beat on the head, ankles, or elbows; to conk. 
apokopok2 ko-o (transitive verb) to eat something hard or raw (as of raw potatoes, cassava, etc). 
apokor ko-o (transitive verb) to take away something big. apokor akwena: to have a big laugh, to guffaw. apokor etyang: to kill a big animal. apokor euga: to take a big lump of posho.
apokot (plural apokoi) (noun F) the ear of grain; the head of millet. 
apokun akonye ko-o (transitive verb) to bulge out the eyes; to ogle. 
apolisit (plural apolisin) (noun F) a policewoman; a woman constable. cp. asirikaalet, akeeyarit
apolitisian (plural apolitisians) (noun F) a woman politician; a woman member of parliament.
apolo1 (noun F) growth; development; progress; advance.
apolo2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to grow; to become big; to develop; to expand. epoloi ngesi: she/he is growing. 
apolokin1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to grow up (somewhere or for or in); to be brought up at. epolokit ngesi Busia: she/he was brought up at Busia; she/he leads Busia. kapolokit eong aswam na: I cannot manage this work (because it is much). apolok eong toma aswam na: I have grown up doing this work. 
apolokin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to be bigger than; to be too big for; to lead or be in charge of. kipolokit ijo eong: you are bigger than me: you are my senior. epolokit nges akoik: she/he has a very big stomach; she is in her last stages of pregnancy (can hardly move about). apolokin eicolong: to be chairman; to preside (at meeting). 
apolokiniton (plural apolokinitok) (noun F) controller; manager; organiser; the in charge; commander; leader. apolokiniton ajakaanuto kodistrikt: the chief administrative officer in a district. 
apolokit ko-o (transitive verb) to control, to manage, to organise; to be in charge of; to have power over; to be in command of; to lead. 
apolon (plural apolok) (noun F) a respected man in the age range 42–66 years; a master or a boss; a principal. apolon kateker (plural apolok kateker) (noun F) a clan leader or elder. 
apoloor ko-o (reflexive verb) to develop; to grow bigger; to become important; to increase in size; to accrue. 
Apolot (noun F) (formerly) a name given to a girl-child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after the preceding child has died); a woman’s name common in Teso. cp. Opolot 
apolou (singular noun F) importance; greatness; meaning; age; explanation; extent; size; rank; magnitude. ikar luka apolou: age; a lifespan. 
apolounon (plural apolounok) (noun F) one who has just grown up; an adult. etiai kalukapolok: the adult population.
apomor ko-a (intransitive verb) to be corpulent around the stomach. 
apomoror ko-a (intransitive verb) to be corpulent around the waist or belly. ipomoror nges akoik: she/he is corpulent around the belly. cp. abomoror, ajomosos, apongosos (of buttocks). 
aponere ko-a (intransitive verb) (plural of abunere) to come. abuni: I will come. kiponi: we shall come. epote: they will come. kopotu (plural imperative) come. ekot ngesi abunere, ekotos kesi apokare: she/he, they want to come. Past tense: abu (plural kipou): I (we) came. aponi nges kinomai: she/he was beaten or shot. aponi kebungai eong: I was beaten. 
apongorut (plural apongor) (noun F) a lump of soil or clay; a clod. 
apongosos ko-a (intransitive verb) to have fat buttocks; to be fat, corpulent around the buttocks. 
aponikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to befall; to overcome (used with plural noun). kaponikis eong ican: problems have befallen me. 
Apoo1 (noun F) a woman’s name.
apoo2 (plural apooi) (noun F) a scrub hare, Lepus saxatilis; a rabbit (its droppings are believed to heal fire burns if smeared on the affected part). 
apoopi (plural apoopin) (noun F) a bicycle pump. cp. abuuba. 
apoopo ko-a (transitive verb) to tear off big chunks repeatedly. epoopoi ngesi akiring: she/he tears off meat (with her/his teeth). 
apoore (plural apoorei) (noun F) a scar; a mark on the skin or in the soul; a cicatrix. apoore namam elemar: an eternal scar. 
apopir ko-a (transitive verb) to twist a rope, etc between fingers; to roll cigarettes; to spin. apopirikin: to roll up for. kopopirikinai eong esigala: roll me a cigar. 
apopong (plural apopongo) (noun F) a branch of euphorbia plant (figurative) a gun; a bazooka; a rifle.
aporitoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to fly about; to be in flight or airborne. 
aporoc ko-a (transitive verb) to fling with a catapult; to sling; to dart. 
aporocaar ko-a (transitive verb) to sling away; to loosen the sling; to dart away, fling away, or to project (reflexive verb) to go too far; to run forward. 
aporocet (plural aporoceta) (noun F) a catapult; a sling (for throwing a dart or a stone). cp. abiiwu 
aporocikin ko-a (transitive verb) to throw a dart at; to fling at. abu Daudi koporocik Goliasi amoru akou: David slung a stone at Goliath’s head. 
aporogot (plural aporogon) (noun F) a tilapia fish; ngege fish. cp. agar
aporokin ko-o (intransitive verb) to fly on; (of birds) to settle on. abu akokor koporok odula: the hen flew on top of the granary. 
aporor ko-o (intransitive verb) to fly away; to disappear quickly, take to flight; to get away quickly. aipor akeje: to go fast, run away. apotu asigirian eporete akeje karab karab: the donkeys are coming along galloping. aporosi akipi ngun: that water went the wrong way, i.e. went in the wind pipe, did not pass through the throat (hence, causing someone to cough). 
aporun ko-o (intransitive verb) to fly out (from the nest, tree or of white ants from the anthill). aporo ekongot: the white ant has flown away. cp. aimin: to swarm (of white ants). 
aposik ko-o (intransitive verb) to be heavy, grave, difficult. eposik ngesi; eposik kesi: she/he is (they are) heavy. eposik aswam kon: you job is difficult. cp. alangir.
aposikikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to be too heavy for. kaposikikit eong epuko lo: this sack is too heavy for me. akirot naeposik: a serious matter; an important matter; a hopeless task. 
apoti ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a woman or animal) to be pregnant. epotie aberu ngin: that woman is pregnant (a verb to mean pregnancy of animals is aiwacun). 
apotikik ko-a (intransitive verb) (of porridge, beer, sauce, etc) to be thick; (of a person) to be dense, stupid, or obese. 
apotikin ko-o (transitive verb) to make pregnant; to fertilise; to impregnate. 
apotionut1 (noun F) fertility (of women). 
apotionut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a woman) to be conceiving fast. epotiyono aberu ngin: that woman is fertile. 
apotipot (plural apotipotin) (noun F) a ferry (a water vehicle). cp. alaita
apotiu (singular noun F) pregnancy; gestation; conception. aberu napotion (noun F): a pregnant woman.
apotiun ko-o (transitive verb) to conceive. apotiu apese ngin: that girl has conceived or has become pregnant. 
apotokok ko-a (intransitive verb) (of clay, food, beer, etc) to be thick; (of road, compound) to be dirty, muddy. cp. amodokok 
apotuunio (singular noun F) conception; beginning of life; origination. 
apoun ko-a (transitive verb) to strip, peel off for oneself. 
apua (singular noun F) dust; power or vim (to do something). 
apucet (plural apuceta) (noun F) a peace offering. 
apuconut1 (noun F) peacefulness; conciliation. 
apuconut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be peaceful; to be inclined to non-violence. 
apucun ko-o (transitive verb) to educate; to polish up; to furbish. 
apudokin ko-o (transitive verb) to go out early for somebody or something or somewhere. kopudok aswam: go out early for work. cp. adilokin
apudor ko-o (intransitive verb) to go for work, etc early. ipudorete itunga aswam: people go out early to work. epudosi kesi amat: they have gone out early to booze. 
apugan (plural apuganisia) (noun F) administration; governance; the regime. erono apuganike: her/his regime or government is bad. apugan nakotem: sub-county administration. apugan naka ikulepek akwap: the local government. apugan nakedaran: an interim government; a protectorate government.
apugur ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a bent back; to go with a bent back; to be stooping. ai bo ipuguri ijo?: where are you off to with your hunchback? 
apugurikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be bent (of a person’s back). epugurikina ngesi: she/he is hunched. 
apuikin ko-o (transitive verb) to kill for (intentionally); to slaughter for. apotu kesi kapuikis eong emong: they killed a healthy bull for me. 
apujan (plural apujana) (noun F) a marshy lakeshore; a big dried-up swamp with trees. 
apukenit (plural apukenito) (noun F) a clay lid of a granary. 
apuket (plural apuketa) (noun F) a bottle or tin opener
apukokin ko-a (transitive verb) to open for; to uncover (as of a box). 
apukokinio (singular noun F) a revelation; a disclosure. Apukokinio: the Book of Revelations (according to St. John).
apukor ko-o (transitive verb) to open; to reveal; to uncover; to take off the lid or cover; to denude. apukor aki: to listen; to pay attention. apukor akonye: to open eyes; to see. 
apukun ko-o (transitive verb) to discover; to open or uncover; to expose. 
apulakikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to rust; to boil down, be well cooked, well done. apulakiki edia: the vegetables are well done, well cooked. apulakiki ekileng: my knife has rusted or is rusty. 
apulasita (plural apulasitan) (noun F) an adhesive plaster or bandage for wounds; plaster of Paris. 
apuleeje (plural apuleejen) (noun F) a furrow, gutter; a ditch; a rut (in the road). 
apuleera (noun F) (in the Catholic church) a brotherhood; a vicariate; a monastery. cp. ebikirane
apuna (noun F) a soft swamp grass, Panicun astrosanguineum. 
apuneke (plural nukapuneke) (noun F) a wild cat hunted for its meat, Felis silvestris. 
apungure (plural apungurei) (noun F) a log (of wood); a tree stump; a chump. keguiki eong apungure: I have stumbled my foot against a tree stump. ajo bala apungure: to lie or sleep like a log (heavy and without turning).
apunuka (plural apunukan) (noun F) a digestive stomach of a cow or hoofed animals; the abomasum. 
apuny ko-a (transitive verb) to kill for sacrifice at a funeral feast. 
apunya1 (singular noun F) (Usuk) the last funeral rites ceremony. 
apunya2 ko-a (transitive verb) to sack, rob, or plunder; (Usuk) to perform the last funeral rites to the dead (by killing bulls and drinking brew for the purpose). apunya lokatwan: to kill an animal for a funeral feast.
apunyai (plural noun F) the wakes; an annual feast for the departed. 
apuor ko-o (reflexive verb) to escape; to break out (of prisoner); to go beyond limit; to degenerate. apuor etau: insatiable, libertine. cp. acilor. 
apupa ko-a (transitive verb) to rub grain between hands; to grate. epupaete kesi imare: they are rubbing the peas (to take off the husks). cp. anina.
apupaar ko-a (transitive verb) to rub off (as of husks of peas, etc). cp. aninaar. 
apupet (plural apupeta) (noun F) something to hear with; an ear; a hearing aid; a newspaper. cp. apupetait.
apupetait (plural apupeta) (noun F) something to hear with; an ear; a hearing aid; a newspaper. cp. apupet
apupio (singular noun F) the hearing; a court hearing. apupio naka emusaago: court hearing of a case.
apupo (intransitive verb) to be rumoured. akiro nuepupos: rumours. 
apupokin ko-a (transitive verb) to listen in; to attend to or listen with care; to wait a little before acting; to be patient. kopupok ber: first listen (to what I have to say). apupokin ber esimu: to attend to the telephone first. apupokinit: to pay attention; to listen or look with care.
apuponut1 (noun F) listening; attentiveness; compliance; submission. 
apuponut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be obedient; to be ready to listen; to hear 
apupu (plural apupui) (noun F) a hedgehog, Atelerix frontalis. cp. ecoc
apupun ko-o (transitive verb) to hear, listen, or obey. etyono apupun akiro ecelasi itunga: it is difficult to hear when people are shouting. 
apurasas ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fat, corpulent, or obese; to be fat all over. cp. apongosos. 
apuri ko-o (intransitive verb) to be smoking; to evaporate. epurie etogo: the house is smoking. eur etogo lo apuru: this house smells of smoke. 
apurikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to be dusty, covered with dust or flour, brown with dust. ipurikit ijo: you are ashen or dusty. (only used of persons: of table, etc. say ileleba apua omeesa: the table is covered with dust). apuriki nges akekuwan: her/his body is dirty, filthy with age. 
apuriongong ko-o (intransitive verb) to be whitish, pale, ashen (with dust or ash). 
apurior ko-o (intransitive verb) (of gas) to effervesce, fizz, or to bubble. 
apurokin ko-a (transitive verb) to plead for; to reply (in court); to intercede for, make peace with; to pacify. 
apuru (singular noun F) smoke; vapour; gas. 
apurukuc (plural apurukucin) (noun F) a knee-cap; a patella. 
apurus ko-o (intransitive verb) to have diarrhoea; to impale many. cp. aiwurut
Apus (noun F) a pet name for a bluish-grey cow.
apusa ko-a (transitive verb) to beat somebody or something big; to break a big thing; to throw over something full of liquids; eat a juicy or fat thing. epusaete Imugis ikur: the Bagisu eat fat caterpillars. adau ikoku yen apusa akamoti kere: this child has broken all my pots. (used with a plural object).
apusaanar ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall down, throw oneself down repeatedly (as Ateso women do in mourning). 
apusaar ko-a (transitive verb) (used with singular and plural object) to knock down; to break. apusaa etelepat ekatuo: the boy has broken my gourd. 
apusakin ko-a (transitive verb) to throw (of something big); to kill for; to knock down something big somewhere (reflexive verb) (of persons and large objects) to fall down with a thud. 
apusaun etau (reflexive verb) (of heart) to beat suddenly or quickly. apusaun eong etau: my heart has missed a beat (a sign of bad omen). cp. adou eong etau. 
apuserut1 (noun F) a kind of grass. 
apuserut2 (plural apuser) (noun F) a widow. 
apusianar ko-o (reflexive verb) (plural apusiakar) to become purple-grey. 
apusianut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be purple-grey; to have purple-grey spots. 
apusit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be like; to have the appearance or to resemble. epusit ngesi ngai?: whom does she/he resemble? (note: not used of things; of things use: ikoni ai? or ikoni bo ai?) ikoni egoe lo ai?: what does this cloth look like? cp. aiput.
aput (plural aputosia) (noun F) an image; a resemblance; a likeness; a picture; a photo. kinom aputoka: take my photograph.
aputiot (plural aputio) (noun F) a muscle or tendon; a gut. cp. aputot, amoorit
aputokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be like; to be of same colour. aputokinos ngesi ka etyang: she/he is like a brute (an animal). 
aputonor ko-o (reflexive verb) to resemble each other. eputonoro kesi: they resemble each other. 
aputoor ko-o (intransitive verb) to resemble; to be like; to act like. aputoo ngesi Emusugut: she/he acts like a European. 
aputot (plural aputio) (noun F) a muscle or tendon; a gut. cp. amoorit.
apuuga (plural apuugai) (noun F) an unmarried hard-to-control girl; a miss. cp. apese. 
apuun ko-o (reflexive verb) to be spoiled, degenerated; to be alone; to come out, break through. apuun akoniberu: your wife has run this way for protection. 
apuuta (plural apuutai) (noun F) a carnivorous fish - Nile Perch. cp. ageget, agar
apuuton (plural apuutona) (noun F) a sandy plain. 
apuworo ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a wild longing for (usually used with etau). 
apuyapuyat (plural apuyapuyan) (noun F) a crumb. apuyapuyan nuka emugaati: bread crumbs. 
apuyapuyaun ko-o (reflexive verb) to disintegrate; to decay. 
apuyat (plural apuyan) (noun F) a crumb. apuyan nuka emugaati: bread crumbs. cp. apuyapuyat
apuyo ko-o (transitive verb) to take away; to rob; to escape with, run away with. apuyere igoen luka Obore: they robbed Obore’s clothes. apuyo ngesi ikaboro: she/he ran off with my property. 
apwakanut ko-a (transitive verb) to have the initiative. 
apwasaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to fall with a splash. 
apwasakin ko-a (reflexive verb) to smash something against. apwasakin etwo kwap: the gourd was smashed on the ground and is broken completely. apwasakisi ikokolak engarot lo ti okek: the thieves have smashed a huge stone against the door (so as to force the door open).
apwatar ko-a (transitive verb) to polish off; to dust, mop. 
apwatun ko-a (transitive verb) to make clean; to clean, wipe, cleanse. (reflexive verb) to become clean, polished, cleansed. 
apwosok ko-o (intransitive verb) (of groundnut shells) to be empty; (of a person) to be without strength; (of a person) to be without guts or courage. epwosok emaido: the groundnuts shells are empty (no nuts inside). epwosok eketau: she/he has no guts. 
apyakiar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become stale. (used with noun in plural). elosete ajon nu apyakiar: this beer is becoming tasteless (due to water having been poured many times). 
apyaniar ko-a (intransitive verb) to become tasteless, stale (used with noun in singular).
apyanikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be tasteless, stale to; to be distasteful to. kapyanikis eong ajon ngun: that beer is tasteless to me: I find that beer tasteless. 
apyanus1 (singular noun F) tastelessness; staleness; insipidness. 
apyanus2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be tasteless, to be stale, insipid. ajon nu ekotos apyakus: this beer tends to tastelessness. 
apyanuun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become tasteless, stale. apyakuut ajon: the beer has become tasteless (plural apyakuun).
apyeede (plural apyeedei) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a nightjar (bird). 
apyetun ki-a (transitive verb) to devour; to polish off. 
apyeun ko-a (transitive verb) to sweep out; to take out (as of what remains in a granary). ikoto ijo apyeun edula kere?: do you want to empty the whole granary (leaving nothing inside)? 
-ar verbal suffix denoting a repeated act: aanyanar: to check repeatedly; to re-inspect; to re-examine. 
-ar verbal suffix denoting action away from speaker or acquisition of quality: akodar: to drag away. amear: to chase off, to rustle away. (Present tense prefix and suffix: i-ete. Perfect tense suffixes: -a , -asi) 
araakit1 (plural araakin) (noun F) an old woman (beyond reproductive or child-bearing age). cp. arakan
araakit2 (plural ararak) (noun F) a woman from the Irarak clan; a hen or woman with more than the normal number of fingers or toes.
araanut1 (noun F) fertility, fruitfulness, fecundity (of trees, not of animals and human beings). 
araanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of trees)to bear much fruit; to be prolific. 
araba (plural arabai) (noun F) a rubber eraser. 
arabal (plural arabala) (noun F) a women's skirt of skin. cp. aroba.
arabo ko-o (transitive verb) (of plural objects) to clasp tightly (as when riding pillion); to get hold of; to press many things together; to rumple or crumple things in the hand; to fold (as of leaves); to fold or crumple hard things noisily. eraboete idwe apapulai: the children crumple papers. 
araboikin ko-o (transitive verb) (used with plural or singular object) to crumple, rumple. iraboikit ijo ekaitaabo: you have crumpled my book. (reflexive verb) to be crumpled, folded, creased, rumpled, or pressed together. 
aracakin ko-a (transitive verb) (of fluid or semi-fluid) to throw on; to spill on. sirikiracak eong erit: don't throw mud at me (reflexive verb) to fall on, drop on. aracakin acece ogoeneka: the sauce has stained (fallen on) my clothes. 
aracanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pelt somebody with mud or semi-liquids. 
aracar ko-a (transitive verb) to throw away; to spatter (of liquids, or semi-liquids). aracasi idwe akima: the children have splattered the porridge about. 
araet (plural araeta) (noun F) a fruit (in general); an offspring. 
aragoit (plural arago) (noun F) a stubble or stump of burnt grass. 
arai1 (adverb) or; if; whether. arai...arai: whether...or. arai ebuni, arai da mam ebuni: whether she/he comes or not. karaida: although; even if. dimarai: unless; except. nabarai or naarai (adverb) seeing that; because. nabarai edit apak mam abuni: I shall not come because I have no time. arai bo: probably; maybe. 
arai2 da (conjunction) although; even if. cp. karaida.
arai3 present indicative of araus (to be) followed by noun or pronoun. arai: I am; irai: you are (singular); erai: she/he/it is; kirai: we are; eraas: they are. erai ngesi ejakait: he is a chief. cp. ajaus, araus. 
araikiliokit (plural araikiliok) (noun F) a small red and blue fish. 
araikin ko-a (transitive verb) to bear fruit for. 
araitoit (plural araito) (noun F) a fruit (in general). 
arakakin ko-a (transitive verb) (of women and animals) to become barren, be barren, or sterile. erakakit aberu ngin: that woman is barren. 
arakan (plural arakana) (noun F) a barren female (person or animal). cp. adonge.
arakirak ko-a (intransitive verb) (of eyes) to be watery, running; (of an egg) to be watery, half cooked; (in general) to look like phlegm; to be phlegmatic. erakirakete je akonye bala epoon ewaragi: that guy has watery eyes like a crude alcohol distiller.
aramakin ko-a (transitive verb) to beat on, for (of drum). koramak atenus: beat the drum. 
aramet (plural arameta) (noun F) a stick for beating a drum; a stick for threshing grain. cp. agigit
arangan ko-a (transitive verb) to eat greedily; to eat in hurry (intransitive verb) to fuss, do nervously. erangani ekesa ngol enyami: that fellow eats greedily or shakes with greed when eating. 
aranganet (plural aranganeta) (noun F) appetite; eagerness; keenness; enthusiasm; excitement; fervour; impatience. 
arany (plural aranyeta) (noun F) a leather or fabric with four straps (used by women to carry a child on the back). 
aranyet (plural aranyeta) (noun F) a saddle. 
arapaitelait (plural arapaitela) (noun F) a game bird - black ibis, Abdims stork (usually moving in great flocks and eat locusts). cp. aliabong: white ibis.
arapakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to cover up or over, put on lid or cork (reflexive verb) to be covered, be concealed; to lurk. 
arapakinet (plural arapakineta) (noun F) a cover; a lid. cp. arapetait. 
arapanar ko-a (intransitive verb) to screen, cover and keep taking away. araparap: to keep covering many things.
arapar ko-a (intransitive verb) to cover up, hide away, screen off, shelter, or to envelop (reflexive verb) to be covered, screened off. 
arapetait (plural arapeta) (noun F) a cover; a lid; a top. cp. arapakinet. 
araping (noun F) a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis. 
arapud ko-o (intransitive verb) to build flat-roofed or low-roofed houses. erapudete Ilugai itogoi: the Indians build flat-roofed houses (note: plural object used, itogoi).
arapudud ko-o (intransitive verb) (of house) to be low, dwarfish, short. irapududos itogoi ngul: those houses are low. cp. arepenyeny (of man). 
arara1 (plural ararai) (noun F) a cheetah, Acinonyx jubatus. cp. eris: leopard
arara2 ko-a (transitive verb) to collect; to gather; to let things drop down; to shed (tears, leaves). erarai ngesi akito: she/he collects firewood. eraraete akiyo: they are shedding tears. arara akiro: to jabber, talk much; to rattle off words. araraasi ikito akwi: the trees have shed their leaves. araraaros akwi: the leaves have fallen. arara akolong akwi: the sun has made the leaves drop. araraar akwi: to shed leaves. 
araraanar ko-a (transitive verb) to strew on (as of soil or leaves); to spill on. 
araraar ko-a (transitive verb) to shed (as of feathers or leaves); to clean (as of table). araraasi ikito akecekwi: the trees have shed their leaves. 
ararap ko-a (transitive verb) to grope, feel one’s way (as of a blind person or one in the dark). 
ararapaar ko-a (transitive verb) to feel around (as of a person in the dark or a blind person). 
ararapun ko-a (transitive verb) to take without bargaining; to get blindly. ai bo kirarapunia ijo egoe ngol?: where did you buy such a bad cloth? were you blind when you bought such cloth? ararapun aswam: to take any job offered (good or indifferent). 
ararasit (plural ararasia) (noun F) a waste piece; a remnant; crumbs; scrap. kotukonokis ararasia nuka emugaati: gather the breadcrumbs. 
araratoi ko-o (transitive verb) to have the habit of shaking off, of shedding; to crumble off. eraratoi ekitoi akekwi: the tree sheds its leaves regularly. eraratos alup kwap: the plaster of the wall is crumbling away. 
araraun ko-a (transitive verb) to let fall, drop (of fruits from tree or of tears, or spittle). (reflexive verb) to fall down, drop (fruits). araraunos araito kwap: the fruits have fallen (from the tree). 
ararum (plural ararumo) (noun F) the back of body (of man or animal). 
arasaasit (plural arasaasin) (noun F) a bullet; a buckshot; a cartridge; a lead shot. 
arasai (plural noun F) two days old millet or sorghum brew - follows ewinyiwiny (or ebibisi), precedes abeitok, then aperoi: well fermented or good beer. cp. ajon. 
arasakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to start at once. korasak einer alimun akonikiro: say at once what you have to say. 
arasar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go right on, straight forward; to be quick. 
arata ko-a (transitive verb) to do simultaneously; to do together. erataete kesi aida: they beat simultaneously. erataete einer: they talk simultaneously. cp. airot. 
arataikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to reach at the same time, supervene, coincide. arataikinos imopiiran aipany: the balls fell into the hole simultaneously. 
aratakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to insult one another. 
arataun ko-o (transitive verb) (used with infinitive of verb) to do together, coincide. 
aratun ko-a (transitive verb) to call names (once), insult, abuse (once). 
araun ko-o (reflexive verb) to become; to be; to be in a condition. araunos idwe ikiliok: children have become men. tetere araun(or) inyo?: so as to become what?
araus ko-a (transitive verb) to become; to be (followed by noun or pronoun), exist, be in a condition. cp. araut, ajaus. Conjugation of araus: erai (she/he/it is); irai (you are - singular); kirai (we are); iraas (you are – plural); eraas (they are).
araut ko-a (transitive verb) to become; to be (followed by noun or pronoun), exist, be in a condition. Conjugation of araut: erai (she/he/it is); irai (you are - singular); kirai (we are); iraas (you are – plural); eraas (they are). cp. araus, ajaus.
areanar ko-a (transitive verb) to keep pushing away or aside (as when making way through a crowd or high grass. cp. anyaanar.
arear ko-a (transitive verb) to lead away; to push away, urge on or away. 
arebi ko-a (transitive verb) (used with a plural object) to rob, take by force. abu nges korebi ikaboro: she/he robbed me of my belongings. 
arebiar ko-a (transitive verb) to cheat and take away; to rob (of one or many). 
arecekek ko-a (transitive verb) (of ground) to be muddy, slippery (after rain), clammy. 
arege ko-a (transitive verb) to force; to intrude. arege akiro: to make excuses. eregeitoi: to interlope; to intrude.
aregem (plural of aregemit) (noun F) dregs or remnants of groundnut paste. 
aregemem ko-a (intransitive verb) to be thin with a protruding tummy. 
aregerego (plural aregeregon) (noun F) a flour or a grain mill. 
areikin ko-a (transitive verb) to allege or attribute something to someone ; to impute. cp. aluikin: show hatred; to show refusal (by words). 
areit ko-a (transitive verb) to have a dislike for; to persecute; to come to hate; to avenge, detest, or hate; to be spiteful or harsh on; to be odious. kireit ijo eong: you hate me. cp. aila. 
arem ko-o (intransitive verb) to fight (of animals); to push each other. eremos imongin: the bulls are fighting. 
aremerem ko-o (transitive verb) to pierce repeatedly; to riddle (with knife or spear wounds). karemeremeto eong ikukwa: the thorns pricked me. 
aremetoit (plural aremeto) (noun F) a puncture, hole; a spear wound; thorn wound. kitodikinai aremeto: show me the spear wounds. 
aremit ki-o (intransitive verb) to incite, urge on. 
aremo (singular noun F) a bull-fight; fencing. aremo naka imongin. 
aremokin1 ko-o (transitive verb) to push into; to force to do. koremok itaok togo: push the calf into the stable. 
aremokin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to spear for or somewhere; to thrust spear at. aremok eong ekingok ekokolan togo: I speared the thieving dog in the house. 
aremor ko-o (transitive verb) to push away, or to push over; to upset; to exclude, propel, rebut, throw at, or to fling at; to extrude; (of spear) to hurl. aremor edeke: to offer a sacrifice to the god of calamity (in case of an epidemic, crop failure, etc). aremo ikapa akile: the cat upset the milk pot. sirikibirok ekingok amor: do not throw stones at the dog. 
aremot (plural aremon) (noun F) a puncture; a wound (caused by a spear or thorn). cp. aremetoit. 
aremunun ko-o (transitive verb) to keep pushing out one by one (reflexive verb) (of water, blood) to gush. eremununos akipi komoru: the water is gushing from the mountain. 
arengaanut1 (noun F) redness; glow; rosiness; flush. 
arengaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be red, crimson. 
Arengebela (noun F) a pet name for a red-brown cow. 
arengekok (plural arengekokia) (noun F) a superb starling (bird). 
arengeun ko-a (reflexive verb) to become red; to redden. 
arengiar ko-a (reflexive verb) to become red; to redden. 
arengus (singular noun F) redness; ruddiness; rosiness; flushness; blush; glow. 
arepenyeny ko-a (intransitive verb) to be dwarfish, short. 
arereng1 (plural arerengusio) (noun F) luck; boon; benediction; chance. kakotor eong ijo arereng: kanerokit eong ijo arereng: I wish you good luck. abolia naka arereng: gambling; gaming; luck-game. arereng naronon: bad luck; adversity; misfortune. 
arereng1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be lucky, or fortunate; to be blessed. irereng ijo (irereng yesi): you are lucky. arereng arereng: by accident; by chance.
arerengikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be lucky in or with; to favour; to bring luck to. karerengikinit lolo eong ecor: I was lucky today in fishing (literally, the lake favoured me today). arerengikin adumun: to find or discover accidentally. arerengikin ibore: to take advantage of something. abu eong ketaswam arereng naepuwakatar agwelak iboro agweluna amuk: I took advantage of the sales to buy myself some shoes..
arerengonut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be always lucky, fortunate, or blessed. 
arerengoor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become lucky, fortunate, or blessed. 
areret (plural arerei) (noun F) a feather of a pelican (used as a mouthpiece of a drinking tube); a quill of a feather. 
arereu ko-a (intransitive verb) to be rancid; to have the smell of human urine.
ares (plural aresia) (noun F) a stripe (as on cloth, animals, or shaven head); tonsure. aresia nuka akou: patches on the person’s head (natural or shaven). 
aresi ko-a (intransitive verb) (of baby) to yell; (of lighting, rain) to thunder; (of person) to shout in anger. ireta edou: the rain thunders. 
aresiait (plural aresia) (noun F) the eyebrow. cp. abukyoit: eyelash or eyelid.
aresianar ko-a (reflexive verb) to keep shouting in anger. 
aresiar ko-a (reflexive verb) to shout; to flare up, scream. abu ngesi koresiar nepe abuni eong: she/he flared up when I came. 
aretokin ko-o (transitive verb) to hit against; to clash with; to crash on; to rattle teeth; to jar; to slam on; to collide with; to shoot with a lead shot. abu ikoku koretok ekek: the child banged the door. (reflexive verb) to knock oneself against somebody or something; to clash with. 
aretokinet (plural aretokineta) (noun F) a collision; a crash; a conflict. 
aretonokin ko-o (transitive verb) to keep knocking one against another. (reflexive verb) to rattle, clash one against another; (of teeth) to rattle. aretonokinos amotokan: the motorcars collided. 
areun ko-a (transitive verb) to push back (not of things); to lead this way (as of goats, cattle, etc). koreu akituk lailo: drive the cattle this way. 
ari (plural arion) (noun F) general direction. aloto kesi ari nanyoin?: in what direction did they go? aloto ari nakokide: they went to the east. 
aria ko-a (intransitive verb) to crack, split open. arias amor: the rocks split open. 
ariacet (plural ariaceta) (noun F) a crack; a fissure; a cleave. 
ariak ko-a (intransitive verb) (plural form of arian) to be equal, alike, the same; to be similar (in size). iriaka iso: we are equal, alike, the same size or same age. iriakas yesi: you (plural) are equal, alike, the same. iriakas kesi: they are equal, alike, the same. cp. aiput (for quality). kiriaka iso kajo: we and you (singular) are equal. 
ariakat (plural ariaka) (noun F) a kind of white beads. 
ariako (plural ariakin) (noun F) a species of grasshopper. 
arian1 (plural ariak) (noun F) equality (in size); flat or level; horizontal. 
arian2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be equal, be alike, be the same (size). 
arianakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to become equal, become the same (size). erianakinos ikito ngul: those trees are of the same height; coincide. 
ariang (plural ariangia) (noun F) a garden from where a millet crop has just been harvested; a stubble of millet crop; stumps left after reaping millet; (in Karamoja) the government (or its agencies, such as the police, the councils, etc). 
ariap (adverb) (to be startled) very suddenly; startlingly. cp. riak.
ariar ko-a (transitive verb) to split once. koria akitoi ngin: split that stick or wood. 
ariariatoi ki-a (intransitive verb) to go about aimlessly; to wander about. 
ariasit (plural ariasia) (noun F) a crack; a split; a rift; a fissure. 
aribik ko-o (intransitive verb) to be pitch black 
aribirib ko-o (intransitive verb) to be pitch black, shining black; (of night) to be pitch dark. 
aribokin ko-o (transitive verb) (of sunlight) to become dark, dull, momentarily. ariboki akwap: it is dark, cloudy, overcast. 
aribokinit (noun F) penumbra; darkness; gloom or shade. 
aribor ko-o (intransitive verb) to become dark, throw a shadow, become dull. 
aricakin ko-a (transitive verb) to keep in custody for. (reflexive verb) to stick together, be inseparable friends. 
aricar ko-a (transitive verb) to get hold of and take away. 
aricun ko-a (transitive verb) to get hold of and bring home. 
arida ko-a (transitive verb) to beat with a big thing. 
aridakin ko-a (transitive verb) to squeeze or grip; to press upon; to fasten between clips; to clasp, constrict, or clamp. kikunya, kiridak ijo eong: extend, you are squeezing me. (reflexive verb) to be squeezed between, pressed, or clasped. karidaki eong ekek: the door squeezed me. aridakina ibokor okek: the fingers were squeezed in the door. 
aridar ko-a (transitive verb) to squeeze into or through (narrow opening); to clasp between pincers and take away. korida epaabaka: take my little cotton with yours. (reflexive verb) to pass through a narrow opening, squeeze oneself through, infiltrate. abu eong keteleka, konye arai aridar: I won, but it was just squeezing through. 
aridat (plural aridan) (noun F) narrow space or passage, gate, pass (between rocks or in bushes). 
aridet (plural arideta) (noun F) pincers; clasp. 
aridi (plural aridieik) (noun F) a narrow gate or passage; a corridor; a railed off passage for animals between the kraal and the grazing grounds. 
aridirida ko-a (intransitive verb) to be squeezed together; to crowd together; to be crowded. 
aridunet (plural ariduneta) (noun F) pincers; clasp; tong. 
arieba ko-a (intransitive verb) to feel pain; to feel anxious; to be aching for. arieba eong abunere nekon: I am anxious to come to see you. 
ariebakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to get sick, suffer pain, feel pain in. ariebakin eong akou: I have a pain in my head. 
ariebo (singular noun F) pain; ache; suffering; hurt; ailment; sickness; disease. cp. apipilu
ariengakin ko-a (transitive verb) to be startled at, get a shock on account of, be excited with. ariengaki nges emuudu: the gunshot startled her/him
ariengun ko-a (intransitive verb) to be startle; to be thrilled; to get a shock, get excited; to be frightened, be altogether surprised, be flabbergasted; to shudder; to be disturbed; to stand aghast. abu nges korieng nepe eduor emuudu: she/he was startled when the gun went off. 
arietait (plural arieta) (noun F) a crack; a split (in a pot or anything). 
arigirigi (plural arigirigin) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a one-stringed tube fiddle played to accompany a human voice; an African violin. cp. adigidigi.
ariikin ko-a (transitive verb) to put crosswise, obstruct. (reflexive verb) to obstruct. iriikino ikukwa orot: thorns obstruct the road. eriikis kesi akitoi orot: they have put a wooden barrier across the road. 
ariim ko-a (intransitive verb) to be thin; to be slender. 
ariimim (noun F) slimness; slenderness; skinniness. 
ariit (plural ariito) (noun F) a crossbeam (in a building); the milky-way (in astronomy). 
arikodod ko-a (intransitive verb) to be thin, wasted (after illness). irikododas itunga luedekas esilim: AIDS patients are thin or wasted.
arikokin ko-a (transitive verb) to lead for or somewhere; (of material things) to link; (of premises) to connect to power or water supply. arikokin akanin: to link arms. arikokin akim naka eipyei: to connect electricity to (a building).
arikomom ko-o (intransitive verb) to be long (of body); to be tall. 
arikor ko-o (transitive verb) to lead away (by the rope or hand) (reflexive verb) to go away hand-in-hand. 
arikosit (plural arikon) (noun F) a link; a bond; a chain. 
arima ko-o (intransitive verb) to go often, go frequently, or go everyday; to frequent. erimaete kesi oreka duc: they frequent my home. erimaete itunga toma aswam: people go daily to their work. 
arimaanut1 (singular noun F) faithfulness; dutifulness; obedience; docility; amenability; fealty; allegiance. 
arimaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be faithful, obedient, dutiful, amenable. 
arimaar ko-a (transitive verb) to obey; to be amenable, be faithful to. erimaarit ikoku totoke: the child obeys its mother. 
arimaarit (noun F) fidelity; obedience. 
arimakin ko-a (transitive verb) to believe, obey, follow, be docile, be polite to; to take somebody's word. esabi ngol, mam irimakini akiroke: he is telling lies, do not take his word. 
arinyor ko-o (intransitive verb) to begin to shrivel, wrinkle, fade, wilt (from drought); to get thin. arinyo eong kanuka adeka: I am thin on account of my illness. 
arinyoret (plural arinyoreta) (noun F) a wrinkle (on face or body); a crinkle (due to withering). 
arinyot (plural arinyon) (noun F) an old potato garden or plot. 
ario (plural ariyoi) (noun F) obstacle; barrier; impediment. 
ariodik ki-a (intransitive verb) to bend the knee, curtsy, genuflect. 
ariodikikin1 (noun F) a curtsy; a genuflection. 
ariodikikin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to bend the knee (for); to kneel on one knee; to curtsy (reflexive verb) to genuflect. eriodikikinos itunga kokelesia: people genuflect in the cathedral. cp. akukokin: to kneel. 
Ariokot1 (noun F) (formerly) a name given to a girl-child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after preceding child has died). 
ariokot2 (plural nukariokot) (noun F) a species of grasshopper. 
ariong (plural lukariong) (noun F) a peace-maker of old. kolo karionga (adverb) long ago. kolo karionga, ariongitos itunga abotei; konye kwana, edakitos itunga imuudun: in the olden days, people carried their clubs about; but nowadays, people carry guns. 
ariongakin ko-a (transitive verb) to carry for or on shoulder. eriongakinit ngesi ebela okeper: she/he carries a stick on her/his shoulders. (reflexive verb) to be carried on shoulder (as of a child, big enough to be carried on shoulders). 
arior1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to die (literally, to stretch one’s body in death). 
arior2 ko-o (transitive verb) to stretch; to put straight; to straighten; to correct (a person making a mistake); to draw out. arior akiro: to settle a difficulty. arior akeje: to stretch one’s legs. arior emukeeka: to unfold a mat. korior kodai: lie down and be beaten.
aripad ko-a (transitive verb) (used with plural objective) to hammer down, beat with a big club; (of houses) to build low or flat. itunga luko Misiri eripadete itogoikec: the Egyptians build flat houses. 
aripaduun ko-a (transitive verb) to make low, flat; to flatten. aripaduun akai: to build a low house (for oneself). (reflexive verb) to fall down slowly, come down slowly, be low (as of house, etc). 
aripakin ko-o (transitive verb) (Usuk) to look at through an eye-hole; to go one behind another. 
aripar ko-o (reflexive verb) to accompany, follow after, or go together. eriparos kesi oiduka: they are going together to the shops. cp. aupar, adipar.
aripidid (intransitive verb) (of a man or boy) to have small buttocks and narrow hips. cp. animokok. 
aripiny (plural noun F) self-seeded groundnuts. 
aripirip ki-a (intransitive verb) (of the sea) to flicker, glimmer or shimmer in a dull way. cp. aparipar: (of the sea, lake, mirage) to glimmer brightly. 
aripooti (plural aripootin) (noun F) a report (about class perfomance); a testimony. 
arira ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a fire) to burn away (without being used); to blaze away. 
ariri (singular noun F) a shore; a river bank; a brim; the edge; a vicinity; a place near to; the beach. ariri nak’ecor: the shore of the lake; the river bank. ariri naka akonye: near the eye. apero ariri naka akim: to sleep near the fire. 
aririet (plural aririeta) (noun F) a splinter or chip of wood. 
aririp ki-o (transitive verb) (of sky) to be overcast; to be cool. cp. aribokin
aririu1 (singular noun F) a smell of raw fish or of urine; rancidity. 
aririu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to smell like fish or urine; to be rancid. eriri ebilaangit ekulam: the blanket smells of urine. emekenyit eriri agaria: a Mukenye fisherman smells of fish. 
arita (plural aritai) (noun F) a bundle; a parcel; a load; (number) thousand. aritai: thousands. 
aritikik ko-o (intransitive verb) to be very fat, thick and with knock-knees; to be huge and knock-kneed. iritikikos imongin ngul: those bulls are very fat and knock-kneed. 
aro (plural aroatin, aroan) (noun F) a large uninhabited zone; wild savannah; a large wild plain. 
aroa ko-a (transitive verb) to look at one another; to spoon. eroas akokoroi, apolouke epote lolo ipejok: the chickens are sizing each other, it means we shall have visitors today. 
aroanakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to look at oneself (in mirror or otherwise).
aroanar ko-a (transitive verb) to oversee. 
aroar ko-a (transitive verb) to go to visit. 
arobat (plural aroba) (noun F) a woman’s laced skin-skirt; strips of leather to support the girdle; a belt. cp. arokoba, arabal. 
arobeikin ko-o (transitive verb) to rob or take by force. 
arobi ko-a (transitive verb) to take somebody else’s thing (along with one’s own); to cheat or hoodwink. 
arobiar ko-a (transitive verb) to take away somebody’s things (as if by mistake); to take by force; to confiscate. cp. ademar. 
arobiikin ko-a (transitive verb) to rob, take away by force. cp. arobeikin. 
aroboota (plural arobootai) (noun F) a bale (of cotton, or an assortment of used clothing). 
arocakin ko-a (transitive verb) to tie to (reflexive verb) to be lassoed, tied to. 
arocet (plural aroceta) (noun F) a lasso; a rope to catch animals with. 
arocun ko-a (transitive verb) to trip (an animal with a rope); to lay by the heel (reflexive verb) to be lassoed. 
arodakin ko-a (reflexive verb) to cheat one another; to be deceived; (of chess board pebbles) to get mixed up. arodakinos amor: the pebbles (used in the game of aile) are mixed up. 
arodiar ko-a (transitive verb) to take by deceitful means; to defraud; to usurp. arodia ngesi ajakaanut: she/he has usurped power. karodi eong: I have been cheated. 
Arododo (noun F) (in the Teso week) Saturday. cp. Naemukaaga
aroet (plural aroeta) (noun F) a mirror; a looking glass. 
aroikin1 ko-a (transitive verb) to examine for; to inspect for; to taste (vegetables or beer) for somebody. 
aroikin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to make narrow, cause to shrink. aroikin aki: to close ears to; to turn a deaf ear to. 
aroikin3 ko-o (transitive verb) to oppress; to compress; to rule firmly; to govern severely; to rule with an iron hand; to pinch. eroikit ejakait ngol iketunga: that ruler oppresses his people. (reflexive verb) to fall in (as of cheeks of old people). aroikinos ikekitinyo: she/his cheeks have fallen in. (reflexive verb) to cower. 
aroikinet (plural aroikineta) (noun F) a dictatorship; a tyranny; oppression. 
aroikinon (plural aroikinok) (noun F) a despot; a tyrant; a dictator; an oppressor. 
arok (plural arokio) (noun F) a gulf; a bay; a recess. arok naka acer: the milky way. arok naka akou: arok naka ereet: a receding forehead. 
arokoba (plural arokoban) (noun F) a belt; a strap; a girdle; cincture. cp. arobat. 
arokodet (plural arokoden) (noun F) a species of bird. 
arokodod ko-o (intransitive verb) (of body) to be very thin due to sickness. cp. arikodod, adikoror. 
arokonut ko-o (intransitive verb) to be fond or apt to acquire or contract good or bad habits. 
arokotot ko-a (intransitive verb) to be rough, uneven (as of bad road, skin or board, etc). 
arokun ko-o (transitive verb) to adapt or copy; to derive. arokun ibore: to adapt or copy something.
aromait (plural aroma) (noun F) (outside Usuk) an injury; a beaten or hurt spot; a bruise; swelling of or inflamation of the throat. cp. amusungut, akangas, aromwait.
aromococ ko-a (intransitive verb) to be knock-kneed. 
aromwait (plural aromwa) (noun F) (Usuk) an injury; a beaten or hurt spot; a bruise. cp. amusungut, akangas.
arongokin ko-o (transitive verb) to gorge, take a bite at or in. 
aronianakin ki-a (intransitive verb) to be frequently bad for, not to agree with; to disagree with often. karonianakini eong emugaati: the bread nauseates me. 
aroniar ki-a (reflexive verb) to become bad, evil, spoiled, nasty, depraved, or deteriorated. arokiaros: they have become bad. erokiaros: they will become bad. arokiata: they have become bad. 
aronikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bad for, etc 
aronus1 (plural aronusyo) (abstract noun F) sin; evil; badness; wickedness. 
aronus2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bad, evil, spoiled; to be wicked, or sinful. erono: she/he/it is bad, wicked, etc. irono jo: you (singular) are bad, depraved, etc. kiroko oni: we are bad, evil, etc. iroko yesi: you (plural) are bad, dirty, etc. 
aropetait (plural aropeta) (noun F) a wage; emolument; a reward; a recompense; an award; a premium; a merit; a remuneration. cp. eropit.
aropi ko-o (transitive verb) to elongate by adding; to join end to end. 
aropiar ko-o (transitive verb) to make longer by adding; to continue from where someone else stopped. 
aropikin ko-o (transitive verb) to join onto or to join for; to go together. 
aropior ko-o (transitive verb) to make longer by adding; to continue from where the speaker stopped; to join; to extend. 
arorokanut1 (noun F) greed; avarice (involving grabbing from others).
arorokanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be avaricious, grasping 
arorwai (plural arorwa) (noun F) a gap; a lapse in security or defences; a passage in a fence, forest, mountains, etc. cp. epiding; acingat, aridi. 
arotakin ko-a (transitive verb) to spy for; to spy somewhere. 
arotongong ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a deformed brick-shaped head, with a narrow thin face. 
aroun ko-o (transitive verb) to see for oneself; to find out for oneself. 
arowot1 (plural arowoi) (noun F) an iron collar (as worn by Iteso in the past).
arowot2 (plural arowon) (noun F) a calabash; a vessel made of calabash. cp. adere
arubakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to heal up, congeal, coagulate. arubakis akile: the milk is congealing. cp. aikamun
arubangat (plural arubangan) (noun F) (rare) an evil spirit; an idol. aijaanakin arubangat: to worship an idol; idolatry. 
arucetait (plural aruceta) (noun F) a knot; a joint; a connection. 
arucokin ko-o (transitive verb) to join, connect, or put (wire, rope) together; to tie (wire, rope); to knot together; to link (of chain) or join (anything); to fit. 
arucokiniton (plural arucokinitok) (noun F) a coordinator; a link. 
arucosit (plural arucesia) (noun F) a knot; a link. 
arudangang ko-a (intransitive verb) to be narrow-headed; to have a narrow head. cp. amudangang. 
arugamat (plural arugaman) (noun F) a hunch-back, i.e. a deformation of the backbone. cp. arugamo.
arugamo (plural arugamon) (noun F) a hunch-back, i.e. a deformation of the backbone.
arugut (plural arugui) (noun F) a fictitious hyena-like ogre; a child-eating ogre in Teso fables. cp. arara: cheetah
aruikin1 ko-o (transitive verb) (of a drum) to sound; to make a noise, roar, bellow, low; (of a gun) to go off somewhere. 
aruikin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to spit at or somewhere; to spout at or into. abu emun karuik eong akeimula: the snake spat its venom at me. 
aruja (plural arujai) (noun F) a basket for trapping fish or birds; a no-return trap or a snare made of wire mesh or withies (generally used for birds and rats); a cage for transporting birds to the market. cp. ebukit, eisobwa
arujakin ko-a (transitive verb) to fold up, pull together, cover over (as of skin on wound); to shoot at or somewhere (with an arrow); to hit (with an arrow shot) (reflexive verb) to pucker; to wrinkle; to contract, pull itself together (as of skin after wounding). arujakin akeje: to stand to attention. 
arujanut1 (noun F) (of medicine on wound) astringency. 
arujanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of embrocation) to be binding, astringent. 
arujuruj ki-a (transitive verb) (of lips or buttocks) to contract or compress, become hard. arujuruj akituk: to compress lips (as in great pain). 
aruk (plural arukia)(noun F) a hump (on the back) as on African Zebu cattle; a hunch. 
arukan (plural arukana) (noun F) a whip; a leather thong. 
arukio ko-o (transitive verb) to pursue; to chase. 
arukit (plural arukito) (noun F) a pestle or a pounding stick made from the wood of epuuton, ekungur, or ekisim. ingai ikoku eoj adepar totoke? arukit: (a riddle) what child is taller than its mother? a pestle (being longer than the mortar).
arukokin ko-o (transitive verb) to chase away for; to expel for, dismiss for (reflexive verb) to run after somebody and try to catch them. 
arukor ko-o (transitive verb) to crush in a mortar. 
arukoria ko-a (prepositional verb) to drive away; to chase away, or to expel. korukoria ekingok: chase away the dog. 
arukudikin ko-a (transitive verb) to bend up, fold up (as of back or body). arukudikin ikoku: to bend the little child (when carrying it on the back) (not used for other things). cp. aikud, aibong, 
arukudud ko-a (intransitive verb) to be bent in the back; to be stooping. irukududas kesi: they have bent backs. 
arukumuikep (plural nukarukumuikep) (noun F) a bird, ostrich pebble-roller. 
arumonor ko-o (transitive verb) to finish one after the other; to complete one after the other; to consume one after the other; to terminate one after the other. 
arumor ko-o (transitive verb) to finish, terminate, kill, consume. arumosi kesi inyamat: they have finished the food. (reflexive verb) to die; to be completed, terminated, or consumed; to expire. 
aruo1 (plural lukaruo) (noun F) a great talker; an orator. eruo ngesi tai: she/he is simply a talker and does nothing. 
aruo2 (singular noun F) a thunder; a sound; a boom. 
aruo3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to sound, make a noise; to roar, low, bellow, hoot; (of a drum) to sound, (of gun) to go off; to clack. eruo ngesi tai: she/he just talks or roars but does no harm. 
aruonut1 (singular noun F) sounding; thundering; lowing; roaring; growling; croaking; crowing. inyukutan lukaruok: inyukutan lueruos: vowel letters: a, e, i, o, u. 
aruonut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be sonorous, noisy, etc.
aruopokok ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a receptacle, a pod, a tyre, etc) to be empty. aruopokok naka akoik: the hungry state (stomach empty); the fast (abstention from food). iruopokok eong akoik: I am hungry. iruopokok emopiira: the football is deflated. iruopokokos itunga apaarasia nuka Ailung: people are hungry during Lent. cp. apedekek.
aruor ko-o (transitive verb) to spit out. aruun: to spit this way. cp. agumun akipi. 
arupaada (plural arupaadan) (noun F) a catapult. cp. aduwet, aporocet, asupaada
arupeede (plural lukarupeede) (noun F) a woman with small buttocks. 
arupepe (plural arupepen) (noun F) a side-blown trumpet for summoning people; a bugle; a megaphone. aikut arupepe: to blow a trumpet. imulokolen luka arupepe: trumpet-blowing Christian sects who go about preaching in the street with megaphones.
arupiya (plural arupyai) (noun F) (formerly) a rupee (Indian money); (any) money. 
aruput (plural arup) (noun F) strips of dried fatty meat. cp. aleat, alean. 
aruruak1 (singular noun F) solid fat for smearing or other external use. akile nueruruakito: congealed milk. aruruak naka ao: beeswax. cp. asyepai.
aruruak2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to begin to congeal (of fat or milk). aruruakata acec nuasiepai: the fatty soup has begun to congeal. aruruaket naka akile: the cream of milk.
aruruakikin ko-a (intransitive verb) (of fat or milk) to congeal. 
aruruk ko-a (intransitive verb) to catch up, run for something, or to try and be in time to. koruruk abaasi ekoto anyoun: catch the bus before it leaves. korurukai eong: (an SOS) come quickly to my rescue. 
arurukaar ko-a (intransitive verb) to go quickly; to hurry away. arurukit agiriaun isirigin luebaga nges eyaununei akangasia nuimotokan angeset naka ekaru: the drivers’ greed to rip profit during Christmas time is the cause of many car accident at the year end.
arurukanut1 (singular noun F) disaster preparedness; swift-reacting; swift response. 
arurukanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to always respond swiftly. 
arurukikin ko-a (transitive verb) to bring early to (before anybody). (reflexive verb) arrive early, come early. korurukikinos aitac isirigin luka aiwadikaun: pay registration fees early. 
arurukuun ko-a (intransitive verb) to come quickly; to come early; to hasten to come; to return in a hurry. 
arurut1 (noun F) slipperiness; slime; grease. erurut erot: the road is slippery or smooth.
arurut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be slippery, slimy, smooth (of anything), clever, or slick. 
arurutaar (intransitive verb) to become slippery, smooth or slimy. 
arurutikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be slippery for. 
arurwak (singular noun F) lard used for smearing spear shafts; (Ateso Atororo) soap. cp. akuruny
arutat (singular noun F) ground vibration; sound of running feet or people running. 
arutor ko-o (transitive verb) to uproot, throw away, eradicate (as of vice or weeds), dislodge; to stretch out (limbs). koruto iponesio lueroko: eradicate bad habits or bad manners. 
arutuk ko-o (transitive verb) to beat simultaneously, hammer all together, stamp the ground simultaneously (as when making a mud floor or in a military drill). 
arutun ko-o (transitive verb) to pull up, uproot, eradicate, or dislodge. 
aruturut akuwan ko-o (transitive verb) to exercise the body; to take physical exercise; to have physical training. 
aruun1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to sound, clang (as of a bell). cp. airu. 
aruun2 ko-o (transitive verb) to spit out. 
arwaar ko-a (transitive verb) to stretch (especially of rope); to draw out, draw up (as of a line of soldiers). 
arwadak ko-a (intransitive verb) to go about covered with dirt. 
arwadakak ko-a (intransitive verb) (of anything) to be dirty, covered with dirt. 
arwait ko-o (intransitive verb) to be wearing across the shoulder. arwaitos kolo Iteso ibilaangin: the Iteso of the past wore blankets over their shoulders. 
arwarwa ko-a (transitive verb) to crack, crackle (as of finger joints, or maize roasting in hot stove). 
arwatat (plural arwatatin) (noun F) (Usuk) a wall; a partition; a barrier. cp. apama
arwaun ko-o (reflexive verb) to startle, jump up, be excited; to start up. arwaun ikoku kotoma aperit: the child jumped up suddenly from its cot. 
arwetar ko-a (transitive verb) to tear off or away; to snatch or pull away. 
arwetun ko-a (transitive verb) to pull out; to get off, take off (as of a patch on wound, or handle from tool) (reflexive verb) to come off (by itself). 
arwopokok ko-o (intransitive verb) (of stomach, tyre, or football) to be empty. 
aryengun ko-a (intransitive verb) to be startled. aryengun riaka riak: to be very startled or frightened.
asaajait (plural asaaja) (noun F) a pack-saddle. 
asaanit (plural asaanin)(noun F) a plate; a dish. ejaas inyamat asaanit: there is food in the plate. cp. ebakuli: a bowl.
asaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to go along slowly; to go late alone; to go later than others unhurriedly. 
asaara ko-a (intransitive verb) (of people, especially children) to be well-behaved or neat; to be gentle and good. esaara akiro ngun: that issue is settled. asaara akiro kore?: is all well at home? esaara akiro ejok?: is everything ok? esaara erekon?: is everything ok at your home? esaara akuwan?: are you alright? 
asaasaat (plural asaasaan)(noun F) a palm leaf; a palm frond. 
asaati (plural asaatin) (noun F) a blouse or a top (for women). 
Asabaato (plural Asabaaton)(noun F) (biblical) Sunday; the Sabbath. 
asabakin ko-a (transitive verb) to tell lies about somebody; to slander or libel; to malign; to give too much (of anything) to. cp. akwamakin.
asabakinet (plural asabakineta)(noun F) a slander, defamation, misrepresentation, scandal, calumny. 
asaban (plural asabak) (noun F) a witchdoctor; a liar; a charlatan. 
asabunet (plural asabuneta) (noun F) a lie; slander; calumny; a draught (of water, etc); an amount of anything taken up at once. 
asabuuni (plural asabuunin) (noun F) soap. isabuuni: a little soap; a piece of soap. asabuuni nakiloset: washing soap. asabuuni nakilongis: toilet or bathing soap. atekat naka asabuuni: a bar of soap. apeelet naka asabuuni: a flake of soap. asabuuni n’akiria: powder soap. cp. amasabu, asabuunyu
asabuunyu (plural asabuunyun) (noun F) soap. isabuunyu: a little soap; a piece of soap. asabuunyu nakiloset: washing soap. asabuunyu nakilongis: toilet or bathing soap. atekat naka asabuunyu: a bar of soap. apeelet naka asabuunyu: a flake of soap. asabuunyu n’akiria: powder soap. cp. amasabu, asabuuni
asacanut1 (singular noun F) avoidance; deviating; shunning. 
asacanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of parents of their children, birds and their eggs) to avoid, shun, or shirk. 
asacar ko-o (reflexive verb) to shirk or avoid. 
asaduku (plural asadukun) (noun F) a box; a suitcase; a coffin. 
asaet (plural asaeta) (noun F) a nursery (for children); orphanage; a maternity home. 
asagarar ko-a (intransitive verb) (of hair) to be uncombed; to be rough, be bare (as of a leafless tree), be spread out (as of fingers). 
asakasak ko-a (intransitive verb) to stroll about; to have a walk; to take a stroll. esakasakai: she/he is strolling about. esakasakaete: they are strolling about. isakasakae: you are strolling about. asakasakae: I am strolling about. cp. eilat. 
asakat (noun F) a strong and nasty smell, especially of traditional tobacco. asakat naka emakole: the nasty smell of tobacco smoke. 
asaket (plural asaketa) (noun F) a smell (good or bad). 
asakunun ko-a (transitive verb) to glean or gather (what reapers left). 
asalabait (plural asalaba) (noun F) a scab on an ulcer; an incrustation; a dried-up eye exudate.
