asalakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to remain over, stay behind. asalakis idwe ore: the children stayed at home (adverb) (nothing remains to be done) except. asalaki do alosit ore: there is nothing left but to go home. asalanakin: asalenen: to stay away, remain behind often or always. 
asalang (noun F) a grass, Brachiaria kotschiana. 
asalanut1 (noun F) absenteeism; bunking off; skiving. 
asalanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined or in the habit of staying behind 
asalun ko-a (intransitive verb) to remain here; to come to an end; (of plan) to come to nothing, be frustrated. 
asamukuk ko-o (intransitive verb) to have long hair. isamukukos angor ngun akwes: those ladies have long braided hair.
asangad1 (singular noun F) a dance; a prance. 
asangad2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to dance, or to jig.
asangal (plural noun F) the simsim stalks left in the garden after harvest. cp. atolong. 
asangalal ko-a (intransitive verb) (of wasps) to be ready to sting; (of dog, cat, etc baring teeth or claws) to be ready to attack. cp. aisangang. 
asangan ko-a (intransitive verb) to tremble, shake with excitement; to be eager, on the alert, do greedily. esangani ikoku akuwan enyami: the child eats greedily (with the body trembling). cp. arangan.
asanget (plural asangeta) (noun F) the end; the finish; the cessation; acme; conclusion; abrogation. cp. esange. 
asangir ko-o (intransitive verb) to dishevel, ruffle hair or feathers. 
asangirir ko-o (intransitive verb) (of hair) to be dishevelled; (of hair) to stand on end; (of hair of cat or dog when attacking) to stand up. isangiriros ajul: the fur or feathers stand on end. 
asangironokin ko-o (transitive verb) (of birds) to preen feathers. 
asanyakak ko-a (intransitive verb) to be shabby, decrepit, ragged. 
asanyirir ko-a (intransitive verb) to have bristling hair (of dog or cat when afraid). 
asanyisany (plural asanyisanya) (noun F) the third stomach of a cow, abomasum; (slang) the genitalia or vagina of a woman. cp. apunuka; anyakinyak.
asaot (plural asaon) (noun F) a kind of plant (with edible fruit). 
asapan1 (singular noun F) (Usuk) the initiation ceremony for adolescents and adult men to senior age groups; initiation to elderhood. cp. eigworone.
asapan2 ko-a (transitive verb) (Usuk) to initiate a man to a senior age group. 
asapatu (plural asapatun) (noun F) a rubber slipper (shoe or sandal). cp. asilipat
asapirir ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a person) to have ruffled or unkempt hair.
asarab ko-a (transitive verb) to drink noisily (as of thick hot porridge). angobun akima sarab: to drink porridge noisily. 
asarabaar ko-a (transitive verb) to drink noisily; to drink something thick. sirikisarabaa akima kere: do not drink all the porridge (noisily). cp. angobar
asarai (plural asara) (noun F) afterglow in the sky; a big blaze (as of grass fire). 
asaran ko-a (intransitive verb) (of fire) to glow; to smoulder; to be fiery; to be red hot. esarani akim: the fire is red hot. esaranete akonyeke bala akim: her/his/its eyes are red like a flame. cp. aidop.
asaranun ko-a (intransitive verb) to become red hot, glow, blaze up. 
asasam ko-a (intransitive verb) to be sour (as of vinegar). (note: it is used of eggs and meat only to mean ‘nice’). akiring na esasam noi: this meat is very nice or delicious. inyami ijo neesasam: you are alright, you get nice food. atap naesasam: millet bread cooked with sour (fermented) milk or apedur fruit. akile nuesasam: sour or fermented milk. ajon nuesasam: millet brew that has gone bad (bitter to the taste).
asasamaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to turn sour. akile nu asasamaaros: this milk has gone sour. 
asasamunet (plural asasamuneta) (noun F) a flavour (a sour or bitter taste). 
asasiai (plural asasia) (noun F) a fruit or sand-fly often sucking beer, ripe fruit, etc. cp. ejur.
asasit (plural asasin) (noun F) a bullet; a cartridge; a lead shot. cp. arasaasit. 
asaun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come late; to come in style. asaunun akiro: to articulate issues. 
asaunet (singular noun F) a nice smell; a fragrance; an aroma. 
asear ko-a (transitive verb) to pick and take away; to select and take away; to choose and take away. 
Asebeit (plural Asebei) (noun F) a woman native to former Sebei (the present day Kapchorwa district); a Sabiny woman; a word in the Sebei language. Asebei: the Sabiny women; the Kupsabiny language. 
asebot (plural asebon) (noun F) the top end of the spinal cord; the medulla oblongata. 
asedenyeny ko-a (intransitive verb) to be shallow, not deep. cp. asudeny. 
Aseera (plural noun F) women from Serere county in Soroti district; the Serere dialect of Ateso language that take ‘gw’ for ‘bw’, for example, Aseera say aigwot instead of aibwot, aigwang instead of aibwang, aigworo instead of aibworo. 
Aseerait (plural Aseera) (noun F) a woman from Serere in Soroti district; a word from the Serere dialect of Ateso language. 
aseg ko-a (intransitive verb) to be clean, neat, spotless, unstained; to be holy, perfect, immaculate. 
asega (singular noun F) cleanliness, neatness; hygiene. 
asegakin ainyam ko-o (reflexive verb) to eat without having done any work. cp. ainyam ekulukulu
aseganut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to or fond of being neat, dainty or clean. 
asegis (singular noun F) cleanliness; neatness; spotlessness; perfection; holiness. 
aseikin ko-a (transitive verb) to choose for; to select for. koseikinai eong egoe loejok: select a strong, nice cloth for me. 
aseit (plural aseito) (noun F) a peg used for pegging out skins and hides to dry; a polling station, booth. 
asekar ko-a (transitive verb) to pick and take out, away. asekun: to choose, pick, select. 
asekeny ko-a (intransitive verb) to go through the high grass. 
asekenyeny ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a garden, homestead, etc) to be overgrown; (of a house) to look untidy. 
asekenyu (noun F) desolation; untidiness. 
asekisek ko-a (intransitive verb) to choose several times; to pick out many things; to make a choice. 
asekunun ko-a (intransitive verb) to pick up one after the other (like a hen or bird). cp. atodunun. 
aselel ko-a (intransitive verb) (of anything, especially of the skin) to be smooth. eselel emong: the skin of the bull is smooth. 
aselelu (singular noun F) smoothness (of skin , etc); sheen; gloss.
asenesen ko-o (transitive verb) to beat heavily many times. 
asenon (plural asenok) (noun F) one who deals a blow. 
asenyit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be thin, lean, emaciated; to be withered.
aseo (singular noun F) elections; voting; sampling.
aseor ko-o (intransitive verb) to stretch out, draw out, fetter, make tense, spread out (reflexive verb) to stretch oneself out. aseor aibwo: to stand at attention; to stand straight and still. (euphemism) to die. cp. arior. 
asepeo (plural asepeon) (noun F) a bowler hat. cp. akopiira: a cape or cap.
asereseeti (plural asereseetin) (noun F) a fork (cutlery). cp. auma
aseror ko-o (transitive verb) to eject spittle. 
aserun ko-o (transitive verb) to vomit; to eject liquid. 
asesen ko-a (transitive verb) to gaze at; to stare at; to watch for; to look at closely; to examine closely; to behold. cp. angoliar. 
asesena ko-a (reflexive verb) to look at one another; to stare at, gaze at, or behold one another. 
aseun ko-a (transitive verb) to elect; to select; to choose; to pick out; to sort out, reserve; to vote. 
asiat (plural asian) (noun F) a tilapia fish, Tilapia variabilis. 
asibilian (plural asibilians) (noun F) a civilian; a woman who is not a member of the armed forces or the police force. 
asid (plural noun F) a string of beads round a woman’s or baby’s waist; acid (battery acid, etc). 
asidak (singular noun F) dregs of beer or any dry sediment. 
asiepai (singular noun F) lard; fats. 
asigiria (plural asigirian) (noun F) an ass; a female donkey; mule; a jennet; a burro. 
asigirikolong (plural asigirikolonga) (noun F) a burrowing viper; a stinging centipede. cp. amuge, aipom. 
asigirir ko-o (intransitive verb) (of hair) to stand upright. 
asiigiri (singular noun F) a charcoal stove. 
asiikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to escape notice; to evade; to foil; to do secretly. asiiki eong ewenat: the prisoner has eluded me. 
asiilyanut1 (noun F) filth; uncleanness; repulsiveness; dirt. inera ngesi nuka asiilyanut: she/he speaks filthy language. 
asiilyanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be very dirty, unclean, obscene, filthy, repulsive, horrible, abominable.
asiinit (plural asiinin) (noun F) a rafter or stick for building roof. cp. aliit. 
asiira (noun F) a variety of sweet potatoes.
asiiriany (plural asiirianya) (noun F) a vole (a small animal like a rat with a tail of a squirrel), Claviglis murinus. 
asiirikin ki-a (transitive verb) to inform; to communicate. kesiirikit eong ijo ebe, abuni moi: I inform you that I shall come tomorrow. 
asikaat (plural asikaatin) (noun F) a woman’s skirt. cp. apeeti, apale
asikei (plural noun F) crushed dry droppings of sheep, goats, or rabbits. 
asiles1 (noun F) emptiness; desolation; loneliness; ugliness. 
asiles2 ko-a (transitive verb) to be unbecoming, unseemly, displeasing to, ugly, or evil. esil eong aswam ya: that work is unbecoming to me. esil kes ener ngun: it is unbecoming of them to say such. 
asiles3 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be empty, lonely, deserted, desolate, solitary or uninhabited. 
asilikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be lonely somewhere; to be too solitary for; to be too desolate for. kasilikinit eong ere ngol: it is too lonely for me in that home. 
asilipat (plural asilipan) (noun F) a slipper (shoe or sandal). cp. akalabata, asapatu
asiloor ko-o (intransitive verb) to die; to go out (as of lamp or fire). 
asima (singular noun F) face; likeness or the look; photograph; picture.. yenik’asimake: her/his double or likeness. 
asimasim (plural asimasiman) (noun F) a creeper used in rain dance. 
asimokok (plural asimokokon) (noun F) a spider; a network or a web. 
asinge (uncountable noun F) sand; a grain of sand; (figurative) crystal sugar. cp. esukaali
asinit (plural asinin) (noun F) a fencing wire. asinit nakarengan: a copper wire. asinit naka ikec: a barbed wire. 
asiniya (plural asiniyan) (noun F) a metallic or plastic tray. cp. akataasa
asio (singular noun F) a female deity of laziness; laziness (personified). 
asiomakin ko-a (transitive verb) to read out to or for; to backbite somewhere. 
asioman (noun F) reading; education. 
asiomet (plural asiometa) (noun F) a reading book; a reading, i.e. chapter and verse in the bible or scriptures. 
asionor ko-o (transitive verb) to keep thumping on the back. (reflexive verb) to have constant great pain; to have colic. 
asior ko-o (transitive verb) to give a heavy blow; to cause great pain; to clobber. (reflexive verb) to have great pain; to have colic. 
asiorotot ko-a (intransitive verb) (of anything) to be tall, long, straight, without bends. isiorotot ekitoi ngol: that tree is tall and straight. 
asip (plural noun F) germinated grain destined for beer-making. asipisip asip: to drink beer ravenously.
asipat (plural asip) (noun F) unground germinated grain destined for beer-making. cp. amurat. 
asipet (plural asipeta) (noun F) a foundation of a building. asipet naka akwara: the spike of a spear. 
asipetait (plural asipeta) (noun F) foundation of a house; a base on which something stands (as of candlestick). 
asipirit (singular noun F) methylated spirit (fuel). 
asipo ko-o (intransitive verb) to stand upright, straight; to rest firm; to stand up steady; to keep your balance. esipos amoti kokek: the pots are standing near the door. 
asipokin ko-o (transitive verb) to erect; to set up; to establish (a home); to pitch (tent) or to put up (a house); to put on end; to set up or institute. alosi asipokin ere loitet: I am going to erect a new home (reflexive verb) to stand straight; to be erected; to calm down (as of waves); to stand up; to settle down (as of weather or anger). asiponokin atek: to stand poles in the ground. asipokina: to stay steady; to keep your balance.
asipokinet (plural asipokineta) (noun F) a base; bottom; foundation; basement; substructure. 
Asiriamut (plural Asiriamun) (noun F) a Muslim woman; a word from the Koran. 
asirikaalet (plural asirikaalei) (noun F) a woman soldier; a female security guard; a woman sentry. ipu kwana asirikaalei da kajore: there are also many women in the armed forces nowadays. cp. apolisit
asirimait (plural aasirim) (noun F) a stalk of maize, sugarcane or sorghum. cp. agagaat.
asirimim (plural asirimima) (noun F) the bridge of nose; nose-bridge. 
asiriomom ko-o (intransitive verb) (of child's face) to be dirty. 
asirit (plural asirin) (noun F) a row of things or men; a line of people; a list of things. alosit asirit: to go in Indian file. 
asisi ko-o (intransitive verb) to get burned, get charred (of food only). asisiooto acok: the potatoes are burning. asisi akiring: the meat is getting burnt. akimai nuasisiooto: burnt millet. cp. aiyuk (burning of other things).
asisiet (plural asisieta) (noun F) the remains of burnt food or anything. 
asisinit (collective noun F) hyperrhenia grass whose growth in a place is a favourable guide that the soil is good for crops, Hyperrhenia filipendula. 
asisit (plural asisi) (noun F) a peg used for drying skins or hides. cp. aseit. 
asisiun ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a boy or girl) to reach manhood or womanhood; (of a person or animal) to give out the odour or smell akin to a billy goat; to smell like cotton aphids or greenfly. 
asitaani (plural asitaanin) (noun F) a devil; an evil thing or person. 
asitaapu (plural asitaapun) (noun F) a postage stamp; a seal, engraving or ink stamp. 
asitoopu (plural asitoopun) (noun F) a kerosene stove. 
asiun ko-a (intransitive verb) to come stealthily; to escape this way. asiun ebong: to come secretly in the evening. 
aso (interjection) have it; now then; well then; get on with it; come on. aso kolot: hey, go. aso konye: there you are!
asoaso-aswam (noun F) a bird (believed to sing the words meaning, ‘get on with your work’, when it sees people standing idle in the garden), a Red-crested cuckoo. 
asodit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be first; to initiate; to originate something. 
asodokin ko-o (transitive verb) to start for; to show somebody how to do something. 
asodore ko-o (transitive verb) to start; to do first. esodete moi kace atemar ebe mam eong akoto kes: they might in future say that I don’t like them. 
asog ko-a (intransitive verb) to swagger; to swank, bluster, boast noisily. esoga ngesi ebe ebarit ere kec: she/he swanks that their family is well off (plural esogas kesi ebe ebaritai kore kec). esogas itelepai ngul: those boys are swaggering. 
asogakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to swagger somewhere, or in presence of; to swank in the presence of or somewhere; to boast to or somewhere. asogakin do je ebe egogong kanupe ebungaa ikoku: he now swaggers that he is strong after beating a child.
asoganut1 (noun F) vanity; pride; swaggering; bluster; in-fashion. 
asoganut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be inclined to pride, vanity; to swagger; to be inclined to bluster; to be inclined to swank 
asogimim ko-a (intransitive verb) to be awe-inspiring, grisly; to be dreadful, horrifying, repulsive, terrifying, fearsome. akirot naisogimim: a wonderful story; something wonderful. cp. angosibib.
asogol1 (plural asogolin) (noun F) a roundabout way; detour; circuit; a story; a legend. awomaar asogol: to go or do in a roundabout way. abu ngesi kowomik asogol elosi oduka: she/he went to the shops in a roundabout way. awomaar einer: awomikin einer: to tell in a roundabout way; to beat about the bush. 
asogol2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of horns, teeth, or anything) to be protruding, projecting; to talk in a circumlocutory manner or beat about the bush. 
asogolol ko-a (intransitive verb) (of anything) to be protruding or projecting. 
asogomior ko-o (reflexive verb) to grow or become ugly. 
asogomom ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to be awkwardly tall and thin. 
asogoror ko-a (intransitive verb) to be awkward, unhandy, clumsy, cumbersome, ungraceful. isogoror etelepat ngol engoi atap: that boy is ungraceful in mingling millet bread. 
asogot (plural asogon) (noun F) a corruption of amusogot: a phoenix palm, Phoenix reclinata.  
asokodod ko-o (intransitive verb) (of stick, beak, nose, etc) to be hooked, curved or bent; to have the back of the head protruding. isokodod ekabela: my walking stick is bent or hooked at the head. 
asokosit (plural asokosin) (noun F) a sock (a fabric covering the foot and ankle, worn inside the shoe). 
asola ko-a (transitive verb) to pull out things secretly. 
asolaun1 ko-a (transitive verb) to pull out of a hiding place. 
asolaun2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to come out of hiding, bush suddenly and try to escape. 
asolit (plural asolin) (noun F) (archaic) ammunition; a bullet. cp. asasit; abiasit. 
asomakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to jump at; to jump on; to bounce on or to. 
asoman1 (noun F) (archaic) reading; education. 
asoman2 ki-a (transitive verb) (archaic) to read. cp. asioman
asomanar ko-a (reflexive verb) to skip; to hop. 
asomar ko-a (intransitive verb) to jump away; to bounce away. 
asomeroit (plural asomero) (noun F) a school girl; a student; a school-goer. 
asomet (plural asometa) (noun F) (formerly) a discotheque. cp. edisiko
asomun ko-a (reflexive verb) (of a wound spring) to spring out; to jump out; (of crops) to sprout or grow quickly; (of water in well) well up; (of ball) to rebound. 
asongol ko-a (intransitive verb) to pretend to; to talk in vain; to travel for nothing; to go or do in vain. 
asongolaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to feign; to pretend. asongolaar ngesi apero, ebala ebe edeka: she/he went to bed, pretending to be sick. 
asonya1 (adverb) of very long ago; during ancient times. kolo kasonya: once upon a time; very long ago; in the olden days. 
asonya2 (noun F) very long ago; ancient times. 
asonyok (plural asonyoka) (noun F) a tail of sheep; (jocular) the behind; the buttocks.
asoogot (plural asoogon) (noun F) a deep pit; an abyss; a deep valley; a deep hole. 
asoorian1 (singular noun F) submission; surprise; sulkiness. 
asoorian2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to look subdued; to look gloomy, shocked; to sulk. esoorianete idwe kiretakin: children are sulky when reprimanded. cp. aiswop: to look angry. 
asoridid1 (singular noun F) dirt; obscenity; filth; squalor.
asoridid2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of anything) to be dirty or filthy. 
asorony (plural asoronyo) (noun F) large intestine; colon. cp. asworony
asoso (plural asosoi) (noun F) a species of antelope, a Klip-springer oreotragus. 
asot (plural asotia) (noun F) a word of admiration or praise, ‘nice fellow’, ‘good fellow’. abu asot ya: there she comes (used for anything). 
asoto (plural asotoi) (noun F) a roof of a granary; a hood; an umbrella; a hat; a cupola. 
asuat (plural aswa) (noun F) an iron bar; a metal bar; an iron ornament; a bracelet; an anklet. 
asubakin ko-a (transitive verb) to make or create for; to displace; to sacrifice to; to mould or form for; to finish off; to give the finishing touch to; to immolate. (reflexive verb) to shift (a setting, standing) once; to move once; to be displaced. sirikisubakin!: do not move! (as when taking a photo or being put at gunpoint). kosubak epelukon: finish off your task. 
asubanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to worship, sacrifice to; to keep creating; to make often for (as of pots); to sacrifice often. esubanakini ngesi eong amoti: she/he makes pots for me. Edeke Lokasuban esubanakini oni inyamat: God the Creator provides food for us. (reflexive verb) to keep shifting from one to the other; to turn oneself about; to keep moving about (when sitting or lying or standing). 
asubanit (plural asuban) (noun F) the ceremonial throwing away of the vigil ashes after the death of a person (- it marks the end of the formal mourning and it is the time when the property of the deceased is allocated); a funeral rite; a ritual; a sacrificial victim; a sacrificial ceremony. asubakin asuban: to offer sacrifice. asubanit naka emisa: the sacrament of Mass. 
asubia ko-a (prepositional verb infinitive) to create with; to make (pots) with. ekoto ngesi elupe asubia amoti: she/he wants clay to make pots. elupe ngesi esubere amoti: clay is used to make pots. 
asubun ko-a (transitive verb) to make for oneself; to create, mould, form for oneself. 
asubunet (plural asubuneta) (noun F) nature; creation; instinct. 
asudenyeny ko-a (intransitive verb) to be small or dwarfed. 
asudokin ko-a (transitive verb) to add to; to mix with. kosudok emaido odia: mix the groundnuts paste in the vegetables. 
asudonokin ko-a (transitive verb) to be adding to; to go on mixing. 
asueny ko-a (intransitive verb) to walk away proudly and slowly; to swank. 
asuenyikin ko-a (transitive verb) (of a short person) to walk away with short and fast paces; to swank. 
asujak ki-a (transitive verb) to eat leafy vegetables without salt or groundnut paste; to eat boiled ecomai leaves before they are pounded; to chew emairungi leaves. 
asuketait (plural asuketa) (noun F) a fold; a crease; a knee joint or elbow joint. 
asukitoit (noun F) a grass, Eragrostis turgida. 
asukokin1 ko-o (intransitive verb) to bend up; to warp; to fold up, or crumple. asukokin akungin: to draw up the knees. asukokin asoto: to close an umbrella. asukokin epateit: to have cramps from sitting with drawn legs. asukokin angajep: to trip somebody in words. asukokinos amunyin: the skin is wrinkled. asukokin: to bend for, fold for. asukokin akan: to fold one’s sleeves. asukokin ebokorit: to bend finger; to crook the index finger (as a sign of contempt). asukokin akeje: to sit with drawn legs
asukokin2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to wince, cringe, flinch, or recoil. 
asukonor ko-o (intransitive verb) to lope; to gallop or leap. 
asukor ko-o (intransitive verb) to scurry; to rush away; to dash off. asukor akeje: to draw up legs.
asukusuk1 (plural asukusukun) (noun F) a wood wind instrument in the trumpet family (made of a long hollow stick ending in a hollowed gourd to provide a baritone like the sound of esukusuk to the sound created by the vibrations of the lips of the blower), used in ajosi dance.
asukusuk2 ko-o (transitive verb) to crease; to rumple; to crinkle. 
asulaj ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a beard; to wear a beard; to be hairy (of a man or anything). 
asulajaj ko-a (intransitive verb) to be hairy (as of beard); to be bushy, overgrown; to be full of weeds. cp. aisuulaarit. 
asulyany (singular noun F) a blessing; good luck; benediction; prosperity; good fortune; boon. akipi nuka asulyany: holy (blessed) water. ainakin asulyany: to give a blessing to; to bless. 
asulyanyanut1 (singular noun F) luck; blessedness; fortune; beatitude. 
asulyanyanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be lucky; to be blessed, fortunate, prosperous. cp. arereng, asyanut. 
asumet (singular noun F) bone marrow. 
asupaada (plural asupaadan) (noun F) a catapult. cp. aduwet, aporocet, arupaada 
asupaanut1 (noun F) medium-size; average (in size); brevity (in length). 
asupaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be medium-sized. 
asuponut1 (noun F) a dog’s cleverness in tracking people or game through smell. 
asuponut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (of dog) to be a good tracker 
asupor ko-o (transitive verb) (of dog) to smell out, or find out. 
asupun ko-o (transitive verb) (of a dog) to follow its own track; to scent, trace, or track down. esupuni ekingok ekelos: the dog scents its own track or follows its own track. 
asuretait (plural asureta) (noun F) a bamboo leaf, stick or pole. 
asuritomei (plural nukasuritomei) (noun F) a grey plantain-eater, (a bird believed to scatter elephants by its honks). 
asurokin ko-a (transitive verb) to attack; to assault, or to fall upon unexpectedly; to ambush, maraud, or assail. 
asurokinet (plural asurokineta) (noun F) an aggression; an assault; an attack. 
asuror ko-o (reflexive verb) to scatter, disperse. asuroros idwe: the children have dispersed. 
asurubeeti (plural asurubeetin) (noun F) a music band or troupe. 
asurup (plural asurupo) (noun F) enmity; hostility; feud; animosity. ejai oni asurup: kirai oni lukasurup: we are enemies. 
asusujai (plural noun F) rubbish; trash. 
asutor ko-o (transitive verb) to claim and take away. abunit eong asutor emong kaujo kon: I have come to claim and take a bull from your kraal. 
asutukees (plural asutukeesin) (noun F) a suitcase; a trunk. 
asutun ko-o (intransitive verb) (of many) to come to the rescue of; to come in a crowd (to demand something). kosututu: kopotu: come here (plural). 
asuuka (plural asuukai) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a shawl; a bedsheet. 
asuulyany (plural asuulyanya) (noun F) (Usuk) a nightjar (a bird believed to bring good luck to the beholder); a goat-sucker. cp. asulyany.
Aswairit (plural Aswairin) (noun F) the Swahili language; Kiswahili language; a Swahili woman; a Swahili word. 
aswalar ko-a (transitive verb) to give a painful blow; to refuse (as a reprisal); to give a painful feeling; to smart; to be attracted (by love); to fascinate, charm, infatuate. abu apese koswala etelepat etau: the girl fascinated (attracted) the boy. 
aswalun ko-a (transitive verb) to make nice and tasty sauce from vegetables (especially emalakany or eboo or anything); to draw a beautiful picture or portrait; to get a clear snap or photograph. 
aswam1 (plural aswamisio) (noun F) acts; actions; conduct; deed; performance. Aswam (noun F) (in the Teso week) Monday. cp. Naebalaasa
aswam2 (plural aswamusinei) (noun F) work; business; task; duty; use; occupation; employment; job; office; action. 
aswam3 ki-a (intransitive verb) to work; to act; to labour (transitive verb) to do; to make, fabricate, fashion, or form. eswama ngesi nen tir: she/he has worked there all day. educoki ngol epelu ke: that man has persisted on his task on a daily basis. iswamai: working; in action. mam iswamai: not working; out of action.
Aswamisio (plural noun F) Acts (of the Apostles) – a book in the Bible.
aswamisioit (plural aswamisio) (noun F) a deed; an accomplishment; a feat. 
aswarajikin ko-a (transitive verb) to put a dirty thing somewhere. 
aswarun1 ko-o (reflexive verb) to come or run out in numbers or swarms. 
aswarun2 ko-o (transitive verb) to cause to run out in swarms. cp. atwarun.
asweenyeny ko-a (intransitive verb) to be small in stature; (of person) to be short, dwarfed.
aswei (plural asweyon) (noun F) a kind of anthill on which small edible mushrooms, called eswei, grow. 
aswetun ko-a (transitive verb) to cut a small piece for oneself. 
aswongolol ko-o (intransitive verb) (of clothes) not to fit. 
asworony (plural asworonyo) (noun F) the large intestine (of a person or animals); the colon. amoeteka nuapolok: the colon
asyanikin ko-a (transitive verb) to be kind, generous, liberal, hospitable, merciful to. 
asyanus (singular noun F) kindness; generosity; liberality; mercifulness. 
asyanut1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be kind, generous, liberal, hospitable, or merciful. cp. asyanus
asyanut2 (singular noun F) the grace (after the Lord’s prayer); hospitality; benevolence; kindness; liberality; favour; bounty; generosity; humaneness. 
asyarasiara (plural noun F) crumbs; remnants; little bits. 
-at suffix denoting zeal, expertise in, dexterity at, ingenuity in doing something. ekeswamat (noun M): a zealous worker; workaholic. ekadanyat (noun M): a mass killer, murderer. 
-ata suffix of 2nd and 3rd person plural in past and imperative and subject persons. kiswamaata (plural imperative): work! konyamata!: eat! kibungaata!: beat her/him/it!
ataaba (plural ataaban) (noun F) an underground rock; base rock.
ataadalo (plural ataadaloi) (noun F) an open air wooden or metallic (plate) rack for drying utensils in the sun.
ataagi (plural ataagin) (noun F) a water or oil tank; a big metallic or plastic water reservoir. 
ataagoroit (plural ataagoro) (noun F) a root of tree; taproot. 
ataakit (plural atak) (noun F) a young female animal; a heifer. cp. ataok. 
ataamu (plural ataamun) (noun F) a division of the school or academic year; a semester; a school term. 
ataan ko-a (intransitive verb) to shout; to howl; to roar; to cry out; to bewail; to din. etaanete idwe ke: her/his children are shouting.
ataanikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to shout at or for; to cry out to or somewhere; to mourn for. 
ataayi (plural ataayin) (noun F) a cravat; a necktie; a neckerchief.
atabalait (plural atabala) (noun F) a large-mouthed earthenware pot for water or for vegetables. 
atabo (plural ataboi) (noun F) a small cooking pot, more bowl-like in shape, mainly used for vegetables. cp. atado.
atabok (plural ataboka) (noun F) a piece of broken pot; a potsherd; a shard.
atabonyony ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a person) to have small buttocks. 
atacakin ko-a (transitive verb) to pay to or for; to reward for; to expiate for; to refund for; to remunerate; to dance for or somewhere; to reimburse. 
atacanar ko-a (transitive verb) to pay all debts; to pay everybody. adau ngesi atacanar apeseninike: she/he has finished paying her/his debts.
atacaret (plural atacareta) (noun F) a paying off (of monies, debts, etc); instalment (part-payment).
atacit (plural atacin) (noun F) a trap for big animals, consisting of a hole dug in the game track, a ring of etirir thorns over the hole and a rope tied on a log, with the noose of the rope over the thorns.
atado (plural atadoi) (noun F) a small bowl for food; a can. cp. atabo.
atagoroit (plural atagoro) (noun F) a root (of a tree or anything). cp. ataagoroit, aliasit. 
atai (adverb) (to do something) in vain; for nothing; gratis; banal. cp. atitai
atak (plural of ataok) (noun F) (female) calves; heifers. 
atakan (noun F) clarity; aspect; visibility. 
atakan ko-a (intransitive verb) to appear; to be seen; to be prominent or clear; to be visible. etakani noi: conspicuous. etoil mam etakani: a wraith or ghost is invisible. 
atakanikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to come in sight; appear to. 
atakanikinet (plural atakanikineta) (noun F) an appearance; an apparition; a sight; a vision; an occurrence. cp. aitapoet
atakanunet (plural atakanuneta) (noun F) appearance; a happening or event.
atakar1 ko-a (intransitive verb) (of animals) to gallop; to run or buck; to race; to jump with all four feet; to canter. 
atakar2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to break down (a house); to chip. 
atakar3 ko-a (transitive verb) (of body) to peel off; to take off; to copy; to blister (reflexive verb) (of wound) to break open; (of enamel off plate) to come off or peel off; to come off (as patch from rubber tube or tyre). 
atakarikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to jump away from (as in play); to run away (as of cow from bull).
atakasit (plural atakasia) (noun F) a blister.
atakatak ko-a to copy often or many times; to beat on ears; to keep copying; to take off (something fixed). 
ataker (plural atakerin) (noun F) a canoe; a boat; a craft; a launch; a big wooden trough for watering cattle. cp. atuba: a small wooden trough for watering or feeding animals. 
atakorit (plural atakor) (noun F) mucous dysentery (of man or animal); faecal slime. 
atakun ko-a (transitive verb) to pull off; to tear off; to take off; to break down by oneself (of house). atakun akiro: to copy words or text. 
atakunet (plural atakuneta) (noun F) a copy; a duplicate; a photocopy. cp. atiaket; ekopi. 
atakwa (plural atakwan) (noun F) a large, tall cooking pot with wide opening and used for cooking atap; (Ateso Atororo) a basin. cp. atabo, aalakany.
atalanta (singular noun F) talent; a special or innate skill, aptitude or ability, especially for art, music, etc; expertise. 
ataliiba (plural ataliiban) (noun F) a crowbar; a pick axe.
atamakin ko-a (transitive verb) to try for a short time; to test for a short time. (reflexive verb) to try each other; to fight each other; to dare each other; to wrestle. cp. ainingokin. 
atamakinet (plural atamakineta) (noun F) an experiment; a test; a trial; an examination. 
atamit ko-o (transitive verb) to be trying; to endeavour; I am a bit okay (in reply to a greeting, ‘ijai biai?’). 
atan (plural atanin) (noun F) a water or oil well; a stream; a waterhole. alosit atan: to go to well; to go for water at the well. 
atanu (singular noun F) a heap of bricks arranged for firing (burning). ainapakin atanu: to pile up raw bricks for burning. 
atanya (plural noun F) earthen ware; crockery; vessels. 
ataok (plural atak) (noun F) a heifer; a female calf. cp. akumukiliok. 
atap (plural atapio) (noun F) cooked millet meal. cp. alos.
atapakin ko-a (transitive verb) to dab on; to infect; to dip lightly into; to touch lightly; to mop up. atapakin edeke: to infect with disease (through contact). atapakin akiro: to get someone into trouble. 
atapakinet (plural atapakineta) (noun F) infection (process); a light-touch; a dab or light dip. 
atapar1 (plural ataparin) (noun F) a pond; a water reservoir; a drinking place (for livestock); a dam. 
atapar2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become plentiful; to abound. cp. aipuar. 
ataparac (noun F) the early morning (before 11:00am). cp. atupuruc
atapat (plural atapan) (noun F) a silverfish (an insect that eats books and clothes); a bookworm. 
atapen (plural atapeno) (noun F) the smaller of the two grinding stones (held in hand by women when grinding). cp. akangas.
atapeng (plural atapengo) (noun F) a guinea fowl (a wild hen). 
atapikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be common to; to be plentiful; to be seen commonly. atapikitos eong ipejok: I get visitors often (the visitors frequent my place). atapikis ikapa imirio: the cat gets plenty of rats (literally, rats are plentiful for the cat). 
atapit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be common, ordinary, usual, or banal. etapit ngesi asalenen ore: she/he usually stays at home; 
atapon (plural atapono) (noun F) leprosy; a severe skin and nervous disease which can be passed from one person to another, and which causes serious and permanent damage to the body, including loss of fingers, limbs, etc affected. cp. angoti
atapun ko-a (transitive verb) to dip gently into (vegetables); to touch lightly; to contract a disease. etapunit ngesi atapon: she/he has contracted leprosy. 
atar (plural ataria) (noun F) deep waters; the deep part of a dam or swimming pool.
atarion ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fatty and juicy (of meat); to be greasy (of anything).
atarionor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become fat, juicy, or greasy. akiring naetaryono: akiring nacokom: fatty or juicy meat (not lean meat). 
atarukot (plural ataruk) (noun F) a vulture, Neophron percnopterus (a scavenging bird of prey). ikoloror akou kon bala naka atarukot: you are as bald as a vulture. kolimokinai ikabore ‘akongu Kenya’? atarukot: (a riddle) what is it that sees as far as Kenya? A vulture (because it can detect a dead prey thousands of kilometres away!) cp. acut.
atata ko-a (transitive verb) to forge iron; to shape metal. ekatatan etatai isiman: the smith forges the little bells (strapped on legs for dancing). 
atataet (plural atataeta) (noun F) smithy; a forge. cp. atatas
atatait (plural atatai) (noun F) a female grandchild; a female descendant; a granddaughter. 
atatas (plural atatasia) (noun F) the hammer and the anvil. 
atatinyo (plural atatinyon) (noun F) the inside of heel, i.e. the soft section. cp. atitibat: heel of foot. etau loka akeju: the instep or the insole.
ataulo (plural atauloi) (noun F) a towel. ataulo nakilongis: a bath towel. ataulo naka akan: a hand towel. ataulo naka ereet: a face towel. ataulo naka asaanin: a plate towel.
ataus ko-a (intransitive verb) to be (attributive) ata: I am; ita: you are (singular); eta: she/he/it is; kita: we are; itaas: you are (plural); etaas: they are. ataus ba: to be hard. ataus ti: to be silent or invincible; to be very heavy. ataus ci: to be cold. ataus do: to be nice or sweet. ataus du: to be very red or crimson. ataus kia: to be white or ashen. ataus lyo: to be deserted or empty. ataus ria: be bitter or sour. ataus pe: to be hot. ataus tul: to be pungent, rank or smelly. etaas doo do: they are very sweet, tasty or delicious. 
atear ki-a (transitive verb) a corruption of atemar (to say; to speak). 
atedokin ko-o (transitive verb) to make marks or incisions on. atedokin ekia akuwan: to incise a part of the body and put an embrocation. 
atedun ko-o (transitive verb) to make a cut in for oneself; to cut off for oneself. atedun akiro: to pronounce distinctly; to utter once but clearly.
ateele (plural ateelei) (noun F) (formerly) a piece of skin dress worn by women, just to cover the pubic area (while the rest of the body would be naked). 
ategerioit (plural ategerion) (noun F) a door post; a doorframe; a pillar; a main support; a mainstay; a jamb. 
atego (plural ategoi) (noun F) a clap trap. cp. amutego; eic; akuluma. 
ategum ko-o (intransitive verb) to walk with a big fat stomach. etegumete ijaka ngul kedautu aiju ajon: those gentlemen walk away with their distended bellies after quaffing a lot of booze. 
ategumum ko-o (intransitive verb) (of a person or an animal) to have a big stomach. 
ateikin ko-o (transitive verb) to carry loose on the head without holding; to poise; to balance a load on the head. eteikinit aberu akemot: the woman carries her pot on her head without holding it. 
atek (plural of atekat) (noun F) bars (of soap); balks; timber; tie-beams of a roof. atek nuka asabuuni: akito nuka asabuuni: bars of soap. 
atekat (plural atek) (noun F) a bar; balk; timber; a pole for building. atekat naka asabuuni: akitoi naka asabuuni: a bar of soap. 
ateker (plural atekerin) (noun F) a clan; a family (from common ancestor); a generation; a tribe. cp. eitekere.
Atekok (plural of Atekit) (noun F) a name of a Teso clan. cp. Ikatekok
atela (plural atelai) (noun F) the only child (produced by a particular woman). cp. alemura, anume, ateluna. 
atelepanut1 (noun F) boyhood; adolescence; youth. 
atelepanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be young or adolescent. 
atelor ko-o (reflexive verb) to go away by oneself and forget something behind; to travel by oneself. 
atelun1 ko-a (transitive verb) to have one child only; to count one by one; to bring one only (instead of many of anything). etelunit akweny abeet: the bird laid only one egg. 
atelun2 ko-o (reflexive verb) to come alone; to come by oneself. 
atemar ko-a (transitive verb) to say; to speak; to mean or suggest; to speak out. ngesi atemar ai?: what does it mean or imply? atemasi kesi ai?: what did they say?; what have they said? ngesi atemar ebe: that is to say…. 
atemel ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to have a good figure or body shape; to have a nice figure; to be pretty, comely, elegant. 
atemele (plural nukatemele) (noun F) a woman with a good figure or body shape; the pretty, comely, or elegant one; a beauty queen. 
atemelel1 (singular noun F) good-looking; faultlessness; perfection.
atemelel2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be well-proportioned in build; to be good-looking; to be handsome; to be erect, beautiful, pretty, or a beau. 
atemonon (plural atemonok) (noun F) a mother nursing her newly-born baby; a confined woman (after childbirth); an ayah (a wet nurse). cp. naketemonon. 
atenak (plural noun F) times; days. abu eong kaper ngina atenak aare: I slept there two nights (or twice). 
atenit ko-o (intransitive verb) to be steady; to be straight. etenit ekitoi: the tree is straight. etenit ere ke: her/his home is steady (peaceful).
atenu (plural atenweik) (noun F) a branch (of a tree or an organisation); a bough.
atenus (plural atenusyo) (noun F) a drum (musical instrument); a dance to the sound of drums. airam atenus: to beat the drum; to hold a dance. ananganang atenus: to beat the drum (with the hand). cp. emidiiri loka imu: a drum for the twin-dance. 
atenyar ko-a (transitive verb) (with a singular or plural object) (of anything) to touch a sore or wound (so that it hurts) (reflexive verb) to hurt; to be touched and ache. 
atepakin ko-a (transitive verb) to rain on; to fall on (of rain) (intransitive verb) to rain somewhere. atepaki edou ikaraan: it rained on my crops. etepakit itunganan edou: it has rained on somebody, i.e. somebody is tipsy or drunk.
atepetepet (plural atepetepen) (noun F) a wild duck. cp. atudot
atepokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to run to; to rush to; to run to the rescue. 
atepor ko-o (reflexive verb) to go at once. kotepor: go at once. cp. aniemar 
atepun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come at once. cp. eniemun.
atepurait (plural atepuraitan) (noun F) a typewriter; a keyboard of a computer. 
ateran (plural aterak) (noun F) a bride. cp. eteran
ateranet (plural ateraneta) (noun F) honeymoon period; training; preparation; internship. 
aterar ko-a (transitive verb) to stretch out; (of umbrella) to open, spread out; to deploy. aterar akanin: to stretch out arms.
atere ko-a (transitive verb) to tell openly; to tell in the face; to confess openly, boldly. 
atereikin ko-a (transitive verb) to tell somebody openly in the face; to come face to face; to be challenged. 
atereikinet (plural atereikineta) (noun F) a challenge; an obstacle. 
atereun1 akiro ko-a (transitive verb) to speak out; to confess openly. atereunit eong alimun nukabeit: I have confessed the truth. 
atereun2 ko-a (reflexive verb) (of someone or something that should be in hiding) to come openly; to walk openly towards speaker. 
aterit (plural aterin) (noun F) a penis; a phallus. cp. edino, elokomacar, elomocor.
aterot (singular noun F) cold; chill; fresh air; cold wind. ketingit eong aterot: I feel cold or chilly. ededeng aterot: it (the weather) is very cold. akoto adumun aterot: I want fresh air. ejai aterot: epol aterot: it is cold. ebisi aterot: it is very cold. cp. etutum: cold (in the nose). 
aterun ko-a (transitive verb) to stretch out this way. aterun auno: to stretch out rope (this way). 
ates (plural atesin, atesia) (noun F) a grave; a corpse (in the grave); a tomb.
atese ko-a (transitive verb) to break brittle things. 
atesear ko-a (reflexive verb) to break (as of glass, egg or small brittle things). 
ateseikin ko-a (transitive verb) to break (glass and the like) somewhere. ngai bo keteseikini asaanit ne?: who broke this plate here? 
atesek ko-a (intransitive verb) to be brittle or crisp, frail, fragile, breakable. 
atesin (plural of ates) (noun F) a graveyard; a cemetery. alosi eong atesin: I'm going to the graveyard or cemetery. 
Ateso (plural of Atesot) (noun F) the language of the Iteso people; the women from Teso; the vocabulary or words in the language of Iteso. kalimonoki lolo je eong Ateso: he told me off; he used hard words on me.
Ateso Atororo (noun F) the dialect of Ateso language spoken by Iteso from Tororo and Kenya, characterised by the heavy use of letter k in verbs and nouns with prefixes ai- or ei-. aipany: a hole, becomes akipany. eicolong: a chair, becomes ekicolong. ainyam: to eat, becomes akinyam.
Atesot (plural Ateso) (noun F) a Teso woman; a Teso word. 
ateten (noun F) the right (not left). akan nakoteten (noun F): the right hand. akediany: lefthand.
atetiot (plural atetio) (noun F) metal rings or clips on ears, lips, nose or tongue; a brooch, ear-pin. 
ateyaar ko-o (reflexive verb) (of solids or crystals) to dissolve or disperse. ateyaar esukaali kakipi: the sugar has dissolved in water.
ati (plural nutiok F) (adjective) big; important; whole; complete; large; huge; enormous. aberu ati: a huge woman. amoni ati: a large bush. apungurei nutiok: big logs. cp. napeti. 
atiar ko-a (transitive verb) to say (used before reported speech). ngesi atiar: that means; that is to say. etiarete kesi ai?: what will they say? atiasi kesi nen: they have said so/thus. cp. atemar. 
atiaus ko-a (intransitive verb) to amount to (quantitatively – i.e. volume or level); to be so (in shape, quantity). etia: she/he/it is this/that much. etiaas: they are that/this much. etia ngesi ai?: how big is she/he/it? etia nen: she/he/it is so big, so much. etiaas nen: they are so big; there are so many. (note: for quality, use araus). cp. ajaus.
atibar ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a fat person) to walk with a heavy stride. 
atibara (plural nukatibara) (noun F) a fat big woman (literally, a big shit). 
atibiba nakokwap (plural atibib nukokwap) (noun F) bedrock; basement; substructure.
atibo (plural atiboi) (noun F) a food bowl or a dish made of clay. cp. atabo, atado, atido
atibok (plural atiboka) (noun F) a cracked earthenware bowl or pot; a potsherd. atibok naka amot: a potsherd. cp. atidok. 
atibolok (plural atiboloka) (noun F) a potsherd; the remains of a broken pot, gourd or calabash.
atibong (plural atibonga) (noun F) evening; dusk; nightfall; sundown. cp. abong. 
atibonga (plural noun F) the evenings. 
atica (plural aticai) (noun F) a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer. cp. akesisianakinan
atido (plural atidoi) (noun F) a small wide-mouthed earthenware pot for vegetables. 
atidok (plural atidoka) (noun F) a piece of broken earthenware pot; a potsherd. cp. atibok. 
atigo (plural atigoi) (noun F) a vegetable plant whose leaves are used to give slipperiness to eboo sauce, Corchorus trilocularis. 
atiiba (plural atiiban) (noun F) a jutting granite rock (a physical feature). cp. atiida 
atiida (plural atiidan) (noun F) a granite rock or slab (a physical feature). cp. atiiba.
atikat (plural atikan) (noun F) a quagmire; a swamp; a mire; a fen; a bog; a marshland; a morass.
atiket (plural atiketa) (noun F) a crossbar (used for barring doors or windows).
atiketait (plural atiketa) (noun F) a delay; a hindrance; an obstruction. cp. aitikokinet. 
atikijij ko-a (intransitive verb) to have abnormally fat cheeks. cp. atukalal. 
atikir ko-o (intransitive verb) to gallop; to jump for joy; (of cattle) to stampede. apotu akituk kotikiroto: the cattle stampeded. 
atikisimu (singular noun F) catechism (a book or a series of questions and answers about Christianity, used to instruct confirmation candidates). cp. katekisim
atikit (plural atikin) (noun F) a ticket; a permit; an authority letter; a travel document.
atikokin1 (noun F) any traditional ceremony held to bless new property. atikokin akinyet (noun F): a traditional fertility and initiation ceremony where a newly married woman spends a night with her husband without bathing off the ghee and esas shavings she was smeared with on her introduction. 
atikokin2 ko-o (transitive verb) to hold down; to press down; to curb. atikokin etau: to hold one’s heart (wants and desires). atikokin eiyengane: to hold one’s breath. atikokin etogo: (of a man) to initiate a newly built house by spending a night with a woman in it. atikokin ekirakira: (by two groups of leap-dancers) to stop the dance with one thunderous throb of the feet hitting the ground.
atikokinet (plural atikokineta) (noun F) an obstruction; a delay; a hindrance; a dissuasion; a rebuff; a ban. 
atikonut1 (singular noun F) continence (control over one’s appetites and passions, or over one’s bowels and bladder); decency.
atikonut2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to have self-control over one’s appetites and passions; to have the ability to control one’s bowels and bladder. 
atikor ko-o (transitive verb) to push over by knocking against; to overpower; to jostle; to overwhelm; to overthrow. sirikitiko ekitwi: don’t run into the bush in fear. 
atikum (plural atikumo) (noun F) a rubber stamp. cp. akikum. 
atikun ko-o (reflexive verb) to fall or collapse this way. 
atilas ko-a (transitive verb) (of a fat person) to walk or move about naked; to walk with nothing around the waist. 
atilasas ko-a (transitive verb) (of a fat person) to be naked; to be nude; to have nothing round the waist. 
atilo (plural atiloi) (noun F) a plant from which salt is extracted, Hygrophila spinosa; a traditional salt. 
atilon (singular noun F) an abyss; a depth. 
atingatinga (plural atingatingan) (noun F) a tractor (especially a farm tractor or a road grader); a bulldozer. cp. agureeda 
atingit ko-a (transitive verb) to have hold of; to hold in custody; to contain; to be looking after somebody’s goods as guarantee. 
atinot (plural atinoi) (noun F) an ear of grain; a small head of millet. 
ationikin ko-o (intransitive verb) to be hard or difficult for; to be awkward or arduous for. 
ationis (plural atiokisyo) (noun F) a difficulty; an awkwardness; arduousness; a mystery; a drawback; a hardship. cp. ationus. 
ationoor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become difficult, hard, or not easy; to become awkward; to become arduous. (plural atiokoor)
ationore ko-o (intransitive verb) to be fully grown; to become ripe; to be ready for use; to be hard; to mature. atyoko acok: the potatoes are mature. atyono emaido: the groundnuts are mature. atyoko ikoku akojo: the child’s bones have become hard (are mature, fully grown). 
ationus (plural atiokusyo) (noun F) a difficulty; an awkwardness; arduousness; a mystery; a drawback; a hardship. cp. ationis
atipe (plural noun F) a girdle of beads for the waist.
atipei (plural atipein) (noun F) a plant, Emilia sagittata.
atipet1 (adverb) once; at once; forthwith; in a flash; immediately; suddenly; presently; very quickly. atipet noi: very soon; immediately; at once; quickly, etc 
atipet2 (plural atipe) (noun F) a bead. cp. aculoit. 
atiraja (plural nukatiraja) (noun F) a plant from which salt is extracted, Ageratum conyzoides.
atirikiki (plural atirikikio) (noun F) an antelope, Klipspringer oreotragus. 
atirit (plural atirin) (noun F) a penis (generally). cp. edino, aterit, elokomacar, elomocor.
atirokin ko-o (transitive verb) to touch, feel, finger for (reflexive verb) to touch one another. 
atiron (noun F) speed of racing; swiftness 
atironor ko-o (reflexive verb) to become fast or speedy; to run fast; to run quickly. 
atiror ko-o (transitive verb) to touch once; to affect; to feel; to handle; to finger. sirikitiro nges: don’t touch her/him/it.
atiroret (singular noun F) a touch; contact; a feel. 
atisaar ki-a (transitive verb) to melt. (reflexive verb) to dissolve. 
atitai (adverb) (to do) in vain; gratis; free; for nothing; without reason. cp. atai. 
atitibat (plural atitiban) (noun F) a heel (the back of the foot). cp. atatinyo: the inside or sole of foot.
atiting1 (singular noun F) courage; boldness; bravery; endurance; intrepidity. ainakin atiting: to embolden.
atiting2 ko-o (transitive verb) to dare; to brave; to challenge; to defy (intransitive verb) to be impervious; to pain; to hold out; to be long suffering; to be brave. 
atitingikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to endure for; to bear with; to suffer on; to hold out; to hold on; to dare. 
atitingoor ko-o (reflexive verb) to endure; to persevere; to be brave. atitingoor ngesi: she/he has endured, persevered, or stuck to it. 
atitiny (singular noun F) a corruption of atiting: courage; bravery; endurance; intrepidity. 
atitinyikin ko-a (intransitive verb) a corruption of atitingikin: to endure for; to bear with; to suffer on; to hold out; to hold on; to dare. 
atitipu (plural atitip) (noun F) an anthill; a heap. (slang) a big woman who just lies in bed without taking part in intercourse. toto katitipu: a queen ant. 
atitir ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to be insipid, bland, flat, or tasteless; to satiate; (Usuk) sweet like sugar. 
atitirikin ko-o (transitive verb) (Usuk) to become too sweet for; (outside Usuk) to pall on; to become insipid to. katitiriki eong emaido: groundnuts have become bland or tasteless to me.
atitot (plural atitono) (noun F) a calabash or pot for straining or extracting salt from ashes of burnt plants; a salt filter. 
atiya ko-a (transitive verb) to break down; to pull down; to kill (a big man or animal); to cause to crumble; to break to pieces (as of house, anthill, etc); to destroy; to collapse. (reflexive verb) to fall down; to crumble away; to fall to pieces; to collapse. 
atiyaar ko-a (transitive verb) to pull down (wall or house); to demolish. akoto atiyaar ekatogo: I want to break down my house. abu edeke kotiyaa ekamong: rinderpest killed my bull.
atiyakin ko-a (transitive verb) to break down for. kotiyak ekonitogo: break down your house (reflexive verb) to fall down; to fall in (of house); to collapse; to sink down or in. 
atiyanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to collapse repetitively; to crumble. 
atiyatiyaun ko-a (reflexive verb) to crumble away entirely; to fall to pieces; to disintegrate; to fall to bits; to crumble to powder; to be dilapidated; to moulder. 
atiyaun ko-a (transitive verb) to pull down (wall or house) (reflexive verb) to fall down. 
atoba (plural atobai) (noun F) a heifer. cp. akumukiliok
atodokin ko-o (transitive verb) (of a bird) to peck something for. 
atodonor ko-o (transitive verb) (of a bird) to keep pecking and taking away. 
atodor ko-o (transitive verb) (of a bird) to peck once and take away something.
atodotod ko-o (transitive verb) (of birds) to keep pecking.
atodunun ko-o (transitive verb) (of birds) to keep pecking. 
atoet (plural atoeta) (noun F) a natural gap between upper centre incisor teeth. cp. angecel.
atokit ko-o (transitive verb) to have hemmed; to finish off; to put finishing touches to. itokit ijo emukeeka?: have you hemmed the mat? 
atokitoit (plural atokito) (noun F) a hem; a rim (of basket or granary); the edge (of a basket, blanket, mat, etc). 
atokosit (plural atokosio) (noun F) a hem; a rim; a braid; an edge (as of basket, blanket, or mat, etc). 
atola ko-a (transitive verb) to shed tears in torrents. atola akiyo: to shed tears in big drops; to weep incessantly. cp. aitotom akiyo: to shed a lot of tears.
atolong (plural noun F) the simsim chaff after threshing. cp. asangal. 
atom (plural atomian) (noun F) (in Karamoja) a rifle; a gun. cp. emuudu 
atomon (singular noun F) (numeral) ten. 
aton ko-a (intransitive verb) (from fear or cold) to cringe; to truckle (to submit or give in passively or weakly); to slouch. etonos ipakasin kaneejai ejakait: the workmen cringe in front of their employer. 
atongolol ko-o (intransitive verb) to be handsome, beautiful; to be nice-looking. itongololos kesi: they are handsome or nice-looking (of anything). cp. atolongong, atemelel. 
atongora (noun F) a plant, Honekenya ficifolia. 
atonokin ko-o (reflexive verb) to be humble; to be self-effacing; to cringe; to crouch with servility; to fawn; to be devoted to. 
atoogan ko-a (intransitive verb) to complain; to grumble; 
atoot (plural atooto, atoon) (noun F) a big ditch or gutter between two riverbanks; a passage between rocks or tors. 
atoris (plural atorisyo) (noun F) a head band; a ribbon round the head; a head ornament of beads. cp. atoritoit
atoritoit (plural atorito) (noun F) a girdle; a belt. cp. atoris
atorob (plural atorobusio) (noun F) the chest (of the body); the trunk (of a human or animal body); the bosom; the might or power. aitosom atorob adumunia ibore: to use force to obtain something.
atorokin ko-o (transitive verb) to tie a band round head, waist, etc; to gird. kotorok egoe kon karokoba: tie your clothes with a belt (reflexive verb) to gird oneself; to be tied round; to gird. 
atorom (plural atoroma) (noun F) a trunk of tree; a bole of tree; the trunk or torso (of a person). 
atosa ko-a (transitive verb) to enjoy something tasty, nice and juicy (of anything); to munch or crunch. atosai eong emaido loiwowatai kamuunyu: I am enjoying the taste of groundnuts fried with salt. 
atosatosa ko-a (transitive verb) to keep enjoying; to enjoy always (something soft and nice); to eat something nice and soft; to pluck nice and soft vegetables. etosatosaete idwe eitola: the children are enjoying sugarcane. atosatosai eong akiring na: I enjoy this nice tender meat. 
atotoet (plural atotoen) (noun F) a white-breasted stork (bird), Abdim's stork. 
atotol nukamor (noun F) coal. 
atotolet1 (plural atotol) (noun F) charcoal; coal; embers; cinders; dry cells or battery. 
atotolet2 (singular noun F, slang) a guy; a buster (a form of greeting or praise for a man or boy).
atuba (plural atubai) (noun F) a rough wooden dish; a manger; a trough.
atubarar ko-a (intransitive verb) (of person) to be maimed or crippled; (of body) to be mutilated; (of limb) to be without toes or fingers. 
atubetait (plural atubeta) (noun F) a cut; a portion; a fragment; a share. 
atubokin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut or judge for. atubokin akiro: to give judgement on; to give a sharp reprimand; to tell off; to adjudge. atubokin egelit: to impose a fine. atubokin aitisilaario: to condemn to or give punishment. atubokin akile: (of the milker) to stop milking (leaving the remainder - called esurup - for the calf). atubokinio akiro: a conviction; to be found guilty of wrongdoing or crime. atubokin atwanare: to sentence to death; to put on death row. atubokin awenio amaisa: to sentence to life imprisonment.
atubon (plural atubok) (noun F) a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. atubon akituk: a butcher of cows. atubon imusaagon: a court judge.
atubonokin ko-a (transitive verb) to cut (meat) for many; to cut into many pieces for; to cut short or out repeatedly (as when milking or pouring out again and again). 
atubor1 ko-o (reflexive verb) to pass by; to go across; to take a shortcut; to go past. atuboros akiro: that is a thing of the past; that is past. ketuboros apaarasia nuipu: (in narratives) after many days. atubor kojokan: to fare well. kotubor kojokan: farewell! atubor erono: to fare badly. 
atubor2 ko-o (transitive verb) to cut off. atubor atenu: to cut off a branch atubor akou: to behead. atubor akan arai akeju: to amputate the arm or the leg.
atubosit (plural atubosia) (noun F) a cut; a rip; a cleft; a dissection.
atubun ko-o (transitive verb) to cut this way; to cut for oneself (reflexive verb) to come this way; to cut across this way; to arrive (as of unexpected visitors); to drop in. 
atubutub ko-o (transitive verb) to cut up into pieces; to divide; to analyse. 
atubutubonokin ko-o (transitive verb) to apportion; to cut into pieces and put into (as tomatoes into sauce).
atudakin ko-o (transitive verb) to plant in little groups here and there. kotudak akimai: make or plant a small plot of millet. 
atudek ko-a (intransitive verb) to dance, prancing like a hare; to jump about; to caper; to jig. cp. ekosio. 
atudo (plural atudoi) (noun F) a female duck; a goose. cp. atudot
atudot (plural atudoi) (noun F) a duck; a goose. cp. atudo
atujomom ko-o (intransitive verb) to have a dirty or unclean body. itujomomos itelepai: the boys have not bathed (they have dirty bodies). 
atukalaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go with fat cheeks like one with yaws. 
atukalal ko-a (intransitive verb) to have broad cheeks; to have protruding cheeks. itukalal ngesi: she/he is broad-cheeked or puff cheeked.
atukalikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to go about with puffed, round, or protruding cheeks.
atukalun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come with fat cheeks. 
atukaret (plural atukareta) (noun F) a draught (of liquid); a gulp; a mouthful of liquid. 
atukit ko-a (transitive verb) to keep or hold liquids or solids in the mouth. 
atukituk (plural atukitukin) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) any big machine that is run by an engine. cp. apotipot.
atukokin ko-o (transitive verb) to gather together somewhere; to collect for; to heap up; to assemble together somewhere; to compose; to amass (reflexive verb) to gather; to assemble; to congregate; to crowd together; to come together; to cluster; to conglomerate. atukokinos itunga: many people have come together. 
atukonokin ko-o (intransitive verb) to accumulate; (of certain Christian sects) to assemble for seasonal prayers. 
atukos (plural atukosio) (noun F) a place of assembly or meeting or crowding together; a classroom.
Atukot1 (noun F) (in the Teso week) Thursday. cp. Naiwongonet
atukot2 (plural atukono) (noun F) a crowd; a court; a meeting; an assembly; a class (of school); a league; a committee; a party; a heap; a council; a pile; a quantity of things. atukot naka anya: a heap or sheaf of grass. 
atukucel (plural nukatukucel) (noun F) a hamerkop (bird). 
atukunyu (plural nukatukunyu) (noun F) a civet cat, Civettictis civetta. cp. etawoi, egwang.
atukurur ko-a (intransitive verb) to be small and short in stature; to be stumpy; to be short (in height). 
Atular1 (singular noun F) sudden death; anthrax (in cattle). 
atular2 ko-a (transitive verb) to kill suddenly by poison; to murder suddenly; to poison; to bewitch; to be fatal to. etularit nges atwanare: she/he died a sudden death (reflexive verb) to die suddenly (by poison); to be poisoned; to be bewitched; to go bad; to wither. ailel nakikoto atular: ecstasy.
atulerer ko-a (intransitive verb) (of eyes) to bulge; to be staring (of eyes). itulereras nges akonye: her/his eyes bulge. itulerer ngesi: she/he has bulging eyes. 
atumaanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to disobey; to be obstinate to. 
atumaanut1 (noun F) obstinacy; disobedience; unwillingness; stubbornness.
atumaanut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be contumacious or contumely; to be presumptuous, conceited, or arrogant; to be disobedient, stubborn, obstinate, or unwilling
atumes (singular noun F) fatness; corpulence; thickness; obesity; heaviness. 
atumit ko-o (intransitive verb) to have gained weight; to be obese; to be fat. etumit nges akeju: she/he has fat legs (elephantiasis of the legs is implied). 
atumun1 (noun F) puberty; adolescence.
atumun2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to develop at puberty; to become stout; to become fat.
atumunan (plural atumunak) (noun F) a young girl or boy of 14–16 years; an adolescent. 
atun (plural atunin) (noun F) a bundle of grain; a package; a parcel (of anything); (Ateso Atororo) ten. 
atunakin ko-a (transitive verb) to embrace (somewhere); to hold; to put hands or arms round (something). atunaki toto ikekoku atorob: the mother pressed her child to her bosom. etuni ikoku totoke: the child embraces its mother. 
atunu (plural atunun) (noun F) a bundle; a packet; a parcel. 
atunuru (plural atunurun) (noun F) (outside Usuk) the woodwork of a house roof; principles of roofing; roof timbers; frame of roof; a cupola. cp. atunyuru, asoto.
atunyany (plural noun F) rough furrows; roughly cultivated field. 
atunyeny (plural noun F) rubbish from vegetation. 
atunyuru (plural atunyurun) (noun F) (Usuk) roof timbers of a house; wooden roof-work; a dome. cp. atunuru, asoto. 
atunyurur ko-o (transitive verb) to be blunt and rounded. itunyurur akwap: the world is round like a ball (implying that fortunes in the world keep changing, and thus the lucky ones today can become unlucky tomorrow).
atupakin ko-a (transitive verb) to follow somebody; to come or go after; to succeed (as leader or ruler). atupakin akiro: to obey. atupakinit: to emulate. etupakini: next; following that; after that.
atupar ko-a (transitive verb) to go and follow after. 
atupit ko-o (transitive verb) to emulate; to follow. atupit acoa ka: to emulate me. atupit itunganan arai ibore: to be after or follow someone or something; to hunt or want someone or something.
atupiton (plural atupitok) (noun F) a follower; a disciple; an apostle; a recruit; a partisan; a proselyte; a pupil; a believer.
atupun ko-a (transitive verb) to follow after (this way); to arrive after. 
atupuruc (singular noun F) the morning; dawn; sunrise; daybreak.
atur1 (plural aturio) (noun F) an age-set; a generation; one's age mates. 
atur2 (plural of aturot) (noun F) a plumage; a feather-ornament.
aturasas1 (intransitive verb) to have fat buttocks. 
aturasas2 (singular noun F) fatness (of buttocks). 
aturiaar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go to a place accidentally or by chance. 
aturiaikin ko-a (reflexive verb) to encounter; to meet by chance; to meet unexpectedly; to discover; to bump against; to come across unexpectedly; to stumble into; to light upon. aturiaikin eong amuran kosokooni: I stumbled into my mother-in-law at the market. abu eong katuriaikin ebe ekokitos inyamat: I chanced that food was ready.
aturiatoi ko-o (intransitive verb) to keep getting lost; to stumble about; to grope; to drift. 
aturiaun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come by chance; to arrive unexpectedly; to come suddenly upon. 
aturio (plural of atur) (noun F) generations; age groups. 
aturo ko-o (intransitive verb) to flower; to bloom; to blossom. eturoete kwana ikito: the trees are now blooming or flowering.
aturokin ko-o (transitive verb) to cut big pieces of meat for. 
aturor ko-o (transitive verb) to cut away big lumps; to take away big pieces or lumps. 
aturot (plural atur) (noun F) a flower; a blossom. 
aturukana (plural noun F) small intestines in animals. amoeteka nudidik: small intestines. cp. asworony.
atusaar ko-a (transitive verb) to break a pot or gourd. cp. adusaar.
atuta (plural atutai) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a ridge made across a path to prevent erosion; a dam; a dyke; a mole. cp. amatuta.
atuteanut1 (singular noun F) frivolity; thoughtlessness. 
atuteanut2 ki-a (intransitive verb) to be frivolous, or light-hearted 
atutubet (plural atutuben) (noun F) a cut; a part or a fraction; a half; a portion; a share; a fragment; a syllable; a paragraph. atutuben: odds and ends. 
atuule (plural atuulei) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a thumb piano. cp. akoogo
atwaanar ko-a (transitive verb) to smear oil, etc on body; to rub off anything (reflexive verb) to smear; to rub oneself with soap or oil. 
atwaar ko-a (transitive verb) to wipe; to brush off. atwaar apua: to dust. 
atwakare ko-a (intransitive verb) (plural of atwanare) (of many) to die; (of fire) to go out. 
atwakiar ko-a (transitive verb)(plural) to lose; to suffer loss of; to forfeit; to be bereft of. atwakiasi idwe lu totokec, arautu ikokiok: these children were bereft of their mother, they have become orphans. 
atwakikin ko-a (intransitive verb) (of many) to die for; to die somewhere; to die on, in, or at. atwakikis itunga orot: people have died on the way (through an accident, perhaps).
atwakun ko-a (intransitive verb) to work very hard; to work to death. etwakunit nges akaswam: she/he is working herself/himself to death for me. 
atwalanakin ki-a (transitive verb) to mark; to stain; to paint anyhow. 
atwamakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to improvise. 
atwamitoi (intransitive verb) to be rash or mindless. 
atwana (plural atwaka) (adjective) dead; finished; extinct. 
atwanare1 (singular noun F) death; fate. 
atwanare2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to die; (of fire) to go out. atwana: I am dead. itwana: you (singular) are dead. atwana: she/he/it is dead. kitwaka: we are dead. itwaka: you (plural) are dead. atwaka: they are dead. atwanare etengei: to die of hunger; to starve. kotwana eong akuwan: I was stunned. abu ekatau kotwana: I felt down-hearted; I was sick at heart. atwanare akwena: to burst out laughing; to laugh for long (literally, to die of laughter). erai ibore atwanare ka aijar: it is a matter of life and death.
atwaniar ko-a (transitive verb) to lose; to suffer loss of; to forfeit; to be bereft of. atwania ikoku yen totoke, arau ikoki: this child has lost its mother, it has become an orphan. 
atwaniaret (plural atwaniareta) (noun F) an expense; a loss; a forfeiture. atwaniaret akos: a total loss (in insurance). atwaniaret adios: a partial loss. atwaniaret naepol: a big loss. itimitoi ikalia luatwakiasi luminan kec: condolences to those who have lost their beloved ones.
atwanikin ko-a (intransitive verb) (of one) to die for; to die somewhere; to die on, in, or at. atwaniki esapat ajore: the boy died in the army
atwario (singular noun F) discharge (of a patient from hospital); a farewell (of a departing person). 
atwaun ko-a (transitive verb) to pluck (fruit); to knock down (fruit). atwaun iturutur: to knock down hornets or wasps. 
atwenyitwenyit (plural atwenyitweny) (noun F) a spark; a brand (live coal); a glow.
atyak ko-a (intransitive verb) to separate; to part; to dissever. eraasi kesi ipapero lumam etyakas: they are inseparable friends. 
atyakakin ko-a (transitive verb) to give a part to (reflexive verb) to part from one another; to separate from one another. 
atyakanakin ko-a (transitive verb) to divide, dole out, deal, apportion, or parcel out amongst. 
atyakanar ko-a (transitive verb) to take shares; to divide into parts; to divide into portions. 
atyakar ko-a (transitive verb) to separate; to segregate; to divide and take away; to part; to keep separate; to seclude; to dissociate (reflexive verb) to part from one another; to say goodbye; to keep separate; to be a hermit; to live in seclusion. 
atyakat (plural atyakata, atyakan) (noun F) a boundary; a partition; a distinction; a difference; a part; a division; a crack; a split. cp. ecilet. 
atyakatyak ko-a (transitive verb) to cut up; to distinguish; to dismember; to divide into many parts or many portions; to disintegrate.
atyakatyaka ko-a (reflexive verb) to be divided, disunited, separated, or cut up, etc 
atyaketait (plural atyaketa) (noun F) a difference; a distinction; a dissimilarity; a disagreement; a boundary; a border.
atyakun ko-a (transitive verb) to divide, cut a portion and bring.
atyonore ko-o (intransitive verb) to become mature; to mature; to ripen; to become hard. atyokoto imomwa: the sorghum is mature. (plural atyokore)
atyonus1 (plural atyokusio) (noun F) difficulty; awkwardness; hardness; inflexibility; austerity; stiffness; rigidity; acerbity.
atyonus2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be difficult; to be hard; to be awkward or unbecoming. 
auj (plural aujoi) (noun F) a cattle kraal; a stable; a cowshed; (formerly) a military school for initiates to elders in asapan. ipu akituk kauj: there are many cows in the kraal. 
aujo (plural aujoi) (noun F) a species of tsetsefly, Tabanus species. cp. eimonit
aujot (plural aujoi) (noun F) a species of bird. 
aukede (noun F) genital ulcers; syphilis. cp. etaala, aminyine
aukokin ko-o (transitive verb) to take a big load; to give one a big load; to carry a big load. koukokinai esaduku lo: carry this big box for me. 
aukor ko-o (transitive verb) to remove a big thing. kouko ekitoi lo korot: remove this big tree from the road. 
aukot (noun F) a corruption of aokot: an edible yam. 
aukun ko-o (transitive verb) to take up a heavy load. 
aulaar ko-o (reflexive verb) (of a fat or big person) to hasten away; to dash off; to hurry away. 
auleru (plural aulerun) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a flute. cp. alamaru 
auma (plural aumai) (noun F) a fork (an eating or cooking implement with prongs, for spiking and lifting food). cp. asereseeti
aumen ko-o (intransitive verb) to groan; to grumble; to moan (at anything). 
aumeno1 (singular noun F) a groan; a grouse; a moan. cp. eidiny.
aumeno2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be groaning or grumbling; to bemoan. eumenos idwe kotogo: the children are groaning with pain in the house. cp. aiumuumo
aumokin ko-a (intransitive verb) to wonder at; to be astonished at; to admire; to be surprised at; to be flabbergasted. apotu kesi koumokis amotoka: they were surprised at seeing a motorcar. 
aumokina ko-a (intransitive verb) to be wonderful; to be astonishing or surprising; to be amazing. 
aumokinet (plural aumokineta) (noun F) a wonder; a miracle; an exclamation mark (!). 
aumosit (plural aumosia) (noun F) a miracle; an exclamation (mark). 
auno (plural aunoi) (noun F) (Usuk) a rope; a string; a cord; a snare (made of rope) for catching animals or people. aunoi: cordage. 
auny ko-a (transitive verb) to hiss with anger (like an injured bull). apotu itunga luaunyasi kobilutu ekokolan kawenis nako polis kosodete aibunga aidyak aiyar: an angry mob broke into police cells and got a suspected thief whom they beat to near death. cp. aisu, aiju. 
aup1 (plural lukaup) (noun F) a buddy; comrade; friend; an associate; a companion. 
aup2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be in the company of; to be often with; to go about with. akoto aup kajo: I want to be in your company: I want to accompany you. 
aupakin ka ko-o (reflexive verb) to go together with; to go in the company of. kaupakinos: let us go together. 
aupakin ko-a (transitive verb) a corruption of ayupakin: to thread onto; to string on; to plant in the ground (a pole, a knife, a stick, etc). koupak atipet ngin da: string that bead also. 
aupan ko-a (transitive verb) to roast things. eupani ngesi acok: she/he roasts potatoes. 
aupanikin ko-a (transitive verb) to roast for. koupanikinai eong acok: roast some potatoes for me. cp. aipe. 
aupar ko-o (reflexive verb) to accompany; to go away with; to go in the company of; to go away together. aupar kede icetunganan: to accompany someone. kouparos ore: go home together. alosi ne nan kiupara iso: I am going to where we went together. 
auparat (plural auparan) (noun F) a tortoise living in rocks.
aupaupan (plural noun F) matured brew, 4 - 5 days old. 
aupet (plural aupeta) (noun F) a string (of beads, fish, or anything); a female companion, aide, or escort. aupet naka agaria: a string of fish. aupet naka atip: a string of beads. 
aupit ko-o (intransitive verb) to feel tired; to feel satiated or fed up (with food, drink, work). eupitos ikagoen elos: my clothes are full of dirt. 
aupuli (singular noun F) a plague. 
aupun ko-o (reflexive verb) to come with; to fall down with; to come together. aupunos ngesi katenu: she/he fell down together with the branch. kiupun eong ka nges: I will together with him/her. 
aupwal (plural aupwalia) (noun F) a Turkana shield. cp. ebuku.
aur ko-a (transitive verb) to bring forth; to give birth to; to lay eggs; to bear. euriete ikweny abeei: birds lay eggs. 
aurakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to go to bed hungry. 
auramam ko-a (intransitive verb) to have a protruding stomach; to have a portly belly.
aures1 (noun F) a smell (good or bad); odour; scent. 
aures2 ko-o (transitive verb) to smell of. aur eong ajon: I smell of beer. eurok kesi ajon: they smell of booze. eur saa: she/he/it smells nicely or smells sweetly (aromatic, spicy). 
auri ebu (singular noun F) rainfall showering while the sun shines; sun shower (literally, the hyena has brought forth). 
aurian ko-a (intransitive verb) (of cattle or chickens only) to rest; to lie down. euriakete akituk: the cattle are resting. ekotos akituk auriak: the cows want to rest.
aurianakin ko-a (intransitive verb) to bear or produce for; (of a man) to be impregnating a woman often. 
aurianar ko-o (reflexive verb) to become short, stumpy, or low. 
aurianikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be too short or too low for. kaurianiki eong ekek lo: this doorway is too low for me. 
aurianun ko-o (intransitive verb) to become short. aurianu auno ngin: that rope has become short. 
aurianut1 (singular noun F) shortness; brevity; abbreviation; fertility (of women). 
aurianut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be short or low; (of woman) to be fertile 
auries (plural auriesia) (noun F) uterus.
aurikin ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a woman by a man) to impregnate. auriki ngesi apese: he has impregnated a girl. 
aurio (singular noun F) birth; nativity. Aurio naka Kristo: the birth of Christ; the Nativity. apaarit naka aurioka: my birthday.
auriun ikoku ko-a (intransitive verb) to give birth to a child; to bring forth a child. 
aurokin ko-o (intransitive verb) to give one a smell of something; to smell (good or bad). kauroki eong esigala: I smell a cigarette. 
auruma ko-a (intransitive verb) to crouch; to stoop low. euruma akokor kotoma abeei ke: the hen is sitting on its eggs. 
aurumikin ko-o (reflexive verb) to crouch down on or somewhere; to stoop low on something. 
aurup ko-o (transitive verb) (used with plural objects) to snatch away things. 
aurupikin ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch for or from. kourupikinoi asaduku kotoma akim: snatch my box from the inferno. 
aurupoor ko-o (transitive verb) to snatch away from speaker. abu etoori kourupoo imiyot: an eagle snatched away a chick. 
aurupuun ko-o (intransitive verb) to snatch for oneself; to save or to deliver from danger by snatching. 
auruun ko-o (intransitive verb) to begin to smell badly; to begin to fester; to begin to go bad; to begin to corrupt; to begin to decay. 
auryanet (plural auryaneta) (noun F) a place where cattle rest; a courtyard where people sit and talk; a meeting-place; a council hall. 
auryaunun ko-a (intransitive verb) (of breath) to often become short or shallow. euryaunene eong etau kanuka etengei: my breath often becomes short on account of hunger, i.e. I am very hungry. 
auselel ko-o (intransitive verb) to have large prominent buttocks; (of a person) to have large or big buttocks. 
ausi (plural ausyo) (noun F) a belt made of cloth; a ribbon; a cord. 
Ausuko (plural of Ausukoit) (noun F) women from Usuk county or sub-county in Katakwi district; Ateso dialect spoken in Usuk county, with elision of letter ‘k’ in words such as akipi, akituk, ekicolong, etc.
Ausukoit (plural Ausuko) (noun F) a woman from Usuk county in Katakwi district; a word from Ateso usually spoken in Usuk county (example: iidai: yes; itotoka: Oh my; aipi: water; iyo: you; aituk: mouth, cows) 
ausumoit (plural ausumo) (noun F) an elephant snout fish; Marcusenius. 
ausur ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to be rather big; to be rather fat. 
ausurikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to prepare or serve much food for somebody. kausurikit eong atap na: you served rather a big mound of food for me. 
ausurur ko-a (intransitive verb) (of body) to be fat. 
auta ko-a (intransitive verb) to struggle; to wrestle; to wriggle; to do or attempt. eutasi kesi: they are wrestling.
autakin ko-o (reflexive verb) to wrestle with or for; to be doing or attempting. autakinos itelepai: the boys are wrestling with each other. 
autanut ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of or clever at wrestling; to have wrestlemania. 
auto (plural autoi) (noun F) cooking oil; vegetable oil.
autokin akerit ko-o (reflexive verb) to get up and run away; to escape by taking off. 
autor ko-o (intransitive verb) to pull away; to take out and away. kouto epir ngol: pull out that pole. auto nges ariebo: sickness has overcome her/him. 
autotorot (plural autotoron) (noun F) a flower of Hibiscus sabdariffa. 
autun ko-o (transitive verb) to pull out; to extract. kout ekakelai: extract my tooth. 
aututu (plural aututun) (noun F) a green dove. 
autuutu (plural autuutun) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) a wooden trumpet with a gourd attached as a resonator. cp. arupepe. 
auya (plural auyan) (noun F) new grain. cp. awuya
awaan ko-a (intransitive verb) (of people or animals) to groan; to sing together in unison; to cry together in low tones; to roar; to bellow like a fighting bull. ewaanete itunga kanuka lokatwan: people are mourning for a dead man. cp. ataan.
awaanikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to begin to cry for; to howl or sing together in low tones. 
awaar ko-a (intransitive verb) (of sky or anything) to look pale or ashen. 
awaarit1 (noun F) anaemia; paleness. 
awaarit2 ko-o (intransitive verb) to be pale, wan, pallid, anaemic or cadaverous; to remain pale; to turn pale. ewaarit ngesi: she/he has turned pale or light. 
awadet (plural awadeta) (noun F) something for scraping or scooping; a scraper; a dredging tool. 
awadun ko-a (transitive verb) to scoop up something thick with the hand. 
awai (adverb) aside; away. kolot awai: go aside. 
awaikin ko-a (transitive verb) to crack a joke; to jest with; to tell a pleasant experience; to tell news from elsewhere. 
awaitin (plural of awai) (noun F) the sides. 
awakai (plural awakan) (noun F) (Ateso Atororo) the back of the house. cp. agule.
awakakin ko-a (transitive verb) to give in big lumps or in big pieces (intransitive verb) (of a woman’s breasts or a cow’s udder) to grow big. cp. aiwaca. 
awakar ko-a (transitive verb) to break off something big; to knock out (as of teeth).
awakawak ko-a (transitive verb) to take in large lumps; to cut into large pieces; to beat repeatedly. ewakawakaenenei akiring: she/he always takes meat in big pieces. awakun emuogo: to eat or break cassava in big a chunk. 
awaket (plural awaketa) (noun F) the udder of cow, goat, etc. 
awalaj ko-a (intransitive verb) to cut in big pieces; to vomit (in big chunks); to puke. 
awanasit (plural awanasia) (noun F) a wound; a gash. cp. awanat
awanat (plural awanasia) (noun F) a wound; a gash. 
awanawan ko-a (transitive verb) to wound all over the body; to rip open in several places.
