awanawanaun ko-a (transitive verb) to get wounded all over the body; to be injured all over. ewanawanauna Ecibu kakangas naka emotoka: Ecibu got injured all over in a car accident.
awaragat (plural awaragasia, awaragan) (noun F) a story; a fable; a parable; a riddle; an allegory. inera ngesi kotoma awaragasia: she/he speaks in parables. 
awarikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to become dark on somebody or somewhere; to spend the whole day until dark. kawariki eong akwap orot: darkness overtook me on the way. aitawar akwap: to make it dark, i.e. to do until dark. cp. aiwalakin: to do the whole night till daybreak.
awariwar ko-a (intransitive verb) to loom; to be transparent; to be pellucid. ewariwari (plural ewariwarete): it is (they are) transparent, whitish, grey. 
awasia1 (adverb) at the side; at the end; the extreme or the furthest. ibokorit yenikawasia: the little finger; the little toe. ingai iboyie kawasia?: who is sitting at the end or at the side?
awasia2 (noun F) the end (of the world – as predicted in the Holy Bible). 
awatan ko-a (transitive verb) to roast by putting near heat; to fry slightly. awatan akiring: to roast meat over the fire. 
awate (plural of akuwan) (noun F) bodies (flesh, bones and blood). 
awawaat ko-o (intransitive verb) to hover about; (of a person) to wait on the sidelines for a chance to take action. cp. abwobwoot.
awear ko-o (reflexive verb) to scatter; to broadcast seeds, grain, news, etc at random. aswam ka Radio Uganda, Butebo, nges awear iyemuto luka apugan kide nako Uganda: the work of Radio Uganda, Butebo Channel is to broadcast state news to the eastern part of Uganda.
aweet (plural aweeta) (noun F) a planting time; a sowing period. 
aweikin ko-a (transitive verb) to sow, disperse or broadcast for or somewhere. aweikin ekia: to throw poison at; to bewitch. aweikis amalayan esilim Teso: prostitutes have spread HIV/AIDS in Teso.
awenan (plural awenak) (noun F) a jailer; a prison officer; a guard; a warder; a warden. cp. ekedaran
awenio (singular noun F) custody; confinement; incarceration; detention; imprisonment. 
awenis (plural awenisya) (noun F) a jail, prison, or detention centre; a gaol. cp. ejeera
awiinyikin ko-a (intransitive verb) to be sugary or sweet for. kawiinyikit eong ekaajo: I find sugarcane nice and sweet. 
awiinyu1 (singular noun F) sweetness; sugariness. 
awiinyu2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to become sweet
awinar ko-o (intransitive verb) a corruption of ayunar: to slip through an opening. 
awoere ko-o (intransitive verb) (Usuk) to sing (a song or hymn); to talk often; to tell often. 
awoga ko-a (intransitive verb) to be proud (in the way one walks – swaggering, with arms held away from the body). ewogas kesi: they are proud. 
awogakin ko-a (reflexive verb) to be proud of. awogakin ngesi kanuka aswamuke: she/he is proud because of her/his job; to become proud of. 
awogar ko-o (reflexive verb) to walk about proudly. 
awoikin1 ko-o (intransitive verb) (Usuk) to sing for; to sing to; to talk often to; to tell often to; to drip into, onto; to leak somewhere. kowoikinoi: sing for me. ai bo ewoi kataagi?: where is the tank leaking? 
awoikin2 ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to help to put a load on the head. kowoikinoi asaduku na: help me to put this box on my head. 
awoisioit (plural awoisio) (noun F) an anthem; a hymn; a song. 
awojat (plural awojan) (noun F) a species of grasshopper.
awoji ko-o (transitive verb) to spin a rope or thread; to make rope; to twine. ewojiete isomero aunoi: the schoolboys are making ropes. cp. aicib: to plait.
awojior ko-o (transitive verb) to ravel; to twist (rope). 
awokit (plural awokito) (noun F) a vessel for drawing water, beer, etc. 
awokokin ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to draw water for; to fetch water for. awokokin akipi, ajon, akiria: to draw or scoop water, beer, or flour. 
awokor ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to draw (water, beer, flour) and take away. cp. aokor
awokot (plural awokon) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a variety of yam. cp. aokot
awokun akipi ko-a (transitive verb) to draw water. 
awolanet (plural awolaneta) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a bomb blast; an explosion; pent-up anger (causing aol to swell). cp. eboomu
awoli ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to stray; to go astray; to be lost; to be at a loss (what to do). ewoliete akituk kosamai: the cows are lost in the swamp (cannot find their way home). awolit eong nualosi einer: I am at a loss what to say. 
awolior ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to get lost; to be lost. awoliosi akituk: the cows are lost. 
awolit ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to be ignorant; to be at a loss. iwolito yesi akiro nu?: do you not know these issues? iwolitos yesi akiro ngun?: don't you know that? 
awoliun ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to stray this way; to be lost near here. 
awolobobot ko-o (intransitive verb) to be loud-mouthed or outspoken on trivial issues; to vainly speak of oneself; to be vainglorious or magniloquent. 
awolokok1 (noun F) (outside Usuk) emptiness; vanity; hollowness. cp. aworor. 
awolokok2 ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to be empty; to be hollow. 
awolokonyoit (plural awolokonyo) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a shell (of egg or anything). cp. abubuket. 
awolong ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to act big. 
awomikin ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to fetch for or somewhere; to go and fetch from. kowomikinai akipi: go and fetch me some water. 
awomowom ko-a (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to think over; to ponder; to meditate; to consider. kowomowomaata ber nuilosete aswam: first consider what you are going to do. 
awomun ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to come and fetch. 
awongor (plural nukawongor) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a dark-brown wading bird. cp. aongor. 
awonore (plural awokore) (noun F) (outside Usuk) to dry; to wither; to fade. awono ngesi (plural awoko kesi): she/he/it has (they have) dried up. 
awook ko-a (intransitive verb) (of weight) to be light; to be buoyant. ewook kesi: they are light (not heavy). cp. abenenu.
awookaar ko-a (reflexive verb) to become lightweight; to become buoyant. 
awoong ko-a (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to yawn; to gape.
awoonor ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to leak; to pass through a sieve or filter. ewoonorete akipi kamot: the water leaks from the pot. 
awoore ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to sing; to be singing. ewoi (plural ewoete) she/he/it is (they are) singing. 
awoot (plural awootin) (noun F) (Usuk) a mark left by something moving on the ground; a spoor; a rut of a car; a trace; a trail or track made by a crawling animal. nakinyo awoot ngin? erai ngin awoot naka emun: what trail is that? It is the trail of a snake. 
aworet (singular noun F) a corruption of aoret: cow-dung; manure; (jocular) huge human faeces. 
aworonokin alup ko-o (transitive verb) to scoop up earth (and fill a hole, etc). 
aworor ko-o (intransitive verb) to be hollow; to have a hole; to leak; to be perforated. eworori amot: the pot has a leak. 
awororikin ko-a (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to become or be hoarse or husky; to be empty for. kawororiki eong: I am hoarse. awororikinit (of voice) to be husky, hoarse, or raucous.
awosan ki-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to sue; to accuse; to plead a case; to state a case in court. iwosaete kesi akiro: they are pleading their cause. alosi awosan: I am going to plead my case. 
awosianut1 (singular noun F) (outside Usuk) slowness in conceiving. 
awosianut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to be slow in conceiving. ewosyana aberuka: my wife is slow in conceiving. 
awosikin ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to let go; to set free; to release; to give permission; to emancipate. kowosik akaakan: let go off my arm. kowosik amotoka kotubor: let the motorcar pass. 
awotoun ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to lift and put down once (off fire or off someone’s head). 
awoun ko-o (transitive verb) a corruption of abwoun: to testify against; to resist.  
awoun1 ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to begin a song; to drip or leak just once.cp. awotoun.
awoun2 ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to take or lift down a load from the head. kowounoi ajerikan na: please, take down this jerry-can off my head: help me to unload this jerry-can. 
awowa ko-a (transitive verb) to rub lightly; to stroke or caress. ewowai ngesi ekapa: she/he strokes the tomcat (more than once). 
awowaar ko-a (transitive verb) to stroke (just once); to rub off gently. bia kowowaarai eong: please, come and rub me gently. 
awu (singular noun F) (outside Usuk) a honey-bee. 
awudet (plural awudeta) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a bicycle pump. cp. aisiket. 
awuikin ko-o (transitive verb) to pass wind on or somewhere; to fart for. 
awuj (plural awujoi) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a kraal; a cowshed. 
awulaar ko-o (reflexive verb) (outside Usuk) (of a fat person) to be off in a hurry; to hasten away; hurry away. ai bo iwulaar ijo?: where are you off to in such a hurry? 
awulak ko-a (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) (of a fat woman) to waddle. 
awulanet (plural awulaneta) (noun F) (outside Usuk) dynamite; an explosive. epol awulanet: explosive. 
awumokin ko-o (intransitive verb) (outside Usuk) to wonder at. 
awunene (plural awunenei) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a ground harp consisting of a taut string tied to a flexible stick at one end and a calabash buried in the ground on the other end, and strummed with fingers. 
awuno (plural awunoi) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a rope; a string; a cord; a snare (made of rope) for catching animals or people. cp. auno.
awuny ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to hiss with anger (like an injured bull). apotu itunga luawunyasi kobilutu ekokolan kawenis naka polis kosodete aibunga aidyak aiyar: an angry mob broke into police cells and got a suspected thief whom they beat to near death. cp. aisu, aiju. 
awupakin ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to string on or somewhere.
awupet (plural awupeta) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a string of beads, fish, or anything. 
awures1 ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to smell after; to stink. 
awures2 (singular noun F) (outside Usuk) a smell (good or bad); a stench; an aroma; an odour. loewur ejok, loewur erono: good and bad smelling. ewur ejok: (of a smell) pleasant, balmy. cp. eur.
awuri ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) (of man or animal) to give birth to; to bring forth; to bear. 
awurikin ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to impregnate (reflexive verb) to have been impregnated. awurikinos apesur ngun kore: these girls have been impregnated at home (before marriage). 
awuris (plural awurisya) (noun F) (outside Usuk) uterus.
awuruget (plural awurugen) (noun F) a small species of ngege (tilapia). 
awurup ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to snatch (many things); to grab (things). 
awurupoor ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) (used with singular or plural object) to snatch away; to grab. 
awuryaanut ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to be short; to be stumpy, dwarfish, brief, curt, or abrupt. (noun F) shortness; abruptness; curtness. 
awuryanet (plural awuryaneta) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a children’s park; a courtyard. 
awuryanut ko-a (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to be prolific, fertile, fruitful (noun F) fertility; fruitfulness. 
awutun ko-o (transitive verb) (outside Usuk) to pull out this way; to dislodge. 
awututu1 (plural awututun) (noun F) a hooting instrument or thing. 
awututu2 (plural awututun) (noun F) (outside Usuk) a plant, Aframomum. 
awuya (plural awuyai) (noun F) (outside Usuk) newly harvested grain. 
ayaar ko-a (transitive verb) to take away; to lead away; to rule; to govern; to translate into. ayaar aberu: to marry. ayaar aberu kitunganan: to take away someone’s wife. koya elepa kon ngina: stop your impudence. cp. ayangaar.
ayaara bon ko-a (intransitive verb) to be independent. eyaara ngesi bon: she/he is independent. 
ayait ko-o (transitive verb) to rule; to direct; to reign; to contain; to hold; to manage; to represent; to control. 
ayangaar ko-a (transitive verb) to take away; to carry off; to abduct; to assume; to accept. ayangaar aberu: to marry (by taking a woman away from her parents). cp. ayaar.
ayangaun ko-a (transitive verb) to bring this way; to fetch; to transport this. cp. ainyakun: to bring back.
ayanyanar ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to oversee; to inspect; to monitor. 
ayanyun ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to see; to perceive. kaloto ayanyun: let us go and see. ayanyun ican: to suffer hardships or poverty (literally, to see trouble).
ayapiar ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to go near to; to approach. nepe eyapiarete ore, kotwani papakec: no sooner had they come near home than their father died. 
ayapiu (singular noun F) (Serere) nearness; vicinity; proximity; approximation.
ayapiun ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to be near here; to become nearer. 
ayapu ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to be near. eyapie: she/he/it is near. eyapiete: they are near. cp. ayapiu
ayapuun ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to come near (to the speaker); to become nearer. 
ayaun ko-a (transitive verb) to bring hither; to cause; to engender; to adduce; to afford. koyau nges ne: bring her/him/it here. ayaun ejie: to cause or bring fighting or war. ayaun adeka: to bring or cause disease. akataasa naeyaunere inyamat: a tray. ayaun ekisil: to enact a law.
ayedakin ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to press or crush; to touch or wink at somebody (to draw attention or give a clue); to press on (as between fingers when killing lice); to kill between fingers. koyedak elacit: kill the louse (between fingers). ayedanakin akonye: to keep blinking the eyes; to peer through half-closed eyelids. cp. aiwedanakin. 
ayekar ko-o (intransitive verb) (Serere) to go far; to be gone (away); to have departed; to do well, become an important person. 
ayekeret (plural ayekeren) (noun F) a prostitute; a sex worker. cp. amalayat; abwaade
ayekun ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to come this way; to arrive. koyeku lailo: come this way. 
ayelo ko-o (intransitive verb) (Serere) (of a person) to have intercourse; to commit adultery or fornication. eyeloi ngesi (plural eyeloete kesi): she/she is (they are) having illicit sexual intercourse. cp. aelo 
ayenar ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to tie and take away; to fasten, bind and take away. cp. awenar
ayenikin ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to tie on, to, for; to fasten to; to bind to, for. koyenik akine oloit: tie the goat to the peg. cp. awenikin
ayep (plural ayepei) (noun F) (Serere) an axe; a machete. cp. aep
ayeriyer ko-a (intransitive verb) to be translucent or transparent. 
ayeyait (plural ayeyai) (noun F) (Serere) a niece (as referred by the aunt). cp. acenio, acen.
ayiara ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to be safe. eyiara ikaboro: my property is secure/safe. 
ayiikin ko-a (transitive verb) to submit, defend; to guard for someone; to protect for. koyiikinai ikakoku kinyekinai ainomonom atitai: shield my child from being beaten for nothing. 
ayikokin ki-o (reflexive verb) to become calm; to calm down; to settle down (as of a vagabond). adau ekwam ayikokin: the wind has calmed down. cp. ainapakin, aiyamakin.
ayikomo (plural ayikomon) (noun F) a thick brass or copper armlet; a bangle. cp. akoomat. 
ayikong (plural ayikongo) (noun F) a short wooden hammer (mallet) for pounding pottery clay, or for hammering out barkcloth; (Ateso Atororo) a threshing stick. 
ayikuro (plural ayikuron) (noun F) a peninsula; a cape; an isthmus. cp. agule. 
ayilarar ki-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) (of a tall bare-headed person or bird) to have a long neck.
ayile1 (plural ayilei) (noun F) (Serere) a big clay pot. 
ayile2 (singular noun F) (Serere) the irritating hairs of plants. cp. aile
ayilit (plural ayilin) (noun F) (Serere) nest of birds; birdcage. aiyilit akonye: to be very curious; to look around often (curiously). cp. ailit
ayiliyil ko-o (intransitive verb) (Serere) to look horrible or distasteful. eyiliyili ates: the corpse looks horrible. cp. ailiil
ayinakin ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to give to. cp. ainakin
ayinanakin ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to give often to; to give (something) to many (reflexive verb) to give to each other; to do by turns. eyinanakinos kesi aswam ngin: they do that work in turns. 
ayines (singular noun F) (Serere) stinginess; close-fistedness; avarice. 
ayinit ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to be stingy; to be closefisted or avaricious; to be niggardly. eyinitos itunga lu: these people are stingy 
ayinyakin ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to tell off; to deride; to mock at, reprimand. 
ayinyanakin1 ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to ridicule; to laugh at the poverty of somebody. inyo bo kiyinyanakina ijo ngol lokican?: why do you make fun of (ridicule) that poor man?
ayinyanakin2 ko-a (transitive verb) (Serere) to tell off often; to keep telling off (in one’s face). 
ayipan ko-a (transitive verb)  to chip off; to chisel; to cut off. 
ayipanar ko-a (transitive verb) to cut off or chisel off a piece of wood, etc many times to make it sharp or pointed. 
ayipar ko-a (transitive verb) to cut off or chisel off a piece of wood, etc once only. 
ayipilil ko-a (intransitive verb) (of bottom of gourd, etc) to be protruding or visible; to be pointed. iyipilil akituk kon bala naka ebilicoro: your lips are pointed like the beak of the buffalo-weaver (an insult). 
ayirang ko-a (intransitive verb) (of a person) to have a big fat head. 
ayirangang ko-a (transitive verb) (of a person) to have a big fat head. iyirangang ijo: you have a big, fat head. 
ayiriyir ko-o (intransitive verb) (of eyes, water, glass, polished things) to glitter, shine. eyiriyirete akonyeke naarai edekas: her/his eyes are glazed because they are inflamed. 
ayis (plural ayiswan) (noun F) (Serere) a jungle; uninhabited bush; the high-grass. cp. ais
ayisang ayisang (adverb) (as  a big-headed person walking) swaying from side to side. 
ayisang ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to go or walk about with a big head; to have a big head. eyisangi ngesi: she/he has a big head. 
ayiset (plural ayiseta) (noun F) a water spring, fountain, source (of water or any liquid). 
ayisomom ki-a (intransitive verb) (of people only) to be tall; (of a person) to be higher. 
ayitakin ko-a (transitive verb) to sharpen, point for somebody; to drip or trickle on to something. 
ayitakinet (plural aitakineta) (noun F) a drop; a point; a spot; a dot. 
ayitanut1 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be fond of sharpening. 
ayitanut2 (noun F) habit of sharpening or pointing. 
ayitar ko-a (causative verb) to make pointed, sharp. koyita ekalaamu lo: sharpen this pencil. 
ayites (noun F) spikiness; sharpness; tapering. 
ayitunet (plural ayituneta) (noun F) a drop of liquid; a trickle. 
ayiyara ki-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to be safe; to be protected.
ayogan (singular noun F) a greeting; a welcome. 
ayoit (plural ayoi) (noun F) pain (after a knife-cut); soreness (after cut); a knife-cut; a minnow (a species of small fish). 
ayonganut1 (noun F) timidity; fearfulness; veneration.
ayonganut2 ko-a (intransitive verb) to be timid; to be timorous or inclined to fear 
ayonge (noun F) the residue in salt-making after draining brine. 
ayonget (plural ayongeta) (noun F) apprehension; fear; awe. 
ayongikin ko-o (transitive verb) to be afraid of; to stand in awe of.
ayongit ko-o (transitive verb) to be in constant fear of; to be afraid of; to be in reverence. eyongit ikoku ngin itunga: that child is afraid of or respects people. 
ayoore ko-o (intransitive verb) (Serere) to sing (a song or hymn). 
ayooya (plural ayooyan) (noun F) a cycle rim (without the tyre and spokes). cp. anamusiga. 
ayoroi (plural ayoro) (noun F) (Serere) a branch, a twig, or leaf of eyoroi tree. 
ayuara (singular noun F) a protection; shelter; fortification; security.
ayuaret (plural ayuareta) (noun F) a defence; an explanation in support of; a plea.
ayunar ko-o (reflexive verb) to go through a narrow opening; to slip through; to escape through a narrow opening. abu emir koyunar kapedot: the rat escaped through a narrow opening. 
ayunun ko-o (reflexive verb) to enter quickly; to slip in. 
ayupakin ko-a (transitive verb) to string on something. 
ayupet (plural ayupeta) (noun F) a string of beads, fish, or anything. 
ayupit ko-a (intransitive verb) (Serere) to be tired; to be fed up. cp. awupit
ayuun ko-a (transitive verb) to save; to rescue; to liberate; to redeem. 
ayuunan (plural ayuunak) (noun F) a rescuer; a saviour; a liberator; a redeemer. cp. ekayuunan.
ayuunet (plural ayuuneta) (noun F) a guarantee; a bail; a bond.
ayuunio (singular noun F) a rescue; a redemption; salvation; liberation; emancipation.
ayuwara (singular noun F) a corruption of ayuara: protection; security; shelter; fortification.
-B- 
b (noun neuter) the second letter of the Ateso alphabet.
ba1 (adverb) (of strength, tightness, hardness) very. egogong ba: she/he is very strong, hard. koyen ba: tie firmly. ataus ba: to be hard. eta amoru na ba: this rock is very hard. cp. baa ba
ba2 (interjection) indeed; in fact; certainly. ajai eong ba!: indeed I am here. bia ba!: in fact, do come (singular). ijo ba lo: you here: I mean you (singular M). cp. bo.
baa ba (adverb) (of strength, tightness, hardness) very. egogong baa ba: she/he/it is very strong, hard. itenara akimat baa ba: the old woman is very rigid (bodily, perhaps due to her age). ataus baa ba: to be very hard. eta amoru na ba: this rock is very hard. 
bala (adverb) about; approximate; as; like; nearly. epogana bala ajokit: she/he is as proud as the devil. erai bala; ikoni bala; esubit bala: it is as if; it is as though; in a way that makes you think something. elosi ngesi kosubite bala edeka: she/he walks as if she/he were sick.  etia bala: as…as (used with uncountable things). ipu/ikidioko bala: as many/few as. edolete itunga bala itomon kwangin: there are approximately ten people. 
bangal (adverb) (of soft and fat things, down fall) floppily. abu emun lokatuman kibirun kokitoi bangal: a fat snake fell from a tree with a flop. 
bangar (adverb) (of big things, fall with a) flop. adoo acokit kwap bangar: the (cooked) potato flopped down. 
bas (adverb) ok then; that is it. 
batabat (adverb) (of a duck or a fat and short person running) waddling; wobbling. ikeri ijo batabat: you run heavily like a duck. 
batisimu (noun neuter) baptism; induction into a faith or religion; initiation ceremony (especially into Christianity). 
be1 (adverb) (of colour red) very; extremely. ereng abebe akituk be: an antelope’s mouth is very red. arengeu emukaro be: the kiln is red hot.
be2 (interjection) no; nay. be, mam eong acamuni nepecep da!: nay, I will not accept it in the least! cp. beket.
bec (adverb) (to fit, do, or go) exactly, punctually. erai isaawan itomon bec: it is exactly 4:00 o’clock. cp. becebec
becebec (adverb) (to fit, do, or go) exactly, punctually. erai isaawan ikany-kape becebec: it is exactly 12:00 noon (or 12:00 midnight).
bee (adverb) (emphatic) very red. 
bekebek (adverb) (imitative) like the sound of a bird pecking nutshells or eggshells. 
beket (interjection) no; nay. beket, esabet ngol inera ijo: no, that is a lie you are now telling.
ber (adverb) first of all; so far; before; yet. koge ber aswam: (you) first begin to work. kobia ber: (you) come first. mam ber: not yet. 
bia (singular imperative) come! come hither! cp. abunere; potu; kobia; kopotu. 
biai? (interrogation) how? ijai biai?: how are you? (singular greeting). ijaasi biai?: how are you? (plural) 
bian (adverb) yesterday; last night. 
-bicil (plural –bicililas) (suffix, adjective) (of a pot, gourd, or person) narrow-mouthed. 
bir (adverb) (of a flame or fire) roaring; flaring; flaming; blazing. egasi akim bir, apolou ke ebe ejaas ipejok orot abunore: when a wood-fire blazes noisily, it means guests are on the way coming.
biribir (adverb) (of a flame or fire) roaring; flaring; flaming; blazing. enokiete airiirin biribir: twigs are flaring on fire.
bisaali (adjective) yellow (in colour like curry); creamy. 
bisali bisaali (adverb) very yellow or creamy. emunatai ajon bisali bisaali: the brew is creamy (the colour is like curry, hence well-made). 
bo (interjection) perhaps; then. inyo bo?: what is it then (do you want?). ai bo?: where then? do bo jo?: what about you? aso bo do: very well then; there you are!
boat (adverb) a corruption of bo nat: anyway; by the way; at all. ingai boat ijo?: who are you at all?(a challenge) cp. bonat
bobo (adverb) again; anew; afresh. bobo bobo: again and again. lu bobo: again these. mam bobo: never again. moi bobo: tomorrow again.
bokobok (adverb) (to tremble; to shiver) all over, very much. amaran bokobok: to shiver terribly. amaran teletel: to shudder terribly. 
bon (adverb) (used after singular reflexive verbs and personal pronouns) alone; by oneself; mere. eong bon: I alone; by myself; I solely. iso bon: we alone, ourselves; by ourselves. 
bonik (adverb) (used after plural reflexive verbs and personal pronouns) one another; by themselves; each other; mere. oni bonik: we alone; by ourselves. iso bonik: we alone, ourselves; by ourselves. 
boo (adverb) (to rain) heavily; incessantly. etepi edou boo: it is raining heavily. 
bu1 (adverb) (of red) very. 
bu2 (interjection) Oh! Oh my!
Buganda (noun F) the land of the Baganda people of central Uganda (districts such as Kampala, Mukono, Masaka, Mpigi, Luwero, etc); the pre-colonial kingdom of Buganda governed by the Kabaka (king).
Bulaya (noun F) Europe  (misinterpreted nowadays to mean the United Kingdom) 
Bunyoro (noun F) the pre-colonial kingdom of Bunyoro governed by Omukama - king (the present-day Uganda districts of Hoima, Masindi, and parts of Kibaale and Mubende); the land of the Banyoro people.
Busoga (noun F) the land of the Basoga people governed by Isebantu - king; the present day districts of Jinja, Iganga, Kamuli, Mayuge and Bugiri.
butubut (adverb) (of the sound of water being poured from a narrow-mouthed vessel, especially a gourd) gurgling; gushing.
buu! (interjection) Oh! Alas! cp. bu!
buua1 (adverb) (of the sound of a cow) moo; the lowing of a cow. cp. mee: the sound of a goat. merrr: the sound of a sheep.
buua2 (noun neuter) (to a child) a cow.
bwang (adverb) (to be finished) completely; utterly; totally. adaun bwang: to finish completely. adaunos bwang: erikaros bwang: they are completely finished. cp. pit
bwangabwang (adverb) (of pain) like nettles; burning hot like red pepper. emwaka akeje bwangabwang: the feet are burning like they are on fire. 
-C-
c (noun neuter) the third letter of the Ateso alphabet; (a mark indicating) the third highest grade or quality.
ca (interjection) (as a sign of impoliteness, with bo) well! indeed. eeca! yes, indeed; ay, aye. mam ca!: no, of course not. aso cabo! well, if you like! right! eong ca: it is I.
caat (adverb) perhaps; it may be so; well now. arai caat: perhaps. cp. ca nat; arai ca nat
cakaya cakaya (adverb) imitation of the rattle of a railway train as it chugs away. 
cani (adverb) just awhile; a moment. koyau cani kaany: just let me have a look. 
caricar (adverb) (to do something) for nothing; idly; in vain. aiboi carirar: to sit idly. cp. atitai
ce (interjection) how dare you? 
-ce- (suffix or infix of adjective & pronominal) another; other; some. ece- (M): another one; someone else. ace- (F): another; someone else; some more. aceparit: another day. icekoku: another child. lokacekwap M or nakacekwap F: a stranger. eceipone: a different manner; differently. loce (M): the other companion; so-and-so. nace (F): the other companion; so-and-so. 
ceger (adverb) (of a tall thing or person falling or jumping) gently, quietly, softly. ebala ekapa esomun kwap ceger: a cat jumped down lightly (not with a thud). 
cekicek (adverb) (of rainfall) incessant; non-stop. atep lolo edou cekicek: it has been raining incessantly today. 
cep (adverb) not in the least. mam nepecep da: not at all. cp. nepecep
ci (adverb) very (cold, chilly). ataus ci: to be very cold or chilly. eta akipi nu ci: this water is very cold. cii ci: very (awfully) cold. cp. elilim cii ci: very cold. 
-cici (plural -cicik) (adjectival suffix) small; immature; young; a little (thing). nediocici: a little while. ediocici: a little. akoto epaaba ediocici bon: I want only a little cotton wool. abuni nediocici: I’ll come in a little while, soon, now. 
cii ci (adverb) (of coldness or chilliness) very; awful. elilim abaraapu cii ci: ice cream is very cold.
cikil (adverb) (of something falling into a liquid and sinking) plop; plonk.
codok (adverb) (to jump) over. 
cogor (adverb) (of a long thing or person falling, moving or jumping) awkwardly, inelegantly, clumsily. ebala egoro elosi cogor cogor: a heron walks awkwardly (with long thin legs) 
cuc (adverb) very; absolutely; extremely (black or dark). iryono etogo lo cuc: this house is pitch dark. emutono akware na cuc: it is pitch dark tonight. egoe loribik erurut kiryono cuc: an alpaca is a very dark smooth cloth.
cut (adverb) (of intensity, quality, or degree) very; utterly; completely; entirely; quite; really; indeed; verily; truly. ka cut: especially. cuticut: certainly; exactly. 
cuticut (adverb) certainly; exactly; indeed; definitely; surely. konye cuticut atwana toto?: but surely mother is dead?
cwa (adverb) with a lot of confused noise; with a din; in commotion 
cwi (adverb) (to hold) firmly; strongly; (to tie) fast; tightly. aikamun cwi: to hold firmly, tightly, with the hand. 
-D-
d (noun neuter) the fourth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
da (adverb) also; not even. ajai ngesi da: she/he/it was also there. mam da: not even. mam ediopet da: not even one. iida: yes. 
daang (adverb) all; altogether; entire. atwaka akinei daang: all the goats are dead. atwaka kesi daang: they are all dead. cp. kere, dangadang.
dalac (adverb) (of a long soft thing unwinding and falling) flop softly. adacun emun kwap dalac: a snake fell down flop. cp. latak. 
daladal (adverb) (of a long thing) hanging listlessly. edeka emong ngol omulat, ebala amulat daladal: the bull is suffering from bovine pleuro-pneumonia, its mouth is drooling with saliva.
dau dau (adverb) (of something that can be felt or touched) glossy; silky; soft or smooth (to the touch). abu ekoroi ebala dau dau: the he-goat has come with a nice soft skin. enapit lolo ejakait nebala dau dau: the chief is dressed in silks today. ekuye asabuuni dau dau: the soap is foaming nicely.
de (adverb) very, completely (dry, desicated, arid); (Ateso Atororo) also; too. aono akwap de: the earth is completely dry; there is a great drought. akoto eong de akinyam: I also want to eat.
dee de (adverb) very, completely (dry, desicated, arid). aokoto nges ipon dee de: her/his lips are completely dry (due to thirst or hunger). cp. kara kar
di (adverb) (to hide, to get lost) entirely; completely. aingop dii di: to hide carefully. abu je kidat di keanyu ijaka luka esolo: the other guy hid himself completely when he saw graduated tax collectors. cp. du du.
-di- (diminutive infix, put between nominal or verbal prefix and noun or verb). akoto adijon: I want a little beer. alosi adipejo: I am going on a short visit. cp. dio, dit, dis. 
diala dial (adverb) (of somethind attached loosely) dangling; hanging; floppy. ebala emaradaadi loka atip kogoe diala dial: the decorative beads on the cloth are dangling loosely.
diat (adverb) perhaps; probably. cp. arai. 
-dicar (adjectival suffix) a little; a few. koinakinai ijon idicar: give me a little beer. akoto eong emuogo edicar: I want a little cassava. koyau akile adicar: bring a little milk. (note: only prefix e-, a-, i- changes for masculine, feminine, and diminutive to match the noun). 
-didi (adjective) suffix very small. koyau imeleku yenididi: bring a very small hoe. 
die (adverb) (to, from) nearby place; next to. alosi eong die nepene: I am going just near here. abuni eong kodie: I came from nearby. die ka: near me. die!: (when commanding draft-oxen) to the right! Turn nearby.
dii (adverb) (of people or animals moving) Indian file; one behind another. elosete imukunyo eriga dii: the ants are going hunting Indian file.
dii di (adverb) (to hide or get lost) entirely; completely. 
dikidik (adverb) throb frequently; thud often; pulse repeatedly, etc. ebala abus dikidik: the boil throbs (says dikidik). 
dikila (interjection) well done! fine! (mostly used by children in songs) 
dimarai (adverb) except; unless; before. mam ikukonokin idekesio ice, dimarai Eong bon: do not worship any other gods, except Me alone. cp. dimikito. 
dimicaat (adverb) perhaps if; except if; unless; if not; provided. abonguni eong, dimicaat kelomut acekiro: I shall come back unless something prevents me. 
dimikito (adverb) except; unless. mam inyami aperosit ngin, dimikito kalimok eong ijo: do not eat that food leftover of yesterday unless I have told you to. cp. dimarai.
dimito (adverb) a corruption of dimikito: except; unless. cp. dimarai. 
ding (adverb) (of size) very big; gigantic. epol ngesi ding: she/he is very big. cp. noi
dingiding (adverb) (of size or quantity) very big; very much. cp. ding; noi noi
-dio (plural -dis) (indefinite pronoun prefix) some; a little (of something). ediomoro: some other day. kookokinoi adisikipi: fetch me a little water. (note: -dio follows the prefixes e-, a-, i- and precedes the noun without the prefix). 
diolo diol (adverb) (of wet ground or slimy vegetable) very, extremely polished, slippery, or smooth. ebala eboo diolo diol, esubit bala ekwamakina atigo toma: the eboo vegetable is very slimy, it looks like too much atigo condiment was put. erurut erot diolo diol: the road is very slippery.
-dis- (adjective) (an infix denoting) a few. adisikinei: a few goats. idisitunga: a few people. (note: dis follows a prefix and precedes a noun; it is also used as an adjective following a noun). itunga idis: a few people. adisikipi: adisikile: a little water, milk. 
-ditai (adjective) suffix a small amount; a little. akoto eong akile aditai: I want a little milk. 
diye (adverb) (to, from) nearby place; hereabouts. alosi eong diye nepene: I am going just near here. abuni eong kodiye: I came from nearby. diye ka: near me. diye!: (when commanding draft-oxen to) the right! Turn nearby. cp. die.
do nat (adverb) sooner; later on. adau ngesi aibunga eong, doot ijo: she/he has already beaten me and now he is going to beat you. 
do1 (adverb) (of sweetness) intense; very. ejijim esukaali do: the sugar is very sweet. cp. doo
do2 (adverb) then; now. do ijo: now you! inyo bo do?: what then? doot aikonakin ai?: what can we do then? what can be done then? or what is to be done then?
doine (adverb) a corruption of do konye: after which; so that. ejai ijo adolun ne moi, doine idumuni epale: you have to come here tomorrow if you want to get the trousers. cp. tetere konye.
dolodol1 (adverb) (of something long and hanging) loosely; dangling sideways. ebakasi ekoroi itou dolodol: the he-goat’s testicles are swinging loosely. 
dolodol2 (adverb) in a lazy manner; idly; sluggishly; lazily; indolently. iswamai ijo dolodol: you work sluggishly. 
doo (adverb) very; too (sweet, syrupy, sugary). ejijim esukaali doo: sugar is very sweet. eta doo; ebala doo; ejijim doo doo: it is very sweet.
doot (adverb) a corruption of do nat: later on; sooner. adau ngesi aibunga eong, doot ijo: she/he has already beaten me and now he is going to beat you. 
dotini (adverb) a corruption of do konye: and then; so that. koloto ber yesi dotini eong da aswam nuka: you better go so that I may do my work. cp. tetere.
du1 (adverb) (of red or crimson) very. arengeun du: (of a solid object on fire, of the fire place itself) to become red hot, very hot, or very red. akinyeta nuebulucete emukule iterengeunete ijo du: bleaching creams make you very red. 
du2 (adverb) (to hide, to get lost, or to disappear) entirely; altogether; completely. aingop duu du: to hide completely. aolio ngesi du: she/he/it is lost altogether. cp. duu du, dii di.
duc (adverb) always; all the time; everyday; usually; daily. akoto eong ijo kobunenei duc: I want you to come always. 
ducuduc (adverb) always; all the time; continually; usually; repeatedly; very often. akoto eong ijo kobunenei ducuduc: I want you to come very often. 
dukum (adverb) (of a fruit, cooked food) soft; ripe; tender. akokoto acok dukum, ebucitos aipisiar: the sweet potatoes got very soft in cooking, it nearly turned watery.
dupuk (adverb) (of a clap-trap, to go off with a) thud; crash or bang. agwetakin akuluma dupuk: the clap-trap went off with a thud, crash. motoko eic da kitilim akiro, konye akuluma dupuk dupuk: the string trap allows you to squeak, but a clap-trap kills you outright (said at a meeting of Rats - in a children song). 
dus (adverb) (imitative of a sound of a hard object falling on a resounding surface) thud; thump; bump; (of a heartbeat) throbbing; pounding. ebala akou edoi kwap dus: his head fell down with a thud. ebala etauka dus del: my heart is throbbing madly (like it wants to fall off its strings).
dusuk (adverb) (of something cooked) very soft; completely or totally soft. 
duu du (adverb) (to hide, to get lost, or to disappear) entirely; altogether; completely. aingop duu du: to hide completely. aolio ngesi duu du: she/he/it is lost altogether. arengeun duu du: (of a solid object on fire, of the fire place itself) to become red hot, very hot, or very red. akinyeta nuebulucete emukule iterengeunete ijo duu du: bleaching creams make you very red. cp. dii di.
-E-
e (noun neuter) the fifth letter of the Ateso alphabet; a vowel letter as in ‘jet’.
e- a prefix denoting: a) masculine nouns. etelepat: a boy b) large objects. emoru: a big stone or a mountain. c) adjectives. etunganan lo ejok: a good man. d) third person of ko-verbs. eduki ngesi: she/he builds. e) first person of ki-verbs. eswamai eong: I work. 
Eale (noun M) Mt. Elgon; the Sebei country. aite oalei: to die (some Teso clans bury their dead with graves facing east – the direction of Mt. Elgon from Teso). cp. Eyale
eapie1 (plural eapiete) (adjective) being a short distance away; near; adjacent; approximate; contiguous. oiduka loeapie: at the adjacent shop.
eapie2 (plural eapiete) (adverb) soon; nearly. eapie ngesi abunere: she/he/it is nearly coming. eapikit ngesi atwanare: she/he/it is nearly dead. eapie oni adolore ngina: we are nearly there.
Earabut (plural Iarabun) (noun M) an Arab. cp. eyarabut
earamor (plural iaramorio) (noun M) Sasswood or Ordeal tree, Erythrophleum suaveolens. The bark is poison, hence the 'ordeal tree'. The tree provides shade, firewood, and timber.
eari (plural earete) (adjective) fatal; deadly; lethal; incurable; terminal; mortal; serious; grave; critical. 
ebaado (plural ibaadoi) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of maize with big cobs and seeds. orwa! abures ikel bala ebaado ngina: go away with your big teeth! (an insult to a toothy person). cp. ekirididi
ebaaja (plural ibaajai) (noun M) a debt; indebtedness; money owing. epuakata eong ibaajai noi: I am heavily in debt.
ebaale (plural ebaale) (noun M) a mushroom (in general). ebwangunit ebaale katitipu kangin: mushrooms have sprouted on that anthill.
ebaba (plural ibabai) (noun M) the last person (in class or in athletics race);a shrub, Rhus incana. 
ebabu (plural ibabun) (noun M) a poor man; a beggar. irai ijo ebabu: irai ijo loka ibabu: you are a beggar. cp. lokibabu.
ebac (plural ibacia) (noun M) an evergreen tree, Rauvolfia caffra. The roots and bark are medicine (abac) for hypertension, and the wood is used for poles, beehives and firewood.
ebaga (plural ibagai) (noun M) Christmas feast, celebration, festivity, rejoicing, or banquet; Noël tide. cp. epucit
ebai kide (adverb) at dawn. kiding ebai (adverb) at dawn, about 4:00 am. cp. tupuruc sek
Ebaibuli (plural Ibaibulin) (noun M) the Bible, i.e. the sacred writings of the Christian Church, consisting of the Old and New Testaments. ebaibuli: a copy of the Bible. ebaibuli: a highly-detailed book, regarded as an authority.
ebajeret (plural ibajeren) (noun M) a foreign made bracelet. 
ebajet (plural ibajetin) (noun M) a budget; a financial forecast; any plan, especially for a particular period of time, showing how money coming in will be spent.
ebakat (plural ibakat) (noun M) a man with feet full of jiggers; a man with very dirty feet; one who walks with difficulty (riadariad) with toes spread out. ibakatat: (you are) dirty! ibakatatas: (they are) dirty!(a term of reproach or abuse)
ebakedo (plural ibakedon) (noun M) avocado pear or tree, Persea americana. Its fruit is used as food or cosmetic, oil is extracted from the seed, while the tree provides shade and firewood.
ebakuli (plural ibakulin) (noun M) a vegetable bowl. 
ebalangit (plural ibalanga) (noun M) a tree, Protea paveta crassipes. 
ebalasa (plural ibalasan) (noun M) a verandah; a porch; a balcony; a loggia; a portico. cp. akadapao
ebalelet (plural ibalel) (noun M) (rare) a mushroom (general). 
ebalua (plural ibaluan) (noun M) a letter; mail; a memo. ibaluan: mail. aiwadikakin ebalua: to write a letter to. ebalua loilipit aswam: a job application letter. ebalua loilipit aibois: an application for a vacancy. ebalua loacamakinio aiboisit: an admission letter.
ebang (plural ibangiok) (noun M) a fool; an idiot; a dumb person; a mad person; a duffer; a buffoon; a twin boy-child. isusit ebang aoret otimake: the madman has smeared cow-dung on his hair. 
ebangaana (plural ebangaaka) (adjective) stupid; mad; dumb; daft; dull; foolish; deaf; silly; dense; absurd. 
ebangit (plural ibangin) (noun M) a male twin-child. cp. emuut.
ebanyet (plural ibanyeta) (noun M) a razor blade. cp. ebarenit, emweeso. 
ebar (plural ibaria) (noun M) (formerly) a cleared space outside the village (used for ebar dance); a dance at night without drums; faeces (human or animal); solid excreta (of people).
ebarakis (plural ibarakisin) (noun M) a barracks. 
ebarara (adjective) numerous; abundant; copious; profuse; many. 
ebarenit (plural ibarenito) (noun M) a razor for shaving; a razorblade. cp. emweeso
ebarit (plural ebaritos) (adjective) affluent; rich (in livestock, money, or non-crop items). 
ebasang (plural ibasanga) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a slave. cp. ebulesut, ebusiat
ebasikooti (plural ibasikootin) (noun M) a waistcoat. 
ebata (plural ibatai) (noun M) a Sirris tree or red and white nongo - Albizia zygia, Albizia glaberrima  (a tree in etekwa family). Its leaves and bark are used for soap (foaming lather), leaves are fodder, extract from flowers, bark and seed are medicinal. 
ebatalion (plural ibatalionin) (noun M) a battalion (a number of companies). 
ebatiira (plural ibatiiran) (noun M) elephantiasis of the feet. cp. abotirir, akuwe. 
ebe (adverb) thus; that, “……”; quite; like this. (Used with direct quotation) abala eong ebe, ‘mam akoto’: I say (thus), ‘I don’t want.’ (used before indirect or reported speech, meaning that 'he says.' ebala ngesi ebe ebuni moi: he says he will come tomorrow. (without ebe: ebala ngesi ebuni moi).
ebebele (plural ibebelei) (noun M) (outside Usuk) an edible mole rat with a white-tipped tail. cp. edoomelu, omelekes.
ebeei (singular noun M) a price; the cost of on a good or service. cp. etiai.
ebeele (plural ibeelei) (noun M) a fight as a result of double dealing; wrong information given by rumour-spreader; mischief-making. ayaun ebeele: to cause a disturbance. 
ebeere (plural ibeerei) (noun M) a grasshopper in general. 
ebega (plural ibegai) (noun M) a detective; a spy; a sleuth. cp. ekangican.
ebego (plural ibegoi) (noun M) a pedigree; a select or choice seed; a variety or stock (ancestry). cp. ekinyomit. ibecokino aipit ebego loka akokoroi: it is advisable to rear farm breeds of chicken.
ebekubeku (plural ibekubekun) (noun M) a variety of red-headed edible mushroom growing in sandy plains. cp. ebaale
ebela (plural ibelai) (noun M) a stick; a cane. 
ebelat (noun M) a variety of cowpeas. cp. odiiri. 
ebelat (plural ibelan) (noun M) a person to be wounded on the head (with stick.) 
ebele (plural ibelesio) (noun M) affair; an issue; a matter; a concern; a problem. inyoika ibelesio kus kane?: what is your business here? (what are you doing here?)
ebelekinyom (plural ibelekinyom) (noun M) a variety of small white edible mushroom, Sarcocephalus esculentus 
ebelekuma (plural ibelekumai) (noun M) a vegetable, Commelina. 
ebelel (adjective) (it is) split, cracked, bashed in (as of a head using ebela - stick). 
ebeli (singular noun M) famine; starvation. cp. etengei.
ebeliodole (plural ibeliodolei) (noun M) a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock.
ebelo (plural ibeloi) (noun M) (rare) profit. emamei ebelo kotoma agwelanar kon: there is no profit in your business or trade. cp. ameda: profit.
ebenen (adjective) (of weight, work, movement) light, easy, brisk; agile or simple. ebenen amot na: this pot is light. 
ebenet (plural ibeneta) (noun M) a bayonet, i.e. a knife attached to the barrel of a rifle. cp. epima. 
ebenot (plural ibenoi) (noun M) a plant that grows near water, Ricinodendron heudelotii; It is a thorny leguminous shrub with yellow flowers with cork wood often used for rafts and corks.
ebenyana (plural ebenyaka) (adjective) harsh; vicious; quarrelsome; malevolent; cruel. 
ebenyo (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a tree, Acacia mellifera. 
eberiang (adjective) excited; animated; lively; bubbly. 
eberu (noun M) a very big woman; a virago; an amazon. 
ebeuna (adjective) truthful; affirmative; right; direct or straightforward. 
ebia (noun M) spear grass, Imperata cylindrica. Its presence in the soil means the soil is good for growing crops.
ebiasara (plural ibiasaran) (noun M) for-profit business; trade; economic activity. 
ebibiru (plural ibibirun) (noun M) the top of the inside of the house; the apex; a tower; a minaret. 
ebibisi (plural ibibisin) (noun M) sweet brew (two days old, after which it is called arasai). cp. ewinyiwiny
ebico (plural ibicoi) (noun M) a small pot; a vessel with narrow mouth. cp. eico
ebicupuli (adjective) fake; bogus; counterfeit; phoney; sham. eiswamae lo ebicupuli: a phoney manner of working or doing business. isirigin lu ebicupuli: counterfeit currency.
ebidio (plural ibidion) (noun M) a video; a VCR player. cp. etelebision; esineema
ebikirane (singular noun M) (in the Catholic church) a sisterhood; nuns of a certain religious order. cp. apuleera
ebilaangit (plural ibilaangin) (noun M) a blanket (in general); a coverlet; eiderdown. 
ebilaep (plural ibilaepen) (noun M) a tree - the root of which is used as medicine for wounds, Acacia macrothyrsa. 
ebilat (plural ibilan) (noun M) a long chair (that can be folded together); a deck chair. 
ebileng (plural ibilenga) (noun M) mudfish; lungfish, Protopterus. cp. ekolia
ebili (singular noun M) bad luck; misfortune; hard luck; a curse. aremor ebili: to cast off a spell or a curse. cp. enyege.
ebilibila (adjective) (of a woman or girl) bashful; pretend to be shy or embarrassed; (of anything) broken many times.
ebilicoro (plural ibilicoron) (noun M) a buffalo weaverbird. cp. ekerekeret
ebilikeret (plural ibilikereta) (noun M) a guineafowl-like francolin. 
ebilil (adjective) broken; bent; crumpled; creased; folded; conquered. 
ebilionit (plural ibilionin) (noun M) a billion; a thousand million. ibilionin ka ibilionin: billions upon billions. cp. emilionit. 
ebilo (plural ibiloi) (noun M) a flute with 2-6 holes.
ebinika (plural ibinikan) (noun M) a kettle; a tea-pot.
ebino (plural ibinoi) (noun M) wine, i.e. an alcoholic drink made from the fermented juice of fruits such as grapes, passion fruits, tangerines, etc 
ebinu (plural ibinun) (noun M) an unusually shaped pot with no neck, tall in relation to its width, tapering to a fairly small aperture. cp. eico; ebico.
ebirinyaanya (plural ibirinyaanyan) (noun M) an eggplant; the aubergine fruit. cp. etulelut
ebisaali (plural ibisaalin) (noun M) curry powder; a plant whose root is used to make curry 
ebit (noun M) piles; greed, avarice; egoism. 
ebitet (plural ibitei) (noun M) the stem of a smoker’s pipe; the sharp end of a spear. 
ebiti (plural ibitin, ibitia) (noun M) a small spear. 
ebiya (plural ibiyai) (noun M) factory or industrial beer or brew; a lager. cp. ajon nuacupa. 
ebobore (plural iboborio) (noun M) a fig tree in the ebule and ebyong family, Ficus sycomorus. This tree has sacred or religious significance and is not cut in anger. The tree bears edible fruits, and the wood is good for carving troughs as well as for timber or firewood. aisieb ebobore: to deny any wrong-doing by cutting or piercing ebobore, hence wishing the accuser death (if the accused is guilty, the death wish boomeranges on his family).
ebocit (plural ibocin) (noun M) an impotent man. ebocit: a man dressing and behaving like a woman. cp. ebwacit, abwacit.
ebodaboda (plural ibodabodan) (noun M) a pay cycle, i.e. a commercial bicycle or motorcycle. icaki ngesi ebodaboda: she/he carries passengers on a cycle (for money). cp. egaali, epikipik
ebogo (uncountable noun M) a mixture of churned and fresh milk. cp. akile nuituryanitai. 
ebogoya (noun M) a variety of banana plant bearing long big fruits eaten yellow. cp. adeke, ematooke. 
eboi (plural iboyan) (noun M) a fishnet; a web. cp. aitiiba, ekokota
eboikinon (plural eboikinok) (noun M) one who sits. eboikinon aingito: one who sits for exams or tests; an examination candidate. 
eboit (plural iboin) (noun M) (formerly) servant (from English ‘boy servant’); ploughing oxen.
ebok (plural ibokia) (noun M) (a reference among friends) a guy; a fellow; a mature man. cp. ebok.
eboket (plural iboketa) (noun M) a tool for digging; a crow-bar. cp. emeleku: a hoe. 
ebokoi (plural ibokoi) (noun M) the first part of a song. 
ebokolinga (plural ibokolingan) (noun M) (Usuk) a red-necked lizard. cp. ecokolinga.
ebokorit (plural ibokor) (noun M) a finger; a toe of man or animals. ebokorit loka akeju: a toe. ebokorit lokapolon: a thumb. ebokorit lokokiding: a middle finger. ebokorit lomedelit or imedelit: a little finger or toe. ebokorit losodit: index finger. ibokorit yenikawasia: the little finger or toe. ebokorit lokepeta: a ring finger. adeka nakibokor: onychia (fungal infection affecting the skin between toes or fingers). 
ebokot (plural ibokotas) (adjective) (of anything) rough; misshapen; ill-formed. ebokot amot na: this pot is roughly done. 
ebol (plural ibolia) (noun M) a swelling on the knee (due to too much kneeling), Bursitis juxta articular nodules. cp. ekabolit
ebola (singular noun M) ebola fever (a very contagious and deadly disease whose victims die of severe internal bleeding).
ebole (plural ibolei) (noun M) a pact; a wager; a bet; a recompense; a promise; a testament, law; agreement. aiar ebole: to breach a contract. cp. aiboleikin. 
ebolet (plural iboleta) (noun M) playing field. cp. eisaawe.
eboli (plural ibolin) (noun M) a young Bagrus fish. 
eboliana (plural eboliaka) (adjective) playful; sporting; sportive; frivolous. 
ebolibol (plural ibolibolin) (noun M) a tree, Ficus ovata. 
ebolo (plural iboloi) (noun M) a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock.
eboloca (plural ibolocai) (noun M) a tree, Grewia mollis. 
eboluk (plural iboluk) (noun M) a fat man (especially one with a double chin) (an insult). 
ebomibom (singular noun M) a variety of orange tree bearing big fruits. cp. emakada
ebomo (plural ibomoi) (noun M) a creeper tied round the necks and wrists at ailelekej (rain dances) and before the sowing of grain. 
ebonet (plural ibonei) (noun M) a swelling on the skin; a growth on a knee. 
ebong (adverb) in the evening; afternoon; at dusk. 
ebonge (singular noun M) the time of return, going back, retiring. 
ebongut (plural ibongun) (noun M) a barkcloth fig tree, Ficus natalensis. Its bark is used for making barkcloth, while the leaf extract is medicine for dysentery and sore throat.
ebonibonit (plural ibonibon) (noun M) the ear lobe. 
ebonot1 (plural ibonoi) (noun M) beads of metal cylinders strung together (formerly used as an apron, a ring, or a crown). 
ebonot2 (plural ibonotas) (adjective) (of a person or animal) smooth; well fed; quite well developed (physically); most beautiful; unpretentious, considerate, nice; (of manners being) meek; elegant; well-mannered, easy. ebonot etelepat ngol: that boy is nice, quiet, humble, serious, etc 
eboo1 (noun M) leaves of peas, Vigna; a common vegetable from pea leaves. cp. edila
eboo2 (plural ibooi) (noun M) a tree, Hyma nocardia acida. 
ebood (plural iboodin) (noun M) a board, especially of directors; an official group of people controlling or managing an organisation, etc., or examining or interviewing candidates. ebood loka idairekitan: a board of directors. ebood loka aingito: an examinations board.
eboole (plural iboolei) (noun M) work in exchange for beer in future; a communal feast held after millet harvest prepared for those who helped in the harvesting. cp. edira.
ebooma (plural iboomai) (noun M) a town (especially an administrative headquarters of a district). cp. eigoo, etaun. 
eboomu (plural iboomun) (noun M) a bomb-shell; a grenade. cp. awolanet
eboot (plural iboon) (noun M) an isolated hut or house; a new home (with just one isolated hut). 
eborosit (singular noun M) (disapprovingly) a lot of things; a heap of things; a conglomeration of things; a cluster of things. 
ebosana (plural ebosaka) (adjective) (of anything) liable to become rotten quickly.
ebosino (plural lukebosino) (noun M) a male child surviving after the death of other children born before him; a soldier who survives in a battlefield. 
ebotet (plural ibotei) (noun M) a club; a big stick; a cudgel. 
ebu (plural ibuin) (noun M) a hyena (spotted – Crocuta crocuta; striped – Hyena hyena); a greedy person or glutton who eats anything and in large amounts. eicolong-ebu: a praying mantis. kinyami ebu kolek: you are so disgusting (literally, even the hyena will vomit on eating you).
ebubaani (plural ibubaanin) (noun M) frankincense; incense. 
ebukit1 (plural ibukito) (noun M) a large reed basket. cp. edita: a small reed basket; edude. emuret: a basket for mixing and fermenting flour. eisowa: basket work for gourds. 
ebukit2 (noun M) a herbaceous plant, Acalypha. 
ebuku (plural ibukui) (noun M) a county; a skin or hide shield; a dwelling place; abode; armour. obukon bo ai?: obukon ne?: where do you come from? is this your home area? buka: my home. obuka: at my home. obuka: my home area. obukec: their home area. obukui: in (to) the countries abroad, overseas. obukusio kere: everywhere; the world over. cp. aupwal
ebukuit (plural ibukui) (noun M) a stranger; an alien; a foreigner. 
ebulaayat (plural ibulaayan) (noun M) a European man. 
ebule (plural ibulei, ibuleik) (noun M) a tree in the ebobore and ebyong family, Ficus platyphylla. Its latex is medicine for ringworms. The latex is also the source of Niger Gutta gum. The tree is good for soil improvement and conservation because of its fruit that attracts birds.
ebuleesut (plural ibuleesun) (noun M) a man slave; a man servant. 
ebulit (plural ibulito) (noun M) grease stains around mouth (a sign that one has eaten oily or fatty food). 
ebulolo (plural ibuloloi) (noun M) chicken flea; chicken louse. cp. apinat. 
ebuloni (singular noun M) a morass; a bog or quagmire. cp. akao, ecoa. 
ebulukucwa (plural ibulukucwaan) (noun M) a species of bird named after the sound it makes, Crimson breasted shrike. cp. amulukujun. 
ebulumuka (adverb) at random, haphazardly, or indiscriminately. apotu ipolisin kibungaata itunga luediiyaete korot ebulumuka: the riot police beat demonstrators indiscriminately.
ebune (plural ibunei) (noun M) the sterile head of sorghum or millet (with black fungal spores). 
ebuni (noun M) a castor oil plant, Cussonia arbore. cp. ekakale.
ebur1 (plural eburok) (adjective) big, huge, plump. eburok acok: the potatoes are big. eburok ipon: she/he is big-lipped or thick-lipped cp. ibatalalas ipon. 
ebur2 (plural iburin) (noun M) a river bank; deep water, a fissure or deep hole in the rock; the deepest part of the lake, hole, pit, or crevice. 
ebura (singular noun M) claiming of a debt; debt-collection. 
ebure1 (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum.
ebure2 (singular noun M) a method or manner of covering, sheathing or binding (of book, a sword, spear, etc). 
eburiged (plural iburigedin) (noun M) a brigade (a number of battalions). 
eburoit (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis chalcantha. 
eburu (plural iburun) (noun M) a boring bee. 
eburuka (plural iburukan) (noun M) a plant, Euphorbia. cp. epopong; eligoi. 
eburukunyu (plural iburukunyun) (noun M) a large grasshopper; a mushroom (when first emerging). 
eburwoi (plural iburwoi) (noun M) a drop (of water or any liquid). cp. esima. 
eburwoit (plural iburwo) (noun M) a swollen scar; a keloid. aiger iburwo: to make tribal marks, engravings, tattoos, or incisions.
ebus (plural ibusion) (noun M) a blue monkey, Centropithecus mitis stuhlmannii. 
ebusi (plural ebusete) (adjective) (of beings, spirits) immortal; eternal. 
ebusiat (plural ibusiai) (noun M) a male slave; a male servant; one who stays with a chief to get food or clothes (a parasitic person); a draught ox (that pulls carts or ploughs). 
ebusibus (plural ibusibusio) (noun M) a tree, Steganotaenia araliacea. Its root extract is used as a liniment for rheumatism or sciatica.
ebutono (plural ebutoko) (adjective) (of a living thing, especially a person) eternal; living for long. 
ebutot (plural ibutoi) (noun M) a young mudfish; a young ebileng (mudfish) 
ebutuura (plural ibutuuran) (noun M) a fruit-eating bird resembling a parrot (with a slightly curved beak) with red and black feathers. 
ebuu (noun M) a shrub, Ficus sur. 
ebuubuu1 (adjective) (of an animal) spotted or dappled brown (like a hyena). 
ebuubuu2 (noun M) a shrub, Allophylus subceriaceus. 
ebuune (noun M) shame; embarrassment. ebuune lokakou: swelling of the head on account of shame; blushing. abu nges akou kobutu nealimokinia eong nges akiro ngun: she/he blushed when I told her/him that. 
ebuunit (plural ebuunitos) (adjective) (of a gland or anything) swollen; bloated; enlarged; engorged; inflated. 
ebuyat (plural ebuya) (noun M) spear grass, Imperata cylindrica. 
ebuyu (plural ibuyon) (noun M) a mole rat; a honey badger, Mellivora capensis. 
ebwaade (plural ibwaadei) (noun M) a large bird of prey in the eagle family; a male prostitute; a man who is always going about looking for food; a loafer. cp. emalayat.
ebwacit (plural ibwacin) (noun M) a barren man; an impotent man; a homosexual; a gay. araus ebwacit: (of a man) to be impotent or homosexual. araun ebwacit: (of a man) to become gay, barren or homosexual. 
ebwaet (plural ibwaeta) (noun M) a bracket; a fence; a hedge. 
ebwalaana (plural ebwalaaka) (adjective) (of a person) slow; negligent. 
ebwalai (plural ibwalai) (noun M) a tree of ebule family, Gymnosporia senegalensis & gracilipes. 
ebwanaterak (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet quick-maturing cassava (a famine crop for newly married women). cp. ouma
ebwata (plural ibwatai) (noun M) a neck chain worn as ornament; a tassel; a tail ornament. 
ebwiino (plural ibwiinon) (noun M) ink. 
ebwikinitai (adjective) compulsory. 
ebwolo (plural ibwoloi) (noun M) a custard apple bush, Annona senegalensis. Its root is a deadly poison for eyes, the fruit is edible, and the liquid from the pounded and boiled roots is a dressing for septic wounds (in livestock) and snake bites. The bark is a dye. 
ebwolococo (plural ibwolococon) (noun M) a tree, Lannea barteri. 
ebwonor (noun M) (formerly) a variety of cassava. 
ebworon (plural ebworok) (noun M) a mourner; the bereaved; a fierce person or animal. 
ebwos (plural ibwosio) (noun M) a multi-mammate mouse (literally, a rat which eats the abwo of old women). cp. enyamabwos
ebyera (plural ibyerai) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum. 
ebyong (plural ibyongia) (noun M) a tree resembling ebobore and ebule and whose bark is used for fibre and the wood for charcoal burning -Ficus glumosa. 
ecaai (singular noun M) tea (beverage). ecaai lo atibong: evening tea.
ecaalo (plural icaaloi) (noun M) the village; upcountry; the rural area. ecaalo kosi ejai Katakwi: our village is in Katakwi district. iponesio lukocaalo: village mannerisms.
ecaaman (plural lukecaaman) (noun M) a chairman. 
ecabicabi (plural ecabicabete) (adjective) (of a water body or sky) cloudless; clear. 
ecaboi (noun M) (outside Usuk) a vegetable whose root extracts are drank to stimulate childbirth, Gynandropsis pentaphylla. cp. ecadoi
ecadoi (noun M) (Usuk) a vegetable whose root extracts are drank to stimulate childbirth, Gynandropsis pentaphylla. cp. ecaboi
ecakara (adjective) abject; abandoned; abjured; castaway. 
ecak-eupa (plural lukecak-eupa) (noun M) a greedy man or boy who searches for food after feeling the hearth warm with the foot.(A nickname given to a man or boy who tests whether ashes are warm to find out whether anything has been cooked. This kind of person always searches a house for food if he discovers that the hearth is warm).
ecamuna (adjective) acceptable, agreeable, compliant. 
ecamusana (plural icamusanai) (noun M) a bribe, a kickback; bribery. 
ecanit (plural ican) (noun M) grief; trouble, misery, poverty; adversity; affliction; sorrow. kakotos eong ican ka Okula aiyar: I am in great poverty or misery (comparable only to a dog – Okula). lok’ican (plural luk’ican): poor man. aanyun ican: to get in trouble or misery. aanyunit eong ican: I am in great misery. ianyunit ican: well well, you have got problems. 
ecar (plural icaria) (noun M) (Usuk) a traditional heart-shaped hoe used for weeding a finger millet crop. cp. engiti, emeleku 
ecaut (plural icaoi) (noun M) a shrub with edible fruit, a Framomum. 
ecawoit (plural icawoi) (noun M) a plant, Alpima mutica. 
ece- (masculine adverbial prefix) some; another; more. ecekaru (plural icekar) (adverb) another year. ecekiliokit: another man.
ecebore (plural iceboro) (noun M) something; another thing. cp. ecetunganan.
ececelu (plural icecel) (noun M) gland in the groin; the groin. 
eceelet (plural iceelei) (noun M) a small elevation or hill; a protrusion. 
eceeret (plural iceeren) (noun M) a species of black bird; ox-pecker, Buphagos. 
ecegere (plural icegerei) (noun M) fork of a tree; a traditional three-legged stool; a lamp stand. cp. eicegera
ecekana (plural ecekaka) (adjective) (of land, body, scalp) fertile; easily producing hair or weeds; prolific. ecekana ekesa ngol: that guy is very hairy. 
ecekem (plural icekemas) (adjective) (of ground, vegetables, bed) thoroughly wet, soaking wet. 
ecekereng (noun M) (Ateso Ateso) a tree in the acacia family, Acacia hockii. 
ecelana (plural ecelaka) (adjective) noisy; irritable; excitable; quarrelsome. ecelana aberu kon: your wife is quarrelsome. 
ecelet (plural iceleta) (noun M) noise; a clamour; a quarrel; a shout; a row; an uproar; tumult; conflict; discord. ejai ecelet ore lo: there is a row in this home. 
ecen (plural icenion) (noun M) a nephew on sister’s side (from the point of view of the woman’s brother). (note: on brother’s side these are called okoku: son). cp. ejejait: a nephew (from the point of view of both the maternal or paternal aunts).
ecepa (plural icepai) (noun M) a fork-tailed drongo, Dicrurus spp. 
ecepe (plural icepei) (noun M) insignia; stars or diamonds as signs of rank in the armed forces; shoulder epaulettes.
eceroono (plural ecerooko) (adjective) striped; hooped; lined; banded. cp. ebuubuu.
ecetunganan (plural icetunga) (indefinite pronoun M) someone; somebody. cp. ediotunganan.
eceu (singular noun M) a guinea-worm, Dracunculus. 
ecici (singular noun M) a grass used for making idula (mud-and-grass granaries), Laudelia simplex; a climbing plant. Rhoicissus erithrodes. 
ecicikwa (noun M) a small wild creeping sisal plant, Aloe vera. Its juice is used in the manufacture of modern cosmetics. Traditionally, the leaves are roasted and the liquid squeezed is smeared on the itching foot as a remedy.
ecigwa (noun M) a plant, Solanum dudiflorum. 
ecii1 (noun M) a fungus on crops. 
ecii2 (plural iciidon) (noun M) a species of grasshopper. 
eciidait (plural iciid) (noun M) a hookworm; a tapeworm. cp. emelekede.
eciirit (plural iciirin) (noun M) one of the bells tied on the leg and worn by men for dancing.
ecilaboi (noun M) a grass that grows in swamps and used for making brooms, Sporobolus indica.
ecilet1 (plural icileta) (noun M) a stream; a rivulet; a swamp or marsh joining two water masses. 
ecilet2 (plural icileta) (noun M) a thong for fastening child on back. 
eciletait (plural icileta) (noun M) one of the four leather thongs of anapet. 
ecilikiki (plural icilikikin) (noun M) a double-edged knife resembling a spear (about 15 centimetres in length). 
ecilil1 (adjective) torn; split. loecilil eponoi: a man with a hare-lip. 
ecilil2 (plural icilila) (noun M) (Usuk) an oryx, Beisa Oryx. 
ecirit (plural icirin) (noun M) a dancing pellet-bell tied on the lower leg. cp. esimat. 
eco (plural ecoak) (adjective) clever, cute, shrewd, cautious; (of chicken) grown up. 
ecoa (plural icowai) (noun M) a morass; a swamp; a bog or quagmire. cp. akao, ebuloni. 
ecobe (adjective) clever; wise; adroit; intelligent; astute; shrewd. ecobe etelepat ngol: that boy is intelligent.
ecoc (plural icocia) (noun M) a porcupine, Atherurus africanus. Its quill is mixed in a gourd with grain bound for planting as a ‘blessing’ to the grain. cp. apupu.
ecoco (plural icocotei) (noun M) a misanthrope; a hater of people.
ecocoot (plural ecocooto, ecocootos) (adjective) (of man or animal) rather clever, timid, timorous, shy; (of a chicken) rather big. ecocoot ekingok: the dog is timid, or afraid to be beaten. ecocoot eculot ngol, kikamutu kotuboi: that cockerel is rather big, catch it for slaughter.
ecocot (plural icoc) (noun M) a hole in an anthill; a small hole in the anthill, an air passage for anthills. 
ecocote (plural lukecocote) (noun M) a misanthrope; a hater of men.
ecododo (plural icododoi) (noun M) a cripple. cp. engwalas
ecoe (plural icowei) (noun M) a bag (in general); a crop (of birds); a pocket, purse, sack. ecoe loka epiu: gall-bladder. ekot ejakait ecoe loka inusio: the chief wants a bag of money. ecoe loka ekulam: a urine bag; a urinary bladder. cp. agol.
ecoget (plural icogen) (noun M) a strut; forked stick; pillar; prop. cp. engas. 
ecoitono (plural ecoitoko) (adjective) prudent; careful; cautious; discreet; wise. acoitono eong atubitoi kokitwi: I am careful when making shortcuts through the bushes (wary of snakes). 
ecoka (plural icokai) (noun M) school chalk; lime. 
ecoke (plural icokei) (noun M) a tree, Ficus sp. 
ecokikinon (plural ecokikinak) (noun M) one who herds (cattle, etc) for somebody; a hireling. 
ecokit (plural icok) (noun M) a seed (in general); a kernel; a nut. 
ecokolet (singular noun M) chocolate. 
ecokolinga (plural icokolingan) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a red-necked lizard. cp. ebokolinga.
ecokoliro (plural icokoliron) (noun M) a cock’s comb. 
ecokolokipi (plural icokolokipin) (noun M) a mushroom growing in the swamp. 
ecokom (adjective) (especially of meat) nice, juicy and tasty. 
ecokopita (singular noun M) (Usuk) cooked ecaboi or esukumawiki vegetable dish. 
ecolibe (plural icolibei) (noun M) a coucal or bottle bird, Centropus senegalense. 
ecolooni (plural icoloonin) (noun M) a pit latrine. cp. aipany
ecom (plural icomin) (noun M) a common chimpanzee, Pan troglodytes. cp. edokolet, egeye
ecomai (plural icoma) (noun M) a tree, Balanites aegyptiaca. The foliage (ecomai) is vegetables in Usuk county during the dry season, edible oil is extracted from its seeds, the wood is termite resistant, crushed fruit and bark extract is used to purify water since it kills snails and waterfleas (cyclops) that carry bilharzia and guinea worms respectively. 
ecooga (plural icoogai) (noun M) a he-goat paid to a fiancée’s father before dowry. 
Ecoolit (plural Icoolin) (noun M) an Acholi tribesman; a man native to Gulu, Kitgum or Pader districts of northern Uganda. Icoolin: the Acholi people. cp. Enyakoit: a man from the north.
ecooro (noun M) a lung disease of fowls, Coccidiosis. 
ecoot (plural ecootos, ecoitos) (adjective) careful; clever; wary. 
ecooto (plural icooton) (noun M) an engine; the core, the heart of a machine or automobile. 
ecopile (noun M) a kind of grass. 
ecopot (plural icop) (noun M) a pupil of the eye; the eyeball. aitocoun icop: to look wise. 
ecor (plural icorin) (noun M) a lake; a well; a river. cp. ecilet, esamai. angolol: sea. 
ecorai (plural icora) (noun M) a variety of edible mushrooms. 
ecoro (plural icoron) (noun M) a water plant, Pistia. 
ecoroko (singular noun M) green grams. cp. elikidi 
ecototo (noun M) a vegetable plant growing wild, Hibiscus cannabinus. 
ecounet (plural icouneta) (noun M) a sense (of sight, hearing, etc). 
ecucukwa (plural icucuk) (noun M) aloe plant. 
ecucut (plural icuc) (noun M) a (house) fly. ecucut lomelomelo: a bluebottle (fly). ingai iirana inyamat? ecucut: (a riddle) who always likes tasting food? a housefly.
ecudet (plural icudeta) (noun M) harmful witchcraft; any eccentric or abnormal behaviour in people; a charm; cannibalism; night-dancing. 
ecue (plural icuwei) (noun M) a bag; bladder; urinary bladder. 
ecuet (plural icueta) (noun M) wine-press or a press in general; a squeezer (for lemons, etc); a wringer (for clothes). 
ecugasa (noun M) a plant, Solanum nudiflorum. 
ecugur (plural icuguras) (adjective) high shouldered; hunched back; stooping. 
ecukat (plural icukai) (noun M) a draft ox. iso icukai lukane: we are the draft-oxen of this place i.e. doing the heavy work. 
ecuke (noun M) the act of encouraging animosity between others; intrigue, mischief. kocoite etunganan ngol, iswamai ngesi nuka ecuke: beware of that man, he is an intriguer. 
ecukean (plural icukeak) (noun M) a person who encourages others to start a fight; an inciter; an instigator. 
ecukia (plural icukiai) (noun M) a flower, Leonotis.
eculetait (plural iculeta) (noun M) a spot of dirt; a stain on anything or on character. egoe lo ileleba iculeta: this cloth is full of stains. cp. eculokinet, aculeta
eculi (plural iculin) (noun M) (in fables and legends of Teso) a tricky animal; a wild cat. 
eculokina (adjective) stained, tainted, blemished, or marked; out of place; intruding or interfering.
eculokinet (plural iculokineta) (noun M) a spot of dirt; a stain on anything or on character. egoe lo ileleba iculokineta: this cloth is full of stripes. 
eculuculo (adjective) chequered; spotted. eris erai etyang loeculuculo emukule: a leopard is a spotted animal. 
ecumacuma (noun M) a plant that encourages lactation. 
ecupa (plural icupai) (noun M) a bottle. inyo ibore yenimam enyami, kodiding akituk, kopol akoik? ecupa: (riddle) what is it that does not eat, yet has a small mouth and a big stomach? a bottle.
ecur (plural icuria) (noun M) a hawk. 
ecura (plural icurai) (noun M) a toilet cleaner; a night soil man. 
ecuramol (singular noun M) (slang) dry gin; crude distilled alcohol named after a bitter anti-malarial trademark drug (curamol). cp. ewaragi, ejuge.
ecurukileng (plural icurukilenga) (noun M) a kind of edible root. 
ecus (plural icusia) (noun M) a vagina (human). cp. eosin, alipong, edodot.
ecuude (plural icuudei) (noun M) a tuft of hair left on the head of human beings (especially small children, or on women who have once born twins) at the time of shaving; a crest (of feathers) on heads of birds. 
ecuuma (plural icuuman) (noun M) an iron tool; a spanner; a factory; a ginnery. ecuuma loka epaaba: a cotton ginnery. ecuuma loesukaali: a sugar mill. ecuuma loigoen: a textile factory. 
ecuwe (plural icuwei) (noun M) a bird, lily-trotter. cp. ecoe 
ecwala (singular noun M) (of human beings) colostrum: first milk after child birth. cp. edos. 
ecwarenit (plural icwaren) (noun M) a bed-bug. 
ecwataarat (plural icwataaran) (noun M) a mongrel; a man with Somali features or origin; a half-cast or mulatto. 
ecwenene (singular noun M) (outside Usuk) an edible grasshopper. cp. esenene.
ecwi (plural icwi) (noun M) a metallic necklace. 
ecwilil (plural icwilian) (noun M) (outside Usuk) an oryx, Beisa oryx. cp. ecilil
edaak (plural idaak) (noun M) a person with a big and flat head (adjective) flat-headed (an insult) 
edabada (plural idabadai) (noun M) (long) trousers. cp. eroodi, epale
edairekita (plural idairekitan) (noun M) a director; a manager. cp. engarenikinon
edakana (plural edakaka) (adjective) (of a grass-eating animal) gluttonous. 
edakiika (plural idakiikan) (noun M) a minute. idakiikan akais akany kape ejaas osaawa ediope: sixty minutes are in an hour. 
edal (plural idalia) (noun M) a bird, yellow widow. 
edalac (plural idalaca) (noun M) a tree, Ficus glumosa. The ripe figs are edible, while the wood is for charcoal burning.
edaladalakisin (noun M) an inedible wild cucumber plant, Cucubitaceae. 
edamok (plural idamokos) (adjective) empty; having nothing inside. cp. enonok. 
edangala (plural idangalai) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of cassava. 
edanyot (plural idanyoi) (noun M) a sheanut; the seed of ekungur. cp. elemut. 
edapaic (plural idapaica) (noun M) a woman’s undergarment; a tampon; a rag. cp. eyokobiyat, esokoleket.
edapal (plural idapalas) (adjective) flat; level; even. edapal akekou: her/his head is flat. 
edasit (plural idas) (noun M) a whip; a scourge; a lash or whip made of plaited cowhide, used at asapan initiation ceremony. cp. edoi. 
edauna (adjective) complete; absolute; finished. abeit naedauna: an absolute truth. ejaas ajon osokooni? mam, edauna: is there beer in the market? no, it is finished. eringa edauna: not yet finished or it is not yet complete. cp. mam ber, eroko.
edaunit (plural edaunitos) (adjective) ample; sufficient. cp. edolit: enough.
edawoi (plural idawoi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a castrated bull; an ox. cp. edonge. 
ededeng (adjective) fierce; bellicose; strict; cruel; severe; furious; harsh; wild; malignant; unkind; hard; difficult; barbaric; savage. etyang loededeng: a fierce animal. 
edeet (singular noun M) trypanosomiasis in cattle; nagana; sleeping sickness in animals caused by tsetse flies. 
edege (plural idegei) (noun M) an aeroplane; an aircraft. kede edege: by air; by plane; in an aeroplane. cp. ekweny, epororet. 
edeidei1 (noun M) (formerly) a red variety of sorghum. 
edeidei2 (plural ideidein) (noun M) a pustule. ejai eong edeidei: ideideit eong akuwan: I have pustules. 
edeideit (noun M) a grass, Perotis indica. 
edek1 (noun M) a grass, Cynodon plectostachion. 
edek2 (noun M) a sauce made of crushed beans or peas cooked in amakadi. 
edeke1 (plural idekesio) (noun M) a deity of calamity; syphilis; gonorrhoea; a pestilence; rinderpest; a plague; a spirit or god of calamity. ejai edeke toma akituk: there is rinderpest amongst the cattle. aidede naka edeke: show signs of infestation with flukes. cp. esotoka.
Edeke2 (singular noun M) God (to an Anglican Protestant Christian). Edeke Lokapedor kere: God the Omnipotent. Edeke Lokalaunan: God the holy one. ejai Edeke toma akuj: God is in heaven.
edel (noun M) pride; obstinacy; fractitiousness. mam akoto edel kus: I do not like your obstinacy, pride. 
edengerot (noun M) a grass for covering roofs (thatching), Hyparrheni. 
edep (plural idepio) (noun M) a swarm; a big crowd of offspring (locusts, bees, children). shoal of fish. ijo bo naejai edep: you with your swarm of children (women-to-women insult). edep loka agaria: a shoal of fish. cp. alwek.
edeparit (plural edeparitos) (adjective) beyond; exceedingly; very; more than, better than, more, etc. ideparit ijo eong kapolou: you are older than me. 
edepidepit (plural idepidep) (noun M) a flea. 
edere (plural iderekai) (noun M) a big calabash used to protect children’s heads against the sun and rain. 
ederepa (plural iderepan) (noun M) a driver (of a car). 
ederit (plural iderin) (noun M) a bushbuck, Tragelaphus scriptus. cp. emalit.
edes (noun M) gonorrhoea. 
edetekewai (plural idetekewan) (noun M) a kind of bush with the adetekewa berries, Rhus glaucescens. 
edia (plural idiasio) (noun M) vegetables in general; relishes. 
ediasit (singular noun M) relishes; different types of vegetables. 
edideo (plural idideon) (noun M) a hoopoe, Nile- kakelaar. 
ediding (adjective) narrow; slender. ediding akonye: narrow-eyed. ediding ekek: the door is narrow. ediding ijo aomisio: you are narrow-minded. 
edidiot (plural ididiin) (noun M) a species of bird, Helmet shrike. 
edidit (noun M) a grass, Perotis indica eragrostis. 
edie die (adverb) face-to-face; vis-à-vis; closely; at close range; at short distance. korem etyang edie die: spear the animal at close range. 
edieranakinan (plural edieranakinak) (noun M) a donor; a distributor; a generous (liberal) person. 
ediguri (plural idigurin) (noun M) a university degree award. adumunit eong ekadiguri loka agwelanar ko Makerere Yunibasite, edipoloma da Makerere Yunibasite: I obtained my commerce degree in Makerere University, and the diploma also at Makerere. cp. edipoloma. 
ediiga (plural idiigai) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a ram; a male sheep. cp. emerekek
ediije (plural idiijen) (noun M) a male disc jockey
ediini (plural idiinin) (noun M) a religion; a doctrine; a cult. 
ediiro (plural idiiron) (noun M) a lobby, a passage, or a lounge of a house. 
ediisi (plural idiisin) (noun M) (formerly) a DC - district commissioner (a representative of the central government administration in a district). 
ediit (plural idiita) (noun M) a tsetse fly; a short-sighted person. 
edijerane (singular noun M) a kind of eruption, rash or herpes around the mouth after a fever. 
edikait (plural idika) (noun M) a milk curd. 
ediket (plural idike) (noun M) a leech. 
edikisyonari (plural idikisyonarin) (noun M) a dictionary; a glossary; a lexicon. 
edikonit (plural idikonin) (noun M) an Anglican Church deacon. 
edila (singular noun M) (Usuk) a common vegetable of wild pea leaves. cp. eboo.
edilidilit (plural idilidilin) (noun M) a growth on the earlobe or on the little finger; ear-rings; keloids on face. 
ediliwas (plural idiliwasia) (noun M) a kind of poisonous snake. cp. agurai. 
ediloi (singular noun M) the spinal cord. cp. ewutune.
edimasita (plural idimasitan) (noun M) a headmaster; a head teacher. cp. esisianakinan
edingana (plural edingaka) (adjective) hostile; inimical; aggressive. edingana ngesi: she/he is very hostile. 
edinget (plural idingeta) (noun M) hatred; enmity; misunderstanding; contention. 
edino (plural idinoi) (noun M) a penis; a male sexual organ. cp. atirit, elongot.
edinyot (noun M) a grass, Panicum maximum. 
edio- (plural idis-) prefix preceding a masculine noun, denoting a few; a little of; some. koinakinai idisinyamat: give me a little food. koinunai ediogoe: bring me some cloth.
ediobore (plural idioboro) (indefinite pronoun M) anything; a scrap (of something). 
ediocici (adverb) just a little. 
ediokasilon (plural idisikasilok) (adverb) very little. cp. ediocici. 
edioli (noun M) a vegetable eaten during the dry season, Maerua angolensis. 
ediolidioli (plural ediolidiolete) (adjective) slippery; smooth. ediolidioli etogo loka abikiran: the floor of the nuns’ house is smooth and slippery. 
ediope diope M (numeral adverb, used with singular masculine nouns) one by one; one after another; singly. aidome emaido ediope diope: to eat groundnuts one at a time. kolomanasi ediope diope: go in one by one. kopotu ediope diope: come one by one, singly. 
ediopet M (numeral adjective) one. ediopet emong: one bull. ekoroi ediopet: one billy goat. 
ediotai (adverb) a little; some; a bit. koinakinai edia ediotai: give me just a little sauce. 
ediotitai (adverb) a little; some. koinakinai esukaali ediotitai: give me some sugar. 
ediotunganan (plural idisitunga) (indefinite pronoun M) any man. cp. ecetunganan.
