edipal1 (adjective) stumpy; dwarfish. akiteng adipal: a dwarfish cow. mam akoto adipal ngin: I don’t want that dwarf (cow or woman). 
edipal2 (plural idipal) (noun M) a dwarf (or anything stunted in growth) 
edipoloma (plural idipoloman) (noun M) a college or university diploma certificate award. cp. ediguri. ikosimwalimun luipu ejaatar idipoloman luka aisisianakin luko Ngeta, Nagongera, Kyambogo arai bo Kamuli: most of our teachers have their teaching diploma certificates from Ngeta, Nagongera, Kyambogo or perhaps Kamuli national teachers colleges.
edipor (plural idiporio) (noun M) beeswax; saliva of mudfish, with which it protects itself by clouding clear water. 
edir (plural idirin) (noun M) a species of bird, Yellow-backed pytilia. cp. ididiit. 
edira (plural idirai) (noun M) communal labour in return for beer in future. cp. eboole.
edirikori (plural idirikorio) (noun M) a long-tailed bird - Coly 
edirikwap (noun M) (formerly) a deep rooting variety of sweet potatoes.
edirio (plural idirion) (noun M) a species of bird - Paradise whydah. 
edirisa (plural idirisan) (noun M) a window (in general). idirisa: a small window. 
ediro (plural idiroi) (noun M) a small antelope, dik-dik, Rhynchotragus kirkii. cp. esiro
edisiko (plural idisikon) (noun M) a discotheque; disco music or dance. cp. asomet
edistrikt (plural idistriktan) (noun M) a district (an administrative unit consisting of counties). erai Katakwi da edistrikt loka Uganda: Katakwi is also a district of Uganda. 
edit (plural edisiak) (predicative adjective) little; tiny; modest; small; trivial; unimportant; childish. idisiak yesi: you are small; you are childish. (adverb) not very; barely; hardly. (pronoun) not much. edit: loedit: (plural) luedisiak. akoto luedisiak arai nuedisiak: I want the small ones. apesur nuedisiak: the small girls. cp. ikidioko: few. aikidiokut: fewness. 
edita1 (noun M) (formerly) a variety of bananas. 
edita2 (plural iditai) (noun M) a big reed basket. cp. adita: a small reed basket. 
edita3 (plural iditai) (noun M) an editor of a newspaper or a book, etc. 
editiana (plural editiaka) (adjective) childish; silly; immature. 
edoan (noun M) weeds in general; a grass that prefers unfertile soil, Rhynchelytrum repens.
edobo (plural idoboi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a big fishing hook. cp. ekone and egolu.
edodet (plural idodeta) (noun M) the index finger; a signpost; an instrument for pointing out, like a speedometer needle on a car or motor cycle. ebokorit lododet: index finger. 
edodoi (plural idodo) (noun M) a sausage tree, Kigelia africana.Its fruit is believed to increase sweet-potato yield if buried in the garden, and the leaves are applied as a liniment for mumps. Dye can be got from its cut and boiled sausage fruit. 
edodor (adjective) quick; easy; hasty; quick to learn; liable to; quick tempered; easily heated; early-ripening. edodor amot na: this cooking pot heats up quickly. 
edodot (plural idod) (noun M) the vagina. cp. eosin, alipong, ecus. 
edoel (adjective) slender; emaciated. 
edoi (plural idoyan) (noun M) a whip made of rope or grass and used to drive locusts away, or for youths lashing each other. eleas itunga k’idoyan: people lash each other with whips. 
edoket1 (plural idoke) (noun M) an immaturely harvested groundnut seed when dry; wrinkled and sterile groundnuts removed from choice seeds in shelling (usually eaten raw).
edoket2 (plural idoketa) (noun M) a bridge; a harbour; a landing site; a ford. 
edokita (plural idokitan) (noun M) a male doctor (who administers western medicine). cp. emuron loka adekis 
edokol (plural idokol) (noun M) the vulva; a female urethra. 
edokole (plural idokolei) (noun M) epiglottis (a flap that prevents food from entering the windpipe). cp. ekilimiiti.
edokolet (plural idokolen) (noun M) a vervet monkey, Cercopithecus aethiops. 
edokomuny (plural idokomunyio) (noun M) a serval cat, Leptailurus serval. 
edokor (plural idokor) (noun M) a thin person. 
edola1 (plural idolai) (noun M) a chronic topical (skin) ulcer on the leg or other part of the body; incurable wound. cp. ajimi; ejimi.
edola2 (plural idolas) (noun M) a dollar (currency of the USA). 
edolit (plural edolitos) (adjective) enough; adequate; sufficient. cp. ekadit
edolot (plural idoloi) (noun M) lath; cross-pieces on roof; a batten. 
edome (plural idomei) (noun M) a gum tree of which the fruit juice is used as gum, Cordia sinensis; the fruit of this tree. The leaves are used as sandpaper, the fruit is edible and also produces glue. The wood is good for making bows.
Edominika (noun M) (formerly) Sunday. 
edomo1 (plural idomoi) (noun M) a hook or harpoon for hippo hunting. cp. edoobo.
edomo2 (singular noun M) tertiary yaws. cp. etuma, ekurara.
edonga (singular noun M) a kind of dance (originating from Karamoja but popular in Adacar, Ngariam and Magoro sub-counties in Katakwi district) involving leaping high up and down, in which no musical instrument is used apart from hand-clapping by the chorus; a leap; a jump. cp. ekirakira.
edongana (plural edongaka) (adjective) persevering; persistent; insisting; determined; in the habit of pinching. edongana ekesa ngol: that guy is very persistent/determined/fond of pinching. 
edonge (plural idongei) (noun M) a castrated animal; an ox; a bullock; a eunuch; impotent man. cp. ekolip, ebwacit, arakan: barren (not used of animals). 
edongodongot (plural idongodongon) (noun M) (Usuk) a cow bell. 
edongol akonye (adjective) hollow-eyed. 
edongororot (plural idongororon) (noun M) the elbow. cp. esidongororot
edongot1 (plural idongon) (noun M) a bell. cp. ekide
edongot2 (plural idongon) (noun M) one of twins; the second born twin. 
edonyis (plural idonyisyo) (noun M) a sewing needle. cp. epiiso: a doctor’s needle. 
edonyony (adjective) sewn; stitched; patched; embroidered. 
edoodoo1 (plural idoodoon) (noun M) a big variety of mango fruit or plant. cp. emuebe
edoodoo2 (singular noun M) a vegetable akin to amaranthus but with purple leaves, Amaranthus caudatus. cp. aboga
edookiyo (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes with floury tubers.
edoomelu (plural idoomelun) (noun M) (Usuk) an edible mole or cane rat with a white-tipped tail. cp. omelekes, ebebele.
edoos (plural idoosas) (adjective) (of a person or animal) slightly built; weak. etelepat loedoos: a poorly-built boy; a weakling. 
edoot (plural idoono) (noun M) a grey salty anthill. ikocete akituk edoot: cows lick and eat the grey anthill clay (as a kind of salt). 
edo-piric (plural ido-piricin) (noun M) a little bird that lands with a lot of hullabaloo. Robin chat.
edopudopu (plural idopudopun) (noun M) a boring beetle; the powder ejected by the boring beetle. 
edoret (plural idoreta) (noun M) an enemy. cp. lokasurup. 
edoronyit (plural idorony) (noun M) a dog's vomit; cat's vomit; anything repulsive through the mouth. (fingurative) dirty talk. koyangaa ekonidoronyit ngina: go away with your nonsense! take your obscenity elsewhere. adum eong kesi ineras nukidorony: I got them talking their obscenity, dirty talk, shameful talk. cp. asiilyanut.
edos (plural idosion) (noun M) egg yolk; (of animals) first milk after birth – colostrum. cp. ecwala. 
edosoono (plural edosooko) (adjective) yellow. 
edote (plural idotea) (noun M) an adulterer; a fornicator. cp. lokadotean.
edoteana (plural edoteaka) (adjective) loose loving; immoral; adulterous; lecherous. aberu naedote: a loose-living woman. 
edou (plural idowon) (noun M) a cloud; rain; thunder. etepi edou loepol: there is a lot of rain. aberu naka Okiru erai edou: Okiru’s wife is of a bitter scolding disposition (she is a thunderbolt). anangar idowon (euphemism): (of a person) to die (literally, to penetrate the clouds). edou lodaset or akiru nadaset: early rains for breaking new ground or clearing the fields.
edu (noun M) (outside Usuk) a sheanut tree, Butyrospermum paradoxum. cp. ekungur
eduan (singular noun M) (Usuk) weeds 
edude1 (plural idudei) (noun M) a small wicker basket. 
edude2 (plural idudei) (noun M) (Kaberamaido) the buttock; the butt; the bums; the arse. 
edudu (plural idudui) (noun M) a species of bird, Bell cuckoo-shrike or Plantain eater.
edudumak (plural idudumakin) (noun M) (formerly) DDT insecticide spray for termites. 
edudumeri (plural idudumerio) (noun M) a very small dove or pigeon with black head. 
edudut1 (plural idudu) (noun M) a bush, Cassia mimu soides. 
edudut2 (plural idudui) (noun M) the Bakenye (a fisher tribe on the shores of lakes Kyoga and Bisina) (an insult); the bird which goes and ducks into the water for fish. cp. emekenyit. 
eduele (plural iduelei) (noun M) a dwarf mouse, Leggada bella. 
eduidui (plural iduiduin) (noun M) a species of small bird, Cordon bleu. cp. idiidiit. 
eduke (noun M) style of building, constructing. ejokuna eduke kec Iusuko: the building or thatching style of people from Usuk is good (thatching ascends in rows up to the peak). 
edukokina (adjective) married. eraas kesi luedukokina: they are married people. etogo loedukokina ne: a house built here. 
edukono (plural edukoko) (adjective) fast or clever at building or architectural work. erai ngesi loedukono: he is a fast builder. 
edukudukut (plural idukudukun) (noun M) African fan palm, Borassus aethiopium. Its hollowed boles are used for beehives, the seed and fruit are edible, the fibre is used for making ekodo (beer sieves), and the leaves are a thatch.
edukuru (plural idukurun) (noun M) a small hut as for calves or sick people; a camp; a booth; a cottage. cp. emanyata
edukut (plural idukun) (noun M) a corruption of edukudukut: African fan palm, Borassus aethiopium. 
edula (plural idula) (noun M) a big non-movable grass, mud and cow-dung granary, built up and shaped like a huge water pot on a base of timber, which rests on posts or stones as protection against termites; a food store. cp. etuja: a small version of edula; ekerei: a granary made from twigs. 
edulagol (plural idulagoloi) (noun M) a guinea fowl-like eagle. 
edulo (plural iduloi) (noun M) a tree, Ficus sur. Its leaves are used as goodluck amulets, the wood is for carving mortars and troughs, and the shade is used in ceremonies.
edulukait (plural iduluka) (noun M) a tree, Acacia mildbraedii. 
edunyana (plural edunyaka) (adjective) indefatigable; exacting; zealous; industrious; persevering. edunyaka apesur ngun: those girls are very zealous. 
edupuk (adjective) soft (as of cloth); loose (as of sand, dust, flour); fine (as of flour). edupuk apuna: the apuna grass is soft (to the touch). asinge nadupuk: loose sand. 
eduro (noun M) (formerly) a variety of millet. 
edurukoi (plural idurukoi) (noun M) Apple-ring acacia tree, Acacia albida. The tree is a good ceremonial shade and nitrogen fixer, the leaves and pods are good fodder, and the wood is for firewood.
edusuku (plural idusukun) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of short sorghum. cp. ekarepet; enyang. 
edusutau (singular noun M) a love potion to stimulate love; an aphrodisiac. cp. eramatau
edutana (plural edutaka) (adjective) liberal; generous. etunganan loerai ekadutan iboro: a generous man (generous with things). 
edutat (plural idutan) (noun M) a gift; contribution; endowment; a present, reward. 
eduwan (singular noun M) (outside Usuk) weeds. cp. eduan. 
edwalaana (plural edwalaaka) (adjective) lazy; lax (in cleaning teeth or in anything) (an insult of a big-bodied weakling). cp. ekalanyana. 
edwaliro (plural idwaliroi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a hospital; a clinic. odwaliro: at or to the hospital.
edwar1 (noun M) a kind of grass. 
edwar2 (plural edwarak) (adjective) bitter; biting; sour; pungent; acrid; sarcastic; sharp and harsh cutting. edwar ekia ria ria: the drug is very bitter. edwar akitukuke: she/he is sarcastic in her/his speech (i.e. she/he makes biting remarks). edwar Eloket etau, kipedori aicum: the Karimojong rustler is quick tempered, he may spear you any time. edwar: to be in the act of, to be occupied. edwar nges ainyam: she/he is eating. 
edwarai (noun M) a bush from which salt is extracted, Vernonia grantii. 
edwaramany (plural idwaramanya) (noun M) a kind of fish (with bitter liver?). 
edwasi (noun M) a disease, Haematuria bilharzia. 
edweet (plural noun M) (in a bad sense) a crowd of children. cp. alwek.
edweli (plural idwelin) (noun M) a kind of tree (with edible fruit). 
edwesisit (plural noun M) (in a bad sense) a crowd of children. cp. alwek.
edwokai (singular noun F) vanity; self-importance; affectedness; snobbishness; pretentiousness.
edyamakou (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum. cp. ediima 
edyatakina (plural idyatakina) (adjective) treasured; gathered; compiled. 
edyera (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet (eleusin) or sorghum with long scattered ears. 
ee (interjection) yes. cp. eebo
eeba (interjection) ay aye; yes indeed.
eebo (interjection) yes; aye; yes indeed. 
eeburan (plural eeburak) (noun M) (Usuk) a claimant (of debt, etc); a debt collector. cp. aibura. 
eebusianan (plural eebusianak) (noun M) (Usuk) a drudge; one who works hard for little pay. 
eebwalaan (plural eebwalaak) (noun M) (Usuk) an enticer; one who keeps another from working; a negligent and slow-working person. 
eebwanan (plural eebwanak) (noun M) a laureate. 
eebwanyan (plural eebwanyak) (noun M) (Usuk) a gatecrasher; an intruder into parties; an uninvited guest; a parasite.
eebwokan (plural eebwokak) (noun M) (Usuk) a porter who carries things for others; a carrier. 
eeca (interjection) yes indeed. eeca bo: yes, of course.
eeciran (plural eecirak) (noun M) (Usuk) a milker; a milkman. cp. ekeciran.
eecodon (plural eecodok) (noun M) (Usuk) a person who limps; a cripple. cp. ekecodon
eecokon (plural eecokok) (noun M) (Usuk) a herdsman; a shepherd; a church pastor or cleric. eecokon akituk: a herdsman; eecokon amerekekin: a sheperd. cp. ekecokon. 
eecololon (plural eecololok) (noun M) (Usuk) a hypocrite; a fraud; a charlatan. ekecololon ijo: you are a hypocrite. 
eecoran (plural eecorak) (noun M) (Usuk) a counsel; an adviser; a counsellor; a guru. 
eecukon (plural eecukok) (noun M) (Usuk) a welder; a hot iron brander; an inciter (to a quarrel or a fight). 
eedaan (plural eedaak) (noun M) (Usuk) a man who buries; grave digger; a mourner; an undertaker.
eedaran (plural eedarak) (noun M) (Usuk) a watchman; a guardian; a keeper; a protector; a waiter; a curator; a foster-parent. cp. ekedaran, awenan.
eede (adverb) pretending; under pretext; seemingly; with deceit or sham (adverb) under pretence of. abu ngesi neajai eong ican eede: she/he came to me pretending to cry of poverty. sirikilip eede: do not act as if you were praying; do not pretend to pray. cp. ejose
eedyatan (plural eedyatak) (noun M) (Usuk) a treasurer; a collector; a compiler. cp. ekengadan. 
eegangan (plural eegangak) (noun M) (Usuk) an ally, a pleader, a lawyer, an advocate. 
eeja (plural nukeeja) (noun M) (Usuk) aunt. eejaka: my aunt. cp. ijaa, mamai: uncle.
eejaanakinan (plural eejaanakinak) (noun M) (Usuk) a constant or regular attendant or protégée. 
eejerukon (plural eejerukok) (noun M) (Usuk) an unmanageable, disobedient, unruly, defiant, disloyal, or seditious man. 
eejo (interjection) look! hear! eejo nges: look at him; hear him!. eejo eejo: hear, hear! 
eejodon (plural eejodok) (noun M) (Usuk) a sycophant; toady; flatterer. cp. aanyamakinan
eejuliran (plural eejulirak) (noun M) (Usuk) a prosecution witness. cp. ajenan.
eekaan (plural eekaak) (noun M) (Usuk) a hunter, a seeker; a persecutor, a tormentor, a bully, a tyrant, an oppressor, or an intimidator. cp. lokekaan
eekamaran (plural eekamarak) (noun M) (Usuk) a captor or an abductor; a kidnapper; a hijacker; a hostage taker. 
eekeon (plural eekeok) (noun M) (Usuk) a carpenter; a carver; an engraver; an etcher. 
eekoban (plural eekobak) (noun M) (Usuk) a transcriber; one who copies; one who transmits or passes on. 
eelaman (plural eelamak) (noun M) (Usuk) a curser; a high-jumper (in athletics). 
eelipan (plural eelipak) (noun M) (Usuk) a beggar; one who prays, begs, or asks. 
eelipat (plural eelipak) (noun M) (Usuk) a habitual beggar; a tramp.
eelu (plural ielun) (noun M) a tree bearing edible round black fruit called aelut or akarukwait, Markhamia platycalix. 
eema1 (interjection) truly; yes indeed; so it is. eema, ilim ijo ejok: yes, you are right. cp. eecabo, eebo, eeba. 
eema2 (plural iemai) (noun M) a tent; a tarpaulin; canvas. cp. ewema, eyema.
eemanimanan (plural eemanimanak) (noun M) (Usuk) inspector, examiner, checker, superintendent, overseer, assessor, supervisor. 
eemorikikinan (plural eemorikikinak) (noun M) (Usuk) a mediator; a reconciler. cp. ekadiekan. 
eemukean (plural eemukeak) (noun M) (Usuk) medical staff; a nurse (male or female). 
eemunonan (plural eemunonak) (noun M) (Usuk) one who conceals; an obscurantist; a doctrinaire; an obfuscator. 
eemut (plural iemuto) (noun M) (Usuk) news; rumours; a report. kolimokinai iyemuto luka akwapukus: tell me the news of your country. cp. eyemut; nuk’abe.
eenat (plural ienan) (noun M) (Usuk) a prisoner; the one to be tied. 
eenen (adjective) tied up; bound up; fastened; packed. 
eeneran (plural eenerak) (noun M) (Usuk) a speaker (the person, not the machine); an orator; a lecturer; a presenter; a narrator; a spokesman. 
eenet (plural ieneta) (noun M) a prison; a lock; a thing for tying. 
eengadan (plural eengadak) (noun M) (Usuk) a treasurer; a keeper (of things in a store).
eengalan (plural eengalak) (noun M) (Usuk) a liar; a pretender; a con artist; a fraudster.
eengarakinan (plural eengarakinak) (noun M) (Usuk) a helper; an assistant; an accomplice (to a crime).
eengarenikinon (plural eengarenikinok) (noun M) (Usuk) a leader; a guide; a director; a manager.
eengarenon (plural eengarenok) (noun M) (Usuk) a leader; a director; an organizer; a manager.
eengitan (plural eengitak) (noun M) (Usuk) a questioner; an inquirer; an examiner like Uganda National Examinations Board.
eengomingomon (plural eengomingomok) (noun M) (Usuk) a gobbler; a greedy person.
eenyagan (plural eenyagak) (noun M) (Usuk) a robber; a bandit; an organized thief or thug. cp. eerurwon.
eenyamiton (plural eenyamitok) (noun M) (Usuk) an escort; an aide; a guide; a body guard. cp. ekenyamiton.
eenyoolan (plural eenyoolak) (noun M) (Usuk) a driver of a motorcar. 
eepitan (plural eepitak) (noun M) a livestock breeder; one who rears (animals or people) to maturity. eepitak ibaren: livestock breeders.
eepoon (plural eepook) (noun M) (Usuk) a cook; a chef. cp. lokepoon, ekepoon.
eepugan (plural eepugak) (noun M) (Usuk) a ruler; a governor; a head of state; a monarch; a sovereign. 
eeputan amuk (plural eeputak amuk) (noun M) a shoe-shiner. 
eeraban (plural eerabak) (noun M) (Usuk) a speaker (in an assembly); a judge, a lawyer; a talkative man; a pleader, or a barrister. 
eereere (plural iereeren) (noun M) a tree, Trema orientalis. Uses: the fruit is edible; leaves, pods, seeds are used as fodder; black dye is made from bark, brown dye from leaves; oil is extracted from seeds; the leaves are used as an antidote for poison; leaves are also medicine for deworming and cough; and the tree's shedding of leaves is an indicator of the planting time for finger millet. 
eerimon (plural eerimok) (noun M) (Usuk) a tramp; a vagabond; a rover; a vagrant; a hobo; a hawker.
eerionokinan (plural eerionokinak) (noun M) (Usuk) a pessimist; a naysayer; a cynic; a person who throws cold water on everything good; a wet blanket. 
eerumunan (plural eerumunak) (noun M) (Usuk) a heir; an inheritor; a successor; progeny; a catcher-up (in a race).
eerurwon (plural eerurwok) (noun M) (Usuk) a raider; a robber; a plunderer; an organized cattle rustler. cp. eenyagan.
eerut (noun M) a edible wild plant root, Courbonia virgata. 
eeryonon (plural eeryonok) (noun M) (Usuk) an African; a Black person. cp. ekeryonon.
-eese (adjectival suffix) bluish-grey. 
eeseana (plural eeseaka) (adjective) of bluish-grey appearance or colour. 
eesiaan (plural eesiaak) (noun M) (Usuk) a beginner; a novice; a starter; a learner; an innovator. 
eesicatan (plural eesicatak) (noun M) (Usuk) a supporter; a backer; a sponsor. 
eesidikon (plural eesidikok) (noun M) (Usuk) an inciter; an agitator; an instigator; a mastermind; an organizer. 
eesidounon (plural eesidounok) (noun M) (Usuk) a mid-man; a midwife. cp. naesidounon.
eesisian (plural eesisiak) (noun M) (Usuk) a student; a learner; a pupil. 
eesisianakinan (plural eesisianakinak) (noun M) (Usuk) a teacher; a schoolmaster; a professor. 
eesisiaunan (plural eesisiaunak) (noun M) (Usuk) a man or boy who has just acquired knowledge; a learner; a pupil; a novice. 
eesomesan (plural eesomesak) (noun M) (archaic) a man who teaches reading and writing; a teacher for lower primary school. 
eesupan (plural eesupak) (noun M) (Usuk) a wooer; a campaigner; an amorous man; an intriguer. 
eeswaman (plural eeswamak) (noun M) (Usuk) a workman; worker; an agent; an employee. 
eetajaran (plural eetajarak) (noun M) (Usuk) a saviour; a rescuer; a reviver. cp. etajaran. 
eetanan (plural eetanak) (noun M) (Usuk) a feeder; a nurse.
eetelemunan (plural eetelemunak) (noun M) one who causes something to be removed. eetelemunan esolo: a tax-collector; a tax assessor. eeteleman epaaba: a supervisor or headman of cotton sorters or pickers. eetelemunan eluk: one who causes payment of a fine by another committing adultery.
eeteon (plural eeteok) (noun M) (Usuk) a guardian; one who looks after; a spectator; an onlooker. 
eetimon (plural eetimok) (noun M) (Usuk) a merciful or forgiving person. 
eetisian (plural eetisiak) (noun M) (Usuk) one who aids another to escape.
eetisilan (plural eetisilak) (noun M) (Usuk) a confessor (in penance). 
eetobwoan (plural eetobwoak) (noun M) (Usuk) one who makes somebody to stand up, i.e. an accuser. 
eetumunon (plural eetumunok) (noun M) (Usuk) one who promises or pledges. 
eewadikan (plural eewadikak) (noun M) (Usuk) a writer; a journalist; an author; a secretary. 
eeworon (plural eeworok) (noun M) (Usuk) a talkative person; a loud caller; a taxi or bus broker or tout. cp. ekaruwon. 
eeyuunan (plural eeyuunak) (noun M) (Usuk) a believer; one who agrees; one of the faithful. 
egaala (noun M) vegetables cooked without groundnut paste. ainyam egaala: to be poor (unable to afford groundnuts).
egaali (plural igaalin) (noun M) a bicycle. alosi eong ka egaali: I go on bicycle.
egaaso (plural igaason) (noun M) a big refugee camp; a settlement for the poor or the internally displaced people.
egaat (noun M) (formerly) a variety of arid-cultivated sorghum used for making beer; a grass, Sorghum verticilliflorum. 
egada (noun M) a species of elephant grass used as reeds for building, Gennisetum purpureum. 
egagarikina (adjective) disruptive; obstrusive; awkward; obstructive; unhelpful; obstreperous. egagarikina ngesi ne: she/he/it is too big for this place. igagarikina ijo toma aswam ngin: you are too big for that (small) task. 
egala (noun M) a shrub, Lannea stuhlmannii. 
egalala (noun M) vegetables cooked in water only i.e. without appetisers or flavourings. 
egalunak (plural noun M) a mob; a rabble; crowd of rioters. 
egamira (plural igamirai) (noun M) a camel. cp. akaala. 
egaraama (plural igaraaman) (noun M) an expense; a cost; a charge; a hazard or a difficulty. cp. atwaniaret; ationus. igaraaman luiyatakina: additional costs.
egarai (plural igara) (noun M) a small tree, Lannea schweinfurthii subsp. stuhlmannii. Its fruit is edible, the roots, bark and leaves have medicinal properties. The wood is used for firewood, timber and charcoal burning.
egaraji (plural igarajin) (noun M) a garage, i.e. where cars are kept, or a place where cars are bought, sold, or repaired. 
egasia (plural igasian) (noun M) a tree, Senna spectabilis. A tree used for bee forage, firewood and shade.
egasit (noun M) cursing someone on an anthill; wishing someone ill-luck or misfortune. aicum epuu: to curse someone by sticking a sewing needle in epuu stem.
egecit (plural igec) (noun M) a small spur of birds; a small bone behind hoof of cattle. cp. emagegeret; ekwecit
egeget1 (adjective) having a taste of half-ripe bananas; astringent. araito nuegeget: half-ripe or astringent fruits. 
egeget2 (plural igegeta) (noun M) cashewnut tree. cp. emaidokoit. 
egego (plural igegoi) (noun M) the shoulder or wing of a bird killed for food. cp. eitutu.
egeit (plural egeito) (adjective) antecedent; previous; preceding; earlier; prior; before. 
egela (plural igelai) (noun M) a stranger; a different person; an alien. abu eong kadum etunganan egela: I met a stranger. (adverb) differently; variously. ibunit ijo egela: you have come differently or for quite a different reason (adjective) different. cp. logela.
egelara (adjective) different, diverse, altered, changed, unlike, dissimilar, unrelated; extraneous; strange, odd, bizarre, weird, extraordinary, eccentric, unfamiliar; alien, Martian, inappropriate, off the point, unconnected. 
egelegela (adjective) varied; unlike; dissimilar; of many different kinds; different, not the same. egelegela iponesio luka itunga: people’s characters, customs, or manners are different. 
egelit (noun M) a debt; a fine; obligation, liability; compensation, recompense, reward, damages, costs, reparation, or reimbursement. 
egerec (plural igereca) (noun M) a species of frog. cp. aidodok; akori; akido; aburututu. 
Egereesat (plural Igereesan) (noun M) an English man; an Anglican Christian (man). 
egereger (plural igeregeren) (noun M) a monitor lizard, Varanus nilotica. 
egereset (plural igereseta) (noun M) an embrocation; a massage. 
egeu (plural igewon) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a blue monkey, Cercopithecus mitis. cp. egeye.
egeye1 (plural igeyei) (noun M) (Usuk) a black and white colobus monkey, Colobus polykomos. cp. edokolet, ecom
egeye2 (plural igeyei) (noun M) (Usuk) a he-goat with a tuft of hair on the forehead. 
egigit (noun M) a kind of euphorbia plant. cp. epopong. 
egiilo (plural igiilon) (noun M) a borehole pump (named after a pioneer driller in Teso in the 1940s, S. Gill). 
egilaasi (plural igilaasin) (noun M) a beaker; a tumbler; a wineglass; a cup; a chalice. cp. agilaasi
egili (plural igilii) (noun M) a parrot (bird). 
egiligilet (plural igiligileta) (noun M) a tobacco case made of a cow horn.
egilut (plural igilun) (noun M) a ring (on nose or ear of animal).
egingilyici (noun M) a grass, Branchiaria brizantha. 
egirigiran (plural egirigirak) (noun M) a clerk; a scribe. 
egirigirio (plural igirigirion) (noun M) a species of bird, Great spotted cuckoo. 
egirigiroi (plural igirigirio) (noun M) a tree, Acacia campylacantha. 
egirikoca (plural igirikocia) (noun M) bone cancer; stomach or cervical cancer (often causing haemorrhage in women). 
egiro (noun M) a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis. 
egirone (singular noun M) divorce; separation; split of marriage. cp. elakit
egisa (plural igisai) (noun M) oral poison. cp. eidada
egita1 (plural igitai) (noun M) a solitary animal or man; one living alone; a hermit; a pet child; a favourite woman or man; a pet animal; a loner. 
egita2 (plural igitai) (noun M) a water shrimp. 
egitara (adjective) different; unlike.
egitigita (adjective) different; unknown; separate; dissimilar. egita ibore ngin: that thing is unknown. 
egitu (plural igitun) (noun M) a plant, Echinops amplexicaulis. 
egoe (plural igoen) (noun M) a cloth; clothing; a dress; a garment; a costume. cp. inapat, inapen. 
egogong (adjective) strong; energetic; hardy; severe; strict; hard; firm; difficult; burly. egogong akirokus: your case is difficult. egogong akonye: barefaced; brazen; shameless; blatant; bold; unashamed. egogong akituk (plural egogong akitukes) (adjective) argumentative; quarrelsome; confrontational; belligerent; aggressive; challenging; irascible; hard to give in; contrary. egogong akou (plural egogong akwes) (adjective) stubborn; obstinate; inflexible; wilful; mulish; hard-headed; obdurate; intractable.
egogot (plural igog) (noun M) intestinal worm. cp. eciidait. 
egole (plural igolei) (noun M) an African white-spotted harrier hawk, Polyboroides radiatus. cp. epeket.
egoleono (plural egoleoko) (adjective) grey-spotted. 
egoliam (plural igoliam) (noun M) a tall thin person. 
egolis (plural igolisio) (noun M) a door; anything for shutting or locking the door or window; a shutter; a screen or blind. 
egologolot (plural igologolon) (noun M) a goat bell made from a hollowed coconut kernel. cp. edongodongot: a cow bell. 
egolokino (adjective) barred; impenetrable; shut; locked; blocked up; choked up; clogged up; jammed. 
egolol (adjective) shut; locked; closed; blocked. egolol erot: the way is blocked (no thoroughfare). 
egoloro (adjective) excluded or exclusive; barred; disqualified; debarred; expelled; restricted; limited; select. 
egolu (plural igolun) (noun M) (Usuk) a gaff or a big metal fishhook attached to a string. cp. elikot: small fishhook. cp. ekuret.
egoluno (adjective) included or inclusive; built-in; incorporated; integrated; all-encompassing. 
egomas (plural igomasin) (noun M) a cassock-like polyester or silk dress for women; a tunic. cp. eiteitei. 
egongakina (adjective) contiguous; close; nearby; adjacent; adjoining; proximate; neighbouring; leaning on. 
egongor (plural igongorin) (noun M) a large green mantis with thin legs. cp. aguuru. 
egoolo (plural igoolon) (noun M) a goal (post or score in a football game). 
egooro (plural igooro) (noun M) uvula; epiglottis. 
egoreara (adjective) hidden, concealed, out of sight, veiled, secluded; remote, isolated, tucked away. 
egoria (noun M) root of water lily. 
egorigor (singular noun M) whooping cough; bronchitis. cp. elweera
egoro (plural igoroi) (noun M) a heron; a species of bird with a long neck and legs, African jacana.
egorogoro (plural igorogoron) (noun M) a feeble person; an invalid; a weak person. 
egoromoit (noun M) (formerly) a variety of groundnuts that creep and bears more than three big grey seeds in a pod, harvested by digging up with a hoe.
egoroopa (plural igoroopan) (noun M) a double or multi-storeyed house. 
egudugudwi (noun M) a plant, Acalypha. 
egulugulut (plural igulugulun) (noun M) expanded sides of stomach (as of goat after feeding).
egunia (plural igunian) (noun M) a gunny bag; a sack. cp. epuko. 
egura (plural igurai) (noun M) the spine; the backbone; the upper part of a book; a midrib of leaves; veins of leaf; a keel of a boat. ogura: on the back; on the spine. kenomata kesi eong ogura toma: they have hit me exactly on the spine. 
egureedi (plural igureedin) (noun M) a grade; a quality; a category. 
egurum (plural igurumo) (noun M) a garden or field mouse, Arvicanthis. cp. eleli: a striped field mouse. cp. emir, esolima
eguruneet (plural iguruneetin) (noun M) a grenade (a hand grenade or rocket-propelled grenade).
eguruupu (plural iguruupun) (noun M) a group; a gang; a clique; a set. eguruupu lok’isekan: a select group. 
eguti (plural igutin) (noun M) a kind of edible mushroom. 
egutit (plural igutin) (noun M) a small grasshopper. 
eguudo (plural iguudoi) (noun M) a highway; a main road; a street. 
egwaigwai (noun M) eczema; mange. 
egwali (noun M) a grass, Chloris virgate. cp. eogor. 
egwang (plural igwangia) (noun M) a wild cat that catches chicken, Felis silvestris. cp. ikapa
egwanga (plural igwangai) (noun M) a plant, Abutilon fanzibaricum malvaceae. 
egwangira (singular noun M) a bitter vegetable, the wild cousin to emalakany, whose leaf is rubbed on the cheeks of a person due for tooth extraction, Hibiscus cannabinus. 
egwapet1 (noun M) a tree, Steganotaenia araliacea. Its root has medicinal properties.
egwapet2 (plural igwapeto) (noun M) an eland, Taurotragus oryx. 
egwari (plural igwarin) (noun M) a kind of thorn-bush. 
egwaunana (adjective) aggressive; violent; provocative; antagonistic; hostile; bellicose. 
egwegwet1 (plural igweg) (noun M) a flea; chicken louse. cp. eidepidepit. 
egwegwet2 (plural igwegwen) (noun M) a very poisonous and dangerous tree snake, Green mamba. cp. emun loesomitoi kwape ka egwegwet: a snake that jumps like a flea. 
egwei (singular noun M) indigestion; dyspepsia; flatulence. eijer egwei: to belch on account of indigestion.
egwele (plural igweleik) (noun M) a species of eagle, Bateleur eagle. 
egweleke (noun M) a grass, Commersoni. 
egwelet1  (noun M) a bush, Hoslundia opposita. 
egwelet2 (plural igweleta) (noun M) a price; a value; a sale. egwelet loka epaaba ekaru lo ejok: the price of cotton is very high this year. 
egwelit (plural igwelito) (noun M) a bribe; bribery (by buying favours). 
Egweritonit (plural Igweritok) (noun M) a man from Gweri sub-county in Soroti county. Igweritok: people from Gweri sub-county in Soroti.
egworon (plural egworok) (noun M) a mourner; the bereaved. 
eibel1 (noun M) greed; lust; craving; gluttony; extreme hunger. 
eibel2 (plural noun M) pimples or a rash around the head after hair-cut, or due to measles, chicken pox, etc healing up after a week. 
eibelit (plural iibel) (noun M) scale of fish, crocodile, or snake. 
eibibia (singular noun M) a sickness which makes the body brown, makes it swell and feel unwell. 
eibidaet (plural iibidaeta) (noun M) fishing hook. cp. egolu; eiliketait; elikot. 
eibidas (plural iibidas) (noun M) a fishing hook. cp. egolu; eiliketait; elikot. 
eibobo (plural iiboboi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a house lizard. cp. egereger: a monitor lizard. cp. eidodo.
eibuga (plural iibugan) (noun M) a city; a town (of Kampala’s size). cp. etaun
eibuket (plural iibuketa) (noun M) a churn. cp. ekeret, emalas.
eibulesene (singular noun M) slavery; serfdom. 
eibutone (singular noun M) a gift from an uncle towards marriage dowry of the nephew. 
eibwanyane (noun M) intruding into drinking parties; gate-crashing. 
eibwong (singular noun M) applause; acclamation; incantation. 
eibworone (singular noun M) (outside Usuk) (formerly) an initiation ceremony for youths and adult men to senior age groups (especially to married life). cp. asapan. 
eic (plural iica) (noun M) a string snare for catching rats; a trap. musi eici da kitilim akiro, konye akuluma dupuk-dupuk: perhaps the string trap may make you shout, but the stone trap kills you right away. 
eicegera (plural iicegeria) (noun M) a fork of a tree; a traditional three-legged stool; a lamp stand. cp. eceger 
eicipa (noun M) ordinary knot. cp. ajarus: slip-knot. 
eico (plural iicoi) (noun M) a large pot, tall, with a fairly small neck, used mainly for storing liquids. 
eicod (singular noun M) limping; hobbling; hopping. 
eicodet (plural iicodeta) (noun M) a crutch. 
eicolong (plural iicolongo) (noun M) a chair; a traditional bobbin stool; any seat. 
eicolong-ebu (plural iicolongo-ibuin) (noun M) a praying mantis. 
eicorakina (plural iicorakina) (noun M) commandment; a rule; a mandate; a ban; a behest. 
eicum (singular noun M) a duel or fight with spears. 
eicur (singular noun M) leaping or jumping; playing or dancing; jubilation. 
eicweane (singular noun M) a heart-burn. 
eidada (plural iidadai) (noun M) poison given in food (makes the stomach swell); bane; a disease following poisoning. iidadasia: various kinds of poisons. cp. egisa
eidapala (plural iidapalan) (noun M) a traditional stool used as a seat. 
eidedia (adverb) (of anything) lying face up; lying on the back.
eideng (noun M) a sickness causing sores on arms, legs or fingers. 
eidenyet (plural iidenyeta) (noun M) food for a journey. cp. lukidenyet
eidepit (plural iidep) (noun M) a flea. cp. edepidepit
eidicane (singular noun M) companionship; solidarity; camaraderie; togetherness; belongingness; unity. 
eidiko (plural iidikoi) (noun M) a cricket game or ball. cp. eidilo. 
eidil (singular noun M) abundance; profusion; concentration; plenty. cp. aidiles.
eidilo (plural iidiloi) (noun M) cricket game or ball. 
eidiny (singular noun M) a groan; a sigh; a grunt; groaning. cp. aumeno
eiditeu (singular noun M) youth; smallness; humility. 
eidodikinet (plural iidodikineta) (noun M) a pointer; an arrow road sign 
eidodo (plural iidodoi) (noun M) (Usuk) a wall or house lizard. cp. eibobo. 
eidon (singular noun M) ceaseless rain; (of rain or a leak in roof, etc) dropping. cp. ekidon. 
eiduka (plural iidukai) (noun M) a shop; a kiosk; a stall. eiduka loepol: emporium; a supermarket; a booth. 
eidukula (plural iidukulan) (noun M) a kind of fishing basket or fishing trap. cp. eijang. 
eiduma (plural iiduman) (noun M) (in parts of Teso bordering Bantu-speaking areas) a maize plant or cob maize. cp. ekwakoit, ekirididi. 
eiduny (plural iidunyeta) (noun M) neighbourhood; neighbourliness; proximity; nearness; closeness. toma oidunyete kon ejai loejeni aitemonokin igaalin: in your neighbourhood there is one who repairs bicycles. 
eidunyet (plural iidunyeta) (noun M) a neighbour; the one near; a vicinity; neighbourhood; abutment. itunga luka eidunyete kon eroko: the people in your neighbourhood are bad. erai ngesi lokidunya ka eong: he is my neighbour. 
eiduporo (plural iiduporo) (noun M) a martyr; a sacrificial victim; a victim. eiduporo losodit kobaibuli nges Stepano Lokalaunan: the first martyr in the Bible was St. Stephen.
eidyaset (plural iidyaseta) (noun M) a gourd in which churned milk is kept. cp. eidyatet
eidyatat (plural iidyatan) (noun M) a bank, treasure house or museum. 
eidyatet (plural iidyateta) (noun M) a gourd in which churned milk is kept. 
eigang (singular noun M) an alliance; a coalition, mutual help or assistance; a detente. cp. eigangane
eigangane (singular noun M) an alliance; a coalition; a detente. 
eiges (singular noun M) a staggering gait. 
eigoliro (plural igoliron) (noun M) a load; a burden, kit. erai aswam na eigoliro: this work is a burden. 
eigoo (plural iigoon) (noun M) a trading centre; a settlement (with a central market). cp. ebooma, eibuga. 
eigwerane (singular noun M) herpes zoster lessions. cp. eijerane
eigwong (singular noun M) applause; acclamation; incantation. 
eigworone (singular noun M) (a Serere version of eibworone) the initiation ceremony for youths and adult men to senior age groups. cp. eibworone, asapan
eiise (noun M) a leak; a drip; a leakage. amotika ejai eiise loepol: my pot has a bad leak. 
eiit (plural iin) (noun M) a granary made of twigs. cp. ekerei; edula - general name for granary. 
eijaanakine (singular noun M) service; way of serving. mam akoto eijaanakine kooteeri kangol: I do not like the service in that hotel. 
eijaikina (plural iijaikina) (noun M) an offer, gift, present, contribution, reward, bequest, donation, endowment, or souvenir. 
eijaloga (noun M) a plant, Acalypha. 
eijang1 (noun M) a plant, Acalypha ornata. 
eijang2 (plural iijangin) (noun M) a scoop fishing basket resembling a manger. 
eijang3 ki-a (intransitive verb) to shake; to rock; to move to and fro; to oscillate. 
eijek ki-o (intransitive verb) to be dangling. 
eijekelut (plural iijekel) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a cockroach. cp. ejekelut. 
eijer ki-a (transitive verb) to belch. 
eijerane (singular noun M) belching; burping; letting out air through the mouth. cp. eigwerane: herpes.
eijiij (noun M) dropsy (an abnormal accumulation of fluid in any part of the body). 
eijiliet (plural iijilieta) (noun M) a strainer; a filter; a sieve. cp. aijililet
eijim (singular noun M) haze; mist; fog; smog. 
eijin (plural iijinin) (noun M) a motor engine. 
Eijiri (singular noun M) the Gospel (any of the New Testament books of Matthew, Mark, Luke and John); the life and teachings of Christ. 
eijulauna (plural iijulauna) (noun M) a boy child delivered (born) with the legs coming out first – such a person is believed to have natural powers to paralyse the ‘enemy’ if he buried reptiles on enemy soil before a cattle raid. cp. ekungut. 
eijuluna (plural luijuluna) (noun M) a child surviving after others have died. cp eipolyauna
eikaajo (noun M) a sugarcane. aigit eikaajo: to eat sugarcane. cp. eitola
eikaresone (singular noun M) sneezing. 
eikep (plural iikepia) (noun M) a hammer or round stone to roughen a grinding stone, or to pound dry potatoes, etc 
eikiiki (plural iikiikin) (noun M) a deciduous tree, Prosopis africana. Its dry fruit is used as a rattle and the sticks are used in making cricket bats in the game of eidiko. The timber is very hard. The fruit and bark are used in making tannin and dye.
eikit (noun M) a grass used for making carrying pads.cp. etunu. 
eikito (plural iikiton) (noun M) food leftover from the night before, used for breakfast. 
eikoi (plural iikoyon) (noun M) a kind of white cloth (ekikoi) with red stripes at both ends. 
eikong (plural iikongio) (noun M) a hammer; a mallet. 
eikopo (plural iikopon) (noun M) a cup; a chalice; a cruet. 
eikoru (plural iikoruo) (noun M) a frontier; a boundary; a dividing line; a periphery. 
eilat (noun M) a stroll, walk, hike. alot ngesi eilat: she/he has gone for a visit, or for a stroll. 
eiliili (plural eiliilete) (adjective) scary; intimidating; frightening. eiliilete akaninika: my hands are very dirty. eiliili emun: a snake is frightening, strikes fear into one. eiliili akouke: she/he is swollen-headed; she/he is proud. eiliili ates: the corpse is very scary. 
eiliketait (plural iiliketa) (noun M) a fishing hook. cp. elikot.
eililinga (adverb) in silence; silently; noiselessly. 
eilip ki-a (transitive verb) (only used in infinitive) the begging; the act of begging. epol eilip kane kocaalo: there a lot of begging here in the village. epol eilip loka esigala: there is a lot of begging for cigarettes. 
eilipe (plural iilipesyo) (noun M) way of begging, asking, praying. 
eilit (plural iilin) (noun M) a path made by mice and rats; a burrow. cp. eipur. 
eilongis (plural iilongisia) (noun M) a bathroom. 
eilopakina (plural iilopakina) (noun M) inherited or passed on property. ibore ngin ngesi eilopakinaka: that is my property by inheritance. 
eimae (singular noun M) the way to make porridge. 
eimaret (plural iimareta) (noun M) something for counting; an abacus. eitaabo lokimaret: an arithmetic book. 
eimidi (singular noun M) fever; malaria; (of a person having) a high temperature. cp. emaleria
eimil (noun M) the flash (of lightning or anything); the shine; lustre.
eimonit (plural iimon) (noun M) (Usuk) a tsetse fly (a vector for nagana or sleeping sickness); cattle fly. cp. ekamonit
eimukis (plural iimukisyo) (noun M) a covering blanket; a bedsheet; anything to cover with. cp. eimukos
eimukos (plural iimukosia) (noun M) (Usuk) a covering blanket; a bedsheet; anything to cover with. cp. eimukis
eimyel loka etau (noun M) a strong desire; a craving; longing; hankering after; heart’s desire. imyela eong etau akiring: I long for meat: ejai eong eimyel loka etau ainyam akiring. 
einakina1 (adjective) (of a person) dedicated; devoted; determined; resolute. 
einakina2 (plural iinakina) (noun M) a gift; a grant; a gratuity; an award; a reward. 
einer (plural iinerio, iinerin) (noun M) a limb or upper part of the body; any of the four parts of a dissected bird. iinerin luka akokor: the four parts of a chicken. 
einere (plural iineresinei) (noun M) a mode or way of talking; a dialect; a nuance. einere loko Serere: the dialect of Serere. iineresinei: a group of dialects; speeches. epol einere loko Usuk kodikisyonari kalo: the Usuk dialect of Ateso is prevalent in this dictionary.
eingarenikine (noun M) manner of leadership; management style. 
eingite (singular noun M) the way or manner of asking, or of setting exams. 
eingokit (plural iingok) (noun M) acne; a pimple. cp. ekangokit
eingony1 (singular noun M) heavy traffic; congestion (of roads and passage-ways). 
eingony2 (singular noun M) illicit sexual intercourse; sexual relationship between near relatives; incest; free-for-all sexual relationship in the neigbourhood, i.e. men and women are loose (like in the biblical Sodom and Gomorrah).
einik (adjective) black; dirty. egoe lo erai einik noi: this cloth is very black or dirty. igoen luinikino: dirty clothes. 
eining (singular noun M) wrestling; grappling; tussling. 
einyakit (plural iinyak) (noun M) a rag; a worn out piece of cloth. 
einyangane (noun M) revenge; vengeance; reprisal; retaliation; retribution.
einyure (plural iinyurei) (noun M) the game of cricket. cp. eidiko, eidilo. 
eipajane (singular noun M) relationship; connection; affiliation; association. 
eipapane (singular noun M) fatherhood. 
eipaperone (singular noun M) friendship; amity; attachment. 
eipara (noun M) telepathy; second sight; a feeling that something is wrong or is going to be amiss. 
eipiane (singular noun M) the itch. cp. ewinyiwiny, ajokeiko
eipiirione (singular noun M) expertise; know-how; skill. cp. apiirianut
eipimaet (plural iipimaeta) (noun M) a measure; a foot rule; a weight (with which to weigh). 
eipiret (plural iipireta) (noun M) a stick (often with a head shaped like a bowl or tripod) for stirring sauce (especially peas); a hole or thread drilling machine. 
eipise (singular noun M) a method of breeding or rearing animals. aise ibegoi luka ibaren luejokuka nges kwana eipise itojokiaritos ipiiriotin luka ibaren: selective breeding of livestock is a method of animal breeding advocated for by livestock experts. cp. eipite
eipite (singular noun M) a corruption of eipise: a method of breeding or rearing animals. agolit ikweny ajoora, arai bo alacakinit kilatos tai – ali bo eipite akokoroi ejok adepar?: keeping birds within a wire mesh, or leaving them to roam about – which method of rearing chicken is better? cp. eipise.
eipoe (singular noun M) a way of cooking; cuisine; gastronomy. 
eipois (plural iipoisyo) (noun M) (Usuk) a kitchen; a place for cooking. amot nak’ipois: a cooking pot. cp. epiibiro
eipolyauna (plural iipolyauna, luipolyauna) (noun M) a child surviving after others have died. 
eipone (plural iponesio) (noun M) a kind; a habit; a manner; a method or methodology; a character; a sort; a behaviour; a custom; a bearing; a category; know-how. eipone edio kere: in any way. cp. enepes, epone.
eipongut (plural iipongun) (noun M) a lump of unthreshed millet left in the granary; a knot in the wood or on the mud wall; a clod of earth. 
eipud (singular noun M) a need; a desire; attachment; liking; preference; aspirations. 
eipugae (singular noun M) the method of ruling or governing. eipugae loaronon: bad governance; misrule.
eipyei (singular noun M) lightning (static energy in the sky); a flash of lightning. iretuni eipyei: it will thunder. imilia lolo eipyei: it is lightning or flashing today. ireta lolo eipyei: it is thundering today. abu eipyei kicwe ekatogo: lightning struck my home. abu eipyei kipumupum akiteng: the lightning struck a cow (but the cow was not killed). cp. ekipyei
eipyel (singular noun M) strong desire, longing, craving, hanker.
eirab (singular noun M) a discussion; a debate. kilosi iso eirab: we are going to discuss or to have a long talk. 
eirabo (plural iirabon) (noun M) offertory at church or burial. 
eires (singular noun M) roaring; a roar; the thunder; the roaring; a flare. cp. agiro. eires lokedou: thunder. 
eiriairia (noun F) a whirlwind; a stroll. aiiriairia naka akipi: a whirlpool. aiiriairia naka ekwam: a whirlwind. 
eiris (singular noun M) an amulet chiefly worn by children round the neck; a charm. 
eirotane (singular noun M) polygamy; bigamy. 
eiruk (singular noun M) a dance; a song; a motto or maxim. cp. emong; ekuret: girl’s part in a song or dance. 
eirumane (singular noun M) cohabitation; living together without marriage; concubinage; inheriting a woman from the clan.
eirumuna (plural iirumuna) (noun M) an inheritance. aberu nakirumuna: an inherited wife (i.e. a wife given to a man by his clan after the death of her husband). iboro lukirumuna: inherited property (whose original owner has died).
eiruru (noun M) guilt. anyam ngol eiruru: he is guilty. aitanyam eiruru: to find someone guilty.
eis (singular noun M) (the ceremony of) paying of dowry, or the showing of dowry. alosi eong ois ke inacika: I am going to the ceremony at which my sister’s dowry will be paid. 
eisaawe (plural iisaawen) (noun M) a playground; a field. eisaawe lokidegei: airfield, airport, aerodrome, helipad. eisaawe lokemopiira: football field. 
eisigane (singular noun M) a hiccup. kerumit eong eisigane: I have hiccup. 
eisiilooret (plural iisiilooreta) (noun M) an anaesthetic. 
eisiisa (plural iisiisan) (noun M) a brake of car or bicycle. mam iisiisan iswamaete: the brakes have failed.
eisiitunet (plural iisiituneta) (noun M) a memento; a memorial; a reminder; a remembrance; a sign (to remember with). 
eisil (singular noun M) a hiss; a whistling; a declaration not to.
eisinye (singular noun M) greed; stinginess; selfishness; gluttony; avarice; cupidity (craving, desire, passion, eagerness, lust, or acquisitiveness). 
eisiret (plural iisireta) (noun M) an ornament, adornment, or accessory; a decoration, an embellishment, ornamentation, or beautification. 
eisirwa (plural iisirwai) (noun M) a grasshopper, Zonocerous veriegatus. 
eisiwa (plural iisiwan) (noun M) a stink greenish-yellow giant grasshopper. cp. ebeere 
eisobwa (plural iisobwan) (noun M) a conical fishing reed trap thrust into mud to ensnare fish. cp. aruja. 
eisolet (plural iisolen) (noun M) a granary made of twigs or reeds. cp. ekerei.
eisongot (plural iisongon) (noun M) a ball in the hip; a nodule on the hip or elbow; juxta-articular nodule; a knot in wood. 
eisupane (singular noun M) courtship; illicit love affair; an affair; a liaison; a tryst; a flirtation. 
eisuwa (plural iisuwan) (noun M) a species of big yellow-green grasshopper, Zonocercus variegatus. 
eiswaget (plural iiswageta) (noun M) a toothbrush; a thing for scrubbing or polishing with; a sponge or steel wool to clean with. cp. epwatet. 
eiswamae (singular noun M) the manner or method of work, acting or conducting business. 
eit (plural eitak) (adjective) sharp; pointed. eitak ikilenga lu: these knives are sharp. 
eitaabala (plural iitaabalan (noun M) a handkerchief; a hankie; a neckerchief; a scarf; a headband; a table cloth.
eitaabo (plural iitaaboi) (noun M) a book; a register; a ledger; a log (book); a roster; an account. eitaabo loisirigin: a financial or bank account. iitaaboi luisirigin: books of financial or bank accounts.
eitaada (plural iitaadan (noun M) a bed - a camp bed, crib, cradle, bunk bed, double bed, single bed, etc.
eitabira (plural iitabira) (noun M) an offering; a sacrifice. cp. asubanit. 
eitai (singular noun M) communal work for reward (usually for beer); a reward; payment for work; salary; work for beer; task or work. 
eitane (plural iitasia) (noun M) (the ceremony of) paying of dowry, or the showing of dowry; the method of nurturing or aitan. alosi eong oitane ka inacika: I am going to the ceremony at which my sister’s dowry will be paid. ainyam aperosit erai eitane idwe lomam ejok: eating the previous night’s leftover food is not a good way of bringing up children. cp. eis; eipise 
eitanit (plural iitana) (noun M) the opening of a teat of females; the aperture of a pressure pump. ikisin ka akiteng kangin egolol iitana kec: the openings of the teats of that cow’s udder are blocked. cp. etupanit
eitanuna (plural iitanuna) (noun M) a nurtured child (not biological child of the person taking care of it); a foster-child; a step-child; an adopted child.
eitarane (noun M) (formerly) marriage of children in advance of maturity; a form of marriage whereby the parents of a boy-child approached the parents of a girl-child they hoped to be future wife of their son and married her in childhood. The girl-child was tied an arm band to signify she is married, until her maturity when she would join her husband.
eitebwone (singular noun M) a swelling of stomach; flatulence; constipation. cp. emuunu, egwei.
eitei (singular noun M) face-to-face; the look; the aspect. eiteikec: their look. cp. eiduny – adjacent.
eiteitei (plural iiteitein) (noun M) a dress with a blouse and skirt joined as one (made of the same fabric); a frock; a gown. 
eitekerane (singular noun M) tribalism; a tribal or ethnic manner of doing things – not on merit. cp. ateker. 
eitekere (plural iitekerio) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a sub-clan; a family (from common ancestor); a sub-tribe. cp. ateker
eitela1 (plural iitela) (noun M) (formerly) an administrative unit composed of homes on the land between swamps; (formerly) an administrative unit (equivalent to a parish) bigger than erony (sub-parish) but smaller than etem (sub-county).
eitela2 (plural iitela) (noun M) an area of land clearly defined by natural swamp or valley boundaries.
eitelepane (singular noun M) boyhood; adolescence; youth. cp. eipesurane: girlhood; maidenhood.
eitemes (plural iitemesio) (noun M) weighing scales; a measure. 
eitemet (plural iitemeto) (noun M) a corruption of eitemes: weighing scales; a measure. 
eitena (adverb) (done or spoken in a) straightforward or frank manner. einer eitena: to talk in a frank and simple manner. 
eitetere (plural iiteterei) (noun M) a fishing basket. cp. ekodo. 
eiteunet (plural iiteuneta) (noun M) a prototype; a model; archetype. cp. aiteunet
eitinyo (plural iitinyo) (noun M) a cheek; the chap. aibap eitinyo: to slap on the cheek. cp. ekitinyo
eitiyo (noun M) small termites for feeding chicks, their anthill found in swamps are called esugiria. 
eitodikina (singular noun M) a command; a law; a commandment. cp. eicorakina. 
eitola (plural iitolan) (noun M) a sugarcane. kobilak eong da iisongen iuni luka eitola: break for me three nodes of sugarcane. cp. eikaajo.
eitolima  (noun M) a riverbank; a beach; a lakeshore. 
eitotone (singular noun M) motherhood. 
eitubuset (plural iitubuseta) (noun M) an ornament; an adornment; a decoration. 
eitule (singular noun M) a swelling and reddening of the vulva (the pudenda); cancer of the female genitals. 
eituli (plural iitulin) (noun M) a tyre puncture or leak. cp. aremetoit. 
eitunet (plural iituneta) (noun M) an island. 
eitunganane (singular noun M) humanity; mankind; human nature. 
eituritono (plural iituritono) (noun M) a praiseworthy person; a hero. 
eitutu (plural iitutun) (noun M) the breast of a fowl. cp. egego.
eituudu (plural iituudun) (noun M) a piece; a cigarillo; a stub of smoked cigarette. 
eituutooret (plural iituutooreta) (noun M) an instruction booklet or manual; a training manual. 
eiwiny (intransitive verb) to be whistling with the lips; to whistle (singular noun M) whistling (with the lips). 
eiwiny (singular noun M) whistling with one’s lips. 
eiya (adverb) (of grinding, work) evenly; equally; all sides. kiswama alaro kon eiya: level your courtyard. 
eiyara (adjective) safe; protected; defended; secure; guarded; shielded. eiyara ngesi: she/he is safe. 
eiyas ki-a (transitive verb) to increase, multiply, grow. isirigin luko toma aingadis elosete eiyas/iyatas: money in the savings bank accrues interest. abu keyat: I added. apotu kiyatata: they added. eong eyata: I grow/increase. kesi iyatas: they grow bigger/increase. abu eong keyatakin: I grew up or became big. kiyat! kiyatak! (singular imperative of eiyas): add! Increase! kiyatakin (singular imperative): (you) grow! (you) increase! kiyatakinos (plural imperative): (you) reproduce! cp. aipuar; apoloor; aiyatakin.
eiyek (singular noun M) hanging; dangling. cp. eijek
eiyeng (singular noun M) breathing; panting; respiring. cp. eiyengane
eiyengane (singular noun M) breath. ebos eiyenganeke: she/his breath is vile. 
eiyengane (singular noun M) breathing; panting; respiration.
eiyiny cp. eiwiny: (Serere) to whistle. 
ejaajalo (singular noun M) (in Pallisa) bean seeds or plants. cp. emarooge
ejaanakinan (plural ejaanakinak) (noun M) a servant; a waiter; a houseboy. 
ejaapu (noun M) a wild creeper with edible leaves cooked with ecadoi, emoros, egwangira, and elwata, Commicarpus plumbagineus. 
ejaaye (singular noun M) Indian hemp; bhang; hashish. emasi ngesi ejaaye: she/he smokes hemp.
ejae (plural ijaesio) (noun M) a state (of things); a station in life; being; state of being. cp. ajaus, ajaut. 
ejago (noun M) a tomato-like fruit. 
ejai (plural ejaas) (adjective) real; actual; it, she, he is present. ejai edia amot: sauce is in the earthenware pot. ejaas itunga ogaago: people are in the shed. ejai eong aswam: I have to do; I have work.
ejakaana (plural ejakaaka) (adjective) well off; real chief. ijakaana ijo: you are well off, you are a real chief. 
ejakait (plural ijaka, ijako) (noun M) mister; sir; master; chief; gentleman; principal; director; husband or owner of house. naka ejakait (mutan): (used in addressing a man) to Mr (so and so). Ejakaitiwok: Our Master (Jesus Christ); Our Lord.
ejaket (plural ijaketin) (noun M) a jacket. cp. ekooti; esweeta. 
ejakuna (adjective) released; saved; be on holiday. cp. elakuna
ejala (plural ijalai) (noun M) an idler; a layabout; a loafer. erai etunganan lo ejala, mam ekoto aswam: this man is a layabout, he does not want to work. 
ejalakinio (adjective) admissible; permissible.
ejalakitai (adjective) free; divorced; left alone; remaining.
ejalana  (plural ejalaka) (adjective) free with; ready to give a lot of something.
ejalakuwan (plural ijalawat) (noun M) a reckless, wild, irresponsible person; a hero, idol. 
ejalal (adjective) (to be) public property; accessible to all; (to be) free for all. ejalal araito nuka ekitoi kangol: the fruits of that tree are public property. 
ejalam (plural ejalamak) (adjective) (Usuk) (of liquids, etc) lukewarm; (of men) kind, good-hearted, generous. akipi nuejalam: lukewarm water. itunga luajalamak: kind, generous people, easy to approach. 
ejamu (plural ijam) (noun M) (formerly) a skin or hide for sleeping on (ijam, is now used to mean ‘beddings’). ayaunit eong ikajam: I have brought my bedding along. 
ejamut (adjective) (outside Usuk) (of liquids, etc) lukewarm. akipi nuejamut: lukewarm water.  
ejanta (noun M) enjoyment; pleasure; gratification. ainyam ejanta: to enjoy oneself.
Ejapadolait (plural Ijapadola) (noun M) a Jopadhola man (the Luo speakers of Tororo district). Ijapadola: the Jopadhola people (in general). 
ejarakina (adjective) loose; slack; lax. 
ejaroto (plural ijarotoi) (noun M) a slipknot. 
ejatoto (singular noun M) a vegetable plant, Asystasia schimperi.
ejau (noun M) a grass, Aristida adscendascienis. 
ejautene (singular noun M) a way of living; a state or station in life; a bearing; a quality; a climate. ejai ejautene kec erono: they live in misery. ejok ejautene: the conditions are good. isogoror ejautene: the situation is unpleasant.
ejeburu (plural ijeburun) (noun M) (Usuk) an abandoned house or home. ejeburu ngesi ere loabwosere kotoma: a derelict home is one from which the people have shifted away. cp. ameje.
ejeet (plural ijeeta) (noun M) a piece of gourd or wood to smoothen a clay pot (before drying it in the sun). 
ejejait (plural ijejai) (noun M) a nephew (called so by aunt). 
ejekelut (plural ijekel) (noun M) (Usuk) a cockroach. cp. ekajekelit. 
ejelejele (noun M) a grass, Paspalum commersoni. 
ejelel (plural ijelelo) (noun M) a tree, Acasia depanolobium. cp. ejelel; eyelel
ejena (plural ejenas) (adjective) famous; well-known; eminent; prominent. 
ejenio (plural luejenio) (noun M) a celebrity; a famous person; a superstar; an icon; a public figure; a personage; a big shot. 
ejenunet (plural ijenuneta) (noun M) a sign; a trademark; a mark; a token; a wonder; a miracle; an omen; a symbol; a musical note. 
ejepel (plural ijepelin) (noun M) a clitoris; a female’s urethra. cp. eteede, emanerit.
ejepep (adjective) maimed; cheated; cut down; felled. etunganan loejepep: a maimed person; a cheated person. 
ejese (plural ijesesio) (noun M) a colour; a hue; a tint or shade; a category of something. cp. eraagi.
ejesi kia (plural ejesete kia) (adverb) it is very white; (plural) they are very white. 
ejibat (plural ijibai) (noun M) a domesticated pigeon; (slang) playboy; lover man. ijibai: deep lovers.
ejie (plural ijiisio) (noun M) a fight; a contest; a contention; a war; a battle; a combat. 
ejiirit (plural ijiirin) (noun M) a cricket. cp. epude
ejiis (plural ijiisio) (noun M) weapons (for fighting). 
ejijim (adjective) yummy; sweet; appetising (of food or anything); delicious; enticing. ejijim doo do: ejijim laa la: very sweet; very delicious or luscious. ejijim dokodok: very sweet or very nice (to the taste).
ejikai (plural ijika) (noun M) a tree, Sclerocarya birrea subsp. caffra. Its fruit is edible as food and fodder, the leaves are fodder, the bark and root are medicinal, while the wood is used as general-purpose timber and firewood. ainyam ejikai; aikony ejikai: (of someone staying far) to keep quiet for long. 
ejikit (plural ijikitas) (adjective) deaf. ijikitas aki: she/he is deaf. ijikitas akika: my ears are deaf.
ejikooni (plural ijikoonin) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a kitchen; a cooking place. cp. eipois 
ejimi (plural ijimi) (noun M) a big ulcer; a big sore. 
ejinga (plural ijingai) (noun M) a tree in the emidit family, but with adventitious roots - bark cloth tree, Ficus sycomorus. cp. ebwalai.
ejiono (plural ejioko) (adjective) fond of fighting. ejioko kesi: they are fond of fighting. 
ejiose (plural ijosei) (noun M) (formerly) a war dance; a battle dance. cp. ajosi.
ejipai (noun M) a drop of perspiration or of water or of milk, etc cp. eburoit or esima
ejipopo (plural ijipopoi) (noun M) a kind of sour bitter vegetable resembling ejaapu (eaten during the dry season). 
ejiput (plural ijip) (noun M) scabies; mange; a mite. 
ejo (interjection) stop; cease; leave off; you there; listen! ejo, kinyek!: you there, stop/leave! cp. ejong
ejok1 (adverb) well; kindly; justly; nicely. kijokis (in Kwapa –Ateso Atororo) all. akoto aswam kon kojok: I want your work to be good; let your work be good. kojok aswam kon (plural kojokak): let your work be good. ti ejok: it would be good. 
ejok2 (plural ejokak) (adjective) good; kind; just; nice; fair; beautiful; (of soil) fertile. 
ejokorot (plural ijokoron) (noun M) a short, strong tube for sucking beer made from a stem of a reed. cp. epii
ejokuna (plural ejokuka) (adjective) acceptable; good; affable; nice; fine; healthy; well; right, etc ijokuna ijo?: are you ok? 
ejolot (plural ijolon, ijoloi) (noun M) a servant; (formerly) a slave. cp. enyamuret. (note: ejolot was a slave belonging to the family but of another tribe, not Etesot). 
ejon (plural ejonok) (adjective) unripe; premature; immature; undercooked; raw; uncooked; fresh. sirikimat aokot ejonok: do not drink uncooked, raw blood. enyamete idwe araito nuejonok: children eat unripe fruits. atap na ejonit enyaritai ‘epule’: raw or poorly mingled millet/sorghum bread is known as epule. 
ejoreon (plural ejoreok) (noun M) a raider; a rustler. Ikaramoja eraas itunga luejoreok: the Karimojong are raiders. 
ejorit (plural ijorian) (noun M) a fruit fly (likes sweet fruits). cp. ejur, asasyai: a fruit fly that likes sour fruits and drinks such as beer.
ejoroi (plural ijoro) (noun M) a shrub, Teclea nobilis. Its leaf extract used as medicine for ear-aches.
ejose1 (adverb) pretending; under pretext; seemingly; with deceit or sham (adverb) under pretence of. abu ngesi neajai eong ican ejose: she/he came to me pretending to cry of poverty. sirikilip ejose: do not act as if you were praying; do not pretend to pray. cp. eede
ejose2 (plural ijosei) (noun M) (formerly) a war dance. cp. ejiose.
ejosi (adverb) in the early afternoon. 
ejotono (plural ejotoko) (adjective) often asleep; sleepy; drowsy; lethargic; heavy-eyed; sluggish; tired. ijotono ijo: you are fond of sleeping or dreaming. 
ejuge (singular noun M) (slang) dry gin; crude distilled alcohol. cp. ewaragi, ecuramol.
ejuju (noun M) a kind of plant with prickly purple flowers - a thistle. cp. egitu. 
ejuka (plural ijukai) (noun M) a plant, Solanum africanum. 
ejulai (plural ijulai) (noun M) a corruption of ejutat: a cannibal; one who kills secretly; a witch or wizard. cp. ejutat, ecudan
ejulat (plural ijulai) (noun M) a person not satisfied with his own tribe, who likes to be called or thought to be of another tribe. 
ejuliran (plural ejulirak) (noun M) a prosecution witness. cp. ajenan; ekejuliran. 
ejungula (plural ijungulai) (noun M) a plant used for a hedge, Jatropha curoans. ainya ejungula: to be rich. anyaa ngol ejungula: that man has many wives, he has become rich. cp. aibar. 
ejuput (plural ijup) (noun M) a corruption of ejiput: measles; rash; eczema. cp. ejiput
ejur (plural ijuria) (noun M) a small fly that feeds on beer or fruit or rotten things. cp. ejurit
ejurit (plural ijuria) (noun M) a small fly that feeds on beer or fruit or rotten things. cp. ejur.
ejurusitoi (adjective) (of a person) slick, polished, efficient, glossy, smooth, or professional; clever, witty, or brainy; (of a car) quick, rapid, fast, speedy, swift, or nippy. 
ejutat (plural ijutai) (noun M) one who kills quietly or secretly; a cannibal; a serial killer. cp. ejulai. 
ejutet (plural ijuteta) (noun M) a razorblade. cp. ebarenit, emweeso
ejuulu (plural ijuulun) (noun M) a crest of feathers on a bird’s head. cp. ecuude. 
ejwele (adjective) (of taste) insipid; dull; bland; wish-washy; characterless; colourless; stale; tame; unexciting. 
eka1 (plural ekas) (noun M) an acre. 
eka2- (prefix of agent in ko verbs) ‘one who...’ekalokan: one who traps; a trapper. ekatupan: one who follows; a follower. ekacudan: one who bewitches; a wizard; a witch.
eka3 M (adverb) (in salutation) my friend; my dear. ekatuan, eyalama aanyun: my friend, I am happy to see you.
ekaabi (plural ikaabin) (noun M) a refugee camp; an internally displaced people’s camp; a laager. cp. egaaso.
ekaajo (noun M) a sugarcane. 
ekaalet (plural ikaalen) (noun M) the Flood age group. 
ekaame (plural ikaamei) (noun M) a shell formerly used as a spoon or a tool for weeding millet. 
ekaanyanaran (plural ikaanyanarak) (noun M) a Church of Uganda bishop; inspector; overseer. 
ekaapuni (plural ikaapunin) (noun M) a company; corporation; enterprise; a business; a theatre company; a troupe; touring company; a syndicate; an organization; a consortium; an association
ekaaran (plural ikaarak) (noun M) a murderer; a killer; a serial killer. 
ekaaso (plural ikaason) (noun M) a cassock; a long white robe. 
ekabadi (plural ikabadin) (noun M) a cupboard; a locker; a sideboard.
ekabaka (plural ikabakan) (noun M) (any) king or monarch; a cultural leader of the Baganda tribe.
ekabalagala (plural ikabalagalai) (noun M) a pancake. 
ekabaracaroi (plural ikabaracaro) (noun M) a tree, Vitex cuneatus. 
ekabaran (plural ikabarak) (noun M) a rich man; a wealthy man. cp. lokabaran
ekabarenon (plural ikabarenok) (noun M) a barber; a man who cuts or shaves people’s hair.
ekabarit (plural ikabarin) (noun M) a plant, Crotalaria poly sperma. 
ekabeji (plural ikabejin) (noun M) an edible cabbage. cp. ekabit, esukumawiki
ekabelan (plural ikabelak) (noun M) one who wounds someone’s head with a stick. 
ekabelit (plural ikabel) (noun M) scale of fish, crocodile, or snake. cp. eibelit
ekabenyan (plural ikabenyak) (noun M) a guerrilla fighter; a rebel; a rogue; a lawless person, etc. 
ekabit (singular noun M) the kale plant or leaves (akin to cabbage without a head) eaten as vegetable. cp. esukumawiki.
ekabokan (plural ikabokak) (noun M) a spy, tempter; a digger; one who digs. ekabokan atesia: a professional grave-digger. cp. engu.
ekabolian (plural ikaboliak) (noun M) a player; a jester; a joker; a sportsman or an athlete. 
ekabu (plural ikabun) (noun M) a trench coat; an overcoat; a cloak; a big skin or hide formerly worn by chiefs and Nandi (a tribe in Kenya) and by Sabiny (a tribe native to Kapchorwa or Sebei in Uganda). cp. ekooti, ekabut
ekabuliokong (plural ikabuliokonga) (noun M) sty in the eye. 
ekabuoron (plural ikabuorok) (noun M) a robber; a confiscator. cp. ekademaran. 
ekaburon (plural ikaburok) (noun M) the fat or the thick one; the one who replaces another; a substitute. 
ekabut (plural ikabun) (noun M) a trench coat; an overcoat; a cloak; a big skin or hide formerly worn by chiefs and Nandi (a tribe in Kenya) and by Sabiny (a tribe native to Kapchorwa or Sebei in Uganda). cp. ekooti
ekabwaan (plural ikabwaak) (noun M) a superintendent; a guard (of things); a headman; one who builds fences or enclosures. 
ekabwoan (plural ikabwoak) (noun M) a sponsor; one who stands (bail, etc). cp. ekabwaan
ekabwoikinan (plural ikabwoikinak) (noun M) a sponsor, etc. 
ekabwoikiniton (plural ikabwoikinitok) (noun M) a sponsor or guarantor; a godparent; a delegate; one who stands and challenges another. cp. abwoikiniton.
ekaceeret (plural ikaceeren) (noun M) a species of ox-pecker. 
ekacelan (plural ikacelak) (noun M) a shouter; a quarrelsome, irritable person. cp. lokacelan. 
ekacelat (plural ikacelak) (noun M) a vowel letter, such as a, e, i, o, u. 
ekacoan (plural ikacoak) (noun M) a wise man; the maggi; a wise person, a clever person. cp. lokacoan
ekacodan (plural ikacodak) (noun M) a tempter or examiner; a tester. 
ekacudan (plural ikacudak) (noun M) a witch; a wizard; a cannibal; a night dancer (figurative) (approvingly) a person who does things cleverly, in a clever way, like a juggler. 
ekaculon (plural ikaculok) (noun M) an arbiter; intermediary; arbitrator; a go-between. ekaculon mam ebelakinio angole: (an adage) a peace-maker is not to be molested (literally, a go-between should not be hit on the head).
ekadakalu (plural ikadalun) (noun M) a water rat; an otter. cp. abubusia
ekadakan (plural ikadakak) (noun M) a carrier; a porter; a carer (of children only). cp. lokadakan.
ekadanyat (plural ikadanyak) (noun M) a glutton; a great murderer; gourmand. 
ekadedengan (plural ikadedengak) (noun M) a harsh, cruel, fierce, wild, severe man or animal. 
ekadekan (plural ikadekak) (noun M) a patient; a sick or ill man. cp. lokadekan.
ekademaran (plural ikademarak) (noun M) a grabber or snatcher; a robber; a plunderer. cp. ekabuoron. 
ekadepit (plural ikadep) (noun M) a flea. cp. eidepit. 
ekadiekan (plural ikadiekak) (noun M) a judge; a mediator; an arbitrator or arbiter.
ekadilon (plural ikadilok) (noun M) an early riser or traveller. amina eong ikadilok: I like early risers. 
ekadinaali (plural ikadinaalin) (noun M) a Roman Catholic bishop or cardinal. cp. episikopi
ekadingiriran (plural ikadingirirak) (noun M) a fast runner; a fast cyclist. 
ekadit (plural ekaditos) (adjective) not enough; inadequate; insufficient. ekadit ekwam: breathless. cp. edolit. 
ekadongot (plural ikadongon) (noun M) a gong; a big church bell. cp. edongot, ekide.
ekadonyon (plural ikadonyok) (noun M) a tailor; a dress-maker. 
ekadot (plural ikadoi) (noun M) a plantain-eating bird. cp. acugia. 
ekadotean (plural ikadoteak) (noun M) an adulterer; a fornicator; a prostitute; a sex worker. cp. edote; adote: a woman who has illicit sexual intercourse (free or for money) constantly; a harlot; a prostitute; a sex worker. cp. amalayat.
ekadukon (plural ikadukok) (noun M) a builder; an architect; a mason. erai ngesi lokadukon itogoi: he is a builder or architect. 
ekaduliai (plural ikadulia) (noun M) a kind of tree with edible fruit. 
ekaduot (plural ikaduok) (noun M) a marksman (of gun). cp. ekaguman: an archer (for arrows).
ekadutan (plural ikadutak) (noun M) a generous or liberal person (in giving things). 
ekadwaran (plural ikadwarak) (noun M) a prophet, foreseer, or a diviner; a bitter thing. amugogot nakadwaran: bitter banana for beer-making. 
ekadyekan (plural ikadyekak) (noun M) an intercessor; an adjudicator; a separator; judge; an arbiter; a rescuer. cp. ekadiekan.
ekaelon (plural ikaelok) (noun M) a bad friend; a lover; an intimate friend; fornicator; adulterer. aelo ijukanari ekaelon alosit aanyun akepese: a sudden sexual impulse prompts the lover to visit his girlfriend. 
ekaenan (plural ikaenak) (noun M) one who ties, binds, packs, imprisons, etc. koyautu ikaenak etogo: bring men to tie the grass on the roof of the hut. 
ekageretan (plural ikageretak) (noun M) one who massages, embrocates (sets a bone); a masseur; a physiotherapist.
ekagogongon (plural ikagogongok) (noun M) the strong, severe, hardy, difficult, strict one. lukagogongu: the mighty ones; the strong ones. 
ekagolon (plural ikagolok) (noun M) a doorkeeper; a prison guard; a loser; a failure. cp. lokagolon
ekaguman (plural ikagumak) (noun M) an archer.
ekagwelan (plural ikagwelak) (noun M) a buyer; a purchaser. 
ekajakunan (plural ikajakunak) (noun M) a rescuer; a saviour; a redeemer; a liberator. 
ekajalan iboro (plural ikajalak iboro) (noun M) a generous, liberal, open-handed, big-hearted, charitable, or munificent person. cp. ekadutan
ekajaran (plural ikajarak) (noun M) a living person; the living. lukajarak ka lukatwak: the living and the dead. cp. lokatwan.
ekajean (plural ikajeak) (noun M) a potter; a person who moulds with clay, etc. 
ekajenan (plural ikajenak) (noun M) an eyewitness; a martyr; one who knows; a deponent. 
ekajengan (plural ikajengak) (noun M) a skinner; a person who removes the skin from a slaughtered animal.
ekajepan (plural ikajepak) (noun M) a wood cutter; a lumberman; a cheat; a trickster. 
ekajikaj (plural ikajikaja) (noun M) a fruit tree with sour fruit, Sclerocarya birrea subsp. caffra. 
ekajion (plural ikajiok) (noun M) a fighter, combatant, boxer, wrestler, pugilist, rebel; a warrior, soldier. 
ekakaa (plural ikakaan) (noun M) a tree the root which is used to speed up shea-nut butter (alinyo, akungurit) making or is planted near gardens to deter witchcraft on a grain crop (- the leaves of same tree are used in beer-making to prevent beer going bad or as a treatment for wounds), Lonchocarpus laxiflorus. 
ekakaas (plural ikakaasia) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a banded mongoose, Mungos mungo. cp. ekokoas
ekakadakinan (plural ikakadakinak) (noun M) an annoyed, sad, downhearted, or disgusted person. 
ekakale (plural ikakalen) (noun M) a castor oil shrub, Ricinus communis. The ricin in its seed coats is poisonous, while the seeds are used to extract castor oil which has medicinal value.
ekakapiton (plural ikakapitok) (noun M) a soldier in arms; a person in arms. 
ekakinangan (plural ikakinangak) (noun M) one who hears but does not answer; a mute. 
ekakolon (plural ikakolok) (noun M) an adversary; an enemy; a contestant. 
ekakolot (plural ikakolok) (noun M) a great adversary; a vicious enemy; a serious contestant. 
ekakoran (plural ikakorak) (noun M) a distributor; a benefactor. 
ekakorion (plural ikakoriok) (noun M) a farmer who cultivates land; a planter; a grower of crops. 
ekakwangan (plural ikakwangak) (noun M) white; the white one; the bright one. akoto egoe ekakwangan: I want a white cloth. koyau ekakwangan: bring the white one. 
Ekakwat (plural Ikakwa) (noun M) a Kakwa tribesman; a man native to parts of Arua district of Uganda west of the Nile. Ikakwa: the Kakwa people. 
ekakwenan (plural ikakwenak) (noun M) one who laughs; a scoffer; a scorner. 
ekakwenaran (plural ikakwenarak) (noun M) one who ridicules; a derider or disdainer. 
ekal (plural ikalia) (noun M) a marriage or compound of married people; a home; a family unit; a wife and her children; a basic social unit. 
ekalaamu (plural ikalaamun) (noun M) a lead pencil. 
ekalaani (plural ikalaanin) (noun M) a clerk; a secretary; amanuensis. 
ekalakunan (plural ikalakunak) (noun M) a saviour; a redeemer. 
ekalany (plural ikalanyik) (noun M) a lazy, indolent, idle, lethargic or sluggish person. 
ekalanyana (plural ekalanyaka) (adjective) lazy; idle; indolent. 
ekalaunan (plural ikalaunak) (noun M) the clean man; the holy man or a male saint. cp. nakalaunan (plural nukalaunak). 
ekalean (plural ikaleak) (noun M) one who beats or canes. 
ekaledi (plural ikaledin) (noun M) a tree used to fence kraals, Rhus incana. 
ekalees (noun M) (in Karamoja) an ostrich, Struthio camelus. cp. ekuulu
ekalelan (plural ikalelak) (noun M) one who rejoices; a happy man; a happy-go-lucky fellow. 
ekaleo (plural ikaleon) (noun M) a bush, Tiziphus mauritianus. 
ekalerut (plural ikaleru) (noun M) a plant, Cucurbitacaea; a cucumber-like creeper used as medicine for mange (emugege) in animals - Krotalario polysperma. 
ekalia (plural ikalian) (noun M) a tree, Grewia mollis. 
ekaliagaman (plural ikaliagamak) (noun M) the tall, high one. 
ekalianan (plural ikalianak) (noun M) a baby (a newly born child).
ekaliaton (plural ikaliatok) (noun M) a creeper; a creeping thing (like a snake, worm). 
ekaliliton (plural ikalilitok) (noun M) the jealous or envious one. 
ekalimonokinan (plural ikalimonokinak) (noun M) a preacher, cleric, or reverend. 
ekalimoron (plural ikalimorok) (noun M) a reporter; a betrayer, traitor, rebel, turncoat, defector, or a deserter; an announcer, presenter, telecaster, or a broadcaster; an informer.
ekaliokon (plural ikaliokok) (noun M) a liar; a hypocrite; a quack. 
ekalitiini (plural ikalitiinin) (noun M) a quarantine; an isolation of animals to prevent the spread of disease among livestock; a transit depot for animals. aigol ekalitiini: to enforce a quarantine. angaar ekalitiini: to open up a quarantine.
ekalituusi (plural ikalituusin) (noun M) eucalyptus or Blue-gum tree, Eucalyptus spp. 
ekalokan (plural ikalokak) (noun M) a man who ensnares; a man who traps; a man who sets traps. 
ekalokit (plural ikalok) (noun M) a large brown sugar ant. cp. omukeke. 
ekalokunan (plural ikalokunak) (noun M) an adolescent male. 
ekaloman (plural ikalomak) (noun M) an entrant; one who enters somewhere; an adulterer. ekaloman aberu (plural ikalomak angor) (noun M) adulterer. cp. lokeluk. ekaloman kinga: a guard; a watchman; a witch. cp. ekacudan.
ekalomaran (plural ikalomarak) (noun M) one who enters; an entrant; a recruit; a newcomer. 
ekaloton (plural ikalotok) (noun M) a pedestrian; a traveller, explorer, voyager, trekker, tourist; a passenger, or a commuter.
ekalumon (plural ikalumok) (noun M) a swimmer; a diver. 
ekalungan (plural ikalungak) (noun M) one who refuses something (in anger). 
ekalyaton (plural ikalyatok) (noun M) a creeping thing. 
ekalyoi (plural ikalyo) (noun M) a thorn tree with hooked thorns, the liquid from the pounded and boiled roots of which is used as a dressing for wounds in livestock, Securidaca ongipendulata. cp. aleli. 
ekama (singular noun M) measles. cp. epuuru; ekwam
ekambak (plural ikambakin) (noun M) a retrenched, laid off, or deserting army man now living a civilian life in the village; a come-back. cp. akambak.
ekamejan (plural ikamejak) (noun M) a hunter; a seeker. 
ekameran (plural ikamerak) (noun M) a sot; a drunkard; an alcoholic. 
ekamerat (plural ikamerak) (noun M) a perpetual drunkard; an alcohol addict. 
ekamesyana (plural ekamesyaka) (adjective) spotted; dotted; speckled; dappled; freckled. eris erai etyang loekamesyana: the leopard is a spotted animal. 
ekamet (plural ikam) (noun M) a kind of small tree. 
ekamodan (plural ikamodak) (noun M) a cheat; a conman; fraudster; swindler; one who cheats. 
ekamole (adverb) pretending; feigning; seemingly. ejotoi ngesi ekamole: she/he is pretending to sleep. cp. ejose
ekamonit (plural ikamon) (noun M) a tsetse fly. 
ekamonyan (plural ikamonyak) (noun M) one who weeps; lachrymose. 
ekamule (plural ikamulen) (noun M) a millet or sorghum brew made for sale. 
ekamuran (plural ikamurak) (noun M) (Usuk) a father-in-law; a brother-in-law; the wife’s brother. ikamurak: all in-laws generally (female or male). cp. emwi: a brother of one’s husband (a brother-in-law).
ekamuriei (plural ikamuria) (noun M) a wild mulberry spiny shrub, Carissa edulis. The ripe fruit is edible, root extract is medicine, while crushed young fruits are used for seasoning vegetables such as ekipikipi, ecadoi, esukumawiki, etc.
ekang M (adverb) my friend; my dear; dear me. okwe ekang kolot, nukon nupe inerai: my dear friend go away, they are talking about (killing) you. (ekang used in a salutation or beginning a letter to a man: Dear Sir). 
ekangatan (plural ikangatak) (noun M) a robber, burglar, mugger, raider; a brigand, bandit, or thug.
ekangatat (plural ikangatak) (noun M) one fond of robbing or raiding; a perpetual raider or bandit. 
ekangibiriran (plural ikangibirirak) (noun M) a fast runner. cp. ekadingiriran
ekangokit (plural ikangok) (noun M) acne; a pimple. cp. eingokit. 
ekaniki (plural ikanikin) (noun M) black lustre (of cloth); alpaca; sheen; shine; patina; gleam.
