ekaninikan (plural ikaninikak) (noun M) a tough one; the resilient; a diehard. 
ekanisa (plural ikanisan) (noun M) a Protestants church. cp. ekelesia: a Catholic church. 
ekanon (plural ikanonin) (noun M) an Anglican Church canon in charge of a parish. 
ekansila (plural ikansilan) (noun M) a local administrative council male representative.
ekansulo (plural ikansulon) (noun M) a local administrative council. ekansulo lo ocaalo: a village council (LC-I). ekansulo lokoitela: a parish council (LC-II). ekansulo lokotem: a sub-county council (LC-III). ekansulo lokobuku: a county council (LC-IV). ekansulo lokodistrikt: a district council (LC-V).
ekanyaman1 apese (plural ikanyamak apese) (noun M) one who takes part of a girl’s dowry.
ekanyaman2 itunga (plural ikanyamak itunga) (noun M) a cannibal; a man-eater (lion). engatuny lokanyaman itunga: a man-eating lion. cp. angu.
Ekanyangit (plural Ikanyanga) (noun M) a man native to former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts); a Mugisu man (because he is brown – enyangaana). Ikanyanga: the Bagisu or Bamasaba people (in general). cp. Emaikokoit, Emugisut.
ekanyumit (plural ikanyum) (noun M) a seed of simsim; a simsim plant, Sesanum idieum. 
ekao (noun M) a kind of grass used as broom. cp. ajanit: Sporobolus pyramidalis. 
ekaonon (plural ikaonok) (noun M) a thin or skinny person. 
ekapa (plural ikapai) (noun M) a domestic cat; a tomcat. cp. ipus
ekapakapa (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet. 
ekapakina (adjective) ready to do; armed; in arms; prepared; equipped; organized; all set. inyo bo ekapakina itunga lu ejie?: what are these people armed for? 
ekapegan (plural ikapegak) (noun M) one who denies or argues; a debater; one who objects. 
ekapelimen (noun M) (in Karamoja) a tree, Acacia nilotica subsp. subalata. Its pulpy pods are edible, the root extract is medicinal, the bark is used as a stimulant, tannin and dye.
Ekapelyoit (plural Ikapelio) (noun M) a man from Kapel. 
ekapelyono (plural ekapelyoko) (adjective) (of animals, hills or anything) white-spotted; white patched; freckled; flecked; dappled. 
ekapetan akiro (plural ikapetak akiro) (noun M) a lawyer; a pleader. 
ekapetan aperit (plural ikapetak aperito) (noun M) a bed maker; a room attendant. 
ekapeton (plural ikapetok) (noun M) a kicker; one who kicks. ekapeton emopiira: a skilled football player. emopiira lopetot: a ball to be kicked, a football. 
ekapiira (plural ikapiiran) (noun M) a cheap second-hand polyester garment. 
Ekapiirit (plural Ikapiirin) (noun M) a pagan (non-Christian), an atheist, a kaffir; a man from Kapir sub-county in Kumi district. 
ekapilan (plural ikapilak) (noun M) a wicked person; a wizard; one who bewitches by mere presence or passing by; one with evil eyes; the devil. 
ekapodon (plural ikapodok) (noun M) a man who worries, grouses; a grouser; a man who complains. 
ekapodot (plural ikapodok) (noun M) one who is fond of grousing, worrying, or complaining.
ekapolon (plural ikapolok) (noun M) (formerly) a man who has been initiated to elderhood (through asapan ceremony); a great man; a principal; an important man. 
ekapucon (plural ikapucok) (noun M) one who prepares a feast to reconcile with another; a peace-maker; a reconciler; an arbiter. cp. lokapucon
ekapuletenyit (plural ikapuletenya) (noun M) a cyst; a growth in the body; an ulcer; a sore; a carbuncle; a swelling. 
ekapupon (plural ikapupok) (noun M) one who is listening; a listener; a hearer. ikapupok: the audience. 
ekapurokinan (plural ikapurokinak) (noun M) one who replies or answers back; a pleader; a lawyer; an intercessor. 
ekaput (plural ikapun) (noun M) (formerly) one cent piece. ikapun: money in general
ekarac (plural ikarac) (noun M) the bowlegged one; one with deformed legs. ecom erai etyang lokarac: a baboon is a bow-legged animal. cp. aipagag.
ekaracunat (plural ikaracuna) (noun M) a youthful warrior or raider. 
ekaramoto (plural ikaramotoi) (noun M) a plant from which salt is extracted, Achirantes aspera. 
ekaramwai (plural ikaramwa) (noun M) (in Karamoja) white-galled acacia or whistling thorn, Acacia seyal. The bark is medicinal, exudes gum Arabic, and also used for tanning leather and for dyes.
ekarata (singular noun M) a paper card game, played with 54 cards. etopoloosi kwana isapa abolia ekarata kotaun aibois naka akor: boys these days spend a lot of time in town playing cards instead of farming.
ekare (singular noun M) (of women only) shouting and screaming for joy; ululation. 
ekaremon (plural ikaremok) (noun M) one who spears; one who punctures. 
ekarengan (plural ikarengak) (noun M) the red one; the red Indians. akoto iikopon lukarengak: I want the red mugs (cups). 
Ekarimojongait (plural Ikarimojong) (noun M) a man native to former Karamoja (the present day districts of Moroto, Kotido and Nakapiripirit). Ikarimojong: the Karimojong people generally.
ekaromait (plural ikaromwa) (noun M) a bush, Acacia seyal. 
ekaromata (plural ikaromatai) (noun M) a tree, Euphorbia calycina. 
ekarotan (plural ikarotak) (noun M) a spy; a sleuth; a scout; a detective. ekarotan iyemuto: a journalist. ekarotan akiro: a spy or sleuth.
ekaru1 (plural ikar) (noun M) a name given to a man who is born deformed (such as one who grows up without teeth, born lame, or is born deaf). 
ekaru2 (plural ikar) (noun M) a year. ekaru je: last year. ekaru ngol: next year. ekaru logeet: the starting year. ekaru loka asioman: the academic year. ekaru loka aurio: the year of birth. ekaru loka Ejakaitiwok: the year of our Lord (anno Domini – AD).
ekarucon (plural ikarucok) (noun M) a fitter; a plumber; a linkman. 
ekarukwe (noun M) a lily, Gloriosa varifolia. 
ekarukwei (plural ikarukwa) (noun M) a Black plum tree, vitex doniana. Uses: it bears round edible fruits (black when ripe) called aelun or akarukwa; the tree provides shade; fuel is got from its firewood and charcoal; building materials from its poles and timber; its leaves, fruit, bark and roots have medicinal properties.
ekaruwon (plural ikaruwok) (noun M) a commander-in-chief of an army or any group.
ekasaan (plural ikasaak) (noun M) a man servant. ekasaan ateker: a family or clan caretaker; an attendant; a servant. 
ekasaban (plural ikasabak) (noun M) a liar; fraudster; conman; a charlatan doctor. 
ekasabat (plural ikasabak) (noun M) a regular liar; one clever at lying. 
ekasekenyait (plural ikasekenya) (noun M) a brown small hornet. cp. eturuturut, ekasekenyit
ekasekenyit (plural ikasekeny) (noun M) a brown small hornet. cp. eturuturut. 
ekasian (plural ikasiak) (noun M) one who escapes, i.e. an escapee; one who runs away; a fugitive; a deserter. 
ekasilon (plural ikasilok) (indefinite pronoun) a little. cp. ediokasilon: a small one; a little; a bit. nediokasilon: a little distance; a little while. akasilok: a small quantity of liquid. akiro akasilok: a few words. akipi adikasilok: a little water. 
ekasuban (plural ikasubak) (noun M) the maker; the creator; the moulder; the manufacturer; God the Creator. Daimler-Chrisler nges ekasuban imotokan luka Mercedes Benz: Daimler-Chrisler is the manufacturer of Mercedes Benz cars. cp. lokasuban
ekasupon (plural ikasupok) (noun M) a tracker dog; a ferret dog; one who finds out (something hidden). 
ekasweet (plural ikaswei) (noun M) a drizzle; a little rain. cp. elimilim.
ekateit (plural ikatei) (noun M) a small termite egg (given to chicks). cp. eitiyo
ekateite (plural ikateitein) (noun M) a plover (bird) - Caspian plover. 
ekatereunan (plural ikatereunak) (noun M) a confessor of bad doing; a rat (one who betrays a cause); a black leg; a sell-out. 
ekatetelit (plural ikatetel) (noun M) a gill of fish; a cockscomb. 
ekato (plural ikatoi) (noun M) an inoculation; a vaccine; vaccination; a booster; a jab; a shot; an injection. cp. aicum epiiso. 
ekatubon (plural ikatubok) (noun M) a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. ekatubon akituk: a butcher of cows. ekatubon imusaagon: a court judge.
ekatulikit (plural ikatulikin) (noun M) a member of the Roman Catholic Christian faith. 
ekatumunan (plural ikatumunak) (noun M) a young man 14 -16 years of age; a male youth; an adolescent boy. 
ekatupiton (plural ikatupitok) (noun M) a follower; an attendant; a cohort; an aide; a servant; a henchman; a companion. ekatupiton Yesu: Christ’s disciple.
ekatwan (plural ikatwak) (noun M) the mortal being; the dead one.
ekauda (singular noun M) a grass, Chloris. cp. eudu. 
ekaukau (adverb) backwards. elosi ngesi ekaukau: she/he is going backwards or retreating. 
ekaulero (plural ikauleron) (noun M) a pepper plant. 
ekaulo (adverb) afterwards; subsequently; then; next after (that); later than. cp. kokau
ekaupuli (singular noun M) a plague; a pestilence; a disease outbreak; an epidemic. cp. atular: sudden death.
ekaurian (plural ikauriak) (noun M) a parent; a producer (bearer); a begetter; a primogenitor; a progenitor; a forebear.
ekaut (noun M) a grass - Sporobolus pyramidalis. cp. ekaot.
ekauton (plural ikautok) (noun M) a castrator; an emasculator. cp. aidong. 
ekawean (plural ikaweak) (noun M) a man who sows; a broadcaster (of news or seeds).
ekawo (noun M) the big peas. cp. imare: cowpeas; a small variety of peas, whose leaves are a vegetable called eboo.
ekawokon akipi (plural ikawokok akipi) (noun M) a water-drawer; a water-fetcher. 
ekawurian (plural ikawuriak) (noun M) a parent. cp. ekaurian.
ekayaiton (plural ikayaitok) (noun M) a ruler; a sovereign; a governor; a president; a monarch. 
ekayelon (plural ikayelok) (noun M) a man who has illicit sexual intercourse. cp. ekaelon
ekayeton (plural ikayetok) (noun M) a carver; one who chips away. 
ekayo (plural ikee) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a poison; a medicine; a drug; a remedy; tablets; an injection; a linctus; pills; medication; a toxin; a herbal cure. cp. ekia
ekayoit (plural ikayo) (noun M) the cutting edge; a knife cut. ekileng lo emameete ikayo: this knife is blunt (has no edge). cp. iyo. akwanus. 
ekayuunan (plural ikayuunak) (noun M) a rescuer; a saviour; a liberator; a redeemer. 
eke- (prefix for nouns, denoting agents of ki verbs). eke- (M); ake- (F); ike- (Dimin.) (note: ko verbs have eka- as prefix). 
ekeara (adjective) puffed up; overblown; exaggerated; elevated; prominent. cp. ingosibib. 
ekeburan (plural ikeburak) (noun M) claimant (of debt, etc); debt collector. cp. aibura. 
ekebusianan (plural ikebusianak) (noun M) a drudge; one who works hard for little pay. 
ekebwalaan (plural ikebwalaak) (noun M) an enticer; one who keeps another from working; a negligent and slow-working person. 
ekebwanyan (plural ikebwanyak) (noun M) a party intruder, a gate-crasher. 
ekebwokan (plural ikebwokak) (noun M) a porter who carries things for others; a carrier. 
ekebwokot (plural ikebwokok) (noun M) a regular porter (who helps to carry things on his back or on the head); a beast of burden. 
ekeciran (plural ikecirak) (noun M) a milker; a milkman. cp. lokeciran.
ekecit (plural ikec) (noun M) a spur (of a bird or horseman); a barb (of wire). asinit nak’ikec (noun F) barbed wire. 
ekecodon (plural ikecodok) (noun M) a person who limps; a cripple. 
ekecokon (plural ikecokok) (noun M) a herdsman; a pastor. ekecokon akituk; a sheperd: ekecokon amerekekin. 
ekecololon (plural ikecololok) (noun M) a hypocrite; a fraud; a charlatan. ekecololon ijo: you are a hypocrite. 
ekecoran (plural ikecorak) (noun M) a counsel; an adviser; a counsellor; a guru. 
ekedaan (plural ikedaak) (noun M) a man who buries; grave digger; a mourner; an undertaker.
ekedaran (plural ikedarak) (noun M) a guardian; a keeper; a watchman; a protector; a waiter; a curator; a foster-parent. cp. lokedaran, awenan.
ekedekede (plural ikedekeden) (noun M) a species of bird, a red-billed hornbill. 
ekediany (plural ikedianya) (noun M) a southpaw or left-handed man – believed to have powers to bless rustlers whom he smears them with mud. 
ekedot (plural ikedo) (noun M) brand marks or beauty marks on cattle or pottery. 
ekedyatan (plural ikedyatak) (noun M) a treasurer; a collector; a compiler. cp. ekengadan. 
ekeegere (plural ikeegerei) (noun M) a bicycle bell. cp. angoobe: a car horn. 
ekeeki (plural ikeekin) (noun M) a cake. 
ekeeyarit (plural ikeeyarin) (noun M) a soldier; an army man. cp. epolisit, esirikaalet
ekegangan (plural ikegangak) (noun M) an ally, a pleader, a lawyer, an advocate. 
ekejaanakinan (plural ikejaanakinak) (noun M) a constant or regular attendant or protégée. ajaanakin duc: regular attendance or presence. 
ekejerukon (plural ikejerukok) (noun M) an unmanageable, disobedient, unruly, defiant, disloyal, or seditious man. 
ekejodon (plural ikejodok) (noun M) a sycophant; toady; flatterer; a fawn. cp. aanyamakinan
ekejuliran (plural ikejulirak) (noun M) a prosecution witness. cp. ejuliran, ajenan.
ekek (plural ikekia) (noun M) a doorway, entry, or entrance; a family or tribal lineage of common ancestry; extended family. kogol ekek: close the doorway. ilomunit ijo kokek kangai?: to which family lineage do you belong? 
ekekaan (plural ikekaak) (noun M) a hunter, a seeker; a persecutor, a tormentor, a bully, a tyrant, an oppressor, or an intimidator. cp. lokekaan
ekekamaran (plural ikekamarak) (noun M) a captor or an abductor; a kidnapper; a hijacker; a hostage taker. 
ekekemeran (plural ekekemerak) (noun M) a happy-go-lucky man; one who chances upon something. 
ekekemoi (singular noun M) a loud laugh or cackle (especially by troublesome women in ekirakira dance). ejaikina oni ekekemoi loejok: we had a good laugh. cp. akyena, akwena. 
ekekeon (plural ikekeok) (noun M) a carpenter; a carver; an engraver; an etcher. 
ekekes (adjective) (physically) strong; powerful; obstinate; difficult. ekekes ijo etaukon: you are obstinate. ekekes etunganan ngol: he is a strong man. 
ekeket (plural ikeketa) (noun M) an iron tip of a spear casing. cp. eketit
ekekoban (plural ikekobak) (noun M) a transcriber; one who copies; one who transmits or passes on. 
ekekwa (plural ikekwan) (noun M) the other side of the river or lake; the opposite bank. 
ekelai (plural ikel) (noun M) a tooth; a fang; a tusk; an incisor; a dagger; a cog. ainakin ikel: to make ridiculous. angiikin ikel: to show one’s teeth to (in anger). abu je kangiik eong ikel: he showed me his teeth, i.e. he threatened me. angiikin ikel: to set one’s teeth; to persevere when doing a difficult work or in great anger or pain. ekelai k’etom: an ivory; elephant tusk.
ekelaman (plural ikelamak) (noun M) a curser; a high-jumper (in athletics). 
ekelapilapan aswam (plural ikelapilapak aswam) (noun M) a work shirker or dodger; an idler; lazybones. 
ekelesia (plural ikelesian) (noun M) a Roman Catholic church (building). cp. ekanisa: a Protestant church. 
ekeli (plural ikelio) (noun M) salivary glands. 
ekelijilijan (plural ikelijilijak) (noun M) a suckling (child, piglet, etc); a penetrator; a biter. 
ekelipan (plural ikelipak) (noun M) a beggar; a pleader; a petitioner; an appellant.
ekemanimanan (plural ikemanimanak) (noun M) inspector, examiner, checker, superintendent, overseer, assessor, supervisor. 
ekemeran (plural ikemerak) (noun M) an albino. 
ekemerana (plural ekemeraka) (adjective) albino; lacking pigment. 
ekemorikikinan (plural ikemorikikinak) (noun M) a uniter; a mediator; a reconciler. cp. ekadiekan. 
ekemunonan (plural ikemunonak) (noun M) one who conceals; an obscurantist; a doctrinaire; an obfuscator. 
ekenep (plural ikenepo) (noun M) a nettle with stinging leaves; a plant, a root of which is used as cough mixture. ainyam ekenep: to become daring and cruel.
ekeneran (plural ikenerak) (noun M) a speaker (the person, not the machine); an orator; a lecturer; a presenter; a narrator; a spokesman. 
ekengadan (plural ikengadak) (noun M) a treasurer; a keeper (of things in a store).
ekengalan (plural ikengalak) (noun M) a liar; a pretender; a con artist; a fraudster.
ekengarakinan (plural ikengarakinak) (noun M) a helper; an assistant; an accomplice (to a crime).
ekengarenikinon (plural ikengarenikinok) (noun M) a leader; a guide; a director; a manager.
ekengarenon (plural ikengarenok) (noun M) a leader; a director; an organizer; a manager.
ekengitan (plural ikengitak) (noun M) a questioner; an inquirer; an examiner like Uganda National Examinations Board.
ekengomingomon (plural ikengomingomok) (noun M) a gobbler; a glutton or greedy person.
ekenit (plural iken) (noun M) a curse; blasphemy; profanity; sacrilege; wickedness; swearword; malediction. cp. elamit. 
ekenyamiton (plural ikenyamitok) (noun M) an escort; an aide; a guide; a body guard. cp. enyamiton.
ekenyoolan (plural ikenyoolak) (noun M) a driver of a motorcar. 
ekeo (noun M) a tree, Oxytenanthera abyssinica. 
ekeoron (plural ikeorok) (noun M) a talkative person; a loud caller; a taxi or bus broker or tout. 
ekepalisionon (plural ikepalisionok) (noun M) a procrastinator; a man who delays; a lazy, careless, negligent, slovenly, idle person. 
ekepep (adjective) circumcised; (of a skin, finger or toe nails, etc) cut round. ikepep yesi: you are circumcised. 
ekeper (plural ikeperin) (noun M) a shoulder. 
ekepoon (plural ikepook) (noun M) a cook; a chef. cp. lokepoon.
ekepugan (plural ikepugak) (noun M) a ruler; a governor; a head of state; a monarch; a sovereign. 
ekeraban (plural ikerabak) (noun M) a speaker (in an assembly); a judge, a lawyer; a talkative man; a pleader, or a barrister. 
ekere (plural ikereo) (noun M) a plant - Harrisonia abyssinica - whose bitter red berry is not edible and its root is used for abortion and a treatment for eye cataract, and the twigs are used for making granaries; a portable granary made from these twigs and plastered with mud and cow-dung.
ekerekeret (plural ikekeren) (noun M) a Nubian woodpecker. cp. ebilicoro.
ekeresia (noun M) a corruption of ekelesia: a Roman Catholic cathedral. 
ekeret (plural ikereta) (noun M) a gourd churn for making butter when milk poured in it is jerked for some time. cp. eibuket, emalas.
ekeriaut (noun M) a sedge or grass growing in swamps, Cyperus. 
ekerimon (plural ikerimok) (noun M) a tramp; a vagabond; a wanderer; a nomad; a rover; a vagrant; a hobo; a hawker.
ekerionokinan (plural ikerionokinak) (noun M) a pessimist; a naysayer; a cynic; a person who throws cold water on everything good; a wet blanket; a party pooper; a killjoy. 
ekeru (plural ikerun) (noun M) a shelf; a ledge, sill, or outcropping; a bookshelf or mantelpiece. 
ekerumunan (plural ikerumunak) (noun M) a heir; an inheritor; a successor; progeny.
ekerurwot (plural ikerurwok) (noun M) a great plunderer; a real raider (both clever at and used to it). 
ekeryonon (plural ikeryonok) (noun M) an African; a Black person. cp. eeryonon.
ekesa (plural ikesa) (noun M) a fellow; a man; a guy; a bloke; a chap; a member of an age group. ekesa ngol: that fellow over there. ikesa kwi: those fellows over there. 
ekesese (plural ikesesei) (noun M) a tall man; a giant. 
ekesiaan (plural ikesiaak) (noun M) a beginner; a novice; a starter; a learner; an innovator. 
ekesicatan (plural ikesicatak) (noun M) a supporter; a backer; a sponsor. 
ekesidikon (plural ikesidikok) (noun M) an inciter; an agitator; an instigator; a mastermind; an organizer. 
ekesidounon (plural ikesidounok) (noun M) a mid-man. cp. naesidounon.
ekesisianakinan (plural ikesisianakinak) (noun M) a teacher; a schoolmaster; a professor. 
ekesisiat (plural ikesisiak) (noun M) a clever student; a clever learner; a clever pupil; a bookworm. 
ekesisiaunan (plural ikesisiaunak) (noun M) a man or boy who has just acquired knowledge; a learner; a pupil; a novice. 
ekesit (plural ikes) (noun M) a bundle (of grass, sticks, etc); a sheaf; a stack; a wad; a pile. 
ekesupan (plural ikesupak) (noun M) a wooer; a campaigner; an amorous man; an intriguer. 
ekeswaman (plural ikeswamak) (noun M) a workman; worker; an agent; an employee. 
ekeswamat (plural ikeswamak) (noun M) a good worker; a quick worker; a clever workman; an expert. 
eketajaran (plural iketajarak) (noun M) a saviour; a rescuer; a reviver. cp. etajaran. 
eketanan (plural iketanak) (noun M) a feeder; a nurse.
eketeon (plural iketeok) (noun M) a guardian; a caretaker; a spectator; an onlooker; a witness. 
eketimon (plural iketimok) (noun M) a merciful or forgiving person. 
eketisian (plural iketisiak) (noun M) one who aids another to escape.
eketisilan (plural iketisilak) (noun M) a confessor (in penance). 
eketit (plural iketita) (noun M) an iron spike on the spear shaft. 
eketobwoan (plural iketobwoak) (noun M) one who makes somebody to stand up i.e. an accuser. 
eketumunon (plural iketumunok) (noun M) one who promises or pledges. 
ekewadikan (plural ikewadikak) (noun M) a writer; a journalist; an author; a secretary. 
ekeyuunan (plural ikeyuunak) (noun M) a believer; one who agrees; one of the faithful. 
ekia (plural ikee) (noun M) poison; curative medicine; charm; drug; linctus; medication; remedy. aingalakin ekia: to poison someone (through food). ekia loinyonyoikina akuwan: an embrocation. ekia lotudokina: an ointment (for eyes or ears). ekia lopedokino: injectable drug. ekia loilikoro: an oral medicine. ekia loikel: toothpaste. ekia loamuk: shoe polish. eitwasamae ekia lokaronon: drug abuse. cp. amakereeda, ekomyo, ekulony
ekibira (plural ikibirai) (noun M) a forest; a jungle; a woodland. 
ekiboko (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a corruption of eiboko: a whip; a lash.
ekibui (plural ikibwo) (noun M) a big tree of the ficus family with edible fruits. 
ekicoi (plural ikico) (noun M) a shallow seasonal well; a waterhole; a burrow. cp. ekucoi.
ekicolong (plural ikicolongo) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a chair; a traditional bobbin stool; any seat. cp. eicolong
ekide (plural ikidei) (noun M) a bell; a gong. cp. edongodongot
ekideit (plural ikidia) (noun M) a name of the eastern peoples; somebody from the east. 
ekidima (plural ikidiman) (noun M) a factory-made hoe with a metre-long haft (handle or amusenu). 
ekido (plural ikidoi) (noun M) an island; an atoll; an islet; an isle; a sudd; a floating island of vegetation.
ekidon (singular noun M) ceaseless rain; el-nino. cp. eidon.
ekigimac (plural ikigimacia) (noun M) a thorn tree, Alstonia boonei. A shade tree yielding firewood and timber. A decoction from its bark is used as a traditional remedy for venereal diseases. cp. ekisim.
ekiiko (plural ikiikon) (noun M) a local administrative council meeting; a council hall. ejaas lolo ikiliok okiiko atubokinio esolo: today, men are at the council hall to be assessed graduated tax. 
ekiimit (plural ikiimin) (noun M) a small key-hole bee fond of picking earwax, Trigona. 
ekiira (plural ikiiran) (noun M) a plant, Achyranthos aspera. 
ekiitani (plural ikiitasia) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a wedding ceremony; a marriage ceremony. cp. eiis. alosi eong okiitani ka ejakait Omagor: I am going to the wedding of chief Omagor. 
ekiiwa (plural ikiiwan) (noun M) the hub of a cycle (the centre of the wheel holding the spokes). cp. epiororo. 
ekiki (singular noun M) shouting by women at a certain dance called edonga. 
ekikopo (plural ikikopon) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a cup; a mug. cp. eikopo
ekile (noun M) a plant with excessive latex, Euphorbia prostrata, Sonchus bipontini, Stolms kioldia. 
ekile (plural ikiliok) (noun M) a husband; a mate; a male spouse; a man. cp. okilen, ekiliokit. 
ekilen (plural ikiliok) (noun M) a husband. iyalama ya aanyun okilenike: she is happy to see her husband. cp. ekile. 
ekileng (plural ikilenga) (noun M) a 15-centimetre single-edged knife; a dagger; cutlery; a stiletto; a blade. 
ekilenyasit (plural ikilenyasia) (noun M) a joint (in the arm or leg or any part of the body). cp. aileny. 
ekilikil (noun F) squirming; wiggling; twisting; wriggling (of one wriggling through a crowd; a bird trying to escape from hand holding it; one in great sorrow; as one trying to escape). 
ekilimiiti1 (plural ikilimiitin) (noun M) a pigeon peas shrub, Cajanus cajan. Its root extract is used as a stomach-ache remedy as well as an aphrodisiac, while the seeds and pods are edible. It is a good nurse crop for tree seedlings.
ekilimiiti2 (plural ikilimiitin) (noun M) epiglottis (a flap that prevents food from entering the windpipe). cp. edokole.
ekilingait (noun M) a grass, Hyparrhenia variabilis. 
ekiliokit (plural ikiliok) (noun M) a full-grown man of 26–42 years of age; a male person or animal; a husband. 
ekiliokone (singular noun M) manliness; maleness; masculinity; manhood. 
ekiliokosisit (collective noun M) a crowd of men. 
ekiliton1 (plural ikilitona) (noun M) a scorpion. cp. ekiriton. 
ekiliton2 (singular noun M) a vegetable, Sonchus bipontini. cp. elokile, ekile.
ekilomita (plural ikilomitan) (noun M) a kilometre; 1,000 metres. cp. emita, eyaadi, amairo.
ekimat1 (plural imakio) (noun M) a black large biting ant. cp. esuunyoit. 
ekimat2 (plural imakio) (noun M) an old man; a crone; a reverend (in the Anglican church); an elder. ekimat loka ekanisa: a parson. cp. emojong. 
ekimeng (plural ikimenga) (noun M) a tree in the ekulony and ekwooro family, Combretum ghasalense. 
ekimia (plural ikimia) (noun M) an animal like a squirrel; a field rat, Gertille taterona liadon dundasi. cp. epude. 
ekimidi (singular noun M) (Ateso Atororo) malaria fever; ague. cp. eimidi, emaleria
ekiming (plural ikimingiok) (noun M) a deaf man; the deaf. 
ekimingana (plural ekimingaka) (adjective) deaf; hard of hearing; unable to hear; hearing-impaired; she/he is (they are) deaf. 
ekinei (plural ikinei) (noun M) a bird living with goats. 
ekinepes (singular noun M) (Ateso Atororo) mannerism; idiosyncrasy; characteristic; peculiarity.
ekingok (plural ingokwo) (noun M) a male dog; a greyhound, Alsatian, or mongrel; a very poor man. 
ekingol1 (plural ikingolia) (noun M) a palm tree or a palm frond, Phoenix reclinata. cp. emusogot.
ekingol2 (plural ikingolia) (noun M) fornication (of a married with an unmarried person); incest. 
ekinono (plural ikinonoi) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a tradition; custom; practice; ritual; belief; institution; folklore; habit; convention. cp. einono.
ekinyomit (plural ikinyom) (noun M) a choice seed for planting; (figurative) a sperm. cp. ebego.
ekiosik (plural ikiosikin) (noun M) a kiosk; a stall. cp. eiduka. 
ekipikipi (singular noun M) (Usuk) a vegetable cooked without using magadi salt, such as ecadoi, esukumawiki, elwata, edila, etc. 
ekipoliauna (plural ikipoliauna) (noun M) a child who has survived after serious illness, or a child surviving after all others died. cp. eijulauna. 
ekipyei (singular noun M) lightning; radio electric current. akim naka ekipyei: electricity. cp. eipyei.
ekirakira (singular noun M) a national dance of the Iteso (in imitation of the crested crane – ewalu - and popular in Usuk county in Katakwi district) that involves two groups leaping high up and down in alternation, in which no drums are used but men wearing ankle-bells leap to the accompanying foot-stamping chorus of female singers. cp. edonga.
ekirebet (plural ikirebet) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) scissors; shears; clippers; cutters; secateurs. cp. emakaasa
ekirididi (plural ikirididin) (noun M) cob maize; corn seed. cp. ebaado
ekirigi (plural ikirigin) (noun M) a door shutter made of reeds; a hero; a brave man; a prime minister of Iteso Cultural Union. Jethro Opolot nges kwana erai ekirigi loka atukot na imorikikinit Iteso kotoma oinono: Prof. Jethro Opolot is now the prime minister of the Iteso Cultural Union.
ekirimat (plural ikirima) (noun M) a variety of red sorghum seldom eaten by birds. 
ekirio (noun M) a plant, Hippia adoensis. 
ekiriton (plural ikiritona) (noun M) a corruption of ekiliton: a scorpion.
ekiror (plural ikiroria) (noun M) a name (person’s name, first name, Christian name, forename, given name, surname, family name, or middle name); appellation; a tag; a designation; a title; a label; a brand. kokiror ke: on his/her behalf; in the name of someone. kokiror ka: on behalf of someone; on my behalf; in my name.
ekisel (plural ikiselio) (noun M) a third-born child in a birth and still alive. cp. obosino, ekipolyauna, engoorit.
ekisil (plural ikisila) (noun M) a negative command (prohibition); a law; a rule; a command; a commandment; a regulation; precept; an edict. aitutub ekisil: to enact a legislation. ayaun ekisil: to bring law and order; to stop anarchy. 
ekisim (plural ikisimo) (noun M) a thorn bush, Acacia hockii. It is used for twigs and medicinal purposes - the leaf extract is a gonorrhoeal wound remedy, and root extracts cure cough.
ekisin (plural ikisin, ikisina) (noun M) a breast; an udder; a mammary gland. cp. awaket: udder.
ekisoko (plural ikisoko) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) (formerly) an agent or assistant to the parish chief. cp. erony.
ekison (plural ikisonin) (noun M) an auction; a public sale; a cattle market; an open air market. 
ekisu (plural ikiswan) (noun M) a mortar for pounding grain, groundnuts, or maize, etc. cp. arukit: a pestle.
ekitabala (plural ikitabalan (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a handkerchief; a hankie; a neckerchief; a scarf; a headband; a table cloth.
kokiror ka (preposition) on behalf of; on someone's behalf 
ekitabo (plural ikitaboi) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a book. cp. eitaabo.
ekitada (plural ikitadan) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a bed; a camp bed. cp. eitaada.
ekitai (singular noun M) (Ateso Atororo) communal work for reward (usually for beer); a reward; payment for work; salary; work for beer; task or work. 
ekitanuna (plural ikitanuna) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a foster-child; a step-child (with no biological mother to bring it up); an adopted child.
ekitebwone (singular noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a swelling of stomach; flatulence; constipation. cp. emuunu, egwei.
ekiteitei (plural ikiteitein) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a dress with a blouse and skirt joined as one (made of the same fabric); a frock; a gown. 
Ekitekere (singular noun M) (Ateso Atororo) the Iteso of Tororo, Kenya and Pallisa. cp. Iworopom 
ekitela (plural ikitela) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) an area of land clearly defined by natural swamp or valley boundaries.
ekitelek (noun M) (outside Usuk) the armyworms (caterpillars that destroy finger millet crop). cp. ekutelek
ekitinyo (plural ikitinyo) (noun M) a cheek; the chaps. aibap ekitinyo: to slap on the cheek. cp. eitinyo.
ekitoi1 (plural ikito) (noun M) a medicine; a herb; a drug; a remedy; a linctus; a medication. cp. ekia. 
ekitoi2 (plural ikito) (noun M) a tree; a bush. ejai ikwenyit okitoi: a bird is on the tree.	
ekitui (plural ikituo) (noun M) high grass; a bush; a jungle. akwap naka ikituo: a bush country. cp. amagoro: wilderness; desert. alomar okitui: to join guerrilla fighting or rebellion against a government. cp. ekitwi.
ekituki (noun M) a grass, Cymbopogon. 
ekitunet (plural ikitunen) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) island; isle; islet; atoll. 
ekitwi (plural ikitwo) (noun M) a jungle; a bushy place; high grass. alot okitwi: she/he has gone to the toilet or latrine. cp. ekitui.
ekiunione (singular noun M) trinity. ekiunione loagion: (in the Catholic faith) Holy Trinity - God the Father, the Son, and God the Holy Spirit.
ekiyai (plural lukiyai) (noun M) firstborn boy child. cp. lokiyai, yenikiyai
ekiyakia (plural ikiyakia) (noun M) a messenger; a delegate; a representative (to a committee or assembly).
ekiyot1 (plural akwi) (noun M) a potato variety identified by leaf type. ejok ekiyot lo: this potato variety is good. ekiyot asiira emini acokit naemiedana: the potato variety asiira yields a floury tuber that often chokes the consumers.
ekiyot2 (plural ikwi) (noun M) a bush; a shrub; a scrub. 
ekobet (plural ikobe) (noun M) the outer rim of the ear or pinna. 
ekoboi (plural ikobwa) (noun M) a tree whose root extract is used as a gargle to reduce toothache, Terminalia torulosa
ekobokobot (noun M) edible cucumber fruit or plant. cp. akolilit
ekoburo (plural ikoburoi) (noun M) a tree. Gymnosporis buxifolia. 
ekoc (plural ikoco) (noun M) (a reference among friends) a guy; a mature man. cp. ebok.
ekode (plural ikodei) (noun M) a hooked stick; a walking stick; a hook. 
ekodeit (noun M) a grass – a notorious weed - used as a favourable guide to soil fertility, Chloris gayana. 
ekodet (plural ikodeta) (noun M) a crowd; a mob; a gang; a club (of people); a category; a delegation; a Government department. 
ekodikod1 (plural ikodikodia) (noun F) a network or web (of telecommunication lines, roads, etc). 
ekodikod2 (plural ikodikodia) (noun M) a creeping plant; a climber. 
ekodo (plural ikodoi) (noun M) a plunge or scoop basket fish trap; a tiny sieve or filter attached to the bottom of a beer drinking tube called epii; a hamper; a basket. 
ekodoi (singular noun M) a deadly disease epidemic giving rise to rashes all over a person’s body, such as smallpox, chickenpox, or rinderpest. 
ekodokodoi (plural ikodokodo) (noun M) a twining plant with thorny hooks. 
ekodokodwoi (plural ikodokodwo) (noun M) a thorny shrub, Acacia senegal. Its fruits are edible, while the root extract are medicinal, and seeds are used for dye. cp. ekalyoi. 
ekoduot (plural ikoduo) (noun M) a splendid glossy starling. 
ekoed (plural lukoed) (noun M) a slender man. 
ekoile (noun M) a grass with prickly hair; a tree - Berkheya spekeana. 
ekojo (plural ikojoi) (noun M) a small double-headed spear with 2-inch blades, usually twisted at the neck, used for stabbing fish (note that this spear has a religious and magical significance and is associated with rain-making); an arrow for use with a bow. 
ekojolo (noun M) a grass - Hyparrhenia variabilis. 
ekoko (singular noun M) cocoa beans, tree or the drink made from processed seeds, Theobroma cacao. Uses: cocoa from the beans is used for chocolate, beverage is made from processed beans, and it contains a stimulant called theobromine.
ekokoas (plural ikokoasa) (noun M) (Usuk) a slender mongoose (a big rodent), Galerella sanguinea. cp. ekakaas, ekolimong
ekokolan (plural ikokolak) (noun M) a petty thief; one who steals; a pilferer; a pickpocket. cp. eenyagan: an organized robber or bandit. 
ekokolana (plural ekokolaka) (adjective) thieving; fond of stealing; kleptomaniac; sticky-fingered; light-fingered.
ekokom (plural ikokoma) (noun M) a huge crested black eagle - a Batelleur eagle. 
ekokor (plural ikokoroi) (noun M) a cock; a rooster; a male bird. etyang ka akokoroi - egwang: a wild cat. 
ekokoro (plural ikokoron) (noun M) a line (in a writing book or of growing plants); a verse (in the Bible chapter or a poem); a circle; a line of thatch or tie beams; a water wave; a longitude or latitude. ekokoro lok’akipi: a water wave. aira okokoron: to plant in rows. 
ekokot (plural ikokon) (noun M) a red-beaked bird. cp. egogot. 
ekokot1 (noun M) concrete; bedrock. cp. engarot
ekokot2 (plural ikok) (noun M) a termite Micro-cerotermes; a soldier ant. cp. ikok: gravel; murram. 
ekokota (plural ikokotan) (noun M) a seine net; a non-selective fishing net (catches small and large fish alike); a large marauding gang of armed cattle rustlers or raiders.
ekokote1 (noun M) cancer. cp. edola, egirikoc 
ekokote2 (plural ikokotei) (noun M) mischief; annoyance; jealousy; malice. ekokote kon nges kemiki eong adumun aswam: your jealousy prevented me from getting work. 
ekoleit (plural ikole) (noun M) a corruption of ekolia: a cat-fish. cp. ebileng.
ekoleji (plural ikolejin) (noun M) a college; a further education college. Kaliro erai ekoleji loituutuonorere imwalimun lukosiniya ko Busoga: the National Teachers’ College Kaliro is a college for training secondary school teachers in Busoga region.
ekoler (plural ekoleroto) (adjective) insomniac; sleepless; wakeful. 
ekolera (singular noun M) cholera. cp. ailep, ailek aokot.
ekoli (plural ikolin) (noun M) a looped rope; a hook; a three-forked stick (to hang things on); a dipper; a long calabash with a handle. 
ekolia (plural ikole) (noun M) a lungfish; a mudfish; a cat-fish, Clarias. cp. ebileng.
ekoliget (plural ikoligetin) (noun M) a toothpaste; Colgate brand of toothpaste. cp. ekia loikel. 
ekolilit (plural ikolil) (noun M) a cucumber seed. 
ekolimong (plural ikolimonga) (noun M) (Usuk) a white-tailed mongoose, Ichneumia albicauda. cp. ekokoas
ekolip (plural ikolip) (noun M) an impotent man. 
ekolipana (plural ekolipaka) (adjective) (of a person or an animal) sterile, barren or impotent. 
ekolo1 (plural ikoloi) (noun M) the soft stem of certain plants. ekolo loka amugogot: a stem (pith and xylem) of a banana plant; stem of papyrus. 
ekolo2 (plural ikolosio) (noun M) enmity; rivalry; antagonism; opposition; a contention; a quarrel; trouble; a feud; a dissention. 
ekolomiye (plural ikolomiyei) (noun M) a glossy starling (a bluish bird with red eyes, and eats red pepper). 
ekolono (plural ekoloko) (adjective) quarrelsome; troublesome; grumpy; grouchy; bad-tempered; tetchy; irritable; snappy; gruff; cranky. 
ekolor (plural ikolor) (noun M) a bald man. cp. ekular, epacal. 
ekomera (plural ikomerai) (noun M) a fence; a hedge; a barricade; a jail. cp. abwas: ereg. 
ekomiiti (plural ikomiitin) (noun M) a committee; a team; a working group; a panel. 
ekominiti1 (plural ikominitin) (noun M) the community; a group of people living in a particular locality. 
ekominiti2 seeta (plural ikominiti seetan) (noun M) a community centre; a place where members of a community may meet for social, sporting or educational activities. 
ekomira (plural ikomirai) (noun M) finger euphorbia tree, Euphorbia tirucalli. Its latex is eye poison that can be neutralised by application of human milk. The plant can be used as a boundary marker or hedge. 
ekomision (plural ikomisionin) (noun M) a commission (an official group); a working group or task force; a committee. ekomision loka aseo: an electoral commission.
ekomisiona (plural ikomisionas) (noun M) a commissioner (a member of a commission); an administrator. ekomisiona loka polis: a police commissioner (a high ranked police officer). arai kolo Stephen B. Akabway ekomisiona loka Ekomision Loedararoroi loka Aseo: Stephen B. Akabway was a commissioner in the Interim Electoral Commission. 
ekomol (adjective) brown-spotted; having brown-spotted colours, as of goat, cow, python, cloth, a hyena, etc 
ekomoliana (plural ekomoliaka) (adjective) brown-spotted; having brown-spotted colours, as of goat, cow, python, cloth, a hyena, etc 
ekomyo (plural ikomyon) (noun M) a tree stump; poison (especially herbal, as used by witches). cp. ekukut, arago: burnt grass stump. ekomyo kakirot: root of word, bottom of the truth, or of case. ekomyo loka emopiira: a strong man or a strong footballer, a football champion.
ekone1 (plural ikonei) (noun M) a big fish-hook. cp. egolu.
ekone2 (plural ikonei) (noun M) a male friend (in Ngakarimojong); a male lover. 
ekongot (plural ikong) (noun M) a white ant (edible); a termite. 
ekonit1 (plural ekokito) (adjective) (of fruit, food on fire) ripe; ready.
ekonit2 akuwan (plural ekokito awate) (adjective) dispirited; saddened. 
ekonokamu (noun M) a grain ripening towards dry season, July-October; (formerly) a variety of sorghum, planted late and ripening in the dry season (kamu). 
ekontrakt (plural ikontraktin) (noun M) a contract; a business deal. ejaiki eong edistrikt ekontrakt loka aiduk isomeroi: the district has awarded me a contract to build schools.
ekontrakta (plural ikontraktan) (noun M) a contractor; a supplier; a service provider.
ekonyelet (plural ikonyelen) (noun M) a dung-rolling beetle. 
ekonyokoit (singular noun M) a traditional ceremony (especially in Katakwi) of having a breastfeeding mother start eating beef with bone, and involves the killing of a bull supplied by the woman’s parents for the purpose, drinking of ajon, etc. (note: a breastfeeding woman is supposed to abstain from beef and vegetables cooked with amakadi or abalang - salt ash - in favour of offals such as small intestines and vegetables like emalakang that stimulate lactation). cp. aikony abalang, aipudun ikoku.
ekonyukoit (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis turgida. 
ekoodakita (plural ikoodakitan) (noun M) a conductor; a man who collects fares from passengers on a bus, taxi, etc. cp. akoodakita. 
ekoodo (plural ikoodoi) (noun M) a door latch; a hook and eye; a press-stud. 
ekoodot (plural ikoodon) (noun F) an armed robber; a burglar; a bandit; a thug. 
ekoona (plural ikoonai) (noun M) a corner; an angle; a road junction or curvature.
ekoosi (plural ikoosin) (noun M) a training course, curriculum, lessons, or classes. 
ekooti1 (plural ikootin) (noun M) a coat. cp. elou; ekabut: a mackintosh; a raincoat. 
ekooti2 (plural ikootin) (noun M) a law court; a magistrate’s court. cp. adieket. 
ekopi (plural ikopin) (noun M) a copy – reproduction, duplicate, replica, facsimile, print, carbon copy, photocopy, or a fake. 
ekopiton (plural ikopitona) (noun M) a tree whose bark is used for fibre, Dombeya goetzenii. 
ekor (plural ikoria) (noun M) a species of animal – honey bear or ant-eater. 
Ekoraan (plural Ikoraanin) (noun M) the Quran or Koran; the holy bookof the Muslims. cp. Ebaibuli.
ekore (plural ikorwa) (noun M) a bush which if cut is believed to bring drought (no rain for long), Gardinia jovistonantis. 
ekori1 (noun M) stinginess; miserliness. cp. emwane, ebit. 
ekori2 (plural ikorio) (noun M) a giraffe, Giraffa camelopardalis rothchildi; an okapi, Okapia johnstoni. isilo luka ekori (noun M) armlet made of hair of giraffe’s tail or hair from the tail of any animal. 
ekori3 (plural ikorio) (noun M) a line or a row of houses, plots, etc; a tail (of animal or of birds); buttocks; the stern of a boat. cp. ekorobe
ekori4 (plural ikorio) (noun M) a tail-like piece of land left uncultivated in the midst of a cultivation. cp. ekorobe
ekori5 k’ekingok (noun M) a grass whose leaves are eaten to prevent cough, Setaria pallidifusca; Pennicetum polystachion. 
ekori6 k’ekunyuk (noun M) a grass used as a broom, Eragrostis. 
ekori7 k’eris (noun M) a grass (literally, a leopard’s tail), Setaria. 
ekori8 k’eris (plural ikorio k’irisai) (noun M) an insect like a bee that eats flies (literally, a leopard’s tail), Aristida ascensionis. 
ekorikitoi (plural ikorikito) (noun M) a giant rat that has a strange smell, Cricetonia gambianus. cp. imokol. 
ekorikojwiny (plural ikoriokojwiny) (noun M) a bird with a long tail - a male weaver bird; widow-bird; a paradise fly-catcher (a polygamous bird) whose meat (used as a love potion) is believed to give a boy who eats it powers to attract many girls. 
ekorobe1 (plural ikoroben) (noun M) a line of plots (to be cultivated); a street. ekorobe loka itogoi: a line of houses or people; a street. cp. ekori
ekorobe2 (plural ikoroben) (noun M) Indian file; a line. 
ekorobwong (plural ikorobwongo) (noun M) an edible vegetable plant, Oxygonum atriplicifolium. 
ekoroi1 (plural ikorwa) (noun M) a male goat; a billy-goat; a he-goat. 
ekoroi2 (plural ikorwa) (noun M) a straggling shrub, Harrisonia abysinica, used for drying the afterbirth of animals (the afterbirth was formerly dried on that bush, smoked and eaten). 
ekorok (plural ikoroka) (noun M) a corruption of ekuruk: a pied crow. cp. ekuruk, agak. 
ekoroko (plural ikorokoi) (noun M) a reed granary; (figurative) a prison. cp. etuja. 
ekorokonyit (plural ikorokonyita) (noun M) slime; goo; gloop; gunk. cp. eorokonyit
ekorokote (plural ikorokoten) (noun M) a bush or creeper, Capparia. cp. ekorote; erokorokotoi. 
ekoromait (plural ikoroma) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a tree in the acacia family, Acacia seyal. 
ekoromit (plural ikorom) (noun M) a root of a waterlily; a waterlily; a floating yellow waterlily flower. inyo bo ingiitor ijo bala ikonyit ikorom?: why the display of teeth (anger) as if you have bitten the waterlily (said to be very bitter)?
ekoropot (singular noun M) a creeping weed whose leaves are used as flavouring for certain vegetables, Commelina beniniense. 
ekorote (plural ikorotei) (noun M) a creeping shrub, Capparis. cp. ekorokote. 
ekorubang (plural ikorubanga) (noun M) an owl with no ear-like feathers; a barn owl. cp. etukuri okitom: an owl with ear-like feathers.
ekoruny (plural ikorunya) (noun M) an ankle. cp. ekuuruny.
ekos (adjective) immense; huge; gigantic. erai etom etyang ekos: an elephant is a huge animal.
ekosile (noun M) a grass whose root extract is a treatment for sore throat or to stimulate the expulsion of the placenta (afterbirth) in women, Eragrostis aspera. 
ekosimabu (noun M) a grass, Chloris. 
ekosio (plural ikosiosinei) (noun M) a song; a chant; a hymn; a tune; a dance, bop, or boogie. 
ekosobwan (plural ikosobwa) (noun M) a buffalo, Syncerus caffer. 
ekotono (plural ekotoko) (adjective) loving; affable. eong papa kon loakotono: I am your loving father. ngesi aberu kon naekotono: she is your loving wife. 
ekotonoro (adjective) (of people) congenial, friendly, affable, amiable, pleasant, agreeable, good-natured, or hospitable. 
ekotot (plural ikoton) (noun M) beloved; darling; dear. eong akoku kon naminat: I am your beloved daughter. cp. eminat
ekristayone (noun M) Christianity. 
ekristayot (plural ikristayon) (noun M) a Christian man. 
eku (adverb) (in doing something) slowly; sluggishly; indolently. ipoi ijo ikoninyamat eku: you are late (you have been long in cooking your food). ilosi ijo eku: you walk slowly. iswamai ijo eku: you delay in your working.
ekube (plural ikubei) (noun M) a small eagle that hunts reptiles and can stay in the same spot in the air (by flapping its wings) while taking aim; a mouse buzzard. cp. ewoc. 
ekubui (plural ikubuwo) (noun M) a tree with edible fruits, Ficus tonningii. 
akubui (noun F) a leaf or branch of ekubui tree. 
ekucoi (plural ikuco) (noun M) a corruption of ekicoi: a seasonal well, a waterhole, a burrow. 
ekude (singular noun M) animosity; hostility; hatred; loathing; ill-feeling; ill-will; enmity; bitterness; acrimony. 
ekudep (plural ikudepa) (noun M) a shrub, Teclea nobilis. Its leaves and roots are medicinal, while the sticks are used for firewood.
ekudokina (adjective) (as of cloth, road, rope, stick, etc) bent; crooked; folded. 
ekudulinga (plural ikudulingai) (noun M) a big caterpillar. 
ekuetete (plural ikueteten) (noun M) froth; foam (of milk, soap or anything); suds. 
ekugulu (plural ikugulun) (noun M) a chequered woman’s dress, i.e. a dress having alternating patterns of squares or colours. 
ekuje (singular noun M) (euphemism) menstruation. edeka aberu ekuje: the woman is menstruating. cp. ejai kuju, ejai olap, aibam. 
ekujukuju (singular noun M) (formerly) a kind of tobacco used by Banyankole herdsmen in Teso. 
ekuku (plural ikukui) (noun M) a species of bird, Lourie. 
ekukujo (plural ikukujoi) (noun M) traditionally rolled tobacco (for smoking). cp. etaba.
ekukuny (adjective) (of food) smell nice, pleasant, or enjoyable. akiring na ekukuny: this meat smells nice. 
ekukurana (plural ekukuraka) (adjective) busy; industrious; hard working; zealous; diligent; active. 
ekukurut (plural ikukur) (noun M) a black-biting ant. adeka naka ikukur: pimples caused by the bite of black biting ants. cp. esukukurut. 
ekukut1 (plural ikuk) (noun M) a tree stump; a broom stump. 
ekukut2 (plural ikukut) (noun M) a footprint of man or animal. aibwapar ikukut: to follow footprints. 
ekukuye (plural ikukuyen) (noun M) sternum. 
ekukwai (plural ikukwa) (noun M) a thorn; a spine; a prickle. 
ekulaac (plural ikulacin) (noun M) a clutch (a foot pedal of some cars that enables the driver to change gears). 
ekulac (plural ikulaca) (noun M) a creeping plant used as medicine against ticks, Strychnos innocua,. 
ekulam (plural ikulama) (noun M) urine (generally) (of a person or animal). cp. acoto (urine of animals only). ecoe loka ekulam: urinary bladder. 
ekular (plural ikular) (noun M) a bald person; a bald head. cp. ekolor, elarong. 
ekulony (plural ikulonyo) (noun M) a tree in the ekwooro and ekimeng family with smooth leaves and stems, Combretum collinum. Its root extract stops diarrhoea and vomiting, while the cut branches are used in fencing and building (atek); (euphemism) traditional or traditional medicine (herbs and roots, as administered by traditional medicine men). cp. ekia: medicine (in general), a drug; ekomyo: poison (as used by witches).
ekulu (plural ikulun) (noun M) a jungle; high grass. cp. aisu. 
ekulukulu (plural ikulukulun) (noun M) a fish eagle; a turkey. ainyam ekulukulu: to eat without working for the food; to tramp about. enyami ngesi ekulukulu: she/he lives on the dole: she/he lives doing nothing. cp. enyamuret 
ekuluurut (plural ikuluurun) (noun M) an open wound on the toe (due to knocking against a stone, etc). 
ekum (plural ikumio) (noun M) an evergreen African ebony tree, Diospyros mespiliformis. Its wood is good for drum-making since it is fungus and termite resistant; fruit is edible, the bark and roots are medicinal.
ekuma (plural ikumai) (noun M) a cow-bell made of wood; an all-day dance without drums. cp. ebar.
Ekumamait (plural Ikumama) (noun M) an Etesot man, so called by the Karimojong; a Kumam man (native of Kaberamaido district) who speaks a language akin to Luo and Ateso. 
ekumare (plural ikumaren) (noun M) a plant with edible leaves, Cassia tora. cp. eodo, elekumare
ekume (plural ikumes) (noun M) the nose; a road culvert; nostrils; mucous of nose; the front of a boat; a bridge. eyiete eong ikumes: I am bleeding through the nose. ekume kitaok (noun M) a vegetable; (euphemism) butter or ghee (literally, a calf’s nose or a calf’s mucous). ekume kamerekek (noun M) a kind of mushroom (literally, a sheep’s mucous). ikumes katitipu (plural noun M) ‘nostrils’ (air-holes) of an anthill. ekume lokodos: an aquiline (or hooked) nose. ekume lobarany: a big flat nose (of a person). ekume locugur: a bent or curved nose. ekume k’auno: a noose. ekume lobatang (noun M) a snub nose. 
ekumege (plural ikumegei) (noun M) a tree, Craibia laurentii. 
ekuna (plural ikunai) (noun M) ordinary mist; light fog; haze. emuna: very thick mist or fog that greatly interferes with vision. ikunaikit akwap: it is foggy, misty, hazy. cp. elisina.
ekungin (plural ikungin) (noun M) a weed, Brachiaria comata, Digitaria velutina urochooa panicoides. 
ekungur (plural ikunguro) (noun M) a shea-butter tree, Butyrospermum paradoxum subsp. niloticum.Used for timber and carving stools, high-quality charcoal; sheanut butter is extracted from roasted and pounded seeds mixed with water and boiled, and the fruit is edible when ripe. cp. edu
ekungut (plural ikungun) (noun M) a boy child conceived without the mother having had menstruation – such a man is believed to have powers to spy on the enemy without being found out. 
ekunia (plural ikuniai) (noun M) a poisonous medicine; a charm; a spell. emun loikuniai: a poisonous snake. abu ekunia kopia ikatunga: a charm or a poison killed all my people. 
ekunyuk1 (noun M) a grass, Chloris. 
ekunyuk2 (plural ikunyuko) (noun M) a ground squirrel, Xerus inauris. cp. eles: a tree squirrel.
ekuolong (plural ikuolonga) (noun M) the Uganda brown parrot. cp. egili
ekupa (plural ikupai) (noun M) (formerly) cloth worn by old people. 
ekupup (adjective) (of a person or an object) stubby; short, strong (of a stick or handle of a hoe). amusenu naekupup: a strong short handle of a hoe. ebela loekupup: a strong short stick.
ekupuulu (plural ikupuulun) (noun M) a lock; a padlock. 
ekuran (plural ikurak) (noun M) a prickly shrub, Ptero lobium lacerans. 
ekurara (noun M) yaws; syphilis. ekurara lourunet: congenital syphilis. 
ekuraut (plural ikuraun) (noun M) a tree growing near lakes, Acacia pennata. 
ekure (plural ikurei) (noun M) a legendary plant, believed to stop rain from falling if touched by a person; a very long drought; a famine. ecai lolo ekure: there is a big drought these days. ejai ekure toma akwap: there is famine. cp. ebeli, ekore. 
ekuret1 (plural ikureta) (noun M) a large fishing hook. cp. egolu
ekuret2 lokapesur (noun M) the girls’ part in a mixed dance called edonga, the boys’ part is called eiruk. cp. eidim, eidimone. 
ekuriei (plural ikuriesik) (noun M) a timid man; a coward; a backslider. 
ekuron (plural ikurono) (noun M) ash (remains of a wood fire). cp. ekurwon, ekuroba
ekuruba (plural ikuruban) (noun M) a bog on fire; smouldering ashes after burning swamp grass; a heap of ashes. kidupok acokit okuruba: cast that potato into the heap of hot ashes. cp. eupa.
ekuruk1 (plural ikuruka) (noun M) (slang) an Anglican pastor (because of the white collar).
ekuruk2 (plural ikuruka) (noun M) a pied crow (a bird in the raven family, but with a white ring of feathers on its neck); Cormorant. inyo kolo kisisianakini oni ainap ataayi? ekuruk: (a riddle) what taught us to wear a necktie? a pied-crow.
ekurukuru (noun M) an edible root. 
ekurungat (plural ikurungan) (noun M) an anklet. 
ekurunyon (plural ikurunyok) (noun M) a man who melts lard for use in cooking. 
ekurupeta (plural ikurupeta) (noun M) a 5-centimetre knife worn on the thumb for harvesting millet. cp. emakaut. 
ekurut1 (plural ikur) (noun M) a worm; a caterpillar; a maggot; a bacterium; a small insect; a virus; a germ. ededeng ekurut loka esilim: HIV is very fatal.
ekurut2 (plural ikur) (noun M) an eagle coloured like a guinea-fowl. cp. edulagol. 
ekurwokina (adjective) futile; in vain; impossible; unworkable. alosite kus erai naekurwokina: your journey is futile, in vain. ekurwokina akirot ngin aiirar: that is a mystery. 
ekus (plural ikusya) (noun M) a pin; a needle; a point of spear; a prickle; axle (of the earth). cp. emutu. 
ekusai (noun M) naughtiness; cheek. ejai ijo ekusai: you are cheeky(you have cheek). cp. elol.
ekuse (adjective) (of meat) lean; bony; wiry; sinewy. cp. etaryono: fatty.
ekusu (plural ikusui) (noun M) a parrot. cp. egili, ekuolong 
ekutelek (singular noun M) armyworms (very destructive caterpillar pest of finger millet crop or grass). 
ekutukana (plural ekutukaka) (adjective) (of a person) hot-tempered; rude; quarrelsome; harsh; unruly; strict. 
ekutukong (plural ikutukong) (noun M) an ant-bear; aardvark, Orycteropus afer. 
ekutukwap (plural ikutukwapa) (noun M) a short poisonous burrowing snake. 
ekutur (plural ikutur) (noun M) a dwarf. cp. ekupup. 
ekuukuut (plural ikuukuun) (noun M) a red and black bird living in swamps and makes such sound as it perches on a tree. cp. igogot. 
ekuulit (singular noun M) snuff; (formerly) tobacco used by Karimojong, Nandi, Kipsigis, Masai, or Kikuyu. 
ekuulu (plural ikuului) (noun M) an ostrich, Struthio camelus (the female ostrich is called aula, the male is otiira). 
ekuuruny (plural ikuurunya) (noun M) the ankle. 
ekuurunyit (plural ikuurunya) (noun M) the ankle. cp. ekuuruny. 
ekuwam1 (adjective) (of face) rough (like unshaven); (of body) rough (like crocodile, lizard, etc. skin) cp. engenge, ekwatam.
ekuwam2 (plural ikuwam) (noun M) a rough bodied person or animal. 
ekuwe (plural ikuwei) (noun M) a fox; a black-backed jackal, Canis mesomelas. cp. ekwee, ekue
ekuyo (plural ikuyoi) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) the game of cricket. cp. eidiko, eidilo. 
ekuyum (adjective) (of biscuits) soft; (of dry soil) loose; (of boiled amukeke) soft and floury. 
ekwaaso (plural ikwaason) (noun M) a safety pin. cp. ekus. 
ekwadakwada (plural ikwadakwadan) (noun M) a water-beetle; a crab. 
ekwadoit1 (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet (Eleusin corocona). 
ekwakoit2 (noun M) (formerly) a variety of big-seeded and thick testa maize. cp. eiduma, ekirididi. 
ekwalakwala (plural ikwalakwalan) (noun M) a small evergreen tree, Garcinia buchananii. Its fruit wine is drank, the fruits are edible while the wood is for firewood and building.
ekwalinga (plural ikwalinga) (noun M) whitlow (on finger or sheep’s foot). 
ekwam (plural ikwamin) (noun M) wind, air; measles; smallpox. ikwamin: demons or evil spirits; weather. ekusi ekwam: the wind is blowing; it is windy. adeka naka ekwam: measles or smallpox outbreak. ekamutu apese ngin ikwamin: demons have possessed that girl. ejautene loikwamin: the state of weather (especially, winds).
ekwana (plural ekwaka) (adjective) (of knife, poison, tongue) sharp; keen; acute. ekwana ekileng lo, ekwaka akwaras ngun adepar: this knife is sharp, those spears are sharper. ekwana akituk: quarrelsome
ekwang (plural ekwangak) (adjective) white; pale; ashen. ekwang kia: very white. 
ekwanga1 (plural ikwangai) (noun M) a grey tree associated with cursing, Croton macrostachyus. 
ekwanga2 (plural ikwangai) (noun M) a plant with bright flowers and whose bark is used for fibre, Lachnophylis oppositifolia. 
ekwangal (plural ikwangal) (noun M) a light, thin (not heavy) person. 
ekwangale (noun M) (formerly) a white variety of finger millet. 
ekwangan (plural ekwangak) (noun M) a sailor; a ferry-man; one who takes people across water in a canoe; a marine. 
ekwange (singular noun M) whiteness; white dust (of flour); brightness. elelebun ijo ekwange loka akiria: you are white with dust (after grinding grain or cassava). 
ekwaru (plural ikwarun) (noun M) a serval cat, Felis serval. 
ekwe (plural ikuwei) (noun M) a plant, Calotropis procera. 
ekwecit (plural ikwec) (noun M) the spur of a cock-bird or of a python snake; the arm (arms) of an armchair. eicolong loka ikwec: the armchair. ebela loka ikwec: a forked stick. 
ekwee (plural ikweei) (noun M) (Usuk) a jackal, Canis mesomelas; a fox (believed to portend death in the family when it barks in the vicinity). cp. okejukusa
ekweetete (singular noun M) (Usuk) foam; froth; lather. cp. ekuetete
ekwele (adjective) (of the skin) pale; anaemic. ekwele ngesi (plural ekwele kesi) she/he is (they are) anaemic.
ekweny (plural ikweny) (noun M) a bird; an aircraft or plane. cp. edege.
ekweru (plural ikwerun) (noun M) a kind of bush, root of which is used as medicine; medicine from ekweru bush. korukokinai ekweru kager akuwan: pound the ekweru root for me to incise in my body. 
ekwikwi1 (plural ikwikwiin) (noun M) a kind of mushroom. 
ekwikwi2 (singular noun M) (Usuk) a quiet laugh; asthma. 
ekwiniini (noun M) quinine (drug for malaria). 
ekwinyikwiny (noun M) epilepsy; fits; hysteria. 
ekwooro (plural ikwooron) (noun M) a small tree in the ekimeng and ekulony family, Combretum molle. The root extract is medicine for hookworms, snake bites, stomach-ache, fever, dysentery and leprosy. 
ekyala (plural ikiyal) the hearth; one of the three traditional stones on which a cooking pot rests when on fire; a stove; a tripod. 
elaagano (plural ilaaganoi) (noun M) a competition; a contest. cp. abolet. 
elaanakina (adjective) spaced; having spaces in between. elaanakina epaaba: the cotton is planted apart. 
elabo (plural ilaboi) (noun M) cream (of milk). cp. elago, elibibi. 
elabwata (singular noun M) a method of arresting or catching animals by throwing a rope round the neck or the legs. 
elacac (adjective) loose; untied; unlocked; released; undone. 
elacamuk (plural ilacamuka) (noun M) a large monitor lizard. cp. egereger. 
elacara (adjective) loose; untied; unlocked; released; undone. 
elace (singular noun M) the way or method of loosening, undoing, untying, opening, undressing, etc. 
elacet (plural ilaceta) (noun M) a key; a spanner (of a car, plough, etc). 
elacit (plural ilac) (noun M) a louse (a parasitic insect that lives in dirty clothes and hair). 
elado (plural iladoi) (noun M) an arm-band of zebra tail hair; a fly whisk (switch) made of a zebra’s tail used in certain traditional dances (such as ajosi, ekirakira) as a costume tied above the elbow. 
elagagamit (plural ilagagam) (noun M) the collar-bone; clavicle. 
elagara (noun M) a grass used for thatching and whose root extract is a remedy for measles, Hyparrhenia rufa. 
elago (noun M) a cobweb; fluff; cream (of milk). cp. elibibi, elabo.
elaisi (plural ilaisin) (noun M) an auction sale; a grand sale (prices are low).
elakara (adjective) joyful; happy; glad; cheerful. 
elakas (plural ilakasia) (noun M) a tree of which the branches are used to make a fence. 
elakit (singular noun M) divorce; separation; split of marriage. cp. egirone
elal (plural elalak) (adjective) wide; broad; capacious; spacious; commodious. 
elala (singular noun M) alarm; warning; attention. apupunit eong elala: I heard the alarm. cp. elulu.
elamai (plural ilama) (noun M) a wild-grape fruit shrub or tree, Ximenia americana. Uses: its fruit juice is used to flavour or season atap and vegetables; oil used in lubrication and soap is extracted from its seeds; its sticks are used for fuel and building.
elamit (singular noun M) a curse; a malediction; an anathema. 
elangir (adjective) heavy; thick; difficult; weighty; burdensome; important. elangir epelu lo: this task is hard. elangir akirot na: this is a difficult case. (euphemism) (of a woman) pregnant. aberu naelangir: a pregnant woman. aitalangir: to burden. 
Elangot (plural Ilangoi) (noun M) a Langi tribesman native to Apac or Lira districts of northern Uganda; a common Teso name. cp. emiroit; enyakoit: a man from the north. 
elap (plural ilapyo) (noun M) moon; month. elamu elap: new moon has risen. emaaraniki elap: first quarter. ekesaki elap: the moon is overhead. agonga elap: the moon is leaning to the west (three quarter moon). alumo elap: the moon has set. alosit olap: adeka elap: to have menstruation (literally, to go to the moon: to suffer from the moon). aica naka elap: moonbeam or moonlight. aige elap: to start a new month. atwana elap: the old moon has gone (literally, the moon has died). elap losodit: January; the first month. elap loiyareit: February; the second month. elap lokiuniet: March; the third month. elap loiwongonet: April; the fourth month. elap loikanyet: May; the fifth month. elap loikanyet-kape: June; the sixth month. elap loikanyet-kaare: July; the seventh month. elap loikanyet-kauni: August; the eighth month. elap loikanyet-kaongon: September; the ninth month. elap loitomonet: October; the tenth month. elap loitomonet-kalodiop: November; the eleventh month. elap loitomonet-kaluare: December; the twelfth month.
elapada (noun M) a kind of grass. 
elapat (adjective) clear; open; bare. elapat erot: the road is clear, clean (no weeds, no people on it, no overhang). 
elarilar (plural ilarilarin) (noun M) a common grey lizard, mostly staying on granaries. cp. ebokolinga
elarilari (plural elarilarete) (adjective) bare; clear. 
elaro (plural ilaroik) (noun M) a firmament; the sky; an international airport. 
elarwarwa (plural ilarwarwan) (noun M) a crackling of joints. 
elatiri (plural ilatirin) (noun M) a stone used in weighing scales; pound weight. 
elaunana (plural elaunaka) (adjective) disobedient; obstinate; neurotic. and v.i. 
eleana (plural eleaka) (adjective) fond of beating or caning. 
elebeni (plural ilebenin) (noun M) a spirit-level. cp. erebeni
elebilebiton (plural ilebilebitok) (noun M) a talker, conversationalist, speaker, orator, gossiper, chatterer, raconteur; talkative person. cp. ailabilab, ailebileb. 
elecorai (plural ilecorwa) (noun M) a tree, Crossoptery febrifuga. 
eleget (adjective) (of character) clean; chaste; beautiful; just. 
elejek (plural ilejekas) (adjective) weak; flexible; soft. 
elekede (plural ilekeden) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of big red beans, Phaseolus vulgaris.
elekek (plural ilekekin (noun M) a gourd with a long neck. etwo lolekek: a gourd with a long neck. ikisin lulekekin (plural noun M) breasts with long nipples. 
eleket (plural ileketa) (noun M) mouth of river; bay, inlet. 
eleketete (plural ileketeten) (noun M) a creeping weed whose boiled pounded leaves are used as a disinfectant for livestock and a potion taken by breast-feeding mothers to stimulate the production of more milk, Portulaca sp. 
elekumare (noun M) a vegetable shrub, Acacia sp. cp. eodo. 
elelana (plural elelaka) (adjective) fond of rejoicing; festive; jovial; celebratory; jolly. 
elele1 (adjective) (of food, especially cassava in marshland) watery and likely to cause vomiting. 
elele2 (noun M) a grass whose growth in a place indicates the soil is good for growing crops, and is also a remedy for wounds, Setaria sphacelata. 
elele3 (noun M) a vegetable, Sesamum. cp. alaire. 
elele4 (plural ilelei) (noun M) a white faced tree-duck. cp. egirogiro. 
elele5 (singular noun M) shame; ignominy. cp. ileic. elele ka lo/na: shame upon him/her.
elelebo1 (noun M) a creeping clover. 
elelebo2 (singular noun M) a corruption of elelebwa: dizziness; vertigo. cp. elelebwa. 
elelebwa (singular noun M) epilepsy; dizziness. cp. ipumu 
elelei (plural eleleete) (adjective) effluent; flowing; loose, not fitting. 
elelekeja (singular noun M) a rain-dance. 
eleleku (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis superba. 
elelemit (plural ilelem) (noun M) (Usuk) a tadpole or larvae (in the water). cp. elemelemet.
eleli1 (plural elelete) (adjective) blithe; merry; happy-go-lucky; amiable; happy. 
eleli2 (plural ilelio) (noun M) a striped mouse, Rhabdomys pumilio (a dormouse – believed to portend a beer party if it crosses one’s path). 
elem (plural ilemwo) (noun M) a bull, goat, etc without horns. lolem M, nalem F (plural ilemwoik) (adjective) hornless. emong lolem (plural imongin lulemwoik) hornless bull(s). 
elemana (plural elemaka) (adjective) quick at, fond of picking or removing or stealing. 
elemelemet (plural ilemelem) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a tadpole or larvae (in the water). cp. elelemit.
elemet (plural ilemei, ilemia) (noun M) allergic swellings caused by eating pork, ham or bacon when one has yaws. cp. ikasongon. 
elemuni (adverb) perhaps. elemuni alot: perhaps she/he/it has gone. cp. motoko.
elemunyang (plural ilemunyanga) (noun M) a legendary sickness or disease of dogs; a stye in the eye. cp. emaala (they make a dog lick to cure it). 
elemura (plural ilemurai) (noun M) the only child (male) born to a woman. cp. enume. 
elemurang (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum grown in the hot season. cp. ekonokamu. 
elemut (plural ilem) (noun M) (Usuk) a sheanut - the seed of ekungur; a kernel or seed of a fruit. cp. edanyot. 
elemwoono (plural elemwooko) (adjective) (of an animal) hornless.
elepa (singular noun M) impudence; cheekiness; nonsense. koyanga ekonilepa ngina: go away, you impudent fellow! (literally, take your impudence away).
elepit1 (noun M) a bush, Mimusops fragrans. 
elepit2 (plural ilepito) (noun M) a milking pail or jug. akile elepio k’elepit: milk is milked into a milk pot or pail. cp. eiciret. 
elepo (plural ilepoi) (noun M) a gerbil or desert rat; a rat burrowing in the sand, Taterillus emini. 
elepulepu (plural ilepulepun) (noun M) an evergreen hardwood tree, Mimusops kummel. Its fruits (alepulepwo) are edible, and the wood is for timber and charcoal.
elepunoit (plural ilepunoi) (noun M) a boil. cp. ailipilipun. 
eles (plural ilesia) (noun M) a tree or sun-squirrel, Heliosciurus cepapi. cp. ekunyuk: ground squirrel.
elet1 (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis. 
elet2 (plural iletio) (noun M) a grassy plain along a river. 
eleuleu (plural ileuleun) (noun M) a tree growing in swamps, Melia azederach. 
eleuleut (noun M) a water-lily, Gloriosa variifolia. 
eli (plural iliyan) (noun M) a large pot, with a fairly narrow neck, in which beer is mixed and left to ferment for a few days; a large beer brewing pot. 
eliagam (plural iliagam) (noun M) a tall man; a high tree, etc. iliagam ekitoi ngol: that tree is very tall. 
elibaana (plural elibaaka) (adjective) green; emerald; lime; jade; olive; verdant. 
elibibi (plural ilibibin) (noun M) milk cream. cp. elago, elabo. 
elibit (plural elibito) (adjective) verdant; lush; leafy; grassy. 
elicerai (plural ilicera) (noun M) a tree used for building poles, Crossopteryx febrifuga. 
elidaana (plural elidaaka) (adjective) (of a person or rubber band) holding tight; relentless; revengeful, vindictive.
elidana (plural elidaka) (adjective) (of a glutton) picking big morsels of food; greedy.
elidio (adjective) unripe; premature; very young, fresh, raw. elidio acok: the potatoes are premature. 
eligim (qualitative verb) to be distended (of belly, on account of pregnancy or food). akoik naligim: akoik nailigimim: a distended stomach. 
eligoi (plural iligo) (noun M) a bush used for hedges, Euphorbia tirucalli; a gum tree with white latex. 
eliibo (plural iliiboi) (noun M) a graveyard; a cemetery; a funeral home. cp. ates. 
eliiro (plural iliiron) (noun M) a kingfisher bird. 
elikidi1 (singular noun M) green grams (the plant or its seeds). cp. ecoroko
elikidi2 (plural ilikidin) (noun M) a greedy person; one who eats alone; a stingy or mean person; close-fisted person. cp. lok’ebit, lok’etau, lok’emwane. 
elikot (plural ilikoi) (noun M) a small fishing hook. cp. egolu, edoobo.
elilat (plural ililai) (noun M) a blind worm. cp. amurumuron. 
elilim (adjective) cool; cold; clammy; chilly. elilim akwap: it is cold. akoto akipi nuelilim: I want cold water. elilim cii ci: very cold; cool. elilim akuwan: to have no go, laid-back. elilim ngesi akuwan: she/he has no go in her/him. 
elilingan (plural elilingak) (noun M) one who has the habit of keeping silent; a taciturn or introverted man. 
elilot1 (noun M) a sesamum plant, Sesamum spp. 
elilot2 (noun M) sauce made from groundnuts paste and elilot plant. 
elilyo (plural ililyo) (noun M) a tree fibres of which are used for tying, Securidaca longipedunculata. cp. elilio
elilyoi (plural ililyo) (noun M) a shrub, Securidaca longipendunculata. Among its many uses are: the leaves are antidotes for snake bite and a cough mixture, powdered bark is an abortifacient, the root infusion is for tooth-ache, the roots are for soap, the seeds and flowers are for oil production, while the wood is used for firewood and poles. 
elimilim (singular noun M) a drizzle; drops of rain; a little rain. 
elingaana (plural elingaaka) (adjective) marked black and white or red and white. 
elinget (plural ilingeta) a mark; a sign of anything, water or milk; a water mark; a boundary or limit in graduated instrument. 
elingo (adjective) (of quality of cooking atap) bad, poor or unprofessional. ipoete kesi elingo: they cook badly; they do not allow water for mingling bread to boil, or they over-boil it. cp. epule. 
eliodo (plural iliodon) (noun M) a small brown hornbill that nests in tree-holes. cp. emyede. 
eliogot (adjective) clean; pure; immaculate; holy; perfectly clean. Edeke ngesi emoyo loliogot: God is a holy or perfect spirit. 
eliokine (plural iliokinei) (noun M) a plant with plenty of sap, Lactuca capensis. 
elipilepo (plural ilipilepon) (noun M) a small tree, Sapium ellipticum. Its roots and leaves are medicine for mumps, and the wood is for firewood and charcoal.
elipongait (plural iliponga) (noun M) a black stinging ant (believed to prefer biting genitals). 
elir (plural iliria) (noun M) a deaf man; a hearing-impaired male; a very stupid man. elir kapugan: a prize fool (literally, a government fool); a scapegoat. cp. ekiming.
elira1 (plural ilirai) (noun M) a small tree mostly grown in homesteads as a source of timber, Melia azedarach. Its seeds are poisonous and the leaf effusion is used as insecticide on vegetable gardens. elira lomoit: a neem tree, Azadirachta indica. The bark of a neem tree is medicinal, the root system keeps termites away, while the powdered leaves contain azadirachtin used as a fumigant/ insecticide for grain weevils.
elira2 (singular noun M) rinderpest. cp. esotoka, ekodoi.
eliri (noun M) silk. enapit amucaalat egoe loliri: the lady is wearing a silk dress.
elirira (plural ilirirai) (noun M) a deaf mute; a deaf and dumb man. 
elisina1 (plural ilisinai) (noun M) excessive wealth (in cattle). ejai ngesi elisina epol: she/he is rich in cattle. cp. abar, amio.
elisina2 (singular noun M) fog; mist. cp. ekuna. 
elisipata (plural ilisipatan) (noun M) a small Spanish horse, Genetta stuhlmanni. 
elit (plural ilitia) (noun M) a parasitic plant - mistletoe - Loranthus; an amulet; witchcraft (in general). elit etasuro: an amulet worn to frighten or terrorise an opponent. elit emakak: an amulet worn to immobilise or paralyse an opponent. elit edusutau: elit eramatau: a charm for causing someone to love you; a love potion.
elitoto (plural ilitotoi) (noun M) a variety of simsim grain used for oil extraction. 
eloa1 (singular noun M) a fungal infestation of the skin, Tinea versicolor; ringworms; a skin disease or ringworm of adult people, cattle and other animals. cp. etapa
eloa2 (plural ilowai) (noun M) a false muvule  or false iroko tree, Antiaris toxicaria. It's a hard wood tree for timber, the root and leaf extract are used as medicine for mental illnesses.
eloba (plural ilobai) (noun M) a hartebeest (a species of antelope), Tragelaphus oryx. 
elodot (plural ilodoi) (noun M) (Usuk) reeds, withes or osier twigs used as horizontal rafters to tie grass thatch or roof of traditional huts. cp. edolot. 
elogec (plural ilogecas) (adjective) bandy-legged; bow-legged. 
elogook (plural ilogooka) (noun M) a tree, Acalypha villicante. 
elogoroto (plural ilogorotoi) (noun M) Adam’s apple; the slight lump, part of the thyroid gland, that projects from the front of a man’s neck. 
eloit (plural iloin) (noun M) a peg; a tether (to measure a house or to tie an animal). eloit lokaswam: occupation. kiyenikina iso oloit lokaswam: we are tied down by duty. kiyenikitai iso toma oloit loka aitumunet: we are bound by our promise. 
Eloket1 (plural Iloke) (noun M) (an Ateso derogative reference to) a Karimojong tribesman (especially a cattle rustler or raider). 
eloket2 (plural iloketa) (noun M) a Karimojong headdress or hair ornament. 
elokile (noun M) a plant whose root is used as a purgative as well as an emetic, Sonchus bipontini. cp. ekile
elokit (plural ilokito) (noun M) a trap; a snare (for a person, to catch somebody); a ball joint. elokit loka etul: a pelvic joint.
elokomacar (plural ilokomacarin) (noun M) the dorsum or root of the penis; the hinge of the penis. 
elolom (adjective) (of a borehole or well) having few people; empty; vacant; unfilled; free. elolom lolo ecor, mam itunga emariaete akipi: the borehole is free today, people are not struggling to fetch water.
elomabon (singular noun M) (in Karamoja) a cassava tuber or plant (literally, that which grows by itself). cp. emuogo.
elomet (plural ilometa) (noun M) entrance; exit; a club or spear (a thing to enter or come out at night with). alomet (for feminine things). 
elomocor (plural ilomocoria) (noun M) a penis of a big animal, such as a he-goat or a bull. 
elomorut (plural ilomor) (noun M) a trap or knot. 
elongot (plural ilongoi) (noun M) a (man’s or dog’s) penis. 
elongwaana (plural elongwaaka) (adjective) (of a person) idle; lazy. 
elongwaut (plural ilongwau) (noun M) one who is from outside the clan; a stranger; an alien. cp. emoit.
elono (noun M) a desert rose, Adenium globesum. A very poisonous shrub whose latex and root extract is medicine for boils and venereal diseases, the sap as arrow poison, and pounded roots are fish poison and rat bait.
elooji (plural iloojin) (noun M) a lodge; an inn.
eloon (plural iloonin) (noun M) a loan; a financial advance; credit. 
eloori (plural iloorin) (noun M) a lorry; a truck. 
elooro (plural ilooroi) (noun M) a tertiary syphilis causing enlargement of groin, Alopecia. cp. etaala. 
elopane (noun M) accusation; blaming; finger pointing.
elope1 (plural ikulepek M) (adverb) by himself; alone; the very one. iboyie ngesi elope bon: he lives by himself. ijo elope: you yourself. ngesi ejakait elope: he is the chief himself (no other person).
elope2 (plural ikulepek) (noun M) the owner. elope akwap: a male native or inhabitant of a region or country. eong elope akituk: I am the owner of the cows. ilope (neuter): the owner (general). cp. papa.
elopodo (plural ilopodoi) (noun M) a species of tilapia fish with a wide mouth. 
elore (plural ilorei) (noun M) a beam of light of the sun, moon, etc.; a dazzle. 
elos (plural ilosio) (noun M) dirt; filth (as in finger nails); dirt on body; a personal smell. erono ekonilos: you are hated or you are unfortunate (literally, your smell is bad).
elose (singular noun M) a gait; a way of walking; a mode of transport.
elotot (plural ilotoi) (noun M) an edible burrowing rat. cp. edoomelu.
elou (plural ilowi) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a coat (worn by women); (formerly) an animal-skin shawl worn over one shoulder. cp. ebasikooti
elout (plural ilowun) (noun M) poverty. kekamutu eong ilowun: I have become poor. cp. ican, ibakor.
eluatat (plural eluatak) (noun M) one who urinates (in bed or anywhere) often. 
elubooni (plural iluboonin) (noun M) an earnest, i.e. a part-payment made in advance, especially to confirm an agreement; an advance, i.e. money paid to someone before payment is due; a deposit. 
elucat (plural iluca) (noun M) an amulet or talisman used superstitiously to prevent death of children. 
eluera (plural ilueran) (noun M) whooping cough; bronchitis; disease of the chest or lungs. cp. elweera.
Eluga (plural Ilugai) (noun M) an Indian man. 
elugum (adjective) (of the belly, etc) round, blown out. 
elugura (plural eluguras) (adjective) sitting down with a bent back; stooping; hunched; arched. eluguras ilugai k’okekiakec: the Indians sit down at their door with bent backs. 
Elugwaarat (plural Ilugwaara) (noun M) a Lugbara tribesman; a man native to Arua district. Ilugwaara: the Lugbara people of West Nile in Uganda.
elujuk (adjective) flexible; supple; soft; weak, not strong; lithe. auno naalujuk: a flexible rope. elujuk isapat ngin: that little boy is not strong. 
eluk (plural ilukio) (noun M) adultery. aikamun etunganan eluk: to catch a person in adultery. alemun eluk: aigel eluk: to pay fine for adultery. aswam nuk’eluk: to commit adultery. ikamunitai ngesi eluk: he (she) was caught in adultery. abu ngesi kogel eluk: she/he paid fine for adultery. cp. ekingol.
eluke (plural ilukei) (noun M) a fast-flying green pigeon. 
elukumit (plural ilukumin) (noun M) a thousand. ilukumin ka ilukumin: thousands upon thousands cp. arita. 
elulu (noun M) an alarm cry; hue and cry; warning. epurie elulu kokide, apotu Ilok: the alarm is sounding from the east, the Karimojong raiders have come. 
elumang (adjective) (of a person) stupid; dull; (of an animal) hornless. cp. iluumum. 
elungung (adjective) objectionable; repulsive; detestable; hateful; disgusting. 
elupe (noun M) clay for bricks or pottery. 
elure (plural ilurei) (noun M) a wild cat. cp. atawoi, atukunyu. 
elurun (plural elurunos) (adjective) haggard; drooping; sagging; fatigued; very weak. abu kadum nges iluruna: I found her/him exhausted. 
elutaari (plural ilutaarin) (noun M) an altar; a shrine. cp. abila
eluube (plural iluubei) (noun M) flu (especially chicken flu); fever; a plague (especially coccidiosis in chicken). 
eluurut1 (plural iluurun) (noun M) a tree insect - a cicada.
Eluurut2 (plural Iluurun) (noun M) an Alur tribesman from the district of Nebbi and speaking a Luo dialect called Alur. Iluurun: the Alur people in general.
eluwe (adverb) (to swallow) whole; intact; complete (without masticating or chewing). ailik eluwe: to swallow like a dog; to gulp down solid food. 
eluworo (adjective) desperate; anxious; treacherous; changed. 
elwala (plural ilwalai) (noun M) an olive baboon (a maize pest), Papio cynocephalus. cp. ecom
elwana (plural elwaka) (adjective) far; distant. elwana akwap: it is far. cp. eoja akwap. 
elwanalwanakina (adjective) far apart; sparse; thinly populated (of a country). itunga luelwanalwanakina: people who live far apart. erai Moroto akwap naelwanalwanakina ireria: Moroto district is a place where homes are far apart. 
elwanalwanat (plural elwakalwakatos) (adverb) rather far; not very far; rather soon. ebuni ngesi, konye eroko ber apak elwanalwanat: she/he is coming but not very soon. 
elwanikina (adjective) aloof; unfriendly; distant; far off. 
elwata (noun M) a plant whose leaves are used as seasoning for ecadoi, eodo, and emoros, Erythrococoa kirkii. 
elweera (noun M) whooping cough; pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) - disease of the lungs with coughing; bronchitis. aingalakin etunganan elweera: to give somebody poison that causes bronchitis. cp. epaganga, egorigor
