elyana (plural elyaka) (adjective) fresh or raw smelling; smelling as of fresh milk, fish, or a newly born baby. ilyana ijo akile: you smell after fresh milk. ilyaka yesi agaria: you smell after fresh fish. elyaka akile ngun: the milk has a fresh (newly milked) smell.
elyokono (plural elyokoko) (adjective) deceitful; deceiving; lying; false-hearted. etunganan loelyokono: a deceitful man. 
ema (noun M) a ritual grass, Hyperrhenia themadra. It's used for building mock huts in swamps that are burnt during the purification ceremony for those who have committed incest. aicwe ema: to perform a purification ceremony for those who have committed incest (sexual intercourse between close relatives - considered wizardry in Teso culture).
emaabo (noun M) a kind of shrub used in the twin dances; a creeping plant. 
emaagalo (plural imaagaloi) (noun M) pincers; a pair of pliers; forceps. 
emaagira (singular noun M) crushed peas cooked in the magadi salt and fried groundnut paste mixed with it – best eaten with fresh cooked sweet potatoes. 
emaala1 (plural imaalai) (noun M) a dog tick.
emaala2 (plural imaalai) (noun M) a stye (a small swelling on the base of the eyelid). cp. elemunyang, etotile
emaali (singular noun M) income; property wealth; revenue. ejokuna aur da, ikonikoku eyauni emaali ore: it is also good to bear (and educate) children, they are a source of wealth to the home.
emaara (plural imaarai) (noun M) a huge strong bull; a male buck or deer (Uganda kob); a very strong man. 
emaaridi (plural imaaridin) (noun M) a nickname for Crested Crane brand of cigarettes, because of its aroma that lingers on the smoker’s path. 
emaaset (plural emaase) (noun M) a locust. ebunit emaase epol noi: there is a big swarm of locusts coming. cp. esenene.
emabaleo (plural imabaleon) (noun M) a fashion; a craze; a fad. 
emabuusut (plural imabuusun) (noun M) a prisoner; a detainee; an inmate; a jailbird; a convict. cp. eenat; loeenen. 
emabwor (plural imabworin) (noun M) a red patas monkey, Erythrocebus patas. cp. elwala, engabwor.
emacar1 (plural imacarin) (noun M) (Usuk) a fishing spear. cp. akwara
emacar2 (plural imacarin) (noun M) a brand on the body caused by beating or fire; a lash. 
emacaret (noun M) a kind of grass; a tool for beating, drawing, tattooing, branding, etc. 
emadak (noun M) a bush, Annona chrysopholla. 
emadangit (plural imadang) (noun M) a tick; a mite. cp. etularut. 
emaderait (noun M) (formerly) a purple variety of sweet potatoes (popular in Madera in Soroti district). 
Emadit (plural Imadi) (noun M) a small stumpy man; a dwarf; a Madi tribeman; a man native to Moyo or Adjumani districts on the north-western tip of Uganda. Imadi: the Madi people in general.
emadoit (plural imadoi) (noun M) an armlet or wristlet. 
emaekeke (plural imaekeken) (noun M) pyorrhoea or dental caries (a disease that loosens teeth and swells gums). 
emaet (plural imaeta) (adjective) (of a name) pertaining to flattery or praise. ekiror lomaet: a nickname; a pet name. 
Emagarait (plural Imagara) (noun M) a man native of Busoga or Bugwere; a Musoga or Mugwere tribesman. Imagara: Basoga, Bagwere people. cp. Emusogat: a Musoga tribesman.
emagegerit (plural imageger) (noun M) a hoof (of a grass-eating animal); a claw. cp. emolokony
emago (plural imagoi) (noun M) the work done for wages or beer. 
emagorot (plural imagoron, imagoroi) (noun M) a wild sheep or goat. 
emaido (plural imaidon) (noun M) groundnuts; a cashew-nut. 
emaidokoit (plural imaidoko) (noun M) a kidney-fruit tree; a cashew-nut tree or its nut, Anacardium occidentale. The liquid resin in a raw cashew-nut was traditionally used for tattooing people's bodies.The fruit and the roasted nuts are edible, while oil for varnishing and brake lining is extracted from the raw nuts.
emaikina (adjective) named; called. ekiror lomaikina ijo: the name given to you. 
Emaikokoit (plural Imaikoko) (noun M) a Mugisu tribesman; a man native of Bugisu, i.e. the present day Mbale and Sironko districts in eastern Uganda. Imaikoko: the Bagisu or Bamasaba people (in general). cp. Ekanyangit, Emugisut. 
emairungi (noun M) an evergreen shrub, Catha edulis. Its stalked leaves and shoots are chewed as a stimulant as well as medicine to treat asthma, cough, stomach-ache and chest pain. This tree grows in mountains in Karamoja, and its leaves are chewed by Somali people as a drug to prevent sleep.
emait (noun M) a corruption of ema: a kind of tall grass.
emajaani (noun M) an evergreen tea bush, the leaves of which tea is made, Camellia sinensis. 
emaji (plural imajin) (noun M) an eel-like fish, Mastacembalus victoria. 
emajing (plural imajing) (noun M) a deaf man. cp. ekiming. 
emakaasa (plural imakaasan) (noun M) a pair of scissors. 
emakada (plural imakadan) (noun M) a tangerine, mandarin; a kind of orange tree or fruits, Citrus reticulata. The fruits are eaten. cp. emucuuga
Emakadait (plural Imakada) (noun M) a Muganda tribesman from the Baganda tribe – one of the Bantu-speaking tribes of central Uganda; a man native to Buganda – the present day Masaka, Mukono, Kampala, etc. Imakada: the Baganda people (in general). cp. Emugaanat. 
emakak (singular noun M) a paralysing charm; a spell.
emakanika (plural imakanikan) (noun M) a mechanic (a person who repairs machines).
emakaut (plural imakaun) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a harveting knife. cp. ekurupeta. 
emakole (plural imakolei) (noun M) hand-made foul-smelling cigars. cp. ekukujo. 
emakuk (plural imakuko) (noun M) (Usuk) a traditional two, three, or four-legged stool; a bobbin stool. cp. edapala. 
emal (plural imalia) (noun M) a barbed arrow (shot with a bow). emal loebakere abus (noun M) (formerly) an arrow for opening abscess.
emalaika (plural imalaikan) (noun M) an angel; a seraph; a cherub. 
emalakang (noun M) (Usuk) a sour vegetable good for breast-feeding mothers to eat to stimulate production of milk, Hibiscus sabdariffa. cp. emalakany
emalakany (noun M) (outside Usuk) a sour vegetable, Hibiscus sabdariffa. cp. emalakang
emalakao (noun M) a vegetable, Asystasia schimperi. 
emalas (plural imalasia) (noun M) a gourd for keeping unchurned milk; a churn (the milk is poured from the elepit - milking pail - into emalas). esosol bala emalas: pungent like (fermented milk in) a churn. cp. ekeret, elepit.
emalayane (noun M) prostitution; sex trade. 
emaler (plural imalera) (noun M) a shrub or tree, Vangueria apiculata. Uses: its hard fruit is edible; the poles for building; firewood and charcoal for fuel. 
emalera (plural imalerai) (noun M) a red gown. 
ecamakinitai (adjective) allowed; authorised; sanctioned; free to; allowed to do something that you want to do.
emame (plural emameete) (adjective) absent; missing; not in attendance.
emameotor (plural emameototor) (adverb) without; lacking; free from.
emaleria (singular noun M) malaria fever (from mosquito bites); (of a person) having a high temperature. cp. eimidi.
emalit (plural imalin) (noun M) a lesser kudu, Tragelaphus imberbis - a species of antelope. cp. ederit
emanana (plural emanaka) (adjective) circumspect; roundabout; fond of roaming about. cp. irimono
emane (plural imanei) (noun M) a kind of fish. cp. erengaman. 
emaneja (plural imanejan) (noun M) a manager. cp. engarenikinon
emanerit (plural imanerin) (noun M) a clitoris; the vulva. emanerit katokon: your mother’s clitoris (an insult).cp. ejepel, eteede, eteele.
emangor (singular noun M) a stew (a mixture of fresh sweet potatoes and peas/beans cooked together). 
emanikor (plural imanikoria) (noun M) a big garden; a cultivated farm. cp. amana. 
emaniman (plural imanimania) (noun M) a climbing plant, Rhoicissus erytrodes; Clematis incisodentata. 
emanit (plural imanin) (noun M) a plant used for making beer tubes; a drinking tube made from this plant. cp. epii. 
emanukeret (plural imanukeren) (noun M) a bird in the thrush family. 
emany (plural imanyin) (noun M) a liver (an organ). 
emanyata (plural imanyatan) (noun M) a manyatta; a Karimojong encampment or homestead. cp. edukuru. 
emanyit1 (plural imanyin) (noun M) clotted blood (used for food); a blood clot (in the blood vessel can cause heart attack). aponi kibungai ekokolan toni aitelekun imanyin: the thief was beaten to near death (literally, beaten until he spat blood clots).
emanyit2 (plural imanyito) (noun M) a marriage ceremony where dowry or bride price is agreed on or paid. epu itunga alositos omanyit ke Arugai: there were many people who went to Arugai’s marriage party. cp. eitane.
emapeera (plural imapeeran) (noun M) a guava fruit or tree, Psidium guajava. The fruit is edible, and the wood is used for poles and firewood.
emapule (plural imapulei) (noun M) an iroko or Muvule hard wood tree famous for its heavy timber, Milicia excelsa. cp. eloa
emaradaadi (plural imaradaadin) (noun M) ornamentation; decoration. 
emaret (plural imare) (noun M) a cowpea (in general) or a bean, Phaseolus tephrosia. 
emarooge (plural imaroogei) (noun M) a bean seed or plant, Phaseolus vulgaris. cp. ejaajalo
emarukit (plural imaruk) (noun M) a large white mushroom. 
emasenik (plural imaseniko) (noun M) a choice bull or male of all herbivorous (i.e. grass-eating) animals. (jocular) a man; a big man. 
emaset (plural imaseta) (noun M) a cup, a vessel for drinking; a little gourd used as a drinking cup; a cupping horn for sucking blood. 
emaswa (plural imaswai) (noun M) a big man; a young bull. 
emata (plural ematas) (adjective) drinkable. akipi numam ematas: undrinkable water. 
ematakiro (plural imatakiro) (noun M) a small tree, Lannea schweinfurthii subsp. stuhlmannii. Its fruit is edible, the roots, bark and leaves have medicinal properties. The wood is used for firewood, timber and charcoal burning.
ematata (plural imatatan) (noun M) a swelling in the neck. 
ematerai (plural imatera) (noun M) a tree, Vangueria edulis. cp. etirai
ematet (plural imateta) (noun M) a beer party; a drinking spree or binge. 
ematira (plural imatiran) (noun M) an isolated traditional (small) hut. cp. ekai. 
ematooke (noun M) a variety of banana plant bearing bananas for cooking while green. cp. adeke, ematooke. 
ematun (plural ematunos) (adjective) drinkable; (of liquid) can be drawn. akipi numam ematunos: undrinkable water. 
ematuuda (plural imatuudai) (noun M) a passion fruit or plant in general, Passiflora edulis. Its fruit is used as food, drink or wine.
emaweeli (plural imaweelin) (noun M) bulrush millet. 
emedelit (plural imedelin) (noun M) the little finger or toe. 
emeeba (plural imeeban) (noun M) a member (of a club, an association, or committee); a representative. emeeba loka airabet: a member of parliament (MP).
emeedera (plural imeederan) (noun M) a banner; a standard; a streamer; a flag; an ensign; a pennant, pennon; colours; a bunting. 
emeesa (plural imeesan) (noun M) a (dining) table. emeesa loejengere: (in a hospital) an operating table. ejai eitaabo omeesa: the book is on the table.
emeimei (singular noun M) a skin disease which causes round scales on the scalp; a head ring worm. cp. etapa. 
Emekenyit (plural Imekenyin) (noun M) a man from the Bakenye tribe - a fisher tribe of Bantu origin that lives near lakes in Teso. Imekenyin: the Bakenye people in general.
emeketa (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. 
emelekede (singular noun M) a worm infestation of the human or animal gut. cp. iciida.
emeleku (plural imelekes) (noun M) a hoe. emeleku loka imongin: an ox plough. 
emelemeloana (plural emelemeloaka) (adjective) shiny and brown-spotted, like a bluebottle (a large fly with a shiny blue body). 
emelemeloi (plural imelemelo) (noun M) a brown spotted fat edible grasshopper. 
emelet (plural imelei) (noun M) a swallow (bird). 
emelikin (plural imelikina) (noun M) an evergreen tree in the ekum and emusya family, Craibia laurentii. 
emelut (plural imel) (noun M) the head of a penis; meatus of the penis; the glans. cp. elemut: a seed or kernel of a fruit. 
emenana (plural emenaka) (adjective) malcontent; rebellious; disobedient. 
emengerana (plural emengeraka) (adjective) disobedient; defiant; insolent. 
emenia (plural imeniai) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a houe or fruit bat (in general), Eidolon helvum. cp. enenwa. 
emeo (noun M) a grass with cutting leaves. 
emera (plural emeras) (adjective) drunk; inebriated; intoxicated; rusty; high; under the influence. 
emerana (plural emeraka) (adjective) (of a person) habitually drunk or inclined to be drunk. 
emerekek1 (plural imerekekin) (noun M) a ram; a male sheep; an abnormally big or fat sheep. 
emerekek2 (plural imerekekin) (noun M) a water fly (running on top of the water); a dragonfly. cp. otitot.
emeret (plural imereta) (noun M) drunkenness (caused by alcohol); dizziness; light-headedness; wooziness; giddiness. epol lolo nges emeret: she/he is very drunk today. 
emeri (plural imerieik) (adjective) striped (bluish colour). 
emeridian (noun neuter) longitude; an imaginary line on the earth’s surface passing through the poles at right angles to the equator (these lines run from north to south). emeridian 0o: longitude 0o.
emerikol (plural imerikolia) (noun M) any striped animal; a spotted genet, Genetta genetta. 
emerimong (plural imerimongin) (noun M) a tribal division; a tree in the ekum family, Craibia laurentii. cp. emelikin. 
emerukwa (plural imerukwai) (noun M) a ploughing ox; a ploughing bull; a big bull; a draught ox; a man who does all the difficult work; a big strong man. mam eong arai ekonimerukwa: I am not your ploughing ox (I am not going to do your dirty, heavy work). 
emeswa (plural imeswan) (noun M) a nest of a rat; rat hole. (figurative) a poor man’s home or house; a humble abode. alosi eong omeswaka: I am going to my humble home (abode). cp. aduke. 
emidaalit (plural imidaalin) (noun M) a medal; a medallion; a pendant. 
emidet (plural imideta) (noun M) a point of an arrow or spear (the tip of any weapon); a teat (of breast); a peak (of a spire, turret, or of a mountain). cp. aidio
emidiiri (plural imidiirin) (noun M) a long drum covered with (monitor) lizard skin played (together with two small drums – ideteta) with the flat of the hand at twin dances. 
emidil (plural imidil) (noun M) a man with slit dirty eyes. 
emidit (plural imidin) (noun M) a tree in the ebyong family, but with smaller leaves and fruit, Ficus capensis; a parasite, a leech. iramaana ijo bala emidit: you hang onto somebody like a leech: please, mind your own business. 
emidol (singular noun M) the sap from sweet potatoes.
emiitono (plural emiitoko) (adjective) wealthy in crops; abounding in. emiitoko kesi inyamat: they are rich in food. 
emiliangole (plural imiliangolei) (noun M) a Karimojong bull with a white spot on the forehead. 
emilimili (plural emilimilete) (adjective) shining; flashy. ecucut loemilimili: a bluebottle (fly). 
emilionit (plural imilionin) (noun M) a million. imilionin ka imilionin: millions upon millions. cp. akwat. 
emilisiat (plural imilisian) (noun M) a militia man; a civilian fighting force used to supplement a regular army in emergencies. 
emimir (adjective) (of butter) rancid, rotten, sour, or stale. 
emina (plural iminai) (noun M) sticky sap; resin; gum; glue; adhesive; latex. emina loka etaba: nicotine. 
eminaasi (plural iminaasin) (noun M) a coconut fruit. 
eminana (plural eminaka) (adjective) amatory; affable; genial; pleasant; friendly; sociable; easy-going; jovial. 
eminanara (adjective) compatible; congenial; like-minded; well-suited; agreeable. 
eminat (plural iminan) (noun M) dear; the beloved one or favourite one; dear one; popular; darling (used in letters, translated as ‘yours dearly’). Lokon eminat: Yours affectionately…(used by male writers). Nakon aminat: Yours affectionately (used by female writers).
eminit (plural iminito) (noun M) a tree in the etirir and ekisim family, but with leaves darker than etirir but with fewer thorns, found growing near swamps, Acacia gerrardii.The bark has medicinal properties.
emir (plural imirio) (noun M) a generic name for a rat. 
emira (singular noun M) an African tree used for its myrrh resin (i.e. a resin from an African tree used for medicine and perfume). 
emiria (plural imiriai) (noun M) a hippopotamus, Hippopotamus amphibious.
emiroit1  (noun M) (formerly) a black variety of finger millet supposedly introduced from Lango. cp. omududu. 
Emiroit2 (plural Imiroi) (noun M) a man native to Lango, i.e. of the districts of Lira and Apac; a Langi tribesman (one of the Luo-speaking peoples of northern Uganda). cp. Enyakoit, Elangot.
emisa (plural imisai) (noun M) the sacrament of Holy Mass. 
emisaani (plural imisaanin) (noun M) a weighing scale. 
emisikaut (plural imisikau) (noun M) a plant, Sesbania. 
emision (plural imisionin) (noun M) a Roman Catholic mission (a residence for priests and nuns).
emisyana (plural emisyaka) (adjective) observant; discerning; shrewd; intelligent; wise. 
emita (plural imitai) (noun M) a distance measure of one metre; a metre rule. imitai 1,000 ejaas toma okilomita ediope: a thousand metres are in a kilometre. cp. ekilomita
emiti (plural imitin) (noun M) an evergreen nsambya tree, Markhamia lutea. Its leaves have medicinal properties.
emitina (plural imitinan) (noun M) scabies; mange in animals and people. cp. ejuput 
emitir (plural imitir) (noun M) a slender person. cp. eriim. 
emiyono (plural emiyoko) (adjective) tending to be wealthy in crops. 
emocana (plural emocaka) (adjective) fond of joking; playful. 
emocet (plural imoceta) (noun M) a joke; badinage. koinakinai iso emocet: tell us a joke. emocet bon mere ejie: it is only joking not fighting. 
emod1 (plural imodia) (noun M) a hair-dress made of clay to fix in feathers. 
emod2 (plural imodia) (noun M) elephantiasis of the legs. cp. erojiroj, ebatiira. 
emodana (plural emodaka) (adjective) deceitful; cunning; sly; wily; devious; crafty; sneaky; shrewd; scheming. 
emodingoit (noun M) a variety of finger millet. cp. edyera. 
emodio- (adverb) (prefix used with masculine nouns) some; a little of. akoto emodiodia: I want some sauce or vegetables. emodiodek: some peas pudding. cp. edio. 
emodit (plural imodito) (noun M) deception; eyewash; a ruse. 
emodo (plural imodoi) (noun M) a civet cat, Viverra civetta.
emodol (singular noun M) the burnt remnants from boiled sweet potatoes or cassava.
emodu (plural imodui) (noun M) a scoop-shaped head of eipiret used for mashing cooked peas or sweet potatoes.
emoit1 (plural imo) (noun M) a male foreigner, especially of Bantu origin; a non-native; a Karimojong raider or rustler; a gentile. adeka naka imo: stomatitis (in babies at teething time). cp. elongwaut.
emoit2 (plural imo) (noun M) an imported crop or grain (especially millet, maize, or potato variety). cp. emiroit, emaido lomoit: an imported variety of red groundnuts with long shells. 
emojong (plural imojongik) (noun M) an old man above 66 years of age (no longer paying graduated tax); a crock. cp. ekimat. 
emojongana (plural emojongaka) (adjective) inclined to look or grow old soon, especially of a woman. 
emokoda (singular noun M) fractiousness; faddiness; pickiness; peevishness; pettiness; fastidiousness; meticulousness, precision, or annoying care. cp. aican, ejangijang, emingiming, etigitig. 
emokol (plural imokolia) (noun M) a big rat; a giant rat. cp. ekorikitoi. 
emokoliait (plural imokolia) (noun M) a traditional medicine man or doctor believed to have the art of making barren women fertile; a traditional bishop. 
emokorat (plural imokoran) (noun M) a criminal person; a villain; one who acts against the law. 
emolojon (plural imolojonia) (noun M) an edible plant, Kleinia longiflorus. 
emolokony (plural imolokonyo) (noun M) a hoof (of a person or an animal); a trotter (of pigs, etc). cp. emagegerit
emome (plural imomei) (noun M) a low anthill from which black flying ants come. ikong luka emome: black edible flying ants. 
emomo (plural imomoi) (noun M) a tree, Sporospermum campestre. 
emomwai (plural imomwa) (noun M) sorghum vulgare. ajon nuka imomwa: beer made from sorghum. cp. emumwait.
emon (noun M) a grass, Harpachne schimperi. 
emonaki (plural imonakin) (noun M) a monarchy; a kingdom. 
emong (plural imongin) (noun M) a bull; a motto or maxim. emong edonge: a castrated bull; an ox. emong emasenik: a choice bull for mating. eiruk lo Uganda ebala, ‘kanuka Edeke ka akakwap’: the Uganda motto says, ‘For God and my Country’.
emongomongot (plural imongomongon) (noun M) a curd; a ball or cake of fried akiria (beer dough). 
emoni (noun M) a plant, Crotalaria senecio discifolium. 
emono (plural imonoi) (noun M) a field or food crop destined for a famine period; a food bank; a bank balance (money in the account to cater for emergencies); a child’s garden from which the harvest is not normally eaten unless the parents stock of food runs out. 
emonuk (plural imonuk) (noun M) a well-fed person; a big bellied man. cp. lomonuk
emonyon (plural imonyono) (noun M) a vegetable marrow; a pumpkin; a poison; a medicine. cp. ekulony, ekomyo, ekitoi. 
emopiira (plural imopiiran) (noun M) a ball; football; a big tyre. 
emopim (noun M) a smelling plant used as flit against mosquitoes or to wash hands after burial or after eating smelly things like fish, Ocimum; a plant, Coleus aromatic.
emor1 (noun M) a food mixture; any combination. 
emor2 (noun M) black remnants after the boiling of butter, eaten as food. 
Emorimor (plural Lukemorimor) (noun M) the Iteso cultural leader whose duties, among other things, is to revive, preserve and promote the Teso culture (including Ateso language literacy); the chief executive of all Teso clans.
emoringa (noun M) a horse-radish tree, Moringa oleifera. A highly valued shrub - the fruits and young leaves are eaten, the leaves and fruits have medicinal properties, the seeds are used in oil extraction and water purification, and young roots are spices.
emoro (singular noun M) (archaic) a day; a period of time. ecemoro: some day; another day. emoro lo: today. ediomoro: some day. ngolimoro (adverb) always, every day. 
emorono (plural emoroko) (adjective) abusive; obnoxious; insulting; rude. emoroko kesi: they are fond of insulting, scolding, etc 
emoros (singular noun M) a creeper used as a vegetable seasoning, Cissus adenocaulis. It removes the bad smell from ecadoi, ekabit, or eodo and gives the other vegetables a smooth feel. It is also used as a costume at rain-dances, or as a drug to procure abortion or rubbed on feet to treat sores caused by stepping on human faeces. 
emorosing (plural imorosinga) (noun M) a neck; the front of neck. ejai ngesi emorosing: she/he is stiff-necked; she/he is stubborn; she/he is proud; she/he is cheeky, insubordinate. cp. alari; emurusing.
emorotot (plural imorototin) (noun M) a python. 
emoru (plural imor) (noun M) a big stone; mountain; big rock. 
emorudoi (plural imorudoin) (noun M) a tree, Strychnos. 
emorukaalet (plural imorukaalei) (noun M) a martial eagle, Polemaetus bellicosus; an eagle capable of killing an animal the size of a kid. 
emorumoru (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet; a plant species, Hibiscus lunarfolicos. 
emoto (noun M) a grass whose presence indicates that the soil is not fertile, Strigacelosia havaya. 
emotoka (plural imotokan) (noun M) a motorcar; an automobile; a car. 
emoyo (plural imoyoi) (noun M) the spirit; the soul. Emoyo Loagion: (in the Catholic faith) a Holy Spirit. Emoyo Lokalaunan: (in the Protestant faith) the Holy Spirit.
emuatonit (plural imuatok) (noun M) a twin. cp. emuut. 
emuatonon (plural imuatonok) (noun M) a twin. 
emuceeri (noun M) rice grain; a rice paddy field. 
Emucigat (plural Imuciga) (noun M) a Mukiga tribesman; a man native to Kigezi (the present day Uganda districts of Kabale and Kisoro), speaking a Bantu language called Rukiga. Imuciga: the Bakiga people in general.
emucuuga (plural imucuugai) (noun M) a sweet orange tree or fruit in general, Citrus sinensis. The fruits are eaten or drank as orangade while the peels, leaves, and flowers are used to extract citrus oil.cp. enimu
emudang (adjective) having small ears; having small cuts in ears. 
emududu (plural imudud) (noun M) burnt sediment of food; burnt crust of food left in the cooking pan; burnt lumps of grain after making beer. ileleba akiria nu imudud: this flour is full of burnt crusts. 
emudukana (plural emudukaka) (adjective) blind; sightless; unsighted.
emuduko (adverb) (done) blindly; sightlessly; (to do) with eyes shut. ibu ijo kogwel egoe lo emuduko: you bought this dress without thinking (literally, with eyes closed).
emuduku (plural imudukun) (noun M) a hard wood tree (not easily eaten by ants), Bridelia sclero neuroides. 
emuduma (plural imuduman) (noun M) (in Pallisa) maize or corn. cp. ekirididi. 
emudumudu (adverb) blindly; in the dark. cp. emuduko. 
emudunga (plural imudungan) (noun M) a corruption of emuduma: cob maize or corn. cp. ekirididi, emuduma. 
emuebe (plural imuebeko) (noun M) an ordinary mango fruit or tree, Mangifera indica. cp. edoodoo.
Emugaanat (plural Imugaana) (noun M) a Muganda man; a man native to Buganda (central and southern Uganda districts such as Kampala, Mukono, Masaka, Entebbe, Mpigi, etc). Imugaana: the Baganda people of central Uganda. cp. Emakadait.
emugaati (plural imugaatin) (noun M) bread; a pancake; a doughnut; a bun. cp. ekabalagala
emuge1 (adjective) (colour of fur) brownish-black. 
emuge2 (plural imugeik) (noun M) (formerly) a strip of skin tied round the neck or arm of the widow/widower to distinguish the bereaved from other mourners; (nowadays) any attire that distinguishes the bereaved from other mourners (for instance, wearing of black clothing or a piece torn from the shroud).
emugege (plural imugegei) (noun M) a skin disease that removes hair, especially in goats; scabies in animals. cp. etapa.
emugeono (plural emugeoko) (adjective) brownish-purple or brownish-black. 
emugigi (plural imugigin) (noun M) a catechism class. asiomi eong omugigi: I am learning the catechism. 
Emugisut (plural Imugis) (noun M) a man native to former Bugisu (the present day Mbale and Sironko districts); a Mugisu man. Imugis: the Bagisu or Bamasaba people. cp. Emaikokoit, Ekanyangit.
Emugoat (plural Imugoan) (noun M) a Goan; an Indian from Goa in south-western India. 
emugogolit (plural imugogol) (noun M) rough ground (like in a swamp) during dry season; little heaps of dry soil; a hunch, hump. 
emugolet (plural imugolen) (noun M) an initiate into a religion; a bridegroom (a man going to wed).
emugugut (plural imugug) (noun M) a bundle (of luggage); burdens; a shipment, consignment, or cargo; a load (of something heavy). cp. eigoliro. 
emugur (plural imugur) (adjective) (one with) bent or stooping back or shoulders; (a) hunchback(ed). 
Emugweriot (plural Imugwerio) (noun M) a man native to Budaka and Kibuku counties of Pallisa district; a Mugwere tribesman. Imugwerio: the Bagwere people (in general). 
emuisa (plural imuisai) (noun M) a tree, Protea. 
emujejel1 (adverb) shortly; a little time; insufficiently; momentarily. aanyu eong nges emujejel: I saw her/him for only a (little) moment. cp. imyelimyel. 
emujejel2 (plural imujejel) (noun M) a very little food; a very short time. 
emukaro (plural imukaron) (noun M) a kiln; an oven; a furnace. 
emukeeka (plural imukeekan) (noun M) a raffia mat; matting. cp. epar. 
emukisa (plural imukisai) (noun M) a good-luck charm; an amulet; a talisman. 
emukok (plural luemukok) (noun M) a man who does things at dusk or evening. 
emukoki (plural imukokitos) (adjective) (of time of day) dusking or becoming evening; (of trees) leafy, overgrown. 
emukopit (plural imukopin) (noun M) a peasant; a subordinate of a chief; a simple native or ordinary person; a commoner. 
emukule (plural imukulen) (noun M) a hide; a skin (tanned or raw); a pelt; a dermis (skin of human body); a sleeping skin. cp. akapet; ejamu; amunyelet; amuny. 
emukuny (plural imukunyo) (noun M) a stinging black ant. 
Emulaalot (plural Imulaalo) (noun M) a Muhima or Munyankole tribesman; a man native to Ankole (the present day districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo). Imulaalo: the Banyankole people of south-western Uganda.
emulalu (plural imulalun) (noun M) chilly sauce; chillies; pepper (red or green). 
emulang (plural imulang) (noun M) a hornless cow or animal. 
emuleera (plural imuleeran) (noun M) a red border round the neck and down the chest of a traditional gown. 
emulokolet (plural imulokolen) (noun M) a member of teetotalling Christian sects (especially sects having origins in the USA); a savedee or born-again. 
Emulubit (plural Imulubin) (noun M) a Nubian man native to Bombo, parts of West Nile, and Southern Sudan. Imulubin: the Nubian people (in general). 
emuluka (plural imulukai) (noun M) a lay reader (an unordained person licensed to undertake some religious duties); an Anglican Church pastor in charge of a sub-parish. 
emululut (plural imululun) (noun M) an unmarried man staying alone; a poor man living in solitude; a widower. amuulet: an unmarried woman; a widow. cp. emuulut
emumu (adjective) violent, aggressive, brutal, fierce; unruly, vicious. emumu itunga ngun: those people are rowdy or unruly. ekingok loemumu: a wild or rabid dog. 
emumwait (plural imumwa) (noun M) (generic name) sorghum; guinea corn. ajon nuka imumwa: beer made from sorghum. cp. emomwai. imumwa k’ajele: a bush, Clerodendron myricoides. 
emun (plural imunuo, imunwo) (noun M) a snake (in general). aicak amun ekori: to get into trouble (literally, to tread on a snake’s tail). 
emuna1 (plural imunai) (noun M) a stew; a mixture of ghee or sheanut butter and roasted groundnuts paste. aigur emuna: to make emuna. 
emuna2 (plural imunai) (noun M) a very thick mist or fog, especially round hills or in swamps. cp. elisina, ekuna. 
emunaara (adjective) spoiled; ruined. etogo loemunaara: a ruined house or a house in ruins. 
emunan (adjective) (of beer) brewed; fermented. ajon nuemunan: brewed beer; beer ready to drink. 
emunet (plural imuneta) (noun M) cheek; chutzpah; silliness; nuisance. 
emunokina (adjective) hopeful; expectant; encouraged; positive; confident. 
emunoono (plural emunooko) (adjective) fond of hoping; hopeful; reliable; trusting; trustworthy.
emunot (plural imunon) (noun M) a trustworthy, dependable, reliable, or honest man. cp. lomunot
emunwoit1 (collective noun) a big collection of snakes. 
emunwoit2 (plural imunwo) (noun M) an intestinal worm: askaris lumbricoides. 
emunyal (plural imunyala) (noun M) a coloured clay used for dressing hair. 
Emunyoorot (plural Imunyooro) (noun M) a Munyoro tribesman; a man native to Bunyoro (the present Uganda districts of Hoima, Masindi, and parts of Kibale and Mubende), speaking a Bantu language called Runyoro. Imunyooro: the Banyoro people native to Hoima, Masindi and parts of Kibale and Mubende districts of Uganda.
emuogo (plural imuogon, imuogoko) (noun M) a cassava tuber; the cassava plant; cassava flour; tapioca - Manihot utilisima
emurana (plural emuraka) (adjective) (of stomach) often astringent; constipated. 
emuret (plural imureta) (noun M) a basket used to ferment the beer-dough. 
emuria (noun M) a creeping grass usually growing near or in kraals, Cynodon dactylon. emuria kolia. kolia!: (prayer at birth of a child in the clan) may the clan prosper. Let it flourish! (literally, may the creeper, emuria, flourish).
emuriei (plural imuria) (noun M) a bush with edible fruit called amuriait; mulberry; a vine 
emuron (plural imurok) (noun M) a traditional priest or doctor knowledgeable in local herbs and cures and uses them for social good – such as foretelling the future, curing the sick, providing love potions, or bringing the rain; a doctor in general. cp. ekacudan: a witch. emuron loka adekis: a western doctor (a clinical officer or any person who diagnoses and treats using modern methods).
emurududu (noun M) a crust of bread (at the bottom of a dry saucepan); a simmering. cp. aisiiyakinet: a crust. 
emurumuron (plural imurumurok) (noun M) a blind worm; a headless snake. 
emurusing (plural imurusinga) (noun M) a neck; the front of neck. cp. alari; emorosing.
emurwon (plural imurwok) (noun M) a traditional doctor or priest; a health officer or doctor of western medicine. emurwon loka angaleu: a health officer. cp. emuron
emusaago (plural imusaagon) (noun M) a lawsuit; a case; a complaint. aitanyam emusaago: to decide in a law court that someone has done wrong. apetor emusaago: to defeat a case brought against one; to find innocent. cp. adiakaret. 
emusaala (plural imusaalan) (noun M) salary; pay; reward; wage. cp. eropit, eitai. 
emusaga (plural imusagan) (noun M) a spitting cobra. 
emusalaba (plural imusalaban) (noun M) a cross; a crucifix. 
emuseit (plural imusein) (noun M) an old man. cp. emojong. 
emusia (plural imusian) (noun M) a tree in the emelikin and ekum family whose root acted as a traditional lipstick and a ringworm remedy, and the leaf extract is used as a purgative, Mystroxylon aethiopium. 
emusibet (plural imusiben) (noun M) a prisoner, convict, inmate, jailbird; a captive, detainee, hostage. 
emusika (plural imusikai) (noun M) an heir, successor, legatee, beneficiary, inheritor. 
emusikiiti (plural imusikiitin) (noun M) a mosque; a Mohammedan place of worship. 
Emusogat (plural Imusoga) (noun M) a man native to Busoga (present day districts of Jinja, Iganga, Kamuli, Mayuge and Bugiri); a Musoga tribesman. Imusoga: the Basoga people (in general). cp. Emagarait: a Musoga or Mugwere tribesman.
emusogot (plural imusogon) (noun M) a Mukindu or wild date palm tree, Phoenix reclinata. Its leaves are used as ornament and thatch, the fibre and leaves are used in basketry and mats, while the sticks are used in making traditional doors and roofing.
Emusugut (plural Imusugun) (noun M) a European or a white man. 
emusumeeni (plural imusumeenin) (noun M) a wood saw; a hacksaw. cp. eraada.
emusuuja (singular noun M) fever; malaria fever. cp. emaleria; eimidi
emusuurut (plural imusuurun) (noun M) a stinking or foul smelling bug (like those found on ripening cotton bolls). 
emutojo (noun M) a kind of grass; continuous headache, migraine. 
emutono (plural emutoko) (adjective) (of time of day, manner, bush) dark; overgrown; gloomy; mysterious; sinister; shady; shadowy. emutono cucucuc: (of the night) extremely dark; very dark.
Emutoorot (plural Imutooro) (noun M) a Mutooro tribesman; a man native to Tooro (the present day western Uganda district of Bundibugyo, Kabarole, Kyenjojo, Kamwenge and parts of Kibale and Kasese). Imutooro: the Batooro people in general.
emutu (plural imutun) (noun M) a 12-centimetre needle for sewing cracks in a gourd; a punch. cp. ekus. 
emutula (plural imutulan) (noun M) a saltless sauce of groundnuts and sour milk eaten with pure millet bread by a breast-feeding woman; a traditional ceremony for initiating breast-feeding women into eating saltless food.
emuturu (plural imuturun) (noun M) a heartwood tree used for making pestles and threshing sticks, Ozoroa insignis subsp. reticulata. 
emutuugulu (plural imutuugulun) (noun M) an onion. cp. etuugulu
emuudu (plural imuudun) (noun M) (general) a firearm; a gun. 
emuuja (plural imuujai) (noun M) a jigger. cp. epuusa. 
emuulut (plural imuulun) (noun M) a corruption of emululut: an unmarried man staying alone; a poor man living in solitude; a widower. amuulet: an unmarried woman; a widow. 
emuunu (plural imuunui) (noun M) constipation; a poisoned stomach; a distended stomach. cp. eidada, egwei, eitebwone. 
emuut (plural imu) (noun M) a twin (person or animal). cp. ebangit.
emwaanyi (singular noun M) a coffee tree or bush; coffee berry. cp. akaawa: a coffee beverage.
emwalimu (plural imwalimun) (noun M) a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer. cp. esisianakinan
emwana (plural emwaka) (adjective) hot; it is hot; greedy; aglow; snug, cosy, comfy, warm. emwana nges akuwan: she/he is quick, alert. emwana nges akuwan pe pe: she/he is ill; she/he has fever. emwana nges etau: emwana nges ekori: emwana nges aidoole: she/he is very greedy. cp. otaupe. akipi nuemwaka: hot water. akiro nuamwanak: akiro nuemwaka: a tight corner. agwaunit eong akiro nuemwaka: I am in a tight corner. 
emwane (singular noun M) gluttony; greediness.
emweeso (plural imweesoi) (noun M) a razor for shaving; razorblade. cp. ebarenit
emwekimweki (plural emwekimwekete) (adjective) flashy; shining; dazzling; glittering, etc 
emwi (plural imwiyok) (noun F) a brother of one’s husband. omwika ngol: that is a brother of my husband. [note: a) brother-in-law is omuran by other in-laws, but is called ekamuran by the sister’s husband. b) the young brother of one’s husband is called okilenika locici by the wife. c) elder brother of the husband is called papa by the wife]. 
emyede (plural imyedei) (noun M) a small brown hornbill nesting in tree-holes. cp. esukusuk: a big black African hornbill.
emyelimyel (adverb) only a little; a sip; only a moment; insufficiently. abu eong kaany nges imyelimyel: I saw her/him only a moment. anyam eong imyelimyel: I only ate a little, or I ate only a little. 
emyelot (plural imyeloi) (noun M) a hot-tempered person. 
emyetara (adjective) (of body, buttocks) flat; plain; even (as of board). 
enaaba (plural inaabai) (noun M) a number; a digit; a figure; numeral; integer; amount; quantity. 
enaabi (plural inaabin) (noun M) a prophet; a foreseer; a diviner. cp. ekadwaran.
enaabiya (plural inaabiyai) (noun M) a love potion (believed to make the recipient fall in love with the giver); an aphrodisiac.
enaanara (adjective) commited, faithful, or devoted (to each other). enaanara kesi: eraas kesi luenaanara: they are devoted to each other. 
enaijeria (noun M) a variety of cassava, origin Nigeria, whose tubers are not eaten raw because they are poisonous. cp. ebwonor
enaka (noun M) a small flying termite. 
enanaasi (plural inanaasin) (noun M) a pineapple fruit or plant. 
enange (singular noun M) abrogation; the end. 
enangiya (plural inangei) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) cloth (general); apparel; attire. cp. inapat 
enapwor (singular noun M) a kind of plant used as a vegetable. 
enasoro (plural inasoron) (noun M) a common thing; a public property; a communal grain store. 
enebek (adjective) (of cloth, skin) silky-smooth; glossy; soft and shiny. enebek egoe lo: this cloth is silky-smooth. 
enee (adjective) compacted; squashed; crammed; condensed; compressed. 
eneko (noun M) a corruption of enyeko: jealousy, envy, suspicion, resentment among co-wives. 
enema (plural ineman) (noun M) (in the Catholic church) sanctifying grace; poise; style; charm; elegance. enema loketwasaman: active grace. enema loketalaunan: sanctifying grace. 
-enen a verbal suffix denoting a repetitive or continued action either towards or away from the speaker. alosit: to go away (once only); alosenen: to keep going away (often). abunore: to come this way (once only); abunenen: to keep coming this way (often). akerit: to run off (once only); akerenen: to keep running away (often). 
enenwa (plural inenwai) (noun M) (Usuk) a general name for a house or fruit bat, Tadarida limbada. cp. emenia. 
enepes (plural inepesio) (noun M) habit (in anything); peculiarity; idiosyncrasy. ejai nges enepes lokolo ka papake: she/he has the peculiarities of her/his father. ejai eipone lope ejaar: there is something queer or strange about him/her/it. cp. eipone, ekinepes. 
eneran (plural enerak) (noun M) a talker; a speaker or an orator. 
enerat (plural enerak) (noun M) a talker; a chatterbox. aineraneratoi: always talking, babbling, chattering. 
engaano (singular noun M) wheat; wheat flour. 
engaara (adjective) open; ajar; agape. 
engabwor (plural ingabworin) (noun M) an olive baboon (i.e. a kind of ape or monkey), Papio anubis. cp. emabwor. 
engadan (plural engadak) (noun M) a steward, treasurer or storekeeper. cp. ekengadan.
engaet (plural ingaeta) (noun M) a prop, support; a forked stick (to support the roof of a granary); door-handle or knob. 
engalan (plural engalak) (noun M) a liar; a deceiver, hypocrite. cp. ekasaban, ekengalan.
engalerut (plural ingaler) (noun M) the pip of fruit; a wingless termite (after shedding wings). 
engalura (plural ingalur) (noun M) a kidney. 
engalurat (plural ingalur) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a kidney. 
engang (plural lungang) (adjective) (of a person, etc) very big; huge; gigantic cp. engasingas, ekos. adum eong emun longang: I met a huge snake. akiro nungang: a big case; a tall story. 
engangatono (plural engangatoko) (adjective) bustling (with negative connotations); inclined to hurry about (but ending up delaying). 
engarana (plural engaraka) (adjective) malignant; cruel; hateful; odious. 
engaranakinan (plural engaranakinak) (noun M) a helper; an assistant; aide de camp. 
engarenikiton (plural engarenikitok) (noun M) a leader; a guide; a director; a manager.
engarenon (plural engarenok) (noun M) a leader; a director; an organizer; a manager.
engarot (plural ingaroi) (noun M) a pebble; gravel; grit; iron ore; murram. alosi eong aibe ingaroi: I am going to break up the ironstone. aitutu ingaroi orot: to stamp murram on the road. amatapaalin nuk’ingaroi: murram blocks. 
engas (plural ingasia) (noun M) a prop or support; a forked stick to support the roof of a granary. 
engasingas (plural lungasingas) (noun M) a giant; a monster; a very big person, thing or animal. Maria angasingas ya eputos ka etop: Mary is very big; she is like the Morning Star. 
engasit (plural ingasito) (noun M) plundering; robbery; raiding; rustling; pillaging, or looting. adau engasit ka Ikaramoja ko Teso ikar akais akany adepar: the Karimojong raiding in Teso has taken over fifty years.
engatuny (plural ingatunyo) (noun M) a lion, Panthera leo; a brave man; a male member of the Lions Club. 
engecer (plural ingecera) (noun M) a person who is very thin (the thighs are far between) or walking naked. cp. eceger. 
engeded (adjective) (of rope or thread) broken, or torn. engedengeda iusio kosaatika: my shirt is torn. 
engedengeda (adjective) (of cloth) torn in many places; (of rope) broken into many pieces.
engejep (plural ingejep) (noun M) one who stutters or stammers. 
engejepana (plural engejepaka) (adjective) stammering; stuttering; lisping. 
engelecomoit (plural ingelecom) (noun M) a contemptuous or despicable man; a coward; a traitor. 
engelerep (plural ingelerepo) (noun M) a swift brownish venomous snake, Rhamphiophis. 
engeluna (adjective) (of a piece of anything) broken off. engeluna atibok: a piece of pot has broken off. 
engenge (adjective) rough; coarse (like sand); harsh; austere. 
engerebebe (singular noun M) a very severe kind of diarrhoea; dysentery; ulcer of the stomach. 
engerengerwai (plural ingerengerwa) (noun M) a bush whose roots are used as a liniment for wounds, Cassia singueana. 
engerepoit (plural ingerepo) (noun M) a white ant flying in the morning from an anthill called angerep. 
engeret (plural ingereta) (noun M) a sickle. cp. eriiga
engereteny (plural ingereteny) (noun M) a floating rib; rib cartilage. 
engerono (plural engeroko) (adjective) obstinate; rebellious. 
engesana (plural engesaka) (adjective) sudden; unforeseen. 
engeseb (adjective) easily broken (of rope, cloth, pot etc); fragile; delicate; brittle; weak. engeseb etau: my heart is very tender; I am very susceptible to; easily affected by; (of rope) to be weak; (of cloth) easy to tear. engeseb erot: the road can easily be cut short. cp. ebenen.
engeso (plural ingesoi) (noun M) a disaster; a sudden occurrence (such as premature birth, death, earthquake, etc). atiokisio nuka engeso: disasters.
engesuna (adjective) casual; unexpected; adventitious; unforeseen; unanticipated; unpredicted; surprising; startling; astonishing; sudden; out of the blue. 
engibirirana (plural engibiriraka) (adjective) fast running; speedy; swift; rapid. ingibirirana ijo: you run fast. irai ijo ekangibiriran: you are a fast runner. 
engiet (plural ingieta) (noun M) incisor tooth. cp. etirikadait.
enginam (adjective) toothless; having no teeth.
engingi (adjective) blunt; not sharp. engingi ikilenga lu: these knives are blunt. 
enginyat (plural enginyak) (noun M) a backbiter; a slanderer; a glutton. 
enginyot (plural inginyo) (noun M) a small piece of cassava or potato (harvested prematurely); the two end parts of cassava or potatoes cut off first. 
engiol (plural ingiol) (noun M) a man with protruding teeth; anything protruding. ikel lungiol: ikel luingiololas: protruding teeth. 
engirikino (adjective) endured; sustained; borne bravely. ariebo nangirikino: pain borne bravely; endured pain. 
engiringirio (plural ingiringirio) (noun M) a tree, Gymnosporia senegalensis. cp. egirigiroi. 
engiriony (plural ingiriony) (noun M) a man with a bruised face; a man with broken teeth. 
engiro (plural ingiroik) (noun M) the brown one; a mulatto or mongrel. 
engiroono (plural engirooko) (adjective) brown; chocolate coloured; coffee coloured; tan; russet; brunette; auburn; tanned; sunburnt. 
engite (plural ingitei) (noun M) a flowering shrub, Stereospermum kunthianum. Its sticks are used as toothbrushes and the root extract as a medicine for wounds, and the fruits chewed with salt is a remedy for cough. 
engiti (plural ingitia) (noun M) a hand hoe with a heart-shaped blade. cp. ecar
engiti lokimongin (plural ingitia lukimongin) (noun M) an ox-plough. cp. emeleku. 
engole (plural ingoleik) (noun M) an animal with a scar or bare patch on the head; one with a white patch on the head. 
engoleit (plural ingolei) (noun M) a large hornet with a white spot on the forehead. 
engoleono (plural engoleoko) (adjective) (of a person or an animal) having a bald patch or scar on the head (after an injury). 
engolet (plural ingolei) (noun M) a man or animal with a scar on the head. 
engolopana (plural engolopaka) (adjective) (of a person) quarrelsome; contentious; cantankerous.
engolor (plural ingolor) (noun M) a man with a cataract in his eye. 
engomo (plural ingomoi) (noun M) a kind of plant with edible fruit. 
engoorit (plural ingoorito) (noun M) the lastborn boy child. kiwaliwal, eong engoorit: (an address to the cloudy or rainy weather by a boy) clear up, I am the last born. cp. ekiyai.
engorojojo (plural ingorojoja) (noun M) half-cooked millet bread; half-ready millet bread or atap; badly cooked food; badly mingled and half-cooked atap.
engorot1 (noun M) old millet (not current year's harvest) or anything. 
engorot2 (plural ingorok) (adjective) ancient; antique; prehistoric; primeval. 
engosob (plural ingosob) (noun M) a man with protruding teeth. 
engosoorot (plural ingosooron) (noun M) a Ugandan coral, Red-hot-poker or lucky-bean tree bearing small black and red seeds, Erythrina abyssinica. Its crushed leaves treat skin diseases in livestock. The seeds can be used to make curios, the light wood is used as corks for fishnets and for carving beehives and utensils.
engu (plural inguok) (noun M) a gravedigger; an undertaker. cp. ekedaan
enguingui (singular noun F) a row or disagreement (especially within a family); a squabble; a dispute (with people just grumbling). epol enguingui kane: there is a lot of grumbling here.
enguleteny (plural inguletenya) (noun M) a stump (after cutting); a stub; a bump.
engulot (plural inguloi) (noun M) a male leper; a maimed man (with a limb or part of a limb cut off).
engulul (adjective) (of limbs or parts thereof) cut up into pieces, maimed. 
engulungul (plural ingulungulia) (noun M) a part of the spine or backbone; a chop of meat from the animal’s neck or spine. 
engulungulut (plural ingulungulun) (noun M) the nape; the back of neck at the junction with the spine; a chop of meat from the animal’s neck or spine. 
engunget (plural ingungeta) (noun M) controversy; discord; a disagreement; enmity; a quarrel; a squabble; grouse; friction. ejai iso engunget ka nges: we have a quarrel with her/him. 
engwalas (plural ingwalasik) (noun M) a lame man; a cripple. 
engwaringwari (plural engwaringwarete) (adjective) of colour of fur) spotted; dappled; fluorescent. 
enibik (adjective) (of cloth) nice and soft to feel. enibik egoe lo: this cloth is nice and soft to the fingers. 
enicik (plural inicikas) (adjective) (of wet clay or fine strong cloth) thick; well kneaded. egoe loenicik: fine, strong and thick cloth. elupe loenicik: kneaded clay (for making pots or bricks). 
enikos (singular noun M) a chronic and incurable carbuncle or sore on a person’s foot (preventing the person from walking properly). cp. acany
enimok (plural inimok) (noun M) a man with small or tiny buttocks. (an insult) cp. eripid
enimu (plural inimun) (noun M) a lemon tree or fruit, Citrus limon; an evergreen lime shrub, Citrus aurantifolia. The fruit is used for lemonade drink and as a source of citric acid; lime oil, lemon oil, and cosmetics are extracted from peels.
eninaet (plural ininaeta) (noun M) a thing to rub with, such as a towel, brush or India rubber. 
eninan (adjective) oiled; (of medicine or oil onto the skin) rubbed in; (of fried groundnuts) unhusked. 
eninik (adjective) (of meat) tough; (of wood) strong; elastic; (of person) resilient; (of character) inflexible; (of rubber) expandable; stretchy; (of millet or grain) moist. eninik akiring ngin: that meat is tough. akiring naeninik: tough meat. eninik etau: (of a person) brave, courageous, hearted. eninik akimai: the millet is moist, i.e. hard to grind because it is not well dried. (transitive verb) to be hard-hearted; to be tight-fisted. 
eniniko (noun M) a vegetable and weed - Justicia matanense. 
eniniku (plural ininikun) (noun M) a kind of tree with an edible fruit. 
enino (singular noun M) simsim (and sometimes with groundnuts) seeds fried and ground into paste. cp. ekanyumit.
enipono (plural enipoko) (adjective) (of hunting dogs) good at sniffing and tracking game animals; (of person’s character) persistent, unrelenting. 
enirono (plural eniroko) (adjective) (of food) satiating; nauseating; sickening. 
eniumoniya (singular noun M) pleuro-pneumonia in human beings. cp. oukoi
enokit (plural enokitos) (adjective) (of someone in pursuit of another) coming near dangerously; closing on. 
enokosa (plural inokosan) (noun M) a swollen vesicle. 
enoman (plural enomak) (noun M) one who beats (another); a football kicker. enoman aputosia: a photographer; a picture drawer. enoman igoen: one who irons clothes as a trade. enoman epiki: a gambler.
enomut (plural Inomu) (noun M) a man from the Teso clan of bone-setters; a bone-setter; a physiotherapist. 
enon (plural inonio) (noun M) a caecum of a ruminant filled with select fatty meat, liver, small intestines, etc. spiced, sealed and cooked as a delicacy. 
enonok (adjective) (of something) soft; (of character) weak; (of food, meat) tender; flimsy; flexible; languid. 
enoot (plural inootin) (noun M) a zero; nought; nil. cp. esupuri
enukuro (plural enukuros) (adjective) doubled up (with pain); ensconced (with pleasure).
enume (plural inumei) (noun M) the only child (born to a family). cp. elemura. 
enusu (plural inusio) (noun M) a shilling; a currency unit. 
enyaanyaa (plural inyaanyaan) (noun M) a tomato plant or fruit. cp. ejago
enyaapala (plural inyaapalan) (noun M) a works superviser; a headman; an overseer; a slave driver. apaarasia nuka Kakungulu, adedeng inyaapalan aituduk itunga irotin: during the days of Kakungulu the roadworks overseers fiercely forced people to build roads. 
enyaapalane (singular noun M) overseeing; supervision; management; control. 
enyabwos (plural inyabwosio) (noun M) a multi-mammate mouse, Mastomys couchae Ugandae. 
enyadak (plural inyadak) (noun M) a man who is dirty. enyadak nges akuwan: (she/he is dirty) she/he has a dirty body. 
enyadu (singular noun M) blue swamp clay. (slang) money. 
enyagan (plural enyagak) (noun M) a robber, raider, plunderer, a cheat. 
enyagirit (plural inyagirio) (noun M) a kind of bird. 
enyaiyon (plural enyaiyok) (noun M) a man who is fastidious; a man who pretends aversion; a man who pretends to shirk food. 
enyaiyot (plural enyaiyok) (noun M) a man given to extreme fastidiousness, meticulousness, precision or delicacy. 
enyakinyak (plural inyakinyakia) (noun M) a rag; a torn or worn out garment. cp. edapaic. 
enyakoit (plural inyakoi) (noun M) a man hailing from the north; a northerner; a Nordic. ebunit ngesi konyakoi: she/he comes from the north. 
enyakoka (plural inyakokan) (noun M) an edible plant, Hibiscus. 
enyakuka (plural inyakukai) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum. 
enyamana (plural enyamaka) (adjective) (of person, animal) gluttonous; guzzling; fond of eating; greedy; insatiable. 
enyamio (adjective) (of food) edible; eatable; safe to be eaten; not poisonous. enyamio ityang lu ko Teso: eputir, amor, ekori, ekosobwan, etuko kede ice da: these animals are edible in Teso: a warthog, a duiker, a giraffe, a buffalo, a zebra among others. konye mam enyamio ebu, ekingok, edokolet, eris, eidodo, egereger, engatuny, kice da: but a hyena, a dog, a monkey, a leopard, a common lizard, a monitor lizard, a lion, etc are not eaten in Teso.
enyamiton (plural enyamitok) (noun M) one who accompanies; an escort; aide de camp (ADC); a guide; a body guard. cp. ekenyamiton.
enyamukware (plural inyamukwaren) (noun M) a kind of plant. 
enyamun (plural enyamunos) (adjective) (of a thing) wearing off; (of food) consumable; (of an asset) depreciating. 
enyamuret (plural inyamuren) (noun M) a gatecrasher; a hanger on; a tramp; a destitute; one who eats at other people’s homes. 
enyang1 (plural inyangaik) (adjective) (of skin colour, fur) light brown; speckled; tan; yellowish-orange. akiteng anyang: a light brown cow. 
enyang2 (singular noun M) morning sun, i.e. sunshine between 7:00 am and 10:00 am. aipyer enyang: to warm oneself in the morning sun. alosi eong aipyer enyang: I am going to warm myself in the morning sun. cp. enyango.
enyang3 (singular noun M) a variety of sorghum grown during the dry season (requiring less rainfall). cp. ekonokamu.
enyangaana (plural enyangaaka) (adjective) (of colour or hue) light brown; yellowish-brown; tan; red-brown; auburn. edoso-nyang: canary colour. 
enyango (singular noun M) (outside Usuk) the morning sunshine (before 10:00 am, believed to be healthy). 
Enyarwaadat (plural Inyarwaada) (noun M) a Rwandese tribesman; a man native to Kisoro district at the extreme south-west of Uganda and the Republic of Rwanda. Inyarwaada: the Rwandese people in general.
enyede (collective noun M) young locusts. 
enyege (singular noun M) bad luck (for being the last to come down a tree – causing a person to fall); misfortune; hard luck. cp. ebili.
enyeko (noun M) envy, jealousy among co-wives. 
enyel (plural inyelia) (noun M) rust; iron (ferrous) oxide. aikamun enyel: amasikin enyel: to be or become rusty. 
enyikibon (singular noun M) a weed, Bidens pilosa. cp. esisiit.
enyilil (adjective) (of something soft) torn; frayed; in shreds; ragged; tattered. 
enyimo (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis tenuifolia. 
enyola (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis aspera, 
enyolo (plural inyoloi) (noun M) rust; stain (on metal). 
enyongai1 (plural inyonga) (noun M) a tree, Steganotaenia araliacea. Its roots have medicinal value.
enyongai2 (singular noun M) a variety of sorghum plant whose stalk is eaten like sugarcane. 
enyoodo (plural inyoodoi) (noun M) a hammer; a mallet; a tack hammer; a sledge hammer. cp. anyul 
enyoolan (plural enyoolak) (noun M) a man who pumps (a borehole); a person or thing that turns a mechanism to make it rotate or spin. 
enyoota (plural inyootan) (noun M) a craving, lust, hankering; military insignia on the shoulder (in form of diamonds or stars). 
enyukunyuk (plural inyukunyukia) (noun M) a mole, Cryptomys leche. 
enyukuta (plural inyukutan) (noun M) a letter of the alphabet. enyukuta loapolon: a capital letter. inyukutan ludidik: small letters.
enyuluk (adjective) (of feathers) easy to pluck; (of rope) easily broken. 
enyunyinere (plural inyunyinerei) (noun M) a tree, Acasia senegal. 
enyunyurana (plural enyunyuraka) (adjective) inclined to anger; irritable; tetchy; short-tempered; hot-tempered; huffy. 
enyurinyur (noun M) a short grass, Eragrostis ciliaris. 
enyuru (plural inyurui) (noun M) an edible cane rat, Thrynomys harrisonia. 
enyutel (adjective) insensate; numb; unfeeling; insensible; not sensitive. 
eodo (singular noun M) (Usuk) a green vegetable boiled without magadi salt. 
eodor (noun M) (Usuk) a grass, Dioscorea bulbifera. 
eoj (plural eojak) (adjective) (Usuk) tall; high; long. ekitoi loeoj: a tall tree. eoj nges etau: she/he has a long breath (she/he can run or dive for a long time without breathing); she/he is greedy. 
eojakori (plural iojakorio) (noun M) (Usuk) a long-tailed bird, a Coly bird. 
eoke (plural iokei) (noun M) a kind of tree. 
eokito (plural of eonit) (adjective) (Usuk) empty; dry; parched; dessicated; arid; waterless.
eome (plural iomei) (noun M) (Usuk) a creeper with yellow flowers, Cucubitaceae. 
eomikina (adjective) (Usuk) too big; very big; huge; arrogant. eomikina etelepat lo: this boy is too arrogant. 
eong (1st person singular pronoun) I; me. arai eong Apuda Egenatio: I am Apuda Ignatius. eong ma, onac: it is me, brother. cp. oni: us, we. iso: us, we.
eongo (singular noun M) (Usuk) vainglory; self-seeking; self-complacency; self-conceit. 
eongor (adjective) (Usuk) (of colour) dark-drown; purple-brown. 
eongoryana (plural eongoryaka) (adjective) (Usuk) (of colour) blonde; flaxen; fair-haired; dark or purple brown.
eonit (plural eokito) (adjective) (Usuk) dry; arid; poor; thin. 
eonokori (plural ionokorio) (noun M) (Usuk) a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock.
eorokonyit (plural iorokonyo) (noun M) (Usuk) slime; goo; gloop; gunk. cp. ekorokonyit 
eorooro (plural iorooron) (noun M) (Usuk) a snake said to make a hoarse noise, Rhamphiophis. cp. eworoworo; engelerep. 
eosin (plural iosino) (noun M) the vagina (of women or animals); the birth canal. cp. alipong, edodot, ecus, ewosin.
eosiyana (plural eosiyaka) (adjective) (Usuk) (of a female animal or person) having long period between pregnancies. cp. akori
eoteeri (plural ioteerin) (noun M) a hotel; restaurant; bistro; cafe. 
epaaba (singular noun M) the cotton plant; cotton yarn or fibre (fluffy down covering the cotton seed). 
epaabo (plural ipaaboi) (noun M) a summons; a subpoena; court fees or legal charges. 
epaaran (plural ipaarin) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a fellow; a companion. opaaraka: my (male) friend (in a bad sense). apaaraka: (my) girlfriend; my lover (in bad sense). 
epaasi (plural ipaasin) (noun M) a flat-iron for smoothing creased clothes. 
epacol (plural ipacol) (noun M) a man with a bald or scarred head. 
epadal (adjective) flat; level or even; horizontal. 
epadic (plural ipadic) (noun M) (Usuk) a male friend; a companion. cp. epading.
epading (plural ipading) (noun M) an enemy; a foe. lokeding (plural lukeding): an enemy. cp. lokasurup. 
epaduk (plural ipaduk) (noun M) a neighbour. 
epadurat (plural ipadur) (noun M) a bad male friend; a lover (an insult). cp. epae, epaelot. 
epae (plural ipaelon) (noun M) a male lover; a male friend. cp. epaelot
epaelot (plural ipaelon) (noun M) a male lover; a male friend. cp. epapero, ekone.
epagal (adjective) (of a situation) clumsy; inconvenient; awkward; difficult to handle. 
epaganga (singular noun M) a severe lung disease - phthisis; pulmonary tuberculosis; a whooping cough. cp. elweera, egorigor
epailot (plural ipailotin) (noun M) a pilot; a cosmonaut. etekeran edege nges epailot: one who flies an aircraft is a pilot.
epajan (plural ipajan) (noun M) a relative; a clansman; a kinsman. 
epajang (plural ipajangas) (adjective) (of a person) flat-headed. 
epaka (noun M) a competition; a contest; rivalry. 
epakasit (plural ipakasin) (noun M) a male labourer; a porter; a man-servant. 
Epalaasat (plural Ipalaasan) (noun M) a French man. 
epalal (adjective) wet; fresh; damp; moist. epalal eong akan: I am rich; I am generous. cp. iinat eong akan: I am well to do. 
epalana (plural epalaka) (adjective) negligent; lax; ready to forego; ready to sacrifice; inclined to give in; inclined to be generous. 
epale (plural ipalei) (noun M) a pair of trousers or shorts; pants; underwear. cp. egoe, oidoolei
epali (singular noun M) cheek; insolence; contumely; arrogance; obstinacy; stubbornness. cp. aipalionut. 
epalisi (plural ipalisin) (noun M) a big mattress; a wire mattress: epalisi lok’asinin. 
epalisyono (plural epalisyoko) (adjective) lazy; negligent; idle; slovenly; lax; careless. cp. apalikin. 
epalo (plural ipaloi) (noun M) a pod of ekaikai tree, Prosopsis africana. 
epalunana (plural epalunaka) (adjective) level-headed; cool-headed; apathetic; not easily disturbed, cool, detached, calm, deliberate; dogged. ibusakinit engarenikiniton korai etunganan loepalunana: it is necessary that a leader be level-headed. 
epamor (plural ipamor) (noun M) a man who shares in or who contributes to the same action; a member of a club; a shareholder of a company. cp. epamorat
epamorat (plural ipamor) (noun M) a shareholder; partner. cp. epamor.
epapaali (plural ipapaalin) (noun M) a tree-like herb or papaya plant or a pawpaw fruit, Carica papaya. The ripe fruit is used as food, jam or drink, while the leaves are meat tenderisers when used as wrappers.
epapai (plural ipapa) (noun M) a decidious Camel's Foot leaf tree, Piliostigma thonningii. Its bark can be used as fibre or rope, and root extract is used as a remedy for scorpion and snake bites, rectal ulcers and genital syphilis. The pods are eaten as food, or roasted with seeds to make dye. The tree provides poles and firewood.
epapait (plural ipapai) (noun M) a grandchild; a great grandchild. cp. etatait (plural itatai) grandchild. ipapai k’ipapai: posterity; children of great grandchildren; descendants. 
epapang (adjective) (of taste) astringent; sour. 
epapero (plural ipapero) (noun M) a friend; a chum. 
epaperone (singular noun M) friendship; camaraderie; amity. 
epar (plural iparia) (noun M) a papyrus mat (for any purpose). cp. esaapa. 
eparian (plural iparian) (noun M) an equal (in age); a contemporary. kirai iso kere iparian: we are all age mates; we are all equal. 
eparis (plural iparisia) (noun M) a small tree or shrub, Grewia mollis. Its strings of bark used for fibre, and smooth stick are used for spear hafts and walking sticks. 
Epasika (singular noun M) Easter. 
epasit (plural epasitos) (adjective) tired; weary; fatigued; exhausted. 
epata (plural ipatai) (noun M) a bald head; balding; hair loss. cp. apaloror.
epataasi (plural ipataasin) (noun M) a chisel; a wood plane (carpenter’s tool).
epatana (plural epataka) (adjective) easy; tame; cheap; gentle; self-evident; harmless; innocent.
epate (plural ipatei) (noun M) a political organisation or party. eridakit apugan naka e Movement ipatei; mam ecamakit kesi angaanar atenueik kokinga nako Kampala: the Movement government is oppressive to political parties; it has prevented them from opening branches outside Kampala. 
epateit (plural ipatei) (noun M) the calf muscle (the muscle behind the lower leg). asukokin epateit: to have cramps in the leg. 
epaup (plural ipaup) (noun M) a male chum; a male companion; a partner; a buddy; a male friend; one of a pair of male things; the other of two males. epaupaka: my friend.
epaupane (singular noun M) friendship; partnership; association; camaraderie. 
epeded (adjective) pierced; having a hole; perforated; punctured. 
epedel (plural ipedelas) (adjective) flat; shallow; thin (as of a flake of bar soap). abao napedel: flat board. epedel asabuunyu: there is little soap left; the soap is thin. asabuunyu napedel: a thin piece of soap. kotubokinai emugaati lopedel: cut me a thin slice of bread. 
epedele (plural ipedelei) (noun M) a tinker bird. 
epedet (plural ipedet) (noun M) an instrument with which to make holes; a bore; a drill; a prick; a bradawl. 
epedokino (adjective) pierced through; leaking. epedokino emopiira: the ball has a puncture. epedokino itiny: to have dimpled or hollow cheeks. 
epedor (plural epedoros) (adjective) possible; able; competent; manageable; permissible; capacity. mam ngun epedoros: that is impossible. epedorio: she/he/it is possible. mam epedorio: it/she/he is impossible. 
epeduru (plural ipeduro) (noun M) the tamarind tree, Tamarindus indica, with the fruit (apedur) used to spice up atap, fruit pulp is eaten as food, the leaves are fodder as well as medicine. epeduru locici (plural ipedur lucicik) (noun M) a cassia plant, Cassia negricans. Its cold leaf-infusion is used to expel intestinal worms in cattle and people. 
epeera (plural ipeerai) (noun M) a wage; a pay. 
epeero (singular noun M) a grass whose root is chewed to treat cough, Laudetia superba. 
epeet (plural ipeen) (noun M) a hunting dog; a wild dog, Lycaon pictus. 
epeeti (plural ipeetin) (noun M) a woman’s silk underwear resembling a skirt, often with ornamentation at the fringes; a petticoat; a slip; underskirt. 
epegana (plural epegaka) (adjective) fond of contradicting or answering back; obstinate; argumentative; belligerent. 
epege (plural ipegei) (noun M) a male pig; a boar; a dirty man. cp. eputir: a warthog; a wild pig. 
epeget (plural ipegeta) (noun M) an argument; a controversy; a discussion; a debate; a dispute; a contest; a contention; a competition. epol epeget kangina: there is a great discussion going on over there. 
epeipeyana (plural epeipeyaka) (adjective) rare; sparse; (of plants) found scattered singly. 
epejal1 (plural ipejala) (noun M) a platform outside the homestead for drying grain; a threshing floor. cp. alaro
epejal2 (plural ipejalin) (noun M) a plant whose roots are pounded and mixed with water and drenched on cattle as a treatment for east-coast fever, Indigofera endecaphilla. 
epejel (plural ipejelin) (noun M) a spear-like arrow for killing rats or birds. 
epejonon (plural ipejok) (noun M) a male guest; a male visitor; a male caller; a male tourist. epejonon loapolon: a chief guest.
epeket (plural ipeken) (noun M) a falcon (small hawk with grey-spotted feathers). cp. egole.
epeleboi (noun M) a grass, Echinochloa pyramidalis. 
epelec (plural ipeleca) (noun M) a small silvery fish, Engraulicy pris argenteus. cp. opelec.
epeleikinitai (adjective) intended; deliberate. 
epelekecoit (plural ipelekeco) (noun M) a short stick (usually two) to beat a log of wood in order to attract white ants (emome – a dark variety of flying ants) to come outside (the sound of the log being beaten deceives the white ants as if raindrops). 
epelepelet (plural ipelepelen) (noun M) a butterfly. 
epeleuna (adjective) new; invented; improvised. 
epelu (plural ipelui) (noun M) a task; a job; an assignment of work; a duty, office. cp. ekori. iswamaete kesi epelu: ejaas kesi toma opelu: they are doing a task or a work. 
epem1 (plural ipemion) (noun M) a platform or elevation of the floor used as sleeping place or bed; a dais; any little elevation or platform as in a law court (where judges sit). cp. etut. 
epem2 (plural ipemion) (noun M) a rack made of twigs in the form of a huge wicker basket raised off the ground by four poles and used as a grain store. 
epene (plural ipenei) (noun M) (in football) a spot kick or penalty. 
epeneesi (plural ipeneesin) (noun M) a perennial evergreen shade tree producing jackfruit, Artocarpus heterophyllus. 
epenek (plural ipeneka) (noun M) a beard (on the lower jaw); the chin. 
epepe (adjective) sensitive; guilt-conscious; susceptible epepe nges etau: she/he is very sensitive; she/he is very hot-tempered or very excitable; she/he is on edge. loepepe etau (plural luepepe itawon): a sensitive person. 
epepet (plural ipepen) (noun M) a scapula; a shoulder blade. cp. ekeper: shoulder. cp. elagagamit: a collar-bone or clavicle.
eperet (singular noun M) a parade; a march past; a procession; a display or pageant; a salute. ainom eperet: (of a soldier or policeman) to salute. alosit eperet: to walk in procession. aibwo eperet: to stand in a parade.
eperit (plural iperin) (noun M) a pair; two together. eperit lok’amuk: a pair of shoes. 
eperot (plural iperon) (noun M) a sleeping place. etogo loperot: house for sleeping in; accommodation; a sleeping apartment. 
epesiara (adjective) great; spread out; commodious. 
epesurone (singular noun M) girlhood; adolescence of girls. 
epeta (plural ipetai) (noun M) a ring; a wedding; a washer (of a screw and bolt); a bolt and screw; a hinge (of a door). aiwen epeta: to marry in church; to wed. aberu naka epeta: a wedded wife, i.e. a woman married in church. 
epetet (plural ipeteta) (noun M) a tree, Ambatch. herminiera elaphroxylon. 
epetono (plural epetoko) (adjective) fond of kicking; fond of playing football; good at playing football. 
epetuno (adjective) convex; turned in; curved. 
epidaponi (plural ipidaponio) (noun M) a tree, Hymenocardia acida. 
epiding (plural ipidinga) (noun M) gardens around the home; a back entrance to a traditional house; a small opening or gap in a fence (used as private entrance). 
epii (plural ipiin) (noun M) a reed, Kecker opsis uniseta; a drinking tube for beer (made of epii reed). cp. emanit, ejokorot. epii loka ekulam: the ureter or urethra (the urine tubes in general).
epiibiro (plural ipiibiroi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a kitchen; a cooking place. cp. eipois 
epiigo (plural ipiigoi) (noun M) a handcuff; manacle; shackle; chain; cuff. cp. auno
epiila (plural ipiilai) (noun M) (outside Usuk) groundnut sauce. aitokony epiila: aitokony abalang: to let a woman taste salt for the first time after birth. 
epiirioit (plural ipiiriotin) (noun M) a clever person; an expert; an expatriate; one with insight or intelligence. 
epiiryana (plural epiiryaka) (adjective) clever; sharp-witted; witty; cunning; wise. epiryana k’akanin: dexterous. 
epiiso (plural ipiison) (noun M) a needle; an injection. adumun epiiso: aicum epiiso: to receive an injection. icumitai nges epiiso: she/he has received an injection. icumit ngesi epiiso: the needle has pricked her/him. 
epiit (singular noun M) a fig tree. cp. abobore, ewoke, ekubui. 
epiki (singular noun M) speculation; betting; gaming; wager; gambling game. ainom epiki: to gamble, wager, or bet. enoman epiki: a gambler; a speculator.
epikipik (plural ipikipikin) (noun M) a motorcycle; a motorbike; a scrambler. 
epikisit (plural ipikis) (noun M) the lower leg, i.e. the calf and the shin. 
epikoron (plural epikorok) (noun M) a conqueror; a subjugator; a victor. 
epilias (plural ipiliasia) (noun M) a snake, Chlorophis. 
epilili (plural ipilili) (noun M) (outside Usuk) groundnut sauce; a relish. 
epilipili (plural ipilipilin) (noun M) (outside Usuk) red pepper; chillies. cp. emulalu. 
epima (plural ipimai) (noun M) a dagger; a sword; a rapier. cp. ebenet, ekileng.
epinipinit (plural ipinipinin) (noun M) a small leakage; a puncture; the urethra; any duct in the body. 
epinot (plural ipinon) (noun M) a cowbell. cp. esimat: a goat bell. edongot: a big Ben or bell. 
epiokoit (plural ipioko) (noun M) (Usuk) a self-seeded groundnuts. cp. aropiny. 
epiororo (plural ipiororoi) (noun M) a flywheel of a cycle. cp. ekiiwa. 
Epiot (noun M) name of the first born boy twin (because it was the victor, i.e. aipior). (note: the second born boy twin is called Edongot or Odong because it remained behind, i.e. aidong).
epipa (plural ipipai) (noun M) a big barrel; a big metallic tank or drum for storing liquids. 
epipil (adjective) painful; agonizing; excruciating; aching; hurting; sore. 
epipiot (plural ipip) (noun M) the ear-hole (auditory canal); ear-opening; a small hole (anywhere); a pore. kitoik epipiot: listen well (by approaching ear). 
epir (plural ipirin) (noun M) a pole; a pillar; a post; a spoke of a wheel; a stay, buttress, or support; a leader; the big man. epir lok’aica: a ray of light. epir loegaali: a bicycle spoke. epir lok’akim: an electricity post or pole. epir lok’esimu: an telephone or telegraph post or pole.ingai ekusipir?: who is your leader or hero? epir lok’ere: the owner of a home; mainstay or support of a family. 
epiria (singular noun M) green moss (on top of the water or on rock or bark of trees); lichen; a shoal of fish. 
epirididi (plural ipirididin) (noun M) a severe diarrhoea onset. cp. engerebebe.
epirio1 (collective noun M) a flock of birds; a flight of birds; a bevy; a group (of anything raising dust); a caravan (of vehicles); a procession. cp. esipani
epirio2 (noun M) a sharp grass with a hollow stem blown by children like a mouth organ, Otenuin concinnum. 
epiro (noun M) a grass, Loudetia superba. 
epirya (adjective) (of colour) green; emerald; jade; lime colour. cp. lopir.
episikopi (plural ipisikopin) (noun M) a Roman Catholic bishop. cp. ekadinaali
epit1 (adverb) if not. epit eong adeka, ti mam kidumak eong ore: if I had not been ill, you would not have found me at home. cp. kedim.
epit2 (plural ipitesio) (noun M) a habit; a custom.
epiteni (plural ipitenio) (noun M) a habit; a custom; a kind; a sort. 
epitina (singular noun M) dislike; enmity; antipathy. kiinakit ijo eong epitina: kitokokolit ijo eong: you are my rival; you are against me; you have something against me. 
epitinan (plural epitinak) (noun M) a misanthrope; an envious person. 
epiu1 (plural ipiwan) (noun M) a large crocodile; an alligator. cp. akinyang: small crocodile. 
epiu2 (singular noun M) bile; gall. ecoe loka epiu: gall-bladder. epinipinit loka epiu: bile duct.
epiye (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a cedar tree, Terminalia brownii. Its leaves and bark are medicinal, the leaves are fodder and mulch, while wood can be used as firewood and charcoal.
epodo (plural ipodoi) (noun M) East African yellow-wood tree, Podocarpus latifolius. It is used as a shade and an ornamental avenue tree, as well as providing timber and firewood.
epodono (plural epodoko) (adjective) fond of worrying, complaining, grousing, or grumbling. 
epogana (plural epogaka) (adjective) (to be) inclined to swagger, brag, boast, etc 
epoget (singular noun M) pride; contumely; smugness; conceit; arrogance. 
epoison (singular noun M) poison. aingalakin epoison: to poison. cp. eidada, ekia
epokono (plural epokoko) (adjective) (of a person) inclined to take in big quantities; greedy; ravenous; voracious; gluttonous. 
epol (plural epolok) (adjective) big; ample; important; much; fundamental; burly. epol ecelet: there is much quarrelling or much noise. epol akoik: the stomach is big; she is pregnant. 
epola (plural ipolai) (noun M) shame; disgrace; ignominy; embarrassment; indignity; dishonour. 
epoli (plural ipolin) (noun M) a water-buck (a wild game). 
epolio (singular noun M) polio; poliomyelitis, i.e. a disease that causes crippling of limbs. cp. angwalu 
epolisit (plural ipolisin) (noun M) a policeman; a cop; a constable. cp. esirikaalet, epolisit
epolitisian (plural ipolitisians) (noun M) a male politician; a male member of parliament.
epolokilokia (noun M) a plant, Opilia celtidifolia.
epolomuny (plural ipolomunyo) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet with a thick testa. 
epolon (plural ipolok) (noun M) a man in the age range 42–66 years; an old man. 
epolopolot (plural epolopoloto) (adverb) rather big, old, important, considerable. 
epolot (plural ipolon) (noun M) a line of thatch in a traditional Usuk hut or granary. 
epone (plural iponesio) (noun M) a kind; a habit; a manner; a method or methodology; a character; a sort; a behaviour; a custom; a bearing; a category; know-how. eroko iponesio kec: their manners are bad. ipoitoi inyamat luka iponesio kere: all kinds of food have been prepared. 
eponga (plural ipongai) (noun M) a Barbary mouse, Arvicanthis abyssinicus. 
epongai (plural iponga) (noun M) a shrub whose root is an ingredient in a potion taken by women to accelerate the expulsion of the placenta (afterbirth) or a diarrhoeal remedy, Dombeya rotundifolia. 
eponoi (plural ipon) (noun M) a lip, i.e. the flesh forming the mouth or vaginal opening; the labium. 
epoode (adjective) (of speech) flagrant; free; at liberty. inera ngol epoode: he is talking at liberty (without fearing any consequences).
epopong (plural ipopongo) (noun M) euphorbia or cactus tree, Euphorbia candelabrum. Its copious milky sap is eye poison and also applied to swollen glands of cattle suffering from east-coast fever. The tree can be used as a live fence. The hollow wood is used for carving musical instruments like thumb pianos (akoogoi).
epori (plural eporete) (adjective) (of bird, aeroplane, etc) flies; can be airborne. 
eporiporit (plural iporipor) (noun M) a moth. 
eporiposi (noun M) a plant, Asclepias semilunata, Clotalaria intermedia. 
eporitoi (adjective) (of bird, aircraft, etc) in flight; in the skies; airborne. 
eporo (plural iporoi) (noun M) elopement; flight of love-birds. 
eporokoca1 (noun M) a swamp; blue clay from the swamp; a quagmire or bog. 
eporokoca2 (plural iporokocan) (noun M) a pickaxe. cp. esululu. 
eporokot (plural iporoko) (noun M) a swallow that carries mud in its mouth, Hironde semirufa gordoni. 
epororet (plural ipororeta) (noun M) an aeroplane; a thing to fly with. 
eporoto (plural iporotoi) (noun M) the throat; the voice (a say or influence); a melody or tune. adeka naka iporotoi (noun F) throat infection; tonsilitis. eporoto loko kuju: high voice. eporoto loko kwap: low voice. 
eposita (plural ipositan) (noun M) the post; the post office. 
eposok (adjective) (of a part of a person, animal or plant) brittle; fragile; easily broken. 
epotoido (noun M) a grass, Brachiaria. 
epotolo (plural ipotoloi) (noun M) a military operation of cordon-and-search nature, involving the arrest of suspected wrongdoers such as tax defaulters, rebels, etc. 
epucit (plural ipucito) (noun M) a feast; an initiation feast; a banquet. cp. ainumunum. 
epucono (plural epucoko) (adjective) inclined to be peaceful; peace-loving. 
epude1 (plural ipudei) (noun M) a large cricket (insect). cp. ejiirit, 
epude2 (plural ipudei) (noun M) an ant lion or ant-bear. 
epuding (plural ipudingin) (noun M) pudding. 
epuesa (singular noun M) silver (a precious shiny grey metal widely used for making jewellery and coins). cp. esaabu.
epujait (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a tree, Acacia seyal. 
epuko (plural ipukoi) (noun M) a sack; a bag; a gunny bag. 
epulaani (plural ipulaanin) (noun M) a vest. cp. esaati	
epulaket (plural ipulaketa) (noun M) a resin; rust; frankincense; incense. 
epule1 (adjective) (of quality of cooking) poor; bad. ingo ijo atap epule: you have served bread raw. cp. elingo, engorojojo.
epule2 (noun M) half-cooked or poorly prepared millet bread (atap). ipoit ijo epule: you have cooked badly. cp. ainesu; engorojojo.
epuleera (plural ipuleeran) (noun M) (in the Catholic church) a brother; a vicar; a monk. cp. abikirat
epuliida (plural ipuliidan) (noun M) a lawyer; a pleader, counsel, barrister. 
epuluga (plural ipulugai) (noun M) a nicely prepared groundnut sauce. cp. epilili. 
epungula (plural ipungulai) (noun M) a creeping plant tied on waists or head in a rain dance and from which salt is extracted, Coreopsis ugandiesis. 
epupono (plural epupoko) (adjective) inclined to listen, to obey; obedient; docile; submissive. 
epura (plural ipuran) (noun M) the back; the rear; the flipside; the reverse. 
epurakimat (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes with rough tubers (literally, the old woman’s back).
epureemu (plural ipureemun) (noun M) a frame or structure (of anything). 
epurie (plural epuriete) (adjective) (of potatoes or cassava when well done) floury or dusty; (of the atmosphere) smoky, dusty, foggy, hazy, etc. 
epuripur (noun M) a variety of high-yielding sorghum popular for making industrial beer. erai ‘Eagle Lager’ ajon nuka Epuripur: Eagle Lager is a beer made by Nile Breweries Ltd from Epuripur sorghum. 
epuroguram (plural ipuroguramun) (noun M) a programme; an agenda, plan or schedule; a series of planned projects to be undertaken. cp. epurojekt
epurojekt (plural ipurojektan) (noun M) a project; a plan, scheme or proposal; a research or study assignment. 
epus1 (adjective) (of colour) purple grey. epus kakou: one with grey hair. 
epus2 (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet.
