epuserone (singular noun M) widowhood. cp. aipuseronut. 
epuserut (plural ipuser) (noun M) a widower. cp. apuserut
epusiana (plural epusiaka) (adjective) (of colour) purple-grey. 
epusupus (singular noun M) chickenpox. edekas idwe epusupus: the children have chickenpox. 
eputir (plural iputiro) (noun M) a warthog, Phacochoerus aethiopicus. cp. epege
epuu (plural ipuun) (noun M) a grey plant used in cursing and witchcraft (for example, if it is twisted or a sewing needle is stuck in it, a person being cursed dies – so it is believed), Calostropis procera. 
epuudit (plural ipuudin) (noun M) an artisan; a craftsman. epuudit loka amatapaalin: a bricklayer or mason. epuudit loka abaoi: a carpenter. 
epuuru (plural ipuurun) (noun M) measles.
epuusa (plural ipuusai) (noun M) a jigger; chigoe; chigger. cp. emuuja.
epuuti (plural ipuutin) (noun M) a pace; a stride; a foot measure. 
epuuton (plural ipuutona) (noun M) a tree, Pseudocedrela kotschyi. It grows on sandy plains and its wood is popular for making traditional stools, and the root extract is used to treat wounds caused by gonorrhoea, 
epuwai1 (adverb) aside. kibwaik nges epuwai: put it aside. cp. awai: aside. 
epuwai2 (plural iwaitin) (noun M) one side; the other side. epuwai ekwang, epuwai ereng: one side is white and (the other) one side is red. 
epuwal (plural ipuwalisia)(noun M) contents of stomach (of man or animals). 
epuyo1 (singular noun M) amniotic fluid in animals. cp. akipi: in humans.
epuyo2 (singular noun M) bluish swamp clay used for plastering houses, etc. cp. eporokoca
epwatet (plural ipwateta) (noun M) a shrub, Stereospermum kunthianum. Its branch is used as toothbrush, the fruit chewed with salt is medicine for cough; any toothbrush. 
epwatuna (adjective) clean; polished; cleansed. 
epyana (plural epyaka) (adjective) tasteless; bland; unsavoury; insipid; stale; unexciting. epyana nges akituk: she/he talks nonsense. epyaka akiro kon: there is nothing sensible in what you say. epyana akecebolia: their play is boring.
eraada (plural iraadai) (noun M) a hacksaw. cp. emusumeeni.
eraagi (plural iraagin) (noun M) a colour, dye, tint; a paint; a hue, tone, tinge, sort, type. 
eraakit (plural irarak) (noun M) a man from the Irarak clan; a cock or man with more than the normal number of fingers or toes.
eraana (plural eraaka) (adjective) fertile, productive, prolific, fruitful. 
eracakina (adjective) splashed; fallen; spattered. aracakin akinyet kwap: the butter has spattered on the ground. 
eragwe (noun M) a bush, Flueggea virosa. 
erai (noun M) a grass, Hyperrhenia.
eramatau (noun M) a creeper used as a potion to stimulate love. cp. edusutau, enaabiya
erame (plural iramesio) (noun M) the manner of beating the drum; the drum beat; a rhythm. 
erapakina (adjective) covered; hidden; buried; veiled; concealed. cp. erapap 
erapap (adjective) covered; hidden; buried; veiled; concealed. 
erapara (adjective) screened; covered. cp. erapap. 
erapid (adverb) (manner of shooting with a machine gun) rapid. ainom emuudu erapid: to shoot with bullets coming in quick succession.
eratum (plural iratumo) (noun M) a tree, acasia macrothyrsa. 
eraubei  (noun M) a plant, Indigo fera. 
ere (plural ireria) (noun M) a home; a village; a habitat; a homestead; an abode; a kraal; a residence; a palace. ore: at home; homewards. oreka: my home. kore: from home; at home. ejai nges ore: she/he is at home. iboie ngesi kore: she/he sits at home. ore: at home; in the home. ere lok’apugan: Government headquarters.
-ere verb suffix forming passive infinitive of relative prepositional forms. esokoni ngesi aiboisit na earere ibaren: the butchery is the place where cattle are killed. 
erebeeni (plural irebeenin) (noun M) a spirit-level. cp. elebeni. 
erec (plural ireca) (noun M) a fiscal shrike. 
eredio (plural iredion) (noun M) a radio receiver; a wireless; a walkie-talkie. oredio: on the air; on radio.
ereet (plural ireetin) (noun M) a forehead; a front-face; a brow. lokoreet (adverb) the one in front. oreet (adverb) in front; in the face. oreeteka: in front of me; on my face. 
eregai (plural irega) (noun M) a wait-a-bit shrub or thorn bush, Acacia mellifera. Its bark has medicinal properties. The plant is good for nitrogen fixation and soil conservation, and flowers are bee forage.
erege (plural iregei) (noun M) a fishing net. cp. eboi, ekokota
ereirei (noun M) nasty behaviour; sarcasm; cynicism; irony;  disparagement; ridicule. 
ereit (plural ireitos) (adjective) adverse; detesting; hating; unfriendly to. ereitos kesi idwekec: they are harsh on their children. 
erejesita (plural irejesitan) (noun M) a register; a list; a record.
ereka (plural irekas) (noun M) a spy; a sleuth; a scout; a detective; one who reconnoitres. cp. ekarotan.
erelwe (plural irelwen) (noun M) a railway; a railroad. 
eremokino (adjective) pushed; pressed; hard-pressed. 
ereng (plural erengak) (adjective) (of colour) red; cherry; crimson. erengak ilugai lu America; konye luko India, enyangaaka: American Indians are red; but those of India are brown. 
ereng du (adverb) very (red, crimson, or carmine). 
erengabor (plural irengaboria) (noun M) a Bateleur eagle. 
erengerenget (plural erengerengetos) (adjective) (of colour) cherry; reddish; cerise. 
erepeny (plural irepeny) (noun M) a dwarf; a midget; a pigmy. 
erere1 (adjective) (of urine, anything) rancid; having the smell of urine.
erere2 (noun M) a grass, Hyparrhenia filipendula.
ereret1 (plural irerei, ireren) (noun M) the big pelican; African saddle-billed stork, Balaeniceps rex. 
ereret2 (plural ireren) (noun M) a brim (of a vessel); an edge (of a container); a hem (of a cloth). ileleba eikopo aitodol oreret: the cup is full to the brim. ereret loka egoe: the hem of the cloth. 
eriago (plural iriagon) (noun M) a bag; a pocket; a satchel. 
eriau (singular noun M) a grass that you cut today and the next day it has germinated, Digitaria volutina. 
eribik (adjective) jet black; very black; pitch dark; shining black. 
eribit (plural iribin) (noun M) black cloth; alpaca; a rivet (a metal peg attaching or joining two metal parts together). 
eridakina (adjective) (of clothes) tight; (of space) squeezed; stretched. 
erie (plural eriete) (adjective) awry; bent; curved. 
eriga (noun M) a common game hunt; a hedge; a fence. koyangaasi akituk origa: take the cows into the fence. 
eriiga (plural iriigai) (noun M) a sickle; a scythe. cp. engeret
eriim (adjective) (of anything) thin; lithe; slender. eriim kesi: they are thin. anyait naeriim: a thin blade of grass. 
eriketait (plural iriketa) (noun M) a rope or chain or stick (to lead with). 
erikot (plural irikoi) (noun M) a chain; a bond. ekosio erikot: dancing in circles; dancing hand-in-hand, with joined hands. 
erimaana (plural erimaaka) (adjective) docile; obedient; faithful; amenable; compliant; complaisant. 
eringa1 (adverb) still; not yet. eringa iswamai: she/he is still working. not yet (used with relative prepositional forms). eringa kiswama: it has not yet been done. eringa ebuno: she/he has not yet come. eringa (by itself): not yet. cp. eroko; mam ber: not yet.
eringa2 (conjunction) before. 
erinyin (adjective) (of cloth, etc) hard (to the touch). 
erionget (plural iriongeta) (noun M) a group; a company; a flock; an army; a league; a crowd (not used for a football team). erionget lomam egongakina apugan: a non-governmental organisation. iriongeta luapolo: development agencies. cp. esipani. 
erionoi (plural iriono) (noun M) a tree used for firewood, poles and charcoal, Margaritaria discoideus. 
erior ki-o (transitive verb) to slander; to talk about somebody; to chat or to talk (in general). cp. einer. 
eripipi (plural iripipin) (noun M) a wooden framework or structure for drying simsim stalks before extracting seeds; a statistical table. 
eripooti (plural iripootin) (noun M) a report; information; details. 
eriribwas (plural iriribwasia) (noun M) a sparrow-hawk. 
eririo (plural iririoi) (noun M) a plant from which salt is extracted, Lippia adoensis. 
eris (plural irisai) (noun M) a leopard, Panthera pardus. cp. arara
erit (noun M) mud (especially that in a wet kraal or swamp). 
eritanit (plural iritan) (noun M) a common earthworm. 
erite (plural iritei) (noun M) a winnowing tray made of woven withies (reeds) and smeared with cow-dung. cp. asiniya
eroet (plural iroeta) (noun M) a developing breast of a young girl. 
erogec (plural irogeca) (noun M) a kind of tree. 
erogoit (plural irogoi) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. 
eroirwo (singular noun M) rust; mould; mildew. 
erojiroj (plural irojiroja) (noun M) elephantiasis of the legs or scrotum. cp. ebatiira: elephantiasis of the legs. akuwe: elephantiasis of the scrotum. cp. abotirir.
erojo (plural irojoi) (noun M) a moored trap made of netted strings with a noose that tightens behind the trapped animal as it enters deeper into the trap; a squirrel trap made from sisal or reeds.
eroko1 (adverb) still; meanwhile; not yet; ere, i.e. before (used with relative prepositional verbs to mean ‘not yet’). eroko ngesi iswamai: she/he is still working. eroko kiswama: mam iswamat: she/he has not yet done. eroko (by itself): not yet. abu ejakait? eroko: has the chief come? not yet. lueroko iitunitos: those who still remember. 
eroko2 (plural of erono) (adjective) bad; appalling; horrific; awful; terrible; dreadful. eroko kesi: they are bad. 
erokon (plural irokonin, irokono) (noun M) a gouge or chisel; an adze; a small traditional hoe used for hollowing or smoothing out wood. 
erokono (plural erokoko) (adjective) fond of adopting or copying vice or any habits. 
erokorokotoi (noun M) a bush, Capparis tomentosa. Its root extract is very bitter and is used as a fever remedy. 
eromo (plural iromoi) (noun M) a water-rat, Aethomya kaiseri. 
erongat (plural irongan) (noun M) a mountain range. cp. eukot.
erono (plural eroko) (adjective) bad; evil; offensive; odious; invalid; wicked; depraved; false; spoiled; dirty. erono noi: atrocious. 
erony (plural ironya) (noun M) (formerly) an administrative unit smaller than eitela (parish); a piece of land occupied by families of common lineage; a sub-parish; a communal grazing land; a sub-parish chief.
eroodi (plural iroodin) (noun M) a pair of trousers or slacks. cp. edabada.
eropit (plural iropito) (noun M) a salary; a pay; a reward; an emolument, etc cp. aropetait.
erorokana (plural erorokaka) (adjective) avaricious; greedy; grasping. 
erot (plural irotin) (noun M) an avenue; a lane; a street; a path; a road; a way; a direction; a means, course. kaolikit eong erot lodumunet ibaren: I do not know how to get, or I have no means of getting, cattle or dowry. irotin luilogas: labyrinth; a maze.
eroyet (plural iroyeta) (noun M) death; demise. aikony eroyet: to die. anyam nges eroyet: she/he died. cp. eroet.
erubit (plural erubitos) (adjective) intact; whole; complete; full; untouched; unscathed. 
erujana (plural erujaka) (adjective) (of an embrocation) binding; astringent. 
erukudo (plural irukudoi) (noun M) a murram or tarmac road; a highway. cp. eguudo.
erumunan (plural erumunak) (noun M) an heir; a successor. adeka naerumunan: an infectious or contagious disease. cp. emusika.
eruono (plural eruoko) (adjective) noisy; sounding; sonorous; inclined to be noisy. 
erupe (plural irupei) (noun M) a malicious report. akiru naka erupe (noun F) short-rains preceding the return of the wet season. 
erurwo (singular noun M) a plunder; a raid; a foray. 
erusurus (singular noun M) a soft and edible variety of mushroom. cp. ebekubeku, ebaale
erute (plural irutei) (noun M) a gate; the entrance to a kraal; a culvert; a gateway. 
erwaara (adjective) a corruption of erioro: tall; straight up. 
erwaitoi (adjective) (of a person) excitable; neurotic. 
erwanit (noun M) the multiplication sign X; multiplication. airwana: to multiply. airwanaar: to multiply; to forecast; to extrapolate. 
erwerweet (plural irwerween) (noun M) a big black tit (bird). 
erwom (singular noun M) rumours; unverified news. Erwom ka Iteso: a defunct Ateso language newspaper during colonial times, i.e. the 1950s. cp. abekoi, aabe. 
erwopookot (plural irwopookon) (noun M) an edible plant whose pounded roots are used as a liniment. 
eryeco (plural iryecoi) (noun M) a tree, Bridelia sceleroneulioides. 
eryor ki-o (intransitive verb) to talk; to speak; to converse or discuss. eryor loka adotea erai loesil noi: the language of prostitutes is very obscene.
esaabu (plural isaabun) (noun M) gold (a soft yellow precious metal used for making jewellery, coins, etc). cp. epuesa
esaala (plural isaalan) (noun M) a petition (an appeal, entreaty, prayer, request, solicitation, supplication). 
esaapa (plural isaapan) (noun M) a papyrus mat (for any purpose). cp. epar; emukeeka
esaasa (plural isaasan) (noun M) (formerly) county chieftainship. cp. ebuku. 
esaasaa (plural isaasaan) (noun M) a wild oil palm-tree, Elaeis guineensis. Its seeds are used in making palm oil, the oil is medicinal properties and also used in soap-making, while sap is for making palm wine.
esaati (plural isaatin) (noun M) a shirt (for men). cp. asaati: a blouse.
esaawa (plural isaawan) (noun M) a clock; an hour; a watch, chronometer; time. adolo isaawan idi?: what time is it? mam eong ajeni esaawa: I don't know the time. isaawan ikany luka tupuruc: eleven o’clock in the morning. esaawa ediope loka abong: seven o’clock in the evening. esaawa kere: all the time; always. cp. akolongit.
esabana (plural esabaka) (adjective) fond of telling lies; deceitful. 
esabet (plural isabeta) (noun M) a lie; falsehood; lying; fibbing. 
esabibu (plural isabibun) (noun M) (Biblical) a fig tree; vine. araito nuka esabibu: grapes. 
esabiiti (plural isabiitin) (noun M) a week. osabiiti ejaas apaarasia akany kaare: a week has seven days. apaarasia nuesabiiti: days of the week. Naesabiiti: Sunday. Naebalaasa: Monday. Naiyareit: Tuesday; the second. Nakiuniet: Wednesday; the third. Nakiongonet: Thursday; the fourth. Naikanyet: Friday; the fifth. Naemukaaga: Saturday.
esabuli (plural isabulin) (noun M) a psalm. Isabulin: the Book of Psalms (in the Old Testament of the Bible).
esacana (plural esacaka) (adjective) fond of forsaking; refraining from; abandoning; renouncing; rejecting, or avoiding.
-esacit (noun suffix): naesacit (plural nuesacito) a woman who refuses a man. esacit ngesi ikiliok: she refrains from sexual intercourse with men. 
esae (singular noun M) (any kind of) perfume; fragrance; cologne; aroma; scent. 
esagaite (plural isagaiten) (noun M) an enclosure (made of reeds, sedge, etc) for bathing in; a (urinal) shelter. 
esagari (plural isagarin) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. 
esairi (plural isairin) (noun M) barley cereal. 
esakale (noun M) a grass, Sorghum arundinacea. 
esakarameetu (plural isakarameetun) (noun M) a sacrament. esakarameetu loka oridini: the sacrament of priesthood. 
esalana (plural esalaka) (adjective) inclined to be absent. 
esalir (plural isaliro) (noun M) a bird’s crest; tuft of hair; a lion’s mane; forelock. 
esamai (plural isama) (noun M) a swamp; a river; a marshland. 
Esamariat (plural Isamarian) (noun M) a Samaritan, one from (biblical) Samaria. 
esanga (plural isangai) (noun M) ivory; an elephant tusk. cp. ikel k’etom.
esange (singular noun M) the end; the limit; termination; boundary; bounds; abrogation. esange ngol: that is the end.
esangisang (plural isangisangin) (noun M) a kind of climbing plant. 
esanyir (plural isanyir) (noun M) bristling (of dog or cat when afraid). cp. esalir, esapir. 
esao (plural isaon) (noun M) a handbag; bag; satchel; pocket; pouch. 
esapaali (plural isapaalin) (noun M) a journey; a safari; a travelling; a trip. (slang) a sexual round (one trip being equivalent to an orgasm).
esapat (plural isapa) (noun M) a young man of 18–26 years of age; (formerly) an apprentice doing menial tasks for his sponsor befor initiation to a senior age group. cp. apese: a girl of 18 – 26 years old. esapanete isapa: the boys are getting initiated to full-grown men. 
esapir (plural isapir) (noun M) a man or boy with ruffled or unkempt hair; one who is unkempt. 
esapuli (plural isapulin) (noun M) a rosary. 
esas (plural isasia) (noun M) (formerly) a stick carried by pregnant women (the number of those sticks representing the total pregnancies she has had to date). 
esasam (adjective) (of fermented milk, beer, etc) sour. 
esasame (plural isasamei) (noun M) a kind of tree with sweet fruit. 
esasedoti (plural isasedotin) (noun M) a corruption of esaseredooti: a priest.
esaseredooti (plural isaseredootin) (noun M) a Roman Catholic priest. 
esaseredootone (singular noun M) priesthood. 
esawe (plural isawei) (noun M) a goat paid by the brother of the bride to those who bring the dowry from the in-laws. 
Esebeit (plural Isebei) (noun M) a man native to former Sebei (the present day Kapchorwa district); a Sabiny man. Isebei: the Sabiny people (in general). cp. eyale.
esedeny (adjective) (of a well, hole, pit) shallow, not deep; (of ideas) trite, frivolous, silly, trifling; (of actions) inconsequential, insignificant, superficial. 
Eseerait (plural Iseera) (noun M) a man from Serere county in Soroti district. 
eseere (noun M) a grass used as a charm, Sorghum rigidifolium. 
esega (plural esegas) (adjective) pure; clean; neat; dainty. 
esegana (plural esegaka) (adjective) fond of cleanliness, neatness; fond of being dainty. 
esegaru (singular noun M) a plant, Polygonum. 
esege (noun M) a water grass, Pennicetum; a plant, Sesbania. 
esegis (plural isegisia) (noun M) a thing which is for personal care or hygiene; personal thing. iboro lusegis: personal effects. 
esegwa (plural isegwai) (noun M) a pole for pushing or propelling a canoe into deep waters (so that the boat engine can be switched on, or for rowing to start). 
esekeloi (singular noun M) mockery; ridicule; sarcasm.
esekeretariat (plural isekeretarian) (noun M) a secretariat; the administrative department of any large organisation, its staff or premises.
esel (plural iselyo) (noun M) a big dress that sways about as the wearer walks. ailoli iselyo: to be uneasy. cp. enapat.
esele1 (plural iselei) (noun M) a large venomous arboreal snake. 
esele2 (plural iselei) (noun M) a secretary bird, Saggitarius serpentarius. 
eselel (adjective) (of skin or surface) smooth; shined; glistened; glossed. 
eselotep (singular noun M) cellotape or adhesive sticker. eselotep erai amilimilit naiminai epuwai: cellotape is a synthetic tape that is sticky on one side.
esemutuudu (plural isemutuudun) (noun M) a Bagruss fish. cp. okuk.
esenot (plural isenon) (noun M) one to be beaten. 
eseny (singular noun M) AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome); a health condition transmitted by a virus which attacks a person’s immune system and leaving the person vulnerable, often emaciated and sickly. cp. esilim.
esenyit (plural esenyitos) (adjective) (of a person or animal) thin; lean; emaciated; withered.
esepuria (plural isepurian) (noun M) a saucepan; a metallic cooking pot. 
eseuna (plural iseuna) (noun M) elected; sorted; chosen; picked; reserved. 
esiaale (plural isiaalen) (noun M) (formerly) a woman's pudendal fringe of beads. cp. arobat: apron made of strips of hide. 
esiaduk (plural isiaduko) (noun M) (in children) cranial fissure (fontanelle); the top of the head. 
esial (plural isialia) (noun M) an end; the aim. 
esibilian (plural isibilians) (noun M) a civilian; a man who is not a member of the armed forces or the police force. 
esicatan (plural esicatak) (noun M) a support; a prop. erai ngesi esicatan loka totoke: he is the support of his mother. 
esidaani (plural isidaanin) (noun M) an injection; a needle for administering drugs. cp. epiiso, ekus. 
esidengideng (plural isidengidengio) (noun M) the worm that cuts trees round the trunk till they fall; a fissure in palms of hand or foot. esidengideng lok’akit: sore on ear. 
esidepidep (plural isidepidepio) (noun M) epiglottis; tonsil; uvula. 
esidokokot (plural isidokokon) (noun M) the protruding back of the head. 
esidongororot (plural isidongoror) (noun M) elbow joint. cp. edongororot.
esiedan (plural isiedana) (noun M) a Thomson’s gazelle, Gazella thomsoni. 
esiegot (plural isiegoto) (noun M) a reddish-brown roan antelope, Hippotragus equinus. 
Esiepet (plural Isiepei) (noun M) a Masai tribesman from Kenya or Tanzania (formerly a nomadic tribe, of Nilo-Hamitic origin). cp. Eturukanat.
esiepit (plural isiep) (noun M) a tree from which they cut sticks used at ajosi dances, Grewia nyanze. cp. ebela. 
esigala (plural isigalan) (noun M) a cigarette. 
esigalikinan (plural esigalikinak) (noun M) assistant; a helper. cp. lokesigalikinan
esigarikiring (plural isigarikiringio) (noun M) a spiny asparagus plant, Asparagus plumosa. 
esigigir (plural isigigirio) (noun M) the spine or fins of fish. aisigigirit ajul: to make the hair stand on end (as of dog, a zebra, a donkey, cat or he-goat fighting). 
esigirait (plural isigira) (noun M) a cowrie shell. 
esigiria (plural isigirian) (noun M) a male donkey; a jackass. cp. asigiria.
esigirio (noun M) a plant, Amaranthus spinosus. 
esigitan (plural isigitana) (noun M) a nail splinter; a nail-fold. 
esiilyana (plural esiilyaka) (adjective) filthy; lewd; very dirty; repulsive in appearance; unclean; loathsome; shocking. 
esiisa (plural isiisan) (noun M) the brakes (of a bicycle or a motorcar). cp. eisiisa.
esik (singular noun M) honey. esik loka ao: bees honey. esik loka aamimit: small bees honey. akapet naka ao: honeycomb. 
esikarukaru (plural isikarukarun) (noun M) a plant whose root extract is drank as a cure for a hydrocele (elephantiasis of the scrotum), Vitex doniana. 
esikitoit (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis turgida. 
esil1 (plural esiliok) (adjective) unbecoming; unseemly; illicit; displeasing; evil; bad; ugly; unlawful. esil ekonigoe: your dress in unbecoming (dirty or ill-fitting). akiro nuesiliok: bad, dirty, idle talk; nonsense. 
esil2 (plural esiliok, esilok) (adjective) empty; uninhabited; solitary; lonely; desolate; deserted; dreary. 
esilang (plural isilanga) (noun M) a bush or tree, Ziziphus abyssinica. Uses: the bushes can be used as live fence; its sticks provide fuel as firewood and charcoal; cinnamon-coloured dye is got from its bark.
esilim (singular noun M) acquired immuno-deficiency syndrome (AIDS) or human immuno-deficiency virus (HIV) - a sexually transmitted disease, that is incurable at the moment, that is decimating the human population seriously. cp. eseny.
esiliot (plural isilion) (noun M) a dirty person (figurative) a hog. 
esilito (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis superba. 
esiloewa (noun M) a grass, Bothriochloa blabra. cp. esilito.
esilot1 (plural isilo) (noun M) a hair of cow’s tail; a hair of giraffe’s tail; a trap (made of string with a noose set from sticks put in the tracks of animals or birds) to catch small animals and birds; the stamen of flowers; a fibre (as in some fruits or root tubers). esilot loka acokit: shoot of potato (beginning of potato). 
esilot2 (plural isilo) (noun M) placenta; placental membrane (of human beings). 
esimamor (plural isimamor) (noun M) a dwarf mouse, Leggada bella. 
esimat (plural isiman) (noun M) a bell worn by toddlers or by dancers on the ankles. cp. ecirit.
esimato (plural isimaton) (noun M) a certain bush plant. 
esimit (uncountable noun M) cement; concrete; mortar; plaster of Paris; epoxy. 
esimooni (plural isimoonin) (noun M) (formerly) a fifty cents piece. 
esimu (plural isimun) (noun M) (formerly) a telegraph; a telephone; telegram; cable. ainom esimu: to make a telephone call. abongokin esimu; alemun esimu: to answer the telephone; to pick up the telephone when it rings and speak to the person who is calling. esimu lok’akan: a handset; a mobile phone. esimu lok’arwatat: wall-mounted phone; a phone booth.
esineema (plural isineeman) (noun M) a cinema; a video film; a movie; a dramatisation. 
esingelelet (plural isingelel) (noun M) a small black or brown sugar ant. 
esingingir (plural isingingir) (noun M) a line on forehead. 
esingorot (plural isingoron) (noun M) an elbow. cp. edongororot, esidongororot.
esinyokit (plural isinyok) (noun M) a white particle in beer i.e. poorly ground yeast. aituk isinyok: to drink millet or sorghum beer in a calabash. alosit aituk isinyok: to go to drink beer (ajon).
esiomit (plural isiomito) (noun M) gossip; backbiting; a little hollow near a well where women place their water pots whilst they gossip about their husbands). ‘koom esiomit’: said by emuron to the person consulting him about some misfortune, meaning that he wants the earth from the above pothole, with which he mixes his medicine. 
esiorot (adjective) dead-straight; straight without a bend; straight as a die. 
esipaana (plural isipaanan) (noun M) a spanner or wrench (of a car, plough, etc). cp. elacet, ecuuma.
esipani (plural isipanin) (noun M) a flock; a herd; a team; a crowd, or a host (of men or animals). cp. epirio.
esipiidi (plural isipiidin) (noun M) a speed; haste; a hurry. aibunyit amotoka esipiidi loetyono noi: to move a motorcar at high speed. 
esipiran (singular noun M) a wood weevil. epol esipiran kodula: there are a lot of weevils in the food store. 
esipo (plural esipos) (adjective) firm; rooted; established; steadfast; loyal. 
esipokina (adjective) upright; straight; erect; standing. enyek eong ere esipokina: I left when the home was already established. 
esirapurap (plural isirapurapun) (noun M) a skin on boiled milk; a membrane (as around bowels or in plants); a membrane in general. 
esire (plural isirei) (noun M) a wild cat. 
esirikaalet (plural isirikaalei) (noun M) a soldier; a security guard; a sentry. cp. epolisit
esirike (singular noun M) a grass, Digitaria abyssinica; eragrostis aspera
esiro (plural isiroi) (noun M) a small antelope, Damara (Kirk’s) dik-dik, Madoqua kirkii. cp. amor, amiam.
esirut (plural isiru) (noun M) a mosquito. 
esisi1 (adjective) stinking; smelling like a billy goat (he-goat) or a crushed bedbug. 
esisi2 (plural isisi) (noun M) a bedbug. cp. ecerenit. ecwarenit. 
esisian (plural esisiak) (noun M) a learner; a pupil; a disciple; an apprentice; a student. cp. ekesisian
esisianakinan (plural esisianakinak) (noun M) a teacher; schoolmaster; professor. cp. ekesisianakinan
esisiar (plural isisiarin) (noun M) earwig (an insect with pincers at the end of its body, once thought to crawl into the person’s brain through the ear). 
esisiarit (plural isisiara) (noun M) crossroads; bifurcation; junction. 
esisiit (singular noun M) a weed, Bidens pilosa. cp. enyikibon.
esisio (plural isision) (noun M) a grasshopper, Phimateus.
esitaali (plural isitaalin) (noun M) a margin in a writing book; a line on an ironed cloth; a crease; a pleat; a fold. cp. ekokoro. 
esiteseni (plural isitesenin) (noun M) a railway, radio or police station. 
esiyana (plural esiyaka) (adjective) (of a person or an animal) fond of escaping or deserting a place or a cause. cp. esyana: (of a person) kind; merciful; generous; hospitable.
esoda (singular noun M) soda – carbonated soft drink like Coke or Pepsi. 
esode (noun M) commercial millet or sorghum brew. cp. ekamule.
esogana (plural esogaka) (adjective) vain; vainglorious; proud; swaggering, blustering; swanking. 
esogim (adjective) awe-inspiring; dire; eerie; repulsive; dreadful; horrifying; fearsome; terrifying; ferocious. 
esogo (plural isogoi) (noun M) a weaverbird, Reichenow’s weaver. 
esogol (adjective) inconvenient; awkward; difficult. 
esogom (plural isogom) (noun M) a tall and thin man. 
esogomit (plural isogom) (noun M) intestinal roundworm; a kind of water beetle. 
esokoko (plural isokokoi) (noun M) a tree, Acasia senegalens. 
esokolet (plural isokoleten) (noun M) a worn out cloth (formerly used as underwear by women); a menstrual pad. cp. edapaic, eyokobiyat. 
esokooni (plural isokoonin) (noun M) a marketplace; a market (demand for a commodity or service). 
esokot (plural isokono) (noun M) a narrow path for walking people; a foot-path; a spoor; a lone game path. 
esokotan (plural isokotak) (noun M) one who rolls tobacco. esokotan etaba: a tobacco roller.
esolima (plural isolimai) (noun M) a house rat (that often eats people’s feet), Rattus rattus. cp. emir
esolo (singular noun M) a tax (of any kind) - import or export duty; poll-tax; graduated tax. alemun esolo: to pay tax. aitelem esolo: to tax, i.e. to levy taxes (of any kind). 
esoman (plural esomak) (noun M) an employee; a worker. cp. eswaman.
esomero (plural isomeron) (noun M) a school (primary school, secondary school, or college). 
esomeroit (plural isomero) (noun M) a school boy; a student; a school-goer. 
esomesan (plural esomesak) (noun M) (archaic) a literacy teacher. cp. aasioman
esonget (plural isongen) (noun M) a joint (of anything); a node in wood; a joint in a stalk; a joint in finger; a segment (of sugarcane, etc). 
esooda (plural isoodai) (noun M) a corner or angle of a house or an object. 
esorokan (plural isorokana) (noun M) a young bull. cp. etoba, emong.
esorom (plural isoroma) (noun M) nasal discharge; mucus. 
esos (plural isosio) (noun M) a cone-flute or whistle made of goat horn and blown across the wider end of the cone. 
esosol (adjective) (of badly brewed beer) stale; sour; (of fermented milk, etc) pungent. 
esosoloi (noun M) self-conceit; hypocrisy; insincerity. 
esosot (plural isosoi) (noun M) a tiny sieve or filter attached to the bottom of a beer drinking tube called epii. cp. ekodo.
esot (plural isotia) (noun M) a word of admiration or praise, ‘nice big fellow’, ‘good fellow’. ee abu esot ngol: there he comes, the nice big fellow. 
esotoka (plural isotokan) (noun M) rinderpest (a disease of cattle); meat of a cow that died of disease. cp. edeke
esude (plural isudei) (noun M) a species of green monkey. 
esudeny1 (adjective) (of hole, mind, etc) shallow; having little depth. cp. esedeny
esudeny2 (plural isudeny, lusudeny) (noun M) a small person; a dwarf. cp. losudeny
esugugurut (plural isugugur) (noun M) a creeping plant whose leaves are edible (vegetable) when young and the seeds have spikes, Tribulis terrestris. 
esukaali (plural isukaalin) (noun M) sugar in general - cane sugar; blood sugar; beet sugar. adeka naka esukaali: diabetes. ecuuma loka esukaali: a sugar mill. ejai esukaali ocaai: there is sugar in the tea.
esukaligulu (singular noun M) molasses; jaggery. emunaere esukaligulu ajon nuipois ewaragi: molasses are used for brewing crude dry gin.
esukukurut (plural isukukur) (noun M) a black biting ant; a thorny creeping plant. 
esukumawiki (singular noun M) a variety of kale closely resembling ekabit, but most popular in Kenya as a vegetable. cp. ekabit
esukunyoit (plural isukunyo) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a stinking ant, Ponera. 
esukusuk (plural isukusukun) (noun M) a big black African hornbill, believed to herald either rain season or dry season by its hoots (and a long spell of drought is believed to result if this bird is killed). 
esukut1 (noun M) a species of grass, Eragrostis turgida. 
esukut2 (plural isuk) (noun M) a Bambara nut. 
esukuulu (plural isukuulun) (noun M) a school. cp. esomero. 
esulianyana (plural esulianyaka) (adjective) blessed; lucky; prosperous; fortunate. cp. erereng, esyana.
esululu (plural isulului) (noun M) a crowbar; a mattock or pickaxe. 
esulut (noun M) a salute (by raising the hand to the side of the head, palm open, and then lowering it again – like soldiers greeting their superiors).
esumaalit (plural isumaalin) (noun M) an iron nail; a srew; a door bolt; a man from Somalia. 
esumeredede (singular noun M) myalgia; numbness of the limbs; paralysis. 
esumuluso (plural isumulusoi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a key (a lock opener). cp. elacet. 
esupaana (plural esupaaka) (adjective) medium-sized (usually of humans); (of length of anything) brief, curt, or laconic. 
esupono (plural esupoko) (adjective) (of a dog) good at tracking by smell. 
esupuri (plural isupurin) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) zero; nought (from Kiswahili: sifuri: zero) 
esuretait (plural isureta) (noun M) a bamboo plant. It is believed in Teso that beating someone with a bamboo stick makes him/her thin, hence it is forbidden to cane children with bamboo.
esurugia (singular noun M) hillocks in a swamp, home to eitiyo ants. 
esurukamu (noun M) a grass, Hyperrhenia rufa; wild sorghum. 
esurulac (plural isurulaca) (noun M) (literally, the one that scatters lice) a plant whose root is used to make a potion for indigestion, Echinopsis amplexicaulis. 
esurup (singular noun M) milk left in the cow's udder by the milker for the calf to suckle. 
esusut (plural isus) (noun M) a sod of grass; a turf; a sward; the root (of anything); a cassava or groundnut plant. akoto ajenun esusut loka akiro kangun: I want to know the origin of that matter. cp. ekido.
esutuwa (plural isutuwan) (noun M) a store; a storeroom; a warehouse (storehouse, depot, arsenal, repository). 
esuubusa (plural isuubusai) (noun M) a triangle-shaped pastry often filled with mincemeat, peas, beans or vegetables.
esuubusit (plural isuubusin) (noun M) a trader; a merchant. 
esuujo (plural isuujoi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a vegetable marrow; pumpkin. cp. emonyon. 
esuuku (plural isuukui) (noun M) Gonorrhoea condylomata. 
esuula (plural isuulai) (noun M) a chapter (in a book); a lesson. cp. enyukuta: a letter of the alphabet.
esuunyoit (plural isuunyo) (noun M) (Usuk) a large stinking biting black ant, Ponera. cp. esukunyoit
esuuti (plural isuutin) (noun M) a suit; a twinset. cp. egomas. 
eswaagi (plural iswaagin) (noun M) a toothbrush. cp. epwatet. 
eswaat (plural iswaan) (noun M) a tree, Cassia spp. 
Eswairit (plural Iswairin) (noun M) a Swahili man; a Kiswahili speaker; a Swahili thing. 
eswam (plural iswamia) (noun M) a poor person’s dwelling; a simple house or hut; a rat’s nest. 
esweeta (plural isweetan) (noun M) a sweater; a jumper; a pullover. cp. ekooti. 
eswei (singular noun M) a variety of small mushroom growing on an aswei anthill; the mushroom sauce from eswei. 
eswi (plural iswiyon) (noun M) a little thatched house or hut. eswika: my little hut. 
eswii (plural iswiin) (noun M) a point of roof; a pinnacle; a garret; a loft. 
eswiit (plural iswiitin) (noun M) a sweet; a bonbon; a candy. 
esworom (plural isworom) (noun M) mucus; nasal discharge. cp. esorom; ekume. 
esyana (plural esyaka) (adjective) liberal; generous; beneficent; kind; hospitable; accommodating; merciful; humane; affable; benign; charming. 
esyanana (plural esyakaka) (adjective) (always) kind, generous, etc. cp. asyanut. 
esyep (plural isyepion) (noun M) a side; a flank; the coast; the edge. esyep lokecor: coast; beach; seaside; coastline. 
-et or –es suffix denoting instrument, or use made of the object or days of resting. adaket: a thing for carrying; a carrier; a bier. akoto aijiiko nanyamet: I want a spoon for eating. edoket: a landing site. 
etaala1 (plural itaalai) (noun M) a hurricane lamp; a lighting device. 
etaala2 (plural itaalai) (noun M) a sexually transmitted infection causing severe bleeding; genital syphilis; rectal ulcers or swellings (treated traditionally with herbal extracts from epapai, ekwooro and ekisim plants). cp. aukede
etaan (plural itaanin) (noun M) a tonne weight (one thousand kilogrammes).
etaba (singular noun M) tobacco plant, or its cured leaves; snuff tobacco. aimat etaba: to smoke traditionally rolled tobacco; to snuff tobacco powder (through the nose). 
etabaasa (plural itabaasan) (noun M) a hurricane lamp; a lighting device. 
etabaco (noun M) a grass, Sida schimperiana. 
etabiranakulo (plural itabiranakulon) (noun M) a tabernacle; a platform for sacrifice; an altar. 
etabitaban (plural itabitabak) (noun M) a little child; a toddler. 
etacit (plural itacito) (noun M) payment; refund; reward; expiation; remuneration. cp. egelet; etiai lotacat: price to be paid; amount to be paid; a debt. 
etaget (plural itage) (noun M) a banana fruit (cooked or uncooked). 
etajaran (plural etajarak) (noun M) a saviour; a rescuer; a reviver. cp. eetajaran. 
etajik (adjective) tepid; lukewarm. cp. ejalam, ejamut.
etakalari (plural itakalarin) (noun M) an edible plant whose leaf is used as an embrocation to stimulate hair growth, Commicarpus plumbagineus. 
etakara (adjective) blistered; copied; peeled. 
etakuna (adjective) unpasted; unglued; clean. cp. etakara
etakura (plural itakuran) (noun M) a partridge bird; Gedge's francolin. 
etal (plural italia) (noun M) a clan ritual; a clan taboo; a clan custom; abstinence; a caste. 
etalakaaran (plural etalakaarak) (noun M) a comforter; an entertainer; a comic. 
etalisit (plural italisin) (noun M) a courier; a postman; a mail-runner; a messenger.
etaloka (plural italokan) (noun M) a rainbow; the iris (of the eye). 
etaluka (plural italukan) (noun M) a corruption of etaloka: a rainbow; the iris (of the eye). 
etamarukwa (plural itamarukwai) (noun M) a greater bustard (bird). 
etamit (plural etamitos) (adjective) (it/she/he is/I am) fine; okay; in good health; so-so (in reply to the greeting ‘Biai bo akuwan – how are you?’ or ‘Biai bo ngina – how is there?’). 
etamuro (plural itamuroi) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a second; a sixtieth of a minute. cp. iteketeket
etanga (plural itangai) (noun M) a ritual; a rite. 
etangorobobo (plural itangorobobon) (noun M) a cartilage. cp. etaroboboi.
etaniboi (plural itaniboin) (noun M) a tonne boy; one who carries heavy luggage in a bus or truck. cp. epakasit. 
etanoka (noun M) a grass, Setaria verticillata. 
etanunan (plural etanunak) (noun M) a foster-father; step-father
etany (plural itanya) (noun M) a large earthen bowl for serving food; a wooden three-legged stool with a round top for sitting on or used as a leg rest. cp. ebakuli
etanyam akiring (plural itanyam akiring) (noun M) a tree, Abizia sericicephala. 
etapa (plural itapai) (noun M) a hair-removing disease (hair falling out); a ringworm on the scalp. cp. emeimei. 
etapakon (noun M) a kind of herb whose root was used for making cricket balls in Teso in the game of einyure. cp. emijimij. 
etapan (singular noun M) small ants (eating wood of a house). cp. emijimij. 
etapana (plural etapaka) (adjective) inclined to become common, usual, or ordinary. cp. epatana: simple; easy. 
etapipirio (plural itapipirion) (noun M) a whirlwind; a tornado; a cyclone; an eddy; a hurricane; a typhoon. 
etapo (plural itapoi) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a minute; a sixtieth of an hour. cp. edakiika
etapukon (noun M) a plant, Solanum. 
etaroboboi (plural itarobobo) (noun M) gristle (cartilage, especially in meat); cartilage. cp. etangoroboboi
etaryono (plural etaryoko) (adjective) fatty and juicy; greasy. etaryono akiring na: this meat is fatty and juicy. etaryono ekileng lo: this knife is greasy or oily (having been used for cutting fatty meat). 
etasuro (plural itasuron) (noun M) a bad omen (especially feeling feverish before receiving bad news); a foreboding; a portend; a fright; an apprehension.
etatai (singular noun M) a forge; a smithy. 
etatait (plural itatai) (noun M) a male grandchild; a descendant; a grandson. 
etatas (plural itatasia) (noun M) the metal workshop; tool factory. cp. ecuuma.
etate (plural itatei) (noun M) a tree, Gymnosporia senegalensis. 
etau (plural itawon) (noun M) a heart; the mood; the centre or core (of anything); the bosom; greed. aibwaikin etau: to heed; to pay attention; to put the mind to; to be on guard; to take to heart. aomoom k’otau: to consider in one’s heart; to ponder or meditate. kariebi etau: my heart aches. erieba eong etau: I am anxious. etau k’akan: the palm of the hand. etau loka akeju: the sole or the instep of the foot. agir ekatau: I don’t want it. emwana nges etau: she/he is greedy. atikun etau: to search one’s heart. epapero lok’otau: a bossom friend. adeka naka etau: heart disease. ejaas ngesi k’etau: she/he is greedy. cp. aicaket.
etaun (plural itaunin) (noun M) a town; a municipality; a small city. cp. eigoo, ebooma, eibuga
etawoi (plural itawoi) (noun M) a caracal, Caracal caracal; a wooden arch or centering (for building a brick arch). cp. ekwaro: serval cat; egwang; ekapa
eteba (plural itebai) (noun M) a tree whose bark is a treatment for wounds and skin ulcers, Gymnosporia senegalensis. 
etebakori (plural itebakorio) (noun M) a plant, Sida schimperiana. 
eteebe (plural iteeben) (noun M) a plant, Emilia sagitta canna. 
eteede (plural iteedei) (noun M) (Usuk) a female external genitalia - a clitoris. cp. eteele
eteele (plural iteelei) (noun M) (outside Usuk) the female external genitalia - a clitoris. cp. emanerit, ejepel.
eteepelo (plural iteepelon) (noun M) a temple (house of worship). 
etegearan (plural etegearak) (noun M) the author; the initiator; the starter.
etekat (plural itek, itekan) (noun M) a very large granary made of intertwined twigs or reeds. cp. etuja: a mud and grass granary; ekerei: a large reed granary; atukit: a half-granary made of reeds for storing utensils – also called epem.
eteke (plural itekei) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet. 
etekit (plural itekin, itekito) (noun M) a spout of a wide-mouthed vessel. etekit loka aokit: the spout of a small calabash or any scooping vessel. 
etekwa (plural itekwan) (noun M) a tree in the ebata family whose wood is used for carving big drums, the roots and bark are medicinal, while the leaves are used for ripening bananas; the incense tree and whose flowering is an indicator for the beginning of the planting period for finger millet, Albizia coriaria. 
etela (plural itelai) (noun M) the only child (produced by a particular woman). cp. elemura, enume, eteluna. arai Yesu Kristo ikoku itela ka Edeke: Jesus Christ was God’s only child.
etelebision (plural itelebisionin) (noun M) a television (TV); a telly. cp. esineema.
etelepana (plural etelepaka) (adjective) young; youthful; adolescent; pubescent.
etelepat (plural itelepai) (noun M) a boy between the age of six and fourteen years; a young man who has not reached puberty; an adolescent; a male youth. cp. esapat: a boy reaching adolescence. 
eteluna (plural luteluna, iteluna) (noun M) the only child. cp. lolemura, enume.
etem (plural itemwan) (noun M) an administrative unit equivalent to a sub-county; an age-group; the hearth or shrine (around which discussions were held in the past). ejakait Morunyang arai kolo loketem Katakwi: Mr. Morunyang was the sub-county chief of Katakwi. 
-etenaran (noun suffix) that which stiffens. adeka nak’etenaran (noun F) meningitis; tetanus; any disease causing a stiff back or lockjaw.
etengei (singular noun M) hunger; famine; appetite. mam etengei kariebi eong: I have no appetite; I am not hungry. aikany etengei: to fast; to suffer hunger. inyo ibore kidedengikini ijo noi ido komam ijo ipedori aanyun nges? etengei: (a riddle) what is it that harasses you very much yet you cannot see it? hunger.
etenit (plural etenitos) (adjective) straight; direct; peaceful; stable.
eteran (plural iterak) (noun M) a bridegroom; an initiate or undergraduate in training (perhaps to become a university graduate, a bride, a confirmed Christian, etc). 
etereema (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of red-seeded sorghum (not eaten by birds). 
eteregege (singular noun M) paralysis; meningitis. 
eteregu (plural iteregun) (noun M) a tree, Hymenocardia acida. 
etereikina (adjective) face-to-face; challenging (testing). 
Etesot1 (plural Iteso) (noun M) a man or a native Katakwi, Soroti, Kumi, parts of Kaberamaido, Pallisa and Tororo districts of Uganda and Teso district in Western Kenya; a Teso tribesman. Iteso: the Teso people in general. Etesot obe: a true Etesot (by birth and character).
etesot2 (singular noun M) a variety of groundnuts (with reddish seeds and a creeping plant) native to Teso. 
etesurut (noun M) a grass, Panicum atrosanguineum. cp. epesurut. 
etetei (plural itetein) (noun M) a misnomer for ekerei (a reed granary for storing grain). cp. ekerei. 
etetiot (plural itetio) (noun M) a nose ornament; ring for ear, lip, or tongue. 
eti (plural lutiok M) (adjective) big; important; whole; complete; large; huge; enormous. ebeli eti: a severe famine. emoni eti: what a big bush. cp. lopeti. 
etia ai? (interrrogative pronoun) how big? how much? cp. imwaas ai?
etiai (singular noun M) amount; size; number; quantity; value; price. etiai ke (plural etiai kec): his/her/its (their) size; its price. etiai kosi: our number, as we are. 
etiang (noun M) a corruption of etyang: an animal; a beast. 
etibang (plural luetibang) (noun M) a big fool. 
etibar (plural luetibar) (noun M) a fat big man (literally, a big shit). 
etibinet1 (plural itibin) (noun M) a plant, Veronia perottelli. 
etibinet2 (plural itibin) (noun M) a precious stone; a girdle of metal rolls (like beads) formerly worn by women round the waist; a jewel or ornament; tinsel. aiyup itibin: to string metal rolls. 
etica (plural iticai) (noun M) a school teacher; a tutor; a lecturer. cp. esisianakinan
etid (plural itidai) (noun M) a pancreas (a body organ producing insulin). 
etida1 (plural itidai) (noun M) a big healing drum; a dance for healing possessed people, consisting of a big drum (called etida) and a small high-pitched drum (itelele) played by the same person. airam etida: to beat the big drum to heal a person possessed by evil spirits. alosi eong otida: I am going to the etida dance (which heals hysterics). (the British colonial government used to forbid etida dance). erum nges etida: she/he has hysterics (on account of etida dance). cp. abwangar kanuka etida: to get hysterics (on account of etida dance). aikerepikin, aibilerikin: to become mad; to become delirious. 
etida2 (plural itidai) (noun M) a spleen (a small organ lying near the stomach that purifies blood). 
etidot (plural itido) (noun M) a sting (of bee, wasp, etc); a stinging hair of plants. 
etigo (plural itigoi) (noun M) a variety of wild simsim. 
etiibi (singular noun M) pulmonary tuberculosis; a whooping cough; bronchitis. cp. elweera, epaganga
etiido (plural itiidoi, itiidon) (noun M) a concrete bridge; a concrete culvert. cp. ekume: a water culvert. 
etiimu (plural itiimun) (noun M) a team; a line-up; a squad of players. 
etikesa je (plural itikesa kwi) (noun M) that big fellow.: those big fellows. 
etil (plural itilio) (noun M) a Uganda kob (an animal whose picture is found on the Uganda Court-of-Arms, etc), Adenota kob thomasi. 
etilono (plural etiloko) (adjective) (of anything) deep; abysmal. apak namam etilono: a shallow place (literally, not a deep place). 
etimat (plural itim) (noun M) hair of the head; a hairdress (costume); a blood capillary. 
etimijako (plural luketimijako) (noun M) a very delicious (but black and ugly-looking) mushroom. 
etimon (plural etimok) (noun M) a merciful or forgiving person. 
etingunana (plural etingunaka) (adjective) having a retentive memory; powerful in recalling; mentally persistent.
etipet (plural itipei) (noun M) a tree, Gymnosporia senegalensis. 
etirai1 (plural itira) (noun M) a sickle bush whose presence is an indicator of overgrazing, Dichrostachys cinerea. Used as live fence, pounded leaves and roots are used to treat epilepsy.
etirai2 (plural itira) (noun M) a thorny shrub, Acacia glomerulata. 
etiri (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a tree, Acacia tortilis. 
etirikidait (plural itirikida) (noun M) a molar tooth; a grinding tooth. cp. engiet.
etirir (plural itirira) (noun M) a long white-thorn tree, Acacia sieberiana. Its leaves are used as fodder, and the wood is firewood.
etirono (plural etiroko) (adjective) running fast; fast; speedy; quick.
etit (plural ititio) (noun M) a tree in the palm family, Phoenix reclinata
etiti (plural ititin) (noun M) a tree with a thick bark, Lannea barteri. Its fire-resistant wood is good for carving mortars, pestles and traditional stools. 
etiting (adjective) courageous; enduring; manful; long suffering (pain); manly; intrepid; brave; daring; defying.
etitiny (adjective) a corruption of etiting courageous; enduring; manful; long suffering (pain); manly; intrepid; brave; daring; defying.
etitir (adjective) insipid; bland; satiating; not tasty; not nice. cp. epyana.
etitiyo (adverb) silently; noiselessly; quietly; secretly. kolototo emanyit etitiyo: go for the marriage ceremony secretly. 
eto (plural itoon) (noun M) (formerly) the back of a house where goats sleep. 
etoba (plural itobai) (noun M) a young bull (not yet castrated); a cockerel. cp. esorokan
etoboco (plural itobocon) (noun M) a tree (whose bark is used for fibre), Lannea humilis. 
etoc (plural itocoi) (noun M) a kind of bird. 
etodooma (plural etodooman) (noun M) a candle lamp; a little kerosene lighting device made of an enclosed tin or bottle receptacle with a wick. 
etogo (plural itogoi) (noun M) a house; a dwelling; a building; an abode. papa k’etogo: owner or proprietor of a house (the landlord). etogo loeperio: a house for sleeping. etogo loejengere itunga: (in a hospital) an operating theatre.
etoil (plural itoilon) (noun M) an image; a spirit of a dead person; a wraith; a ghost; a phantasm.
etok (plural itokion) (noun M) a lesser bustard bird. cp. etakura. 
etoke (plural itokei) (noun M) the seeds of emalakany or egwangira plants. 
etolim (plural itolimo) (noun M) a shade (of tree, etc). ejaatar ekitoi etolim, konye itunganan ejaatar etoribe: a tree has a shade, but a person has a shadow. cp. etoribe.
etolo (plural itoloi) (noun M) bile-stained vomit. eleki ngesi etolo, etakani edeka eimidi: his/her vomit is bile-stained, it seems he/she has malaria fever.
etolomunan (plural etolomunak) (noun F) the editor (of a newspaper or a book); producer or printer; the source (of data).
etolut (plural itolun) (noun M) a Marabou stork (bird). 
etom (plural itomei, itomian) (noun M) an elephant (a huge animal that bears ivory or tusks), Loxodonta africana. angoti n’atom: nodular leprosy. 
etometomet (plural itometomen) (noun M) a wart; a mole (on the skin). 
eton (plural etonos) (adjective) feeling cold; fearful; unctuous; cringing; deferential. 
etooci (plural itoocin) (noun M) an electric torch; a flashlight.
etoori (plural itoorion) (noun M) an black eagle; an African kite. 
etop (plural itopion) (noun M) Venus; the morning star (a bright star that appears in the east at dawn) or evening star (a bright star that appears in the west just after sunset). Etop: a state-owned Ateso language newspaper founded in the early 1990s. itopion kwi kere mam eputosi kalo: the Venus of the yesteryears was not like this one. 
etopocon (plural itopocono) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a cassava tuber; the cassava plant; cassava flour, Manihot utilisima cp. emuogo
etoribe (plural itoribei) (noun M) a shadow (of a person, an animal or a cloud). cp. etolim
etoro (plural itoroi) (noun M) a cockscomb; a strip of unshaven hair left on the baby’s head as a clan sign. cp. ecokoliro. 
Etororoit (plural Itororo) (noun M) the Etesot from Tororo or Teso district of Kenya. 
etorube (plural itorubei) (noun M) a corruption of etoribe: a shadow of anything; a shade of anything; a spirit of the dead. cp. etoribe.
etotile (plural itotilei) (noun M) an eye cataract; a stye in the eye. 
etotoyo (plural itotoyon) (noun M) a short beer-guzzling tube. 
etotule (plural itotulei) (noun M) a corruption of etotile: eye cataract; nebula. 
etout (plural itou) (noun M) a testicle; testis; the ‘balls’.
etuan (plural itunga) (noun M) (colloquial of etunganan) a man; a human being; a bloke. cp. etunganan. 
etube (singular noun M) a method of cutting; a way of cutting; a way of judging; a judgement; a way of deciding. etube loka emusaago: the judgement of a court case. etube akiro: a decision; a judgement. mam ngesi iyuunit etubekon: she/he does not agree with your decision or judgement. 
etuboro (adjective) past; bygone; archaic; prehistoric; history.
etuborutu (plural ituborutun) (noun M) a plant in the etulelut family, Solanum torvum. 
etubuno (adjective) unexpected; sudden; abrupt. 
etubusumeesa (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes (with purple and white coloured tubers – hence the name etubusumeesa, ‘the beautifier of the table’). cp. Ocailap
etudo (plural itudoi) (noun M) a male duck; a drake. 
etuen (plural itunga) (noun M) (Serere - colloquial of etunganan) a man; a guy; a bloke. cp. etunganan. 
etuja (plural ituja) (noun M) a small simsim granary made of clay (elupe) and grass (ecici); a prison or a jail. aiwen otuja: to imprison; to incarcerate. etekat is a large reed granary. edula is a big version of etuja.
etuke (plural itukei) (noun M) (in Karamoja) a parrot. cp. ekusu, egili, eluke. 
etuko (plural itukoi) (noun M) a zebra (a wild animal like horse or donkey with white and black stripes), Hippotigris quagga subsp. burchellii. cp. esigiria.
etukuba (noun M) a rosette disease in groundnuts (making leaves yellow and spotted). cp. aiburukuny. 
etukubai (plural itukubai) (noun M) a tree, Spathodea campanulata. Its wood is good for carvings, firewood, and charcoal.
etukumel (plural itukumel) (noun M) an edible mole rat; hamster rat (with a white tail-tip). cp. edoomelu, omelekes, ebebele.
etukuri (plural itukurin) (noun M) an owl (a night bird with big eyes and believed to portend bewitchment in the family if it perches and hoots on the hut at night – the effects of the witchcraft can only be averted by throwing a glowing firewood or acukumac at the owl to scare it away). 
etukuton (plural itukutono) (noun M) an ant-bear. cp. ekutukong. 
etul (plural itulin) (noun M) a hip bone; a hip. esonget loka etul: pelvic joint. 
etulari (plural etularete) (adjective) killing suddenly; fatal; lethal; deadly; mortal. 
etularut (plural itular) (noun M) a swollen tick. 
etulelut1 (plural itulel) (noun M) a plant, Cucumis colcoynthis. 
etulelut2 (plural itulel) (noun M) a Sodom apples plant whose yellow fruit is believed to bring crop high yield when scattered over the grain field, and the stem is used to make ear drops, Solanum aculeastrum. 
etulia (plural itulyai) (noun M) soot; smut; tar; carbon. alemar etulia: to decarbonise. 
etulubong (plural itulubongo) (noun M) a plant, Tephrosis.
etulutulu (singular noun M) sulphuric acid; vitriol. 
etuma (singular noun M) mumps, i.e. a disease that causes the swelling of the ears. edeka ngesi etuma: she/he has mumps. 
etumaana (plural etumaaka) (adjective) disobedient; obstinate; stubborn; unwilling. 
etumit (plural etumitos) (adjective) fat; burly; obese; thick. 
etumunan (plural itumunak) (noun M) a corruption of atumunan: a young boy of 14 – 16 years; an adolescent boy. 
etumura (singular noun M) fermented cassava tubers used in the preparation of flour for beer-making or for atap. cp. amurat
etunganan (plural itunga) (noun M) a man; a bloke. cp. itungasinei: men in general; mankind; all men.
etungasisit (collective noun M) a mass, a crowd, or a mob of people. 
etungat (collective noun M) a mass, a crowd, or a mob of people. 
etunyuny (adjective) (of a knife, etc.) blunted; unsharpened. 
etuo (plural itwol) (noun M) a gourd. aloma akolong otuo: the sun is setting (between 4:00–6:00 o'clock in the evening). 
etupanit (plural itupan) (noun M) a nipple (of breast or udder); a teat. 
etupitono (plural itupitono) (noun M) a maxim; an example; a person worthy of emulation; a guideline. eraas itelepai lu itupitono: these are exemplary boys. 
eturubango (plural iturubangon) (noun M) a tree, Albizzia malacophylla. 
Eturukanat (plural Iturukana) (noun M) a Turkana tribesman from north western Kenya; a Nilo-Hamitic tribe akin to the Masai, Karimojong and Iteso. cp. Esiepet.
Eturukit (plural Iturukin) (noun M) a Turk; a man from Turkey. 
eturukuku (plural iturukukun) (noun M) a tree bearing hard orange-size fruits, Strychnos innocua pomegranata. Its stem is a remedy for caries (emaekeke) when used as toothbrush. The wood is used for hafts for traditional tools, and for firewood and charcoal.
eturuturut (plural iturutur) (noun M) a brown and white hornet; a black stinging wasp.
etusuroi (noun M) a grass, Eragrostis aspera. 
etut (plural itutio) (noun M) a heap (of anything); a rampart of a dam; a boundary mark; a milestone; a raised sleeping platform; an altar in a traditional shrine. 
etute (adjective) always moving; restless; agitated; impatient. 
etutum (singular noun M) human flu - coryza; a runny nose - catarrh. 
etutumu (plural itutumun) (noun M) a bush from which salt is extracted, Vernonia amygdalina. 
etuturumoi (singular noun M) trouble-causing; provocation; incitement; negative influence. 
etuugulu (plural ituugulun) (noun M) an onion. cp. emutuugulu
etuuru (singular noun M) fever and flu; sleeping sickness; coccidiosis (in chicken).
etwaat (noun M) a colloquial of etunganan: a man; a human being. 
etwali (plural itwalin) (noun M) iron shaft of a spear. 
etwan (noun M) a corruption of etunganan: human being. 
etwat (noun M) a corruption of etunganan: a man. 
etwo (plural itwol) (noun M) (Usuk) a gourd. aloma akolong otwo: the sun has set. cp. etuo. 
etyakara (adjective) secluded; discrete; apart; separated; segregated; divided; cut off, etc cp. egelara. 
etyang (plural ityang) (noun M) an animal; a beast. 
etyangatyanga (noun M) a climbing wild bean. 
etyono (plural etyoko) (adjective) difficult; hard; awkward; arduous; unbecoming. etyono akoko: it is unbecoming to steal. etyono etelepat ngol: that boy is a difficult character. 
euduwudu (noun M) a grass, Dactyloctenium. 
euga (noun M) maize flour; posho. 
euji (plural noun M) porridge made from posho or maize flour. cp. akima. 
eukarisita (singular noun M) the holy Eucharist. 
euko (plural iukoi) (noun M) a lung. adeka naka iukoi: pleuro-pneumonia; any lung disease.
eukot (plural iukono) (noun M) a big hill; a mountain range. cp. erongat
eul (noun M) disobedience (by refusing to do something); strike; obstinacy. inyami nat eul: you will be sorry for your obstinacy (literally, you will eat your disobedience). 
eula (plural iulai) (noun M) an arm-band of cow’s tail hair; a fly whisk (switch) made of a cow’s tail used in certain traditional dances as a costume tied to the upper arm. 
eulacom (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes.
-eumokina (noun suffix) akiro nueumokina (plural noun F): startling news; wonderful happenings; a wonder; a miracle. 
eunya (plural eunyas) (adjective) hissing and sizzling with anger (like an injured bull). apotu itunga luaunyas kobilutu ekokolan kawenis kosodete aibunga aidyak aiyar: an angry mob broke into jail and got a suspected thief whom they beat to near death. cp. aisu, aiju. 
eupa (plural iupai) (noun M) a fireplace; a heap of embers (as in a campfire); a pile of ashes. aicak eupa: to step on embers; to stir embers (i.e. looking for food). ecak-eupa (plural lukecak-eupa) (noun M) a greedy person who searches for food after feeling the hearth warm with the foot. eupa loti: a bonfire. eupa loidopit: an inferno; Hell.
eupanara (adjective) accompanying; going together; relating to; associated with. eupanara aberu ngin kokilenike: that woman agrees with her husband (literally, that woman always goes together with her husband). apapulai nueupanara ka aitac esolo: tax related documents.
eupet (plural iupeta) (noun M) a male companion; an aide; an escort.
eur (plural eurok) (intransitive verb) to smell of.
euri (plural iurin) (noun M) a fragrant plant, Ocimum. 
euria (singular noun M) steam; vapour; gas; breath.
euriana (plural euriaka) (adjective) short; stumpy; low; (of female animals, birds, or people) fertile, prolific, productive, or bearing many. 
euriat (plural iurian) (noun M) a native; an indigenous person; a born of somewhere; an aborigine. euriat loko Teso: a born of Teso. 
eurien (plural iuriesik) (noun M) a dwarf; a short person; a midget; a gnome; a pygmy; a homunculus; a Lilliputian; a manikin.
euris (plural iurisio) (noun M) a plant, Elaedendron cucchanani. 
eurukoroi (plural iurukorwa) (noun M) a plant from which salt is extracted, Laggera alata. 
eusi (plural iusio) (noun M) (Usuk) a sewing thread; a spider’s web. 
eusuk (plural iusuko) (noun M) a tree from which Usuk (county or sub-county) derives its name - Zanthoxylum chalybeum. Uses: its crushed seeds are used as spices in tea; its roots, berries and bark treat malaria (eimidi), stomach-ache (ariebo naka akoik), measles (ekwam), joint pain (obilibil), ekodoi (skin rashes caused by smallpox epidemics), eteregege (meningitis or paralysis), ekurara (yaws) and syphilis (esuuku), among other diseases.
Eusukoit (plural Iusuko) (noun M) a man from Usuk county or sub-county in Katakwi district. Iusuko:
eusur (adjective) (of a person) rather big; (of anything) somehow fat. eusur etelepat ngol: that boy is rather big. 
eutana (plural eutaka) (adjective) fond of or clever at wrestling. 
eutudoole (plural iutudoolei) (noun M) a shrub, Sarcocephalus latifolius. Its root extracts are a good treatment for early leprosy. The fruit is eaten as food while the leaves and fruit are fodder for livestock.
eutune (plural iutunei) (noun M) (Usuk) the spinal cord. cp. ediloi.
ewadikan (plural ewadikak) (noun M) a writer; a clerk, a journalist. 
ewaet (plural iwaeta) (noun M) a joke; a jest. 
ewai (plural iwaitin)(noun M) the side; compass direction; a border; a margin; a page (of a book); a legacy; a portion; a part; one’s portion of inheritance. iwaitin kere: all over; in every part of a place. kolot awai: go to the side. 
ewalu (plural iwalun) (noun M) a crowned or crested crane, Balearica regulorum. Uses: this beautiful bird is a national bird in Uganda; can be a good sentry at night against intruders to a home because it wails on seeing danger.
ewangala (plural iwangalan) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. 
ewaragi (noun M) dry gin; crude distilled alcohol variously called ejuge, ecuramol, etc.
eware (noun M) a grass, Simplex. 
ewaya (plural iwayai) (noun F) a fencing wire; line (for hanging out clothes to dry); an overhead electric wire. 
ewayo (plural iwayoi) (noun M) a bush with sour fruits (used for preparation of atap when green), used as toothbrush. cp. epwatet. 
ewelu (plural iwelui) (noun M) a black plum tree, also known as ekarukwei, Vitex madiensis. Uses: ripe black fruits are eaten; the bark, leaves, roots, and fruits are medicinal; tree provides shade; fuel from firewood and charcoal; building materials from its poles and timber.
ewema (plural iwemai) (noun M) a tent; a canvas material. 
ewenat (plural iwenan) (noun M) a prisoner; a detainee. 
ewenet (plural iweneta) (noun M) a thing for tying; a rope; a cord. cp. auno.
ewiiny (adjective) sweet; sugary; honeyed; saccharine.
ewila (plural iwilai) (noun M) a plant, Tephrosia barbigera. 
ewinyiwiny1 (plural iwinyiwinya) (noun M) an ulcerated callosity. cp. eipiane. 
ewinyiwiny2 (singular noun M) sweet or raw brew (two days old, after which it is called arasai). cp. ebibisi. 
ewoc (plural iwoco) (noun M) a buzzard (a large eagle-like bird which hunts small animals for food); a black-shouldered kite. 
ewode (singular noun M) the manner or method of serving food. aijul ewode (noun M) a balanced diet; (intransitive verb) to change the manner of serving food. 
ewoe1 (adjective) (it is) leaking 
ewoe2 (plural iwoisio) (noun M) singing; a manner of singing; a totem. ewoe kec erono: their singing is bad or is wrong (at discord or out of tune). 
ewogor (noun M) a kind of grass. 
ewoi (noun M) a tree, Faidherbia albida. 
ewois1 (plural iwoisio) (noun M) a hymn book; a song book; a hymnal; a poetry anthology. 
ewois2 (plural iwoisio) (noun M) a song; a hymn; a chant; a poem; an ode. 
ewojakori (plural iwojakorio) (noun M) a long-tailed Coly bird. 
ewokiwok (noun M) a grass, Rotboellia exaltata. 
ewoliwol (plural iwoliwolia) (noun M) dropsy (i.e. abnormal accumulation of watery liquid in body cavities or tissues). 
ewom (collective noun M) a gang of labourers. 
ewongo (plural iwongon) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a boast; a bombast; bragging; vaunting. 
ewoodi (plural iwoodin) (noun M) a ward; a building in a hospital with beds for patients.
eworo (singular noun M) a call, a holler; an invitation. 
eworoworo (plural iworoworon) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a species of very poisonous snake. 
ewosin (plural iwosino) (noun M) a corruption of eosin: a vagina. 
ewosit (plural iwos) (noun M) a buttock; the behind; a bum. 
ewosyana (adjective) a corruption of eosiana: slow in conceiving. 
ewuko (plural iwukoi) (noun M) a corruption of euko: a lung. adeka naka iwukoi: pleuro-pneumonia; any lung disease. 
ewukot1 (plural iwukon) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a hill; a mountain. 
ewukot2 (plural iwukoi) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a lung. 
ewul (adjective) (outside Usuk) disobedience; obstinacy. 
ewula (plural iwulai) (noun M) (outside Usuk) wristlet of cow's-tail hair; a tassel; a tress; a fly whisk.
ewunyot (plural iwunyoi) (noun M) one who lifts or raises (anything). ewunyot ekume: one who turns up his/her nose in contempt. cp. ekewunyot.
ewupa (plural iwupai) (noun M) (outside Usuk) the hearth; embers. 
ewuryaana (plural ewuryaaka) (adjective) (outside Usuk) short; stumpy; dwarfish; brief; curt; abrupt. 
ewuryana (plural ewuryaka) (adjective) (outside Usuk) prolific; fertile; 
ewusi (plural iwusio) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a sewing thread; a spider’s web. cp. eusi.
ewutune (plural iwutunei) (noun M) (outside Usuk) the spinal cord. 
eyaadi (plural iyaadin) (noun M) a yard (a British length measure); a parking yard (for trains or cars).
eyaat (plural iyaan) (noun M) a person of blessed trinity. iyaan iuni: the three persons of holy trinity, i.e. God the father, God the son, and God the Holy Spirit. 
eyakia (plural iyakia) (noun M) a delegate; a messenger; a servant; an apostle; an emissary. eyakia lokibaluan: a mail-runner. 
eyakiton (plural eyakitok) (noun M) one who sends others on errands. 
eyala (singular noun M) conversation; pleasantry; trifle.
Eyale (singular noun M) Mt. Elgon (Masaba). cp. Eale. aite oyale: to be dead or to die (literally, to face Mt. Elgon in the east – the direction the dead face during burial in certain Teso clans). cp. aimur akituk: (of a person) to die. atwanare: to die.
eyapeesi (plural iyapeesin) (noun M) an office; the place of work; an administrative centre; workplace.
eyara (plural iyarai) (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sorghum. 
Eyarabut (plural Iyarabun) (noun M) an Arab. cp. Earabut
eyati (noun M) a grass, Chloris virgate.
eyelel (plural iyelelo) (noun M) (Serere) a thorn tree, Acacia deponolopium. cp. ejelel
eyemut (plural iyemuto) (noun M) news. apupunit eong eyemut ebe ededeng Kony ko Gulu: I heard news that Kony rebels have intensified attacks in Gulu. 
eyepamoni (plural iyepamonia) (noun M) (Serere) a bird with orange-coloured feathers, black and white striped wings and fan-like fethers on top of its head, Crested hoopoe. 
eyeriyeri (plural eyeriyerete) (adjective) see-through; transparent; translucent. cp. ewariwari.
eyeyait (plural iyeyai) (noun M) (Serere) a nephew (as called by the aunt). cp. ocenio, ecen.
eyeyis (plural iyeyisio) (noun M) (Serere) song-book; hymn book; a hymnal.
eyileyile (plural iyileyilen) (noun M) a plant used together with etulelut (sodom apple) for aipolia (prevent witchcraft or evil eye on) a potato garden or emukaro (to thwart an evil eye that would prevent the kiln getting red-hot or roasting potatoes well), and from which salt is extracted, Trichodesma zeylanicum. 
eyokobiyat (plural iyokobiyan) (noun M) a worn out cloth (formerly used as underwear by women); a menstrual pad. cp. edapaic, esokolet. 
eyongana (plural eyongaka) (adjective) timid; timorous; fearful. 
eyoroi (plural iyoro) (noun M) (Serere) a tree the leaf extract of which is used as medicine for ear-aches, Teclea nobilis. cp. ejoroi.
eyosi (adverb) (Serere) in or during the afternoon. cp. ejosi
Eyudayat (plural Iyudayan) (noun M) a Jew (a person from Judea). 
eyunibasiti (plural iyunibasitin) (noun M) a university; campus; institution of higher education. erai Makerere eyunibasite lokapolon ko Uganda kere: Makerere University is the biggest university in Uganda. cp. esomero, ekolej
eyuunan (plural eyuunak) (noun M) a believer; a follower; a devotee.
-G- 
g (noun neuter) the sixth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
gabumenti (noun neuter) (formerly) the government. 
Geana (singular noun neuter) (biblical) Hell (the place of eternal fire and suffering); the abode of Satan. cp. Jeana
genger (adverb) (sound imitation of an object falling without bouncing much, like a fully-inflated football or a bag of cotton well-filled, or of a stumpy, well built person) thud; thump; bump. 
gulugul (adverb) sound of rumbling or rattling of stomach. 
gwai (adverb) rather; quite; somewhat; slightly; to a certain extent. 
gwok gwok (noun neuter) (of a dog, to) bark; the sound of a dog; (to a child) a dog. cp. miao: the sound of a cat. merrr: the sound of a sheep.
-I-
i (noun neuter) the seventh letter of the Ateso alphabet; a vowel letter as in ‘ink’.
i-	a) prefix of neutral and diminutive nouns - itunganan: a person in general. ikoku: a child. ikitoi: a small piece of wood. b) plural prefix of masculine and diminutive nouns - ekiliokit: a man - (plural) ikiliok: men. ikoku: child - (plural) idwe: children. c) pronominal prefix of second person singular and plural of all verbs and weak adjectives - iduki, idukete: you (singular, plural) build. ilipi, ilipete: you pray. d) pronominal prefix of third person singular and plural of all ki verbs - ilipi: he/you pray or ask. ilipete: (plural) you/they pray or ask. e) prefix of masculine plural numerals - ikany: five. f) prefix of second person singular and first person plural of present indicative of verbs - iduki: you build (singular). kiduki: we build. ilipi: you pray (singular); ilipete: they pray or you pray (plural). 
-ia (plural -iata) suffix of relative prepositional form of verb: akan naanyamia eong: the hand with which I eat. akoto asaanit anyamia: I want a plate to eat with. 
iare (noun neuter/Dimin.) two. lokiareit (plural lukiareit) (adjective) the 2nd. nakiareit (singular noun F) Tuesday; (ordinal number) the 2nd. yenikiareit (plural lukiareit) (adjective) the 2nd.
ibabu (plural noun neuter) shame; moral poverty; shamefulness; obscenity; bad language. inera ngesi nuk'ibabu: she/he talks obscenity. lok’ibabu; lok’ileic - a shameful man: one who is ashamed; a poor man. cp. ileic 
ibakanyany (plural ibakanyanyas)(adjective) (of an opening, mouth, entrance) large, wide. ibakanyany amot ngin akituk: that pot has a wide mouth. ibakanyanyas itunga akitukes akwena: people are wide-mouthed with laughter. 
ibakor (plural noun neuter) poverty; misery. cp. ican; elout. 
ibalel (plural of ebalelet) (noun M) fungus, toadstool, mould, mildew, yeast; mushrooms. 
ibalua (plural ibaluan) (noun Dimin.) a chit; a note. 
ibalusus (plural ibalususos) (adjective) (of stomach) fat; gigantic; enormous; huge.
ibamarar (plural ibamararas) (adjective) (of a person, an animal, or an object) fat, thick, paunchy. koany etuan lobamar akoik ewadi alosit korot: look at a man with a fat belly waddling on the road. cp. ibomoror; ipomoror. 
ibang (plural ibangiok) (noun Dimin.) a little blockhead; a dense child. ikoku yenibang egolenenei katukot: a stupid child/pupil comes last in class. 
ibangarar (plural ibangararas) (adjective) huge; gigantic; large. cp. ibalusus
ibanyakak (plural ibanyakakas) (adjective) (of a person) short and stout (with bow legs and low buttocks). 
ibaranyany (plural ibaranyanyas) (adjective) (of a gourd, pot, or a person’s waist) broad; wide. 
ibarasit (plural ibaren) (noun neuter) a cow (as riches). 
ibaren (plural of ibarasit) (noun neuter) cattle; livestock. 
ibatalal (plural ibatalalas) (adjective) (of a vessel or an instrument) broad, wide, large. amot na ibatalal akituk: this pot has a wide mouth. ibatalalas je akeje: that guy has wide fat feet (or webbed feet like a goose) (term of abuse) 
ibatangang (plural ibatangangas) (adjective) (of lips, nose) thick and fat. ibatangangas ipon: thick lipped. ekume lobatang: snub nose (Term of abuse)
ibecokino (adjective) accurate; exact; congruous. 
ibeeleana (plural ibeeleaka) (adjective) mischievous; vicious; belligerent. 
ibeketet (plural ibeketetas) (adjective) (of a person’s feet, hands) having long and dirty nails; dirty; rough. 
ibelesio (plural noun neuter) business; occupation. 
ibeliyana (plural ibeliyaka) (adjective) greedy; insatiable (food-wise); gluttonous, etc 
iberu (noun Dimin.) a very small woman (an insult to a petite woman)
ibiler (plural noun neuter) delirium tremens; hysteria. cp. etida
ibilibela (plural ibilibelai) (noun Dimin.) a swift (a small fast-flying insect-eating bird similar to a swallow but with longer wings and a shorter tail). cp. amodyalat. 
ibilibilikaalet (plural ibilibilikaalei) (noun Diminutive) (Usuk) a swift (bird). 
ibityono (plural ibityoko) (adjective) stingy; greedy; selfish; miserly; egoistic. 
ibokonyony (plural ibokonyonyas) (adjective) having a big lower jaw. (an insult) 
ibokoror (plural ibokororas) (adjective) (of skin, bark, or wood) rough. emukule loibokoror: rough skin. 
ibokorwa (plural noun M) east coast fever; a disease causing skin warts. cp. adidinga. 
ibomoror (plural ibomororas) (adjective) (of body) large; (of stomach) fat. (an insult) 
ibonotot (plural ibonototas) (adjective) (of physique) quite well developed; most beautiful, considerate, nice; (of manners) elegant; well-mannered. 
ibore (plural iboro) (noun Dimin.) a thing; an object; something. ejai ngesi ibore: she/he/it is at such a place (not now remembered). ore k’obore: at so-and-so’s home. 
ibotolol eponoi (plural ibotololas ipon) (adjective) having a fat or thick lip. 
ibucelel (plural ibucelelas) (adjective) (of lips) red (due to lip cancer or lipstick). 
ibulucuc (plural ibulucucas) (adjective) (of body) without skin; (of face) browless (i.e. without eye-brows). ibulucucas nges akonye: he/she has no eye-brows. 
ibululu (plural lubululu, nubululu) (adjective) blue 
ibulurur (plural ibulururos) (adjective) (of the ear) swollen (from fitting earring). 
ibus (plural ibusiak) (adjective) (of a person or anything) beautiful; handsome; right; lawful; (of weather) warm. ibusiak itogoi ngul: those houses are beautiful. ibus lolo akwap: it is warm today.
ibusakinit (plural ibusakinito) (adjective) apt; pertinent; appropriate; suitable; proper. ibusakinit oni aswam kagogong: it is necessary that we work hard.
ibuturur1 (plural ibutururas) (adjective) (of person) gloomy; sulking; angry-faced; purse-lipped; mooching or moping. 
ibuturur2 (plural ibutururos) (adjective) (of cutting edge) blunt; rounded.
ibwanyana (plural ibwanyaka) (adjective) (of a beer-drinker) intrusive; fond of gate-crashing. 
ibwenyi bweny (interjection) a reply of people cursing a thief. 
icana (plural icanas) (adjective) poor; badly off; lowly; destitute. 
icangang (adjective) (of dry potatoes, cassava, etc) pounded; crushed. 
icawaana (plural icawaaka) (adjective) (of person) backbiting; detractive. 
ice- (diminutive or neutral adverbial prefix) some. icebore (plural iceboro) (adverb) another thing; something. icetunganan: another person; someone.
icebore (plural iceboro) (indefinite pronoun) something. cp. icetunganan
icel (plural noun M) (Ateso Atororo) money (based on cowrie shells as currency). 
icelelee (plural iceleleete) (adjective) (of a hill, elevation) sticking up; lofty; protruding. 
icenion (noun M) posterity; nephews. 
icetunganan (plural icetunga) (indefinite pronoun) somebody; someone. cp. idiotunganan
icicikat (adjective) (of cloth, etc) bleached; washed-out. 
icidikik (plural icidikikas) (adjective) (of breasts) tiny; small. cp. idalakak
icigiciga (plural icigicigas) (adjective) (of person walking, running) unsteady; like one having sore ankles. 
icikik (adjective) (of contents, flour) compacted; pressed together; compressed; squeezed together. icikik akiria nuatap opuko: flour is compacted in the sack.
icipip (adjective) (of rope, lace, hair, etc) plaited; woven, knitted.
icira (plural iciras) (adjective) (of a milking cow) tame; easy. akiteng naicira: a milk cow. akiteng na mam icira: this cow is difficult to be milked. 
icodio (plural noun M) fore-runners of a swarm of locusts. cp. emaase. 
icodongong (plural icodongongas) (adjective) (of people, things and animals) tall. icodongongas yesi: you are tall. 
icogoror (plural icogororas) (adjective) (of person's limbs) awkward; ill-shaped. 
icok-ajele (plural icok-ajeleik) (noun M) a bush with edible berry the doves feed on, Hoslundia opposita. 
icolibib (plural icolibibas) (adjective) (of beak of a bird, of nose, finger-nail, spear, pencil) pointed; sharp. 
icolirir (plural icoliriras) (adjective) (of person with long neck, etc) tall.
icolisis (plural icolisisas) (adjective) (of person with long finger-nails, limbs, etc) long; pointed. cp. icolirir
icongidid (plural icongididas) (adjective) (of person) tall and slender. cp. icolirir. 
icoperer (plural icopereros) (adjective) (of ears, leaves) pointed. ekingok loicopereros aki: a dog with pointed ears. cp. icopirir
icopirir (plural icopiriros) (adjective) (of ears, leaves) pointed. ekingok loicopiriros aki: a dog with pointed ears. cp. icoperer
icukeana (plural icukeaka) (adjective) (of a misanthrope, double-dealer) fond of inciting, urging on. 
iculul (adjective) (of container) congested; heaped; amassed. 
iculurur (plural iculururas) (adjective) (of things) in a heap; heaped; gathered. 
icumum (adjective) (of anything) speared; pierced; impaled. 
icunyetait (plural icunyeta) (noun Dimin.) a small mark; a dot; a full stop; a speck. 
icupa (plural icupai) (noun Dimin.) a cruet; a vial. 
icuro (plural icuros) (adjective) (of a kid) frantic; bouncy; full of life; lively; (of cassava, potatoes being pounced in a mortar) hard and bouncy. 
icurono (plural icuroko) (adjective) (of youths, kids) playful; joyful. icuroko apesur ngun: those girls are very playful. 
icwa (noun neuter) a bird that makes such sound, Black-headed heron. cp. ebuluk-cwa, Crimson-headed shrike. 
idaakak (plural idaakakas) (adjective) (of person) bossy-headed. 
Idacara (plural noun M) Iteso people from Adacar in Usuk county in Katakwi district. Adacarait: a woman from Adacar. Edacarait: a man from Adacar. 
idaidait (plural idaidain) (noun Dimin.) a little drum. 
idalakak (plural idalakakas) (adjective) (of a female) having fallen breasts. idalakak aberu ngin: that woman has fallen breasts (a fallen-breasted woman). 
idamokok (plural idamokokos) (adjective) (of bag, breasts, football or any receptacle) empty; unfilled. 
idapokok (plural idapokokos) (adjective) (of person) having flat small buttocks, i.e. not protruding. cp. inimokok. 
idaukuk (plural idaukukos) (adjective) (of head, skin) woolly; like wool; fluffy. 
ideke (plural idekesio) (noun Dimin.) an idol; a carved god; a false god.
idekerer (plural idekereras) (adjective) (of person, animal, stick) thin; emaciated. 
idelana (plural idelaka) (adjective) (of a snob) showy, flashy, ostentatious; (of a child) petulant; huffy; having fits of tantrums. idelana ikoku ngin: that child is obstinate (does not want to be pacified, shows a fit of tantrums); to go into a tantrums. 
idelelee (plural ideleleete) (adjective) (of anything) protruding; conspicuous; visible; standing out; prominent, evident, exposed. akiro ace nuedeleleutu: emerging issues. ideleleete akiro ngun: those things are very obvious.
idepidepana (plural idepidepaka) (adjective) (of person) jabbering; babbling; talkative. idepidepana ijo: you are a chatter-box, a tale-teller.
idepio (plural noun) a brood, young ones of locusts, fleas, spiders; off-spring (an insult when used to refer to someone’s children). koyanga idepio kon ngina: depart with your brood. cp. alwek.
iderakina (adjective) (of homes) sparse, (of plants) far apart, few in-between. iderakina emaido loelomit: only a few groundnuts have germinated. 
ideridera (adjective) (of plants, homes, people) scanty; few; sparse. ideridera akimai komanaka: the millet is sparse in my garden. 
idetetait (plural ideteta) (noun Dimin.) a small drum used (together with a long drum – emidiri) at twin-dances. cp. idaidait: a thumb-knife used for harvesting finger millet.
