ideuna (adjective) (of anything) spare; left over. emameete nuideuna: there are none to spare. emameete bobo eong nuideuna: I have said all I had to say. 
Idi1 (singular noun neuter) the ninth month of the Muslim year, during which Muslims fast between sunrise and sunset. cp. Ramadan. 
idi2 (interrogative pronoun) M, Dimin.&neuter plural: how many? idi: (adverb) how many (are they)? yesi idi?: how many are you?
idicic (adjective) (of flour, groundnuts, etc) ground fine; pulverised. idicic akiria nu: this flour is well ground. 
ididi (plural ididiin) (noun Dimin.) a species of small birds - Waxbill. 
ididiit (plural ididiin) (noun Dimin.) a small bird, Yellow-backed pytilia. cp. ididiot; ididi. 
idiimim (plural idiimimas) (adjective) (of body, stick, etc) thin; emaciated; (of grain) underdeveloped; stunted in growth. idiimimas akimai nu akwes: this millet has underdeveloped ears (is stunted in its growth). 
idik (plural idikok) (adjective) (of liquids) thick; viscous; gooey. 
idila (plural idilas) (adjective) (of anything) plentiful; rampant; copious; widespread. 
idiobore (plural idioboro) (indefinite pronoun) anything; a scrap (of something). 
idiope diope (adverb used with plural masculine, neuter or diminutive nouns) one by one; one after another. kolomanasi togo idiope diope: go in the house one by one. (adverb) singly; one by one. kopotu ore idiope diope: come home one by one, singly. itunga idiope diope: one person after another. iboro idiope diope: one thing after another.
idiopet (numeral adjective)(used with Dimin. & neutral nouns) one. idiopet itaok: one calf. ikalel adiopet: one kid. ikoku idiopet: one child. 
idiopetait (plural idiopeta) (noun Dimin.) any of the digit numbers; a unit. idiopeta ikany: five units. 
idiotai (adverb) a little; some; a bit. koinakinai ikiring idiotai: give me just a little meat. 
idiotunganan (plural iditunga) (indefinite pronoun) anyone; anybody. cp. icetunganan
idipalal (plural idipalalas) (adjective) stumpy; dwarfish; stunted in growth; rutty (of a road). idipalalas itunga luko Kasese: the people of Kasese (the Bakonzo) are dwarfish, stumpy. 
idipanyany (plural idipanyanyas) (adjective) (of house, person) short; low. idipanyany etogo ngol: that house is low. 
idipolol (plural idipololas) (adjective) (of person's buttocks) small; tiny. cp. idapokok. 
idisidisin (adverb) a few; a minority. apugan naka itunga idisidisin: a minority government; a government by a few.
ido (adverb) moreover; also; then; and; again. kolot ber Katakwi, ido konye Kapujan: first go to Katakwi and then to Kapujan.
ido bobo da (preposition) and besides; and again; and more than that; further still. ejokuka apese ngin iponesio, ido bobo da kitemelel: that girl has good manners, moreover she is beautiful.
idodomat (plural idodomatos) (adjective) (of a road) endless, too long; (of a mango fruit) very ripe. 
idoelel (plural idoelelos) (adjective) (of belly) slender; sunken. 
idokidokono (plural idokidokoko) (adjective) (of person) having a good memory; vengeful. 
idokorian (noun neuter) a plodder; a persistent or persevering person. 
idolidola (plural idolidolas) (adjective) (of person) lacking energy; (of rope, etc) long and coiled. erai ngesi etunganan loidolidola: he is a lazy man. cp loelongwaana, loekalanyana: a lazy person (but with strength). 
idolit (noun Dimin.) a child born with umbilical cord round the neck. 
idolol (adjective) (of rope, clothes, snake, etc) folded; coiled. abu eong kadum egoe idolol: I found the cloth folded. 
idomococ (plural idomococas) (adjective) (of body) dripping wet; drenched; (of cooked potato, cassava) soft and watery. idomococas ikagoen kere: my clothes are full of perspiration (or thoroughly wet). 
idongoror (plural idongororas) (adjective) (of plant) heavily laden with fruit. idongororas imucuugai ekaru lo: this year the orange trees are laden with fruit. 
idoponyony (plural idoponyonyos) (adjective) (of a person, animal) one-eyed. 
idoudout (noun M) azure; sky-blue. 
idukulet (plural idukulen) (noun Dimin.) a small bead; a small round pond; a circle. 
idukulul (plural idukululas) (adjective) concave; hollow. idukulul akaale: a spoon is concave. 
idukumum (plural idukumumos) (adjective) (of cooked food) mellow; soft; tender; (of fruit) ripe. 
idul (plural idulok) (adjective) (of hole) deep. idulok icileta lu: these rivers are deep. idul ajimikon: your wounds are deep. 
idungulul (plural idungululos) (adjective) (of limb, fingers, toes) short; maimed; amputated. 
idunya (plural idunyas) (adjective) (of things) adjacent; near; close together. itogoi luidunyas: neighbouring houses. cp. eyapias.
idupukuk (plural idupukukos) (adjective) (of cloth, flour, cat's fur) fine to touch; soft. idupukuk apalisi naepaaba: a cotton mattress is soft. 
idusukuk (plural idusukukos) (adjective) (of cooked vegetables) tender; mellow; (of person) stout. 
idwe (plural of ikoku) (noun neuter) children.
idwomen (plural noun neuter) (derogatively) food; edibles; eatables. cp. inyamen
idwomococ (plural idwomococas) (adjective) (of vegetables) well-prepared and tender; (of cooked potatoes, cassava) soft and watery. koinakinai eong edia loidwomococ: give me nice vegetables. 
idwomokok (plural idwomokokos) (adjective) (of pod, any receptacle) empty; unfilled. 
idyakalal (plural idyakalalas) (adjective) (of anything) soft and watery. idyakalalas acok idoritoi: the potatoes have been cooked very soft and watery. 
idyamakak (plural idyamakakas) (adjective) (of wet sticks) soft and bendable, pliable. 
idyatuna (adjective) (of anything) accumulated; collected. 
idyeletet (plural idyeletetas) (adjective) (of floor, road surface, etc) smooth; slippery. idyeletet erot lo: this road is slippery (plural) idyeletetas irotin lu. cp. erurut. 
igabuna (plural igabunan, lukigabuna) (noun neuter) (formerly, during the colonial era or the reign of Idi Amin Dada) a regional governor; (derogatory) a tramp (eats without working). 
igalal (adjective) (of liquid) strained; skimmed. akile nuigalal: skimmed milk. 
igaluna (adjective) (of tasks, resources) shared out; pooled; gathered; joint. kesi inyamat luigaluna: this is pooled food. 
igangit (plural igangitos) (adjective) (of actions) collateral; supportive; helpful; sympathetic; encouraging.
igarigara (adjective) (of space) commodious; roomy; spacious; vast. 
igasiana (plural igasiaka) (adjective) (of homestead, etc) dirty; unclean; filthy; mucky. igasiana ekonire: your home is always dirty. 
igayoono (plural igayooko) (adjective) holy; saintly. 
igeriat (plural igeriai) (noun Dimin.) a small seed-eating songbird, Hooded finch. 
igetemem (plural igetememas) (adjective) (of person) having a distended belly (an insult) koyanga akonigetemem ngina!: off with your distended stomach! kingalakin ikoku ekia, igetemem do tai: somebody gave the child poison, now its stomach is swollen. 
igetet (adjective) (of potato or cassava tubers) sliced and dried. acok nuigetet: sliced dried potatoes. 
igole-idodo (plural igole-idodoi) (noun neuter) a lizard buzzard. cp. ekube, igolemir. 
igolemir (plural igolemirio) (noun neuter) a mouse buzzard. cp. ekube. 
Igoria (plural of Egoriat) (noun M) a Teso clan of Builders or Masons. 
igoromom (adjective) (of girth) big, distended; near full pregnancy; (of a tree) heavily laden with fruit. 
igungurur (plural igungururas) (adjective) (of person) small and mature. Zakayo arai etunganan loigungurur: Zacchaeus was a man small in stature. 
Iguotok (plural noun M) people from Agu (a swampy place in Serere county). 
igurumum (plural igurumumas) (adjective) (of person, pot) rounded and fat-bellied. 
igwaamam (plural igwamamas) (adjective) (of surface, skin) rough; (of manners) uncouth. 
igwaramam (adjective) (of surface, skin) rough, scaly. 
Igwaramot (plural noun M) a Teso clan. 
igwelanara (plural noun M) merchandise; goods. ileleba igwelanara oiduka ngol: that shop is full of merchandise. 
ii (interjection) yes, of course; yes (an answer in response to a call); naturally; indeed; surely. 
iicudan (plural iicudak) (noun Dimin.) (euphemism) a penis (literally, a little wizard). cp. edino.
iikinyiny (plural iikinyinyas) (adjective) (of face of person with aching tooth or ear) puffy, swollen, or bloated; fat-cheeked (due to diseased ear or swollen tooth).
iikong (plural iikongio) (noun Dimin.) a small wooden mallet. 
iisineret (plural iisinereta) (noun Dimin.) inverted commas. 
iitaabo (plural iitaaboi) (noun Dimin.) a booklet; a brochure.
iiyengunet (plural iiyenguneta) (noun Dimin.) a short rest; a comma. 
ijaa (plural nukijaa) (noun neuter) (outside Usuk) aunt; the sister of one’s mother or father. ijaaka: my aunt. cp. mamai: uncle; the brother of one’s mother.
ijamakak (plural ijamakakas) (adjective) (of belly) fleshy, plump, fat, obese, corpulent. ijamakak epege lo: this pig is very fat. etelepat loijamakak: a fat boy. ijamakakas akeje: kija eong kakejeka nuijamakakas: I have soft, supple feet. 
ijangijanga (plural ijangijangas) (adjective) (of anything) shaky, insecure, unstable; rocking; unsteady, wavering, vacillating. ijangijanga aduko kec: their marriage, relationship, friendship is shaky, unsteady. 
ijarijara (adjective) (of rope, belt, etc) loose; slack. epale ngol ijarijara: those trousers are too big or loose. 
ijauna (adjective) acceptable; receivable. 
ijegejege (plural ijegejegen) (noun neuter) (formerly) a 5 cents coin; coin money (in general). 
ijejait (plural ijejai) (noun neuter) (Usuk) a nephew or niece (called so by aunt). cp. iyeyait
ijekokino (adjective) (of slacks, measure, etc) too short; too little. ijekokino auno ya: that rope is too short. 
ijerer (adjective) (of behaviour, branch, or rope) twisted, warped, or perverted. 
ijeruko (plural ijerukosi) (adjective) (of bull, etc) rebellious; unmanageable. 
ijesuna (adjective) (of price, measure, level, etc) lowered down; slipped down. aijesun etau: to lose courage. cp. adou ekatau: I am down-hearted. 
ijieta (plural noun M) weapons; arms; military hardware. 
ijikitit (plural ijikititas) (adjective) (of person) deaf. 
ijip (plural noun M) scabies. 
ijo (plural yesi) (personal pronoun second person singular subjunctive form) you; thou. ai bo ilosi ijo?: where are you going? (note: objective and dative form isyo). ingai kinomi jo?: (singular) who beat you? ijo ba na: (singular F) you here. ijo ba je: (singular M) you there. ijo ba lo: (singular M) you here. ijo bo je: (singular M) you there. 
ijokoinet (plural ijokoinei) (noun Dimin.) a brown wagtail - a little bird that moves with grazing animals in order to catch grasshoppers. 
ijokot (plural ijokoi) (noun Dimin.) a small bird that follows cows to catch ticks or grasshoppers. 
ijopijopo (adjective) (of many heights, lengths, etc) unequal, uneven, lopsided, irregular, or disparate. 
ijopokino (adjective) (two heights, lengths, etc) unequal, uneven; disproportionate. ijopokino akitoi na ka ya: this piece of wood is not equally as big or as long as that. ijopokino akonye: unequal eyes (one wider than the other); squinting or distorted sight. 
ijugume (plural ijugumei) (noun Dimin.) a little drum used at twin-birth dance. cp. ejukume
ijukujuka (plural ijukujukas) (adjective) (of enclosed place, passage, etc) crowded; jam-packed. ijukujukas itunga kagwelanaret: there are too many people at the market. 
ijukume (plural ijukumei) (noun Dimin.) a small drum used for twin-birth-dance. cp. ijugume. 
ijulul (adjective) (of sides) converse; opposite; reverse; opposed. 
ijululue (plural ijululuete (adjective) (of something hanging) head down; slanting; diagonal; leaning. 
ikaalei (plural of ikalol) (noun M) kids; young goats. 
ikabinin (plural noun neuter) worthless sorghum grain. cp. inyeg. 
ikadet (plural ikadei) (noun Dimin.) a small seed-eating bird. 
ikaidu (plural nuikaidu) (noun Dimin.) a man’s favourite wife (especially the latest and possibly the youngest) among many. (It is believed a husband sleeps, bathes and eats frequently at ikaidu’s house and he loves her most – to the chagrin of other wives).
ikajaran (plural ikajarak) (noun neuter) a living thing. cp. ikatwan.
ikalelo (plural ikalelos) (adjective) afloat; buoyant. 
ikalol (plural ikaalei) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a kid; a young goat. cp. imerekek: a lamb 
ikang (adverb) (general) my friend; my dear; dear me. okwe ikang konyou, nukon nupe inerai: my dear friend go away, they are talking about (killing) you. (ikang used in a salutation or beginning a letter to everybody: Dear Sir/Madam). 
ikangasana (plural ikangasaka) (adjective) (of equipment, activity, etc) fatal, deadly, lethal; hazardous, dangerous, harmful; risky. 
ikangikanga (adjective) (of cooking, grinding, etc) perfunctorily done; quickly and badly done; done in passing, hastily, hurriedly, superficially. ikangikanga alos na iryeitai: this flour was poorly ground.
ikanyana (plural ikanyaka) (adjective) (of person, animal) obstinate, pig-headed, inflexible, adamant, persistent; stubborn, intractable, obdurate, mulish.
ikapa (plural ikapai) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a cat; a pussy cat. cp. ipus
ikapai (plural noun M) people with fighting equipment; people or soldiers in arms; armed guards or escorts. 
ikapan (plural noun M) equipment; kit; apparatus; paraphernalia. cp. lukapan
ikapun (plural noun M) currency, money, legal tender, coins, notes, cash. 
Ikarebwok (plural of ekareut) (noun M) a major Teso clan (ateker) of rain-makers and from which warriors, hunters, and leaders of clans came; the Warrior clan. 
ikatanyany (plural ikatanyanyas) (adjective) (of utensil, especially a bowl, basin or basket) having a broad opening at the top. cp. elal. ikatanyany ngesi akituk: she/he has protruding wide lips. ebukit loikatanyany: a big open basket. 
Ikatekok (plural noun M) a major Teso clan (ateker) - they do not eat the meat of a bushbuck (ederit); the Thwarting or Restraining clan; the Pacifists. cp. Atekok 
ikatirir (plural ikatiriros) (adjective) (of cloth, skin, etc) thick; tough; layered. erai ekaki egoe lokatir: khaki is a tough cloth.
ikatwan1 (interjection) bad spelling of ikatunganan: my (little) friend 
ikatwan2 (plural ikatwak) (noun neuter) the dead. cp. ikajaran.
ikaurian (plural ikauriak) (noun neuter) a parent; a begetter; ancestor; a forebear.
ikawoo (plural noun neuter) shame; embarrassment; humiliation; disgrace; indignity; dishonour; infamy. kenyekikiniata eong ipejok ikawoo: the visitors left me in embarrassment or in shame because I had nothing to give them. aisamisam ikawoo: to savour shame. cp. ileic.
ikeara (adjective) (of a person) arrogant, conceited, haughty, egotistical, proud, supercilious; stuck up; (of anything) high up; aloft. 
ikee (plural of ekia) (noun M) medicine; drugs; poisons; medications. 
ikeeki (plural ikeekin) (noun Dimin.) a wafer, cracker. 
ikela k’etom (plural noun M) elephant tusks; ivory. cp. esanga
ikelesia (plural ikelesian) (noun Dimin.) a chapel. 
ikerep (plural noun M) lunacy; insanity; psychosis; mental illness; madness; mania, craze, or obsession. ikerep luka etyang: rabies.
ikerepono (plural ikerepoko) (adjective) crazy; fanatical; insane; maniacal. 
ikesa (plural ikesa) (noun Dimin.) a little fellow; a small guy; a chap; a member of a young age group. ikesa: a person. ikesa ngin: that little fellow over there. 
ikesisian (plural ikesisiak) (noun neuter) a student; a pupil; a scholar; a disciple. cp. eesisian
iketakina (adjective) (of anything tied, etc) taut; tight; rigid; stiff; firm; inflexible. 
iketana (plural iketaka) (adjective) (of person’s behaviour) hard; obstinate; dogged; inflexible. 
iketerer (plural iketereras) (adjective) (of person, birds) skinny; bony; lean. iketerer ikokuka, engerit apoloor: my child is skinny, it does not grow.
ikeuna (adjective) prominent; outstanding; raised; elevated; hoisted; supported; propped up; shored up. 
ikiara (adjective) lifted up; elevated, aloft, towering, sky-scraping, or tall; prominent, high up, high-flying. cp. ikeuna. 
Ikidetok (plural noun M) people from the east; natives of Kidetok in Serere county. 
Ikidia (plural noun M) the eastern people. cp. Inyakoi: northerners
ikidioko (adjective) few. ikidioko angor: women are few. ikidioko ikiliok: the men are few. 
ikijit (plural noun M) (Usuk) contents of bowels or entrails of animals. cp. ikwijit.
ikilarar akou (plural ikilararas akwes) (adjective) (of person) big-headed and hairless. ikilarar nges akou: she/he is bigheaded and hairless. cp. akularar. 
ikiliok (plural of ekiliokit) (noun M) men; husbands. 
ikingok (plural ingokwo) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a puppy; a little dog; a despicably poor person (an insult). 
Ikisimo (plural noun M) people from Akisim. 
ikisin lulekekin (plural noun M) breasts with long nipples. cp. ikisin lucidik: breasts with short nipples.
ikitinyo (plural noun M) chaps; cheeks. cp. iitinyo
ikitoi (plural ikito) (noun Dimin.) a seedling or small piece of wood. 
ikiyonit (plural ikwii) (noun Dimin.) a bud; small, young leaf.
ikocolol (plural ikocololos) (adjective) (of person or animal) having hairless patches or bald patches on the head. 
ikodomom (plural ikodomomas) (adjective) (of person) tall and round-shouldered; tall and hunched; tall and bent. 
ikoelel (plural ikoelelos) (adjective) (of person or animal) big-eared; long-eared. ikoelel etom: the elephant has big ears. 
ikoi (plural noun M) poorly ground beer yeast i.e. unground yeast radicles in millet beer or on fermenting beer. 
ikojoi (plural of ekojo) (noun M) lightning bolts; arrows; shots; bullets. 
ikoki (plural ikokiok) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a little orphan. ekoki: an orphan boy. akoki: an orphan girl. 
Ikokolemwo (plural of Ekokolemwoit) (noun M) one of the four main divisions of the Teso tribe and native to Kaberamaido and parts of Soroti district – their language has a mixture of Ateso and Luo words. (These people prefer being called Kumam, not Ikokolemwo). cp. Ingoratok, Iseera and Iteso (of Usuk county). 
ikokoteono (plural ikokoteoko) (adjective) nasty; jealous; envious. ikokoteoko itunga lu aitecel eong duc: these people are nasty, they always attack me verbally. 
ikoku (plural idwe) (noun neuter) a small child (whether male or female) under six years; a baby; an infant. alot ikoku osomero: the child has gone to school.
ikolededet (plural ikolededen) (noun Dimin.) a small black cat-fish, Bagrus. 
ikolodong (plural ikolodongo) (noun Dimin.) a young tortoise; a Volkswagen Beetle car. 
ikolol (adjective) (of liquid) congested with; brimming with. ikolol ajon ngun akipi: that beer is too watery.
Ikomolo (plural noun M) a major Teso clan that blessed others (but could also wish others bad luck if denied something); the Spittle clan; people from Komolo - Wera in Katakwi district. 
ikopitoi tai (plural ikopas tai) (adjective) (of disease or action) desultory; indiscriminate; infectious; contagious. 
ikoria (plural noun M) breasts with long nipples. cp. elekek. 
ikorococ (plural ikorococos) (adjective) (of head or ground) hard and bare. ikorococ akonikou: you are hard-headed; you are stupid. cp. egogong. 
ikorodod (plural ikorododas) (adjective) (of a person, especially a woman who has borne many children) gassing or farting easily. ikorododas amojongik ngun: those old women fart at a slightest provocation.
ikorwa (plural of ekoroi) (noun M) he-goats; billy-goats.
ikosobwa1 (plural noun M) a variety of people’s hair resembling buffalo hair (soft, fluffy, curly and like for a mongrel or mulatto and greys very fast). 
Ikosobwa2 (plural noun M) one of the clans in Teso. 
ikososoi (plural ikososoete) (adjective) (of anything standing) gigantic; huge; colossal; oversize. 
ikote ai? (interrogative pronoun) how are they? kikote nepenen: so be it; amen. cp. aikon. 
ikote nen (adverb) things are thus; well then; thus. 
Ikristayot (plural Ikristayon) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a Christian; a Christian child. 
ikudelel (plural ikudelelas) (adjective) (of platter, tray, etc) flat. cp. apedelel. 
ikuetet (plural ikuetetas) (adjective) (of man or animals) having swollen testicles; (of soil) rocky, infertile and shallow. ikuetet (plural ikuetetas kesi): he, they have swollen testicles. ikuetet akwap, mam apedori akor: the ground is very dry, I cannot cultivate. cp. akwetet.
ikulepek (plural of elope, ilope) (noun M) owners of; (used with plural of reflexive verb) themselves. lukangai ikulepek iboro lu?: who are the owners of these things? kesi ikulepek ejenete: they know it themselves. 
ikumemei (plural ikumemeete) (adjective) (of anything lying down) huge; massive. 
ikungurur (plural ikungururas) (adjective) (of a person) pudgy i.e. short and thick; thick and fat. 
ikupa (adjective) (of a garden) ready for gleaning. amisiri naikupa: a plot ready for gleaners, i.e. the owner has allowed others to gather leftover grain, etc from it. 
ikureana (plural ikureaka) (adjective) often feeling or causing thirst. ekureana: I am continually thirsty. ikureana: you are continually thirsty. ikureana: she/he/it is continually thirsty. kikureaka: we are continually thirsty. ikureaka: they are continually thirsty. 
Ikuruka (noun M) the Crow clan of Teso. 
ikusana (plural ikusaka) (adjective) (of person, animal, bird) playful; restless; fidgety; fussy; cheeky. ikusana ikoku ngin: that child is fidgety. cp. iloliana, etutiana.
ikuwamam (plural ikuwamamas) (adjective) (outside Usuk) (of surface, skin) rough, etc. cp. engenge, ekwatam. 
ikwaamam (plural ikwaamamas) (adjective) (Usuk) (of skin, surface) coarse, rough.
ikwangalal (plural ikwangalalas) (adjective) (of weight) light, thin. cp. ebenen; ebwale. 
ikwareget (noun Dimin.) a species of small black birds. cp. iregeget
ikwaresia (plural noun M) white ants that fly at night from an anthill called aibulu or aswei.
ikwatarar (plural ikwatararas) (adjective) (of person, animal) rough bodied and thin. 
ikweje (plural ikwejei) (noun Dimin.) a small quail-like weaverbird. 
ikweny (plural of ekwenyit) (noun M) birds in general; aircraft; planes. 
ikwenyit (plural ikweny) (noun neuter) a bird (in general). 
ikwes (plural of ekwesit) (noun M) (outside Usuk) sheafs, bundles or loads of grass, fire-wood, etc. 
ikweta (noun neuter) the equator; latitude 0o; an imaginary line passing round the earth at an equal distance from north and south poles (this line runs from east to west).
ikweterer (plural ikwetereras) (adjective) (of a person, chicken) short and skinny. 
ikwii (plural of ekiyot) (noun M) bushes; shrubbery. 
ikwiin (plural nukikwiin) (noun neuter) queen; empress; (also) jetliner. cp. akabaka.
ikwijit (plural noun neuter) (outside Usuk) the contents of the intestines of herbivorous animals. cp. epuwal. 
ikwongakina (adjective) (of packing) mixed up; in disorder; topsy-turvy. 
ilabanyany (plural ilabanyanyas) (adjective) (of opening of clothing, pot, door, etc) too wide; not fitting. ilabanyany ekasaati: my shirt is too wide. 
ilabilabana (plural ilabilabaka) (adjective) (of person) talkative; garrulous; loquacious. 
iladad (adjective) (of a wall, surface) smeared; plastered. iladad arwatat na: this wall is plastered. 
ilajilaja (plural ilajilajas) (adjective) (of something tied, a rope, a screw, etc) slack, loose. 
ilamam (adjective) (of anything) cursed; accursed; jumped over. 
ilamitoi (adjective) (of speech, activity, train of thought, etc) desultory; aimless; random; unfocused; haphazard. cp. ikopitoi tai
Ilangoi (plural noun M) the Langi people - one of the Luo-speaking tribes of northern Uganda; the natives of Lira and Apac districts. cp. Inyakoi: northerners (generally). 
ilapadae (plural ilapadaete) (adjective) (of herdsmen) wandering, nomadic, peripatetic, travelling, rootless, roving; (of speech) drifting, discursive, unpredictable, unreliable, inconsistent; (of movement) free, unrestricted, at liberty.
ilararaara (adjective) (of land, scalp, etc) bare, clear, open. 
ilarongong (plural ilarongongos) (adjective) (of person, bird) bald-headed. 
ilatirir (plural ilatiriros) (adjective) (of sheet metal, etc) dense; thick. 
ilebilebana (plural ilebilebaka) (adjective) (of person) talkative; loquacious. 
ileic (plural noun neuter) shame; shyness; disgrace. aanyun ileic: adumun ileic: to be ashamed. abu eong kaany ileic kanukon: ibu ijo kitaany eong ileic: you made me ashamed. airum ileic: to be shy; to blush; to be ashamed. kerumitos eong ileic: I feel ashamed. aiturum ileic: aisurum ileic: to make ashamed; to humiliate. 
ileicono (plural ileicoko) (adjective) bashful; shy; coy. 
ileisit (plural ileisio) (noun neuter) one of the sixty-four beads in a board-game called aile (omweso) played by two people on 32 holes. cp. imorut.
ilekileka (adjective) (of partly-eaten food) wasted. abu kadum atap ilekileka: I found food was being wasted (eaten at every point and yet unfinished). 
ileleba (adjective) (of a container) replete; full; (of space) congested; (of anything) copious; prevalent. eleleba eong: I am full: I am satisfied.
ilengerer (plural ilengereras) (adjective) (of a man) circumcised. ilengereras Imugis: ekepep Imugis: the Bagisu men are circumcised. cp. ekepep
ilepaana (plural ilepaaka) (adjective) (of person) cheeky; impudent. ilepaana ngesi (ilepaaka kesi): she/he (they are) impudent.
ilerara (adjective) (of floor, ground, etc) hardened; dried. ilerara alup, mam apedori aibok: the soil is very hard, I cannot dig it up. 
ilererei (plural ilerereete) (adjective) (of anything visible) plain, obvious, clear. ilererei akirot ngin: that idea or statement is clear, obvious. ilerereete inyukutan: the words are legible. 
ilesiara (adjective) (of person, animal, etc lying) spread-eagled; on the back and stretched out. ilesiara ngesi koitaadake: she/he lies stretched out on his bed. 
iletenyeny (plural iletenyeny) (adjective) (of an excavation) shallow; flat. 
iliagamam (plural iliagamamas) (adjective) (of a person, tree, etc) tall and thin; high and lanky, etc. iliagamam egoro noi: a heron is very tall. 
iliamamai (plural iliamamaete) (adjective) (of surface) flashy, glitzy, garish, dazzling. 
ilidongong (plural ilidongongas) (adjective) (of waist, body) narrowed like a wasp; slim, slender. 
iligerer (plural iligereros) (adjective) (of neck in relation to big belly) elongated. 
iliikik (plural iliikikas) (adjective) (of head) large and unproportional to small body. 
ilikidyana (plural ilikidyaka) (adjective) (of person) greedy; miserly; stingy; close-fisted. cp. ibityono, itawono, imwaneono. 
ililingana (plural ililingaka) (adjective) (of person) taciturn; reticent; reserved; introverted. 
ilimia (plural noun M) (slang) coin money; currency in general. cp. isua, alim.
ilimilimit (plural ilimilimito) (adjective) (of surface) spotted; dotted; speckled; dappled; mottled; (of rain) having drizzled. 
iliogotot (plural iliogototas) (adjective) (of body, character) immaculate; unblemished; faultless. isapat yen iliogototas iponesioke: this boy’s manners are without blemish. 
ilipana (plural ilipaka) (adjective) (of person)fond of begging, praying. 
ilipet (plural ilipeta) (noun M) a petition; a small request. ayaunit eong ilipet: I have a little request. 
iliriangang (plural iliriangangas) (adjective) (of person) deaf; hearing-impaired; unable to hear. cp. ekimingana.
ilisioror (plural ilisiororas) (adjective) (of plant) tall and thin, slender. 
ilobob (adjective) (of a garden) prepared; ploughed. ilobob amanaka: my plot was cultivated or ploughed again. 
ilociloco (adjective) (of lengths, heights) different; unequal. ilociloco ibokor: the fingers are different in size. ilociloco apapulai: the papers are mixed up. 
ilocomom (plural ilocomomos) (adjective) long-necked and big-bellied. cp. iligerer
ilogecec (plural ilogececas) (adjective) (of legs) bowed, bandy. 
ilogiloga (plural ilogilogas) (adjective) (of passages, routes) labyrinthine; complicated; elaborate. 
Ilogir (noun M) a Teso clan.
iloja (plural noun neuter) grain falling off from the heads of grain during drying. It is used for beer-making. (slang) beer from iloja. ajon nuka iloja: beer made from iloja. cp. iloya. 
ilokiloko (plural ilokilokos) (adjective) (of a pole, post, tooth, etc) loose; movable; shaky. 
ilokonyony (plural ilokonyonyas) (adjective) (of dental formula) having missing teeth while others grow haphazardly. arai eong ekimat loilokonyony: I am an old man with missing teeth. cp. anguco.
ilolomono (plural ilolomoko) (adjective) (of person, randy he-goat) cantankerous; noisy; raucous; boisterous. 
ilolony (singular noun neuter) exhaustion; fatigue; tiredness. cp. alongwaar. 
ilolyana (plural ilolyaka) (adjective) (of a child) touchy; playful; mischievous; naughty. ilolyana ijo: you are cheeky. 
ilope1 (plural ikulepek) (adverb) by itself; alone; the very one. ijo ilope: you yourself.
ilope2 (plural ikulepek) (noun neuter/Dimin.) the (little, despicable, or unspecified) owner. iboyie ngesi ilope bon: it stays by itself. ilope akiro: the unidentified accuser. ilope akwap: a native or inhabitant of a region or country. ilope (neuter): the owner (unidentified). 
ilopodot (plural ilopodon) (noun Dimin.) a species of small birds. 
iloror (adjective) (of a knot, ground) tight; rammed; hard. iloror akwap: the soil is very hard (no rain). cp. itoror. 
ilosiikit (plural ilosiikito) (adjective) (of a person’s body) dirty; grimy; filthy.
ilosikino (adjective) (of speech, action, amount, etc) apt; sufficient; appropriate. itunga lu kere mam ilosikinos togo lo: all these people cannot be accommodated in this house. ajon ngun mam ilosikinos itunga lu: that beer will not be sufficient for these people. 
ilotot (adjective) (of body, clothes, etc) washed; cleaned out. inyekinit ijo asaanit mam ilotot: you left the plate unwashed. 
ilotuna (adjective) (of a container, clothes, etc) well washed; cleaned out. ilotuna igoen lu: these clothes are washed, are clean. ilotuna ekatau neejai ijo: I like you very much. cp. ilotot
ilugokina (adjective) (of road, stick, etc) bent, crooked. 
ilugumum (plural ilugumumas) (adjective) (of bottle, belly, etc) very stout; tubby; portly; corpulent. 
ilugurur (plural ilugururas) (adjective) (of back, character, etc) hunched; bowed; crooked; criminal. 
ilujukuk (plural ilujukukos) (adjective) weak, flexible. 
ilukumum (plural ilukumumas) (adjective) (of vessel, pond, etc) round; circular. itogoi luka Iteso ilukumumas: the houses of the Iteso are round. 
ilukumuna (adjective) (of huts, ponds, etc) detached; distinct. ilukumuna itogoi lu: these houses are detached. cp. agituna. 
iluluono (plural iluluoko) (adjective) (of person) alarmist; panicky; jumpy. iluluono tai: sounding alarm for nothing. 
ilulwa1 (noun neuter) a fraction. oni da kidumuni ilulwa: we shall also receive a share. 
ilulwa2 (plural ilulwas) (adjective) (of anything) whole; unblemished; unscarred; perfectly smooth. ilulwas akiro ngun: that case has not been tried. 
ilumangang (plural ilumangangas) (adjective) (of a person) stupid; daft; (of cow, sheep, etc) hornless; (of big object) rounded; without a protrusion. cp. iluumum, elumang.
ilumudud (plural ilumududas) (adjective) (of wound) scabby; (of pot's contents) swollen up, orotund, etc. 
ilunguret (plural ilungureta) (noun Dimin.) a pill; a tablet; a knob (of stick or anything). ilunguret yenika ekia: a table or a pill. 
ilungurur1 (plural ilungururas) (adjective) (of anything) rounded, round. 
ilungurur2 (plural ilungururos) (adjective) (of a leper's limbs) toe-less; finger-less; amputated; maimed. 
ilunyuny (adjective) (of body, skin, etc) abraded; scratched. 
ilupudud (plural ilupududas) (adjective) (of nose, wound, etc) oozing; dripping. 
ilusumum (plural ilusumumas) (adjective) (of a round thing, especially a head or club) smooth; rounded; (of cow, sheep, goat, etc) hornless. 
iluterer (plural ilutereras) (adjective) (of eyes) bulging; protruding. 
iluumum (plural iluumumas) (adjective) (of cow, etc) hornless; (of a club) round-headed. cp. alumangang, alumudud, alumusus. 
ilwatana (plural ilwataka) (adjective) (of person, animal) peeing often; urinating often; bedwetting always. 
ilwer (plural ilweria) (noun neuter) a lesser bushbaby (a small, furry, tree-living animal with big eyes and a long tail), Galago crassicaudatus.
imadakak (plural imadakakas) (adjective) (of anything) very dirty; filthy; grimy; mucky; grubby; muddy; polluted. imadakakas ikonikel: your teeth are dirty. 
imadingana (plural imadingaka) (adjective) (of person) dangerous; desperate; atrocious. 
imagulul (plural imagululos) (adjective) (of anything) bent; warped; crooked. 
imakacac (plural imakacacas) (adjective) (of person) splay-footed. imakacac etunganan naarai imakacacas akejeke: he is splay-footed, because his feet are turned outwards. cp. imakucuc. 
imakakina (adjective) (of anything) stuck to; fixed to; adhering to. imakakina eong eporoto: I am hoarse. 
imakio (plural of ekimat) (noun M) (in the Anglican church) the clergy; old men; aged men. 
imakucuc (plural imakucucos) (adjective) (of person) splay-footed. cp. imakacac
imalaikakit (plural imalaikakitos) (adjective) angelic, saintly. 
imalalana (plural imalalaka) (adjective) (of person) cheeky; rude; mischievous; disrespectful; naughty. 
imaliasas (adjective) (of person) splay-footed. cp. imakacac, imakucuc. 
imanangit (plural imanang) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a calf.
imanangit (plural imanangito) (adjective) (of a cow, an elephant) having a newly-born calf.
imangara (adjective) (of anything) knocked down or knocked over. 
imare (plural of emaret) (noun M) cowpeas, Phaseolus tephrosia. 
imarimaret (plural imarimareta) (noun Dimin.) something small for listing; a colon. 
imatamana (plural imatamaka) (adjective) (of person) stubborn, obdurate, mulish, bolshie. 
imatat (plural imatan) (noun neuter) a beverage; a drink; a brew; a swill. ekia lomatat (plural ikee lumatan) (noun M) medicine for drinking. akipi numatan: drinking water.
imaten (plural of imatat) (noun neuter) drinks; beverages. 
imatongong (plural imatongongos) (adjective) (of face) thin; mean. 
imaukuk (plural imaukukos) (adjective) (literally) big-headed. 
imedelana (plural imedelaka) (adjective) (of person's character) temperate; kind; merciful; clement; (of stature) tall and slender. 
imegerer (plural imegereras) (adjective) (of person, plant) not growing well; skinny. 
imerekek (plural imerekekin (noun Dimin.) a lamb; a young sheep; a small sheep (despicably). 
imidimida (plural imidimidas) (adjective) (of candlelight, voice) dim, weak, or muted. 
imilia (plural imilias) (adjective) (of lightning, surface) flashing; gleaming; glaring. 
iminai (plural iminaete) (adjective) (of surface, glue, etc) sticky; gluey; adhesive. 
imir (plural imirio) (noun Dimin.) (figurative) a small child; a baby (literally, a little rat). edeka ikamir kore: my little baby is ill at home. imirio: little kids or children. cp. ikoku.
Imiro (plural noun M) a Teso clan. 
imiroit (plural imiroi) (noun Dimin.) an illegitimate child; a bastard; a street kid. imiroi duc emameotor alup nudukot: bastard children often have no land to build homes. cp. imuyaayet.
imiyot (plural imiyoi) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a chick; a young of a chicken. cp. aculot. 
imodilil (plural imodililas) (adjective) (of child) dirty; mucky; grubby; filthy. 
imodiobore (adverb) (used with singular nouns) anything; something; nothing. emamei imodiobore einakitai nges: nothing has been given to him/her.
imodioboro (adverb) (used with plural nouns) anything; something; nothing. mam ikokolak apotu koyangaasi imodioboro kotogo: the thieves did not take anything from the house. 
imodo (plural imodoi) (noun Dimin.) a species of little birds. 
imokodana (plural imokodaka) (adjective) (of person) fastidious, finicky, hard to please, or peevish. 
imomot (plural imomotos) (adjective) (of fruit) half-ripe or yellowish. 
imongot (plural imongo) (noun Dimin.) a small fruit left after picking the big ones. cp. inginyo: of sweet potatoes, atinoi: of millet. 
imono (plural imokos) (adjective) (of person, animal, tyre, etc) satisfied; fulfilled; content; happy. 
imoriarit (plural imoriaritos) (adjective) inclusive; comprehensive; wide-ranging; broad. 
imorikikina (adjective) united; integrated; joined; married. 
imorimora (adjective) varied; mixed; assorted. 
imoru (plural imor) (noun Dimin.) a pebble; a small stone. imoru yenetiai: a prize jewel. 
imorut (plural imor) (noun Dimin.) 1. one of the sixty-four beads or pebbles used in aile or omweso board-game; 2. the method of playing that game. ededeng ikemorut: his/her method of playing omweso always leads to winning. cp. ileisit.
imu (plural of emuut) (noun M) twins. cp. toto k’odwe: mother of twins. cp. imuatok. 
imucakina (adjective) (of passage, etc) closed up, filled up by itself. 
imudangang (plural imudangangas) (adjective) (of person, sheep) having small or cut ears. 
imudongong (plural imudongongos) (adjective) (of a person, animal) having little crumpled ears. 
imug (plural noun M) gourd seeds, i.e. seeds of amugit. 
imugulul (plural imugululos) (adjective) (of limb, stick, pole, etc) twisted; crooked; warped. 
imujalal (plural imujalalas) (adjective) (of a person) naked; nude; exposed. 
imujurono (plural imujuroko) (adjective) (of person) scowling, frowning, often. cp. ijerukono. 
imukeru (plural imukerun) (noun neuter) a baby (girl or boy); a baby under two years of age, i.e. before it is weaned. ikoku yenimukeru: a little baby or infant child. 
imukerut (plural imukerutos) (adjective) babyish; infantile; puerile. eroko ngesi imukerut: she/he is still a baby. isirut yenimukerut: a mosquito larva. 
imukokit akwap (adverb) evening time; dusky. cp. atibong; awar akwap. 
imukoro (adjective) (of anything) covered with cloth; (of people) uncivilised; primitive; (of development) delayed. iringa ijo imukoro: you are still uncivilised. sirikimukor, adoloto isaawan: do not delay, it is time. imukoro ateran kegoe: the bride is covered with a veil. 
imukurur (plural imukururas) (adjective) steep; hilly. 
imulangang (plural imulangangas) (adjective) (of cow, etc) hornless. cp. aluumum
imunonitai (adjective) (of identity) concealed; kept secret; obscured. 
imunonoritai (adjective) (of identity) concealed; kept secret. 
imunwo (plural of emun) (noun M) intestinal worms - ascaris; snakes (in general). 
imurwono (plural imurwoko) (adjective) forgetful; inclined to forget; scatterbrained. 
imusungana (plural imusungaka) (adjective) injurious, harmful, dangerous or risky. 
imuut (plural imu) (noun neuter) a twin (person or animal). 
imuyaayet (plural imuyaayen) (noun Dimin.) a street kid; an illegitimate child; a bastard. ipu imuyaayen ko Kampala: there are a lot of street children in Kampala city. cp. imiroit.
imwaas ai? (interrogation) how many are they, you? 
imwace (adverb) a colloquial form of moi kace: in future. 
imwaneono (plural imwaneoko) (adjective) (of person) greedy; gluttonous; close-fisted; stingy. imwaneono ijo: you are close-fisted. cp. aibitionut. 
imyela (plural imyelas) (adjective) (of person, animal) hungry for; eager for; impatient for. 
imyelimyel (plural imyelimyelio) (noun Dimin.) (Serere) a small grey house gecko; a newt; an eft. cp. ingitiyo
inac (plural nuinac) (noun F) a sister; a cousin sister. onaceka: my brother; my cousin brother. inacika: my sister; my cousin sister. 
inamana (plural inamaka) (adjective) joking; fond of joking; fond of cracking jokes. 
inangai (plural nukinangai) (noun F) so-and-so; a woman that shall not be identified. abu inangai: so and so has come (in a despicable tone). 
inangei (plural of enangiya) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) clothing (in general); apparel; attire. cp. inapen 
inangirir (plural inangiriros) (adjective) (of gums) thick; (of skin) abnormally thick (like a skin of a hippo). 
inapaara (adjective) (of person, animal) polite; humble; gentle; well-mannered. etunganan loinapaara: a nice, polite, well mannered, or humble man. 
inapakina (adjective) (of anything) calm; peaceful; quiet. mam ber akwap nako Teso inapakina: the Teso country is not yet peaceful. ainapakin akeje: to sit down with legs or thighs closed (as women do). 
inapap (adjective) (of things) folded; arranged; organised; methodical; tidy; neat. 
inapat (plural inapen) (noun neuter) clothes; clothing in general; apparel; attire; garb. emameete eong inapen: I have no clothes. 
inarurut (plural inarurutos) (adjective) (of the body) swollen from lashes or insect bites. inarurutos iwosike naarai edaitai: her/his buttocks are swollen because they were beaten or caned on. 
inepukuk (plural inepukukos) (adjective) (of fur, downs, mattress, pillow, etc) soft; spongy; fluffy; downy; cosy. egoe loinepukuk: a soft cloth. 
inepunit (plural inepunitos) (adjective) burning; ablaze; (of desire) enthusiastic. 
inepuuk (plural inepuukos) (adjective) a colloquial form of inepukuk: soft; spongy; fluffy; downy; cosy. apaliisi nainepuuk: a soft or spongy mattress. 
inerana (plural ineraka) (adjective) loquacious; garrulous; talkative. 
ingaamam (plural ingaamamas) (adjective) having many teeth; with a fuIl set of teeth. cp. angoomom. 
ingabarar (plural ingabararas) (adjective) (of a big bowlegged person) having fat buttocks and wide hip-bones. 
ingabinyiny (plural ingabinyinyas) (adjective) (of a small person) to have flat buttocks and bow legs. cp. akoritit, aripidid, abelenyeny, animokok, akubanyany. 
ingadakina (adjective) (of anything) hidden; preserved; kept in custody; put aside; saved up. isirigin luingadakina: money put aside, saved. 
ingadana (plural ingadaka) (adjective) fond of storing up (like bees or ants or people). 
ingai? (plural lukangai M, nukangai F) (interrogative pronoun) who? whom? lokangai? (nakangai F) (plural lukangai, nukangai?) whose? ngai ma ngol (ngin F)?: by the way, who is that? ingai ijo?: who are you (singular)? ingai ekirorikon?: what is your name? lukangai ikusikiroria?: what are your names?
ingalana (plural ingalaka) (adjective) fond of deceiving; dishonest; elusive; deceitful. 
ingalat (plural ingalatos) (adjective) having deceived; bogus; phony; sham. 
ingarakit (plural ingarakitos) (adjective) supporting; beneficial; supplementary. 
ingaren (adverb) forward; in front; the future; ahead. cp. kingaren.
ingarenit (plural nuingarenito) (noun neuter) antecedent; precedent; guiding; standard. 
Ingariama (plural noun M) Iteso people from Ngariam sub-county in Katakwi district. Angariamait: a woman from Ngariam. Engariamait: a man from Ngariam. 
ingarot (plural ingaroi) (noun Dimin.) a pebble; a piece of grit.
ingatan (plural noun M) booty; spoils of war; plunder; pillage; the loot. cp. ludeman.
ingatuna (plural lungatuna) (noun neuter) the loot; booty; ill-gotten gains. iboro lungatuna: things robbed; the loot or booty. itunga lungatuna: captives after a raid. 
ingeberer (plural ingebereras) (adjective) (of dress, cloth, or trousers) short; brief; mini. 
ingecelikino (adjective) (of anything) overlapping; unequal; going beyond. 
ingedeses (plural ingedesesas) (adjective) (of hips) lopsided (one leg shorter than the other, or the hip-bone ill-formed. 
ingejingeja (plural ingejingejas) (adjective) inarticulate; mumbling; faltering; tongue-tied. 
ingepesikina (adjective) partly overlapping. 
ingeretenyit (plural ingeretenyitos) (adjective) (of person) thin; emaciated. abongu ngesi kangina ingeretenyit: she/he came back from there very thin. 
ingesebeb (plural ingesebebas) (adjective) (of rope, cloth, pot etc)easily broken; fragile; delicate; brittle; weak. cp. ebenen. 
inginamam (plural inginamamas) (adjective) (of person) toothless.
inginyana (plural inginyaka) (adjective) (of person) fond of backbiting or slandering; gluttonous; (of cook) fond of mashing food. 
inginyiny (adjective) (of food) crushed; mashed. akoto edia loinginyiny: I want mashed (or well-cooked) vegetables. 
ingiol (plural ingiol) (noun Dimin.) a person with protruding teeth. 
ingiolol (plural ingiololas) (adjective) (of a person) with teeth protruding; having a harelip. 
ingirabab (plural ingirababas) (adjective) (of teeth) broken or worn out. ingirababas ikonikel: you have got broken teeth. 
ingirionyony (plural ingirionyonyas) (adjective) (of person) having a bruised face or broken teeth. 
ingisolol (plural ingisiololas) (adjective) (of person) having protruding teeth or a harelip. 
ingitiyo (plural ingitiyon) (noun Dimin.) (Usuk) a little light grey house gecko; a newt; a gecko lizard. cp. imyelimyel. 
ingobelono (plural ingobeloko) (adjective) desirous; covetous; longing; craving; pining; lusty. 
ingonyas (adjective) (of networks) complicated; elaborate; (of people) hurly burly. 
ingoomom (plural ingoomomas) (adjective) (of person, trees, etc) toothy; thorny; teeming, crowding. ingoomomas ikukwa korot kangol: there are plenty of thorns on that road. ingoomomas ikel: the mouth is full of teeth (no gaps); toothy. 
Ingoratok (plural noun M) one of the four main divisions of the Iteso people and natives of present day Kumi district counties of Ngora, Kumi and Bukedea. Their dialect of Ateso was formerly regarded by Christian missionaries stationed in Ngora as ‘standard’ Ateso which they recommended for use in written (as opposed to colloquial) Ateso. cp. Iseera, Ikokolemwo.
ingoriana (plural ingoriaka) (adjective) (of a man) fond of women; womanising. 
ingosibib (plural ingosibibos) (adjective) (approvingly) esteemed; estimable; (disapprovingly) awful; dreadful. 
ingosobob (plural ingosobobas) (adjective) (of mouth) toothy. 
ingotolol (plural ingotololas) (adjective) (of face) disfigured; gnarled. ingotolol nges akuwan: her/his body is disfigured (having one eye, short leg, a dented face, etc). 
ingularar (plural ingulararas) (adjective) (of limbs) maimed; disfigured; mutilated. ipu itunga luingulararas kanuka ejie: many people are maimed due to war. 
ingulenyeny (plural ingulenyenyas) (adjective) (of person) stumpy; dwarf. 
inicakina (adjective) (of adjacent things) close together; compacted. yeninicakina (plural luinicakina): that, those that are compacted.
inicanakina (adjective) (of neighbouring things) close or closely fitted together. kibwaik kes kinicanakina: put them close together. 
inimokok (plural inimokokas) (adjective) (of buttocks) tiny and shrivelled.
inokok (adjective) on fire; (of food) well done, hot (literally, well cooked). inokok etaala: the lamp is lit. koyau akipi nuinokok: bring hot or boiled water. inokok acok ngun: those potatoes are well cooked. 
Inomu (plural of enomut) (noun M) a Teso clan of bone-setters and masseurs; the physiotherapists. 
inukusana (plural inukusaka) (adjective) (of person) fond of sleeping for too long or waking late. 
inusio (plural noun M) coin money; mint. cp. ilimia.
inyadakak (plural inyadakakas) (adjective) (of mouth, teeth) dirty; unclean; grimy. 
inyaiyono (plural inyaiyoko) (adjective) (of person) fastidious; particular about things; hard to please; fussy. 
inyalal (adjective) (of things) mixed; compounded; amalgamated; composite; multifaceted. 
inyalikik (plural inyalikikos) (adjective) (of body, meat, etc) soft to touch; squashy; spongy like a dead cat. 
inyalinyala (adjective) (of things) mixed; confused; assorted; varied. 
inyamat (plural noun M) food; edibles; nourishment; meal. 
inyamen (plural noun neuter) food (derogatively); edible things. cp. inyamat
inyangana (plural inyangaka) (adjective) revengeful; vindictive; spiteful.
inyeg (plural noun neuter) worthless millet grain. cp. ikabinin. 
inyekoono (plural inyekooko) (adjective) (of a co-wife) jealous; envious; green-eyed. 
inyikokinit (plural inyikokinitos) (adjective) (of a person, sickness, etc) continuing; earnest; serious; grave; sombre; stern-faced.
inyo bo? (interrogation) what now?; what then? 
inyo? (interrogation) what? kanukinyo?: why? alosi ngesi kinyo?: how did she/he go? (on foot or on bicycle?) lonyoin? M, nanyoin? F (plural lunyoika? or nunyoika?) which kind? what kind? (referring to colour or quality). inyoin ikoku? (itelepat arai ipese?): what sex is the child? (a boy or girl?) 
inyodokok (plural inyodokokas) (adjective) (of mouth, teeth) unbrushed; dirty; grimy; unclean. 
inyogirir (plural inyogiriros) (adjective) thick or (to be) difficult to please (of man). 
inyonyoikina (adjective) the anointed; the smeared. 
inyorakina (adjective) (of things, especially cooked food) mixed; added. inyamat luinyorakina acok ka imare: a mixture of potatoes and peas. cp. emangor; inyolakina. 
inyoridid (plural inyorididas) (adjective) (of body) dirty. 
inyus (plural inyusak) (adjective) (of dough, clay, mortar, food) thick; solid. 
-io suffix for present indirect and infinite of passive form. enyekinit eong etogo edukio: I left the house being built. 
ipa (plural lukipa) (noun neuter) (used in letters) sir; My Lord; Your Highness. ipa: papa (father).
Ipaapa (plural lukipaapa) (noun neuter) the Pope. 
ipajanas (adjective) (of people, animals) consanguineous; related. 
ipak (plural ipakio) (noun Dimin.) a moment; a jiffy; a split second; an instant. 
ipaliyono (plural ipaliyoko) (adjective) obdurate; insolent; mulish; stubborn. 
ipaloror (plural ipalororos) (adjective) (of a head) bald; bare; clean-shaven. 
ipaperono (plural ipaperoko) (adjective) (of person) friendly; sociable; welcoming; amiable. 
ipaset (plural ipaseta) (noun Dimin.) a full-stop; a resting point. cp. iyengunet
ipege (plural ipegei) (noun Dimin./neuter) a piglet; a little pig; a little dirty child. 
ipegeta (plural noun M) (formerly) arguments at initiation ceremonies. 
ipeket (plural ipeken, ipekei) (noun Dimin.) a small grey hawk. 
ipelakina (adjective) (of anything) precarious; unstable; in a falling position; shaky. 
ipemerer (plural ipemereras) (adjective) (of a child or a thin man) having a distended stomach.
iperito (plural noun neuter) beddings. cp. ejamu
ipese (plural ipesur) (noun Dimin.) a female infant. cp. atumunan: an adolescent girl; a young girl. 
ipicara (adjective) (of something semi-liquid) crushed; quashed; flattened. 
ipidipidiara (adjective) (of height) very far up; (of tree) very tall, high. ekitoi loipidipidiara: a very tall tree. 
ipiitit (plural ipiititas) (adjective) (of person) stunted, underdeveloped. 
ipinyana (plural ipinyaka) (adjective) (of person) inclined to gorge, over-eat. 
ipiricara (adjective) (of food, fruit, etc) crushed; squashed; pressed out. emucuuga loipiricara: a crushed orange. 
ipirisakina (adjective) (of solids, crystals) dissolved; liquefied; thawed out. 
ipirit (plural ipiritos) (adjective) (of wood, dried potatoes, etc) weevil-eaten; rotten; decayed. 
ipisakina (adjective) (of a container) absolutely full; full to the brim. cp. ileleba
ipokirir (plural ipokiriras) (adjective) muscular; burly; beefy; hefty. ipokiriras itelepai lu: these boys are burly.
ipongosos (plural ipongososas) (adjective) (of buttocks) huge. cp. aduleses, apurasas, auselel, atirajaj. 
ipoo (plural ipooi) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a scrub hare, Lepus capensis; a rabbit. 
ipopanyatoi (plural ipoponyatos) (adjective) (of a rhino, bull, etc running) noisy and forceful, dangerous. 
ipopolana (plural ipopolaka) (adjective) (of person) boisterous, rowdy. 
iporo (adverb) during the wet season. eweyo ikinyom iporo: seeds are sown during the wet season.
iporo (adverb) in, during the wet or rainy season. 
ipu (plural ipuwak) (adjective) many; much; plenty. ipu akipi: water is much. ipu itunga: people are many. ipu agasia: rubbish is much. epol emaase: many locusts. epuata kesi: they have become many. 
ipucakina (adjective) (of an opening) blocked, closed, plastered or fastened. 
ipudanara (adjective) (of people) desirous of each other; loving one another. 
ipugurikina (adjective) (of person) hunch-backed; stooped. 
ipugurur (plural ipugururas) (adjective) hunch-backed; hunched; arched; stooped. 
ipumu (plural noun neuter) epilepsy; seizures; fits. ejaas ngol ipumu: erai ngesi lok’ipumu: he has epilepsy. lok’ipumu (noun M) an epileptic. 
ipus (plural ipusio) (noun neuter) a pussy cat; a kitten. cp. ikapa. 
iput (plural iputio) (noun neuter) a stunted child; a dwarf; a midget. 
ipuwak (adjective) numerous; many. itunga luipuwak mam edumunete aswam: many people will not get work. cp. ipu, luipu. 
iraat (plural iraan) (noun neuter) a thing planted; a plant. 
iragag (adjective) (of grain) poorly ground, coarse. 
irajakak (plural irajakakas) (adjective) (of body) flaccid; flabby; floppy. 
irajiraja (plural irajirajas) (adjective) (of anything) tied loosely. cp. ilajilaja.
irangaana (plural irangaaka) (adjective) (of person) greedy; gluttonous. 
irangangai (plural irangangaete) (adjective) (of meat, wound, eyes, etc) very red. 
irapudud (plural irapududos) (adjective) (of person, animal) short; dwarfish. 
Irarak (plural noun M) a Teso clan of Hunters; the Cheetah clan. 
iraruna (noun M) a thing found or picked up. ikoku yenikiraruna: foundling; a stray child picked by someone who is not a relative. 
iregeget (plural iregegen) (noun Dimin.) a small black bird. 
iregemem (plural iregememas) (adjective) (of a sick person) thin with small protruding belly. 
iregemit (plural iregemitos) (adjective) (of eyes) dirty. iregemitos akonye kon: you have dirty eyes (like groundnut dregs). 
iregwa (plural iregwai) (noun Dimin.) a small black bird. 
iremana (plural iremaka) (adjective) (of a dog) good at barking. 
irengamoni (plural irengamonia) (noun Dimin.) a little shrike. 
irengemany (plural irengemanyia) (noun Dimin.) a small fish with red-tipped fins. 
irengerenget (plural irengerengen) (noun Dimin.) a robin (bird). 
irepenyeny (plural irepenyenyas) (adjective) (of animal, person) short, dwarfish. ikingok yenirepeny: a pug dog. 
irereono (plural irereoko) (adjective) observant; watchful.
ireria (plural of ere) (noun M) homes; villages; homesteads; abodes; kraals; residences. 
iriapongong (plural iriapongongos) (adjective) (of a person) cock-eyed; squinting. 
iribikik (plural iribikikos) (adjective) (of cloth, the night, etc) jet black; very black; pitch dark; shining black (like alpaca cloth). 
iridet (plural irideta) (noun Dimin.) a clip; a clamp. 
iriorono (plural irioroko) (adjective) (of person) talkative; chatty. 
iripadad (plural iripadadas) (adjective) (of something big, a person) flat; low; depressed; stumpy. 
iritongong (plural iritongongos) (adjective) (of person) cock-eyed; squinting. 
irokodod (plural irokododos) (adjective) (of head) pointed at the back. irokodod nges akou: she/he has a head protruding at the back: her/his head protrudes at the back. 
iromococ (plural iromococas) (adjective) (of person) knock-kneed. cp. irocokok
irotongong (plural irotongongos) (adjective) (of the head, an object) narrowed; squeezed. 
irumuna (adjective) (of wife, property, etc) inherited; innate; inborn; hereditary. iboro luirumuna: inherited property. aronus nairumuna: original sin. aberu nairumuna: an inherited woman (i.e. wife of a dead relative).
irumunet (plural irumuneta) (noun neuter) apostrophe; the sign (’). 
irumurumaara (adjective) (of body, the face) bloated; swollen; distended. 
irupeana (plural irupeaka) (adjective) (of person) double-dealing; fond of reporting, duplicity, and being devious. 
iruruono (plural iruruoko) (adjective) (of gangs) fond of raiding, plundering, robbing. 
irwa (imperative) go away; get out of the way; be gone. irwa kane!: get out of here! vamoose! (plural) irwa yesi kane! cp. oria.
irwa etom (singular noun M) a sensitive plant that folds up on being touched, Biophitum. 
rwaru (adverb) in the far future; in the distant future.cp. ekaulo, rwaru. 
irwerweet (plural irwerween) (noun Dimin.) a tit (a small bird). 
irwopokok (plural irwopokokos) (adjective) (of stomach, tyre, football, etc) empty; deflated.
irwoporo (adjective) (of a container, such as a rubber tube) empty, unfilled, etc. epesete itelepai emopiira loirwoporo: the boys are kicking a deflated football.
iryono (plural iryoko) (adjective) (of complexion, the night, etc) black; dark; dirty. iryono cucucuc: (of the night) very dark; (of anything) very dirty; very black.
iryoro (plural iryoros) (adjective) (of person, radio, telephone, etc) talking; speaking. iryoro ikoku katukot: the pupil is talking in class.
iryorono (plural iryoroko) (adjective) (of person) talkative; garrulous; loquacious; chatty. iryorono emuluka loka ekanisa kangol: the pastor of that church is talkative.
isagarar (plural isagararas) (adjective) (of hair, dry grass, etc) rough, shaggy, shabby, or unkempt. 
isamukuk (plural isamukukos) (adjective) (of hair, head) overgrown; hairy; shaggy. isamukukos idwe akwes: the children have long hair. isamukuk eong akou, ekoto abarenio: my head is overgrown (hair too long), it needs a shave. cp. aicek: overgrow (of hair on body or weeds). cp. aisular: overgrow (of roadside or garden weeds). 
isanyirir (plural isanyiriros) (adjective) (of hair) bristling, bedraggled, shaggy. 
isapirir (plural isapiriros) (adjective) (of person’s hair) unkempt. cp. isangirir, isanyirir. 
isaseredootin (plural of esaseredooti) (noun M) the (Roman Catholic) clergy. 
isean (plural noun M) the chosen ones; the elite; the elect. 
isedenyeny (plural isedenyenyas) (adjective) (of a hollow, pit, etc) shallow. 
Iseera (plural noun M) the Iteso from Serere; one of the four main divisions of the Iteso people and natives of present day Soroti district counties of Serere, Kasilo and Soroti, and Amuria and Kapelebyong counties in Katakwi. (Iseera speak a dialect of Ateso distinguished by their use of letters ‘gw’ instead of ‘bw’ in words such as aibwo, aibworo, Ikarebwok, etc. cp. Ingoratok, Ikokolemwo.
isekelono (plural isekeloko) (adjective) (of person) inclined to scoff at, ridiculing or laughing at. 
iselio (plural noun neuter) poorly fitting large garments. ailoli iselio: aiil iselio: to be alarmed (literally, to sway with large garments). 
iselyo (plural of esel) (noun M) a corruption of iselio: big dresses (that swing about as the wearer walks). ailoli iselyo: to be uneasy. cp. inapen.
iseren (plural iserin) (noun Dimin.) a butter fish, Shilbo. 
iseuna (plural noun M) the elect; the chosen ones. cp. isean: the elite.
isididiara (adjective) (of tree, evil, etc) cannot be eliminated or eradicated; deep-rooted. 
isigala (plural isigalan) (noun Dimin.) a cigar; a cigarillo.
isikakina (adjective) (of passage, etc) blocked; clogged; jammed. isikakina eong eporoto: I am hoarse. 
isikik (adjective) stamped; rammed; blocked; pumped up; beaten up. 
isilarit (plural isilaritos) (adjective) contrite; sorry; remorseful; repentant; apologetic; penitent. 
isimu yenikakan (plural isimun lukakan) (noun Dimin.) a mobile phone; a hand-held phone.
isinerit (plural isinerito) (adjective) engaged to; affianced to; betrothed to. isineritai apese: the girl is betrothed or is wooed. 
isinyeono (plural isinyeoko) (adjective) (of person) greedy, voracious. 
isiorotot (plural isiorototas) (adjective) (of tree, pillar, etc) dead-straight; straight without a bend. 
isiriamut (plural isiriamun) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a Muslim in general; a little Mohammedan; a Muslim child or thing.
isirigin (plural noun M) money; currency; legal tender. isirigin luko Uganda edit egogong adepar luko Kenya arai Tanzania: the Ugandan currency has less value than that of Kenya or Tanzania.
isiriomom (plural isiriomomos) (adjective) (of face, etc) dirty. 
isirir (adjective) adorned; decorated; festooned; bejewelled. 
isisiat (plural isisian) (noun neuter) a lesson; a little teaching. 
iso (personal pronoun 1st person plural subject or object, but exclusive of the listener) we; us. cp. oni: we; us (inclusive of the listener). cp. isyo.
isogoror (plural isogororas) (adjective) (of a part, etc) sticking out; protruding; protuberant. 
isokodod (plural isokododos) (adjective) (of handle of walking stick, beak of bird of prey, nose, etc) having a round bend; curved; hooked. 
isomelel (plural isomelelos) (adjective) (of an egg, sheanut fruit, etc) oval; stream-lined; elliptical. 
isoridid (plural isorididas) (adjective) (of anything) sordid; dirty; filthy. isorididas kes awate: their bodies are filthy. 
isorodod (plural isorododas) (adjective) (of anything) dirty; dingy; filthy; squalid; (of language) lewd; obscene. cp. isoridid
isosolono (plural isosoloko) (adjective) (of person) arrogant; self-confident; being a wiseacre. 
isoswa (plural noun M) pretence; sham; feigning; make-believe; pretending. mam akoto ikonisoswa: I don’t want your pretence. 
isot (plural isotia) (noun Dimin.) a word of admiration or praise, ‘nice little fellow’, ‘good little fellow’. ee abu isot ngin: there comes the good little fellow! 
isotia (plural of isot) (noun M, Dimin.) (only used by close friends) heroes; guys. apotu isotia kwi or apotu asotia kwa: our heroes are come: our heroines are coming. 
isua (plural noun neuter) (slang) coin money (currency). cp. inusio
isubat (plural isuban) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a creature. 
isugurana (plural isuguraka) (adjective) (of person) phlegmatic; showing unwillingness or reluctance (by going slowly). cp. aisigira. 
isujakak (plural isujakakas) (adjective) (of head, body) hairy; shaggy; hirsute; bristly. 
isuk (plural of esukut) (noun M) Bambara nuts (a variety of beans). 
Isukukur (plural noun M) Christmas time (period around 25th December). apaarit naka Isukukur (plural apaarasia nuka Isukukur) (noun F) Christmas (25th December). cp. ebaga
isulajaj (plural isulajajas) (adjective) (of beard) hairy; hirsute; (of head) overgrown; (of garden) full of weeds. 
Isureta (plural noun M) a Teso clan of denouncers and blasphemers (who kill by incantations and sacrificing at anthills); people from Asuret in Soroti county or some other place of that name. 
iswagara (adjective) (of utensils, floor, etc) clean; polished; scoured; scrubbed. 
iswamana (plural iswamaka) (adjective) (of person, animal) hardworking; industrious. 
iswapakak (plural iswapakakas) (adjective) (of eyebrows, eyelashes) overgrown, long. 
isweenyeny (plural isweenyenyas) (adjective) (of a person) small, dwarfed, meagre, tiny, or of slight build.
iswomodod (plural iswomododas) (adjective) (of nose, face) very dirty with dripping thick mucous; (of sex trade) iniquitous; lewd; obscene. 
iswongolol (plural iswongololos) (adjective) (of a person’s character) maladjusted; (of dress) not fitting. 
isyalakak (plural isyalakakas) (adjective) (of hair) rastafarian; unkempt; (of clothes) in rags, pieces or strands. 
isyarasiara (adjective) (of bread, etc) scattered; spread about; dispersed. 
isyo (personal pronoun, 1st person plural, subject or object - exclusive of listener) us; we. eong: I; me. cp. iso
-it suffix of verb active tense, present indicative, effective or continuous tense or result of completed action. edukit ngesi eketogo: she/he has built her/his house. elipit eong ijo: I ask or keep asking, begging you. 
itaditada (plural itaditadas) (adjective) (of pole, tooth, etc) infirm, unsteady, or shaky; (of teeth, etc) loose. ejaas eong ikel luitaditadas: I have loose teeth. cp. ilokiloko.
itagitaga (plural itagitagas) (adjective) (of a pole) loose, rickety, or unsteady; (of any furniture) rickety, wobbly, or shaky. itagitagitoi: it/she/he is staggering on.
itak (plural of itaok) (noun neuter/Dimin.) calves. 
italakana (plural italakaka) (adjective) (of a person) consoling; condoling; cheering; heartening.
itanaki (plural itanakete) (adjective) (of a mother) breast-feeding.
itangaleuni (plural itangaleunete) (adjective) (of drug, etc) curative; remedial; healing; therapeutic. 
itaok (plural itak) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a calf. 
itaparin (plural noun M) a grass, Andropogan. 
itapatani (plural itapatanete) (adjective) simplifies; makes easier.
itasiono (plural itasionos) (adjective) humble; repentant; sorrowful.
itawono (plural itawoko) (adjective) (of a person) greedy; selfish; egoistic. cp. ibityono. 
itebeikina (adjective) congruent; appropriate; fitting; suitable; facing, in front of.
itegelikina (adjective) especial; unique; special; singular; different; peculiar.
itegumum (plural itegumumos) (adjective) having a big belly or tummy. 
iteketeket (plural iteketeken) (noun Dimin.) a second – one sixtieth of a minute; a jiffy. karai ejaas iteketeken akais akany-kape odakiika ediope, idi bo do iteketeken ejaas toma osaawa ediope?: if sixty seconds are in a minute, then how many seconds are in an hour?
itela (plural itelai) (noun neuter) the only child produced by a particular woman. 
itelele (plural itelelei) (noun Dimin.) a small drum (often beaten together with a big etida drum for curing a sick person). 
itemelel (plural itemelelas) (adjective) (of a lady) beautiful; good-looking; gorgeous. 
itemokino (adjective) prepared; orderly; arranged; measured; justified. 
itemoro (adjective) (of formatted text) justified; measured; exact in measure; (of dress, etc) fitting. cp. itemokino. 
itemwan (plural of etem) (noun M) sub-counties. 
itenakina (adjective) lengthwise; straight; standing; upright. 
itenara (adjective) upright; erect; straight; vertical. 
itengeana (plural itengeaka) (adjective) always hungry; ravenous. 
Itengor (plural of Etengorit) (noun M) a Teso clan. 
itenya (plural noun M) sores on knuckles; arthritis of the knuckles.
itepegit (plural itepegitos) (adjective) contra; hostile; opposed; anti.
iteregeg (plural iteregegas) (adjective) stiff; paralysed; rigid. 
Iteso (plural of Etesot) (noun M) natives of former Teso (present-day Katakwi, Kaberamaido, Soroti, and Kumi) and parts of Bukedi (current Pallisa and Tororo districts) in Uganda and Teso in western Kenya; a Nilo-Hamitic tribe in eastern Uganda and parts of western Kenya, numbering at least two million people – probably the third largest of Uganda’s 53 tribes - akin to Karimojong, Turkana and Masai; the people of original Usuk county in Katakwi district (the people who pride themselves as being from U.K – Usuk Katakwi) with a dialect characterised by elision of letter ‘k’ in certain nouns such as akipi, akituk, ekicolong which they pronounce as aipi, aituk and eicolong respectively. cp. Iseera, Ingoratok and Ikokolemwo.
itesot1 (adjective) of Teso or its people; pertaining to Iteso people, their language and culture. 
Itesot2 (plural Iteso) (noun Dimin.) a child or little person from Teso. (note that referring to an adult as itesot is an insult). 
itet (plural itetiak) (adjective) new; fresh; young; recent; clean; unused; modern. cp. emojongit
itetiak (plural of itet) (adjective) new; brand new; young; recent; unused; modern. 
itia (adverb) for; instead of; in place of. koyau akine itia emerekekeka: bring a goat instead of my ram. 
itia nyo? (interrrogative pronoun) on account of what? cp. kanukinyo
itica (plural nukitica) (noun Dimin.) a female school teacher (especially in primary or nursery school). cp. akesisianakinan
itiirianakina (adjective) equalised; levelled; arrayed; adjusted; contemporaneous. itiirianakina ikar kec: they are equal (in age); they are contemporaries.
itilasas (plural itilasasas) (adjective) (of fat women) naked above the waist; half-naked. itilasasas aloke toni kwana: the Karimojong women are naked up to this day. 
itim (plural of etimat) (noun M) hair on the head; a hairdress (made of human hair and worn during traditional dances as a costume); blood capillaries. 
itimaikinit (plural itimaikitos) (adjective) (of an organ) having capillaries; (of scalp) hairy. 
itimono (plural itimoko) (adjective) lenient; forgiving; merciful. 
itingatoi (plural itingatos) (adjective) indisposed; reluctant; half-hearted. 
itinitina (plural itinitinas) (adjective) peevish; shy; finicky. itinitina ber apese egeunio aisup: a girl will be shy when courtship starts.
itirajaj (plural itirajajas) (adjective) (of a woman) having huge rolling buttocks. cp. iduleses, ipurasas, iuselel, ipongosos. 
ititimana (plural ititimaka) (adjective) fussy; vacillating; undecided; delaying. 
ito (interjection) (Usuk) dear me! oh oh! alas! ito! kiyangaa bo jo ajon kere, ido bodo eong ka nyo?: alas! if you carry away all the beer, what will I remain with?
itodikitai (auxiliary verb) I, you, etc must or should; you are dictated or commanded to (do something).
itogo (plural itogoi) (noun Dimin.) a cottage; a hut; a little house. kotogo: indoors. 
itokokolit (plural itokokolitos) (adjective) antagonistic; anti; opposing; competing with.
itomon (plural noun neuter) ten. irwana tomon: ten times. itunga itomon epote: ten people will be coming.
itongolol (plural itongololos) (adjective) (of man) handsome; praiseworthy; meritorious.
itonokit (plural itonokitos) (adjective) causing to come near; causing to close on; firing up or keeping on fire. 
itopolono (plural itopoloko) (adjective) haughty; arrogant; self-important; conceited; inclined to be proud; stuck up.
itoronana (plural itoronaka) (adjective) (of person) critical; eager to blame; nit-picking; captious; fault-finding. 
itoror (adjective) (of a path, road) trampled down; trodden hard. itoror ijo aki: you are very deaf; you are hard of hearing; you cannot hear. 
itotoka (interjection) (Usuk) dear me! oh my (mother)! alas! itotoka! adunge akim komukaro: oh my! the fire in the kiln has gone out.
itotokang (interjection) (Ateso Atororo) dear me! oh my (mother)! alas! itotokang! adunge akim komukaro: oh my! the fire in the kiln has gone out. cp. itotoka
itubet (plural itubeta) (noun Dimin.) something small for cutting; a semicolon. 
itudot (plural itudoi) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a duckling; a gosling. cp. atudo
ituen (plural itunga) (noun neuter) (Serere) a person; a bloke. cp. etunganan. 
itugai (plural noun M) an armlet or bracelet made of plant roots or giraffe hair.
itujomom (plural itujomomos) (adjective) (of a child) having a dirty body; having an unclean face. 
itukalal (plural itukalalas) (adjective) puffy or fat-cheeked; bloated. cp. itikijij. 
itunganan (plural itunga) (noun neuter) a person (man or woman); a human being.
itungasinei (collective noun plural) the people; the masses; mankind. 
iturasas (plural iturasasas) (adjective) (of a person) fat-buttocked; fat-arsed.
ituria (plural ituryai) (noun Dimin.) a small spear used by children. cp. ikwara. 
ituro (plural ituros) (adjective) proud; arrogant; self-conceited. 
iturono (plural ituroko) (adjective) fond of praising, approving, flattering; fond of exalting. 
itwala (plural itwalai) (noun Dimin.) a little pied (black-and-white) wagtail.
ityangaikinit (plural ityangaikinitos) (adjective) (of person) bestial; beastly; brutal; loathsome; wild; feral; untamed; abominable.
iulana (plural iulaka) (adjective) disobedient; stubborn; obstinate. 
Iusuko (plural of Eusukoit) (noun M) people from Usuk sub-county or county in Katakwi district.
iwangana (plural iwangaka) (adjective) (of person) eating half-cooked food; greedy. 
iwolokok (plural iwolokokos) (adjective) (of anything) hollow; empty; vain; inane. iwolokok asaduku: the box is empty. 
iwololo (plural lukiwololo) (noun Dimin.) a loud caller; a taxi or bus broker or tout. cp. eeworon. 
iwongono (plural iwongoko) (adjective) bombastic; high-flown; vainglorious; presumptuous; inclined to boast, brag or vaunt. 
iwonyana (plural iwonyaka) (adjective) (only of walking) brisk; fast; quick; speedy. iwonyana ngesi: she/he is quick, walks fast. 
Iworopom (plural noun M) a Teso clan; Iteso from Tororo and Kenya distinguished by their heavy use of letter ‘k’ in Ateso nouns and verbs with prefixes ‘ai’ and ‘ei’ (for example: verbs aicum, aitep, aibunga become akicum, akitep, akibunga respectively; nouns eicolong, eitela, eitaada become ekicolong, ekitela, ekitaada respectively). 
iworoworo (plural iworoworos) (adjective) (rare) leaking; porous. 
iwulana (adjective) a corruption of iulana: disobedient; insubordinate. 
iyakiana (plural iyakiaka) (adjective) obedient; inclined to obey; dutiful; submissive.
iyakitono (plural iyakitoko) (adjective) obedient; submissive; subservient; dutiful; beneficial; useful; handy; versatile; serviceable. amot na erai nakiyakitono: this is a handy pot. ekiyakitono etunganan ngol: he is a useful or handy man. cp. iyakiana. 
iyalana (plural iyalaka) (adjective) conversational; good at telling jokes; good-natured.
iyamakina (adjective) (of anything) peaceful; undisturbed; serene. 
iyamara (adjective) (of manner, attitude) gentle; meek; mild; quiet. 
iyapono (plural iyapoko) (adjective) (of a person) inclined to swearing or to make vows. 
iyapununee (plural iyapuneneete) (adjective) (of user, spender) frugal; economical; thrifty; sparing.
iyata (plural iyatas) (adjective) (of amount, conflict, etc) rising; escalating; increasing; growing; mouting. 
iyatakina (adjective) excessive; needless; unnecessary; extreme. 
iyeda (plural iyedas) (adjective) (of belly) slender, slim. 
iyeyait (plural iyeyai) (noun neuter) (Serere) a nephew or niece (called so by aunt). cp. ijejait
iyiyaikina (adjective) (of surface, etc) smooth; level; even. 
iyo (personal pronoun) (Serere)  a corruption of second person singular personal pronoun ijo: you
iyogiyoga (plural iyogiyogas) (adjective) (of teeth, poles, wall, etc) shaky; rickety; unsteady.
iyuuna (adjective) (of story, etc) credible; believable; plausible. 
iyuunana (plural iyuunaka) (adjective) (of person) gullible; naive; credulous; easy to fool. 
-J-
j (noun neuter) the eighth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
je (plural kwi) (demonstrative pronoun masculine singular) that man (far away). koleje pac: recently. koleje (adverb) in the recent past; previously; some time ago, not long ago. laije (preposition) over there; that side. okekwa je: the other side (of the river or of the swamp). oitela je: at the next parish or village. olap je: the previous month. ekaru je: the previous year. je bo je: (emphatic) there he is. cp. ya; yi.
Jeana (singular noun neuter) (biblical) Hell; the abode of Satan. 
jelijel (adverb) very tasteless, insipid. epyana atap jelijel: the millet bread is very tasteless. ijelijelit ekatau aswam ngin: I am disgusted with that work. cp. jwelejwel.
jepeje (demonstrative masculine pronoun singular) that one over there. cp. kwipekwi.
jik (adverb) (Usuk) completely; surely; absolutely. aidong jik: to stay put. agir je ainyam jik: he has refused to eat totally. cp. noi, cut
jokan (adverb) very well; firmly. kiting nges jokan: hold her/him/it very well. cp. kojokan
jui (adverb) (in Karamoja) all day; the whole time; often; constantly. apaaran jui: the whole day; all day long. cp. duc, juijui
jui jui (adverb) (in Karamoja) all day; the whole day; completelely; entirely; often; constantly. apaarit jui jui: the whole day; all day long. komat jui jui: drink completely. cp. ducu duc.
jukujuk (adverb) (of people, an activity, etc) too much; congested; crowded; jam-packed. elosete kesi jukujuk: they are crowded together. 
juwai (adverb) on the other side; (preposition) across; on the other side of; over from one side to the other side of something. okekwa juwai: on the other side of the river, valley, forest, desert, etc. mam imwangi yenejai okekwa juwai: (proverb) respect the fellow who has crossed the river. juwai ketogo: on the other side of the house. 
jwele jwel (adverb) (tasting) insipidly; dully; blandly. epyaka acuc jwele jwel: the ajon remnant is very tasteless.
-K-
k (noun neuter) the ninth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
-k suffix of plural nouns whose singular ends with '-on' or '-an': ekadukon (singular): ikadukok (plural); ekelipan (singular): ikelipak (plural). 
k’ prepositional prefix of place meaning 'from' (followed by feminine noun of place or verbal noun or other feminine nouns). alemunit eong nges kasaduku: I took it from (out of) the box. abunit eong katapar: I came from the swamp. abunit kaira epaaba: I come from planting cotton. cp. ko, kaneka.
-k-1 infix forming plurals of adjectives which have root ending in 'n': ejokuna: good (plural ejokuka: good).
k-1 prefix for conjugation of the far past, conditional and optative forms - abu eong kaduk: kaduk eong kolo sek: I built a long time ago. kadukoto ne: let us build here. kaduk eong ne: let me build here. 
-k-2 infix indicating plural form of verbs in '-n-': atwanare (singular): atwakare (plural): to die. atwana: she/he/it died. atwaka: they have died. 
k-2 prefix indicating objective personal pronoun of the 1st and 2nd person singular and plural prefixed to verbs. (note: objective pronoun, not subjective) kelipit eong ijo: I pray or ask you. kilipit ijo eong: you ask me. (plural): kilipitos yesi eong: you ask of me. 
k-3 pronominal prefix meaning 'when' or 'if'- kebu ejakait, kisiira eong: when the chief comes, let me hear from you, i.e. warn me. kalot eong Kampala, kejukakini agangat: if/when I go to Kampala, I shall send you help. kilot Soroti, sirikimurwok agwelun etabaasa: if you go to Soroti, do not forget to buy a lamp.
-ka preposition 'of' denoting possessive case preceded by relative pronoun lo-, na-, yeni- (plural lu- for masculine and diminutives, nu- for feminine): aberu naka Ojangole: the wife of Ojangole. angor nuka lteso: the women of the Iteso. 
ka1 conjunction and preposition 'and' used before proper nouns beginning with vowel A-, such as Aoja, Asuret, Arapai, etc: and; with; by means of; also used to form numerals above 5: ikany kape - 6. the 'a' of ka is elided before nouns beginning with a, except in proper nouns and pronouns. ijo ka eong: you and I. ibuni ka eong: you come with me. Oceger kikokuke: Oceger and/with his child (a of ka elided before I of ikoku). abu eong kaara ngesi kebela: I killed him by means of a stick (club). abuni ka Amuria: she/he came from Amuria.
ka2 possessive pronoun of first person 'my' used adjectively: etogoka: my house (note: if used by self: M loka: mine; plural luka: mine. F naka: mine; plural nuka: mine. Dimin. yenika: mine; plural luka: mine). 
ka3 cut (adverb) most especially. eroko isapa lu, ka cut Otoke: these boys are bad, most especially Otoke.
kabeit (adverb) truly; in truth; truthfully; really; in fact; actually; accurately; strictly. kabeit, emamei kwapekwana ngesi kane: she/he is not actually here at the moment. kabeit elimunit ngesi ngun?: did she/he actually say that?
kace (adverb) (F) in addition; and others. kace da: and so forth; et cetera. 
kadodi (singular noun F) a lively Kigisu circumcision dance with drums, rattles and ankle bells. 
kadoogo (plural luakadoogo) (noun neuter) (a despicable code-word during the 1987–1991 insurgency in Teso) a child soldier; a Uganda government soldier in the late 1980s.
kai1 (adverb) in, at, to the house; at home. cp. togo, ore
kai2 (interrogation) (outside Usuk) from where? kibuni kai?: where do you come from? cp. kakai?
kaina (adverb) a corruption of kangina: over there. 
kakai? (interrogation) (Usuk) from where? kipote kakai?: where do you come from? cp. kai
kakeje (adverb) (to go) on foot; with the feet.
kakeju (adverb) with the foot; by foot.
kakongu (adverb) with the eye; from the eye. 
kakonye (adverb) in future; in front; forward; with the eyes. 
-kakwap (adjectival suffix) (lokakwap M, nakakwap F, yenikakwap Dimin.): native; indigenous; rural. 
kama (adverb) from. kama ejai (preposition) from where; from where she/he/it is. abuni eong kamaejai ejakait: I come from the chief. cp. kanejai.
kamoi (interjection) goodbye till tomorrow; till tomorrow; farewell till tomorrow. 
kamu (adverb) (done) in or during the dry season. 
kana demonstrative pronoun feminine singular: and, on, from this. kakan kana: kowai kalo: on this side. 
kane (demonstrative pronoun) from here; in this place; from this point. kolot kane: go from here. kane eonit: on dry land. kanewok: where we are; one of us. ingai kanewok?: which one of us? koge kane egeunia: begin from the beginning. koge aswam kane: start work here. kane ibunitor ijo: from where you have come. 
kaneka (preposition) from me; from my home. ibunit ijo kaneka?: have you come from my home? abunit eong kaneka ejakait: I have come from the chief's place. kanekon: from you (singular). kaneke: from her/him/it. kanekosi: from us (excluding the person spoken to). kanewok: from us (including the person spoken to). kanekus: from you (plural). kanekec: from them. 
kanen (adverb) and then; thereupon; so. kiroko iso kinyami kanen kobuni edou: as we were still eating the rain came.
