kanenice (adverb) partly; from somewhere else; in other ways. kanenice ejok, ido kanenice erono: it is partly good and partly bad. ebunit ngesi kanenice: she/he/it comes from somewhere. 
kanepekanen (adverb) there and then; instantly; here on the spot. cp. atipet. 
kangina (adverb) over there; from there. cp. kane: from this spot.
kangun demonstrative pronoun: therefore; for that reason; that is why; henceforth; and so. kangun, akoto alosit oreka: that is why (therefore) I want to go home. 
kanuka (possessive 1st person singular) for my sake; on my behalf; on my part. kanuka: on behalf of; because of; for. kanuka, alemunit eong emong ediope: on my part, I donate one bull. kanukon: for your sake. kanukon bon: of your own accord; without being asked. kanuke: on his behalf. kanukosi: on our behalf (excluding you). kanuwok: on our behalf (including you). kanukus: on your behalf (excluding me). kanukec: on their behalf. 
kanuka nu (adverb) ad hoc; for this reason. 
kanukangun (adverb) therefore; for that reason; consequently; as a result; so; hence. kanukangun, mam ipedori alosit: therefore, you cannot go. 
kanukinyo? (interrogation) why? 
-kape (numeral noun suffix) six (adverb) together with. 
kara kar (adverb) very, completely (dry, arid, desicated, or empty). aono akeit kara kar: the frying pan is completely empty.
karaba karab (adverb) (sound) like animals galloping; like soldiers goose-matching. 
karai (conjunction) if; when; in case. kibwokuna inyamat karai ilosi ocaalo: bring some foodstuff if you are going to the village.
karai bo (conjunction) if perhaps; or perhaps. komanyai, karai bo kimina: marry me, if perhaps you love me. cp. arai bo.
karaida (conjunction) even though; even if; although. karaida kigir ijo, eong alosit kwapekwangin: even though you refuse, I’ll go all the same. karaida…karaida: either…or. cp. arai da
Karamoja (noun neuter) the land of the Karimojong people - the present day districts of Moroto, Kotido and Nakapiripirit in the north-eastern corner of Uganda.
karibu (interjection) welcome in; come in. karibu ore!: welcome home! (a reply to kodi!)
karoba (adverb) long ago (noun neuter) old times. kolo karoba: kolo kasonya: long ago. ikoto ijo ainyakunit karoba: you want to bring back old times, i.e. you are backward. cp. kasonya
kasoorian (adverb) unhappily; gloomily; sulkily. abu ngesi kasesen eong kasoorian: she/he looked at me gloomily. 
katekisim (noun neuter) catechism. 
katipet (adverb) at once; immediately; very fast 
Katoda (noun neuter) (in the Roman Catholic church) God. 
katulik1 (adverb) of, about, or belonging to the Roman Catholic church. 
Katulik2 (singular noun M) the Roman Catholic Christian faith, with the Pope as its head. 
katupeta (adverb) respectively; in that order; correspondingly. apotu itunga iwongon kodumutu abootin 89, 46, 40 kede 15 katupeta: the four people got 89, 46, 40, and 15 votes respectively.
katuputupeta (adverb) respectively; in that order; correspondingly. 
kau (adverb) at, to the back; behind. ai bo jo kau?: by the way, where do you come from (village)?
kawai (adverb) at the farthest side of; at the extreme end. kobwo kawai: stand on the far side, over there; stand aside. cp. kawasia.
kawasia (adverb) at the farthest side of; at the extreme end. kobwo kawasia: stand on the far side, over there. cp. kawai. 
-ke- (suffix or infix of possessive pronoun 3rd person singular) his; hers; its. aberuke: akeberu: his wife. okilenike: her husband. ikoku ka totoke: the child and its mother. 
ke- (pronominal prefix of verbs in 2nd person singular) if she/he/it; when she/he/it. kemataa ngesi ejuge, erai teni ededengu aibunga angor ke: when he takes alcohol, he really becomes violent in beating up his wives. kebuu ngesi, kolimok kobu oreka: if she/he comes, tell her/him to come to my home.
kebil (conjunction) if; had …not; unless (with past tense or infinitive); perhaps; maybe. kebil ijo abunere: if you had not come. kebil alot nan ore: perhaps she/he has gone home. kebil ijo abunore, ti eong kalot bon: had you not come, I would have gone alone. cp. kedim.
-kec- suffix or infix possessive personal pronoun 3rd person plural: their; theirs. ikokukec: their child. lokec: lukec (theirs singular: plural M); nakec: nukec (theirs singular: plural F); yenikec: lukec (theirs singular: plural Dimin.). erai ngesi lokec: it/he is theirs. 
keceipone (adverb) otherwise; by other means. 
kecerot (adverb) by other means; by a different road. 
kede (conjunction) and; also; with; by; as well as; in addition to; along with. kede bobo: further more. eong kede ka jo: you and I. kede ka (preposition): with. 
kediany (adverb) on the left; to the left. akan nakokediany (adverb): on the left. 
kedim (adverb) had it not; if not (usually followed by verb in infinitive); but for; if you had not (followed by subject). (preposition) except; excepting; but not. kedim ijo abunere, ti kalot eong apejo: if you had not come, I should have gone on a visit. kedim papaka adolun, ti eong kalot: if my father had not come, I would have gone. cp. kemam.
keeya (adverb) of the army; belonging to the armed forces; in, to, for the military; of the Defence ministry. atuboros amotokan nuka keeya ibwokito ikeeyarin: army vehicles carrying soldiers have passed. cp. polis
kekekek (adverb) very hard; too heavy. eriata kwi apungure kekekek ba: they pulled at a log with all their strength, but to no avail. 
kemere (interjection) good luck!; good fortune! kemere, ado akan!: Sweet fortune, I have chanced it! 
kepuwai (adverb) partly; on the contrary; on one side; on the other hand. 
kere (adverb) all; really; entirely; altogether. ai kere?: where on earth? where at all? itunga kere: all the people; everyone. ai kere ilosi?: where on earth are you going? inyo kere?: what on earth? inyo kere inera jo?: what on earth are you saying? abu kere papa: watch out, daddy has come. kokeri kere, aker onacekon: run, mind your brother is running. ikoto kere ijo apega nu ijeni?: you want really to deny what you do know? akwap kere kere: everywhere. 
kes (plural of nes or nges) personal pronoun 3rd person plural used as object: them.
kesi (personal pronoun) they; them. (note: kesi is subject, kes is object) cp. kes.
-ki- infix to all ordinal numbers above one. lokiareet: the second. lokiuniet: the third. 
ki- verbal prefix denoting: 1) first person plural in all tenses. kipou kabwoutu ber ko Getom agwela ibilenga: we stopped awhile in Getom to buy mudfish. 2) second person past tense in ki-verbs. kibungai ca bian je ebutuunitos akonye: it looks like the other one with swollen eyes was beaten yesterday. 3) imperative prefix of all verbs (infinitives and causatives). kiswama!: work! Do! 4) third person past tense. kinyamit iso: we have eaten. 5) second and 3rd person subjunctive. 6) a negative imperative of all ki-verbs. kinyekik kwangin!: stop it!; leave it there! 7) imperatives of all causative verbs. kitanyam idwe: feed the children!
kia (adverb) (of colour or lustre) shiny; very white. ejesi kia: it is very bright. ejesete kia: they are very white. cp. ataus kia; eta kia; etaasi kia. 
kibwar kibwar (adverb) sound imitation of a four-legged animal running quickly and heavily (adjective) apace; swiftly; briskly; rapidly. 
kice da (adverb) et cetera; and others. 
kidari (interjection) goodbye; bye-bye; adieu; farewell; may God keep you. (abbreviation for) kidari Lokasuban: may God bless you.
kide (noun neuter) the east. (adverb) eastern; easterly. acila kide: dawn has broken; it is dawn. kokide: in/from the east. agiru edou kokide: the rain has thundered in the east. 
kidenyite (plural kidenyito) (adverb) (a saying meaning) on purpose, determinately, be prepared. kidenyite ibuni: be prepared when you come. iswamat ijo ngun kidenyite: you did that on purpose. 
kidim (adverb) had (she/he/it) not; unless. cp. kedim.
kiding (preposition) in the middle of; in the midst of; in the centre of; between; amidst; among; amongst; amid. kidding kus: amongst you. kokiding: in the middle; from the middle; from among. kiding ocor: to the middle of the lake. kiding paran: midday. kiding kuare: midnight. ebokorit lokokiding: middle finger. kiding ebai (adverb) at (mid) dawn, about 4:00 am. 
kijokis (indefinite pronoun) (Ateso Atororo) all. cp. kere. 
kikir kikir (adverb) sound of animals galloping very fast. atakarikisi imongin akerit kikir kikir: the bulls have galloped away very fast. 
kilar (adverb) (of a bald-headed person falling) thump; crack; bump. ado etelepat osimit kilar: the boy has fallen heavily on the cement (the head touching the ground). 
kilar kilar (adverb) (of a person, to go about) bald-headedly. elosi ngesi kilar kilar: she/he is walking bald-headedly. 
kilong (adverb) (of sound of a bell) clang; clank. 
kimwa ai? (interrogation) how many are we? 
-kin1 a verbal or noun suffix to denote a repeated action or the acquisition of a characteristic. aiareikin: to do again. kiareik: do it again. kiuniik: do it a third time. aikingokikin (from ekingok: a dog) to become very poor; to behave like a dog; to become a vagabond, homeless. 
-kin2 verbal suffix forming dative or prepositional form of verb. kiswamanakini kesi ejok: we do good to them. kolot aiswamakin nges ngina: go and work for him over there. 
kinga (adverb) outside; in the bush; exterior; abroad or overseas; afield. ejaas ityang kinga: animals are outside (in the bush). kinga ketogo: outside the house. kinga kakan: the back of the hand. nukokinga (plural noun F) distractions; things outside. alosit kinga: to go to the toilet; to go overseas or abroad. aiboi kokinga: to live abroad; to stay outside (the house). cp. moding.
kingaren (noun neuter) ahead (adverb) before; in front. kingarenika: in front of me; ahead of me. kolot kingarenika: go in front of me. apak nakoingaren: in the future. cp. apak naka akonye. 
kiokiot (adverb) (to finish food from the pot) altogether; completely; entirely (imitates the scraping sound of a ladle against the bottom of an empty vessel). akitunos inyamat kiokiot: the food is totally finished. cp. adaun cut
kire (adverb) (in Karamoja) truly; really; actually; in fact; truthfully. kire, ejulak eong akaomisio: actually, I have changed my mind. agir kire: she/he has truly denied or refused it. kire irai ijo Etesot?: truly, you are an Etesot? cp. abeit.
kito (adverb) (if) at all. mam kito oni kicela da: we were not shouting or quarrelling at all. ngai kito kicelatatar kane?: with whom at all were you quarrelling here? arai kito: if at all. kiputo kito: we are the same. kiputo kito, inyo nat ejai ijo?: we are the same, what have you got more than I? arai kito kimina ijo eong, koinakinai akiteng: if at all you like me, give me a cow. 
kiton (adverb) up to; till; as far as. kiton Ngariam: up to Ngariam sub-county in Katakwi. alosi apejo kiton Anyara: I am going for a visit up to or as far as (not further than) Anyara in Kalaki county – Kaberamaido district. 
kitoni (adverb) as far as; until; straight on to. kitoni do kesi alosit: until they went. kitoni Nairobi: right on to Nairobi. kitoni bobo: then again. 
kiya (adverb) the whole night through; all night long (pronounced as one syllable). aram bian Okolimo adeudeu kiya: Okolimo played the harp all night long. aikweny kiya: to be awake all night. cp. kia kia
kiya kiya (adverb) the whole night through; all night long. eremas bian ingokwo akware kiya kiya: the dogs barked the whole night. aikweny kiya kiya: to be awake all night; to be sleepless or insomniac. cp. kia
ko-1 prefix of prepositional masculine nouns beginning with consonants or proper nouns beginning with vowels e, i, o, u, implying ‘inside’ or ‘from’ kotogo: from the house. ebunit ngesi kotogo: she/he comes from the house. iswamai ngesi koipois: she/he is working inside the kitchen. abonguni ngesi ko Bulaya: she/he just returned from Europe. abuni eong ko Usuk: I came from Usuk.
ko-2 verbal pronominal prefix used: a) for imperative of ko-verbs: koduk: build (plural kodukoto). b) third person past tense of ko-verbs: abu ngesi koduk: she/he built. c) second and 3rd person subjunctive singular and plural: akoto ngesi koduk: let her/him build. 
kocoite (imperative) be careful; take precaution, be circumspect (adverb) carefully, purposely. kolosi kocoite: go carefully. kodakite nges kocoite: carry it/him/her carefully, purposefully, intentionally. ibu ijo kolim ngun kocoite: you said that carefully. 
kodi (interjection) may I come in? (the reply is, karibu: please do come in).
kodoco (adverb) truly; properly; as it should be. ibusakinit ijo aitodiar ijenuneta kon kodoco: it is desirable that you display your identifications properly.
kojokan (adverb) well; rightly; properly. 
kokau (adverb) (of time) later; after; afterwards; at the back; behind. ebuni ngesi kokau: she/he is coming behind, after somebody else. abu ngesi kokau: she/he came late. kokau ka: at my back; behind me. iboie ngesi kokau ka: she/he is sitting behind me or stays in my boys-quarters. iboienene ngesi kokau ka: she/he sits always behind me. cp. kau.
kokiding (adverb) in, at, from the middle; in the amidst. 
kokinga (adverb) from outside. 
kokokok (adverb) (to finish) completely; altogether; entirely. amataas kesi ajon aikokoor kokokok: they drank and finished the beer completely. 
kokoliro koo (singular noun neuter) the sound of a rooster; cock-a-doodle-doo. 
kokuju (adverb) from heaven; from above. ebunit kokuju: she/he comes from heaven, or from above. inera kokuju: she/he speaks from up there. 
koleje (adverb) in the recent past; not long ago. 
kolo (adverb) formerly; long ago; of old; in the past. kolo sek: long ago. kolongoe: lately. koleje: lately; in the recent past; previously. kolo karoba: kolo karionga: kolo kasonya: ngo kasonya: in the days of our forefathers or ancestors; once upon a time. kolo apengo: long ago.
komam (preposition) without. sirikilot komam eong: do not go without me. sirikilot komam inyamit: do not go without eating first. 
-kon (plural –kok) suffix of certain nouns that have eka- prefix: ekadukon: a builder. ekaliokon: a liar. ekarokon: one who copies.
-kon- suffix or infix of possessive pronouns in 2nd person singular. aberukon arai akoniberu: your wife. 
kongin (adverb) a corruption of kwangin: in vain; like that. atyakatyak etengei ateker, abongu eong kongin kore kamamai: famine has divided the clan, I have come in vain from uncle’s home (without any food). cp. kwangin
konye (conjunction) but; however. konye bo: but then. kosodi konye: kosodi konyete: after that; and then. koyanga ebalua lo, kosodi konye alosit ore: take this letter, and then go home. 
kopirimasio (singular noun neuter) confirmation ceremony in the Roman Catholic church. 
koponesio (adverb) by manner; by character; by category. ekodikod loirotin koponesio: road network by category, i.e. perennial and seasonal roads.
kopuwai (adverb) aside; apart; away.
koroc koroc (adverb) very (hard and bare). eonit akwap koroc koroc: the ground is very hard and bare. 
korododo (adverb) noise of continuous diarrhoea. ebala amojong ebie korododo: korododo, thus farted an old woman. cp. porododo
korot (adverb) on, from the road; on the way. 
-kosi first person plural possessive pronoun infix or suffix, exclusive of person spoken to: our. erekosi: ekosire: our home (excluding you). cp. –wok; -kus.
kosodi1 (adverb) (singular) and then. kosodete (plural) and then (used in the narrative form). cp. kopaari, kopaarete (plural); kopenyakini, kopenyakinete (plural). kosodi ngesi (plural kosodete kesi) abongor: and then they returned. kosodi konye: and then she/he/ it…; also; in addition. kosodete konye(te) (plural): and then they. cp. aige.
kosodi2 (plural kosodete) (conjunction) and then (expression for narrative forms followed by infinitive verb). apotu kesi koloto ore, kosodete kesi ainyam, kosodete alosit apero: they went home, and then they ate, and then they went to bed. cp. aisod, aige. 
kotenan (adverb) (to do, to speak) straight, correctly, justly, accurately, or well. kiswama erot lo kotenan: make this road straight. kotub akiro nu kotenan: settle this case justly. kikam nges kotenan: hold it well or hold her/him fast. kiner kotenan: speak accurately. cp. kojokan, aiten.
koteten (adverb) on, to the right (hand). akan nakoteten (noun F): the right hand (adverb) to the right (side). kolot akan nakoteten: go to the right. lokoteten M, nakoteten F, yenikoteten neuter: the one to the right. koteten (adverb) right. akan nakoteten: the right hand. 
kotogo (adverb) from, at, in the house. kolem edia kotogo: get vegetables from the house. 
kotoma (adverb) inside; within; amongst; from within. ejai loecudi kotoma kus: one amongst you is a witch. kwap toma: underneath. 
Kristo (plural luka Kristo) (noun M) Christ. luka Kristo (plural noun M) Christians. 
kuju (preposition) above; on top of; upstairs; in heaven. einer kuju: to speak aloud. kokuju kangun: (conjunction) in addition to that; above all; more than anything else. kuju kangin (conjunction) on top of that (one). ejai kuju: (it) she/he is above. elosi kuju: she/he (or it) goes to heaven or up. ejai eikopo kuju omeesa: the mug is on the table. kikea eporoto kuju: lift up your voice: speak loudly. ejai aberu kuju olap (euphemism): the woman is having menstruation (literally, the woman is up on the moon). cp. aibam, aikuje, ekuje. 
kukur (adverb) (low sound of a log or big stone being rolled once) bumpety-bump. ekokorior amoru kukur: the stone has been rolled down pumpety-bump. 
kukuru kukur (adverb) (low sound as of a log or big stone being rolled many times) bumpety-bump. ikokorit ekingok ekisu kukuru kukur: the dog is rolling a mortar pumpety-bump (perhaps after licking it). 
kulu kulu (noun neuter) (of a turkey, to) chuckle; the sound of a male turkey; (to a child) a turkey. cp. miao: the sound of a cat. kutu kut: the sound of a breeding hen.
kulut (noun neuter) a game of seek-and-hide (for boys and girls).
kurub (adverb) (sound of boots against hard surface or teeth grinding hard) crunch. icakete ikeeyarin eperet kurub kurub: the soldiers take their salute or parade with resounding steps.
kuruc (adverb) crunching sound. 
-kus- possessive pronoun, 2nd person plural suffix or infix. etogokus: ekusitogo: your house. 
kut kut kut (adverb) (sound of a person calling chicken) cluck, tut, chuckle. kut kut kut, asosi inyamat lu: cluck cluck cluck, here is mash. 
kwa (demonstrative pronoun plural feminine) those far off; those far away. cp. ya: that one far off. nu: (feminine plural) these. ngun (feminine plural) those. angor kwa: those (far off) women. cp. kwi (masculine plural) those far off. 
kwa ka (adverb) like this; similar to; as. kwa ka ya: like that feminine one (far off). kwa ka lo: like this one (masculine). kwapekwangin: like that. kwapekwana: just now. kwabo kwa: (of cows or women or feminine objects) there they are. 
kware (adverb) at, in the night; during the night. cp. kuare
kuare (adverb) at, in the night; during the night. cp. kware
kwabo (conjunction) whereas (with negative); whilst; moreover. abala lem eong ebe eco Oguti, kwabo mam: I always thought Oguti was clever, whereas he is not. kwabo nan: kwabo sek: whereas before. 
kwana1 (adverb) (in demonstrating how something works) like this; in this way. kwanata: like this; thus.
kwana2 (adverb) now; nowadays; these days; at the moment; at present; in the present day.
kwanata (adverb) (in demonstrating how something works) like this; in this way; thus; as you will now read or hear; as follows.
kwangal (adverb) (imitative sound of a big metallic object falling on hard surface or a thin tall person falling awkwardly) clang; clank. 
kwangin (demonstrative pronoun) like that; thus; just so (adverb) gratis; for nothing. kinyek kwangin: leave it just so, like that. kwapekwangin: like that. ape kwangin: (that is enough for you,) you can go now. aberu naka kwangin: an unmarried woman. alosit kwangin: to go naked; to go without. ainakin kwangin: to give for nothing. 
kwap (adverb) down; below; underneath; beneath (followed by ka); on the ground or floor. ejai ngesi kwap ka emeesa: it is under or beneath the table. kokwap: on the ground; down there. mam ajeni nuiswamas kokwap kangina: I do not know what goes on down there. 
kwape (conjunction) how (followed by prepositional verb); like; as (in the job of). mam ajeni kwape iswamaere: I do not know how it is done. kiswama kwape ekotor ngesi: do as she/he wishes. mam ajeni kwape elosio: I do not know her/his travel plans (itinerary). kwape lem sek: as usual.
kwape ka (adverb) like; as. kwape kanu: like these ones. 
kwapekwa (demonstrative pronoun, feminine plural) those female things over there. cp. kwipekwi
kwapekwana (adverb) just now; at once; at this moment. kiwadik ebalua kwapekwana: write a letter just now.
kwapekwangin (adverb) like that; thus; just so. komat ijo da ajon kwapekwangin: you also take the beer as it is (without complaining).
kwapuke (adverb) underneath it; beneath it; below it. (plural kwapukec: underneath them; below them). yenikokwap: lokokwap: something below; somebody lower. kirai oni lukokwap kotoma aijen: our knowledge is of a low standard. elope (plural ikulepek) akwap: an inhabitant; a native. 
kwatekwangin (adverb) so much; that big; that much; that tall, etc. elwana kwatekwangin: is it that far? when it is that far! cp. kwapekwangin.
kwe kwe (interjection) (I told you) again and again; (did I not tell you) now and again? kinyek akiro ngun kwe kwe: (I told you in vain to) stop those things. 
kweret (adverb) (Ateso Atororo) nil; null; zero; nothing. 
kwi (demonstrative pronoun 3rd person plural masculine or diminutive) those yonder or over there; those far away. konyarau itelepai kwi kopotu: call those boys over there to come. cp. kwa (feminine) 
kwic (adverb) (to fill with a liquid, to block) completely, to the brim. elelebun amot kwic: the pot is very full; the pot is full to the brim. cp. kwici kwic.
kwici kwic (adverb) (to fill with a liquid, to block) completely, to the brim. elelebunos akipi opipa kwici kwic: the drum is completely full of water. cp. kwic, lud.
kwii kwi (adverb) (of a cough, breathing) noisy, wheezing. edeka ngol epaganga, ebala eola kwii kwi: that man has pulmonary tuberculosis, his cough wheezes. 
Kwinkwagesima (singular noun neuter) Quinquagesima (the Sunday before Lent).
kwipekwi (demonstrative pronoun, masculine plural) those males over there. Iloke kwipekwi emeetos akituk: the Karimojong rustlers are just over there driving rustled cattle. cp. kwapekwa
kyo kyot (adverb) to finish completely; absolutely finished (used with adaun: to finish; airikar, anyamaar or amataar) 
-L-
l (noun M) the tenth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
laa (adverb) extremely sweet; very delicious, nice. ejijim laa - very sweet
ladalad (adverb) (of movement of an invalid or a snake) wriggling; winding; snaky; twisting
laije (adverb) over there; that way. cp. lailo
lailo laije (adverb) here and there; this way, that way. cp. lailo
lailo (adverb) here; this way; hither. cp. juwai. 
lali? (interrogative pronoun) where? 
Lango (noun neuter) the land of the Langi people; the present districts of Lira and Apac of northern Uganda.
latak (adverb) (the way a long soft thing or person falls) softly; soundlessly. abu emusaga kocakun kwap latak: the cobra fell down softly. cp. dalac. 
lejelej (adverb) (of cooked food) very soft; (of walking) very weakly; sluggish; without energy. akono akiring lejelej: the meat is thoroughly cooked. anapet naimanyimanyitai ejok ebala lejelej, mam iketerer: a well tanned hide used for carrying babies on the back is soft, it is not stiff.
arai lem (adverb) I wish she/he/it could; if only…(In wishes after arai, means only ‘would that’: arai lem kotep da: if only it rained: I wish it could rain) would; I wish that; I may that. lem eong kadum egaali da, ti ejok: I wish I could get a bicycle, it could be better. (note: lem is followed by subjunctive ‘kadum’) 
lem (adverb) usually; hitherto; in the past. mam eroko ebuni, abunenenei lem sek: she/he does not come anymore, she/he used to come some time ago. mam lem enyamenenei, konye kwana enyami: she/he used not to eat, but now she/he eats. 
lengileng (adverb) one only; one by itself; cut off; all alone; marooned. atwaka ikatunga kere, do eong bon ajai lengileng: all my people have died, I am left alone by myself. 
ler (adverb) (of a pebble, to fall down or drop) once; singly. cp. lereler
lere ler (adverb) (of noise of continual dropping as of fruit or droppings of a goat or other little solids, maggots, hailstones) repeatedly; continually. ebala akako lere ler edoenene kwap: one hears the rattling noise of hailstones falling. cp. baa ba
lia lia (adverb) (of a source of light or a reflecting thing, to shine) very bright; irridiscently; glittering. enokiete akimian kotaun lia lia: street lights shine bright in town.
lis (adverb) (of a spear or any pointed instrument piercing) through; from side to side; completely. aicum lis: to spear through. abu eong kecum etyang lis: I speared the animal through. 
litania (noun neuter) litany (a series of prayers or supplications with a response which is repeated several times by the congregation). 
lo1 (plural lu) (demonstrative masculine pronoun singular) this. lopelo (M): napena (F): this one. lokolo (M): nakolo (F): the one of old; the former one. lokolo kasonya (M): nakolo kasonya (F): the one of long ago. loti lo (M): nati na (F): this big one. 
lo2 (plural lu) (relative pronoun masculine) who; which. cp. loe, loke. lo + noun: like. ekeri lotyang: she/he runs like an animal. lo + adjective: stands for definite article. akoto loepol: I want the big one. 
lo- (plural lu-) prefix of derivative masculine nouns, implying ‘he who’; ‘that which’. cp. na-, loki-. loameton: he who drives animals. loangiirit: he who has gums. loatyonon: the difficult one. 
loameton (plural luametok) (noun M) a (cattle, livestock) driver. 
loangiirit (plural luangiirito) (noun M) a toothless man.
loatyonon (plural luatyokok) (noun M) a difficult one; an awkward customer; the unbecoming one. 
lobonot (plural lubonot) (noun M) a humble boy (man). 
loce (indefinite masculine pronoun) so and so. cp. luce (plural M), nace (singular F), nuce (plural F), yenice (singular Dimin.). 
loce ka (plural luce ka) (pronoun M) my companion; my comrade; my friend. cp. opaupaka. 
loduc (plural luduc) (adjective) (used with masculine nouns) usual; ordinary; common. etunganan loduc: an ordinary man. ekingok loduc: a common village dog (that roams about).
loebelel (plural luebelel) (noun M) a person struck on the head with a stick. 
loebur (plural lueburok) (noun M) a stout man; a plump, fat person or thing. 
loedakana (plural luedakaka) (noun M) a glutton. 
loekokolana (plural luekokolaka) (adjective) thievish; kleptomaniac. 
loekupup (plural luekupup) (noun M) a strong, able-bodied man. etelepat loekupup: an able-bodied boy. 
loemariana (plural luemariaka) (noun M) a grabber. 
loemenana (plural luemenaka) (noun M) a rebel; an insurgent; a mutineer; a radical; a revolutionary; a dissenter; a man who constantly disobeys. 
loemerana (plural luemeraka) (noun M) a drunkard; a sot. 
loemorono (plural luemoroko) (noun M) one who is fond of scolding, insulting, or offending others. 
loemudukana (plural luemudukaka) (noun M) a blind one (man or animal). cp. emuduk 
loemunoono (plural luemunooko) (noun M) an optimist; one fond of hoping for. 
loengangatono (plural luengangatoko) (noun M) one who is inclined to dally or waste time. 
loengolopana (plural luengolopaka) (noun M) a man fond of quarrelling; a quarrelsome man. 
loeranga (plural lueranga) (noun M) a gormandiser; a foodie; a glutton. cp. lokeranga.
loerurwon (plural luerurwok) (noun M) a raider; a rustler of livestock or other property; a robber. 
loesenyit (plural luesenyitos) (noun M) a thin or emaciated man 
loesulyanyana (plural luesulyanyaka) (noun M) the blessed or lucky one. 
loetirono (plural luetiroko) (noun M) a sprinter; a racer; a pacesetter. 
loetukuan (plural luketukuak) (noun M) one who makes another escape; a redeemer; a rescuer; a saviour. 
loetute (plural luetute) (noun M) one who is frivolous, restless, light-hearted, or thoughtless. 
loeworotoi (plural lueworotoi) (noun M) (the invited) guest; the one who was invited or called. 
loewosikitai (plural luewosikitai) (noun M) the one left over; a free man. 
loeyaara bon (plural lueyaara bonik) (noun M) an independent person. 
loeyari (plural lueyarete) (adjective) deadly, mortal, lethal. aarenen: to kill continually; to kill often. 
logeet (plural lugeet) (noun M) the first born; the one to begin with. kotoma akoik katotokos, Agwang Amoding nges akiyai, Apuda nges engoorit: Agwang Amoding is our mother’s eldest child, Apuda is the last-born. cp. ekiyai.
logela (plural lugela) (noun M) a stranger; a different person or thing; an alien. cp. egela
logereset (plural lugereset) (noun M) (for) embrocation: medicine rubbed on skin to reduce pain and blood clot. 
loibatisatai (plural luibatisatai) (noun M) a baptised person. cp. ekapiirit: a heathen, pagan, animist.
loicuma (plural luicuma) (noun M) a man to be impaled (speared), pricked, stabbed, or injected. 
loicumum (plural luicumum) (noun M) a man who is impaled (speared), pricked, stabbed, or inoculated. 
loideuna (plural luideuna) (noun M) a leftover; the remnant. cp. naideuna.
loiilonor (plural luiilonoros) (noun M) a palsied man; a paralytic; one who keeps collapsing. cp. adeka naka aiteregegiar. 
loijoseono (plural luijoseoko) (noun M) one who always pretends; a pretender; an impostor; a fraud; one who shams or is fond of shamming. ijoseono ekesa ngol adeka duc: that fellow always shams illness or pretends to be ill. 
loijunet (plural luijunetas) (adjective) (of a person, animals and plants) the barren; the degenerate; the sterile; to have very flat bums or buttocks. ikamomwa luijunetetas: my sorghum that is degenerate (no seeds, dried up, not pollinated). aberu ngin erai naijunet: that woman is barren. 
loikeara (plural luikeara) (noun M) the arrogant, the conceited, the haughty, egotistical, proud; stuck up. 
loimono (plural luimokos) (noun M) one who is satisfied. 
loimuuna (plural luimuuna) (noun M) one of the twins. 
loipinyana (plural luipinyaka) (noun M) a man who is fond of overeating or gorging. 
loipoikino (plural luipoikino) (noun M) a married man (who they cook for). 
loiraruna (plural luiraruna) (noun M) a thing found or picked up; a foundling. 
loiryorono (plural luiryoroko) (noun M) a garrulous man; one who talks much or chatters. 
loisinyeono (plural luisinyeoko) (noun M) a man who has the habit of being selfish, stingy, greedy, sensual, eager, or passionate. 
loisiorotot (plural luisiorototas) (noun M) the straight one; the tall and slim one (person or tree). 
loiteregeg (plural luiteregegas) (noun M) one with meningitis; a paralytic; a paraplegic. 
loitet (plural luitetiak) (noun M) the new one; the fresh one; the young one. koyau eikopo loitet: bring a new (clean) cup. papa loitetet: a new father of an asapan initiate. 
loiwangana (plural luiwangaka) (noun M) a greedy man who eats food hot or half-cooked. 
loiwosatai (plural luiwosatai) (noun M) a defendant; the accused. 
loka M (preposition) of (plural luka); naka F (plural nuka); yenika Dimin. (plural luka). (possessive pronoun) loka, luka M: mine; naka, nuka F: mine; yenika, luka Dimin.: mine; lokon, lukon: yours (2nd person pronoun). Lokon obe: Yours sincerely; Yours truly. loke, luke M: his. lokosi, lukosi M: ours. lowok, luwok M: ours. lokus, lukus M: yours. lokec, lukec M: theirs. loka, loke M: with (adjective prefix for definite masculine article). loejok, lokajokan M: the good one. 
lokaanyiton (plural lukaanyitok) (noun M) superintendent; inspector. 
lokaaran (plural lukaarak) (noun M) a murderer; a killer. 
lokabeit (plural lukabeit) (noun M) the true one; one that is not fake or counterfeit. 
lokacekwap (plural lukacekwap) (noun M) a stranger; an alien; a foreigner; outsider. 
lokacelan (plural lukacelak) (noun M) a shouter; a quarrelsome, irritable person. cp. ekacelan 
lokacoa (plural lukacoa) (noun M) a wise man; the maggi; a wise person, a clever person. cp. epiirioit.
lokacoan (plural lukacoak) (noun M) a wise man; a wise person, a clever person. cp. ekacoan.
lokadakan (plural lukadakak) (noun M) a carrier; a porter; a carer (of children only). cp. ekadakan.
lokadedengan (plural lukadedengak) (noun M) a severe, savage or cruel man or animal. 
lokadekan (plural lukadekak) (noun M) a patient; a sick or ill person, etc cp. ekadekan.
lokadukon (plural lukadukok) (noun M) mason; builder; architect. 
lokadwaran (plural lukadwarak) (noun M) a prophet; a soothsayer; a rainmaker; augur; clairvoyant. 
lokaelon (plural lukaelok) (noun M) a fornicator; an adulterer. aelo ijukanari lokaelon alosit aanyun akepese: a sudden sexual impulse prompts the lover to visit his girlfriend. cp. ekaelon 
lokageret (plural lukageret) (noun M) embrocation (medicine rubbed on skin to reduce pain and blood clot). 
lokagion (plural lukagiok) (noun M) (in the Roman Catholic church) a saint; a holy person; a perfect person; a paragon. cp. nakagion
lokagwean (plural lukagweak) (noun M) a potter; a moulder; one who folds round. 
lokagwelanaran (plural lukagwelanarak) (noun M) merchant; seller; vendor; trader; dealer; broker; traitor; betrayer. 
lokajengan (plural lukajengak) (noun M) a butcher; a surgeon; a slaughterer; an operator. aijeng akoik: to have caesarean section; to have an abdominal operation. 
lokajokan (plural lukajokak) (noun M) the good one, etc 
lokajonon (plural lukajonok) (noun M) the unripe; the immature; the raw; the uncooked, etc. akiring na erai nakajonon, do bo akiring ya erai na ajono: this meat is raw but that meat is cooled (after cooking). 
lokalaunan (plural lukalaunak) (noun M) the clean man; the holy man; a saint. cp. nakalaunan (noun F)  (plural nukalaunak). 
lokalean (plural lukaleak) (noun M) one who beats; one who thrashes. cp. ekalean
lokalelan (plural lukalelak) (noun M) a happy-go-lucky fellow. cp. ekalelan
lokaliagaman (plural lukaliagamak) (noun M) the tall, high one. 
lokaloton (plural lukalotok) (noun M) a pedestrian; a traveller, explorer, voyager, trekker, tourist; a passenger, or a commuter.
lokamaranan (plural lukamaranak) (noun M) a nervous person. 
lokamatan (plural lukamatak) (noun M) a drinker; the imbiber. 
lokamwanan (plural lukamwakak) (noun M) a hot person or thing; a greedy man. cp. otaupe
lokapesen (plural lukapesenin) (noun M) a debtor; a defaulter. 
lokapolon (plural lukapolok) (noun M) the big one; an adult; the important one; the master; the boss; the elder; the chief. 
lokapucon (plural lukapucok) (noun M) a peace-maker; a reconciler; a host; an arbiter. 
lokaraan (plural lukaraak) (noun M) (one) always bearing fruit; one who or which is prolific.
lokasaban (plural lukasabak)(noun M) a liar; a fraud; a charlatan; a traditional healer with dubious methods. 
lokasalan (plural lukasalak) (noun M) abider; absentee truant; one who stays behind; one left behind; a remnant. lukasalak: remnants. 
lokasenyan (plural lukasenyak) (noun M) a man or boy who is becoming thin; one whose body is wasting away; an AIDS sufferer or patient. 
lokasuat (plural lukaswa) (noun M) of iron; of steel; metallic. asaduku nakasuat: a metallic casket; a safe; a coffer; a strongbox. ibore yenikasuat: a thing made of iron, steel, or metal. 
lokasuban (plural lukasubak) (noun M) the creator; the maker; the manufacturer. Edeke Lokasuban: God the Creator.
lokasurup (plural lukasurup) (noun M) an enemy; a foe; an adversary; an antagonist; an opponent; a disputant. ejai ngesi asurup ka je: there is a feud between her/him and the other man. akerit asurup: to escape vengeance (run away from enemies). 
lokatapon (plural lukatapon) (noun M) a leper; a man who has leprosy. 
lokateranet (plural lukateranet) (adjective) of honeymoon; nuptial; conjugal; marital. 
lokatitingon (plural lukatitingok) (noun M) a brave man; a courageous man; a hero; a daredevil. cp. lokatitinyon
lokatitinyon (plural lukatitinyok) (noun M) a brave man; a courageous man; a hero; a daredevil. 
lokatubon (plural lukatubok) (noun M) a judge; an arbiter; a cutter; a referee; an umpire; a magistrate; a butcher. lokatubon akiro: an arbiter; an umpire. lokatubon imusaagon: a magistrate; a judge.
lokatwan (plural lukatwak) (noun M) the dead one. lukatwak: the dead.
lokawoon (plural lukawook) (noun M) the singer; a vocalist; a bard. 
loke (plural lukec) (personal pronoun masculine used subjectively) his, hers, its. erai ngesi loke: it/he is hers/his (property). (plural lokosi, luwok, lokus, lokec) 
lokebeele (plural lukebeele) (noun M) spreader of rumours; rumour-monger; mischief-maker; one who causes strikes or blows. 
lokebit (plural lukebit) (noun M) the greedy one, an avaricious man; an egoistic man. 
lokecanicanan (plural lukecanicanak) (noun M) a sinner; a transgressor; a destroyer. 
lokeciran (plural lukecirak) (noun M) the milker; a milkman. cp. ekeciran.
lokecokon (plural lukecokok) (noun M) a herdsman: lokecokon akituk; a sheperd: lokecokon amerekekin. 
lokeibel (plural lukeibel) (noun M) the greedy one, etc. 
lokekaan (plural lukekaak) (noun M) a game hunter, a seeker; a persecutor, a tormentor, a bully, an oppressor, or an intimidator. 
lokekolo (plural lukekolo) (noun M) an adversary; an opponent; a rival. 
lokelocon (plural lukelocok) (noun M) an interpreter; an exchanger. lokelocon apeesan: money changer. 
lokemunet (plural lukemunet) (noun M) a cheeky, foolish, or troublesome man. 
lokenyangan (plural lukenyangak) (noun M) an avenger; a man who is spiteful; a retaliator; a nemesis. 
lokepitina (plural lukepitina) (noun M) an envious or jealous one. 
lokepoon (plural lukepook) (noun M) a cook; a chef. cp. ekepoon. 
lokepugan (plural lukepugak) (noun M) a ruler; a governor; a head of state; a monarch; a sovereign. 
lokepyedan (plural lukepyedak) (noun M) a harbinger (of bad omen); a witch. 
lokeranga (plural lukeranga) (noun M) a gourmand; food-lover; glutton. cp. loeranga
lokesaasa (plural lukesaasa) (noun M) (formerly) county chief. cp. lokebuku: county chief. 
lokesiecan (plural lukesiecan) (noun M) one who exchanges; a money-changer. 
lokesigalikinan (plural lukesigalikinak) (noun M) an assistant; a helper; an aide. 
lokesosoloi (plural lukesosoloi) (noun M) a hypocrite. 
loketatamanakinan (plural luketatamanakinak) (noun M) a story-teller; a narrator; a novelist; a minstrel. 
lokewadikan (plural lukewadikak) (noun M) a writer; a clerk, a scribe. 
lokewongo (plural lukewongo) (noun M) a boaster; a braggart; an attention-seeker or a vaunting man. 
lokewongon (plural lukewongok) (noun M) a boaster; a braggart; a spoilt brat. 
lokeworoton (plural lukeworotok) (noun M) the host (the invitee). 
lokewosan (plural lukewosak) (noun M) a plaintiff; a petitioner; the accuser. 
loki- (plural luki-) masculine prefix forming ordinal numbers greater than one (1); prefix of masculine derivative nouns formed from verbs, adjectives or other nouns, implying “one with” a specified characteristic. lokiareit: the second. lokiuniet: the third. lokibakor (noun M) (formed from the noun ‘ibakor’ – poverty) one with poverty; a destitute man; a poor man; a beggar.
lokibakor (plural lukibakor) (noun M) a destitute man; a poor man; a beggar. ateker naka Iteso arau nakibakor akaulo naka ejie lokokaru 1987 toni 2003: the Teso people have become impoverished as a result of the 1987-2003 wars.
lokicaru (plural lukicaru) (noun M) a mad fellow; a fierce person. 
lokikerep (plural lukikerep) (noun M) a mad man; a lunatic; a maniac. 
lokiliokit (plural lukiliok) (adjective) male or like a man. 
lokiloset (plural lukiloset) (noun M) something for washing (like a basin or soap). akoto esabuuni lokiloset igoen: I want soap for washing clothes. 
lokitomonet (plural lukitomonet M) (noun M) (ordinal number) the tenth. elap lokitomonet: the tenth month; October. 
lokituritono (plural lukituritono) (noun M) a praiseworthy man.
lokiyai (plural lukiyai) (noun M) the first born. cp. ekiyai.
lokokau (plural lukokau) (noun M) the man behind; the latter thing. 
lokokitono (plural lukokitono) (noun M) a friend; a protégé; a prisoner (to be guarded well). 
lokolic (plural lukolic) (noun M) a man having red or white spots on the skin. 
lokoputuke (plural lukoputuke) (noun M) (in Karamoja) a species of bird, Fork-tailed drongo. 
lokori (plural lukori) (adjective) (cattle, cloth, a hen) striped; variegated. 
lokos (plural lukos) (adjective) very big; huge; enormous; gigantic; mammoth; immense. Elgon erai emoru lokos: Elgon is a massive mountain. etom erai etyang lokos: an elephant is a huge animal. edukit ngesi etogo lokos: she/he has built a very big house. cp. ekos, lopeti.
lokou (plural lukou) (noun M) (in Karamoja) an epileptic. 
lokowai (plural lukowai) (noun M) husband; the one at the side. nakowai: a wife. 
lokowaike (plural lokowaikec) (noun M) her husband. 
lolenger (plural lulenger) (noun M) a circumcised man. 
lolo (adverb) today. 
lolong (plural lulong) (noun M) a good-for-nothing person; a beggar, a hobo, a vagabond, or a tramp. 
lolukum (plural lulukum) (adjective) (of hut, bowl, etc) round; circular. etogo lolukum: a round hut. 
lominat (plural luminan) (noun M) the beloved one; the favourite one; the dear one. 
lomonuk (plural lumonuk) (noun M) a well-fed person; a big bellied man. cp. emonuk
lomuge (plural lumuge, lumugeik) (noun M) the brown-black one. 
longinam (plural lunginam) (noun M) a man without teeth. cp. naangaarany.
longolong (adverb) in the long past; once upon a time. cp. kolo kasonya
longotol (plural lungotol) (noun M) a disfigured man (having a big defect on the face). 
lonyadak (plural lunyadak) (noun M) the dirty one. 
loongor (plural luongor) (adjective) (of colour of fur, feathers) dark brown. 
looreet (plural luoreet) (noun M) the one in front. looreeteka: one in front of me. 
lope (adverb) practically. 
lopelo (plural lupelu) (demonstrative masculine pronoun) this is he; this is the very man (spoken about); this is the one (you want). cp. napena
lopepitelo (plural lupepitelu M) (adjective) this kind; this is the very kind. lopepitelo nges akoto eong: this is the very kind I want. cp. lopeponelo. 
lopeponelo (plural lupeponelu M) (adjective) this very kind, category or type. cp. lopepitelo. 
lopetai (plural lupetai) (adjective) worthless; useless. etunganan lopetai: a useless man. 
lopeti M (plural lupetiok) (adjective) huge; very big; important; gigantic; enormous; colossal. erot lopeti: the highway; a long journey. cp. napeti
lopirya (plural lupirya) (adjective) the green or emerald one. cp. epir.
lopus (plural lupusieik) (adjective) purple grey. lopus kakou: one with grey hair. 
loropat (plural luropan) (noun M) a hireling; a paid servant. 
lorudang (plural lurudang) (noun M) one with a narrow head. 
loruped (plural luruped) (noun M) a man with small buttocks. 
loseny (noun M) a grass, Rhynchelytrum repens. 
losiorot (plural lusiorot) (noun M) the straight one; the tall and slim one (person or tree). cp. loisiorotot 
losodit (plural lusodit M) (adjective) the first (one). 
lotai (plural lutai) (adjective) commonplace; the ordinary. etelepat lotai: a useless boy. nepetai: at all; just a little; at least. 
lotesot (plural luteso) (adjective) of or pertaining to Teso, its culture and people. emaido lotesot: a Teso (variety of) groundnut. 
lotikaojan (plural lutikaojak) (noun M) a giant; a tall man. 
lowai (preposition) this side; this way. cp. juwai: opposite of lowai, the other side. 
lu a) (demonstrative pronoun, masculine plural) these. itunga lu: these people; you people. kesi lu: these are the ones. cp. ngul M: those, kwi M: those far off. na, ngun, kwa F  b) lu forms numerals after multiples of ten. itomon kaluongon: fourteen. akaisaare kalukany M: twenty five (men). c) lu is relative pronoun, masculine plural. lukajokak: (those) who are good. 
luakapanakin (plural noun M) equipment; tools; kit or utensils (for soldiers or a feast or journey, etc). cp. ikapan
lud (adverb) (to block up, to seal, to fill) completely, to the brim. cp. pis, pas, kwic. 
ludeman (plural noun M) the spoils; the loot; the booty. 
ludu lud (adverb) (to block up, to seal, to fill) completely, to the brim. cp. pisi pis, pasa pas, kwici kwic. 
luedeunos (plural noun M) those left over. 
luegituna (plural noun M) things separated, kept apart or back, put aside. sirikiyanga iboro ngul luegituna: do not take away those things put aside. 
lukapan (plural noun M) equipment; kit; gear; tools; utensils; apparatus; paraphernalia. 
lukateker (plural noun M) relatives (both close and distant); extended family. cp. ekal: a nuclear family.
lukatinenikwana (plural noun M) the present generation.
lukawook (plural noun M) singers, a choir. 
lukecor (plural noun M) fish (in general). 
lukiraa (plural noun M) crops (in general). cp. iraan. 
lumanyet (plural noun M) dowry. ijaatar ijo kede ibaren lumanyet?: do you have cattle to give as dowry?
lumiduna (plural noun M) food (literally, those which are licked). 
Lusipeeri (singular noun M) Satan; Lucifer. cp. asitaani.
lwaru (adverb) a corruption of rwaru: in future; in the distant future; some day far off. 
lyo (adverb) (of a place or home) very desolate; empty; deserted. esil etogo lyo: the house is quite empty (nobody lives inside). esil ere lo lyo: this home is deserted completely.
-M-
m (noun neuter) the eleventh letter of the Ateso alphabet.
ma (interjection) used to express a threat or astonishment; also used to express a request ‘please’. ngai ca ma etunganan lo?: by the way, who on earth is this man? bia ma jo: please, do come. 
maa (adjective) (of a nice smell) aromatic; nice; spicy. eur edia maa: the vegetables smell nice, spicy. asabuunyu naeur maa: an aromatic soap. akinyet natuanaret naeur maa: this smearing oil has aromatic.
maaba ka (plural luamaaba ka) (noun neuter) my friend, companion, comrade. maaba, awar akwap kaloto: my friend, it is dark let us go. 
maaba! (interjection) say; by the way. maaba! ai ilosi ijo?: I say, where are you going? 
madak (adverb) (to step, sit, or do) dirtily or in a dirty way; with muck; filthily. abu ngesi kiboikin madak oicolongoka: she/he sat on my chair dirty as she/he was. 
mam (adverb) no; not; nay. mam ajeni: I do not know. mam adis: not even a little. mam ca: of course not; not at all. mam bobo: never again; no longer; no more. mam nepecep da: not at all; not in the least; on no account; never. komame: and there was none. (note that mam is used with adjectives and verbs, but with nouns and adverbs, use mere; with imperative, use siri) mere ijo, mere ejakait: not you, not the chief. mere kwangin: not like that. sirikilip: do not beg. cp. mam…arai: neither…nor. eebo, eeba.
mam ber (adverb) not yet. cp. eroko; eringa: not yet.
mama (adverb) over there; towards; yonder. kolot mamaejai papakon: go to your father. koyanga nges mama: take it there. 
mamai (plural lukamamai) (noun M) maternal uncle; the brother of one’s mother; (an Ateso reference to) a Karimojong. (note: paternal uncle is papa). 
Mande (noun neuter) (archaic) Monday. cp. Naebalaasa
mape mama (adverb) just there; that place. 
mapekon (adverb) just to you. abunit mapekon: I have come just to you (nowhere else). 
mati (adverb) so far; as far as; perhaps. mati Ngora kibunio ijo: perhaps you came from Ngora? alosi eong mati Ngora: I am going far, as far as Ngora. 
mee (noun neuter) (of a goat, to) bleat; the sound of a goat; (to a child) a goat. cp. buua: the sound of a cow. merrr: the sound of a sheep.
mere (adverb) no; not; neither; it is not. Used: a) before nouns: mere ejakait ebunit: it is not the chief who has come. b) before pronouns: mere ijo: it is not you. c) before adverbs: mere kwangin: not like that. mere nat: not later. d) before subjunctive: mere kalot, mere kolot: let me (her/him) go. mere ber: wait a bit; a moment. mere noi: not at all; not much (words you say to someone who has just said "eyalama noi" - thank you very much). cp. kinyek ber. Also note: mam – not - is used for verbs and adjectives; siri – not - is used only in imperative and subjunctive: mam alosi: I shall not go. mam ejok: it is not good. sirikilot: do not go. 
merrr (noun neuter) (of a sheep, to) bleat; the bleating of a sheep; (to a child) a sheep. cp. mee: the sound of a goat. buua: the sound of a cow.
miyot miyot (noun neuter) (of a chick, to) peep; cheep; the cry of a chick; (to a child) a chick. cp. miao: the sound of a cat. kutu kut: the sound of a breeding hen.
moding (adverb) in, from, at the wilderness; from the wild or bush.
Mohamed ekadwaran (noun M) Prophet Mohammed (the founder of Islam).
moi (adverb) tomorrow; soon; the near future. moi kace: the day after tomorrow; the near future. 
moolo (adverb) in the distant future. abuni moolo: I shall come later on. cp. rwaru. 
mot (adverb) slowly; softly; lightly. motimot: slowly; carefully; little by little. 
motimot (adverb) slowly; carefully; little by little; bit by bit; fifty-fifty (in reply to a greeting ‘Ijai biai – how are you?’). cp. mot
moto (adverb) a corruption of motoko: perhaps; possibly; maybe. cp. musiki, diat, motoko
motoko (adverb) perhaps; possibly; maybe. cp. musiki, diat, moto
muliamulia (adverb) (of movement) sluggishly; snaky; twisting; blindly. ilosi ijo muliamulia: you walk like a lame person. emun elosi muliamulia: ebala emun muliamulia elosi: the snake moves in a wriggling manner. cp. ladalad.
musi (adverb) perhaps; suppose. musi bo je kobu, ikwaikini bo jo ai?: suppose he comes, what will you do? musi ebuni: perhaps she/he will come. 
musiki (adverb) perhaps; suppose; maybe. musiki bo je kobu, ikwaikini bo jo ai?: suppose he comes, what will you do? musiki ebuni: maybe she/he will come. 
mutan (plural lukamutan M, nukamutan F) (noun) so-and-so; somebody; someone (man or woman). 
mwadamwad (adverb) (to do or to act) like a blind person. 
mwekemwek (adverb) (to be) dazzling; twinkling; glittering. ebala angolol paran mwekemwek: the lake dazzles at noon. cp. mwemwe
mwemwe (adverb) (to be) dazzling; flashing; glittery. ebala aacerit mwemwe: the star is twinkling. cp. mwekemwek
-N-
n-1 adverbial prefix indicating time or place or relative clause ‘where’ or ‘when’. Where - mam ajeni neejai ngesi: I do not know where she/he is. When - neelosio ngesi: when she/he goes. 
n-2 prefix before feminine parts of speech: naberu: female or feminine; naejok: a good (woman) (plural nungor, nuajokok) 
-n suffix of participles or agents (M or F) - ekajenan: a witness; lokajokan: a good one; ekamejan: a hunter. (note that in plural this -n changes into –k: ikamejak). 
n (noun F) the twelfth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
na feminine demonstrative pronoun singular, na: this. aberu na: this woman. natina: nasina: this (big or fat) one. It is also a suffix forming feminine nouns and adjectives of definite articles - aberu nakajokan: the good woman. aberu naejok: a good woman. Also forms the preposition ‘of’ for feminine nouns: aberu naka ejakait: the wife of the chief. 
-na- infix to verbs indicating repeated action or reciprocal action: ailipanakin: to beg or pray often for somebody else. eminanara: they love one another. (note that many verbs have –no- instead of –na- infix, adukonokin, ekotonoro: they like one another). 
naarai (conjunction) because; on account of; for that reason. irono ijo naarai ibitiono: you are bad because you are greedy. kanu naarai: because of; as a result of something.
nabarai (conjunction) seeing that; considering that; since; because; on account of. nabarai imamei ijo, mam eong da abuni: because you are absent, I am also not coming. abunit eong kanuka emong, nabarai ijo kitumunit eong: I come for the bull, because you promised me. cp. naarai.
nabonot (plural nubonot) (noun F) a humble girl. 
nadote (plural nuadoteak) (noun F) a whore; a prostitute. 
naduc (plural nuduc) (adjective) (used with feminine nouns) usual; ordinary; common. aberu naduc: an ordinary woman. akingok naduc: a common village bitch.
naemanyany (plural nuemanyany) (noun F) a married woman. cp. naedukokina. 
naerimon (plural nuerimok) (noun F) a prostitute (mobile lover); a one night stand; a vagabond; a truant. cp. amalayat, nakerimon
naesidounon (plural nuesidounok) (noun F) midwife. loesidounon: midman; birth attendant. 
-nai a verbal suffix to change certain –un verbs to first person imperatives implying a request. adakun: to lift and put down; kodakunai: lift me off, please. alakun: to redeem; kolakunai: redeem me, please.
naidedet (plural nuidedetos) (noun F) a pustule. ekotos ajimi aidede kakuwanaka: my body is developing sores (or wounds). idedet eong akuwan: I have pustules. 
naideuna (plural nuideuna) (noun F) a leftover; the remaining. cp. loideuna.
naitet (plural nuitetiak) (noun F) the new one; the fresh one; the young one. koyau asaanit naitet: bring a new (clean) plate. toto naitetet: a new mother of an asapan initiate. 
nakaanyiton (plural nukaanyitok) (noun F) superintendent; inspector. 
nakagion (plural nukagiok) (noun F) (in the Roman Catholic church) a saint; a holy lady; a sanctified female thing. cp. lokagion
nakakwena (plural nukakwena) (adjective) comic; funny; humorous. erai ngin akirot nakakwena: that is a funny statement (utterance). 
nakasaan (plural nukasaak) (noun F) a nursemaid; a maid servant. nakasaan idwe (plural nukasaak idwe) (noun F) a baby-sitter. 
nakasenyan (plural nukasenyak) (noun F) a woman or girl who is becoming thin; one whose body is wasting away; an AIDS sufferer or patient. 
nakatipet (plural nukatipet) (adjective) urgent; immediate; sudden; quick. atwanare nakatipet: a sudden death. abongokinet nakatipet: a quick answer; a retort. cp. atular: sudden death.
nakatumunan (plural nukatumunak) (noun F) a young girl of 14–16 years; an adolescent girl. 
nake (plural nuke) (possessive pronoun singular F) his, hers, its (used with feminine nouns). 
nakeburunan (plural nukeburunak) (noun F) an adolescent girl (with breasts just developing). 
nakec (plural nukec) (possessive pronoun singular F) theirs (used with feminine nouns) 
nakejaanakinan (plural nukejaanakinak) (noun F) a maid servant; a waitress; a housegirl. 
nakekal (plural nukekal) (noun F) a housewife. adumunit eong nakekal: I have got a wife or I am married. arai eong lokekal: I am married or I am a man with a family of my own. idumunit ijo ekal?: are you married? nukekal: connubial, marital, or conjugal issues. adeka nakekal: a hereditary or inherited disease. 
nakepoon (plural nukepook) (noun F) a cook; a chef; cordon bleu. 
nakerimon (plural nukerimok) (noun F) a prostitute (mobile lover); a one night stand; a sex worker; a vagabond; a truant. cp. amalayat. 
naki- (plural nuki-) feminine prefix for ordinal numbers. nakiareit: the second; Tuesday. cp. loki-
nakibakor (plural nukibakor) (noun F) a destitute woman; poor woman; a beggar. ateker naka Iteso arau nakibakor akaulo naka ejie lokokaru 1987: the Teso people have become impoverished as a result of the 1987 war.
nakitoi (plural nukito) (adjective) wooden. amuka nukito: sandals; sabots; clogs. 
nakitomonet (plural nukitomonet F) (ordinal number) the tenth. akiteng nakitomonet: the tenth cow. 
nakokal (plural nukokal) (noun F) a house wife (literally, the woman of the home). nakokaleke: his wife. nakokaleka: my wife. nakokalekon: your wife.
nakon (used in closing letter, possessive pronoun singular F) yours.
nakon da (interjection) reply to the greeting: yoga aswam: meaning ‘the same to you’, when replying to one person.(note: nakus da is used when replying to more than one person). 
nakowaike (plural nukowaike) (noun F) his wife (literally, the one on his side). 
nalangiron (plural nualangirok) (noun F) a pregnant woman or animal (literally, the heavy one). aberu nalangiron: a pregnant woman (literally, the heavy woman). 
nama (adverb) a corruption of mama: over there. namaka: at my home; to me. 
namanam (adverb) (of insects falling on) in a crowd; in swarms. apotu icuc namanam toma ajimi: the flies settled on the wound in swarms. 
naminat (plural numinan) (noun F) the beloved one or favourite one; the dear one. 
namiyot (plural numiyoi) (noun F) a darling; a dear heart; a sweetheart. 
nan (adverb) a moment ago; a moment earlier; a while ago (3 or 4 hours ago, today); a short time ago. alot nan ngesi: she/he went off a short time ago. cp. nat, kwana.
nan sek (adverb) sometime ago; sometime earlier; earlier today; a short time ago. alot ngesi nan sek: she/he went off sometime ago. cp. nat, nat sek. 
nangiirit (plural nukangiirit) (noun F) a toothless woman.
nape (adverb) as soon as; no sooner…than. nape ekwenyuni toto kocalaar ikoku: no sooner had the mother woken up than the baby yelled.
napena (demonstrative pronoun F) this very one. adolunike da ngesi napena: she/he has also just arrived. 
napus (plural nupusieik) (adjective) purple grey (used of females). napus kakou: a female with purple-grey hair. 
naranar (adverb) (of the earth, underfoot) shaking; vibrating; quivering; shuddering; juddering; pulsating; throbbing; trembling. ebala akwap naranar ireta edou: the earth shakes when rain thunders. cp. taratar. 
-nare (plural –kare) suffix of certain verbs or nouns - atwanare: to die (verb, singular); death (noun F). atwakare: to die (verb, plural). 
nasodit (plural nusodit F) (adjective) the first one. 
nat (adverb) soon; soon after; later. idumuni nat: you will get it soon. 
nat kwana (adverb) now. nat kwapekwana: just now; this minute. ajai ngesi ne nat kwapekwana: she/he was here just now. nat bo: afterwards. nat ebong: this evening or afternoon. nat kuare: tonight.
nat sek (adverb) sometime soon; sometime later. idumuni nat sek: you will get it later. 
nata (adverb) this female here (emphatic); this one here. erai ngesi nata: it/she is this one here (no one else). 
naticokom (adjective) (only said of meat) nice; juicy. akiring naticokom: a juicy piece of meat. 
natupat (plural nutupat) (noun F) a precept; a rule; a guideline; an instruction; a principle.
ne ka ngina (preposition) here and there; about; to or in many places. 
ne (adverb) here. neka: my place, home where I am; to me, my part. cp. owaika. nekon: your place, your home, where you are; to you. alosi eong nekon: I am going to your home. 
ne lem (adverb) the former place; the usual place; the ordinary place. alosi ne lem sek ajai: I am going to my usual abode or residence. abunit eong kane lem: I come from the usual place. 
ne syo (adverb) ours; our (noun neuter) (euphemism) genitals (a term used by men only talking to women, or women only talking to men). edeka ngesi ne syo: she/he is having a problem with our bodies, or she/he has a genital infection (the listener is of opposite sex). 
ne oni (adverb) ours; our (noun neuter) (euphemism) genitals (a term used by men only talking to men, or women only talking to women). edeka ngesi ne oni: she/he is having a problem with our bodies, or she/he has a genital infection (the listener is of opposite sex). ne oni nges ebunitor ngesi: she/he comes from ours (home) (inclusive of listener). 
nediat (singular noun neuter) (in a game of archery or marksmanship) a bull’s-eye; a targeted point. 
nedidio (adverb) nearly; almost; a little. nedidio ti ketwana: she/he nearly died. 
nediocici (adverb) nearby; close by; a little away; awhile. kinyamarai ber eong nediocici: accompany me a short distance. kopaik ber nediocici: stay awhile. 
nediokasilon (noun Dimin.) a little time or distance. 
neejaas (adverb) where there are; where they are. 
neejai (adverb) where there is; where she/he/it is. 
negwelanaret (singular noun neuter) a marketplace; a selling place; a shop; a bazaar. 
negwelet (singular noun neuter) a marketplace; a buying place; a shop; a bazaar. cp. negwelanaret
neisidos (singular noun F) a maternity; a labour ward; a delivery room. agola naisidoere angor: a labour room. cp. aidois.
neisidounet (singular noun F) a maternity; a labour ward; a delivery room. cp. aidois
nen (adverb) there. kibwaik nges nen: put it there. etia nen: it is as big as that; they are that many; it is like that. ikote nen: it is like that. ikote akiro nen: that is that; that is so. ekote nen: things were like that; they were thus or so; it was thus.
nen ta (adverb) there (you are); that is the place. nen nen: there there; it is here; over there. 
nenice (adverb) elsewhere (noun neuter) alibi; a defence; explanation; excuse. kanenice: from somewhere else; from elsewhere. kanenice: and partly. kanenice inera ngesi Ateso, kanenice inera amo: he talks partly Ateso and partly a Bantu tongue. 
nenidio…ti (adverb) almost; nearly. 
nenipe (adverb) together; jointly. elosete kesi nenipe: they go together. 
nepe (conjunction) while (doing something); whilst; as soon as; where. nepe abala keswama: as I was about to do. nepe ilosi ijo kodoluni ngesi: as soon as you went she/he arrived. nepe kuare: during the night; at night. nepe sek: very early. nepecep: not in the least; not at all. itunganan yen ekalanyana mam edumuni isirigin ka nepecep da: a lazy person will not get my money, to say the least. nepe eroko ber: before. nepe eroko ber akwap iwalara: before dawn. nepe lem: at least. nepe lem aideun ajon adicar da: at least a little beer should have been left.
nepecep da (adverb) not in the least; not at all. mam ijo kitelekaari eong nepecep da: you will not defeat me, not in the least.
nepene (adverb) right here. kanepekane: here and now; forthwith; just now. konyam kanepekane: eat it here and now. 
nepenen (adverb) right there; that very spot; that very point or place. kikote nepenen: let it be thus; so be it; Amen. kikote nepenen?: were they like that? kilipi ngun kere kokiror loka Yesu Kristo ekosijakait, kikote nepenen: we pray all that in the name of Jesus Christ our Lord, Amen.
nepepe (adverb) together (with); in one place. kere nepepe: all together; everyone or everything at the same time. nepepe ka: together with. kopotu Ikilai nepepe ka Ikiror: let Ikilai come together with Ikiror. cp. nenipe.
nepetai (adverb) slightly; lightly; nearly; only a little; a short while; approximately. nepetai ti eong kebiror: I nearly fell down; I almost failed exams. kinyek nepetai: wait a little. kebap ngesi eong nepetai: she/he hit me slightly. mam nepetai da: not at all; not in the least. nepetai: a little; not in the least. nepetai ti kikamun ijo ikokoi: you were almost caught red-handed stealing.
nes1 (adverb) that is why; that is where; that is how; therefore. nes alosio eong: that is why I go; therefore I go. Ngora nes abunitor eong: I come from Ngora (from nowhere else?). moi nes alosio eong: I will be going tomorrow. (note: nes is followed by a relative prepositional verb) 
nes2 (plural kes) (personal pronoun 3rd person singular, used as object) him; her; it. ajeni eong nes: I know him (her, it). cp. nges. 
nesi (plural kesi) (personal pronoun third person singular, used as subject) the person spoken of: him, her, it (subjects). ejeni nesi nges: she/he knows her/him. nesi: it is she/he. nesi eong: I am (he is) the one. cp. ngesi.
-net suffix of certain derived masculine and feminine nouns. acodunet: a temptation; a spike. epeleunet: a thing for starting, repeating or for initiating.
neta (adverb) here (emphatic); this place. ejai neta: it is here (nowhere else). 
neti nen (preposition) that much; all that long; all that far. etia neti nen: it is that big. ngai epedori aswam naetia neti nen?: who can manage so big a task? ketemasi neti nen: and that is what they said. neti kolo ngina: it is a long time since. neti kolo kaanyunitor eong ijo ngina, eapie?: is it not a long time ago since I saw you? 
newois (singular noun neuter) a place for singing; a choir loft. 

-NG-
ng (noun neuter) the thirteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
ngai? (plural lukangai M, nukangai F) (interrogative pronoun) who? whom? lokangai? (nakangai F) (plural lukangai, nukangai?) whose? ngai ma ngol (ngin)?: by the way, who is that? ingai bo jo?: who are you? loce or olongai or inangai (indefinite pronoun) so-and-so; the aforesaid. 
ngalakimak (singular noun F) the south.
ngany (adverb) (to refuse) altogether, absolutely. agir ngesi abunere ngany: she/he refused to come absolutely. 
ngaoi (adverb) a cry of a wild cat. ebala atawoi ngaoi ngaoi: the wild cat cries ngaoi, ngaoi. 
nges atemar (adverb) that is (to say); 'id est'.
nges (personal pronoun 3rd person singular used as an object) him; her; it. akoto eong nges: I like it/her/him. cp. nes.
ngesi (personal pronoun 3rd person singular used as a subject) he; she; it. ebuni ngesi: she/he/it will come. cp. nesi. 
ngil (adverb) (of pain, to be) sharp, pricking. ebala akakoik ngil: I feel a sharp pain in my stomach. 
ngilingil (adverb) (of pain, to be) acute, aching. ebala akeju ngilingil: my foot aches.
ngin (demonstrative pronoun F and Dimin. singular) that one; whoever; every; each. nginiberu: every woman; each woman. mam akoto ngin: I do not want that (female) one. ngipengin: that very (female) one (plural ngupengun: those very female ones). kwangin: like that; therefore. kwapekwangin: like that; that is right. kwangin (adverb) naked; without; just like that. elosi ngesi kwangin: she/he goes naked or nude. abu ngesi kwangin: she/he has come empty-handed. nginice: the other (female) one. nginiibois: everywhere; every place. nginitunganan: everybody (neuter). nginibore: everything. nginidiope: each one. nginipaarit: always; everyday. nginituan: everybody; everyone; each one. (note that ngin: every, is followed by the infix -i-, which stands for the noun prefixes e-, a-, i- in the three noun gender classes M, F, and neuter/Dimin. respectively). 
ngina (adverb) over there; yonder. kolototo ngina abolia: go over there to play.
ngio (adverb) (to sleep) deeply; soundly. ajotoor ngesi ngio: she/he is sound asleep. 
ngipengin(adverb) (used to refer to feminine, neuter, and diminutive pronouns) that very one. ngipengin: that (very female) one over there.
ngipengina (adverb) just over there; that very location. 
ngiuu (adverb) a cry of a cat. ebala ikapa ngiuu: the cat wauls. 
ngo (adverb) long ago (adverb) (Ateso Atororo) nil. ngo kolo (adverb) in the olden times. kolo apengo: once upon a time. cp. kolo kasonya. 
ngo ngo (adverb) very long ago. 
ngodial (adverb) on to, towards, the left. cp. kediany. 
ngol demonstrative adjective and pronoun, masculine singular: that; each; every. ngopengol: that very (male) one. ngolitunganan: each or every man. ngolimoro: every time; always; every day. ngolidiope: each (male) one. (note that ngol and ngin: each, are followed by the infix -i-: nginiberu, ngolitunganan, nginikoku). 
ngolimoro (adverb) always; everyday. cp. nginipaaran: everyday; nginiduc: everyday.
ngomongom (adverb) (to eat or devour) greedily; voraciously; ravenously; quickly. enyami ekingok ngomongom: ebala ekingok enyami ngomongom: ebala ekingok ngomongom enyami: the dog eats quickly and greedily. 
ngoon (adverb) (Usuk) yesterday but one. ngoon kace: the day before yesterday. cp. bian. 
ngopengol (masculine singular demonstrative adjective and pronoun) that very man; that is the man. 
ngorob (adverb) (imitation of a dog eating something hard, but with the mouth open) crunch; chomp; munch. ebala ekingok iboiboi akoit ngorob ngorob: the dog crushes bones noisily. cp. ngurub
ngul (demonstrative adjective masculine plural) those. itunga ngul: those people not far away. (suffix) every; all (used with plural masculine nouns). ngulutunga: each group of people. ngupengul: those very men or males or groups. cp. ngin-
ngularangular (adverb) (of limbs) maimed; crippled. elosi ngesi ngularangular: she/he walks in a crippled manner (as a maimed person). 
ngun (demonstrative adjective and pronoun feminine plural) those. angor ngun: those women. (suffix) every (followed by a plural feminine noun). ngunupesur: every group or crowd of girls. kanukangun (adverb) on account of that; that being so; for that reason; therefore. ngunu da: those also. 
ngupengul (demonstrative adverb and pronoun masculine plural) those (emphatic); those are the very ones. eraas ngupengul ikokolak: those are the very thieves, no other.
ngupengun (demonstrative adverb and pronoun feminine plural) those (emphatic); those very ones. ngupengun F: those are the very ones. ngupengun edolitor ijo alosit: that is the very reason why you should go.
ngurub (adverb) (imitation of a person eating something hard, but with the mouth shut) crunch; chomp; munch. ejo, ipupete yesi Ilok ebakasi emuogo ngurub ngurub kokinga?: listen, do you hear the Karimojong thieves chomping fresh cassava tubers outside? cp. ngorob
Noeli (singular noun neuter) Christmas; Noël tide. 
noi (adverb) very much; extremely. noi noi: very, very much. kakoto ijo noi noi: I like or I want or I love you very much. cp. cut.
-noi a verbal suffix to change certain –un verbs to first person imperatives implying a request (not an order). awoun: to put down a load from someone’s head; kowounoi: lift this load off my head, please. awomun: to come for; kowomunoi: come for me, please.
-nokin a verbal suffix denoting a repetitive action away from the speaker. awotokin: to lift onto (once only); awotonokin: to keep lifting and loading onto (people’s heads – many times). aremokin: to push or plunge into (once only); aremonokin: to keep pushing or plunging into (often). 
nono (adjective) nude; naked; undressed. alosit nono: to move about naked or undressed.
-nore (plural –kore) a suffix of certain verbs used with singular or plural nouns respectively – adau egoe aonore: the dress is dry; adautu igoen aokore: the clothes are dry. adau emuebe atyonore: the mango is mature; adautu araito atyokore: the fruits have matured. adau eupa ajonore: the fireplace is cold; adautu acok ajokore: the potatoes have cooled. adau epapaali akonore: the pawpaw is ripe; adautu ipapaalin akokore: the pawpaws have ripened. 
nu1 (demonstrative pronoun feminine plural of na) these. angor nu: these women. akinei nu: these goats. 
nu- (relative pronoun feminine plural of na) who; which. angor nuabala eong kesi nu: the women I talked about are these. nu nan: the aforesaid. 
nu2 (used with relative prepositional verbs to imply) the reason why. nuakotor eong alosit kes nu: the reason why I want to go is this. 
nuabekoi (plural noun F) unconfirmed news; rumours. 
nuegeete (plural noun F) preface; foreword. 
nuejaas toma (plural noun F) table of contents; contents (of a book). 
nuelomunete (plural noun F) consequences; results; outcomes; effects. 
nuelosikinitai (plural noun F) objectives; aims; purposes; intentions. 
nueumokina (plural noun F) wonders; miracles. 
nuibwaa (plural noun F) mysteries; secrets; anonymity; hidden matters. 
nuitogogongete (plural of naitogogongi) (noun F) supporting evidence; corroborating evidence. 
nuka1 (1st person possessive feminine pronoun plural of naka) mine. akinei ngun eraas nuka: those goats are mine. 
nuka2 (adverb) concerning; on account of; therefore; consequently. kanukinyo?: why? kanukangun: for that reason; consequently. kanuka akiro nuka bian: concerning yesterday’s matters. ekoto einer ka jo nuka aingito kon: she/he wants to talk to you about your exams.
nuka3 (F plural of naka) (preposition) of. angor nuka ejakait: the women of the chief. 
nuka- (prefix to feminine plural adjectives) angor nukapolok: the principal women; ladies. 
nukabe (plural noun F) rumours. nuabe: rumours; nonsense. akiro nuabeak: the truth. 
nukabeit (plural noun F) the truth. 
nuke (third person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nake) his/hers/its. akokoroi ngun eraas nuke: those chickens are his/hers. 
nukec (third person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakec) theirs. apopongo ngun eraas nukec: those guns are theirs. 
nukisisianakina (plural noun F) moral lesson; the teaching; instructional material; drills; tenets; philosophy. nukisisianakina nuka akelesia: the teachings of the Roman Catholic church (literally, the things taught by the Roman Catholic church). 
nukisuduno (plural noun F) caprice; vagary; whimsical acts; impulsive actions. 
nukon (2nd person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakon) yours. apungurei ngun eraas nukon: those logs are yours. 
nukos (1st person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakos) ours (excluding the person addressed). aperito ngun eraas nukos: those beds are ours (you excluded). 
nukus (2nd person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nakus) yours. aperito ngun eraas nukus: those beds are yours. 
-nut a suffix of intransitive verbs and feminine verbal nouns implying tendencies. anyamanut: (intransitive verb) to be fond of eating all the time. akukuranut: (adjectival feminine noun from ekukurana) diligence; efficiency; hardwork. aipit: to breed animals or plants; aipitanut: to be fond of rearing animals. 
nutiok (plural of nati F) (adverb) the big ones. koyau amor nutiok: bring big stones. cp. lutiok M. 
nuwok (1st person possessive feminine pronoun plural of nawok) ours (including the person addressed). asaanin ngun eraas nuwok: those are our plates (those plates are for me and you). naka: (possessive pronoun feminine singular of nuka) mine. nakon, nake, nakec, nakus: yours, her/his/its, theirs, yours. naka: (adverb) that; of (for feminine nouns) aberu naka Orena: Orena’s wife. 
nwom (adverb) emptily; vacantly; vacuously. anyamaar nwom: to swallow at once (like nothing was ever put in the mouth).

-NY-
ny (noun neuter) the fourteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
nyakoi (noun neuter) the north (adverb) in the north; northern; northerly.
nyalanyal (adverb) (of the skin sensations) creepily. ebala eong akiring nyalanyal: I have a creepy feeling; I feel my flesh creep. cp. rikirik, 
nyilak (adverb) (of a soft or furry thing falling or getting cut) softly; soundlessly. abu ikapa yen etwanit kodacun kwap nyilak: the dead cat fell down softly. 
nyong (adverb) look! there! cp. kongolik, eejo. 
nyudunyud (adverb) (of people or animals moving together, or of fire burning slowly) at close quarters; head to tail 

-O-
o o exclamation of wonder or disgust. cp. okwe, okwe toto, otukwi, ooi, u uu. 
o-1 prefix forming locative cases - ore: at home. okitoi: in or on the tree. osamai: in the swamp. 
o-2 prefix of prepositional nouns. ore: at home. osomero: at, to, in the school. otunga: in, among, towards people. oboro: in, among things
o-3 prefix of some masculine proper names - Okinei (plural luokinei): Mr. Goat. Opus (plural luopus): Mr. Purple-grey. Otaupe (plural luotaupe): Mr. Hot-heart the greedy one. Okurut (plural luokurut): Mr. Maggot, Mr. Caterpillar, etc. Okiring: Mr. Meat, Beef, or Flesh.
-o1 suffix of passive infinitives. adukio: to be built. 
-o2 suffix of verbs in -or singular, 3rd person singular, 1st person singular, plural indicative. kilimo ngesi ijo: she/he told on you; she/he reported you. 
-o3 suffix to some verbs and nouns in -kin, -kino: - adukokino: marriage. 
o (noun M) the fifteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet; a vowel letter as in ‘owl’.
obaet (adverb) at dawn. 
obar (adverb) to, at, from outside field or village. alosit obar: to go to the toilet. 
obe (indefinite pronoun) own; proper; sincerely; truly; true. eong lokon obe: (when ending letters) I am yours truly. aiboisit kon obe: your real or proper home address. obe (adverb) the real one. ngesi obe: she/he/it herself/himself/itself. kesi obe: they themselves. akekiro obe: her/his actual words; verbatim.
obebera (plural luobebera) (noun M) (usually used with negative connotations) initiator; instigator; originator; one who hurries ahead of others. 
obeet (noun M) (formerly) a variety of millet and potatoes. 
obilibil (plural lukobilibil) (noun M) joint pain; mild arthritis.
obonipe (noun M) one who lives alone; childless person; hermit. 
obwabu (noun M) a man as poor as a dog. 
ocailap (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet potatoes. cp. etubusumeesa
ocero (noun M) a name given to a person or animals with striped clothes or skin. 
ocigicig (noun M) gout (a disease of the blood that causes painful swelling of the joints); athlete’s foot. 
ocole (noun M) (formerly) a variety of cassava.
ocookonye (noun M) a man with lustful eyes; enfant terrible; a very curious person, always looking about.
Ocoto (noun M) September (literally, the month of plentiful cow urine used in butter-making). cp. Otibar
odidi (plural lukodidi) (noun M) a species of bird, black-faced waxbill, Cordon bleu. 
odiiri (noun M) (formerly) a variety of cowpeas. cp. emaret. 
odikisyonari (adverb) in, to or from a dictionary; of a glossary; in, to or from a lexicon. 
odood (adverb) (of a person’s movement) awkwardly; clumsily; (of sound of the beating of the jugular artery) throbbing; lub-dub. ekeri ngesi odood: ebala ngesi odood ekeri: she/he runs in an awkward way. cp. uduud.
oduk (noun M) (outside Usuk) a tree in the ekimeng and ekulony family, Combretum molle, whose leaves or roots are a cough remedy. In Usuk it is known as ekwooro.
Odunge (noun M) April (literally, the month of smouldering fires and cloudy skies, plentiful rains and flying ants – adunge). 
oduu (plural nukoduu) (noun neuter) a scrub hare, Lepus saxatilis. 
odwaratau (plural lukodwaratau) (noun M) a hot-tempered man; a suicidal man; a suicide bomber (like the Palestinian or Iraqi resistance fighters).
odwomen (plural lukodwomen) (noun M) a glutton; gormandiser.
ogangarakou (plural lukogangarakou) (noun M) one with a big head; a fat-head (as a term of abuse)
ogaria (plural lukogaria) (noun M) a pigmy kingfisher; a large, fish-eating bird of prey with a brown back, and brown and white underparts, Osprey. 
ogeana (adverb) (biblical) in, to, belonging to Hell. 
ogiegio (plural lukogiegio) (noun M) a species of fish, Heterobranchus. 
ogogolo (noun M) (formerly) a variety of big-seeded cowpeas. cp. ebelat. 
ogoloi (singular noun M) gonorrhoea or any disease of the urinary system. 
ogurememe (plural lukogurememe) (noun M) a greedy person; a glutton; a foodie; a gastronome; a food-lover; a gourmand; a greedy-guts. cp. otaupe. 
oi (interjection) exclamation of pain. oi to: oi toto!: exclamation of ‘dear me’. 
oidoolei (plural lukoidoolei) (noun M) a knicker; pants; underwear. cp. egoe, epale
oisanga (plural lukoisanga) (noun M) a man or boy with a large head (term of abuse). 
oitolima (adverb) on the river bank; on the lake-shore. 
Ojok (singular noun M) God the Benevolent; God the Good One. 
ojokokan (plural lukojokokan) (noun M) a good rich man; a benefactor; a donor; the giver (good hand). 
ojokotau (plural lukojokotau) (noun M) a kind-hearted man; a charity or aid organisation. ekorete iriongeta lukojokotau ikerai iperito kede inyamat kokaabin luko Teso: aid organisations (such as Action-Aid, Lutheran World Federation, Oxfam) distribute clothing and food to the internally displaced people in camps in Teso. 
okaleka (adverb) at my house; in my family. enyamenenei ngesi kokaleka: she/he often eats at my home.
okapet (noun M) a grass, Brachiaria. 
okejukusa (plural lukokejukusa) (noun M) (Usuk) a bat-eared fox (believed to portend death in the family when it barks in the vicinity), Otocyon megalotis. cp. ekwee.
okekwa (adverb) the other side of river or valley. okekwa juwai: okekwa je: on the next hill; on the other side of the river. 
okelo (noun M) a boy born after twins.
okeper (adverb) abreast; shoulder to shoulder; on, at the shoulder. 
okewas (singular noun M) black quarter – a disease of cattle akin to rinderpest. 
okidia (noun M) the country to the east. 
okinei (noun M) (formerly) a variety of reddish sorghum. 
okiru (plural luokiru) (noun M) a bee-eating bird. cp. elele. 
okituk1 (noun M) a grass, Bothriochloa glabra. 
okituk2 (plural lukokituk) (noun M) a big-mouthed man; a cantankerous person; a big liar.
okitwi (adverb) in the jungle; in the bush; in the high grass. alomar okitwi: to wage a guerrilla war.
okok (plural lukokok) (noun M) a species of fish - Bagruss. cp. okuk.
