okoku (plural odwe) (noun M) a son; a male child. (adverb) the son of (a person specified). okoku oduk: a son for posterity.
okoku koduk (singular noun M) so-and-so; somebody; everybody. ayangaa okoku koduk ekagaali: somebody has taken my bicycle. cp. mutan. 
okoku kojokotau (plural odwe kojokotau) (noun M) son of a good-hearted father. okoku kalukojokotau: son of good-hearted parents. 
okoku oduk (plural odwe oduk) (noun M) children of Teso; son for posterity; children of men (exclamation of praise for one providing for the future). cp. idwe kitunga. 
okokuka (plural odweka) (noun M) my son. 
okoleji (adverb) at, in, to the college. alomasi apesur aisiom okoleji: girls have gone to study in college. cp. osomero
okoli (noun M) a stingy or greedy person. cp. otaupe
okolonga (plural ikolongai) (noun M) (Ateso Atororo) a patriarch, a name given to one who enters the etem, i.e. who has left boyhood for manhood. 
okori (plural lukokori) (noun M) one who goes about to finish meal remnants from other people’s plates. cp. otaupe, ogurememe. 
okuk (plural lukokuk) (noun M) a species of fish, Bagruss. 
Okurut (noun M) a name of a man. 
okutukut (plural luokutukut) (noun M) an African black and white horn-bill. cp. esukusuk
Okwang (noun M) March (literally, the month of the grey skin, because of dust from preparing fields and also due to the fact that food is getting scarce after the long dry season and the beginning planting season). 
okwangole (plural lukokwangole) (noun M) (a nick-name for) a very thin man or animal. 
okwaras1 (plural lukokwaras) (noun M) a shrub used for smallpox wounds, Acacia pennata. 
okwaras2 (singular noun M) a plant from which salt is extracted, Aspilia kotschyi. 
okwe (interjection of shock or entreaty) please; oh dear. okwe toto: oh dear mother. Okwe, katamata oni da aitopol angajepewok: please, let us also try to propagate our mother tongue. okwe lolo eong: oh dear me! cp. ito, otukwi: alas; alack. 
okwenyu ainyam (plural lukokwenyu ainyam) (noun M) a very heavy cast-iron saucepan made at the blacksmithy (literally, wake up to eat – so because the saucepans are so heavy they last generations). 
okwii (adverb) to or at the green bushes; to or at the shrubbery. kolot okwii kwi: go to yonder (those) green bushes. 
okwir (plural luokwir) (noun M) a species of long-tailed gregarious ravens, making like sounds. 
olalaboi (plural lukolalaboi) (noun M) a glutton; Mr Wide Stomach. cp. ogurememe.
olangirikibwoko (plural lukolangiribwoko) (noun M) a person who always carries heavy loads. 
olap (adverb) in, at, of, with the moon; in or during the month. abuni eong olap loitomonet: I will come in October. abu etunganan losodit kodo olap okaru 1968: the first man landed on the moon in 1968.
oliborit (plural luoliborin) (noun M) a green plantain snake. cp. acak. 
Olica (noun M) a pet name for a white cow. 
Olobai (noun M) October (literally, the month of hartebeests, ilobai). cp. Osokosokoma. 
oloit (plural lukoloit) (noun M) a prison warder. cp. lokedaran 
Oloja (noun M) August (literally, the month when storing millet grain, iloja). cp. Otikoik. 
olongalong (plural lukolongalong) (noun M) one who likes to talk big or to boast; Mr. Bombastic. 
olongolong (adverb) (of speech or movement) over-confident; expressing pride and big talk. ebala ngesi olongolong elosi: she/he walks proudly. 
Omaruk (noun M) June (literally, the month of large white mushrooms, imaruk). cp. Oserede.
omatet (plural omateta) (adverb) at a beer party; in or to a drinking spree or binge. 
omeena (plural luomeena) (noun M) a tiny edible fish in the orugeny and ayoit family (a good remedy for measles). 
omelekes (plural luomelekes) (noun M) (outside Usuk) a tidy edible mole rat that sneaks into people’s homes and snatches domestic wares to store in its burrow in a dead anthill. cp. edoomelu. 
omeleku (plural luomeleku) (noun M) a big swallow (bird). cp. imodyalat: a small swallow bird. 
omilimil (plural luomilimil) (noun M) a bluebottle (fly). cp. ecucut
Omodokokingol (noun M) July (literally, the month of the dirty or thick stirring stick, akingol). 
omoit (plural omo) (noun M) a mouse-bird, Coleus-stratus. 
omolimol (noun M) trypanosomiasis (a disease of cattle spread by tsetse flies), causing the animal to drool. 
omududu (noun M) (formerly) a black variety of finger millet. cp. emiroit. 
Omugabe (noun M) the title of former kings of Ankole (the present day Uganda districts of Mbarara, Bushenyi, Ntungamo); the cultural leader of the Banyankole people.
Omuk (noun M) February (literally, the month of shoes – amuk - because the sun is scorching hot, and also when trees grow new leaves, aimuk).
Omukama (noun M) the title of former kings of Tooro or Bunyoro kingdoms; the cultural ruler of the Batooro or Banyoro people.
omukeke (plural lukomukeke) (noun M) a harmless black or brown sugar ant. 
omulat (noun M) Trypanosomiasis (a disease of cattle spread by tsetse flies). cp. omolimol.
omuran (plural amurak) (noun M) all male in-laws. 
omusaalatwo (plural lukomumusaalatwo) (noun M) a clan leader as an unpaid agent of Government (literally, his wages are a gourd of beer). cp. apolon kateker. 
omusenu (singular noun M) a grass whose extract is used as a liniment in a guineaworm infection.
omusikiiti (plural omusikiitin) (adverb) at, in, to, from the mosque. 
omweso (singular noun M) a board game played with 32 holes and 64 peas (imor). cp. aileisit
onac (plural lukonac, inacan) (noun M) brother; cousin brother. cp. inac: sister. 
onges (plural lukonges) (noun M) a small scorpion with a very painful sting. cp. ekiliton, adero
ongoliakide (plural lukongoliakide) (noun M) a black-crested eagle in the esele family that responds to its name by looking in different directions. cp. esele.
oni (1st person pronoun plural of eong) we; us (inclusive of persons spoken to). (note: iso: we; us, exclusive of those spoken to). 
-onor a verbal suffix used with bi-syllabic '–or' verbs to denote a repeated action away from the speaker. aiwucor: to throw away (once only); aiwuconor: to keep throwing away (often). aremor: to topple over (once only); aremonor: to keep pushing over (often). 
onyamen (plural lukonyamen) (noun M) a greedy man; a glutton; Mr Food. cp. odwomen.
onyangairiare (plural lukinyangairiare) (noun M) a short beer tube, ‘the Mill Compensater’. 
ooret (plural lukooret) (noun M) a variety of edible mushroom (growing on cow-dung heaps). 
opaara (plural luopaara) (noun M) a friend. 
opar (adverb) on, to the papyrus mat. 
Opedelei (noun M) May (literally, the month of hunger and slim stomachs, apedelel). cp. Abwoatidwe.
opelec (plural lukopelec) (noun M) a small silvery fish, Engraulicy pris argenteus. cp. epelec. 
Opio (noun M) name of the first born boy twin (because it was the victor, i.e. aipior). (note: the second born boy twin is called Odong because it remained behind, i.e. aidong). cp. epiot.
Opo (noun M) (abbreviation of Opolokalokai) December. 
Opolokalokai (noun M) December (literally, the month of setting animal traps).
Opolot (noun M) (formerly) a name given to a child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after preceding child has died). 
Opoo (noun M) a man’s name. 
opunuka (plural lukopunuka) (noun M) a glutton; Mr Distended Stomach. cp. ogurememe.
opus (noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet with purple-grey seeds. 
opyet! (interjection) Finished! it is over! I stop there! 
-or a verbal suffix, indicating motion away or to become (in verbs in ki-o or ko-o class). 
Orara (noun M) January (literally, the month when trees shed their leaves and women stock firewood, arara). 
ore (adverb) at home; indoors. 
oria (imperative) (Usuk) clear out!; go away! cp. irwa. 
oriatom (plural lukoriatom) (noun M) a sensitive folding plant. 
oriimikuwan (noun M) a nickname for a thin person or a little fellow. 
orima (plural lukorima) (noun M) the faithful or obedient one. 
orinyo (noun M) a plant, leaves of which are edible, Astrochlaena. 
Oriokot (noun M) (formerly) a name given to a child passed through the roof to prevent its premature death (after preceding child has died). cp. opolot
Orodiini (singular noun M) Holy Orders. esakarameeto lok’Orodiini: the Sacrament of Priesthood. 
orugeny (plural lukorugeny) (noun M) a species of tiny (small) fish in the ayoit or omeena family; a National Resistance Army soldier (Uganda government army in the late 1980s), named so by the insurgents because of the general presence of child-soldiers in the army ranks.
oruk (plural lukoruk) (noun M) a grasshopper with a ridge-back, Phymateus; a caterpillar with humps on the back; (formerly) a variety of groundnuts with red and white big seeds (often causing headache when eaten raw).
orwa! (imperative) go away!; get out of the way! orwa ijo kane!: get out of here! vamoose! (plural) orwa yesi kane! 
osaapa (adverb) on or to the papyrus mat.
osarapune (noun M) a greedy man or boy; a selfish man; Mr Hot Porridge; a glutton. cp. ogurememe; otaupe. 
Oserede (noun M) June (literally, the month of plentiful beer, asered). cp. Omaruk.
Osokosokoma (noun M) October (literally, the month of drooping high grass, ema, heralding the beginning of the dry season). cp. Olobai.
osuat (plural lukosuat)(noun M) a bishop bird. cp. aisurit. 
Osuban (noun M) November (literally, the month of the wakes or funeral rites, asuban). 
osyep (plural osyepion) (adverb) on the side; at the side of something long; along; on the shore. kopaenene imotokan kosyep lokediany: always keep left when passing on-coming motorcars.
otapasulyany (plural lukotapasulyanya) (noun M) the fortunate one; Mr Lucky One; the blessed one.
otaupe (plural lukotaupe) (noun M) a greedy person; a glutton; a stingy person; Mr Hot Heart.
Otibar (singular noun M) September (literally, the month of plenty to eat and drink, hence the month of big shit, feasting and dancing, ebar). cp. Ocoto.
otibok (noun M) a grass, Urochloa panicoides. 
Otikoik (singular noun M) August (literally, the month of plenty to eat, hence the month of a big stomach, akoik). cp. Oloja.
otitiro (plural lukotitiro) (noun M) a herb whose root is believed to give virility to the men who chew it; traditional viagra or levitra plant.
otitot (plural luotitot) (noun M) a dragonfly. cp. emerekek.
otogoro (singular noun M) (Ateso Atororo) electricity; electric power. cp. akim naka ekipyei: electricity.
otokwi (interjection of surprise, wonder, or of sudden pain) (outside Usuk) oh! oh! 
otolim (adverb) in, at, towards the shade. alosi eong aiboi otolim: I am going to sit in the shade. 
otukwi (interjection) (Usuk) oh oh! alas! expression of pain, hurt, or misery. 
otwele (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of finger millet. 
oukoi (singular noun M) bovine pleuro-pneumonia; a fatal cattle disease that attacks the lungs, causing animals to foam in the mouth and die. cp. omolimol
ouma (noun M) (formerly) a variety of sweet quick-maturing cassava. cp. ebwanaterak
owewe (plural lukowewe) (noun M) a fire-crowned bishop bird. 
owo (plural lukowo) (noun M) a species of bird, Bittern exobrychus. 
oyapeesi (plural oyapeesin) (adverb) at, in, from office; at, from the place of work; at the administrative centre.
oyokiyok (plural luoyokiyok) (noun M) one who wears rattling ornaments; an ajosi dancer. 
oyunibasiti (adverb) at, in, to the university. ikoku yenecobe esiomi toni oyunibasiti: a bright child studies upto university level.

-P-
p (noun neuter) the sixteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
-pa- infix indicating: being with, possessing. epaupa: my male friend; my male companion. epading: my male enemy. epae: a man friend. epadic: a male companion. eparian: a male equal; a male contemporary. epajen: a male relative. epaper: a male friend. 
pac (adverb) recently; a short time ago. koleje pac: in the recent past. yenipac: the latest thing. nupac: the latest news. 
pamar (adverb) (of a fat soft thing, to fall with a) thump; bump; thud. abu asirikaalet natuman kolatar koperet pamar aiilor: a fat female soldier collapsed and fell with a thud at the parade.
papa (plural lukapapa) (noun M) one’s father (biological or otherwise); the brother of one’s father; the elder brother of one’s husband; the owner; the master; the superior; the boss. papa-odwe: the father of twins (literally, the father of many). papa k’ican: a very poor man; a pauper. cp. ipaapa, papaa.
papaa (plural lukapapaa) (noun M) a grandfather; a brother of grandfather; a father of one’s husband. lukapaa: forefathers; ancestors. 
papakiye (plural lukapapakiye) (noun M) a man who causes trouble. cp. totokiye (plural nukatotokiye) (noun F) a woman who causes trouble. 
papa-odwe (plural lukapapa-odwe) (noun M) father of twins. 
paran (adverb) by day; during the day; at daytime. paran ecumere nges: it was during the day when she/he was stabbed. adol akolong kiding paran: the time or the sun has reached mid-day.
pas (adverb) (of fullness) very full; full to the brim; completely full. ileleba pas: it is very full. cp. pasa pas, pis.
pasa pas (adverb) (of fullness) very full; full to the brim; completely full. ileleba pasapas: it is very full. 
pe (adverb) (of warmth or heat) very; extreme. ikoru ijo acok emwaka pe: you have served potatoes steaming hot. emwaka akipi pe: the water is very hot. cp. pee pe.
-pe a suffix used in numerals to stand for ‘one’. epe M, ape F, ipe Dimin. (noun) one. akany kape (noun F): six (literally, five and one). ipeikoku: ikoku ipe: idiopekoku: one child. ediope: one; a single one. atipe: once. 
-pe- infix used with a demonstrative pronoun with an emphatic meaning: lopelo M: this very one. napena F: this very one. yepeyen Dimin.: this very one. lupelu (M plural): these very ones. nupenu (F plural): these very ones. jepeje M: that very one. kwipekwi (M plural): those very ones. kanepekanen: forthwith; immediately. nenipe: nepepe: all together; in one place. apenan: since time past. 
pee pe (adverb) (of warmth or heat) very; extreme. inepit emukaro amwanus pee pe: the kiln is continuing to be very hot. amwana akolong pee pe: the sun is very hot. emwana akolong pee pe: the sun is very hot. cp. pe.
pel (adverb) (of a fire, a faggot) flaming, blazing. ekeritor aberu acukumac kuare pele pel: the woman runs with a blazing faggot at night.
Penetesia (singular noun neuter) a sacrament of penance, atonement or apology; self-punishment. adumun penetesia: to receive penance. 
Pentekosit (singular noun neuter) Pentecost (the seventh Sunday after Easter, commemorating the descent of the Holy Spirit on the apostles). apaarit naka Pentekosit: the day of Pentecost. 
petek (adverb) (of an light or thin animal jumping or prancing) lightly, soundlessly. 
peu (adverb) (of pain, heat) intense; severe; extreme. emwaka akima peu: the porridge is very hot. cp. pee pe.
pii1 (adverb) (of movement of body fluids) slowly; sluggishly. ebala akuwan pii: the body is sluggish. ebala eong akuwan pii: I am not feeling well; I do not feel well. 
pii1 (adverb) (of something syrupy, flowing) slowly; thick. ebala esik pii: honey flows thick or is syrupy.
pio (adverb) (of something getting finished) completely; altogether; entirely. adaunos akipi pio: the water is completely finished. adaunos akipi kamot pio: the water is completely finished in the pot. 
piric (adverb) (to squash, to crush) altogether; completely. ecak emotoka emucuuga piric: the car squashed the orange altogether. epiriciki emotoka eong elupe: the motorcar has squirted mud on me.
piripir (adverb) (of water, a reflection or a mirage) glittering; dazzling; shining. cp. twaratwar 
piris (adverb) (of a soft thing being crushed, dissolved or melted) totally; completely. ecak egaali emuebe lokabosan piris: the bicycle crushed a rotten mango totally. cp. piric.
pis (adverb) (of extent of fullness of liquids or solids) very; brimming. aileleba pis: to be very full. cp. pisi pis
pisi pis (adverb) (of extent of fullness of liquids or solids) very; brimming. aileleba pisi pis: to be very full. cp. pasa pas
pit (adverb) (of something getting finished) completely; absolutely; altogether; quite; utterly. adaunos akipi pit: the water is completely finished. cp. piti pit
piti pit (adverb) (of something getting finished) completely; absolutely; altogether; quite; utterly. adaunos inyamat kosepuria piti pit: the food is completely finished from the sauce pan. cp. pio
po (adverb) (of something falling or hitting a hard surface) conk, thud, rap. ebiror ngesi po: she/he fell down with a thud. 
polis1 (plural lukapolis) (adjective) police; relating to the police force. igoen lukapolis: police clothes – police uniforms. ipolisin luenapete igoen lukaraya: plain clothes police (detectives). cp. raya, ajees
polis2 (singular noun neuter) the police (law-enforcement) institution; a police station.
politiks (singular noun neuter) politics (the science or business of government); moves and manoeuvres concerned with the acquisition of power or getting one’s way. politiks lunyodok: dirty politics, involving slander, mudslinging, murders, etc. cp. apugan.
poo (adverb) (of rain falling or a tree branch suddenly breaking) heavily; violently; powerfully. ebala edou etepi poo: the rain is falling heavily. abilun atenu poo: the tree branch has broken off suddenly.
porododo (adverb) noise of continuous diarrhoea. ebala je elepi porododo: porododo, thus goes the sound of his diarrhoea. cp. korododo
Praide (noun neuter) (archaic) Friday. cp. Naikanyet
puc (adverb) (of fullness of vessels with liquids) entirely; brimful; full to the brim. ileleba amot puc: the pot is brimful (with water or beer). cp. pas, pis.
pue (adverb) (of spearing or knocking) right through 
pukupuk (adverb) (sound imitation of the heart or a kerosene lamp) throbbing, beating, palpitating; fluttering, flickering, or sputtering. ebala ekatau pukupuk: my heart is throbbing, palpitating. elomarit ekwam otabaasa ngesi nen ebalar pukupuk: air has entered the lamp that is why it is flickering.
pururu (adverb) (sound of bird flying off) suddenly; swiftly. aporo ekweny pururu: the bird flew away very fast (making a purururu noise). 
purus (adverb) (of a soft thing being speared or stabbed) right through; completely. aremi emerekek kakwara purus: a ram has been speared (impaled) right through. cp. piric.
purus (adverb) (of a spear or any sharp object piercing something soft) right through. aicum purus: airem purus: to spear right through. cp. piris
pus (adverb) (of a spear or any sharp object piercing flesh) all through; easily; effortlessly. arem eong ekukwai akeju pus: a thorn has pierced my leg badly. cp. purus 
puu (adverb) (of something exploding or falling) thunderous; booming; crashing. ebir ikoku abaati kede engarot puu: the child has hit the iron roof boom with a stone. aduo eboomu kokide puu: a bomb has exploded massively in the east.
pwa pwa (adverb) (of a child bathing or splashing in water) noisily; loudly; carelessly. ilongi ikoku pwa pwa mam irigai akuwan da: the child is splashing water on its body without even scrubbing. 
pwe (adverb) (of breaking of a soft thing, such as a rotten twig, a pot, a wet anthill) easily; effortlessly; noiselessly. abu ngesi kobwang amot pwe: she/he broke the pot noiselessly. 
pwos (adverb) (of a hollow object falling and breaking) completely; utterly. adusaar etwo loka akipi pwos: a gourd of water has fallen and broken completely.
pyana pyan (adverb) (tasting) insipid; dully; blandly; characterless; unexcitingly. epyaka acuc pyana pyan: the ajon remnant is very tasteless. 
pyanga pyang (adverb) (of an agitated liquid not full in a vessel being carried) shaking; unsteady; sloshing. ebala amot namam ileleba pyanga pyang kakou: a half empty pot of water shakes unsteadily as you carry it on the head. 
pyo (adverb) (of something getting finished or exhausted) completely; totally. adaun edia pyo: the vegetables are finished completely. cp. pio
pyu (adverb) (imitation of sound of something small thrown fast as of a sharp stone) whizz. 

-R- 
r (noun neuter) the seventeenth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
rac (adverb) (sound of mud, paste, or cow dung falling on hard surface) splash; splatter. adoo aoret kwap rac: the cowdung fell with a splash. 
-rai a verbal suffix to change certain –ar verbs to first person imperatives implying a request or repeated action. aninaar: to rub away; koninaarai: massage me, please. aitalakaar: to please or to amuse; kitalakaarai: amuse me, please.
Ramadan (singular noun neuter) the ninth month of the Muslim year, during which Muslims fast between sunrise and sunset. cp. Idi.
rau (adverb) (of red pepper, etc) hot; burning; searing. eta emulalu rau: the red pepper is hot to the taste. 
raya (plural lukaraya) (adjective) civilian; not relating to the armed forces or the police force. igoen lukaraya: civilian clothes – not uniforms of the army or police cp. ajees, polis
ria (adverb) very (bitter). eta ria: it is very bitter. edwar abalang ria ria: the traditional salt is very bitter. 
riak (adverb) (to frighten, startle, scare) suddenly; abruptly. abu ngesi korieng riak: she/he was startled suddenly, got a sudden start, shock (on hearing or seeing something shocking). 
riaka riak (adverb) very (startled, scared, shocked). asalaki ikoku ebala riaka riak akaulo ikapa asomakin nges: the child has remained startled after the cat jumped on him/her.
riapa riap (adverb) (of walking, gait) precariously; shakily; blindly; unsteadily; like a blind person. ebala emuduk riapa riap elosi: a blind man is unsteady while walking.
rit1 (adverb) (sound imitation of things falling, or soldiers’ feet when taking a salute) in unison; together; at once. 
rit2 (adverb) (to be finished) completely; entirely; very; altogether. cp. pit; kiokiot 
-roi a verbal suffix to change certain –or verbs to first person imperatives implying a request or repeated action. akoor: to scratch away; kokooroi: scratch my back, please. aipikor: to defeat or to overwhelm; kipikoroi: defeat me, if you can.
-roroi a suffix after verbs and added to them, to mean 'to do ….meanwhile'. konyamaroroi ber ijo (plural konyamaroroete): you eat meanwhile (I do something else). 
rwa (adverb) the sound of crackling joints. 
rwarwa (adverb) (like the sound of a wild bush-fire on half-dry grass) crackling; rattling; clapping (of hands). aibap akanin rwarwa: to clap hands in unison. 
rwopo rwop (adverb) (of or like a deflated stomach, tyre, or a football) emptily; vacuously. etapas ya egaali awuyonor, alomaki do aicak ngesi kobala amopiira rwopo rwop: the bicycle has disturbed that woman by getting deflated every now and again, she has decided to ride on with an empty tyre. 
rya (adverb) very (bitter). eta rya: it is very bitter. 

-S-
s (noun neuter) the eighteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
saa (adverb) fragrantly; nicely; pleasantly. esaete ikonigoen: your (singular) clothes smell nicely. 
Sande (noun neuter) (archaic) Sunday. cp. Naesabiiti
sangasang (adverb) trembling; shaking. ebala akakuwan sangasang: my body is trembling. 
sarab (adverb) (sound of drinking something thick) noisily. 
Satade (noun neuter) (archaic) Saturday. cp. Naemukaaga
sek (adverb) before; ago; formerly; already; early; anterior. nan sek: earlier on today. kolo sek (adverb) long ago; in the past. kolo sek kasonya: very long ago; in the far past. tupuruc sek: early in the morning. adilun sek: to rise early; to come early. sekisek (adverb) very early. kobu sek (imperative) come early; come betimes. 
serena (singular noun M) (formerly) a variety of short and early ripening sorghum (developed from Serere research farm). 
serenat (singular noun M) a variety of purple groundnuts that is easily eaten by weevils (developed from Serere research farm). 
sereser (adverb) (of a snake’s tongue) darting; flitting. ebala emun angajep sereser: the snake’s tongue is darting about. 
-si- an infix forming causatives in verbs with 'i' in the root (whether the infix should be –ti-, and not –si-will depend on the ease of vocalisation and the judgement of the speaker) aimik: to deny, refuse; aitimik: aisimik: to cause to refuse or fail, etc. 
sibilian (plural lukasibilian) (adjective) civilian; not relating to the armed forces or the police force. igoen lukasibilian: civilian clothes – not uniforms of the army or police cp. ajees, polis, raya
sig (adverb) (of something getting stuck or stopping) suddenly; at once; abruptly. aeniki emotoka esiisa sig nepenen: the car braked there and then.
sigig (adverb) (of something getting stuck or stopping) suddenly; at once; abruptly. aremokin emeleku okomyo sigig: the ox-plough has got firmly stuck on a tree stump.
-sinei a suffix for generic plural of nouns. itunganan: a person; plural, itungasinei: people generally, tribes upon tribes, races. akwap: a country; plural, akwapusinei: the whole world.
sinia (adverb) at, in, to, from senior school. 
siri- a negative prefix, 'do not', followed by any form of verb. aarenen: to kill often; siriarenene: do not kill. adote: to fornicate; siridote: do not fornicate or commit adultery. akoko: to steal; sirikokoi: do not steal.
siriki- a prefix for the negative imperative 'do not' or 'thou shall not'. (note that after siriki, all verbs are ki verbs). 
-sisi a suffix on adjective meaning 'grey' - losisi M, nasisi F, yenisisi Dimin. (adjective) grey. 
-sodit a suffix implying 'the first'; 'the initial'; 'the original'. losodit (adjective M) the first. nasodit (adjective F) the first. yenisodit (adjective Dimin.) the first. 
Solot (proper noun) the old name of Soroti. 
sude (adverb) (to upset, tip, turn or push over) completely. abu esirikaalet kisudeor sude: the soldier made a perfect somersault. 
sue (adverb) (to fall over) awkwardly, clumsily. aido sue: to fall over. ado eong sue: I tumbled over. cp. swe.
suenye sueny (adverb) (of the manner of walking of a short person) with short brisk steps. ebala ngesi elosi suenye sueny: she/he walks with short brisk paces. 
swaraj (adverb) (to put something somewhere) dirtily; offensively; foully. 
swe (adverb) (to fall over) clumsily; awkwardly. ado eong swe: I tumbled over awkwardly. 
swee (adverb) (sound of rain falling) in little drops, drizzles. etepi edou swee: the rain is drizzling. 
swi (adverb) (of many things) teeming; plentiful; congested; crowded. 
swiswi (adverb) snivelling sound (as of one with a bad cold or asthma). 
swoswo (adverb) (to gape or be open) widely; broadly. eorori etogo swoswo: the house has a big opening or gap; the house is empty. 

-T-
-t- with vowel of root of verb, forms infix of causative verbs which are all ki-verbs and have the ki conjugation; the ‘ta te ti to tu’ infixes follow the verbal prefix a- or ai- and precede the root of the verb: ainyam (to eat): aitanyam (to feed, to cause to eat); aiten (to put to be straight): aiteten (to cause to be straight); ailip (to pray, to beg): aitilip (to cause to pray, to cause to beg); ailot (to wash): aitolot (to cause to wash); aidum (to get): aitudum (to cause to get or find).
t (noun neuter) the nineteenth letter of the Ateso alphabet.
-ta adverbial suffix, emphatic ‘this, that, etc very one’ after demonstrative pronouns: nata F or lota M: this very one; nuta F or luta M: these very ones; neta: just here, etc.
-ta- infix of causative verbs with ‘a’ in root: ainyam: aitanyam; ainap: aitanap; aidak: aitadak 
Taaside (noun neuter) (archaic) Thursday. cp. Nakiongonet
tai (adverb) anyhow; in vain; for nothing. imonyi ijo tai: you are crying for nothing.
taitai1 (adverb) very; too much; exceedingly; everywhere; all over the place. itaditos itunga itogoi okaabi taitai: people have built randomly at the refugee camp. 
taitai2 (adverb) a corruption of atitai: (to do something) in vain; for nothing. aari etunganan ngol taitai: that man was killed for nothing (i.e. he had no fault). cp. atitai
tani (adverb) just awhile; a moment. bia tani ne: come here a moment. cp. cani, tope
taparac (adverb) in the early morning. taparac sek: very early in the morning (before sunrise). 
tapi (adverb) from that; so that; consequently; therefore; forthwith; after which. tapi bo ijo abunere: after which you should have came. abu edou kotep apaarit ngin tapi bo naimecia ijo ne: it rained on that day so that you took shelter here. cp. tipi
taratar (adverb) (of metallic and sonorous objects overhead) shaking, trembling, or trilling. ebala abaati taratar ijangijanga akwap: the iron roof is vibrating noisily during the earth-quake. cp. naranar. 
tata (plural nukatata) (noun F) grandmother (either on father or mother’s side); the senior wife; the principal wife (called thus by concubines).
-te- causative infix for verbs with 'e' in the root: aitep (to rain): aitetep (to cause to rain); aidem (to confiscate, grab): aitedem (to cause to confiscate, rob). 
tei (adverb) (to break a small glass or brittle thing) into bits; completely. abwanga igilaasi tei: the glass tumbler has broken into bits. cp. tes
teketek (adverb) (to break) completely; (of a broken thing) rickety; shaky; dangling; swaying. abila akan teketek: the hand is completely broken. 
teletel (adverb) (to shake or tremble) very much; vigorously. amaran teletel: to tremble or shake extensively due to cold or fear.
teni (adverb) truly; really; verily; all right. teni bo: in fact, true indeed, or very much so. teni bo kabala eong yes: I’m definitely telling you. ejaas teni teni: they are at it for real; they are doing the actual thing.
teong (exclamation of disapproval) don’t!; stop it; now now! look! You see!
ter (adverb) a sound of a wound spring falling or the splitting of glass slightly. ebala akilauri ter edea: the glass of a hurricane lamp split by itself.
Teriniti (singular noun neuter) Trinity. Sande na Teriniti: Trinity Sunday.
tes (adverb) sound of a brittle article breaking. aibwang tes: to break into pieces. cp. tei
Teso (singular noun neuter) (formerly) a district in eastern Uganda with the headquarters in Soroti town, native land of the Iteso people; a district in South Western Kenya occupied by Iteso of Kenya; the areas of Soroti, Kaberamaido, Katakwi, Kumi, Tororo and Pallisa occupied by the Teso tribe.
-tesot (plural -teso) (adjective) (suffix) of or pertaining to Teso, its people or its culture. 
teten (adverb) to, at the right hand. akan nakoteten (adverb) to, at the right hand. cp. kediany: at, to the left.
tetere (adverb) in order that; so that. kiswamata tetere idumunete inyamatakus: work in order that you may get your meal. tetere mam: lest. korimaana tetere mam ijo kitisilaaro: be obedient lest you be punished.
ti1 (adverb) (of weight; of silence) very; absolute. ililingi amoru na ti, mam ipedori aijangakin da: this stone is very heavy, one cannot even move it a little. kidum itunganan kililing ti, adumu neenyamia: if a person suddenly keeps quiet (when she/he was previously noisy), that person has got something beneficial to do. aililing ti: to be quiet. cp. tii ti
ti2 adverb in conditional mood, meaning ‘would, should, may, perhaps’. ti kalot: I would (should, or might) have gone. abunar akokor ebe ti akokoar: to snatch a chicken with the intent of stealing it.
-ti- causative infix of verbs with 'i' in root and preceding the verb: airim: to turn (vowel in root 'rim' is 'i' causative is ‘tirim’ or ‘sirim’) hence aitirim: to make (cause, let, force) to turn or rotate. 
ti3 enclitic after lo, na, yen, lu, nu, and other demonstrative pronouns: lo ti lo (also lo si lo): this one. 
tiarai (conjunction) should; might; could; would rather; preferably; she/he/you/I better do. tiarai ijo ilosi: it should have been you going. tiarai adukokin ekonitogo ne: you rather build your house here. cp. ti bo aria, tibarai.
tii ti (adverb) (of weight; of silence) very; absolute. ililingi lokadekan tii ti, mam epedori bobo einer da: the patient is very quiet, cannot even talk a little. aililing tii ti: to be absolutely quiet; to be too heavy. kililingata tii ti: keep very silent; keep very quiet.
tilikida (interjection) hurrah! Bravo!; hooray! tilikidaa tilikida, ya: (said by a dance-leader morale boosting his/her fellow dancers) yeah hurray!
tinenikwana (adverb) (in reference to the past) at this time in the past; about this time in the past. tinenikwana kinyouni: we would be leaving at this moment (about this time yesterday). 
tipi (adverb) such that; so that. iwalarit ca lolo erono, tipi idedeng ijo kwangin: you may have woken up badly such that you are irritable like that. cp. tapi
tir (adverb) all day; constantly; repeatedly; daily; continually. eboi ngesi kane tir: she/he/it has stayed here all day. cp. duc.
tiritir (adverb) all day; constantly; always; often; many times; repeatedly; daily; continually. ebunenenei ngesi ne tiritir: she/he/it comes here very often (hence, I am tired of him/her/it). cp. duc.
Tiuside (noun neuter) (archaic) Tuesday. cp. Naiyareit
-to- causative infix of verbs with 'o' in root and preceding the verb: aitor: to pass, vowel in root is 'o' and the causative is ‘totor’, hence aitotor: to let pass; to force to pass. 
togo (adverb) in, within, at, from, towards the house. ejai ngesi togo: she/he is in the house. 
toi (adverb) (to sting, bite, or peck once) badly. kakony eong elacit engabet toi: a louse has bitten me hard on the waist once.
toi toi (adverb) (to be stinging, biting, or pecking) very much; badly. kakony eong emukuny iwos toi toi: the black ant bit me several times on the buttocks painfully.
-tok a noun suffix indicating people of a place (frequently used in place nouns beginning with consonants and ending in vowels): Ingoratok: people of Ngora county (in Kumi district); Imuriatok: people from Amuria county (in Katakwi district); Ikumetok: people from Kumi town or Kumi district. Igweritok: people from Gweri sub-county in Soroti.
toma (adverb) in; into; inside; through. ejai edia toma osepuria: vegetables are in the cooking pot.
toni (preposition) until; and so; and then; then; as far as; up to. aiboi toni tupuruc: to stay upto morning. cp. aitodol.
too (noun neuter) west (adverb) to, from, in the west; westerly. elomari akolong too: the sun sets to the west. 
tooka a corruption of totoka (my mother) or of togoka (my house). cp. totoka, togoka. 
Tooro (noun neuter) the land of the Batooro people; the pre-colonial western Uganda kingdom ruled by an Omukama (king).
tope (adverb) just awhile; a moment. bia tope ne: just come here a moment. cp. cani.
toto (plural nukatoto) (noun F) mother; the elder sister of one’s husband; mama; a female parent; an elderly lady. totoka: my mother. toto-acelit: a snail. toto katitipu: a queen ant. toto k’ican: Mother of sorrows. totokiye: Mother Trouble. totowok: our mother. 
toto katitipu (plural nukatoto katitipu) (noun F) the queen ant.
toto-akit (plural nukatoto-akit) (noun F) the eardrum..
totokiye (plural nukatotokiye) (noun F) a woman who causes trouble; Mother Trouble (euphemism) the anus; the arsehole. 
toto-odwe (plural nukatoto-odwe) (noun F) the mother of twins. cp. papa odwe.
tototot (adverb) (of a flood of liquid or tears from a person crying) bubbling incessantly; flooding unrestrained.
-tu- a causative infix of verbs with 'u' in root and preceding the verb - aitub: to cut; vowel in root 'tub' is 'u', the causative is tutub hence aitutub: to make or cause to cut, or cause to pass (or cross). 
tuitui (adverb) (of a person or animal walking about) heavily; with feet thumping the ground. ebakasi alotok korot kuare tuitui: the foot steps of those walking on the road at night can be heard. 
tul (adverb) (to rot or decompose and smell) completely; altogether. ebos akitukuke tul: his/her mouth smells badly (has a very foul smell). aibos tul: to rot altogether or completely. eur etulutulu tul: sulphuric acid is very pungent. ebos emalas tulu tul: the milk churn smells nasty. cp. tulutul
tulutul (adverb) (to rot or decompose and smell) completely; altogether. ebos amot tulutul: the pot smells very badly (has a very bad smell). 
tupuruc (adverb) in the morning; at dawn; at daybreak. tupuruc sek: very early in the morning.
twar (adverb) (of light being reflected) dazzling; flashing; beaming. ebala edou twar: there is lightning accompanying the rain. aimilia twar: to flash brightly. cp. twaratwar
twaratwar (adverb) (of lightning) dazzling; flashing; glittering. ebala edou twaratwar: there is a lightning storm. aimilia twaratwar: to keep flashing brightly.
twilitwil (adverb) (of something small) very or extremely small. edit ngesi twilitwil: she/he is very small. 

-U-
u1 	(noun neuter) the twentieth letter of the Ateso alphabet; a vowel letter as in ‘woo’.
u2 	exclamation of wonder, painful surprise, or of entreaty - please; oh! u bia!: please do come here! u okwe papa!: oh, father! u toto abei lolo ai?: u ito, abei lolo ai?: oh, mother, where shall I go? woe upon me! cp. u okwe: wu okwe: exclamation of horror, dismay or contempt.
-un verbal suffix indicating action towards the speaker: imperative singular -u, plural –utu: kobu (come) becomes kopotu; plural 2nd & 3rd person –unete: adolun (to arrive) becomes edolunete (they arrive); reflexive singular –un and plural –unos: emata (drinkable) – ematun (to absorb) becomes ematunos (to be absorbed) in plural reflexive. 
-uni suffix of cardinal number three (3) or thirty (30). angor auni: three women. itelepai akais-auni: thirty (ten times three) boys. akinei atomon-kanuuni: thirteen (ten and three) goats. 
-uniet suffix of ordinal number three (3): the third; Wednesday. lokiuniet M: the third. nakiuniet F: the third; Wednesday. 
-unun a verbal suffix denoting a repetitive action towards the speaker. awoun: to put down from someone’s head (once only); awounun: to keep lifting and putting down (from people’s heads – many times). aremun: to push down (once only); aremunun: to keep pushing down this way (often). 
us exclamation of contempt or of refusal: pooh. us, etumit ngol tai: gosh, he is fat for nothing (he is a useless fellow). 
uuss (interjection) (sigh of disapproval) pooh; humph.
uwokwe (interjection) a corruption of u okwe: exclamation of horror or contempt. 

-W-
w (noun neuter) the twenty-first letter of the Ateso alphabet; a semi-vowel sound.
waa (adverb) imitation of sound of a pressure lamp, radio atmospherics or drizzling rain. ebala eredio waa: the radio is not clear due to atmospherics. ebala edou waa: the rain is pelting the zinc roof hard. 
wailo (adverb) this side, to this side. bia wailo: come to this side. cp. juwai (adverb) the other side; to the other side: okekwa je. 
waije (preposition) to the other side of; across. kolot waije: go to the other side of. 
Wenside (noun neuter) (archaic) Wednesday. Wenside nakekurwon: Ash Wednesday (the first day of Lent or the Christian fasting season). cp. Nakiuniet
wiliwil (adverb) (of pain, to hurt) very sharply or acutely. epipil akajimi wiliwil: my sore is very painful. 
winyiwiny (adverb) (of itching, a sore) very (painfully sweet).
-wok a suffix forming possessive pronoun 1st person plural of -ka: our (inclusive of audience). lowok M, nawok F, yeniwok Dimin.: ours. papawok: our father (mine and yours). ngesi lowok: that is ours (you inclusive). 
wori? (interrogation) when? ibuni ijo wori?: when will you come? 
wu exclamation of wonder or painful surprise or of entreaty, horror, or contempt. wu okwe kingarakinai!: oh, please help me! wu okwe papa!: oh dear, father! wu toto abei lolo ai!: oh, mother, woe betide me! 
wu okwe exclamation of painful surprise, horror or contempt.

-Y-
y (noun neuter) the twenty-second letter of the Ateso alphabet; a semi-vowel sound.
ya demonstrative of feminine singular nouns, meaning ‘the female far off’. apak ya: at that time. aberu ya: that far off woman. eyapeya: there she is. cp. kwa.
yakayak (adverb) imitation of a cracking or rattling sound, as of dry leaves falling or being walked on. ebakas akwi nukaokok yakayak: dry leaves crackle when walked on. cp. rwarwa. 
yapeya feminine demonstrative pronoun: ‘that very female’ we talked about; that far off woman (or feminine object). aberu yapeya: that very (female) one we know.
yem (adverb) like the sound of dry grass being shaken or disturbed. ebala ibore yem kokitwi: something is shaking the dry bushes.
yen diminutive demonstrative pronoun: this. ikoku yen: this child. 
yen- prefix of relative pronoun of diminutive or neutral nouns: who; that. ikoku yenedeka: the child who is sick. yeti yen: this very (small) one. yepeyen (emphatic): this very (small) one. 
yenegei (plural luegeete) (noun neuter) the first (to do something or to be born). cp. loegei, ikiyai, loelingi (M), naelingi (F): the first (to go, to start, to be born). yenegei nges edumuni ainakinet: the first one will receive or get a gift. 
yenelingi (plural luelingete) (noun neuter) the one that comes first; the first born child. cp. yenegei, ikiyai. loelingi (M), naelingi (F): the first. loelingi nges edumuni ainakinet: the first one will receive a prize. 
yenemodomodoo (plural luemodomodoo) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a dupe; one who is deceived. 
yenice indefinite diminutive pronoun: the other. komina yenicekoku: love your sibling.
yenididi (plural ludidik) (noun Dimin.) the little or small one. 
yenikaronon (plural lukaronok) (noun neuter) an evil or bad one (thing); a sinner (in general); a criminal. 
yenikatupan (plural lukatupak) (noun neuter/Dimin.) a succeeding one (child); the child following another in the order of birth; a person following up something (an issue, a case, etc). 
yenikaurian (plural lukauriak) (noun neuter.) a parent; a producer (bearer); a begetter; a primogenitor; a progenitor; a forebear.
yeniki- (plural luki-) a prefix of ordinal numbers in neuter or diminutive: the nth. yenikiareit: the 2nd one. yenikiuniet: the 3rd one. 
yenimeo (plural lumeo) (adjective) (only of plants and animals) thin-bodied; willowy. 
yenisodit (plural lusodit) (adjective) the first (one). 
yenitemeri (plural luitemerete) (adjective) intoxicating; causing drunkenness or dizziness. 
yes (personal pronoun 2nd person plural used as an object) you. ajeni yes: I know you. 
yesi (personal pronoun 2nd person plural used as a subject) you. ijenete yesi: you know. cp. kesi.
Yesu Kristo (noun M) Jesus Christ (the founder of Christianity).
yi (plural kwi) a demonstrative diminutive pronoun: that far off little one. ikoku yi: that child over there. yitoyi (emphatic): that very little one over there. ikesa yi: that far off little fellow.
yoo yo (adverb) (of a knife, a razorblade, etc) very sharp. ekwana ekileng yoo yo: the knife is very sharp, it just slices through. 
yoga (interjection) good day; greetings to you; how do you do? congratulations. yoga aswam: well done. yoga noi: many tidings (greetings). yoga do: bye-bye; bye for now.
